title: NEW BOND ISSUES: TUESDAY, MARCH 31, 1987
SEVEN-WEEK TRIAL TOUCHED MANY BASIC EMOTIONS
description: Beyond the walls of Judge Harvey R. Sorkow's courtroom here, experts in philosophy, law and psychiatry wrestle with social, cultural and ethical questions about surrogate parents that go far beyond the Baby M custody case.

title: Islanders Win, 4-3
description: Pat LaFontaine scored twice, leading the Islanders to a 4-3 victory tonight over the St. Louis Blues in a battle of playoff-bound teams.

title: FAT WOMEN SAY IT'S NOT A DIRTY WORD
description: EVEN simple acts are complicated for Susan Mason.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 1, 1987
description: Markets

title: BABY M CASE CHRONOLOGY
description: Feb. 6, 1985 - Mary Beth Whitehead agrees to be artificially inseminated by William Stern. Their pact stipulates that she will relinquish all rights to the child in return for $10,000.

title: RICE: THE PRIZE OF SICHUAN PROVINCE AND BREAKTHROUGH GIFT OF CALIFORNIA
description: TO many Americans, rice is rice. It comes in a box with short but intimidating directions. When it's cooked, you eat the part that you didn't burn with some other kind of food that has some kind of taste. The fact is, to many Americans, rice is boring.

title: The U.N. Today: April 1, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SHUFFLING THE SMITHSONIAN PORTFOLIO
description: More than a year and a half ago, the governing board of the Smithsonian Institution divided sharply over whether to continue owning stock in companies that do business in South Africa. Some members argued that a body as closely identified with the American nation as the Smithsonian ought to sell such stocks so as to set an example of opposition to racist policies.

title: MORE THAN A GAME FOR INDIANA FANS
description: In this state where basketball is more than just a game, the Indiana Hoosiers came down from Olympus today, greeted by some 15,000 fans in a deafening welcome-home celebration for the national collegiate champions.

title: Post-Postseason: Not for Preps
description: The idea, which has surfaced before at this time of year, is to take advantage of the interest in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament by creating an invitational playoff for four to eight national high school powers the week after the Final Four. There has been no national high school basketball championship since a tourney sponsored by the University of Chicago lapsed more than half a century ago, but that, of course, was in the pre-television age.

title: RAIN, WIND AND A RECIPE FOR COPING IN NEW YORK
description: On your mark - sneakers tied, galoshes pulled into place.

title: Glass Company's Chief Tries Hand in Takeover
description: Randall D. Hubbard has hauled ice, harvested wheat, taught school and salvaged ailing glass companies. Now, as chairman and chief executive of AFG Industries and a partner of Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, Mr. Hubbard is trying his hand as a takeover artist with a $2.2 billion bid for Gencorp Inc.

title: Thrift Unit Official Sentenced
description: A third former executive of the Home State Savings Bank was sentenced today for his part in the thrift institution's 1985 collapse.

title: POPE, ON LATIN TRIP, ATTACKS PINOCHET REGIME
description: Pope John Paul II bluntly labeled the Chilean Government of President Augusto Pinochet ''dictatorial'' today and insisted that the Roman Catholic Church must struggle to bring democracy to Chile.

title: Another Hit
description: Kenny Rice, sports director at WTVQ-TV in Lexington, Ky., after Austin Peay of Clarksville, Tenn., upset Illinois in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament: ''It's the biggest thing to happen in Clarksville since the Monkees took the last train there.''

title: Baltimore Symphony Plans Tour in Soviet
description: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra announced today that it would perform in the Soviet Union this spring, marking the first time in 11 years that an American orchestra had appeared before Soviet audiences.

title: U.S. Farm Exports Dip
description: American farm exports dropped 10 percent in 1986, to $26 billion, an Agriculture Department report said. ''Rising grain production in importing countries cut overseas demand and U.S. exports,'' the report said.

title: Schwab Group Completes Buyout
description: The purchase of Charles Schwab & Com pany, the discount brokerage, from the BankAmerica Corporation has been completed by the CL Acquisition Corporation, a company formed by investors led by Charles R. Schwab, senior management and employees through a profit-sharing plan. The $280 million price is being financed by a syndicate of seven banks led by the Security Pacific National Bank.

title: New Job
description: Less than a month after the Tower commission wrapped up its investigation of the Iran-contra affair with a long report, at least one key staff member of President Reagan's blue-ribbon panel is heading for a job at the White House.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have a tingling feeling in my elbows, and my legs are numb.

title: Life in the 30's
description: Anna Quindlen is on vacation. Her column will resume April 8.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Unchanged
description: Prices farmers got for raw products in March, on the average, were unchanged from a revised February index and also a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: BIG BEAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 15 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: HOUSING SEGREGATION: NEW TWISTS AND OLD RESULTS
description: Predominantly segregated housing patterns that seemed to be breaking up in the 1960's and early 1970's have been quietly reasserting themselves in New York City and its suburbs, according to a wide range of experts and studies.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
UNSULLIED SALADS
description: LEAD: IN spring, our fancy turns to huge, cool, misted salads, laden with all manner of fresh produce. So why do we sully such edible beauty? Are we so distracted by trifles like the opposite sex - or whatever they say we're supposed to attend to in spring - that we compromise our salad visions so easily?

title: Humanism Doesn't Mean Not to Teach Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf Coach to Retire
description: He has won more National Collegiate Athletic Association championships than any other coach, and now, after 16 titles, Dave Williams has decided to retire. The 68-year-old Williams announced he would leave the University of Houston on Aug. 1 after 36 years as the golf coach. When he began at Houston in 1952, the Cougars had never won a tournament. It wasn't until 1956 that he won his first title, which started a string of five. His last championship team was in 1985. Last year, 13 former Houston players won money on the PGA Tour, among them Fuzzy Zoeller, Art Mahaffey, Bill Rogers and Fred Couples.

title: Socialists Meet Amid Shifts in Italian Alliance
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi opened a weeklong convention of his Socialist Party here today, paving the way for the possible formation of a new government in Italy.

title: CHIP PANEL'S LEADER DEFENDS SANCTIONS
description: As chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association's public policy committee, George Scalise has been instrumental in persuading Washington to impose trade sanctions against the Japanese. But Mr. Scalise, who is also senior vice president of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the Sunnyvale, Calif., chip maker, said he views the sanctions as ''incentives'' for the Japanese to comply with the trade agreement signed last July 31, not as a punitive measure.

title: FOR APRIL SHOWERS, A BIT OF HISTORY
description: 1.Operas of Old April showers are the perfect reason to cover yourself with glory - the glory of New York's cultural past. These elegant umbrellas in navy and gold is decorated with copies of paintings of the old Met by E. Lee Spruyt, who drew the historic opera house in 1966 before it was torn down. For $60 in the gift shop of the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center. 2.For Spring Getaways This travel kit adds some cheer to a man's accessories. It is striped cotton, in either blue and white or red and white. Lined with vinyl for easy cleaning, the kit costs $30 in Bonwit Teller for Men on the lower garden level of Trump Tower, 4 East 57th Street. 3.Thrifty but New Tomorrow through Saturday, the Cancer Care Thrift Shop will offer new spring clothing at greatly reduced prices. The selection includes cotton and silk dresses, blazers, blouses, skirts, slacks, shorts and sweaters. The cotton sweater shown here, in white and burgundy, was made in Italy and costs $12. The thrift shop is at 1480 Third Avenue, between 83d and 84th Streets. Cancer Care helps cancer patients and their families cope with the disease. 4.Victorian Posies Patrick Frey, a Paris designer, has reproduced a Victorian floral pattern on this versatile wool and silk shawl, which measures 55 inches square. It can be worn with a coat, suit or dress, or it can serve as a tablecloth, adding drama to a dinner party. The price is $300 in Chelsea Passage on the main floor at Barneys, Seventh Avenue at 17th Street.

title: By Paul H. Nitze
description: The formal comments of high-level Reagan Administration officials on arms control matters are generally cleared by the White House before they are delivered. But a recently published article by Paul H. Nitze, an arms control adviser to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, was a conspicuous exception, officials say, and it irritated some hard-liners in the Administration.

title: Market Place; Technicians Are Sanguine
description: ANY time the stock market takes a terrific jolt - as it did on Monday with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 57.39 points - investors like to know what Wall Street's technical analysts see ahead.

title: A NEW SHOWCASE FOR ART BY WOMEN
description: Born with a silver spoon in its mouth and bred to be noncontroversial, the National Museum of Women in the Arts will open to the public April 7 after a ceremonial ribbon-cutting by Barbara Bush, the wife of the Vice President. The first museum devoted solely to female artists in a historical context, it occupies a handsomely renovated landmark building - formerly a Masonic Temple - at New York Avenue and 13th Street, two blocks from the White House.

title: INQUIRY INTO SLAYING OF JUDGE FOCUSES ON HIS CASE
description: Detectives, searching for a motive and clues in the slaying of a Parking Violations Bureau hearing officer, are focusing on about 900 cases handled by the officer in recent years, police officials said yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: SONOMA COUNTY, which plays Avis to Napa County's Hertz, last week showed New Yorkers the fruits of trying harder. While Napa's wines still lead in overall quality, Sonoma's have gained by a fraction.

title: 3 Well-Known Towers in City Become Official Landmarks
description: Three elaborate and fanciful towers that have graced Manhattan's skyline for more than 50 years became official landmarks yesterday with the designations of the former New York Central Building on Park Avenue and the San Remo on Central Park West.

title: 'I WANTED TO BE FREE'
description: EVER since he was a youngster growing up in this North Texas town of 2,000, the son of a county road worker and sometime cattle hauler, Billy Gilbreath wanted to be a cowboy. At the age of 20, on the Lambshead Ranch, he is a new recruit to an old trade.

title: ACADEMY AWARD CEREMONY ON ABC
description: THE introduction of a trap door for handling long-winded winners was one of many improvements to be found on Monday night's 59th Academy Awards show. Mindful, perhaps, that every year's eagerly anticipated Oscar telecast is also met with a modicum of dread, those who planned the presentation took the home audience's endurance problems into account. So despite the relative dearth of glamour and excitement that has afflicted the last few Oscar shows, this was the trimmest, most varied and best-paced program in years.

title: THEATER: 'BLITHE SPIRIT,' WITH BLYTHE DANNER
description: IN Noel Coward's ''Blithe Spirit,'' a middle-aged novelist named Charles Condomine must contend with the outspoken ghost of his not so dear, departed wife. The spirits who hover over the play's revival at the Neil Simon Theater are another story. Watching this flat all-star ''Blithe Spirit,'' one can only think back to Broadway's last misbegotten all-star assault on the same playwright - the Elizabeth Taylor-Richard Burton ''Private Lives'' of 1983. Whatever Coward himself is up to in the spirit world, it's safe to assume he has no clout at central casting.

title: U.S. Retaliates on Latest Asian Export: The Flying Roach
description: Imagine a New York City cockroach with chutzpah. It has wings, a preference for bright lights and a sex drive so lusty it can produce 75 million offspring a year. That's the Asian roach, Blatella asahinai, and it has been vacationing in Florida this winter since arriving on cargo ships from Asia. It is expected to move north. Killing cockroaches is big business - American consumers spend $2 billion a year in the effort - and flying cockroaches are expected to stimulate the market. Most current insecticides are effective against the newcomer, but scientists fear it may develop resistance to chemicals, as has its cousin in New York, the German roach. Entomologists at the Agriculture Department's Research Service in Gainesville, Fla., are developing compounds designed to attract Asian roaches. These attractants could be combined with toxic chemicals or substances that render the roaches sterile, the scientists said. The center has already contributed to the success of several commercial products including hydramethylnon, found in Combat bait trays, and hydroprene, the cockroach birth control. American Home Products, maker of Black Flag insecticides, is doing its part by providing consumers with all the information they could possibly want -and more - on the new insect pest.

title: G.M. Receives Canada Loan
description: In a move likely to stir opposition in the United States, General Motors of Canada Ltd. today received an interest-free loan of $220 million (Canadian) from the governments of Canada and Quebec in return for guaranteeing the continued operation of an auto plant.

title: Nuclear Unit to Cut Pacific Gas Net
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it expected its 1987 earnings to be reduced by about $470 million, or $1.25 a share, because of a change in accounting procedures related to the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant. The reduction is equivalent to almost half of the company's net income. But the company said the accounting change would not affect its cash position and that its annual dividend would remain at $1.92.

title: WEBSTER TO BE QUESTIONED ABOUT MEESE'S INQUIRY
description: The chairman and vice chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said today they planned to raise detailed questions about Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's handling of the Iran-contra affair at hearings next month on the nomination of William H. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence.

title: AM RADIO IS HOPING FULL FIDELITY LURES LISTENERS
description: IN a demonstration of cooperation seldom witnessed in the highly competitive worlds of broadcasting and electronics, station owners and major electronics companies are banding together to save AM radio.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Koreans in New York There are, according to the Korean Grocers Association, about 1,000 Korean greengrocers in the city (and 1,000 Korean fish markets, 1,000 laundries, not more than 50 Korean grocery stores and about 45,000 Koreans). This familiar and recent New York phenomenon is the subject of today's talk in the Asia Society's continuing series of Wednesday lectures, ''Discover Asia: Asian-Americans in New York City.'' The topic, ''Your Korean Corner Grocery,'' will be discussed by Illsoo Kim, a professor at Drew University.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-After a loss of $2,099,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter; and the year includes income from discontinued operations of $11,029,000 and an extraordinary charge of $3,000,000 from extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss of $115,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $3,300,000 for the year. The latest year results include after-tax gains of $4,230,000 from the All American Gourmet Company's sale of one million newly issued shares to the public and $1,894,000 from General Host's sale of its Hot Sam Cos. division. The company also said the prior year includes an after- tax gain of $8,259,000 from its initial sale of a minority interest in All American Gourmet to the public. The latest year also includes an after-tax gain of $5,880,000, including a fourth quarter increase in the gain of $1,565,000 as a result of settling the accumulated benefits under a retirement plan by purchasing annuities with plan assets. The latest fourth quarter and year include a $4,200,000 adjustment to record prior year merchandise purchases of General Host's Frank's Nursery & Crafts Inc. subsidiary. After income taxes, the adjustment reduced income by $2,200,000. However, this adjustment was largely offset by a $1,500,000 credit from eliminating income tax reserves which are no longer required. The prior fourth quarter and year include the $6,805,000 prior year credit from eliminating income tax reserves which are no longer required. The latest year reflects the restatement of third quarter results. The company also said the latest year income from discontinued operations reflects the July 1986 sale of Milk Specialties Company for an after-tax gain of $9,990,000 after fourth quarter adjustments which were principally for additional income taxes. Sales of this discontinued operation amounted to $24,781,000 up to the date of the sale in 1986, and $63,186,000 in the prior year.

title: Privatized Reform in Albany?
description: Albany's legislative leaders seem intent on embarrassing themselves by denying Governor Cuomo's $5 million budget request for a Commission on Government Integrity. What do the legislators have to hide? Their refusal to cooperate only whets public curiosity.

title: MANAGEMENT SHIFTS AT I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced a shuffling of its top executives yesterday, with the promotion of two longtime officials to the new position of executive vice president, and the retirement of the company's vice chairman, Paul J. Rizzo.

title: Israelis Divided About Reports on Soviet Jews
description: Senior Israeli officials were divided today in their assessment of reports that Moscow would soon permit large-scale Soviet Jewish emigration directly to Israel and more freedom of religion for Soviet Jews.

title: NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $94,843,000 which was related to the company's abandonment of its Bailly nuclear plant.

title: KNIGHT PRAISES HIS CHAMPIONS
description: Nearly half an hour after Indiana had defeated Syracuse Monday night, 74-73, Coach Bobby Knight offered a perspective on the significance of winning his third national championship.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $10.7 million in inventory adjustments and currency costs relating to fluctuations with the Italian lira. c-After $189.1 million in unusual charges related to the judgment of $205.4 million plus legal fees and expenses resulting from patent litigation between the company and Hughes Tool Co. The latest year loss before tax includes a $46.6 million charge to reduce the carrying value of excess capital assets and to write down certain inventories and other assets to estimated realizable value, and an $18 million charge relating to employee severance and relocation costs and Chapter 11 expenses. The prior year loss before tax is after $216.9 million in unusual charges related to the judgment of $205.4 million plus legal fees and expenses resulting from patent litigation between the company and Hughes Tool.

title: TRUMP REPORTS LARGE PROFIT FROM WOLLMAN RINK
description: New Yorkers were grateful when Donald J. Trump finished ahead of schedule and under budget in renovating the Wollman Memorial Rink, where the city had spent six years and $12 million trying to produce ice.

title: Raytheon Contract
description: The Raytheon Company has been awarded a $3.5 billion contract to provide the Army with 4,491 Patriot antiaircraft missiles over five years, the Pentagon said. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., ranked as the nation's seventh-biggest military contractor in 1986 with $4 billion in Defense Department business.

title: A PROVINCIAL CHEF'S PARISIAN EDUCATION
description: It was the typical country chef comes to the big city story. In its first year, Alain Raye's new Paris restaurant, which bears his name, survived a fire in a refrigerator and a flooded basement. Instead of packed tables and a waiting list, Mr. Raye faced a nearly empty dining room every night. And the Michelin guide removed the one star it had awarded him when he was at the stoves at Chez Uginet in Albertville, in southeastern France.

title: RICHARD J. SMITH
description: Dr. Richard J. Smith, a prominent hand surgeon, died Monday after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

title: AIRLINES STRESS TEAMWORK IN COCKPIT
description: On a recent United Airlines flight from Reno to San Francisco a bomb exploded in the luggage hold.

title: CHAD SAID TO WIN VAST LIBYAN BOOTY
description: Western diplomats said today that military equipment abandoned by Libyan forces retreating from northern Chad was believed to be worth half a billion dollars.

title: Racism: From Closet to Quad
description: Crude, overt racial bigotry has again come out of campus closets and onto the quads. Reports of public slurs, cross-burnings, even outright physical conflict now ring routinely from schools throughout the country, including some of the most prestigious. A society's universities ought to be among its chief civilizing influences. Lately, however, America's seem to be incubators of racial intolerance.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES ANTITERROR EFFORT TO WEST
description: The Soviet Union has asked several Western governments to cooperate with it in fighting international terrorism and has suggested that they negotiate extradition treaties providing for the return of terrorist suspects, according to French and other diplomats.

title: NBC and Union Talk In Face of Strike Threat
description: The National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians and NBC, which employs most of that union's 2,500 members, were continuing negotiations last night in the face of a strike deadline of midnight P.S.T. (3 A.M. New York time).

title: INSIDE
description: Segregation in New York Patterns of racially segregated housing, which began easing two decades ago in the New York City area, are reasserting themselves. Page B1. Hiring Plan Under Fire The Reagan Administration renewed its attack on an affirmative-action hiring plan in the District of Columbia despite a Supreme Court ruling backing such programs. Page A14. Showcase for Women's Art The Museum of Women in the Arts opens in Washington Tuesday, with its very premise inspiring supporters and detractors. Page C23.

title: VAN GOGH PRICE SHAKES ART WORLD
description: The auction price of one of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' paintings paid Monday at Christie's in London -$39.9 million, roughly four times the previous record for a work of art -brought reactions of shock and bafflement yesterday among museum officials, dealers and other art professionals.

title: SOME NEW YORK STATE WINES SHINE
description: FOUR New York State chardonnays and three seyval blancs shone last week at a tasting sponsored by the New York Wine and Grape Foundation. All were 1985's, and three of the chardonnays came from Long Island.

title: Testaverde Pact Near
description: Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy winner, is expected within a week to sign a contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers that would make him the National Football League's third-highest-paid player, according to The Associated Press. Bob Woolf, Testaverde's attorney, said, ''I'm very optimistic of making an agreement, although we don't have one yet.'' The Buccaneers, who have the first pick in the draft April 28, had no immediate comment. According to a source cited by A.P., the contract for the former University of Miami quarterback would be the most lucrative ever for an N.F.L. rookie and would place Testaverde behind two other quarterbacks, Jim Kelly of the Buffalo Bills and Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins, as the highest-paid players. Kelly's contract reportedly is for $8 million over five years, while Marino's reportedly is for $9 million over six years. . . . Testaverde's alma mater also produced some big financial numbers. The Fiesta Bowl game on Jan. 2 between Penn State and Miami for college football's national championship provided each school with $2.4 million, a bowl record for net payments, John Junker, the Fiesta Bowl's associate executive director, announced. Junker said that 21,940,000 households per minute were tuned into Penn State's 14-10 victory. giving the Fiesta Bowl the record for television viewership by households for a college sporting event.

title: Oral Roberts Vigil Ends In New Plea for Funds
description: The evangelist Oral Roberts, who had said God told him he would die unless he raised $8 million by the end of March, wound up a 10-day prayer vigil today with a final entreaty to followers to send money.

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 3
About New York; City's April Fools: They'd Be Jailed In Pittsburgh
description: The trouble with April Fool's Day in New York City, of course, is that there's no way to tell who's kidding and who's not.

title: Infant Mortality Is Part of the 'Star Wars' Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghans Say Pakistan Shot Down an Airliner
description: Afghanistan said today that the plane shot down by Pakistani fighters on Monday was a passenger aircraft with 40 people on board.

title: Henning Dismissed
description: With only two games left in the regular season, Lorne Henning was dropped as coach of the Minnesota North Stars. His replacement on an interim basis: Glen Sonmor, the team's director of personnel and a former North Star coach. Going into last night's games, the North Stars were a point ahead of Toronto and tied with Chicago in a struggle for the last remaining playoff spots in the Norris Division. Lou Nanne, Minnesota's general manager, was not immediately available for comment. In the long-range picture, there is speculation that Herb Brooks, a former coach of the Rangers, will become the Minnesota coach. Under Henning last season, Minnesota finished with 85 points, a big jump from 62 the season before. But the North Stars' record now stands at 30-39-9 for 69 points, and in the last 15 games, they are only 2-11-2.

title: CHANCES OF INJURY CALLED SUBSTANTIAL
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard confronts the pounding fists of Marvelous Marvin Hagler in Las Vegas, Nev., Monday, the chances that he will come out of the fight with another detached retina are no greater than if his eye had not previously been injured, according to the eye surgeon who operated on Leonard in May 1982.

title: 3 REPUBLICAN SENATORS URGE DIPLOMACY IN LATIN AMERICA
description: Three Republican Senators who have been key backers of the Administration on Nicaragua have warned President Reagan that unless he makes a series of policy changes, they may no longer support his policies.

title: PLAN ROOTED IN BROOKLYN
description: Brooklyn's Brownsville section, which has been a synonym for urban decay, has produced an innovative effort to renew housing in the Nehemiah Plan.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,998,000 for overfunding of pension plan.

title: SENATE, DEFYING PRESIDENT, PASSES HOUSING BILL, 71-27
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a housing bill costing up to $38.3 billion that is strongly opposed by the Reagan Administration as too expensive.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Ways to Make Work, and Milk
description: At the curb, a handful of airplane passengers look for transportation to downtown Bombay. Across the way, in the airport parking lot, a hundred or so taxi drivers take the morning sun. A naive traveler attempts to hail one but is studiously ignored. What's the secret?

title: STUDENTS AT BLACK COLLEGES HIT HARD BY GRANT CUTS
description: Students at the nation's 57 historically black private colleges are bearing the brunt of Federal grant cutbacks and are falling deeply into debt to finance their educations, according to a new study.

title: Fiero Slips After a Fast Sales Start
description: If advance dealer orders are any indication, Chevrolet's new Corsica and Beretta will be hot sellers. But even if those initial orders do translate into consumer purchases, the General Motors Corporation knows only too well that a fast start does not guarantee big sales over the long haul.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL LINEUP SET
description: NEW YORK CITY'S annual summer jazz festival -formerly Newport-New York, then the Kool Jazz Festival, now the JVC Jazz Festival - will be back this year beginning June 19.

title: Equal Partners
description: To The Living Section:

title: BRITISH CALEDONIAN LOSS
description: British Caledonian announced today that it lost $:19.3 million, equivalent to $30 million, in the year ended last October, and atributed it mainly to American fears of terrorist attacks in Europe. In the year before, the airline had a pretax profit of $:21.7 million.

title: SLAIN ADVISER THE SOLE AMERICAN AT SALVADOR BASE
description: The Defense Department said today that the American military adviser killed in a guerrilla attack on a Salvadoran Army base this morning was the only American on the base.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $10,210,000 and $4,262,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $1,985,000 for the quarter and $1,320,000 for the year.

title: GAF OFFERS $46 A SHARE TO BUY BORG
description: The GAF Corporation made a takeover bid for the Borg-Warner Corporation yesterday, offering $46 a share, or $3.17 billion.

title: California Gets New Rape Bill
description: A bill that would direct colleges to actively investigate rapes on campus even if the victims do not file criminal charges has been introduced in the State Legislature.

title: Second Murder Charge For Philadelphia Man
description: Gary Heidnik, the man charged with murder after the police found body parts in his refrigerator and women chained in his basement, was charged today with a second count of murder.

title: The 1986 Oscar Winners
description: Here is a list of winners of major categories at the 59th annual Academy Awards presentations Monday night: PICTURE: ''Platoon.'' DIRECTOR: Oliver Stone, ''Platoon.'' ACTOR: Paul Newman, ''The Color of Money.'' ACTRESS: Marlee Martin, ''Children of a Lesser God.'' SUPPORTING ACTOR: Michael Caine, ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' SUPPORTING ACTRESS: Dianne Wiest, ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' FOREIGN-LANGUAGE FILM: ''The As sault'' (The Netherlands). ORIGINAL SCREENPLAY: Woody Allen, ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' SCREENPLAY ADAPTATION: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, ''A Room With a View.'' ORIGINAL SCORE: Herbie Hancock, '' 'Round Midnight.'' ORIGINAL SONG: ''Take My Breath Away'' ''Top Gun''). CINEMATOGRAPHY: ''The Mission.'' ART DIRECTION: ''A Room With a View.'' COSTUME DESIGN: ''A Room With a View.'' DOCUMENTARY FEATURE: Tie. ''Artie Shaw: Time is All You've Got''; ''Down and Out in America.'' DOCUMENTARY SHORT SUBJECT: ''Women - For America, For the World.'' FILM EDITING: ''Platoon.'' ANIMATED SHORT FILM: ''A Greek Trage dy.'' LIVE ACTION SHORT FILM: ''Precious Images.'' SOUND: ''Platoon.'' SOUND EFFECTS: ''Aliens.'' VISUAL EFFECTS: ''Aliens.'' MAKEUP: ''The Fly.'' These awards were announced previously: IRVING THALBERG AWARD: Steven Spiel berg. HONORARY AWARD: Ralph Bellamy.

title: Panel Formed to Back Senate Bid by Dawkins
description: A group of prominent New Jersey Republicans announced today that they had formed a committee to raise money for a possible campaign for the United States Senate by former Brigadier General Pete Dawkins.

title: U.S. AND FRANCE END RIFT ON AIDS
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France ended a festering international scientific dispute today, announcing that researchers from the two countries would share credit for discovery of the AIDS virus.

title: Names Ad Infinitum
description: To The Living Section:

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.7% IN FEBRUARY
description: The Government's main gauge of future economic activity rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, but many economists said it was overstating economic strength. The long-awaited rebound in growth, they insisted, will be modest at best.

title: Along a Distant Arctic Border, Peace Reigns
description: While four NATO nations conduct winter war games 300 miles to the west, peace and tranquillity prevail at this headquarters of the Norwegian border guards at the Soviet frontier.

title: Let's Change The Subject
description: You are not going to have to read about old what's-his-name today, the unspeakable one who dominated the Final Four with the menacing slouch of a Southern sheriff, puffing out his red sweater like Rod Steiger jiggling his billy club and his handcuffs and his pistol and his walkie-talkie in one of those old movies, ''In the Heat of the Knight,'' that is, ''Night.''

title: FOUNDATION PLANS PANEL ON LITERATURE
description: Wheatland, the foundation started by Ann Getty and Lord Weidenfeld that has sponsored conferences on the opera and on the symphony, said today that it planned also to hold conferences on literature.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I WAS fascinated to read recently how Cornish hens were popularized in this country. In the 1950's, Victor Borge, the pianist and comedian, raised the birds on a farm he owned in Connecticut and sold them dressed and ready for the oven. They are a cross between an American fowl, the Plymouth Rock hen, and a Cornish or Bantam rooster or small gamecock.

title: CUOMO SEEKS TOUGHER PENALTIES FOR RACIAL CRIMES
description: Governor Cuomo proposed legislation today that would toughen the penalties for racially motivated acts of violence and would allow victims to sue their attackers for money.

title: REPORT SAYS FUNDS FOR MEDICARE PLAN WILL LAST TILL 2002
description: The Social Security fund that pays for Medicare hospital benefits improved over the past year but still faces bankruptcy shortly after the turn of the century, the fund's trustees said today.

title: IN PARAGUAY'S JUNGLE, NO LETUP IN BATTLE FOR SOULS
description: About 30 newly converted Ayoreo Indians set off from a Protestant mission in northern Paraguay in late December to contact ''unreached'' members of their tribe whose tiny jungle settlement had been spotted from the air by a missionary pilot.

title: Dome Reports Loss for 1986
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the financially beleaguered Canadian oil company, said yesterday that it had lost $2.2 billion (Canadian) in 1986, about $15.5 billion (United States) at current exchange rates. The loss appears to be the largest annual loss ever reported by a Canadian business.

title: New Jitters On Wall St.
description: The stock and bond markets began to recover yesterday from the dollar's steep drop against the yen.

title: 3 PREMIERES FOR NETWORK SITCOMS
description: THIS week's headlines tell us that the number of homeless families wandering the nation's streets has reached record numbers - to mention just one current crisis - but television entertainment seems determined to assure us that everything will be all right as long as we remain adorably bubble-headed. The sitcom marches on to the sounds of its own sweetened laugh track. Three new entries are coming on line this week.

title: AIDS Funds Gain in House
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to appropriate $20 million in foreign aid money for the 1988 fiscal year to help fight the spread of AIDS in developing countries. The action stipulates that the money be used for treatment, research and control of acquired immune deficiency symdrome.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 17wks to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a charge of $398,000 resulting from the reversal of investment tax credits taken in January and February 1986. The company said the charge was offset by transitional credits of $510,000. The company said in fiscal 1986, investment tax creditss reduced its income tax provision by $5.2 million. It said its effective tax rate for the latest year was 50.2 percent, compared with 44.4 percent for the previous year. The latest quarter and year are 17 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively; compared to the year-earlier periods of 16 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively.

title: Advertising; British Buy Rogers & Cowan
description: ROGERS & COWAN, a major American public relations firm that specializes in show business promotions, has been acquired by Shandwick P.L.C., Britain's largest public relations operation, which bought two other American companies in December.

title: People
description: * Michael J. Vogel has been elected to the board of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: On the Fast Track At the JWT Group
description: In the marketplace it is rumored that Ronald A. Kovas, a director of the JWT Group, is marked for even greater greatness at the company.

title: Star Broker Gets 15 Years
description: Leslie Roberts, who dropped out of college and became a top broker for E.F. Hutton & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company, has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for defrauding his uncle of millions of dollars.

title: Deep Six?
description: Fin swimming, in which competitors use rubber fins to add a powerful boost to their kick, is a fast sport that has been making slow progress in the United States since it was imported from Europe a few years ago. Now one version of it seems to have reached its high-water mark.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns totaling $2,084,000,000 before a reduction in deferred income taxes of $571 million. c-Net income Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago period. The company also said its financial results for 1986 also include $124 million in accumulated foreign exchange losses, which normally would be amortized over the remaining period of the loans to which they apply, but because of the uncertainty arising from its proposed restructuring plan, were charged to current expenses. The company said it reported a fourth quarter writedown in the value of its oil and gas properties of $1,204,000,000 before a reduction in deferred income taxes of $305 millioon, the result of a year-end accounting change in conjunction with the new full cost accounting guideline issued by the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants. This writedown is in addition to the $880 million writedown in the value of certain other assets taken largely in the third quarter.

title: BROADER FAMILY CARE URGED AT LABOR SESSION
description: The growing number of women in the work force is compelling businesses to broaden their benefit programs to such a degree that employers are beginning to play a much greater role in the care of families, according to Government officials and labor leaders meeting at a conference here today.

title: SHOPPING CENTER IS PLANNED FOR BRONX
description: When Irving Pergament started work a few years ago on the 184 houses he is now putting up in the Baychester section of the Bronx, a shopping center was not in the home builder's development plans.

title: FILM: YASUJIRO OZU, AS DIRECTOR AND SUBJECT
description: THE work and life of Yasujiro Ozu (1903-1963) are evoked with insight, intelligence and spirit in the splendid program opening today at the Film Forum 1. It's a double bill of ''The Only Son'' (1936), the Japanese film master's first ''talkie'' (he didn't want to rush into sound without knowing how to use it), and ''I Lived, but . . .'' (1983), a nearly two-hour documentary on Ozu's career made by his longtime associate, Kazuo Inoue.

title: First City Expects Additional Losses
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., which suffered large losses on energy and real estate loans in 1986, said it expected operating losses to continue ''for the foreseeable future.'' The bank holding company also said for the first time that its independent auditors had qualified the company's 1986 financial statements, meaning they determined that First City's ability to remain in business was in doubt unless the bank holding company could raise new capital.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HENLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $286 million in pre-tax restructuring charges that are related primarily to asset revaluations and writedowns for both the quarter and year; and the year also includes approximately $100 million for the amortization of good will and step-up depreciation. The company said that during the 1985 fourth quarter, it charged $47 million pre-tax of restructuring costs to earnings. These changes included a $35 million writedown of an operation's assets held for sale and $12 million to cover the streamlining of operations. The 1986 restructuring charges reflect writedowns and asset revaluations resulting from a comprehensive reappraisal of the company's businesses. By year-end, good will had been reduced to $467 million from $917 million at the beginning of 1986 as a result of revaluations and amortization. The results include the effect of the acquisition of businesses of Signal Cos. by Allied Corp., effective Oct. 1, 1985, which has been accounted for as a purchase of Signal by Allied. This transaction resulted in the formation of Allied-Signal Inc.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE TO OVERRIDE VETO ON HIGHWAY MEASURE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives today voted to override President Reagan's veto of the highway bill. A yes vote was a vote to override the veto. A no vote was a vote to sustain it. Voting yes were 248 Democrats and 102 Republicans. Voting no were one Democrat and 72 Republicans. An xxx denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Harris, yes; Nichols, yes. Republicans - Callahan, yes; Dickinson, yes. ALASKA Republican - Young, yes. ARIZONA Democrat - Udall, yes. Republicans - Kolbe, no; Kyl, no; Rhodes, no; Stump, no. ARKANSAS Democrats - Alexander, yes; Anthony, yes; Robinson, yes. Republican - Hammerschmidt, yes. CALIFORNIA Democrats - Anderson, yes; Bates, yes; Beilenson, yes; Berman, yes; Bosco, yes; Boxer, yes; Brown, yes; Coelho, yes; Dellums, yes; Dixon, yes; Dymally, yes; Edwards, yes; Fazio, yes; Hawkins, yes; Lantos, yes; Lehman, yes; Levine, yes; Martinez, yes; Matsui, yes; Miller, yes; Mineta, yes; Panetta, yes; Roybal, yes; Stark, yes; Torres, yes; Waxman, yes. Republicans - Badham, no; Dannemeyer, xxx; Dornan, no; Dreier, no; Gallegly, no; Herger, no; Hunter, no; Konnyu, yes; Lagomarsino, no; Lewis, yes; Lowery, yes; Lungren, no; McCandless, yes; Moorhead, no; Packard, yes; Pashayan, yes; Shumway, no; Thomas, yes. COLORADO Democrats - Campbell, yes; Schroeder, yes, Skaggs, yes. Republicans - Brown, no; Hefley, no; Schaefer, yes.

title: McDonnell Douglas Warns Of Cracks in Some DC-10's
description: The McDonnell Douglas Coporation has warned all airlines using DC-10's to check their horizontal stabilizers for cracks.

title: SAKHAROV TELLS THATCHER OF NEED FOR WEST TO BACK SOVIET CHANGES
description: Andrei D. Sakharov told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain today that it was vital for all nations to give support to the moves for a more open Soviet society espoused by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE THANATOS SYNDROME. By Walker Percy. 372 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about New York Stock Exchange specialists inaccurately described the profitability of the specialist that handles Eastman Kodak. A spokesman for the firm, RPM Securities, said that it fulfilled all its specialist responsibilities on Monday, when Kodak and the overall market declined sharply, and that it lost money trading in Kodak on that day.

title: DELTA-WESTERN MERGER BLOCKED
description: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco blocked the $860 million merger of Delta Air Lines and Western Airlines last night, just hours before it was to go into effect. The court said the merger would be prohibited until an arbitrator settles a dispute over union representation.

title: ART: A TURNER SHOWCASE IN LONDON
description: When the new Turner Building at the Tate Gallery in London is inaugurated Wednesday by the Queen, an ancient and ever more conspicuous wrong will be righted. J. M. W. Turner (1775-1851) is widely regarded as the greatest of all British painters. A man of all-comprehending genius, he has had no rival in British art for range, ambition, power of imagination and the ability to conceive of great and unprecedented undertakings and carry them to fulfillment.

title: Pratt & Whitney Wins Swiss Order
description: Swissair announced an order for what could be as many as 69 Pratt & Whitney aircraft engines, giving its second boost to the American aircraft industry in as many weeks.

title: DOW RAISES BUT RATES POSE PERIL
description: The stock market's session was over yesterday when Citibank surprised the financial community by raising its prime interest rate to 7 3/4 percent, and equity prices were thus able to recover from Monday's sharp selloff.

title: Aide Indicted for Gifts To Gov. Moore's Drive
description: West Virginia's Energy Commissioner, Kenneth R. Faerber, was indicted today on charges of violating a state election law by indirectly contributing funds to Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. through his two young children.

title: Trial Begins for 242 in Italy In 10-Year Heroin Gang War
description: Two hundred forty-two men went on trial today in connection with a 10-year gang war to control the heroin trade between northern Italy and Sicily in which 60 people were killed, officials said. The trial is expected to last at least a year.

title: JERSEY G.O.P. LEADERS TO PROPOSE BILL REQUIRING AUTO-PREMIUM CUT
description: Republican leaders in the Assembly said today that they would introduce legislation to require an average $90 cut in automobile insurance premiums as part of a bill intended to reduce the number of accident suits.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Prime Rise Aborts Recovery
description: The bond market was recovering some of Monday's sharp losses when it was shaken anew late yesterday after Citibank raised its base lending rate to 7 3/4 percent, from 7 1/2 percent. Chase Manhattan quickly followed suit.

title: A $1.6 Billion Offering Is Set by Puerto Rico
description: Puerto Rico is offering $1.6 billion of new bonds in the second-largest financing ever for the municipal market, and the largest ever backed by the full faith and credit of a local government.

title: A Gleeful Convention For Cable Television
description: At the annual meeting of the Cable Advertising Bureau, which drew more than 1,000 interested parties to the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, most of the talk had to do with the positive changes that have resulted from the deregulation of the industry, the growing involvement of system operators in programming and the emergence of marketing as a strong force.

title: THIRD MARINE GUARD FROM U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW ARRESTED
description: The Marine Corps has arrested a third enlisted man who served as a guard at the American Embassy in Moscow on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women, the Pentagon said today.

title: NOT JUST FOR VEGETARIANS
description: IT has been a long time since the word ''vegetarian'' conjured images of barefoot cooks with flowing tresses and of brown rice with seaweed. Vegetarianism has become so much a part of our culture that its definition has been expanded - erroneously - to include people who don't eat red meat but do eat fish and chicken. Even meat eaters, the vast majority of people, have increased their consumption of vegetable dishes and may on occasion even have a meatless meal.

title: C.W. MURCHISON JR. DIES IN TEXAS AT 63
description: Clint W. Murchison Jr., the scion of a Texas wildcat oil family who created the Dallas Cowboys football team, died Monday night. He was 63 years old. Mr. Murchison, who had been debilitated by a neurological disorder, was admitted to Gaston Episcopal Hospital here about two weeks ago, said Sandy McCoy, an associate administrator of the hospital. She said he died of complications caused by pneumonia.

title: Oscars Win, 2-1
description: ABC's telecast of the Academy Awards show drew nearly twice the audience as the N.C.A.A. basketball championship on CBS Monday night, according to the ratings released yesterday. In 13 markets in the Nielsen survey, the live telecast from Hollywood got an overall 33.8 rating and a 53 share compared with a 19.1 and a 27 share for the game. The second half of the game overlapped with the first hour of the Oscar show and during that period, according to an Arbitron survey, the show drew a 30.6 rating and a 45 share, while the game drew a 16.2 and 24.0 share.

title: CONTRACT UPHELD; THE ABSENCE OF GUIDELINES
description: The ruling yesterday in the Baby M case settled the specific question of who is granted custody of the child, but other courts and state legislatures will continue to face the larger question of whether surrogate-motherhood agreements are legal.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. DISSENTS ON SPECIAL PROSECUTORS
description: The Justice Department is opposing recent court orders that court-appointed special prosecutors are exempt from certain laws on conflict of interest that cover department employees.

title: SLEEPING ON THE JOB LEADS TO SHUTDOWN OF REACTOR
description: The Peach Bottom nuclear plant in Pennsylvania was ordered shut down today by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which said it found control room operators sleeping on duty.

title: KEVIN D. MURPHY
description: Kevin D. Murphy, a partner of KMS Corporate Brokers, a Wall Street bond brokerage concern, died of a heart attack Friday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 48 years old and lived in New York City and Newtown, Conn.

title: Commercial Credit Notes Noncallable
description: The Commercial Credit Company, a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, is offering $150 million of 8 percent noncallable notes, due in 1992, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Exchange to Add Hours
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said it planned to extend its trading hours to evening sessions to correspond with prime trading hours in the Far East. The change, expected to begin this summer, must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Richardson Indicted
description: Micheal Ray Richardson has been indicted by a Bergen County grand jury on charges of illegally cashing a check for more than $9,700. Dennis Kwasnik, an assistant prosecutor, said Richardson's auto insurance company, State Farm, gave Richardson the check to reimburse an auto repair shop for work done on a car owned by his wife. Instead, the check was deposited in an account of Richardson and his wife, according to the prosecutor. The 31-year-old Richardson was not arrested and will be notified of a court hearing within a month.

title: New Moody's Bond Index
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday introduced a new index of corporate bonds that it hopes will eventually become the basis for a new futures contract on the Commodity Exchange.

title: An Important Idea For Today, April 2
description: What this nation needs is an Official Fool. ''We have plenty,'' you say. ''The Federal Government's full of them.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 4, Maple Leafs 2: Bob Gould scored two goals last night to lead Washington, which was playing at home. Washington, second in the Patrick Division, is unbeaten in its last six games with a 5-0-1 record and has allowed only 13 goals in that span. The loss cost the Maple Leafs a chance to move into third place in the Norris Division. Toronto remained a point behind the Chicago Blackhawks and Minnesota North Stars. Chicago has three games remaining, Minnesota and Toronto two each. Both of Toronto's remaining games are with Chicago. (AP) Bruins 4, Nordiques 3: Goals by Tom McCarthy and Nevin Markwart 33 seconds apart in the third period broke a tie for the Bruins in Quebec. McCarthy got his 29th goal of the season on a rebound at 4:08 of the third period to break a 2-2 tie and Markwart scored 33 seconds later on a breakaway. The victory enabled Boston to move 1 point behind the Montreal Canadians in the struggle for second place in the Adams Division. (AP) N.B.A. 76ers 116, Cavaliers 105: Charles Barkley scored 34 points and had 12 rebounds and Steve Colter added 20 points for Philadelphia last night in Richfield, Ohio. Despite snowfalls that approached 20 inches in the Cleveland area, a crowd of 17,641 turned out to watch the 76ers' star, Julius Erving, in his final appearance at the Richfield Coliseum. Erving, who will retire at the end of the season, scored 17 points. The 76ers led, 83-80, with 2:36 remaining in the third quarter but outscored the Cavaliers, 10-5, over the rest of the period and then went on a 9-0 run to take a 102-85 lead with 8:32 left. (AP) Bulls 101, Bullets 75: Michael Jordan scored 36 points as Chicago clinched a playoff berth. The Bulls took control with a 16-0 surge in a six-minute span during the second quarter to go from a 34-31 deficit to a 47-34 lead. Jeff Malone led Washington with 22 points. Chicago led, 31-26, at the end of the first quarter, with Jordan scoring 16 points. (AP) BOXING Defending Champion Advances: Kenneth Gould, the defending two-time welterweight champion, scored a 5-0 decision over Derrick Rolon in a preliminary bout yesterday at the United States Boxing Championships in Buffalo. Rolon, 18 years old, of Elizabeth, N.J., was a National Golden Gloves quarterfinalist at 147 pounds in 1986. The tournament, conducted by the United States of America Amateur Boxing Federation, uses Olympic-style scoring based on how many punches hit with the white part of the gloves. The tournament is the first of four major amateur boxing competitions this year, leading to the 1988 Olympic trials. (AP) TENNIS Connors Advances: Second-seeded Jimmy Connors survived a first-set tiebreaker loss and rallied to win the second set before his opponent, Todd Witsken, dropped out because of the flu in an opening-round match of the $315,000 Volvo Chicago tournament last night. The 34-year-old Connors advanced, 6-7, 6-2, 2-1, when Witsken of Carmel, Ind., retired. In other first-round action, third-seeded Tim Mayotte of Bradenton, Fla., took just 53 minutes to oust Derrick Rostagno of Brentwood, Calif., 6-1, 6-1. (AP) Mandlikova Beats Smylie: Top-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia defeated Australia's Elizabeth Smylie 3-6, 6-2, 6-3, in a bitter battle last night to advance to the second round of the United States Women's Indoor championships at Piscataway, N.J. It was the first time the two have met since Smylie upset Mandlikova in the third round at Wimbledon in 1985. Earlier in the day, Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia and Australia's Wendy Turnbull scored second-round victories, but seventh-seeded Melissa Gurney was upset. Gigi Fernandez of Puerto Rico, unseeded and ranked 56th in the world, reached the quarterfinals with an unexpectedly easy 6-3, 6-0 vitory over the 17th-ranked Gurney. Sukova, who is seeded second, dominated Ann Henricksson with big serves to advance to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 6-3 victory, while the 34-year-old Turnbull took the last six games in defeating Kathrin Keil, 6-4, 6-1. Fourth-seeded Lori McNeil won a first-round match, defeating Susan Rimes, 6-0, 6-4, while Barbara Potter cracked 14 aces in a 6-3, 6-2 triumph over Pilar Vasquez of Peru. (AP)

title: BOARDER BABIES FIND COMFORT IN FOSTER GRANDPARENTS' ARMS
description: THREE HUNDRED abandoned ''boarder babies'' who have been living in the hospitals where they were born, some for months, while awaiting foster care may be placed by November, according to a plan announced by the city last week. But they still wait, although not without special attention: a program giving the elderly a role in their care has recently begun.

title: Micro-victory in the Chip War
description: When Samuel Johnson proclaimed that patriotism was the last refuge of a scoundrel, he failed to cast his net wide enough. For patriotism is also the last refuge of more and more law-abiding American businessmen who can't cope effectively with foreign competitors.

title: JAPAN PLANS TO DENY VISAS TO ALIENS WITH AIDS VIRUS
description: The Japanese Government submitted legislation today that would deny visas to foreigners who are known to carry the virus that causes acquired immune defficiency syndrome and are considered ''likely to spread the virus to many people in Japan.''

title: Bridge: In New Duplicate Laws,An Old Query Is Banned
description: The revised ''Laws of Duplicate Bridge,'' which come into force today in North America, will be a shock for some, particularly those who were social players before they became duplicate enthusiasts.

title: Rainmaking in the Aegean
description: Real differences over sea boundaries and oil drilling rights no doubt carried Greece and Turkey to the edge of military conflict in the Aegean. But the speed with which this storm erupted, and then evaporated, suggests it was artificially seeded by political rainmakers. Certainly the spat has helped Greece's populist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou: he roused cheers on the right by denouncing Turkey, and on the left by threatening to close down an American supply depot. With this in mind, better to cast a cool eye than to jump.

title: MEREDITH MONK AND PING CHONG
description: AN evening-long work by Meredith Monk and Ping Chong that opened last night at the Joyce Theater, ''Paris/Venice-Milan/Chacon,'' is a magical, intricately woven and many-layered excursion through time. Strange sounds and music and words in several languages form a haunting aural backdrop for this voyage. Men and women who are at once mysterious and commonplace people the landscape. Ms. Monk and Mr. Chong subtitle their piece, created over four years in the mid-1970's, ''the travelogue series.'' They are the travelers. We wander with them through time and space and memory, always a little apart and yet as deeply immersed as objects in a stream.

title: Bonn Denies Plan to Release Lebanese Sought by the U.S.
description: West German Government officials denied today that there were plans to free a Lebanese hijacking suspect rather than extradite him to the United States.

title: No Impropriety in Frankfurter Conversations
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwards's 'Blind Date' In Top Box-Office Spot
description: ''Blind Date,'' a Blake Edwards comedy that stars Kim Basinger and Bruce Willis as her ill-fated date, took in $7.5 million in its first weekend to gain the No. 1 spot at the box office.

title: Use Port Authority Toll Hikes for Mass Transit, Not Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT BACKS WIDE SEARCHES BY PUBLIC EMPLOYERS
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that public employers have ''wide latitude'' to search employees' offices, desks and files without warrants or probable cause to believe that the search will uncover evidence of wrongdoing.

title: ALEX L. HART
description: Alex L. Hart, a transportation consultant who in the 1960's was executive director of the New York-New Jersey Transportation Agency, died March 11 in Aurora, Colo. He was 73 years old and was a former resident of Centerport, L.I.

title: Offices Are Bombed in Lima
description: Guerrillas bombed the headquarters of Peru's ruling party and eight party offices in Lima today, police officials said. Dynamite thrown from a speeding car at dawn blew out windows and wrecked furniture in the headquarters of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance. Flying glass wounded a guard. The police blamed the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,565,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are translated from Italian lira to U.S. dollars at the Dec. 31, 1986, exchange rate. The company attributed the 1986 improved performance to a gain of $18,752,000 resulting from the issuance of stock by its Maserati subsidiary to Chrysler Corp. in connection with an October 1986 financing transaction.

title: Board Studies Rocket Failure
description: A nine-member board began an investigation today into the failure of a rocket carrying a communications satellite that may have been hit by lightning. The chairman, Jon R. Busse, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the board would review the launching then break up into smaller groups for more detailed study. The $78 million Atlas-Centaur rocket, carrying an $83 million military communications satellite , broke apart 52 seconds after it was launched in a rainstorm Thursday.

title: HARRY G. HACKETT
description: Harry G. Hackett, the first black man appointed a Federal bankruptcy judge, died here Saturday. He was 64 years old.

title: Article 829487 -- No Title
description: After months of agreements made and broken, the State Legislature passed tonight a bill to allow work to begin on a five-year, $8.6 billion rebuilding of New York City's mass-transit system.

title: Yields 4% to 6.90% On Illinois Bonds
description: Illinois yesterday offered $250 million of general obligation refunding bonds through underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: CHIRAC IS ASSURED IN REAGAN TALKS
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France met with President Reagan today and came away with the assurances he was seeking on nuclear weapons in Europe as well as a possible political boon for himself.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: I AM not a timid person. But as with most people, being in a hospital, sick and scared, stripped me of my usual ability to fight for my rights.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday gave the incorrect network for the debut of ''Roxie'' tonight at 8 P.M. The half-hour situation comedy will be shown on CBS. Also, a cast change was announced after press time; Jack Riley, not Jerry Stiller, is featured.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend to be paid April 21.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the sale of one of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' paintings for $39.9 million misstated the circumstances of the artist's suicide. Van Gogh died at Auvers-sur-Oise, France, two days after shooting himself near there and several weeks after leaving an asylum at St.-Remy.

title: ECHOES OF NEW MOSCOW REACH SIBERIA, FAINTLY
description: Tatyana M. Malinovskaya is the party boss in a county where reindeer outnumber people, 200,000 to 26,000. Her office in this gold-mining town in northeastern Siberia, opposite Alaska, is closer to Washington than to Moscow.

title: THE COWBOY, MAN AND MYTH ALIKE, IS ALIVE AND WELL IN NORTHERN TEXAS
description: THE winter is breaking now along the Clear Fork of the Brazos River, a hardscrabble land of limestone ridges, draws and dry creek beds dotted with mesquite and prickly pear cactus. On the vast ranches that drape over the brush-covered uplands, the annual roundup has begun. These are hectic days, the time to bring in the new calves, vaccinate, dehorn, brand and castrate them.

title: Thrift Insurance Fund
description: A House subcommittee voted today to pump $25 billion into the fund that insures savings and loan association deposits. The House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions voted 23 to 20 for a proposal by Representative Thomas Carper, Democrat of Delaware, that would raise $10 billion from assessments on the industry and $15 billion from bonds sold in the capital markets.

title: Audi to Offer $5,000 Discount
description: Audi of America Inc., which has had bad publicity involving sudden acceleration problems in some of its earlier models, said Monday that it would give $5,000 discounts to Audi owners who buy new models.

title: 'A GOOD, CLEAN LIVING'
description: THE son and grandson of North Texas cowboys, George Peacock was to be nothing else. That's all he ever knew, breaking horses, roping calves and driving wagon teams even before he went to school. He began as a wrangler, turning out at 4 A.M. to pen the horses for the other hands. Today, at the age of 52, he is the foreman of the Nail Ranch, one of the region's most respected cowboys, punching cows by day and writing checks by night as ranch manager. Mounted on Buckshot, his 22-year-old bay, with his walrus mustache and floppy black hat, George Peacock is a master of an ancient trade.

title: WHO'S WHO IN THE FIGHT FOR BABY M
description: Baby M Called Melissa by the Sterns, Sara by the Whiteheads... had her first birthday last Friday... described as happy, alert and resilient. Mary Beth Whitehead 29 years old... dropped out of high school at 15... married at 16, had two children before she turned 19... signed a surrogate agreement with William Stern in February 1985... was to receive a $10,000 fee for carrying the baby... gave birth on March 27, 1986... refused the money... fled to Florida and lived there for 87 days to avoid giving up the child. Richard Whitehead 37 years old... sanitation worker... said he has struggled to overcome alcoholism... had a vasectomy six months after the birth of their second child... initially said ''no way'' to his wife's desire to become a surrogate mother... slipped out a window with the child when officers delivered court papers ordering her returned to the Sterns. William Stern 41 years old... biochemist... born in Berlin... parents are dead... other relatives were killed in Nazi concentration camps... agreed to pay Mrs. Whitehead to bear a child using his artifically inseminated sperm. Dr. Elizabeth Stern 41 years old... put off child-rearing to study for a medical degree... became a pediatrician in 1981... assistant professor of pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York... also has a doctorate in human genetics... has a mild case of miltiple sclerosis... said she feared pregnancy would jeopardize her health. Judge Harvey R. Sorkow 57 years old... family court judge... stressed during the trial that the best interest of the child should come before the needs of the adults... sought to have the trial closed to the public, but was overruled by the New Jersey Supreme Court. Harold J. Cassidy Whitehead lawyer... 41 years old... studied to be a Catholic priest before graduating from St. Peter's College... called the idea of paying surrogate mothers to bear and surrender infants ''repulsive and repugnant''... has served on the defense team of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a former boxer, and John Artis, accused of killing three people in Paterson, N.J. in 1966. Gary N. Skoloff Stern lawyer... 53 years old... a leading divorce lawyer in New Jersey... author of a three-volume textbook on family court law... said his goal was to create a perception of Mrs Whitehead as a ''liar''... argued that surrogate motherhood arrangements could not be obviated by principles that govern adoptions... cited 35 reasons why Mrs. Whitehead was unsuitable for custody.

title: CHEVY'S CRUCIAL NEW MODELS
description: A shark's fin glides through dark blue water and then a car emerges from the deep. The clear message of the television commercial is that the 1988 Chevrolet Beretta is as sleek and aggressive as a shark - and, even more important, a break from the General Motors Corporation's recent run of undistinguished lookalike cars.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A new two-year contract proposal that would pay Roger Clemens a $1.5 million base salary in 1988 was rejected yesterday by the Boston Red Sox. However, General Manager Lou Gorman said, ''We want to keep the line of communications open and see if we can work something out'' to get the right-handed pitching ace back with the team, which he left March 6. . . . Vida Blue, who quit baseball last month, says he hopes to get back into the game. The 37-year-old left-hander and former American League Cy Young Award winner told KNBR radio in San Francisco that he had received an offer to pitch in Japan. He declined to discuss his monthlong participation in a drug rehabilitation program last November.

title: ALBANY INQUIRY EXPANDING TO CAMPAIGN REPORTS
description: In an apparent violation of election law, some candidates for the State Legislature did not report that some campaign workers were being paid for their services with state funds, according to a review of campaign documents and interviews with state election officials.

title: Contras Cut Power
description: Nicaraguan rebels destroyed two electrical towers in raids close to the country's border with Costa Rica, the Nicaraguan Energy Institute said today. The attacks have cut off the supply of electricity to Nicaragua from Costa Rica, the institute said. It did not provide details on the extent of blackouts caused by the attacks.

title: Cone Hot in Debut With Mets
description: David Cone made his debut as the newest arm on the Mets' pitching staff today, and sizzled: three innings against the St. Louis Cardinals, two singles, no walks, no runs and five strikeouts, and just about everything thrown around 90 miles an hour.

title: REBELS KILL 43 SALVADOR TROOPS AND U.S. ADVISER
description: Leftist guerrillas severely damaged a key army base here this morning, killing 43 Salvadoran soldiers and a United States military adviser, the first to die in combat in El Salvador.

title: Happy April Fool's Day
description: The best bet here on April Fool's Day is that the winner of the next Presidential election will be a man whose first or second name begins with the letter B. The reason for putting your money on the buzzing B's is that there are so many of them now swarming around the greasy pole.

title: CENTURY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,974,554. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $268,000.

title: On the Road With Senator Dole, the Campaigner
description: Minutes after a private jet carrying Senator Bob Dole left Washington's National Airport for a series of Presidential campaign appearances in New York, the flight attendant told the Senate Republican leader that Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, was on the telephone. Mr. Dole thought for a moment, then said he would return the call on a more secure phone line once the plane landed.

title: Backer Buys Toronto Firm
description: Eight-year-old Backer & Spielvogel has made its first acquisition in a foreign land. It has bought Straiton, Pearson, Martin & Holman of Toronto, with which it shares two clients, Hyundai, the South Korean conglomerate and car maker, and Quaker Oats' Fisher-Price toys.

title: CBS'S TISCH ADDRESSES BROADCASTERS
description: Laurence A. Tisch, the president of CBS, today questioned the constitutionality of forthcoming Congressional hearings on the operations of the news departments of the three major networks.

title: CAJUN AND CREOLE: FRENCH
description: COUNTLESS words have been written by now about the joys of Creole and Cajun cooking. The popularity of those foods - from Cajun popcorn (deep-fried crawfish) to jambalaya and shrimp Creole - continues apace. Blackened redfish has become an obsession for some; others consider it a plague.

title: FOOD INDUSTRY EYES IRRADIATION WARILY
description: MORE than 500 pounds of ripe, juicy papayas were sneaked into Los Angeles last week and unobtrusively delivered to supermarkets. The papayas had been treated with radiation to kill fruit flies, and while that is legal it is also controversial. The growers were trying to get the fruit to shoppers without alerting the National Coalition to Stop Food Irradiation, whose members were on a ''shelf watch,'' ready to swoop in as soon as irradiated fruit appeared.

title: Homosexual Is Given Right to Visit Children
description: A woman will allow her former husband, a homosexual, to have overnight visits with their two daughters, ending an 18-month legal battle that began when she demanded that he be tested for the AIDS virus, lawyers said today.

title: Words You Can't Learn in Our Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Strikes Jet in Air; Eagle Is Held at Fault
description: A midair collision between a jet airliner and a fish delayed an Alaska Airlines flight for about an hour Monday while the plane was inspected for damage.

title: JAPAN WEIGHING STEPS TO EASE TRADE DISPUTE
description: The Japanese Government has begun to consider a broad range of measures to defuse the intensifying trade crisis with the United States.

title: KHAKI ATTIRE GOES TO TOWN IN A GENTLER, FEMININE GUISE
description: IN the beginning, there were khaki-colored drill cloth trousers, the kind worn by the British Army when it occupied India in the 19th century. Then came British Khaki, a clothing manufacturing company opened seven years ago by Robert Lighton, whose family owns men's stores.

title: High and Low
description: The standing of the conferences whose teams won at least one game in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament: W L Pct. Pacific Coast A.A. 4 1 .800 Big East 14 5 .737 Big Ten 12 5 .706 Independents 5 3 .625 Southeastern 8 6 .571 Big Eight 5 4 .556 Western Athletic 3 3 .500 Mid-Continent 1 1 .500 Midwestern Collegiate 1 1 .500 Atlantic Coast 5 6 .455 Atlantic 10 1 2 .333 Ohio Valley 1 2 .333 Pacific-10 1 2 .333 Sun Belt 1 2 .333 Southwest 1 3 .250 Note: A total of 15 conferences had a cumulative record of 0-17.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TOM ARMSTRONG is director of the Whitney Museum of American Art. He and his wife, Bunty, are also weekend gardeners, currently involved in landscaping their country place. The perfect addition to the front of their house, the Armstrongs decided, would be a pair of American beech trees. They telephoned their nursery and were told that, yes, there were two American beeches available but one, unfortunately, had a ''serious problem.'' Exactly what would that be, the Armstrongs wanted to know.

title: ALL MOSCOW MARINES SAID TO FACE POLYGRAPH TEST
description: The 28 Marine guards at the American Embassy here have been told that they will be asked to take polygraph tests after their return to the United States, according an American close to the contingent.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes special gains of $10,456,000 and $56,250,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a charge of $1,518,000 for the quarter; and the year includes special gains of $10,086,000. Prior year results are restated. The company said unusual items amounting to $56,438,000 in 1986 include gains on sales of investments, a gain on the issue of shares by Campbell Red Lake Mines Ltd. and a provision for the decline in the quoted market value of marketable securities. Results are in Canadian currency.

title: Economic Scene; U.S.: 'Borrower Of Last Resort'
description: IN their highly charged state of nervousness, financial markets initially reacted to the United States announcement that it would impose punitive tariffs, amounting to $300 million, against Japan for its failure to comply with a semiconductor agreement as though the end of civilization as we have known it might be approaching.

title: NIEKRO NAILS DOWN YANK STARTING ROLE
description: The day was going to be relatively quiet, but it turned into a morning full of revelations after Rick Rhoden's scheduled appearance in a minor-league game was called off following an overnight storm.

title: Customs Held Drexel Official
description: Robert Kramer, a vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert, was detained last Friday by United States Customs agents as he was leaving the Bahamas for failing to declare $88,000 in cash and securities in his possession, Drexel officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Orders Up 4.3% at U.S. Factories
description: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods, led by heavy demand for military equipment, shot up 4.3 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the best showing in five months.

title: Emery Air Freight Bids for Purolator
description: The Purolator Courier Corporation, the package delivery company that is the subject of a $35-a-share buyout offer, received a higher takeover bid of $40 a share last night from the Emery Air Freight Corporation.

title: A Memory Dishonored
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS PUT END TO LOSS STREAK
description: With seven seconds remaining, Chris McNealy replaced Louis Orr. There was no particular game strategy involved in Bob Hill's move. The Knick coach was simply looking for an ovation for Orr, the 6-foot-9-inch forward who had 28 points last night - equaling his career high - in the Knicks' surprising 128-120 victory over the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 1, 1987
description: International A3-12 Rebels damaged a key army base in El Salvador, killing at least 43 Salvadoran soldiers and a U.S. military adviser. It appeared to be the most important and successful rebel operation in recent years. Page A1 The Pope labeled Chile a dictatorship and insisted that the Roman Catholic Church must struggle to bring democracy to the nation. John Paul II spoke to reporters aboard a plane carrying him to South America. A1 William Webster will be questioned about Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's handling of the Iran-contra affair at hearings next month on Mr. Webster's nomination to be Director of Central Intelligence. A6 A third embassy guard was arrested Sunday on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women, the Pentagon said. The enlisted man has not been charged with espionage. A1 All nations must support ''glasnost,'' Andrei D. Sakharov told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over lunch.
