''A more democratic, more open country is safer for the world as a whole,'' he said. A1 Moscow has asked for help from several Western nations in fighting terrorism and has suggested that treaties be negotiated to provide for the return of terrorist suspects, according to diplomats. A3 Israeli officials were divided in their assessment of reports that Moscow would soon permit large-scale Soviet Jewish emigration directly to Israel and more freedom of religion for Soviet Jews. A9 A3 A Socialist Party convention in Italy opened yesterday, paving the way for the possible formation of a new government. Five parties of the governing coalition are struggling to rearrange their alliance. A5 Chirac assured in Reagan talks A7 Peace reigns along Artic border A11 Senators urge diplomacy in Latin America A12 National A14-22 The House easily overrode the veto by President Reagan of the $87.9 billion highway bill, leaving the Senate as the battleground for a major test of Mr. Reagan's power in his final 22 months in office. A1 A $38.3 billion housing bill was approved by the Senate. The bill, which rejects the efforts of the President to cut housing programs, would break a seven-year deadlock in Congress over housing policy. A14 Credit for discovering the AIDS virus will be shared by researchers from the U.S. and France, President Reagan and Prime Minister Chirac announced. The unusual agreement ends a festering scientific dispute. A1 Japan may deny visas to foreigners who are known to carry the AIDS virus and are considered ''likely to spread the virus to many people.'' A spokesman said the country does not plan to screen all foreigners. A18 A hospital faces loss of funds from Medicare and Medicaid because of the transfer of uninsured poor patients to other hospitals. The Government has begun an investigation into five such cases at the hospital in San Pablo, Calif. A17 Public employers may search employees' offices, desks and files without warrants or probable cause, the Supreme Court ruled. But it rejected the idea that there are no limits on such searches. A15 The Justice Department renewed its attack on a local affirmative action plan in the District of Columbia in spite of last week's Supreme Court decision upholding the legality of such programs. A14 Students at black colleges are bearing the brunt of Federal grant cutbacks and are falling deeply into debt to finance their education, according to a new study. A19 The cowboy and his spirit survives. He may drive to work in a truck and sometimes round up the cows with a helicopter, but his basic tools are the same and his sixth sense about livestock remains intact. C1 500 pounds of irradiated papayas were unobtrusively delivered to Los Angeles supermarkets last week. While it is legal to treat some food with radiation to kill pests, it is also controversial. C1 Teamwork urged in cockpit A14 Cold grips South and Midwest A16 Blood-clotting substance tested A18 Washington Talk A20 On the road with Senator Dole The Smithsonian's stock Regional B1-6, B24 Baby M will live with her father. Judge Harvey Sorkow awarded custody of the baby born under a surrogate-parenting agreement to William Stern and stripped Mary Beth Whitehead of all parental rights. A1 Excerpts from the ruling B2 News analysis: The Baby M ruling settled the specific question of who is granted custody of the child, but it does not resolve the question of whether surrogate-motherhood agreements are legal. A1 Questions about surrogate parenting that go far beyond the Baby M case are being raised by experts in philosophy, law and psychiatry. The mood appears to be one of caution rather than quick action. B2 Segregated housing patterns that seemed to be breaking up in the 1960's and early 1970's are reasserting themselves in New York City and its suburbs, according to a wide range of experts and studies. B1 Detectives searching for a motive in the slaying of a Parking Violations Bureau hearing officer are focusing on about 900 cases handled by the officer in recent years, police officials said. B6 The Wollman Memorial Rink earned a profit of about $400,000 to $500,000 in its first season after being renovated by Donald J. Trump. The ice-skating rink was expected to break even. The money will be donated to charity and public works. B3 Rain and wind in New York City turn everyday activities into Olympian events. ''In weather like this, you don't just leave for work,'' said one woman. ''You have to psyche yourself up.'' B1 An $8.6 billion mass-transit bill to rebuild New York City's mass-transit system was approved by the State Legislature last night. The M.T.A. announced it would begin spending money by the end of the night. B1 Cuomo seeks tougher penalties for racial violence B5 Jersey plan on auto premiums B24

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $2,610,000 for the quarter and $18,066,000 for the year, and a gain of $2,614,000 on the termination of pension plan for both periods, and the quarter also included a $3,605,000 reversal of net operating loss carryforward. c-After realized investment gains of $2,442,000 for the quarter and $13,557,000 for the year. The latest full-year results include a pre-tax gain of $5,772,000 relating to Guaranty National Corp.'s public common offering. The 1985 fourth quarter and full- year results were restated to reflect the deconsolidation of Guaranty National's financial statements, since Orion's investment in Guaranty now is reflected in the consolidated financial statements using the equity method of accounting and to conform with the classifications used in 1986.

title: Keeping a Name
description: To The Living Section:

title: TO SERVE 'THE BEST INTERESTS OF A CHILD'
description: Following are excerpts from the decision by Judge Harvey R. Sorkow in the surrogate-mother dispute between Mary Beth Whitehead, the mother of Baby M, and William Stern, the father. The Issue

title: ADMINISTRATION ATTACKS AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration today renewed its attack on a local affirmative action plan involving the District of Columbia Fire Department in spite of a Supreme Court decision last week upholding the legality of such programs.

title: RENEE GILL
description: Renee Gill, a former remedial reading teacher, died Monday at her home in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. She was 67 years old.

title: Livestock Contracts Up As Grain Prices Retreat
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures eased slightly today despite analysts' expectations that a decline in acreage would be forecast in the year's first official survey of farmers' planting intentions.

title: Dropout in California
description: Representative Tony Coelho, the Californian who is one of the House Democratic leaders, predicted here the other day that the party's 1988 Presidential nominee may be chosen in a ''brokered'' convention next summer in Atlanta.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: More Spring Lamb Traditionally, consumers look for spring lamb for their Easter menus or for Passover around this time. The official season for spring lamb, however, is considerably longer. The period in which these lambs must be slaughtered to qualify for the Federal designation ''genuine spring lamb'' extends from March 1 through early October, although use of the designation by meatpackers is optional.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for 12mos Feb 28
COMPUTERS IMPROVE THE FIT OF ARTIFICIAL JOINTS
description: ADVANCES in computer-aided design and manufacturing are allowing superior custom-made bone or joint replacements, enabling many patients to live free of disfigurement or crippling disabilities.

title: HOSPITAL MAY LOSE FUNDS OVER TRANSFERS OF POOR
description: The Federal Government has notified a California hospital that it plans to end Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement there because of the transfer of uninsured poor patients from its emergency ward to other hospitals.

title: Axing of Snowwoman Is Disorderly Conduct
description: A woman who destroyed a bikini-clad snow sculpture with a hatchet because she found it sexually offensive must answer for her actions in court, the chief city prosecutor said today.

title: HUMAN TESTS BEGUN ON MANMADE FACTOR FOR CLOTTING OF BLOOD
description: A health care company reported Monday that it had started the first testing in humans of a manmade version of the clotting substance missing from the blood of most hemophiliacs.

title: CLOSE TEST SEEN IN SENATE TODAY
description: The House of Representatives today easily overrode President Reagan's veto of the $87.9 billion highway bill, leaving the Senate as the battleground for a major test of Mr. Reagan's power in the final 22 months of his Presidency.

title: KEY RATES
Chez Stennis
description: Consider, alas, the poor catfish, an estimable creature despite its humble origins.

title: Kidnapped Japanese Is Freed in Philippines
description: A kidnapped Japanese businessman has been released unharmed after a four-month abduction, the Government said today.

title: DEVILS SET RECORD WITH 29TH VICTORY
description: Two goals 15 seconds apart in the last period, including the third in the game for Perry Anderson, led the Devils to a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CONTRACT UPHELD; SURROGACY IS LEGAL
description: A judge awarded custody of Baby M today to her father, William Stern, and stripped the child's biological mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, of all parental rights.

title: CHAMPION'S ART STAYS ELEMENTAL
description: In the early 1980's, at a time when Marvelous Marvin Hagler was struggling for public recognition, he was invited to appear on CBS-TV's weekend sports anthology show.

title: CITIBANK RAISES ITS PRIME RATE
description: Citibank raised its prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent yesterday, the first increase by a major bank since June 1984.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THERE ARE RAINBOWS IN TROUT OPENER
description: MORE fishermen than fish were visible along the East and West branches of the Croton River yesterday morning, but that is a typical opening-day scenario that never seems to trouble anyone.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES TENNESSEAN AS DIRECTOR OF COMMUNICATIONS
description: President Reagan completed an overhaul of the White House staff today by naming Thomas G. Griscom as the new director of communications, a job that puts him in charge of efforts to make the President more visible to the public.

title: WARHOL IS REMEMBERED BY 2,000 AT ST. PATRICK'S
description: The glittering New York crowd that Andy Warhol loved paid tribute to him yesterday at one of his favorite New York places. More than 2,000 people crowded into St. Patrick's Cathedral for a memorial mass honoring the late artist.

title: 4G DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CHALONE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AXLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BROKERS SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $76,657. c-Net income d-Includes extraordinary credits of $33,654 and $42,654 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest fourth quarter loss is related to management and staff efforts being centered around the completion of the company's initial public offering in November 1986.

title: SECURITIES ISSUES SET A RECORD
description: An environment of generally steady, low interest rates proved fertile for securities underwriters in the first quarter, and the volume of bonds and stock issued by corporations soared to a record.

title: WESTRONIX INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company acquired Cutronics Inc. on Dec. 26, 1986 and for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1986, Cutronics reported a loss of $2,086,000 on sales of $26,775,000.

title: CITY INCREASES INCOME LIMITS IN RENTAL PLAN
description: Families with incomes significantly higher than originally announced will be eligible for apartments under the first phase of the Koch administration's 10-year plan to renovate abandoned, city-owned housing.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago quarter and 9 months' sales include revenue from Mr. Gatti's restaurant operations, which were divested in June 1986.

title: DUNE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ANOTHER IS SOUGHT IN POLLARD CASE
description: American officials are concerned that an American living in Israel may have been involved in the Jonathan Jay Pollard espionage case and are seeking his cooperation, according to sources with knowledge of the case.

title: Politics, Not Religion, Drives Mideast Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: PUERTO RICO COURT SET TO TRY 3 IN HOTEL FIRE
description: The three men charged in the New Year's Eve hotel fire that killed 97 people and injured more than 140 others will stand trial in local court on charges of first-degree murder, arson and conspiracy, Judge Luis Saavedra of the Commonweath District Court ruled today.

title: PEN Selects 2 Winners Of Freedom Awards
description: The PEN American Center chose a Soviet dissident poet and a South African playwright as winners of its Freedom-to-Write Awards.

title: Tampa Drug Test Challenge
description: Water workers have sued the city, contending that surprise on-the-job drug tests violated their constitutional rights. The suit was filed Monday in Federal District Court by eight employees of the Tampa Water Department on behalf of all city water workers. It seeks an order declaring drug testing unconstitutional. Employees sought an emergency order blocking further testing, but Judge William Castagna denied that and set a hearing for April 7.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS $5 BILLION RESCUE OF F.S.L.I.C.
description: The House Banking Committee voted today to raise $5 billion over the next two years to help the ailing Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which Government auditors say is technically insolvent.

title: A Soldier Dies; a Commitment Remains
description: Salvadoran rebels demolished a supposedly impregnable base Tuesday, killing scores of soldiers, including a U.S. adviser. But the setback doesn't diminish the value or need for continued commitment to human rights and legitimate civilian rule in a country that has known little of either.

title: BLACKS AND POLITICAL POWER: THE KEY TO EASING TENSON
description: The single most important step in improving race relations in the New York City area is greater participation by blacks in the political process at the grass-roots level, according to a wide range of politicians, city officials and political experts.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 16
description: b-Includes a one-time pre-tax gain on the sale of assets of $181,000. c-Net loss

title: DYNAMIC HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net loss

title: 3 BANKS RECLASSIFY BRAZIL DEBT
description: Three major banking companies said today that their loans to Brazil would be placed on nonaccrual status, actions that would reduce their net income for 1987 by tens of millions of dollars.

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax provision of $30,338,000 for impairment of geothermal properties for the quarter and year. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $19,500,000 for the quarter and $20,590,000 for the year.

title: Report Finds Fewer Dropouts
description: High school dropout rates declined in the 1970's and early 1980's, a report by the Census Bureau indicates.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $23 million on oil and gas properties and a $30.3 million provision for impairment of geothermal property.

title: MISSILE DIPLOMACY: EUROPE PREPARES
description: A new triangular relationship between Britain, France and West Germany has been forged as the leaders of the three nations seek to define their strategic interests vis-a-vis Washington and Moscow.

title: Evangelist Now Calls For $8 Million a Year
description: The evangelist Oral Roberts told his followers today that God had spared him because they had contributed more than $8 million, but he said the Lord had told him ''we must continue'' to raise that amount every year until the Second Coming of Christ.

title: To Amend or Not: The Debate Continues
description: In May 1787 Congress called a convention to revise the Government charter, the Articles of Confederation. Before the delegates adjourned they had thrown the charter out.

title: Evil of the Holocaust
description: To The Home Section:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The sudden fame and fortune he achieved is nice. But we sort of robbed him of his youth.'' - Frank Cashen, the Mets' general manager, on Dwight Gooden. [ A1:6. ]

title: OWNER TAKES OVER U.P.I.'S OPERATIONS AS PRESIDENT QUITS
description: Mario Vazquez Rana, the Mexican publisher who owns United Press International, announced yesterday that he had taken over operating control of the financially troubled news agency.

title: Caesars Takeover Venture Called Off
description: The New York investor Martin T. Sosnoff said two Dallas-based concerns had ended talks with him on a joint venture to acquire Caesars World Inc. In a statement, Mr. Sosnoff said talks with the Pratt Hotel Corporation and the Southmark Corporation, a real estate developer, had not been actively pursued since they were announced on March 20.

title: Funds to Go To Grumman
description: A sum of $300 million earmarked for building the T-46A jet training planes will stay on Long Island for aircraft production by the Grumman Corporation, Representative Samuel S. Stratton said today.

title: CABARET: KAREN AKERS
description: AMONG the overlapping subdivisions of cabaret singing that include saloon, jazz, ''legit'' theatrical, actor-singer, and pop-rock approaches, the ''art'' singer, who treats pop with the gravity of serious concert fare, may be the rarest breed.

title: MOTO PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $15,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss The company said the year-earlier revenue figures are restated to be consistent with the 1986 presentation.

title: The U.N. Today: April 2, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FROM 'BIG HOUSE' TO GREENHOUSE'
description: ''TODAY'S lesson is about plant functions,'' Arthur Sheppard announced as he drew the parts of a plant on the blackboard. About a dozen students, in chairs scattered about the greenhouse, began taking notes.

title: Sentence Delay For Siegel
description: The sentencing of Martin A. Siegel, the former mergers chief at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was delayed yesterday until April 30 at the Government's request. He had originally been scheduled for sentencing today. Mr. Siegel pleaded guilty in

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Canadian Fur Trappers Corp., a chain of 77 women's apparel stores, appointed N. Gerald Eatroff president and chief executive.

title: No Headline
description: N.H.L. Canadiens 3, Whalers 2: Bob Gainey poked the puck through the legs of the Hartford goaltender, Mike Liut, with 1 minute 51 seconds to play last night to give Montreal the victory. Montreal, playing at home, stalled the Whalers' clinching of the Adams Division title. The Whalers, who lead the second-place Canadiens by 3 points, need only a victory or a tie in their final two games - or a Montreal loss or tie - to win their first regular-season championship. The Canadiens trailed, 2-1, after the first period. Goals by Dean Evason and Ron Francis of the Whalers had offset Mats Naslund's 25th goal. But Montreal pulled even at 14 minutes 35 seconds of the second period. (AP) N.B.A. Pacers 99, Bulls 94: Chuck Person had 19 points and 10 rebounds last night for the Pacers, who clinched a playoff spot for the first time since 1981. The Pacers earned the playoff spot when the Cleveland Cavaliers lost to the Philadelphia 76ers, moving one game past the Washington Bullets and the Bulls for the sixth-seeded position in the Eastern Conference. The Bulls were led by Michael Jordan with 26 points, 11 below his season average. (AP) 76ers 108, Cavaliers 99: Charles Barkley had 25 points and 17 rebounds as the 76ers eliminated the Cavaliers from playoff consideration. Roy Hinson scored 22 points, Julius Erving added 20 and Steve Colter had 10 assists as the 76ers defeated the Cavaliers for the second time in two nights. Coach Lenny Wilkens of the Cavaliers was hit with two technicals and ejected by Referee Jack Madden with 2:49 left in the third quarter. (AP) Celtics 103, Bullets 86: Boston, led by Larry Bird's 30 points, held Washington to 34 points in the second half after the Celtics had only a 1-point halftime edge. Despite the defeat, the Bullets clinched a playoff spot because Cleveland, ninth in the Eastern Conference ,lost. Boston went on an 11-2 run that made the score 76-66 with 3:14 to go in the third quarter. (AP) Tennis Mandilkova Wins: Top-seeded Hana Mandlikova overcame an aching back and posted a 6-1, 6-3 victory yesterday over Marianne Werdel to advance to the quarterfinals of the $150,000 United States Women's Indoor championships in Piscataway, N.J. Immediately afterward, Mandlikova withdrew from the doubles tournament. Mandlikova, ranked No. 4, said her back was hurt in practice Monday. Mandlikova will next play eighth-seeded Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, who advanced with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Catherine Tanvier of France. (AP) Kriek Upset: Peter Fleming won a first-set tiebreaker en route to a 7-6, 6-4 upset of fifth-ranked Johan Kriek in the second round of the $315,000 Volvo Chicago tournament. Fleming had not played a singles match in a Grand Prix tournament since last October. Ranked No. 123 in the world, he had to go through qualifying play to earn a spot in the 32-player field in Chicago. (AP) Boxing Lonon Advances: Brian Lonon of the United States Army took another step on the long road to an Olympic boxing team berth with a quarterfinal victory yesterday in the United States amateur championships. The 22-year-old Lonon, of Fort Hood, Tex., defeated an aggressive Nolan Barclay of Honolulu, 5-0, in a 106-pound match at Memorial Auditorium. Lonon was one of five defending amateur champions who won bouts on the afternoon card. The others were Michael Bent, of Cambria Heights, Queens, in the 201-pound division; Michael Collins, of La Porte, Tex., 119 pounds; Anthony Hembrick, of Fort Bragg, N.C., 165 pounds, and Kenneth Gould, of Rockford, Ill., 147 pounds. (AP) Squash Talbott Wins Canadian Open: Top-seeded Mark Talbott defeated seventh-seeded Todd Binns Tuesday night in Toronto to capture the $60,000 Xerox Canadian Open, the richest event on the World Professional Squash Association tour. The scores were 15-12, 11-15, 15-10, 14-15, 18-14. In the women's final, top-ranked Alicia McConnell of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., defeated second-seeded Sue Cogswell of New York, 15-12, 15-8, 15-16, 15-10.

description: Natan Sharansky said today that the West should refrain from making concessions to the Soviet Union without assurances that all Jews who want to leave will be able to emigrate. He told 40 people who demonstrated in front of Parliament that 400,000 of the Soviet Union's 1.7 million Jews wanted to emigrate. Moscow has spoken of 10,000 Jews who would be allowed to leave.

title: AS NATION GRAYS, A MIGHTY ADVOCATE FLEXES ITS MUSCLES
description: ''We used to be a sleeping giant - big in numbers but sleeping like a hibernating bear,'' said Cyril F. Brickfield, the 68-year-old executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons. ''But now the bear is awake.'' Indeed, the nonprofit colossus, with its 24 million members and $5 membership fee, has adopted an active new stance in a time of prodigious expansion. In the last year alone, its membership increased by 3 million; almost 40 percent of the 61.8 million Americans over the age of 50 are members.

Taiwan to Reduce Debt
description: Taiwan, with $53 billion in foreign-exchange reserves, will reduce its foreign debt by about $1 billion this year, to $2.4 billion, Finance Minister Robert Chien said today. He told Parliament the country's debt, excluding private debt, stood at $3.41 billion at the end of last year, down from $4.77 billion in 1985. ''We have too much foreign exchange and do not need borrowings from other countries,'' Mr. Chien said. ''We now maintain a small amount of debt with foreign banks in order to keep our commercial relations with them.'' Taiwan has the world's third-largest foreign reserves, after West Germany and Japan.

title: RECITAL: BENITA VALENTA, SOPRANO
description: BENITA VALENTE first broke into public awareness in the 1960's when she sang ''Der Hirt auf dem Felsen'' on a Marlboro Festival recording that is out of print but would still be worth any Schubert lover's hunting down. Her voice was not big or extraordinarily colored but of such a spring-water purity that it perfectly matched the pastoral innocence of the music. For one listener, at least, the memory of that sound in that song has spoiled many a performance since by other fine sopranos.

title: Bethlehem Prices
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had raised the base prices of its carbon, high-strength and low-alloy plate steel by $25 a ton, or about 6.5 percent, effective July 1. The company said its composite prices for alloy plates would also increase by $25 a ton. The company does not publish its prices for those products. Bethlehem said the affected products represent about 8 percent of its sales. The increases follow a similar move by the USX Corporation, which recently increased prices on its plate products by 7.2 percent.

title: EVIDENCE FOUND LINKING JEWISH DEFENSE LEAGUE TO TERRORISM

title: Half a Bite
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach, lost more than a chance for the national title when the Rebels fell to Indiana in the semifinals last Saturday. It turns out that just 24 hours before the Indiana game, Taco Bell, the fast-food chain, signed Tarkanian to a deal in which he allowed the company to place 16 of its logos on the towel he habitually gnaws during play. Eight logos were printed onto either side of the towel, so that no matter which side was visible, it could be seen that Tarkanian was munching Taco Bell during the Final Four.

description: WHEN they need more storage space, homeowners and apartment dwellers often think the only solution is a larger home. But the problem can often be solved by making better use of existing space.

description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a medication to prevent heartworm in dogs that can be administered once a month, a spokeswoman said Tuesday.

title: HEIRLOOM TABLECLOTHS AND LINENS
description: UNTIL 1985, Suri Kops of Queens, above, was a lawyer and a dealer in turn-of-the-century linens from Europe. After the birth of her son, she turned exclusively to her linen business. ''I love these fabrics, because none are alike, but all have a bit of character and nostalgia,'' she said. ''They are romantic mementos of the past.''

title: Old-Timer Finishes
description: A crowd cheered 81-year-old Norman Vaughan as he drove his dog team down a wet, bare street in Nome, Alaska, early yesterday to complete the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race six days behind the final official finishers. Vaughan and his traveling companion, Carolyn Muegge of Marietta, Ga., competed unofficially after they were disqualified from the 1,157-mile race March 21 in Grayling for failing to reach Unalakleet within the required five days of the race leaders. The race, which began in Anchorage, was won by Susan Butcher March 18. A musher for more than a half-century, Vaughan drove a dog team during Adm. Richard E. Byrd's Antarctic expedition. He has entered the Iditarod race nine times, and it was suggested it might be time to retire from the event. He responded by saying he would drive dogs ''until I die.''

title: How Baker Gets Help From His Friends in Congress
description: When Senator Bob Packwood arrived at his Capitol Hill office this morning, he already had an urgent phone message. It was from Howard H. Baker Jr., his old friend and Senate colleague, and Mr. Packwood returned the call immediately.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Jets traded Kirk Springs, a safety and kick-return specialist, to the Indianapolis Colts for an undisclosed conditional draft pick in 1988. . . . Graig Nettles, who won a job with a spring power spree, signed a one-year contract with the Atlanta Braves. It calls for a base salary of $200,000 plus award bonuses and performance bonuses. . . . Pete Vuckovich, the American League's 1982 Cy Young Award winner, retired as a player at age 34 after struggling this spring with the Milwaukee Brewers. . . . Bill Caudill, the 30-year-old relief pitcher, was given his outright release by the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Six G.M. Plants To Close for Week
description: The General Motors Corporation, fighting slumping car sales and loss of market share, will close six plants for a week, temporarily idling 21,600 workers, officials said. The plants scheduled for closing April 6-13 are in Wentzville, Mo.; Pontiac, Flint and Hamtramck, Mich.; North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Oshawa, Ontario, a G.M. spokesman, Jim Smidebush, said.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an inventory writedown of about $550,000. c-Includes a gain of $56,000 from the purchase of the company's 9 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures at below face value, a gain of $229,000 from the sale of property and an inventory writedown of $550,000. d-Includes an inventory writedown of $275,000 and an increase of $208,000 for the allowance for doubtful accounts for the quarter and year.

title: Harrelson, Ross Named
description: Ken Harrelson, the former general manager of the Chicago White Sox, and Spencer Ross will be the broadcasters for the 100 Yankee games on SportsChannel this season, the cable company said yesterday. Mickey Mantle will join them for his annual stint of about 25 games, but gone are Bill White and Phil Rizzuto, who had broadcast games aired by both SportsChannel and WPIX-TV. White and Rizzuto will remain with WPIX, which will show only 40 Yankee games this year. The number of games shown by the two outlets, a reversal of the pattern of recent years, results from a court ruling over conflicting contracts the Yankees signed with SportsChannel and WPIX. ''This is our first year as the primary broadcaster of Yankee games and we wanted to establish our own identity,'' said Larry Wahl, a spokesman for SportsChannel, when asked why Rizzuto and White were dropped. Harrelson, who broadcast games for both the White Sox and Red Sox before moving to the front office, had a nine-year major-league playing career that ended in 1971. Ross has broadcast Yankee games for the last two years, for WPIX in 1985 and primarily on radio last year.

title: ARCHITECTURE: THE NEW MUSSEE D'ORSAY IN PARIS
description: Old buildings in Paris never die -they are converted into museums. From the Louvre, which began as a royal palace, to the grand town house that became the Picasso Museum, making a museum is the way Paris has traditionally given new life to great buildings that have outlived their original usefulness.

title: A SUSPENDED JUDGE PLEADS GUILTY TO RACKETEERING IN REALTY WORK
description: A suspended Civil Court judge pleaded guilty yesterday to racketeering charges and agreed to forfeit $150,000 in illegal proceeds.

The company said the writedown of Genex's L-Phenylalanine manufacturing plant and estimated costs related to its disposal accounted for about half of the net loss for 1985. The company also said that in light of its new business focus, it reduced the capitalized value of its patents by $900,000. This charge is included in the company's total writedowns of $8.5 million for 1986.

title: 'COLETTE,' A FOUR-PART SERIES ON 13
description: OVER the next several weeks, WNET will be offering what it calls a ''Vive la France!'' series, another of its thematic programming packages. There is a Thursday series of profiles, beginning tonight at 10 with ''Max Linder: The Man in the Silk Hat,'' about Max Linder, a comedian and film maker who was an influence on Charlie Chaplin. The series continues in subsequent weeks with essays on Nadia Boulanger and Maurice Chevalier. The Saturday series ''Film on Film'' will focus on such screen figures as Jean Renoir, Georges Melies, Jean-Louis Barrault and Jean Gabin.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 2, 1987
description: Companies Three major banks will reclassify loans to Brazil. BankAmerica, J. P. Morgan and Manufacturers said they would account for the loans when interest payments are received, rather than on an accrual basis. The actions came six weeks after Brazil stopped interest payments on the debt. The move will cost BankAmerica $40 million in first-quarter net income, while Morgan will lose $20 million and Manufacturers $18 million. Talks with Brazil begin next week, and the banks predicted an accord. [ Page D1. ] Topps plans to go public again, three years after going private. The baseball card and bubble gum concern intends to sell 4.5 million shares, or a 31 percent stake, for $15 to $18 a share, giving its current owners a paper profit of more than $140 million. [ D5. ] Revlon's dominant stockholder began a $721.5 million bid to acquire the rest of the cosmetics giant. [ D5. ] Wharton Econometrics and Chase Econometrics will merge, in the latest consolidation in a troubled industry. The two respected forecasters did not disclose terms of the deal. [ D24. ] Delta Air Lines completed its merger with Western and told most of its new employees they had lost union representation. [ D6. ] The Economy The rise in the prime rate has stirred fears that interest rates have bottomed out and are edging higher. If this is the case, economists agree, borrowers can expect to pay more for everything from factory equipment to home furnishings. [ D1. ] Lee M. Henkel Jr. quit the Federal Home Loan Bank Board amid accusations that he may have violated Federal laws. In his resignation statement he noted that two official reviews had exonerated him. [ D1. ] The U.S. and Japan will consult on a computer chip dispute, but Washington is unlikely to call off the trade sanctions it has announced, American officials said. [ D24. ] The House Banking Committee voted to raise $5 billion over two years to help the ailing F.S.L.I.C. [ D2. ] Construction spending rose 1 percent in February, but analysts still expect outlays to be weaker this year. [ D10. ] The Senate failed to override the President's veto of a $89.6 million highway bill, but the Democratic leadership moved immediately to force a second vote. [ A1. ] NASA hopes to replace the current shuttle rockets by the mid-1990's and is asking manufacturers to develop engineering plans for an ''advanced'' solid-fuel booster rocket. [ A20. ] Markets The surging stock market produced some notable losers in the first quarter, including a ''trufflet'' manufacturer and a company that dismissed a third of its board. Meanwhile, offshore drillers, metals and mining concerns and home builders stood out among the big winners. [ D1. ] Aided by steady, low interest rates, underwriting of corporate stock and bond issues soared in the first quarter to a record volume of $87.7 billion. [ D1. ] Treasury bill rates fell sharply, in response to heavy buying by foreign central banks and the late afternoon announcement about bank actions on Brazilian loans. [ D25. ] Yields on C.D.'s and money market mutual funds rose slightly, while bank money market accounts slipped a notch in the recent week. [ D19. ] Stock prices ended mixed after falling in early trading. After the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen by about 25 points, a spurt of buying by bargain hunters lifted the blue-chip index to 2,316.05, for an 11.36-point gain. [ D12. ] The dollar rose as foreign exchange markets continued to react favorably to the higher prime rate. [ D22. ] Silver and platinum futures advanced as more banks lifted their prime rates. But gold futures closed unchanged. [ D22. ] Today's Columns Boxing's largest guaranteed purse in history will go to Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Sugar Ray Leonard. Next Monday's middleweight fight will probably bring record theater TV revenues, too. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] A host of special-situation stocks merit a closer look, some portfolio managers contend. Despite the market's torrid first quarter, they expect the profits and prices of selected issues to appreciate further in the next three months. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: Senators Warn Bonn On Trading of Suspect

title: SALADS AND COOKING GREENS: NEW SEEDS FOR '87 PLANTINGS
description: A CHILD of my time and place, born in Dallas at the height of the Great Depression, I spent my first 20 years in abysmal ignorance as regards leafy vegetables. Lettuce meant one thing only: tight heads of iceberg lettuce, raised in California, bought at the grocery store and kept in a drawer of the refrigerator until put into a salad whose flavor owed everything to its dressing and nothing to the lettuce. My salad days were impoverished, though I didn't know it at the time.

description: Leftist guerrillas thoroughly infiltrated a major army base before destroying it Tuesday, according to two senior military analysts here. They added that the American military adviser who was killed in the raid had probably been sought out by the rebels.

The businesses will be operated as a joint venture of CPC and Ajinomoto.

For one thing, they entertain, and whether through God or their own personnas, they comfort and inspire.

title: Gooden's Troubles
description: Dec. 27, 1985 - In an incident that is not revealed until a year later, sheriff's deputies in Tampa, Fla., acting on what they described as a tip from a confidential informant that Gooden is carrying ''a large quantity of cocaine and drugs,'' trails his car for six hours and then stops him. After he agrees to allow the deputies to search his car, with the assistance of drug-sniffing dogs, they report finding $4,000 in cash, a holstered pistol, several empty and half-empty beer cans and some baking soda - but no drugs.

title: Q&A
description: Q.We don't like the color of the newly renovated cabinets and counter tops in the kitchen and bath of our co-op. Since they are new, it is senseless to replace them. Can we paint them another color? A.You can paint them with any good quality alkyd enamel, but once painted they will have to be repainted regularly. Also, no paint will hold up for long on counter tops if you cut or scratch the surface when preparing food, or if you scrub with abrasive cleaners. If you do paint, make sure the surfaces are perfectly clean.Lightly sand all surfaces thoroughly to give the slick surface some ''tooth'' so the paint will bond better. Q.When I had my house treated for termites the exterminators drilled holes in the concrete floor of the basement to inject chlordane into the soil. They filled the holes with half-inch-thick plugs of cement and sand, but after the first heavy rain the plugs were loose and the basement was full of water. The exterminators then packed the holes with tightly rolled plastic, driving it down three or four inches; they poured in volcanic ash and again plugged the final half inch with cement and sand. But the plugs still work loose and leak. What should have been done? A.It sounds as if the holes were never properly patched or filled. Instead of using half-inch cement plugs, the holes should be filled with poured concrete that is at least as deep as the thickness of the concrete floor (usually four inches). A latex binder should be added to the new concrete to assure a solid bond between the new and the old. Q.Eight years ago I had front steps built outside my house, made with brick risers and limestone treads that are two inches thick. All four treads have developed hairline cracks and I am afraid freezing and thawing will cause them to widen. Is there a filler that I can use that will not be unsightly? A.Chances are that any patching material or filler will be visible, but how visible is hard to tell. You can experiment in one corner with a white patching cement or with a white epoxy cement to see if the patch is objectionable. Remember, however, that hairline cracks are almost impossible to fill without first cutting them out wider; this, of course, will make the patches even more noticeable. You may be able to fill them with a brush-on epoxy coating in clear or white, but test this in a corner, also. Questions about home repair problems should be addressed to Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: A MANHATTAN NURSING HOME FACES CUTOFF OF FUNDS
description: Federal officials took steps yesterday to terminate Medicaid and Medicare payments to one of the largest profit-making nursing homes in New York City as a result of repeated instances of inadequate nursing care and poor patient treatment.

title: Awaiting Perle's Man
description: For several years Frank J. Gaffney Jr. has been known as a protege of Richard N. Perle, the hard-charging and outspoken Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy. Now the 33-year old Mr. Gaffney is in line to succeed Mr. Perle, who is leaving the Reagan Administration later this spring to write a novel and join the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative-leaning research group in the capital.

title: Cardinals Get Pena
description: The St. Louis Cardinals added the considerable talents of Tony Pena, the four-time all-star catcher, to their lineup yesterday in a trade with the Pittsburgh Pirates. The Cardinals had to give up two first-string players, Andy Van Slyke and Mike LaValliere, as well as a minor leaguer. Pena, 29 years old, batted .288 with 10 home runs and 52 runs batted in last season. He has a career .286 average with 63 homers and 340 r.b.i., and he won Gold Glove awards in 1983, 1984 and 1985. He is in the last year of his contract. Van Slyke, a 26-year-old outfielder, had his finest season in 1986, when he hit .270 with 13 homers, 61 r.b.i. and 21 stolen bases in 137 games for the Cardinals. LaValliere, also 26, opened the 1986 season as the Cardinals' backup catcher but won the job by midseason. He finished his rookie season batting .234 with 3 homers and 30 runs batted in. LaValliere will split the catching duties with Junior Ortiz in Pittsburgh. The Cardinals also gave up Mike Dunne, a minor-league pitcher.

It had the scale and cast of a Cecil B. De Mille production.

''My reaction,'' said Michael Trainer, Leonard's lawyer, ''was that it might be nice if we all sat and talked.''

The move is part of a restructuring announced by Allis-Chalmers March 4. Allis-Chalmers, which is based in Milwaukee, said it did not expect any material gain or loss from the sale of the division, which employs 4,300.

title: LEG INJURIES LINKED TO HARDER SURFACES
description: Tennis traditionalists may be disappointed as indoor carpets and outdoor cement become increasingly popular surfaces, replacing grass and red clay. But the impact of these synthetic courts on the sport go beyond esthetics and tradition. There are indications that they are responsible for an increasing number of leg injuries, which could deprive tournaments of some of the bigger names in tennis for weeks and months at a time.

title: Jawboning Justice

Charles Fried, the Solicitor General of the United States, finds this remark ''deeply troubling.''

title: RHODEN PLEASED WITH PROGRESS

In the relative quiet of the Yankees' spring camp, their single greatest concern - the strained muscle in Rick Rhoden's left side - appears to have subsided.

title: Aid Pledged for Mozambique
description: United Nations members and voluntary agencies pledged $207 million in emergency aid for Mozambique at a conference in Geneva on Wednesday, officials said today. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar began an appeal for more than $244 million in food and medical aid last month. Mozambique officials say the country is continuing to suffer from starvation caused by a prolonged drought.

title: Making Carriers Unsinkable
description: The Navy's campaign to win approval for two new aircraft carriers is marked by tactical cunning and sharp strategic insight. Against formidable odds, the admirals' assault plan stands a fighting chance of immobilizing all potential opposition in Congress. Were the same ingenuity applied to weapons design, the Russians would surely quit the high seas in despair.

title: Metro Matters; New York City On $13 a Day: A Welfare Tale
description: There are no curtains on the windows of Barbara Jiggett's 20th-floor apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens. There are no lights in the bedroom shared by her 7- and 8-year-old daughters and only one in the living room where Ms. Jiggett sleeps (her 4-year-old son has the other bedroom). She has a television set and a terrace but no phone and only three kitchen chairs, which makes it difficult to join her three children at the table for meals.

title: Rules, Roles And Court Time

To ProServ and the International Management Group, which represent a number of big-name players on the tour, it's a threat to financial well-being. Given such incompatible views, the matter would seem to be headed to court. In this case, however, the two sides have rushed things a bit. They had already filed lawsuits against each other well before the council took its latest action.

title: Jonsson Rejoins Team
description: Tomas Jonsson, the Islander defenseman who suffered a multiple fracture of the jaw in a car accident in Detroit Jan. 22, received medical clearance to rejoin the team yesterday. Jonsson, who practiced Wednesday afternoon for only the second time since the accident, said his conditioning was acceptable but his timing was off. With just three regular-season games remaining and with Denis Potvin being used cautiously after his return Tuesday from a 17-game absence, the Islanders were undecided whether to use Jonsson tonight against Quebec.

title: Now Mets Know About Gooden
description: For nearly a year, the Mets had wondered about Dwight Gooden, wondered why he wasn't quite the same Doctor K who at age 20 had dazzled baseball with a 24-4 record, a 1.53 earned-run average and 268 strikeouts two seasons ago. Ever since he was shelled early in spring training, the Mets had wondered about his stride and his motion, even about his grip on the ball. But now the Mets know that it's a matter of his grip on himself.

title: Border War
description: Speaking of Bobby Knight, so is Jerry Abramson, the Mayor of Louisville, Ky. Before the Louisville Cardinals met Duke for the N.C.A.A. title in Dallas last year, Abramson ran into the Indiana coach and noticed that Knight, a close friend of Coach Mike Krzyzewski of Duke, was sporting a Duke button. Abramson told Knight that he was a graduate of I.U. and that, seeing as how they were neighbors and all, it would be nice if Knight were wearing a Louisville button instead. Knight ignored him. As soon as Louisville had won the title and the Mayor was back home, he had 20 large signs made declaring the city to be the home of the national champions. Mindful of the incident with Knight, he made sure that the first sign went up on the Second Street Bridge spanning the Ohio River and that it faced toward nearby Jeffersonville, Ind.

title: OPERA: 'BORIS GODUNOV'
description: Paata Burchuladze, a young bass from Soviet Georgia, has attracted enormous attention for his few appearances in the West, principally at La Scala in Milan. So his United States operatic debut Monday night with the Opera Company of Philadelphia in the title role of ''Boris Godunov'' naturally attracted visitors from outside the Philadelphia area.

title: K X'd for J Day
description: News of Dwight Gooden's troubles came just as the Knicks were preparing to send out some promotional material about their Dr. J Day next Monday, when Julius Erving of the Philadelphia 76ers will be playing his final game in New York. As part of the tribute, the Knicks had already invited a number of well-known ''doctors'' to the game, and the one-page reminder to the news media that they distributed yesterday bore photographs of nine of the special guests, including Joyce Brothers, Frank Field, Ruth Westheimer and, in the very center of the three-doctor-by-three-doctor arrangement, a smiling Dr. K. Assuming that Gooden's rehabilitation would force him to miss the game, and trying to spare him further embarrassment without actually scrapping the mailing, the Knicks came up with a resourceful solution. They carefully covered Gooden's face with a sticker depicting their logo.
