description: A key House panel has voted to eliminate most funds for the Air Force's anti-satellite weapon and to cut sharply the funds sought by the Pentagon for President Reagan's plan to develop a system to shoot down attacking missiles.

title: CONGRESS GETS REPORT ON ISRAELI MILITARY AID TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: In a report to Congress, the State Department said today that Israel had provided military aid to South Africa in violation of an international embargo.

title: LAXALT EXPLORES PRESIDENTIAL BID AS RUMSFELD DECIDES NOT TO RUN
description: The Republican Presidential landscape for 1988 was altered again today as former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada prepared to form an committee to look into whether he should run and Donald Rumsfeld announced that he would not be a candidate.

title: China Opens Fifth Market
description: China opened a fifth securities market this week, but expansion of stock trading is now being given a low priority because it is too ideologically sensitive, according to various officials and Chinese newspapers.

title: RAUCOUS ROCKERS ADD A MESSAGE
description: ''THE traditional text of rock lyrics is adolescent love, period,'' said Robert Sietsema of the New York rock band Mofungo. ''We're not adolescents anymore, and we're not so interested in adolescent love, either. We read the paper and watch the news and when we get together to rehearse, we often start by discussing something we've read or seen. And frequently that gives rise to a song.''

title: N.Y.U. Names Director Of Humanities Institute
description: A. Richard Turner has been named director of the New York Institute for the Humanities at New York University. An authority on Italian Renaissance painting, Mr. Turner, a former president of Grinnell College, was most recently the dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science at N.Y.U.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 3, 1987
description: International A3-8 Andrei D. Sakharov's strong support of the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev has caused some disillusionent among Soviet dissidents who had viewed him as a hero of almost mythical proportions. Page A1

title: McAdoo Is Star In Europe Final
description: Bob McAdoo, former National Basketball Association scoring champion, scored 15 of his 21 points in the second half today as Tracer Milan won the European Champions Cup by edging Maccabi Tel Aviv of Israel, 71-69, in the final.

title: 2 at Symphony Space
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will present a double bill containing new productions of ''Trial by Jury'' and ''The Sorcerer'' tonight at 8, Saturday at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. Tickets are $15 to $25; information: 864-5400.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 14
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,123,000. c-Net loss

title: BITTER DEMOTION FOR MEACHAM
description: Bobby Meacham sat alone in front of his dressing stall today, tears welling and the thought of another demotion to the minor leagues sitting uneasily in his mind. A teammate, Dennis Rasmussen, came by to console him, but the hurt was too deep. Meacham had performed capably enough to win a job with the Yankees in their spring camp, yet he will not make the trip to Detroit Saturday afternoon for next the opener Monday.

title: Dollar Falls Versus Yen After Yeutter Remark
description: An apparently innocuous statement by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, helped send the dollar lower against the yen in foreign-exchange trading today.

title: YOGI'S PITCH
description: Yogi Berra, in a forthcoming television commercial for Miller Lite: ''It's got a third less calories than I probably thought it didn't have, and it's less filling than it would have been if it was more filling than they didn't want it to be.''

title: FRANCE AND U.S. AIDING CHADIANS WITH INTELLIGENCE TO ROUT LIBYANS
description: Intelligence information provided by the United States and France is helping the Chadian Army in its successful campaign against Libyan forces in the northern part of the country, according to senior Chadian officials in Ndjamena, the capital.

title: G.I. AND BRIDE GET SOVIET ASYLUM
description: The Soviet Union announced today that an American soldier and his West German wife had been granted asylum.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''LETHAL WEAPON,'' the story of two Los Angeles policemen who try to break open a drug-smuggling ring, is a runaway hit. By the end of last weekend, the film, which opened on March 6, had grossed nearly $33.6 million, and had been No. 1 in the country for three weeks in a row. What's more, it actually did better in its second weekend than its first, grossing $7.1 million from 1,256 theaters the second weekend after grossing $6.8 million from the same number of theaters in the first. In an industry where each success breeds numerous imitators out to capture the same golden goose, people are wondering what happened.

title: 2 CHARGED IN CHICAGO STILL SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: If Alderman Wallace Davis Jr. wins re-election here Tuesday, supporters of the West Side officeholder will have to celebrate without him. Mr. Davis is in jail. And Clifford P. Kelley, a South Side Alderman seeking another term on the City Council, awaits a verdict from the courts as well as from the voters.

title: 'THE BABY BUSINESS'
description: THINK of the case of Baby M and recent pronouncements by the Vatican. ''The Baby Business,'' on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tomorrow night, is right on top of the news. The NBC program examimes biomedical advances, private adoptions and the moral and legal problems of surrogate motherhood. It is a thoughtful piece of work.

title: KOCH IS CRITICAL OF DINKINS PLAN FOR APARTMENTS
description: A recent proposal from the Manhattan Borough President, calling for a vast expansion in the number of apartments the city rehabilitates for the homeless, ''makes no sense,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: WATER SUPPLIERS ARE HELD LIABLE OVER HYDRANTS
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that water companies could be sued for failing to provide adequate water pressure for fighting fires.

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months' results include a charge of $3,470,000 for the discontinuance of certain products and the relocation of certain facilities.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 3, 1987
description: Companies

title: AIDS SPECTER FOR WOMEN: THE BISEXUAL MAN
description: Seven years ago a Miami office worker had an affair with a bisexual man. She recalls that his confusion about sexual orientation was one of the things that made her feel tender toward him.

title: 13 REFUSE TO SHIFT
description: The Senate, with not a vote to spare, overrode President Reagan's veto of the highway bill today despite an extraordinary personal appeal by the President at the Capitol.

title: HART SEEKING PEACE WITH HIS PAST
description: Gary Hart came home and, for a moment, he did not live up to his reputation. He nearly cried. Hours after he placed flowers at his parents' grave, Mr. Hart, known for his cool intellectualism, tried to tell an audience at Ottawa University here about his father Carl and his mother Nina.

title: ENS BIO LOGICALS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company did not provide year- ago share earnings because of an amalgamation with the Rose Group, which was a limited partnership. Because of the amalgamation Sept. 26, the results include the Rose Group for the 12 months and the biotechnology and telecommunications operations of Bio Logicals for the period from Sept. 26. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Why TV News Is So Expensive
description: As a reporter who has covered business for 32 years - the last 12 for ABC News - I am nonplussed by the rhetoric being used to describe the current wave of firings and budget cuts at network news divisions.

title: RIVALS SAY MACHINES ARE NO 'CLONE KILLERS'
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's competitors in the personal computer industry, who had been bracing for the worst, breathed a slight sigh of relief today.

title: BRAZIL SEEKING $20 BILLION IN NEW CREDITS BY 1992
description: Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, said today that the Government hopes to raise $20 billion in new foreign credits over the next five years despite its suspension of some interest payments to banks.

title: DAVIES SETS PACE WITH A 66
description: Four days after Sandy Lyle of Surrey, England, won the $1 million Tournament Players Championship on the men's PGA Tour, another young golfer from Surrey, Laura Davies, became the surprise first-round leader in the $500,000 L.P.G.A. Nabisco Dinah Shore event. Davies, a 23-year-old, 5-foot-10-inch player who hits as long a ball as anyone on the L.P.G.A. Tour, shot a six-under-par 66 at the Mission Hills course. Amy Alcott and Betsy King were two strokes behind, and Val Skinner was another shot back. Pat Bradley, last year's winner, trailed by six strokes after posting a par 72.

title: AUCTIONS
description: FLORA WHITNEY MILLER chose art and furniture that expressed fantasy and wit for her duplex at 10 Gracie Square and her porticoed mansion in Old Westbury, L.I., her daughter, Flora Miller Biddle, recalled this week. The offbeat artworks and antiques that Mrs. Miller collected along with the more sedate French 18th-century furniture she inherited from her mother, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, are included in sales of the contents of these homes that will be held at Sotheby's New York galleries over the next two months.

title: AMERICAN LINKED TO POLLARD CASE REPORTS WORK FOR ISRAELI MILITARY
description: An American lawyer who has been linked to the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case said today that he had been a legal adviser to the Israeli Defense Ministry and that Israel had refused to allow him to be questioned in the United States.

title: What the Mets Will Miss
description: The major leagues' biggest winners in the three seasons since Dwight Gooden broke in:

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic, under the direction of Lukas Foss, will play the New York premiere performances of Oliver Knussen's ''Music for a Puppet Court'' tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 2 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The program will also include Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto, played by Elmar Oliveira, and Symphony No. 2 by Johannes Brahms. The academy is at 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section. Tickets are $10 to $20; information: (718) 636-4120.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE rain splattering the windowpanes added some notes Handel never wrote, but the New York Harp Ensemble played on and Eva Marton lifted her glorious voice above it all at Monday night's musicale in Jenifer and George Lang's West Side apartment. Then the guests - who included Marion and Elie Wiesel, Renate Ponsold and Robert Motherwell, Dietlinde and Lorin Maazel, Shirley and Milton Glaser, Peter Jennings, Tom Margittai and Vera Stern - trooped in the rain to the Cafe des Artistes for a dinner celebrating the restaurant's 70th anniversary.

title: TOUR GUIDES LEAD URBAN SAFARIS THROUGH CITY'S PAST AND PRESENT
description: THE walking season is suddenly upon us, and all roads lead to the biggest show in town: New York City itself. Walking tours of the city - which have become a year-round institution, with determined strollers slogging through the slushiest streets - are suddenly in full bloom. There are more than a half dozen of them scheduled this weekend alone and the pace will continue through early autumn.

title: CONVEST ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter loss was due primarily to a writedown of $12,087,000 on the partnership's oil and gas properties since the net capitalized cost at Dec. 31, 1986 exceeded the present value of estimated future net revenue. Total writedowns for the year totaled $18,970,000.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE 21-year-old Sal Anthony's is one of those durable neighborhood institutions that have survived by cosseting a core of regulars, the type of customers who dismiss the menu with a wave and ask for ''the usual.'' Watching all the cheek-pecking and bear-hugging there one evening, I felt like an intruder at an exclusive private club. Although the food and service I experienced on three recent visits merit one star, it is clear that members of the inner circle get something extra in the ambiance that keeps them coming back.

title: BRUCE, ROBERT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: MULRONEY SEES U.S. TRADE PACT
description: After months of uncertainty and tension, Canada and the United States are within reach of a ''historic'' trade agreement that would eliminate most tariff and non-tariff barriers between the two nations over 10 to 15 years, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has concluded.

title: Hoffman Released
description: Glenn Hoffman, a seven-year veteran who missed most of the 1986 season with a cardiac problem, was cut by the Boston Red Sox yesterday in what Manager John McNamara called ''one of the toughest decisions I've ever had to make.'' Hoffman, who was Boston's regular shortstop before his illness, Kevin Romine, an outfielder, and five rookies were cut as the Red Sox got down to 25 players. The roster includes Roger Clemens, the American League Cy Young and Most Valuable Player Award winner, who will be suspended if he doesn't return before the 1987 American League opener Monday in Milwaukee.

title: Senate Panel to Force Secord Clerks to Testify
description: The Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra arms case voted today to compel the testimony of two clerical employees of Richard V. Secord, a principal figure in the affair, by giving them limited immunity from prosecution.

title: ORATORIO MERGES CHRIST AND BUDDHA
description: For Somei Satoh, the universe ''is a very small thing.''

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC AND KRYSTIAN ZIMERMAN
description: IN several appearances since his New York debut in 1978, the Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman has proved himself a substantial artist whose formidable technique is enlisted in the service of a sensitive musical mind. His performance of the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 last evening with the New York Philharmonic, under the baton of his countryman Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, brought both aspects of his talent into clear focus.

title: E.P.A. ASKS RULES TO PREVENT LEAKS IN UNDERGROUND TANKS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed new rules to prevent leaks from underground storage tanks, half of which are used to store gasoline.

title: SEWER ACCORDS ADVANCE PROJECTS IN TWO SUBURBS
description: So many new homes are being built in suburban areas near New York City that many municipalities are finding they are unable to keep up with the added demand put on their waste treatment facilities and sewage systems.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Denny Crum, the coach of the United States Pan American Games basketball team, has chosen Jud Heathcote of Michigan State and his own assistant coach at Louisville, Jerry Jones, as assistant coaches of this year's squad. Crum also said that 48 players would be invited for tryouts for the team May 14-18 at Colorado Springs from which 12 players and 3 alternates will be chosen. . . . Jeff Calhoun, a left-handed pitcher, was traded by the Houston Astros to the Philadelphia Phillies for Ronn Reynolds, a catcher formerly with the Mets.

title: 'I WILL FIGHT TO THE END,' BABY M'S MOTHER VOWS
description: Mary Beth Whitehead vowed today to fight to overturn the court ruling that ended her maternal rights to Melissa Stern, the 1-year-old girl at the center of the Baby M custody fight.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's 380 money market mutual funds decreased $832.5 million, to $235.4 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $341.4 million, to $65.17 billion. Assets of the 197 general purpose funds were up $1.1 billion, to $63.21 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds fell $1.59 billion, to $107.02 billion.

title: DEMOCRATIC, BUT DOWNCAST: CAN THIS BE BRAZIL?
description: Fed by economic uncertainty and political confusion, a deep mood of pessimism appears to be taking hold of Brazil barely two years after the country emerged from more than two decades of military rule.

title: Advertising; M*A*S*H Reunion For I.B.M.
description: AS you all know by now if you watched the evening news, ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Family Ties'' or ''Cheers'' last night, most of the M*A*S*H team has re-enlisted under the I.B.M. banner.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $499,754 and $825,673 for the quarter and year, respectively; and tax credits of $243,489 for the quarter and $1,113,168 for the year. c-Includes realized investment gains of $987,774 for the quarter and $998,405 for the year; and tax credits of $29,012 and $365,249 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: RESERVING A PAIR OF SEATS BEHIND THE TV CAMERAS
description: ON the far reaches of West 57th Street, a line snakes into the Unitel Video studio. Once inside, the people clamber to their seats, arced around a tiny stage that looks like a cross between a doctor's office and a living room. Cameramen mill about as first the stage manager, then the producer and finally the co-host warm up the audience with the sort of banter that can be heard only in that province of videoland known as studio-audience television. Batteries of moonlike lights go on, the applause signs flicker and out comes Dr. Ruth Westheimer, the sex therapist of the airwaves.

title: Hagler Loses Again in Court on Title
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler suffered his second legal setback of the week when a Federal appeals court today refused to stop the World Boxing Association from stripping him of its middleweight crown.

title: L.I. Man Wins Delay Of Deportation Order
description: A Long Island man facing deportation to the Soviet Union as a war criminal, won a delay yesterday until at least Monday so that his lawyers could go to the United States Supreme Court.

title: THATCHER'S VISIT: GLASNOST IN ACTION?
description: Midway through her visit here, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher could not resist recalling the sense of discovery she felt two years ago when she became one of the first Western leaders to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a man then stepping onto the world stage.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $3,781,000 for the latest year and $2,177,000 for 1985, both from discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Reports on Tuesday of a New York Times/CBS News Poll on evangelical ministers and television programs misstated the number of people interviewed. The total was 1,392, not 1,394, and those who said they never watched evangelical ministers totaled 887, not 889. In the accompanying article about Presidential preferences based on the same poll, percentages were misstated for Senator Albert Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt. They were the choice of 2 percent of Democratic primary voters, not 1 percent.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $301,000 loss related to the company's discontinued single- family housing division for both the quarter and year. c-Includes losses of $3,426,000 and $5,503,244 for the quarter and year, respectively, related to the discontinued single-family housing division; the $5,503,244 loss is net of a $1.4 million tax benefit. The results for the year-ago quarter also include an extraordinary charge of $1,579,000 from the reversal of tax credits in earlier quarters as a result of the company's net loss for the year.

title: Dow Rises 4.40 in a Wary Market
description: Stock prices rose only marginally yesterday, stymied by continuing concern over the course of interest rates and inflation.

title: FILM: 'CLUB LIFE'
description: ''CLUB LIFE'' may well be the only film ever to set a funeral scene inside a disco, with mourners lined up along the railings, and the coffin and floral arrangements set up on the lighted dance floor. So it's original, anyhow. It also includes a gangland murder shot in a hall of mirrors, and a love scene shot on a transparent waterbed filled with fish.

title: ANTIQUARIAN TREASURES FOR THE BIBLIOMANIAC
description: BIBLIOMANIA is a mental and emotional disorder that is chronic, progressive, incurable and entirely benign. Those suffering from this delightful affliction, which may or may not cost a bundle to treat, are urged to seek emergency relief at the New York Antiquarian Book Fair. It opened last night and the rare-book dealers on duty will administer first aid to all bibliomaniacs through tomorrow.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $6,693,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in some copies yesterday about the indictment of former Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx carried an incorrect quotation from Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan. Speaking about corruption, he said, ''It is going to take more than the one or two convictions that have taken place so far to change these people and the way they operate.''

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sonny Rollins, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Encounters with Sonny Rollins, the reigning master of the tenor saxophone, can be positively transcendent. They can also be frustrating, because Mr. Rollins is one of those rare improvisers who play directly on the inspiration of the moment, and don't keep a ready fund of cliches handy for times when inspiration is in short supply. This makes going to see the man something of an adventure, but there are certain things one can count on - the man's huge, warm sound and unique ability to mix, match and deconstruct obscure pop tunes and standards, for example. Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 tonight and tomorrow night; admission is $11.

title: Rockport Shoe Fan Mail Is Basis of Campaign
description: It's hard to believe, but apparently a shoe company can get fan mail from happy wearers.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADNG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $78,000 from reversal of tax credit for the quarter; and a tax credit of $315,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $145,000 and $585,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: LOSS SEEN BY MELLON; PAYOUT CUT
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh said yesterday that it would report a first-quarter loss of between $55 million and $65 million, news that sent its stock plunging.

title: JEM RECORDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LILLY SELLING ITS COSMETIC UNIT
description: Cosmetics are glamorous, but not necessarily on Wall Street.

title: F.A.A. BARS USE OF DRUG-TESTING LAB
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today barred its own medical institute from conducting alcohol and drug tests after aviation accidents. It said it had asked the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology to conduct a ''thorough and independent assessment'' of the F.A.A. institute's procedures.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A LIFE IN MOVIES: An Autobiography. By Michael Powell. 705 pages. Alfred

title: AIDS Prisoners Should Be Incarcerated for Their Full Sentences; Don't Punish for Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: CASEY SAID TO HAVE FAILED TO FOLLOW ARMS RULE
description: William J. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence, promised in writing in June 1986 to notify the Senate Intelligence Committee of any secret United States arms sales, but failed to tell it about the clandestine weapons sales to Iran then under way, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has disclosed.

title: Mars, Certainly, but Not in One Giant Step
description: To the Editor:

title: TELESCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $122,900 for the quarter and year, and tax credits of $453,000 and $494,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest year loss includes restructuring charges of $5,078,199.

title: Clifford Jackson Dead at 71; Singer and Dramatic Coach
description: Clifford Jackson, a baritone and coach, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,676,527 on the termination of a pension plan for the quarter and year, an investment gain of $96,157 and an investment loss of $202,787 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $362,500 for the quarter and a gain of $2,187,500 for the year on the sales of a reinsurance unit, a loss of $149,396 and a gain of $333,858 for the quarter and year, respectively, on the sales of a LIFE unit, and investment gain of $7,239 for the quarter and investment loss of $353,918 for the year.

title: The U.N. Today: April 3, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: REACTOR CLOSING SHOWS INDUSTRY'S PEOPLE PROBLEM
description: The Federal shutdown of the Peach Bottom Atomic Power Station here illustrates a mounting problem for the nuclear power industry: the people who work in the plants are often less reliable than the technology.

title: PINOCHET FOES CHEERED BY THE POPE'S PRESENCE
description: As Pope John Paul II delivered a homily in the Metropolitan Cathedral shortly after his arrival here Wednesday, student protesters were assembling outside.

title: Moody's Lowers Chemical Ratings
description: The Chemical New York Corporation's debt ratings were reduced yesterday by Moody's, shortly before the bank holding company announced that it was no longer accruing interest on more than $1 billion of loans to Brazil.

title: SAKHAROV'S PRO-GORBACHEV STAND: ATTACKED, HE STANDS HIS GROUND
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, by vigorously supporting Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has caused some disillusionment among dissidents who once regarded him as a hero of almost mythical size.

title: LONG-DELAYED TIMES SQUARE PLAN IS TAKING MORE NEW TWISTS
description: Faced with the possible collapse of the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project, New York City and state officials have renegotiated one portion of the plan and have opened new talks with developers in an effort to save the others.

title: PROGRESSIVE SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year reflects an increase of $5,060,406 in the association's reserves for estimated losses on real estate owned and certain loan instruments. In the prior year, the company decreased its reserves for losses by $215,158.

title: Bilzerian Seeks Pay N Pak
description: The investor Paul A. Bilzerian, seeking to take over the Pay N Pak Stores hardware chain, offered to buy all shares that he does not control for $19 each, or about $171 million.

title: REPUBLICANS GOT A PERSONAL PLEA
description: For many, it was one of the most difficult and distressing moments of their political lives, a moment when their loyalty and affection for their President clashed directly with the economic interests of their home states and their own political fortunes.

title: 2 SHOWS IN FOX PRIME-TIME DEBUT
description: WITH young (under 30) top executives and a budget of $150 million in place, Fox Broadcasting Company is taking its first wobbly steps this Sunday toward what its hopes will be a fourth commercial network in prime time. Two half-hour series are being unveiled: ''Married. . . With Children'' at 7 P.M., and ''The Tracey Ullman Show'' at 7:30. In an unusual programming ploy, repeats of the entire hour will be offered at 8 and 9 P.M. In short, if you go anywhere near Channel 5 that evening, you are going to see these shows whether you like it or not.

title: Lloyd Divorce Sought
description: Citing irreconcilable differences, Chris Evert Lloyd has filed for divorce from John Lloyd, a tennis professional and her husband since April 17, 1979. Their marriage in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was heralded by a sign saying: ''Love Match: Chris Evert and John Lloyd, A Perfect Set.'' Papers for the divorce were filed in Broward County, Florida. Chris Lloyd is ranked third in the world behind Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf, and her husband, once No. 1 in Britain, is ranked 426th. The two were separated for the second time late last year.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Turning Highway Pork Into the Alamo
description: It was a mistake for President Reagan to veto the highway bill - and a bigger one to insist that his Presidency depended on Congress's sustaining the veto. Yesterday, the Senate joined the House in overriding, hanging Presidential prestige out to dry.

title: It'll Be a Cold Day In August
description: For a record-breaking marathon swimmer who has conquered the 31-mile-wide English Channel and once spent 12 1/2 hours covering the 20 miles across the Cook Strait of New Zealand, Lynne Cox wouldn't seem much challenged by a piddling couple of miles. But the 2.7-mile island-to-island course she has set for herself this August is across the Bering Strait between Alaska and the Soviet Union, and if the 30-year-old Californian makes it, she'll be the only person known to have done so, for a good reason: At its warmest, the Strait's water temperature is between 34 and 39 degrees, far colder than Cox or anyone else has been willing to endure for the two hours or so she expects the swim to take.

title: REAGAN VETOES: 8 HAVE FAILED
description: President Reagan has now been defeated by Congress eight times on legislation he vetoed. These measures became law after Mr. Reagan vetoed them and Congress overrode him:

title: IRVING N. EPSTEIN
description: Irving N. Epstein, an apparel industry executive in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died of cancer Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sarasota, Fla.

title: We Need All the Facts in the Pollard Spy Case; Americans First
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday JUILLIARD CONCERTS The Juilliard School will present a series of three free concerts in its first ''New Music Weekend.'' The series is entitled ''Then and Now,'' and features music by 20th-century pioneers and new composers, Tonight at 8, works by Charles Ives, Roger Sessions, Vincent Persichetti and Milton Babbitt will be played at Alice Tully Hall under the direction of Paul Zukofsky. The program includes Ives's ''Unanswered Question'' and Babbitt's ''Composition for Four Instruments.'' Tomorrow night at 8, at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, the concert will include works by John Antony Lennon, Joseph Schwantner, Stephen Montague and two composers currently studying at Juilliard, Ron Yedidia and Behzad Ranjbaran. Sunday night at 8, again at the Juilliard Theater, the program will consist of works by John Adams, Lou Harrison, Joan Tower, Robert Erickson and two Juilliard students, Sebastian Currier and Elena Ruehr. Admission to all events is free, but tickets are required; call 874-7515 today between 9:30 A.M. and 5:30 P.M. for reservations. READING WRITINGS New York is, of course, home to a large number of writers. This afternoon at 12:15, three of them - Eleanor Lerman, a poet, novelist and screenwriter, and Gary Glickman and Terry McMillan, both novelists -will read from their work in the Ground Floor Auditorium at Chase Manhattan Plaza (Pine Street just east of Nassau Street in lower Manhattan) as part of a continuing series entitled ''New York Voices.'' Admission is free, with seating unreserved. Latecomers and early leavers are said to be welcome. Information: 269-0320. Saturday WORLD ART SALE Artexpo N.Y. '87 arrived at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center (between 34th and 35th Streets and 11th and 12th Avenues, along the Hudson River) on Thursday, but was open only to the art and design trade. On Saturday and Sunday, the public is welcome to buy or browse among more than 1,200 booths of contemporary paintings, prints, sculptures and posters, including a selection of works from China. There also are fiber, functional and even ''wearable'' artworks. Some 540 galleries, dealers and artists from more than 25 countries will be represented at the center. Admission is $7 a day. Show hours are Saturday from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: 935-7607. INTERNATIONAL CARNIVAL Saturday from 1 in the afternoon until 11 at night, International House will metamorphose into a grand carnival, with booths representing many different countries and selling food, drink, clothing and other goods from around the world. It's all part of ''Night of Nations,'' an annual event produced by residents of International House, who represent nearly 100 countries and who reside at the house while pursuing academic or professional training in New York. The Yale Russian Chorus will perform at 4 P.M., and the Allnations Dance company at 8:30. Admission is $7 for all or part of the day; $4 for students and children. International House is at 500 Riverside Drive, near 122d Street. Information: 316-8486. BRITTEN CONCERT The personal and professional partnership of Benjamin Britten and Peter Pears was directly responsible for the creation of some cherishable music. Saturday evening at 7:30, Michael Dash, a countertenor, Tony Boutte, a tenor, and Kenneth Merrill, a pianist, will present a memorial concert in honor of the two men at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The program will include the New York premiere of Britten's ''Everyone Sang.'' The cathedral is at 1047 Amsterdam Avenue (at 112th Street). Admission is free. Information: 662-2133. FILMS ABOUT ASIA It's a good weekend to see motion pictures from around the world. On Saturday and Sunday, the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, near 70th Street, will present 10 new films and videos about Asia. The series, entitled ''Filmwarming: New Independent Films on Asia,'' is a program of documentaries and shorts by independent film makers, who will be present to discuss their works and their craft. There will be films about India, Japan and Thailand, among others, all screened in the society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium. Among the films to be shown on Saturday are ''No Longer Silent,'' focusing on ''dowry deaths'' in India, and ''Cycle,'' an animated feature based on an aboriginal folk tale. On Sunday, the films include ''Creative Spirits,'' about Taiwan's young artists, and ''Journey on the Trans-Siberian Express,'' an animated feature. The videos will be shown in the society's conference room. The programs start at 4 P.M. on Saturday and 2 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $4; $3 for students, the elderly and members of the society. Admission to the Asia Society galleries is included in the ticket price. Information: 288-6400. Sunday A PHILIP GLASS PREMIERE Philip Glass is best known for his music for films and theatrical works. Sunday afternoon at 3, Paul Zukofsky will play the world premiere of Mr. Glass's Violin Concerto, the first major concert piece the composer has written in more than a decade. Dennis Russell Davies will conduct the American Composers Orchestra at the Carnegie Hall concert. The program also includes the world premiere of Nancy Laird Chance's ''Odysseus'' and music by Henry Cowell and Irving Berlin. Admission is $9 to $15. Information: 247-7800. BURL IVES PROGRAM Carl Sandburg once called him ''the mightiest ballad singer of this or any other century,'' but this encomium barely begins to sum up the appeal of Burl Ives. He played on Broadway in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' won an Academy Award for his performance in ''The Big Country'' and delighted several generations with his rendition of ''The Bluetail Fly.'' Sunday night at 7:30, Mr. Ives will appear at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Suffolk, a 600-seat auditorium at 74 Hauppauge Road in Commack, L.I. Admission is $15. For information and directions: (516) 938-4600 or (516) 462-9800.

title: We Need All the Facts in the Pollard Spy Case
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
ZIMMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The latest year loss includes a provision of $2.5 million primarily for the writedown of inventories of its motor coach operations caused by major product changes.

title: Bridge: Winners of National Swiss Bore Down in Final Stretch
description: The last round of a Swiss Team Championship almost invariably produces tension. Several teams are likely to have a chance of victory, and the players know it is vital to bid thoughtfully and concentrate in the play.

title: MOST AT 7 3/4 PRIME
description: Most major banks have increased their prime lending rate to 7 3/4 percent from 7 1/2 percent, completing a move that started Tuesday. The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was among the last major banks in New York to adopt the higher rate.

title: FROM SMALL POOL TO BIG TIME
description: The basement swimming pool at the Trinity School at 91st Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan is not exactly high technology. It is 25 yards long and six lanes wide. It is only 4 feet deep and the ceiling is only 12 feet high.

title: RJR Nabisco Sells 4 Pipe Tobaccos
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it had sold its Prince Albert, Carter Hall, Apple and Royal Comfort pipe-tobacco brands to John Middleton Inc., a family-owned tobacco concern in Pennsylvania. Terms were not dislcosed.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons 119, Pacers 73: Vinnie Johnson scored 25 points and Rick Mahorn and John Salley added 17 each last night to lead Detroit to victory at home over Indiana. The margin was the greatest ever for the Pistons. The Pistons led by as many as 49 points, 115-66, while winning for the third time in their last four games. Detroit's previous victory margin record was set in a 144-100 triumph over Kansas City on Feb. 18, 1973. Steve Stipanovich scored 12 points to lead the Pacers, who had won 8 of their last 10 games.(AP) N.H.L. Blues 5, Sabres 3: Rob Ramage's power-play goal at 14 minutes 39 seconds of the third period last night put St. Louis ahead to stay in a victory over Buffalo that clinched second place in the Norris Division for the Blues. St. Louis trails the first-place Detroit Red Wings by 3 points. Both teams have two games remaining, including playing each other in Detroit on Sunday night. Before the loss, Buffalo was eliminated from the playoffs when Quebec beat the Islanders, 4-1. The Sabres trail fourth-place Quebec in the Adams Division by 6 points with two games to play. Ramage's 10th goal gave St. Louis a 4-3 lead. Doug Gilmour picked up an assist on the play, his second point of the game and 101st of the season. Bernie Federko then scored a goal, his 19th, at 17:22.(AP) Tennis Mandlikova Rallies to Advance: Top-seeded Hana Mandlikova rallied from two service breaks down in the opening set last night to post a 6-4, 6-1 victory over eighth-seeded Sylvia Hanika to advance to the semifinals of the $150,000 United States women's indoor tennis championships in Piscataway, N.J. Mandlikova advanced to a match today with fourth-seeded Lori McNeil, who beat sixth-seeded Wendy Turnbull, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2. The other semifinal will pair second-seeded Helena Sukova and unseeded Gigi Fernandez. Sukova defeated fifth-seeded Catarina Lindqvist, 6-4, 6-3, and Fernandez eliminated Grace Kim, 6-1, 7-6.(AP) Scanlon Topples Gilbert: Bill Scanlon upset fourth-seeded Brad Gilbert, 7-5, 6-4, in a second-round match of the Volvo tournament in Chicago. Third-seeded Tim Mayotte survived a scare from Todd Nelson before winning, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3, and eighth-seeded David Pate of Las Vegas, Nev., outlasted Paul Annacone of Bridgehampton, L.I., 7-6, 6-2. Gilbert, from Piedmont, Calif., had grabbed a 5-4 advantage in the first set. After Scanlon, from Dallas, held serve, Gilbert went up, 40-30, on his serve, but lost the next three points and the game. Scanlon lost the first two points off his serve in the 12th and final game, but rallied, scoring on three passing shots to take the set.(AP) Becker Moves On: Boris Becker, avenging a recent Davis Cup upset, defeated Sergio Casal of Spain, 6-2, 6-4, in a second-round match of the $345,000 Fila Trophy indoor tennis tournament in Milan, Italy. Becker, top-seeded in the competition and ranked No. 2 in the world, qualified for a quarterfinal match against Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland. Earlier, Mats Wilander beat a fellow Swede, Jan Gunnarsson, 6-3, 6-4, in a second-round match.(AP) Scanlon Topples Gilbert: Bill Scanlon upset fourth-seeded Brad Gilbert, 7-5, 6-4 in a second-round match of the Volvo tournament in Chicago. Third-seeded Tim Mayotte survived a scare from Todd Nelson before winning, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3, and eighth-seeded David Pate of Las Vegas, Nev., outlasted Paul Annacone, of Bridgehampton, L.I., 7-6, 6-2. Gilbert, from Piedmont, Calif., had grabbed a 5-4 advantage in the first set. After Scanlon, from Dallas, held serve, Gilbert went up, 40-30, on his serve, but lost the next three points and the game. Scanlon lost the first two points off his serve in the 12th and final game, but rallied, scoring on three passing shots to take the set. Down by 3-2 in the second set, Scanlon swiftly took the next three games, and ended the 101-minute match in the 10th game with his fourth ace of the match. In the Mayotte-Nelson match, the score was tied, 30-30, in the ninth game of the second set when Nelson, from San Diego, failed to return a vicious forehand smash, and then double faulted to go down 4-5. But Nelson recovered to square the set at 5-5. In the tiebreaker, Nelson zoomed to a 5-1 advantage and won 7 points to 4, as Mayotte, from Bradenton, Fla., failed to return a backhand that went into the net. But Mayotte recovered to control the final set. (AP)

title: New York City's Cabaret Law Is Pulling the Plug on Jazz
description: Not long ago, the great jazz saxophonist Lee Konitz was asked in a seminar on his work why he played so rarely in New York City. ''Nobody ever asks me,'' he said. How tragic it is that officialdom in our city, the world's jazz center and home for the world's largest community of jazz musicians, is so unreceptive to the performance of their art.

title: New Owners at Lear Replace 3 Executives
description: The new owners of Lear Siegler Inc. announced yesterday that Norman A. Barkeley, the company's president, chairman and chief executive, had resigned, as had two other top officials, as part of the restructuring of the diversified automotive and manufacturing company.

title: LIVINGWELL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in share earnings for 1986 was primarily attributable to the elimination of preferred dividend requirements during 1986.

title: Coping With Japan
description: When President Reagan imposed punitive tariffs on Japan because of its gains in the microchip market, I was just finishing ''The Reckoning,'' David Halberstam's fascinating book on the decline of America's auto industry and the rise of Japan's. How ironically the President's action underlined the powerful themes of the book.

title: No Headline
description: ''I see myself as I saw myself 10 years ago. I still say what I think.'' - Andrei D. Sakharov. [ A1:1. ]

title: WHY GOODEN, TOO?
description: So Dr. K turns out to be Dr. D. K, as in strikeout, D as in dope.

title: GOODEN'S FALL FROM GRACE SADDENS AND ANGERS FANS
description: On street corners and bar stools, on sandlots and subway platforms, on the ticket line and on the Shea Stadium infield where workers prepared for next Tuesday's season opener, New Yorkers yesterday dissected the latest fall from grace by an athletic hero.

title: 3 Mile Island Owner Sets 15/ Dividend
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation declared a dividend yesterday for the first time since 1979, when it sustained severe financial difficulties following the accident at its Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
Busch Faces 2 Investigations
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, parent of the world's largest brewer, said it was under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Federal grand jury over reports that some executives had received improper payments.

title: Who Thinks Green?
description: Legislators from New England apparently think the greenest thoughts. An analysis of votes on key environmental legislation by the League of Conservation Voters found that the delegations from the New England states had the highest percentage of ''right'' votes from an environmentalist perspective. New Englanders in the Senate voted with environmentalists 79 percent of the time, and those in the House, 68 percent.

title: Devils to Shift Farm Team
description: The Devils are planning to move heir top minor league affiliate from Portland, Me., to Utica, N.Y., John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, said yesterday.

title: A FUND-RAISER UNITES THE LITERATI AND THE GLITTERATI
description: New York's old guard joined forces with the new on Wednesday night, and for $750 a ticket the oldeau and the nouveau got the chance to rub elegant elbows with the city's spiffed-up literary world. The result, at the Metropolitan Club, was a jam-packed, celebrity-studded event at which even the most blase eyes opened wide in amazement.

title: Collision Course Ahead
description: Presidential Chief of Staff Howard Baker, and President Reagan himself, have pledged a new effort to get along with Congress in the wake of the Iran-contra scandal. But it is clear on Capitol Hill that this has to mean some policy accommodation, not just informing legislators a little sooner of what the White House wants and working Congressional politics much better than Donald Regan knew how to do.

title: Lone Rangers
description: In a break from the open style with which Phil Esposito has run the Rangers during the regular season, making himself and his players always available for scrutiny, Esposito will isolate the players for the first round of the playoffs, which begin next week. The Rangers will be in one hotel, the reporters in another. ''It's just old-fashioned,'' Esposito said. ''We used to do it when I was with the Bruins. It gives everyone a chance to concentrate.'' Yesterday, the team was making reservations for Philadelphia, since it was a near-certainty that the Rangers would play the Flyers in the first round. Another thing that seemed almost certain was that John Vanbiesbrouck would be named the No. 1 goalkeeper for the playoffs.

title: 2 POLITICANS IN MARYLAND INDICTED IN WEDTECH INFLUENCE-BUYING CASE
description: Two members of a prominent Maryland political family were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore in connection with the investigation of the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor.

title: AIDS Prisoners Should Be Incarcerated for Their Full Sentences
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUGH TRAINING FOR DEALERS OF NEW I.B.M. PC'S
description: Dealers who want to sell the new generation of I.B.M. personal computers - which the company says will be the mainstay of corporate America for the next decade - must take an advanced, expensive training course, I.B.M. officials said today.

title: TALKS ON SPENDING EXCLUDE GOVERNOR
description: As officials struggled to come up with a state budget, already two days late, Governor Cuomo acknowledged today that his administration was not part of key negotiations and that the Legislature was putting together a fiscal plan without him.

title: Getting a Little Bas-Relief
description: Visitors to the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden getting into the spirit of the setting yesterday as they enjoyed the warming rays of a fleeting sun. The live portion of the show will probably be absent today as temperatures should reach only the mid-40's under cloudy skies. (NYT/Marilynn K. Yee)

title: VICTOR D'AMICO, 82, A PIONEER IN ART EDUCATION FOR CHILDREN
description: Victor D'Amico, a pioneer in art education and the director of the education department at the Museum of Modern Art for more than 30 years, died Monday at the Southampton Nursing Home in Southampton, L.I. He was 82 years old, and lived until recent months at his home in Amagansett, L.I.

title: WOOSTER GROUP ON LOVE, LUST AND LENNY BRUCE IN 'ST. ANTHONY'
description: In the opening segment of ''Frank Dell's St. Antony,'' the newest performance piece by the Wooster Group, images of naked flesh and spiritual obsession interact in a provocative collage of music, video and dramatic monologue. Wearing sunglasses and a bathrobe, the actor Ron Vawter stands beneath video monitors on which members of the company are shown lounging around in the nude and engaged in desultory conversation.

title: Islanders Unable To Make a Move
description: Bryan Trottier, after insisting that there is reason for the Islanders to be optimistic, was not - at least not in his evaluation of tonight's 4-1 loss to the Nordiques that clinched a playoff spot for Quebec and left the Islanders adrift in the lower confines of the Patrick Division.

title: TWO RIKERS INMATES ARE WOUNDED IN JAIL SHOOTING
description: Two Rikers Island inmates were shot and slightly wounded Wednesday night, and the authorities have not determined who used the .25-caliber automatic handgun found nearby.

title: Amazing Energy From Russia
description: Of all the things to be said of Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms this is one of the most telling: He has made his country exciting. It is true, of course, that what would be unworthy of note in Paris, Rio or Tokyo is stunning when coming from Moscow. Soviet life has been that sluggish. Yet this is more than mere stirring from the dormant. There is energy coming from the Soviet Union, and it has the world intrigued.

title: ART: CARVINGS BY HAGUE, A MAN OF FEW ANSWERS
description: CONTRIVED mystery, the kind that saves skins or enhances images, is a commonplace. The real thing, on the other hand, is a rarity, and never more so than in the realm of contemporary art. Raoul Hague qualifies if only as a sculptor who, at the age of 82, has but seven solo shows to his credit and who, it seems, has never taught. Add to this the fact that he was 57 when he made his public debut at the prestigious but now defunct Egan Gallery in 1962. But if this artist, who for years has been living reclusively in a Woodstock, N.Y., cabin, is not prominent, he is far from being an obscurity and, as demonstrated by the current show of wood carvings at Xavier Fourcade Inc., 36 East 75th Street, he continues to produce.

title: Dining Out Guide: New Jersey
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARCHER'S, #1310 Palisade Avenue, Fort Lee (201-224-5652) - **(Nov. 30, 1986) Now that spring is officially here, areas outside the city seem to beckon; whether you're going to or coming from New Jersey, you might stop at this popular Italian restaurant in Fort Lee. There are two dining rooms - one upstairs and one down - a bar and a glassed-in lounge area. The enormous menu offers some interesting choices.

title: ART: PAINTING IS ATTRIBUTED TO TITIAN
description: AFTER cleaning and restoration at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and exhaustive research by a Met curator, a large painting attributed simply to ''Workshop of Titian'' is now attributed to the great Venetian master himself.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ASSAIL HIGHER PHONE CHARGES
description: House Democrats today assailed a Federal Communications Commission board proposal for a $1.50 increase in monthly telephone charges for households and small businesses, signaling a possible reduction.

title: RAY MILLER
description: Ray Miller, a former featherweight boxer and later a referee with the New York State Boxing Commission, died Tuesday. He had been suffering from lung cancer for some time, his wife said. He was 82 years old.

title: 2 ARE INDICTED FOR FAULTY PART FOR WARPLANES
description: Two officials of a defunct Long Island military subcontractor were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury and accused of producing a defective part for radar-jamming equipment that could have made American combat pilots ''sitting ducks'' to hostile fire.

title: CPC Sells Unit In South Africa
description: CPC International Inc., which has been doing business in South Africa for more than 65 years, said it had sold its business there to a group of European and South African investors for undisclosed terms. ''In recent months, operating a business in South Africa has become increasingly difficult both for companies headquartered in the U.S. and their subsidiaries in South Africa,'' said James Eiszner, the president of CPC, a major food concern.

title: We Need All the Facts in the Pollard Spy Case; Forbidden to Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN WAS TOLD IN '85 OF PROBLEM IN MOSCOW EMBASSY
description: A secret report sent to President Reagan by his advisory panel on intelligence two years ago warned that the United States Embassy in Moscow was vulnerable to Soviet espionage, Government officials said today.

title: PROGRAM OF TIGHT SUPERVISION ENLIVENS PROBATION AGENCY
description: Called the green berets of New York City's Department of Probation, members of the agency's 18-month-old Field Service Unit are breathing new life into an agency considered overwhelmed and ineffective by judges, prosecutors and many probation officers themselves.

title: Guided Day Trips By Cycling Tour Group
description: As April arrives, so does the urge to clean up the bicycle for another season of riding. This weekend, Country Cycling Tours will offer its first guided day trips of the season. Tomorrow, the group will tour the horse farm country of New Jersey. On Sunday, the route will be along the North Shore of Long Island. Each trip, which includes transportation, is $23; bicycles can be rented for $17. Information: 874-5151.

title: SOVIET DENIES ANY DEAL WITH ISRAEL AND ON JEWS
description: The Soviet Union today denied Israeli assertions that there had been an agreement on exchanging consular missions.

title: I.R.S. Speeds Processing
description: The backlog of unprocessed Federal tax returns is 18 percent lower than at this time a year ago, indicating a shorter wait for refunds, the Internal Revenue Service said today. Through last Friday, 52.8 million couples and individuals had filed returns, down from the 54 million received during the corresponding period last year. But the I.R.S. has processed 42 million returns this year, up 3 percent. That leaves a stack of 10.8 million unprocessed returns, down from 13.2 million at the end of March 1986. During the comparable period of 1985, when computer problems slowed processing to a crawl, the backlog was more than 26 million returns.

title: DATA FROM STELLAR EXPLOSION GIVE CLUE ON FATE OF UNIVERSE
description: A shower of subnuclear particles spewed across the earth by the spectacular exploding star that appeared over the Southern Hemisphere a month ago has given scientists important new evidence bearing on the ultimate fate of the universe, two leading physicists reported yesterday.

title: Our Towns; Making a Way For the Children All Others Shun
description: Lots of money is spent fighting over a few children in our society - Baby M, Baby Jane Doe, the sons and daughters in divorce custody wars.

title: GOODEN PROVIDED NO CLUES TO TEAM
description: Dwight Gooden flew to New York today and entered a drug rehabilitation clinic, where his use of cocaine will be measured and treated. But, from the front office to the recesses of the Mets' locker room, his employers and teammates insisted that they had neither known nor suspected that he had ever used drugs.

title: Market Place; Mutual Fund Sales Charges
description: MUTUAL fund sales charges were once relatively static affairs; a fund either levied a ''load'' - or front-end sales charge - or else it was no-load. But lately a number of management companies have put into effect strategies aimed at garnering a bigger share of the booming fund business.

title: XOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 loss includes a one-time, $32 million non-cash charge resulting from Xoma's acquisition of the rights and technology of Xoma Research Partners Ltd. There was no revenue recorded for 1986 or for the 1985 fourth quarter. The revenue for full-year 1985 comes mainly from contract revenue received from a research and development limited partnership.

title: NOT GUILTY IS SIMON'S ANSWER TO U.S. EXTORTION INDICTMENT
description: Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, pleaded not guilty yesterday to the Federal extortion indictment that was filed against him Wednesday.

title: DIVIDED COURT UPHOLDS AN OLD PRINCIPLE
description: New York's highest court was sharply divided yesterday over the ancient legal principle summarized by the maxim ''ignorantia legis neminem excusat'' - ignorance, or even mistake, of the law is no excuse.

title: 2 Top Officers Quit Wheeling
description: The president and vice president of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest steelmaker, resigned today in a pay dispute.

title: Cigarette Output Down
description: Cigarette production last year dropped about 3 percent, to 643 billion cigarettes, an Agriculture Department report said. ''Domestic use fell, but exports rose,'' the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday. ''U.S. smokers consumed 584 billion cigarettes in 1986, about 2 percent fewer than in 1985.''

title: PHILIP COLLECK
description: Philip Colleck, an antiques dealer in Manhattan and London, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

title: Cunningham Reception
description: Merce Cunningham and his company will be the guests of honor at a gala champagne reception for the benefit of the Lehman College Art Gallery tomorrow following a performance starting at 8 P.M. by the company at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts. An ''Event,'' created by Mr. Cunningham, will be presented at the performance and the reception will take place at the art gallery on the Lehman College campus, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx. Bus transportation from Lincoln Center is available for $7. Tickets are $60 for the performance and reception; tickets for the performance alone are $13, $15 and $17.50. Information: 960-8733.

title: Judge Seeks Bhopal Aid
description: A judge hearing the Indian Government's suit against the Union Carbide Corporation today asked the two sides to agree on interim compensation. Judge M. W. Deo said he made the appeal because the court case was likely to be a long struggle for victims of the disastrous leak of methyl isocyanate gas.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ON first impression it looked a little too swanky to be taken seriously as a pasta house, what with all that brass and glass and movie-star murals and a tinkling waterfall in the dining room. Then again, the menu seemed inviting, and a wind current of garlic and oregano grabbed me by the scruff of the neck and tugged me inside, so I decided to give it a try.

title: ART: COURTAULD GROUP OF MASTERWORKS AT MET
description: ''IMPRESSIONIST AND POST-IMPRESSIONIST MASTERPIECES: The Courtauld Collection,'' now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through June 21, is an anthology of 48 paintings by Manet, Cezanne, Monet, Degas, Renoir, Gauguin, van Gogh, Seurat and others. Even in the Met, which is not short of paintings of that kind and date, some of the Courtauld pictures make a spectacular effect. Not only is there Manet's ''Bar aux Folies-Bergere,'' but there is also a small-scale version of his ''Dejeuner sur l'Herbe.'' The nine paintings by Cezanne range in date from 1875 to 1896 and include two of his most monumental studies of peasants and peasant life and a late and glorious view of the Lake of Annecy. There are no fewer than eight oil paintings by Seurat. As for Renoir's ''Loge'' of 1874, it is just about everyone's favorite work by that immensely uneven and often repellent painter.

title: HELM RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $20,000 and $60,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and an extrarodinary charge of $38,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $162,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,291,000 for the quarter and $1,590,000 for the year; and an extraordinary gain of $1,941,000 for both the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter loss is after an approximate $200,000 charge atributable to a 28 percent owned subsidiary's year-end writedown of oil-related seismic data and an approximate $90,000 charge related to the company's writedown of its oil-related seismic data.

title: OLYMPIC BROADCASTING reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
GENEVE CAPITAL GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After realized gains on investments of $11,113,718, and includes a non-recurring loss of about $1 million related to the restructuring of a subsidiary. c-After realized gains on investments of $5,208,016.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $294,000 for the quarter and a gain of $279,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $294,000 for the quarter and $979,000 for the year.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Margaret Whiting, the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800). ''It Might As Well Be Spring,'' the title of her recently published autobiography, is also the name of Margaret Whiting's new cabaret act, in which she interweaves her musical history with anecdotes about the hotel, which she is performing in for the first time. Ms. Whiting's sensual trumpet of a voice is a pillar of resilience and warmth. The high points of the show, in which she is accompanied on the piano by Tex Arnold, include her early hit ''My Ideal,'' and a bold, declarative ''Mad About the Boy.'' Shows are at 9:15 and 11:15 tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 food and beverage minimum and a $20 music charge.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 15
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain, after taxes and employee profit sharing, of $6,789,000 from the sale of about 1 million shares of Cypress Semiconductor for the quarter and 6 months.

title: OJEDA EARNS START ON OPENING DAY
description: The Mets began the painful task of regrouping their spirits and their pitching today, and started by naming Bob Ojeda to replace Dwight Gooden as their opening-day pitcher against the Pittsburgh Pirates next Tuesday in Shea Stadium.

title: David Adler, 51, Physicist; Expert on Semiconductors
description: Dr. David Adler, a physicist who dealt with the nature and properties of solid matter, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 51 years old.

title: Moynihan Assailed
description: The Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms has named it ''Moynihan's Monstrosity.'' It is a bill drafted by New York's Democratic Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, to bar the manufacture and importation of .25- and .32-caliber ammunition as an indirect way to restrict the use of millions of pistols privately owned by Americans.

title: S.E.C. Review Of 'Greenmail'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will once again consider whether to recommend legislation to eliminate the practice known as ''greenmail,'' according to Commissioner Charles C. Cox. Greenmail is the repurchase of shares, at a premium, from unwanted suitors, in order to head off hostile takeovers.

title: Kean Tells Legislators To Look at Surrogacy
description: Governor Kean said today that he found the issues surrounding surrogate parenthood ''deeply, deeply disturbing'' and that he wanted the Legislature to take a hard look at the practice.

title: Israeli Court Rejects Appeal By Suspected War Criminal
description: Israel's Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by the defense to disqualify the three-judge panel presiding over the trial of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being a Nazi war criminal.

title: I.B.M. OFFERS A BLITZ OF NEW PC'S
description: Six years after it began to make its personal computer as familiar in American offices as the filing cabinet, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced a new, far more powerful line of desktop machines designed to carry it into the 1990's.

title: Who Owns This Land?
description: This land is not necessarily our land. The Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service has found that the amount of land in the United States owned by foreigners is rising sharply.

title: Britain to Sell Off Royal Ordnance
description: Britain's Defense Ministry has agreed to sell the state-owned armaments manufacturer Royal Ordnance to British Aerospace for $:190 million, or about $300 million at current exchange rates. Defense Secretary George Younger said the sale would end a period of uncertainty for the 15 Royal Ordnance factories and open a wide range of opportunities for expansion of its business.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ANDY ROONEY THREATENS TO QUIT CBS
description: Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator who has had a running dispute with CBS management over cutbacks and a writers' strike at CBS News, said last night that he would quit CBS if the strike is not soon resolved.

title: REAGAN LEGAL VIEWS CHALLENGED
description: The Federal district judge who ordered the Boston schools desegregated and took control of them for nearly a decade said today that the Reagan Administration was mistaken in its emphasis on judicial restraint.

title: Meese Given New Evidence On Waldheim's War Record
description: The Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit has given Attorney General Edwin Meese 2d new evidence on the wartime record of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to bolster its recommendation that he be barred from the United States, Justice Department officials said today.

title: Michael Lytle
description: Michael Lytle will play a solo concert of new music for clarinet today at 9 and 10:30 P.M. at the Spare Room, 107 Morton Street (807-6267). Admission is $3.

title: Tolls to Rise April 12 On Hudson Crossings
description: On April 12, automobile tolls on the three Hudson River crossings into Manhattan will rise, to $3 from $2, and PATH fares will increase, to $1 from 75 cents, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

title: SENATE VOTE ENCOURAGES WELFARE CHANGE
description: The Senate unanimously passed a bill today authorizing the Federal Government to pay bonuses to states that move long-term welfare recipients into jobs in private industry.

title: INSIDE
description: Outlook for Times Sq. City and state officials are taking steps to save the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project from possible collapse. Page B1. Windsor Jewels Auctioned Jewels of the Duchess of Windsor were auctioned in Geneva for $33.5 million. This 31-carat diamond ring fetched $3.15 million. Page A18. New I.B.M. Computers I.B.M. introduced much more powerful personal computers that are likely to bring sweeping change, and some confusion, to the industry. Page D1.

title: ACCORD ON KING PAPERS
description: As a result of an agreement with the estate of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a historian at Stanford University is editing the complete papers of the civil-rights leader, and the University of California Press will publish them in 12 volumes over the next 15 years.

title: Fiddling as Economic Problems Burn
description: The dollar skidded again this week, sending stocks and bonds into a brief but worrisome nosedive. Talk persists of a trans-Pacific ''trade war'' over microchips and broken promises. Now, unexpectedly, banks have raised their prime loan rates. All a little unnerving. The events showed, once again, the calamities that could lie ahead unless Washington and Tokyo stop tinkering and testing each other and address the underlying problems.

title: District Attorney Subpoenas Council's Personnel Records
description: Personnel records for the entire New York City Council staff were subpoenaed yesterday as part of the Manhattan District Attorney's investigation of state legislative hiring practices, a Council spokesman said last night.

title: STAGE: FUGARD'S 'PLACE WITH THE PIGS'
description: ''A Place With the Pigs,'' now enjoying its world premiere engagement at the Yale Repertory Theater, is a surprise: an Athol Fugard play not set in South Africa. The play takes place instead, as its title indicates, with the pigs - or, as the program says, in ''a pigsty, in a small village, somewhere in the author's imagination.'' That's fine, but doesn't every play unfold somewhere in its author's imagination? When a writer must inform an audience of that fact, one immediately starts worrying that the piece at hand is not fully imagined.

title: Giants' Staff Signed
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants was ''worried'' after the Super Bowl, he admitted yesterday. ''I was worried about signing all the coaches,'' he said. ''All the assistants' contracts were up after the season.'' But all have re-signed and talks are going on regarding an extension of the remaining two years of Parcells's contract. ''Continuity is one of the most important things to have in a coaching staff,'' Parcells said. ''It was something the Giants didn't have for many years. You've got to be able to have the same people so that you can put in the same programs without disruption.'' In his first discussion of the attempt by the Atlanta Falcons to disrupt things by asking the Giants for permission to talk to Parcells, the coach conceded that the talk of his going to Atlanta had bothered him. ''It was embarrassing,'' he said, adding, ''I have every reason to think things will be fine.''

title: Dwight Gooden, On the Shelf
description: New York Mets fans won't feel much like cheering the departure of Dwight Gooden for drug rehabilitation - it's the latest in a series of setbacks that cast doubt on the team's chance to retain the world championship. But as the move reflects baseball's determination to discipline drug-abusing players, it deserves applause.

title: France Ousts 3 Soviet Diplomats It Calls Spies
description: France expelled three Soviet diplomats today, after the disclosure that six people arrested here two weeks ago on charges of spying to obtain European space secrets were supervised by members of the Soviet Embassy.

title: Charlotte Awarded N.B.A. Franchise
description: In a surprise move, the National Basketball Association's expansion committee recommended yesterday Charlotte, N.C., as its first choice when it begins its three-team expansion process with the 1988-89 season.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON HIGHWAY BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today overrode President Reagan's veto of the highway bill: FOR OVERRIDING VETO - 67 Democrats - 54 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont.; Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Chiles, Fla. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D. Kerry, Mass. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Levin, Mich. Matsunaga, Hawaii Melcher, Mont. Metzenbaum, Ohio Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Moynihan, N.Y. Nunn, Ga. Pell, R.I. Proxmire, Wis. Pryor, Ark. Reid, Nev. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W.Va. Sanford, N.C. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Shelby, Ala. Simon, Ill. Stennis, Miss. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 13 Bond, Mo. Cochran, Miss. D'Amato, N.Y.
