Quayle, Ind. Roth, Del. Rudman, N.H. Simpson, Wyo. Stafford, Vt. Stevens, Alaska Thurmond, S.C. Trible, Va. Wallop, Wyo. Warner, Va.

title: 2 Books on Philadelphia Win '87 Bancroft Prizes
description: Two books about Philadelphia have won the 1987 Bancroft Prizes, awarded annually by Columbia University to honor books of exceptional merit and distinction in American history and diplomacy.

title: Paine Webber Indictments
description: A Federal grand jury indicted two more executives of Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday in connection with what was characterized as a $700,000 money-laundering scheme. The executives - Joseph

title: BUDDY RICH, JAZZ DRUMMER WITH DISTINCTIVE SOUND, DIES
description: Buddy Rich, a hot-tempered musician who drummed his way through vaudeville shows and big bands, died yesterday at UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

title: New-Music Series
description: Horst Rickles will perform tomorrow at 10:30 P.M., followed by the Ordinaires at midnight, in the new-music series at Tin Pan Alley, 220 West 49th Street (582-9376). Admission is free.

title: ROADWAY MOTOR PLAZAS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HAGLER'S TRIANGLE COVERS ALL ANGLES
description: When boxing champions step into the gym, more often than not they are preceded by large entourages.

title: REPORT CARDS DUE TO DERBY CLASS OF '87
description: By tomorrow evening, there should finally be some clear favorites for the 113th Kentucky Derby May 2, because almost every leading contender is making a key start tomorrow afternoon.

title: Devils Lose Bid For Fifth
description: Troy Loney scored two goals to help the Pittsburgh Penguins defeat the Devils, 6-2, tonight and assure themselves of beating the Devils out of fifth place in the Patrick Division.

title: Home Sellers To Tell I.R.S.
description: Anyone buying or selling a home may be affected by the Government's new effort to catch tax cheats.

title: TRYING AGAINST ALL HOPE
description: They told Ronald Reagan not to do it, but he went ahead anyway.

title: Textron's Offer To Yield 9.50%
description: Textron Inc. is offering $150 million of 9 1/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 1/2 to yield 9.50 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Bond Prices Resume Descent 8% Yield Near On Treasuries
description: Bond prices resumed their downward spiral yesterday. Securities dealers said that tepid buying early in the day was overshadowed by large sell orders in the afternoon.

title: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES COURT NEW YORK
description: There may be votes in Iowa and New Hampshire but there's gold in New York, and that's why Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are shuttling in and out of New York a year before the state's presidential primaries.

title: ART: WORKS BY GOURFAIN AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: THERE is much that is admirable about Peter Gourfain's exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. It is called ''Roundabout and Other Works,'' and it consists of 56 paintings, works on paper, ceramic pots and reliefs. The ambition is epic. Mr. Gourfain wants to include everything, inspire justice and transformation and compose a narrative on nothing less than the human condition.

title: JOHN PAUL CALLS FOR CHILEANS TO MOVE TOWARD DEMOCRACY
description: Pope John Paul II visited Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's military ruler, in his palace today and a few hours later called for Chile to move toward democracy in the ''not distant future.''

title: Economic Scene; Behind the Rise In Prime Rate
description: THE decision of Citibank to raise its prime rate of interest by one-quarter of a point, to 7 3/4 percent - a move quickly followed by other major banks - took Wall Street by surprise.

title: BROADWAY
description: LAWRENCE KASHA, a co-producer of such shows as ''Applause'' and ''Woman of the Year,'' doesn't believe that the American musical is dead. He's got a new one coming up - or at least a workshop version of a proposed musical - and two more in the works, and if his dream comes true, he will be back on Broadway later this year. His workshop production is a musical based on ''To Sir, With Love,'' a 1967 film that starred Sidney Poitier.

title: John W. Rockefeller, A Consulting Engineer
description: John W. Rockefeller Jr., a consulting engineer who perfected and manufactured the mainspring of the Norden bombsight used in Allied fighter planes in World War II, died Tuesday at the Green Grove Health Care Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Asbury Park, N.J.

title: Wyoming Lures Dees
description: A day after he said he almost certainly would remain as basketball coach at the University of New Orleans, Benny Dees was lured away for twice the money by his alma mater, the University of Wyoming. This was only Dees's second season as coach of the Privateers. But he led them to a 26-4 record, their first national ranking, 16th at the end of the season, and their first appearance in the N.C.A.A. tournament since the school began Division I play in 1975. The Privateers beat Brigham Young in the opening round before losing to Alabama. ''I honestly thought I was coming back,'' Dees said about his comment on Wednesday, when he was quoted as saying, ''I'm 99 percent sure I'm going to be here.'' Then Charley Spoonour of Southwest Missouri, the only other candidate for the Wyoming job, withdrew his name. The Wyoming job had been vacated when Jim Brandenburg resigned to move to San Diego State after nine years as the Cowboys' coach. The Cowboys were offering a package of around $160,000 a year, which included a salary of $67,000, radio and television income of $20,000 and income from a summer camp. Dees had been offered a raise to $70,000 at New Orleans and revenue from other sources amounting to about $10,000 more.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FILM: 'CAPTIVE,' WITH OLIVER REED
description: MOVIES like Paul Mayersberg's ''Captive'' are as rare as peacocks' teeth, and even more precious.

title: PANEL BACKS MEESE ON LIMITED INQUIRY
description: The Federal judicial panel that administers the law on special prosecutors ruled today that it did not have the authority to broaden the scope of a special investigation after the Attorney General refused to do so.

title: Cotton Prices Tumble Amid Export Worries
description: Cotton futures reversed course and tumbled today as concerns about sagging exports outweighed a report that farmers plan to reduce production.

title: Peter Serkin
description: The pianist Peter Serkin will play his debut concert at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. The program will include works by Bach, Beethoven, Toru Takemitsu, Olivier Messiaen and Stefan Wolpe. Tickets are $14 to $22.50. Information: 247-7800.

title: WINDSOR JEWELS BRING AN AUCTION RECORD
description: At 9:23 tonight, in a party tent poised somewhere between romance and avarice, an auctioneer hammered out the sale of the first of the costly baubles that were scattered as love tokens across the lives of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.

title: 2 Shareholders Sue Home Shopping
description: Home Shopping Network Inc., the largest television shopping company, has been sued by two shareholders in Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla. The suit accuses the company of making false and misleading statements in public filings. The shareholders, Burton Rosenfeld and Victor P. Ganderson, are seeking class-action status.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday about a memorial service for Andy Warhol misidentified Claes Oldenburg's wife.

title: Henri Cochet Is Dead; French Tennis Leader
description: Henri Cochet, one of the famed Four Musketeers of French tennis, died Wednesday night after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Air Force Academy Change
description: President Reagan has nominated Maj. Gen. Charles R. Hamm for a promotion and new assignment as superintendent of the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, the Defense Department said today. If the nomination is confirmed by the Senate, General Hamm would receive his third star and replace Lieut. Ge,. Winfield W. Scott Jr.

title: GROUP THERAPY KEY IN DRUG CENTER
description: Patients arriving at the New York center where Dwight Gooden has been sent for help in coping with his drug problem are first interviewed about their dependency.

title: Eastern Airline Pilots Picket on Safety Issue
description: Eastern Airlines pilots in uniform picketed the carrier's major terminals today to dramatize their charges that Eastern's new cost-cutting work policies could create unsafe flying conditions.

title: University Names President
description: John W. Shumaker, vice president of planning and development at the State University of New York in Albany, was named today to succeed F. Don James as president of Central Connecticut State University. Dr. Shumaker, 44 years old, will assume his new post on Aug. 1. Mr. James is retiring after 19 years as president of the 13,500-student school. Dr. Shumaker, a scholar of Greek and the classics, was previously acting vice president at Albany and was the first dean of the school's College of Humanities and Fine Arts.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Teltscher Upsets Connors: Steady Eliot Teltscher won the battle of the baseline by mixing in a series of spectacular forehands to upset second-seeded Jimmy Connors, 6-3, 6-1, in the quarterfinal round of the $315,000 Volvo Chicago tournament yesterday. Teltscher advanced to today's semifinal, in which he will face third-seeded Tim Mayotte. Bill Scanlon will play the second semifinal against the winner of the Mel Purcell-David Pate match. Mayotte, of Bradenton, Fla., played almost-errorless tennis to dispose of Peter Fleming of Glen Cove, L.I., 6-2, 6-3. Scanlon, of Dallas, defeated sixth-seeded Scott Davis of Bardmoor, Fla., 6-3, 6-3. Teltscher's victory marked the first time the native of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., was able to beat Connors in 16 meetings dating to 1979. Connors raced to an early 2-0 first-set advantage with a break in the opening game. But Teltscher put aside his serving problems by breaking Connors in the sixth and eighth games for a 5-3 advantage, then took the first set when Connors hit a return into the net. Connors, who plays out of Sanibel Harbour, Fla., then lost the opening serve of the second set en route to a 4-0 deficit. He held service in the fifth game, but withered under Teltscher's attack.(AP) Mandlikova Withdraws: Top-seeded Hana Mandlikova withdrew hours before her semifinal match in Piscataway, N.J., with Lori McNeil because of a pulled stomach muscle. That sent the fouth-seeded McNeil into the final of the $150,000 United States women's indoor championships against second-seeded Helena Sukova, who advanced with a 6-3, 7-5 victory over Gigi Fernandez. Sukova, who reached the final for a second straight year, finished off her match by breaking Fernandez in the 12th game of the second set.(AP) Becker in Semifinals: Boris Becker of West Germany defeated Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the semifinals of the $345,000 Fila Trophy indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. Becker, the top-seeded player, will be matched today against Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, who beat Paolo Cane of Italy, 6-1, 6-1. Becker broke Hlasek's serve once in each set to win in 1 hour 9 minutes. He has lost only 16 games in three rounds. In an earlier quarterfinal match, Mats Wilander of Sweden, playing unusually aggressive tennis, trounced a Spaniard, Emilio Sanchez, 6-3, 6-1, and gained a semifinal berth against second-seeded Miloslav Mecir. Mecir, a 22-year-old Czechoslovak ranked sixth in the world, defeated a countryman, Tomas Smid, 6-4, 6-4.(AP)

title: A Mortgage From Seller Leonard sloane
description: SELLER-FINANCED mortgages are still an important part of the real estate scene.

title: WINTER, JACK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $630,000 for the latest quarter and $220,000 for the year-earlier period. c-Net income and after an extraordinary tax credit of $174,000.

title: Letter: On The E.P.A.; A Problem of Funding, Not Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Ars Longa, Price Absurda
description: Yes, I am the secret purchaser who paid $40 million for one of Van Gogh's sunflower paintings, and not one of his best either, they tell me. Any other questions? Question: Are you a collector? Answer: Not anymore. I used to collect corporations until Lou Harris I think it was took a poll. It showed everybody thinks corporation collectors are parasites, so I quit.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes $93,000 received in partial litigation settlement for both periods. c-Net loss The company said the prior year results include a $300,000 increase in earnings for litigation reversed in favor of Florafax.

title: VMS SHORT TERM INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Nancy Hits the Heights

title: Shearson Drops Role
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. will no longer serve as a financial adviser for the financier Khoo Teck Puat, Shearson said in a statement. Shearson had formulated a proposal on Mr. Khoo's behalf for repayment of debt to the National Bank of Brunei. The authorities in Brunei closed the bank last November, contending that 90 percent of its loans had been extended, without documentation or guarantee, to companies controlled by Mr. Khoo's family and friends.

title: A GUIDE TO MEDICAL TEST
description: THE American College of Physicians and the nation's largest insurer, Blue Cross and Blue Shield, say they have developed guidelines to determine when 15 commonly performed medical tests are unnecessary.

title: 'BLACK CARS' TAKE OVER RADIO CALLS OF TAXIS
description: The days of the radio-dispatched yellow taxicabs ended last month. In their place, a new industry has rapidly become a favorite of executives and other professional people in New York City.

title: Testaverde Signs
description: More than three weeks before the National Football League draft, Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback, signed a six-year contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who have the first selection. Terms of yesterday's signing, which will make Testaverde the richest rookie in N.F.L. history, were not disclosed, but the former University of Miami star will reportedly be paid $8.2 million. Testaverde had no reservations about joining a team that has had only three winning seasons in the franchise's 11-year history. ''It's easy to take the easy road, but you feel a lot better when you have to work for it,'' he said.

title: CHARGES REPORTED NEAR IN A NEO-NAZI INQUIRY
description: A Federal grand jury in Arkansas that has been investigating neo-Nazi terrorist activity for several months appears ready to issue indictments against right-wing extremist leaders, according to officials with knowledge of the investigation. The charges are said to include possible counts of sedition, The grand jury inquiry, in Fort Smith, Ark., as well as others in Spokane, Wash., and Denver, grew out of earlier Federal investigations that, in Seattle in early 1986, led to the conviction of 10 members of a violent anti-Semitic group calling itself the Order. Six other members pleaded guilty and were also given prison sentences.

title: NICHOLS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CRIMINAL INQUIRY INTO THIOKOL DISCLOSED
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a criminal investigation of Morton Thiokol Inc., the company that made the faulty booster rockets that were blamed for causing the Challenger space shuttle disaster last year, a Federal law-enforcement official confirmed today.

title: Grand National Play Moves Into the District Semifinals
description: The protracted battle for Grand National Team honors, which began at club level four months ago and is to end in Baltimore in July, continues today at the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1987
description: Markets

title: Wind a Handicap to L.P.G.A.
description: ''You need your shoes full of lead just to keep from blowing over,'' said Val Skinner after shooting a three-over-par 75 today in a 40-mile-per-hour wind during the second round of the $500,000 Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament.

title: Two Ways to Respond to Teen-Age Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Libyans Said to Bomb Planes Seized by Chad
description: Daily bombing raids by Libyan jets have destroyed or damaged half of the Soviet-made aircraft seized intact by Chadian troops when they captured the Libyan base of Wadi Dum two weeks ago, a French military officer said today.

title: Murderer Is Caught 9 Years After Trial
description: Nine years after he was convicted in absentia of a Queens kidnap-murder, a 34-year-old man was apprehended yesterday based on an anonymous tip that he had been seen around a Brooklyn housing project, the authorities said.

title:
PATENTS;
Fabric Loop Makes 8-Foot Soap Bubbles
description: LEAD: Soap bubbles eight feet in diameter can be made with apparatus patented this week by David R. Stein, a New York architect. The equipment, called Bubble-Thing, is being marketed through several chains of toy stores.

title: TV MOUSE ROARS BACK AT THE MAYOR
description: Mayor Koch has had to deal with more than a few irritants over the last many months. But guff from a mouse?

title: Opponents, Not Opposition, in Chile
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet rules Chile by default as well as by force. He is surrounded by opponents but they, unlike those who supplanted dictators in Argentina and the Philippines, have yet to transform themselves into a viable political opposition. Beyond the courage to speak out, these opponents need the wisdom to transcend division and establish a new pragmatic consensus.

title: When Childbirth Is Fatal
description: For women in the developing world the most worrying question about pregnancy is not ''Will it change my life?'' but ''Will it end my life?'' Reducing this maternal mortality rate - a goal recently, and commendably, set by the World Bank - depends heavily on birth control and health care services. Sadly, over the last three years the United States Government's commitment to this noble cause has continued to diminish.

title: KEY RATES
J.D.L. Bomb Suspect Is Released on Bond
description: A member of the Jewish Defense League who Federal authorities have linked to several terrorist bombings was released on a $1 million bond yesterday by a United States magistrate who sternly warned him not to use his ''little toys'' or make ''infernal devices'' while awaiting trial.

title: E & B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TAKING A CUE FROM FLIPPER
description: If you saw the first three finishers in last night's 100-yard backstroke in the national collegiate swimming championships, you might not have believed what you saw. If, indeed, you saw anything.

title: PUBLISHING: AUTHORS HELP AN INJURED COLLEAGUE
description: Five literary afternoons, at which 10 prominent authors read from their works to raise money for a badly injured colleague, wound up raising nearly almost $85,000. The money will be used toward the medical bills of Andre Dubus, a short-story writer and novelist whose leg was amputated after he was struck by a car last July while helping another motorist.

title: WINDSOR AUCTIO: $50 MILLION
description: Nostalgia continued to spur intense bidding last night in the final session of the auction in Geneva of the Duchess of Windsor's jewels. Bidders in the tent overlooking Lake Geneva, and at Sotheby's in New York, vied for the trinkets and treasures that had filled table tops, drawers and jewelry boxes in the residences of the Duke and Duchess. The total of the two-day sale was $50,281,887, seven times Sotheby's presale estimate, a record for a jewelry sale.

title: KIRSCHNER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SAXON OIL DEVELOPMENT PARTERS L P reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results include writedowns of oil and gas properties of $3,075,841, and the year- earlier periods include similar writedowns of $42,317,582.

title: JAZZ: TRIO WITH BRAFF, CORNETIST
description: Ruby Braff, whose lyrical cornet is rarely heard in New York these days, has turned up at an unexpected venue - Zinno, the restaurant at 126 West 13th Street where the musical instrumentation is usually piano and bass. Mr. Braff, with John Bunch on piano and Michael Moore on bass, is the first horn player to be featured at Zinno.

title: Gulf States Utility
description: The Gulf States Utilities Company said that its condition has ''significantly deteriorated'' and that its operating cash reserves would be inadequate by May unless it received additional financing or rate relief from state authorities in Texas and Louisiana. In its newly released annual report and 10-K filing, Gulf States said that bank lenders had notified it last month that no additional credit would be granted. In addition, Gulf States said the banks had requested the utility to begin making prepayments by the end of this month that exceed its estimated lease payments.

title: The New Tennis House: A Net Gain
description: On their toes to anticipate an architectural drop shot, some Central Park tennis players talk of resisting replacement of their familiar tennis house with a new building. It is reasonable for New Yorkers to be suspicious of Central Park ''improvements''; many have turned out badly. But the present stuccoed tennis house, a midget Greek Revival anachronism set in the Victorian Gothic wonderland of Central Park, deserves demolition. If players would look at architectural drawings of the planned replacement, they might shed their anxiety and welcome the change.

title: GREECE VOTES TAKEOVER OF CHURCH-HELD ESTATES
description: After hours of heated debate, Parliament approved legislation today, enabling the Socialist Government to take over huge estates held by the Greek Orthodox Church within six months.

title: Thrift Unit to Buy Broker
description: In an effort to diversify, the Franklin Savings Association, a large Kansas-based thrift institution, has agreed to acquire Underwood, Neuhaus & Company, a brokerage house based in Houston.

title: GOODEN'S APPEAL FOR ADS LESSENS
description: The appeal Dwight Gooden had for advertisers, already on the wane because of some well-publicized problems last year, has virtually vanished because of his involvement with cocaine, industry representatives said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday misstated the role of Charlotte, N.C., in expansion plans by the National Basketball Association.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The highlight of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Sunday afternoon program was the world-premiere performance of Tobias Picker's chamber arrangement of his own ''Keys to the City'' for piano, winds and string quartet.

title: MARS GRAPHIC SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
THEATER: 4 MUSICALS EARLY 50'S
description: ''Wish You Were Here,'' ''Peter Pan,'' ''Kismet'' and ''Out of This World,'' the four early 1950's musicals that were surveyed and sampled at the 92d Street Y's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series Sunday and Monday, have little in common beyond their period and the fact that they originated as plays. Presented in a digest format with a narration by Earl Wrightson and eight singers recreating a variety of roles, they made for an entertaining cross section of vintage second-rank Broadway shows.

title: COPORATE SECRETARY AT I.B.M.
description: John H. Manningham, the newly appointed secretary of the I.B.M. Corporation, and his wife, Patricia, were killed in a fire that swept their home in Ridgefield, Conn., early yesterday. He was 53 years old and she was 54.

title: New York State Set to Spend $375 Million on 60 Projects
description: The overriding of President Reagan's veto of the highway bill will allow New York State to proceed with $375 million of road construction on 60 projects.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a $1,023,592 gain on the sale of property interest.

title: DEROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Carlton Indian Reliever
description: Steve Carlton, a starter throughout his 22 years in the major leagues, signed today with the Cleveland Indians and will become a middle-inning relief pitcher in his latest attempt to revive his career. ''We're gambling that he can fill a role for us,'' said Joe Klein, the Indians' vice president. ''He's healthy, and the point is, he can fall out of bed and pitch two innings. If we were getting him to be a starter, he wouldn't be ready. But the way we're going to use him, he's ready.''

title: A Quarter for the Old Guy Can't Hurt
description: LEAD: When I came to New York, I was struck by the occasional shapeless form lying on the street, with people stepping around it as if it wasn't there. In Tennessee, where I came from, we called an ambulance when we found someone on the street, or at least we tried to find out what was wrong. But New York wasn't Tennessee, and I was trying hard to be a New

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Baker Hughes Inc.
description: The Baker International Corporation and the Hughes Tool Company said that they had agreed to a Department of Justice consent decree and had completed their previously announced merger. The newly formed company, Baker Hughes Inc., with headquarters in Houston, will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday under its symbol, BHI, the company said. The proposed merger of the two Houston-based oilfield-services companies, which was originally announced in October, had faced objections from the Justice Department on antitrust grounds.

title: GROOM AND BEST MAN KILLED IN CAR CRASH AFTER L.I. WEDDING
description: A 27-year-old Long Island man, who had just been married, and his best man were killed on the way to a wedding reception in Lido Beach yesterday when a speeding car slammed into their limousine.

title: CITIES TURN INTO ENTREPRENEURS
description: The business of running local governments is getting ever more businesslike.

title: BUILDING TOO TALL, COURT SAYS
description: An appeals court has ruled that a condominium on the Upper East Side is 12 stories too tall and it may have to be partially dismantled unless a higher court grants relief. A lawyer for the developer said, meantime, that an appeal is planned.

title: GIANT YELLOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said it changed its method of calculating depreciation and amortization to the unit production method on Jan. 1, 1986.

title: 10TH TITLE BY MORALES
description: Pablo Morales of Stanford won his 10th national collegiate individual swimming title tonight, tying John Naber's career record. If Morales wins the 200-yard butterfly Saturday night, he will become the leading winner in the 64-year history of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's championships.

title: DIVISIVE ISSUE IN ISRAEL: RENEWING TIES WITH MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union may soon discover that it is much easier to break diplomatic relations with Israel than it is to improve them.

title: Sewage Plant Breaks Down
description: Nearly 23 million gallons of virtually raw sewage will flow into San Francisco Bay each day for the next week because of a breakdown at a treatment plant, officials say. Preliminary tests indicate that the sewage is not poisonous and is mixing with the treated output from several other plants before being discharged into San Leandro Bay, an official of the Union Sanitary District said Thursday.

title: PEC ISRAEL ECONOMIC CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $355,317 for the latest year and $2,059,388 for 1985. The prior year revenue includes about $1.3 million realized by the company as a result of the exchange of its shares of Canada-Israel Development Ltd. (CID) for its proportionate share of the fair market value of CID's net assets and cash. Corrected from Thursday, April 2, editions.

title: California Tornado Damage
description: A tornado ripped the roofs off 16 greenhouses as it swept through a large nursery today, injuring an employee of the nursery, the authorities said.

title: COURT REFUSES MOTHER A VISIT TO BABY M
description: A three-judge appeals court refused today Mary Beth Whitehead's request to suspend the sweeping ruling in the Baby M custody case during the appeal.

title: CALIFORNIA CITY IS CHARGED IN BUTTERFLY'S DEMISE
description: The combination of a rare blue butterfly, the plant commonly called locoweed and the construction of a baseball field has led to Federal criminal charges against the City of Rancho Palos Verdes.

title: William F. Shellman Jr., 70; Taught Architecture 45 Years
description: William Feay Shellman Jr., emeritus professor of architecture at Princeton University, died Wednesday at Princeton Medical Center. He was 70 years old and had been ill with cancer.

title: INSIDE
description: Vigilantes in Philippines Right-wing vigilante groups are spreading through the Philippines in a new approach to counterinsurgency endorsed by many officials. Page 5.

title: CUOMO BACKS PLAN
description: A sweeping revision of the New York State tax code -lowering the maximum tax rate on wages to 7 percent from the current 9 percent - was agreed to today by leaders of the State Legislature and appeared virtually certain to become law.

title: METS' RIVALS NOT BUOYED BY DOWNFALL OF GOODEN
description: There was no gloating today from the teams that stand to gain the most by the Mets' loss of Dwight Gooden, the very symbol of the club's success. Instead, there was sympathy for Gooden as a kind of national resource that nobody could afford to lose.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
White House Honors
description: President Reagan and the Indiana University basketball coach, Bobby Knight, traded compliments in the Rose Garden yesterday as the President welcomed the N.C.A.A. men's championship team to the White House one day after greeting the women's champions from the University of Tennessee. ''Critics aside, one thing is certain: Bobby cares deeply about his players on and off the court,'' the President said. ''When all is said and done, Bobby is my kind of coach.'' In response, Knight commented on his team's ability to rally in critical situations and said: ''Mr. President, I think you have shown all of us across America what it's like to be tough in critical situations, and we have great appreciation for your mental toughness and your competitiveness in situations in which you have been involved.''

title: ERVING HAS BIG 6-POINT NIGHT
description: It was May 12, 1976, and the Nets had just beaten the Denver Nuggets, 112-106, to win the American Basketball Association championship.

title: A's Get Eckersley
description: The Chicago Cubs traded Dennis Eckersley, a right-handed pitcher, to the Oakland A's yesterday in a five-player deal. Along with Eckersley, the Cubs sent Dan Roan, an infielder, to the A's for three minor league players - David Wilder, an outfielder; Brian Guinn, an infielder, and Mark Leonette, a right-handed pitcher. Eckersley, 32 years old, who came to the Cubs in June 1984 from the Boston Red Sox in a trade for Bill Buckner, the first baseman, posted a 10-8 record for the Cubs in '84 while helping them win the National League East. He was 11-7 in 1985 and fell to 6-11 last season with a 4.57 earned run average.

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: Michaels changed its fiscal year- end to Feb. 1 from a calendar year. For the 3 months ended Dec. 29, 1985, the company had net income of $1,133,000, or 12 cents a share, on sales of $36,519,000, and for the year it had net of $1,484,000, or 19 cents a share, on sales of $76,197,000.

title: HAGLER LOWERS HIS GUARD
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight champion, turned up in public today in a bright red cap modeled after the headgear worn by the French Foreign Legion, right down to the twin flaps hanging at the back of his shaven head.

title: Mellon Stock Drop Prompts Lawsuit
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation was named in a suit filed by a shareholder in response to the sharp drop in Mellon's stock price since the banking company reported on Thursday that it would post a first-quarter loss of $55 million to $65 million. The decline continued today, with Mellon's stock falling $3.625 to close at $40.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. It had dropped $6.25 on Thursday.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as fears subsided that the higher prime rate would spread to other lending costs, increasing inflation.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Stanley for Opener
description: Bob Stanley, returning to a starting role after six years in the Boston bullpen, was named to start for the Red Sox in their season opener at Milwaukee. Stanley was picked to replace Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, who has a sore pitching shoulder. Contract negotiations continued, meanwhile, with Roger Clemens, the team's star right-hander.

title: OSHAP TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures for both periods are based on a translation rate of 40.05 Belgian francs to each dollar.

title: South Korean Stocks Plunge
description: The South Korean stock market fell sharply today on news of Government plans to curb the boom that has pushed the share index up by more than 50 percent this year.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $6,758,000 from a change in accounting principles. c-After a charge of $1,264,000 from reversal of tax credit. Telephere said that because it changed its year-end to Dec. 31 from Jan. 31, the latest quarter includes only two months and the latest year, 11 months. The loss for the year includes about $6.6 million in writeoffs of dialers, inventory and cost for network configuration, and costs of about $2.5 million for implementing its national network backbone. Total writeoffs, accounting changes and non-recurring expenses were about $17.4 million.

title: David Watt, 55, Dies; British Political Writer
description: David Watt, a British journalist and political commentator, died on March 27 in an accident at his home in Lewknor, England. Mr. Watt was electrocuted when he picked up a live power line that had blown down across his driveway in a storm. He was 55 years old.

title: THE DANCE: TMU-NA, FROM ISRAEL
description: Theater of the Riverside Church offered a rare look at Israeli experimentalist theater and dance when it presented Tmu-Na on Thursday. The Tel-Aviv group, founded in 1982 by Nava Zukerman, takes its name from the Hebrew word for moving pictures. And that, essentially, is what this good-looking company presents on stage. But the work Tmu-Na chose for this New York debut engagement is a disappointing one.

title: PRESIDENT SCALES BACK PLANS FOR SPACE STATION OVER COSTS
description: President Reagan, who has enthusiastically supported a proposed space station, today scaled back the plans and approved a delay in the projected date for manning the station for research.

title: Group Riding Plan For Taxis to Start
description: A pilot program for group ridership in medallion taxicabs will begin Monday, formalizing a longstanding practice of riders sharing cabs from the Upper East Side to the financial district in lower Manhattan.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The University of South Alabama yesterday withdrew the coaching offer it made to Lefty Driesell, the former Maryland coach, citing the possibility he would become coach of a prospective pro basketball franchise in Charlotte, N.C. . . . Eddie Fogler, who in his first year as basketball coach at Wichita State won 22 games, the Missouri Valley Conference postseason tournament and a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, has received a one-year extension on his four-year contract, Fogler, a native of Flushing, Queens, served for 13 seasons as assistant to Dean Smith at North Carolina before taking the job with the Shockers. . . . Bob Chipman of Washburn University, whose team won the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics men's basketball championship last month, has been named N.A.I.A. coach of the year in a mail vote of coaches. . . . Five National Hockey League players - four from the Devils - have been named to the United States National Hockey Team for the World Championships in Vienna, April 17-May 3. Jim Johnson of the Pittsburgh Penguins was named along with New Jersey's Aaron Broten, Mark Johnson, Craig Wolanin and Chris Terreri, the goaltender. Neither the Penguins nor the Devils qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Jersey Well Water Tests Show No PCB Traces
description: New tests on drinking-water wells near the Texas Eastern Gas Pipeline in West Amwell, N.J., have found no detectable traces of PCB's, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency reported today.

title: 3 G.I.'s Die in Colorado Blast
description: An explosive charge used to clear minefields blew up prematurely in a training exercise today, killing three soldiers, an Army spokeswoman said. No one else was injured in the accident. The victims' names were being withheld until relatives could be notified, said the spokeswoman, Specialist 4 Kim Hoppens of the Fort Carson public affairs office.

title: RISE IN VALUES SPURS RESCUE OF BUILDINGS
description: Two months ago, tenants of a once-elegant, turn-of-the-century Harlem building were preparing to celebrate.

title: HURDLE MAKES CLUB AS NO. , CATCHER
description: The Mets, still trying to piece together the team after the loss of Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell, made a surprise move today when they cut John Gibbons and kept Clint Hurdle as the No. 3 catcher.

title: Electricity Prices in New York Are Not Too Low
description: To the Editor:

title: 65-M.P.H. SIGNS SPROUT OUT WEST, BUT NEW YORK REGION HOLDS OFF
description: The rush was on yesterday to raise highway speed limits to 65 miles an hour, but New York, New Jersey and Connecticut seem unlikely to join the stampede.

title: Allied's Amphenol To Be Sold to LPL
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its Amphenol Corporation to LPL Investment Group for $430 million in cash. Amphenol, which makes connectors for electrical cables, had operating income of $33 million on sales of $487 million in 1986. That sales figure is roughly five times the 1986 revenues of LPL.

title: CHINA HELPING U.S. ON SOVIET A-TESTS
description: The United States is using monitoring devices in China to improve estimates of the size of Soviet nuclear tests, according to Defense Department documents and interviews with Administration officials.

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for 14wks to Jan 3
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pre-tax expense of $1,576,000 from the purchase of the company's common stock at a premium in settlement of a lawsuit for both the 14 weeks and 53 weeks. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,000 and $15,000 for the 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, from early extinguishment of debt; and the year also includes pre-tax net capital gains of $1,257,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Chapter 11 For Air Atlanta
description: Air Atlanta, the three-year-old airline that was the brainchild of a black businessman, Michael R. Hollis, filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. All of its flights were grounded immediately, and its workers were laid off.

title: TV DEALS WITH SEX MORE CANDIDLY
description: Sex, long a prime target for television's censors, has been gaining prime-time exposure this season.

title: Corrections
description: A Jerusalem dispatch on Wednesday about Soviet Jewish emigration misstated the nationality of Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress. (A dispatch on Thursday about Israeli-Soviet relations, in discussing world Jewish leaders, similarly mischaracterized him by implication.) Mr. Bronfman, who was born in Canada, is an American citizen.

title: Joe Williams
description: Joe Williams will sing today at 9 and 11 P.M. at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). There is a $20 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: A KRESGE-McCRORY REUNION
description: In 1897, Sebastian S. Kresge and John G. McCrory together opened the first Kresge store in Memphis, offering ''a variety'' of 5-to-10-cent merchandise from stationery to combs to sewing supplies. Mr. McCrory, who had already been operating a small chain in Pennsylvania under his own name, eventually left the partnership to concentrate on his own business.

title: SOLDIER WHO KNEW HE CARRIED AIDS VIRUS FACES ASSAULT CHARGES
description: An Army private has been accused of aggravated assault for reportedly having sexual relations with two other soldiers when he knew he carried the AIDS virus.

title: 40 Years After the Pivotal Article by ''X''
description: LEAD: The main issue in the summer of 1947, the second summer after World War II ended, was, as it is today, how to deal with the Soviet Union. The two key debaters were intellectual giants. Arguing what might be called the hard line was George F. Kennan, then 43 years old, chairman of the State Department's policy planning council, a talented and experienced diplomat who had, despite relative youth, become a ''wise man'' adviser to the nation's leadership.

title: FOR BIRDES, ALL ROADS LEAD TO KLEINFELD'S
description: These are the times that try brides' souls. It's 10:50 A.M. on Fifth Avenue - Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, that is. In precisely 10 minutes, I. Kleinfeld & Son, the store that is to wedding gowns what the Pentagon is to fighter bombers, will open.

title: Ex-Middie to Bengals
description: Steve Fehr, Navy's career-leading field-goal kicker, who has spent the last five years on active duty in the Marine Corps, has been signed as a free agent by the Cincinnati Bengals. The 6-foot, 185-pound soccer-style kicker, who is 28 years old, made good on 44 of 62 field-goal attempts in his three seasons with the Middies.

title: How Lindsay Helped Race Relations
description: The racial violence in Howard Beach has focused increased public attention on race relations citywide. Such concern is overdue. Tensions remain high, and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has warned of the possibility that violence will erupt in communities around the city this summer. Howard Beach may only be the tip of the iceberg.

title:
PATENTS;
Utility Meters in Homes Are Read Automatically
description: LEAD: Equipment to permit all utility meters in a home to be read automatically, at any time, by a utility's central computer has been invented by Edwin F. Shelley of New Rochelle, N.Y. He was granted patent 4,654,868 this week for what is trade-named the Hometron.

title: Fed Money Policy Unchanged
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in early February, but they indicated that they were ready to tighten credit if forced to by economic conditions, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: U.S. Indicts 3 in Cuba Sales
description: Three men were indicted today on charges of selling more than $1 million in computer equipment to a company for shipment to Cuba, violating the Trading With the Enemy Act.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 28 U.S. monitoring devices in China are being used to improve estimates of the size of Soviet nuclear tests, according to Defense Department documents and interviews with Administration officials. Page 1 Two more marines are implicated in violations of security rules at the United States Embassy in Moscow, raising concerns that they may have allowed Soviet agents to enter the building, Representative Les Aspin said. 1 News analysis: Soviet-Israeli ties are so explosive an issue that any Israeli government seeking to resume an alliance with Moscow will face political obstacles that could stall the budding Soviet-Israeli detente. 3 Hungary denounced Rumania in an expansion of a long-smoldering dispute between the two European allies of the Soviet Union. The dispute centers on the right to identity of about 2 million Hungarians who live in Rumania. 5 Vigilante groups in the Phillipines get support from many military and Government leaders, including Corazon C. Aquino, even as fears have grown that a new form of anti-Communist armed terror has taken root in this violent nation. 5 In Chile, the police used tear gas and water cannons to battle anti-Govern ment protesters as Pope John Paul II was saying a beatification mass in a large public park. 3 Greece may seize church property within six months, under legislation approved by Parliament. The decision sharpened a fierce dispute between the Greek Orthodox church and the state. 3 Japan is talking about 'Iwate shock,' a phrase symbolizing the strong, widening opposition to the Prime Minister's plans for a new 5 percent sales tax, that started in Morioka and the rest of Iwate Prefecture, a rice-growing center. 2 Far-right Afrikaaners have established an electoral stronghold in Nylstroom, about 80 miles north of Pretoria. The Conservative leader, Andries P. Treurnicht, is assured of another victory there. 4 Portugal's government falls 2 New split over P.L.O. amity effort 28 Palestinian aid blocked in Beirut 28 NATIONAl 6-8, 14 A stampede to raise the speed limit on highways in largely rural states to 65 miles an hour was not being followed in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where all three Governors have made clear their opposition. 1 On Wall Street, a grand flourish in the stock market capped off a tumultuous week. The Dow Jones industrial average tallied its largest single-day advance ever, pushing up nearly 70 points just five days after it plummeted almost 60 points. 1 Lack of unity in the Republican Party has been revealed by the overriding of the President's veto of the highway bill, Senate Republicans said, raising concern about their effectiveness as a minority. 14 The unemployment rate edged down to 6.5 percent in March but job growth slowed sharply, the Government reported. The data were on the whole less robust than expected, analysts said. 7 Space station plans were scaled back by the President, who approved a delay in the projected date for manning the station for research, a decision designed to cut the project's rapidly rising estimated costs. 6 When Dallas voters go to the polls Saturday they will be deciding the most costly and perhaps the most wide-open mayoral election in the city's history. Four wealthy, probusiness contenders are politely vying for the job. 6 Smoking restrictions in Beverly Hills limit it in most restaurants, retail stores and at public meetings under a new law. The ordinance was passed unanimously by the Beverly Hills City Council last month. 6 Indictments against neo-Nazis in Arkansas may be issued soon, officials say. A Federal grand jury has investigated terrorist activity by right-wing extremist groups for months. 7 Use of child labor in New England appears to be increasing, a response to a shortage of workers created by demographic changes and an economy with growing opportunities in low-skilled hourly jobs. 7 A storm snarled the Deep South with its first April snow accumulation on record, closing schools, disrupting power to thousands and dropping more than a foot of snow on Appalachia. 8 Lightning tied to rocket failure 6 F.B.I. investigates Thiokol 6 Regional 29-31, 50 Revision of New York's tax code -lowering the maximum tax rate on wages to 7 percent from the current 9 percent - was agreed to today by leaders of the State Legislature and appeared virtually certain to become law. 1 Jersey has the lowest unemployment rate among industrial states, the Department of Labor said. Massachusetts had held the number one spot for 36 months, but in March, its rate was 3.9 percent, while New Jersey's was 3.7 percent. 1 Siphoning of funds from the Intrepid Air-Sea-Space Museum was disclosed by investigators. They said labor racketeering by a Manhattan gang called the Westies defrauded the museum of extensive funds. 1 An upstate hotel may be a shelter for homeless men from New York City. If the plan goes ahead and weathers opposition, up to 600 men would live and work at the Catskills resort. 29 No stay on the Baby M ruling will be granted pending an appeal, a three-judge appeals court ruled in refusing Mary Beth Whitehead's request. The judges said they did not want to disrupt the child's life. 29 More AIDS patients in hospitals in New York City are taking up beds that Federal health planners said would not be needed for AIDS victims until 1990, private and municipal hospital officials said. 31 A setback for the 63d Street subway tunnel came when Federal officials said they would not release money for the project's completion until the Transit Authority proved it would meet fire safety standards. 31 ''Black cars'' take over from taxis 29 Rise in values spurs rescue of buildings 29 Ethics money may be denied 30 TV mouse roars back at Mayor 31 Scalia on the law and morals 32

title: LEGISLATORS APPEAR SET TO DENY ETHICS MONEY
description: Key legislators in Albany are prepared to deny funds for a commission that Governor Cuomo has proposed to investigate possible unethical conduct in state government, according to people close to the discussions.

title:
PATENTS;
Patent Chief Amenable To 'First to File' Shift
description: LEAD: Donald J. Quigg, Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, said this week that, if other countries made acceptable concessions in their patent laws, he would be willing to recommend legislation to grant a patent to the first person who applies rather than, as now required, to the first inventor of the device or process.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SMOKING BAN CLEARS AIR BUT ASH TRAYS STAY
description: As of today, smoke-hazed lunches and dinners in Beverly Hills restaurants are a thing of the past. In most restaurants, anyway.

title: ROCKET FAILURE TIED TO STORM
description: A pinpoint hole in a charred chunk of a failed satellite rocket was strong evidence the rocket was hit by lightning before it broke apart last week, the head of an investigation team said today.

title: A Michelangelo Find Waiting to Be Made?
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Electrical Fracture Treatment
description: LEAD: AN apparatus for applying electricity to the body in order to stimulate the repair or growth of bones was patented this week by Sheldon Thaler of Princeton, N.J. Mr. Thaler, who plans to grant licenses for the apparatus, is vice president of Geomed Inc., a medical products company in Middlesex, N.J.

title: Perry E. Nussbaum, 79, Rights Figure in South
description: Rabbi Perry E. Nussbaum, a civil rights figure in the 1950's and 1960's, died Monday of cancer in San Diego. He was 79 years old. In 1967 Rabbi Nussbaum, a former resident of Jackson, Miss., became the first white clergyman whose home and house of worship were dynamited by racists. His synagogue, Temple Beth Israel, was bombed in September and his home two months later.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a $156,000 reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,041,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $2,257,000 and $3,589,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Florida Battles Fruit Fly
description: Four million sterile Mediterranean fruit flies were dropped over 49 square miles of Florida today as part of the state's battle to eradicate the insect, which is a threat to Florida's citrus industry. Agriculture officials hope the sterile flies will mate with female fruit flies. The result is infertile eggs. A total of 200 million sterile flies will be released within the next three months.

title: SPLIT OVER P.L.O. RECONCILIATION
description: A split has developed in a major Palestinian guerrilla group over efforts to close ranks within the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: PORTUGAL'S GOVERNMENT FALLS
description: A censure vote on the economy today brought down Portugal's 16th Government since a military coup ended half a century of right-wing dictatorship in 1974.

title: DOWNFALL OF NAKASONE? IT COULD BE A TAX PLAN
description: This rice-growing center in northern Japan is an unlikely place to start a revolt. But if Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is forced into early retirement, as seems increasingly possible, Morioka and the rest of Iwate Prefecture is where his downward slide began.

title: VOTE OF CONFIDENCE FOR PINIELLA
description: Remember, you heard it here first.

title: REPUBLICANS BLAME THEMSELVES ON HIGHWAY VETO
description: Republicans in the Senate said today that the overriding of President Reagan's veto of the highway bill revealed a troublesome party weakness that, if not corrected, would render the party an ineffective minority.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $574,363 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $444,932 and $537,950 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NORTH EAST INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: EUROPEAN GROUP
description: The Chamber Orchestra of Europe is an interesting idea, and the first of its three New York-area concerts Thursday night in Carnegie Hall -the end of a two-week United States tour - had its moments. But not enough moments to make for a truly memorable evening.

title: ON SOUTH AFRICA RIGHT, LIFE IS BLACK AND WHITE
description: ''I would rather have a small South Africa that is white than a big South Africa that is dominated by a black majority!'' the leader of South Africa's far-right Conservative Party thundered to a packed hall in this northern Transvaal farming town on Tuesday.

title: DALLAS FACING MAYORAL RACE TODAY
description: In most other cities, the prospect of four wealthy, probusiness contenders rather politely vying for the job of Mayor might make for pretty dull politics.

title: IN NEW ENGLAND, LOW UNEMPLOYMENT SPURS A NEW 'CHILD LABOR'
description: Textbook and dictionary at hand, occasionally chewing on her ballpoint pen, Joy Paradis was doing her Latin homework as she sat behind a pastry wagon in the Maine Mall, pausing now and then to serve an occasional customer.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
'Star Wars' Defies Laws of Physics
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERMARK GAMING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JERSEY BEST OFF OF BIGGEST STATES IN JOBLESS RATES
description: New Jersey has replaced Massachusetts as the major industrial state with the lowest unemployment rate in the nation, according to the United States Department of Labor.

title: Nicaraguan Peace Will Take More Than Promises From Managua
description: To the Editor:

title: SCALIA ON THE LAW AND MORALS
description: Associate Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court said Thursday night that the laws of the United States could suffer from an ''erosion of moral responsibility'' if Americans continued to honor what is technically legal over what is morally right.

title: COUSINS PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
EXPERTS PONDER GOODEN'S DESIRE FOR TEST
description: A puzzling aspect of Dwight Gooden's misfortune is why he seemed so willing - even eager - to be tested for cocaine use when it would surely show that he had recently used the drug.

title: FILM: 'POLICE ACADEMY 4'
description: The Police Academy series seems to shoot for an ever younger crowd. The optimum viewer for ''Police Academy 4: Citizens on Patrol,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, would be a 10-year-old boy. Even better, it would be a whole pack of them. That's not to say the film isn't funny; it means only that the sense of humor being addressed is very specific. Stay away if drawing room farce is what you're after.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the quarter and net from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $1,383,000 and $1,941,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RAIN MAY DAMPEN CAPOTE'S CHANCES
description: ''D. Wayne off the plane!'' is a rallying cry among New York horseplayers who are accustomed to watching horses from the D. Wayne Lukas stable win major races after being flown here from California. But what about D. Wayne in the rain?

title: Safeway to End Dallas Division
description: Safeway Stores Inc., the largest supermarket chain in the country, said today that it would pull out of the northern Texas market, either closing or selling the 141 stores in its Dallas division by April 24.

title: U.S. QUESTIONS FIRE SAFETY OF 63D ST. SUBWAY TUNNEL
description: In another setback for the 63d Street subway tunnel in New York City, Federal officials said yesterday that they would not release money for the project's completion until the Transit Authority proved that it would meet fire safety standards.

title: Big Board to Move N.Y.F.E.
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its board had reached an agreement to relocate a subsidiary, the New York Futures Exchange, to the floor of the New York Cotton Exchange at 4 World Trade Center. The agreement is subject to approval by the board of the Cotton Exchange, which is expected to act Tuesday.

title: INTERFUND CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $7,500. c-Net loss

title: RIGHT-WING VIGILANTES SPREADING IN PHILIPPINES
description: A year ago in the densely populated urban shantytown of Agdao, three men gunned down a notorious Communist hit man, raised their rifles and shouted, ''Arise, masses!''

title: Open House at the Y
description: Young adults who would like to learn about summer activities sponsored by the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, can attend a free open house tomorrow at the Y. Among the offerings for those 12 to 17 years old are workshops in bicycle repair, playwriting, singing and video production, as well as day-trip and day-camp programs. The open house runs from 2 to 4 P.M. Information: 996-1100.

title: Schizophrenia Telethon
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENT CLASHES BREAK OUT AS POPE SAYS MASS IN CHILE
description: The police used tear gas and water cannons today to battle anti-Government protesters as Pope John Paul II was saying a beatification mass in a large public park. Gunshots were reportedly fired during the clashes and scores of people were said to have been injured.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings reflect the issuance of additional shares in conjunction with the April 1986 conversion of 9 7/8 percent convertible debentures as if such conversion had taken place at the beginning of fiscal 1986.

title: BID RAISED TO $110 FOR GENCORP
description: An investor group led by Wagner & Brown of Texas and AFG Industries of California tentatively sweetened its takeover bid for Gencorp Inc. yesterday by $225 million, raising its offer to $2.46 billion.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Man Arrested in Torture Case Tries to Hang Himself in Jail
description: A man charged with murder after the police found three women chained in his basement and body parts in his freezer tried to hang himself in jail Thursday but was not seriously injured, the authorities said.

title: Convert Doesn't Pay
description: Ever since World War II, Presidents have been using ''covert operations'' to pursue political aims that they did not want to admit - often with consequences damaging to the United States as well as to the target nation.

title: THE PERFECT WEDDING: ONLY TEARS A JOY
description: Martha Stewart has a perfect life. The exotic Araucana chickens she raises at her Westport, Conn., ''farmette'' are perfect. The azalea bushes she planted in the garden for her husband, Andy, for Father's Day are perfect. The herbed potpourri lying just so in her guest bathroom is perfect.

title: DOW INDUSTRIALS SURGE 69.89 POINTS IN RECORD SHOWING
description: The stock market capped off a tumultuous week yesterday with a flourish, as the Dow Jones industrial average soared 69.89 points - its largest single-day advance ever.

title: Possibilities of Love
description: WALKING DISTANCE. By Marian Thurm. 279 pages. Random House. $16.95.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $3,856,000 for the latest year and $3,245,000 for the year-earlier period; and the latest year also includes an after-tax non-recurring loss of about $2 million related to the restructuring of Standard Security Life Insurance Co. of New York.

title: JOBLESS RATE DOWN BUT GROWTH OF JOBS ALSO FALLS
description: The nation's unemployment rate edged downward to 6.5 percent in March but job growth slowed sharply, the Government reported today.

title:
PATENTS;
Way Found to Produce Cumulus Rain Clouds
description: LEAD: A method of producing cumulus rain clouds was patented this week for the Navy. Patent 4,653,690 was granted on the weather modification to Pierre St. Amand and Larry A. Mathews, employees at the naval base at China Lake, Calif.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We clearly failed in our procedures and the way we have gone about the job.'' - Arthur A. Hartman, former Ambassador to Moscow. [ 4:6. ]

title: 39-6 Run Tops Knicks, 126-89
description: Dominique Wilkins and Mike McGee each went on hot shooting streaks as the Atlanta Hawks outscored the Knicks, 39-6, in an 11-minute span of the second half on the way to a 126-89 victory tonight.

title: STRATEGIC PLANNING ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05P.M. (TV - Channel 9, 1 P.M.; Radio -WHN 1050, 1 P.M.). YANKEES VS. BALTIMORE ORIOLES, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:15P.M.).

title: 'The First Guy To Fly'
description: In his final house call in Phoenix not long ago, Doctor J was applauded by thousands of patients wearing surgical caps and masks. Before his last incision in other National Basketball Association operating rooms, he received a total of about $50,000 in donations to the Lupus Foundation, dedicated to a cure for the disease that took the life of his brother Marvin at age 16 several years ago.

title: Food for Besieged Beirut District Is Destroyed
description: A new attempt to get food to the besieged Palestinian refugee district of Shatila in southern Beirut failed today when a truck was hit by a rocket as it reached the district.

title: AMID SCANDALS, FUNDAMENTALISTS SEEK CONSOLATION
description: ''This is terribly upsetting,'' said Ginger Harney, a 76-year-old California woman, who was sending money to the TV evangelists Jim and Tammy Bakker until the scandal involving charges of adultery, hush money and drug abuse erupted. Ms. Harney said she has cried herself to sleep several nights since.

title: Lawsuit Seeks Silver Of Convicted Killer
description: A New Jersey businessman, who was sentenced to death for arranging to kill his wife, is being sued by her estate to collect silver bars he and his former lover bought, a lawyer for the estate said.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed these trouble spots for weekend traffic:

title: AUTO SALES ROSE 19.3% IN LATE MARCH
description: Automobile sales rebounded in the last third of March, to show a 19.3 percent increase over the 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. Sales of domestically made light trucks were strong as well.

title: ALTERNACARE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $418,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Webster Hearings to Begin
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that hearings on William H. Webster's nomination to become the Director of Central Intelligence would begin next Wednesday. Mr. Webster, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is expected to face questioning about the F.B.I.'s connection, if any, to the Iran-contra affair. He was nominated last month by President Reagan to replace William J. Casey.

title: CARRIER-MUSEUM CALLED TARGET OF RACKETEERS
description: Labor racketeering by a Manhattan gang called the Westies siphoned off extensive funds from the air-sea-space museum on the aircraft carrier Intrepid, investigators disclosed yesterday.

title: THE STAGE: SEVEN ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: If the prospect of seeing seven new one-act plays over two evenings seems daunting, here's a suggestion: Choose Evening A of the Class One Acts annual festival, dally over dinner and get to the Nat Horne Theater at intermission, about 9:30. You'll be in time for ''Beirut,'' Alan Bowne's stunner about love in the plague years.

title: Sonics' Lister Out
description: The National Basketball Association playoff hopes of the Seattle SuperSonics took a severe blow Thursday night when Alton Lister, the 7-foot center who is the team's top rebounder, shot-blocker and fourth-leading scorer, suffered a fractured right foot in a 117-114 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers. After making a layup late in the first half, he left the game with what was believed to be a sprained ankle. But postgame X-rays revealed a fracture. Clemon Johnson is expected to start at center in the team's remaining regular-season games and perhaps in the playoffs.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $3,256,000 for a prepayment penalty for the early retirement of debt. c-Includes a charge of $970,000 for the reversal of income tax credit for the quarter; and the year includes a credit of $6,418,000 primarily from the gains on the sale of branches. The company said the latest year results include $68,000,000 in loan losses and $13,000,000 for the writedown of real estate.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about television shows taped before studio audiences carried an incorrect time for recording of ''Best Talk in Town'' for Channel 11 in New York. It begins Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at 4:15 P.M., not 4:45.

title: 2 MORE MARINES CALLED SUSPECTS IN MOSCOW EMBASSY SECURITY CASE
description: Two more marines who served at the United States Embassy in Moscow have been implicated in violations of security rules, raising concerns that they may have allowed Soviet agents into the building, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said today.

title: NORTHWEST GIVES AIRBUS A $2.5 BILLION JET ORDER
description: The European Airbus consortium announced today that it had received an order worth at least $2.5 billion from Northwest Airlines for a proposed line of passenger jets that would compete with American-made planes. The deal bolsters the likelihood that the aircraft, still on the drawing board, will be put into production.

title: Judge Reverses Ruling In Allende Visa Case
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the Government illegally barred the widow of former Chilean President Salvador Allende Gossens from entering the United States for speaking engagements in 1983.

title: CATSKILLS HOTEL SUGGESTED FOR HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration is considering buying a hotel in the Catskill Mountains as a residence for homeless men.

title: Eligibility at Issue
description: The United States Olympic Committee began its annual meeting today, but the key debate is expected Saturday on the question of eligibility.

title: Severance Deals At Harper & Row
description: Harper & Row Publishers Inc. has entered into severance agreements, commonly known as ''golden parachutes,'' with 34 of its senior executives. The conditions of the agreements would become effective with Rupert Murdoch's planned $300 million takeover of the New York-based publishing concern.

title: Tommy Davis, Ex-49er, Dies; Set Record for Extra Points
description: Tommy Davis, a record-setting kicker with the San Francisco 49ers, died of lung cancer Thursday at his home in San Bruno, Calif., his relatives here reported today. He was 52 years old.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: PERIODIC TESTING URGED FOR GOODEN
description: Probation officials in Florida will recommend that Dwight Gooden be required to submit to periodic drug testing during the three years he is on probation in connection with his no-contest plea to felony charges last January.

title: BRIEFS
description: * British Telecommunications P.L.C., London, said it would begin to market electronic data transmission equipment of its own design in North America.

title: U2 STARTS NATIONAL TOUR ON A POLITICAL NOTE
description: A national tour by the Irish rock band U2 got off to a controversial start Thursday night at Arizona State University in Tempe. The group issued a statement before the show deploring Gov. Evan Meacham's recent rescission of a state holiday on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, and announcing that they had made a financial contribution to a committee for the Governor's recall.

Thus, there is an incentive to discharge Medicare patients sooner. 5. title: NEW YORK HOSPITALS REPORT RISE IN NUMBER OF AIDS PATIENTS
description: The number of AIDS patients in private and municipal hospitals in New York City increased by one-third during the last 12 months, taking up beds that Federal health planners said would not be needed for AIDS victims until 1990, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: HUNGARY REBUKES RUMANIA ON RIGHTS
description: In an expansion of a long-smoldering dispute between two European allies of the Soviet Union, Hungary has issued a strong denunciation of neighboring Rumania.

title: TWO WAYS TO RESPOND TO TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane E. Berentson Is Wed To Frederick R. Bleakley
description: Jane Elliott Berentson, managing editor of Corporate Finance magazine in New York, and Frederick Robert Bleakley, an assistant business editor of The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in Manhattan by William G. Thymius, the executive assistant to the city clerk.

title: Pakistan Offers Nuclear Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'RETURN TO THE RIVER' IN AFRICA
description: A few minutes after the lights go up on ''Return to the River,'' we know we are in for a consciousness-going-up session as Al Gilroy, a black attorney for an American oil company, arrives at the awareness that South Africa is his problem. The play's problem is that of many problem-plays: characters tend to become walking pamphlets and the stage becomes a lecture platform.

title: THE GOLFING MACHINE
description: SCATTERED ROUND the sixth green at Torrey Pines golf course, just outside San Diego, are some of the most noble mugs and beloved shapes in golf: Andy Bean, golf's Li'l Abner; Raymond Floyd, shoehorned into beige polyester; sweet, sad Tom Kite, and ''the Walrus,'' Craig Stadler.

title: Battling Harassment as Clinton Gentrifies
description: NO ONE lives in 814 Tenth Avenue. Rows of arched windows, lifeless and cavelike, stare mutely at the street, forlorn as voided checks.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''People who were expecting clone killers were disappointed. I.B.M. has not rolled over and crushed the competition.'' - Richard A. Shaffer, editor, Technologic Computer Letter, on I.B.M's new computers.

title: Amy Fern Sklar, Lawyer, To Wed R. B. Kremnitzer
description: Announcement has been made by Evelyn Sklar of Fort Lee, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Amy Fern Sklar, to Ronald Bruce Kremnitzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kremnitzer of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Lynn M. Hattrick to Marry Francis X. Mara on June 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hattrick of Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lynn Marie Hattrick to Francis Xavier Mara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington Mara of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is to be June 20.

title: FRENCH FARE IN BETHEL
description: FROMISES, promises - too many restaurants promise too much. But attractive decor, agreeable service and an appealing menu do not satisfy if the food misses the mark.

title: The Price of Prejudice
description: 'The stiff criminal penalties and civil remedies provided for in this bill represent our recognition of the particularly serious consequences to victims, the community and the public order when violent acts motivated by prejudice and hate are committed.' Robert Abrams New York State Attorney General, commenting on legislation proposed by Governor Cuomo to increase penalties for racially motivated violence.

title: FLOWING PROFILES FOR FALL
description: In one of the first fall and winter showings in New York, shiny seams undulated down the back of a coat, the fronts of some jackets, skirts and a halter-neck dress. If one looked closely, the wavy lines formed a profile. Sometimes the profiles were subtly outlined in black thread on black wool or jersey. At the back of a two-color melton coat they were more obvious, serving as the dividing line between wine and black sections.
