title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: Battle for Dien BienPhu Written, directed and produced by Peter Batty. Narrated by Bernard Archard. Evergreen Video Society. (Available through mail order (212) 714-9860). 49 minutes. $35.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan to Canada Today

title: SAFETY DEVICES FAIL IN NEW SUBWAY CARS
description: Electrical controllers - sometimes called the brains of a subway car -have been failing on many of the two newest models in the city's fleet, according to Transit Authority officials.

title: Virginia Daly to Wed
description: Mrs. William Patrick Daly of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Virginia Adkins Daly, to Martin Patrick Cusack, the son of Mrs. Martin Vincent Cusack, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Cusack. Ms. Daly, the daughter also of the late Mr. Daly, is an editor for the special projects division of Adweek magazine in New York. Her fiance is a senior rating analyst for Insurance Services Office Inc. in New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Postings: Rudiments of Repairs; Super School
description: A mouse shoots across the floor. The oven conks out before dinner. A ring slips down the drain and lodges in a pipe below.

title: Homosexuals' Political Power Tested in West
description: This city's large homosexual population will test its political strength Tuesday in a special election to fill the unexpired Congressional term of the late Sala Burton.

title:
GARDENING;
A CHARMING BORDER WITH DIVERSITY
description: LEAD: THE charm of a well-planned herbaceous border lies in the great diversity within that group of plants called herbaceous perennials. Each species, hybrid or cultivar has its own unique characteristics, and the number of perennials is so great that there can be little excuse from the early spring through late summer for having an uninteresting border.

title: IT'S TIME TO USE THE SPADE AND TROWEL
description: THE rush is on to plant, rake, feed and seed. Even though the weather is ''iffy'' at times, April is the month to put the garden in order. Rake, feed and seed bare spots in lawns. But tender vegetables and annuals should be kept waiting until next month; this means delay planting of peppers, tomatoes, eggplants and seed of beans, especially limas, corn, squash and melons. Flowering plants such as impatiens, marigolds, coleus and petunias also need warmer soil and nights until they can be set out. Roses. Clean up and remove any of last season's leaves, prune and feed all rosebushes; start the spray program to discourage diseases. Weeds. A perennial problem, they are best conquered before the plants appear. This means putting down pre-emergent weed controls on lawns especially to control crabgrass. For lawn grasses the most common pre-emergent weed controls are benefin, bensulide, trifluran and siduron. These materials should be put down when the forsythia blooms and before lilac fades. Trifluran is also now packaged under several trade names for use on garden borders and utility areas where it can prevent unsightly weeds from sprouting. But read the rate/caution label carefully before application, as some ornamental plants are particularly sensitive to pre-emergent weed control. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS EARLY RHODODENDRON

title: M.T.A. ON ROAD TO FINANCIAL BONDAGE?
description: WHEN their $8.6 billion capital improvement plan finally was approved in Albany last week, officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority barely paused to celebrate. In short order, they signed contracts for 200 new subway cars, the renovation of 290 old cars and 300 new buses from General Motors.

title: PROSTITUTES' ROLE IN AIDS SURVEYED
description: LEAD: EARLY data from a federally sponsored study of prostitutes in northern New Jersey show that 57 percent may be infected with AIDS, a rate seven times higher than the average for other metropolitan areas where similar studies were made.

title: MULTITUDE OF ITEMS AT HARTFORD SHOW
description: FROM Washington and 13 states on the Eastern Seaboard and in the Middle West, from Madison Avenue in Manhattan to the Glass Factory Schoolhouse Road in Willington, Conn., antique dealers will assemble in Hartford Friday, Saturday and Sunday for the 14th annual Connecticut Spring Antiques Show.

title: A SMALL TOWN, A TINY GYM, AND A HERO
description: WHEN I was 8 years old and living with my family in two large rooms on the second floor of a white frame house in a small South Dakota town, one of my winter diversions was an imaginary basketball game played with a rolled-up sock lofted toward the space between the top of a door frame and the ceiling. Although that was almost 40 years ago I remember the inner voice that guided me:

title: U.S. Denies New Sales Of Arms to the Iranians
description: The Pentagon has denied an NBC News report broadcast Friday night that military equipment continued to be sold to Iran after the Reagan Administration had called a halt to such dealings.

title: The Japanese Left Us With Little Choice
description: WHEN President Reagan announced that he would impose sanctions in response to Japan's failure to comply with last year's semiconductor agreement, it created shock waves around the world. Stock, bond and currency markets were temporarily thrown into turmoil, the result, many analysts said, of fears of an impending trade war. These fears are unfounded, a fact that the markets' subsequent rebound shows is widely understood.

title: IN OLYMPICS OPPORTUNITY FOR MISCHIEF
description: For the last six years, ever since this capital won the right to stage the 1988 Summer Olympics, the Games have loomed as South Korea's equivalent to the Promised Land.

title: Mary Stuart
description: To the Editor: Ann Pringle Harris's ''Edinburgh Off Season'' (Travel, Feb. 8) is replete with invaluable suggestions for any season in that fascinating city. For travelers seeking ''Where to Dine'' information, I strongly recommend Hendersons (Hanover Street) for vegetarians and nonvegetarians and the Celtic Tea Room (opposite Lady Stairs House) on the Royal Mile for outstanding homemade soup.

title: 'Our Shad Leap and Dance'
description: When it comes to spring migrations, the birds get most of the attention. But another migration, hardly noticed, is beginning now as the fish start their annual homecoming up the Hudson River. The finny migrants keep out of sight and make no noise that man can hear as they move along the city's shores, only a few feet above those other river travelers making their daily trips through the Hudson tunnels.

title: SOLD: VINCENT'S FADED YELLOW, A DUTCHESS' GOLDEN CACHE
description: CALL it the week of the acquisitive. The world of million-dollar auctioneering had rarely experienced such an overheated display as occurred on a few nights this week, here and in London, in the name of art and romance.

title: Edith C. Keenan Is Married
description: Edith Collins Keenan and Gordon Lindane Barker, graduates of the University of New Hampshire, were married yesterday at the Stratham (N.H.) Community Church, United Church of Christ, by the Rev. Jay Bodine. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. John Cavanagh Keenan of Irvington, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. C.Warren Barker of Stratham. The bride owns and operates Fresh Cut Flowers by Edie in Stratham. Mr. Barker, a Selectman in Stratham, manages the family-owned vegtable farm.

title: NEW LAWS IMPACT MOST AT THE SLAM LEVEL
description: THE new Laws of Duplicate Bridge, which came into force on April 1, have no impact on social players. Many of the changes will be unnoticed by the duplicate community. But the law on claims and concessions has been strengthened, requiring any clarifying statement to be made immediately rather than, as happened in a recent national tournament, after prolonged thought. The law on leading from the wrong hand has been weakened: The declarer can be required to lead from the correct hand, but is not obliged to lead the same suit.

title: Fistfights Erupt at Meeting Of Opposition Party in Seoul
description: Fistfights broke out at the headquarters of the main opposition party today after about 200 supporters of an opposition legislator stormed in to protest a disciplinary hearing he is facing.

title: Pope Speaks Out For Democracy In Tense Chile
description: Pope John Paul II took on Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile's authoritarian President, in statements and gestures last week that heartened opposition politicians and human rights advocates.

title: 1,091 Furs Lead to 1 Arrest
description: Shortly after 2 A.M. yesterday, on the rain-soaked roof of a garment-district building, the police said, they found 1,091 fur pelts, one sable coat and George Koutsakis of Astoria, Queens.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Bessie Smith And Friends With Lena Horne, Eubie Blake, Nina Mae McKinney, the Nicholas Brothers. Jazz Classics, a division of Videofidelity. 39 minutes. $19.95.

title: LACK OF FIGURES ON RACIAL STRIFE FUELING DISPUTE
description: Underlying a debate that has been raging between Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds and civil rights advocates over whether racial violence in the country has increased lies a fact that neither side disputes: there are no reliable data on racial, religious and ethnic violence.

title: WHO WILL WIN, HAGLER OR LEONARD, AND WHY?
description: The fact that people will line up for tickets to this fight continues to amaze me. Hagler has not lost in 10 years. He has beaten every style of fighter put before him. He is an excellent boxer who can also take you out with one punch from either hand. He has a granite chin. He is a natural middleweight.

title: PHEASANT FARMERS FIXING DAMAGE FROM WINTER
description: WITH spring here, Connecticut's commercial pheasant farms are beginning to repair some of the worst snow damage that they have seen in several years.

title: The Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: 'FENCES': NO BARRIER TO EMOTION
description: WHEN MARY ALICE FI-nally takes a fist to James Earl Jones in the second act of August Wilson's ''Fences,'' what was suspected becomes solidly, startlingly clear. There are, we come to find, two or maybe even three audiences at this play - and for some portion of them, this is not theater, this is life. As a former critic who is most comfortable crouched behind his critical distance, I found it disturbing at first to count myself among those for whom this is more than a play. Nonetheless, that is where ''Fences'' took me.

title: Data Update
description: HOUSING COSTS: N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area*

title: Dance
description: Laura Dean is celebrating the 10th anniversary of her company, Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians, with a double-threat season that few choreographers could pull off. For Ms. Dean has created not just the dance but the music for each of the three pieces to be performed at the anniversary season, which opens on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. For ''Magnetic,'' a New York premiere, Ms. Dean has composed a dramatic synthesizer score. ''Tympani,'' a signature work, is scored for two pianists and a tympanist. And drumming sends ''Sky Light'' coursing on its way, in dancing that is typically complex, filled with exhilaratingly building patterns, poses and quick footwork.

title: WHAT GOODEN TELLS US ABOUT OURSELVES
description: AS the news about Dwight Gooden spread the other afternoon, the same things were being said all over, and it is hard to disagree with any of them. Yes, of course, the poor guy merits sympathy. But, damn right, no one put a gun to his head! Hey, on the other hand, he's still just a kid - 22! -and this is the kind of mistake kids make. But how could the jerk do this to himself? To us?

title: KEY L.I. ISSUES ON ALBANY'S LIST
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND has a number of key issues at stake in the 1987-88 state budget that was being finalized in Albany last week. Legislative leaders grappled with a $2 billion tax cut and a school aid package that could top $7 billion.

title: Should Pro Hockey and Basketball Alter Playoff Formats?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: BUYING RAILROADS FOR FUN AND PROFIT
description: THE MORGANS Private International Bankers 1854-1913.By Vincent P. Carosso with the assistance of Rose C. Carosso. Illustrated. 888 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $65.

title: 2 LIVES INTERWOVEN WITH THE ARTS
description: LEAD: ELIZABETH JENNERJAHN hasn't created a wall hanging in decades. In fact, the artist, who studied with Anni and Josef Albers 40 years ago at the fabled experimental Black Mountain College in North Carolina, almost threw away the fabric-and-stitchery collages that are on exhibit at the Discovery Art Gallery in Glen Cove through

title: Televising Politicians
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Searching
description: NOW that Lefty Driesell, the former Maryland coach, is out of the running for the basketball job at South Alabama, school officials have been looking high and low for another candidate, and, it seems, finding a prospect at each level. The next step is to decide whether whether to reach up to the pros and hire Bill Musselman of the Rapid City Thrillers, the Continental Basketball Association's coach of the year, or down into the junior college ranks to sign Ronnie Arrow, the San Jacinto coach. Driesell, meanwhile, is keeping his gaze aloft, eyeing a possible job with a prospective Charlotte, N.C., expansion franchise in the National Basketball Association.

title: Elite and Less Elite in White South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE TROUPE SEEKS TO SHOCK
description: WHEN AKAJI MARO was casting about for a name for his dance troupe, he hit upon ''camel.'' The animal is misshapen and unattractive -somewhat like the deliberately shocking images Mr. Maro includes in his dances.

title: Dr. Bertha Bauer Engaged to Marry D.L. A. Moyer 3d
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Bauer of Brooklyn and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Bertha Anne Bauer, to Dr. Lawson Auburn Moyer 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moyer Jr. of Harbor Bluffs, Fla. The wedding is planned for June 14.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
Town Supports Retail 'Village'
description: LEAD: ONE of the largest commercial developments in this Berkshire Mountains resort town, Lenox House Country Shops, is expanding once again as part of the area's growth in retailing.

title: Health and I.B.M.
description: To the Editor:

title: REDS' ERIC DAVIS: A MAJOR TALENT WAITING TO BLOSSOM
description: THE baseball world, always eager to watch the development of a Don Mattingly or a Roger Clemens, breathlessly anticipates the carnage that Eric Davis will commit on National league pitchers and catchers this season. Cincinnati's center fielder is so exciting a player that observers are prepared to expect him to hit a home run every time up or stroke a mere single, then steal second, third and home. In his last 93 games last season, after all, Davis hit .297, drove in 60 runs, scored 78, socked 23 home runs and stole 63 bases.

title: LOSING NOTE IN METS' FAREWELL
description: The Mets ended their 26th and final spring training in St. Petersburg today, and also ended 62 years of New York baseball presence in this city on the Gulf of Mexico where Babe Ruth and the Yankees once trained.

title: ROCK LOOKS HOMEWARD
description: DOWN IN NEW ORLEANS, the commercial FM rock station WYLD has started a daily afternoon show devoted to New Orleans music, past and present. Last year, in Helena, Ark., the historic live blues show ''King Biscuit Time'' was revived on KFFA. All around the country - in San Francisco, Chicago and Minneapolis, as well as at last night's New York Music Awards - hometown performers are acting proud to be provincial. Rock is reclaiming its local color and regional accents.

title: PENSION INCREASES SOUGHT
description: LEAD: RETIRED police officers and firefighters are working to garner votes in the Legislature to override an anticipated conditional veto by Governor Kean of a bill to double the basic pensions of some of the state's oldest and poorest widows.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Passport to Pimlico With Stanley Holloway, Betty Warren, Margaret Rutherford. Directed by Henry Cornelius. 1949. Prism Entertainment. 85 minutes. $19.95.

title:
ART;
'STATE OF THE ARTISTS' AT THE ALDRICH, OFFERS A FLATTERING MIX
description: LEAD: ''STATE OF THE ARTISTS'' at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is an invitational that mixes generations and levels of renown. Every artist in it lives in Connecticut and the show adds up to a quite flattering self-portrait.

title: The Problems Go Far Beyond Chips
description: AMERICANS have been spoiling for a fight with Japan over trade issues. They tend to see their nation as a Gary Cooper or a John Wayne character: well-intentioned and wanting to be fair, but willing to throw a few punches if necessary. Japanese attitudes are hardening as well. As Kazuo Nukazawa, an official of Keidanren, a powerful business association, said: ''Japan has become a big boy, so it shouldn't be kicked around by the teacher.''

title: Sellers Finding Condo Resales Shaky
description: FIVE months ago Diane Hyman decided to sell an elegant East Side condominium she bought in 1985 for $239,000. With its wall-to-wall windows, southern exposure and wide balcony, the one-bedroom unit opened on the resale market at $285,000. ''That was a very realistic price,'' Ms. Hyman said, ''although I figured I might let it go for a little less.''

title: LOUD BATS BOLSTER QUIET TALK
description: The mornings were blanketed with a soft dew, the afternoons warmed by a generous sun. As the days ambled into nights through February and then March, the Yankee camp seemed serene and peaceful. The theme music could have been a lullaby.

title: AS AMERICAN AS MUTTERHOOD UND APFEL PIE
description: AS a witty saying goes, an immigrant is a person who lost everything but the accent.

title: DECISION TIME IN SEOUL, AND 'CLOCK IS RUNNING'
description: Behind the unapproachable walls of the Blue House, the seat of South Korean power, President Chun Doo Hwan is an aloof, enigmatic figure to most of his 41 million countrymen.

title: HOW ONE-SHIP FLEET ALTERED U.S. TREATY
description: AN INTERNATIONAL confrontation that ended in a new defense treaty between the United States and Iceland began three years ago when Mark W. Yonge, a New Jersey entrepreneur, impelled by a spirit of competition - and knowing a bit about American shipping law - managed to win an important Navy contract that had been held by Icelandic companies for more than a decade.

title:
MUSIC;
SALIERI HAS HIS DAY AT RIDER
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Broadway play and movie ''Amadeus'' showed the worst of Antonio Salieri's character, there are those who are committed to performing and doing research on his music.

title: Conviction in OTB Theft
description: A former regional manager of Offtrack Betting parlors in Erie and Niagara Counties has been convicted of embezzling $27,500 from six branch offices. The defendant, Harry Manuszewski of North Tonawanda, was convicted of four counts of grand larceny and four counts of falsifying business records in the verdict Friday by Erie County Judge Joseph P. McCarthy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf International Senior Sweep: The International team captained by Gary Player continued its domination of the $600,000 Chrysler Cup championship yesterday, sweeping the top two places in two-man best-ball medal play to open a commanding 46-20 lead after three rounds of the Senior PGA Tour event in Sarasota, Fla. Player and Bob Charles were joined by the tandem of Bruce Crampton-Harold Henning in shooting six-under-par 66 totals that provided 9 points apiece for the International team. Peter Thomson and Roberto DeVicenzo shot a 68 to add 5 points to the team total as the Internationals earned 26 of 34 points awarded and moved to within 5 points of victory over the same eight-man United States team that won the inaugural Chrysler Cup event 68-31 a year ago.(AP) Boxing Curry Retains Crown: Donald Curry successfully defended his United States Boxing Association junior middleweight in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday when his opponent, Carlos Santos, was disqualified for excessive head-butting by Referee Carlos Padilla at 2:25 of the fifth round of a scheduled 12-round bout. After two warnings, Padilla deducted a point from Santos for butting in the fourth round. And when Santos was guilty of the same infraction a round later, Padilla stepped between the fighters and signaled the judges to deduct another point. When Santos lowered his head against Curry and opened a cut on the champion's right brow in the fifth round, Padilla waved an end to the fight, disqualifying Santos. Curry's record goes to 27-1. Santos is now 30-3. Amateurs Retain U.S. Titles: Eight amateur boxers including 112-pound Arthur Johnson, who fought with a broken right hand, successfully defended their national titles at the United States Amateur Boxing Championships final yesterday in Buffalo. Johnson, of St. Louis, who scored a split 3-2 decision over Sergio Reyes of Fort Worth, said he broke the knuckle on the index finger of his right hand while training for the Goodwill Games last July and reinjured it earlier this week.(AP) Steeplechasing Maori Venture Wins Grand National: Maori Venture, a long shot with a habit of clipping hurdles, scored an upset victory in the Grand National yesterday that gave the owner, Jim Joel, his first victory in the race. Maori Venture, a 28-1 shot, charged into the lead past the flagging pacesetter, Lean Ar Aghaidh, just after the final jump and pulled away to a five-length victory in 9 minutes 19.03 seconds, the third-fastest Grand National. Worth $104,243, the victory also meant the end of 60 years of Grand National frustration for the 92-year-old Joel, who was in South Africa and missed the triumph.(AP) Rugby England Defeats Scotland: England beat Scotland, 21-12, yesterday in a Five Nations' rugby union championship match in Twickenham, England. France finished first in the standing at 4-0.(AP) Auto Racing Pruett Wins in Trans-Am: Scott Pruett ran off to an easy victory yesterday in the season-opening Long Beach (Calif.) Trans-Am. Pruett earned his first victory in the Sports Car Club of America's Bendix Trans-Am series. The winner's Mercury Merkur XR4Ti averaged 69.498 miles an hour. The only other driver on the lead lap at the end was Tom Kendall, in a Mercury Capri.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 110, Bulls 97: Dominique Wilkins scored 5 of his 24 points in a 10-0 run late in the third period as Atlanta built a 90-67 lead and coasted to victory at home. Atlanta led, 53-51, at halftime and 80-67 midway through the third period before blowing the game open for its 50th victory of the season. Chicago's Michael Jordan, who was rested after Atlanta took the large lead, led all scorers with 31 points.(AP) Mavericks 121, Jazz 107: Mark Aguirre scored 28 points and made three of Dallas's league-record 10 three-point field goals in a game in Dallas. The previous record for 3-pointers was nine, held by four teams, including the Mavericks earlier this season. Utah's Kelly Tripucka had two 3-pointers giving the teams a total of 12, also an N.B.A. record. The Mavericks, who reached the 50-victory plateau for the first time in franchise history, increased their divisional lead over the Jazz to 10 games.(AP) Bullets 127, Cavaliers 111: Moses Malone scored 38 points and grabbed 17 rebounds as Washington handed the Cavaliers, playing at home, their fourth consecutive loss. Malone scored 26 of his points as the Bullets took a 65-61 halftime lead, but Cleveland rallied to lead 87-86 on two foul shots by Ron Harper with 3:38 remaining in the third quarter. Washington's Jay Vincent then made a layup, hit a 20-foot jumper and added another layup to spark Washington to a 94-89 lead entering the fourth quarter.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 4, Red Wings 3: Mario Lemieux scored his 54th goal of the season at 1:26 of overtime to give Pittsburgh a home victory that prevented the Red Wings from clinching the Norris Division title. A tie would have assured the Red Wings of finishing in first place for the first time since the 1964-65 season. Pittsburgh's Dan Quinn scored a short-handed goal at 5:21 of the third period to force the overtime before Lemieux scored on a slapshot. The Penguins ended their season 30-38-12 and in fifth in the Patrick Division.(AP) Capitals 3, Flyers 2: Larry Murphy's second goal of the game at 3:19 of overtime gave Washington the victory. Mike Gartner scored on a penalty shot and Murphy on a power play in the second period to rally the Capitals from a 2-0 deficit. (AP) Maple Leafs 3, Blackhawks 1: Greg Terrion, Wendel Clark and Steve Thomas scored Toronto's goals as the Leafs clinched a Norris Division playoff berth in front of home fans. The Maple Leafs' victory left them tied with Chicago and Minnesota at 70 points. Minnesota, playing its final regular-season game, lost at St. Louis last night and can make the playoffs only if the Blackhawks lose again to Toronto today.(AP) Canadiens 3, Bruins 1: Larry Robinson scored his 13th goal of the season with 3:08 left in the third period to snap a tie as Montreal won its eighth straight victory. The triumph clinched second place in the Adams Division for Montreal, which will open the playoffs at home Wednesday night against the third-place Bruins. Robinson fired a shot from the slot over the shoulder of the Boston goalie, Doug Keans, for the winner and Ryan Walter scored his 23d goal less than two minutes later over a sliding Keans. (AP).

title:
ABOUT MEN;
The Son-in-Law Watcher
description: LEAD: I WATCH FROM THE SIDELINES AS MY first-born daughter and a tall young man whom I just barely know exchange an unintelligible vow of what I suppose is love and are then pronounced husband and wife.

title: U.S. CATHOLIC BIBLE AVOIDS USING 'MAN'
description: An updated text of the New Testament that avoids the use of ''man'' in references covering both men and women was introduced yesterday by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops.

title: DANBURY PLAYS HOST TO SUPREME COURT
description: HIGH SCHOOL students, aspiring lawyers and a contingent of Brownies will be among the spectators filing into Danbury Superior Court this week when the State Supreme Court comes to town.

title: WHO WILL WIN, HAGLER OR LEONARD, AND WHY?
description: I am sick and tired of hearing how great and unbeatable Marvelous Marvin Hagler is. Hagler is very beatable and Sugar Ray will prove that. First, Hagler is strong, but he's only strong if he can connect, and he has never faced a fast and sly fighter like Leonard. Leonard has only boxed once in five years, against a journeyman. But Hagler hasn't fought in a while too, so that isn't much of an edge. Also, the Washington area knows what kind of shape Sugar Ray has been staying in.

title: Brief Alaska Fishing Period Brings Big Profits
description: It was not exactly a crap shoot, only something like one, but everyone hoped there would be no losers. Fifty-two fishing boats and their crews were poised to go after 3,600 tons of herring that would take about four hours to net and bring the fishermen perhaps $4 million.

title: Social Events; Exotica and Make-Believe
description: For Educational Aid April 6 - The estimated 150,000 Sephardic Jews in this country are aided by the youth-education programs of the American Sephardi Federation, which will benefit from a 7 P.M. premiere showing of the movie ''Sweet Lorraine,'' starring Maureen Stapleton. Following the movie at the Paris Theater on 58th Street, just west of Fifth Avenue, there will be a buffet supper at the Plaza. Tickets, $125, from 212-730-1210. Asian Evening April 7 - The food will be from Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Malayasia, the Philippines and Brunei, and the dancers from Thailand, with music provided by a gamelan, a percussion ensemble. The black-tie evening starts with cocktails at 8 at Bloomingdale's, which will be marking the opening of its South China Seas Festival. Guests can also watch silk weaving, batik making and other activities throughout the store. The opening will be a benefit for the Asia Society, which promotes scholarly Asian studies and tours by Asian performing artists. Tickets, $200, from 212-288-6400, extension 269. 'Dallas' in New York April 7 - The atmosphere in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza will be reminiscent of the television show ''Dallas,'' with a black-tie ''Diamonds and Stetsons'' dinner dance and auction to benefit the American Cancer Society. Larry Hagman, who plays J. R. Ewing, is scheduled to be on hand. The evening will begin at 7 with cocktails, and items to be auctioned include a walk-on part in ''Dallas'' and lunch with Mr. Hagman; a steer, live or dressed and delivered, and a private tap-dance lesson with Gregory Hines. Tickets, $300, from 212-586-8700, extension 555. Vineyard Celebration April 7 - Alfred Eisenstaedt, the renowned photographer, will present slides of Martha's Vineyard at the National Arts Club on Gramercy Park South at 6:30 P.M. Fresh seafood, wine, baked goods and desserts, all from the Vineyard, will be served, followed by dancing. The evening benefits the Yard, which since 1973 has provided a haven on Martha's Vineyard for more than 500 professional artists to work on theater, dance and music projects. Tickets, $125, from 212-206-7885. Briefly Noted: April 7 - There will be Champagne at the Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, following the 7:30 P.M. premiere of ''Magnetic'' by the Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians. Tickets, $50, from 212-741-2643. April 8 - The Children's Museum of Manhattan on West 54th Street, where art and science lessons are offered, is holding a benefit at F.A.O. Schwarz in the General Motors Building, Fifth Avenue at 58th Street, from 6 to 8 P.M. A buffet dinner, wine and children's fare will be served. Tickets, $125 for two adults and one child or $75 for one adult and $10 a child, from 212-765-5905. April 8 - Champagne and strawberries will be served at a preview of ''Masterpieces of American Folk Art'' at the new Hirschl & Adler Folk gallery, 851 Madison Avenue (70th Street), from 5 to 9 P.M. The showing will benefit the Museum of American Folk Art. Tickets, $25, at the door. April 8 - The Chelsea Arts Project, which has dance programs for the young, will benefit from a 9 P.M. to 4 A.M. performance and party at Limelight, Avenue of the Americas at 20th Street. Tickets, $15 for general admission and wine or $35 including a buffet, at the door. April 9 - Now in its 11th season, the Battery Dance Company will hold a benefit, starting with a performance at the Schimmel Center of Pace University at Spruce and Gold Streets, near City Hall. Supper at St. Maggie's Cafe on Wall Street will follow. Tickets, $75, from 212-219-3910. April 9 - The Rotunda Gallery, 209 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn Heights, is holding a Champagne reception from 5:30 to 8 P.M., with music and a photographic show to benefit the nonprofit gallery. Tickets, $35 at the door. Information: 718-643-3490. April 9 - The Drawing Center's 10th anniversary will be celebrated in its new home at 35 Wooster Street (Grand Street) at 6 P.M. with cocktails and a showing of ''The Art of Drawing in France: Master Drawings From the National Museum in Stockholm.'' Dinner will follow at the Leo Castelli Gallery. Tickets, $250, from 212-219-2166. Party in Chinatown April 10 - Founded in 1898, Hamilton-Madison House is one of the oldest settlement houses in the city, serving the Lower East Side and Chinatown with health, recreational and educational programs. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. followed by a 10-course Chinese banquet and dancing at the Silver Palace Restaurant, 52 Bowery (Canal Street), will benefit the group. Tickets, $50, from 212-349-3724, extension 314. Aid for Nursing Care April 10 - The Visiting Nurse Service of New York, which since 1893 has been caring for the sick and disabled in their own homes, is holding a black-tie dinner dance at the St. Regis Roof, beginning with cocktails at 5:30 P.M. Tickets, $125 or $85 for those under the age of 30, from 212-222-8598. Japan at the Opera April 11 - Appropriately, the Annual Ball at the Opera House, a benefit for the Metropolitan Opera's 1988 tour of Japan, will have a Japanese theme. After the 8 P.M. performance of ''La Boheme,'' there will be formal dining and orchestral music around the grand staircase; cordials, sweets and light classical music in the Belmont Room; sushi, Japanese beer and jazz in the Board Room and a discotheque in the Opera Club Room, where a continental breakfast will be served at dawn. White-tie requested; tickets, $325 or $275 for the post-performance activities only, from 212-496-1516.

title: 2 LEGISLATORS PRESS CAUSE FOR ELDERLY
description: IN what is considered an unusual legislative initiative, two Westchester lawmakers have released the first section of what they describe as a three-part blueprint for action by the Board of Legislators to benefit the county's older adults.

title: Jennifer Morgan, a Student, to Marry Roger C. Martindell, a Lawyer, in June
description: The engagement of Jennifer Morgan to Roger C. Martindell has been announced by her parents, Maureen Morgan of Ossining, N.Y., and Douglas O. Morgan of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The future bridegroom is the son of Anne C. Martindell of Princeton, N.J., and Jackson Martindell of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: HOME VIDEO: SPORTS
description: LEAD: Little League's Official How to Play Baseball by Video MasterVision. 70 minutes. $19.95.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: SOME 12 years ago, Mark Fabiaschi was sitting in the cafeteria of Colorado State University when he spotted a terrific-looking girl in the salad line. He hated salad, but desperate situations require desperate measures. Mr. Fabiaschi got up, edged next to her and indicated that he was crazy about lettuce.

title: DESERT TACTICS OF CHADIANS: LIKE OLD WEST
description: Chadian tactics that led to the spectacular defeat of 5,000 Libyans at Wadi Dum last week are described in a variety of colorful ways by Chadian, French and American officials in the capital here.

title: Miss Neale to Wed P. T. McCormick
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Neale of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Corinne Neale to Patrick Thomas McCormick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. McCormick of Chappaqua, N.Y. The wedding is planned for August.

title: MEDIATION: ALTERNATIVE TO SUITS
description: LEAD: TO Judge Paul A. Lowengrub of State Superior Court, Camden County had no choice: If it did not replace the old, crumbling treatment plants that were spewing raw sewage into streams and rivers, it would be violating the Federal Clean Water Act.

title: Chinese Bus Plunge Kills 19
description: The provincial newspaper Shaanxi Daily has reported that 19 people died and 28 were injured when a bus plunged off a cliff on March 29 in Shaanxi Province. The paper said the accident was being investigated.

title:
ANTIQUES;
NEWARK ACADEMY SHOW ADDS SPEAKERS
description: LEAD: A roster of distinguished speakers will add considerable luster to this year's presentation of the Northern New Jersey Antiques Show at Newark Academy.

title: HOME DESIGN PREVIEW
description: RALPH LAUREN got his inspiration from the leather tooling on a wing-tip shoe. Designer John Mascheroni studied the delicate ironwork that was the trademark of artist Diego Giacometti's furniture.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: CHINESE HERBAL MEDICINE. By Daniel P. Reid. (Shambhala, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $17.95.) ''It seems about time,'' writes Daniel P. Reid, ''for the West to start paying serious attention to Chinese medicine, and to benefit from its profound insights and potent remedies.'' To fail to do so, he argues, is tantamount to medical negligence.

title: POSSIBLE CHUN SUCESSORS
description: Although President Chun Doo Hwan says he will step down next February, it is generally assumed that he wants to designate his successor.

title: SLASH CASE JUROR FACES QUERIES
description: The State Supreme Court Justice presiding in the trial of two men accused of slashing the face of a model, Marla Hanson, will question a juror Tuesday about a hearsay report that she believed the jury was ''afraid to convict.''

title: DECLARATIONS OF VICTORY
description: VIETNAM ON TRIAL Westmoreland vs. CBS. By Bob Brewin and Sydney Shaw. Illustrated. 414 pp. New York: Atheneum. $21.95. BLOOD LIBEL The Inside Story of General Ariel Sharon's History-Making Suit Against Time Magazine. By Uri Dan. 270 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Prison for Coffee-Spiker
description: Glenwood D. Brogden, 18 years old, a student at Hammond High School in Columbia, has been sentenced to six months in jail for spiking the coffee of Janet Thurman, a teacher of home economics, with a derivative of cayenne pepper. Ms. Thurman has undergone minor surgery several times since she drank the coffee last October.

title: UNHISTORIC VINYL SIDING GOES UP ON A MASSACHUSETTS HOME
description: Eloise Laino says she is delighted to exchange the colorful stripes and gingerbread man she painted on her house in a historic district for ordinary gray vinyl siding.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
description: IN January, Bernan Foods, which for 25 years has marketed hors d'oeuvres primarily through kosher caterers and stores, introduced Bernie's East Bagel Dog, a kosher, all-beef frank encased in bagel dough that will be sold through supermarket chains. For the first time the Newark company is actively pursuing non-kosher consumers, through ads in general circulation publications.

title: DEFENDING A NEW 'TURANDOT'
description: To the Editor:

title: LIABILITY STUDIES DRAW ON $6 MILLION FUND
description: USING a new $6 million state trust fund, several towns are planning programs intended to reduce potential liability claims.

title: POTVIN REACHES THE 1,000 Mark
description: It was another third-period rally for the Islanders, who this season have used them the way most performers use curtain calls. Tonight their late-found theatrics not only forced a 6-6 tie that survived overtime, but helped Denis Potvin make hockey history as he became the sport's first defenseman to score 1,000 points.

title: The Danger of Disarming
description: The very concept of ''A World Without Nuclear Weapons'' is an illusion. Assume for a moment that all nuclear weapons have been destroyed. Unless the means for building them are also destroyed, or placed under some airtight supervision, a number of nations would still be able to produce them quickly. In the event of a war that threatens its survival, would any state able to make nuclear weapons abstain from quickly producing them?

title: State Showdown Over Spanking
description: THE Bible says in Proverbs 13:24, ''He who spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him is careful to discipline him.'' Citing verses like these, 11 church-affiliated day-care centers in North Carolina balked at a regulation of the state's Child Day Care Commission.

title: RACIAL BIAS PRITEST AT COLUMBIA
description: More than 300 people gathered at Columbia University yesterday for a rally and march against racial violence and to protest the response by the administration and the Police Department to a fight involving black and white students on the campus two weeks ago.

title: NEW ISSUES DISPLAY HISTORIC TRADITIONS
description: AUSTRALIA'S stamp program for this year begins with its Australia Day issue. The national holiday celebrates the official beginning of European settlement in Australia in 1788. The event has been marked by Australia Post each year since 1978.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
AND SO TAKE ME OUT TO THE OLD -- ER, UH -- NEW BALL GAME
description: LEAD: BASEBALL is a great game, a thinking man's game, but it's not perfect. It's not football.

title: WHY TAX AMNESTY IS FAIR, EQUITABLE, AND OF BENEFIT TO ALL
description: HONEST New Jersey taxpayers, when they first hear about tax amnesty, sometimes react like this:

title: PIONER JOURNALIST RECALLS WAR DAYS
description: ON a spring day 42 years ago this month, Ann Stringer was soaring east through the skies over war-torn Germany in a Piper Cub when she saw smoke rising from a small village adjacent to a river.

title: Elusive Master Of Radical Graffiti
description: FOR nearly five years, according to the authorities, William Depperman drove New York City sanitation inspectors up a wall.

title: Prost and Rahal Could Keep On Rolling
description: The world's two major series for open-wheel racing cars are revving up for the start of their 1987 seasons. The North American-based PPG Indy Car World Series kicks off its 15-race schedule today in the streets of Long Beach, Calif., while the 16-race Formula One schedule starts next Sunday at Rio de Janeiro with the running of the Brazilian Grand Prix.

title: Mary E. Evans and David Leahy, Lawyers, Marry
description: At Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington yesterday, Mary Elizabeth Evans, an associate in the Washington law firm Venable, Baetjer, Howard & Civiletti, was married to David Michael Leahy, an associate in the Washington office of the New York law firm Debevoise & Plimpton. The Rev. Robert F. Drinan, a professor of law at the Georgetown University Law Center, performed the ceremony.

title: A Civilized Pastime
description: I'M A BASEBALL FAN. IT is a game you don't have to weigh 250 pounds, or stand 7 feet tall, or be South American to play well. Also, it is not played on ice. I used to think I could grow up and be a major league baseball player, since I knew by age 9 that I would never weigh 250 pounds, grow 7 feet tall, be South American, or learn to keep my balance on ice skates while acting like a saloon brawler.

title: 2 THEATERS STAGE CLASSIC IBSEN DRAMAS
description: TWO plays by Ibsen are in local theaters. The Arena Players Repertory Company of East Farmingdale is presenting ''Ghosts,'' while the innovative Victory Repertory Theater of Great Neck is producing ''A Doll's House.''

title: DEVILS ARE ROUTED
description: Michel Goulet and Peter Stastny each scored two goals as the Quebec Nordiques romped to an 8-4 victory tonight over the Devils.

title: NOW SYAS MOST U.S. WOMEN IN EDUCATION ARE FACING BIAS
description: Most American women are vulnerable to sex discrimination in schools and universities, according to a report by the National Organization for Women.

title: MAINE RETREAT'S UNWANTED NEIGHBOR: A LANDFILL FOR WASTE FROM ALL OVER
description: When Fran Metcalf and her husband, Earl, left a rapidly developing town on the Maine coast to settle here seven years ago, they thought they had found everything they wanted: a huge historic home in a quaint little New England village, a good place to rear their two children.

title: Victory at Eton
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow, in Retaliatory Step, Expels 6 Frenchmen
description: The Soviet Union announced today it was expelling four French diplomats and two French businessmen in retaliation for the expulsion of three Russians from France after the French said they had uncovered a high-technology spy ring.

title: Olivia Henry Is Affianced
description: Mrs. S. Morgan Henry of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Olivia Peters Henry, to Timothy Philip Gurshin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin W. Gurshin of Newburyport, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: MANAGUA CRACKS DOWN ON GROUP THAT PRESSES FOR PRISONERS' RIGHTS
description: On Tuesday afternoon, calmly and quietly, Concepcion Salazar Gonzalez sat explaining the new movement she and other relatives of prisoners have recently formed.

title: Reversal in Zimbabwe
description: It was with high hopes and high standards that Rhodesia became Zimbabwe in 1980, and nothing showed it more persuasively than this:

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: The Quiller Memorandum Starring George Segal, Alec Guinness, Max Von Sydow, George Sanders, Senta Berger. Screenplay by Harold Pinter. Directed by Michael Anderson. 1966. Key Video. 103 minutes. $59.98.

title:
GARDENING;
A CHARMING BORDER WITH DIVERSITY
description: LEAD: THE charm of a well-planned herbaceous border lies in the great diversity within that group of plants called herbaceous perennials. Each species, hybrid or cultivar has its own unique characteristics, and the number of perennials is so great that there can be little excuse from the early spring through late summer for having an uninteresting border.

title: DEFENDING A NEW 'TURANDOT'
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He'll do fine in that place for 30 days. But what's going to happen when he comes out and visits Los Angeles, Chicago, St. Louis and all those places? That's what I'm worried about. Can he handle that?''

title: Recent Sales
description: Commack $155,000 12 Audrey Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; fin ished basement, patio, solar hot-water sys tem, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Fort Salonga $520,000 3 Mystic Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old contempo rary; fireplace, cathedral ceilings, private beach rights, water view; taxes $6,000. Glen Head $200,000 18 Edgewood Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; den, basement, attic, laundry room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,400. Mastic Beach $105,000 33 Grassmere Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; den, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,300. Massapequa Park $170,000 177 Von Huenfeld Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; din ing room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Setauket $270,000 39 Gaul Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; fire place, dining room, basement, 2-car ga rage, brick and cedar siding; taxes $4,600. OTHER AREAS Milford, Conn. $340,000 67 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; on waterfront, newly remodeled; taxes $2,200. Millburn, N.J. $220,000 79 Linden Street 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old colonial; din ing room, 1-car attached garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,006. Yonkers, N.Y. $198,500 169 Rockne Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old brick/frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, walk to schools and stores; taxes $3,046.

title: SAMPLING THE DNA
description: INTRUDERS The Incredible Visitations at Copley Woods. By Budd Hopkins. Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Albany Agrees On Sweeping Cuts In State Taxes
description: Republican and Democratic leaders of the New York State Legislature last week presented Governor Cuomo with just what they wanted, a sweeping revision of the state income tax code that would cut the average tax bill by 20 percent.

title: Verse Versus Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: The Best of Times In British Business
description: EXPORTS are surging. Corporate profits are growing smartly. Productivity is climbing. Strikes are scarce. And this year the economy may grow faster than any other in the industrial world.

title: MUSIC: THE JUILLIARD QUARTET
description: NOT too many ensembles with established reputations would devote the better half of a concert to a lengthy new piece by a young composer. But this is just what the Juilliard String Quartet did Wednesday night when it played the String Quartet No. 1 by Christopher James at the Juilliard Theater.

title: A TRIO OF WASHINGTON GUIDES
description: Springtime in Washington means two kinds of blossoming, as the Japanese cherry trees explode in a mass of colors and the museums, national sites and restaurants fill up with tourists. Cherry Blossom Week begins today, an event that annually has tourism officials hoping they scheduled it correctly.

title: Tenure Denial Stirs Academic Freedom Issue
description: One spring morning in 1985, Barbara C. Foley, a professor of English at Northwestern University, opened her mailbox and found two pieces of mail. One was a new copy of her first book, the other a letter requesting her resignation.

title: DAVID W. PAYNE
description: David W. Payne, who became a lawyer after working for years as a Broadway theater manager and in other positions related to the performing arts, died of lung cancer on March 27 at Howard County General Hospital in Columbia, Md. He was 48 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: SCHOOL VOTING SET FOR TUESDAY
description: IN RACES marked more by routine than controversy, New Jerseyans in 550 of the state's 606 school districts not only will elect local school-board members Tuesday, but also decide the fate of budgets.

title: THE 'INVISIBLE' SPEAKER ARRIVES
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, BE-fore Dr. Spock and permissiveness, it used to be said that children should be seen but not heard. Exactly the opposite is what some people like in loudspeakers. They want them to be heard but not seen.

title: Persian Nights
description: Diane Johnson is the author of six novels, among them the literary mystery ''The Shadow Knows.'' That work (currently out of print) is a classic in its genre, a textbook on menace and suspicion, on the nature of fear itself. The protagonist, N, a divorced mother studying for an advanced degree, living in a housing project and pursuing an affair with a married lover, discovers who she is by projecting her fears about herself onto the very real threats surrounding her.

title: The Stakes in a San Francisco Election
description: LEAD: In most cities, electing a high-powered, nationally prominent political activist like Nancy Pelosi to Congress would send a clear message that the days of old-boy rule were finished and that an articulate and capable woman has as much of a chance as any man to win elective office.

title: DREDGING: PERIL TO ENDANGERED BIRDS?
description: NESTLED among patches of marshland shrubbery along the Nissequogue River shoreline, two brownish birds appeared robust and playful as they ascended to a nearby plateau.

title:
GARDENING;
A SELECTION OF LAVENDERS FOR SUMMER'S FRAGRANCE
description: LEAD: ONE of the most popular aromatic herbs must certainly be lavender. Its scent, synonymous with cleanliness and nostalgia, has charmed generations of gardeners. Fragrant oils, distilled for centuries in both homes and factories, have made it a household scent popular in soaps, sachets and after-shave lotions.

title: ROLLER HOCKEY AS AN ART FORM
description: HOCKEY had to rank somewhere between football and mauling in the choice of sports I'd like to have seen my son involved in, but for whatever reason (and I suspect speed has much to do with it), roller hockey was the only sport that held any real attraction for him.

title: CONCERT: BROTT AND BERNSTEIN BY ORATORIO SOCIETY
description: OUR large amateur choruses exist in part to provide people the pleasure of communal singing. For that purpose - and to help fill our large midtown concert halls - a steady recycling of the great choral masterpieces seems necessary. But these organizations also serve to explore more unusual repertory. On Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall, the Oratorio Society of New York offered three fairly exotic works and one older classic that is not quite so overfamiliar as some.

title: Laurie J. Caldwell To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William T. Caldwell of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Jean Caldwell, to Peter Vevier Brandow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd E. Brandow Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: RECITAL: PETER SERKIN
description: IF the progress of music can be defined in terms of a slowly advancing army - one that continually occupies new ground but must look to its flank for nourishment - than many of today's worthwhile composers have leaped perilously ahead of their line of supply.

title: A LA CARTE
description: ROBINS and crocuses spell spring for many. But for serious eaters on Long Island and elsewhere, asparagus symbolizes spring.

title: Arms Control, Not Competition
description: It is a measure of the limited vision of many so-called experts that they were shocked when Ronald Reagan said to Mikhail Gorbachev at Reykjavik what he had been saying to Americans for years - that he would like to see a world with no nuclear weapons at all. Mr. Reagan is entirely right in wanting to achieve such a world, and he was also right to say so to Mr. Gorbachev. It is good for Soviet and American leaders to share their understanding that nuclear weapons are not a blessing to mankind.

title: Preserving a Rural Vista
description: A $300 million office complex with 2.4 million square feet of space will be created on 140 acres of land in Bridgewater Township, N.J., without consuming the site.

title: Entering the Postnuclear Age
description: Long before Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev started talking about abolishing nuclear weapons, the trend moving us step by step toward a ''postnuclear era'' was clear and relentless. To be sure, there are more nuclear weapons around than ever before. But the effect of nuclear weapons on the military balance has continued to diminish.

title: BRADLEY AND KING TIED
description: Pat Bradley, who has won four of the last five women's major golf tournaments, moved into a tie for the lead today through three rounds of the Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament.

title: Negative Signal In Cable Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GOING AWAY, GOING HOME
description: There it is, Prospero's island rising in the mist. Will it be there when our plane descends or will it have ''melted into air, into thin air?''

title: Staying Home In Style
description: Are the Young Fogies unaware of poverty and hunger, or that most people do not earn hundreds of thousands of dollars (''Staying Home in Style,'' by Michael Gross, Fashions of The Times, March 1)?

title: Gabrielle Gelzer Becomes a Bride
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Greensboro, N.C., yesterday evening, Gabrielle Valerie Gelzer and Donald Hanna McCree 3d were married by the Rev. Dr. Charles Reckard. The bride is an urban affairs banker at Chemical Bank in New York, where her husband is an officer in the agribusiness unit.

title: Talking: Jumbo Loans; FINANCING 'ALL-CASH' CO-OPS
description: SOME of the most desirable apartments in New York City are in fewer than 100 in New York City are in fewer than 100 tives along Park and Fifth Avenues from the East 60's to the East 90's.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: LIFE WISH. By Jill Ireland. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) In the spring of 1984, Jill Ireland, the actress and wife of the actor Charles Bronson, was diagnosed as having cancer of the breast and lymph nodes. This book tells what followed the diagnosis: a radical mastectomy, six months of chemotherapy and a period of intense self-discovery.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
description: The laws of kashrut, as the Jewish dietary laws are more formally called, constitute a complex set of requirements. The two best-known are the proscriptions against eating pork and shellfish, and against eating milk and meat at the same meal. For food manufacturers, that means that they must not use both dairy foods and meat products in the same item; they are forbidden even to use the same machinery to make milk and meat products unless it has been thoroughly cleaned between uses.

title: CHEAP FUEL, ACID RAIN: NATIONAL DEBATE
description: LEAD: A BILL allowing the Long Island Lighting Company to burn high-sulfur fuel in its power plants has ensnared the utility in a nationwide debate over the complex political and environmental problem of acid rain.

title: B & B in France
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest ''France's Way with B and B's'' (Travel, March 1).

title: DOLLOPS OF DROLLERY BY NOEL COWARD
description: NOEL COWARD. THE NAME STILL CONJURES up images of unsurpassed elegance, sophistication and drawing-room wit. It encompasses an age and an attitude that were, after all, very much part of this century. All the more startling, then, to find the effervescent Coward fading still further into the fuzzy dimensions of period pieces, still demonstrating his talent to amuse but, more's the pity, looking somewhat quaint and at times perfectly silly.

title: Digging a Bucket of Diamonds a Day
description: MILES and miles from anywhere, this inhospitable lunar landscape in the northwestern corner of Australia is home to six-foot-high anthills, kangaroos, baobab trees - and the world's largest diamond mining operation.

title: D.A.R. Operates Trumbull House
description: A March 1 article about the town of Lebanon [ ''Book Tells of the Life of a Town'' ] stated that the Jonathan Trumbull House was maintained by the Lebanon Historical Society. In fact, the Trumbull House, on the green, is owned and maintained by the Connecticut Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution as a museum. It is open to the public May 15 through Oct. 15 and is furnished with period antiques, including some belonging to the Trumbull family. JEAN HEMSTREET Wilton The writer is State Regent of the Connecticut Daughters of the American Revolution.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: All Sorts of Shapes And Uses in Plastics The Plastic Works! in New Rochelle is celebrating its 17th year is business - in the early years it was called Canal Street Plastics - by offering discounts of 20 percent on cut-to-size plexiglass in several thicknesses and on custom Lucite projects fabricated by the Plastic Works!

title: Miss Brecker Has Wedding
description: Pamela McAlpine Brecker and Douglas Tadd Hendrickson, commercial banking officers in the banking and corporate finance group of Chemical Bank in New York and Dallas, respectively, were married yesterday in New York.

title: Robin D. Gunty Weds Physician
description: Robin Diane Gunty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Gunty of Portland, Me., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Joel Mark Evans, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Evans of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York.

title: WHO WILL WIN, HAGLER OR LEONARD, AND WHY?
description: When you consider that neither fighter will make less than $11 million for their showdown, both Marvin Hagler and Ray Leonard would seem to be winners, with the I.R.S. finishing a close second. Nevertheless, only one man will emerge as the middleweight champion and that man will be, simply, Marvelous.

title: DISCOVERING L.I.'S ''OTHER SIDE''
description: GREAT blue herons, like Northern retirees, enjoy spending their winters in warner climates than Long Island. Florida, for example, happens to be one of their favorite hangouts. I was thus quite surprised to see a group of six of the huge birds on a recent January day, standing in the open waters of a large marshy pond not far from the busy suburbs of Oakdale.

title: DESIGN TRENDS NARROW THE GAP
description: The marketing mavens have long made a distinction in 35-millimeter camera sales between potential buyers of single-lens-reflexes (SLR) and those more likely to buy fixed-lens, auto-focusing, point-and-shoot cameras. They assume, with some logic, that SLR users are a more advanced breed, interested in the controls and options that can make photography fun and possibly even creative. The point-and-shoot crowd, conversely, is thought to be uninterested in anything but bringing home the bacon, in the form of prints that are descriptive, colorful and in focus.

title: The Marais
description: To the Editor: In regard to the article on the Marais section of Paris (''An Old Quarter of Paris Is New Again,'' Travel, Jan. 11), I would like to call attention to a site that was not mentioned. It is a school at the intersection of Rue des Francs-Bourgeois and Rue des Hospitalieres St.-Gervais, about 100 yards from the intersection of Rue des Rosiers and Rue Vieille-du-Temple. A plaque placed by the Government on the school reads: ''165 ENFANTS JUIFS DE CETTE ECOLE DEPORTES EN ALLEMAGNE DURANT LA SECONDE GUERRE MONDIALE FURENT EXTERMINES DANS LES CAMPS NAZIS. N'OUBLIEZ PAS. The English translation is: ''165 Jewish children from this school, deported to Germany during the Second World War, were exterminated in the Nazi camps. Never forget.''

title: NAMES AND PLACES: A BIT OF HISTORY
description: If there had been proper research on when Breslau became Lindenhurst, it would not have been erroneously speculated [ ''What's in a Name? History,'' About Long Island, March 1 ] that ''the same sort of wartime sentiment that turned German measles into Liberty measles may have affected the alteration.''

title: When Policy Makers Become Cowboys
description: The staff of the National Security Council ran amok in the Iran-contra affair. President Reagan conceded that much even before appointing the Tower board to investigate what happened. The Tower report subsequently warned that the N.S.C. staff, so deeply engaged in hostage ransom and Nicaraguan intrigue, must never again become ''operational.'' In other words, it is proper for the staff to make and coordinate policy, but dangerous to execute it.

title: TENANT KILLS YORKSVILLE LANDLORD
description: A 45-year-old man angry over water leaking into his apartment stabbed his landlord to death yesterday after a dispute erupted in the landlord's Upper East Side office, the police said.

title: MAINE CATS HAVE LETTER-WRITING FANS
description: State Representative Paul Jacques has been called a two-legged slob, a rat and an ailurophobe. One person said he ought to be shot. Another suggested neutering.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts and Leisure on March 29 about Argentine films misidentified the director of ''The Official Story.'' He is Luis Puenzo.

title: Reagan Stalls On Acid Rain
description: LEAD: Less than three weeks ago, as planning began for the meeting today between President Reagan and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, Mr. Reagan renewed his promise to spend $2.5 billion on research to develop technology that could help reduce acid rain.

title:
SYMPOSIUM: A WORLD WITHOUT NUCLEAR ARMS?;
A European Strategy for Peace
description: LEAD: It took some two or three years to invent a nuclear world. By the late 1940's, atomic weapons were enclosed in a comfortable domesticity, a daily life of economic necessity. As early as 1949, the first head of the Atomic Energy Commission, David E. Lilienthal, was concerned about a ''widely held notion that an atomic weapon stockpile affords this country a relatively cheap and easy solution of our problems of military security.

title: Cityscape: The Metropolitan Club; A Gilded Heritage Marred by Financial Troubles
description: THE recent proposal by the Metropolitan Club to sell the air rights over its landmarked clubhouse is but another chapter in the history of a club with perennial financial problems. The rights would be used by a developer to erect a 37-story apartment house over the the rear section of the club, originally built as a ladies' annex.

title: RECITAL: OKADA AND KAMO
description: THE combination of two pianos is a medium inherently troubled by crowded textures and clangorous sound. In general, only lesser composers have attacked it with any seriousness, while great ones have given it occasional, but only casual, attention.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF SHERLOCK HOLMES
description: Of course, everybody knows the Great Detective never really died at all. He managed to climb out of the Reichenbach Falls and make his way back to England where he lives still, keeping bees on the South Downs, or so his admirers say.

title:
GARDENING;
A CHARMING BORDER WITH DIVERSITY
description: LEAD: THE charm of a well-planned herbaceous border lies in the great diversity within that group of plants called herbaceous perennials. Each species, hybrid or cultivar has its own unique characteristics, and the number of perennials is so great that there can be little excuse from the early spring through late summer for having an uninteresting border.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Focus: Apartments; The Glut Benefits The Renter
description: FOR apartment-seekers in many sections of the country, this is a season of satisfaction, a time of landlord deals and vacant apartments in abundant supply.

title: Stephanie S. Porta to Wed William Eisele in August
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Porta of Coral Gables, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Stockton Porta to William Eisele, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Eisele of Aurora, Ohio. The wedding will be in August.

title:
DINING OUT;
SOMETHING NEW ALONG THE RARITAN
description: LEAD: THE first time I entered D'Auricchio's in New Brunswick, it seemed like deja vu. It reminded me so strongly of the nightclubs in some 1940's movies that I half expected Joan Crawford or Franchot Tone to walk across the floor. An ivory-colored grand piano (complete with pianist on Friday and Saturday nights), ivory banquettes, dark-blue carpeting and pillars complete the picture.

title: Urologist to Be Honored
description: Dr. John Kingsley Lattimer, chairman emeritus of the Department of Urology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, has been selected to receive the National Kidney Foundation of New York and New Jersey's first award in urology for his lifetime achievements in the field. The award will be presented at a banquet at the New York Hilton this evening.

title: The Eye Of Sugar's Storm
description: THE eye. From the time nearly a year ago when Sugar Ray Leonard began talking about challenging Marvelous Marvin Hagler for the middleweight boxing championship, people have wondered about the risk to the left eye that required detached-retina surgery nearly five years ago. In training, Sugar Ray sparred with a hooded red headgear that protected the eye. But tomorrow night the brown eye that stays open when he winks will be the eye of the desert storm of controversy that surrounds this fight. Tomorrow night the eye will be there to be hit by a devastating puncher who has produced 52 knockouts in his 62-2-2 record.

title: The Palme Investigation
description: I want to thank you for some fine journalism in recent weeks. Judith Miller's article ''The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre'' (Jan. 4), Seymour M. Hersh's article ''Target Qaddafi'' (Feb. 22) and Richard Reeves's investigation into the Palme assassination in Sweden are exceptionally well written pieces of journalism, and ones of which you should be extremely proud. CATHY OLSHEFSKI Pittsburgh

title: Sterling Forest Sale Off
description: THE insurance company that owns Sterling Forest and has been trying to sell the 30-square-mile tract of mountains, lakes and woodlands straddling the New York-New Jersey border has announced that it no longer is actively marketing the property and instead is studying alternatives to a sale, including developing up to 3,000 housing units while still preserving large sections of land.

title: John Paul Journeys to 'the End of the Earth'
description: A commitment to visit all Chileans brought Pope John Paul II today to the southernmost city in the world, this cold and windy little place on the very tip of the American mainland.

title: A PERMANENT HOME FOR ON-LOCATION COMPANY
description: WITH its premiere play in 1985 - ''Inherit the Wind,'' which was performed in a courtroom -the New Haven-based Ensemble Theater Company established a ''site specific'' identity. In this form of theater, any structure or setting can be transformed into a stage space, providing it is appropriate to the play. Thus, ''Agnes of God'' was seen in a cathedral; ''The Artful Murder'' in an art gallery, and ''Equus'' in a barn - all in the New Haven area.

title: THE WHITNEY BIENNIAL SEEKS A SOFTER TONE
description: THE LAST TIME AROUND, TWO years ago, there was disco music pounding, a neon sign flashing, sculptures that twirled, collages mixing images from high art and soft porn, and a packing crate filled with embalmed fetal pigs. It was the Whitney Biennial Exhibition, the once-every-two-year show at the Whitney Museum of American Art that presents a survey of what it deems to be the best of the nation's newest art.

title: TELEVISION TALK SHOW AWAITED IN NEW HAVEN
description: WHEN the national televison talk show host Sally Jessy Raphael moves her morning show to New Haven in June she will create a lot of firsts.

title: MEETING OF HEARTS AND OF MINDS
description: HE found his way to the familiar chair at the desk in his one-room apartment at a Fairfield County retirement home. ''Shall we read the mail?'' he asked me. ''I have two days' mail here,'' he said, fumbling with a pile of unopened letters.

title: Residential Resales: Closings in the week ended March 21
description: MANHATTAN Gramercy Park East $267,300 200 East 27th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, large entrance foyer, dining area; maintenance $809, 55% tax-de ductible (Broker: H.H. Kleigerman Associates) Upper East Side $500,000 1040 Park Avenue 2-bedroom, 3-bath, prewar co-op; doorman; dining area, maid's room, fireplace; maintenance $961, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) Upper West Side $235,000 225 Central Park West (The Alden) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; concierge, 24-hr. doorman, dining area, closet kitch en, roof terrace, Central Park views; maintenance $1,256, 68% tax-de ductible (Broker: Thompson Realty) Upper West Side $1,050,000 15 West 81st Street 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; formal dining room, 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, maintenance $1,500, 33% tax-de ductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Upper West Side $250,000 275 West 96th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 900-sq.-ft. post war condo; terrace, 24-hr. doorman, concierge, use of health club; com mon charges $353, taxes $1,200 (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) BRONX Castle Hill $150,000 2160 Cross Bronx Expressway 2-family brick semidetached house; 3 bedrooms and fireplace in primary unit, 1 bedroom in secondary unit; eat-in kitchens and 1 bath in each; garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Gold Circle Realty) Riverdale $100,000 3840 Greystone Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 786-sq.-ft. post war co-op; eat-in kitchen, dining area, large living room; mainte nance $414, 54% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. title: POP, OP AND MODERN FLOPS
description: THE STATE OF THE ART By Arthur C. Danto. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Prentice Hall Press. $19.95.

title: CHESCA CONSERVA MARRIED TO KENNETH ROBERT BARRE
description: Mary Frances Conserva and Kenneth Robert Barre, the manager of business affairs and a senior art director, respectively, for Ally & Gargano/MCA Advertising in New York, were married yesterday at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair, N.J. MSGR. Vincent E. Puma performed the ceremony.

title: PRETORIA PLANS TO CHARGE LIBERAL
description: A pro-Government newspaper reported today that the Government is planning to charge the former leader of the liberal white opposition with possessing a publication of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: SUFFOLK FILLS POSTS IN NASSAU STYLE
description: THE designation of Frank R. Jones as the new interim supervisor of Islip demonstrated anew the continuing power of Anthony Pace, the Islip Republican leader, and represents a Suffolk version of the recent political ups and downs in Nassau County.

title: Corrections
description: A video-cassette review of ''The Last of Mrs. Lincoln'' in Arts and Leisure on March 8 misidentified the writer of the play. He is James Prideaux.

title: STATE RUSHES PLAN TO EXPAND PRISONS
description: CONNECTICUT'S crowded prison system is undergoing a major expansion, which is intended to keep pace with a steadily rising population of inmates - an increase that shows no signs of abating.

title: Susan Tabas Engaged To Kenneth L. Tepper
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Tabas of Haverford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Kimberly Tabas to Kenneth Lewis Tepper, a son of Debra Gross of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia and Edward B. Tepper of Villanova, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
description: AT THE first-ever Kosher Food and Life Expo at the Jacob Javits Convention Center last month, more than 50,000 people eagerly noshed their way through everything from gefilte fish to kosher tacos. For the plain old hungry folks in the crowd, the day represented great fun. But to Irving Silverman, the show's ebullient organizer, and to the food industry executives milling about, the huge turnout branded kosher food as a blockbuster sales item.

title: Q/A
description: LEAD: Grenada Question: Are there any figures showing how many people are going to the island of Grenada these days? - W. K., Philadelphia Answer:The only official figures available come from the Grenada Government and they report an increase in visitors in 1986 compared with the previous year.

title: Paterno's Philosophy
description: HE'S better known for his success on the football field, but Joe Paterno, the Penn State coach, has always had a keen interest in education, so it should come as no surprise that his latest honor comes from the Friends of Libraries USA. It gave him a life membership and a plaque at a ceremony in Philadelphia on Friday. Paterno's credentials as a friend of libraries is impeccable. His familiy has donated $120,000 to a library endowment fund at Penn State.

title: 4 People Are Shot at Funeral Of California Gang Member
description: Gunmen opened fire Friday on a crowd of mourners at the funeral of a slain gang member, wounding four people and narrowly missing children in a school nearby, the police said.

title: Iowa Gas Facility Explodes
description: An explosion ripped through a natural gas storage terminal here today, sending flames high into air and forcing evacuation of about 75 homes within 2 1/2 miles, the authorities said. No injuries were reported. Civil defense officials said they were contemplating expanding the evacuation area fearing further explosions at the site, a Mid America Pipe Line Company facility here. Officials were advising residents of a five-mile area to leave their homes.

title: Monique Lowery Planning to Wed Eric Lindh Foster
description: The engagememt of Monique Lowery to Eric Lindh Foster has been announced by the Rev. and Mrs. James L. Lowery Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Grantham, N.H., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of William C. Foster of Great Falls, Va., and Mrs. Par Kettis of Stockholm and Castine, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: UNEASY LIES THE CROWN ON DEFENDER'S HEAD
description: NOW it's the Mets' turn to challenge the syndrome that has afflicted World Series winners in recent years. They begin the challenge Tuesday knowing that none of their eight predecessors has been able to repeat as champion.

title: Mary Stuart
description: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed James Barron's article, ''The Royal Progress'' as well as the others on Mary Queen of Scots and Edinburgh.

title: ESPOSITO PONDERS COACHING FUTURE
description: There was Phil Esposito going through his routine of pointing, shouting and sometimes even pouting at the referee, doing anything to extol his club. And from way up in the seats, Tom Webster watched, jotting notes.

title: ARCHITECT'S FLOWING VISION AND WORKS AT THE KATONAH GALLERY
description: LEAD: ENTER the lobby of the Katonah Gallery. Straight ahead, the back wall has been painted off-white and stencilled in black letters with a label for the current exhibition: Edward Larrabee Barnes Museum Designs. To the left, a side wall has been painted in signature ''Barnes blue.'' On the reception desk stands a vase of white tulips.

title: Pirate's Treasure
description: LARRY McWILLIAMS, a veteran left-hander bothered in recent seasons by shoulder problems, was released yesterday by the Pittsburgh Pirates in one of the costliest contract buyouts in major league history.

title: Broadcast TV
description: What do ''Ben-Hur'' (1959) and ''El Cid'' (1961) - due this week on the home screen - share besides Charlton Heston, visual grandeur and music by Miklos Rosza? They move, not only physically but emotionally, unlike so many blockbuster spectacles. Wisely, Channel 9 is presenting each lengthy feature in two parts on successive nights -''Ben-Hur'' on Monday and Tuesday beginning at 9 P.M., and ''El Cid'' on Wednesday and Thursday, same time.

title:
ART;
FOUND OBJECTS IN THE WHIMSICAL SPIRIT OF DUCHAMP
description: LEAD: IN the years immediately before World War I, when Marcel Duchamp produced his first series of ''readymade'' sculptures composed of such common manufactured objects as a bicycle wheel, a bottle rack and a urinal, the idea of art made from industrial materials was new and strange. Before then, creations fashioned out of scrap metal and other castoffs were the province of the folk craftsman, usually with whimsical intent.

title: Shining Knight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SALVADORN REBELS KEEP THE PRESSURE ON
description: IN a crushing attack that killed an American military adviser and more than 70 soldiers, Salvadoran leftist rebels served rude notice last week that they still intend to wage a long war and block the consolidation of the American-backed Government in El Salvador.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LEARNING TO LIVE WITH THE TURNPIKE
description: LEAD: FOR THE last 30 years, East Brunswick Township and the New Jersey Turnpike Authority have been adversaries.

title: 8,900 Line Up for 200 Jobs in West Virginia
description: For many residents of West Virginia's chemical-manufacturing area, the lure of good pay and steady work remains far stronger than the fear of any potential dangers from a job at a plant.

title: THE STORIES BEHIND THE OSCARS
description: WITH EYELIDS THAT BE-come increasingly heavy with every lost minute, we sit through each Academy Awards telecast to find out who wins what award. We eat and drink as if there's no tomorrow, though tomorrow has already come. We think we're waiting to hear the names of the winners. We assume that's the appeal, but we may be wrong.

title: Will Takeovers Be Bad for Books?
description: WOULD Rupert Murdoch's News America Holdings Inc. - or any other corporate giant - publish the next e.e. cummings? What about Charles Darwin? Karl Marx?

title:
THE NATION;
TOBACCO FARMERS FACE TOUGH CHOICES
description: LEAD: NORTH Carolina tobacco farmers have grown accustomed to antismoking campaigns, but they do not expect discouraging words from their own state government. So it was something extraordinary when the State Goals and Policy Board called tobacco a ''crop whose future is in jeopardy.''

title: The Readable Thomas Wolfe
description: To the Editor:

title: Posting: Apple Orchard Retained; A Convent in Transition
description: In 1874, the Sisters of the Good Shepherd bought a huge tract of land in Peekskill, N.Y. During the next century, it evolved into Mount St. Florence, a major convent with a girls' school, stable, dairy and orchard.
