Now the idyllic setting, on Chapel Hill Drive off Maple Street, is being translated into a 566-unit residential community on 123 acres to be called Chapel Hill Estate.

title: No Headline
description: THE grim routine is the same in every spy case. Even before the arrests are announced, a team of intelligence analysts begins pondering a question that can never be answered with certainty: ''How much damage was done?''

title: Postings: New England Flavor; An Office Building in the Tradition of a Mill
description: ''We're in Fairfield County, and we can barely call ourselves New England, but we are,'' said Roger Ferris, president of Ferris Architects of Southport, Conn.

title: MAINE TEEN-AGER FOUND GUILTY IN TWO FIRES Special to The New York Times
description: A 15-year-old Madison high school sophomore was found guilty today of arson and attempted arson in connection with two of a series of fires that terrorized residents in nearby Madison for two months last year.

title: 20 HURT AND 10,000 FLEE FUMES ON NORTH DAKOTA CHEMICAL BLAZE
description: A fire ignited toxic chemicals in an agricultural warehouse today, spewing a thick black cloud that sickened at least 37 people and forced an estimated 10,000 people to flee their homes at least temporarily.

title: GOOD TIMES TOUGH ON POLICE RECRUITING
description: WITH their populations increasing, many Connecticut communities are finding they need more police, and some of them are finding it tougher and tougher to recruit qualified candidates.

title: A Soviet-Israeli Misunderstanding
description: Relations between Israel and the Soviet Union seemed to be moving one step at a time last week, but the two sides could not agree on which way they were headed.

title: Music
description: Although Wagner hardly intended it, ''Parsifal'' and the Easter season have become inextricably linked, and it's that time of year again. While the Metropolitan Opera's 1970 production of the opera is not exactly news, it's still highly recommendable (it will be staged Monday evening and Saturday afternoon, with two more performances next week).

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MANKIEWICZ TO SPEAK Joseph L. Mankiewicz, the distinguished film director and screenwriter and winner of four Oscars, will speak at 8 P.M. Wednesday at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford where he is a parishioner. His topic is ''Religion and the Movies,'' and according to his wife, Rosemary, ''he only talks for about 20 minutes, then opens the floor to questions - he really likes that.''

title: MICHIGAN TOWNSPEOPLE RESIST THE LURE OF GROWTH
description: There will be no Howard Johnson's blocking the bay, nor a fancy shopping mall nor any condominiums if most people here can help it.

title: A MAVERICK EASES INTO THE ABOVEGROUND
description: LA MONTE YOUNG, THE 51-YEAR-OLD American maverick composer, is often called the father of Minimalism, but one could make an equally strong case for him as the father of punk rock.

title: WOMEN AND LAW IN NEW YORK STATE
description: On Feb. 15, the Connecticut Guide column contained an item titled ''Women and Law,'' which discussed a book by Karen Berger Morello. Alice Miskimin was quoted in paraphrase as stating that female lawyers were not admitted to membership in the New York State Bar Association until the 1930's. That information was not correct.

title: WHO WILL WIN, HAGLER OR LEONARD, AND WHY?
description: Answer: Both will lose.

title: L.I.R.R. FUNDS, UNUSED, INCREASED
description: AS the Long Island Rail Road embarks on still another attempt to improve service, it risks leaving $95 million in Federal funds stranded.

title: BEST SELLERS: APRIL 5, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 3 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 9 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 3 3 10 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 4 4 4 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an international arms-selling intrigue. 5 6 2 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) The 30-year romance of a couple with diverse backgrounds and ambitions. 6 5 36 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 7 11 27 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 8 7 12 NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A mission to keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans. 9 13 23 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war over Vietnam. 10 10 7 OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) Tracking down a mysterious disease that strikes certain physicians and their patients. 11 8 30 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 12 9 11 THE PANIC OF '89, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A financial wizard undertakes to defuse the crisis besetting Wall Street and the American economy. 13* 1 SANTORINI, by Alistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Espionage, treachery and retrieval of a sunken atom bomb in the Aegean. 14 15 22 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 15 14 3 THE RED WHITE AND BLUE, by John Gregory Dunne. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) America during the past 25 years, seen through the lives of a rich and powerful California family. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 14 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the Indiana University basketball team. 2 2 6 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $17.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his family's place in upstate New York. 3 11 3 BOONE, by T. Boone Pickens Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) The autobiography of an oilman and corporation-takeover entrepreneur. 4* 7 18 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 5 3 7 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) From the Boston slums of Irish immigrants to the White House: three generations of a family. 6* 4 48 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 7 6 8 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Perigord/Morrow, $18.95.) A case involving the murder of a Pennsylvania high school teacher and the disappearance of her two children. 8* 5 8 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. 9 8 5 INTIMATE PARTNERS, by Maggie Scarf. (Random House, $18.95.) Changing patterns in love and marriage. 10 9 3 BETTY: A Glad Awakening, by Betty Ford with Chris Chase. (Doubleday, $16.95.) A former First Lady's recovery from alcoholism and drug abuse. 11 10 56 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 12 1 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 13 13 12 THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the show starring Lily Tomlin. 14 15 26 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. 15 1 JOHNSON V. JOHNSON, by Barbara Goldsmith. (Knopf, $18.95.) The courtroom war between six children and their stepmother over a half-billion- dollar estate. Weeks This Last On Week Week List ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 1 26 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 2 2 23 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 3 5 2 HOW TO BE YOUR OWN NUTRITIONIST, by Stuart M. Berger. (Morrow, $16.95.) Ways to create a diet regimen for health and energy. 4 3 42 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 5 4 82 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ARTFUL PARTNERS: Bernard Berenson and Joseph Duveen, by Colin Simpson. (Macmillan, $22.50.) An international art world with all the moral nicety of an underwater feeding frenzy, and the two biggest fish in partnership, one of whom, Bernard Berenson, is indicted here for an appetite that unscrupulousness helped sate. BERNARD BERENSON: The Making of a Legend, by Ernest Samuels. (Belknap/Harvard University, $25.) Greedy for exquisite sensations, B.B., the subject of this official biography, failed to write the book of art criticism he owed his generation, but would he have lived this life if he had? SONG IN A WEARY THROAT: An American Pilgrimage, by Pauli Murray. (Harper & Row, $23.95.) This posthumously published autobiography of a black woman writer (and later lawyer) born in 1910 could be every black American's history to some degree. VISIONS AND NIGHTMARES: America After Reagan, by Robert Lekachman. (Macmillan, $19.95.) An angry professor of economics sees an America bewitched by the magic of self-enrichment, blind to the commonweal. AN ARROW IN THE WALL: Selected Poetry and Prose, by Andrei Voznesensky. Edited by William Jay Smith and F. D. Reeve. (Holt, $22.95.) Translated by a number of hands (including W. H. Auden and Stanley Kunitz), this book represents the best attempt so far to bring a contemporary Russian poet into a Western context. IN THE CITY, by Joan Silber. (Viking, $16.95.) This second novel, about a minimalist heroine in a room of her own in 1920's New York, has some of the immediacy of a tale written in the 20's. THE MISALLIANCE, by Anita Brookner. (Pantheon, $14.95.) As always, Ms. Brookner's prose is crisp and unerring, her gifts as a psychologist of the wounded woman's heart formidable.

title: MAKING HOME SWEET FOR CENTRAL PARK ZOO ANIMALS
description: Penguins may begin making their way to the Central Park Zoo from San Diego as early as this summer, followed shortly by polar bears from Buffalo, sea lions from the Bronx and ants from Cincinnati.

title: A Passover Seder
description: UNTIL I MET CHEF BARRY WINE OF NEW York's four-star Quilted Giraffe restaurant, I had thought that the Passover seder meal, just like the seder itself, should stick to tradition. After all, 3,400 years after the Exodus of the Jews from Egypt, the seder, which starts April 13, is being celebrated in much the original way. Jews still eat the unleavened bread, taste the bitter herbs, ask the four ritual questions and drink four cups of wine.

title: 'ORPHANS' DISPLAYS DIRECTOR'S AND ACTORS' TALENTS
description: THE first image in the Penguin Repertory production of ''Orphans'' is striking.

title: Solid Waste Recycling Urged
description: The United States is rapidly running out of space to dump its garbage but could avert a crisis by recycling its solid waste, according to a report issued today by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: Note on N.I.T.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE ELUSIVE LANGUAGE OF PLEASURE AND PAIN
description: RILKE was probably right when he wrote that the events of the human body - pain, orgasm, taste, smell -are indescribable. These are events and experiences for which language offers no solution. They cannot be conveyed. The writer falls back from his assault upon these citadels of sensation and contents himself with encircling the body with an array of sentences, besieging it with paragraphs in the hope that he will awaken a connection, however dim, between what his character is feeling and what the reader has felt in his own lifetime. The writer must try to awaken the buried past of the reader.

title: IT'S NOT ALL CAMELS AND CADILLACS
description: THE ARABS Journeys Beyond the Mirage. By David Lamb. 333 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Photograph Of an AIDS Patient
description: By including a photograph of an AIDS patient covered from head to toe with lesions, in a photojournalism spread, you acted irresponsibly (''Photojournalism's Colorful Era,'' March 1).

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; PLEASANTVILLE
description: IN Pleasantville, it has long been the custom around Christmas for villagers to gather at the gazebo near the railroad station to sing carols. A few years ago, a woman who was the guest of a local family watched as the man leading the singing paused to ask who had been there before.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
CATALOGING A LOVE OF BOOKS
description: LEAD: IT was a small, narrow-windowed building, its red brick facade faded to a warm ochre color and its front door fashioned of gleaming oak and studded with polished brass hinges and an imposing plaque that read ''Brooklyn Pvblic Library: Sheepshead Bay Branch.''

title: OFF BROADWAY GETS A MADCAP DOSE OF RELIGION
description: OVERZEALOUS EVANGELISTS have been an easy butt of satire, from Sinclair Lewis's ''Elmer Gantry'' to Flannery O'Connor's ''Wise Blood.'' ''Tent Meeting,'' the new comic play that opens Wednesday at the Astor Place Theater, derives much of its humor from the megalomaniacal showmanship and just plain madness of its revival preacher, the Rev. Ed Tarbox.

title: REPRESENTING 'THE AVERAGE FAMILY'
description: REPRESENTATIVE John G. Rowland's idea of recreation is to go to a in the Fifth Congressional District and mix with the crowd.

title: A FAMILY'S SECURITY STOLEN BY THIEVES
description: THIEVES have stolen our peace of mind. Returning home one afternoon last week, my little boy and I discovered our door wide open. A muddy sneaker print on the door showed clearly what had happened. In the middle of the afternoon on a clear sunny day a stranger had kicked in our side door.

title: Corrections; CORRECTIONS
description: ''Kicking the Habit,'' a listing of anti-smoking programs last Sunday in The Good Health Magazine (part 2 of The Times Magazine), misstated the cost of the New York Lung Association's program. The series of six 90-minute sessions costs $40.

title: THE SHIRAZ QUARTET
description: LEAD: PERSIAN NIGHTS By Diane Johnson. 352 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: GETTING EVEN WITH FLAUBERT
description: LUI A View of Him. By Louise Colet. Translated by Marilyn Gaddis Rose. 317 pp. Athens, Ga.: The University of Georgia Press. $24.95.

title: Soviet Says Plane Pakistanis Downed Had Military Insignia
description: The official Soviet news agency Tass today said an Afghan plane shot down by Pakistan on Monday bore military markings but was unarmed and was carrying civilians on an internal flight.

title: LET'S NOT TALK DOWN TO OURSELVES
description: THIS is a very strange country. It has created an enormous university system in which flourishes, among the omnium-gatherum of things learnable and pursuable, an intense subculture of poetry and fiction writing. The outpouring of literary work is so great as to obscure itself, too great to be attended to with the kind of care a slenderer production would allow. It is a novelty to treat the writing of poetry as an academic subject, but to do it merely expresses the cultural expectation that every worthy enterprise should take the form of learning. Out of this assumption comes the privileged place of the universities themselves, which function, like the medieval cities they have often been built to resemble, as the protectors and sponsors of arts and skills and crafts, as the guarantors of extraordinary freedom to those intent upon some business of their own that has no established place in the outside world.

title: TROUBLESOME PRIESTS
description: THE JESUITS The Society of Jesus and the Betrayal of the Roman Catholic Church. By Malachi Martin. 525 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: PROGRAM HELPS DISABLED ENTER THE WORK FORCE
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH her speech is impaired, Darlene LaRue carries a message to self-advocacy groups of disabled people in institutions, group homes and sheltered workshops: ''Take responsibility for yourselves,'' she tells them. ''Don't depend on other people. Try things. Don't give up. and maybe someday you'll be out on your own like normal people.

title: MAKING LOVE IS NOT AEROBIC - SO WHAT?
description: EXERCISE books and I never seem to work out. It is not in my nature to read anything for ulterior purposes, except maps, and sometimes even there I eschew routedness to frolic in the names of rivers. Sure, I read with an agenda: to become a better person. But in hard-to-specify respects.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A Commercial Boom Hits Hillsborough
description: LEAD: GROWTH in Hillsborough over the last two decades is apparent in the many single-family homes and condominium complexes that stand on what was once prime farmland. But commercial development in Somerset County's largest township has been limited.

title: EGYPT GETTING A 'DOSE' OF DEMOCRACY
description: ''Stability, Development, Democracy'' say the election banners strung across Cairo's crowded streets by President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party.

title: THE MOTHER AND THE JUDGE
description: The Baby M case was a tragedy without villains until the very end, and then the judge stepped forward.

title: Sydney
description: To the Editor: We were pleased to read about the Sydney Opera House, which brought back memories of our visit in 1984. We had bought the package ''An Evening at the Sydney Opera House'' before we left. We enjoyed the visit but did have a problem with the guided tour. For those of us who are older and/or arthritic, the numerous steps are an obstacle. There are no elevators. We would hope the new renovations are addressing this problem. VIVIAN E. NEWSTROM Oneonta, N.Y.

title: IN GLOBAL FINANCIAL CIRCUS, EVERYONE IS GROWING FRANTIC
description: THE world economy last week was like a three-ring circus, with the turbulent events in each ring spilling over into the others.

title: THE ESSENCE OF SOME EMINENT VICTORIANS, COURTESY OF MAX BEERBOHM
description: IF YOU HURRY - IT IS ONLY on for a few more days - you can catch a delectable show at the Bertha and Karl Leubsdorf Art Gallery in Hunter College (at Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, through Friday). It consists of some 60 caricatures by Max Beerbohm -most of them little known, and a number of them never before exhibited or reproduced. Together they offer a dazzling conspectus of Beerbohm's pictorial skills.

title: Carlton Looks Ahead
description: RENEWED by a change in mechanics, Steve Carlton said yesterday he signed with the Cleveland Indians because ''I've got two or three more years, absolutely.'' Carlton, the only pitcher to win the Cy Young Award four times, insisted he is far from over the hill at age 42.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; A 'Hoptel' Rx for New Haven Hospitals
description: NOW that many hospitals in Connecticut no longer find it profitable to treat patients on a day-to-day basis, they are seeking ways to make themselves more efficient and cost-effective.

title:
SYMPOSIUM: A WORLD WITHOUT NUCLEAR ARMS?;
Defense Is The Best Defense
description: LEAD: Will the balance of terror ever end? Will it end in a balance free from terror, or a terror lacking all balance?

title: A VILLA-TO-VILLA TOUR BEYOND LUCCA'S WALLS
description: Lucca's guests have never been disappointed. Or so it would seem from reading their encomiums stretching back as far as Montaigne who rode through the villa-strewn countryside in 1581 recording the scene. Even a visitor today would agree that the same porticoes, loggias and gardens of the same villas the Frenchman admired ''add greatly to their beauty,'' as he wrote in his journal.

title: 'FORWARD VIEW' AT THE SQUIBB: AN ABUNDANCE OF ETHNICITY
description: As an institution, Afro-Ameri-ican art has proved that there is more to black art than the work of stars such as Jacob Lawrence and Romare Bearden.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CELEBRITY READINGS Libraries are celebrating National Library Week with celebrity readings, in which notable people read from works that have significance for them. Three interesting sessions will be in Easton, Westport and Hartford.

title: AT RETIREMENT AGE, FEDERAL JUDGES CHOOSE TO HELP REDUCE COURT'S CASELOAD
description: Judge Milton Pollack completed a stock-fraud trial last week, conducting it in the stern style that he has used for almost 20 years in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Radio Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: A GOLD MEDAL WINNER WHO IS NEVER SATISFIED
description: FOR someone who has made many people happy, Pablo Morales is still trying to achieve happiness himself.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: LEAD: Some photographic portraits of artists are generally considered to be works of art in their own right - for example, Henri Cartier-Bresson's 1943 portrait of the aged Matisse surrounded by fluttering doves, Berenice Abbott's 1950 full-length study of a dour Edward Hopper in his bare studio, and Arnold Newman's 1954 portrait of Picasso, hand to furrowed brow, one eye piercing the viewer.

title: David Richards And Jane Battle Wed in Virginia
description: Jane Tavernor Battle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cullen Battle of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to David Douglas Richards, a son of Cynthia Richards of Duxbury, Mass., and Douglas Richards of Springfield, Vt. The Rev. W.Ramsey Richardson performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville.

title: Icy Journey
description: ICELAND RIVER CHALLENGE National Geographic Video. Directors: Paul Vander-Milen, Bruno Casa. Narrated by Gene Galusha. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: DATA BANK: April 5, 1987
ORATORIO: IN BROOKLYN, SATOH'S 'STABAT MATER'
description: THE ARTS AT ST. ANN'S is an ambitious, large-scale performance-art series at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Steeets in Brooklyn Heights. Right now the series is offering its second collaboration between the Japanese composer Somei Satoh and the German theater director Manuel Lutgenhorst. Their first was called ''Journey Through Sacred Time'' and took place in 1985. This one is ''Stabat Mater.'' It opened Friday night and continues tonight and Friday and Saturday. As it turns out, this is another ''journey through sacred time,'' and it would seem to have about the same blend of virtues (mostly Mr. Satoh's) and faults (mostly Mr. Lutgenhorst's) as before.

title: A Food Critic's Cravings
description: Contrary to the title of Marian Burros's article ''A Road Not Often Taken'' (Food, March 8), the food critic Jane Stern has chosen a path that is becoming increasingly common: alternating between diets and binges.

title: So, You Want to Be a Broker
description: Many small investors at one time or another -perhaps after taking a bath on a particular stock -have thought they could do at least as well in the market as their broker. Indeed, some investors may even have wondered if they could succeed as a stockbroker for a Merrill Lynch, an E. F. Hutton or a Dean Witter.

title: Why Dollar Is Almighty
description: To the Editor:

title: STAR WEATHERMAN: Willard Scott A Huckster For All Seasons
description: FORGET Ed McMahon. Put Joan Collins and Bill Cosby on hold. Go after Willard Scott.

title: MAKING DO AT NEWARK
description: The good news about infamous Terminal B at Newark International Airport is that gigantic Terminal C is on the way. The bad news is that the New York hub of Continental Airlines, still struggling to digest the People Express whale, will continue to be Terminal B during the height of this year's travel season. By the best guess, this means there is a chance of 1 in 6 that a traveler flying into or out of the New York area will pass through Terminal B. Some travel experts have called Terminal B, with its luggage mountains and stairwells stacked with skis, the laughing stock of the airline industry, which makes the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey bristle and blame its tenant, Continental, for most of the problems.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 22 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: EARLY SCHOOLS IN HUNTINGTON
description: In reference to your story about the ''Little Red Schoolhouse'' in Elwood [ Long Island Journal, March 8 ] , please be informed that this is not the ''first'' school in the district. School districts were set up in New York State in 1812 and reformed in 1816.

title: AN OUTSIDER INSIDE THE THIRD REICH
description: BERLIN DIARIES, 1940-1945 By Marie Vassiltchikov. Illustrated. Maps. 324 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: JAZZ/POP SINGERS FIND FRESH ROADS TO TRAVEL
description: SINGERS WORKING IN THE twilight world between pop and jazz who develop a stylized approach early in their careers may find this a helpful and secure base for a while. But as time goes by, the style is apt to lose its vitality and limit the singer's horizons.

title: Sugarcoating Science
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD
description: Madeleine Cooks Chicken Breger Video.(800) 228-5511. 90 minutes. $39.95

title: THE SUDDEN FALL OF A BASEBALL PHENOMENON
description: In the garage on East Elm Street in the Hillsborough section of Tampa, the red Porsche and silver Mercedes stand as the symbols of success. In the modest one-story house, the agonized looks, the 13-month-old baby and the missing father stand as the symbols of failure.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FIGHTING BACK The Struggle for Gay Rights. By Sabra Holbrook. 99 pp. New York: Lodestar/E. P. Dutton. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: VIETNAM MEMORIAL GAINS
description: LEAD: SOMETIME next week, the Suffolk County Legislature is likely to approve a proposal that will pave the way for a monument to the county's Vietnam War veterans. The $100,000 proposal would provide money for a design contest for the memorial.

title: HEARINGS IN RACIAL ATTACK FOCUS ON POLICE QUESTIONING OF SUSPECTS
description: Pretrial hearings in the Howard Beach racial-assault case have focused on how the defendants were initially handled by the police.

title: ADOPTION MARKET: BIG DEMAND, TIGHT SUPPLY
description: The legal battle over Baby M that was decided this week in a New Jersey courtroom has focused attention on a widening gap between the number of infertile American couples who want children and the number of babies available for adoption.

title: UNCOVERING WELFARE FRAUD
description: LEAD: CITING typical welfare-fraud cases, Westchester officials said that one county resident was done in by her greed, two other residents by a computer and a fourth by an acquaintance.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Montserrat Caballe The Woman, the Diva Directed by Antonio Chic. Stereo. Kultur. 67 Minutes. $39.95.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: The Gruntled Employee
description: WE OUGHT TO SIT quietly and think about how we handle Mike,'' wrote Oliver L. North to Bud McFarlane, ''so that he does not start talking out of disgruntlement (if that's a word). . . .''

title: POMONA AIRPORT PLAN DUE SOON
description: LEAD: AN East Orange consulting company is putting the finishing touches on a master plan for Atlantic City International Airport that is expected to recommend that an authority take over the facility in Pomona, a dozen miles northwest of here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, APRIL 5, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: 10 AMERICANS TO HEAD FOR SOVIET IN JUNE FOR FRIENDLY FISHING
description: THE Russians have responded to a long cast from an imaginative band of American fly fishermen.

title: WARM WEATHER IS BLOW TO MAPLE SYRUP CROP
description: The warm spring weather of the last two weeks has been terrible for Victor and Cindy Putnam and hundreds of other maple syrup farmers in New York State and Vermont.

title: MORALES CAPS CAREER
description: Pablo Morales of Stanford and Matt Biondi of California finished their college championship swimming careers tonight with victories that made the record books. So did John VanSant, a senior from Army, which is hardly a national swimming power.

title: COLLEGES EXAMINE SEX BIAS
description: IN THE wake of sex-discrimination charges against Ramapo College and Rutgers University by female faculty members, many college officials in the state are looking more closely at their institutions' hiring, promotion and tenure procedures.

title: AIDS RATE HIGHEST IN STAMFORD ADDICTS
description: LEAD: FORTY-ONE percent of the intravenous drug users entering methadone treatment in Stamford are testing positive in routine screening for indications of AIDS virus infection, said an epidemiologist with the Federal Centers for Disease Control, Dr. Lyle R. Petersen.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE POISONED WOMB: Human Reproduction in a Polluted World. By John Elkington. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) Few environmental issues inspire more anxiety than the effect of synthetic chemicals on the unborn. Such chemicals may lower fertility, increase the risk of spontaneous abortion and cause fetal deformities.

title: Film; WHY HORROR MOVIES STILL GNAW AT US
description: ''G OTHIC,'' A NEW KEN RUS-sell film, begins with music of vibrating doom, ghoulish spirits whizzing past from another world, an insane frothing-at-the-mouth flamenco. A distant object, floating in the blackness like a murder weapon of some sort, becomes minimally clearer as it approaches, then fills the screen as a human skull while the music booms. And it brings with it many questions about why horror films thrill and possess us.

title: Recent Sales
description: Mount Kisco, N.Y. $368,200 Byram Lake Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 127-year-old clapboard farmhouse; eat-in kitchen, red barn, terrace, playroom, 1.7 acre; taxes $2,941. Ossining, N.Y. $265,000 116 Cedar Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old frame raised ranch; family room, studio, seasonal river view, 0.62 acre; taxes $4,311. Yonkers, N.Y. $198,500 169 Rockne Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old brick/frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, walk to schools and stores; taxes $3,046. Milford, Conn. $340,000 67 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; on waterfront, newly remodeled; taxes $2,200. Roxbury, Conn. $480,000 South Street 4-bedroom, 4-bath, contemporary; new construction, wood moldings, fireplace in master bedroom, 6 acres; taxes $4,033. West Haven, Conn. $141,500 7 Park Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dead-end street, aluminum siding; taxes $2,100. OTHER AREAS Lake Hiawatha, N.J. $118,500 32 Calumet Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fire place, enclosed porch; taxes $1,142. Millburn, N.J. $220,000 79 Linden Street 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old colonial; din ing room, 1-car attached garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,006. Setauket, L.I. $270,000 39 Gaul Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; fire place, dining room, basement, 2-car ga rage, brick and cedar siding; taxes $4,600.

title: McPartland Master Class
description: Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist and composer, will give a master class Tuesday evening at 7:30 at the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue. She will comment on the performances of student soloists and ensembles, and will illustrate certain points at the piano. The two-hour session is free and open to the public; no tickets or reservations are required. For information: (212) 749-2802, extension 534.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
MEN, WOMEN AND ONENESS
description: LEAD: LOVE AND HUMAN SEPARATENESS By Ilham Dilman. 169 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $19.95.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Dover, Del.: Reassessment Sparks Protest
description: LEAD: AN uproar has greeted the first property reappraisal in 21 years in Kent County, jamming phone lines for days with angry calls from homeowners and farmers following their receipt of new assessment notices.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT: VENTURES IN THE SKIN TRADE
description: LEAD: The ancient art of tattoos traveled like gossip over trade routes and continents. King George V, Nicholas II of Russia and Lady Randolph Churchill had them, along with souvenir-crazed Americans and fashionable Victorian women who wished their lips to be a permanent pink. But Japanese tattoo is a serious folk art, like landscape painting or flower arranging, and great tattoo masters still perform their work.

title: JURY'S POWER COMES INTO PLAY IN GOEZ TRIAL
description: THE chief attorney for Bernhard H. Goetz, Barry I. Slotnick, stood before a panel of 18 prospective jurors the other day and asked a question that has echoed through the legal system in this country for more than 300 years: ''If you find that the prosecution has proved its case beyond a reasonable doubt . . . and if the judge instructs you that you must convict on that basis, would you feel obligated to do so?''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Audubon Society is getting a new sanctuary in the Pine Barrens, thanks to an Ocean Township builder, Hirair Hovnanian. He has donated a 265-acre tract in Berkeley Township, along with a cash gift to support a part-time naturalist at the site.

title: DIFFERENT KEYS BRING ENFIELD COMPOSER JOY AND SUSTENANCE
description: ALAN LEICHTLING spends more time at the computer keyboard than at the piano keys upon which he composes. But he said he found time on weekends and at 5 o'clock most mornings in the last nine months to ''scratch out'' his latest composition, Symphony No. 5, which was commissioned by the Greater Bridgeport Symphony.

title: JAZZ: MANCE AND RIVERA
description: POSITANO, a restaurant at 240 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street, joined the city's jazz- piano rooms this week. Unlike most of the other piano rooms, which feature piano and bass duos, Positano is using trios -piano, bass and drums.

title: BLALOCK LOOKS FORWARD TO RETIREMENT IN 1988
description: Jane Blalock, who won a precedent-setting legal battle to remain on the tour 15 years ago, said she would retire from women's professional golf after this season to become a financial consultant.

title: SPLIT OVER FLUSHING BAY CLEANUP PLAN
description: A plan to clean up heavily polluted Flushing Bay in Queens is threatening to divide New York City environmental and parks officials.

title: Dr. Hunt to Wed Dr. Gregg Stave
description: Dr. Christine M. Hunt, a fellow in gastroenterology, and Dr. Gregg M. Stave, a resident in internal medicine, both at the Medical College of Virginia Hospitals in Richmond, are planning a September wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hunt of Virginia Beach, Va., have announced.

title: A ROOM OF ONE'S OWN
description: WILHELMINA HOLLIDAY, touring a museum in Vienna years ago with her husband, was taken with the work of Clara Peeters. Returning to the United States, she attempted to find out more about Peeters. What she found was not only that Peeters was absent from H. W. Janson's ''History of Art,'' but that no other woman artist was included either. Today there is a painting by Peeters hung in the dining room of Mrs. Holliday's Georgetown house. ''Still Life of Fish and Cat,'' acquired about 10 years ago, is indeed the work of a talented person working within the Dutch still life tradition (Peeters was a contemporary of Rembrandt). You could lift this oyster out of the painting; it is so convincingly rendered that you instantly remember the touch and taste of the real thing. The cat stretched above the assortment of food is not a cat anyone would have wanted then or now. Beauty is tempered by an almost chaotic lushness: The ubiquitous cat and prey are pushed to an intensity that makes the modern eye wonder about this painter's wish to comfort with the conventions of the time. Perhaps she felt a kinship with DeHeem, whose paintings of flowers, lush yet teeming with bugs and snails fallen to the tables beneath them, mock any simple ideas of beauty.

title: Cinema Verite
description: During my ''Hollywood press relations'' days, I called Stanley Donen's production company to ask whether anyone there had noticed the goof made in the Alfred Hitchcock thriller ''North by Northwest'' - in the scene in which Cary Grant is being pursued by a small aircraft. The crop-duster gets closer to him with every exciting fly-past. But after pitching around the field, throwing himself into a ditch and then diving under a truck to elude his pursuers, Grant appears in the next scene wearing an immaculate suit.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: MORE vehicles than ever used the bridges and tunnels of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1986, according to statistics compiled by the authority. Some 110 million cars, buses and trucks crossed from New Jersey to New York, compared to 105.6 million in 1985.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: TAKING THE WORLD'S PULSE
description: THEY ALL LAUGHED AT CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS Tales of Medicine and the Art of Discovery. By Gerald Weissmann. 270 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: AFTER A DAY OF GLORY, WHAT'S NEXT FOR CHAD?
description: IN the bazaar here, merchants are hawking Ndjamena's latest novelty - bolts of cotton cloth printed with a map of Chad and blue, yellow and red Chadian flags marking oases recently freed from Libyan military occupation.

title: SAMPLIG SCRAPPLE AT THE SOURCE
description: Scrapple, as its name suggests, is made from scraps - the odds and ends of pork-butchering, boiled into broth and bulked out with grain. It is a thrifty farmers' food, brought from the lower Rhineland, in the late 17th century, to Pennsylvania.

title: Big Winner of TV Evangelists May Be Falwell
description: To the Editor:

title: LOGRANDE RUNNING HARD TO STAY IN PLACE
description: LEAD: ACTING Suffolk County Executive Michael A. LoGrande took some Republicans out to lunch recently. They were county legislators, and Mr. LoGrande, also a Republican, sought to build some bridges the volatile County Legislature won't burn.

title: STUDENTS GET AN AIDS MESSAGE
description: LEAD: ''This is the scariest thing I have ever heard in my whole life,'' said 15-year-old Miquel Gutierrez of Branchburg after hearing a recent talk on AIDS by Dr. Molly Joel Coye, the state's Commissioner of Health.

title: Ms. McCloskey To Wed in May
description: Elizabeth Frances McCloskey, a candidate for a master's degree at the Yale Divinity School, and Peter Collins Leibold, a second-year student at the Yale Law School, plan to be married May 30.

title: IT'S UP AND OVER IN MARYLAND
description: When the lush valleys north of Baltimore begin to brighten with a soft spring green and the hillsides are dotted with flowering dogwood trees, the steeplechase season begins in Maryland's rolling hunt country, as it has since Colonial days.

title: DESPITE WOES, THE CHALLENGE IS WELCOME
description: Dave Johnson, who regularly says that he doesn't like surprises, got a couple of big ones this week.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS LOOK TO FUTURE
description: LEAD: IN front of theaters where the movie ''Platoon'' is playing, members of the local chapter of the Vietnam Veterans of America have been handing out leaflets explaining their group. They also sell raffle tickets for a weeklong trip to Los Angeles, to raise funds for their effort to carry their chapter colors in a ''homecoming parade'' there in

title: LETTING LINZ CASTLE CAST A SPELL
description: It's a stop for all trains on the old Orient Express line, but few visitors to Austria get out in Linz, and most foreign motorists on the Vienna-Salzburg superhighway flit past the Linz exit. They apparently do not realize that the city is famous for the Linzer torte , a renowned cake, and that the old section in the center of town is crammed with Renaissance and Baroque buildings, some with plaques commemorating visits by such composers as Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert and the astronomer Johannes Kepler.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: ARTS AND CHANGE Philadelphia will be host to a national conference on ''The Arts as a Force for Social Change'' next weekend at Drexel University. The three-day conference, which begins Friday, is dedicated to ''the countless artists, known and unknown, whose voices have been silenced by government repression.''

title: COMMISSIONS: WHERE PATRON MEETS COMPOSER
description: THIS AFTERNOON IN Carnegie Hall, as the final work in the final concert of the American Composers Orchestra's 10th anniversary season, Philip Glass's Violin Concerto will receive its world premiere. On Tuesday in the same hall, the Philadelphia Orchestra will open a subscription concert with the New York premiere of Ralph Shapey's ''Symphonie Concertante.''

title: In Basic Black and White, Chanel to a T
description: CHANEL NO. 5. First the perfume. Now . . . the T-shirt? This, of course, is no ordinary T-shirt. If nothing else, its price - $80 at Chanel boutiques - sets it far apart from anything with bunches of fruit on the label. And it has to be one of the few T-shirts that is just as much at home under a full-length mink coat as it is over sweatpants.

title: Sherill A. Leonard, Yale Law Student, Engaged to David Sanger, a Reporter
description: Sherill Ann Leonard, a third-year student at the Yale Law School, and David E. Sanger, a reporter for The New York Times, are planning to be married June 28. The couple's parents are Carolyn Cearley of Round Rock, Tex., and the late Walter Reed Leonard, and Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Sanger of White Plains.

title: BUILDING BLOCKS THAT ASK THE RIGHT QUESTIONS
description: UP TO NOW, I HAVE GENERALLY believed that the best way to interest children in architecture is to let them loose in it - to let them experience soaring space, to let them look up to great height, to let them touch and feel materials and textures and decoration. There's still no substitute for the real thing, but a close second is the exhibition, ''Building Buildings'' that was recently mounted at the Staten Island Children's Museum at Snug Harbor. It is an ideal introduction to architecture for children, not because it is visually spectacular - it is in fact fairly modest, though it is consistently well designed - as because it asks the right questions.

title: Israeli in Pollard's Spy Case Named a Military Instructor
description: Col. Aviem Sella, who resigned his command of a major Israeli air base because of his role in the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy scandal, has been appointed an instructor in the National Security College, the army said today.

title:
GARDENING;
A CHARMING BORDER WITH DIVERSITY
description: LEAD: THE charm of a well-planned herbaceous border lies in the great diversity within that group of plants called herbaceous perennials. Each species, hybrid or cultivar has its own unique characteristics, and the number of perennials is so great that there can be little excuse from the early spring through late summer for having an uninteresting border.

title: DEVELOPMENT ALONG THE HUDSON: TWO VILLAGES, TWO APPROACHES
description: TWO Hudson River villages, Hastings-on-Hudson and Irvington, are grappling with decisions on what to do with their waterfronts. Those waterfronts include some of the county's choicest sites - the kind where millionaires want to live and where developers hope to make their fortunes - with land worth about $100,000 an acre. Residents of both villages are worried about what kind of development might take place.

title: ROBERT LUMIANSKY, A MEDIEVAL SCHOLAR AND TEACHER, DIES
description: Robert M. Lumiansky, a scholar of Medieval English and former president of the American Council of Learned Societies, died of cancer Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ENIGMA VARIATIONS (BUT NOT BY ELGAR)
description: WHEN Ljubomir Ljubojevic uses an opening system that lies outside the mainstream, it is not always easy to know what to make of it.

title: No Headline
description: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to take part in an ''encounter with the world of labor'' here Sunday morning. But the fishermen of this gritty port city, like many other workers in the economically depressed south of Chile, have had to send their regrets.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PARKING PLACES RAFFLED
description: LEAD: In certain parts of Westchester where parking is at a premium, a space to call one's own might be considered the ultimate fantasy.

title: Demystifying The Bomb
description: If we look into the past, we can find many occasions on which nuclear weapons have actually been abolished. We used to have nuclear antiaircraft missiles - Nike-Hercules and Bomarc - scattered widely around the United States. They are not there now. We used to have nuclear intermediate-range missiles - Jupiter and Thor - deployed in Italy and Turkey. They are not there now.

title: LANDMARK STATUS
description: THE guests at a party in New Rochelle ate what they think their ancestors ate in the house where their ancestors lived, at the recent celebration of the awarding of Federal landmark status to the city's oldest house.

title: MEETING NEEDS OF THE POOR AND HOMELESS
description: GOVERNOR O'NEILL, in his State of the State Address in January to the General Assembly, said: ''Let us create the resources to protect the homeless from deathly cold of the lonely streets, to put a roof over the struggling young family and to bring comfort of affordable shelter and care to the frail and the elderly. . . .We regard safe and affordable housing as a deeply rooted and inalienable right of every citizen of our state.''

title: Cinema Verite
description: Mordecai Richler can add to his list of movie-production errors the final scene in Woody Allen's ''Radio Days'': there was no Great White Way in New York on New Year's Eve during the war years (1940's); there was a brownout! JEROME AGEL New York City

title: Andrea Braverman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Monte Braverman of Tenafly, N.J., and Snowmass Village, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Braverman to Lewis Stephen Gross, the son of Mrs. Irwin K. Champman of Closter, N.J., and Maurice A. Gross of Chappaqua, N.Y. Miss Braverman, who heads her own company, Ande's Baby Clothes, in Edgewater, N.J., and Mr. Gross, president of Sports Professional Management Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., are 1983 graduates of Syracuse University. The wedding is to be May 23.

title: TURNING MY WORDS AGAINST ME
description: LAST October I got something in my mailbox at the hospital. There was the usual quantity of free (and unrequested) information from drug companies - ''Finally! A pediatric anti-diarrheal agent that tastes so good kids want to take it!!!'' There were bulletins from the hospital about saving money, not ordering unnecessary diagnostic tests. There were three or four letters offering to lend me astonishingly large sums of money at apparently amazingly low rates (''Dear Young Doctor, we know that now, early in your training, is a time of great hopes and great hardship''). And there was also a photocopied article tucked into a plain envelope, no message, no sender's name. The article, from ''American Beat'' by Bob Greene, was the story of a young writer who, as an experiment, sent out a manuscript by Jerzy Kosinski under his own name, a manuscript that had already been published to great acclaim. Sure enough, no editor or agent recognized the book, not even the publisher who had originally brought it out, and no one thought it was worth publishing. The young writer collected any number of comments, highly comic under the circumstances, and was told among other things that his work read like a weak version of Jerzy Kosinski.

title: SUKOVA TOPS McNEIL TO WIN U.S. INDOOR
description: Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, the second-seeded player, beat fourth-seeded Lori McNeil of Houston, 6-0, 6-3, today to win the singles title in the $150,000 United States Women's Indoor Tennis Championships.

title: PIANO: BRUCE WOLOSOFF
description: BRUCE WOLOSOFF'S evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday was perhaps more imaginative for its planning than its execution. There were, for example, two interesting pieces, one old, one new: the Busoni F-minor Sonata and a new sonata by Richard Danielpour.

title: WHERE HIEDI BELONGS
description: The location scouts for the 1978 remake of the film classic ''Heidi'' had a hard time finding a remote alpine hamlet embodying Dorfli, Heidi's little village. After visiting dozens of sites, they finally discovered exactly what they were looking for: Grevasalvas, a rough farming village tucked away in the Alps.

title: U.S. and France Agree to Truce In AIDS Dispute
description: Science is in many ways a very cooperative venture, but it is also one of the most competitive. As a problem captures the attention of the scientific community, experimental results accumulate, reinforcing and contradicting one another, occasionally reaching a critical mass from which a major discovery emerges. Sometimes these great leaps of knowledge occur in more than one laboratory, almost simultaneously.

title: COPTER COMMUTING: GROWTH AND PROTEST
description: TIRED of the daily commuting grind into Manhattan, Carl Ruderman of Westport decided to get above it all. In the summer of 1985, he began to commute by helicopter.

title: Nina R. Rutenburg Marries Jack Gray
description: Nina Rae Rutenburg, an assistant curator of the department of prints, photographs and architectural drawings at the New-York Historical Society, was married in Brookline, Mass., yesterday to John Winterbotham Gray, an associate at Security Pacific Financial Strategies in Jersey City and New York.

title: THE LORD'S OF HELL'S KITCHEN
description: ON THE AFTERNOON OF MARCH 26, Robert Colangelo, chief of detectives of the New York City Police Department, was in his office, posing for a celebratory photograph with a detachment of his men. ''Let's put up a sign,'' shouted a jubilant Colangelo. '' 'Westies - R.I.P.' Make it as big as you can!''

title: The Epidemic of Traitors
description: The American Embassy in Moscow contains a chamber specially secured against Soviet eavesdropping. But even this bug-proof bubble may not be secure enough for use by Secretary of State Shultz on his forthcoming visit to Moscow. The Marine guards who let the K.G.B. roam the embassy may have compromised almost everything done there. And the continuing revelations are only the latest of many damaging security breaches.

title: MORE SCHOOL DISTRICTS OFFERING FULL DAY KINERGARTEN
description: LEAD: SIGNIFICANT changes in the composition of the suburbs -namely, smaller families, declining enrollments, an increase in the number of households where parents are not home, a high percentage of children attending day care and nursery school and, of course, the influence of Big Bird and company - have convinced a growing number of educators and some parents that the traditional half-day kindergarten program is not enough.

title: DREAM AND ILLUSION, ONE NEW, ONE NOT
description: A CLERK falls asleep and dreams of Napoleon. ''Napoleon Nightdreams,'' at the McCarter Theatre here, is the depiction of that dream by the playwright James McLure and the director Nagle Jackson.

title: CARAMOOR CONCERTS TAKE A TRIP INSIDE
description: THE outdoor concerts at Caramoor in Katonah have long been a proud summer tradition in Westchester, but for the most part only the invited guest could partake of recitals in the sumptuously appointed Music Room of the mansion itself. Happily, the open-to-the-public sign is now up for the indoor cycle of four ''Springtime Serenades'' that begins today at 3 P.M.

title: Haiti Approves A Constitution
description: In the giddy 14 months since the overthrow of the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier, Haiti has often seemed on the brink of skidding into anarchy. But fears were allayed last week when the citizens of the hemisphere's poorest country overwhelmingly approved a new constitution that promises freedom from the tyrannies that have prevailed for most of its history.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Prime Dividend

title: HARVARD SWEEPS SAN DIEGO CLASSIC
description: Harvard's heavyweight crew confirmed its preseason rating by sweeping the varsity and junior varsity eight-oared races today at the 14th annual San Diego Crew Classic. It was the first race of the season for the Crimson, and looking ahead, Jack Rusher, Harvard's six man, said, ''We've just begun.''

title: IN SHORT
description: NIGHT AS FRONTIER: Colonizing the World After Dark. By Murray Melbin. (Free Press, $19.95.) In his celebrated 1893 essay on the West, Frederick Jackson Turner wrote: ''And now, four centuries from the discovery of America, at the end of a hundred years of life under the constitution, the frontier has gone.'' But the frontier had not gone; in fact, it's still here, according to Murray Melbin, only it's not geographic but temporal. It's the night. Like the Old West, the night is at once romanticized and feared, the realm of both fraternity and lawlessness. The prime denizens of darkness, Mr. Melbin observes, are the same people who first went West: young men with few social obligations. ''Night as Frontier'' documents this increasing colonization of darkness. In 1946, Seven-11 stores were open from 7 A.M. to 11 P.M.; by 1978, 82 percent of the 6,599 Seven-11 stores were open around the clock. Citing various sources, Mr. Melbin, a professor of sociology at Boston University, notes that in 1972, Americans averaged 7.83 hours of sleep a night; by 1984, the average had dropped closer to seven. O.K., but is any of this surprising or insightful? Mr. Melbin's one intriguing conclusion - that night people hate day people - rests on a dubious study in which, among other projects, Mr. Melbin's scrupulous undercover research team sprinkled Boston streets with house keys attached to tags with an address 90 miles away and the request ''Please return.'' Having already learned that night folk were more likely to give directions to strangers than day folk were, the researchers were surprised to find that night people returned fewer keys. Mr. Melbin's explanation is that night people help only their own kind; they didn't return the keys because they assumed that they belonged to day people. Why they should assume this is not clear. I can think of other explanations. Perhaps night people are smarter than day people and concluded that a house key with an address on it was too weird to take seriously.

title: BABY M'S FUTURE
description: LAST week, in a decision that created law in the legislative vacuum surrounding surrogate motherhood, Judge Harvey R. Sorkow of New Jersey Superior Court awarded custody of one-year-old Baby M to William Stern, the child's natural father, and his wife, Elizabeth. He stripped Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother, of all parental rights, and ruled that the contract she had signed with the Sterns - and reneged on - was legal.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I'VE been waiting for a long time to put this down on paper. It's all about waiting. As best I know, there has not been any scientific research done on the subject, one that, in a normal life, may account for a good several years of it.

title: STAGE: WOMAN AS ADJUNCTS, IN 'OURSELVES ALONE,' FROM IRELAND
description: Men fight and women wait - and while they wait, they act as couriers and clerks, wives, mothers and mistresses. As Anne Devlin observes in ''Ourselves Alone,'' a new Irish play having its American premiere at the Arena Stage, women in Ireland today are no more and no less than adjuncts to the lives of husbands, lovers and fathers.

title: IN 'SAFE SEX,' HARVEY FIERSTEIN TURNS SERIOUS
description: ''I WAS TRYING TO COME TO terms with the situation, with AIDS, that's why I wrote it,'' said Harvey Fierstein of ''Safe Sex,'' the trio of one-act plays that will open tonight at the Lyceum Theater. He was speaking softly, and his somber demeanor had none of the inspired outrageousness that theater audiences have come to expect on stage: Harvey Fierstein the streetwise imp, Harvey Fierstein the Jewish mother from Bensonhurst, Harvey Fierstein the drag queen with a heart of gold who overcomes life's absurdities with an industrial-strength voice and a face of India rubber. ''This show,'' Mr. Fierstein said, choosing his words carefully, ''was my personal response to living in the time of AIDS. It was an attempt to deal with my confusion about AIDS. This show is really from the heart, and it has all my anger and frustration.''

title: Hae Soon Hahn Wed To Steven Rosenbaum
description: Hae Soon Hahn, a violinist in the Handel Festival Orchestra at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and Steven Rosenbaum, an associate at the law firm Covington & Burling, both in Washington, were married there yesterday. Rabbi Jeffrey Wohlberg performed the ceremony at Adas Israel Congregation.

title: Eurosclerosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia Plane Crash On Sumatra Fatal to 26
description: A passenger plane struck high-voltage electric lines on its landing approach to Sumatra today and exploded, killing 26 people, Government officials said.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Pay Before You Go on Swiss Superhighways

title: Sydney
description: To the Editor: James V. Risser's article on Sydney and its Opera House (Travel, Feb. 1) brought back fond memories of similar experiences we enjoyed in July 1984. Like Mr. Risser, we toured the Opera House, ate at the Bennelong Restaurant and took the ferry to Manly and back.

title: IN SHORT
description: THE FUTURE OF IMMORTALITY: And Other Essays for a Nuclear Age. By Robert Jay Lifton. (Basic, $21.95.) These 20 morally urgent, intellectually rigorous essays by the psychiatrist Robert Jay Lifton encourage us to hope for the future, even though nuclear weapons pose an unprecedented threat of total destruction. The demonstrated capacity of mankind for evil and ''our misguided relationships to technology'' - both of which Dr. Lifton has explored at length in his books on Vietnam, Hiroshima and the Holocaust - have never led him to despair, but to some lessons for our time. The Nazi doctors at Auschwitz taught us that professional healers may participate in mass murder by creating another self (a ''double'' in the literary sense of the term). Survivors of Hiroshima, having been immersed in death, experienced an ''emotional desensitization'' that, in another form, allowed the creators of the bomb to inure themselves psychologically to the horrors they wrought. Vietnam veterans often transformed their ''psychic numbing'' into ''animating guilt'' - inarticulate rage became principled opposition as they bore witness to the human waste in an unwinnable war. Understanding victims and victimizers helps us understand that ''unlimited atrocity'' in which we could become both: the self-extermination of the species in nuclear holocaust. The ''imagery of extinction'' pervades our lives and our literature, as Dr. Lifton argues in persuasive essays on such seemingly disparate subjects as religious cults, the strategic defense initiative and contemporary theater. Having diagnosed our fears of futurelessness, Dr. Lifton prescribes an end to our dependency on and worship of nuclear weapons. For only if we heed his measured call to disarmament can we reaffirm human continuity - the ordinary cycle of life and death that, in the past, gave us faith.

title: Afternoon Naps, Morning Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Margolin, A Banker, Weds
description: Karen Judith Margolin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron H. Margolin of Livingston, N.J., and North Egremont, Mass., was married yesterday to Bruce Efron Seidmon, a son of Maynard Seidmon of Chicago and Pompano Beach, Fla., and Sheila Seidmon of Chicago. Rabbi Azriel Fellner, assisted by Cantor Henry Butensky, performed the ceremony at the Short Hills, a catering center in Millburn, N.J.

title: TO HAVE AND HAVE NOT: THE AVOIRDUPOIS COLLECTION
description: A CASE can be made for diet books as vessels of one of the great spiritual movements of our time - gospels of the American cult of thin. There is the promise of salvation through short-term deprivation, supplemented, naturally, by vitamins. There is the evangelical style, shimmering with such visions as ''painless'' and ''quick'' and ''forever'' (as in slim forever). There are the sacred names, the Tarnowers and the Pritikins, evanescent icons whose magic hardly survived beyond the period it took for their disciples to regain the weight. There is the hope of heaven on earth: like the author, who is often a formerly fat person, you, too, can be happy, good-looking, desirable and possibly even in a higher tax bracket. And, of course, there is the collection plate ($14.95 to $19.95), which is the only full plate you are apt to encounter.

title: The Palme Investigation
description: I lived for two years in Sweden, studying its politics and culture, and I found Richard Reeves's somewhat sardonic report, ''The Palme Obsession'' (March 1), flawed in its street-smarts certainty.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
description: IN 1979, Erma Bressler, an Orthodox Jewish woman from Brooklyn, was 70 pounds overweight. ''I went to diet doctors, hypnotists and weight reduction programs,'' she recalled. ''No one understood the special eating requirements I had. Even the low-calorie recipes included non-kosher ingredients or mixed milk and meat.''

title: JOURNAL AT CUTTING EDGE OF PHYSICS
description: DISCOVERIES worth a Nobel Prize and a fortune have ignited a race for glory in a Long Island journal known to few besides physicists.

title: HIKING: TRAILS FOR EVERYONE
description: SOME 2,200 miles of hiking trails - from those that can challenge an expert to those that let a novice take it easy - crisscross New Jersey.

title: WITH THE HUDSON AS BACKDROP, WRITER CREATES A SMALL TOWN
description: THE novelist Roberta Silman cannot see the Hudson River from her home atop a steep hill in Ardsley. This, she suggested, might not be an altogether negative thing.

title: THUNDER ON THE RIGHT
description: You have to admire President Reagan's bravery at his last news conference, but you don't have to swallow his baloney.

title: When Travelers Can't Get Off the Ground
description: AS increasing numbers of travelers take to the skies, spurred in part by the airline industry's deeply discounted promotional fares, there has been an accompanying rise in flight delays and cancellations. The summer travel season is expected to compound the problem.

title: THE DEVIL'S OWN CENTURY
description: THE THANATOS SYNDROME By Walker Percy. 372 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: EVEN WITHOUT GOODEN, THE METS CAN STILL WIN
description: The best thing the Mets can do for Dwight Gooden is hope and pray he finds the answers to why he chose to self-destruct just before the baseball season, which has been the core of his identity. The next best thing the Mets can do for him is go on without him.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: The Story of the Symphony, Vol.I/ Haydn and Mozart Andre Previn and the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra. Home Vision. 90 minutes. $39.95.

title: No Vodka for Vladimir
description: We tend to think of Vladimir Nabokov as elegant and aloof, but in Paris in the 1930's he was a struggling young writer like so many others. V. S. Yanovsky, another Russian emigre writer, describes Nabokov in in his memoir ''Elysian Fields'' (Northern Illinois University).

title: BIG SHIFT IN BOSTON HOUSING PATTERNS PREDICTED WITH NEW INTEGRATION PLAN
description: After two years of negotiation, the state has approved a Boston plan to integrate all new housing built with any government assistance, beginning with more than 1,300 units that were started in 1986. Officials are predicting that the plan will have a significant effect on housing patterns.

title: FOLLOWING THE CONTEMPORARY FLOW
description: ''MUSIC must be a part of the great organic flow,'' Charles Ives said, ''onwards and always upwards, or else it becomes soft in spirit and dies.'' Appropriately, a work by Ives shares the program with newer music at the fifth anniversary concert of Connecticut Composers Inc. on April 14.

title: Alison G. Lohrfink To Marry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Lohrfink of Yonkers of the engagement of their daughter Alison Gean Lohrfink to David Wayland Blood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayland F. Blood of Orchard Lake, Mich. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE JOY OF PHYSICS
description: LEAD: THE LIFE IT BRINGS One Physicist's Beginnings. By Jeremy Bernstein. Illustrated. 171 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: REIT's as a Hedge Against Hard Times
description: SOME analysts were afraid that last week's news about real estate investment trusts was, to quote Yogi Berra, like deja vu all over again. Of the seven biggest quarterly decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, three were realty trusts. A dozen years ago, such trusts littered the losers' lists on the major exchanges, as the industry was plagued with scores of bankruptcies and other problems.

title: Miss Hill Is Wed To Louis P. Angeli
description: At the Red Clay Creek Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday Michelle Margaret Hill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J.Milton Hill of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married to Louis Peter Angeli, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Angeli of Wilmington. The Rev. Dr. William Evans performed the ceremony.

title: Thatcher Leaves Moscow Hopeful For Arms Accord
description: Margaret Thatcher and Mikhail S. Gorbachev got together again last week, with mutually beneficial results. The British Prime Minister flew home after five days in Moscow, telling reporters she ''would implicitly accept'' the word of the Soviet leader.

title: AFTER THE VACATION, WE NEED ONE
description: MY son and I hugged at Kennedy Airport after he and his girlfriend dropped my wife and me there for a business-pleasure weekend in Florida. As always, I informed him that the will was in the drawer near my side of the bed at home and told him to take care of his sisters if something happened. As always, we laughed.

title: A Bright Dawn Ends a Tenant Nightmare
description: TERESA BUCCI, who withstood years of harassment from a landlord trying to drive her and others from their apartments in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, says she will not soon forget going to sleep at night with the prayer that she and her children would not wake up to a burning building.

title: Recent Sales
description: Butler $185,000 103 Summit Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; two-zone heating, screened porch, family room; taxes $2,005. Lake Hiawatha $118,500 32 Calumet Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fire place, enclosed porch; taxes $1,142. Millburn $220,000 79 Linden Street 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old colonial; din ing room, 1-car attached garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,006. Ogdensburg $132,900 15 Wilson Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; patio, family room with wood-burning stove, pool; taxes $2,065. Paramus $180,000 136 Arcola Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old colonial; ce ment patio, wall-to-wall carpeting, 6-year- old roof; taxes $1,600. West Orange $143,000 7 Nestro Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 1-car attached garage, porch; taxes $2,554. OTHER AREAS Fort Salonga, L.I. $520,000 3 Mystic Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old contempo rary; fireplace, cathedral ceilings, private beach rights, water view; taxes $6,000. Milford, Conn. $340,000 67 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; newly remodeled; taxes $2,200. Yonkers, N.Y. $198,500 169 Rockne Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old brick/frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, walk to schools and stores; taxes $3,046.

title: RISK PAYS OFF FOR SUMMERFARE
description: LEAD: DON'T look for the Pepsico Summerfare offices in the basement of the Performing Arts Center on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: Woman Who Knew Suspect In Torture Inquiry Is Found
description: A mentally handicapped woman who once lived with a man accused of torturing six women and killing two others has been found, ending concern that she might be another victim, the police said.

title: BARNUM'S ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Cinema Verite
description: I, too, suffer from Mordecai Richler's obsession with finding errors in film and literature, but I do it for a living (''Cinema Verite,'' Guest Observer, March 8). As continuity supervisor for a television soap opera, part of my job is to make sure the clocks on the wall show a passage of time, insuring the gas tank reads above ''empty'' when we're going to drive a car somewhere, and watching to see if the actor dials enough numbers when making a call.

title: NEW FOCUS IS PLANNED FOR PROSPECT PARK ZOO
description: After having been stalled for almost two years, the first phase of an $18 million renovation plan for Brooklyn's Prospect Park Zoo is complete and construction should begin within the next year, according to city and zoo officials.

title: Anne Cassidy Wed to T. C. Capehart Jr.
description: Anne Leet Cassidy, a freelance writer, and Thomas Charles Capehart Jr., an agricultural economist for the Winrock International Institute for Economic Development in Morrilton, Ark., were married yesterday in Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Elmer R. Moore performed the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church.

title: HERO OF THE LIFE CYCLE
description: A WAY OF LOOKING AT THINGS Selected Papers From 1930 to 1980. By Erik H. Erikson. Edited by Stephen Schlein. 782 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: THE PRICE OF CONQUEST
description: THE OTHER NUREMBERG The Untold Story of the Tokyo War Crimes Trials. By Arnold C. Brackman. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: CULINARY ACADEMY TO LIMIT EXPANSION
description: ''IS HOUSING available? A 200-bed dormitory is planned, with opening tentatively set for the fall of 1987.''

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Ski Train Plan Is Off for Now

title: DURST INDUSTRIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Bellow's Gift
description: SEIZE THE DAY From Saul Bellow's novel. With Robin Williams. HBO/Cannon. 94 minutes. $79.95.

title: JAZZ: JOE WILLIAMS FOR 3 WEEKS
description: IN fine vocal shape at the age of 68, Joe Williams is also a witty and articulate repository of jazz lore. The former Count Basie singer, who grew up in Chicago where he worked professionally in the late 1930's and 40's, recently opened a three-week engagement at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street. His act blends music, nostalgic recollections of the Chicago jazz world, and playful repartee with the musicians and audience.

title: FOLK ART WITH AN ELEGANT PRICE
description: ''M ASTERPIECES OF American Folk Art,'' the exhibition that will inaugurate the new Hirschl & Adler Folk gallery this Friday, has already caused both controversy and wide anticipation. Both reactions are linked to the emphasis in the exhibition on pieces that have been auctioned in recent years for record-setting prices, and to the fact that the show of 24 paintings, weathervanes, whirligigs, painted furniture, stoneware, needlework, quilts and chalkware was organized by the temporarily homeless Museum of American Folk Art.

title: HELPING SCALLOPS IN NIANTIC
description: LEAD: THE Niantic Bay scallop crop is dwindling, and officials are seeking to reverse the trend.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vancouver, Wash.; New Housing, Old Luster
description: AN ambitious development aimed at restoring some of the luster to a site that once housed Victorian-era generals and Indian-fighting infantrymen is under way on the north banks of the Columbia River, across the water from Portland, Ore.

title: Mary Stuart
description: To the Editor: I am writing re ''The Road to Fotheringay,'' concerning Mary Stuart. Without either defending or castigating the Queen of Scots' husband, Lord Darnley, I, as a gay man, take offense at A. L. Rowse's unfortunate characterization of him as ''worse than useless'' for his having ''preferred the grooms of Holyrood to his wife, the Queen.'' BRUCE-MICHAEL GELBERT Brooklyn

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: EASTERN EUROPEAN ARIAS Teresa Kubiak, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, will perform ''An Evening of Arias and Songs from the Eastern European Repertoire'' in Madison next Saturday evening.

title: LIBRARY ELECTIONS: EXERCISE IN DEMOCRACY
description: I would like to respond to Stan Lipton's comments in ''Library Elections: Consolidate Them'' [ Opinion Page, March 8 ] .

title: Ms. Ambrose to Marry Barry E. Carter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Myles J. Ambrose of Washington have announced that their daughter Kathleen Anne Ambrose is to be married May 17 to Barry Edward Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Byron Edward Carter of Fullerton, Calif.

title: CAJUN AND CREOLE IN EAST SETAUKET
description: THE GREAT ESCAPE in East Setauket bills itself as a nouvelle cuisine restaurant. But the new in this menu comes from New Orleans: New Orleans shrimp remoulade, red beans and rice with andouille sausage, seafood gumbo and rice, New Orleans barbecued shrimp, Commander's Palace redfish Greig, New Orleans chicken Pontalba, Cajun mixed grill and filet mignon Brennan's.

title: HOW FAIR IS THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE?
description: THE authors of the Bill of Rights were presumably not leaving anyone out when, in 1791, they wrote that ''Congress shall make no law . . . abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press.'' If they were writing it today, would they give radio and television the same protections?

title: ROCK: THE NEW PRETENDERS
description: FROM the Pretenders who released their first album in 1980, only one original member remains - Chrissie Hynde, the band's leader and singer. The new Pretenders haven't spurred Ms. Hynde to write songs as unconventional and feisty as her older material. But on Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, opening a four-night stand, the band played the daylights out of all its songs; it has the force and tunefulness of the old Pretenders at their best. Ms. Hynde also showed a new ease and humor on stage; at one point, she cheerfully mocked the rock-video gestures of Stevie Nicks, Eurythumics' Annie Lennox and Heart's Nancy Wilson.

title: AQUARIUS REVISTED
description: DO YOU BELIEVE IN MAGIC? The Second Coming of the Sixties Generation. By Annie Gottlieb. 418 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95. PART history, part handbook, part manifesto and part bugle call to action, Annie Gottlieb's ''Do You Believe in Magic?'' takes a stern but affectionate look at the 1960's and then tries hard to reconcile that era with the present. In the course of her research, Ms. Gottlieb traveled throughout the country interviewing men and women who came of age in the 60's and remember the time well, from the yurt-dwellers Otter and Morning Glory G'Zell to the best-selling horror novelist Stephen King.

title: THAT OLD LET-DOWN FEELING
description: MELANCHOLIA AND DEPRESSION From Hippocratic Times to Modern Times. By Stanley W. Jackson. 441 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: Toscanini Made Accessible
description: Six boxes of Arturo Toscanini's legacy - a few batons, recordings, scores that show how he retouched Debussy and Wagner, even the draft of an angry letter to Mussolini - are now the property of the New York Public Library. Within months, the material should be available to scholars.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: FIRST DO NO HARM: Reflections on Becoming a Neurosurgeon. By J. Kenyon Rainer. (Villard, $17.95.) ''First Do No Harm'' is brain surgery demystified. It is also entertaining; J. Kenyon Rainer, a 34-year-old neurosurgeon practicing in Auburn, Ala., writes well. The best scenes in the book are the operations themselves, which are described so clearly and directly that reading about them is like watching them.

title: I.B.M. Inaugurates a New Standard
description: I.B.M. dropped the other shoe last week. Its first line of personal computers imprinted on the industry a standard that was to become international, a standard copied, cloned or counterfeited by countless other firms. Now I.B.M. has about-faced, deserting its own criterion for a brand-new one, albeit one that is also of its own devising. Ostensibly this defection was necessary in order to create a superior machine. In actuality it seems more an attempt to make cloning difficult and to reassert Big Blue's dominance in the personal computer arena.

title: TIPS ON GETTING MAXIMUM USE OUT OF A PORTABLE ELECTRIC DRILL
description: ALTHOUGH a portable electric drill is probably the first power tool most do-it-yourselfers acquire, and it is one power tool that is found in almost every home nowadays, many homeowners still do not know how to get maximum use out of these tools.

title: Animal Demographics
description: To the Editor:

title: MURDER IN THE PEOPLE'S PRISON
description: THE MORO AFFAIR and THE MYSTERY OF MAJORANA By Leonardo Sciascia. Translated by Sacha Rabinovitch. 175 pp. New York: Carcanet. $16.95.

title: THEY LEFT LONG ISLAND FOR THE HIGH DESERT SUN
description: LEAD: SEVEN years ago, Jack Caffrey of Huntington had a sweet job on Long Island. He was a bay constable in Huntington Bay, charged with enforcing navigation and fishing laws.

title: ABSCAM IS RECALLED IN DAILY NEWS BIAS TRIAL
description: For the last three weeks, lawyers for The Daily News have presented evidence to a Federal jury intended to show that four black employees were victims of their own limitations or improper behavior, not racial bias.

title: Joint Space Efforts Planned
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency will launch a joint mission to the Sun in October 1990 and send a spacecraft to Jupiter in October or November 1989, officials of the agencies said Friday. Both missions will be launched from the space shuttle, the officials said.

title: Not His Vault
