description: Marvin L. Warner, who used to own the Home State Savings Bank in Cincinnati, got into trouble when he behaved as if he also owned the bank's deposits. Mr. Warner and a former Home State president were convicted last month on charges of illegally transferring some Home State investments to a failing Florida securities firm in return for guaranteed profits on their personal accounts at the Florida firm. Home State subsequently collapsed in 1985, touching off a panic among Ohio thrift institutions. Mr. Warner, who was Ambassador to Switzerland in the Carter Administration, was sentenced last week to three and one-half years in prison and ordered to pay the state $22 million in restitution.

title: Article 017887 -- No Title
description: A former police sergeant was awarded $770,000 in damages by a Federal Court jury Friday night in a lawsuit against the Patrolman's Benevolent Association and one of its top officials, according to lawyers for both parties.

title: High and Inside
description: Stunning his fans and his teammates, Dwight Gooden, the 22-year-old pitching star of New York's world champion Mets, last week went on the disabled list for at least two months after testing positive for cocaine use. Mr. Gooden, who had previously denied using drugs and had volunteered to be tested, agreed to enter a four-to-eight-week treatment program at a New York City hospital. The Mets' general manager, Frank Cashen, said the baseball commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, would hold off on disciplinary action ''if Gooden cooperated fully in treatment and aftercare.'' His $1.5 million salary will continue while he is under treatment. A second infaction could result in his being banned from baseball.

title: IN PRESIDENT'S '4TH QUARTER,' A NEW GAME
description: THE morning after the Senate overrode President Reagan's veto of an $88 billion highway and mass transit bill, Democratic leaders and Administration officials expressed the same exhausted conclusion: Let's not go through that again any time soon.

title: Building a Camp For Sick Children
description: IT was a different camp for children that Paul Newman, the actor, and A. E. Hotchner, the author, planned.

title: MUSIC: IMPROVISATIONS BY ZORN AND SHARP
description: THE prospect of two premieres by leading ''downtown'' composers, John Zorn and Elliott Sharp, both of whom have been working on new ways to organize group improvisations, brought a full house to the Alternative Museum on Wednesday night. Mr. Zorn, however, postponed his ''Xu Feng'' for lack of rehearsal time and substituted duets with the guitarist Fred Frith.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: HERE IS A CONTEMPORARY love story.

title: New PC's: Fast And Incompatible
description: The stock market was not especially impressed, but the International Business Machines Corporation last week introduced a line of personal computers capable of tricks that most users never contemplated a few years ago.

title: SACRAMENTO FINDS TROLLEY IS A SYMBOL OF THE FUTURE
description: California's capital, which ripped out the rails of a far-flung trolley network more than 30 years ago, opened a new trolley line recently, and suddenly the familiar old streetcar is being heralded as a symbol of the future, not the past.

title: MEXICO CITY
description: The dollar may be declining in value in most parts of the world, but in Mexico it is still king. The peso, 25 of which equaled a dollar just five years ago, now trades at more than 1,100 to the dollar, and the exchange rate improves daily for those with dollars to spend. For the traveler, that means Mexico City is not only alluring but also a bargain.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
KOREAN OLYMPIC COINS ACCENT LOCAL TALENTS
description: LEAD: THE Republic of Korea has released the first six coins in a set of 24 to commemorate the Summer Olympic Games that will be held in Seoul in 1988. When completed, the set will include eight gold and 16 silver coins.

title: A NEW PAGE IN THE SAGA OF THE HIGH PRIEST OF MUSIC
description: THE LONG-AWAITED OPEN-ing of the Toscanini family archives - thousands of scores, books, letters, records and items of memorabilia that have waited 17 years unsorted in a basement while the conductor's heirs dickered with the New York Public Library, and now at last acquired by the library for the benefit of researchers - comes at a moment of something like high drama in the saga of the great Italian conductor's posthumous reputation. He was revered in his day as a demigod. Today there are those who think Arturo Toscanini synonymous with restrictive, dry, rigid music-making - and those who hardly think of him at all. But every new attempt to put him in perspective raises passions.

title: A CAREER OF WATCHING GARDENERS GROW
description: HOT colors and hot peppers will soon be sprouting in gardens around the state.

title: Amy Falk, an Art Director, Marries Dr. Michael Gross
description: Amy Margaret Falk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Falk of Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Gross, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gross of Hewlett, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Julia Horne Weds C. E. Elberson 2d
description: The marriage of Julia Ashworth Horne and Charles Evans Elberson 2d, account executives for the Young & Rubicam advertising agency in New York, took place yesterday at the Boardwalk Presbyterian Church in Wrightsville Beach, N.C. The Rev. Susan Ashworth, a cousin of the bride and a Methodist minister, and the Rev. Gary Cline, the bride's uncle and an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BEDSIDE MANNERS: The Troubled History of Doctors and Patients, by Edward Shorter. (Touchstone/ Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) The centuries-old, ever-shifting relationship between doctors and patients ''resembles an intense, stylized and changeable dance'' in this study, Fitzhugh Mullan said in The Book Review last year. The author, he said, ''provides us with a solid historical analysis of our medical system and a provocative diagnosis of our current status.'' LIFE AND FATE, by Vasily Grossman. Translated by Robert Chandler. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) Completed in 1960 and smuggled out of the Soviet Union, Vasily Grossman's novel ''is a passionate onslaught against state-sponsored political terror,'' whether of the Stalinist or Hitlerite variety, Ronald Hingley said here in 1986. Its hero, Viktor Shtrum, is a Soviet nuclear physicist who becomes the target of an anti-Semitic witch hunt in the early 1940's. Grossman's ''account of Soviet life - penal, military and civilian - is encyclopedic and unblinkered,'' the reviewer said. ''Love affairs, divorces, the problems of acquiring a ration card or a residence permit - they are all here, the tragic and the trivial side by side.'' AFTER THE NIGHTMARE: Inside China Today, by Liang Heng and Judith Shapiro. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) Liang Heng, a writer, left China as a dissident student in 1981 and returned four years later with his American wife, Judith Shapiro, to note the changes in his homeland, his family and his friends. Last year our reviewer, Carolyn Wakeman, called this account of their journey ''a moving catalogue of victims 'sacrificed on the altar of Mao's revolution,' '' and ''a compelling glimpse of the society that is being rebuilt on the ashes of the Cultural Revolution.'' HANDLING SIN, by Michael Malone. (Pocket, $4.95.) Raleigh W. Hayes, a 45-year-old member in good standing of the Thermopylae, N.C., Civitan Club, sets out on a sort of literary scavenger hunt that takes him and a circus of supporting players through the Southern states. Michael Malone's novel is a ''hilarious success,'' A. C. Greene said here in 1986. His ''twists and turns and surprises are downright phenomenal, verging on genius. There are entire chapters in this book that are funny, sentence by sentence.'' BOSTON BOY, by Nat Hentoff. (Faber & Faber, $7.95.) Nat Hentoff's book is a memoir not only of his youth but of the Boston of the 1930's and 40's, and of the Savoy Cafe, where he encountered the world of jazz and jazzmen. The work ''should be appreciated not only by adults who grew up through the fires of their own rebellion, but by those restless young people who are now bringing their own views and questions to the world they are inheriting,'' Dan Wakefield said here in 1986. SWORD AT SUNSET, by Rosemary Sutcliff. (Tor, $4.50.) Rosemary Sutcliff's historical novel reinvents King Arthur, and the result, while far from the accepted legend, is ''an expression of the purest affection for the Arthur of her heart,'' Robert Payne said in The Book Review in 1963. ''He is a living presence who moves in a brilliantly lit and fantastic landscape only remotely connected with ancient England. And why not?'' THE SERPENT AND THE RAINBOW, by Wade Davis. (Warner, $4.95.) In 1982 the author, a graduate student at Harvard University, went to Haiti to investigate voodoo sorcery and the potions that can reduce the body's metabolic rate. This chronicle of his adventures ''smacks of show business,'' Jim Haskins said in these pages in 1986. But he called the writing lyrical and the story ''a romantic, highly readable combination of Haitian history, folklore and culture, not to mention pharmacology and ethnobotany.'' HERBS AND APPLES, by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) This nostalgic, semi-autobiographical novel by the author of ''. . . And Ladies of the Club'' follows the fortunes of an Ohio schoolgirl who dreams of becoming an author. The character ''emerges as a capably drawn addition to the thoughtful tomboy breed of heroines - those appealing protofeminists who have long kept energetic girls glued to the page,'' Ann Hulbert said in The Book Review in 1985. A LESSER LIFE: The Myth of Women's Liberation in America, by Sylvia Ann Hewlett. (Warner, $10.95.) The claim that women can ''have it all'' is to blame for the impossible choices facing them in the conflicting worlds of home and the wage market, the author asserts. She uses women's ''powerful, personal . . . poignant stories'' to back her case, Sylvia A. Law said here last year. But ''problems of sexism run deep and strike close to home. An analysis that feminists are responsible for the impossible choices confronting women and all people today is comforting, particularly to those who have no interest in change. It is also wrong.'' CLARA'S HEART, by Joseph Olshan. (Ballantine, $3.95.) Joseph Olshan's first novel is about the complex relationship between a young boy and the middle-aged Jamaican woman who works as a governess-housekeeper for his wealthy New York family. In 1985 our reviewer, Howard Fraser Mosher, described it as ''sensitive and often comical.'' LETTERS TO JUDY: What Kids Wish They Could Tell You, by Judy Blume. (Pocket, $4.50.) The author offers a sampling of her young readers' letters asking advice on topics including sex, drugs, crushes, problems with parents and other worries. ''The book is not a how-to manual,'' Elizabeth Winship said here last year, ''but one compassionate and popular author's way to help parents see life through their children's eyes.'' BAD MANNERS, by Maggie Paley. (Penguin, $3.50.) Maggie Paley's first novel consists of telephone dialogue among four best friends, women in their late 30's. This is a ''mean and funny'' book by ''a practiced observer of modern mores,'' our reviewer, Susan Braudy, said in 1986. ''Read it, and wince while you laugh.''

title: Mets' Stumbles Should Tighten the Race in the East
description: The following report on the National League was prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the order of predicted finish. Lineup cards show probable opening-day lineups; slashes represent a platooned position. EASTERN DIVISION

title: Jill Witlin, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Richard Goldaber
description: Jill Lori Witlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Witlin of North Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Scott Goldaber, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Goldaber of Miami. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony at the Oceanside (L.I.) Country Club.

title: A SOPRANO AND TWO VILINISTS IN FIRST RECITAL APPEARANCES
description: Harolyn Blackwell

title: CONCERN FOR ECOLOGY HASN'T GONE TOO FAR
description: Regarding the question in the column ''About Long Island'' [ March 8 ] : ''Has concern for ecology of our fair country - including Long Island - gone too far?'' I respectfully answer no!

title: Six Homes in a Florida City Damaged as Ground Shifts
description: Six homes damaged by a sudden ground shift Thursday have been condemned by officials in this central Florida city, and residents will have to pay for repairing cracked ceilings, walls and floors before they can move back in.

title: Commercial Property:The Garment Center; A New Zoning Shelter for Harried Manufacturers
description: SAVERIO PRINCIPATO may finally find his ideal landlord - someone who leaves him alone - now that city officials have agreed to restrict office conversions in Manhattan's garment district.

title: NAMES AND PLACES: A BIT OF HISTORY
description: I found the article ''What's in a Name? History'' most interesting, but I must tell you that Las Cruces is still very much alive and well in New Mexico. The town of Hot Springs changed its name to Truth or Consequences after playing host to a live broadcast of the radio program of that name. ROSLYN STARK Coram The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and daytime telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Long Island Weekly Section, The New York Times, 229 W. 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: A MAGNIFICENT GREED
description: DUET FOR THREE By Joan Barfoot. 252 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $15.95.

title: Eyesores Becoming New Homes in Brooklyn
description: Four years ago, the apartment building that Meg Harriman now calls home at 104 St. Mark's Place in Brooklyn was an abandoned eyesore.

title: IN MOSCOW, UNOFFICIAL MEANS UNSAFE
description: THE Russian voice at the other end of the phone line is unknown, the proposal tantalizing. ''I have interesting information for you, can we meet?''

title: PROGRAM TEACHES WAYS TO MANAGE STRESS CAUSED BY SCHOOL 'AND STUFF'
description: Stress comes from many sources: tight travel schedules, competitive sports and even elementary school, say participants in a new stress management course for children 5 to 12 years old.

title: 'CENTER FOR THE VISUAL ARTS' IN SUMMIT
description: WITH minimal fanfare and a modest new sign, the Summit Art Center was recently renamed the New Jersey Center for the Visual Arts.

title: Mr. Moi's Parrots
description: When Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi visited Washington recently, he paid tribute to human rights by denouncing its absence in South Africa. When questioned about the same subject with regard to his own country, he responded with regal irritation, cut short his visit by a day, and saw to it that Kenya's press sang his praises without critical references to h---- r-----.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN KOSHER FOOD
description: PASSING muster with a ''mashgiah,'' a rabbi from one of the several dozen agencies that certify products as kosher, is no piece of cake. ''It's like having another Food and Drug Administration down your back,'' conceded Ms. Spear of the Orthodox Union, which certifies an estimated 80 percent of the kosher products on the market.

title: HOME VIDEO: COMEDY
description: The Joe Piscopo New Jersey Special Starring Joe Piscopo, Eddie Murphy, Gov. Thomas Kean and Joe Piscopo's family. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $59.95.

title: THE CREATIVE PROCESS AND LIBEL
description: A HARVARD PSYCHIATRIST recently testified in Federal court that during the last eight years she had been unable to teach or write because of her distress over the film version of Sylvia Plath's novel ''The Bell Jar.''

title: Judge Says Reporter Need Not Name Sources
description: A newspaper reporter need not disclose his confidential sources for an article about possible legal violations in a Nevada gambling casino owned in part by former Senator Paul Laxalt, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Letter on Lincoln Plot Is Found in Maryland
description: A letter written shortly after Lincoln was shot has been discovered and copies will go on display, its owners say.

title: A STATE MUSEUM DELIVERS ITS EXHIBITS
description: STRIKING photographs of frogs adorn the library at Preston Plains School in Preston. Mac F. Given, a doctoral candidate in zoology, is describing to some 30 students how he went about recording the sound made by carpenter frogs about to attack. .

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: LIBRARY WEEK National Library Week festivities begin today, and through Saturday libraries throughout the Island will commemorate the occasion. For example, in music today at 2 P.M. the classical guitarist John Lehmann-Haupt performs at the Bellmore Library, 2288 Bedford Avenue, and the Baroque Quartet appears at the Middle Island Library, 274 Middle Country Road, while Flutes Plus plays at 2:30 P.M.

title: IN MIDDLETOWN, AN ECHO OF THE OLD TROLLEY ERA
description: THE tracks on city streets are a bumpy reminder of an era when trolleys were the principal mode of transportation. That era ended in the state more than four decades ago, when the last trolley gave way to buses.

title: Joanne B. Lipman To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton E. Lipman of East Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanne Beth Lipman to Thomas Richard Distler, a son of Donald Distler of West Orange, N.J., and the late Bette Feitelson Distler. A June wedding is planned.

title: A New Therapy For Parkinson's
description: The adrenal hormone norepinephrine and the neurotransmitter dopamine are chemically very similar. And so scientists have wondered if they could cure Parkinson's disease, a neurological disorder thought to be caused by a dopamine deficiency, by transplanting tissue from the adrenal glands into the brain.

title: HELP FOR THE DOUBLY TROUBLED
description: LEAD: WHEN Elisa was 14 years old, she started using marijuana, and at 17, while a student at Rutherford High School, heroin. In her early 20's, she began thinking she was being followed by the C.I.A. and she pulled a knife on a woman she believed was conspiring against her.

title: Jennifer Feldman Weds S. P. Lund
description: Jennifer Pulitzer Feldman, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Martin Leach-Cross Feldman of New Orleans, and Steven Paul Lund, a son of Virginia Lund Callaway of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Paul Martin Lund, were married last night. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Murray Blackman at the home of the bride's parents.

title: WHITHER THE WEREWOLF
description: A LYCANTHROPY READER Werewolves in Western Culture. Edited by Charlotte F. Otten. Illustrated. 337 pp. Syracuse, N.Y.: Syracuse University Press. Cloth, $32.50. Paper, $14.95.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Brattleboro, Vt.: Location Again Proves Its Point
description: LEAD: FOUR years ago, Exit One industrial park here was the back 40 of a farm cut in half by Interstate 91, which spikes north from New Haven and follows Vermont's eastern border to Canada.

title: THE HEALING POWER OF OTHERS
description: THE CHILDREN AT SANTA CLARA By Elizabeth Marek. 177 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.

title: Australia II Sold As Museum Piece
description: Australia II, the revolutionary 12-Meter yacht that won the America's Cup for Australia in 1983, has been bought by the Australian Government.

title: SECRECY, POWER AND HOOVER
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
A FAMILY PLACE IN WEST HARRISON
description: LEAD: A cheerful, bustling place, Edmondo's is conspicuously a family-run restaurant.

title: TRAINING WOMEN FOR FALSE HOPES
description: LIKE the Pardoner who peddles fake relics and indulgences in Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales,'' some career consultants and educational institutions are foisting bad job-hunting advice on women.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Lenox, Mass.: Town Supports Retail 'Village'
description: LEAD: ONE of the largest commercial developments in this Berkshire Mountains resort town, Lenox House Country Shops, is expanding once again to keep up with the area's growth in retailing.

title: DIVER TRAVELS IN SEARCH OF CHALLENGE
description: LEAD: IN the opening of her book, ''Night Dive,'' Ann McGovern's 12-year-old protagonist talks about her first experience of scuba diving at night: ''I must be crazy. It's nighttime and here I am on this dive boat, in total darkness. And I'm scared to death.''

title: Brooke E. Conaty To Marry in May
description: Brooke Elizabeth Conaty, a senior analyst for the Bond Investors Guaranty Insurance Company in New York, plans to be married May 9 to Thomas Joyce Farley, an assistant vice president in municipal underwriting for Bond Investors Guaranty.

title: NEW U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW IS SAID TO HAVE WIRETAPS
description: Some members of Congress and intelligence officials say they believe that a new United States Embassy building under construction in Moscow is contaminated with Soviet eavesdropping devices and that the entire $190 million project should be scrapped.

title: IN VERMONT, 'NIGHTMARE' OVER A TOWN'S POLLUTION
description: Andy Shapiro came home one day in December to find state and local officials congregated in his kitchen.

title: OUT OF RETIREMENT AND INTO NEW CAREERS
description: AFTER 28 years as an advertising and portrait photographer, Herb Butler sold his White Plains studio in 1981 and headed for Florida and retirement. High on his list of priorities was to concentrate on two sports he had never had enough time for: golf and tennis.

title: RANGEL SEEKS EXONERATION OF MARCUS GARVEY
description: The young J. Edgar Hoover saw him as a threat to the American way, plotted to deport him on subversion charges and finally succeeded in having him convicted of mail fraud. But millions of others called him ''Black Moses,'' flocked to his Harlem speeches on racial pride and poured money into his ''all Negro'' steamship line founded to ''link colored peoples all over the world.''

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on March 22 accompanying an article on Italian crafts misstated the period of a marriage plate from Lecce. It is a 19th-century plate.

title: Lisa M. Yoo Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Yoo of Cresskill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa M. Yoo to James Edward Hahn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. W. B. Hahn of Saddle River, N.J. The future bride graduated cum laude from Smith College and is a first-year student at the New York University School of Law. Mr. Hahn, a graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, is in the corporate intern training program at Paine Webber in New York.

title: STAGE: 'OLD NEW YORK'
description: IN the New York Art Theater Institute's dramatization of Edith Wharton's ''Old New York,'' the ensemble's 14 members parade stiffly through the parlor of the Old Merchant's House Museum, 29 East Fourth Street, in 19th-century fancy dress fashioned from foam rubber, cut-up garbage bags and shower curtains.

title: Erica Schwartz Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Curtis B. Schwartz of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Erica Ruth Schwartz, to Brett Michael Lowy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lowy of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Charlotte, N.C.;
A Skyline Showdown
description: LEAD: TWO of North Carolina's largest banks have taken their rivalry to this city's skyline and the apparent victor is the NCNB Corporation, the South's biggest bank holding company, which has announced plans to build a downtown tower here at least 50 stories tall.

title: HUNDREDS OF 'TRAINERS' ARE STATIONED AROUND GLOBE
description: THE 50 or so American soldiers stationed in El Salvador to train Government forces represent just one kind of potentially dangerous military commitment.

description: The following report on the American League was prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the order of predicted finish. Lineup cards show probable opening-day lineups; slashes represent a platooned position. EASTERN DIVISION

title: AN EXTRAORDINARY RELATIONSHIP'S SPECIAL LEGACY
description: ARTHUR MITCHELL, ONE OF George Balanchine's stars, founded the Dance Theater of Harlem in 1969 with the late Karel Shook. At the time, it was fair to assume that the new company would be another satellite in the Balanchine empire that was supposedly taking over the American ballet world. The chief difference, presumably, would be that the dancers were predominantly black rather than white.

title: PARALEGALS AID POOR IN DIVORCE CASES
description: As a paid paralegal for the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, Kenneth Kersch's work mainly involves researching corporate mergers.

title: MUSIN: BLUE GENE TYRANNY
description: BLUE GENE TYRANNY, by which name the composer Robert Sheff usually bills himself, was born in Texas in 1945 and has had a lively career. He was an active figure in Midwestern new music during the 1960's, at Mills College in California in the 70's and in downtown New York experimentation of the 80's. Wednesday night he appeared at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, Park Avenue at 42d Street, as part of the museum's series of brief but well-publicized free-admission, new-art events.

title: Beezie Ives to Wed Frederick C. Childs
description: Beatrice Mary Ives, a daughter of the late William Holland Ives and the late Beatrice Bussey Ives, plans to marry Frederick Carter Childs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Childs of New Canaan, Conn., on June 20.

title: CLEMENS RETURNS TO RED SOX
description: Roger Clemens rejoined the Boston Red Sox today after a 29-day walkout, ending a salary dispute settled by the intervention of Commissioner Peter Ueberroth as a mediator.

title: IN SHORT
description: AMERICA'S HEALTH IN THE BALANCE: Choice or Chance? By Howard H. Hiatt. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $18.95.) Health care in the United States is already rationed, Howard Hiatt argues; the country urgently needs a fairer apportioning of resources that will never be limitless. Those whose bills are paid with the help of private or Government health insurance get more than their share, he contends, while more than 35 million Americans - one-third of them children -are left to scramble for medical attention. ''Jumbled policies and blinkered initiatives are literally killing many of us,'' Dr. Hiatt insists in this clear and persuasive book. The United States spends $450 billion a year on health, but ranks 17th among nations in low infant mortality, 16th in life expectancy. Dr. Hiatt, a professor of medicine at Harvard University Medical School and its School of Public Health, prescribes health insurance for all. He suggests regional control, as in Canada, perhaps by state agencies. Everyone would have a doctor who is a general practitioner, as in Britain - where people live slightly longer than Americans and most physicians get along without six-figure incomes. He is candid about British deficiencies, notably long waits for nonemergency services, and the fact that ''many fewer Britons with kidney failure between fifty and sixty-five years of age, and almost none over that age, are begun on dialysis.'' But he says choices are unavoidable. A universal health system, Dr. Hiatt maintains, could reduce wasteful practices, such as unnecessary surgery and superfluous visits to specialists. His priorities for redirecting the resulting savings include improving community care for the poor, home care for the elderly, preventive medicine, research and medical scholarships.

title: ROMBLING IN RURAL SWITZERLAND
description: Overshadowed, almost literally, by the nearby Alps, the Swiss Emmental region is undiscovered and completely unselfconscious.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: LEAD: Now departing, a journey through the ''Great Train Weekend'' at Sunnyside. Stops will be made for models, toys and collectibles. Fare includes special excursions into memory. All aboard!

title: IN SHORT
description: CRUSADE: The Official History of the American Cancer Society. By Walter S. Ross. (Arbor, $18.95.) Within memory of many Americans the word ''cancer'' was once almost taboo. In obituaries the deceased ''died of a long illness.'' Everyone knew that meant cancer, but it was not polite to say so. The American Cancer Society has been a major force in erasing that taboo, in bringing cancer forcefully to public attention, in convincing physicians that some cancers can be cured, others prevented, and that many lives can be saved by trying. In ''Crusade: The Official History of the American Cancer Society,'' Walter S. Ross asserts that the society has become the largest, most influential, most effective private voluntary health organization in history. Mr. Ross, formerly the director of special publications at the society and the author of several books, concentrates on its achievements, since its inception in 1913, in promoting early diagnosis, early treatment and major national efforts at preventing cancers. Its greatest accomplishment came in challenging the powerful American tobacco industry by finding proof that cigarette smoking causes lung cancer and other health complications and persuading the Federal Government to act on the evidence. The book's subtitle should alert the reader to a strong partisan bias; there are few hints that the society's policies have ever been flawed. With that caveat, however, the book is well worth reading. It shows what great feats can be achieved by a band of volunteers mobilized by dynamic leaders.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
WOODLAND VOLE
description: LEAD: Microtus pinetorum Size: To 5 1/2 inches.

title: Correction
description: The Week in Business column last Sunday incorrectly described how the proceeds from the sale of 40 percent of Shearson Lehman Brothers, to Nippon Life and the public, would be distributed. Shearson is expected to receive about $600 million in new capital. American Express, Shearson's parent, is expected to receive about $650 million from the sale of shares to the public.

title: Columbia Celebrates Its Bicentennial (Again)
description: With convocations, proclamations and perorations, Columbia College is celebrating its bicentennial this month - the biggest party since 1954 when, with convocations, proclamations and perorations, it also celebrated a bicentennial.

title: THE KNIFE THROWER'S BAD AIM
description: THE PAPER DOOR And Other Stories. By Shiga Naoya. Translated by Lane Dunlop. 173 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $14.95.

title: OWLS: WOMEN SUPPORTING ISSUES
description: LEAD: STATE SENATOR Amelia P. Mustone said she recalled a ''garden club'' atmosphere in 1979 when she joined the Order of Women Legislators, known as the OWLS club, at the State Capitol. ''Some of the older members were very proper,'' said the Meriden Democrat. They went into the OWLS clubroom to ''get away from the legislature,'' she said.

title:
WINE;
EXCELLENT VALUES FROM SPAIN
description: LEAD: A RECENT sampling of Spanish table wines at three popular area restaurants featuring wide selections of bottles from the land of Don Quixote reveals that most of these products provide outstanding value and mate well with food.

title:
TELEVISION;
A FOOTE FAMILY AFFAIR
description: LEAD: JUST A FEW DAYS AFTER HIS 71st birthday, Horton Foote positively beamed while offering a visitor a frosty Dr. Pepper as a little morning treat, a treat evocative of Mr. Foote's Texas upbringing. As those familiar with his work know, the playwright pays a great deal of attention to such details.

title: U.S. TELLS NAVY TO BOLSTER FORCE AT PERSIAN GULF
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered the Navy to increase its presence near the Persian Gulf in an effort to fulfill President Reagan's pledge to keep oil flowing to allies in Europe and Japan, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Gandhi in Dispute Over Hiring U.S. Detectives
description: The hiring of a private American investigative agency to look into reports of illegal financial activities by Indians overseas has set off a new political dispute for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title: Chadians Celebrate Key Victories Over Libya
description: Some came astride mopeds, their heads swathed in traditional white cloths to ward off the hot desert winds.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CAR OWNERS HAVE THEIR DAY ALLISON S. FEIGENBAUM says her 1986 Chevrolet Camaro smells and stalls. The Cedarhurst resident has to drive with the windows open for the smell, she said, and she's had to call several tow trucks for the stalls. Her car, Ms. Feigenbaum contends, is a lemon. John Aragano's 1985 Volkswagen Jetta ''blew up'' on the way home from the showroom, Mr. Aragano said. ''It let out this big puff of steam. We took it back; the next day the air-conditioning wouldn't work. But the major problem has been the transmission leaks. I've had it back eight times for that.'' His car, Mr. Aragano contends, is a lemon.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: Johnny Shiloh With Brian Keith, Kevin Corcoran. Walt Disney Home Video. 90 minutes. $69.95.

title: The Selling of 'Safe Blood' in the Age of AIDS
description: DR. Joseph Feldschuh has set his sights on becoming a banker -a blood banker - for some of the nation's largest corporations.

title: JUNTAS ARE THE NORM
description: MODERN DICTATORS Third World Coup Makers, Strongmen, and Populist Tyrants. By Barry Rubin. Illustrated. 385 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $17.95.

title: Gone West Beats Capote in Gotham on a Day of Upsets
description: Gone West, Cryptoclearance and Temperate Sil scored upset victories in major 3-year-old prep races around the country yesterday, deepening the list of contenders but also scrambling the outlook for the Kentucky Derby May 2.

title: GLASNOST UPSETTING TO SOVIET ALLIES
description: ACCORDING to a bitter joke circulating in Prague, a man who remembers the 1968 Soviet invasion wonders whether, in light of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's liberalization, it is now Czechoslovakia's turn to send ''fraternal assistance'' to the Soviet Union.

title: Cinema Verite
description: Mordecai Richler writes that his unflinching eye for error earned him a dinner-table approval only once.

title: A WORLD WITHOUT NUCLEAR ARMS?
description: It is likely the question was first asked as soon as it could be - that the hope of abolition followed shortly after the task of creation. J. Robert Oppenheimer, transfixed in the glare of the first atomic explosion in the New Mexico desert, recalled a verse of the Bhaghavad Gita: ''Now I am become death, the destroyer of worlds.'' It is not a role to which man would grow accustomed.

title: SCUBA INSTRUCTION AT SEVERAL SITES
description: LEAD: There are ample opportunities in the county to learn scuba diving. The following list offers a selection of the organizations that provide instruction:

title: NEW U.S. OVERTURE TO NORTH kKOREANS
description: The Reagan Administration has informed North Korea that it is prepared to take major steps that may include lifting a near-total trade ban if the North Korean Government resumes talks with South Korea and sends its athletes to the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, according to American officials.

title: How Medicare Causes Hospital Horrors
description: To the Editor: Dr. William L. Roper's disclaimer of Government responsibility for the medical atrocities being inflicted on Medicare hospital patients under his department's diagnosis-related-group program is a priceless example of how a literal truth may conceal a monstrous falsehood (letter, March 26).

title: A War That None Can Afford to Win
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, Art Buchwald suggested that Japanese executives be sent en masse to the Harvard Business School. There they would unlearn all they know about manufacturing and receive instruction in how to focus on the next quarterly dividend. In no time at all, Japanese productivity would deteriorate, trade surpluses would vanish and we would all be friends again.

title: Rejected Applicant Says Law School Is Biased
description: The City University of New York Law School, in its admissions brochure, says it has a responsibility to create a campus environment ''that is more diversified and more representative of the full range of peoples that make up New York City and the United States.''

title: STORM HITS NEW YORK REGION
description: Heavy rains and high winds hit the New York City region yesterday, flooding highways, bringing some rivers to flood stage and damaging power lines and trees.

title: IS AN ICON BECOMING A HAS-BEEN?
description: COULD WE BE WITNESSING THE DECLINE OF the Ives phenomenon? Although Leonard Bernstein's New York Philharmonic program this week brings back the Second Symphony, major performances of the Yankee eccentric's music have become rare enough to deserve comment. Originally, Mr. Bernstein was to have given over his entire program to Ives, pairing the comparatively conventional Second with the monumental Fourth. Instead, Schubert's Ninth has been substituted for Ives's grandest and most intractable symphony. That is a shame, but for the moment Ives is saved from slipping further toward the semiobscurity that was his lot before a few dedicated Ivesians thrust his music into public attention some 30 years ago.

title: A Rise in the Prime Ends a Long Slide
description: Major banks raised the prime rate to 7 3/4 percent, from 7 1/2, an indication that interest rates have bottomed out after a long, slow slide. The increase, started by Citibank, was the first in nearly three years. The prime's importance has faded and is now mostly symbolic, and most analysts said the increase will not be fully felt at the consumer level for some time. The increase means that the supply of available credit is tightening as businesses expand, which could signal a stronger economy in months to come. * * *

title: STAGE: TIME TRAVELING, IN BULGAKOV'S 'BLISS'
description: HIGH marks for enterprise to the Project III Ensemble Theater for giving us an opportunity to see Mikhail Bulgakov's ''Bliss.'' The Soviet writer, best known in America for his novel ''The Master and Margarita,'' completed in 1934, six years before his death, what the play's accomplished translator, Mirra Ginsburg, calls a ''pessimistic comedy.'' Like much of Bulgakov's work, it was not heard of again until the 1960's, when he enjoyed a measure of rehabilitation by the Kremlin. Since this production is a premiere, comparisons are not possible, but with all due gratitude, one comes away feeling there is more to the work than can be found at the Ohio Theater.

title: Single-Handed Sail: For the Undaunted
description: When Mike Plant left Sydney, Australia Jan. 18 at the halfway mark in his global voyage, he carried with him a spinnaker that was a gift from an America's Cup helmsman.

title: NEW MOTHERS SEEK SUPPORT AND ADVICE
description: LEAD: JUST as Joanne Slot was telling about how her twin baby girls reacted to each other for the first time, Nikki Cole -baby in arms - gracefully slid from her chair to the floor. In seconds, three other women were also crouched on the floor, changing their infants' diapers on portable mats.

title: NEW HAVEN DOG LAW DRAWS MIXED REACTION
description: WHILE some New Haven residents are hoping a newly passed ''pooper scooper'' law will mean cleaner sidewalks and parks, others feel that such change will come about only when dog owners begin acting responsibly.

title: HOUSTON HOSPITAL FOR AIDS BATTLES TO SURVIVE ITS HEAVEY COSTS
description: Three years ago, when he was head of nursing at a Houston hospital, Daniel G. Moreschi found himself contemplating a medical nightmare.

title: Playing Basketball in the Street Led to the American Mainstream
description: To the Editor:

title: KEAN IS PRESSED TO SHIFT POSITION
description: GOVERNOR Kean, who has no more state elections in his future, is coming under increasing pressure from the Republican majority in the Assembly, which faces its most important election in November.

title: Prepayment Penalties
description: Question: I own shares in a co-op in New Jersey. When the building was converted in 1981 the sponsor took back a $2.5 million mortgage for 10 years at 11 percent interest, which he subsequently sold to Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank of New York. The mortgage calls for a prepayment penalty of 5 percent up to the fourth year and subsequent penalties which would decline by 0.5 percent annually. I understand that prepayment penalties are illegal in New Jersey. Are such penalties legal in New York? D. S., Montclair, N.J. Answer: The location of the property in question, not the location of the bank holding a mortgage, determines which state's banking laws apply. The New Jersey banking law that prohibits prepayment penalties covers individual mortgages taken on single-family homes or buildings with up to six units. According to Roger Wagner, of the New Jersey Department of Banking, this rule would not extend to mortgages taken by co-ops.

title: WEST PLANS NEW HELP FOR DEBTOR NATIONS
description: Western industrial nations are planning new steps to ease the financial plight of the poorest developing countries, European financial officials said today.

title: DELAYS AT NEW YORK AIRPORTS FALL FOR FEBRUARY AND MARCH
description: Delays have dropped dramatically at New York's three major airports since air traffic changes went into effect along the East Coast in mid-February, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. But satisfaction with the improvement is tempered with caution about prospects for the heavy summer travel season.

title: GORBACHEV FOES GO TO THE VIDEOTAPE
description: ''The enemy never sleeps,'' Lenin said. And last week in Moscow it seemed that foes of the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and his wife, Raisa, were wide awake, possibly smiling. The reason was an underground video that was said to show Mrs. Gorbachev all gussied up in fashionable clothes and jewels.

title: Yankees Demote Holland to Minors
description: The Yankees made their final roster cut today before breaking camp, and it was one of the most unkind. Al Holland, who came here without a contract or a guarantee that he would make the club, was told he would not be going north with the team even though he had the lowest earned run average in camp.

title: The Bloom Of Youth
description: KATHRYN'S room is like that of many 10-year-olds.

title: PLAYING BASKETBALL IN THE STREET LED TO THE AMERICAN MAINSTREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: LEONARD TAKES AIM AT HAGLER'S COMPOSURE
description: Before Marvelous Marvin Hagler left his dressing room to fight John (the Beast) Mugabi in March 1986, he had a visitor.

title: A TRADE CRISIS HIGHLIGHTS MUTUAL RESENTMENTS - AND NEEDS
description: MIRED in one of their worst trade crises ever, the United States and Japan struggled last week to keep the bitterness from undermining broader economic and strategic interests. Leaders struck conciliatory stances and looked for ways to avert retaliatory American tariffs on Japanese electronic products scheduled to go into effect April 17.

title: Philadelphia Asks Meese's Aid
description: District Attorney Ronald Castille has asked Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to force Federal prosecutors here to help in bringing charges against Nicodemo Scarfo, a reputed leader in organized crime here, and associates of Mr. Scarfo's, in a series of murders.

title: FARMERS LEARNING TO LIVE WITH EVER SHRINKING ACREAGE
description: LEAD: JUST AS they survived the departure of the big food processors a decade or more ago, New Jersey farmers are learning to live with land development that, year by year, reduces the acreage available for agriculture.

title: FINDING COMFORT IN YOUR OWN LANGUAGE
description: WHEN I was a young child, every old person I knew, without exception, spoke English with a foreign accent. My grandparents and great-aunts aunts and uncles. The Chinese laundryman. The Italian candy-store owner and my friend's Irish auntie. All came from somewhere else and spoke with the cadence of tongues accustomed to other sounds. I would see an old person and wait - not knowing I was doing so - wondering what delicious and unfamiliar pronunciations would come from their mouths.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE SQUIRREL THAT WOULDN'T GO
description: LEAD: Guess who's coming to dinner? Well, we had a squirrel who came looking for dinner and he stayed for 10 weeks.

title: TAILORED FOR SUCCESS
description: PAUL J. HANLY JR.'S APPRECIATION of finery is as evident as the tailor-made suit on his back. ''Feel this,'' he urges, extending a sleeve. And he is right; it does seem unlikely that any off-the-rack facsimile could approximate its softness.

title: THE GROVES OF IGNORANCE
description: THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND How Higher Education Has Failed Democracy and Impoverished the Souls of Today's Students. By Allan Bloom. Foreword by Saul Bellow. 392 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: DANCE: WARSHAW GROUP
description: THE stage was clearly a special place at the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Friday night. Miran Mohar had designed a glowing floorcloth for the premiere of Randy Warshaw's ''Fragile Anchor,'' and the six members of the Randy Warshaw Dance Company kept rushing in and whirling about on it.

title: STRENGTH FROM HUMILITY
description: HOLY FEAST AND HOLY FAST The Religious Significance of Food to Medieval Women. By Caroline Walker Bynum. Illustrated. 444 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $29.95.

title: GROUP LENDS HELPING HAND IN ADOPTIONS
description: By the time she had adopted her second child, Dawn Smith-Pliner's telephone in Pawlet, Vt., was ringing constantly with calls from friends and strangers asking her how she did it.

title: Mary Stuart
description: To the Editor: I would have thought it impossible but your writers, James Barron and A. L. Rowse, have done it. They have produced a fascinating, accurate and interesting sketch of the life of Mary Queen of Scots (Travel, Feb. 8) without once mentioning John Knox. Unbelievable but congratulations. FRANK A. LAWRENCE Lancaster, Pa.

title: THE DANCE SHIMAZAKI COMPANY
description: SATORU SHIMAZAKI sought expressive simplicity in the works that the Satoru Shimazaki Dancers presented Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: FISH STEAKS OFFER ADVANTAGE OF SIMPLICITY
description: WHEN I was growing up in England we ate grilled fish often. But our choice was limited. Mostly it was mackerel or herring, the inside spread with mustard and the outside rolled in oatmeal. The fish were grilled until crisp and served with a mountain of boiled potatoes and butter. For special occasions there was trout or salmon. They were always served the same way: the trout, plain with a piece of lemon and a sprig of parsley on the side, the salmon with a hollandaise sauce that was indispensible since the fish was nearly always a little on the dry side.

title: EXPLAINING MONOPSONY
description: ABZs OF ECONOMICS By Susan Lee. Introduction by Leonard Silk. Illustrated by Robert Mansfield. 224 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $16.95.

title: Hidden Treasure
description: The art world these days has all manner of high tech processes for identifying valuable paintings. But in a pinch, an educated eye and a wet finger will do. That was all Piero Corsini, an art dealer, had to work with when he thought he spotted an unknown Titian at a London auction last year. ''It was filthy, but I took a little saliva in my hand and rubbed'' two small sections, Mr. Corsini recalled. ''And I knew that Titian himself had done them.'' He bought it for $50,000. After experts confirmed his judgement, he sold the work to a Texas museum for $1.5 million. Titled ''The Madonna and Child, With Female Saint and the Infant John the Baptist'' it is on view at the Metropolitan Museum in New York City this month.

title: COUNTY STAKE IN HIGHWAY BILL
description: THE controversial $87.9 billion Federal highway bill included $389 million for Westchester County by 1992 and was crucial to the area's road-and-bridge-repair program this year, according to state and local transportation officials.

title: LOVE AMONG THE PEASANTRY
description: ONCE IN EUROPA By John Berger. 193 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: In ''Stretching the Shrunken Dollar'' (Travel, March 1), there was a segment that we feel gives a misleading picture about hotel prices in Spain. The choice of the Ritz Hotel at $308 (40,00 pesetas) for one night, double room, gives the reader a distorted view because it is by far the most expensive hotel in Spain.

title: KYOTO'S HANDMADE BRUSHES
description: Because Kyoto was spared the bombings of World War II that devastated Tokyo, Nagoya, Osaka and other Japanese cities, streets of dark old houses remain intact, pretty much as they were in the 19th century. House-proud Kyoto-ites take care of their seemingly fragile wood, paper and plaster houses and the furnishings within the same way their ancestors have for hundreds of years, often using the same types of equipment, some of it still made by hand within the city. But young people have little desire to apply themselves to the modest and demanding work of making these things, and in many cases the present generation of craftsmen may be the last.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'LEGENDARY POLICEMAN'
description: LEAD: 'Good people gathering for a good person and for a good cause'' is the way Andre F. Baker described this afternoon's cocktail party to benefit the George D. Rooks Memorial Fund. Mr. Rooks, who died in 1984, was a captain in the White Plains Police Department, where he headed the detective division.

title: LEGAL WAR CONTINUES ON L.I.R.R. PARKING
description: LEAD: WHAT began as an effort by Suffolk County officials to buy surplus school property and turn it into a Long Island Rail Road parking lot has erupted into a bitter battle against the county by one school board trustee who says his only interest is the safety of children in Central Islip.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: LEAD: THE BODY SILENT. By Robert F. Murphy. (Holt, $17.95.) In the spring of 1976, Robert Murphy, a professor of cultural anthropology at Columbia University, suddenly realized he was both an ethnographer and a reluctant dweller in the world of the physically disabled. Doctors had discovered an inoperable tumor of the spine that initiated what Mr.

title: OPERA: 'BOHEME' RE-CAST
description: TWO appealing young players took over the leading roles in Puccini's ''Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night.

title: T.W.A. ATTENDANTS SEEKING OLD JOBS
description: Josephine Brown is now a travel agent; Priscilla Harrison is a career counselor. Some of their friends are working in restaurants; some have opened businesses of their own. But almost all of them would rather be flying again.

title: MULRONEY AWAITS VISIT BY PRESIDENT
description: When President Reagan arrives here Sunday for a two-day visit he will find his host, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, more careworn than the last time Mr. Reagan was in Canada.

title: QUESTIONS RISE ON MARINE GUARD UNIT'S DISCIPLINE
description: For all their spit-and-polish presence inside guard booths, members of the elite Marine Corps battalion who provide embassy security appear to be no more disciplined than the corps as a whole.

title: ATHLETES OF YEAR ARE HONORED
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who set two world records in the heptathlon last year, and Matt Biondi, a swimmer from California whose 1986 season included four world records and six American records, were honored tonight as the United States Olympic Committee's athletes of the year for 1986.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Reviving Freeport's Blighted Downtown
description: LEAD: FREEPORT has encountered more setbacks than triumphs in recent years in trying to revive its central business district adjoining Sunrise Highway.

title: HOW HISTORY UPSTAGED THE GERSHWINS
description: THE GERSHWIN CELEBRATION that closed last Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was a public service. The double-feature bill of ''Of Thee I Sing'' and ''Let 'em Eat Cake'' offered a new generation the chance to hear great Gershwin songs and to sample two classics of American musical comedy, even if in a telescoped concert version. ''Of Thee I Sing,'' of course, was an enormous success in its day, while ''Let 'em Eat Cake'' was a relative failure; and the Academy of Music evening raised the question of why one show worked and the other didn't.

title: U.S. Reservists Build Key Road in Honduras
description: IN a remote valley in northern Honduras, United States Army Reserve engineers, supported by National Guard maintenance technicians and military policemen, are working from sunup to sundown to build a gravel-topped road south from the town of Jocon. With each mile pushed through the rough terrain, the road gives Honduran peasants easier access to the port of Trujillo to the north. And when it is driven through the rugged mountains to roads to the south, they will be able to go directly to Tegucigalpa, the capital, in central Honduras.

title: MT. VERNON HOSPITAL: TRAUMA CARE CITED
description: The article, ''Trauma Centers Designated'' [ March 22 ] left a false impression that only those hospitals mentioned in the article were ''special'' based upon their total trauma-care capability.

title: MUSIC: CONSORT GROUP
description: THE highlight of the New Music Consort's Tuesday evening program at Weill Recital Hall was the New York premiere of Tod Machover's ''Soft Morning City,'' an ambitious setting of the final pages of ''Finnegan's Wake'' for soprano, bass and electronic sound.

title: A WORD ON FACILITIES, PARTICULARLY IN YONKERS
description: Your article on trauma centers was in general highly informative; however, certain facts require clarification. Residents of southern Westchester may be under the impression that most of the Westchester medical facilities are located in one hospital. This is not so; all the hospitals in this area have equal total-trauma-care-facilities designations.

title: REVIVAL FOR CARTWRIGHT AND WALKER
description: Motivation is a wondrous thing. Perhaps that is what the Knicks had lacked throughout the season, when winning games seemed almost secondary to the ever-present squabbles between players and coaches - past and present - and among the players themselves. All that is left now for the team is to win - and for various individuals to prove that, at least for them, this miserable season has not been a complete waste.

title: MAN IS KILLED BY AN IRT TRAIN
description: A homeless man was killed yesterday when he was pushed in front of a subway train at the Times Square Station, the Transit Authority police said.

title: IN SHORT
description: REAL RAPE. By Susan Estrich. (Harvard University, $15.95.) Everyone agrees that a woman attacked at knifepoint and forced to have sexual intercourse has been raped. But what about less clearcut cases, where a woman charging rape had dated the accused, or where a man thought the victim's protestations were merely a matter of playing hard to get? Simple rape -where the accused is known to the victim and no actual force is used - is unfairly treated by the criminal justice system as a private dispute rather than a prosecutable offense, Susan Estrich argues in this well-researched call for reform. The early common-law approach, developed to protect men against false accusations by vindictive women, rested squarely on proof of the woman's resistance. As Ms. Estrich, a professor at Harvard University Law School and herself a victim of rape, points out, this leaves rape victims in the untenable position, unique in criminal law, of having to prove their innocence rather than have the state prove the rapist's guilt. Reform of rape laws, a key item on the feminist agenda, made few changes. The author would shift the legal focus to the intent of the accused rapist, asking not whether the woman was raped but whether the man raped her, an approach that negates the need to examine the victim's sexual history and gives less credence to how strongly she resisted. Ms. Estrich also makes a strong case for negligence liability, to punish men who honestly but unreasonably believed that a woman had consented to intercourse. Readers willing to follow an exhaustive study of the development of rape law, with 40 pages of footnotes, will be rewarded with a persuasive argument for legal change.

title: AFTER A CENTURY, TURNER GETS HIS WING
description: AS OF TOMORROW MORNING, visitors to the Tate Gallery in London will at last be able to enjoy the J. M. W. Turner bequest to the British nation as Turner meant them to enjoy it - in a separate building named after him and devoted entirely to his work. That this should be done was a condition of the bequest, which was made in 1851 and consisted in all of no fewer than 19,331 works of art, large, small and tiny.

title: Joint Space Efforts Planned
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency will launch a joint mission to the Sun in October 1990 and send a spacecraft to Jupiter in October or November 1989, officials of the agencies said Friday. Both missions will be launched from the space shuttle, the officials said.

title: A LITTLE NOTORIETY IS A BIG SOCIAL DRAW
description: A dream dinner party, in some strata of New York society, would include Ivan Boesky and Jean Harris, if she happens to be free. The notoriety achieved by both is said to qualify them for the A list among hosts like Carolina and Reinaldo Herrera.

title: OUTDOORS: SECOND SHOT AT TURKEYS
description: NEW YORK State turkey hunters are being given a better chance to bag a second bird in the forthcoming spring season that runs through May.

title: Heavy Supply of Bank Capital Notes
description: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly sale of three- and six-month issues and ending Thursday with a new one-year issue.

title: Market Place; Despite Delay, Uccel Gains
description: IN THE PAST, investors quickly lost interest when software companies failed on promises to deliver computer programs that banks and thrift institutions could use to analyze their lending and financial data rapidly.

title: ANALYSTS URGE CAUTION IN WAKE OF MARKET SURGE
description: Although the stock market ended the week on a very high note after beginning it on a sour one, individual investors should remain cautious in their buying, according to analysts interviewed over the weekend.

title: Single-Issue Illusions
description: Single-issue foreign policy is bringing the same kind of trouble as single-interest lobbies, and for a similar reason.

title: PHILLIPS SEEMS TO BE ON MEND
description: Early last year the survival of the Phillips Petroleum Company, the nation's eighth-largest oil concern, seemed threatened by the crashing price of crude oil and by the legacy of its bruising struggle to defeat back-to-back takeover attempts: a mountainous $7 billion debt.

title: Wendy Coleman, Producer, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Wendy Jill Coleman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Coleman of Roslyn, L.I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Myron R. Nadler, a son of Anne Nadler of Bardonia, N.Y., and the late Louis Nadler, took place yesterday in New York. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien Hotel.

title: Ocean Spray Chooses 3 Agencies as Finalists
description: Ocean Spray Cranberries reported last week that it had selected the three finalists for the non-cranberry end of its business, which will have billings of $15 million.

title: REAGAN, IN CANADA, CHIDED ON ECOLOGY
description: President Reagan arrived here today on a cold and rainy day for his third summit meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and, as it happened, encountered a chilly reception on the subject of acid rain.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $2,220,000 in the value of its oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: DEVILS' GOAL: NEXT SEASON THE PLAYOFFS
description: The Devils missed the playoffs once again and management points to financial restraints, but there seems some validity to the claim that there are better times ahead.

title: Patricia A. Alpert Weds Charles A. Weil, a Lawyer
description: Patricia Ann Alpert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alpert of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles Alfred Weil, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Otto Weil of Plandome, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: FACT, FANTASY AND FEAR
description: IN assessing the outcome of Sugar Ray Leonard's return tonight against Marvelous Marvin Hagler, three scenarios exist. One is based on facts, another on fantasy, the third on fear.

title: CENTURY BUSINESS CREDIT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year revenue includes a $260,000 finder's fee; a $112,000 net gain from the sale of marketable securities and other assets; $115,000 in dividends on marketable securities and $78,000 from the recalculation of Safe Harbor Lease transactions as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The revenue for the prior year includes a $700,000 finder's fee and a $75,000 gain from the sale of an asset. The finder's fee relate to the sale of two apparel companies arranged by the company.

title: Past Perfect
description: Often the things people treasure have no intrinsic Value whatsoever. Report cards, photographs, bridal bouquets, menus, matchbooks, letters, locks of hair - they are everything to their owners but nothing to anybody else. But let time pass, and such items turn into evocations of the past. Then their magic is universal.

title: Your Charity Can Help Pay the National Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: FINE ARTS ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $58,000.

title: SOUP KITCHENS: STUDY PORTRAYS THE TROUBLED
description: A private study of people who use soup kitchens in New York City has found that more than 40 percent survive on one meal or less a day and that most of those eligible for government benefits are not getting them.

title: Egypt Opposition Cites Pre-Voting Detentions
description: On the eve of national elections, an opposition alliance that includes Moslem fundamentalists today accused the police of rounding up hundreds of its supporters whom it designated to monitor polling places.

title: PC QUOTE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Argentine Debt Talks
description: Economy Minister Juan Sourrouille was heading for Washington for talks with creditor banks on rescheduling part of Argentina''s foreign debt. Officials at the Ministry of the Economy said Mr. Sourrouille hoped to reach an agreement rescheduling $30 billion of private foreign debt. Argentina, which seeks $2.15 billion in fresh loans from private international banks to meet 1987 growth targets, has been negotiating with the banks' steering committee since February. Mr. Sourrouille will also attend meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Barbara Lea Sings At Jan Wallman's
description: When Jan Wallman, the veteran cabaret owner, recently relocated from a snug Greenwich Village hole-in-the-wall to better-appointed quarters at 49 West 44th Street, she took with her a roster of loyal performers who rarely appear anywhere else in New York. Topping the list is the jazz singer Barbara Lea, who is appearing at Jan Wallman's Cabaret Saturday nights through April with programs inspired by ''The Melody Lingers On,'' Roy Hemming's history of songwriters and movie musicals.

title: Hans Ericson of Sweden Dies; Longtime Chief of Teamsters
description: Hans Ericson, former longtime leader of Sweden's teamsters union and one of the country's most controversial labor figures, died Saturday at the age of 59, a doctor reported.

title: METS-PHILS TAKES D.C. BY STORM
description: More than 45,000 baseball-starved Washington fans bought tickets for a meaningless exhibition game today between the Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies, largely to demonstrate that, after 16 years in the wilderness, the nation's capital and its prosperous suburbs deserved and would support a major league team.

title: FIRST WORLD CHEESE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest periods is primarily attributable to a $334,000 writeoff of sales and marketing expenses in the latest quarter associated with the introduction of the Olympiad Brand; and an increase of $1,190,000 in sales and marketing expenses for the year, in connection with the development and introduction of Pre Monde Alpine Lace swiss cheese from five to 25 geographic markets in 1986.

title: CENTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 28
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5,755,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $4,933,000. The company said the latest year reflects the sale of all the company's operating assets in February 1987, other than securities and real estate.

title: 12-BLOCK OFFICE-ENTERTAINMENT CENTER PLANNED ON WEST SIDE
description: Gulf and Western Inc., the owner of Madison Square Garden, and Olympia & York, the largest real-estate developer in New York, are on the verge of an agreement to convert a 12-block strip from Pennsylvania Station to the Hudson River into a mammoth office and entertainment center, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

title: India Is More Than Cliches About Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Take the Police Academy Out of Manhattan's East 20's
description: To the Editor:

title: FORMER JUNTA MUSTERS A DEFENSE IN PUBLIC DEBATE
description: After backing away from a showdown with civilian authorities over human-rights trials, the Argentine military has begun an aggressive public defense of its actions in the anti-subversion campaign known as the dirty war.

title: NEW SHOWS SEEK FAVOR IN TV'S TRYOUT SEASON
description: Not a single night of network programming is the same as it was just weeks ago.

title: DALLAS VOTE FOR MAYOR SETS RUNOFF
description: Mayor Pro Tem Annette Strauss of Dallas led a crowded field Saturday, but failed to gain a majority of the vote in her effort to become the first woman elected mayor here.

title: MASTERS TOURNEY: FAIR BUT NOT EASY
description: THE 51st Masters will start Thursday with between 70 and 80 players and about 25 possible winners. Although it has most of the better known pros competing, its small field will exclude such players as Scott Hoch, last year's Vardon Trophy winner, and Rodger Davis of Australia, winner of the 1986 British PGA Championship and Australian Open.

title: 350 DISPLACED BY THE FLOODING OF JERSEY RIVER
description: The Passaic River, swollen by Saturday's rain, crested early today in Wayne, and local officials said they did not expect serious flooding, despite the occasional showers forecast for later today.

title: Signs of Life for the Paralyzed Budget
description: For six years, President Reagan has practiced desperation budgeting. By crushing Congress between the rock of a swelling defense budget and the hard place of his hostility to new taxes, he has worked to deny it any room for domestic spending. Now, his design for budget paralysis is unraveling. The spotlight last week was on overriding the President's veto of the highway bill. But the House Budget Committee, confronted with the Administration's incredible budget reduction plan, produced one that was smaller but considerably more realistic. Practicality may yet prevail. * * *

title: Ted and the Tax Man
description: Memories of yesteryear's stars have always provided an appealing context in which to treasure a new baseball season. But as the 1987 campaign opens today, few fans have as much reason to recall former players as Ted Turner, owner of the Atlanta Braves.

title: KOCH PLANNING 1,000 MODERATE-PRICED CONDOMINIUMS FOR QUEENS
description: The Koch Administration is planning to build up to 1,000 new condominium apartments for middle-income New Yorkers on 14 acres of vacant, city-owned land in Astoria, Queens, the City Housing Commissioner said yesterday.

title: Head of Ciba Vision Expects New Gains
description: Ciba-Geigy Ltd., the large Swiss pharmaceutical company, has been aggressively building a worldwide vision-care business in the last few years under an American manager, James D. Macdonald.

title: Japan Reported Buying Another Supercomputer
description: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry is close to a decision to buy a $20 million supercomputer manufactured by Cray Research Inc., according to press reports and ministry officials.

title: AT&E CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Builder's Stake In French TV
description: A consortium headed by the construction group Bouygues S.A. has been awarded a 50 percent controlling stake in France's oldest and most widely watched television network, the Government-owned Television Francaise-1.

title: WESTWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter and year results include a pre-tax loss of $1,989,498 from disposal of subsidiaries. The year-ago periods' results include a pre-tax loss of $3,063,263 from disposal of subsidiaries.

title: Black Choreographers In Brooklyn Program
description: The Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center is to present ''Solos and Duets by Black Choreographers'' on April 24 and 25 at 7:45 P.M. at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section. The choreographers for the program, directed by Larry Phillips, include Clarence Teeter, Sylvester Campbell, Talley Beatty, Andy Torres, Walter Rutledge, Alfred Gallman, Kevin Hunt, Eugene Little and Roman Brooks. Tickets are $8; $6 for students, children and the elderly; $7 with the purchase of 15 or more tickets. Information: (718) 875-9710.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES LP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Dollar Still Calls Bonds' Tune
description: Weakness in the dollar was the catalyst for a quick rise in Treasury bond yields last week, raising the bellwether issues by more than a quarter of a percentage point to about 7.85 percent, the highest since last fall.

title: COMFORTED BY WHAT YOU WEAR
description: THEY are generally the type of clothes only a mother could hate: the scuffed shoes that have molded to our feet; the slouchy hat that creases just so; the oversize cotton shirt that, after umpteen washings, is soft and cuddly; the baggy trousers that don't bind. They are comfort clothes.

title: PAYROLL-ABUSE INVESTIGATION SEEN AS WATERSHED IN ALBANY
description: Though still in its early stages, the investigation by several district attorneys into abuses of the state payroll appears likely to become a watershed in the politics of New York State.

title: VARIED MENU FOR TV VIEWERS
description: Lou Falcigno, the president of Momentum Enterprises, which has provided viewing sites and pictures in New York for every major closed-circuit boxing match since Joe Frazier defeated Muhammad Ali in 1971, estimates that about 300,000 seats will be sold in the metropolitan area and upstate for tonight's bout between Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Sugar Ray Leonard in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: L.I. MAN, ACCUSED OF WAR CRIMES, READIES APPEAL
description: Already packed and ready to board an airliner, Karl Linnas, a Long Island man accused of Nazi war crimes, was within hours last Thursday of being deported to the Soviet Union, where he has been condemned to death.

title: GLOBAL TV NEWSCASTING MAY BECOME A REALITY
description: Planet 3, described by its creators as the first global television news program, could be appearing weekly on television stations from Peoria to Prague by next spring, according to the British-American partnership that is trying to find the money to begin it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blues 3, Red Wings 2: Rob Ramage's goal at 3 minutes 49 seconds of overtime last night lifted St. Louis to victory over Detroit, capping a week-long comeback that gave the Blues their second Norris Division regular-season title in three years. The Blues won the title by a single point over the Red Wings, who finished at 34-35-11, for 78 points. The Blues, at 32-33-15, had 79 points. (AP) Blackhawks 5, Maple Leafs 2: Denis Savard scored three times to propel Chicago into the playoffs. Savard's goal at 7:07 of the final period blunted a two-goal Toronto comeback. Savard also had two goals four minutes apart in the second period. The Blackhawks wound up in third place in the Norris Division with 72 points. Chicago, tied with Toronto and Minnesota with 70 points apiece entering the final game of the season, will face second-place Detroit in a four-of-seven playoff series beginning Wednesday night. The Leafs, who finished tied with Minnesota, will meet St. Louis beginning Wednesday night in the opening round. Toronto qualified by virtue of more total victories (32-30) than the North Stars. (AP) N.B.A. 76ers 106, Celtics 104: Charles Barkley scored 28 points, including the game-winning basket in overtime. Barkley's follow shot with 1:19 left in overtime gave the 76ers a 105-104 lead. Roy Hinson made one of two free-throw attempts with 16 seconds remaining for the 76ers' final point. (AP) Lakers 126, Nuggets 118: Magic Johnson scored 23 points, grabbed 11 rebounds and added 10 assists and James Worthy scored Los Angeles' first 7 points of the fourth quarter to help the Lakers to a victory over Denver. (AP) Pistons 125, Bucks 107: John Salley scored a career-high 28 points to lead Detroit. The victory lifted second-place Detroit within 1 1/2 games of idle Atlanta in the Central Division. The game was played before 37,712 fans at the Silverdome. (AP) HORSE RACING Grecian Flight Wins Easily: Grecian Flight, with Chris Antley up, made an impressive return to competition following a three-month layoff and scored a 9 1/2-length victory in the $73,600 Bouwerie Stakes for New York-bred 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct yesterday. Grecian Flight, a daughter of Cormorant-Green Greek, raced seven furlongs carrying 118 pounds on the good track in stakes record time of 1:23. The previous standard of 1:23 4/5 was set by Love Is Eternal in 1980 and tied by Halo Dotty in 1983. Peggy's Dream, 116, and ridden by David Nuesch, came from last in the field of 10 to be runner-up, a length ahead of Chase the Dream, 118, with Angel Cordero Jr. riding. Grecian Flight's victory was her fifth in sixth career starts. She earned $44,160 for Henry C. B. Lindh and returned $2.80 for $2 to win. AUTO RACING Earnhardt Takes First Union 400: Dale Earnhardt outclassed the field at North Wilkesboro Speedway, winning the First Union 400 by 1.72 seconds to earn his fourth Nascar victory in six races this year. He led five times for 320 laps in the 400-lap event, and averaged 94.103 miles per hour. (AP) Andretti Wins on Coast: Mario Andretti, continuing his family's dominance of the Grand Prix of Long Beach, scored his third victory in four years by leading the Indy-car season-opener from start to finish. Andretti, driving a brilliant red Lola powered by one of the new Chevrolet-Ilmor engines, was pressed by Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil throughout the first half of the race before Fittipaldi's car went out with a turbocharger failure. Al Unser Jr. finished second for the second consecutive year. (AP) ROAD RACING Dickenson Wins Yonkers Race: Danny Dickenson of the Bronx took the lead at 23 miles and went on to defend his title in the Yonkers Marathon in 2 hours 26 minutes 24 seconds. Rafael Parra of the West Side Y.M.C.A. finished second in 2:30:20. Christine Gibbons of the Millrose A.A. won the women's title in 2:58:16. Rod Dixon of New Zealand, winner of the 1983 New York Marathon, captured the Vivicitta 12-kilometer run in 2:08:59 in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Tom Wood of the Gubbins Running Team won the Queens Half-Marathon in 1:05:53 in College Point. Gillian Horovitz of New York was the women's gold medalist in 1:20:41. Kristiansen Takes Norwegian Title: Ingrid Kristiansen posted a women's world best for the half-marathon, clocking 1 hour 6 minutes 40 seconds, in winning the Norwegian championship at Sandnes. The previous women's best for the 13.1-mile distance was 1:08:34, by Joan Benoit Samuelson of the United States at Philadelphia on Sept. 16, 1984. (AP) TENNIS Mayotte Defeats Pate: Third-seeded Tim Mayotte of Bradenton, Fla., capitalized on overhead slams to defeat eighth-seeded David Pate of Las Vegas, Nev., 6-4, 6-2, and win the Volvo-Chicago indoor tennis tournament in Chicago. (AP) Becker Downs Mecir: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany served and volleyed his way to a straight-set victory over Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia in the final of the Fila Trophy indoor tournament in Milan, Italy. The 19-year-old West German, ranked second in the world, downed Mecir, 6-4, 6-3. (AP) SQUASH RACQUETS Binns-Page Team Wins: Third-seeded Todd Binns of Toronto and Tom Page of New York City, the current North American doubles champions, defeated unseeded David Boyum of Cambridge, Mass., and Kenton Jernigan of Newport, R.I., 15-10, 15-8, 15-13, to win the $15,000 Shearson-Lehman Brothers World Doubles Tournament at the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club yesterday.

title: Workers Are Most Vulnerable When Plants Close
description: To the Editor:

title: David's Cookies Arrives As Della Femina Shifts
description: David's Cookies is no longer satisfied with the advertising it is getting from its in-house operation. So it is switching to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: Flawed Afghan Negotiations
description: LEAD: While a flurry of diplomatic activity is under way to resolve the conflict in Afghanistan, the negotiations are basically flawed. They avoid the central issue in the conflict and would fall well short of assuring a durable solution.

title: Rise in Oil Use Seen Easing
description: The rise in the use of oil by Western nations is likely to slow this year, the International Energy Agency said today. It said growth in oil consumption in the Western industrialized nations is likely to be around 1 percent, down from 2.3 percent in 1986.

title: PINIELLA RETHINKS LINEUP
description: It could have been that Lou Piniella saw something familiar in Gary Ward. Like himself.

title: Grace Wieder Plays Schubert and Brahms
description: The pianist Grace Wieder is at her best in straightforward, songful material. Or so it seemed late Saturday afternoon, when Ms. Wieder played works by Schubert, Brahms, Faure and Wallingford Riegger at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.

title: Illness of Two in Navy Is Linked to a Monkey
description: Two animal handlers at a Navy research laboratory are critically ill, one of them in a coma, after catching what is believed to be a rare monkey brain disease almost always fatal in humans.

title: RASMUSSEN ON TOP, BUT UNDER SCRUTINY
