description: PICTURE this: The Yankees' opening-day pitcher this afternoon at Tiger Stadium won 18 games last season, pitched 202 innings, kept opposing hitters to a collective .217 batting average and became the father of twins during last summer's stretch drive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11, B10

title: GOLD MUTUAL FUNDS LED FIRST QUARTER'S WINNERS
description: ''Gold shares became the hedge, or precaution, against such uncertainties as the fear of inflation, the fall of the dollar, Federal Reserve policy -even the sustained rise in most other equity prices.'' That is how John Van Eck, portfolio manager of the top-performing mutual fund in the first quarter of 1987, explained the latest glitter in precious metal stocks.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax credits of $27,000 for the quarter and $127,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $37,000 for the quarter and $57,000 for the year.

title: BRITISH THREAT TO JAPAN CALLED MISGUIDED
description: Britain's threat last week to oust Japanese financial institutions in retaliation for Tokyo's unwillingness to open its markets to British rivals is misguided and counterproductive, according to bankers and brokers here.

title: Personal Defense Initiative
description: Every American visitor staying at a Moscow hotel comes back with the same story. You discover the bathroom has no soap. You say loudly angrily to nobody in particular, ''What kind of backward country is this, no soap in the bathroom!'' And a few moments later, as if by magic, the chambermaid taps at the door bearing a bar of soap.

title: Diocese Loses in Move To Evict Vietnamese
description: Vietnamese Roman Catholics fighting the Diocese of San Jose for a separate parish cannot be evicted from the church they have occupied since last summer, a judge ruled Friday.

title: PILOTS OFFER $4.5 BILLION FOR UNITED
description: The pilots' union of United Airlines, which has been at odds with management for some time, made an offer yesterday to buy United from the Allegis Corporation for $4.5 billion in cash, subordinated notes and assumed debt.

title: ROLE OF DISSENT RECALLED IN EXTENSION OF LIBERTIES
description: Two centuries' worth of iconoclastic, rebellious, uncompromising, American protesters shoved the establishmentarian framers of the Constitution off center stage in Philadelphia this weekend.

title: ONE YEAR AFTER CHERNOBYL, A TENSE TALE OF SURVIVAL
description: ''We were told there was a high level of radiation. We knew about this. But we saw lots of flames - that was our main job. We are firemen. We are supposed to fight fires.''

title: FOOTE'S 'COURTSHIP'
description: A WEEK or so ago, at Circle in the Square Theater in Greenwich Village, my eye was caught by a youngster in the audience trying mightily but unsuccessfully to stay awake. The play was Horton Foote's ''Widow Claire.'' Here, I thought, was a perfect example of the younger generation, attention span whittled away by television, failing to appreciate the old-fashioned virtues of gentle, thoughtful drama. By evening's end, groggy myself, I was sympathizing fully with the young dozer.

title: Philippine Gunman Arrested Near Site of Talk by Aquino
description: The police arrested a man armed with a grenade and pistol today near a stage from which President Corazon C. Aquino later spoke to an election rally, military officials said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHERE IS NICARAGUA? By Peter Davis. 349 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: FORGET BOXING, DEAL THE CARDS
description: BILL from Atlanta (no last names, O.K.? he says) is an invited guest at Caesars Palace. He's a player, which, in the Vegas vernacular, means high roller.

title: Chairman Shift At Ogilvy Unit
description: William E. Phillips, 57-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group and chairman of its Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide subsidiary, has relinquished the latter title to Kenneth Roman, 56, who has been president of O.&M. The agency, which is the country's fifth largest, is dropping the president's post.

title: NONPROFIT GROUP TO NOURISH ONCE-SHABBY PROSPECT PARK
description: When Tupper W. Thomas became the Prospect Park administrator seven years ago, ''we had the opposite problem from Central Park,'' she recalled. ''People were just not using the park.'' Since then, the city has poured $17 million into Prospect, and the number of park visits has tripled to more than 5 million annually.

title: White, Yankelovitch
description: White, Yankelovich, Skelly Consulting Group of New York and Stamford, Conn., announced its existence last week and reported that it is made up of three units. They are the Futures Group of Glastonbury, Conn., and Washington, D.C., which does strategic marketing studies among other things; Stockman & Associates of Greenwich, Conn., consultants in international marketing, technology transfer, brokerage and distribution, and Van Dyk Associates of Washington, consultants on public policy and government affairs.

title: HEALTH IMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Women and Fiction The centuries-old existence of authors who are women continues to provide grist for a variety of intellectual mills. For example, this season's third and final Lionel Trilling Seminar at Columbia University is ''From the Lighthouse: Women and Fiction Today.''

title: JOSEPHINE BAKER'S STORY
description: SHE was not a great dancer or singer, nor was she ravishingly beautiful. Yet Josephine Baker became one of the show-business legends of this century. With a combination of monumental impudence and enormous energy, she evolved into the consummate entertainer, forging the kind of special bond with her audiences that spells stardom.

title: Stage-Fright Seminar at Y
description: ''Conquering Stage Fright,'' a one-day seminar, is to feature the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne on Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Ms. Horne will discuss her own feelings on the matter during the session, which will be led by Barbara Keller, a pianist and teacher. Admission is $10. Information: 427-6000, extension 129.

title: SWISS VOTERS BACK CURB ON REFUGEES
description: Swiss voters gave overwhelming approval today to Government-backed proposals to tighten restrictions on refugees and make political asylum more difficult to obtain.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Tobacco Co., Stamford, Conn., said George M. Goodridge had joined the company as customer service director and would work at its service center in Richmond.

title: NMS PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: STAGE: HARVEY FIERSTEIN'S 'SAFE SEX'
description: HARVEY FIERSTEIN, playwright and actor, wants an audience to adore him. In ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' his breakthrough plays about a professional drag queen, and now in ''Safe Sex,'' a lumpy trilogy of one-act plays about the AIDS crisis, Mr. Fierstein pushes love - love for himself and, of course, love for all humanity. As a writer, he dreams of a world where everyone gets along: homosexuals and heterosexuals, women and men, adults and children. As a performer, he dreams of holding forth at center stage, getting every laugh with his bullfrog's voice, milking every tear with his wounded, over-the-hill torch singer's gaze.

title: Put College at John Jay
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrrections
description: A map Saturday with an article about right-wing vigilantes in the Philippines incorrectly located Baguio, a resort city that has been a site of vigilante activity. It is on the island of Luzon, north of Manila.

title: Standard Oil's Reply Expected
description: The Standard Oil Company, which is considering an $7.4 billion offer from the British Petroleum Company for the 45 percent of Standard Oil it does not already own, will issue a statement about the offer today, according to persons close to the deliberations.

title: Metro Matters; The Legislature, Payroll Padding And the Future
description: In 1975, payroll padding charges against a former Assemblyman from Long Island were dismissed by a judge who declared: ''This defendant has been singled out and indicted for his participation in a practice that has prevailed in this state for decades.'' In short, Albany County Judge John J. Clyne said, the legislator was a victim of selective prosecution.

title: TRADE PACT FOES RALLY IN CANADA
description: As President Reagan arrived here today for a 24-hour official visit, a coalition of Canadian groups including the Canadian Labor Congress, the country's biggest trade union organization, completed formation of a new lobbying body to campaign against any broadly based trade agreement with the United States.

title: Refiguring Arms Debts
description: Paying for weapons is a problem for many developing countries, and last December the United States offered 38 foreign governments the option of deferring payments on the difference between current interest -then about 7.4 percent - and the higher rates of up to 14 percent at which their loans had been made.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $51,000. c-Net loss

title: Young Hunters Electrocuted
description: Three Midland boys hunting in a field were electrocuted Saturday when wind blew a metal irrigation pipe they had picked up onto a 7,200-volt power line, the authorities said. The boys were evidently trying to flush out a rabbit hiding inside the pipe. A passer-by told deputies he had seen a pipe in the air with three figures below and then ''saw a big flash,'' said Sheriff Gary Painter. The passer-by then walked over and found the three bodies, the Sheriff said.

title: DDI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the prior year loss includes a $193,000 gain from discontinued operations.

title: PORTS OF CALL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Gilbert and Sullivan At the Symphony Space
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players present what are consistently the best local performances of the Savoy operas. At the Symphony Space Saturday afternoon, the troupe offered two Gilbert and Sullivan works, ''Trial by Jury,'' the team's ''maiden voyage,'' and a later work, ''The Sorcerer.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sweeping Defense By Caesars
description: Caesars World Inc. announced a sweeping recapitalization plan yesterday that would award shareholders a special one-time, $25-a-share dividend plus some equity in the restructured company.

title: COLLAPSE OF THRUWAY BRIDGE RECALLS CONNECTICUT TRAGEDY
description: The collapse of a bridge in Fort Hunter, N.Y., yesterday recalled the cave-in of a 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge spanning the Mianus River near Greenwich, Conn., on June 28, 1983.

title: HEALTHPLEX INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $2,718,613 premium income earned since March 1986 by a wholly owned subsidiary. Prior to March 1986, the company earned service fee income relating to services provided to this subsidiary. Subsequent to March 1986 the service fee income category was retermed premium income.

title: TARO-VIT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Big Bat in the Basement
description: Rick Rhoden, the best-hitting pitcher in baseball, had a higher batting average with runners in scoring position last season than did Don Mattingly, .318 to .305. When someone at the Yankee camp pointed this out to him the other day, Rhoden, who finished in the cellar with Pittsburgh each of the last three years, merely shrugged and said, ''I needed the runs more than he did.''

title: DANCE: HARLEM 'FIREBIRD'
description: JOHN TARAS'S choreographic version of ''Firebird'' for Dance Theater of Harlem may possess a familiar fairy-tale plot about the way a prince is helped by a bird in his struggle against evil monsters. Yet it tells its story so well that when the curtain falls, sophisticated adults may find themselves cheering like happy children at the triumph of good over evil.

title: GERMAN ECONOMIC DOLDRUMS
description: The West German economy, which has managed about 50 months of inflation-free growth, is beginning to show signs that trouble may be brewing for the year ahead.

title: SCOTT INSTRUMENTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Karen S. Makoff Weds W. J. Silbey
description: Karen Shawn Makoff, a daughter of Dr. Dwight Makoff and Dr. Rhoda Makoff of Santa Monica, Calif., was married yesterday to William James Silbey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Silbey of Short Hills, N.J. Judge Ronald Schoenberg of the Municipal Court of West Los Angeles performed the ceremony at the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Hotel.

title: The Man for the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: NOFZIGER WON'T TESITFY ABOUT LILCO
description: Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political adviser, has told a Senate subcommittee that he will invoke the Fifth Amendment and refuse to testify about $780,000 he has received as a lobbyist for the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Another Car Is Sought In Fatal L.I. Collision
description: A Buick automobile that collided with a wedding party's limousine near here, killing the groom and best man and critically injuring the bride and maid of honor, may have been in a race with another car, the Nassau County police said today.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $299,000 from debt restructuring for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Emirates Oil Output Down
description: Oil output in the United Arab Emirates dropped 10 percent in March from February, to an average 1.05 million barrels a day, mainly because of customer resistance to fixed prices of Abu Dhabi oil, industry sources said today.

title: BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $373,000 related to a delayed exchange offer and a non-cash writedown of oil and gas assets of $3,958,077 due to lower selling prices for the quarter; and the year includes a writedown of $4.1 million of oil and gas assets. c-Net income

title: Shola Lynch Chooses Texas
description: She will not be able to sign her letter of intent until Wednesday, but Shola Lynch, the star middle-distance runner from Hunter College High School, is verbally committed to attend the University of Texas in the fall, her mother said yesterday.

title: Writers Read for Columbia
description: Susan Minot, Mona Simpson and Katha Pollitt are among the writers to read from their works in a benefit for Columbia: A Magazine of Poetry and Prose, on April 16 at 8 P.M. at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Held in conjunction with The Writer's Voice, the benefit is also to include readings by John Fox, Henri Cole and Nancy Schoenberger. William Matthews, poetry editor for Grove Press, is to moderate a panel discussion following the reading. Tickets are $7; $10 with a subscription to Columbia; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 664-1050.

title: PURCHASERS SAY GROWTH IN MARCH WAS STRONG
description: The economy continued to expand in March, but at a much faster pace, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its monthly report to be released today.

title: LIVELY, AFFORDABLE FASHION
description: The clothes and the shows themselves were casual and informal as the fall and winter fashion openings began in New York last week. Two Philadelphians opened the new season with lively young clothes that also were affordable.

title: ISLANDERS SUFFERING AN IDENTITY CRISIS
description: It has been the kind of season that the Islanders, along with their exasperated rookie coach, would like to disown.

title: BRIDGE WAS REPAIRED 5 YEARS AGO AND PASSED INSPECTION IN 1986
description: The 31-year-old bridge that collapsed yesterday into the Schoharie Creek was rehabilitated five years ago and last inspected in April 1986, when it was found to be in good condition, according to the deputy chief engineer of the New York State Thruway Authority.

title: INDEPENDENT FILMS MAKING IT BIG
description: When all the cheers were cheered and all the Oscars arranged on mantelpieces and Academy Award hyperbole boxed away until next year, one thing remained: Hollywood's yearly orgy of self-congratulation had been subverted by movies that were produced and financed outside the major studio system.

title: Oscar Zimmerman, 76, Dies; Longtime Bassist and Teacher
description: Oscar Zimmerman, an American bass player and teacher, died of lung cancer Thursday in Traverse City, Mich. He was 76 years old and lived in Traverse City.

title: LEFTIST LOSE POWER TO THE CONSERVATIVES IN FRANKFURT REGION
description: The Social Democratic Party lost control of the state of Hesse today for the first time since World War II as a coalition led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats won control of the state parliament.

title: MUSIC: NIGHT OF BEETHOVEN
description: SO rewarding was Saturday's evening of cello and piano music -all of it by Beethoven - at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall that one regretted missing its companion concert a week before. Together the two events, featuring Daniel Morganstern and Eric Larsen, programmed the five sonatas and the three sets of variations that Beethoven contributed to this then-unusual combination of instruments.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1987
description: Companies The board of Caesars World approved a restructuring that would give shareholders a one-time, $25-a-share dividend. The action is seen as a blow to efforts by Martin T. Sosnoff to acquire the casino company for $28 a share. [ Page D1. ] The pilots' union offered to buy United Airlines for $4.5 billion. It said the offer to the Allegis Corporation was intended to sever the airline from Allegis's auto rental and hotel interests. [ D1. ] I.B.M. is focusing on the corporate market and turning away from casual users of computers, according to many in the industry who ventured an opinion about the new product line. [ D1. ] International Report Japan is offering compromises in a dispute over access to its telecommunications market, but snags remain. [ D1. ] Many in Britain's financial community oppose their Government's threats of retaliation against Japan. [ D10. ] Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry was reported to be close to a decision to buy a $20 million supercomputer manufactured by Cray Research Inc. [ D10. ] Opposition to a free-trade pact is strong in Canada, where President Reagan is holding talks. [ D1. ] The West German economy is showing signs of faltering, and it will be at least a year before a tax cut is felt. [ D8. ] The ferry disaster at Zeebrugge struck hard at Dover, the British port that is dominated by cross-channel business. [ D8. ] Markets Mutual funds that concentrate on gold were top gainers in the first three months of 1987. [ D1. ] Caution after last week's tumult is advised for investors, even though many analysts continue to think that stock prices have not yet reached their highs for this year. [ D6. ] The Economy Economic growth continued in March, but at a much faster pace, according to a survey of industrial managers. [ D2. ] Today's Columns ''Political litigation'' is a growing specialty among Washington lawyers who help clients deal with the expanding body of laws concerning ethics in government. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] The dollar's effect on Japanese investors has been the focus of the credit market's attention. Credit Markets. [ D7. ] A delay in a product introduction has not hurt Uccel, a software company that has put off bringing out a new $500,000 program for banks. The company has other thriving lines. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: The U.N. Today: April 6, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: THREAT FROM CHRISTIAN MILITIA KEEPS BEIRUT AIRPORT CLOSED
description: Attempts this weekend to reopen the Beirut airport, closed for two months, have turned into a national controversy and heightened tensions between Moslems and Christians.

title: LEONARD MUST PROVE HIMSELF
description: When Jack Klugman was approached about doing television commercials for Monday's Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Sugar Ray Leonard middleweight title fight, he stipulated his deal had to have one perk.

title: A Hill Grows in the Mind of Urban Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: GORBACHEV PUTS OFF HIS JOURNEY TO CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: As Czechoslovakia prepared to greet Mikhail S. Gorbachev with praise for his policies of change, a Government spokesman suddenly announced today that the Soviet leader was delaying his expected arrival Monday until late in the week because of a ''slight cold.''

title: FALLEN BRIDGE ON A NORTHERN LIFELINE, EXPECTED TO AFFECT TRUCKERS THE MOST
description: For hundreds of companies that depend on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway as a lifeline to the rest of the nation, the collapse of a Thruway bridge yesterday will mean more than a year of detours and disruptions, according to state officials.

title: Vons Unit to Thompson
description: The Vons Companies Retail Operations, which has 180 retail food and/or drug units, 130 of which are in the Los Angeles area, has moved its account to the J. Walter Thompson Company from Grey Advertising. Both Los Angeles offices of those agencies. Thompson will handle the $14 million broadcasting account on a full-service basis.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Make Room for Biederman
description: MOVE over, Woody Allen. Move over, Hal Riney. Make room for Barry Biederman -writer, director and performer.

title: THINKING THE UNTHINKABLE IN TEXAS: STATE INCOME TAX IS ON THE HORIZON
description: State Senator Roy M. Blake, a deeply conservative Democrat from Nacogdoches, was long a staunch foe of a state income tax for Texas, even sponsoring a constitutional ammendment to ban it in 1985. But now, as he travels his district in rural East Texas, he says he senses a profound shift.

title: POPE, IN CHILE PROTEST CENTER, HEARS CRY AGAINST TERROR
description: Pope John Paul II heard an anguished cry against Chile's ''culture of death'' today from an Archbishop who complained of terrorism by both the military Government and its opposition.

title: TRANSDUCER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a tax benefit of $24,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and reflects tax benefits of about $186,000 for the quarter and $573,000 for the year.

title: Two Days' Notice
description: To the Editor:

title: Initial Phase Of Chip Talks
description: American and Japanese officials will begin the groundwork Monday for formal meetings about a dispute over computer chip trade. The talks are aimed at heading off millions of dollars of penalty tariffs on certain Japanese exports.

title: Bridge: 2 Manhattan Teams Battle In Area Final for Nationals
description: Teams headed by Saul Bronstein and Kathie Wei, both of Manhattan, battled yesterday at the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street, in the area final of the Grand National Team Championships.

title: Chicago Mayoral Candidate Drops Bid in 4-Way Contest
description: Thomas C. Hynes, the Cook County tax assessor who was one of three candidates bidding to unseat Mayor Harold Washington, dropped out of the race today, saying he did not want to dilute opposition to the Mayor.

title: PAKISTAN EXPECTS RISING PRESSURE AS FIGHTING GROWS IN AFGHANISTAN
description: With heavy fighting expected in the next few months in Afghanistan between Soviet forces and Afghan guerrilla armies, Pakistan is anticipating a period of heightened military and psychological pressure from Kabul and Moscow, according to official and independent analysts here.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has anybody ever played for all four major league teams in New York City - the Mets, the Yankees, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants? It's never happened, and the person who probably came closest was Sal Maglie, who pitched for the Giants, Dodgers and Yankees in New York before ending his career in 1958, four years before the Mets were born and the first year that the Dodgers and Giants were no longer home teams in New York. Others like Maglie who played for all three New York teams were Fred Merkle, first baseman, and the following pitchers: Waite Hoyt, Burleigh Grimes, Johnny Allen and Bobo Newsom. Only Casey Stengel ever suited up for the four New York teams - as a player with the Giants, as a manager with the Yankees and Mets, and as player and manager with the Dodgers. QUESTION: With 90 victories in 1984, 98 in 1985 and 108 last year, the Mets have achieved 90 victories for three years in a row. When's the last time a team did that? Only four years ago, if you exclude the 1981 season, when a strike curtailed the baseball season and no team won more than 66 games. Skipping 1981, the Baltimore Orioles ran off six straight seasons of 90 victories or more, from 1977-1983. (Even in the strike season, they won 59 of 105, a pace of 90 victories.) The last National League teams to reach 90 victories three or more seasons in a row were Philadelphia and Los Angeles in the period of 1976-78. The record for consecutive years with 90 or more victories belongs to the 12 straight from 1947-58, with a high of 103 in 1954, when they finished second to Cleveland. QUESTION: Suppose Rickey Henderson opens the Yankee season with a single, and on the first pitch to Don Mattingly, Henderson bolts for second base as Mattingly hits a chopper over the pitcher's mound. Both the shortstop and the second baseman hesitate because they are unsure who should cover the base, and that allows the ball to continue to bounce toward second without being fielded. If the ball strikes Henderson just as he reaches the base and then ricochets past the shortstop into short left-center field, will Henderson be allowed to take third base - and perhaps even score - or is the ball dead and the runner out for being hit by a batted ball? If Henderson was in contact with the ball and the base at the same time, there's no basis whatsoever for denying him whatever bases he can get on the play. Under a rule designed to protect a fielder from being interfered with on a play, a runner between bases who is struck by a batted ball will be called out automatically whether he deflects the ball accidentally or intentionally, and the ball will be deemed dead as the batter is awarded first base as well as a base hit. But a runner on a base who is struck in the same manner is not automatically out; he can only be called out if an umpire judges that he intentionally deflected the ball to hinder a fielding play, and in that case, the umpire would call the batter out as well. Since the deflection by Henderson was unintentional, then the ball would remain alive and play would continue. Had the ball bounced off Henderson to the shortstop instead of going into the outfield, then the shortstop could have thrown to first base in an attempt to retire Mattingly on a play in which the runner would have deserved as much of an assist as the fielder. QUESTION: How many Canadian-born players are in the major leagues, and have any ever played with the two Canadian teams? As the season opens, there are three players on major league rosters who were born in Canada, and only one is with a Canadian team: Rob Ducey, a rookie outfielder with his hometown Toronto Blue Jays. Ducey is the third native Canadian to play for the Blue Jays, following Dave McKay, an infielder with Toronto from 1977-79, and Paul Hodgson, an outfielder in 1980. The most recent Montreal Expo player from Canada was Doug Frobel, an outfielder from Ottawa who previously played for Pittsburgh and was traded by the Expos last season to the Mets' farm team in Tidewater, where he batted .249 with 11 home runs. Frobel had joined the pitchers Claude Raymond (1969-71), Larry Landreth (1976-77) and Bill Atkinson (1976-79) as the only Canadian Expos.

title: Dr. Koop Defends His Crusade on AIDS
description: The morning that Dr. C. Everett Koop went to Congress to testify in favor of condom advertising, his wife sent him off with these words: ''Well, I'm glad your mother's dead.''

description: For motorists heading to western New York State from the New York City region and seeking to avoid the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, which is sure to be tied up for miles around the scene of yesterday's bridge collapse, the Auto Club of New York suggests the following route:

title: Alert Issued Over Chemical Fire
description: Officials warned residents today to wash exposed eating utensils and clothing and avoid the residue left when a chemical warehouse fire spewed a toxic cloud Saturday that caused an estimated 10,000 people to flee their homes.

title: ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: MAVERICK RESTAURANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter and year losses include a provision for restaurant closings and disposition of $2,250,000 in connection with the closing or planned closing of six restaurants.

title: SPACE STATION LINK ABORTED BY SOVIET
description: An unmanned, 11-ton space research module failed to link up with the orbiting Mir laboratory today, according to Tass, the Soviet Government official press agency.

title: It's Julius, Not Doctor J
description: HE knew how to ''float'' on the basketball court, but carrying himself outside the arena was the real trick.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 1.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Is a Hoosier a Hayseed?
description: New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, is a graduate of Syracuse University, which was about to play Indiana University for the N.C.A.A. basketball championship. Taunting his Senate colleagues from Indiana, he noted that Webster's Third New International Dictionary defined ''Hoosier'' as the nickname for an Indianan but also as ''an awkward, unhandy or unskilled person; esp: an ignorant rustic.''

title: UNFLAPPABLE OJEDA ACCEPTS NEW ROLE FOR SEASON OPENER
description: ONLY one thing bothers Bob Ojeda about his role as the understudy who will replace Dwight Gooden tomorrow afternoon in the big show at Shea Stadium.

title: 3 White Youths Seized In Racial Assault Case
description: Three white teen-agers were arrested Saturday night in a ''bias incident'' on a Brooklyn street corner, the police said yesterday.

title: Education Tree in Brooklyn
description: To most people, a quality undergraduate education means big bucks and, probably, a private institution. But Brooklyn College of the City University of New York defies that stereotype. In 1984, it was cited by the National Endowment for the Humanities, in an otherwise dismal report, as one of the few ''bright spots'' in American higher education. Most recently, it was a top-ranked school in a survey by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

title: Catching Up
description: An update on the 14 Mets who, appearing this way in the batting order, played in the franchise's very first game, an 11-4 loss at St. Louis 25 years ago next Saturday: Ex-Player Pos Age Now That the Cheering Has Stopped Richie Ashburn cf 60 TV-radio broadcaster for the Phillies since 1963. Felix Mantilla ss 52 Is retired in Milwaukee, where he was an insurance agent. Charlie Neal 2b 56 Puralator Courier driver in Fort Worth. Frank Thomas lf 57 Retired from public relations work in his native Pittsburgh. Gus Bell rf 58 Sales manager of family's Cincinnati embroidery company. Gil Hodges 1b - Died of heart attack at age 47 in 1972, while Met manager. Don Zimmer 3b 56 Third-base coach for the San Francisco Giants. Hobie Landrith c 57 Lives in Troy, Mich., where he's a Volkswagen executive. Roger Craig p 56 Manager of the San Francisco Giants. Ed Bouchee ph 54 Manages a Chicago-area warehouse for A.C. Delco. Bob Moorhead p - Died last December after a long illness. He was 48. Herb Moford p 58 Tobacco farmer in Minerva, Ky. Clem Labine p 60 Mortgage originator for a bank in Woonsocket, R.I. Jim Marshall ph 55 Between jobs. Managed Buffalo's minor league club last year.

title: SANDSPORT DATA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said share earnings in all periods are less than 1 cent a share.

title: Arms Sale Challenged
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to sell artillery shells made of depleted uranium to Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Bahrain, but it has not notified Congress. Why? Because the sales total less than $14 million and the law requiring that Congress be notified of arms sales abroad does not cover sales of less than that amount. Still, a few members of Congress have found out about the sales and have moved to block them.

title: A BITTER STRUGGLE SPLITS SOUTH CAROLINA G.O.P.
description: A bitter power struggle between South Carolina Republicans and evangelical Christians underscores the growing tension between the followers of the Rev. Pat Robertson and Vice President Bush and raises the prospect of Republicans' alienating an important voting constituency, conservative Christians.

title: UNLIKELY CABARET ACTS PERFORM FOR WILLIAMSTOWN
description: Celeste Holm singing ''In the Still of the Night''? James Naughton belting rock?

title: Make Power Plants Convertible
description: Back in 1978, when the Arab oil embargo and winter shortages of domestic natural gas still loomed large, it seemed like a fine idea to prohibit new electric power plants from burning oil or gas. But now, in the midst of an energy glut, it strikes many Americans as arbitrary Federal interference. Last year, the House voted to dump the Fuel Use Act, and hearings on repeal are expected in the Senate this spring.

title: Nuclear Slumber
description: The operators of Philadelphia Electric's Peach Bottom nuclear reactor have given new pungency to the phrase asleep at the switch. Those working the night shift regularly nod off while the reactor boringly zaps the energy of neutrons into boiling water. While Pennsylvania sleeps, the reactor operators slumber in big, comfortable chairs with their feet up on their desks, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has learned. It was so horrified it has ordered the plant shut down immediately.

title: Lawn Boy Assigned To Bozell, Jacobs
description: The Lawn Boy Product Group, the Memphis-based unit of the Outdoor Marine Corporation that makes mowers, has decided after a review to assign its advertising to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Atlanta.

title: Business and the Law; Cases That Fall In Public Glare
description: LEONARD GARMENT, one of the capital's best-known lawyers, has taken to calling his specialty ''political litigation.'' He explained: ''By definition, political litigation means trying to present your case publicly.''

title: SHELTON SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shelton converted from a mutual to stock form in August.

title: Chamber Symphony Plays at 92d Street Y
description: The New York Chamber Symphony introduced an appealing new piece by Nicholas Thorne, for bass trombone and orchestra, at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening. ''Songs of Darkness, Power and Radiance'' is the unpromising title (evoking familiar, better ones without achieving their authentic ring, and sounding all too much like a list of the attributes the composer hopes listeners will find in the work), but the concerto impressed as a candidate for wide circulation.

title: Meese Draws F.B.I. List
description: White House officials say Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has been given the task of developing a ''short,'' or final, list of candidates to replace William Webster as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Meese will submit the list to President Reagan, who then will choose a nominee.

title: President of Atlas Adds Chief Executive Title
description: The Atlas Corporation has announced that Richard R. Weaver, its president and chief operating officer, has been named chief executive. Mr. Weaver takes over as the mining company looks forward to a profitable year after three years of red ink.

title: A LEFTIST'S STORY: IDEALISM, REBELLION AND PERSECUTION
description: Kim Chong Jung, a solemn 28-year-old, has been a full-time rebel since the day in 1980 when he picked up an M-1 rifle and effectively declared war on the Government.

title: Six-Shooter
description: At a baseball memorabilia show in Iowa the other day, Minnie Minoso said he would suit up again for a brief stint with the Chicago White Sox in 1990 and thus become the first player to make major league appearances in six different decades. Minoso, still his sinewy self at age 64 and a frequent participant in old-timers' games, was serious. ''It's already done,'' he said.

title: WITH NEW PC'S, I.B.M. COURTS THE CORPORATIONS
description: With the International Business Machines Corporation's introduction of a new generation of personal computers last week, analysts and large computer purchasers said the company focused its attentions on the corporate marketplace and largely turned away from more casual users of PC's.

title: Guns and Past Echo at Shiloh
description: The armies of the Blue and the Gray gathered again this weekend on the fields near Shiloh, Tenn., in a re-enactment of the battle that, 125 years ago this week, marked a turning point in the Civil War.

title: REGAL PETROLEUM reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After 1986 charges for writedowns, depletion and abandonments of oil and gas properties of about $1,396,000. The prior year results can not be presented on a comparable basis because of a change in fiscal year 1985 from Aug. 31 to Dec. 31.

title: SENATOR SAYS RUSSIANS SHOULD PAY TO CLEAR NEW EMBASSY OF BUGS
description: A leading Senate Democrat said today that before the Soviet Union opens its new embassy in Washington it should be required to reimburse the United States for the cost of making the new American Embassy in Moscow secure.

title: INSIDE
description: Gorbachev Misses a Date

title: Cuba Sends 20 Ex-Prisoners To U.S. at Rate of 2 a Week
description: Cuba has allowed 20 former political prisoners to emigrate to the United States in the last 10 weeks at the rate of two a week, United States officials say.

title: Hillary Kahn Is the Bride Of an Account Executive
description: Temple Beth Sholom in Haddon Heights, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Hillary Kahn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S.Benham Kahn of Cherry Hill, N.J., to Curtis Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour L. Morgenroth of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Albert Lewis officiated.

title: OPPOSITION TO SEOUL REGIME IS VAST BUT BADLY SPLINTERED
description: In a small, private room of a coffee house here, several young men and one woman spoke of democracy, firebombs, torture, America, and what they see as other related subjects.

title: OS/2 System: No Free Lunch
description: When I.B.M.'s first generation of personal computers came out, the cost of buying the operating system - the program that acts as the computer's internal traffic cop, directing the flow of data and instructions - seemed inconsequential. I.B.M. charged about $40 for it; many computer dealers threw it in for free.

title: KING WINS PLAYOFF ON 2D EXTRA HOLE
description: Betsy King gained her first victory in a major tournament today when she parred the second hole of a sudden-death playoff to beat Patty Sheehan in the $500,000 Nabisco Dinah Shore event at Mission Hills.

title: Study on Scimed
description: Scimed Life Systems Inc. said Friday that the Bristol-Myers Company was analyzing the pending lawsuit brought against Scimed by Advanced Cardiovascular Systems Inc. to determine whether to continue with its previously announced plans to buy Scimed. The company said it was served with the suit here Tuesday, the day after it announced its definitive merger agreement with Bristol-Myers. The suit contends that Scimed infringed on Advanced Cardiovascular patents. Scimed said the charges were without merit.

title: 2 Killed in Miami Explosion
description: A bomb exploded outside a house about 3 P.M. today, hurling a fireball into the air. The accident left two teen-agers dead and at least four other people injured. The authorities initially attributed the blast to a liquid petroleum tank but later said they found fragments of a military-type bomb at the site.

title: Donna Rude Weds
description: Donna Megan Rude, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Rude of New York, and Barry J. Yellen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Yellen of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Hillel Friedman and Cantor David Rosenzweig officiated. The bride is in charge of production in New York for Marlis/Seeff Productions of Los Angeles, a maker of commercials. Mr. Yellen is a senior partner in the New York law firm Yellen & Herstic.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BRIDGE COLLAPSES ON THE THRUWAY, TRAPPING VEHICLES
description: The center of a 540-foot bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed without warning this morning, sending at least two cars and a truck plunging into a swollen creek. The cause of the collapse was unknown, but it followed two days of heavy rains.

title: Tourist Bus Wreck Hurts 22
description: A double-decker tourist bus crashed into a stone overpass Saturday, shearing off the vehicle's second level and injuring 22 people, four of them seriously, the authorities said. The bus was carrying 62 passengers, apparently to George Washington's homestead, when it slammed into the Morningside Lane overpass on the George Washington Parkway about 7:25 P.M., the authorities said.

title: SIMPSON TAKES GREENSBORO GOLF BY 2
description: Scott Simpson overcame a momentary lapse on the back nine as well as charges by several other golfers today for a two-shot triumph in the Greater Greensboro Open.

title: 'Vase' by Renoir Stolen From a London Gallery
description: Thieves forced open the front door of a London art gallery and stole ''The Vase of Flowers,'' a painting by the French Impressionist Pierre Auguste Renoir valued at $720,000, the police said today.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $39,205. c-Net loss

title: OF YOOKS AND ZOOKS: NUCLEAR EDUCATION IN L.I. SCHOOLS
description: The Barnum Wood Elementary School seems almost to be squirming with activity today. Some pupils are trooping to lunch; others are cheering in the gym. But in the library, second graders sit, listening raptly, as a librarian reads from Dr. Seuss:

title: U.S. IS EXPANDING AMNESTY PROGRAM FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: President Reagan's Administration, expansively interpreting the new immigration law, plans to offer legal status to illegal aliens who have been harvesting fruit, vegetables and ''other perishable commodities'' such as Christmas trees and tobacco.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All of a sudden I just heard this noise. Water splashed up high, and the road and the concrete just fell in.'' - Shawn D. Jablonski, who witnessed a bridge collapse near Albany. [ B2:1. ]

title: NATIONAL ROYALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $47,544.

title: STAGE: SHAKESPEARE REVUE
description: ''STAND-UP SHAKESPEARE'' is, as its subtitle indicates, ''a motley musical'' - heterogeneous rather than homogeneous. As directed by Mike Nichols at Theater 890, the show is, alternately, a felicitous musical entertainment and a self-conscious attempt to lead Shakespeare to make fun of himself.

title: Morris Amchan, a Prosecutor At Nuremberg, Is Dead at 76
description: Morris Amchan, a senior prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II who was also an attorney for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Navy Department, died Friday in Washington after suffering a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer Prices March

title: OIL GIANT IS BUFFER FOR BARTLESVILLE
description: The four buildings that make up the world headquarters of the Phillips Petroleum Company in Bartlesville can be seen for miles, even to the rolling Osage Hills that enclose much of northeastern Oklahoma's Greene County.

title: Creamed Corn
description: Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants' shortstop, plans to stock up on peanuts and ears of corn this season. He won't eat the stuff, though. Better to swing at it.

title: Victoria P. Moskowitz Weds Lee Glickenhaus
description: Victoria Paula Moskowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Moskowitz of New York, was married yesterday to Lee Hadas Glickenhaus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walt Glickenhaus of New York. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: GLOOM IN DOVER, A FERRY HUB
description: The ferry disaster outside Zeebrugge, Belgium, hit hardest in white-cliffed Dover, Europe's leading ferry port.

title: OUSTED AS LESOTHO HEADIN A COUP
description: Chief Leabua Jonathan, Lesotho's Prime Minister for 20 years before he was ousted in a military coup in January 1986, died today in a hospital in Pretoria, the South African Government reported. He was 72 years old.

title: MEDICORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $641,001. c-After income from discontinued operations of $281,818.

title: JAPANESE EASING STANCE IN PHONE CABLE DISPUTE
description: The trade dispute over telecommunications has brought threats of retaliation against Japan from Britain and strong protest from the United States.

title: Northern Telecom Insert In the Fortune 500
description: The Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, meanwhile, has been busy preparing a 21-page, one-shot ad for publication as an insert in Fortune's 500 issue of April 27 for its client Northern Telecom. It will probably cost around $1 million, judging by the magazine's page rates.

title: SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods include a writedown of oil and gas properties of $1,169,765, and the year-ago periods include a similar writedown of $18,086,669.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: DESPITE CHANGES SAME OLD RANGERS
description: The coach who was hired to replace the dismissed coach is not coaching. The new general manager who swore that the last thing he wanted to do was coach is coaching. The big-name acquisition of the season did not produce and is gone. He was replaced by a bigger name who is not producing either. And it turns out that a minor trade has given the team one of their most important players.

title: CHILE'S OPPOSITION GROUPS TRADE BLAME FOR CLASHES
description: The clashes that marred Pope John Paul II's visit here have heightened disagreement within the Chilean opposition over the use of violence.

title: Marjorie Segel Is Wed To Lawrence J. Haas
description: At Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Marjorie R. Segel, a daughter of Irma Segel of Great Neck and the late Sidney Segel, was married to Lawrence J. Haas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Haas of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: The Cancer-Makers Are Out to Get You
description: LEAD: The bad news is that more than one out of every four Americans is developing cancer in his or her lifetime. Better news is that every cancer has a cause. Most often these causes come from outside of us: what we eat, drink and smoke; where we live and work. Thus, we know that cancer can be prevented.

title: NO CLEAR FAVORITE IS FORECAST FOR DERBY
description: Kentucky Derby forecasters peering into their crystal balls today see a crowded scene at Churchill Downs on May 2: a full field of 20 3-year-olds, half of them only a length or two apart as they strain for the finish line.

title: BEFORE COLLAPSE,. A RECORD WATER RUSH
description: Twelve hours before a bridge over the Schoharie Creek collapsed Sunday on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, the rush of water through a dam 40 miles upstream hit a ''historic high,'' a vice president of the New York Power Authority said yesterday.

title: Webster's Checkup
description: Tom Webster, the Rangers' head coach, had a re-evaluation yesterday of the ear infection that has kept him from coaching full-time. He was told that the infection still exists and he was given a new medication. Webster will be examined again in two weeks, at which time the Rangers may be forced to make a decision regarding his future.

title: WEST BANK PROFESSOR CONVICTED OF INCITEMENT
description: A leading Palestinian academic was found guilty of incitement today by an Israeli military court for writing in an English-language newsletter of a West Bank university that Palestinians should reject and resist the Israeli occupation.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NAVY NOMINEE HAS RESERVATIONS ON ROLE OF WOMEN AT ACADEMY
description: James H. Webb Jr., the Reagan Administration's nominee to replace John F. Lehman Jr. as Navy Secretary, said today he still had doubts about the presence of women as midshipmen at the Naval Academy.

title: State Utility Write-Off
description: The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it expects to write off $294 million in the first quarter to reflect costs from two nuclear power plants. As a result, the company said, it expects a loss for the quarter, in contrast to a profit a year earlier of $79.6 million.

title: KEMP TO SEEK PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION
description: Promising to support a weapons shield in space, ''freedom fighters'' abroad, free enterprise in the marketplace and traditional family values at home, Representative Jack F. Kemp announced his Presidential candidacy today.

title: Clarendon Bids For Argonaut
description: Argonaut Group Inc., a property and casualty insurer that was spun off by Teledyne Inc. in November, said Clarendon Group Ltd. had made an unsolicited proposal to acquire it for $37 a share. The offer values Argonaut at $433.2 million.

title: CHALLENGE TO PACIFIC ARCHEOLOGY
description: An archaeologist studying Bikini Atoll as part of preparations for returning the atomic bomb test site to its displaced residents has found evidence humans may have inhabited eastern Micronesia thousands of years earlier than previously thought.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY RELAXES REGULATIONS ON DRUG TESTING
description: The New York City Transit Authority has revised its policy on drugs, to limit the circumstances under which 45,000 employees can be ordered to take drug tests.

title: Syringes, Not Needles, Are the AIDS Culprits
description: To the Editor:

title: Marchers in East Jerusalem Back Inmates' Hunger Strike
description: Protesters marched through East Jerusalem today in support of a hunger strike by Palestinian prison inmates.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., named Duane Wolter executive vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Ralph M. Shulansky, who will continue as senior vice president, administration and investor relations.

title: KNICK RALLY TURNS JEERS INTO CHEERS
description: They came to pay tribute to the tall, lanky kid from Long Island who went on to change the way basketball is played, adding a brand of personal flash that has spawned an entire generation of acrobatic specialists.

title: Police Dismiss Officer Who Shot Man Dead
description: A police officer who fatally shot a man on a Bronx subway platform two years ago and who was acquitted last year of criminally negligent homicide in a jury trial, was dismissed from the force yesterday because of the shooting.

title: Dispute Centers on Getty Contract
description: The dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company centers on which of the companies first reached a binding contract to purchase all or part of the Getty Oil Company early in 1984.

title: The U.N. Today: April 7, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Natural Resources - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Flaw in Physics Theory
description: Since its development in 1947, the theory of quantum electrodynamics has enabled physicists to make accurate predictions about the interaction of atomic particles and to develop important electronic technology based on these interactions. But a team of scientists at the University of Michigan has uncovered evidence that the theory may be fundamentally flawed.

title: Johncock Coming Back
description: Gordon Johncock, a two-time Indianapolis 500 winner who retired in 1985, will attempt a comeback in this year's race, officials at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced yesterday. Johncock, 50 years old, will drive a March-Cosworth entered by Gold Racing of Lincoln, Neb., for the May 24 race. He last drove at Indy in 1984, when he finished 25th after a crash on the front straightaway. Johncock has driven in 20 Indy 500 races, with victories in 1973 and 1982. He practiced at Indy in 1985 but announced his retirement a day before qualifying trials began. He returned to the speedway last year but was unable to find a ride.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5.5 million and an extraordinary credit of $66.4 million on debt restructuring. c-Net loss and is after loss from discontinued operations of $64.6 million. The 1985 results were reclassified.

title: PIANO: THE LABEQUES
description: ALICE TULLY HALL, which has a medium-sized seating capacity, looked only about two-thirds full for Sunday afternoon's duo piano concert by Katia and Marielle Labeque, whom this writer had always supposed to be deliriously popular. Was the presence of Bartok on the program poison for their public? Or have they perhaps been overexposed locally? If Bartok was the problem, it is really a shame, since the Labeques are among the few classical artists on the talk-show and crossover circuit who have a consistent and serious interest in 20th-century music.

title: PALESTINIAN AREA SEES SIEGE LIFTED
description: Relief supplies were allowed into the Palestinian district of Shatila in southern Beirut today, the first big shipment since the siege of the area by Shiite Moslem militiamen began five months ago.

title: NEW DIRECTOR OF FEDERAL PRISON SYSTEM IS CHOSEN
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today announced the appointment of a new director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, naming a longtime bureau employee, J. Michael Quinlan.

title: U.S. LEGISLATORS INSPECT EMBASSY IN MOSCOW
description: A United States Congressman said today that he and a colleague had made an unannounced night inspection of the American Embassy here and that Soviet agents had ''fully compromised'' it. He said it would cost tens of millions of dollars to make it secure again.

title: Zero Coupon Exxon Bonds
description: The Exxon Capital Corporation is offering about $432.3 million of zero coupon bonds, with maturities running from 1990 to 2001, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: DOUGLAS COMPUTER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Fewer European Jobless
description: Unemployment in the European Community dipped in February to 11.7 percent of the civilian work force, from a record 11.8 percent the month before, the community said today. The number of jobless people dropped by slightly more than 100,000, to 17 million, the community's statistics office said in its monthly labor market report. The figures for total number of unemployed include all 12 member countries, but the rates of unemployment exclude Greece, Spain and Portugal.

title: Article 358187 -- No Title
description: In a dramatic move to ward off a takeover, Gencorp Inc. said yesterday that it would spend $1.6 billion in cash to buy back more than half its stock.

title: EGYPTIAN VOTE IS MOSTLY PEACEFUL
description: Scattered outbreaks of violence were reported today as Egyptians voted to elect a national legislature.

title: Wright Takes His Leadership by the Horns
description: Jim Wright, the new Speaker of the House of Representatives, enjoys going out on a limb.

title: Cannon Will Sell Home Video Stake
description: The Cannon Group said it would sell its 50 percent interest in HBO/ Cannon Home Video to Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, its partner in the venture. Analysts said the deal, valued at $20 million, would give the financially troubled Cannon enough capital to continue its curtailed production schedule.

title: VISTA ORGANIZATION LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture yesterday with a biographical sketch of Kim Young Sam, a critic of the South Korean Government, was published in error. It actually showed another critic, Kim Dae Jung. A second picture of Kim Dae Jung also appeared, correctly, with the sketch of him.

title: UMPIRES ACCEPT CONTRACT
description: Major league umpires were on the job yesterday, working for about 25 percent more money than they earned on opening day last year. The pay increase - and their presence on the field - resulted from an all-night negotiating session that produced an agreement two hours before the first scheduled game.

title: Public Relations Unit Of Ogilvy Gets Head
description: L. Michael Dowling, who had been president of Ogilvy & Mather Public Affairs in Washington, has gone west to head the newly formed Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations/West in Los Angeles, which is made up of that office and one in San Francisco, as well as the Ogilvy & Mather/Cole & Weber Public Relations offices in Seattle and Portland.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Jan 2
Samuelson Out
description: Joan Benoit Samuelson, the Boston Marathon women's record-holder who planned to run in the event this month despite her pregnancy, pulled out of the race yesterday because of a thigh injury. Jack Mahoney, a spokesman for the race, which will be held April 20, said Samuelson had a torn muscle in her right thigh that caused internal bleeding.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WORDS AND SCIENCE
description: EVERY now and then a new software package comes along that leaves one's jaw hanging after the utterance of a startled ''Why?'' Manuscript ($495 for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles from Lotus Development Corporation, Cambridge, Mass. 02142, 617-577-8500) is such a package.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,698,000 for the quarter and $13,619,000 for the year, and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $124,176,000 for both periods; the year also includes a charge of $3,719,000 in connection with Chromalloy American Corp.'s loss from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,793,000 and a charge of $544,000 in connection with Chromalloy's loss from discontinued operations. d-After income from discontinued operations of $6,093,000 and a charge of $3,340,000 in connection with Chromalloy's loss from discontinued operations. Sun Chemical merged with Chromalloy just before the end of 1986, but income results for 1986 and 1985 are presented on the basis of Sun's equity ownership in both years.

title: New U.S. Envoy in Moscow Has Meeting With Gromyko
description: Jack F. Matlock Jr., the new American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, presented his credentials today to President Andrei A. Gromyko and they met privately for half an hour, the United States Embassy reported.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Pediatric AIDS will soon be everybody's problem.'' - Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States. [ A23:3. ]

title: PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net loss c-Before a cumulative effect of a change in accounting policy of $2,247,000. Revenue represents sales and membership fees. The fourth quarter results are comprised of 16 weeks.

title: ART: 100-YEAR SURVEY OF WORKS BY WOMEN
description: The National Museum of Women in the Arts, housed in a newly renovated six-story building that was once a Masonic temple, opens its doors to the public for the first time Tuesday. Despite its name, the museum is almost entirely a private endeavor and exists largely because of the efforts of Wilhelmina Holladay, a Washington collector who is its first president.

title: Thatcher's Poll Rating Rises But She Is Silent on Election
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, flush with a rise in opinion poll ratings after her Moscow visit, met today with her chief political advisers but offered no public hint of when she will schedule the next election.

title: DOW PASSES 2,400 ON A 15.20 ADVANCE
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 2,400 for the first time in early trading yesterday and finished the day up 15.20 points, at 2,405.54.

title: SUGAR DOESN'T RUST
description: Sugar thickens and hardens, but it doesn't rust.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PUIG SPEAKS AT BARNARD

title: NEUTRINOS: NEW VIEW INTO SPACE
description: THE nearby explosion of a star and a lucky succession of scientific accidents are combining to create a new branch of astronomy, in which new instruments sensitive to streams of neutrino particles could serve as the counterparts of light-gathering telescopes.

title: WESTERN CIVILIZATION: A METALLIC VIEWPOINT
description: WITH all its faults, the Stone Age may have had its points. For one thing, people hadn't yet learned the knack of smelting ore and thereby creating junkyards; whatever it was that brought down the Neanderthals, metal pollution could hardly have played much part.

title: Dr. Hammer's Role in 'Ivan the Terrible' Trial; Get It Out in the Open
description: To the Editor:

title: CULTURAL GROUPS SEEK NEW HOME IN OLD FERRY HOUSE
description: After years of nomadic or cramped existence, some of New York City's best-known performers - Twyla Tharp, the Big Apple Circus and Dance Theater Workshop - are competing with one another for an extraordinary, if unlikely, new home: the old ferry house at the foot of Whitehall Street.

title: KOOP, AT WORKSHOP ON CHILDREN AND AIDS, STRESSES EARLY EDUCATION
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, said today that AIDS is a growing menace to the nation's children and reiterated his call for early sex education as part of the general effort to halt its spread.

title: Careers; Summer Jobs: Many Sources
description: THE search for summer jobs has begun. The International Business Machines Corporation recently helped start Summer Jobs '87, the New York City area's seventh annual program, as this year's corporate sponsor.

title: Why Paid Parental Leave Makes Sense
description: Should companies be required by law to allow parents up to 18 weeks of unpaid leave to care for newly born or seriously ill children? As Congress prepares to vote on the Family and Medical Leave Act, opinion polls show that most Americans favor the idea. With a majority of mothers in the workforce, including more than half of all new mothers, leaves of absence offer many parents a new opportunity to reach an old-fashioned goal: time with young children.

title: Bring Back the Stork
description: Here are some money figures that have been in the news lately: $50 million - This is roughly the amount various bidders paid for the Duchess of Windsor's jewelry. $39.9 million - This is the sum paid for a Van Gogh sunflower by somebody who doesn't want to be identified. $11.75 million - This is the minimum payment guaranteed Marvin Hagler for appearing in a boxing match last night with Sugar Ray Leonard. $11 million - This is the minimum payment guaranteed Mr. Leonard. $8 million - This is the amount, according to the Rev. Oral Roberts, that God said the Reverend's flock had better come across with if they wanted Mr. Roberts to live to see another April. The money was paid; Oral Roberts lives. $17,500 - This is the amount William Stern contracted to pay Mary Beth Whitehead and the Infertility Clinic for services that produced the person widely known as Baby M. What is striking about these figures is the wide disparity between the amounts spent on frivolity, triviality and grossness and the piffling sum spent on creating a human being.

title: Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., a leading manufacturer of computer work stations based in Mountain View, Calif., has lowered the price of its entry-level model, the Sun-3/50M, to $4,995, from $7,900. The move puts Sun more directly in competition with new personal computers for technical users, including those from Apple Computer Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: LEONARD, DEFYING TIME AND HAGLER, CAPTURES TITLE
description: The conventional wisdom was that boxing comebacks like Sugar Ray Leonard's were doomed to failure.

title: ALOHA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said non-operating items affecting 1985 net earnings included a $2.76 million pretax gain on the disposal of a leasehold interest in a DC-10.

title: ANDY ROONEY'S SALARY IS SUSPENDED BY CBS
description: Executives at CBS News decided yesterday to suspend the pay of Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator who has been outspoken in his criticism of network management.

title: NOW, A CONTEST FOR MAYOR OF CHICAGO
description: Just as Mayor Harold Washington appeared to be coasting easily toward re-election here Tuesday in a crowded field, the sudden withdrawal of a major challenger has put the race on an uncertain turn.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIND-SVP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year and year-earlier periods includes tax credits of $49,000 and $88,000, respectively; and the latest year also includes an extraordinary gain of $333,000 on the sale of the Findex directory business.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1.8 million writedown of inventories taken in the first quarter. c-Net income The company said it completed the sale of its Boston headquarters facility on March 24 for $2.8 million; this transaction produced a capital gain of $2.2 million, which will be reflected in results for the first quarter.

title: SPANISH PREMIER TARGET OF UNREST
description: Subway workers staged a strike last week that typified the political atmosphere here this year.

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said results for 1985 are restated for reversal of certain tax benefits.

title: Don't Put Pressure on Seoul
description: South Korean dissidents have recently stepped up their lobbying campaign in the United States, urging American Congressmen to exert political pressure on President Chun Doo Hwan to accept a particular brand of democracy.

title: Texaco Bonds Drop Sharply
description: In the bond market, where worries about the Pennzoil Company's lawsuit had already reduced prices of the bonds of Texaco Inc., the Supreme Court ruling yesterday led to another sharp drop in Texaco issues.

title: INSIDE
description: Jail Term for Corruption Richard L. Rubin, once a State Assembly aide and top Queens Democrat, was sentenced to five years in prison for payroll fraud. Page B1. Dow Average Over 2,400 The Dow Jones industrial average exceeded 2,400 for the first time, rising 15.20 points, to 2,405.54, after soaring nearly 70 points on Friday. Page D1.

title: SALVADOR REBELS AT TOWN MEETING
description: As thousands of Government troops swept northern El Salvador over the weekend seeking leftist rebels who destroyed one of the army's most important bases last week, the guerrillas themselves nonchalantly held a town meeting in this village just four miles from the devastated fort.

title: ON THE FRONTIERS OF BRAIN SURGERY
description: RELYING on new concepts of the human brain, scientists are progressing rapidly in experiments with nerve-cell transplants that promise to halt and perhaps cure a variety of devastating brain disorders.

title: MISSILE CAPABLE OF LINGERING OVER RADAR SITES IS UNVEILED
description: A missile capable of circulating over enemy radar systems while waiting for the systems to send signals and thus reveal themselves was displayed for the first time today as the Northrop Corporation broke ground for a $100 million plant here that will build the weapons.

title: ARMY SETS UP HOT LINE TO COUNTER ESPIONAGE
description: The Army is setting up a program with a toll-free telephone number that is intended to help catch spies, discover possible security risks and train soldiers to identify both, Army officials said today.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $343,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $858,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: SCOTT INSTRUMENTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'AIRPLANE': HIGH-STAKES CHAIN LETTER
description: From Manhattan to Rochester, hundreds of New Yorkers have been dreaming of flying high in an illegal pyramid scheme called the airplane game. But law-enforcement officials warn that they may lose the $1,500 to $2,500 they have invested in hopes of winning $10,000 or more.

title: Life Styles of the Rich and Shady
description: There once lived a man who bought ''a mansion where he dispensed starlight to moths.'' Everybody came to his parties, people like ''the Catlips and the Bembergs and G. Earl Muldoon, brother to that Muldoon who afterward strangled his wife,'' and ''Miss Claudia Hip, with a man reputed to be her chauffeur, and a prince of something whom we called Duke.''

title: King and Arum in Scuffle
description: Don King and Bob Arum, the rival promoters, engaged in a pushing and shoving match at the end of the Sugar Ray Leonard-Marvelous Marvin Hagler middleweight title fight last night.

title: Tektronix to Buy Estate's Shares
description: Tektronix Inc., a manufacturer of electronic measurement and test equipment based in Beaverton, Ore., said it had agreed to buy about 2.1 million shares of its common stock from the beneficiaries of Howard Vollum, a company founder who died in February. The price is $35.875 a share, or about $75 million.

title: IMMUCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax credits of $93,381 for the quarter and $281,595 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $26,542 for the quarter and $29,842 for the 9 months. The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid April 15.

title: Raging Bull
description: At his current pace - 36.67 points on 27.84 field goals attempted per game - Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls will finish the regular season a week from Friday with not only a higher scoring average but also more shots tried than anyone else in N.B.A. history except Wilt Chamberlain. The biggest guns, ranked according to shots taken:

title: Letter: On Crime; Give Sentence Guidelines a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES G. DONOVAN, AN EX-CONGRESSMAN AND ATTORNEY, DIES
description: James G. Donovan, who was a United States Representative from Manhattan in the 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: COLLAPSED BRIDGE HAD WELL-PROVED DESIGN PLAN
description: The bridge that collapsed into the Schoharie Creek on Sunday was based on one of the most frequently used designs for bridges spanning small bodies of water, according to structural engineers.

title: JURY SELECTION STARTS IN TRIAL OF 12 AS MAFIA CONSPIRATORS
description: Jury selection began yesterday for the trial of 12 men, including a convicted Mafia boss, accused of rigging bids on construction contracts, intervening in union elections and plotting murders.

title: A Leg Up
description: Mack McCarthy, basketball coach at Tennessee-Chattanooga, on the 92-73 loss to Cleveland State in this year's National Invitation Tournament: ''I knew we were in trouble when they showed up and even their cheerleaders had knee braces on.''

title: Czech Jumper Defects
description: Jan Cado, a Czechoslovak triple jumper who competed in last month's world indoor track and field championships in Indianapolis, has defected to the United States, according to a published report. Cado finished fourth in the European Indoor Championships in February with a distance of 55 feet 7 3/4 inches and was 10th in the world championships with a distance of 53-7. The Indianapolis News said that the 24-year-old Cado is living and training in the Chicago area. ''He's under the protection of the Federal government and has requested political asylum,'' Jack Knuepfer, chairman of the board of DuPage County, Ill., told the newspaper. Knuepfer said Cado had come to his home and that he took him to Federal authorities in Chicago.

title: NEW YORK DEMOCRATS BACK ETHICS CODE 9M0>
description: Reacting to scandals that have engulfed the Democratic Party in New York City, top state Democratic leaders yesterday recommended an unprecedented code of ethics for state, county, town and village party leaders.

title: A Phone to Screen Calls
description: The Sanyo Electric Company of Japan said today that it would market a telephone that can be instructed to accept calls only from certain numbers. A Sanyo official, Shigehiko Masuda, said that when the ''selection'' system was turned on, callers reaching the phone would be asked to dial the last four digits of their own phone numbers. If they do not match numbers the phone has been instructed to accept, the connection will be cut. The telephone, to go on sale April 21 in Japan, can accept up to 40 desired callers.

title: 2 Lost From U.S. Navy Sub
description: Two sailors were swept from the deck of the Navy submarine Ulysses S. Grant in rough weather today. One man was pronounced dead at a hospital 90 minutes after being plucked from the ocean by a Coast Guard utility boat. Rescuers briefly sighted the second man, but he disappeared. Ruth Dow, a spokeswoman for the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard here, said neither sailor's name would be released until their families were notified.

title: AMERICAN FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,000,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,829,648 and $7,419,008 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: LEGISLATIVE LAG ON ETHICS PANEL PERTURBS CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo stepped up his criticism of the State Legislature today amid new indications that it was prepared to deny funds for a commission he has formed to investigate government ethics.

title: New York's Competitive Edge
description: Albany's discussions on how to forgo the bonanza expected from a change in Federal tax law now bear fruit: a long-term plan to reduce state income taxes. The plan was inspired by a desire to make the state more competitive with its neighbors in keeping and wooing business. It's a constructive compromise, but improving competitiveness does not depend on low taxes alone.

title: Drug Programs That Help Small Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: TEMPORARY THRUWAY LINK SOUGHT
description: The bodies of three men were found in the muddy Schoharie Creek today as investigators focused on the floodwaters that swirled around a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway when it suddenly collapsed and sent the motorists plunging to their deaths.

title: OUTDOOR HONORS FOR A PARKS PIONEER
description: The National Park Service said farewell Saturday to Horace M. Albright, its co-founder and, for more than 70 years, its guiding spirit.

title: OH SAY DID YOU SEE CANADA START FIRST?
description: Lloyd Moseby hit a homer and drove in three runs and Jimmy Key pitched three-hit ball for six innings today to lead the Toronto Blue Jays over the Cleveland Indians, 7-3, in the American League opener for both teams.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $39,000 for the latest quarter and $8,000 for the year-earlier peirod.

title: POPE, IN ARGENTINA, HITS A POLITICAL NOTE
description: Pope John Paul II today began a six-day visit to Argentina, where he offered a kindly lecture on political responsibilities to the leaders of this young democracy.

title: BILINGUAL PROGRAMS
description: A WAR of words has broken out between the Department of Education and the General Accounting Office, an oversight agency created by Congress. The issue is bilingual education and the dispute centers on a report, ''Bilingual Education: A New Look at the Research Evidence,'' which the agency produced at the request of the chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor.

title: Abuse Charges Upheld In South Africa Study
description: A study by a team of South African doctors says that detainees have been victims of physical and mental abuse.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks 110, Cavaliers 105: Although Cleveland outscored Atlanta by 35 points from the free-throw line, Dominique Wilkins of the Hawks scored the last 4 of his 41 points on foul shots to lead the Hawks at home last night. It was Atlanta's 51st victory, the most the team has achieved since moving from St. Louis for the 1968-69 season. Cleveland stayed in the game by hitting 51 of 59 free throws compared to 16 of 19 for Atlanta as the Hawks were called for 36 fouls. Cleveland, which committed 22 fouls, rallied from a 15-point halftime deficit to tie the game, 105-105, on a free throw by John Williams with 1 minute 23 seconds left. After Wilkins hit two free throws, the Cavaliers had another chance to tie but Mark Price was called for charging with six seconds left. The Hawks closed out the scoring with three more free throws.(AP) Lakers 135, Clippers 112: James Worthy scored 20 points and A. C. Green had 19 as the Lakers clinched the homecourt advantage throughout the playoffs. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 15 points each.(AP) Kings 110, Jazz 104: Joe Kleine, who averages 7 points a game, scored 22 to help the visiting Kings defeat the Jazz and prevent Utah from sweeping the six-game season series. Eddie Johnson of the Kings scored 16 of his 21 points in the second half to spark the Kings, who trailed most of the first half.
