Otis Thorpe led the Kings with 24 points.(AP) Tennis First Round Under Way: Mariana Perez Roldan of Argentina defeated Wiltrud Probst of West Germany by 6-2, 6-1 in the first round of the 15th annual Family Circle Magazine Cup. In other first-round action at the Sea Pines Racket Club at Hilton Head, S.C., Kate Gompert of Rancho Mirage, Calif., seeded 12th, defeated Gretchen Magers of San Antonio, 6-2, 7-5; Mary Joe Fernandez from Miami, seeded ninth, advanced easily with a 1-6, 6-1, 6-1 victory over Anne Minter of Australia. Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia, seeded 14th, was beaten by Marie-Christine Calleja of France, 3-6, 6-2, 7-5. The 56-player main draw includes the defending champion, Steffi Graf, the first-seeded player in the event, and eight-time winner Chris Evert Lloyd, seeded second. First-round action continues today with Graf facing Perez Roldan. Lloyd is scheduled to play her first game tomorrow.(AP) Horse Racing Alioth Returns $5.40: Alioth took the lead out of the gate and led all the way to score a 2 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $45,000 Your Host Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Carrying 113 pounds including Jose Santos, Alioth covered the mile and an eighth on the sloppy track in 1:49 4/5 to beat the favored Lac Ouimet, carrying 118 pounds including Eddie Maple. Strong Statement, with 117 pounds including Jean-Luc Samyn, was third. The victory was the third in seven starts for Alioth, who earned $27,000 for Harp Angel Stable and returned $5.40, $3 and $2.20 for $2 across the board. Lac Ouimet paid $3.20 and $2.60 and Strong Statement paid $3.

title: ARE STRONGER HURRICANES IN OFFING?
description: HURRICANES 40 to 50 percent more destructive could be a byproduct of the gradual warming of the earth expected over the next half-century, according to new calculations by a climate modeler at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: INTERNATIONAL REMOTE IMAGNG SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Dart, Changing Tack, Drops Supermarkets Offer
description: Apparently applying new pressure on its target, the Dart Group Corporation said yesterday that it was withdrawing its proposal to acquire the Supermarkets General Corporation for at least $1.7 billion.

title: RECALLING THE PRE-MED DR. J
description: For the first time in his 27 years as an educator, Charles McIlwain played hooky today, closing the principal's office at the Centennial Elementary School here and heading to the city for Julius Erving's last game at Madison Square Garden.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Business People column yesterday listed one company erroneously among those that are leaders in vision care. The SmithKline Beckman Corporation's Allergan unit belongs in the group, but not Becton, Dickinson & Company.

title: The Kitchen Purchases Its Home for $1.4 Million
description: The Kitchen, more formally known as the Kitchen Center for Video, Music, Dance, Performance and Film, announced yesterday that it had bought its current home, a building at 512 West 19th Street from the Dia Art Foundation for $1.4 million.

title: Bridge: A Strong Finish for Winners In Final for Grand Nationals
description: The area winners of the Grand National Team Championship, which began at the club level in New York City and on Long Island five months ago, are Saul Bronstein, George Tornay, Mike Engel, August Boehm and John Roberts, all of Manhattan, and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Takeover Law Rejected
description: The Supreme Court said today that it had declined to review a ruling that struck down Ohio's takeover law. The case involved the Fleet Aerospace Corporation's bid to acquire Aeronca Inc., a maker of aerospace parts and electronics. A Federal appeals court last June ruled the law was unconstitutional because it placed an impermissible burden on interstate commerce and because it conflicted with Federal takeover laws. Fleet in May 1986 began a tender offer for Aeronca and at the same time filed suit, charging that the Ohio law was unconstitutional. Lawyers for Fleet told the Supreme Court the case was moot as the two companies reached an agreement in June and merged in September. But Ohio asked the Supreme Court to uphold its law.

title: Caesars' Defense Appears to Work
description: Wall Street showed a clear preference yesterday for a recapitalization plan proposed on Sunday by Caesars World Inc. over a $28-a-share offer made by Martin T. Sosnoff, the gambling concern's largest shareholder.

title: Japan May Miss Quota
description: Japanese auto makers may fall short of selling their 2.3-million-car allotment in the United States this year, Automotive News said today. The weekly industry journal said the Japanese auto makers' sales had been hurt by the strength of the yen against the dollar, growing supplies of Japanese-designed cars built in the United States, slumping new-car sales generally, increased competition from entry-level cars from other nations and greater competition for s

title: MARTIN D. JACOBS
description: Martin D. Jacobs, a retired United States magistrate, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Aquino Stops Moore in 5
description: Lupe Aquino, a junior middleweight from Santa Paula, Calif., defeated Davey Moore of the Bronx tonight in a bout before the Sugar Ray Leonard-Marvelous Marvin Hagler fight.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Our Towns; A Video Pioneer Uses Lip-Syncing To Get 'Psyched'
description: ''I pioneered lip-syncing videos on the Island,'' Eliot Goshman was saying in a rare quiet moment between parties. He was heading southbound on the Wantagh Parkway in his Voyager mini-van. Destination: Kim Padron's Sweet 16 party.

title: CANTERBURY PRESS reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $4,300 and $8,300 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fructose Syrup Futures Traded
description: The Minneapolis Grain Exchange began trading futures yesterday in high-fructose corn syrup, a sweetener used in soft-drink and food processing.

title: PROSECUTOR CITES TUROFF'S 'GREED' AT FRAUD TRIAL
description: A Government prosecutor yesterday asked a Federal jury to convict Jay L. Turoff, the former chairman of the city Taxi and Limousine Commission, and three co-defendants, charging that they conspired to commit fraud against the people of New York City in a ''greedy'' and ''arrogant abuse of power.''

title: 225 Red Cross Nurses Strike
description: Striking nurses picketed the American Red Cross in two counties today, idling bloodmobiles and seven of 10 donation centers. The union and the nonprofit agency disagreed about how long blood supplies would last.

title: USX-Armco Unit
description: The USX Corporation and Armco Inc. have merged their oilfield-equipment divisions, after failing to find buyers for the businesses last year. Armco said a new company, National-Oilwell, was being formed from Armco's National Supply Company and USX's Oilwell division. Its headquarters will be in Houston. Both units reported 1986 losses, but officials declined to disclose the amounts and predicted the new company would have a modest profit in 1987.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: STANDARD OIL ADVISERS CALL B.P. BID INADEQUATE
description: The Standard Oil Company said yesterday that its financial advisers had determined that the $70-a-share bid from the British Petroleum Company for the Standard Oil stock it does not already own was inadequate and should be ''at least $85 a share.''

title: Tax Watch; Accountants Overwhelmed
description: JUST when you need help most, your accountant may be at the breaking point.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
FAMINE AS SEXISM EXPLORED ON 'INTERCOM'
description: ''MAN-MADE FAMINE'' means what the title says; food shortages in Africa are caused by men, individual men, not men in the sense of mankind. The one-hour documentary at 11 o'clock tonight, part of Channel 13's ''Intercom'' series, presents a feminist view of famine.

title: Sally Hemmings Steps Forth on Her Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufacturing Profits Down
description: The after-tax profits of manufacturing corporations averaged 3.3 cents a dollar of sales in the final three months of 1986, down a tenth of a cent from the corresponding period a year before, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Seoul to Trim 83 Tariffs
description: South Korea, seeking to avoid more trade friction with the United States, will reduce tariffs on 83 manufactured and farm products by 5 to 20 percentage points July 1, the Finance Ministry said today. The cuts average 6.6 points. The products include television sets, home appliances, beer, lemons, newsprint and automobiles - but not trucks or buses. In January the Government reduced tariffs on 24 other items, including chocolate and cosmetics, in compliance with American requests.

title: CBS GAVE WYMAN $4.3 MILLION
description: Thomas H. Wyman, the former chairman of CBS Inc. who was ousted in a board room revolt last September, received a settlement of more than $4.3 million and an annual payment of $400,000 for life, according to a CBS proxy statement released yesterday.

title: ON ONCE-AGAIN ROADS, 'BUMPER-TO-BUMPER' TRAFFIC
description: As the waters of the Schoharie Creek receded this morning, nearby residents gathered to gape at wreckage pulled from the muddy swirl, and cars, buses and 18-wheel trailer trucks diverted from the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway started crawling along their narrow, normally quiet roads.

title: SIBERIAN GOLD GALORE: BUT WOULD LENIN APPROVE?
description: ''When we are victorious on a world scale, I think we shall use gold for the purpose of building public lavatories in the streets of some of the largest cities in the world,'' Lenin wrote in 1921.

title: PRIME CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Antitrust Lawsuit Against Coastal
description: The Trans-American Natural Gas Corporation filed a $100 million lawsuit in Federal court, charging the Coastal Corporation and its chairman, Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., with antitrust violations.

title: Pitcher's Gallery
description: Much like the most ardent of fans, a number of major league players collect baseball bubble-gum cards themselves. The cards are generally tacked or taped to the player's dressing stall, and each usually has a special meaning to the collector.

title: ARUM IS PROVEN RINGMASTER
description: Bob Arum was on the crowded platform at the weigh-in in the auditorium at Caesars Palace this morning, and he was hollering and waving his arms at one of his assistants. ''Where's Marvin?'' Arum shouted. ''Still taking the exam,'' came the reply.

title: Delta-Western Merger Allowed
description: The Supreme Court, rejecting an emergency request by a Western Airlines union, refused to interfere with the $860 million merger of Western and Delta Air Lines. The court, without any recorded dissent, let stand an order issued last Wednesday by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that cleared the way for the merger.

title: A Realignment Set by Saatchi Scali, McCabe Chosen By Toys 'R' Us for TV
description: The advertising industry and the rumor mongers who feed on it have been eagerly awaiting any realignment of Saatchi & Saatchi's American holdings. Yesterday, one was announced. The British publicly held holding company has created a McCaffrey & McCall Holding Company, which includes not only the ad agency and direct marketing firm of the same name, but also Rumrill-Hoyt, New York.

title: CAMERA PLATFORMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: SCANT days after the end of the showings of European ready-to-wear collections for fall, lesser-known designers began to show their lines in New York. The buyers and press who are invited to these early shows sometimes know very little about these designers, but curiosity is often rewarded.

title: Talking While the Acid Rains
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada first met President Reagan in 1985, the President promised to study acid rain and the three million tons of pollutants the United States disgorges north to Canada each year.

title: Allied-Signal To Sell Ampex
description: Allied-Signal Inc., which is reorganizing to focus on its core aerospace and advanced engineering operations, has agreed to sell another of its electronics businesses.

title: Petrofina Price Inquiry Ended
description: The Energy Department in Washington has quit seeking a fine of $841 million from American Petrofina Inc. over alleged violations of oil price control regulations, Petrofina S.A. said today.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Niemczak Loses Money
description: Antoni Niemczak of Poland, the runner-up in the 1986 New York City Marathon who later was disqualified when a drug test detected the use of a steroid, will not receive any prize money, Fred Lebow, the race's director, said yesterday. The second-place prize money of $25,000 had been withheld since the Nov. 1 race, pending an appeal to the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body for road racing and track and field. But when the New York Road Runners Club, the organizer of the marathon, was told that the appeal applied only to Niemczak's suspension by the I.A.A.F. and not his finish in the race, the club decided to proceed with redistribution of the prize money. Thus, each men's finisher from places 3 through 16 moves up one place and will receive the difference in prize money.

title: A NEW PATH FOR I.B.M.
description: WITH its announcements in New York and Miami Beach last week, I.B.M. finally put an end to many months of speculation about its new family of personal computers. Now, in turn, there will be many months of speculation about what it all means.

title: Montana Agency's Refunding Bonds
description: The Montana Department of Highways is tentatively offering $150 million of refunding highway revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 7.173 percent for a 7 1/8 percent issue due in 2005, at a price of 99 1/2.

title: BOOM TIME IN SOUTH KOREA: AN ERA OF DIZZYING CHANGE
description: For Chong Yong Hi, a 35-year-old housewife, her country's phenomenal economic growth means an apartment of her own after years of scrimping and living five to a room.

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After special charges of $2.3 million for the quarter and a special gain of $4.9 million for the year. c-Net loss d-After special charges of $13.8 million for the quarter and year. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: The Wrong War
description: It is often said, by President Reagan among others, that Mikhail Gorbachev needs an arms control agreement for economic reasons. If limits were put on the arms race, the Soviet Union could devote more resources and talent to solving the severe problems of its civilian economy.

title: BRAZILIAN GAS DISCOVERY
description: A discovery of natural gas in the Amazon region has increased. Brazil's estimated reserves 61 percent, to 150 billion cubic meters, from 93 billion cubic meters, a spokesman for the state oil company, Petrobras, said today.

title: LEONARD BEATS HAGLER FOR TITLE ON SPLIT DECISION
description: In a stunning display of boxing artistry and perseverance, Sugar Ray Leonard, with just one fight in five years, scored a 12-round split decision over Marvelous Marvin Hagler to win the World Boxing Council's middleweight championship tonight at the Caesars Palace outdoor arena.

title: Faberge Assignment
description: Although most of its business is at Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Faberge has assigned the introduction of its McGregor line of cologne and aftershave for men to Smith/ Greenland. The budget, according to the agency, will be from $2 million to $3 million.

title: JEWLERY MIRRORS ITS DESIGNER
description: As the son of an Air Force officer, Robert Lee Morris traveled a circuitous path through childhood, growing up in such exotic lands as Brazil and Japan. It was in the latter country that his artistic inclination first flowered, when he studied floral arranging - not an interest calculated to appeal to a father in the military.

title: Market Place; The Significant First Half-Hour
description: THE first half-hour of trading on the Big Board is of growing significance, because it captures the impact of a growing volume of orders from Japan and Europe. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average marched onto new high ground in the 30 minutes after its 9:30 A.M. opening.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $494,311 incurred in connection with the termination of the company's founder and former chief executive and a charge of $624,849 arising from the discontinuance of Radiation's irradiated and chemically treated polymer wood flooring and architectural products line.

title: A Creedmoor Escapee Gives Up in California
description: A 26-year-old man who fled from the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens last month has surrendered to the authorities in California, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Scali, McCabe Chosen By Toys 'R' Us for TV
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves will be making the television advertising for the Toys ''R'' Us retail chain of more than 300 stores. The previous agency was Grey Advertising, which resigned the account a month or so ago.

title: Satellites and Disease
description: Orbiting satellites might seem a strange tool for predicting widespread outbreaks of a viral disease, but Federal scientists report evidence that the view from space can be valuable for just that purpose.

title: DIVERSIFIED HUMAN REOURCES GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $126,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: People
description: * Herbert A. Miller named senior vice president, director of broadcast production at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Dennis Boyd, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to March 29.

title: MBS TEXTBOOK EXCHANGE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company went public in February.

title: Lobbyists on PAC's
description: A new group, Lobbyists and Lawyers for Campaign Finance Reform, is challenging the widespread assumption on Capitol Hill that lobbyists favor the present system of financing political campaigns through donations from their political action committees. The 60 members of the bipartisan group have pledged their support in a letter to Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, sponsor of legislation to limit PAC contributions. The group did not endorse any specific plan but said its members would support ''comprehensive reform legislation,'' to which, they said, leaders of both houses are pledged.

title: NAKASONE URGES U.S. TO WITHDRAW ITS TARIFF PLAN 888>
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone called on the Reagan Administration today to rescind the tariffs it plans to impose this month on selected electronic products from Japan.

title: CALIFORNIA STUDIES DATA ON PRISONS
description: As California struggles to relieve crowding in its prisons, a study by the State Attorney General's office found that more than one of every three young men in California was arrested at least once from 1974 through 1985.

title: 2 GUARDS DISMISSED OVER BROOKLYN JAIL VIOLENCE
description: Two New York City correction officers were dismissed yesterday and nine others - including an Assistant Deputy Warden and a Captain - were transferred as a result of a fight at a Brooklyn jail on March 24.

title: NEXT MOVE IS IN COURTS OF TEXAS
description: The fight between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company moves back into the Texas court system now, with both companies saying today that they want to find a way for Texaco to secure its potential liability without crippling itself.

title: Albert H. NewMan, 74, Editor And a World War II Reporter
description: Albert H. Newman, a war correspondent, magazine editor and author, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Grand Strand Hospital in Myrtle Beach, S.C. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan and Myrtle Beach.

title: MUSIC: BRAHMS'S FIRST
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic under Lukas Foss brought us two contemporary pieces of unfailing graciousness Sunday afternoon. This Academy of Music event ended with Brahms's much-played First Symphony, but it began with delicacies from England and America. The first was Oliver Knussen's ''Music for a Puppet Court,'' and the second Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto.

title: METS WILL UNFURL 1986 PENNANT TODAY
description: The Mets gathered in Shea Stadium yesterday for the first time since they won the World Series five months ago, and said they were ready to open the season there today without conceding anything, despite the stunning losses of Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 22
NICARAGUA SAID TO SEEK MORE SOVIET HELICOPTERS
description: Nicaragua is negotiating with the Soviet Union to obtain new helicopters in anticipation of increasing warfare, according to Western intelligence reports.

title: New York Fed Advisory Panel
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has formed an advisory committee consisting of top bankers and Wall Street executives to counsel the Fed on the evolution of the international capital markets.

title: 7 HURT AS TRUCK CARRYING PROPANE EXPLODES IN JERSEY
description: Seven people, including a state policeman, were injured when a tanker truck carrying butane tumbled from a highway exit ramp and exploded in Lawrence Township, N.J., during the evening rush yesterday.

title: Citicorp Recruits Mergers Director
description: Citicorp, pushing hard to become a major force in the mergers and acquisitions field, said yesterday that its investment bank had hired Gordon R. Wolf, an executive who most recently was responsible for identifying takeover targets for an investment firm owned by the Belzberg family.

title: TWO ACQUITTALS IN EXTORTION CASE
description: A Federal jury today acquitted a City Councilman and his aide of three counts but deadlocked on 11 others in an indictment alleging that the men tried to extort $1 million from a riverfront developer.

title: Ex-G.E. Official Joins Eaton Electronics Unit
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it had named Charles E. Barron, a longtime executive with the General Electric Company, as president of its military electronics operations.

title: TEXACO'S SUPPLIERS BEGINNING TO WORRY
description: Some of Texaco's suppliers said today that they were growing increasingly concerned that the nation's third-largest oil company would seek protection from creditors in bankruptcy court.

title: AMITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pension Fund Help Is Asked
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today to make ailing Rust Belt industries that raid their pension funds pay annual premiums of up to $150 per worker to insure monthly benefits for millions of retirees.

title: WILLIAM BOWERS
description: William Bowers, a screenwriter who received Academy Award nominations for his scripts for ''The Gunfighter'' (1950) and ''The Sheepman'' (1958), died of respiratory failure March 27 at the Woodland Hills Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 71 years old.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $524,000 for the quarter; and an extraordinary gain of $6,373,000 for the year.

title: WRITING STUDIES: BEYOND MECHANICS
description: THE ''writing process'' - the ideas that ferment in the mind before pen hits paper - has long been considered a mystery. So students are usually taught mechanics: grammar, syntax, usage, spelling. But teachers who emphasize mechanics ignore 99 percent of the process and perform a disservice to students, according to David S. Kaufer, an associate professor of rhetoric at Carnegie Mellon University.

title: Taco Bell Raises Its Stake in Calny
description: The Taco Bell Corporation, a fast-food subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., has raised its stake in Calny Inc. to 14.6 percent, from 9.9 percent. Calny, which has 145 Taco Bell restaurants and is the chain's largest franchiser, recently rejected an $11.50-a-share, $49 million takeover bid from Taco Bell.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PINNACLE PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 results include net charges for writedowns, abandonments, depletion and depreciation of oil and gas properties totaling about $1,268,000.

title: BUDGET SNAG DELAYING $1.3 BILLION IN SCHOOL AID
description: With no state budget in place six days after the deadline, the State Comptroller reported today that New York would not be able to meet on time $1.3 billion in payments to local school districts.

title: Advertising; Merging To Make Money
description: ONE did not have to be at the Embassy Suites Hotel in Phoenix yesterday as members of the Phoenix Advertising Club listened to the guest luncheon speaker to know they were at the edge of their seats.

title: USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of about $690,000 on termination of pension plans for the quarter and year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,092 for the quarter and $19,057 for the year.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE'LL CONSIDER TALKS WITH THE CANADIANS ON ACID RAIN
description: President Reagan said today that he had ''agreed to consider'' a proposal by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that Canada and the United States negotiate a ''bilateral accord'' controlling acid rain.

title: Citicorp Places Notes In Europe for Colombia
description: Citicorp announced yesterday that it had placed $50 million worth of floating-rate Eurodollar notes for Colombia, the first such voluntary Euro-financing for a Latin country since the debt crisis exploded in 1982.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21 Moscow shifted its test ban position from insistence on early agreement for a total nuclear test ban to a new approach that concentrates on limiting the number and size of such tests. Page A1 A U.S.-Canada accord on acid rain will be considered by President Reagan, he said. This marks a significant concession by Mr. Reagan to Canadian demands that he take the acid rain problem more seriously. A1 Salvadoran guerrillas dominate a mountain zone in Chalatenango Department, showing new attention to working with peasants. It is one part of El Salvador where the American-backed Government is not winning the war. A1 South Korea's economic growth has had profound effects on the way people live. Along with prosperity, Koreans now face a worrisome gulf between the haves and the have-nots and the resulting political tensions. A1 A secret U.S.-Japan agreement permitting the United States to take nuclear arms into Japan is explicitly referred to in a document uncovered by Japanese Communist Party members who searched in the Library of Congress. A3 The Pope arrived in Argentina, where he offered a kindly lecture on political responsibilities to the country's leaders. Politics is not expected to occupy as much of his agenda in Argentina as in Chile. A3 Israel's President, in West Germany, began the first visit to that country by an Israeli head of state. Chaim Herzog visited the memorial at the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. A12 In Beirut, relief supplies arrived in the Palestinian district of Shatila. It was the first big shipment allowed since the siege of the area by Shiite Moslem militiamen began five months ago. A14 NATIONAL A22-33, D30 Texaco suffered a court setback when the Supreme Court ruled that it should not have been excused by a lower court from posting a bond of more than $10 billion while it appealed a damage award that the Pennzoil Company won against it. A1 Jack Kemp will run for President, he announced. The New York Republican Congressman promised to support a weapons shield in space, ''freedom fighters'' abroad, free enterprise and traditional family values. A22 Children should be taught about sex and AIDS in school and at church, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said. He recommended that sex education begin in kindergarten. A23 Wheat farmers have been hard hit this year, particularly in Oklahoma, Kansas and Missouri by rains that followed other hardships. As a result many will be unable to plant the crops that qualify them for Federal aid. A22 Chicago's mayoral race has changed since a major challenger to Mayor Harold Washington withdrew on Sunday. ''We've got a horse race now,'' said an alderman who opposes the mayor's re-election. A22 Anti-C.I.A. protesters went on trial on charges of trespassing and disorderly conduct at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst last November. They plan to use the proceedings to draw attention to the agency's actions. A26 Many teen-agers are being exploited by door-to-door sales organizations that hold them in virtual servitude, physically abuse them and cheat them of commissions, a Senate subcommittee was told. A25 A new Bureau of Prisons Director has been named, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced. J. Michael Quinlan, 45 years old, has been with the Bureau of Prisons for 16 years, most recently as deputy director. A31 CBS gave its ousted chairman, Thomas H. Wyman, a settlement of more than $4.3 million and an annuity of $400,000 a year for life, a CBS proxy statement said. Mr. Wyman was also paid $1.1 million in salary and bonuses for 1986. D1 Military space projects are being considered by the Pentagon, which is eyeing NASA's proposed space station for a bevy of missions that would propel the Defense Department into a new era of space operations. C1 Data on prisons studied A29 WASHINGTON TALK A32 Jim Wright takes the Speaker's job by the horns On the Senate press secretary REGIONAL B1-7 The bodies of three men were found in Schoharie Creek as investigators focused on the floodwaters that swirled around a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway when it suddenly collapsed on Sunday. A1 The collapsed bridge's design is common for bridges spanning small bodies of water, according to structural engineers. The steel plate girder design can be found in dozens of other bridges on the Thruway. B5 The bridge detour meant more traffic than usual on the narrow, normally quiet roads of Fort Hunter, N.Y. ''Every car that goes from Buffalo to New York is driving by my house right now,'' one resident said. B4 Two jail officers were dismissed and nine others - including an Assistant Deputy Warden and a Captain -were transferred as a result of a fight at a Brooklyn jail on March 24. B1 A Queens lawyer was sentenced to five years in Federal prison, given five more years on probation and ordered to pay nearly $413,500 in fines and restitution for placing two secretaries in ''no-show'' Assembly jobs. B1 A L.I. man's deportation was blocked temporarily by Associate Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall. The man, Karl Linnas, has been condemned to death as a Nazi war criminal in the Soviet Union. B2 Democrats urged an ethics code for state, county, town and village party leaders. The recommendation, from top state leaders, came in reaction to scandals that have engulfed the party in New York City. B1 Jury selection for a Mafia trial began in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Twelve men are accused of rigging bids on construction contracts, intervening in union elections and plotting murders. B3 School payments delayed in Albany B2 Cuomo criticizes Legislature B2 Transit agency eases drug tests B3 Pyramid scam uses ''plane'' B7

title: JUDGE DELAYS DEPORTATION IN NAZI CASE
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall today temporarily blocked the deportation of Karl Linnas to the Soviet Union, where the Long Island resident has been condemned to death as a Nazi war criminal.

title: COMPUTER SYSTEM HELPS THE DEAF SPEAK
description: KATHY FLYNN, a 16-year-old high school student, can hear only the faintest traces of sounds - enough to tell the difference between a doorbell and a dog barking - but most of the subtlety and intonation of speech is lost to her. She has been deaf since birth.

title: DO WOMEN PREVAIL IN MODERN DANCE?
description: Modern dance in America is an art that has been forged by women.

title: Second Trial in Murder To Begin in Louisiana
description: About 400 prospective jurors reported to a basketball and livestock arena this morning for the second start of the trial of three Colombian nationals accused of the murder of a key Government drug witness.

title: Death Penalty Bill Vetoed
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he has vetoed legislation that would have restored the death penalty in New York. Mr. Cuomo, who vetoed the measure Friday, said that to bring back the electric chair would be to fight ''evil with evil.'' It is the 11th consecutive year that legislation to restore the death penalty in New York has been vetoed. Mr. Cuomo has rejected it five times since he took office in 1983. Gov. Hugh L. Carey had vetoed it six times.

title: PETER TAYLOR IS AWARDED RITZ-HEMINGWAY PRIZE
description: Peter Taylor was named winner today of the Ritz-Hemingway award, one of the richest literary prizes in the world, for his novel ''A Summons to Memphis,'' a family drama set in the author's native Tennessee.

title: He Is Not What You Might Think
description: Question: How many press secretaries does it take to change a light bulb?

title: HERZOG PAYS VISIT TO BELSEN, 'THIS AWESOME PLACE'
description: President Chaim Herzog began the first trip to West Germany by an Israeli head of state today, visiting the bleak memorial at the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.

title: DOOR-TO-DOOR SALES GROUPS ARE SAID TO EXPLOIT TEEN-AGERS
description: A Senator, the Attorney General of New York and three young adults said today that thousands of teen-agers were being exploited by door-to-door sales organizations that hold them in virtual servitude, subject them to physical abuse and cheat them out of promised commissions.

title: Congress Talks Trade
description: While President Reagan is engaged in international trade negotiations with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada in Ottawa, members of Congress are approaching the same question on a more limited basis. For what is believed to be the first time, a dozen members of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition in the House will sit down this morning with a delegation from the Ontario Provincial Legislature to discuss trade on the state-to-province level.

title: A PAC 'Hello Sucker'
description: The Conservative Coalition, which consists largely of Republicans, is trying to raise money for its political action committee by attacking the National Republican Senatorial Committee and the bonuses it paid officers and consultants last year.

title: Cable vs. Free: The Pastime Split
description: Cable-less Yankee fans in the outer boroughs had cause to kick their sets anew yesterday, when the team's opener, no less, was televised locally only by SportsChannel. The game was the first of 100 allocated by the Yankees to cable this year, in a reversal of the portioning the last two seasons, when cable got just 40 games and WPIX got 100. So the question: How do the other major league clubs handle local telecasts of their games?

title: Chess: Ree Shows How to Destroy A King's Indian at Ter Apel
description: The Klooster International Tournament in Ter Apel, the Netherlands, ended in a tie for first place among the Dutch grandmasters Hans Ree and John Van der Wiel and the West German grandmaster Eric Lobron. Each scored 3 1/2-1 1/2 in the six-man round robin celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Ter Apel Chess Club. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Ree 2 0 3 3 1/2 Van der Wiel 2 0 3 3 1/2 Lobron 2 0 3 3 1/2 Miles 1 1 3 2 1/2 Smejkal 1 2 2 2 Ligterink 0 5 0 0

title: Jean-Baptiste Doumeng, 68, Wealthy French Communist
description: Jean-Baptiste Doumeng, a businessman who has been called France's wealthiest Communist, died last night at his home in Noe near Toulouse, his company reported today. He was 68 years old.

title: JAPANESE FUNDS STILL POUR IN: LITTLE AFFECTED BY DOLLAR FALL
description: Over the past two years, the dollar's unrelenting decline has cost Japanese investors huge paper losses in the value of their various holdings in this country. But they are not selling off.

title: SEQUENTIAL INFORMATION SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $2,465. c-Net income and includes a tax benefit of $45,000 for the year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OTHERWORLD JOURNEYS. Accounts of Near-Death Experience in Medieval and Modern Times. By Carol Zaleski. 275 pages. Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1987
description: Companies

title: SMILES AND DOUBTS FOR REAGAN OVER STATEMENT ON ACID RAIN
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney responded with obvious pleasure today to President Reagan's statement that he would consider an acid rain agreement between Canada and the United States.

title: KEY RATES
FIRST RATINGS FOR TWO NEW FOX SHOWS
description: Whether the first night of prime-time programming for the Fox Broadcasting Company was a success depends on how one interprets the overnight figures.

title: HAGLER CONTENDS HE WAS ROBBED
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler was robbed, he contended in the news conference held about an hour after he lost his World Boxing Council middleweight championship title tonight in a split decision.

title: Postage Going Up
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review yesterday of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Sorcerer'' on Saturday at Symphony Space misidentified the performer in the role of Constance. She was Kate Jordan, not Erin Langston, the singer listed in the program.

title: 16 CHARGED WITH ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: W. Cary Edwards, the New Jersey Attorney General, announced indictments today against 16 individuals, including three former North Bergen township officials, and 11 trucking companies on charges of conspiring to illegally dump New York construction debris at several sites in New Jersey.

title: RAINS PUT WHEAT FARMERS IN A BIND
description: Heavy rains since last fall have left fields submerged or waterlogged in parts of Oklahoma, Kansas and Missouri, threatening the economic fortunes of thousands of farmers.

title: JAGUAR'S U.S. SALES FALL
description: Juguar P.L.C. said today that its United States car sales in March came to 1,545, down 21.5 percent from 1.968 a year earlier. But the company said it expected sales of the luxury cars in the United States to climb as part of a 10 percent to 15 percent rise in global sales this year.

title: A.I.D. Head Is Expected To Get Treasury Post
description: President Reagan will appoint M. Peter McPherson, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, to succeed Richard G. Darman as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, Administration sources said yesterday. An announcement is likely today, they said.

title: YANKEES WIN OPENER ON HENDERSON'S DOUBLE IN 10TH
description: It almost seemed eerie, as if this was a game being played in the middle of September, not early April. They could have been two teams huddled near first place, caught in the midst of a decisive and emotional stretch run. But there was a persistent chill throughout the day, and the rain and storm clouds that had settled over the weekend refused to quietly fade away.

title: COSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $207,000 and $131,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: MYLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $109,000 and $243,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: TEXACO SET BACK BY SUPREME COURT IN PENNZOIL CASE
description: In a major setback to Texaco Inc.'s battle for survival, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a Federal District Court should not have excused the company from posting a bond of more than $10 billion while it appealed a damage award that the Pennzoil Company won against Texaco in 1985.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter was impacted by increased costs of goods sold and other cost increases related to higher than expected returns of seasonal merchandise; a more competitive market environment; the $12.4 million loss incurred on the sale of the company's German subsidiary, and the revaluation of the previously purchased tax benefits, as well as an unfavorable year end inventory adjustment of $7.5 million.

title: KUWAITI PROPOSAL ON GULF SHIPPING
description: Kuwait has proposed an indirect way to allow the United States to protect Kuwaiti-owned ships from attack in the Persian Gulf - by transferring the registration of some tankers to the American flag.

title: More Layoffs Set by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would temporarily lay off more than 6,200 workers as it converts assembly plants to make new models and adjusts its production to meet slumping auto sales.

title: INSPECTION OF BRIDGE FAILED TO COVER UNDERWATER PARTS
description: A federally required inspection of the bridge that collapsed Sunday morning on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway did not cover crucial underwater portions of the structure, state authorities said today.

title: Trade Balance Requires a Better Maritime Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTS BY JAPAN NOW SPUR FEARS OF CHIP SHORTAGE
description: Japan's moves to cut the production of computer chips could lead to a shortage of the vital semiconductors, some computer and semiconductor industry executives said today.

title: Snelling Declines Senate Bid
description: Former Gov. Richard Snelling said today he does not plan to be a candidate for the United States Senate next year. Mr. Snelling, the Republican Senate nominee last year in the unsuccessful effort to defeat Patrick Leahy, a Democrat, announced his decision in a letter to friends and supporters. He had indicated after his 1986 defeat that he might run again in 1988 if Senator Robert Stafford, a Republican, retired. In his letter saying he would not run, Mr. Snelling said, ''I continue to want to be primarily a private citizen.''

title: SIGN OF SECRET U.S.-JAPAN PACT FOUND
description: Japanese Communists, searching in the Library of Congress here, have uncovered documentary evidence of a secret agreement that permits the United States to take nuclear arms into Japan.

title: HIGH COURT RULES U.S. LAW HOLDS IN WORK BENEFIT CASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the comprehensive Federal law regulating employee insurance and other benefit plans pre-empts state lawsuits by employees against their employers or insurers charging improper processing of claims.

title: BRIEFS
description: * British Telecommunications, London, announced the creation of British Telecom Inc. as its American subsidiary.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Deere Job Cuts
description: Deere & Company announced it would reduce its work force by 6 percent, or up to 700 people. The company said it would consolidate some agricultural sales branches and merge the administration of its component and tractor factories at Waterloo, Iowa. The program will be coupled with early retirement incentives and is expected to be completed by the end of July.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is it possible to make fuel from old tires, and if so how? A. Several recycling companies have developed procedures for turning scrap tires into high-energy fuel for use in generating electricity. For example, Waste Recovery Inc. of Dallas shreads worn out tires into small pieces about two inches square. The steel wire mesh that remains on the surface of the tire chips is then removed by magnets. The resulting fuel chips, which have traces of whitewall and tread and resemble piles of coal, are used mainly as an additive in other types of fuel. An old tire contains the energy equivalent of 2.5 gallons of oil. Fuel derived from tires has a higher energy value and lower sulfur content than many forms of coal when mixed with other forms of fuel in a boiler or cement kiln. The fuel is burned mainly in the pulp and paper industry to produce steam for electricity or processing. To avoid polluting the environment, plants that burn tire-derived fuel must carefully regulate the amount of this fuel use. Turning tires into energy reduces the need for landfills and eliminates the environmental hazards of stockpiled tires. The Oxford Energy Company is building a waste tire incineration in Westley, Calif., that will burn whole discarded tires to generate steam to drive a turbine and electrical generator. Q. How are magnets manufactured? A. Magnets can occur naturally, such as in the case of lodestone, a strongly magnetic variety of the mineral magnetite. Or magnets can be produced by placing a material such as carbon steel or other alloys in a coil and applying an electric current to the coil. This magnetizes the material. Bar magnets and horseshoe magnets, which are made of steel, retain their magnetism for a long period. Their magnetism is reduced, however, when they are heated or banged.

title: SMARTCARD INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $1,400,000, which includes a pre-tax charge of $3,975,000 to terminate a distribution agreement.

title: JURY SELECTION BEGINS FOR 15 ANTI-C.I.A. PROTESTERS
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of 15 protesters who were arrested on charges of trespassing and disorderly conduct at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst last November in a demonstration against the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: 54 SHANDLING EPISODES ORDERED FOR SHOWTIME
description: Showtime, the pay-cable television channel, has ordered 54 new episodes of its hit comedy series, ''It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' to be broadcast over the next three years. This order is the largest in Showtime's history and one of the largest orders for a series in the history of television.

title: KELLY, DOUGLAS & CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian funds.

title: COSMO COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Short-Term Notes From Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering $300 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Oct. 8, 1987, through various securities dealers.

title: CROWN RESOURCE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEW TOOLS ALTER OLD LIFE ON KOREA'S FARMS
description: At first sight this place looks untouched by time. Farmers bend over their rice fields. Women gather by a small stream, washing clothes with an occasional thump of a wooden stick.

title: KOCH QUESTIONED BY U.S. ON MYERSON
description: Federal investigators questioned Mayor Koch for more than an hour last Friday about Bess Myerson and her companion, Carl A. Capasso, the Mayor said last night.

title: Shades of Teheran
description: Bruce Laingen, who spent 444 days as a hostage of Iranian revolutionaries in 1979-80, finds his first duty after retirement from the State Department curiously reminiscent of part of his diplomatic career. The former charge d'affaires in Teheran is spending much of his time at the department's career counseling center, which happens to be situated in Annex 20, the former Iranian Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue that was seized by the United States in retaliation for Iran's taking of the American Embassy. Mr. Laingen, who is 64 years old, said the other day that the Persian architecture and decoration of the former embasssy gave him ''a strange feeling.''

title: CHEMCLEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits from utilization of net operations loss carryforward of $96,000 and $388,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also includes net of $703,407 from early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income d-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $84,000 for the quarter and $657,000 for the year; and net from early extinguishment of debt of $420,736 for both the quarter and year. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effected in June 1986.

title: PRISON TERM FOR EX-AIDE IN ASSEMBLY
description: A Queens lawyer who has been described as a ''power broker'' for the late Donald R. Manes was sentenced yesterday to five years in Federal prison, given five more years on probation and ordered to pay nearly $413,500 in fines and restitution.

title: FIGURING ON FAMILIARITY
description: Once again, the Islanders and the Capitals, who can't seem to get out of each other's way when the playoffs come around, are eyeing each other familiarly.

title: RANGERS: COUNTING ON PSYCHOLOGY
description: About a month ago, Dave Poulin was asked to select the team he would prefer to play in the opening round of the playoffs. ''Why bother?'' the Philadelphia Flyers' center said. ''You know it's going to be the Rangers.''

title: Consolation Prize
description: Three members of the Devils -Pat Verbeek and Kirk Muller, both forwards, and Bruce Driver, a defenseman - were named to the Team Canada roster for the World Hockey Championship tournament, which begins April 17 in Vienna. Driver, however, has a sore shoulder and will need a checkup before it is determined whether he will be able to play. The Devils were among players named from National Hockey League teams that failed to make the playoffs. More N.H.L. players will be named following the first round of the playoffs. Mario Lemieux, the Penguins' center, declined an invitation.

title: CASTLE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,980,474 from settlement of bank debt. c-Net loss

title: MOSCOW OFFERING TO PUT OFF A BAN ON ATOM TESTING
description: The Soviet Union, in a shift, has offered to postpone its demand for a total nuclear test ban and to concentrate first on intermediate testing limitations.

title: FRIES ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a $3 million reserve related to certain television station bankruptcies. c-Net income

title: Dr. Hammer's Role in 'Ivan the Terrible' Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 HURT IN SHAFT FALL AT THE HOLLAND
description: A man and a woman were seriously injured when they accidentally fell eight floors down a freight elevator shaft in a Times Square welfare hotel last night, the police said.

title: Grace Paley to Read Unpublished Works
description: Grace Paley is to appear in a free reading Friday at 12:15 P.M. in the ground floor auditorium at Chase Manhattan Plaza, Pine Street, just east of Nassau Street. Ms. Paley is to read from unpublished works.

title: SPACE STATION IS STUDIED BY MILITARY
description: THE Pentagon is eyeing NASA's proposed space station for a bevy of projects and missions that would propel the Department of Defense into a new era of space operations in the 21st century. The military's vision, while offering a new source of political support for the embattled space agency, also promises to heat the simmering controversy over plans for a manned station in space.

title: THE BULLY: NEW RESEARCH DEPICTS A PARANOID, LIFELONG LOSER ,
description: IT is as if the young bully's life were destined to leave his victims laughing last.

title: THEATER: 'DAY SIX,' TWO-CHARACTER DRAMA
description: IN the first minutes of Martin Halpern's play ''Day Six,'' Len Cariou unleashes an oratorical torrent in which the actor-singer's musical and dramatic skills fuse into a moment of thunderous intensity. Improvising an inspirational tirade on the sin of pride, he condemns ''proud blaspheming cynics,'' who he warns are joining sides with Satan. Mr. Cariou is every inch the charismatic preacher delivering God's word in rich rolling cadences of intoxicating passion.

title: FASHION'S QUICK CHANGES: FIRST PARIS, NOW 7TH AVE.
description: The fashion change that has been brewing abroad is now bubbling in New York. Bill Blass pulled no punches. Everything was short, flouncy, flirty and different from anything he has shown before, even during the 1960's. With his show yesterday, the New York fall and winter collections were off on the same fast track as the pace-setting Paris styles.

title: BOND PRICES UP IN QUIET DAY
description: Calm returned to the credit markets yesterday as bond prices rose modestly and short-term interest rates fell slightly.

title: A NAZI COLLABORATOR TO SOME, A PATRIOT TO OTHERS
description: One morning almost a year ago, Anu Linnas trimmed her father's thinning, blond hair and helped him select a plaid jacket from the closet. The two of them, with her younger sister, Tina, then set out from this small community for what they thought would be a routine meeting with immigration officials in Manhattan.

title: MORRIS OF TIGERS STARTS ANEW
description: Back home after his unsuccessful shopping trip, Jack Morris returned to his old, and new, place of work. Still in the uniform of the Detroit Tigers, an outfit Morris sought to change during the winter, the pitcher lost a game and re-established a point.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT CHIEF ACCUSES OPERATORS OF RESISTING CHANGE
description: The utility that owns the Peach Bottom nuclear plant, which Federal regulators closed a week ago amid charges that operators slept on the job, said today that operators had resisted tightening of regulations after the accident at Three Mile Island.

title: Eleanor Burke Leacock, 64, A Professor of Anthropology
description: Eleanor Burke Leacock, a professor of anthropology at City College of the City University of New York, died of a stroke Thursday at the Straub Medical Center Hospital in Honolulu. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Blues Sign Collegian
description: Tony Hrkac of the University of North Dakota, named the outstanding college hockey player in the country this season, was signed yesterday by the St. Louis Blues. Hrkac, 21, said he decided early last week that he was going to skip his last two years of eligibility. Hrkac, a center, led North Dakota to the National Collegiate Athletic Association title this season. On Sunday, he was presented the Hobey Baker Memorial Award as the nation's top college player. Hrkac, a 5-foot-11-inch, 165-pound sophomore, set an N.C.A.A. scoring record this season with 46 goals and 70 assists. A Blues spokesman said Hrkac would be able to join the team for the playoffs. Terms of his pact were not disclosed.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NIKI-LU INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $485,000. c-Net loss

title: TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
JAPAN TRIES POLICY SHIFT ON GROWTH
description: In a move that could signal a major shift away from this nation's tight-spending policies, Japan's ruling party today outlined a $34 billion plan to stimulate the economy and ease trade frictions with the United States.

title: Weinberger's Trade Stand
description: Trade barriers cannot halt the American electronics industry's decline in competitiveness, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger told a gathering of business executives today.

title: PHOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
NEW YORK DOCTORS FACE TIGHTER REVIEWS
description: Hospitals and physicians in New York are being investigated more rigorously and monitored more closely than ever before, health officials say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Deep down inside, it takes a lot out of you not seeing number 16 on the mound. It was frustrating. It makes you wonder about life in general.'' Darryl Strawberry, speaking of Dwight Gooden. [ B10:3. ]

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
A Heart-Easy Soup
description: LEAD: SOUP is not yet expendable.

title: Gooden and Society
description: Not since Muhammad Ali lost his boxing title for refusing the draft during the Vietnam War has so much hypocrisy and self-righteousness swamped the press and the airwaves as in the sad case of Dwight Gooden, baseball's boy wonder, who recently tested positive for cocaine use.

title: Angolans and U.S. Officials Confer on Cuban Withdrawal
description: The State Department said today that senior United States and Angolan officials had met in Congo to discuss ways of breaking the impasse over the presence of Cuban troops in Angola.

title: FIGHTING ACID RAIN: THE NEW RESEARCH
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN's promises this week in Canada and his pledge last month to seek $2.5 billion for the development of commercial technologies to combat acid rain have generated a wave of excitement among researchers.

title: SYMBOL OF FRENCH 'INJUSTICE' HELD IN ROBBERY
description: An ex-convict, once proclaimed by leftist intellectuals in France as a symbol of social ''injustice'' and ''judicial error,'' has been arrested and charged with robbing a bank.

title: SEOUL, U.S. FORCES AND THE NORTH: THE BALANCE IS AS DELICATE AS EVER
description: Less than 30 miles from here, just north of the skyscrapers and the traffic jams and the high-tech sales offices, two outsized armies are poised to resume the Korean War. Many people think the possibility is remote. A few think it is just a matter of time.

title: Know Your Cholesterol
description: Those people walking around Captiol Hill this week with paper hearts on their lapels are not tardy celebrants of Valentine's Day.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 1987
description: International A3-18

title: Dr. Daniel Leicht, 40, Health Unit Executive
description: Dr. Daniel C. Leicht, senior assistant vice president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, died after a long illness Sunday at his country home in Ellenville, N.Y. He was 40 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: TEMCO HOME HEALTH CARE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring expense of $204,000.

title: The Longest Day
description: The baseball teams from two Florida junior colleges - Hillsborough of Tampa and Manatee of Bradenton -had a special excuse to sleep late on Sunday. The day before, and evening too, they went at each other for 32 innings and seven-and-a-half hours before visiting Hillsborough came away on top, 6-4. In terms of both time and innings played, the game is believed to be the longest in collegiate history.

title: HIGH COURT WIDENS REVIEW OF ABORTION LAW
description: The Supreme Court today broadened its review of the constitutionality of an Illinois law that restricted minors' access to abortions.

title: Investment Unit For AMR Corp.
description: The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, said today that it had formed a new subsidiary to provide cash and pension fund management services for AMR and other, small to medium-sized companies.

title: Chief Dockmaster Indicted in Extortion
description: New York City's chief dockmaster was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for extortion and mail fraud for accepting more than $6,000 in payoffs for assigning dock space with a view of the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration, prosecutors said.

title: EVESDROPPING ON EMBASSIES IS A HIGH-TECH BUSINESS
description: Security experts say the access that Soviet agents apparently obtained from Marine guards to the United States Embassy in Moscow provided the Russians with a wide range of espionage opportunities.

title: Unisys Introduces Eight
description: The Unisys Corporation introduced eight new models of its large A 15 mainframe computers. The company said that it had improved performance of the computers by an average of 20 percent.

title: IRAN REPORTS ATTACK ON BASRA
description: Iran said its forces were moving toward the Iraqi city of Basra today in response to Iraqi air raids on Iranian oil installations.

title: A SIGN OF WAR IN PHILIPPINES: THE REFUGEES
description: During the recent two-month cease-fire, Communist rebels played basketball in front of the tin-roofed schoolhouse as villagers watched.

title: Boston Museum Picks Chief
description: Alan Shestack, the director of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts for only 20 months, has been named director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. He replaces Jan Fontein, who will retire after serving as Boston's director for 12 years. Mr. Shestack, a specialist in northern European graphic arts of the late Gothic and Renaissance periods, was director of the Yale University Art Gallery from 1971 to 1985.

title: Friends of Poindexter And North Raise Funds
description: It will be another month at least before the public hears from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter about their roles in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Official Resigns At the Garden
description: Gulf and Western Inc. said yesterday that Allan R. Fields had resigned as executive vice president and chief operating officer of its Madison Square Garden Corporation subsidiary.

title: Live, From Secaucus: It's NBC!
description: Any day now, NBC could transmit a devastating signal to the City of New York: an announcement that it is moving out. The move might only be across the Hudson to northern New Jersey, thus inflicting no loss on the economy of the region. Nonetheless, NBC's departure would send a shiver through a city tied to communications, entertainment, financial services and tourism.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON SECURITY AT MOSCOW EMBASSY
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington on security concerns at the American Embassy buildings in Moscow: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Olivetti to Offer New Computers
description: Ing. C. Olivetti S.p.A., the largest personal computer maker in Europe, said it plans to introduce a new line in June. The new Olivetti models would compete with the International Business Machine Corporation's new personal computers. Olivetti's chairman, Carlo De Benedetti, who has in the past called I.B.M. ''enemy No. 1,'' contended that the new I.B.M. personal computers were merely ''copies'' of some Olivetti machines.

title: Elisabeth Coit, 94, Architect And a Specialist on Housing
description: Elisabeth Coit, an architect and specialist on low-income housing, died last Thursday at a nursing home in Amherst, Mass. She was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan and Rockport, Mass.

title: MEDICARE OPTION PLAN IS FAULTED IN STUDY AND MORE CONTROL URGED
description: A Senate report released today asserts that the Reagan Administration should stop promoting prepaid private health plans for the elderly until it starts protecting them from shady sales pitches and sometimes dangerously inadequate care.

title: Ex-VW Aide Held in Fraud
description: The former chief foreign exchange dealer for Volkswagen A.G. has been arrested on suspicion of involvement in currency manipulations at the giant auto maker, the authorities said today.

title: BABY M WILL BECOME ANGRY OVER LEGAL FIGHT, MOTHER SAYS
description: Sitting at the kitchen table of her gray-shingled ranch home three miles from the Atlantic Ocean, Mary Beth Whitehead spoke often today about about the baby's ''coming home,'' her euphemism for ultimate triumph in the court struggle with William Stern and his wife, Elizabeth, over the child known as Baby M. Yet implicit in some comments was the thought of losing the baby, called Melissa by the Sterns and Sara by the Whiteheads.

title: PRETORIA ACCUSES A WHITE OPPONENT
description: The former leader of the liberal white opposition in the South African Parliament, Frederik van Zyl Slabbert, is to be charged with possessing the writings of Nelson Mandela, the jailed leader of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: SYRIANS ENDING SIEGE IN A BEIRUT DISTRICT
description: Syrian troops moved into a Palestinian refugee district in southern Beirut today, ending a five-month siege by Shiite Moslem militiamen.

title: Market Place; Analyst Lists Bearish Signals
description: SINCE the Dow Jones industrial average has sailed past five ''century'' marks already this year, it is no wonder that Wall Street analysts keep lifting their market expectations. Byron R. Wien, domestic equity strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, is no exception.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL POWER reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company went public in January.

title: SEEKING A SWEETER CITRUS JUICE
description: First scientists take the caffeine out of coffee and colas. They take the fat out of potato chips. Now they are looking at limonin.

title: Austrian Privatization
description: The Austrian state oil company OeMV A.G. said today that 20 percent of its shares would be sold to the public this fall, making it the first large candidate to be taken private under a Government plan to reduce the large number of nationalized businesses. OeMV's general director, Herbert Kaes, told a news conference that half of the 20 percent stake would be sold on the Vienna Bourse and the rest through financial institutions abroad. Mr. Kaes declined to give a price for the shares, but bourse sources estimated the flotation would raise between 1.6 billion and two billion schillings, or $125 million to $155 million.

title: The Need for Higher Taxes
description: It's time to talk sense about the Federal deficit, even if the prescription doesn't make us feel good. We need to restrain spending but, equally important, we need to raise taxes if we want to cut the deficit and re-establish a firm foundation for the economy.

title: Economic Scene; German View Of World Debt
description: GERHARD STOLTENBERG, the West German Finance Minister, interviewed in New York on Monday, said the most urgent job before the Washington meetings of the policy-making bodies of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank was to solve the world debt problem.

title: Clemens Gets Start
description: Roger Clemens won't be ready to pitch in the Boston Red Sox home opener against the Toronto Blue Jays on Friday, but the American League Cy Young Award winner and Most Valuable Player for 1986 is expected to make his first start of the season on Saturday. Clemens threw 88 pitches in a workout in Milwaukee yesterday. He presumably showed a good fastball. As his manager, John McNamara, put it: ''He threw the ball very well velocitywise.''

title: E.P.A. WARNING TO GOVERNORS ON ENFORCING POLLUTION PLANS
description: The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency warned governors today that the agency would soon disapprove some of their air pollution control plans.

title: CARDINAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it had to restate sales and earnings for the first three quarters of 1986 to reflect accounting problems with its reliance division that have since been resolved.

title: SOVIET AIDS CAMPAIGN DENOUNCED
description: The Soviet Union has begun a campaign aimed at convincing the world that the AIDS virus originated in an American military laboratory, American officials assert.

title: 10 OR MORE MAY BE DEAD IN BRIDGE FALL
description: Officials said today that they now believe at least 10 people might have been killed after a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed Sunday and their vehicles tumbled into a flooded creek 40 miles northwest of here.

title: STUDY SAYS PAC'S PLAY GROWING ELECTION ROLE
description: Political action committees are playing a growing role in financing elections and accounted for more than one-third of the $227 million collected by candidates for the House of Representatives last year, according to a study released today.

title: CHERISHED TRADITION UNDER SIEGE: THE BATTLE OVER MEN-ONLY CLUBS
description: A 39-year-old New York City doctor finds his ethics, formed in the 1960's, conflicting with his sense of tradition and his desire for the malehis camaraderie of his sporting club. A middle-aged artist is sympathetic to women who fear they are being denied crucial business contacts, but wants to hold on to a piece of the world in which he grew up.

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $309,384 and $205,930 for the quarter and year, respectively, and also includes an estimated loss for disposal of discontinued operations of $1,893,982 for both periods; the latest quarter also includes a pretax charge of $500,000 for writedown of telephone systems inventory, adjustments to accounts receivable due to the bankruptcy of a customer and an adjustment to the barter credit balance. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $79,395 and a gain of about $178,000 from exchange of telephone inventory for barter credits. d-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $372,745.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Passover

title: Comment by Lawmakers
description: Two House members who completed an inspection of the present United States Embassy building here said today that it still had security flaws. They said the equipment and practices that they described as ''fundamentally flawed'' were used to control access to sensitive rooms.

title: FINANCIAL INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LIEBERMAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HUBCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 2.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 107, Celtics 83: Ron Harper scored 30 points, and the Cleveland defense limited Boston to its lowest output of the season last night as the Cavaliers handed the Celtics their eighth loss in the last nine road games. Boston, whose starting center, Robert Parish, missed the game because of a sore elbow, led by 69-68 after Larry Bird made a driving layup with about two minutes to play in the third quarter. The Cavaliers, however, outscored the Celtics, 21-4, over the next six-and-a-half minutes to take an 89-73 lead. (AP) Bucks 95, Bullets 94: John Lucas scored 26 points and played the entire game as Milwaukee edged Washington. The Bucks, who had not won away from home since March 11, when they beat Washington by 115-107, snapped a six-game road losing streak. (AP) TENNIS Graf Beats Roldan in 50 Minutes: The defending champion, Steffi Graf, took only 50 minutes to dispatch her first opponent in the $300,000 Family Circle Cup tournament last night at Hilton Head Island, S.C., when she defeated Argentina's Mariana Perez Roldan, 6-2, 6-0. The 17-year-old West German is top-seeded in the tournament. Chris Evert Lloyd, who has won the event eight times, is seeded second. Graf, seeing action for the first time in the tournament, hammered her famous forehand 14 times for winners against the outmatched Roldan, but she was not satisfied with the way she played. In other action, fourth-seed Claudia Kohde-Kilsch easily dispatched Cecilia Bonsignori, 6-2, 6-4. It was Kohde-Kilsch's first match after a four-week layoff. Lloyd will play for the first time today against Petra Huber of Austria. (AP)

title: Jordan Asks U.S. to Back Mideast Peace Talks
description: The Jordanian Prime Minister urged Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to embrace King Hussein's proposal for an international peace conference on the Middle East.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for July, 1986 2-for-1 stock split.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HOSTILE BID IS DROPPED AT GENCORP
description: A $2.2 billion hostile takeover bid for Gencorp Inc. ended yesterday, three weeks after it began, with the bidding group at least $75 million richer.

title: A Former Official of Turkey Is Given 11 Years in Prison
description: A Turkish military court today sentenced former Deputy Prime Minister Alpaslan Turkes to 11 years in prison on charges of forming an armed gang, officials said. Five supporters were reported sentenced to death for murder.

title: Ex-Buffalo United Way Head Convicted of Taking Money
description: A former United Way campaign chairman pleaded guilty today to taking almost $15,000 that employees of his own company had donated to the organization, officials said.

title: PENTAGON SECRETLY PREPARES PLAN FOR MISSILE DEFENSE IN MID-1990'S
description: The Pentagon is secretly preparing a detailed plan showing how defenses against nuclear missiles could be deployed in space in the mid-1990's, two Senators who oppose the plan disclosed today.

title: TELETRAK ADVANCED TECHOLOGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $278,156.

title: New York City Police Officer Dismissed Over Ticket Fixing
description: A New York City police officer was dismissed from the force without a pension yesterday after being convicted in a departmental trial of participating in a ticket-fixing scheme in the Queens traffic court.

title: INSIDE
description: Toll in Collapse May Rise

title: ORGANIZING PAYS OFF AT FILOFAX
description: The product has been around for three-quarters of a century and can lay claim to no proprietary technology. A generous estimate of the cost to make it would probably be $30, yet the company has the cheek to charge Americans an average of $160 apiece for its product.

title: KELLEY OIL & GAS PARTNERHIP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The partnership went public in January 1986. The share earnings are in units.

title: BUSINESSMEN AS HEAVIES
description: BUSINESSMEN are not nice on television; they lie, steal and murder. A businessman (consider it a nonsexist, generic word) is ''Hollywood's Favorite Heavy,'' which is the title of the documentary on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight. Watch it; it is juicy and provocative.

title: VOLCKER SEES DANGER TO ECONOMY OF U.S. IF DOLLAR FALLS MORE
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned today of ''substantial risks'' to the American economy, including recession, if the United States relied on further depreciation of the dollar to redress its trade deficit.

title: MONDAY TEXACO HEARING SET
description: A Texas appeals court today granted a temporary injunction requested by Texaco Inc. that prevents the Pennzoil Company from seizing any Texaco assets at least until after a hearing set for next Monday in Houston.

title: MUBARAK PARTY WINS IN EGYPT'S VOTE
description: The National Democratic Party of President Hosni Mubarak retained its overwhelming control of the Egyptian legislature in elections Monday, but an alliance including Moslem fundamentalists established itself as the most powerful opposition party, according to preliminary results disclosed today.

title: JERSEY SUPREME COURT WILL EXAMINE IF STANDARD RULES AFFECT BABY M CASE
description: When a New Jersey judge cut off the legal rights that Mary Beth Whitehead had as the biological mother of Baby M last week, he said that he was merely carrying out the promise she made when she voluntarily agreed to become a surrogate mother.

title: Airbus, Boeing Turn to G.E.
description: Both Airbus Industries and the Boeing Company turned to the General Electric Company for engines to power future airliners after International Aero Engines decided to delay the introduction of its V2500 Superfan engine. Airbus had wanted to use the

title: Lawrence Kohlberg Is Dead
description: The body of Lawrence Kohlberg, a professor of education at Harvard University who had been missing since Jan. 17, was found Monday in Boston Harbor after it washed up at Logan Airport.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1986 results are restated to give effect to 10 percent stock dividend distributed June 16, 1986. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the best and worst stock market performers of the first quarter incompletely described one of the better performers, the LVI Group, and its recent earnings. The company has been predominantly engaged in interior construction since late 1985. It earned 11 cents a share throughout the first three quarters of its latest fiscal year and 4 cents a share in the fourth quarter, which just ended.

title: New Home For James Parry Inc.
description: IT looks now as if James Parry will not get to work in all of the country's advertising agencies, but with 10 by the age of 43 he made a good start.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $381,000 and $579,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both periods include a gain of $567,000 from the sale of discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $428,000 and $346,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, the quarter also includes tax credits of $112,000; both periods include a loss of $45,000 from the sale of discontinued operations. Figures for 1985 are restated to reflect the sale of a segment.

title: About New York; Where the Deals Are a Side Order With the Kasha
description: In the V.I.P. area of ''the Polish Tea Room,'' select customers are pampered with plastic placemats and, sometimes, they do not even have to ask for ketchup because the bottles are already on the tables.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Women Need Equality, Not Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO RE-ELECTS WASHINGTON AS MAYOR
description: Mayor Harold Washington, attracting considerably more support among white voters than his main challenger could win among blacks, won re-election here today.

title: WINE TALK
description: BROOKLYN, like Bordeaux, is wine country. Stephan Siciliano can prove it. He is cellar master of Sunset Hills Vineyards, a home winery only three minutes from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. First, he treats you to the panoramic sweep of his backyard vines - both of them. Next, as at any chateau, you tour the winery; here it is reached by going down the basement stairs and turning left at the clothesline. It is state-of-the-art, from a 19th-century standpoint.

title: Dr. Robert Leslie, 101 Leader in Graphic Arts
