description: Dr. Robert Lincoln Leslie, a physician, printer and graphic artist who inspired generations of graphic artists, died Wednesday at the Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn after a brief illness. He was 101 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: BONN NOW SEEKING NEW U.S. MISSILES
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl favors the deployment of a new American shorter-range missile in West Germany and the modernization of a second system to match the Warsaw Pact in the event of an agreement abolishing medium-range missiles from Europe, officials said today.

title: Syracuse Honored
description: Governor Cuomo and state legislators honored Syracuse University's basketball team yesterday in Albany ceremonies. The Governor told the players: ''It would have been great if you had won the last game, but I tell you, I barely remember that, because of the joy and satisfaction of watching you achieve all you did.'' Tom Young, the Mayor of Syracuse, presented the Governor with a sweatshirt decorated with a new Syracuse logo being used as a promotional tool by city officials.

title: ESPOSITO HARBORING SECRETS
description: The final practice session was over so the players milled about, analyzing, reflecting, calculating, prognosticating, and just waiting. Finally, the bus was ready for boarding and the Rangers were ushered away, exact destination unknown.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: C. H. Butcher Pleads Guilty
description: C. H. Butcher Jr., the financier, ended his five-week-old bankruptcy fraud trial today by pleading guilty to conspiracy and banktruptcy fraud charges stemming from the collapse of his banking empire.

title: NUTRITION WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: STEVE ALLEN REMODELS 'MAKE-BELIEVE BALLROOM'
description: ''THE MAKE-BELIEVE BALLROOM,'' the radio program on WNEW-AM that has been a bellwether of mainstream, traditional pop music for half a century, from its beginnings with Martin Block to the curatorship of the late William B. Williams, may be in for a change of emphasis under its new host, Steve Allen. Not that Mr. Allen's taste in music is at variance with the program's continuing style - the Glenn Miller music that was at the heart of Martin Block's programming or William B. Williams's devotion to ''the chairman of the board,'' Frank Sinatra. But as Mr. Allen remarked a couple of days ago, ''I'm not a D.J. - I'm an entertainer.''

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I WAS doing the family grocery shopping accompanied by two children, an event I hope to see included in the Olympics in the near future. Not until we were putting the food on the little treadmill at the checkout counter did I realize I had not personally picked out many of the items in the cart.

title: COLLARS OF LACE ADD DASH
description: 1.Neck Lace Lace collars will be sprouting in the spring. This one, for $17, is part of a collection of pretty collars that can give a brand-new look to dresses or sweaters you have been wearing for ages. They are in the accessories department on the main floor at A&S, 420 Fulton Street, at Hoyt Street, Brooklyn, and in some branch stores. 2.Scottish Desk Dome Dress up your desk with a decorative millefiori glass paperweight from Scotland. A dome of clear glass magnifies an interior design in shades of blue, green, white and brown. The price is $55. Other sizes and colors are available. Look for them at Gem Antiques, 1088 Madison Avenue, between 81st and 82d Streets. 3.Plush Place Mats Pretty place mats brighten any meal. The one shown here, in Laura Ashley's new Chartres print, is sapphire and white. The mat is padded cotton and is reversible. It is $9.50 at Laura Ashley, 714 Madison Avenue, between 63d and 64th Streets, and 398 Columbus Avenue, at 79th Street. Matching napkins are available. 4.Colorful Haggadah This historical Haggadah would be an interesting and colorful addition to a Passover seder next Monday night. It is the Speyer Haggadah, an illuminated reproduction of a 1768 Haggadah illustrated in warm, rich colors by the folk artist Nathan ben Abraham Speyer. The Haggadah is written in Hebrew and Yiddish and comes with a booklet in Hebrew and English that gives its history. The price is $44.50 at the Board of Jewish Education, 426 West 58th Street.

title: AN INNOVATOR IN ITALIAN WINE MAKING
description: LEAD: SEVEN years ago, when she entered the family business, Teresa Lungarotti's sole ambition was to be a good wine maker. She never expected to become a trend setter as well.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Old and Young Aren't Foes
description: LEAD: Under the misleading rubric of Americans for Generational Equity, a new pressure group is framing public-policy questions as if there were competition among the generations.

title: Fighter Replaced
description: J. B. Williamson, who was scheduled to fight Chris Reid tomorrow night at the Felt Forum in a light-heavyweight bout, was found during an examination to have suffered damage to the retinas of each eye. He will be replaced by Ian Mattis. The examining physician said that the tears were considered slight and that neither retina showed evidence of detachment, according to Steve Griffith, a Madison Square Garden spokesman.

title: West Virginia to Close Its Colleges for a Week
description: The West Virginia Board of Regents ordered state colleges and universities today to close for a week and furlough all employees for five days to save $10 million, as ordered by the Governor.

title: The U.N. Today: April 8, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: SHULTZ PLANS TO ATTEND U.S. EMBASSY SEDER FOR MOSCOW JEWS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to dramatize the issue of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union by attending a Passover seder at the United States Embassy with Jewish dissidents in Moscow on Monday, a State Department official said today.

title: Meeting Is Set for Next Week To Pick Bronx Borough Chief
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he would convene a meeting of City Council members from the Bronx next Wednesday to elect a borough president to succeed Stanley Simon.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MANPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $51,327,000.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Parking' Case Charge Settled
description: Michael Davidoff, the former head trader for a securities firm controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, settled civil charges yesterday that said he had engaged in illegal stock ''parking'' schemes with other brokerage firms.

title: 44.60 DROP PUTS DOW AT 2,360.94
description: Higher interest rates and renewed fears about a lower dollar delivered a blow to the stock market yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 44.60 points, to 2,360.94.

title: Bridge: Roy Welland of Manhattan Is Nation's Leading Beginner
description: Each year the American Contract Bridge League uses its master-point records to identify the country's most successful beginner. The Rookie of the Year title goes to the player who begins a calendar year with fewer than five master points and has the best record at the end of the year.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's weekly commercial paper auctions for the first time since late February.

title: REAGAN'S PROPOSAL ON ACID RAIN IS ASSAILED AS A DELAYING TACTIC
description: Members of Congress and environmental groups today assailed President Reagan's offer to consider an acid rain treaty with Canada, calling it another tactic to delay enforcing pollution controls on the sources of acid rain.

title: WALTON DOES BLITZ ON JETS' DEFENSE
description: Faced with a surgically depleted defensive line that may never be as good again, Coach Joe Walton of the Jets said yesterday that he was changing the philosophy of the club's once-famed pass rush.

title: Lucille Chance, Leader In Harlem and Lawyer
description: Lucille Edwards Chance, a lawyer and the second black woman admitted to the New York bar, died in her home yesterday after a long illness. She was 88 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a non-cash charge from the cumulative impact of a change in railroad depreciation accounting.

title: STABILIZING DOLLAR: PROBLEMS PERSIST
description: Top economic officials of the biggest industrial powers will meet here Wednesday to flex their muscles as a demonstration that they can stabilize the dollar for some months at least.

title: U.S. COURT RULING COULD SPUR STATE CAPS ON MEDICARE FEES
description: A Massachusetts law effectively prohibiting doctors from charging elderly patients more than the fees approved by Medicare has been upheld by a Federal appeals court, a decision that could have widespread effect on efforts to control health costs.

title: Ratings Cut for Deere And Dayton Hudson
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered the debt ratings of two industrial companies yesterday, affecting a total of $3.1 billion in outstanding debt.

title: Xerox Venture
description: The Xerox Corporation and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said they plan to form a joint venture to develop and manufacture electronic imaging products. The new firm, called DX Imaging, would combine the existing technology of both companies. The companies said they had already invested a total of $80 million in this technology and expect to invest another $40 million in 1987 to support the joint venture.

title: CANADIANS WHO FIND A WINTER HAVEN IN FLORIDA BRING SEPARATISM ALONG
description: Only now, at the end of the winter season, the English-and French-speaking Canadian residents of Florida are finally getting together. Their numbers are small, and language still separates them, but they gather in places like the Penalty Box Lounge in Fort Lauderdale or in the larger motels along the Sunny Isles oceanfront strip north of Miami to watch hockey games on television from Canada.

title: LAFONTAINE: RISING STAR
description: There is always the threat of Mike Bossy, the Islanders' not-so-secret weapon, and the determination of Bryan Trottier, the team's backbone. But as their playoff series with the Islanders begins on their home ice tonight in Landover, Md., the Capitals know that there is another player to be reckoned with - the fresh-faced fourth-year center, Pat LaFontaine. This season, his best as a pro, he played in all 80 games, scored 38 goals and 70 points, and was among the league's leaders with 19 power-play goals.

title: VOTES BY WOMEN LIKELY TO PLAY IMPORTANT ROLE IN 1988 ELECTIONS
description: Voting by women, born in 1920 but recognized only within the last decade as a potent political force, appears likely to play a more visible and important role than ever before in the 1988 Presidential election.

title: WINFIELD'S AMUSEMENT PARK
description: The morning was bright and warm in old Tiger Stadium, where the Yankees were swatting a few baseballs on a day between games.

title: Mets' Opener Brings Back Glory of '86
description: Up on the message board, it was happening all over again: Len Dykstra leaping, Mookie Wilson levitating, Bill Buckner groping, Jesse Orosco kneeling.

title: Some Answers No One Expected
description: On Monday night, as part of a telecast dealing with the 40th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's major league debut, the ABC News program ''Nightline'' interviewed Roger Kahn, the writer, and Al Campanis, the Los Angeles Dodgers' vice president for player personnel. Campanis had been a good acquaintance of Robinson since 1946, when they were minor league teammates, but within five minutes of the first question put to him by Ted Koppel, viewers bitterly charging racism began placing an unusually large number of calls to the network.

title: Why Duck the Califano Commission?
description: Without making a move, Governor Cuomo's Commission on Government Integrity has done wonders in Albany. It has caused a usually tone-deaf Legislature to hear cries for reform and even rush to pass an ethics bill similar to one requested by the Governor. And now the commission has caused the legislative leaders to bend themselves out of shape trying to avoid its scrutiny. Their resulting posture invites ridicule.

title: A Job Can Be a Home
description: Homelessness is often a function of joblessness. That's why, after considerable prodding, New York City's Department of Employment last year began trying to place homeless men in permanent jobs. Now the agency deserves credit for a small success.

title: THE MAN AND THE IMAGE IN 'LONDON JOHNSON'
description: THERE'S a ''television theory'' about Lyndon Baines Johnson. Instead of being his own bigger-than-life, irascible self on camera, the theory goes, he kept giving the public an earnest, soft-spoken statesman. The image adjustment may have cost him an enormous amount of crucial support. Television viewers might well have preferred a down-home Lyndon to the decidedly artificial Mr. Johnson. What might have been possible can be glimpsed in ''Lyndon Johnson,'' starring Laurence Luckinbill, a 90-minute, one-man show on Channels 13, 21 and 49 at 9 o'clock this evening.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,478,000 and $31,242,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and extraordinary charges of $2,503,000 for the quarter and $4,361,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $952,000 for the quarter and $6,500,000 for the year.

title: HOUSE RUNOFF SEEMS LIKELY IN WEST
description: Nancy Pelosi, a former state Democratic Party chairman, led Supervisor Harry Britt, a leader among homosexuals here, as votes were counted tonight in a special election to fill the unexpired term of the late Representative Sala Burton.

title: Investment Banker Joins Hutton Finance Group
description: Kendrick R. Wilson 3d, an investment banker who advised the E. F. Hutton Group Inc. when it was nearly sold to the American Express Company last year, has been hired to head Hutton's corporate finance department.

title: ARTISTIC GREETINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RIGHT FIELDER HITS ONE FOR 'MY CLOSEST FRIEND'
description: His opening statement disappeared over the right-field fence, and this time, Darryl Strawberry did not tarry as he did during the seventh game of the World Series. He circled the bases briskly, to the cheers that are the sweetest song a ballplayer can hear. With one swing yesterday, he accounted for the winning runs in the Mets victory over the Pirates and fulfilled a pledge he made on behalf of a friend.

title: Barclays Names Chief Of North American Unit
description: Barclays Bank said yesterday that it had named John A. Kerslake as chief executive of its North American operations.

title: AVON PRODUCTS TO ACQUIRE GIORGIO
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $185 million to buy Giorgio Inc., the Beverly Hills, Calif., company that turned a single overpowering fragrance into a $100 million-a-year business.

title: FALLING DEBRIS SHUTS BROOKLYN BRIDGE APPROACHES
description: Falling masonry from the top of the Municipal Building opposite City Hall has forced the emergency closing of key streets leading to and from the Brooklyn Bridge for the remainder of this week.

title: TITLE BANNER FLIES ABOVE FANS' ALIBIS
description: Some cut school, others skipped work and those fortunate enough to operate businesses simply gave themselves the day off.

title: TUDOR HELPS HIMSELF AT PLATE
description: Jim Lindeman, a rookie, and John Tudor, the pitcher, each drove in two runs in a five-run third inning today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the season opener for both teams.

title: Mining Near the Grand Canyon
description: A French-owned uranium mining company has resumed exploratory drilling 400 feet from Grand Canyon National Park, a company official said today.

title: Motta Is Suspended
description: Dick Motta, the Dallas Mavericks' coach, was suspended for one game by the National Basketball Association for suggesting that the Rockets' coach, Bill Fitch, was not doing his best to win a recent game so that he could set up a favorable playoff schedule for Houston. The Dallas management was fined $5,000. Rod Thorn, the N.B.A.'s vice president for operations, said an investigation into Motta's charges had found no basis for concluding that Fitch had done anything wrong. Fitch has called Motta's comments ''irresponsible.'' Motta said last week that it seemed the Rockets wanted to get out of the same playoff bracket with the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference. If the Rockets were to finish fourth or fifth, they would meet the Lakers as early as the second round; if they finish sixth or seventh, however, they would not have to face the Lakers until the Western Conference championship series. The Lakers have already clinched first place and the home-court advantage throughout the playoffs. Motta made the observation after watching a game between the Rockets and the Phoenix Suns. Houston got within 2 points in the fourth quarter but had its best players on the bench. ''Houston looks like they're messing around,'' Motta said. ''They look like they're manipulating.'' Motta first complained to Thorn and then made his views known in an interview published by The Dallas Morning News. The league said the suspension would be served tonight for a game against Utah. ''I thought there was an injustice in the situation, I addressed it, and then I let it die,'' Motta said after the suspension was announced. ''I'll abide by the commissioner's decision on any punishment that he decided to delve out on me.''

title: NEW AIDS BATTLEFIELD: ADDICTS' WORLD
description: Walking slowly down West 115th Street, James Johnson spotted a familiar face from his 20 years on heroin. ''Yo, homeboy,'' he called to a man named Bobby, bent beneath his purple beret, sipping his morning pint. And then, with the credibility that only an alumnus of addiction can claim, Mr. Johnson began to tell Bobby about syringes, spoons and AIDS.

title: Alzheimer Services Criticized
description: Medical and social services for victims of Alzheimer's disease and their families are disorganized, incomplete and often not available, says a Congressional study made public today.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Emery Gets Closer On Purolator Bid
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation, which is seeking to buy the Purolator Courier Corporation for more than $300 million, said that a competing investment group had agreed to drop its $268 million leveraged buyout proposal for the company. The withdrawal of the group, which included senior Purolator managers and a unit of E.F. Hutton Group Inc., clears the way for Emery's $40-a-share tender offer for the air-freight concern.

title: Now the Bad News
description: To the Editor:

title: Stadium Strike Looms
description: The union representing the Yankee Stadium grounds crew voted yesterday to authorize a strike that could begin as early as Monday, when the Yankees face the Cleveland Indians in their home opener. Howard Chaiken, president of Local 54 of the Service Employees Union, said there had been no progress in contract talks with Ogden Allied Services, the contractor at the stadium. Salary and benefits are at issue. A management spokesman was not immediately available for comment.

title: Standards of Beauty
description: To The Living Section:

title: Korea on the Brink
description: South Korea is at once experiencing economic takeoff, wrenching political transition and continued military tension with North Korea. This may be, as made clear by the series of Times articles concluding today, the most critical year in its modern history. The United States, with a significant stake in the outcome, would be wise to resist the illusory temptation to engage in long-distance management and to use its good offices to encourage Koreans to work out their own differences.

title: Nets Beaten, 128-114
description: Ron Anderson came off the bench to score 23 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter as the Indiana Pacers defeated the New Jersey Nets, 128-114, tonight for their eighth consecutive home victory.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Conrail Loses on Arbitration
description: A Federal district judge today rejected Conrail's petition for binding arbitration of its dispute with Amtrak over liability arising from the Jan. 4 train crash that killed 16 people and injured 175. The judge, Oliver Gasch, said the courts, not an arbitration panel, should decide who was responsible for paying damage claims arising from the crash, which occurred after the crew of a Conrail freight engine ignored a series of traffic signals.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: BIO-RESPONSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANY YANK VIEWERS SHUT OUT
description: Opening day in baseball is usually a time for happy anticipation, but the 1987 Yankee season is tainted. The team's victory over Detroit Monday is a nice start, but the game brought home how long, or rather how short, the season will be for many viewers.

title: OLDER DRIVERS: JUST HOW SAFE?
description: ''WE drive because we love our freedom,'' Sylvia Leisengang, who is 70 years old, told her class of 40 students, all in their 50's or older.

title: Sallie Mae Offers Yield Curve Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $100 million of three-year yield curve notes, due in 1990, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: THAI WOODCRAFT SHOP AIDED BY AN AMERICAN LOAN PROJECT
description: The morning the bank president arrived for an inspection tour of Banyen, one of northern Thailand's fastest-growing woodcraft studios, dozens of people were busy carving, sanding, painting and polishing the small company's biggest order ever: 5,000 pieces of Thai art headed for Bloomingdale's.

title: BUDGET-BALANCING LAW: NEW CHEMISTRY
description: The budget-balancing law, after being undercut by a Supreme Court decision last year and derided by many, is proving surprisingly effective in pressuring the Democrats who now control Congress to reduce the deficit.

title: Hinckley Said to Plan To Live With a Friend
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. says he wants to live with a woman who once killed her sleeping daughter and is now ''the biggest influence in my life,'' according to court papers filed today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday misstated the number of senior executives of Harper & Row Publishers Inc. who have agreed to severance packages known as ''golden parachutes.'' Twenty would get such payments, of whom six would receive 2.99 times their ''base amount'' of salary and bonus.

title: SEEQ TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss The company said latest quarter revenue includes $500,000 from a technology arrangement with Motorola semiconductor products and a $600,000 reversal of a previous provision for a loss on discontinued product offerings.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Newshound's Memories A two-sentence news story in a local paper on Oct. 28, 1954, said ''Gabriel Pressman, formerly on the staff of The New York World-Telegram and Sun, has just been appointed a roving reporter by WRCA. The station said he would roam the metropolitan area in search of news and features, operating from a mobile radio newsroom equipped with a tape recorder and a telephone.''

title: OLD FASHION FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: OI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advances in Television; Picture Is Brighter, Its Future Murky
description: A VIDEO image as sharp and startlingly colorful as a 35-millimeter film bursts upon a 10-foot television screen, and stereo sound fills the room. High-definition television has arrived in the United States.

title: CALVIN KLEIN'S AMERICAN TOUR DE FORCE
description: CHEERS, bravos and thunderous applause greeted Calvin Klein as he walked down the runway in a gray double-breasted suit after the best fall collection shown on either side of the Atlantic. It was brilliantly thought out and thoroughly modern, and it sported no extraneous detail. Woven into a fresh composition were all the separate threads that contributed to the widely heralded change fashion is undergoing for the new season; the result was enchanting. The show was the kind of tour de force that makes people look at fashion in a new way.

title: SHUBERT STAGES A DRAMATIC (AND MUSICAL) COMEBACK
description: The Shubert Organization, grappling as recently as last season with the specter of dark theaters, failed investments and the sudden illness of its president, capped a major turnaround recently with the opening of one blockbuster musical, ''Les Miserables,'' at one of its theaters and the fall booking of the smash London hit ''Phantom of the Opera'' into another.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about the treatment of employees in some door-to-door sales organizations carried an incorrect list of magazines sold by this method. Harper's no longer uses such sales organizations.

title: 4 Admit U.S. Charges In Plot on Indian Aide
description: Four Sikhs pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in New Orleans to conspiring to assassinate Bhajan Lal, Chief Minister of the Indian state of Haryana, while he was in New Orleans for eye surgery in 1985.

title: Legion of Honor
description: The French Government has decided to bestow what is perhaps its most prestigious award - membership in the Legion of Honor - on the American economist Paul Craig Roberts.

title: WEBSTER CLOTHES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
15 Writers to Receive Arts and Letters Prizes
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has named 15 poets and writers to receive the organization's annual literary awards, the chairman of the awards committee, Irving Howe, announced yesterday.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results for the latest periods include the operations, since the end of October, of a business purchased from Martin Marietta Corp.

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1985 have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in 1986.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 15
KEY RATES
5,600 New Mexicans Shed 34,000 Pounds
description: About 5,600 New Mexicans have shed 34,000 pounds in the first stage of a 10-year program to increase health awareness and reduce the risk of heart disease in the state.

title: COMVERSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Compulsive Eating
description: To The Living Section:

title: REMEMBERING 44 CHILDREN: SORROW, PITY AND MORE
description: With the trial of Klaus Barbie, the wartime head of the Nazi police in this area of France, scheduled to begin next month, harsh words are being exchanged between some Jews in Lyons, the region's largest city, and two tiny villages touched by an incident of Nazi barbarism 43 years ago.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.2 million from partial settlement of an insurance claim. c-Includes a gain of $3.1 million from the partial settlement of an insurance claim for both periods, and for the 9 months also includes a gain of $2.3 million from the replacement of a pension plan.

title: PARCELLS IS THINKING YOUNG
description: The Giants may be pro football's Super Bowl champions, but Coach Bill Parcells warned yesterday that some players who started last season might not start next season. He said the younger players who had a chance to displace them included William Roberts and Damian Johnson on the offensive line and five defensive players chosen on the first two rounds of last year's draft.

title: A Modest Proposal
description: There are now 19 months before the next national election, and at that time the President-elect will appoint a ''transition team'' that will have 10 weeks to prepare him for his awesome responsibilities.

title: Hanover Buys Building
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that its OFP Inc. subsidiary had acquired a Dallas building, Allied Bank Tower, through foreclosure. The building, with 1.2 million square feet of space, was owned by William and Sharon Criswell.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TEXASVILLE. By Larry McMurtry. 542 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: SENATOR DURENBERGER STIRS NEW CONCERN WITH OUTSPOKENNESS
description: In a city where there is no shortage of circumlocution and obfuscation, Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota has occasionally shocked his Senate colleagues with remarkably blunt talk, even about his personal life.

title: FILM: MORITA'S 'SOREKARA'
description: WATCHING Yoshimitsu Morita's ''Sorekara'' (''And Then'') is like tuning in to the dream of a stranger. It's often very beautiful and exotic, but it remains teasingly remote, beyond the point of depth perception. Without the film's production notes (which aren't available to the ticket-buying public), I'm not at all sure I'd have had any reliable idea when it was taking place.

title: OCEAN BIO-CHEM reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THE DANCE: LAURA DEAN TROUPE AT THE JOYCE
description: LAURA DEAN'S dances look the same but different. She offers surprise within regularity.

title: PEOPLE RIDESHARING reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. OFFICIALS CONCEDE THAT MOSCOW HAS ADVANTAGE IN ESPIONAGE RIVALRY
description: While spy versus spy is an accepted part of the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union, American officials believe a combination of Soviet persistence and American complacency has given Moscow a distinct advantage in the game in recent years.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said the sales increase reflects the acquisition during the latest quarter of certain Sealy licensees and 82 percent of Sealy Inc.

title: TEXACO RULING ASKS COURT'S SHARP DIVISION
description: The unanimity of the Supreme Court's ruling Monday against Texaco Inc. in its $10 billion legal battle with the Pennzoil Company masked a sharp conflict among the Court's nine members on various issues in the complex case.

title: McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it received nine down payments of unspecified amounts to reserve future launching dates for commercial satellites on its Delta II medium-launch vehicle. McDonnell said it would begin launching satellites for commercial customers in late 1988 or early 1989 and would have the capacity to launch up to 12 commercial satellites a year in the early 1990's.

title: Real Estate; Progress For Mall In Queens
description: THE long-discussed shopping mall planned in the former Gertz department store in Jamaica, Queens, has at last moved past the blueprint stage.

title: Knicks Not Talking on King
description: So no one wants to talk about Bernard King. Or, no one is allowed to. Scotty Stirling, the Knicks' general manager, has closed practices and placed a gag order on everyone, including Bob Hill, the head coach who keeps repeating, ''I'm just trying to get him in shape to play.''

title: EMMY-WINNING PRODUCER SHOT TO DEATH IN OFFICE
description: An Emmy-winning television producer and choreographer who staged the original routines of the Chippendale male strippers was shot to death in his office in the garment district yesterday afternoon and the police said the motive was unknown.

title: Main Seoul Opposition Figures Form a New Party
description: South Korea's main opposition party virtually collapsed today as its two dominant figures broke away and formed a new political party.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results for the latest quarter include the acquisition in December of Helikon Furniture Co. and Fairfield Medical Products Corp. The company said the figures for all periods reflect a change in accounting for pensions.

title: NOW, IN THE CENTER RING, CIRCUS COOKING
description: ''A CIRCUS kitchen isn't that different from a three-ring circus,'' said Eric Michael Gillett, who should know, being a ringmaster for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. To the paying customers ''circus cuisine'' may conjure images limited to concessionaire soda, cotton candy and peanuts hawked by vendors. But such arena fare, despite its emphemeral appeal, is nowhere near as interesting as the food that those in the international cast and crew prepare for themselves.

title: G-r-r-eat!
description: Heading into tonight's opening-round game against Los Angeles, Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers needs just 2 points to become the most prolific scorer in Stanley Cup history. Also set to move up: three active Islanders. Here are the top 10 on the N.H.L.'s playoff list. GP G A Pts. Jean Beliveau 162 79 97 176 Wayne Gretzky* 80 64 111 175 Gordie Howe 157 68 92 160 Bryan Trottier* 151 55 101 156 Mike Bossy* 123 83 72 155 Denis Potvin* 170 53 102 155 Stan Mikita 155 59 91 150 Jacques Lemaire 145 61 78 139 Phil Esposito 130 61 76 137 Guy Lafleur 124 57 76 133 *Active.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SERVING freshly cooked warm or hot preparations on a bed of cold salad greens is a fairly recent practice in the United States, borrowed perhaps from Asian cuisines. Yet it has quickly established itself in restaurants and now home kitchens. In America and France, the combinations take many forms: roast breast of duck, for example, or sweetbreads or even preserved goose, confit d'oie.

title: Todd Shipyards In Loan Talks
description: Todd Shipyards Inc. said its banks have agreed to negotiate the terms of its existing loans. The company said it requested the changes to insure that credit remains available. Todd recently reported a loss, which could result in a breach of the loan contracts under their current terms.

title: Change Pension System
description: To the Editor:

title: Compaq Founder Shifts to Religion
description: William H. Murto, one of three founders of the Compaq Computer Corporation, is leaving the company and the personal computer industry for a job in religion, the company announced yesterday in Houston.

title: OPERA: FIRST 'PARSIFAL' OF THE SEASON AT THE MET
description: NO one has ever described the contradictory genius of Richard Wagner more clearly than Thomas Mann, who late in life summed up his love of Wagner's music as a ''love devoid of belief.'' Mann's description of the characters who inhabit ''Parsifal'' as ''an assemblage of extreme and repellent oddities'' is, if anything, an understatement. The magician Klingsor, who emasculates himself in a vain effort to gain entry into an order of celibate knights, is only the most obviously crazed member of a crew whose sick misadventures we are expected to take with the deepest seriousness. And yet, ''Parsifal'' somehow emerges from this spiritual and psychological miasma not as gruesome nonsense but, thanks largely to its transfixing music, as a mythic drama with characters whose counterparts may be recognized all around us today in both the religious and secular worlds.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 12wks to March 8
description: The company said the year-ago 12 weeks results reflect a 4 percent stock dividend paid in January 1987.

title: PIRATE RALLIES PUT OUT BY OJEDA, THEN OROSCO
description: Surrounded by 46,102 fans and the memories of moments past, the Mets returned to Shea Stadium yesterday for the first time since the tumultuous seventh game of the World Series. And, haunted by the absence of Dwight Gooden, they confronted the problems of the future by opening the new season with a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Sweet Privacy
description: The recent commotion on a busy Greenwich Village street corner told something about changing American tastes, or at least changing New York tastes.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is to be a quick stop to pick up some prints.

title: People
description: * Richard E. Wasserman has joined Slater Hanft & Martin as a senior vice president.

title: 'CATCH-22' SEQUEL BY HELLER
description: Joseph Heller, whose madcap ''Catch-22'' evolved from a cult classic to a worldwide best seller, has signed to write a sequel. Before that, however, he will deliver another novel for which he has already completed the first draft.

title: Death of Tampa Black Evokes New Violence
description: Dozens of youths pelted cars with stones and bottles in a predominantly black neighborhood Monday night, hours after the police announced the fourth death of a black man involving white officers since November.

title: JUDGMENT DAY FOR RING JUDGE
description: On the morning after he won the middleweight title, Sugar Ray Leonard treated himself to a $15,000 Piaget watch at a shop at Caesars Palace.

title: 63.6% OF BRIDGES IN NEW YORK STATE ARE RATED DEFICIENT BY U.S.
description: More than half the bridges in New York State are rated as ''deficient'' by the Federal Highway Administration, and the number has been growing in recent years.

title: A BUILDING BLOCK OFF THE OLD CHIP
description: Silicon atoms, the foundation of today's computer industry, have been captured on film for the first time by photographers and researchers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The atoms, magnified a billion times, appear as ''hills'' on a silicon crystal. This photograph, made with a scanning tunneling microscope, is among 50 that make up a collection called ''Micro Scapes: The Hidden Art of High Technology,'' now on display in the Market at the Citicorp Center, 153 East 53d Street at Lexington Avenue.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DO you suffer from depression, fatigue, memory lapses, skin disorders, headaches, irritability, hyperactivity, breathing difficulties, abdominal pain, prostatitis, menstrual problems, impotence, muscle or joint pain, vaginitis, urinary disorders, numbness, recurrent sore throats, heartburn, constipation or other digestive problems? Are you bothered by tobacco, perfume or chemical odors? Have you lost interest in sex? Do you feel sick all over but do not know why?

title: MILLIONS UNTRACED IN AID TO CONTRAS OVER LAST 3 YEARS
description: The Reagan Administration and private supporters raised $83 million to $97 million for Nicaraguan rebels between 1984 and 1986, far more than the main contra group estimated it needed, and more than $20 million cannot be accounted for, a review of rebel finances shows.

title: TWO UPSTATE WINERIES ARE EXPECTED TO MERGE
description: GLENORA WINE CELLARS in Dundee, N.Y., and Finger Lakes Wine Cellars in nearby Branchport, boutique wineries with reputations for premium wines, are expected to announce today that they are merging, a move they hope will increase their marketing power.

title: GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Club Leader Won't Testify at His Murder Trial
description: Attorneys for Joe Hunt, founder of a group of young investors calling themselves the Billionaire Boys Club, have rested their case in his murder trial without calling him as a witness.

title: Time to Teach Remedial National Security Council
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Shifts Managers
description: Apple Computer Inc. today announced management changes that the company said would ''broaden the breadth and depth of Apple's executive leadership.''

title: Merrill Ousts 2 For Gambling
description: Two Merrill Lynch & Company employees in London were dismissed and two others were disciplined for running up debts of $:124,263 (equal to about $200,000) as a result of gambling on the price movements of stocks and bonds, a spokesman confirmed today.

title: Dollar Outlook Helps Yields
description: Bond prices declined sharply yesterday as the specter of a weaker dollar continued to weigh heavily on the minds of investors and speculators.

title: KIRK DOUGLAS HONORED WITH GIBES AND PRAISE
description: With affectionate gibes and exuberant praise, colleagues and other admirers of Kirk Douglas gathered at the Majestic Theater on Broadway on Monday night as the American Academy of Dramatic Arts honored the man and his career of nearly 50 years as an actor, producer and director.

title: EZEKIEL SCHLOSS
description: Ezekiel Schloss, an editor and political cartoonist, died after a long illness on March 30 at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $340,000. c-Net loss The company said the latest year net also includes an after-tax credit of $597,000 from the reversal of reserves no longer deemed necessary.

title: FAFCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Five Soviet Submarines Reported Off Bermuda
description: The United States Navy said today that the Soviet Union had begun a large submarine exercise in the western Atlantic near Bermuda.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS INQUIRY IN MOSCOW INTO EMBASSY SITE
description: President Reagan ordered his intelligence review board today to determine whether a new embassy building in Moscow had been so compromised by Soviet eavesdropping devices that it must be demolished and rebuilt.

title: Upgrading Studied For Indiana Utility
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana's bond rating is under review and could be raised from its current speculative grade status, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: Consumer Borrowing Increases
description: Americans took out $1.77 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in February, an increase that was far below the hefty gains of last year, the Government reported today.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: ''HA!'' you say. ''Who ever heard of really cooking in a microwave oven?

title: Investing: U.S. Vs. 3d World
description: A sharp growth in foreign investment in the United States has drawn capital away from developing countries, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: MICHELANGELO'S MASTERPIECE
description: His name is Angelo Dundee, but it should be Michelangelo now. He's the trainer who sculpted a boxing masterpiece -Sugar Ray Leonard's tactical triumph over both Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Father Time after a virtual five-year leave of absence.

title: No U.S. Blame in Thailand Refugee Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayan Ruins in No Danger of Flooding
description: To the Editor:

title: Questionnaire Used In Genovese Trial
description: A questionnaire that asked prospective jurors their views of the Mafia was used in jury selection yesterday for the racketeering trial of a convicted Mafia boss, Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, and 11 co-defendants.

title: A Bobby Bet
description: Michael Jordan, on Steve Alford's embarrassment of collegiate riches: ''I owe him $100 right now because I told him I never thought he'd stay four years with Bobby Knight.''

title: 23 Seized in Protest On Columbia Clash
description: Twenty-three people, protesting what they called a racially motivated attack on black students at Columbia University, were arrested yesterday after a 15-minute sit-in at Police Department headquarters.

title: Arthur M. Weimer, 77, Educator on Business
description: Arthur M. Weimer, who as dean of the Indiana University School of Business from 1939 to 1963 directed its growth into one of the leading business schools in the nation, died Monday at his home here after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Lyndon Who?
description: ''Lyndon Johnson,'' the latest offering in a Public Braodcasting System series on 20th-century leaders, will air tonight, and, it seems, not a moment too soon.

title: 81 Hurt as 2 Buses Collide
description: A school bus rammed into the rear of another school bus here early Monday, sending 81 people to hospitals. Most of those injured were children 12 and 14 years old. All but two were treated and released, school officials said.

title: Productivity Gain by New York Sanitation Crews Is Even Bigger
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR PASSOVER, ADVENTURES IN GEFILTE FISH
description: THERE'S more than one way to stuff a fish - a gefilte fish, that is. Often the first course for Jewish holiday dinners, especially the Passover seder, gefilte fish means ''stuffed fish.'' Today, it is the stuffing alone that we know as gefilte fish, but that stuffing can go far beyond the traditional round dumpling-in-gelatin form that is so familiar.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THEATER: 'CRACKWALKER,' CANADIAN URBAN DRAMA
description: JUDITH THOMPSON'S ''Crackwalker'' (at the Hudson Guild Theater) is an excessively bleak urban drama about two married couples who are down and almost out in a city in Canada. This new Canadian play is a heavy storm cloud. When a mentally retarded young woman (Elizabeth Berridge) stops at the end of the play and accuses the other characters of not knowing her, her words have an echo. The truth is that we have learned very little about any of these stunted lives.

title: ANCHOR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Halas Gets Lion Bid
description: Wally Halas, who took Clark University of Worcester, Mass., to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament this season, has been offered the job as Columbia's head basketball coach. Halas, a grandnephew of the late Chicago Bears' owner, George Halas, was selected from a group of eight on the final list to replace Wayne Szoke, who resigned a week after the season to become head coach at Monmouth College in New Jersey. Officials at Columbia said the offer needs final approval from the university's central administration.

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes certain writedowns and reserves of $850,000 for the restructuring of the company's Ronson Metals Corp. unit for the quarter and year; the year also includes income of $499,000 on the sale of certain technology. c-Includes a tax benefit of $122,000. d-Net income and includes an extraordinary charge of $306,000, a gain of $570,000 on the curtainment of a pension plan and a tax benefit of $342,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL The Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, warned of recession and other ''substantial risks'' to the economy if the U.S. relied on a further fall in the dollar to trim its record trade deficit. Instead, he said, the U.S. should cut its budget deficit. Mr. Volcker's remarks were seen by some analysts as an attempt to focus attention on American shortcomings and thus to minimize the chances of a trade war. [ Page A1. ] The dollar's decline is a central issue as the U.S. and its major trading partners open talks in Washington. Amid pessimism about the outcome of those talks, the bond market plummeted and the stock market followed. [ D1. ] Japan will spend $34 billion to stimulate its economy, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party said. The program, if enacted, would accelerate public works and provide larger outlays for housing and thus represents an about-face from the austerity programs of Prime Minister Nakasone. The U.S. has hoped that economic growth would lead the Japanese to buy more U.S. goods. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A group of investors withdrew its uninvited offer for Gencorp after the company made a higher offer for 54 percent of its stock. The bidders - the partnership of Wagner & Brown and AFG Industries - may make $75 million before expenses. [ D1. ] Filofax, the maker of looseleaf address-book-and-diaries that most emphatically do not fit in one's pocket, went public in London, offering four million shares at about $1.93 each. The company sees considerable opportunity for expansion overseas. [ D1. ] Texaco won some temporary relief from a Texas appeals court, which issued an order preventing Pennzoil from seizing any Texaco assets until after a hearing in Houston on Monday. The ruling permits Texaco to continue ordinary business activities, but restricts it from any major sales or transfers of assets, as its appeal of a judgment won by Pennzoil continues. [ D5. ] Avon said it would buy Giorgio, the Beverly Hills perfumery that turned a single fragrance into a $100 million-a-year business. The price is $185 million. [ D5. ] International Aero Engines delayed introduction of the engine that Airbus had wanted for its A340 airliner. [ D5. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 44.60 points, to 2,360.94, driven by a sharp decline in the bond markets and renewed fears about a lower dollar. Analysts said that profit taking by institutions also contributed to the slide. [ D1. ] Bond prices declined sharply. Many traders were betting that this week's meetings of financial leaders from industrial countries would not halt the slide of the dollar. [ D19. ] The dollar traded in a narrow range in the U.S. after falling in Tokyo to a new 40-year low against the yen. Gold prices rose. [ D20. ] Silver futures closed at a two-year high, brushing off late selling in Europe. Gold futures, soybeans and oil advanced. [ D20. ] THE ECONOMY Americans borrowed $1.77 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in February, an increase far below the gains of last year, the Government reported today. [ D5. ] TECHNOLOGY Researchers are eager to test their acid-rain remedies, drawing on the $2.5 billion that President Reagan has pledged for development of commercial technologies. [ D8. ] High-definition television has arrived, at least at the demonstration level, with a video image as sharp and colorful as 35-millimeter film. But it will be several years before the new signals can be received at home. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Solving the world debt problem is the most urgent priority, West Germany's Finance Minister said on the eve of meetings in Washington. An essential part of the cure is lower interest rates, he said. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Warning signals will sound before the end of the bull market, according to one analyst. Among the signs he said investors should watch for were several days of extremely high volume and intense speculation in over-the-counter stocks. Market Place. [ D10. ]

HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to Feb. 28 from March 31. The company said for 11 months ended Feb. 28, 1986, it had net of $10.2 million, or $1.07 a share, on revenue of $182.3 million; shares outstanding were 9,582,330.

title: Delta to Match Eastern's Fares
description: Delta Air Lines said today that it would match Eastern Airlines' program to slash fares and remove restrictions for business travelers to and from Atlanta. Eastern, controlled by the

title: Japanese Visit April 19
description: The Japanese appear to be convinced that the Reagan Administration will make good on its threat to impose penalty duties on up to $300 million worth of Japanese electronics goods next week.

title: NEW YORK'S LEGISLATURE TIGHTENS EHTICS RULES IN AN AIR OF TENSION
description: Both houses of the State Legislature, facing increasing public pressure and investigations by half a dozen prosecutors, voted overwhelmingly today for stricter ethics rules governing themselves and other officials.

title: DOW, IN REBOUND, ADVANCES BY 11.22
description: A stronger dollar and a mild improvement in Treasury bond prices combined to lift the Dow Jones industrial average 11.22 points, to 2,372.16 yesterday, one day after its fifth-worst decline ever.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest quarter had no investment tax credit because of the elimination of such credits by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, while the year-ago second quarter had an investment tax credit of $1,440,000, or 2 cents a share. The latest 6 months includes a charge of 4 cents a share from the tax credit elimination, compared with investment tax credits of 5 cents a share in the year-ago period.

title: King Returns to Lineup
description: After being sidelined for more than two years, Bernard King will make his long-awaited return to basketball tomorrow night when the Knicks face the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden. To make room on the roster for the return of King, who tore up his right knee in a game against the Kansas City Kings on March 23, 1985, the Knicks placed Jawann Oldham on the injured list. The 7-foot Oldham has been sidelined with a ligament sprain in his left knee.

title: MUSIC: THE PHILADELPHIA
description: DEBATE continues to swirl over the sound of the renovated Carnegie Hall, not without good reason - but at Tuesday evening's concert one was reminded instead of the remark attributed to Wilhelm Furtwangler, to the effect that the hall with the best acoustics is the one in which the best orchestra is playing.

title: CONCERT: THE INDIANAPOLIS
description: JOHN NELSON, who is probably most familiar to local audiences for his conducting at the Caramoor Festival and is about to take the helm of the adventurous St. Louis Opera, came to Carnegie Hall Monday night for a final concert as music director of the Indianapolis Symphony, which he has led for the past 11 years.

title: JAZZ SINGER WON TONY IN '79
description: Maxine Sullivan, whose cool, precise and rhythmic singing of the Scottish folk song ''Loch Lomond'' in the late 1930's gave her an identity that remained with her throughout her career, died of heart failure Tuesday at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx. She was 75 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Talking Deals; If Bargainers Are Far Apart
description: EVERY deal starts with an assumption - or, rather, two assumptions. What the potential buyer thinks of a company's value is often miles away from the owner's asking price. The truth, where the deal is struck, is likely to lie somewhere in between.

title: FIRST BANCORPORATION OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. AND ARMS CONTROL: INTERNAL DISCORD
description: Three days before Secretary of State George P. Shultz was to leave for arms control talks in Moscow with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he got his negotiating instructions from President Reagan at a meeting at the White House today.

title: TAXPAYERS OFTEN GETTING BAD ADVICE FROM I.R.S.
description: Taxpayers seeking help from the Internal Revenue Service can expect to receive erroneous advice more than 20 percent of the time, Government investigators told a Congressional panel today.

title: Barring Waldheim From U.S. Urged by 2 Congress Leaders
description: Two Congressional leaders have asked Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to act on a recommendation that President Kurt Waldheim of Austria be barred from the United States.

title: SPORTS PEOLE;
description: The average salary for major-league players on opening-day rosters fell sharply from a year ago, according to figures compiled by the Player Relations Committee.

title: BUDAPEST REVIVES ITS SOCIAL SEASON
description: THERE has never been anything like it in Budapest or any other Communist capital, the sponsors say. Champagne will flow and glamorous fashions will be shown by gorgeous models at the main event - more likely the only event - of the Budapest social season.

title: MORGAN, J P & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net investment securities gains in the latest first quarter were $43.1 million, compared with $58.1 million in the year-ago period. There were net recoveries in the latest quarter of $6 million after chargeoffs of $8 million, compared with net chargeoffs of $49 million in the year- ago period, after recoveries of $3 million.
