description: b-After tax credits of $78,000 for the quarter and $154,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: 2 KIMS FURTHER DIVIDE SOUTH KOREA
description: A split of the main opposition party into two groups created new uncertainty for South Korea today, including the threat of possible political confrontations.

title: Third World Debt: A Global Solution
description: A clamor is again growing over the peril caused by reduced bank lending to the heavily indebted less-developed countries. Hand-wringing, breast-beating and a blame-the-banks approach obscure the real issue.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $500,000.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results for the latest periods include the operations, since the end of October, of a business purchased from Martin Marietta Corp. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Walks of Life; The Boardwalk
description: There's a newly splendid spot to welcome spring: the Coney Island boardwalk. The waves, gulls and white beach overwhelm sleazier man-made vistas. Now the boardwalk, newly redone, brightens the scene, thanks to a 12-year rebuilding program that's almost finished.

title: Merc, Under Criticism, Picks Compliance Chief
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, under criticism for volatile trading in its stock index markets, announced yesterday that it had named Paul O'Kelly as chief compliance officer and said he would run a stiffer surveillance program.

title: Group to Explain Alien Law
description: The Federal Government said today that it had awarded a $10.7 million contract to a group that will publicize the new immigration law among employers and aliens.

title: Article 897487 -- No Title
description: Merce Cunningham has received a $50,000 cash prize from the Meadows School of the Arts at Southern Methodist University in Dallas for excellence in the arts.

title: BYRD OPPOSES LEGISLATION TO CURB POLLUTION THAT CAUSES ACID RAIN
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that ''acid rain is not an emergency'' and denounced legislation proposed to control the sources of the pollution that causes it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The country is not spending enough money on maintenance.

title: WITH LIBYANS HUMBLED, CHADIANS PAINT THE TOWN
description: Hadje Akhaye Bineye knelt down in the damp earth of an irrigated field and gave a satisfied squeeze to a tomato ripening on the vine.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Announced the resignation of Al Campanis, vice president of player personnel. Named Fred Claire vice president of player personnel.

title: Studio Glass: Young Craft Comes of Age
description: LEAD: Admirers of contemporary studio glass are about to be treated to a view of the Saxe collection, in an exhibition that opens Saturday at the American Craft Museum. After the Californians Dorothy and George Saxe saw the 1979 exhibition ''New Glass: A Worldwide Survey'' at the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., they decided to collect studio glass as it was being produced.

title: HAND-WOVEN TURKISH RUGS
description: FOR 20 years Marian Miller, above, has been a dealer in antique Turkish kilims. She has added to her stock 70 new one-of-a-kind wool rugs hand-woven in western Turkey, for $180 to $1,300, depending on size. Beginning in 1900 the weavers of such rugs gradually abandoned vegetable dyes for chemical ones. Two years ago the Turkish Government encouraged people to weave more salable rugs in the fresh, clear colors of the vegetable dyes. Hanging behind Ms. Miller are, from left, a brocaded striped rug primarily in green, cream, indigo and crimson, 2 feet 8 inches wide by 9 feet 8 inches long, $340; a medallion design in blue, yellow and green with a zigzag border of soft indigo on a crimson ground, 2 feet 8 inches wide by 9 feet 6 inches long, $340, and a geometric-patterned rug colored primarily in shades of crimson and indigo, 2 feet 7 inches wide by 10 feet 4 inches long, $340. Other rugs range in size from 4 feet by 6 feet to 9 by 12 feet. Marian Miller Kilims is at 148 East 28th Street. She sells by appointment and can be reached at 212-685-7746.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Walks of Life; Alive on the Street
description: New York City's police and transportation departments deserve a bushel of apples for improving the mortality of every pedestrian. The number of pedestrian deaths last year declined to the lowest level since 1912, the apparent result of stepped-up law enforcement and road safety improvements.

title: Act Now to Plug The Ozone Layer
description: LEAD: Strange events in Antarctica, straight out of science fiction, have grabbed the attention of scientists and world leaders. The stratosphere's ozone layer, which screens living things from damaging ultraviolet rays, has been thinning dramatically during the southern spring -the beginning of what some scientists suspect is a worldwide decay of the

title: Garden Reorganizes
description: Richard Evans, president and chief executive officer, said yesterday that Madison Square Garden Corporation had been reorganized into three operating groups: MSG Sports, MSG Entertainment and MSG Facilities Development & Management.

title: 104 More Bodies Retrieved From British Ferry
description: The known death toll from last month's sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise rose to 165 today after divers retrieved 104 more bodies trapped amid debris in the vessel's upper decks.

title: NEW TOOLS TO EASE A GARDENER'S TASKS
description: LEAD: With spring about to reawaken home gardens and grounds, now is a good time to explore new yard-care equipment. The current trend is toward portable, easy-to-operate power tools that are lightweight and make quick work of normally laborious tasks. Gardeners with little storage space may seek equipment designed for convenience - items with folding handles, for example, or multiple-use tools that attach to a single power source.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Marimba Quartet

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Feeding the Press 'American Sushi'
description: By Washington standards, it was a remarkably civilized news conference. No shouts, no sarcasm, no demands of ''Hold on, Mr. Congressman.''

title: Bill on Homeless Stalls In Senate on Pay Issue
description: The Senate today delayed action on a bipartisan bill to aid the homeless because of an issue that few legislators want to tackle: the Congressional pay rise.

title: WOMAN IS CARRYING HER DAUGHTERS BABIES
description: South Africa has managed to broaden the debate on surrogate motherhood by introducing a new puzzle: Pat Anthony, a 48-year-old grandmother in the northern Transvaal, is now in her third month of pregnancy carrying three fetuses for her own daughter.

title: Vandals at Lincoln's Tomb
description: Five teen-agers who told the police they acted out of boredom have been arrested here for spray-painting racist slogans and symbols on Lincoln's Tomb, the police said. Three 16-year-old boys and two 15-year-old girls were charged Tuesday night in the vandalism. Their names were not released. The vandals also knocked over about 30 tombstones, the police said. They also sprayed their names on the monument, which helped the police identify the suspects, the authorities said.

title: Accounts
description: * Central Federal Savings, Long Beach, L.I., to Sturtevant & Hildt.

title: Rumors Lift Treasury Prices
description: Treasury bond prices rebounded yesterday, helped by overnight buying in Tokyo and rumors that a new package of measures to support the dollar would emerge from a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers in Washington.

title: SOUTH CHINA SEA AURA AT BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: BLOOMINGDALE'S charge cards aside, maps and a guidebook might be the most useful items customers could take along when viewing the department store's huge spring promotion.

title: Remaking Soviet Union May Take Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Ambulances Take 23 From a Palestinian District
description: Ambulances entered the beleaguered Palestinian district of Shatila today and removed 23 seriously wounded residents.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: DANCING AROUND THE QUESTION
description: Where does Ray Charles Leonard go from here?

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, APRIL 9, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 An accord to stabilize the dollar was reinforced by top economic officials from the United States and six other industrial democracies. The Washington conferees indicated fear of a trade war. Page A1 The U.S. rejected any postponement of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's coming talks in Moscow. He cited ''potentially promising'' negotiations on arms control and other issues. A1 A third marine is being held on suspicion of espionage while on guard duty in the Soviet Union, the Pentagon said. He is Sgt. John J. Weirick, 26 years old, who was assigned to the American consulate in Leningrad, beginning in 1981. A1 The known death toll in the sinking of a British ferry off Zeebrugge, Belgium, a month ago rose to 165 after divers retrieved 104 more bodies trapped amid debris in the vessel's upper decks. A13 Efficient new superconductors are the focus of a frantic race here and abroad to apply the futuristic technology to transmission lines, computers and transportation in ways that recently seemed impossible A1 Libyans were not told of the heavy losses suffered by their troops in Chad in a national television address by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi before several thousand students packed into a Tripoli hall. A5 The debate on surrogate motherhood has been enlivened in South Africa. Pat Anthony, a 48-year-old grandmother, is in her third month of pregnancy bearing triplets for her daughter. A1 The owner of a van Gogh 'Sunflowers' that is the most expensive artwork in the world, after selling for $39.9 million on March 30 at Christie's in London, is the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Tokyo. C28 A Soviet rock star, Boris Grebenshchikov, worries that fans who once filled the stairwell of his sixth-floor Leningrad walkup with adoring graffiti will think he sold out. A1 Italian coalition collapses

title: REAGAN WILL ALLOW INVESTIGATORS TO SEE DIARY ITEMS ON IRAN AFFAIR
description: The White House and the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair announced an agreement today under which the Congressional investigators and the special prosecutor will be permitted to review some parts of President Reagan's personal diary.

title: GATEWAY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share and shares outstanding data are adjusted for a 10-for-1 stock split in September.

title: U.S. AND 6 ALLIES REAFFIRM ACCORD ON BACKING DOLLAR
description: Top finance officials of the seven biggest industrial democracies today reaffirmed their commitment to stabilize the dollar and also sought to defuse tensions with Japan.

title: Big 3 Car Makers Extend Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had extended its buyer incentive program on light trucks to April 30 from April 6, the program's previous expiration date. Under the program, customers have a choice of 3.9 to 9.9 annual percentage rate financing or a cash rebate of $300 or $600, depending on the type of transmission chosen.

title: Dooley Loses Official Flankers
description: Especially in the South, where college football coaches often enjoy status a rung or so higher than that of the governor, few self-respecting coaches at the big state schools would dream of stepping onto the field at game time without the protection of a pair of state troopers in full regalia, from highly polished footwear to wide-brimmed hat.

title: Passover in Moscow
description: By apt chance, Secretary of State Shultz will arrive in Moscow next week just in time for Passover, and he plans to celebrate the Jewish feast of deliverance at a seder with Soviet Jews. What better time for Mikhail Gorbachev to amplify on hints that his Government will agree, finally, to let an estimated 11,000 Jewish ''refuseniks'' escape limbo and emigrate from the Soviet Union?

title: NATURAL ORGANICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,659,672 from the sale and abandonment of stores and an extraordinary credit of $122,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $111,855 on the sale and abandonment of stores and an extraordinary credit of $320,631.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest year net includes a pre- tax charge of about $6 million from the recent loss of a $5 million lawsuit by a former employee.

title: I.M.F. AND WORLD BANK SEEN SWAPPING ROLES
description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are moving toward a dramatic reversal of roles that is likely to change for years to come the manner in which developing nations obtain loans essential to their economic growth.

title: Dole Still Smarting
description: When Senator Bob Dole, the sometimes sharp-tongued minority leader, went to New York City on Monday to speak at Columbia University's Business School, he was evidently still smarting from the Senate's override last week of President Reagan's veto of the highway bill.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TAKEOVER TALK LIFTS UAL STOCK
description: Shares of UAL Inc. soared $6.25, to $72, yesterday amid intense speculation that a takeover of the company that owns United Airlines could be in the making.

title: BRIDGE IN MISSOURI NEARLY COLLAPSED
description: Missouri, the state with the nation's highest percentage of ''deficient'' bridges, narrowly escaped a disaster last month that could have been worse than the bridge collapse that killed at least three people in upstate New York last Sunday.

title: Segovia in the Hospital With a Heart Problem
description: Andres Segovia, the 94-year-old Spanish guitarist, was admitted to Cabrini Hospital in New York Tuesday for observation of ''heart irregularities,'' his agent, Stewart Warkow, said yesterday.

title: STREET CLOSINGS NEAR CITY HALL DISRUPT TRAFFIC
description: Traffic in lower Manhattan ground to a standstill yesterday morning after city officials had closed several approaches to the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: FRANCE, PLAYING DOWN SPY CASE, IS HIT BY HARSH SOVIET PROPAGANDA
description: A French plan to keep a recent spy scandal from affecting this country's relations with the Soviet Union has been met by a vehement Soviet response that has surprised officials and analysts here.

title: Prosecution Rests In Donovan Case
description: After presenting evidence for seven months in the fraud and larceny trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and eight co-defendants, the prosecution rested its case yesterday.

title: Marwick Sees No Liability
description: Peat Marwick Main & Company, the American unit of the world's largest certified public accounting firm, said yesterday that it did not have any exposure to the negligence allegation made last week by the State of California against KMG Main Hurdman, now a part of Peat Marwick.

title: MARINES DETAIN A THIRD GUARD IN SPYING CASE
description: A third marine guard has been detained on suspicion of involvement in espionage in the Soviet Union, the Pentagon said today.

title: PLANNING CHIEF SEEN AS CHOICE FOR 42ND ST. POST
description: Carl B. Weisbrod, executive director of the New York City Planning Department, has been chosen to be director of the 42d Street Development Project, officials and development professionals said yesterday.

title: SEABROOK ATOM PLANT MAKES NEW LICENSE BID
description: The owners of the Seabrook nuclear plant here opened another front today in their battle to win a license for the $4.56 billion reactor by submitting to Washington an emergency evacuation plan for adjacent areas of Massachusetts over that state's objections.

title: Catherine Cohen Weds Stuart Schwartzstein
description: Catherine Gillian Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H.L. Cohen of Berkshire, England, was married yesterday to Stuart Jacob Danilow Schwartzstein, the son of Mrs. Frederick Schwartzstein of Trenton and the late Mr. Schwartzstein. Rabbi Hugh Gryn performed the ceremony at the West London Synagogue in London.

title: HOUSE RACE IN WEST GOES TO RUNOFF
description: Nancy Pelosi, a former state Democratic chairman, outpolled five fellow Democrats and eight other candidates in a special election Tuesday to fill the unexpired Congressional term of Sala Burton, who died Feb. 1.

title: KEY RATES
BALLET: CANADA'S 'WIDOW'
description: ''I give it a 10,'' a member of the audience said at the close of Ronald Hynd's ''Merry Widow,'' presented by the National Ballet of Canada on Sunday afternoon at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: KEAN FAULTED ON HELICOPTER PURCHASE
description: The chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee said today that the Kean administration had bought a $4.3 million helicopter for the Governor by disguising it as a medivac helicopter and by transferring money from one state account to another to avoid alerting the Legislature.

title: New York Foster-Care System Has to Have Better Forecasting
description: To the Editor:

title: POOL TABLE HOSPITAL
description: YOUR family doctor may not make house calls, but if the family pool table is in need of repair - if the billiard cloth is frayed, the leather pockets ripped or the ball-return system broken -Blatt Billiards will send one of its four two-person crews to your home to fix whatever is needed.

title: NASA AIDE CONCEDES SPACE STATION COST IS HIGHER
description: An official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration conceded today that taxpayers would spend about $20 billion for the first phase of the space station, or one and a half times what it was to have cost under a plan approved only last week by President Reagan.

title: MAN-MADE SNOW KEEPS SKI TRAILS OPEN
description: The rain in recent weeks wiped out lots of snow at Eastern ski areas, but it wiped out even more skiers who didn't want to be out there in the rain. Without business, many areas closed with plenty of snow still covering their slopes.

title: Democratic Rules
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives, wasting no time, this week formally adopted procedures for deciding which of them will go to Atlanta in July 1988 as delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: DRUG GAIN CITED BY CANCER RESEARCHERS
description: Scientists reported yesterday that widespread, advanced cancers disappeared completely in nine patients after experimental treatments with interleukin-2, a drug whose promise has been the subject of intense interest and controversy.

title: Federal Panel to Study AIDS Sought by Reagan's Advisers
description: President Reagan was urged today by his top domestic policy advisers to establish a commission to examine the AIDS virus and make recommendations on what the Federal role should be in combatting it.

title: U.S. THEORY IS THAT FLOOD CAUSED THRUWAY BRIDGE'S FOOTING TO SHIFT
description: The swirling floodwaters of the Schoharie Creek may have dislodged gravel and silt around the footings of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, causing the center to collapse Sunday, Federal authorities said today.

title: CASSETTES ON AIDS FOR USE BY FAMILIES
description: ''THE program you are about to see may save your life. It may also save the lives of your loved ones. You simply have no alternative - you must deal with this information.'' Such is the ominous introduction to one of a growing number of new video cassettes that are bringing knowledge about acquired immune deficiency syndrome into the home.

title: LOWER RATE OF DIVORCE FOUND
description: America's families seem to be stabilizing, with divorce rates at their lowest level in more than a decade, Government statisticians report.

title: Unilever Seeking Buyer for Stauffer
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch conglomerate, has issued a prospectus seeking a buyer for the Stauffer Chemical Company, which it acquired last winter as part of its purchase of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. A spokesman for Unilever said the company had previously said it would shed Stauffer as well as some of Chesebrough's smaller assets, including its Bass footwear and Prince tennis racquet businesses.

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TUROFF CASE IS EXPECTED TO GO TO JURY TODAY
description: A Federal jury is expected to begin deliberating today in the fraud, conspiracy and tax-evasion trial of Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, and three co-defendants.

title: Boeing Jet Deal
description: Canadian Airlines International has agreed to buy six advanced-technology Boeing 767-300ER airplanes and take options on eight additional planes for more than $1.6 billion, the company said. The extended-range plane has a fuselage 21 feet longer than the 767-200 version, which went into service in late 1982, and a range of 6,600 miles, with increased passenger capacity and cargo room. It is to be powered by a General Electric CF-6-80C2-B6 engine. Delivery is scheduled to take place from April 1988 to April 1989.

title: COPYRIGHT SUIT FIGHTS LOTUS 1-2-3
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, which has sued rival computer software companies that it said had copied the ''look and feel'' of its successful 1-2-3 spreadsheet program, was itself sued yesterday on the same ground.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about possible military uses of space stations described the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics incorrectly. It is a professional society of aerospace scientists and engineers.

title: Bakker Case Decided By Church Leadership
description: The leadership of the Assemblies of God in North Carolina emerged from a 10-hour closed meeting early today saying it had reached a decision on the resignation of the Rev. Jim Bakker and a chief aide.

title: ALEX BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: The 1986 results are pro-forma; and the company said the pro-forma figures reflect results as if the company had been public for all periods presented.

title: TRADE AMENDMENT HEATS UP DEBATE
description: On Capitol Hill they are already calling it the Gramm-Rudman of trade policy.

title: Dollar Drops in Tokyo, Then Moves Higher
description: The dollar dropped in early trading this morning amid speculation that the United States and its trading partners had failed to take specific measures to protect the dollar.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes pre-tax losses of $920,000 for the quarter and $863,000 for the 6 months on the disposition of real property; the 6 months also included the positive effect of an accounting change of $2,051,000. c-Net loss and includes pre-tax gains of $52,000 for the quarter and $117,000 for the 6 months on the disposition of real property. The latest periods also include an after-tax gain of $9.5 million arising from exchange of subsidiary for stock.

title: Dance Festival To Mark 10th Year in Durham
description: The American Dance Festival will celebrate its 10th year in Durham, N.C., with a seven-week season of performances by 15 American and foreign companies, starting June 4.

title: Hulk Horner
description: Bob Horner, the Atlanta slugger who became a free agent rather than accept a cut in his $1.8 million salary, is still without a contract and, under major league rules, can't resume talks with the Braves until May 1. In the meantime, an intriguing option has appeared on his horizon. The Charlotte (N.C.) O's, the Baltimore affiliate in the Class AA Southern League, say that if he would agree to serve as their designated hitter at home games, they'd pay him $3,001 a month (a dollar more than Tom Dodd received last year and just enough to make Horner the highest-paid player in O's history) and also throw in a few extras: He could have his own batting-practice pitcher, and he'd earn a $100 bonus for breaking the club home-run record of 32 and $500 for breaking the league record of 42.

title: INVESTIGATORS SAY GROUP RAISED $2 MILLION FOR CONTRA ARMS AID
description: A conservative, tax-exempt organization raised at least $2.28 million in an operation that Congressional investigators say was apparently intended to buy arms for the Nicaraguan rebels. The group says the funds were used to buy Christmas gifts for the rebels' children.

title: National Distillers Selling Spirits Unit
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its spirits division to the James B. Beam Distilling Company, a subsidiary of American Brands Inc., for $545 million. Proceeds will be used to repay debt and for other corporate purposes, including possible acquisitions, the company said.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Grolier Educational Corp., Danbury, Conn., a subsidiary of Grolier Inc., named James L. Hayes president.

title: Newark Physician Has License Revoked
description: The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners yesterday revoked the license of Dr. E. Wyman Garrett, a Newark obstetrician-gynecologist and former Newark school board member. He had pleaded no contest to charges of gross malpractice, including a case involving a 14-year-old who died of complications after an abortion.

title: 'SUNFLOWERS' BUYER: JAPANESE INSURER
description: The new owner of the van Gogh ''Sunflowers'' that is the most expensive artwork in the world - it was sold for $39.9 million on March 30 at a Christie's auction in London - is the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Tokyo.

title: Natural Gas Bill Cleared
description: The Senate unanimously approved legislation today to lift a ban on the construction of natural gas-fired power plants and other large industrial gas-burning plants. The bill, sponsored by Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana and chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, would repeal mandatory incremental pricing of natural gas, which was designed to protect residential consumers from sharp price rises by forcing some industrial users to pay prices higher than the market dictated.

title: GUINNESS THINKS FUNDS WENT TO EX-CHAIRMAN
description: Guinness P.L.C. said today that it suspected its deposed chairman, Ernest Saunders, had secretly received $4.8 million of the company's money during a corporate takeover battle last year.

title: Market Place; High Hopes For the Big 3
description: DIRECTORS of the Ford Motor Company will meet today in Dearborn, Mich., and Wall Street expects another dividend increase from the auto maker, which has raised its dividend seven times in the last 14 quarters.

title: Rolls Jet Unit's Sales Rules Set
description: The British Government, giving the details of its previously announced plan to sell the state-owned Rolls-Royce Ltd. to the public next month, said today that each investor would have to buy a minimum of 400 shares. The price will depend on market conditions.

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,051,000 from a change in accounting. c-Net loss The company said the latest second quarter and 6 months results include losses of $920,000 and $863,000, respectively, from the sale of Freeze-Damaged Groves.

title:
SCOUTING;
Personal Pennant
description: LEAD: Rick Manning of the Milwaukee Brewers, after reading that teams for which he has played throughout his career have wound up an average of 21 games behind: ''If we finish 15 out, I guess that means I had a good year.''

title: NEW SPRINGTIME GEAR, OUTDOORS AND IN
description: ALONG with sparkling windows, newly waxed floors and freshly laundered curtains, nothing is so enjoyable in spring as replenishing the gear and gadgets of the season.

title: ANXIOUS NEIGHBORHOOD WATCHES RESCUE EFFORT
description: On the block where an earsplitting blast turned two buildings into a cloud of white smoke and then a hill of rubble, rescue workers searched brick by brick last night for survivors as crowds waited to see whether friends and relatives would emerge dead or alive.

title: Working Women Need Nurture at Home Too
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS TOLL IN CHILDRJN IS CALLED 'DEADLY CRISIS'
description: The growing number of children with AIDS is ''a deadly crisis,'' according to a conference of public health officials who today urged a multi-pronged educational campaign to stem the problem.

title: Coast Savings Seeks Thrift Unit
description: Coast Savings & Loan Association said it was negotiating to acquire Central Savings & Loan Association of San Diego, which has been under the management consignment program of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation since 1985.

title: Bridge: Jerseyans Erased Big Deficit In Grand National Team Play
description: Many years ago a world-famous player went to bed at a national championship leaving his teammates to play the last 16 deals of a knockout match with an overwhelming lead of about 60 international match points. They eventually had the embarrassing task of waking him with bad news: the match had been lost.

title: Massachusetts Housing Bonds
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $75 million of single-family housing refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.46 percent for those due in 2014. Underwriters led by Paine

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plan to attend an American Embassy seder in Moscow for Jewish dissidents described a Soviet cancer patient incorrectly. He is Veniamin Charny, and is in Moscow, not in the United States.

title: Missile Defense Chief Denies Shift in Goals
description: The director of the Pentagon's research program into space-based missile defenses has denied that its goals have been shifted toward an early deployment, as charged in a report issued by two Senators on Tuesday.

title: New York Foster-Care System Has to Have Better Forecasting; Consistent Assignment
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 9, 1987
description: International

title: J.P. MORGAN NET OFF 3.2% IN QUARTER
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, the nation's fourth-largest bank holding company, said yesterday that its net income in the first quarter had dipped 3.2 percent from a year ago - a somewhat smaller decline than analysts had been expecting.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,721,000 and $9,261,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $91,556,000 for the quarter and $89,600,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $567,000 for the quarter and $33,535,000 for the year; and the year also includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $14,543,000. The year-ago fourth quarter net includes $5 million in pre-tax income from a litigation settlement and a tax benefit of $5.1 million. The latest year loss on disposal of discontinued operations includes a tax benefit of $13.8 million.

title: Referee to Be Fined
description: Referee Jack Madden will be fined an undisclosed amount for a confrontation Monday night with the president of the Atlanta Hawks, Stan Kasten, a National Basketball Association official announced yesterday.

title: FOR SOVIET ROCK MUSICIANS, GLASNOST IS ANGST
description: Six months ago Boris Grebenshchikov was an underground rock idol whose music was passed hand-to-hand on illicit tapes. Today he has a best-selling record on the Soviet Union's only label, he is lionized in the official press, and go-betweens are negotiating the ultimate prize - a recording trip to the United States.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the earnings in the latest quarter reflect interest expense on debt incurred to finance a recapitalization that took effect in October 1986.

title: TV Reporters Sought 2 Jurors in Goetz Case
description: The judge in the Bernhard H. Goetz case called an emergency hearing yesterday after two jury members came forward to report attempts by three news organizations to contact them.

title: Jordan, Manning Gets 2 Lehn & Fink Accounts
description: Jordan, Manning, Case, Taylor & McGrath has been given two additional assignments from Sterling Drugs' Lehn & Fink division: Ogilvie home permanents and Tussy deodorants, with some $8 million in billings.

title: People
description: * Jeanne Lee has been named a senior vice president at Doremus & Company.

title: 'Ich Bin Wallenberg'
description: For 42 years the mystery of the fate of one soaring man has haunted men and women all over the world, not letting them rest. Raoul Wallenberg, savior of thousands of Hungarian Jews, disappeared into a Soviet prison in 1945, but never vanished from memory.

title: RCA Lifts G.E. Profit; Net Up 16%
description: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 16 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, a reflection of the company's recent acquisition of the RCA Corporation and its subsidiary, the top-rated NBC television network.

title: San Miguel Bid by Busch
description: The Anheuser Busch Companies has joined a growing list of foreign companies bidding for the San Miguel Corporation, the Philippines' largest concern, a Government official said.

title: GEODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
TAKEOVER BILL SOUGHT
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he would propose legislation that would dramatically alter the corporate takeover process by requiring would-be investors to disclose their intent to purchase more than 3 percent of a company's shares before they made the purchase.

title: WORST-CASE SCRIPT IN TEXACO'S BATTLE
description: If Texaco Inc., which is fighting a multibillion-dollar legal battle with the Pennzoil Company, were to file for bankruptcy protection, it would be the largest company ever to do so. The action could impede Texaco's ability to operate and could cause hardship for creditors, customers and shareholders, bankruptcy experts and analysts said yesterday.

title: Gorbachev Is Due in Prague Today After Putting Off Visit
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said here today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would arrive on Thursday.

title: 'Miserables' Interrupted
description: A matinee performance of ''Les Miserables'' at the Broadway Theater was interrupted yesterday when the house manager smelled smoke and ordered the theater evacuated, according to Frederick Olsson, facilities director for the Shubert Organization, which owns the theater. No fire was apparent, Mr. Olsson said, and the show resumed after 15 minutes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the debate over New York City's effort to force all-male clubs to admit women misidentified Nadine Strossen. She is a professor of constitutional law at New York University Law School.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that earnings in the latest first quarter were helped by a lower tax rate; the effective tax rate was 35.4 percent, compared with 39 percent in the 1986 first quarter.

title: FROM SWEATER GIRL TO STYLISH VAMP
description: AS the fall fashion openings continued in New York Ralph Lauren extolled the British gentlewoman look, as is his wont, and Oscar de la Renta presented curvy clothes with a nod to Balenciaga that looked more wearable than many of the short styles being shown. Carolyne Roehm developed a more soigne look. Marc Jacobs, one of the most promising young designers of the last two years, showed signs of retrogression.

title: WATERFORD TO BROADWAY: WELL-TRAVELED 'FENCES'
description: The out-of-town tryout has been a part of Broadway at least since the days when George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart spent months on the road writing, rewriting and re-rewriting their comedies before bringing them into New York. But August Wilson's ''Fences,'' which opened last week to resounding critical acclaim and long lines at the box office, was nurtured over a four-year period in productions from New Haven to its initial commercial run in San Francisco. That journey allowed ''Fences'' a nearly unheard-of luxury, given a climate in the commercial theater that rarely grants a play the time to develop before it is put before the critics and the New York audience.

title: Suns' Inquiry Reported
description: The Phoenix Suns are reportedly being investigated for drugs by the National Basketball Association, and one of the team's owners said yesterday that the club has been told not to comment.

title: Health Care Ad Agency To Open Soon in SoHo
description: Edward J. Holland, 55 years old, and his wife, Karen, 40, are half of the title of a new health care ad agency named Holland Holland Metelenis Lynch, which is hoping to open its doors at 155 Spring Street in SoHo in a couple of weeks.

title: PIANO: RUDOLF SERKIN IN BEETHOVEN PROGRAM
description: RUDOLF SERKIN playing Beethoven's last three piano sonatas is like a diver who finds with experience that he can drop deeper and deeper, always finding new levels that would be inaccessible to the young, no matter how brave. At age 84, Mr. Serkin knows where the dangerous reefs and coral beds lie in these mighty works, and he does not so much avoid them as dare them to block his descent into the depths.

title: TEXACO'S TOP OFFICERS GATHER
description: Texaco Inc.'s top executives huddled with lawyers and financial advisers in Houston today, reviewing legal positions, including a potential bankruptcy, according to people close to the embattled oil giant.

title: Yankees Doodle, Then Win a Dandy
description: Children were back in school. Office workers, by the hundreds, had apparently made quick and complete recoveries from the disease that kept them away from their desks on Monday afternoon. The Yankees went on with the business of their season, away from opening-day pomp but into the trying circumstance that is expected to create problems all summer.

title: DANIEL Z. HENKIN, TOP PRESS AIDE FOR PENTAGON IN THE VIETNAM ERA
description: Daniel Z. Henkin, chief spokesman for the Defense Department in the tumultuous days of the Vietnam war, died Tuesday of complications after surgery for a kidney transplant. He was 63 years old.

title: New-Toy Assignment Goes to 2-Shop Team
description: Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, a small but award-winning San Francisco agency, teamed up with Scali, McCabe, Sloves to win a new-product assignment from Hasbro, the nation's largest toy and game company.

title: PARKER DRILLING COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SURVEY GIVES SUBWAYS SOME MIXED REVIEWS
description: New York City's subways continue to suffer from too many broken car doors and too few announcements, according to a survey released yesterday by the Straphangers Campaign.

title: Notes Issued By G.M.A.C.
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $500 million of notes in three-year and seven-year maturities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS LP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: Archbishop Kevin McNamara Of Dublin Is Dead at Age 60
description: Archbishop Kevin McNamara of Dublin, died of cancer today at his residence here. He was 60 years old.

title:
Advertising;
An All-Out Effort for Kool-Aid
description: LEAD: ONCE you view wild and wacky Pee-Wee Herman's new television show you know that his antics and the show's quick-cut format are bound to be picked up by TV commercial makers.

title: ENGLISH WAR BABIES SEARCH FOR AMERICAN FATHERS
description: He was only 7 years old at the time, but Frank Hamilton vividly recalls the day his grandmother told him his father was an American serviceman stationed in England in World War II. ''I was really pleased,'' said Mr. Hamilton, who is now 43 and runs an office-cleaning business in a London suburb. ''My stepfather was a drunk who would beat me up. I was so glad that this horrible man was not my father.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DARLING IS READY TO CLOSE GOODEN GAP
description: On many April afternoons when he was president of Yale, A. Bartlett Giamatti would sneak over to the baseball field, nest in his seat in the dugout and watch Ron Darling pitch for the varsity.

title: UNION TRIES TO ORGANIZE CNN OFFICE
description: A group of writers, producers and other newsroom employees of the Cable News Network's New York bureau have petitioned to join the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians in an effort that, if successful, will be a major inroad for organized labor at the nonunion network.

title: Chiat Acquires Dee Company
description: Chiat/Day of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York, has acquired its first public relations firm, the 10-year-old Jessica Dee Communications of New York. The Dee firm expects a fee income of $2 million this year and is rated the 41st-largest independent public relations firm by J. R. O'Dwyer's directory.

title: New Office Set Up to Review Eligibility for Asylum in U.S.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today announced the creation of a new Justice Department office to review eligibility for political asylum. He took the action in the aftermath of a Supreme Court ruling that made it easier for applicants to gain asylum.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected August 1986.

title: RYAN STRIKES OUT 10 AS ASTROS SWEEP
description: A two-run home run by Jose Cruz highlighted a seven-run seventh inning that rallied the Houston Astros to a 7-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today for a sweep of the season-opening three-game series.

title: WHALERS PREVAIL IN OVERTIME, 3-2
description: Paul MacDermid tipped in a shot by Randy Ladouceur at 2 minutes 20 seconds of overtime as the Hartford Whalers came back from a two-goal deficit to beat the Quebec Nordiques, 3-2, in a fight-marred Adams Division playoff opener tonight.

title: Septien Pleads Guilty
description: Rafael Septien, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of indecency with a child in an agreement with prosecutors that brought him a sentence of 10 years' deferred probation and a $2,000 fine.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: ENGLAND'S late poet laureate Sir John Betjeman is said to have started a speech to the Oxford Union by saying, ''As I get older, I find that there are only two things worth writing about: sex - I mean love - and death.'' On the premise that at any age, what we think about we write about, I will add money.

title: NEW YORK FOSTER CARE: A PUBLIC-PRIVATE BATTLEGROUND
description: The public and private agencies that run New York City's besieged foster care system are deeply split over who should control the system and whether major changes are needed in its structure.

DEFENSE RESTS IN THE DEATHS OF 3 ON MOVIE SET
description: The defense has rested in the trial of five defendants charged in the deaths of three actors in a helicopter crash on a movie set, with only two of the defendants having chosen to testify.

Chrysler to Extend Talks With A.M.C.
description: The Chrysler Corporation and Renault said they had agreed to extend by up to two weeks their talks on reaching definitive agreement on Chrysler's proposed $1.5 billion takeover of the American Motors Corporation. Chrysler and Renualt, the French-owned car maker, said in a statement that they ''now plan to complete work by April 23.''

title: FOR LIBYANS, WAR IN CHAD IS A WHISPER
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appeared on national television Tuesday night before several thousand students jammed into the People's Hall here, and as has been his pattern, he made no mention of the heavy losses suffered by Libyan troops in the war in Chad.

title: Reward Offered in L.I. Killing
description: Friends of Fillippa Savoy, the 31-year-old Bayville, L.I., woman who was fatally shot while driving home from work on March 3, have offered a $21,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of the person who killed her. Mrs. Savoy was shot on Town Path Road in East Hills, L.I. A homicide detective, Sgt. Everett Campbell, said that a ''sniper theory'' had been ruled out and that evidence now showed the woman was shot from a distance of 12 to 15 feet. The assailant could have been in a car or hiding in bushes.

title: Plea to Protect Baldness Drug
description: The Upjohn Company, trying to protect its exclusive rights to sell minoxidil for treatment of baldness, asked Federal regulators today to halt imports of the drug by 20 companies in the United States and six other countries.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year results are translated at a conversion rate of 20.3489 Philippine pesos and 20.2315 Philippine pesos, respectively, for each U.S. dollar. The year-ago quarter results are translated at a conversion rate of 18.5571 Philippine pesos per dollar, and the year results at 18.2743 Philippine pesos per dollar.

title: Conrac in Talks With Other Suitors
description: The Conrac Corporation, the maker of Code-A-Phone answering machines and the object of a tender offer by Mark IV Industries, said it had begun negotiations with several interested suitors. Traders have been expecting other bidders to compete with Mark IV, a diversified manufacturer of plastic products and electronic parts that owns 9.9 percent of Conraac.

title: BANPONCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its subsidiary bank, Banco De Ponce, had placed $11.8 million of Brazilian debt on non- accrual status, which lowered first quarter earnings by $239,614, or 4 cents per share.

title: Metro Matters; Indictment 62/87: A Battered Wife Turns to Violence
description: By the time Karen Straw killed her husband, she was well known to the police. But until then, they knew her only as the victim.

title: MUSIC: A . LEROY'S SONGS
description: THE compositions A. Leroy presented on Monday, in the first of four performances at Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, took an ironic, out-of-kilter look at some American stereotypes. ''Move To,'' for wind instruments and percussion, lurched along like an inebriated marching band. The trumpets, trombones, reeds and flutes blew heraldic fragments that neither developed into fanfares nor resolved harmonically, while bass drum and cymbals crashed on off-beats.

title: RACIAL REMARKS CITED BY DODGERS
description: Al Campanis, the Los Angeles Dodgers' vice president in charge of player personnel, resigned under pressure from the club yesterday as the result of remarks he made suggesting that blacks might not be qualified to be managers or hold executive positions in baseball.

description: Psst. Remember those Rangers who stunned the Flyers and a lot of other people a year ago? It seems they are back.

description: In shutting out the Flyers in the opening game of the playoffs tonight, John Vanbiesbrouck displayed the same brilliance that took the Rangers a long way in the playoffs last season.

title: Senate Panel Breaks Impasse and Votes a Budget
description: After a week's deadlock, the Senate Budget Committee today approved a 1988 budget that includes $11.3 billion in tax increases and $17.2 billion of reductions in projected military and nonmilitary spending.

Better the Contras
description: The official McGovernite villain of 1987 has emerged at the head of the Nicaraguan resistance. He is Adolfo Calero, described by Newsweek as a ''political boss'' who has taken charge of the contras ''only two months after he was forced out by the advocates of democracy and civilian control.''

title: Hong Kong Stocks Soar
description: Share prices surged in Hong Kong today as investors took heart from a stock exchange ruling barring the issue of controversial new shares by Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., the large trading firm. The Hang Seng Index, the market's main indicator, climbed 64 points, to 2,729.55, for its best one-day gain since March 18, when it rose more than 94 points. The stock exchange and the Commissioner for Securities said in a joint statement that they had rejected a plan by Jardine Matheson to issue new shares with proportionately higher voting rights than existing shares.

description: In a discussion by satellite television today, Soviet and American journalists traded complaints about stereotypical reporting and probed to find their differences and similarities in a friendly exchange that was also laced with barbs.

description: b-Net income The latest quarter results include a $7 million writedown of the company's broadcast television investments.

Can you translate the words and thoughts of a 17th-century Mexican nun, for example, into visual images? It's hard, and ''Smithsonian World'' can't always quite make it. When the program succeeds, however, it's gorgeous. It can be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: 6 DIE AS A BLAST LEVELS 2 BUILDINGS IN SOUTH BRONX
description: Two buildings, one four stories high and the other an adjoining one-story grocery store, exploded and collapsed in the South Bronx yesterday afternoon, killing at least 6 men and injuring at least 28 people, the authorities said.

title: Air Traffic Errors Said to Rise
description: Incidents of controllers allowing airplanes to come closer than regulations allow have increased sharply in recent months, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: It's Not Just California's Oil
description: Rebuffed for years by Congress, the Reagan Administration is making another attempt to find a palatable way to develop California's offshore oil reserves. Environmentalists and coastal property owners roar in understandable protest; it's impossible to drill for oil with zero risk to beaches or wildlife. But the risk, if not zero, is low, and given the national need for secure sources of oil, it's a risk well worth taking.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A roof leak caused a 12-inch corner of our bathroom wall and the wallpaper to swell and bubble out. The leak has been repaired but the wallpaper remains puffed out. Can we repair it? A. Usually even after the wall has dried, the gypsum board (if it is drywall) or the plaster has to be replaced, so the ''bubble'' might be part of the wall. However, if the wall is flat, you should be able to paste the paper back down. Slice the middle of the bubble with a razor, then wet the paper to make it soft. Work some wallpaper adhesive or thinned-down white glue behind the paper on each side of the slit and press the paper flat against the wall with a damp sponge. Sponge off all paste that oozes from the slit; rinse the sponge thoroughly and wipe off again. Q. I would like to redo the Formica counter tops in my kitchen. Can I paint or re-cover them? What do I do about the silver trim between the back edge of the counter and the vertical backsplash? A. You can paint the counter top surfaces with a good enamel, but this usually doesn't last long and has to be redone fairly frequently. You can install new plastic laminate over the old surfaces, but you must first remove the sink and all metal trim at the corners and the edges. Sand the old plastic lightly, then clean thoroughly. Put the new plastic on with contact cement; replace the sink and the moldings at the edges and along the bottom of the backsplash. Q. For years I have had a problem with my toilet. There is a good swirling action but the bowl is very slow to empty. I have adjusted the ball in the tank so there is plenty of water in the bowl before it is flushed. I have also cleaned the small openings under the rim. A pipe goes to the roof for venting; might this need cleaning? Any other suggestions? A. The vent line might be clogged or partly blocked, interfering with proper flushing; it should be checked. If it is clear, and if you are sure the tank fills to its maximum, there is probably a partial blockage in the toilet or in the waste line. Usually, blockages can be cleared with a ''snake'' or a power auger. Or you can use one of the drain-cleaning tools that employ water pressure. If that doesn't work, the bowl might have to be taken up to check the waste line and to clear completely the trap built into the bowl.

title: MICHAEL REDSTONE
description: Michael Redstone, founder of National Amusements Inc., and the Northeast Theater Corporation, operator and owner of 400 movie theaters in the Northeast and the Midwest, died Saturday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter results do not include the June 1986 acquisition of RCA Corp.

title: STAND ON ETHICS INQUIRY REVERSED BY PANEL CHIEF
description: The chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, who said Tuesday that the commission would accept $5 million to carry out a broad investigation of state and local government, reversed himself today and said it did not want the money.

title: CLONES OF MADONNA
description: SAY what you will about Madonna - that she's cynical, stereotype-mongering, overpackaged, unoriginal, not much of a singer - but what other performer has spawned an entire radio format in her own image? Turn on what's called ''hot'' radio in New York, where WQHT (103.5 FM) has adopted the format, and ''hot'' or ''power'' radio elsewhere, and 8 songs out of 10 seem to be by Madonna wanna-bes.

description: DAI RAKUDA KAN, the Japanese Butoh dance-theater troupe that made its New York City debut last night at the City Center, is not exactly your typical suburban dinner-theater company.

description: b-Net loss The company said its latest period revenue includes $1,141,000 from the sale and repurchase of foreign exchange futures contracts. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: American industry is embarking on a frantic competition to turn a few gray-black chunks of ceramic into impossibly efficient electric transmission lines, impossibly small computers and impossibly fast levitating trains.

title: CAPITALS 4 ISLANDERS 3
description: Once again, the Islanders had to content themselves with almost recovering from a debilitating scenario.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Walks of Life; Escalation
description: The Day-Glo green sticker looks ugly, and that's the point. It's the New York City Sanitation Department's newest weapon against parking violators. Department agents plaster the stickers on the windows of cars that block the routes of its mechanical brooms. The hope is that humiliation and the annoyance of scraping off the stickers will deter violators where ticketing fails.

title: MOSES MALONES'S 50 SINK NETS
description: It began with Mike Gminski. Then came Ben Coleman, Jeff Turner and finally Buck Williams. Their goal was to try to stop Moses Malone. They all failed. Malone, the Washington Bullets' 6-foot-10-inch center, battered the Nets from the inside and outside with a season-high 50 points that paved the way for a 118-109 victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The 50 points broke the arena record of 43 for a pro, set by Gerald Wilkins of the Knicks earlier this season and later equaled by Mark Aguirre of the Dallas Mavericks. Malone's 18 field goals broke Larry Bird's arena record of 17 and his 31 attempts equaled the mark set by Dominque Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Japan-Britain Trade Tension Rises
description: Britain and Japan clashed today over Britain's demands for greater access to the Tokyo Stock Exchange as a trade dispute between the two countries mounted.

description: In past years, Lynbrook High School had always been knocked out in preliminary rounds of WLIW Channel 21's quiz show, ''Brainstormers.'' ''We never even made it to the televised rounds,'' said the coach, Mimi Butler, a guidance counselor.

title: DOLLARS FOR DAYCARE
description: Few dispute the need for decent day care, but decent salaries are another thing. Day care jobs pay so poorly -$5 to $9 an hour - that the annual turnover is 50 percent. Some centers have had to close because they couldn't keep a staff.

They said they might also team up on other products. Canon's laser printer will use National Semiconductor's microprocessor and other National chips, an important victory for the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif.

description: A Chinese man jailed in France last year for espionage activities has been pardoned by President Francois Mitterrand, judicial officials said today.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d misstated his age.

title: Fish Story?
description: As a conservation measure, many fishing tournaments, especially those involving large saltwater species, are of the so-called catch-and-release variety. Bound more or less by the honor system, competitors radio the time of their catch, its measurement and other details to tourney officials and then throw the fish back. One built-in check helps keep the anglers honest: They generally fish in sight of other entrants, who thus have a good idea whether anybody reports a catch he doesn't make.

title: The U.N. Today: April 10, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SOVIET CHARGES U.S. WITH BUGGING
description: The Soviet Union struck back today in the embassy bugging dispute, displaying an array of devices described as eavesdropping equipment planted by American agents at Soviet diplomatic missions in the United States.

title: After 2 Years on the Mend, King to Play
description: Bernard King has spent many hours during the last several days reliving some of his greatest games on videotape in his home.

title: Triple Crowns
description: In beating Marvelous Marvin Hagler last Monday night, Sugar Ray Leonard was added to this list, now 10 names long, of fighters who have won world titles in three different weight divisions. BOB FITZSIMMONS - middleweight, 1891-97; heavyweight, 1897-99; light heavyweight, 1903-5. TONY CANZONERI - featherweight, 1928; junior welterweight, 1931-32, 1933; lightweight, 1930-33, 1935-36. BARNEY ROSS - lightweight, 1933-35; junior welterweight, 1933-35; welterweight, 1934, 1935-38. HENRY ARMSTRONG - featherweight, 1937-38; lightweight, 1938-39; welterweight, 1938-40. WILFRED BENITEZ - junior welterweight, 1976-79; welterweight, 1979; junior middleweight, 1981-82. ALEXIS ARGUELLO - featherweight, 1974-76; junior lightweight, 1978-80; lightweight, 1981-83. ROBERTO DURAN - lightweight, 1972-79; welterweight, 1980; junior middleweight, 1983-84. WILFREDO GOMEZ - junior featherweight, 1977-83; featherweight, 1984; junior lightweight, 1985-86. THOMAS HEARNS - welterweight, 1980-81; junior middleweight, 1982-86; light heavyweight, 1987. SUGAR RAY LEONARD - welterweight, 1979-82; junior middleweight, 1981; middleweight, 1987.

title: BYE-BYE BASEBALL? SEATTLE FEARS A SALE OF THE MARINERS COULD MEAN JUST THAT
description: For two weeks the mood here has been as in Mudville after Casey's last at-bat.

title: REAGAN HAILS U.S. TECHNOLOGY'S ROLE
description: President Reagan today praised technology as the parent of job creation as he ventured into a region that has suffered a steady loss of manufacturing jobs.

title: Christine Lavin Songs
description: Christine Lavin will perform her songs tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), with O. J. Anderson opening. Shows are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: LOSS OF SHOE LEADS TO JAIL
description: A Brooklyn man who was arrested after losing a shoe at the scene of an attempted robbery was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail by a judge who said a ''quirk of fate'' had brought the man to justice.

title: DONOVAN LAWYER ASKS JUDGE TO DISMISS CASE
description: A defense lawyer for former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said yesterday that Bronx prosecutors had failed in seven months of trial testimony to implicate his client in a $7.4 million larceny and fraud conspiracy.

title: Cataract Surgery Is Under Budget Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the Nov. 1, 1986, acquisition of First Railroad & Banking Co. of Georgia, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Phil Woods's Little Big Band, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street (533-7902). Phil Woods builds slowly and carefully. The quartet that the alto saxophonist formed 13 years ago with Steve Gilmore on bass, Bill Goodwin on drums and Mike Mellilo on piano has remained together with only a single change (Hal Galper replaced Mr. Mellilo in 1981). But since that change, the group has gradually begun to grow. It has been a quintet in recent years with Tom Harrell playing trumpet, and now, as Phil Woods's Little Big Band, it has expanded to an octet, which is making its debut this week, through Sunday, at Fat Tuesday's. The additional members are Nelson Hill, tenor and alto saxophones; Nick Brignola, baritone saxophone, and Steve Turre, who plays trombone. The new octet plays tonight and tomorrow at 8, 10 and midnight, and on Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. There is a cover charge of $12.50 and a minimum of $7.50.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of March 31
description: The latest period per share figures include capital gain distributions of 50 cents a share paid in February 1987 and 83 cents a share paid in December 1986. Assets represent net assets.

title: KEY RATES
AUDIO-VIDEO AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CBT BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results for both periods include First Community Bancshares Inc., acquired March 31, 1987, and accounted for as a pooling of interests. The latest first quarter results also include First Camden Bancorp., acquired Jan. 31, 1987.

title: CUOMO AND LEGISLATORS AGREE ON BUDGET OUTLINES
description: The outlines of a $41.6 billion state budget that cuts taxes, increases welfare benefits and sharply raises aid to education were agreed to tonight by leaders of the State Legislature and Governor Cuomo, although some details remained to be worked out.

title: ATOM PLANT DECISION DELAYED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today put off a decision that would have cleared the way for the start of limited operations at the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire.

title: HOSPITAL FINED FOR TOXIC FLOW FATAL TO PATIENT
description: A Queens hospital was fined $4,000 yesterday in the case of a kidney dialysis patient who died after the water supply to a dialysis unit was mistakenly connected to the hospital's air-conditioning system.

title: ISRAEL SENDS COPTERS AGAINST PALESTINIAN POSITIONS
description: Israeli helicopter gunships attacked Palestinian positions today on the outskirts of the port of Sidon in southern Lebanon.

title: HOME SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $756,000 pre-tax gain on the sale of securities and loans. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,022,000 and includes a pre-tax gain of $2,468,000 from the sale of securities and loans. The bank converted to stock ownership in November. The company said in the latest quarter, for financial reporting purposes, it reflected a tax loss carryforward of $2.4 million as a reduction of goodwill rather as an extraordinary tax credit.

title: HOLES FOUND IN GAS METER AT BLAST SITE
description: Three bullet holes and the aluminum jacket of a pistol bullet were found yesterday in the gas meter of a South Bronx grocery store where six people died in an explosion Wednesday, the police said.

title: If Competitiveness Is to Succeed
description: Policy makers of both parties are finally asking how American industries can become competitive in the global economy. Just in the nick of time: The decline of America's semiconductor production illustrates how quickly industrial decay can spread.

title: BASE IS MAKESHIFT HOME TO RELOCATED WORKERS
description: Camp Smith, a key training site for ground combat units of the state's Army National Guard, assumed a new support role this week: housing General Motors Corporation workers transferring to this region.

title: Columbia College Gala
description: Columbia College will hold a gala celebration of its bicentennial at the Metropolitan Opera House Sunday at 8 P.M. The celebration, to be hosted by Walter Cronkite, will feature performances of musical works composed and arranged by Columbia alumni. The performers are to include Ben Vereen, Robert Merrill, Roberta Peters, Marvin Hamlisch, the ''Chorus Line'' company and Tony Bennett, as well as such alumni as John Kander and Fred Ebb, the lyricist-composer team, who are to perform their own works. A film retrospective of the college's history will also be presented. Information: 517-2310.

title: Bridge: Regional Tournament on L.I. Will Draw From Wide Area
description: The biggest tournament of the year for Long Island players begins today, attracting players from many parts of the Northeast. It is the Long Island Regional at the Physical Fitness Center of Hofstra University in Hempstead, and the schedule is: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; knockout teams, 8 P.M. Tomorrow - Flighted pairs, 1 P.M. and 7

title: CURB ON PRETORIA DEFEATED AT U.N.
description: The United States and Britain today vetoed a Security Council resolution that would have banned all trade and other ties with South Africa because of its occupation of South-West Africa.

title: Why Worry?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUNDS OF EASTER MUSIC FILL CHURCHES AND HALLS
description: EASTER is music's time for storytelling. Thus Holy Week - the unfolding narrative of Jesus' passage to the cross - evokes powerful musical drama that, in turn, enriches the power of the event itself.

title: 'THE SECRET OF MY SUCCESS'
description: ''THE SECRET OF MY SUCCESS,'' directed with a lot of panache by Herbert Ross, is a comedy about the meteoric rise in the Manhattan business world of Brantley Foster (Michael J. Fox), who, when he leaves the Kansas farm, tells his worried mother, ''I want to have a meaningful experience with a beautiful woman.''

title: QUOTE OF THE DAY
description: ''There are certain times in history when the creative forces in a society try to break through the contradictions. This is such a time in Moscow and 1968 was such a time here.'' Jiri Hajek, former foreign minister of Czechoslovakia, on the visit of Mikhail S. Gorbechev to Prague. (A8:3.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday HUNGARIAN FILM VIEW Over the past two decades, Gyula Gazdag, a Hungarian film maker, has produced a wry and iconoclastic body of work unusual in the carefully controlled artistic milieu of Eastern Europe. This evening at 6:30, Mr. Gazdag will appear at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, to introduce his 1974 operatic parody ''Singing on the Treadmill,'' a satire of the Socialist Realist works of the 1950's. At 3, ''The Whistling Cobblestone,'' a 1971 comedy about the generation gap between entrenched authority and rebellious youth, will be shown. Tomorrow at 2:30 P.M., ''Package Tour'' (1984), a documentary about Auschwitz survivors who return to the site as tourists, will be shown, with a repeat screening of ''The Whistling Cobblestone'' at 5:30. On Sunday, ''Singing on the Treadmill'' will be shown at 2:30 P.M.; ''Package Tour'' will be repeated at 5:30. Several other of Mr. Gazdag's films will be presented in the series -which lasts until April 21 - including ''The Long Distance Runner'' (1968), ''Selection'' (1970), ''Happy New Year'' (1974), ''Swap'' (1977) and ''The Banquet'' (1981). All films are in Hungarian with English subtitles, and all are free with admission to the museum: $5 for adults; $3.50 for students; $2 for the elderly. Information: 708-9400. SHE'S FLYING

title: 'Perls' Are Offered By Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday began offering $40.05 million of principal exchange rate linked securities due in 1990 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The securities, call ''Perls,'' in the debt market, carry a 13 1/4 percent coupon and are offered at a price of par.

title: GALVESTON-HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $18,138,000 for the latest year and $18,475,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: 2 G.M. Closings To Affect 9,000
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would close its Chevrolet-Pontiac-G.M. of Canada plants in Oklahoma City and Doraville, Ga., next week for inventory adjustment, temporarily laying off 9,000 workers.

title: Soviet Trade Gap $4 Billion
description: The Soviet trade deficit with the West soared past the $4 billion mark last year, according to official figures released today.

title: Missing Millions
description: Follow the money. That watchword of the Watergate investigations now drives investigators trying to decipher the Iran-contra affair. There's a lot of money to follow.

title: MYERSON QUITS AFTER FINDING OF MISCONDUCT
description: Bess Myerson, accused in a specially commissioned mayoral report of ''serious misconduct,'' resigned yesterday as Mayor Koch's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.

title: College Stars May Have Been Ineligible
description: Court documents filed as part of an agent's suits against several of the nation's top college football players contain promissory notes for several thousand dollars signed by the players. If the signatures are valid, the players violated college rules and should have been ineligible to play.

title: 3 INDICTED ON INSIDER CHARGES
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted three senior Wall Street traders who had been arrested in February on charges of insider trading.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of March 31
description: The latest period per share earnings includes capital gains distributions of 28 cents a share paid in February 1987 and $2.55 a share paid in December 1986. Assets represent net assets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lloyd Advances Easily: Chris Evert Lloyd advanced to the quarterfinals of the Family Circle Magazine Cup at Hilton Head Island, S.C., yesterday by defeating Debbie Spence, 6-3, 6-0. The match lasted only 54 minutes. The best third-round match was between Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, a 23-year-old West German, and Katerina Maleeva, 17, from Bulgaria. Kohde-Kilsch won, 6-3, 6-7, 6-4, in a 2-hour-51-minute match. In other matches, Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami lost to Zina Garrison, 6-1, 6-2; Bettina Bunge defeated Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 6-1, 6-0, and Gabriela Sabatini defeated Hu Na, 6-2, 6-2. Arias Wins: The defending champion, Jimmy Arias, defeated third-seeded Guillermo Vilas, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the $200,000 River Oaks International tournament in Houston. Arias, of Jericho, L.I., defeated Vilas, of Argentina, in a match that began Wednesday but was delayed because of darkness. Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, the top-seeded player, defeated Sammy Giammalva of Houston, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Gomez Takes Marathon Match: Kevin Curren and Andres Gomez had never played each other before but made up for the scheduling oversight last night with a 3-hour-44-minute marathon that Gomez won 6-7, 7-6, 6-7, 6-4, 6-2 in the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis tournament in Dallas. Gomez, of Ecuador, took control with a service break in the first game of the final set, broke again in the seventh game for a 5-2 lead, then won his serve for the match. (AP) BOXING Reid Is Winner: Unbeaten Chris Reid of Little Silver, N.J., a light heavyweight ranked fourth by the World Boxing Association, stopped Ian Mattis of Jamaica, Queens, at 2 minutes 30 seconds of the sixth round of the scheduled 10-round bout last night in Felt Forum. Reid raised his record to 17-0-1 with 16 knockouts, and Mattis, a replacement for J. B. Williamson of Los Angeles, dropped to 11-3. Rinaldo Snipes of Yonkers stopped Melvin Epps of Brooklyn a 1:14 in the fifth round of a scheduled heavyweight 10-rounder to increase his record to 27-6-1. In a middleweight contest, Kevin Moley of Selden, L.I., overcame a sixth-round knockdown to stop Derrick Earvin of Birmingham, Ala., at 2:07 of the seventh round of another scheduled 10-round bout. Moley is 28-2 with 24 knockouts. GOLF Okamoto Leads: Ayako Okamoto shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after first-round play in the L.P.G.A. Kyocera Inamori Golf Classic in San Diego. Tammy Fredrickson and Kathy Whitworth tied for second a stroke back at 67 on the par-72 course at the Bernardo Heights Country Club. A total of 34 subpar rounds were scored. (AP) BOWLING 51-Pin Lead: Amleto Monacelli of Venezuela won five of his eight match games in the fourth round and held a 51-pin lead in the $150,000 Showboat Atlantic City Open tournament last night. Monacelli, who finished second two weeks ago in the Toledo Trust Professional Bowlers Association National Championship, had a pinfall total of 5,818 and a 218 average through 26 games. Mike Edwards of Tulsa, who was also seeking his first title, went 6-2 in match play and moved into second place with 5,767. Tom Crites, the 1985 P.B.A. rookie of the year from Tampa, Fla., posted the best record of the night at 7-1 and jumped from 11th place to third with 5,736. (AP)

title: Moscow Still Believes
description: Gradually, as they explain themselves, the reasons underlying the Soviet leaders' new program are becoming clearer.

title: STAGE: WILDERNESS WOMEN IN 'PATIENCE AND SARAH'
description: IF love were as good-humored, and humorous, as it is in Isabel Miller's ''Patience and Sarah,'' it would be more tolerable. In this fable of 18th-century America -adapted from Ms. Miller's novel of the same name, which was loosely based on the life of the primitivist painter Mary Ann Wilson - two young women overcome ignorance, social taboos and unyielding terrain to journey into the frontier wilderness of upstate New York to establish a farm and live together.

title: NEW STARS ON STAGE AND RESTAURANT ROW
description: ON Sept. 16, 1925, a very nervous Noel Coward made his Broadway debut in his play ''The Vortex,'' and despite his extreme anxiety, he knew ''to my lasting satisfaction, that I gave the best performance that night that I have ever given in my life.'' After the premiere, he said, ''I was hugged and kissed and crowned with glory, and that night is set apart in my memory, supreme and unspoiled, gratefully and forever.''

title: ART: MODERN MASTERS AT SIDNEY JANIS GALLERY
description: ONE of the great paintings of our century has come into town for just a few weeks and can be seen through April 25 at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street. It is ''Nude in Tub,'' painted in 1925 by Pierre Bonnard.

title: LAWSUITS, AND WORRY, MOUNT OVER BIC LIGHTER
description: The Bic Corporation is facing mounting lawsuits on behalf of people who have been burned - and in some cases killed - by fires they say were caused by defects in the company's disposable butane lighters.

title: REAGAN REJECTS SOVIET PROPOSAL TO CURB A-TESTS
description: The United States has rejected the latest Soviet compromise offer on limiting nuclear testing, Administration officials said today.

title: Dow Plunges 32.96 Points, to 2,339.20
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 32.96 points yesterday, battered by a sharp increase in interest rates and rekindled concern about the weakening dollar and the trade frictions between Japan and the United States.

title: McReynolds Rides Welcome Wagon
description: Perhaps it was only natural to wonder whether Kevin McReynolds would be intimidated by his new environment, given the trauma some players have experienced wearing the pin stripes of another New York team.

title: STAGE: IN 'MISALLIANCE,' SHAW'S CLASSIC CLASHES
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 4 -Any company that undertakes ''Misalliance'' has to find a style to deal with the play's unbalanced design. The plot is close to invisible and what action there is - a plane crash, the appearance of a man with a gun - occurs in the second half. The first hour is devoted to what George Bernard Shaw called conversation, a brilliant airing of most of his favorite themes. But for much of the time on the stage of the Palace Theater, it's just talk.

title: TRIAL OPENS FOR AMY CARTER AND 14 OVER A PROTEST
description: Amy Carter and others arrested at rally against the Central Intelligence Agency committed minor crimes to avoid the greater one of allowing agency recruiting, an attorney for the daughter of former President Carter told a jury today.

title: FROM CASUAL TO CONTINENTAL CUISINE ALONG THE SPRUCED-UP 46TH STREET
description: THE gangly young ginkgo trees are about to blossom along 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, marking two causes for celebration: The onset of spring and the fruition of a 12-year-old effort to rejuvenate one of the theater district's premier blocks, known as Restaurant Row.

title: RESTAURANT
description: CINCO DE MAYO, or the Fifth of May, is the day in 1862 when Mexico won a famous battle (but ultimately lost the war) against French invaders near the city of Puebla; closer to home, it is the name of a flamboyant SoHo restaurant that in 1983 unleashed the first salvo in the great guacamole invasion of Manhattan. Six months ago, the original restaurant opened a second, smaller outpost in Tudor City on the East Side.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yugoslav Army Plays No Strikebreaker Role
description: To the Editor:

title: FLYERS 8, RANGERS 3
description: Finally there were breakaways from Philadelphia and goals from in close, and the Flyers restored their series with the Rangers back to order.

title: Yanks' First Loss Revives Doubts
description: But for the grace of the erratic right arm of Darnell Coles, the Yankees could have left here today with three defeats in their first three games of the season.

title: Head of Pilots Unit Has Goal for United
description: Frederick Charles Dubinsky, who is leading an effort by United Airlines pilots to buy the airline, is no stranger to risk.

title: SENATE APPROVES LEGISLATION AUTHORIZING AID TO HOMELESS
description: The Senate on a voice vote today approved legislation to authorize $423.2 million for aid to the homeless this year after settling a dispute over a proposed repeal of the Congressional pay increase that took effect last month.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PACT REFINES GROUP OF SEVEN'S RESPONSE SYSTEM
