description: Behind the seven-nation agreement Wednesday that the dollar has fallen enough are other agreements that could enhance the countries' attempts to control the dollar.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: SEVERAL years ago, when Joe Williams was performing at an awards ceremony at the Kennedy Center in Washington, Leontyne Price was warming up in the next room. The two met and got to talking about the dos and don'ts of singing. And at the end of the conversation, the diva distilled in one sentence a nugget of wisdom that Mr. Williams quoted the other day: ''You perform on your interest, not your principal.''

title: HOUSING IN CHELSEA EDGES INTO A COMMERCIAL BLOCK
description: Some of Chelsea's loveliest apartment buildings, now partly concealed by cherry trees and dogwood, line the 20's between Ninth and 10th Avenues. But the district extending that far west is a checkered one, with gritty industrial strips alternating with residential streets significant in history and architecture.

title: Marty Ehrlich Trio
description: Marty Ehrlich, a saxophonist, will lead a trio tonight at First on First, First Avenue at First Street (982-9310). Sets are at 10 and midnight; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: GORBACHEV ON A PRAGUE STROLL: THE CHEERS AND THE CURIOSITY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today and walked among thousands of cheering Czechoslovaks who thronged streets that 19 years ago were cleared by invading Soviet tanks.

title: SOLISTI IN BRAHMS
description: Solisti New York, under the direction of Ransom Wilson, will present an all-Brahms concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, tomorrow night at 7:30. Admission is free; information: 662-2133.

title: VW Keeps Payout After Fraud Loss
description: Volkswagen gave its shareholders the same dividend as last year's, despite a suspected currency fraud that may cost it as much as 480 million marks ($260 million). Volkswagen's supervisory board set an unchanged dividend of 10 marks ($5.50) a share.

title: Pravda on James Webb
description: James H. Webb, who won Senate confirmation yesterday to succeed John L. Lehman Jr. as Secretary of the Navy, got the usual questions about who and what he is as he went through confirmation hearings. In the for-what-it's-worth department, Pravda, the Soviet newspaper, thinks it has some of the answers.

title: ALLIED BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a securities gain of $500,000.

title: I'm Embarrassed, an Israeli Says
description: LEAD: Good day to you, America, my distant friend.

title: MUSIC: BERNSTEIN AND THE PHILHARMONIC
description: Most discussions of the music of Ives bear down heavily on his prodigal use of quotation and it is true that in a work such as the Symphony No. 2 he seems to be trying to bring the ancient technique of pastiche to new levels of incongruity. However, listening last evening to the New York Philharmonic's superlative performance of the piece under Leonard Bernstein one was struck more forcibly by the artistic unity that Ives achieved than by the diversity of his materials. The patchwork effect that some performers seem to prefer to emphasize in any Ives score was there this time, true, but in Mr. Bernstein's affectionate reading the oddly assorted parts were far less important than the whole.

title: ISLANDERS 3, CAPITALS 1
description: The Islanders, seeking the best strategy for beating the Capitals, looked no further than the first game of this series to plot a method for tying it up in the second.

title: Texas A&M Ruling
description: Texas A&M football players sold complimentary tickets in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, according to the school's investigation of its football program.

title: 30 SOUTH AFRICA MINERS KILLED
description: Thirty South African miners were killed in an underground methane gas explosion Thursday in a coal mine near the eastern Transvaal town of Ermelo, about 100 miles east of Johannesburg, the mine's owners said.

title: INSIDE
description: Bullet Studied in Blast

title: While Zealots Slept
description: For six years President Reagan and his Administration have carried on an obsessive campaign for secrecy in government, trying to keep information from the press and the American public. Meanwhile, real secrets - intelligence secrets - were pouring out to the Soviet Union in a flood.

title: METS ARE POWERED BY STRAWBERRY, 4-2
description: So far, so good. For the second time this season, the Mets played without Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell, and for the second time, they won.

title: JUDGE RULES TOPEKA SCHOOLS ARE NOT SEGREGATED
description: A Federal district judge, acting in a reopened case resulting from the original lawsuit that led to desegregation of American schools, ruled today that the Topeka school district did not discriminate against minorities.

title: MAJOR EXPANSION OF MEDICARE IS BACKED 881M
description: A major expansion of Medicare to cover the costs of catastrophic illnesses seems highly likely in the wake of a vote today by a key subcommittee of the House of Representatives, approving new health benefits for millions of elderly people.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January. The year-ago results are restated.

title: South African Sale by Exxon
description: The Exxon Corporation has sold its South African interests to a trust that would expand the unit's activities under a new name and use the profits to finance social and educational programs for the underprivileged.

title: TRANSPLANT IS FIRST IN NATION
description: Doctors transplanted adrenal gland cells into the brain of a 42-year-old woman today in an effort to curb Parkinson's disease symptoms. Officials said it was the first time the operation was performed in the United States.

title: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The Chamber Music Society of Loncoln Center will play music by Beethoven, Mozart, Schoenberg and Leon Kirchner at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 5. Mr. Kirchner's ''Music for 12'' will receive its first New York performances. Admission is $17.50; information: 427-1911.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Music and Dance of the Fulani People of Senegal, the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street (619-1980). Most of the Senegalese music that has reached the United States has been by Mandingo griots (historian-troubadours) and such Wolof rock musicians as the singer Youssou N'Dour. Now, four musicians from Senegal's third major tribal group, the Fulani, are making their first appearances in the United States, playing music that can be traced to the 11th century. The Fulani, originally a nomadic tribe that has now settled throughout West Africa, have their own troubadour tradition, with histories and praise songs and dance tunes for the royal court and for social occasions. Musicians are known as bambaados, and they play the xoddu (five-stringed fretless guitar), the riti (one-stringed fiddle), drums, gourds and bamboo flutes, solo and in ensembles. The music revolves around short, tightly wound riffs in unexpected combinations; to an American ear, the music suggests both the Arab-influenced music of North Africa and, with its fiddle and raw-voiced singing, American country-blues. The dancing, of course, will have to be seen. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $12 and $15. Information: 206-1050.

title: BANK OF DELAWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Driesell's New Post
description: Lefty Driesell, the former University of Maryland basketball coach who stepped aside after the controversy over the death of Len Bias and took a post as assistant athletic director, has been put in charge of sports information by the school.

title: HENRY E. DEL ROSSO
description: Henry E. Del Rosso, a Republican district leader on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, died of a heart attack Monday at the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AFGHANS AWAY FROM HOME: RUGS, GUNS AND FEAR
description: An Afghan garrison town is rising here on bare, stony hills whose access roads are mainly the gullies of nearly waterless streams.

title: Britain Ordering Westland Copters
description: The Government said that it would place an order worth $:300 million ($480 million) with the Westland P.L.C. helicopter company, which was saved from bankruptcy last year in a controversial bid by an American-led consortium. Britain's Defense Minister, George Younger, told Parliament his ministry would order from Westland, Britain's only helicopter company, 25 EH-101 helicopters for delivery in the early 1990's, as well as 16 Lynx helicopters.

title: New Bid Study On Holly Sugar
description: Shamrock Holdings of California Inc., an investment concern controlled by the Roy E. Disney family, said today that it was considering an offer to buy the one million shares of the Holly Sugar Corporation that it does not already control.

title: Mitchell-Lama Occupants Have a Right to Sell
description: To the Editor:

title: Bakker Decision Delayed
description: Officials of the State Assemblies of God say they want more information before deciding on the resignations of the Rev. Jim Bakker and a top Bakker aide, according to a spokeswoman, Juleen Turnage. Mr. Bakker and the Rev. Richard Dortch resigned from the Pentecostal denomination March 19 and Mr. Bakker also stepped down as president and chairman of PTL, acknowledging a 1980 sexual encounter and payment to ''blackmailers.''

title: British Duke Selling Old Master Drawings
description: The Duke of Devonshire, owner of one of the largest art collections in the world, will sell 16 Old Master drawings by Raphael, Veronese, Barocci, Lorenzo di Credi and Rembrandt in order to raise money to maintain the art at Chatsworth, his ancestral home in Derbyshire, Christie's in London announced Wednesday. The auction house estimates that the drawings will sell for a total of $8 million.

title: DOLLAR PLUMMETS A DAY AFTER ALLIES SET STABILITY GOAL
description: The dollar plunged to new lows against the Japanese yen yesterday, just one day after the United States and its economic allies had pledged to stabilize currency rates.

title: EX-DIRECTOR ACCUSED OF FED LEAKS
description: A former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has been accused of repeatedly leaking market-sensitive interest-rate information to a brokerage firm.

title: A Different Color Bar
description: Perhaps after another 40 years, no one will have to ask why there are no black managers or executives in major league baseball. But this year, the 40th since Jackie Robinson became the first black player in the majors, the question remains regrettably appropriate.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cecil Payne Quartet
description: Cecil Payne, a baritone saxophonist, will lead a be-bop quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Barry Harris and Chris Anderson will each play piano solos Sunday between 6 and 10 P.M. Admission is $8; $5 for students and the elderly.

title: CONCERN ON BIG SUPPLY OF GASOLINE
description: Concern over high gasoline inventories continued for a second day yesterday, as prices of crude oil and petroleum products moved slightly lower in brisk trading.

title: STAGE: RINGLING BROTHERS AT MADISON SQ. GARDEN
description: KING TUSK, indeed!

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Chip Orders Rose in Period
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator improved for the sixth consecutive month, a trade group reported today, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported their highest levels of orders and shipments since 1984. The Semiconductor Industry

title: U.S.-Japan Meeting
description: A senior Japanese trade official met with American negotiators today in an effort to avert the new American tariffs on selected Japanese electronic goods that are scheduled to go into effect on April 17. An American official said the talks seemed inconclusive and that no American statement was planned.

title: FILM: JOHN MALKOVICH IN 'MAKING MR. RIGHT'
description: AS the credits for ''Making Mr. Right'' roll by, the film's barefoot heroine is seen driving her bright red convertible to the sound of a high-voltage pop song, shaving her legs and painting on lipstick as she goes. This is the kind of hot-blooded, fun-loving moment that Susan Seidelman, who also directed ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' and ''Smithereens,'' manages best. In fact, Ms. Seidelman plays with clothes, knickknacks, pop tunes and crazily single-minded characters better than almost any other film maker around. Her ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' will long stand as the definitive guide to everybody who was anybody, and anything that was au courant, in the year in which it was made.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ROBERT DE BELDER, a retired diamond dealer who lives near Antwerp, Belgium, assembled over 30 years one of the finest collections of botanical color-plate books in private hands -holdings that Sotheby's in London is to auction April 27 and 28. The 388 volumes include many of the monuments of botanical illustration, dating from 1600 to 1900, that document the evolution of botanical art. Sotheby's expects the sale to total $4 million to $4.5 million.

title: Underground History
description: To the Editor:

title: Lloyd's Will Help Defrauded Backers
description: Lloyd's of London, in an effort to put a five-year scandal behind it, offered today to help investors in its insurance underwriting syndicates meet losses suffered partly through fraud.

title: Della Femina Adds To Its Sheraton Billings
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which became the corporate agency for the North American operation of the Sheraton Corporation when the HBM/Creamer, New York, agency was merged into it, has been awarded its first regional product advertising assignment, for the Western region as well as for the Hawaii-Japan division.

title: Toy Laser Gun Brings Death to a Teen-Ager
description: An anguished deputy sheriff was taken off duty and given psychological counseling after fatally shooting a teen-ager who was using a toy laser gun in mock combat with friends in a dark schoolyard.

title: ART: WORKS BY LOIS LANE
description: THIS season has seen shows of early and recent work by a number of the artists who have emerged under the ''New Image'' painting heading. The latest to be heard from is Lois Lane, whose exhibition at the Willard Gallery (29 East 72d Street) is one of her best. For this particular outing, on view through tomorrow, the artist is exhibiting three earlier paintings (two from 1977, one from 1981), alongside four canvases made this year, and the cumulative effect indicates that she has gone forward by going backward, returning to her earlier work in order to amplify certain devices and themes.

title: DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Revenue
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $300,000 and $400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, repsectively.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES ON WATER FOR WEST
description: The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation issued final rules today for limiting the amount of subsidized water for large farms in the West.

title: New Ad Drive: Call It 'A Fistful of Leaves'
description: If you were in charge of the country's parks and other public lands, and a bunch of punks were trashing them, what would you do? Hire Clint Eastwood, of course. Make his day.

title: MIDLANTIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter results are restated to include the earnings of Midlantic Banks Inc. and Continental Bancorp Inc., which became subsidiaries of Midlantic Jan. 30, 1987.

title: STAGE: 'TENT MEETING,' REVIVALIST REBALDRY
description: WITH almost daily reports about sexual peccadilloes among the believers, revivalism is a most suitable subject for theatrical ridicule. Because of its theme, ''Tent Meeting'' would seem to be even more topical than when it was first presented at the 1985 Humana New Play Festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., (after its initial engagement in Atlanta). In Louisville, it proved to be a crowd pleaser, although there were some skeptics, including this reviewer, who wanted more art with the iconoclasm.

title: HOMOSEXUAL'S LOVER LOSES HOUSING BID
description: An appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a homosexual whose lover died of AIDS had no right to the rent-stabilized apartment the two men shared because his name was not on the lease.

title: U.S.SEEKS TO END 2-YEAR CHECKS OF BRIDGES
description: The Federal Highway Administration has proposed eliminating a requirement that all public bridges in the nation undergo safety inspection at least once every two years.

title: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: The Guarneri String Quartet will play music by Schubert, Bartok and Brahms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8. Admission is $15; information: 570-3949.

title: DESIGNS FOR 'NOW' BY DAVID CAMERON
description: Is he just a California clone of Stephen Sprouse? ''That question will dog me forever,'' said David Cameron, who designs clothes for the fast and the young. ''What's modern is modern.''

title: JANE COOP, PIANIST
description: Jane Coop, a Canadian pianinst, will present a program of works by Mozart, Brahms, Chopin and Jean Coulthard, a Canadian composer, at the 92nd Street Y Sunday afternoon at 3. Admission is $7.50 to $10; information: 427-4410.

title: JAMES WEBB WINS SENATE'S APPROVAL AS NAVY SECRETARY
description: The Senate voted today to confirm James H. Webb as Secretary of the Navy,despite criticism of an article he wrote in 1979 saying that women in the armed service academies were poisoning the atmosphere there.

title: PERES WINDS UP TALKS WITH SOVIET AIDES
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel concluded three days of talks with Soviet officials here today, and he described the talks as ''the first serious and direct dialogue'' between the two nations.

title: Airlines Accept Europe's Rules
description: The European Community said today that it had shelved threatened legal action against three European airlines after they agreed to change practices that restrict competition.

title: Interstate Alters Latin Loan Status
description: The First Interstate Bancorp said it would place $320 million in Brazilian loans and $14.5 million in Ecuadorean loans on nonaccrual status. The Brazilian action would cover all medium- and long-term loans on which interest payments have been suspended since February. The Ecuadorean step covers all loans to that country, aside from those guaranteed by the United States Government.

title: Jimmy Smith, Organist
description: Jimmy Smith, an organist, will lead his trio, and Houston Person, a saxophonist, and Etta Jones, a singer, will lead their quartet, in a double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Shows begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $7.50 music charge at the bar.

title: Upshaw Again Opposes Testing
description: The head of the National Football League Players Association said today that mandatory testing of professional athletes was not the answer to drug problems in sports.

title: THAIS TENSE AS OFFICERS DEMONSTRATE
description: More than 600 Thai Army officers massed today to back their Commander in Chief in his dispute with a leading civilian politician who criticized him in a speech last week.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 1987
description: Markets The dollar plummeted to a new low against the yen just a day after the U.S. and its economic allies pledged to stabilize currency rates. The decline followed statements by Treasury Secretary Baker that were interpreted by traders as an endorsement of further declines. Early today in Tokyo, the dollar was trading as low as 142.90 yen, after falling to less than 144 yen in New York. [ Page A1. ] A quicker system for reacting to currency fluctuations was agreed upon at the Washington meeting of the Group of Seven, officials of the U.S. and its six trading partners suggested. They also hinted that they had narrowed the secret exchange-rate range for the yen and the dollar that they set in Paris six weeks ago. [ D2. ] Treasury yields rose above 8 percent for the first time in 13 months. Traders were dismayed that the meeting of finance officials in Washington did not produce more vigorous plans to prevent the dollar's decline. [ D1. ] The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 32.96 points, to 2,339.20, battered by the sharp increase in interest rates. [ D5. ] Concern about high gasoline inventories persisted, as prices of crude oil and petroleum products moved slightly lower. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL Treasury Secretary Baker implored commercial banks to sustain the third world by developing new alternatives for borrowing. His remarks reflected growing concern that banks were shying away from loans to the developing world and thus endangering economic growth there.$ [ D1. ] COMPANIES Bic is being sued by people who say their lighters exploded, causing burns, and in some cases, death. Bic settled one case last fall for $3.25 million, but hundreds of suits are pending. Bic has refused to discuss the claims against it. [ A1. ] Hospital Corporation of America received a $3.8 billion offer from two former executives at Republic Health and a lawyer. The three are unknown on Wall Street, where analysts were skeptical of their bid to acquire the nation's largest hospital chain. [ D1. ] Delta and Eastern were accused of deceptive scheduling at Atlanta's airport by the Transportation Department. [ A12. ] Lloyd's of London offered to pay about $77 million toward the liabilities of PCW Underwriting Agencies Ltd., hoping to put behind it a five-year-old scandal. [ D3. ] UAL shares climbed another $1.25, to $73.25, after soaring $6.25 Wednesday, as takeover speculation swirled. [ D3. ] Morton Thiokol wants records about an F.B.I. investigation of its affairs. The Justice Department, which is deciding whether to prosecute a fraud case against Thiokol, the maker of the space shuttle booster, has refused to release the material. [ D9. ] THE ECONOMY The House approved a $1 trillion budget plan, challenging President Reagan by raising taxes and cutting his Pentagon budget. Democrats joined to pass the plan, which was approved 230 to 192, with no Republican support. [ A1. ] A former Federal banker was accused of leaking information about interest rates to a brokerage firm. The accusations against Robert A. Rough, a former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, were made in Federal court in a securities fraud case. No charges have been filed against Mr. Rough. [ D1. ] Insider-trading indictments against three Wall Street traders were handed up. The three - the director of arbitrage at Goldman, Sachs; the head of arbitrage at Kidder, Peabody, and a former trader there - were arrested in February. [ D1. ] General retailers reported sales were mixed in March. Store owners and analysts blamed bad weather and a late Easter. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A real U.S. commitment to trying to stabilize the dollar has emerged from the latest meeting of industrial nations. After their Paris meeting in February, Secretary Baker seemed ambivalent about bolstering the currency. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Investors in Texaco face some tough choices, with prospects for a bankruptcy filing or a settlement payment of $3 billion or more to the Pennzoil Company looming larger. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Italian Premier Resigns
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi resigned tonight, a move widely expected after Christian Democratic ministers withdrew from his Cabinet on Wednesday. Mr. Craxi handed his resignation to President Francesco Cossiga after a debate in the Chamber of Deputies. Mr. Cossiga is expected to appoint an interim government to administer affairs until early elections can be held, probably in June.

title: 17 AT COLOMBIAN AIRLINE ACCUSED OF LARGE-SCALE MONEY SMUGGLING
description: A scheme that used Avianca Airlines flight engineers and flight attendants to transport illegally $10 million or more in United States currency to Colombia over a 15-month period has been broken up with the indictment of 17 employees of the airline, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: THE DANCE: EUROBALLET AT THE RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: UNPRETENTIOUSNESS may not be one of the great attributes of art. But there is a lot to be said for the quality, which seems in rather short supply these days in the increasingly solemn world of dance. The Euroballet Theater, which breezed into the Theater of the Riverside Church on Wednesday night, had adept technique and good-looking dancers going for it. But its happiest feature was a lack of pretension that made the evening seem like a delightful party.

title: LEGISLATURE BARS EMPLOYEES FROM SOME POLITICAL WORK
description: New York lawmakers, under pressure to respond to allegations of payroll abuses in the Legislature, today approved a resolution to prohibit legislative employees from working full time on political campaigns. However, the resolution confirmed the right of those employees to do political work on a part-time basis.

title: Massachusetts Agency In America's Cup Role
description: Mullen Advertising of Beverly Farms, Mass., has been named the core ad agency to prepare for the next America's Cup competition, in 1991.

title: UAL Is Silent As Stock Rises
description: The price of UAL Inc. shares, which soared $6.25 Wednesday, climbed $1.25 yesterday, to $73.25, on reports that Coniston Partners of New York, a money manager, was a major buyer. Coniston would not comment.

title: CAR FOUND WHERE BRIDGE FELL
description: Divers searching Schoharie Creek today found a car crushed under a concrete slab from the bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that collapsed Sunday.

title: NIEKRO, CARLTON WIN AS TEAM
description: Cory Snyder hit a first-inning grand slam, and Steve Carlton recorded his first save since 1967 and the second of his career as the Cleveland Indians routted the Toronto Blue Jays, 14-3, today.

title: Bankers Trust Deposit Notes
description: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 7 percent deposit notes due in 1989 at a price of par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Financial Corp. Assigned Adviser
description: The Financial Corporation of America confirmed that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. as a financial adviser to find new capital for the company and its major unit, the American Savings and Loan Association.

title: GOLDEN PALOMINOS
description: The Golden Palominos, led by Anton Fier on drums and featuring Syd Straw and Michael Sweet on vocals, Bernie Worrell on keyboards and Jody Harris on guitar, will perform tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Rude Buddha will open at 11 P.M., followed by Richard Lloyd at midnight and the Golden Palominos about 1 A.M. Tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 tomorrow.

title: FINANCIAL NEWS NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SUNTRUST BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter results reflect the acquisition of Third National Corp., which was completed Dec. 29, 1986 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Britain's ''Allo, 'Allo,' A New Comedy Series
description: '' 'Allo, 'Allo'' is not Noel Coward; actually, it is less subtle than Benny Hill. Undeniably, however, it is British, the kind of series that the British seem able to mass-produce. Bathroom jokes are in abundance, along with mugging and grimaces. You thought British television was ever so tasteful? '' 'Allo, 'Allo,'' which takes place in Occupied France, uses a homosexual Gestapo man as a running gag.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,820,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Dollar Tumbles Again in Tokyo
description: The dollar continued to plunge in Tokyo this morning, hitting a low of 142.90 yen before rallying slightly to close morning trading at 143.15 yen.

title: GRETZKY BREAKS MARK, SO DO OILERS, 13-3
description: Wayne Gretzky and the Edmonton Oilers set playoff scoring marks tonight in a 13-3 victory that evened their Smythe Division semifinal series against the Los Angeles Kings at one game apiece.

title: Richardson Drafted
description: ''Who am I to be judgmental of Micheal?'' said Coach Dean Meminger of the Long Island Knights after making Micheal Ray Richardson his first-round pick in the United States Basketball League draft Wednesday. ''We all have skeletons in the closet. Being a former member of that player's fraternity, maybe I'm a little more willing to give him one more chance.''

title: Sue Zelda Brown Wed To Gary D. Onishenko
description: Sue Zelda Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Brown of Oceanside, L.I., and Gary Dale Onishenko, the son of Victor Onishenko of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, and the late Mrs. Onishenko, were married yesterday. Rabbis Irving J. Block and Judah Nadich officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: U.S., THIOKOL AT ODDS ON F.B.I. DATA
description: The Justice Department is fighting an effort by Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the space shuttle's solid-rocket boosters, to obtain records about a criminal investigation of the company being conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to court documents.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
President Resigning At Lord & Taylor Chain
description: Harold Leppo, the president of Lord & Taylor, is resigning after 10 years with the retail fashion chain.

title: PRESIDENT OF MEXICO PROMISES TO PROTECT ANCIENT MAYAN SITES
description: President Miguel de la Madrid has promised that any dam built along the Mexican-Guatemalan border ''would have to preclude damage to our archeological sites and to ecological conditions on both sides of the frontier.''

title: Redeeming a Promise
description: Belatedly, New York City and State officials are beginning to make good on a decade of broken promises to the mentally ill.

title: Demjanjuk, Breaking Silence, Questions a Witness at Trial
description: John Demjanjuk broke his silence today for the second time in his eight-week trial on charges of being a Nazi war criminal, to cross-examine a West German historian, Wolfgang Scheffler, about an identification card issued at a Nazi training camp for death camp guards.

title: BROADWAY
description: WILL wonders never cease! Another American musical in the works and apparently a lot further along than the ''planned'' and ''hoped for'' stage. This one is called ''Teddy and Alice,'' and if a little bell rings, it's because some time ago, it was a ''hoped for'' that never happened.

title: FEWER YOUTHS IN SOVIET THAN IN U.S. SAID TO FEAR ATOM WAR
description: Russian teen-agers fear a nuclear war much less than American teenagers do, according to a survey conducted last fall by poll takers in both countries.

title: CLUBS AND GREENS ELUSIVE FOR COOK
description: John Cook lost all of his golf clubs as well as his golf bag during a flight from Tampa, Fla., to New Orleans on March 17. He arrived at the New Orleans airport, as did his other baggage, but his clubs still haven't turned up.

title: Jets Sign Johnson
description: Only a few years ago, the Jets were known as a team that never wanted other teams' veterans. But yesterday, the Jets continued departing from type when they signed Richard Johnson, the career leader in receptions for the United States Football League, which has suspended play the last two years. Last week the Jets signed three former regulars on N.F.L. clubs - Jay Brophy, Miami linebacker; Randy Clark, St. Louis center, and Bob Hamm, Kansas City and Houston defensive end.

title: CENTRAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,222,000, or 16 cents a share, from the reversion of a retirement plan. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 split paid Jan. 6, 1987.

title: FILM: SHELLEY, BYRON AND FRIENDS, IN 'GOTHIC'
description: DURING the summer of 1816, while he was in residence in a villa on the Swiss shore of Lake Geneva, Lord Byron, then 28, was host to his fellow poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, 24; Mary Godwin, Shelley's 19-year-old mistress, whom he later married; Mary's stepsister, Claire Clairmont, 18, who was pregnant with Byron's child, and John William Polidori, Byron's doctor and friend, who was 21.

title: U.S. Concern Over the Dollar
description: FINANCIAL markets have had their eyes trained all week on the meetings in Washington of the major industrial countries and the policy-making bodies of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in an effort to see what they mean for the future of the dollar, interest rates and security or insecurity of world debt.

title: On Campaigns
description: The Presidential campaigns of two House leaders, one Republican and one Democrat, have touched off campaigns to succeed them in their leadership posts.

title: PROBLEMS WITH SOVIET SPACECRAFT
description: The Soviet Union's new Kvant space module failed today to link up completely in a second docking attempt with the manned space station Mir, and Soviet scientists were deciding whether the mission could be saved.

title: ART: WHITNEY BIENNIAL'S NEW LOOK
description: FEAR not the 1987 Whitney Biennial. Instead of the rowdy installations of TODT and Group Material, we now have the Conceptual precision of Joseph Kosuth. Instead of the pop figures of Kenny Scharf - remember him? -running amok over telephone booths and restrooms, we now have a sober, earth-colored, abstract mural of Sol LeWitt in the basement. Stung by savage criticism of the last Biennial, and convinced that contemporary art is in a very different place than it was two years ago, the Whitney has assembled a very different show. It is self-consciously serious, often illuminating, predictably uneven and unusually tame. It is also indispensable.

title: European Airlines Busy
description: The Association of European Airlines said today that passenger traffic in February increased 11 percent from a year earlier. A revival continued on the North Atlantic route, where passenger traffic grew 16 percent.

title: Key Streets Reopened To Brooklyn Bridge
description: Most of the key Manhattan streets leading to and from the Brooklyn Bridge were reopened last night, two days after falling masonry from the top of the Municipal Building had forced their closing.

title: New Play by Howard Fast
description: The premiere of ''Triptych,'' a new play by Howard Fast, will be performed at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, tonight at 7:30. The play will be performed only once. Mr. Fast is to introduce the play and read some of the poetry of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel Prize-winning author. The cathedral is at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Admission is free.

title: WEINBERGER LETTER ON ALLIES' ROLE IN SPACE STATION STIRS FUROR
description: A letter written by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger earlier this week about the Pentagon's plans for possible military uses of the proposed space station prompted a string of protests today, along with warnings that American allies might be forced to drop their participation in the project.

title: Argentina Faults Banks
description: Argentina's Economy Minister, Juan Sourrouille, said today that the ''narrow interest'' of creditor banks was holding up an accord to stretch out debt repayments. He warned Argentina might break off negotiations.

title: New Push by Teheran Reported in Gulf War
description: Iran began an offensive north of Baghdad today while its forces made major advances on the southern front of the Persian Gulf war, capturing an important defense line east of Basra.

title: Philippine Peace Talks Suspended After Clash
description: Government negotiators announced the indefinite suspension of peace talks with Moslem rebels today after a reported firefight earlier this week.

title: SCARFO INDICTED IN '78 SLAYING OF JERSEY JUDGE
description: Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed boss of a Philadelphia-based organized-crime family, and an associate have been indicted for the 1978 killing of a municipal court judge in New Jersey, state officials said today.

title: MAX J. ETRA
description: Max J. Etra, a lawyer and philanthropist, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: A Demolition For the Derby
description: There are plenty of ways to lose the Kentucky Derby, but owners have naturally always cherished those that excuse defeat without diminishing their own opinion of their 3-year-olds: the supposedly hard and cuppy Churchill Downs track, the traffic problems caused by the huge fields, the distractions posed by 100,000 noisy spectators. One old favorite, though, will no longer be handy when the Derby is run for the 113th time three weeks from tomorrow. The Louisville paddock, long among the more legitimate sources of concern, has been leveled and replaced with a new one that will leave little room for complaint.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: KEN RUSSELL'S ''Gothic'' (review on page C16) is a horror story with phantoms that might have sprung from the opium-clouded half-crazed minds of a group of 19th-century British writers, including two of England's greatest poets, Percy Bysshe Shelley and Lord Byron. Ken Russell, another English artist, has tried to re-create on film a stormy night in Lord Byron's mansion in Switzerland, in which a group of friends starts to tell one another ghost stories and then decides to create a ghost - each concentrating on bringing his worst fear to life. The participants were Shelley; his future wife, Mary Godwin; her stepsister Claire Clairmont; Lord Byron, and Byron's doctor, John William Polidori.

title: CALIFANO IS WILLING LEAVE PANEL TO SETTLE EHTICS DISPUTE IN ALBANY
description: Clearing the way for a compromise on the most contentious issue of this legislative session, Joseph A. Califano Jr. said today that he would be willing to step down as chairman of a commission appointed by the Governor to investigate possible unethical conduct in New York government.

title: Soft Landing for the Dollar. So Far.
description: Just 15 months ago, policy makers in the industrial countries were scrounging for ways to let the air out of the high-flying dollar without provoking a crash. Against the odds, they've managed the soft landing they hoped for. The dollar, which sagged again yesterday, has now lost more than a third of its exchange value without inducing panic.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RACIAL TENSIONS PERSIST IN CROWN HEIGHTS
description: About 1:30 A.M. on Feb. 26, someone placed a cardboard orange-juice box and a can containing petroleum in the basement of Willie Mae Reddish's house in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn and set them afire, according to the police.

title: Doner Gets 'Good Guys' For Pride in America
description: Although W. B. Doner & Company is frequently involved in doing public service advertising in Baltimore and Detroit, where its two offices are situated, it has not until now done an Advertising Council campaign.

title: Scouting Report
description: Dick Vitale, the TV analyst, when drafted as a territorial pick by the Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League: ''I can't play a lick, but I can talk a good game.''

title: FILM: 'THREE FOR THE ROAD'
description: ''THREE FOR THE ROAD,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters, has no fewer beer cans or car chases or know-nothing jokes than the usual teen-age adventure-comedy. But it does have a lot less personality than most, which is peculiar. The director, B. W. L. Norton, and the writers, Richard Martini, Tim Metcalfe and Miguel Tejada-Flores, display no idea whatsoever of how to keep a film moving or how to hold an audience's interest. Listlessness and sloppiness on this scale are truly depressing.

title: Shots Wound Member Of a Chinatown Gang
description: A member of a Chinatown gang whose sister was kidnapped and killed last year was shot on a crowded street in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the police said. A 6-year-old girl was also wounded.

title: Five Writers Nominated For the PEN/Faulkner
description: Five writers have been nominated for the seventh annual PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, for the best novels or short story collections published in the United States the previous year.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of Shawmut Home Bank, of Meriden, Conn., and Fidelity Trust Co., of Stamford, Conn., which have been accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''MY grandfather was once discovered looking at roses by bending over to see them through his legs,'' Sir Adam Courtauld Butler recalled. ''He said that when the blood rushes to your head, the colors seem so much brighter.''

title: Leave Set for Boston U. Head
description: John Silber, president of Boston University since 1971, will begin a six-month leave of absence on July 1, ''in order to read and study and to examine and address the wide range of public issues that will affect higher education and the society at large in the next decade,'' the university announced today. Dr. Silber said he would use the time ''to think, read and write'' about such problems as AIDS, American economic competitiveness and the problems of the poor. The provost, Jon Westling, will serve as president in his absence.

title: Assessing Intelligence Breaches
description: He shuns the word ''vindication'' and is too much the patrician to say, ''I told you so,'' but James J. Angleton, who directed United States counterespionage efforts for two decades, is mightily stirred by the latest disclosures of breaches in the defenses of American intelligence operations.

title: PAN AM PILOT AVOIDS COLLISION WITH CARGO JET
description: The pilot of a Pan Am Express turboprop airliner took sharp evasive action Wednesday to avoid hitting a four-engine military cargo jet near McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, officials said yesterday.

title: Article 325687 -- No Title
description: The nation's biggest hospital chain, the Hospital Corporation of America, said yesterday that it had received a proposal to buy the company for $3.8 billion in cash.

title: BAKER ASKS 3D WORLD DEBT ACTION
description: Saying there were no quick fixes for the third-world debt problem, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d called on commercial banks today to develop a ''menu of alternative new money options'' to assure continued financing for poorer countries.

title: Ford Workers End Strike in Mexico
description: Striking workers at the Ford Motor Company plant in Hermosillo said they would return to work Friday, ending a 40-day strike over wages that interrupted production of 1987 Mercury Tracers.

title: A LOOK AT TWO KINDS OF MUSIC ON 13
description: IN unusual combinations of the new and the traditional, Channel 13 is offering two first-rate music essays this weekend. Contemporary ''experimental'' music is the subject of a rather old-fashioned documentary entitled ''Steve Reich: A New Musical Language'' (tonight at 9), and classical music is explored by the video artist Juan Downey in ''J. S. Bach'' (Sunday at 11 P.M.).

title: JUSTICE DEPT. CHANGES STANCE ON SPECIAL PROSECUTOR ETHICS
description: The Justice Department today announced a compromise in which it would permit special prosecutors to continue representing their old clients before the department but would regard it as a violation of ethics laws for the lawyers to take on new cases related to the department after today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TWO LIVES AND A DREAM. By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Walter Kaiser in collaboration with the author. 245 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: BANKS OF MID-AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter.

title: Presidential Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Mineta: 'Divest'
description: Representative Norman Y. Mineta, Democrat of California, is one of six Congressional members of the Smithsonian Institution's board of regents, its governing body. It was in that position that he suggested in 1985 that the regents sell all Smithsonian holdings in companies that do business in South Africa, saying that an institution so closely associated with the American people should not even appear to support South Africa's repressive racial policies.

title: Three Newark Teen-Agers Die When Stolen Car Hits a Tree
description: Three teen-agers were killed when the stolen car in which they were riding hurtled into a tree and was cut in half, the police said today.

title: 'POLICE ACADEMY 4' FIRST IN BOX-OFFICE SALES
description: ''Police Academy 4'' sold $8.5 million in tickets during its first weekend of release to take top spot at the box office for the week.

title: Fund Assets Increase
description: Assets of the nation's 383 money market mutual funds increased $1.39 billion, to $236.77 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds rose $481.8 million, to $65.65 billion; the 197 general purpose funds rose $625.5 million, to $63.80 billion, and the 93 broker-dealer funds rose $285.3 million, to $107.31 billion.

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SPORTSWEAR: A MORE FORMAL SLANT FOR FALL
description: Sportswear, that typically American fashion form, dominated the fall openings yesterday and it was clear that sable and sequins are part of the casual scene. There are plenty of blazers, and at most houses it is still possible to find trousers. But the new formality that suffuses fashion means that fur hats, cashmere, elegant leather jackets and skirts, and plenty of glitter at night have become an integral part of the sportswear field.

title: Seoul Backs Conditional Overtures to North
description: A senior Foreign Ministry official said today that South Korea endorsed recent conditional overtures made to North Korea by the United States, but he expressed doubt that the American moves would yield positive results.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT'S an unlikely restaurant in an unlikely location. C. J. Blanda, a friendly and fastidious little spot done in natural wood and earth tones, clings to the eastern fringe of Chelsea along commercial Seventh Avenue at 22d Street. The remarkably inexpensive menu carries seven rustic pastas, a half-dozen meat and poultry entrees and a smattering of appetizers and desserts. The limited wine list is budget priced, too. The cooking can be a little heavy handed at times, as in the cappellini in a colorful sauce combining sun-dried tomatoes, capers, artichokes, garlic, pine nuts and olives - a surfeit of olives threw it off balance ($10.95). Soothing penne in a tomato and shallot sauce spiked with vodka was better ($8.95). A cursory sampling of the menu was enough to reveal, however, that the staff is earnest and eager to please. Add to this the delightfully relaxing ambiance and you have a special little corner worth noting when you are in the neighborhood. C. J. Blanca, 209 Seventh Avenue, is open from noon to midnight daily except Saturday, when dinner is served from 5 P.M. to midnight (206-7880). $ ? * * *

title: Dining Out Guide: Connecticut
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: A Guest at Plaza Hotel Is Raped in Her Suite
description: A 29-year-old woman was raped at gunpoint in her bed at the Plaza Hotel Wednesday night by a masked man who followed her into her suite and robbed her of more than $150, the police said yesterday.

title: Market Place; The Prospects For Texaco
description: WITH prospects for a bankruptcy filing looming, investors in Texaco Inc. could be facing very rough seas ahead, according to some analysts.

title: Physician Refuses to Cut Off Patient From Feeding Tubes
description: A doctor has refused to obey a court order to cut off a 92-year-old semicomatose woman from the feeding tubes that are keeping her alive, saying it violates his professional beliefs and Jewish faith.

title: Canadian Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus soared to its highest level in more than five months in February, fueled by record automobile exports, Statistics Canada said today. The surplus with the rest of the world rose to $1.25 billion Canadian (about $950 million United States), from an revised surplus of $623 million ($474 million) in January and $189 million ($144 million) in February last year. The Government agency said automotive product exports jumped 23 percent, to a record $3.2 billion ($2.4 billion) in February.

title: TREASURIES TOP 8%, A 13-MONTH HIGH
description: Treasury bond yields rose above 8 percent yesterday for the first time in 13 months, as renewed weakness in the dollar created consternation throughout the credit markets.

title: Bess Myerson and the Public Trust
description: Mayor Koch, who has been criticized for insensitivity, now finds himself charged with softness. He allowed Bess Myerson, an old acquaintance and a political colleague, to resign as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, instead of dismissing her peremptorily before receiving a report on her conduct from former Federal Judge Harold Tyler. The Mayor acted properly. In allowing her to resign, he neither excused her performance nor hid his disappointment in it.

title: BUREAUCRACY QUELLS SHOPKEEPER'S SPIRIT
description: For nearly three decades, Gershon Mamlak has been dodging the bulldozers of urban renewal. An upholsterer and furniture maker, Mr. Mamlak has been forced to move his business three times since 1958 -each time, stores he was renting were condemned to make way for progress.

title: 2 AIRLINES ACCUSED OF 'UNREALISTIC' SCHEDULING
description: The Department of Transportation accused two airlines today of deceptive scheduling at the Atlanta airport and said it was expanding its investigation of airline scheduling practices to three other major airports.

title: HOUSE APPROVES BUDGET FOR 1988 WITH MORE TAXES
description: The House of Representatives today approved a trillion-dollar budget that challenges President Reagan by raising taxes and cutting his Pentagon budget.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it placed $140 million of Brazilian loans and $9 million of Ecuadorian loans on nonaccrual status; it reduced first quarter net by $1.7 million and would reduce full year 1987 earnings by $6.9 million if those loans remain on nonaccrual.

title: Caustic Fumes Send 59 People to Hospital
description: An overheated experiment at a chemical plant spewed caustic fumes into the air in southern Westchester County today and 59 people were sent to the hospital for treatment, officials said.

title: PONCE FEDERAL BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Include gains on sale of securities of $1,755,137 for the latest quarter and $3,001,222 for the year-ago period.

title: TWO YOUNG MODERN-DANCE MASTERS
description: Cydney Wilkes and Nelson Zayas have struck out on their own and made names for themselves as promising modern-dance choreographers of a new generation. They share a program at the Kitchen this weekend, tonight through Sunday, with each contributing a new work that takes human interaction as its departure point. But there the similarity ends. Talking of his young life in dance between rehearsals at the Kitchen one recent afternoon, Mr. Zayas shifted excitedly in his chair, words tumbling out and his huge, dark eyes flashing. Ms. Wilkes has all the mysterious serenity of a Mona Lisa, speaking contemplatively in the measured, private way in which she dances.

title: Let's Dig One Nuclear-Waste Grave at a Time
description: To the Editor:

title: ICE WATER IN THE VEINS
description: Al Campanis is an honorable man, so are all the white baseball club owners and executives, all honorable men.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $416,000 from the early retirement of debt. c-After pre-tax gains from sales of loans and securities of $51.8 million for the latest quarter and $41.1 million for the year-earlier period.

title: Top Marine Promises Action In Espionage Case in Soviet
description: The commandant of the Marines today promised corrective action ''regardless of the consequences'' in the case of four former Marine guards at the American Embassy in Moscow who have been arrested on suspicion of espionage or improper contacts with Russians.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF REPORTEDLY TOLD MEESE TO QUIT INQUIRY
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, urged Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to disqualify himself from the investigation of the Iran-contra affair last November, according to Administration officials.

title: WASHINGTON BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share earnings for year-ago quarter are restated to reflect the year-end 1986 merger of Washington Bancorp and its majority stockholder, Colson Inc.

title: Ammirati's Wreck of 2 BMW's
description: IT makes for a rather expensive TV commercial if in the process two $48,000 BMW's are intentionally destroyed. But Ammirati & Puris knew what it was doing and, besides, the client didn't mind.

title: THYSSEN ART MAY FIND MADRID HOME
description: One of the world's most extensive and valuable privately owned art collections, the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, could end up permanently in Madrid's Museo del Prado.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 1987
description: International The dollar plunged to new lows against the yen after comments by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d that traders interpreted as an endorsement of further declines against the Japanese currency. Page A1

title: SIMON TO DECLARE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDACY IN MAY
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois today announced his intention to enter the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, presenting himself as a candidate rooted in the party's ''traditional values.''

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes equity in net earnings of affiliated companies of $12.1 million for the latest quarter and $4.6 million for the year-ago period, and losses from minority interests in net earnings of subsidiaries of $100,000 and $700,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Giving Richard Perle More Than His Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Investment Group Buys Robins Stake
description: An investment group led by the New York financier Michael H. Steinhardt has purchased a 5.5 percent stake in the A.H. Robins Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Steinhardt said that he had bought the shares for investment purposes only.

title: Feedback Plan Would Reinforce Warnings on Children at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: DOLLAR'S DECLINE OVERCOMES BUYING BY CENTRAL BANKS
description: The dollar slid again today even though central banks were buying dollars and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d offered his assurances that the United States and other countries were ''fully committed'' to stabilizing currencies.

title: Pity College Admissions Officers
description: LEAD: Every April, we read about the excruciating tensions that high school seniors experience as they await news from the colleges of their choice. We see photographs of students pacing anxiously by letterboxes. They peer down their streets for the mailmen. They pray for fat envelopes.

title: HOLLYWOOD BRACES FOR DIRECTORS' STRIKE
description: On May 4, two movies will go into production. They may be the last Hollywood makes for a long time.

title: Company Returns To Wharton Name
description: Just 10 days ago, Wharton Econometrics agreed to merge with Chase Econometrics, forming a company that was to be called WEFA-CEIS. But the two companies, which are among the nation's leading economic forecasting and consulting concerns, acknowledged yesterday that the new name was a bit unwieldy. Lawrence Chimerine, Wharton's chairman and chief executive, said the merged company would be known instead as Wharton Economics.

title: WOMAN IS TO HEAD EDITORS' SOCIETY
description: Katherine W. Fanning, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, today became the first woman to be named president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, a 65-year-old organization whose members include editors of the largest daily papers in the United States.

title: DIME SAVINGS-WALLINGFORD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings for the year- ago period are not available because the bank went public in July 1986.

title: CLIFFORD FITZGERALD, 83, ADVERTISING EXECUTIVE
description: Clifford L. Fitzgerald, for many years one of Manhattan's most prominent advertising agency executives, died Thursday at his home in Thomasville, Ga. He was 83 years old and also lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter excludes results for Fidelity National Bank of Baton Rouge and Southwest National Bank of Lafayette, acquired later in 1986.

title: SOIL EROSION PLAN IS AMENDED
description: The House on Thursday unanimously approved a compromise designed to exempt alfalfa farmers from certain provisions of the nation's soil erosion program.

title: WARHOL RECEIVED INADEQUATE CARE IN HOSPITAL, HEALTH BOARD ASSERTS
description: The New York State Health Department charged yesterday that Andy Warhol was given inadequate care by New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center from his admission to near the time of his death two days later after gall bladder surgery.

title: HERITAGE FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.M. Gives Details Of Repurchase Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to use $1 billion in dividends from its finance subsidiary, a $900 million tax refund and deferred tax payments to generate more than $2 billion this year to fund its stock repurchase program.

title: FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK OF PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company's former name was Bayamon Federal Savings & Loan of Puerto Rico.

title: A 'CAKE' MINUS THE CALORIES
description: Someone has finally made the dream of every calorie-counter come true. Now you can have your birthday cake and eat it, too. Last week I was introduced to a ''cake'' that contained no sugar, no artificial sweetener, no flour, no cream and no butter. It was beautiful and, of course, low in calories, and it was made entirely of fruit. But obviously this is not the kind of fruitcake you keep from Christmas to Christmas, hoping that someone will take it off your hands.

title: FIRST CHICAGO UP; MELLON LOSS
description: LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its net income increased 3.2 percent in the first quarter, while the Mellon Bank Corporation posted its first quarterly loss ever.

title: DERBY CANDIDATES MAY COME UP SHORT
description: Is there a finisher in the house?

title: TRANS FINANCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $169,000 resulting from pension plan revisions.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
10 REPUTED MOBSTERS ARE INDICTED IN PHILADELPHIA IN 1984 SLAYING
description: Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed boss of an organized crime group, and nine associates have been charged with the 1984 murder of a young member of the crime syndicate, District Attorney Ronald D. Castille said today.

title: REAGAN ISSUES CHALLENGES TO MOSCOW
description: President Reagan challenged the Soviet Union today to establish a firm date this year for withdrawing troops from Afghanistan and to move ahead on reaching an agreement to eliminate most medium-range nuclear missiles.

title: BURR LEAVING TEXAS AIR
description: Donald C. Burr, who co-founded People Express and built it into a major carrier, is on his own again.

title: CAPITALS ADD TO BOSSY'S PAIN
description: The Islanders spent most of the tail end of the regular season wondering whether Mike Bossy's injured back would heal in time for the playoffs. Now, they are wondering whether his injured knee will keep him out of the rest of the playoff series with the Washington Capitals, which is tied at a game each.

title: BEENE AND KARAN REDEFINE TODAY'S LUXURY
description: Two weeks of fall fashion openings ended triumphantly yesterday morning as Geoffrey Beene and Donna Karan gave a new, modern interpretation to the idea of luxury in clothes. From Beene's gossamer gilded laces to Karan's cashmere and baby llama woolens, the fabrics formed the opulent base for clothes that wrapped the body in brilliance and warmth. Karan's generous use of stretch fabrics emphasized the trend to clothes that fit as snugly as swimsuits.

title: KEY RATES
COURT RESTORES BABY M VISITS BY WHITEHEAD
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that Mary Beth Whitehead could resume visits with Melissa Stern, the year-old girl who was the central figure in the landmark Baby M custody case.

title: Hospital Corp.'s Stock Jumps $3.50
description: Shares in the Hospital Corporation of America rose $3.50, to $41.625, in heavy New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday after the company received a $47-a-share takeover bid. The offer, valued at $3.8 billion, was from Charles R. Miller and Richard E. Ragsdale, two former officers of the Republic Health Corporation, and Richard L. Scott, a Dallas lawyer.

title: EVAUATING THE FALLING DOLLAR
description: The dollar - whose steep decline in the last few weeks has upset global markets and preoccupied the world's finance ministers - could fall still further, possibly 5 to 10 percent, a number of top United States economists and financial officers said in interviews yesterday.

title: MT BAKER BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect 4-for- 3 stock split paid Feb. 2.

title: Towle Accepts Bid
description: The Towle Manufacturing Company, a maker of silver and crystal tableware that filed under bankruptcy codes last year, agreed to be bought by the First Republic Corporation of America. Under the merger agreement, a wholly owned unit of First Republic will merge with Towle in exchange for newly issued shares of Towle common stock equal to 80 percent of Towle's then outstanding common stock, the companies said. On the New York Stock Exchange Towle's shares jumped $1, to $3.50.

title: 2 Chip Makers Report Improvement in Quarter
description: Two of the nation's largest chip makers reported today that results for the March quarter showed improvement, indicating a continuing turnaround in the semiconductor industry.

title:
PATENTS;
Inventors Honored
description: LEAD: Amar G. Bose and William R. Short, electrical engineers, received the Inventor of the Year Award this week from Intellectual Property Owners Inc. They shared $3,000 and were honored at a Washington reception for their invention of a loudspeaker system that they patented. Also honored as Distinguished Inventors were Abe Widra of Chicago, who has developed a synthetic skin, and Saul and Malon Kit, a father-and-son team in Texas who invented a vaccine against swine diseases.

title: Rise in Mexican Inflation
description: Inflation in Mexico grew at a rate of 23.6 percent in the first three months of 1987, the Government's central bank said today. The rate exceeds the 19 percent reported for the first three months of 1986, a year in which inflation grew a record 105.7 percent for the entire year. The Bank of Mexico figures indicated that the consumer price index had gone up 114 percent during the last 12 months.

title: Inquiry on Columbia Fight Stalls
description: The Police Department said yesterday that an investigation into a campus fight March 22 between black and white Columbia University students had reached an impasse because the black complainants had refused to be interviewed after making a written complaint.

title: '88 FOOTBALL SEASON CANCELED BY S.M.U.
description: Southern Methodist University, which has been barred from football this year because of repeated violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, announced today that it would not field a team in 1988 either.

title: Military Suspends Cargo Airline
description: The Military Airlift Command today temporarily suspended Southern Air Transport Inc. as a cargo hauler for the Pentagon pending a safety investigation after the fatal crash of a cargo plane earlier this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 11, 1987
description: International

title: LEVEL OF WORLD ARMS SALES TO IRAN REGARDED AS LARGELY UNCHANGED
description: Contrary to expectations, the disclosures of Washington's secret arms sales to Iran do not appear to have increased Teheran's ability to obtain military equipment from Western and Communist countries, according to American officials.

title: Mellon Gives $450,000 To the Folger Library
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation of New York has awarded $450,000 to the Folger Shakespeare Library to endow the position of curator of books.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 3 about new efforts to strengthen the New York City Department of Probation misidentified the handgun issued to officers. It is a .38-caliber revolver.

title: PLANS FOR DOMED STADIUM IN QUEENS IN DOUBT
description: New York's plans to build an 82,000-seat domed stadium in Queens are ''pretty much dead,'' and with them, the city's hopes of luring a professional football team back to New York, the head of the state's Urban Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: Earthquake Shakes Tokyo
description: An earthquake shook the Tokyo area today, rattling buildings and interrupting train lines, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Meteorological Agency officials said the quake measured 5.3 on the Richter scale.

title: Pledge by Richardson
description: Saying ''I'm finished with drugs,'' Micheal Ray Richardson signed a contract yesterday to play for the Long Island Knights of the United States Basketball League. Richardson, who was banned by the National Basketball Association because of drug use as a Nets player, will receive a $10,000 salary plus bonuses that could earn him $13,000 this season, according to the league's commissioner, Dan Meisenheimer. The season is from May 15 to July 19.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV TALK ON ARMS AND SOCIAL CHANGES
description: Following are excerpts from a speech here today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, as translated and distributed by the official Czechoslovak press agency:

title: To Cut Air Delays, Auction Peak Takeoff Slots; A Costly Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: N.B.A. 76ers 98, Bulls 96: Maurice Cheeks hit a foul-line jumper with two seconds remaining in overtime last night to defeat the visiting Bulls. Cheeks, sidelined since March 20 with a finger injury, scored the game-winning basket after Michael Jordan completed a 3-point play with 15 seconds remaining to tie at 96. Cliff Robinson led the 76ers with 22 points. (AP) Hawks 101, Pistons 99: Dominique Wilkins scored 22 points in the fourth quarter, including three free throws in the final eight seconds, for Atlanta, playing at home. The victory stretched Atlanta's lead over Detroit in the Central Division to four games. Each team has five games left. Wilkins finished with 35 points. Isiah Thomas of Detroit led all scorers with 36 points.(AP) Golf Okamoto Leads: The first-round leader, Ayako Okamoto, shot a two-under-par 70 to maintain a one-stroke edge after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association's Kyocera Inamori Classic in San Diego. Okamoto's 36-hole total of eight-under 136 was a shot better than Betsy King and Pat Bradley. (AP) Tennis McEnroe Gains Final: John McEnroe, serving almost flawlessly, scored a 7-6, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4 victory over Stefan Edberg in a semifinal of the World Championship Tennis tournament in Dallas last night. McEnroe, who took six months off last year, served 15 aces and lost his service once, but his toughness on big points won the match. There were only three service breaks, and the biggest came in the fourth set's seventh game with McEnroe breaking at love. Edberg missed a simple volley to fall behind, 4-3. The players held serve and in the sixth game, McEnroe, serving for the match, lost the first point but took the next four to wrap it up. After Edberg congratulated him, McEnroe walked raised his index finger in a No. 1 sign. The crowd of 14,000 gave him a standing ovation.(AP) Bowling Floridian Leads: Tom Crites of Tampa, Fla., won seven of eight match games for the second straight round to take a 42-pin lead in the $150,000 Showboat Atlantic City Open. Crites won his first seven games of the day and led with a pinfall of 7,646, after five rounds. Mike Edwards of Tulsa had the second-best matchplay record at 12-4 and was second with 7,604. The fourth-round leader, Amleto Monacelli of Venezuela, had the high average with 216. But he split his 16 matches and was third with 7,593.(AP)

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results included the earnings of Bethesda Bancorp, acquired April 1, 1986, and accounted for under the purchase method. Also included were the results of People's Bank of Chesapeake, acquired Jan. 21, 1987, and accounted for under the pooling of interests method. Results for 1986 have been restated for this acquisition. Securities gains totaled $1.5 million in the latest quarter, compared with year-ago period when no securities gains or losses were taken.

title: EMBASSY IN MOSCOW: A FUROR GROWS
description: In other circumstances, Secretary of State George P. Shultz's departure for Moscow this weekend for talks on arms control might have evoked strong expectations of a fresh start on improving Soviet-United States relations.

title: COMMUNITY BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1986 per share earnings reflect the 2-for-1 stock split paid May 15, 1986.

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AS SHORTAGES PLAGUE LIBYA, HOPE FOR IMPROVEMENT FADES
description: At a fruit and vegetable stall in the central market here this morning, garlic plants were sold by the armful, with some customers buying what seemed enough for months of cooking.

title: HINCKLEY ESCAPE PLAN DISCLOSED
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. wrote a letter discussing plans to escape from the mental hospital where he has been held since 1982 for shooting President Reagan, a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: ULTRA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $3,978,000, or 30 cents a share, due to an accounting change.

title: MUSIC: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG
description: We have become fascinated by the mechanics of sheer force. In our new machines, in sports, in our high-speed, high-volume Broadway shows, power is neither brute nor random -instead it is incisive, efficient, cleverly organized and devastatingly effective.

title: Escape and Memory
description: FAST LANES. By Jayne Anne Phillips. 148 pages. E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: GLITTER AND BOUQUETS: 'TURANDOT' CLOSES AT THE MET
description: It was a night of unadulterated star power, operatic and otherwise, that had veterans of the Metropolitan Opera shaking their heads to remember the like.

title: Ex-Fed Official Is Subpoenaed
description: Robert A. Rough, a former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who has been accused of leaking sensitive interest-rate information, has been subpoenaed in a civil action brought by the trustee of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., a defunct government securities firm.

title: FRANCE APPROVES ARMS PLAN LINKED TO EUROPEAN ALLIES
description: Parliament overwhelmingly approved a major five-year rearmament program Thursday night.

title: 3 Bullet Holes in Meter Blamed for Gas Leak
description: Three bullet holes caused a gas leak in the gas meter of the South Bronx grocery store where six people died in an explosion Wednesday, police investigators said yesterday.

title: FERRER SEEN AS CHOICE IN THE BRONX
description: New York City Councilman Fernando Ferrer has been selected by a majority of his Bronx colleagues to be the next Bronx borough president, Democratic public and party officials said yesterday.

title: Pronounced Problems
description: If New York is such a sophisticated, cosmopolitan city, how come its citizens have such a hard time with foreign words and names - French, Dutch, even Middle Western American?

title: ARMS HOPES RAISED IN REAGAN'S TALK AND GORBACHEV'S
description: With high-level Soviet-American talks imminent, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave speeches today expressing hope for agreement soon on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: TV: 'EYE ON DANCE' FEATURES LOIE FULLER
description: TERE O'CONNOR'S ''In and Around Your House,'' presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, starts out very promisingly. The visual imagery is exquisite as three young women and two young men cross and recross an eloquently lighted stage. The women wear loose white dresses and pale green pinafores, their hair tied back in buns, and the men are dressed in loose white shirts and green breeches. They loop lusciously in little rooted slivers of stylized dance.

title:
PATENTS;
Chemical Is Used To Dissolve Gallstones
description: LEAD: A method and apparatus for dissolving gallstones and removing them from the body were patented this week by Dr. Johnson L. Thistle and Patrick E. Caskey of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. An industrial chemical is pumped into the body and guided through the liver into the gallbladder.

title: PRODUCER PRICES ADVANCE 0.4%
description: A key Government price gauge rose broadly in March, tending to confirm expectations that inflation is returning to at least the 4 percent level that prevailed before last year's sharp drop in oil prices.

title: Pacifism Pays Off, Rangers Discover
description: On the first night, the Flyers came at them with their sticks high and their fists ready. The Rangers turned away, and they won.

title: School Reinstates Girl Who Wore a Swimsuit
description: A teen-age homecoming queen who was expelled from a church school for modeling swimsuits can keep her title and go on working when she returns to school under a settlement reached today.

title: GEORGIA TOWN TO CELEBRATE MANDATORY FIREARMS
description: Five years ago officials in this small Georgia town decided it was time they took a strong stand on gun control.

title: To Cut Air Delays, Auction Peak Takeoff Slots
description: To the Editor:

title: JURY SPLITS VERDICT IN TRIAL OF EX-CHIEF OF NEW YORK'S TAXIS
description: Jay L. Turoff, the former chief of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, was cleared last night of using his office to enrich himself by promoting a taxi meter company formed by his friends and of accepting a bribe.

title: Our Immigration Law Undercuts Duarte
description: LEAD: The new immigration law, which was passed by Congress last year and will go into effect fully next month, has created a troubling situation for the Government of El Salvador and its supporters in the Reagan Administration.

title: GORE ANNOUNCES PLAN TO DECLARE FOR THE PRESIDENCY LATER IN SPRING
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee today announced plans to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination, saying he believed he could offer ''clearer goals'' for the nation than could other candidates.

title: Maxwell to Buy Parade Printer
description: The Maxwell Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the printing facilities of the Diversified Printing Corporation, a subsidiary of Parade Publications Inc., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Spanish Strikes Snarl Transportion System
description: Strikers protesting a Government pay plan paralyzed state-run transportation and curtailed the national health service today.

title: Enrico Caruso Jr., 82; Actor and Son of Tenor
description: Enrico Caruso Jr., an actor, singer and the last surviving son of the great tenor, died after suffering a heart attack Thursday at his home in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed to stockholders June 30, 1986.

title: PALMER'S CONSCIENCE
description: Shortly before high noon, just as the Masters leaders were beginning to go off the first tee, a gray-haired man in a green shirt turned to his bald friend in a white visor. ''Wonder how Ahnie's doin' out there,'' he said. ''Not bad,'' the other said. ''He had 38 for 9.'' ''That's better than the 83 he had yesterday.'' Some golfers wouldn't show up at Augusta National after an 83 in the first round of the Masters, but Arnold Palmer did. Never even occurred to him not to show up. Never even occurred to him that he had an excuse to withdraw: torn cartilage in his right knee, which will undergo arthroscopic surgery later this month. But at 8:37 yesterday morning, when the leaders were just waking up or sipping coffee, Arnold Palmer teed off.

title: DANCE: FROM TORONTO DANNY GROSSMAN TROUPE
description: The dynamism and cleverness evident in the Danny Grossman Dance Company, on view tonight and tomorrow afternoon at Davis Hall at City College (134th Street and Convent Avenue), should come as no surprise to those who remember Mr. Grossman in Paul Taylor's company.

title: 2 ARE CONVICTED IN THEFT OF ART AT WAREHOUSE
description: A London art dealer has been convicted of masterminding a burglary in a Queens warehouse last year to defraud his insurers of $18 million.

title: STANWYCK, DESPITE INJURY, ACCEPTS A FILM AWARD
description: Barbara Stanwyck managed to limp onto the stage to receive the 15th annual American Film Institute Life Achievement Award on Thursday night, having checked herself out of a hospital for a few hours.

title: BRIEFS
