description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, said it had received approval from the Florida Comptroller's Office to merge with Home Federal Bank of Florida, but the company said approval by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. was required before Home Federal Bank could be converted to a state-chartered bank.

title: BSD BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOLLAR'S FALL SPURS CRITICISM IN TOKYO
description: As the dollar fell to new lows against the yen today, there was sharp criticism here of the outcome of Wednesday's meeting of the seven major industrial democracies. The Minister of International Trade and Industry, Hajime Tamura, described the meeting of the Group of Seven as a ''national humiliation'' and called for measures to spur Japan's economy.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 45.

title: Apartheid Protest
description: Shortly before their opening match was to begin yesterday, three members of Spain's Davis Cup team were ordered by their Government to withdraw from a four-nation tournament in Johannesburg. Emilio Sanchez, Sergio Casal and Thomas Carbonell had been scheduled to play against Paraguay before South Africa played Israel today in first-round matches of the Standard Bank Cup tournament.

title: Investment With a Conscience Pays Off
description: To the Editor:

title: PEOPLES BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter results include Mid-South Bancshares, acquired in December 1986.

title:
PATENTS;
A Method to Improve Interferon Production
description: LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week for a method of improving the yield of proteins produced by cultivating bacteria. Patent 4,656,132 was granted to Arie Ben-Bassat and two other staff scientists.

title: AIDS Will Transform the '88 Campaign
description: LEAD: In the early stages of the 1988 Presidential campaign, the announced and prospective candidates have focused their attention on trade policy, the deficit, arms control and the Iran-contra scandal. But another issue is destined to supplant these in importance and to transform the political debate. That issue is AI

title: FIRST NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HERBERT A. GOLD
description: Herbert A. Gold, the founder and president of Jayme Products, a developer and supplier of premiums and promotional merchandise to major marketing companies, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These people are traitors. Execute them. They're not fit to live. We've got to quit being so chicken-hearted.'' - Senator Robert C. Byrd, on Americans convicted of espionage. [ 5:5. ]

title: Coetzee, Getting Prize, Denounces Apartheid
description: J. M. Coetzee, the South African writer, called on his country yesterday to dismantle apartheid, its system of racial segregation. The 47-year-old author spoke after accepting the $5,000 Jerusalem Prize for the Freedom of the Individual in Society from Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem.

title: THE WALLS HAD EARS, RUSSIANS SHOW
description: Soviet diplomats led a fractious parade of American journalists through the new Russian embassy compound today in a sometimes comical news event intended to show off electronic eavesdropping equipment they said they had just found concealed in window frames and air-conditioning ducts.

title: NETS CATCH CELTICS IN DISARRAY
description: The Boston Celtics' road woes continued tonight.

title: Defendant in Iran Arms Plot Goes Free on $1 Million Bail
description: An arms dealer accused of plotting to ship military equipment to Iran and other countries was released yesterday on $1 million bail despite objections from a Federal prosecutor.

title: TALKS HELD BY TEXACO, PENNZOIL
description: Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company today moved closer to a showdown that could force Texaco into bankruptcy proceedings as early as Monday.

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter loss was after a tax benefit of $25 million and the loss reflected a substantial increase in the provision for possible credit losses of $175 million, up from $90 million in the year-ago period.

title: LEADERS OF 3 JUDAISM BRANCHES SEEK COOPERATION
description: In an unusual joint effort, rabbis from the three major branches of Judaism have used the eve of Passover to issue a statement calling for Jews to put aside religious differences and cooperate on common concerns.

title: COLONIAL AMERICAN BANKHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 1, 1986.

title:
PATENTS;
New Ejection Seat
description: LEAD: A molded ejection seat with a rocket motor propulsion system was patented this week. A development contract has been arranged with the aeronautical systems division of the Air Force at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio. Patent 4,655,417 was granted to Gerald F. Herndon, a staff member of the Boeing Company in Seattle.

title: '70 Bombing Figure Sought
description: A man who participated in a fatal antiwar bombing at the University of Wisconsin in 1970 has been charged with helping operate a narcotics factory. The suspect, Dwight A. Armstrong, and four other people were being sought today after a raid at a Bloomington apartment described by investigators as a methamphetamine laboratory. Mr. Armstrong, who is 35 years old, was paroled in 1980 after serving a prison term for the bombing of a building that housed the Army Math Research Center at the university on Aug. 24, 1970, killing a researcher.

title: SOUTHINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock from mutual form of ownership July 3, 1986.

title: Makers of War Toys Criticized
description: Groups opposed to war toys today condemned the laser gun game a teen-ager was playing when he was shot to death by a sheriff's deputy.

title: PANEL FAVORS SICKLE CELL TESTS FOR ALL BABIES
description: Sickle cell diseases affect many more groups than blacks, a Federal panel says, urging that all newborn babies be routinely tested for the inherited blood disorders.

title: SAUL MILLER
description: Saul Miller, former information director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died of a heart ailment at a hospital here Thursday, the labor federation said. He was 68 years old Mr. Miller retired from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1981 after serving two years as its chief spokesman. A former newspaper reporter and editor, he had been director of publications for the federation from 1958 through 1979.

title: KNICKS ARE HUMILIATED
description: For two years, Bernard King refused to concede to logic. Instead, he went into seclusion and worked with a relentless passion to return from a knee injury so severe that no player has ever completely recovered from it. Last night, his efforts resulted in the comeback that few people believed would ever occur.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Fall
description: Bond prices continued to tumble yesterday, despite a late rally that erased half the day's losses.

title: B.Y.U. Expels 2
description: Two Brigham Young football players who were charged in December with altering drug prescriptions were expelled yesterday after being arrested and charged with similar offenses, school officials said.

title: Few N.Y.U. Students Arrested in Drug Sweeps
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET ASKS SHORT-RANGE MISSILE FREEZE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union freeze any deployment of short-range missiles while they discuss limiting and removing such weapons from Europe, independently of current talks on medium-range nuclear arms.

title: INSIDE
description: New York Budget Passed The Legislature early today completed passage of a $41 billion budget that provides for a major cut in state taxes. Page 31.

title: STRAWBERRY'S THIRD BOOSTS METS, 6-3
description: If Shea Stadium can be likened to a theme park, then the emphasis after three games of the season is on the home run. The symbol of the Mets' power surge is Darryl Strawberry.

title: Mariner Sale Prospect
description: Don Drysdale, the Hall of Fame pitcher who is a broadcaster for the Chicago White Sox, said yesterday he was part of a ''small group of people with one member from the Northwest'' investigating the possible purchase of the Seattle Mariners.

title: U.S. BRINGING HOME MARINE GUARD UNIT AT SOVIET CONSULATE
description: The entire detachment of six Marine guards stationed at the United States Consulate in Leningrad will be replaced in May as a security precaution, the Reagan Administration said today.

title: CASHING C.D.'S THAT ARE I.R.A.'S
description: LAST Monday a New Yorker's $4,000 certificate of deposit at Citibank matured. He and his wife had bought the C.D. as an Individual Retirement Account two years ago when Citibank's rate for a two-year C.D. was 10.75 percent. When the rate fell to its present 5.75 percent, they wanted to find another type of investment for their I.R.A.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 11, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5

title: RESEARCH INSTITUTE CHARTS NEW PATHS
description: The Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., long a leader in many areas of theoretical research, appears to be entering a period of gentle transition in which it will come under increasing pressure to strike out in new directions.

title: SABERHAGEN ON 2-HITTER
description: The continuing failures of the Yankee pitching staff were overshadowed for one night by Bret Saberhagen's brilliance.

title: BIAS TRIAL OF DAILY NEWS GOES TO JURY
description: A Federal court jury began deliberations in The Daily News racial-discrimination suit last night after hearing testimony from more than two dozen witnesses in a trial marked by bitterness since it began two months ago.

title: 'SAFE SEX' TO CLOSE
description: ''Safe Sex,'' a trilogy of one-act plays by Harvey Fierstein on the subject of AIDS, will close after the Sunday evening performance. The play, which was produced by the Shubert Organization, opened Sunday at the Lyceum Theater. It will have played for 22 preview and nine regular performances.

title: ALAN BUCHSBAUM, HIGH TECH ARCHITECT, DIES
description: Alan J. Buchsbaum - an originator of the High Tech style and a New York architect who helped redefine Manhattan living styles by conceptualizing lofts as polished, high-design spaces -died yesterday at the University Hospital in Manhattan of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. He was 51 years old and lived in the SoHo section of Manhattan.

title: WHERE CAMPERS LOSE WEIGHT AND GAIN CONFIDENCE
description: Summer marks the beginning of a weight-losing streak for thousands of campers. In idyllic vacation outposts from the Blue Ridge Mountains to Hawaii, young people, and some not-so-young people, will use their vacations to socialize, enjoy the outdoors and shed pounds.

title: MANICURES? WHAT WOULD MAO SAY?
description: As China's campaign against ''bourgeois liberalization'' captures the headlines, Zhen Wen gets her facials.

title: Anni Frind, Soprano, Is Dead; Performed in 20's and 30's
description: Anni Frind, who sang leading soubrette soprano roles in both opera and operetta in the 1920's and 30's, died Wednesday in New Orleans. She was 87 years old.

title: CUOMO TO SIGN BILL BARRING CALIFANO ROLE
description: Ending the most divisive battle of the legislative session, Governor Cuomo bowed to the State Legislature tonight, announcing that he will sign a bill preventing Joseph A. Califano Jr. from heading a commission that Mr. Cuomo had set up to investigate ethics in government.

title: BNH BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Letter: On South America; Paraguay Is Not 'Trapped in 1954'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MORE BODIES FOUND AT BRIDGE
description: Two more bodies were found today by divers and an underwater salvage crew who were searching Schoharie Creek around the wreckage of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that collapsed Sunday.

title: VOLUNTEER BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results are restated. Per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1986.

title: For Lovelorn, A New Adviser Awaits the Call
description: ''It is an honor and an awesome responsibility,'' Linda Sapadin declared, sounding a lot like another New Yorker, Geraldine A. Ferraro, who was also touched by destiny's hand.

title: Amazing! The Thing Is Bugged!
description: I sit way out in what used to be the country waiting for developers to come and ugly everything to death. Why are they called ''developers''? Since their job is creating blight, ''blighters'' would be more logical, but maybe too British. If we quit calling their work ''development'' and called it ''uglification,'' we could call them ''uglifiers.''

title: WALKOUT BY DELTA SETS BACK TALKS TO EASE AIRLINE DELAYS
description: The Transportation Department's campaign for schedule changes to ease airline delays was dealt a major setback today when Delta Airlines walked out of industry discussions. The airline was protesting a department investigation into its scheduling of flights.

title: HURST BLANKS JAYS AT FENWAY
description: Bruce Hurst today became the first Boston Red Sox pitcher to throw a shutout in a season opener in Fenway Park since 1921, allowing only two hits in a 3-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Article 610487 -- No Title
description: The State Legislature began passage today of a $41 billion budget that includes a major cut in state taxes, a record increase in aid to education and increased state spending for prisons, AIDS research and assistance for homeless people.

title: Campaign for Managers
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said that his Operation PUSH hoped to meet with major-league owners and Commissioner Peter Ueberroth in an effort to increase the number of blacks in baseball management positions.

title: The Legislature Humiliates Itself
description: Is there no limit to the Legislature's contempt for New Yorkers? Even as prosecutors close in on corrupt practices in the legislative chamber, the lawmakers obstruct reform and try to preserve a culture of self-dealing, conflicts of interest and payroll-padding. The grudging concessions of the last 48 hours only add to the shame.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who follow the tournament trail enthusiastically have to do a lot of traveling.

title: DOW'S LOSS IS 0.42 AFTER BONDS DROP
description: Stock prices fell a bit yesterday, depressed again by the weak dollar and sharp climb in interest rates.

title: PUMPING IS BEGUN TO CREATE A SECOND SALT LAKE
description: In the 1870's, the Mormon leader Brigham Young was so concerned about the threat to farmland from the rising level of the Great Salt Lake that he dreamed of pumping excess water out onto the desert, but the idea was never accomplished.

title: Senator Stafford of Vermont Declines to Seek Re-election
description: Senator Robert T. Stafford, a Vermont Republican who is one of the Senate's leading environmentalists, announced today that he would not seek re-election.

title: BIC SAYS ITS LIGHTERS ARE SAFE
description: The Bic Corporation denied yesterday that it faced mounting lawsuits on behalf of people who have been injured or killed by malfunctioning Bic disposable butane lighters. Reports of the lawsuits were included in an article in The New York Times.

title: CONTRA GROUP EXPANDS ITS RANGE WITH RAID IN NORTHEAST NICARAGUA
description: After two years of relative calm in northeastern Nicaragua, rebels have mounted the first attack in what they hope will be a new offensive here.

title: Resorts Rejects Davis Offer
description: Resorts International Inc., the big hotel and casino operator, rejected a $200 million takeover offer yesterday from a group headed by Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, and agreed to honor a previous commitment of $101 million from Donald J. Trump, the Manhattan developer.

title: Horner Near Japan Deal
description: Bob Horner is reportedly close to signing a contract to play baseball in Japan this season. The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday that Horner's agent, Bucky Woy, scheduled a meeting yesterday with Kazuo Souma, president of the Yakult Swallows, to reach final details on a one-year contract.

title: Your Money; DISSECTING PARTNERSHIPS
description: JOSH D'AVENZO, a salesman in Hicksville, L.I., is no novice at investing in limited partnerships: he has invested in three since 1980. Yet, Mr. D'Avenzo makes it a point to study carefully the structure of any program he is offered, in order to see just how the profits are divided.

title: Paul E. Gay Dies at 48; Realtor in Manhattan
description: Paul E. Gay, a realtor in Chelsea and Greenwich Village, died of a stroke Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Chelsea.

title: DIAL PAPERS TO RETURN TO YALE, FOR GOOD
description: The Dial papers, among the most important literary collections of the 20th century, have been acquired by Yale University - one month after they were removed from Yale's Beinecke Library, where they resided for almost 40 years and were scheduled to be sold at auction in June.

title: New Job for Unemployment Insurance
description: The national effort to put more welfare recipients to work could learn a useful lesson from California, where an innovative job retraining program shows results without spending new money. The key is unemployment insurance. By applying it inventively to job training, it can reduce and even prevent unemployment.

title: UNITED AIRLINES ATTACKS PILOT UNION LEADERSHIP
description: United Airlines yesterday attacked the leadership of the 7,000-member pilots union for what it called a ''hate management campaign'' and called on pilots to ''set emotion aside and think about your career.''

title: FRENCH EMBASSY CLERK WAS SPY
description: A clerk who coded and decoded messages in French Embassies in the Middle East worked for a decade for the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency, French officials said today.

title: INTERCHANGE FINANCIAL SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its provision for loan losses for the latest quarter and year-earlier period were $75 million and $100 million, respectively. The net income for the quarter was reduced by $5.2 million due to the actions taken with regard to Brazil and Ecuador.

title: ITALIANS TURNING TO INTERIOR AIDE
description: The President of Italy asked Interior Minister Oscar Luigi Scalfaro today to try to form a government to replace Bettino Craxi's five-party coalition, which collapsed in political feuding.

title: Picking on Portugal
description: To the Editor:

title: BRYN MAWR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results includes gain on the sale of residential mortgages equal to 13 cents per share.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN TALK ON SOVIET RELATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech yesterday before the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Horst Dassler Is Dead at 51; Led Adidas Sporting Goods
description: Horst Dassler, chairman of the Adidas sporting goods company since 1984, died today in this Bavarian town, a company spokeswoman said. He was 51 years old.

title: Sabatini to Face Graf In Semifinal Round
description: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina struggled a bit against Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany today, but prevailed, 7-6, 6-4, to gain the semifinals of the Family Circle Magazine Cup.

title:
PATENTS;
DETECTING INHERITED AILMENTS
description: LEAD: AN automated system for chromosome analysis, which could indicate any inherited problems, was patented this week by Prof. Robert S. Ledley of Georgetown University in Washington. He is the inventor of a chromosome analysis machine called the Metachrome.

title: Contras: A No-Win Policy
description: From President Reagan on down, those who preach that we must rely on the so-called contras to stop ''Communist expansion'' in Central America are deluding themselves - or the rest of us. Either way, they point to the eventual involvement of U.S. forces in Nicaragua.

title: MORE JUNKED AUTOS SPOIL A NEWLY CLEANED PARK
description: Less than a week after New York City's Parks Department, in a major cleanup project, removed garbage and auto wrecks from Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, officials discovered a new crop of smashed cars.

title: DOCTORS, FIGHTING THE WAR ON AIDS FIND THEY ARE AMONG THE CASUALTIES
description: Doctors who had never heard of AIDS when they embarked on their careers now find it consuming a widening share of their lives, presenting stresses they never before contemplated.

title: I.R.S. Criticized for 'Bully' Tactics
description: A Congressional subcommittee, considering legislation to give taxpayers greater rights in disputes with the Internal Revenue Service, heard testimony today of abusive tactics employed by I.R.S. enforcement agents.

title: Stern Briefed on Inquiry
description: David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said today that the authorities here have told him that a drug investigation might touch the Suns organization.

title: STRANGE RIDES EAGLE TO LEAD
description: Curtis Strange, who blew his chance to win the 1985 Masters, eagled the par-4 fifth hole today with a 185-yard 6-iron shot into the cup and went on to take the halfway lead in the 51st Masters.

title: KIDDER SAID TO WEIGH SETTLING
description: Executives of Kidder, Peabody & Company and its parent, the General Electric Company, have decided that they would be willing to settle civil insider trading charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to several people familiar with the company and the Government's investigation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Asian and American

title: 2,000 Officers Planned For March in Brooklyn
description: The Police Department will deploy 2,000 officers to Brooklyn today to patrol a planned march by blacks protesting what they assert is harassment of blacks by all-white private security patrols operated by Hasidic Jews in the Crown Heights section.

title: ITALIAN COMFORT IN NEW HAVEN
description: MRESCA'S RISTORANTE in New Haven is something of a sleeper. It is in a quiet, tree-shaded residential area in the Italian section of town, where one expects to find a typical neighborhood eatery. Not so. Although the premises are storefront-tiny, the space is well-utilized, with four smartly napped tables in the ground-level bar and the main dining area up a few steps. Decor is simple, but romantic, with soft lights, fresh flowers and candles on each pink-clothed table, comfortable brass-backed chairs, and a staff attentive and eager to please.

title: SHORT (BUT NOT TOO)
description: ON the runways at the recent couture collections, a lot of leg has been showing. On the street, a little less of it is in evidence.

title: TOO MUCH CAR, TOO LITTLE ROAD
description: ''THE open road.'' ''America's love affair with the automobile.'' Such ancient saws obviously were not created on Long Island, for there is no open road on the Island, and who can have a love affair with a car that's always stopped at a traffic light?

title: A CONTEST GO GIVE PEACE A GAME
description: A PROFESSOR'S proposal to have elementary and junior high school students across the state invent games that have world peace as a theme has attracted support from a number of teacher and administration groups.

title: ENCOUNTERS OF ANOTHER COLOR
description: Junior year abroad, 1980: I am an American in Madrid. More specifically, I am a black American in Galerias Preciados, a downtown department store. I don't shop, however, for very long. In typical tourist fashion I am all over Spain's most cosmopolitan city. I traverse the Retiro, an elegant, formal garden with a lagoon. I make my way to the ancient Plaza Mayor, then stroll along the Rastro, the Orchard Street of Madrid, lined with peddlers of baubles and trifles.

title: ONE YEAR AFTER U.S. RAID, A LOWER LIBYAN PROFILE
description: One year after American warplanes attacked Libya, American officials say that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have reduced his involvement in terrorism, but the reasons they cite seem to go beyond the shock of the bombings.

title: THE STORM CENTER OF BOSTON UNIVERSITY
description: INSIDE the imposing new $100 million science center at Boston University is a black marble plaque the size of a wall. It commemorates the stewardship of the school's president, John R. Silber. ''Under his farseeing leadership and dedicated administration,'' it reads, ''the University has attained academic excellence and achieved distinction by every measure by which the greatness of a university may be judged.'' Like almost everything else at Boston University these days, the inscription and the expansive building, which has greatly added to the school's capacity in science and engineering, have come to be seen as symbols of Mr. Silber's disputatious 16-year dominion.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: April 12, 1987
description: Weeks On Fiction List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert 6 Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by 6 Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Dell, $4.50.) Two sides of a marriage revealed in diary entries. 3 * I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 11 (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 4 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) 3 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 5 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, 6 $4.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 6 THE GREAT ALONE, by Janet Dailey. (Pocket, 1 $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 3 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. 181 (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 11 Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet 45 Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Job and career advice; 1987 edition. 6 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, 22 Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1987. 7 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge 27 Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 8 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1987. 10 (Ballantine, $10.95.) Aid from an accounting firm. 9 J. K. LASSER'S YOUR INCOME TAX. (Prentice 10 Hall, $8.95.) The 1987 edition.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE

title: A SPECIAL OCCASIONS BOOKLET IS ANNOUNCED
description: THE much-anticipated Special Occasions stamp booklet will be issued by the United States Postal Service in Atlanta, Ga. The success of the Love stamps intensified a demand for stamps with messages and encouraged the Postal Service to issue the new booklet. Each booklet will contain one pane of 10 multi-colored 22-cent stamps carrying messages. They are classified as special issues and will remain on sale for a longer period of time than commemoratives.

title: Queens Groups Meet to Bridge Ethnic Gaps
description: The faces in the Queens catering hall were white, black and brown, but their common characteristic was embarrassed laughter. Some 300 people, had been asked as a way of bridging their differences - to hug each other.

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: ''The Prisoner of Seventh Avenue'' adeptly traces the diminution of the Halston trademark. Ironically, however, you refer to the famous designer's use of ''ultrasuede shirtdresses and suits in the 1970's.''

title: Jailed Alderman Loses Race
description: Wallace Davis, a jailed City Alderman, lost his bid for re-election when the last ballots were counted Thursday, but his lawyer said a recount would be sought. Mr. Davis's opponent, Sheneather Butler, defeated the Alderman by 99 votes, 7,184 to 7,085, according to complete but unofficial results. But Mr. Davis's lawyer, Dennis Berkson, said the incumbent planned to seek a preliminary recount, covering 25 percent of the ward's precincts, and possibly a full recount. Mr. Davis faces charges of bribery and assault.

title: A BROAD SELECTION OF CONCERTS AHEAD
description: CONCERTS in the county pretty well come to a halt for Easter, but the musical floodgates open wide again two weekends hence, and we also have at least half a dozen tonal enticements on the schedule today.

title: MACHINES ARE OUT, GARDENS ARE IN
description: FINITE AND INFINITE GAMES By James P. Carse 152 pp. New York: The Free Press. $13.95.

title: SACRED MUSIC FOR THE EASTER SEASON
description: CHURCHES are prepared again to offer a cornucopia of sacred music, today through next Sunday.

title: AQUINO IS THE KEY IN PHILIPPINE VOTE
description: Three rival political rallies competed for crowds here one recent humid night amid the smoke of frying squid and the tinkling bells of ice cream vendors. All three claimed the support of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Mannes Trio Plays Haydn and Schnabel
description: In the wake of its Naumburg International Chamber Music Award last year, the Mannes Trio came to Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night. If this interesting program of Haydn, Schnabel and Brahms showed anything, it was the intelligence, ardor and technique of these three young women. They are also beautifully rehearsed, and each seems to know and sense what the others are going to do.

title: West Virginia Moving To Keep Colleges Open
description: The state Board of Regents will take Gov. Arch A. Moore's advice and use interest money to keep West Virginia's colleges open, despite its earlier rejection of the idea, the board's chancellor says.

title: Recent Sales
description: New Milford, Conn. $229,900 188 Carmen Hill Road 3-bedrooms, 3-bath, new raised ranch; cathedral ceilings and skylights, 1.5 acres; taxes not yet available. Orange, Conn. $363,000 565 Broadview Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; dead- end road, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. West Haven, Conn. $370,000 3 Annawon Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-baths, 65-year-old colonial; newly remodeled, on waterfront; taxes $2,735. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $360,000 317 Elm Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 62-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun room, deck, porch, walk to village; taxes $6,232. Katonah, N.Y. $365,000 Louis Drive 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, pantry, den, workshop, 1.8 acre; taxes $5,586. Lincolndale, N.Y. $122,500 Birch Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 49-year-old frame ranch; fenced yard, deck, clubhouse, beach rights; taxes $1,198. OTHER AREAS Massapequa Park, L.I. $250,000 70 Hemlock Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $5,400. Merrick, L.I. $255,000 13 Silver Birch Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, contemporary kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $4,600. Toms River, N.J. $210,000 1585 Sea Island Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; family room with fireplace, hardwood floors, deck, full basement; taxes $2,650.

title: CAMPAIGN IS WAGED TO ALERT THE NATION TO ALCOHOLISM'S TOLL
description: The National Council on Alcoholism has embarked on a campaign to alert the nation to its ''most costly and damaging drug problem.''

title: Legal Services
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOJOURNALISM LAYS CLAIM TO THE REALM OF ESTHETICS
description: FIFTEEN YEARS AFTER THE DE-mise of Life as a weekly magazine, photojournalism is reclaiming its former glamorous, legendary status. Pictures that were taken on assignments for magazines and newspapers now regularly reappear - in frames - on the walls of museums and galleries. The photojournalists of yesteryear are being enshrined in biographies and celebrated with retrospective exhibitions. Today's photojournalists are big draws on the photography lecture-and-symposium circuit. Meanwhile, college-level programs designed to produce the photojournalists of tomorrow are growing at a rapid rate.

title: LUXURY TODAY
description: Who would have thought that the sight of a walk-in closet would inspire sighs of envy? Or that a gardener's cottage, charming though it may be, would seem as precious as plover's eggs in a porcelain basket? Indeed, many aspects of the home that once were taken for granted now seem like life's greatest luxuries. But even as they disappear, new luxuries are being invented to take their place. Since, for example, there is less likely to be someone minding the house these days, manufacturers have devised ATTAINABLE luxuries, such as machines that monitor everything from flooding to burglaries. In case of trouble, they will track you down by phone.

title: Reagan on Education
description: President Reagan has a story for every occasion and an excuse for every disaster.

title: A VIOLINIST AND 2 PIANISTS IN RECITALS
description: Nina Kennedy

title: SEDUCED BY A PARLOR PINK
description: THE FREE FRENCHMAN By Piers Paul Read. 584 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: KING RETURNS, BUT NOT AT TOP FORM
description: Trent Tucker peeked out of the shower and surveyed the scene. A gathering crowd in front of a locker on the other side of the room had begun to swell onto the area in front of the adjacent stall, his stall. The group made it nearly impossible for the Knick guard to towel off and dress in peace. But Tucker was not annoyed. In fact, he smiled. ''Everything is back to normal,'' he said.

title: Currency
description: To the Editor: Re ''Practical Traveler: Coping With Currency Swings'' (Travel, March 1), you might want to alert your readers about currency exchanging in Canada. If you use a credit card or exchange at a bank, you will get 75 cents for each Canadian dollar. But if you want to get 6 to 8 cents more for each exchanged dollar, do this:

title: Article 795187 -- No Title
description: The Federal Highway Administration has told Congress that it will cost $50.8 billion to repair all the defects in the nation's 575,607 highway bridges. Consultants to the agency say $13 billion is needed immediately to fix the worst defects.

title: Hundreds Flee After Derailment Spills Chemical
description: A freight train derailed today in a crowded neighborhood here, spilling a volatile chemical and dumping paper goods that burned and spewed a thick cloud that forced hundreds of residents from their homes.

title: How to Privatize Big-Time College Athletics
description: To the Editor:

title: STRETCH FABRICS, SMOOTH FIT
description: MANY designers are using elasticized fabrics for fall to achieve a really smooth fit. There's a knack to handling these stretch materials. When used improperly, they can result in bumps, bulges and sausagelike rolls - girdles used to do the same thing.

title: Headliners; Out, on a Judgment Error
description: Al Campanis of the Los Angeles Dodgers was caught leaning the wrong way last week. Mr. Campanis, who is in charge of player personnel, resigned under pressure after saying on television that blacks might not be qualified to be baseball managers or executives. Appearing on an ABC News ''Nightline'' program that observed the 40th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's debut as the first black major leaguer, Mr. Campanis was asked why the major leagues had no black managers. He replied, ''I truly believe they may not have some of the necessities.''

title: Sally-Jane Heit In Comedy and Music
description: The characters that the comedian and singer Sally-Jane Heit portrays in her one-woman show are mature urban women up to their necks in complications and generational contradictions. Her most fully realized character is a woman in her 40's who has finally earned her law degree. In a matter of minutes she learns that her daughter, who has just been accepted into Princeton University, is pregnant and would rather get married and work in a supermarket than go to college. Moments later, her once oppressive mother, now 68, calls to announce she is having a face lift to be more appealing to her 42-year-old boyfriend.

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: We all recognize the psychological importance of one's name to one's identity, but Halston chose to take the risk he did because he wanted lots of money and, indeed, benefited to the tune of millions of dollars.

title: Airport Security
description: To the Editor: As a professional photographer, I always have my camera and film bag hand checked at airport security gates. At the Newark, St. Louis and Detroit International Airports the procedure varies widely. However, I was pleasantly surprised recently at the United Airlines security check at Los Angeles International Airport when the guard asked me to take the cameras and film out of my bag and put them on a tray on the counter. Also, he asked me to place my bag on the conveyor belt for the usual X-ray treatment.

title: Getting Honest
description: So what's wrong with you? Now that everyone is rightly afraid of AIDS, you apparently endorse gays - as in D. Gary Phelps's article. I wish you'd stop and think, for all our sakes! E. McCANN Portland, Me.

title: THEY STILL DON'T DO WINDOWS - YET
description: UNTIL fairly recently, beepers were primitive sorts of contraptions. They were conspicuous, too weighty to carry comfortably, and a pain to use. In fact, they did not even beep. To receive a message, you had to hold the beeper to your ear, press a button and listen to an operator reiterate a bunch of numerical codes.

title: THESE BUILDINGS ARE RATED X
description: LEQUEU An Architectural Enigma. By Philippe Duboy. Illustrated. 367 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $65.

title: Exotic Blooms
description: It has been evident for some time that electronic gadgetry is taking over the American home, but a less noted invasion is that of the house plant. Indoor plants have taken root in our houses and apartments as never before.

title: Lyndel Roubos and Michael Manson, Graduate Students, to Wed in Autumn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gary L. Roubos of Darien, Conn., and Breckenridge, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lyndel Lee Roubos to Michael Scott Manson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Manson of Phoenix. A fall wedding is planned. Miss Roubos and her fiance expect to receive M. B. A. degrees in June from the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. She previously graduated magna cum laude from Middlebury College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Miss Roubos is a provisional member of the Junior League of New York. The future bride's father is the president and chief executive officer of the Dover Corporation in New York, and a member of the boards of the Omnicom Group Inc., in New York, and Reichhold Chemicals Inc., in White Plains. Miss Roubos is a granddaughter of Mrs. Garfield O. Anderson of Berkeley, Calif., and the late Mr. Anderson, and of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dorr Roubos of Denver, Colo.

title: JASON ROBARDS PREVIEWS OLD AGE
description: EVEN IN BEDROOM SLIPPERS AND A bathrobe, he is debonair and as commanding as another man might be in a pinstriped suit. At the moment he is moving with the painful caution of the elderly and infirm, uncertain of how far to trust a deteriorating body; but in the mind's eye he is ever graceful and sure, spinning a long joke or a tall tale or a lovely woman into a dance with the same deft charm. On this stage his lines place him in a home for the elderly, but even as a decrepit retiree, he romances the nurse and teases the housekeeper with the wicked glint in his eye that has characterized performances that range from ''A Thousand Clowns'' to ''The Iceman Cometh.''

title: IT WAS ONLY A TEST
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESS TO THE CENTURY
description: OUT OF STEP An Unquiet Life in the 20th Century. By Sidney Hook. 628 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $29.95.

title: BILL IRWIN CLOWNS AROUND AT THE BEAUMONT
description: WHEN BILL IRWIN'S ''THE Regard of Flight'' opened in New York in 1982, critics called it the most refreshing innovation in theater since air-conditioning - and also said they didn't know whether to categorize it as theater or as a clown show. Since then it has been around the country, and around the world, most recently in Sydney. Now it is back, opening tonight at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, with the original cast - and with Mr. Irwin still wondering how to categorize it.

title: POLL SHOWS JEWS AND NON-JEWS DIFFER ON POLLARD
description: Most American Jews say they believe the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy affair and Israel's involvement in the Iran arms scandal will increase anti-Semitism in the United States, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Miss Julie Embassy Home Entertainment. 90 minutes. $29.95.

title: Yonkers Condo
description: To the Editor:

title: AMBIANCE OUTSHINES SEAFOOD
description: WHY are there crowds of diners at Louie's Shore Restaurant in Port Washington? It can't be the food. It was difficult to find even a small handful of dishes that I could recommend. It seems that for many Long Islanders, Louie's is not just another restaurant. It's a landmark. In fact, it has been so since it opened in 1905.

title: Diana Huffman to Marry
description: Diana Huffman, staff director of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Kenneth S. Levine, vice president for governmental affairs in Washington of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., plan to be married on June 14. The future bride, whose marriage ended in divorce, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William C. Huffman of Louisville, Ky. Her father, who is retired, was a vice president of the University of Louisville and a dean of its University College. Mr. Levine is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Levine of Kane, Pa. His father, who is retired, was a scrap metal dealer in Kane.

title: Prime Freni
description: EUGENE ONEGIN Opera in three acts by Tchaikovsky. Lyric Opera of Chicago production staged and designed by Pier Luigi Samaritani, conducted by Bruno Bartoletti, with Mirella Freni, Wolfgang Brendel, Peter Dvorsky, Nicolai Ghiaurov, Sandra Walker, Jean Kraft. English subtitles. Home Vision. Two cassettes. 157 minutes. $59.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
CHILD ABUSE: WOEFUL PROBLEM WON'T GO AWAY
description: LEAD: THE abuse of children is part of the history of civilization, documented in the Bible, and by the writings of sociologists and social historians. Unable to protect themselves, children have no control over the aggressive behavior of family members or over the practices of the society around them.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ONLY WHEN I LAUGH. By Len Deighton. (Mysterious Press, $16.95.) ''We are part of the process of natural selection; for we deprive the stupid and the inefficient of wealth and prestige. . . . If the stupid prosper, then our society must lose its dynamism and finally falter,'' says Silas Lowther, the quintessential confidence man.

title: Aid Offer Rescinded for Niagara Falls Project
description: New York State has withdrawn a $400 million offer of financial incentives - one of the largest in its history - intended to persuade Canadian developers to build a huge complex of stores and amusements within view of the famous falls.

title:
ART;
ERNEST TROVA'S 'UNFLAPPABLE' SYMBOLIC FIGURE IN CROSS RIVER
description: LEAD: IN the early 1960's Ernest Trova fell into a style of art that has served him profitably as a signature ever since. His ''Falling Man'' is a sleek, robotic humanoid bearing a resemblance to Hollywood's Oscar. These days the figure doesn't fall as often, but undergoes other tests that are symbolic of our times.

title: FOR MATZOH MAVENS, TRADITION LIVES
description: The aroma of dough baking drifts out of Streit's Matzoh Factory on Rivington Street, and, on windy days, it wafts through the Lower East Side.

title: Edmund Wilson Among the 'Despicable English'
description: I MET Edmund Wilson, I think, sometime in the early spring of 1946, after I had come back from Moscow to finish the job I was doing at the British Embassy in Washington. I had been in Washington during the war years, and my friend the Russian composer Nicolas Nabokov, who, like his cousin Vladimir, was a friend of Wilson's, thought that he might like to meet me (I had expressed my intense admiration for ''Axel's Castle'' and ''The Triple Thinkers'') and talk about Russian literature and other topics. Wilson refused. He was convinced that any British official could only want to meet him in order to rope him into the British propaganda machine. He was acutely isolationist: his Anglophobia, which in any case had been fairly acute, was increased by the reflection that England had once again managed to drag America into a dreadful and totally unnecessary war, and he had no wish to meet any representative of that country. However, once the war was over he evidently decided that he was no longer in any danger of being inveigled into pro-British activities, and asked me to lunch at the Princeton Club in New York.

title: BUTTERED TOAST AND BOSWELL'S COW
description: THE ENGLISH A Social History, 1066-1945. By Christopher Hibbert. Illustrated. 785 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $32.95.

title: AFTER THREE YEARS OF HIGH HOPES, AIR ATLANTA IS OUT OF CASH
description: LATE last month, Daniel H. Kolber, executive vice president of Air Atlanta, shut his office door against the incessant ring of telephones to explain to a visitor the options left for the beleaguered airline.

title: Mara L. Orentreich Marries Richard Alan Roth
description: Mara L. Orentreich, a daughter of Selma Orentreich of Manhattan and the late Seymour Orentreich, was married yesterday to Richard Alan Roth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Roth of Endwell, N.Y. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: Correction; A CORRECTION
description: A picture caption March 8 with a Posting on a condominium project in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., misidentified it. It is Hunters Brook.

title: CANADA'S BATTLE FOR THE ARCTIC STRAITS
description: A FASCINATION with the frozen reaches above the 60th parallel has played a central role in the development of the Canadian national consciousness. Although most Canadians have never been within a thousand miles of the region, an enthrallment with ''the Arctic sublime,'' as it has been described by Franklyn Griffiths, a University of Toronto political scientist who has written extensively on the subject, is part of the country's birthright.

title: NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: Following is a roundup of some of the nota-ble recording releases of recent weeks. Tradition: Itzhak Perlman Plays Popular Jewish Melodies The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. Dov Seltzer, conductor and arranger. EMI/Angel LP No. DS-47904. ( Also available on cassette and compact disk.)

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
IF IT'S 'RAD,' IT'S CAMPUS SLANG
description: LEAD: ONE of the subjects college freshmen study with the greatest enthusiasm is the campus jargon. Slang helps define a student's identity, distinguishing him or her from the faculty and community at large, while making school life feel less forbidding and more familiar.

title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: The War at Home Produced and Directed by Glenn Silber and Barry Alexander Brown. Catalyst Media Inc. 1979. MPI Home Video. 119 minutes. $29.95. Vietnam: The Secret Agent Produced by Daniel Keller and Jackie Ochs. Directed by Jackie Ochs. The Human Arts Association. MPI Home Video. 57 minutes. $29.95

title: BUSING'S AFTERMATH: CHILDREN IN YONKERS HIT BY MOTORISTS
description: In the seven months since a court-ordered school integration plan introduced extensive busing to Yonkers, this city of 190,000 people has recorded an alarming number of children being hit by motorists improperly passing halted school buses.

title:
DINING OUT;
SPOT WITH A VIEW IN MAMARONECK
description: LEAD: AT last the old James Fenimore Cooper Inn, tacky and rundown for years, has received a face lifting worth noting. The slice of literary history connected with the place is less interesting than its situation on the Sound, just across the road from the bustling Mamaroneck marina and park with its border of cherry trees ready to burst into pink bloom.

title: FOLK-ROCK: THE FORT IN SERIES
description: THE 1960's folk scene takes a time-warp into the 1980's at the Fort -a movable hootenanny and self-described ''anti-showcase'' that has been settling in various downtown clubs over the last year. On Tuesday, the Fort started a weekly series at Tramps (125 East 15th Street); it commandeers Nightingale's (213 Second Avenue, at 13th Street) on Wednesdays.

title: Getting Honest
description: Reading and rereading D. Gary Phelps's article ''Getting Honest'' (About Men, March 15), I found it uncannily like my own experience, for I, too, left a marriage and two children at midlife in order to live my life as a homosexual. Unfortunately, Mr. Phelps has yet to shed all the persistent prejudices about homosexuality that led him (and, I might add, myself) to hide in the ''closet'' for so many years.

title: Brenda T. Essex Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Brenda Teagle Essex, a daughter of Mrs. Page W. Smith of Palm Beach, Fla., and Easton, Md., and the late Walter C. Teagle Jr. to L.David Callaway 3d, a son of Lawrence H. Callaway of Knoxville, Tenn., and Mrs. Joseph P. Temple of Naples, Fla., took place yesterday. The Rev. Ralph Warren Jr. performed the ceremony at Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach.

title: Sons on Sidelines
description: TO keep the new basketball coaching staff at Washington State straight, you don't need a program so much as a genealogy. Kelvin Sampson, a former Cougar assistant who was named head coach, is the son of a former high school coach in North Carolina. One of his assistants is Dave Harshman, a former high school and junior college coach, whose father is Marv Harshman, a long-time coach at both Washington and Washington State. Sampson's other assistant is Kip Motta, a former assistant at Lamar University in Texas. His father is Dick Motta, the coach of the Dallas Mavericks.

title: NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: Following is a roundup of some of the notable recording releases of recent weeks. Moriz Rosenthal The Complete HMV Recordings, 1934-37 Twenty four-items on two LP's. Archive Piano Recordings: APR 7002. Available by mail from Archive Piano Recordings, P.O. Box 57, Horsham, West Sussex, RH 13, 7 Y Z, England. The price, payable by check or money order, is $23, including air parcel post.

title: HIGH SCHOOL GRADES: SOME ARE MORE EQUAL
description: LEAD: DANIEL GOLDSTEIN, an honors student at Eastchester High School in Westchester County, received an 83 in an Advanced Placement calculus course during the first quarter of his senior year. More than likely, had the 17-year-old taken the standard math course of advanced algebra/ introduction to calculus, he would have received a higher mark.

title: GUADELOUPE: THE CARIBBEAN A LA FRANCAISE
description: LEAD: Danger is not the spice of life. But it is the pepper of travel.

title: SPECULATING ON A BELEAGERED OIL GIANT
description: IS Texaco Inc. - under siege by the Pennzoil Company for a legal judgment that could run to $11 billion - a bargain at $32? If not a bargain, is the stock a reasonable speculation? What about a wild shot in the dark? Investors have heard all those opinions in the last week, as Texaco's price slumped by $5 after a legal setback Monday revived talk that the giant oil producer might seek bankruptcy protection.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: DESTINY. By Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) Move over, Sidney Sheldon, Judith Krantz, et al. - you have formidable competition. In this 822-page saga of glitz, glitter and eroticism, the romantic novel may have reached its ultimate destination - even if some readers will find certain passages just one step shy of hard-core porn.

title: Digital Finds
description: The good life, these days, generally carries a higher price tag than it once did. However, there is at least one exception to the mounting cost of good living, and that is the exuberantly expanding field of electronic home entertainment. In a dramatic reversal of the usual spiral, prices for stereo and video equipment have been going down, and shoppers are happily searching for these affordable luxuries.

title: AFFORDABLE LUXURIES FOR SMALL SPACES
description: Little luxuries - colorful tassels to brighten a pair of curtains, a Chinese bowl filled with flowers or a few decorative pillows neatly plumped on the living-room sofa - can spruce up a studio apartment or a small cottage without costing a princely sum. As department stores and manufacturers have become more and more conscious of price, a dazzling array of affordable, well-designed objects for the home has become available. ''People these days buy accessories for the home as they do stocks,'' observes one retailer. ''They're interested in quality, things that have lasting value.'' Classic designs such as lamp bases in the shape of architectural columns never go out of style. Neither does silver plate, which has become increasingly popular lately. A silver-plated tray or pitcher, for example, costing under $100, can evoke an air of grandeur that will last for generations.

title: BUSINESS ON THE BIG SCREEN
description: LUCKILY, NOT MANY OF US develop our business ethics by studying what we see on the screen.

title: METS' STREAK COMES TO END
description: All the essentials for another victory were in place: Kevin McReynolds brought the fans to their feet and jolted Rick Mahler, the Atlanta starter, with a home run into the bullpen in the fourth inning. Wally Backman's two-run single then put the Mets ahead. All that remained was to see whether Darryl Strawberry could earn a place in the record book alongside Willie Mays.

title: HUMANITIES IS TRADITION AT COLUMBIA
description: Curriculum debate at most colleges usually focuses on the merits of distribution requirements or whether faculty members can be lured into trying an interdisciplinary course. At Columbia College it is more likely to be a battle over whether students should read Goethe's ''Faust'' or Cervantes's ''Don Quixote.''

title: Sports of The Times; TAKING A POLL ON MULLIGANS AT THE MASTERS
description: FOR every green coat that a Masters champion wears, two or three green coats remain empty. During the final holes at Augusta National, several green coats are brought from the champions locker room or the pro shop to the white cabin near the clubhouse where the television ceremony occurs. Various sizes are selected to fit the golfers in contention out there on the treacherous back nine where the Masters is always won, as it will be today. But the back nine is also where the Masters is always lost.

title: THE MORALITY OF 'PLATOON'
description: To the Editor:

title: ON RED CREEK, PLANS PROCEED DESPITE FEARS OVER WETLANDS
description: AS headlines go, this one was particularly prescient. ''Red Creek Ridge: 'It's the Thing of the Future,' '' a newspaper in the Hamptons said of a proposed Hampton Bays development about five years ago.

title: RECORDS INDICATE FLAWS IN INSPECTIONS OF THRUWAY BRIDGE THAT COLLAPSED
description: State records indicate that a number of required procedures were ignored or circumvented during the most recent inspection of the bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that collapsed last Sunday, apparently sending at least 10 motorists to their deaths. Two more bodies were recovered yesterday, bringing the total to six. Although a number of questions about the April 1986 inspection remain unanswered, the inspection report and interviews with state officials revealed several problems and flaws. These were among them:

title: STAGE: 'A STAR AIN'T NOTHIN,' IN BROOKLYN
description: A DYING old woman teaches a young girl the excitement, and painful necessity, of hope in ''A Star Ain't Nothin' but a Hole in Heaven'' by Judi Ann Mason. And the girl learns without instruction that the opportunities won for young blacks in the civil rights movement of the 1960's cost something of inestimable value in the loss of traditional cultural values.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HERMAN AND HIS HERD Woody Herman's Young Thundering Herd will appear at 8 P.M. Saturday at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey in West Orange. Although Mr. Herman is recovering from an illness, he is expected to be on hand with his fellow musicians, He began playing the clarinet when he was 8 years old, toured with bands as a teen-ager and formed his own band in 1936. On his way to becoming a legendary figure in jazz and popular music, he recorded with Bing Crosby and the Andrews Sisters, had his own radio show and appeared in films.

title: Saluting the Salesman
description: To the Editor:

title: Minding Our Own Business
description: For a couple of months now, newspapers have been carrying out their duty to tell television networks how to run their business. TV people get a little upset about this. They should not feel too bad, because newspapers are not picking on them - we tell everybody how to run his business.

title: No Headline
description: SUBLET IN A CO-OP Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a Manhattan building that has been converted to a co-op. In the next year I expect to be out of the country for six to eight months. I would like to sublet my apartment. How would I do this? . . . V. A., Manhattan Answer: Nonpurchasing tenants in buildings that have been converted to cooperative residences who have the right to remain in their apartments also have the right to sublet their apartments. You would be covered by the rules that apply to rent-stabilized units. Although the landlord's approval is required for a sublet to be legal, the landlord cannot unreasonably withhold permission. The state's Housing and Community Renewal Division, which has jurisdiction over rent-regulated apartments, has a specific procedure that must be followed. You should start the process at least 30 days before the sublet is to begin.

title: Signs of Spring
description: NO QUESTION ABOUT IT, spring is a season that seems to unleash a certain carefree spirit-in designers as well as in customers. The former are apt to come up with merchandise and ideas on the romantic, whimsical, even saucy side. The latter, on the other hand, aremorelikely to spendmoney on something that is not needed but simply gives a boost to the morale. This urge often concentrates on clothing for the extremities. Take hats. Their day belongs to fashion's dark ages; no one really needs one anymore, except as a shield from the lements. But suddenly this spring, the idea of a hat, particularly one that isnot serious, is immensely appealing, and delightfully frivolous ones are out there to be had. The same could be said for sassy, even sexy shoes. Then again, just pinning on a fresh flower could impart a touch of spring.

title: CHINA REPLACES ITS TOP POLICE MINISTER
description: In the highest-level shake-up since the resignation of the Communist Party leader three months ago, China today announced the replacement of its Public Security Minister, who directed the country's main police force during student demonstrations last year.

title: English Language Comes Down With Healthcare Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
A COLONIAL HEART IN A VICTORIAN BODY
description: LEAD: IN THE first green, leafy weeks of spring, EverMay-on-the-Delaware beckons as a getaway idyll, a country inn with all the appeal of distance close to home.

title: Penn Takes Childs Cup
description: Penn's varsity crew survived rough water and a spirited challenge by Princeton today to win by 1.5 seconds and complete a sweep of the 109th Childs Cup, America's oldest cup race.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This pushes South Africa clean over the threshold of any claim to democracy.'' - Helen Suzman, a South African legislator, on new restrictions on public dissent. [ 1:6. ]

title: WHAT'S THE QUESTION?
description: A POPULAR television quiz show, ''Jeopardy,'' provides answers and leaves contestants groping for questions. Something of the same sort was happening at bridge tables throughout North America at the beginning of this month. Assume that the answer is: ''Four - double yesterday's number.'' What is the question?

title: Golf; Masters Field Has a Hard Time With Greens
description: Take a wool blanket with a short nap and lay it over a dining room table. Then lift one end of the table and place a brick under each leg so the table tilts just slightly. Then put a golf ball on the high end and try to stop the ball before it goes over the edge.

title: THEATER: 'ABYSSINIA,' A MUSICAL
description: ''Abyssinia,'' the new gospel musical, begins with a miracle. Moments before Patience Jackson (Cheryl Freeman), a young, recently widowed sharecropper, is about to give birth in an Oklahoma cotton field, the sky darkens, and a tornado descends from the heavens. Just as the laborers are about to be swallowed up, Mother Vera (Tina Fabrique), the community's spiritualist healer, turns to face the whirlwind and magically waves it back into the sky, and the child is born.

title: CAMBRIDGE GROUP TAKES ON M.I.T.
description: Just west of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology here in one of the most densely populated cities in the country lie 30 acres of nearly vacant land. Where once the Simplex Wire and Cable Company operated, employing 600 people in blue-collar jobs, weeds thrive, trash abounds and the shell of a brick factory building stands, the words ''Stop MIT'' scrawled on its side.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET LEGISLATORS ARE PLANNING TO DEBATE ON TV
description: The first public dialogue between members of Congress and the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Soviet Parliament, will be televised in both nations this month in six broadcasts on such issues as arms control, human rights, regional conflicts, health and environment.

title: ROBINSON'S LEGACY
description: He was the son of a Georgia sharecropper and the grandson of a slave, and growing up in Pasadena, Calif., in the 1930's and 1940's, he watched movies from segregated balconies and was allowed to swim in the municipal pool only one day a week.

title: SACRED MUSIC, DANCE FOR EASTER SEASON
description: CHURCHES in the county have prepared a wealth of sacred music to perform today, on Maundy Thursday, on Good Friday, for the Easter Vigil on Saturday and next Sunday's Easter-morning services. Programs range from the familiar works of Handel, Purcell, Vivaldi and Bach, to early-American folk carols, Gregorian chants, airs by little-known Baroque composers and the ubiquitous Toccata from the Fifth Symphony of Charles Marie Widor.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Brandon, Vt.;
B&B;'s Enjoy A Fad Status
description: LEAD: SIS AND BOB POULIOT first looked at Cape Cod and other parts of New England, but finally found a house they could afford in this central Vermont village.

title: Deirdre Manning In Flute Recital Debut
description: Deirdre Manning produces an unusually full and lustrous sound from her flute; moreover her phrasing is lively, always interesting. Although Ms. Manning's Wednesday-evening concert at Weill Recital Hall marked her formal debut, she has been well-known within New York musical circles for some time, as a pupil of Julius Baker, Andrew Lolya, Frances Blaisdell and Catherine Curran, and as an instructor at the Manhattan School of Music.

title: Residential Resales; Closings in the week ended March 28
description: MANHATTAN Chelsea $120,000 231 West 21st Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 510-sq.-ft. co- op in recently-renovated prewar building; eat-in kitchen; mainte nance $245, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: H.H. Kleigerman Associ ates) Greenwich Village $350,000 79 Washington Place 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; fireplace, L-shaped living/dining area, roof rights,; main tenance $1,383, 70% tax-deduct ible (Broker: Ambrose-Mar Elia Co. Inc.) Upper East Side $625,000 10 East End Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. co- op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, windowed kitchen, beamed-ceil ings, terrace and balcony, East River views; maintenance $1,455, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: M.J. Raynes) Upper East Side $765,000 930 Fifth Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining room; maintenance $985, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Corco ran Group) Upper West Side $400,000 375 Riverside Drive 2-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, din ing room, maid's room, Hudson River views; maintenance $600, 25% tax-deductible (Broker: Thompson Realty) BRONX Riverdale $92,000 3601 Johnson Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. post war co-op; eat-in kitchen, dropped living room, dining foyer; mainte nance $347, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Morris B. Sopher Real Es tate) Williamsbridge $205,000 2747 Bronxwood Avenue 4-family brick detached house; 2-bedrooms in two units, 1-bedroom in the other two; eat-in kitchens and 1 bath in each; 2-car garage; taxes $1,600 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty Corp.) BROOKLYN Boerum Hill $360,000 96 Bergen Street 2-family 4-story brick town house; 2 bedrooms, dining area, basement recreation room in lower duplex, 2-bedrooms, eat-in kitchen in upper duplex, cathedral ceilings and 1 bath in each; 22- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Barbara D'Er asmo) Midwood $196,000 1181 East 39th Street 2-family 77-year-old Queen Anne styled house; 4 bedrooms in pri mary unit, 3 bedrooms in secondary unit; dining room, eat-in kitchen and 1 bath in each; open veranda, stained-glass windows, original woodwork in each, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,041 (Broker: Dwork & Korn Real Estate Ltd.) QUEENS East Elmhurst $165,000 31-39 Buell Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath single-family stucco house; fireplace, parquet floors, eat-in kitchen, full basement, 30- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $740 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate Inc.) Rego Park $112,000 63-61 99th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath prewar co-op; high-ceilings, formal raised-dining area, eat-in kitchen, part-time door man; maintenance $480, 50% de ductible (Broker: Nu Place Realty) STATEN ISLAND Stapleton 255,000 300 Van Duzer Street 2-family 3-story Victorian; 5 bed rooms, finished basement, 1 bath in primary unit, 3 bedrooms, 1 bath in secondary; eat-in kitchens, dining rooms, stained-glass windows, original woodwork in each, 40- by 175-ft. lot; taxes $1,246 (Broker: Pearl Foreman Realty Inc.) Todt Hill $1,380,000 58 Buttonwood Road 4-bedroom, 4-bath single-family 60- year old New England colonial; re cently remodeled; living room fire place, formal dining room, den, 2-car garage, 1/2 acre lot; taxes $4,300 (Broker: Otto J. Vitale Real Estate)

title: THE 'WHO CARES' VICTIMS
description: CLOSE PURSUIT A Week in the Life of an NYPD Homicide Cop. By Carsten Stroud. 277 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE: MUCH PROGRESS, MUCH TO BE DONE
description: WE have all heard the expression, ''There's many a slip between the cup and the lip.''

title: POTTERY FROM IRELAND
description: Irish ceramic art, though lacking the native historical tradition of handknitting or crystal manufacture, has recently begun to earn a presence as an expression of the country's national life and a reflection of its landscape. Within the last 15 years, a number of craft potteries producing high quality ware in extraordinary settings have sprung up in some of western Ireland's most beautiful counties, such as Mayo, Galway and Kerry. The visual nature of the craft, the independence of the potters and their interest in regional traditions have drawn them to out-of-the-way places that make delightful excursions for tourists interested in craftsmanship and in exploring the relationship between setting and art.

title: Japan Denies Dumping Chips
description: A Japanese trade official denied today that Japan had ''dumped'' computer chips at prices below true value and reaffirmed that Tokyo would take countermeasures if Washington went ahead with its sanction plans.

title: A MARTYR OF AUSCHWITZ
description: LEAD: ON MAY 1, SISTER Teresa Benedicta of the Cross is to be beatified for a holy life that ended in martyrdom at Auschwitz. The ceremony will be at the Sports Stadium in Cologne, West Germany, and my husband and I, Jews and proud of our Judaism, are to be among the invited guests, along with about 20 of our relatives.

title: Portuguese Leader in China
description: Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal arrived here today for an official visit during which he will sign an agreement giving control of the Portuguese colony Macao to China. On March 26, the two nations concluded nine months of talks on Macao, and on Monday, Mr. Cavaco and China's Prime Mnister, Zhao Ziyang, are scheduled to sign the accord.

title: Baseball Notebook; THIS YEAR'S ROOKIES AIM AT SUCESS OF '86 COUNTERPARTS
description: THE stock in and of rookies has risen this year. Seventy-three rookies opened the season on major league rosters, six more than last year, which turned out to be one of the best years ever for rookie performances. Some of the rookies who opened the 1986 season were Jose Canseco of Oakland, Wally Joyner of California, Pete Incaviglia of Texas, Danny Tartabull of Seattle and Todd Worrell of St. Louis. Although this year's crop is larger, it is not expected to produce the number of instant stars that emerged a year ago.

title: 7 ARTISTS IN NEW BRITAIN SHOW
description: THE double-barreled title explains as well as identifies the show that it is conferred on but does so slowly, as if its readers were chronically inattentive. It's a device that, notwithstanding a long career as a structural cliche, few curators can resist. The reason may be the commentations of solemnity that the construction has acquired.

title: POPE'S MESSAGES COVER DEMOCRACY AND DOCTRINE IN CHILE AND ARGENTINA
description: WHEN Pope John Paul II spoke last week of democracy and dictatorship in Latin America, more often than not he was addressing a debate within his own church. In Argentina, the Pope met bishops who used his presence to condemn human-rights violations by past military regimes, and other prelates who were equally determined not to reopen old wounds. Similar dissension troubled him the week before in Chile, where Roman Catholic leaders said publicly that they have been deeply divided by the 13-year rule of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: CURED NEW HERRING OF THE NETHERLANDS
description: Every year on a Saturday in late May, the Dutch herald the new herring season with a festival. It's called Vlaggetjesdag, or Flag Day, and in the harbor at Scheveningen, a resort and seaport two miles from The Hague, ships large and small are festooned with rainbows of fluttering flags. Local people from nearby fishing villages don traditional costumes; there are folk-dancing exhibitions, and folk orchestras play favorite local tunes.

title: GRAMMAR HOTLINES STAY BUSYZ
description: PUZZLED by punctuation? Riled by rhetoric? Help may be just a telephone call away.

title: Vicky Oliver Has Wedding
description: Victoria Anne Oliver, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lee Oliver of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Gordon Geoffrey Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Norman Cohen of New York and Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Charles Lippman and Judge Rodger Hunting of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony at the Palladium, a New York discotheque of which the bridegroom's father is a principal owner.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; MURRAY HILL
description: THE perception of the Murray Hill district on Manhattan's East Side as a genteel turn-of-the-century residential enclave is becoming as faded as an 1890s guerreotype as many of the area's old brownstones are converted into commercial space and residents are forced to move eastward into new high-rise apartment houses.

title: JOE ORTON TESTS HIS BIOGRAPHERS
description: WHAT WAS THE PLAY-wright Joe Orton really like?

title: ARE EMBASSIES CHRONICALLY INSECURE?
description: AFTER radical Iranian students climbed over a wall and overran the United States Embassy in Teheran in 1979, investigators found that only 13 lightly armed Marines and a few civilian security officers had been guarding the 27-acre compound.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO ADD TO SHORES INELIGIBLE FOR INSURANCE HELP
description: ''BUILD at your own risk.'' That is the warning the

title: BUYING TIME FROM THE TAX COLLECTOR
description: IF you are still struggling with your tax return, but it is becoming clear that you will not meet the Wednesday filing deadline, there is a hope of reprieve. It is called Form 4868, and if you file it by April 15, the Internal Revenue Service will automatically grant you a four-month extension to get your tax return in.

title: SUN TZU ON WALL ST.
description: THE CORPORATE WARRIORS By Douglas K. Ramsey. 261 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: LIBERIA OUSTS AMERICAN PRIEST
description: An American priest who served as vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Monrovia has been expelled from Liberia as an undesirable alien.

title: Exhibits of Kandinsky
description: To the Editor:

title: A WALL ST. LAW FIRM BREAKS RANKS
description: DECEPTION. Aiding and abetting a fraud. Conflict of interest. That doesn't sound like the kind of language one member of Wall Street's genteel legal fraternity would use about another.

title: Hartford Legislators to Vote on Social Issues
description: The General Assembly, entering the final two months of its legislative session, is preparing to vote on an array of social legislation that could put it at odds with Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: DOES THE HOLOCAUST DEFY DRAMATIZATION
description: IT'S DIFFICULT FOR A TELEVISION dramatization to come to grips with the Holocaust. Documentaries are better equipped. A dramatization, no matter how thoughtfully done, is still make-believe. A documentary need only show us, say, a pile of children's shoes. We feel a terrible sorrow then; the unimaginable has been expressed.

title: BOY DOESN'T MEET GIRL
description: WOMEN AND MEN By Joseph McElroy. 1,192 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: EXCLUSION FROM PANEL IS CRITICIZED BY CALIFANO
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr. said today that by barring him from the commission that Governor Cuomo had set up to investigate government ethics, state Legislators had ''extended an open invitation to every prosecutor in the state to take a look at them.''

title: DELIGHTING IN THE DISORDER OF THREE CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: THE 17TH-CENTURY POET Robert Herrick had some words for it: ''delight in disorder'' and ''wild civility.'' So did Shakespeare when he spoke of ''so musical a discord, such sweet thunder.'' Neither poet was referring to dance. Nevertheless, recent programs by Dana Reitz, Risa Jaroslow and Stephen Petronio brought those paradoxical phrases to mind, for all three choreographers concerned themselves with juxtapositions of extravagance and decorum.

title: Trump Bid Reported
description: DONALD TRUMP has contacted the owner of the Atlanta Falcons about buying the team and moving it to New York, according to a report in today's issue of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution.

title: MUSIC FILLS THE AIR FOR EASTER
description: LEAD: FOR the next week, choirs, instrumental and vocal soloists and organists have their work cut out for them as Long Island churches celebrate Holy Week with their customary outpouring of holiday music. As usual, the Easter segments from Handel's ''Messiah'' lead the programs, but this year there is also a concerted nod in the direction of more contemporary composers of religious music, such as John Rutter and Ralph Vaughan Williams.

title: HE DID NOT HEAR THE MERMAIDS
description: TWO ROADS TO DODGE CITY By Nigel and Adam Nicolson. Illustrated. 291 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $17.50.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
THE TRUTH ABOUT HOLIDAYS: NOT WHAT YOU REMEMBER
description: LEAD: MY parents taught me everything about holidays: the warmth and caring of the family bound together by a mutual history; the sharing of rituals and traditions, the respite from the stresses of the outside world, the joy of preparations. My parents lied. Nobody I know likes to make holiday preparations; we all like to remember making them.

title: Colleen Butler Is Wed
description: Colleen Haggerty Butler, a widow with two children, and Edward F. Foley, a widower with five children, were married yesterday at St. Peter the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in River Edge, N.J., by the Rev. Leroy Smith. Mr. Foley, the director of security for the Delaware North Companies in New York, was formerly the special agent in charge of the criminal division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York. Mrs. Foley is the debt placement manager for Computer Leasing in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Understanding Toscanini
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'CARMELITES' CAST CHANGES
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's current production of Francis Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'' is among the company's very finest, and I cannot imagine anybody interested in music, theater, history, theology or a half-dozen other disciplines allowing himself or herself to miss it. John Dexter's spartan production, the performances of Jessye Norman, Regine Crespin, Florence Quivar and the conducting of Manuel Rosenthal have already been discussed in these pages. On Tuesday night, however, two new principals joined the cast -Kaaren Erickson as Blanche and Dawn Upshaw as Sister Constance.

title: Outdoors; TALES OF FLY FISHING FOR TROUT AND MUSHROOMS DELIGHTS
description: LEE WULFF, one of the world's best-known and most respected anglers, has reached into his bountiful store of experiences and produced a sparse little book distilling his thoughts on trout and fly fishing for them.

title: Mr. Rosen's Long, Painful Death
description: LEAD: As far as I am concerned, Mr. Rosen - a pseudonym for one of my patients - died weeks before I knew him. Yet medically he was still considered alive when I met him. He was in the hospital's intensive-care unit for almost two weeks before he was transferred to my care on the general medicine floor.

title: DOCTORS CHALLENGE CORPS DUTY
description: THINGS have changed a lot for Dr. Mitchell L. Marks and his wife, Dr. Carolyn A. Houss, since they received $40,000 each in scholarships in 1980.

title: Pennzoil Refuses to Yield on Texaco Security Bond
description: The Pennzoil Company said today that it would not ease its demand for about $11 billion in security from Texaco Inc. The hard-line position puts even more pressure on Texaco to reach an agreement with Pennzoil or file for bankruptcy, a move that could come as early as Monday.

title: ANCIENT PRAGUE'S MODERN DISKS
