description: PRAGUE, THAT ANCIENT, golden city where the beer is strong and the gravy thick, has long been a center of musical composition and performance. Two hundred years ago, Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' and ''Don Giovanni'' had their first performances there. In the more recent past, Czech composers such as Dvorak, Janacek and Smetana have gained international repute, and the strong tradition continues to this day, with a cohesive musical life that is among the most vital in Europe.

title: A NEW JAPANESE NATIONALISM
description: IN A STUDENT AREA OF Tokyo called Takadanobaba, behind a peculiar sculpture showing a nude Marilyn Monroe about to pounce on a sumo wrestler, lies the office of Kunio Suzuki, leader of a ''spiritual movement'' called the Issuikai.

title: Unemployed, With Compensation
description: Being fired as chairman of CBS Inc. last September may have cost Thomas H. Wyman some pride and power, but it appeared to be no financial hardship. A CBS proxy statement released last week showed that Mr. Wyman received a settlement of more than $4.3 million and would get annual payments of $400,000 for life. The 57-year-old executive also got $1.1 million in salary and bonuses for 1986 and the right to exercise stock options worth an additional, undisclosed amount. Roswell L. Gilpatrick, a member of the CBS board, said the settlement reflected Mr. Wyman's accumulated benefits. ''What we were doing was simply putting into a dollar formula the sum total of the contract rights that Wyman had,'' Mr. Gilpatrick said. ''We didn't give him anything new.''

title: ACCEPTABLE TV/VCR ON A BUDGET
description: IF UNITED STATES GOVERN-ment plans for a 100 percent tariff on a variety of Japanese electronic products go into effect, the price increases that would likely result would strain the resources of many budget-minded television and VCR buyers, making it essential to seek models that offer acceptable performance at the lowest price. A recent survey of commendable bottom-priced models by Video Magazine paired them so that the total system cost for a TV/VCR combination would not exceed a list price of $700. With store discounts, the price would be even less.

title: The Illusive Low-Rent Apartments
description: INVINCIBLE COURT is a vintage apartment building of 1920's Harlem, a brick dowager with a dainty sitting area in the lobby and 53 brass mail boxes that still close and lock.

title: Thai Ferry Capsizes in Storm; 16 Die and 107 Are Rescued
description: A ferry capsized early today in the Gulf of Thailand, killing at least 16 people, the marine police said. An undetermined number of passengers were missing and feared drowned.

title: A CONDUCTOR WITH ROOTS DEEP IN THE BACH TRADITION
description: HELMUTH RILLING HAS won an international reputation as a Baroque conductor with an externally conservative style far out of step with that of the ensembles that have contributed most prominently to this decade's understanding of Bach and his contemporaries. When he comes to Carnegie Hall Saturday and next Sunday with his chorus, the Gachinger Kantorei, it will not be to offer the prospect of any new discoveries about the masterworks being performed nor about Baroque or Classical performance style, but rather the fruits of a long, deep immersion in the sacred choral literature of Germany.

title: ABSTRACTION: ALIVE, WELL AND FERTILE
description: LEAD: THE message filtering out from the new three-person exhibition at the Bryant Library Gallery is that abstraction remains fertile ground for exploring and creating new visual experiences.

title: PARENTS GO SHOPPING FOR TEACHERS
description: THERE is a spring phenomenon that, for many teachers, has become tradition. Soon, if it has not already begun, ''concerned parents'' will be filtering in and out of elementary-school classrooms, ''observing the teaching styles'' of their childrens' teachers for the next year, picking and choosing which one will be ''just right'' for little Johnny.

title: Toward Real Reductions in Weapons
description: The Soviet Union's decision to decouple its insistence on restrictions on the Strategic Defense Initiative from talks on intermediate-range nuclear missiles removes a major obstacle to achieving progress toward the Administration's goal of real arms reductions. However, as we proceed, we will be careful not to raise public expectations about when an accord on these missiles will be concluded.

title: 40 YEARS AGO IN BROOKLYN, ROBINSON'S CRUSADE BEGAN
description: ON April 15, 1947, Rachel Robinson left her room in the McAlpin Hotel in New York and rode the elevator down to Broadway and 34th Street. It was cold, and she was cradling her five-month-old son in her arms, worrying that she was late, wondering if she could flag down a taxicab to take her and her baby to Ebbets Field in Brooklyn to watch her husband cross the threshold of history.

title: SCHOOLS ACT ON SUICIDE RISK
description: SCHOOLS across Connecticut have been stepping up efforts to ease the risk of teen-age suicides.

title: MANUFACTURE -- OR ELSE
description: LONG ISLAND'S economy is considered by many to be in the midst of a boom that is unparalleled anywhere else in the United States. Employment is at a record high, real-estate values continue to escalate and dynamics have been established relating to renovation and rebuilding of aging areas. Our standard of living is the highest in the country.

title: A VIDEOTAPE IS SAID TO SUPPORT CHARGES OF POLICE BURTALITY
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday that it would conduct a grand-jury investigation into accusations of police brutality filed by a 27-year-old assault suspect whose arrest and purported beating was being recorded on videotape.

title: Next Week; How Big A Problem Is Racism In Sports?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: Following is a roundup of some of the notable recording releases of recent weeks. Liszt Organ Music. Vol. 1 Zsigmond Szathmary, organist. EMI-German Harmonia Mundi.Two compact disks. CDS 7 47533 8.

title: STUDENTS TRY EASTERN BLOC
description: AT A TIME when spending a semester or two studying in Britain, France and other Western European countries is common, hundreds of American college students are taking a less publicized route - to Eastern Europe.

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: One can empathize with Halston's loss of the right to his name. However, he did receive some compensation. There is no compensation for any person who buys a ''Halston'' fashion at J.C. Penney, thinking that the designer at least reviewed, if not actually designed, the garment. It borders on fraud to market under the name of someone who had no connection. MARJ ALBERT Danville, Calif.

title: WHAT WE TELL NATURE AND WHAT IT TELLS US
description: ''THE greatest delight which the fields and woods minister is the suggestion of an occult relation between man and the vegetable,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson said in an essay on nature. I would like to think I know what he means.

title: WITH AQUINO, TOO, PHILIPPINE POLITICS IS A FAMILY AFFAIT
description: AS one after another of the relatives of President Corazon C. Aquino enters politics, increasing attention focuses on the dominant role of family relationships in the Philippines.

title: IN TODAY'S ISSUE: Education Life
description: Section 12 today is Education Life, including these special reports:

title: Rev. Michael Peterson, Hospital Founder, Dies
description: The Rev. Michael R. Peterson, a priest of the Archdiocese of Washington who was the founder of St. Luke Institute, a psychiatric hospital for priests and brothers and sisters of the Roman Catholic church, died Thursday of complications resulting from the AIDS virus. He was 44 years old.

title: GUIDING ROCKWELL BEYOND THE B-1
description: ABOUT a year from now, if all goes as planned, a huge Rockwell International hangar in the California desert will open its doors and the 100th and final B-1B bomber will roll off the production line into the nation's strategic arsenal.

title: GOOD TIMES ON THE GREAT PLAINS: BEEF PRICES RISE
description: The ranchers' turn has come, cattlemen here in the Western plains are saying. After years of losses, they are now enjoying an upsurge in profits as one of the economic cycles that rule their fortunes has come full circle.

title: WARSHIP CLEARED FOR DUTY OFF IRAN
description: After a 38,000-mile test voyage, the battleship New Jersey has been declared ready for the first time to operate without air cover off the shores of countries of the third world such as Iran, according to Navy officers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, APRIL 12, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15 2,4.1,q>In South Africa, a new law on dissent went into effect, outlawing protest intended to encourage the release of political detainees. The law further tightened the country's 10-month-old state of emergency. Page 1

title: Building in the Classic Style
description: Once upon a time, luxury meant one advantage above all others - space. Sure, a grander house had more elaborate architectural details, finer construction and more bathrooms, but the real plus it had to offer was room. Ceilings were higher, rooms were bigger and there were more of them. It's no news that this kind of luxury is rare today. As prices continue to soar, the size of even the most luxurious residences being constructed now in both city and country has shrunk beneath norms that used to be taken for granted. It sometimes feels as if housing has become like nouvelle cuisine - you pay more to get less.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: MANY AMERICANS suffer from fear of glasnost. Mrs. J. T. of Boluma, La., for instance, writes that she ''can't sleep nights anymore for fear of what those Moscow glasnost devils are up to with their fancy-cut clothes.''

title: Baby M Writes a Chapter in History of Families
description: To the Editor:

title: No Wonder Mr. Gorbachev Wonders
description: Soviet Economic Improvement Below Expectations - headline in The New York Times, March 24.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Philadelphia: Towering Over William Penn
description: LEAD: LATE last month, ground was broken a few blocks from City Hall for yet another mixed-use office and retail development project that will rise higher than the old unofficial cap for the height of buildings.

title: ALBANY PROSPECTS: HOPES RUN HIGH
description: LEAD: RECENTLY the County Board of Legislators sent its yearly package of legislative proposals to Albany, prefaced, as always, by an expression of intent to work ''cooperatively with the members of the State Senate and State Assembly who represent Westchester.'' But this year, unlike some others, both county and state elected officials are cautiously optimistic that such cooperation will exist in practice as well as on paper.

title: No Headline
description: THE theme of the party was Connecticut agriculture, and there was nothing subtle about it.

title: REDESIGNING THE AMERICAN TEACHER
description: CATHY HAEUSLER is a junior at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign who is studying to become a teacher but often feels as if she has been asked to repeat elementary school. ''Everything I do seems to revolve around cutting things out and hanging them on the wall,'' she said.

title: A BIKE TOUR AROUND DENMARK'S GARDEN
description: Arriving at Steensgaard Herregards Pension by bicycle feels a bit like drawing up to the Plaza Hotel in New York on a motor scooter; a horse-drawn carriage might be more appropriate for both. Yet at Steensgaard, and for that matter at all of the Danish inns we pedaled to, the guest who arrives by bicycle is no surprise.

title: SOVIET 'RESTRUCTURING' - THE VIEW FROM SIBERIA
description: IN the frozen isolation of far northeastern Siberia, 4,000 miles from Moscow, adaptability is a matter of physical survival. For Communist Party leaders like Aleksandr D. Bogdanov, who became first secretary of the Magadan Province last September, it is a matter of political survival, too. Provincial officials like him are being closely watched for signs of adherence to the new Kremlin line, called ''perestroika,'' or restructuring.

title: U.S. SENTENCING PLAN URGES FIXED TERMS AND NO PAROLE
description: A Congressionally created commission on Monday will propose the most comprehensive changes ever in the criminal sentencing system used by Federal courts, including the end of parole.

title: HELPING HANDS FOR THE HOLIDAY
description: IT WAS almost Passover. The plans, made months in advance, called for the family to come to us in Cranbury for the seders.

title: Commercial Property: The Space Squeeze; It's a Matter of Balancing Expense and Efficiency
description: LEGAL assistants labor in the former employee-training room at Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, a Manhattan law firm. Secretaries enjoy as much elbow room as commuters on the IRT. Lawyers suffer the presence of extra desks in their once-private offices.

title: Affordable Ideas from Designers
description: Fifteen professionals offer straightforward but imaginative suggestions on how to brighten up a room or add a touch of elegance -- inexpensively. TOM PRITCHARD President, Madderlake, New York City

title: Tax Tip: Refinanced Mortgages
description: As procrastinators race to finish their tax returns by Wednesday, many may still be confused by new rules governing interest on refinanced mortgages. That is a big issue for two reasons: millions of Americans refinanced home loans last year as interest rates fell, and the new tax law rules on refinancings are retroactive to loans closed after last Aug. 16.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: U.S. Steps Up Its Warning on Travel to Peru

title: Ronny Whyte Sings In New Cabaret Setting
description: A new cabaret and restaurant called the Slate is taking shape in an old four-floor brownstone at the corner of 10th Avenue and 56th Street, but both food and entertainment are already being supplied. Ronny Whyte, the singer and pianist who will be entertainment director of the cabaret, is setting the style for the room in the second-floor dining room until the third-floor cabaret is completed.

title: Legal Services
description: To the Editor:

title: CLEMENS, IN FIRST START, IS RATTLED BY BLUE JAYS
description: Willie Upshaw capped a four-run fourth inning with his 100th career homer, a three-run blast, and Jesse Barfield hit a three-run shot in the seventh today as the Toronto Blue Jays spoiled the 1987 debut of the Boston ace, Roger Clemens, with an 11-1 victory over the Red Sox.

title: NIGHT AS DAY: LIVES IN REVERSE
description: LEAD: LAURA BLACK of Stamford sometimes grabs a light snack before going to bed and sits down for a short chat sits down for a short chat with her parents and her sister, with whom she shares a room. Then it's off to sleep, usually by 9 o'clock. While this may not sound too unusual, it must be noted that it is 9 A.M., and Ms.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: PARTICIPANTS in the long-running legislative battle over protecting freshwater wetlands say they are uncertain just how Governor Kean's recent entry into the debate will affect the shaky compromise worked out in the Assembly late last year.

title: Pregnant Girl's Ex-Boyfriend Shoots Her and Kills Himself
description: A pregnant Bronx teen-ager, who was shot once in the head by her former boyfriend before he killed himself Friday, was listed in critical condition yesterday at Lincoln Hospital, the hospital and the police said.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MEDIEVAL MUSICAL PLAY ''Ordo Virtutum,'' which means virtuous rite, is generally acknowledged to be the first musical play ever written - around 1150 in Germany. It will be performed at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers at 8 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday in Reisinger Hall, and again at 4 P.M. April 26 at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale.

title: CORRECTION
description: An In Short review March 29 of ''Stories We Listened To'' by John Haines listed an outdated address for the publisher. Bench Press has moved to 1355 Raintree Drive, Columbia, S.C. 29212.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: ACCORDING to most celebrities, it's no bed of roses being in their shoes. And don't talk about scrambling metaphors - celebrities don't get where they are because they were English majors.

title: THINGS THAT GO BUMP IN THE KITCHEN
description: ONE of the nicer things about living in the 1980's is the enormous variety of time-saving appliances and gadgets available. It's easy to learn how to use them; the difficult part, I find, is to know which sound from which is signaling, ''I'm all finished, dear.''

title: CABLE TV EXPANDS IN NEW YORK, BUT LIMITS PERSIST
description: On the doorsteps of Flushing, a form letter is being delivered that some long-frustrated television viewers had despaired they would never see.

title: ADDING VINYL TILE: IT'S EASIER THAN IT USED TO BE
description: PUTTING down a floor of colorful vinyl tile has long been one of the most popular do-it-yourself projects, and this is truer now than ever before. Recently, new colors and styles have enabled homeowners to put down floors that rival those of professionals, and improvements in adhesives and flooring materials have made installation simpler and more foolproof than ever before.

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: Halston is and was a magnificent talent. He is an American fashion independent in the genre of Charles James and Rudi Gernreich (victims both!), and that can be brutally frustrating.

title: CRIME
description: The Lovejoy of Jonathan Gash's MOONSPENDER (St. Martin's, $14.95) remains unchanged. Lovejoy, the scruffy antiques dealer who has figured in all the Gash novels, is still scrounging around to make an honest or (more likely) dishonest dollar. Perhaps he could do better if he did not spend so much time in bed. Women of all ages for some reason find him irresistible.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN THINKING OF TREES, ONES TO AVOID
description: LEAD: WHILE looking through mail-order nursery catalogues, one cannot help noticing the number of shade trees with undesirable characteristics. Some are short-lived, some subject to disease, some are brittle and some so competitive that little else will grow beneath their branches.

title: Liz Sturgeon Wed To A. I. Rorke 3d
description: Elizabeth Joan Sturgeon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Sturgeon of Bloomsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Alexander I. Rorke 3d, a son of Jacqueline Rorke of Waldwick, N.J., and the late Mr. Rorke Jr. of New York. Dr. Robert Berson, a leader of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite at 1A East 77th Street.

title: STAGE: FRANK MAYA, COMEDY
description: ''I 'M not a stand-up comic or a cabaret artist, I'm a ranter,'' announced Frank Maya, a downtown performance artist and musician, at the first of four Monday-evening performances he will give this month at La Mama, 74A East Fourth Street. Declaimed with a breathless hot-off-the-press enthusiasm, Mr. Maya's ''rants'' are stream-of-consciousness monologues that usually begin with a cynical observation and zoom all over the place.

title: 'Only the Dead.. .' Verbatim 'Only the Dead. . . .'
description: 'I do not bring forgiveness with me, nor forgetfulness. The only ones who can forgive are dead; the living have no right to forget. . . . The mourning of your deaths will be kept in eternal memory in our hearts - not to sustain an enduring enmity, not to maintain a sterile, debilitating hatred but to gain strength and steadfastness.' Chaim Herzog, President of Israel, visiting the site of the Nazi concentration camp at Bergen-Belsen, West Germany, where 50,000 people were killed. His visit to West Germany was the first by an Israeli head of state.

title: THE UNEXPECTED COSTS OF APPLYING TO COLLEGE
description: THE HEADMASTER of a private girls' school tells the following story, which occurred a few years ago at his school:

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: THE COST of travel between New Jersey and New York City went up today as toll increases took effect on the PATH train system and at all Port Authority of New York and New Jersey tunnels and bridges.

title: THE BUSINESS WORLD LEARNS TO 'LOTUS ON THE LAP'
description: LIKE many executives, Gary C. Lewis believes that his personal computer makes him a more productive manager. Using Enable, a program that includes a word processor, a speadsheet and other applications, the 34-year-old president of National Mill, a maker of industrial sewing thread, uses his computer to write letters and memos and to analyze his company's financial performance.

title: ASSEMBLY PANEL MAPPING PLANS FOR 21ST CENTURY
description: WHILE state and local governments wrestle with current problems, an Assembly task force is looking ahead to the next century and trying to decide what kind of state New Jersey should be and what must be done to insure that vision.

title: Matter of Law
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kathleen Murphy Wed To William Conran 3d
description: The wedding of Kathleen Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Murphy of Old Brookville, L.I., to William Francis Conran 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Conran of Locust Valley, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony.

title: A Transit Officer Kills Man During a Dispute
description: An off-duty transit police officer last night shot and killed the former husband of a woman described by authorities as a friend of his. The woman was injured by a shot as the officer and the former husband struggled, the police said.

title: FLORENCE
description: Florence in springtime puffs up its feathers and struts, like the million pigeons roosting on the city's cinnamon-colored cupolas. The hillsides are scattered with daffodils and red tulips, the almond and cherry trees are the first to blossom followed by yellow clouds of mimosa, while the irises, swathed at dusk in shimmering fireflies, grow along the cypress-lined avenues leading up to the Piazzale Michelangelo.

title: SALVADORAN SCHOOL PROPOSED FOR TIES
description: FROM his visit to the University of El Salvador two years ago, Van Gosse, a Rutgers University graduate student from New York City, has vivid recollections of empty libraries, bullet-riddled classrooms and students fearful of more military attacks on campus.

title: Brennan Hails State Courts' Record on Liberty
description: Praising state courts that have given broader protection to individual rights than the United States Supreme Court on which he sits, Justice William J. Brennan Jr. said today that this trend would show ''the true colors of purported federalists.''

title: SHAKESPEARE IN CAPITAL
description: The Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington will open ''Folger's Choice: Favorites on our 55th Anniversary'' on Monday to commemorate the years since its founding in 1932.

title: INQUIRIES UNSETTLE ISRAELI POLITICIANS
description: Behind the pre-Passover calm that traditionally envelops Israel this time of year some time bombs are ticking away beneath Israel's political establishment, and they have within them the power to change the face of Israeli politics.

title: NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: Following is a roundup of some of the notable recording releases of recent weeks. Cesar Franck: Les Beatitudes With Louise Lebrun, Jane Berbie, Nathalie Stutzmann, David Rendall, Marcel Vanaud, Francois Loup. The New Philharmonic Orchestra and Chorus of Radio France, conducted by Armin Jordan. Erato. NUM 75275 (two LP's); MCE 75275 (two cassettes); ECD 88217 (two compact disks).

title: Miss Hubert Wed To Jon Pressman
description: Linda Heddy Hubert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Selmar Hubert of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jon Pressman, a son of Donald A. Pressman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Nancy G. Comenitz of Boston. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman, assisted by Cantor Deborah Bard, performed the ceremony at Stouffer's of Westchester in White Plains.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS SPYING BY SOVIET UNION BEYOND 'BOUNDS OF REASON'
description: President Reagan, asserting that Soviet spying has exceeded ''the bounds of reason,'' vowed again today to make the espionage issue a high priority in Secretary of State George P. Shultz's talks in Moscow.

title: BLENDING HERITAGE AND CHANGE
description: ''WOMEN today are out in the world working, rather than in the house,'' said Ruth Willion Popkin, president of Hadassah, the 380,000-member Women's Zionist Organization of America.

title: THE CHANGES IN PORT JEFFERSON
description: Rarely in the 40 years that I have read The New York Times have I read such an article as ''Waterfront Project Debated'' on March 29.

title: DEBATE CENTERS ON FATE OF OLD VERMONT SCHOOL
description: From the front window of his general store in Shrewsbury, Glendon Pierce can see down the road to the Northam School. Mr. Pierce and his four brothers and sisters went to Northam in the 1920's. He remembers days so cold the children huddled around the wood stove to study, and outhouses that nobody bothered to label ''Boys'' and ''Girls.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SINGLES BY THE HUNDREDS IT was hard to tell who was getting more action, the exhibitors or the attendees at the New York Singles Expo and Convention, held last Sunday at the Holiday Inn in Plainview. While several hundred single men and women eyed the various displays, they were also busy eyeing one another.

title: Ms. L'Esperance Plans to Marry Mark R. Graham
description: Dr. and Mrs. Francis A. L'Esperance Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Ann L'Esperance to Mark Richards Graham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Graham of Tulsa, Okla. A September wedding is planned. The future bride expects to graduate next month from Tulane University. She was presented at the New York Junior League Ball in 1983. Her father is professor of clinical ophthalmology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: DESPERATE SHOTS DON'T ALWAYS WORK
description: WHEN a man has his back to the wall, he cannot be faulted for shooting from the hip. But that doesn't mean he will hit the target, either.

title:
ABOUT THE ARTS: WEST GERMANY;
IN CULTURE, AS IN SOCCER, CITIES COMPETE FOR TALENT AND STATUS
description: LEAD: THE CULTURAL LIFE OF the Federal Republic of Germany, an amalgam of 10 states and the sentinel city of West Berlin, has benefited enormously from fragmentation, dispersal and competition. West Germany has no Paris or London to cast intimidating shadows over the provinces. Rather, it has Frankfurt, West Berlin, Munich, Stuttgart, Hamburg and Cologne - roughly the first Bundesliga of the arts - and then a bewildering proliferation of smaller places, including

title: RESIDENTS OF NEW YORK AREA AMONG GUGGENHEIM FELLOWS
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has chosen 273 artists, scholars and scientists as winners of its 1987 fellowships. The awards, which this year total $6,336,000, are given on the basis of unusually distinguished past achievement and exceptional promise for the future.

title: WHALERS LIFT HOPES FOR TITLE IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD is reveling as its Whalers participate in the National Hockey League playoffs. Although the team has made the playoffs for the second year in a row and the third time since it joined the league in 1979, the Whalers have reached a new height - capturing the Adams Division title.

title: The Raft of the Medusa
description: To the Editor:

title: WATERFRONT RACE DRAWING TOP NAMES
description: WTH a large budget and a host of elite American runners, the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon is quickly being established as one of the country's premier races of its kind.

title: Miss Sanford Wed To R. S.Staffieri
description: Kristie Lee Samford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Sanford of Fox Chapel, Pa., was married yesterday to Ronald Steven Staffieri, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Staffieri of Hicksville, L.I. The Rev. James Dix performed the ceremony at the Fox Chapel Episcopal Church.

title: Q&A FOR THE MUSICALLY INCLINED
description: THIS IS THE GREEN-UP TIME OF YEAR WHEN students send critics long lists of questions, trusting that a passable term paper may somehow grow out of the answers. One cannot but be sympathetic to young scholars facing this perennial springtime crisis. I hurry, therefore, to respond to a survey of music critics being run by a Brooklyn College sociology student who assures me that my answers will help him earn valuable credits toward a degree and hints I may already be late with this assignment.

title: IMPROVING EFFICIENCY IN STATE GOVERNMENT
description: While I appreciate Martin Bierbaum's perspective in his March 15 Opinion Page article, ''Making Rules to Unmake Rules,'' he errs in assuming that the ''regulatory czar'' bill that I recently introduced represents the only effort being made by the Legislature to grapple with the complex problem of excess bureaucracy.

title: COUNTY PREPARING FOR NEW CODE ON SMOKING POLICIES
description: WHEN the Westchester Marriott Hotel finished extensive renovations last summer, 32 of its guest rooms were set aside to create a nonsmoking floor.

title: Dena Wilson and David Smallen Married in Capital
description: Dena Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wilson of Havertown, Pa., was married last night to David Smallen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Smallen of Bricktown, N.J. Rabbi Mindy Portnoy performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Washington.

title: DANCE: HOUSTON-JONES
description: Last summer, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Massachusetts provided several young choreographers with room, board and rehearsal studios and then let them do anything they wanted with their time and space. They did not even have to create a dance. However, all did, and their summer projects will be on view in separate programs through tonight at the Triplex of Manhattan Community College.

title: Atlanta
description: To the Editor: Having flown many a frequent-flier mile to Atlanta, I applaud Robin Toner's encapsulation of the city's beauty and culture (''What's Doing in Atlanta,'' Travel, March 15). One food note for those of us who are often in Atlanta on the run: The Mad Italian restaurant (2245 Peachtree Road) where the menu holds fast fun food and everyone is served in the upbeat ''how are you today?'' manner that makes the city so fresh and welcoming. DAVID L. HERTZ New York

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Brandon, Vt.: B&B;'s Enjoy A Fad Status
description: LEAD: SIS AND BOB POULIOT first looked at Cape Cod and elsewhere around New England, but finally found a house they could afford here.

title: AN ISLAND-BY-ISLAND LOOK AT SUMMER WEATHER
description: The weather on the islands of the Caribbean is, in general, slightly warmer and more humid in summer than in the high, winter season.

title: Art
description: Daniel Buren, a Frenchman, and Sol LeWitt, an American, are painters who have in common that they work on an environmental scale and in an idiom in which there is no trace of an individual hand. Buren works primarily with broad vertical stripes that can turn up anywhere, anytime. Though perfectly at home in museums and galleries, they also have a way of insinuating themselves into metropolitan landscapes the world over.

title: OPERA: MILCHEVA AS DALILA
description: ALEXANDRINA MILCHEVA, a Bulgarian mezzo-soprano and a member of the Bulgarian National Opera in Sofia since 1969, made her Metropolitan Opera debut Wednesday night as Dalila in Saint-Saens's ''Samson et Dalila.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: NORTHERN LIGHTS. By Howard Norman. (Summit, $16.95.) It is 1958, audio days, and in this entertaining first novel that won Howard Norman a Whiting Writers' Award for ''exceptionally promising emerging talent,'' the radio, finally, is the principal character. The story has depth and resonance as it is told by a teen-ager, Noah Krainik.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BETWEEN TWO WORLDS: The Life of a Young Pole in Russia, 1939-46. By K. S. Karol. Translated by Eamonn McArdle. (New Republic/Holt, $19.95.) K. S. Karol, an editor of Le Nouvel Observateur in Paris, left Poland at the age of 15 after the German invasion and traveled east. He traced in reverse the journey of his Russian-Jewish parents some years earlier, his heart ''beating more and more in unison with the USSR,'' where an older brother had told him that the future was being built.

title: Inquiry on Suns
description: THE Phoenix Suns' rookie center, William Bedford, is expected to be supoenaed to testify before a Maricopa County grand jury investigating possible drug use by current and former players of the National Basketball Association team, The Phoenix Gazette reported yesterday. The newspaper, citing sources familiar with the investigation, said the inquiry was focusing on suspected drug use by three or four current and former Suns players, but could possibly widen. Bedford, who played for Memphis State, has refused comment on his situation. He is currently on the team's injured list with a knee ailment.

title: Creature Comforts
description: My litany of household luxuries is simpler than most - I don't really want to live with taffeta curtains that puddle on the floor, with walls tinted by layers of hand-rubbed lacquer or even with a roomful of 18th-century museum-quality antiques. Luxuries like these are too costly and too obvious for my tastes. I prefer smaller and more subtle symbols: never running out of ice, not having to fumble for a bedside light switch, a television remote control that lets me effortlessly silence unbearable commercials. I am, however, fond of comfort, and although I don't like to admit it, some simple luxuries that I cherish - and that few others even notice -have probably cost me as much as a bird's-eye maple highboy.

title: DANCE
description: Natasha

title: Miss Whealan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Whealan Jr. of Eastchester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bernadette Marie Whealan, to Paul Alan Silverstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Silverstein of Dix Hills, L.I. The wedding is planned for June. The future bride is a microcomputer manager at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in New York. Mr. Silverstein is an account representative for Wang Laboratories Inc. in New York.

title: Joan Frawley Weds E. W. Desmond 2d
description: Joan Therese Frawley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Frawley of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Edward William Desmond 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Desmond of Centerville, Mass. Msgr. Eugene Clark performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Good Shepherd Church in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Birmingham, Ala.;
Suit Challenges Sale to the State
description: LEAD: THE sale of an 83-year-old downtown office building to the state's Department of Revenue has led to a political and legal controversy here.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: LAST RESORTS, by Clare Boylan. (Penguin, $4.95.) Harriet Bell, a lonely, divorced Englishwoman with three teen-age children, lures her lover off for an Aegean holiday in an attempt to wrest him from his wife. While Harriet is burdened with ''more problems than even the strongest character could resolve in this novel,'' Deborah Kirk said in The Book Review last year, the author's ''gift for stunning prose and unorthodox images is wonderfully evident.

title: 'Communion' and Extraterrestrials
description: To the Editor:

title: Press Freedom Challenged at Editors' Meeting
description: ''The press is not free,'' Michael G. Gartner, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, told his colleagues here this week for their annual meeting.

title: Meeting Offers Hope for Fewer Animal Tests
description: Efforts to use fewer animals for testing the safety of chemicals and consumer products are progressing, but they are still facing important technical and regulatory obstacles, according to top industry scientists.

title: PINE TREE LANE, ONLY FILLY IN RACE, WINS IN BOLD RULER
description: Pine Tree Lane, the only filly in a field of seven outstanding sprinters, outran the boys at every call to score an impressive 1 1/2-length victory in the $172,800 Bold Ruler Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Patrice King Thierfelder Weds Bernard Burke 3d
description: Patrice King Thierfelder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thierfelder of New York and New Cumberland, Pa., was married yesterday to Bernard Joseph Burke 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke Jr., of Malverne, Pa. The Rev. Dennis Dalassandro performed the ceremony at St. Joan of Arc's Roman Catholic Church in Hershey, Pa., assisted by Bishop William Keller of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Harrisburg and Msgr. Francis Taylor. Mrs. Burke, a model with the IMG Modeling Agency in New York, attended Marymount College. Her father is the director of administration for the New York law firm of Kenyon & Kenyon.

title: Miss Macklowe Engaged to Kent Swig
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Susan Macklowe to Kent Mason Swig has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Macklowe of New York, parents of the future bride. The wedding is planned for May 31. Miss Macklowe, a graduate of the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School and Ithaca College, is an assistant vice president of the Harry Macklowe Real Estate Company in New York, of which her father is the founder and president.

title: LESLIE A. CORNFIELD, A LAWYER, IS BRIDE OF MICHAEL URFIRER
description: Leslie Ann Cornfeld, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Cornfeld of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael James Urfirer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland M. Urfirer of Lake Placid, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Frazin performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: QADDAFI, TAKING SOFTER TONE, URGES U.S. 'MEET US HALFWAY'
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that since the United States Government had failed in its attempt to ''assassinate'' him a year ago, ''they should think of other alternatives to meet us halfway.''

description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars) $ M,04,15,10,10,10 Feb. 87 Feb. 86 Change New York 344 .5 303.6 13% New Jersey 267.2 186.6 43% Connecticut 104.0 75.3 38% Source: F.W.
