title: About Cars; COSTS MAKE TRACER A RARITY
description: MORE and more, the demand for small cars is forcing Detroit to go beyond America's boundaries in search of less expensive labor. Ford is the latest automaker to do that, and the company's Lincoln-Mercury division has a new baby called the Tracer, a good idea that has started, shall we say, inauspiciously.

title: MANAGER ACCUSED OF EMBEZZLING $198,000 FROM FLORIDA BANK
description: A bank manager embezzled nearly $200,000 after considering, on paper, the prospect of travel, parties and women against the risk of running out of money, getting caught and going to jail, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says..

title: Pamela T. Brunet Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Brunet of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Tower Brunet, to Andrew George Foster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Foster of Berwyn, Pa.

title: STEFANIE LEVINE TO BE BRIDE
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm Levine of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Stefanie Ruth Levine to Stephen Michael Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Cohen of Penn Valley, Pa. Miss Levine and her fiance are law students at New York University. She recieved a B.A. degree and an M.A. in English literature from the University of Pennsylvania. He is a graduate of the Wharton School at Penn. The wedding is to be in June.

title: GETTING NEW TEACHERS OFF ON THE RIGHT FOOT
description: NOTHING in my courses on Anglo-Saxon literature, or in pedagogy, or in my master's thesis on Chaucer had prepared me for this,'' Sylvia Barrett, the harried heroine of ''Up the Down Staircase,'' writes at the end of her first day of teaching.

title:
TELEVISION;
ONCE A NEBBISH, NOW A SEX SYMBOL
description: LEAD: WHEN THE LITHE, BLONDE actress walked into the 20th Century-Fox commissary, she didn't give the tables where the studio executives and producers were lunching a second look. Nor did she cast a glance at any of the handsome actors scattered around the room. Instead, she moved directly to the chair that had been saved for her by a little Koala bear of a man who had thoughtfully ordered her a salad while choosing to indulge himself with more caloric fare: a big helping of

title: ALBANY LEGISLATORS ADOPT BUDGET AMID ATMOSPHERE OF CONTENTION
description: A $41 billion state budget that cuts taxes, raises welfare benefits and increases aid to education was approved early this morning by the Legislature, ending one of its most contentious periods in years.

title: 'EXCESSIVE EAGERNESS'?: A CONSENSUS ON AIMS, BUT NOT ON MEANS
description: In the last six months, studies cascading out of Government offices and private research centers have produced a new consensus on the need to overhaul the welfare system. This time around, work is perceived as the solution to dependency, and training and job placement as the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle. But as last week's drafting sessions in the House and hearings in the Senate demonstrated, agreement on linking work to welfare is one thing, hammering out the details is another.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
BLACK CRAPPIE
description: LEAD: Pomoxis nigromaculatus

title: RANGERS SHUT OUT; TRAIL 2-1
description: The Rangers did not have to worry last night about the ringing question of the last few days: To fight or not to fight?

title: CHANGES SWEEPING UNIVERSITIES' CURRICULUMS
description: Students at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., will soon be taking more science courses. At Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., students are studying ''non-Western'' cultures. The faculty at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., recently voted to require students to delve into ''issues of gender.''

title: MOUNTING COMPETITION FOR COLLEGE TEACHERS
description: IF THERE is a talented black historian out there driving a taxicab because he thinks there is still an oversupply of college professors, Wesleyan University has a message for him: Reports of the glut have been greatly exaggerated. Indeed, after losing its black historian to the University of California at Davis last year Wesleyan has not been able to recruit someone of equal caliber to replace him on the Middletown, Conn., campus.

title: HOME VIDEO: FOOD
description: Richard Sax Demonstrates Secrets for Great Dinner Parties Baffico-Breger Video. (800) 228-5511. 90 minutes. $39.95.

title: Miss Carpenter Weds Physician
description: Elizabeth Carolyn Carpenter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Howard Carpenter of Irving, Tex., was married yesterday to Dr. Dirk Anthony Mayo Frater, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Frater of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Clayton Bell performed the ceremony at the Highland Park Presbyterian Church in Dallas.

title: POLITICAL ADS ARE FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: A conservative organization with tax-exempt status barring it from political work actively tried to influence Congressional campaigns last year with issue-oriented television commercials, according to people solicited for contributions and the group's internal documents.

title:
THE TEACHER;
WANTED: 1 MILLION TEACHERS
description: LEAD: ACCORDING TO the American Federation of Teachers and the National Education Association, more than one million new elementary and secondary school teachers will be needed in the next five years - approximately 200,000 teachers each year until 1992. Yet only 100,000 to 120,000 new teachers are entering the profession each year, according to Linda Darling-Hammond, director of the education and human resources program at the Rand

title: Rockers' Message
description: To the Editor:

title: At Your Service
description: Long ago, personal servants usually relieved well-to-do homeowners of the petty nuisances and inconveniences littering life. But now that service staffs are almost obsolete, the electronics industry has begun to manufacture a new type of product. Although perhaps not intended to fill this service void, these devices can do a noble job of freeing us from trivial details, usually at a much lower cost than servants - but without their human attributes.

title: Talking; Mortgages: Paying A Point on Committal
description: BUYERS have long been aware that they must set aside sizable chunks of cash - usually several thousand dollars - to to cover the points charges on their mortgages, otherwise known as loan origination fees. In the past, these sums have been payable at the time of closing.

title: Broadcast TV
description: In size, scope and impact, Franco Zeffirelli's ''Jesus of Nazareth,'' is the most formidable of the biblical-theme films showing this pre-Easter week on the home screen. Another drama stemming from the Scriptures is the lavish Hollywood version of Lloyd C. Douglas's novel, ''The Robe.'' And complementing the spring thaw will be ''Easter Parade,'' with Judy Garland, Fred Astaire and a festive wreath of Irving Berlin ballads.

title: THE ELUSIVE ART OF MULTI-TASKING
description: ''CONFUSION to the enemy'' seems to be the main theme of the International Business Machines' long-awaited announcement of a new line of personal computers. As it turned out, the machines, which were introduced two weeks ago, were not the clone killers they had been previously rumored to be. But their built-in graphics chips, their improved structure for transporting data within the computer and their monitors, which forsake the digital standard and function more like television sets, will certainly make the job of would-be duplicators more complicated.

title: Dr. Rhona Borts Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Borts of Natick, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Rhona H. Borts, to Dr. Edward J. Louis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Louis of Holland Patent, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June 7. The future bride and her fiance are molecular biologists at the Rosenstiel Basic Medical Sciences Research Center at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE WAKING GIANT: Gorbachev's Russia. By Martin Walker. (Pantheon, $17.95.) Mikhail S. Gorbachev was trained as a lawyer. His wife, Raisa, is a philosophy instructor at Moscow University. Their daughter, Irina, is a doctor and her husband a surgeon. Not surprisingly, then, the Gorbachev years signal the political arrival of the Soviet professional class.

title: Willows, Maples, Oaks: Enhancing Wetlands
description: Most developers dwell on the architecture, location and rates of their projects. But Joseph J. LiBassi, who is building a shopping center in the Dongan Hills section of Staten Island, prefers to ponder the 20,000 square feet of plantings that will grace a third of his one-and-a-half-acre parcel, about half of which is designated as wetlands.

title: JAPANESE WHALERS FACE HEAVY SEAS
description: In the warm promise of another spring, the talk was mostly about how it was good to be home.

title: PECE STUDIES RISE
description: AT Mount Holyoke College they debated the ''no first use'' resolution and Pacific nuclear-free zones. At the University of California at Berkeley they heard lectures on biological consequences of nuclear warfare. At Tufts University they designed research projects on treaties and human rights and on the effects of militarization on local economies.

title: TESTIMONY IS GIVEN ON SURROGATE BILL
description: Legislators seeking a bill that would regulate surrogate parenthood drew support this week from a majority of witnesses at an emotional State Senate committee hearing.

title: A CERTAIN MAGNETISM TO WORLD OF ANIMALS
description: IT is spring and people are feeling an animal attraction. Eyes gaze longingly through bars and glass; the urge to touch is irresistible.

title: BOUNCING BEEPS, FROM COAST OT COAST
description: DAVID HODGEMAN'S trucking company, Southern Pride, transports jet engines for some 40 airlines to airports all over the country. When a plane needs a replacement engine - and Mr. Hodgeman receives calls for such replacements more than once a day - his trucks are expected to arrive at the airport quickly enough to keep the flight schedule relatively intact.

title: Vermont Legislators Approve Increasing Speed Limit to 65
description: A bill raising the speed limit to 65 miles per hour on nearly all of the Interstate highways in Vermont has been approved by the State House of Representatives.

title: DESPITE CUOMO'S OPPOSITION, MEMBER ITEMS SURVIVE
description: The Legislature's cherished practice of member-item grants, which Governor Cuomo has criticized and sought to curtail, survived the state budget process virtually unscathed.

title: A NEW 'NAUGHTY MARIETTA' IN MILLBURN
description: IT'S NO surprise that the Paper Mill Playhouse has gone all out for ''Naughty Marietta,'' which runs through May 10.

title: DEVELOPERS REPLACING SULKIES
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has just begun on two more projects along Merrick Avenue in Westbury, continuing the recent commercial expansion on land formerly part of Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Ms. Kornreich, Insurance Executive, Is Married to Robert Rieger, a Banker
description: Nancy Jane Kornreich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Kornreich of Harrison, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last night to Robert James Rieger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Jerome Rieger of Newburgh, N.Y., and Boca Raton. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN THINKING OF TREES, ONES TO AVOID
description: LEAD: WHILE looking through mail-order nursery catalogues, one cannot help noticing the number of shade trees with undesirable characteristics. Some are short-lived, some subject to disease, some are brittle and some so competitive that little else will grow beneath their branches.

title: Eugene Gratovich In Violin Recital
description: Eugene Gratovich is a fine violinist, and he presented a recital of unusual interest at Merkin Concert Hall Monday night with Sylvia Golmon, a pianist.

title: ECONOMY IS THE KEY: THE OUTLOOK
description: In the last six months, studies cascading out of Government offices and private research centers have produced a new consensus on the need to overhaul the welfare system. This time around, work is perceived as the solution to dependency, and training and job placement as the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle. But as last week's drafting sessions in the House and hearings in the Senate demonstrated, agreement on linking work to welfare is one thing, hammering out the details is another.

title: THE GOOD LIFE AND NOTHING MORE
description: THE BIRTHMARK By Dorothea Straus. 206 pp. New York: George Braziller. $14.95.

title: STUDY URGES STEPS TO CURB EARTH'S WARMING
description: The buildup of carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere, which might warm the earth's climate to dangerous levels, could be significantly reduced if governments took concerted action, a study by an environmental research group said today.

title: THE ENCHANTING BLUE YONDER
description: STARING AT THE SUN By Julian Barnes. 197 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: PROTECTING THE PROTECTION: U.S. TO ADD TO COASTAL BARRIER LIST
description: THE Federal Department of the Interior has proposed adding 2,000 acres of land and water along the Connecticut shoreline to the Coastal Barrier Resource System, a national protective program along the East and Gulf Coasts.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: VIETNAM MEMORIAL Combining three traveling exhibitions, for the first and perhaps only time, ''Vietnam Veterans Memorial: A National Experience'' dominates the Bald Hill Cultural Park in Farmingville this month. Assembled by the Town of Brookhaven Council on the Arts to honor those involved in the war, the exhibition consists of a 250-foot replica of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial wall in Washington, inscribed with the names of the war's 60,000 casualties; a 70-piece Smithsonian Institution photographic essay and videotape of the dedication of that wall, and a copy of the original Fredrick

title: CASHIERS DE WOODY
description: LEAD: WOODY ALLEN ON LOCATION By Thierry de Navacelle. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: The Purpose of Lifting
description: I BEGAN LIFTING A few weeks before my 16th birthday, in May 1949. My closest friend and next-door neighbor had bought a used York barbell set and constructed a pressing bench from a slatted wooden cocktail table left unclaimed in the cellar of the Bronx apartment building in which we lived. Frankie had dropped out of high school a month earlier and was bound for Parris Island and the Marine Corps at the end of September. He had five months of life as a civilian in which to get his body into the shape the Marines demanded.

title: 'THE ASSAULT': THE LONG TRAIL TO AN OSCAR
description: IT IS JANUARY 1945 IN THE Dutch city of Haarlem. While most of Europe is sipping the libations of liberation, Haarlem is shivering under a blanket of gray as its starving inhabitants patiently wait for the war to end.

title: SHOULD PRO HOCKEY AND BASKETBALL ALTER PLAYOFF FORMATS?
description: Professional basketball should begin the playoff season the first week of April, immediately following the N.C.A.A. basketball championship tournament, when interest in basketball is at a fever pitch. The N.B.A. should also cut down on the number of teams eligible for the playoffs - preferably allowing only the top two in each division to compete - thus making the regular season meaningful again.

title: Shots Hit Two Vehicles
description: A motorist was slightly hurt and a section of Interstate 95 was closed for half an hour tonight after bullets hit a pickup truck and a car, the state police said. One shot shattered the truck's windshield near Exit 18 at about 5:30 P.M. The driver was cut by glass.

title: FOUR SAXMEN, ONE GREAT VOICE
description: AT THE DUKE Ellington School of the Arts, in Washington, people are shouting, whistling, catcalling, in the hope that the World Saxophone Quartet will return for an encore. More than 800 high school and college students, along with a smattering of adults, are carrying on as though this were a rock-and-roll show. But the body-stirring music they've just heard is jazz, performed by the most original and important group to emerge since Miles Davis, Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane redefined group improvisation at the end of the 1950's.

title: HOME VIDEO: HOW-TO
description: Dry Wall Part of Home Improvement Series. DIY Video Corporation. 5250 77 Center Drive, Charlotte, N.C. 28210. 30 minutes. $19.95.

title: SLEEP-IN YACHTS AND EAT-IN LUNCHES
description: YACHT sales are booming. Electric utility rates are dropping.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: ASPARAGUS SOON WON'T COST A BUNDLE
description: LIKE so many of the fruits and vegetables on the produce stands, asparagus can be found during most of the year. Nevertheless they are especially welcomed in spring. The green of asparagus adds a delectably bright note to seasonal menus.

title: Alexandra R. Mayleas Marries Peter L. Heth
description: Alexandra Rothschild Mayleas, the daughter of Ruth Rothschild Mayleas of New York and William M. Mayleas of Laguna Niguel, Calif., was married yesterday to Peter Lindsay Heth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Heth of San Diego. The Rev. Robert Russell, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Palms, a hotel in Avalon, Calif., on Santa Catalina Island.

title: ON TAKING CANDID PICTURES
description: A READER in Manhattan wants to know what camera to buy to shoot ''crowd scenes, carnivals and city scenes.'' He currently owns a Konica SLR with a 80-to-210 millimeter zoom lens, a combination he finds too heavy for a full day of street shooting. Among the ''miniature'' cameras he has under consideration are several brands of 35-millimeter rangefinders, such as the Minox 35 and the Olympus XA.

title: Chicago's Mayor Gains New Power Along With 2d Term
description: Chicagoans gave Mayor Harold Washington ''all the marbles,'' as he put it, in Tuesday's election. Not only was he re-elected by a comfortable margin, soundly defeating the alderman who had been a thorn in his side all through his first term; he also won a majority in the City Council.

title: THE SOARING COST OF PRICELESS WORKS
description: READING ABOUT THE $39.9 MIL-lion that was paid just the other day at Christie's in London for van Gogh's ''Sunflowers,'' I was reminded of an illustration that ran in the London Graphic exactly 100 years ago. Both image and caption got to the heart of something that has changed not at all in the last century, and most probably never will. In the illustration, Christie's porters were lifting a big painting high in the air for all to see. Every man in the room wore a top hat, and every one of the very few women had on a veil. And this is what the caption said: ''The Christie's audience revels in high prices simply for money's sake, though of course some of the applause is meant for the picture.''

title: IN BREWSTER, CALL HIM MR. MAYOR
description: FINGER sandwiches and dancing may become as familiar at Brewster Village Board meetings as environmental-impact statements and petitions, if the village's colorful new Mayor has his way.

title: DAYDREAMING NOTABLES CHANGE THEIR COURSES
description: LEAD: GROWING UP as the daughter of academics, the actress Judith Ivey had access to ample advice about courses of study and schooling. Yet even she is wistful about the path she chose. ''I wish I would have had a better understanding of the sciences,'' said Miss Ivey, who majored in drama while in college.

title: NEW YORK'S 2 NEW LANDMARKS EXEMPLIFY THE CITY
description: New York's newest landmarks - the former New York Central Building on Park Avenue and the San Remo on Central Park West - have long been exuberant pinnacles on the city skyline. They have a contemporary distinction, too. Their owners have maintained them as if they were landmarks and did not oppose the official designation.

title: Seeking Return Of 'Priceless' Copy
description: IT was only a copy of the Declaration of Independence, but it touched off a legal tug-of-war in New Hampshire.

title: STOPPARD'S 'DALLIANCE' IN NEW HAVEN
description: FROM the plays of Arthur Schnitzler (''La Ronde,''

title: DESIGN: THE RISKS OF RAZZLE-DAZZLE
description: AS THE BROADWAY MEGA-SPECTACLE ''Starlight Express'' moves toward its finale, the extravagant melange of flashing lights and moving trusses, bridges, ramps, platforms and turntables that is the show's set begins to shift and turn and rise and fall. The set's gyrations are at first puzzling, and then it becomes clear: a moment or two before the cast will take its final bows, the set is having its curtain call. And what could be more appropriate? This $2.5 million set, after all, is the real star of the show. ''Starlight Express'' has a thin plot, no memorable music and no book at all. But it has one of the most spectacular sets ever mounted, and its costumes are dazzling.

title: AUTO INDUSTRY WOES SET TONE FOR CONTRACT TALKS
description: The United Automobile Workers is beginning to develop proposals for a new labor contract amid predictions by union leaders that a crisis in the industry will make negotiations difficult and delicate.

title: Jeanne Auerbach, A Nurse, Marries
description: Jeanne Auerbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Auerbach of Essex Fells, N.J., was married last night to Dr. Jeffrey Lewis Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Cohen of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin and Cantor Erno Grosz performed the ceremony at the Forest Hills Jewish Center.

title: Wise Capitulation
description: A mother poses a springtime problem:

title: COAST GUARD TO STUDY TOWING
description: PRESSURED by Congress and commercial towing companies, the Coast Guard has decided to wait until after the summer before deciding whether to give its auxiliary members first shot at towing pleasure craft stranded in nonemergency situations.

title: EDMUND WILSON AMONG THE 'DESPICABLE ENGLISH'
description: I MET Edmund Wilson, I think, sometime in the early spring of 1946, after I had come back from Moscow to finish the job I was doing at the British Embassy in Washington. I had been in Washington during the war years, and my friend the Russian composer Nicolas Nabokov, who, like his cousin Vladimir, was a friend of Wilson's, thought that he might like to meet me (I had expressed my intense admiration for ''Axel's Castle'' and ''The Triple Thinkers'') and talk about Russian literature and other topics. Wilson refused. He was convinced that any British official could only want to meet him in order to rope him into the British propaganda machine. He was acutely isolationist: his Anglophobia, which in any case had been fairly acute, was increased by the reflection that England had once again managed to drag America into a dreadful and totally unnecessary war, and he had no wish to meet any representative of that country. However, once the war was over he evidently decided that he was no longer in any danger of being inveigled into pro-British activities, and asked me to lunch at the Princeton Club in New York.

title: SOME SEE LASER LIGHTS DANCING IN TIMES SQUARE
description: In the minds of a few technological adventurers, a futuristic Times Square is taking shape that threatens to make the neon past look somber.

title: THE LIBRARY OF NONEXISTENT CLASSICS
description: IS reality necessary? Lighthearted, lightfooted reader, do not flee! Our subject is no tough ontological rind. (Philosophers, go home.) It is, rather, the mazy gossamer of make-believe; the desire to be invisible; the longing for strange histories that never were; the urge to slip loose from one's own life. In short, the overcrowded precincts of nonexistence.

title: Rules Britannia
description: ON MY FIRST DAY as an exchange teacher at the Ipswich High School for Girls in Suffolk, England, I entered the classroom and 30 14-year-old girls, identically dressed in gray skirts and red sweaters, rose to their feet and stood in utter silence. I walked to the front of the room. I could barely suppress a giggle - what a far cry, both in distance and behavior, from my suburban Connecticut students. I looked each of the 30 squarely in the eye and intoned, ''Good morning, girls.'' The girls, well prepared, chorused back, ''Good morning, Mrs. Reade.'' Still they stood, and still silence reigned. Like a queen instructing her subjects, I gravely announced, ''You may sit down.'' And they sat.

title: Bond's Wife Recants Accusation
description: The estranged wife of the civil rights leader Julian Bond told the police that her husband used cocaine daily, but later told Atlanta newspapers that she had given false information while ''emotionally distraught,'' the newspapers reported today.

title: ART IS NOT ENOUGH
description: ARTISTS & ENEMIES Three Novellas. By Arthur A. Cohen. 274 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $17.95.

title: Intangible But Attainable
description: Silence, light, space and a view are the earth, air, fire and water of homes - elements that are basic to building desirable environments. There are, however, few apartments or houses with them all, and none, it seems, with too much of them. Especially in apartments in crowded and expensive urban areas, they have often become luxuries. But unlike ''hard'' luxuries, such as silver, fine cabinetry or antiques, they are commodities of the immaterial sort, and where they are lacking, they can be nurtured through design. The noisy apartment can be quieted; the dark one, brightened; the small one, made to appear larger, and the one with no view, given scenery of its own. SILENCE

title: Poll Finds Jews Are Tough Critics of Reagan
description: American Jews remain one of the most Democratic groups in the American electorate and among the strongest critics of President Reagan, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW ROLE FOR AN OLD FIREHOUSE
description: LEAD: RUTHERFORD'S informal little Park Avenue Cafe is the kind of restaurant that I almost hate to finish reviewing. I'd like to drop in one more time for the angelhair pasta studded with succulent lobster chunks in a creamy vinaigrette or, perhaps, the medallions of veal with fresh artichoke bottoms in green peppercorn sauce and then maybe finish with chocolate-chip bread pudding in a pool of bourbon creme anglaise.

title: JOANNE CAMPBELL TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Campbell of Blue Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanne Campbell to Randall Schiefer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Scheifer of Reading Pa. The future bride is a vice president in the international arbitrage department of Salomon Brothers in New York. Mr. Schiefer is a systems coordinator for Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.

title: 'Sunflowers' Goes To Tokyo Insurer
description: The mystery of who paid a record $39.9 million for Vincent van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' was solved last week when the owner of the world's most expensive painting was revealed to be the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Japan.

title: Jackie Robinson, Hero
description: MY father worked at a news agency, so we often heard the big news before it was on the radio or in the papers. There were two calls in a single year that I remember most - the first on April 12, 1945, and my mother crying because F.D.R. was dead. How would we manage without him?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
GRID STAR
description: LEAD: In 1978, Sister Mary Virginia Orna, a professor of chemistry at the College of New Rochelle, was looking for a hobby. ''I had been a crossword-puzzle solver all my life, but solving them was becoming less of a challenge and constructing them seemed to be an interesting and inexpensive hobby,'' said Sister Mary Virginia, who is of the order of Saint Ursula.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: CLARISE CUMBERBATCH WANT TO GO HOME. By Joan Cambridge. (Ticknor & Fields, $15.95.) Clarise Cumberbatch is as vulnerable and naive a poor greenhorn as you are ever likely to meet or read about. Asked by a customs agent at Kennedy airport if she has anything to declare, she replies, ''Only that it cold.

title:
RECORDINGS;
NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: LEAD: Following is a roundup of some of the nota-ble recording releases of recent weeks. Wynton Marsalis: Carnaval Eastman Wind Ensemble. Donald Hunsberger, director. CBS Masterworks 42137. All three configurations.

title: Dance
description: Several choreographers are making unusual use of music this week. Bill Cratty has commissioned a score from Galt MacDermot, composer of ''Hair,'' for ''Going Bananas,'' one of three premieres that the Bill Cratty Dance Theater will offer Thursday at 7:30 P.M., Saturday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday afternoon at 3 at the 92d St. Y. Although set to existing scores, the other premieres are also musically enterprising. ''Muggsy'' is to jazz recordings by Muggsy Spanier and ''Andante Favori'' is a solo to Beethoven. Speaking of Beethoven, Sunday night at 9 is the last chance to see Stephanie Skura's ''Cranky Destroyers'' at P.S. 122. Ms. Skura, a sharp choreographic satirist, has set this work to Beethoven's Symphony No. 5. She calls it ''funny, serious, idealistic and very physical'' - which sounds as if it may have something for everyone.

title: SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE ABOLITION SOUGHT
description: FOR the fifth time in as many years, opponents of the Suffolk County Legislature have filed a petition calling for a countywide referendum on replacing the Legislature with a board of supervisors composed of the 10 town supervisors in the county.

title: A GOLDEN RULE FOR SOFTWARE
description: IN THE classroom and elsewhere, educational floppy disks are entitled to the same copyright protection as the more traditional textbooks. But while illegally duplicated books are easy to spot, the same is not true of software; Once tucked inside a personal computer, the disks are invisible. And many publishers say they fear their material is being copied by student hackers and teachers, for reasons ranging from the fun of breaking a manufacturer's copy-proof code to undersupplied courses that rely on software. Whatever the reason, the result is borne out in red ink for the publisher.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: KITTY FROM THE START By Judy Delton. 141 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFSHDL
description: Tonight was one of those nights when they couldn't get tomorrow off their minds. With both Washington goals essentially scored by Islanders, it was the kind of game they wanted to forget.

title: Texaco Loses Important Round
description: Ever since the Pennzoil Company won a multibillion-dollar lawsuit in 1985 against Texaco Inc., the defendant has been struggling to avoid bankruptcy. With about $35 billion in assets, Texaco faces that prospect unless the judgment, which is now more than $10 billion with interest, is overturned on appeal.

title: 'MOTOR VEHICLES. PLEASE HOLD...'
description: LET'S say that you've moved and you've got to change the address on your driver's license and automobile registration.

title:
ART;
WOMEN TEST LIMITS OF PHOTOGRPAHY
description: LEAD: WRITING to her colleague Frances Benjamin Johnston in 1897, the photographer Eva Watson declared ''there will be a new era and women will fly to photography.'' This optimism was shared by a enough members of her sex to have produced a remarkable group of female photographers active at the turn of the century.

title: Webster Promises He'd Change C.I.A.
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee will wait until after the Easter recess to vote on whether William H. Webster should be Director of Central Intelligence. But his promises over two days of hearings last week seemed tailored, if anything, to heighten the Congressional applause that greeted his nomination.

title: What Price Glory?
description: WHAT SHOULD WE PAY FOR OUR wine?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BOND. OLD BOND
description: LEAD: It doesn't take much to prod Patricia Dohren-wend to do some spring cleaning - just a 115-year-old municipal bond.

title: 'TAKE MY CLASS ...'
description: LAST WINTER, after 25 years of being a class clown, Murray Rosenthal finally got what he deserved - a moment in the spotlight.

title: Marianne Savare Plans to Marry Ronald A. Walter
description: Mrs. Leo Savare of Memphis, Tenn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Marianne Savare, to Ronald Anderson Walter, a son of Norris O. Walter of Memphis and the late Estelle Anderson Walter. A June wedding is planned. The future bride, the daughter also of the late Mr. Savare, is a science teacher, and her mother, Elsie Savare, is an elementary-school teacher in the Memphis school system. She graduated from the University of Tennessee at Knoxville and is a candidate for a master's degree in education at Memphis State University. Her father was a supervisor for the Postal Service in Memphis.

title: Vatican's Right to Speak On Human Procreation
description: To the Editor:

title: What's the Alternative in Nicaragua?
description: Pay, shoot or talk. Those are the choices in Nicaragua. The United States can continue lavishing millions on the contras, the problematic rebel army. Or it could send in the Marines. Or it could negotiate with the Marxist Sandinistas.

title: VARIED PROBLEMS COMPLICATE ISSUE OF GARBAGE DISPOSAL
description: THE disposal of Westchester's garbage, long a focus of debate, took on new complexity last week when private carters were temporarily barred from the resource-recovery plant in Peekskill, municipalities were asked to refrain from delivering bulk refuse and heavy rains created additional problems.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A selection of quotations about the Baby M case last Sunday misidentified the rabbi of the Jewish Center of Teaneck, N.J. The rabbi, who is also the author of ''Health and Medicine in the Jewish Tradition,'' is David M. Feldman.

title: REFUND TO TENANTS IS OVERTHROWN
description: An appeals court has struck down a 1985 court order that would have forced landlords to refund $300 million in fuel-adjustment and vacancy allowances to tenants of more than 800,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City.

title: Winner, by a Surprise
description: Perhaps no punch thrown in the middleweight championship boxing match last week was as stunning as the outcome. Confounding sportswriters who scoffed at his chances and gamblers who took the 3-1 odds against him, Sugar Ray Leonard, who had not fought in nearly three years, won a split decision over Marvelous Marvin Hagler, who had not lost a bout in 11 years. Leonard, the former welterweight champion, outpointed Hagler with superior speed of hand and foot. Speculation that the challenger might re-injure his left eye - he suffered a detached retina in 1982 - proved unfounded. ''I did what I was capable of doing,'' said Leonard, who earned at least $11 million for the bout. Hagler, who earned at least $12 million, disputed the judges' decision. ''I feel in my heart I'm still champion,'' he said.

title: BARBARA COOK: MIXING CABARET WITH BROADWAY
description: A TYPICAL ONE-PERSON BROAD-way show is a hyperbolic star turn in which a performer is escorted by an entourage onto a glitzed-up stage for an evening of self-congratulation. But Barbara Cook, who is opening her one-woman show Wednesday at the Ambassador Theater, will not be cavorting with a chorus or ducking in and out of a flashy set. The 59-year-old lyric soprano, whom Stephen Sondheim described recently as ''one of the two or three finest singers of song,'' will appear onstage with an eight-piece band to sing some 20 pop and theater songs, most of which she has been performing for years in her cabaret act.

title: FOOD
description: AS A BOY GROWING up in Alsace during World War II, Andre Soltner did not always sit down to a bountiful Easter dinner. ''Sometimes,'' he says, ''I was on the edge of hunger.'' At other times, there was plenty to eat because his father was a very good cabinetmaker. Mr. Soltner explains the connection: ''Sometimes you could get lamb on the black market. My father charged so much for a cabinet. Plus a barrel of wine or half a lamb.''

title: JAPANESE BUYING A PLACE ON WALL STREET
description: THE financial markets have long been among the most international of businesses, and Wall Street's financial companies are usually eager to attract foreign investors, both for the operating capital and the business contacts they provide. But when two Japanese financial institutions purchased parts of two major Wall Street firms, the reaction was bittersweet.

title: KURRI, MESSIER SPARK OILERS
description: Jari Kurri and Mark Messier scored two goals apiece to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Kings and a 2-1 lead in the Smythe Division semifinal series today.

title: Kristin Chase Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Kristin Ann Chase to Donald Beales Taylor has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Weldon Alvah Chase of West Simsbury, Conn. A July 25 wedding is planned. Miss Chase, a graduate of Colby-Sawyer College and the University of Rhode Island, is an account executive for Adams, Rickard & Mason, an advertising and public relations firm in Glastonbury, Conn. Her father is a district sales manager for the Stanley Works, a tool manufacturing company in New Britain, Conn. Her mother, Clarice Chase, is a department coordinator for the Simsbury Board of Education.

title: A PEEK AT SOVIET MANSION
description: IT is not every day that the Soviet Government exposes its imposing Glen Cove mansion to public view, but it did so the other day for a group of Long Island businessmen.

title: The Costs of True Luxe
description: If luxury is a personal matter, along with one's age, tax returns and waist size, the price of luxury is even more personal. Nothing is considered more declasse than discussing how much something costs, including home decor. The pages of glossy magazines are filled with homes designed to bring to mind the adage ''You can't afford it if you have to ask.''

title: MUSIC RINGING OUT TO CELEBRATE EASTER
description: LEAD: HOLY WEEK - Palm Sunday to Easter - is not only the most important time on the Christian calendar, but also has inspired some of Western civilization's most impassioned music.

title: MEN'S STYLE
description: THE THREE-BUTTON suit, long perceived as an emblem of decorum, is quietly making a comeback. Spurring its revival are lean, uncluttered lines and a patrician appearance evocative of more gracious times. These days, fans of the style can choose from a wealth of interpretations, all of which, to some degree, retain a traditional look. They range from a pale linen coat and trousers by Hackett of London - it is modeled on a classic Brooks Brothers prototype - to Bill Robinson's advanced rendition with extended shoulders.

title: Performance Art
description: The recent work of John Jesurun, the avant-garde director, writer, designer and film maker, provocatively explores the confusion between filmed and ''live'' reality by featuring actors who compete, interact, and even trade places with filmed characters.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BUXTEHUDE'S BIRTHDAY Legend has it that Johann Sebastian Bach walked 200 miles from Arnstadt to Lubeck to hear Dietrich Buxtehude play, so strong was Buxtehude's influence on young Johann. Yale University School of Music will celebrate the 350th birthday of the Danish composer and church organist with a symposium of concerts and other events today through Tuesday.

title: MANY ALIENS AVOID U.S. AMNESTY PLAN
description: LEAD: CHURCH and other private groups working with illegal aliens say fear of the Government could deter many aliens from applying for the Federal amnesty program that starts next month.

title: SIZING UP BASEBALL SALARIES
description: Fifty-seven players began the baseball season assured of earning $1 million or more this year. Sixty-six players of the 663 who were on opening-day major league rosters or the disabled list will earn $62,500, the minimum salary.

title: AMPHIBIANS VERSUS DEVELOPERS
description: LEAD: THE tiger salamander is a creature only a few inches long, but it has grown large in importance in the Town of Southampton as environmentalists seek to halt or significantly alter a subdivision plan that would disturb the amphibian's habitat.

title: Recent Sales
description: Boonton $260,000 Rockaway Valley Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; stone fireplace, 2-car attached garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,217. East Windsor $163,500 4 Braxton Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old condo minium town house; central air-condition ing, 1-car detached garage; maintenance $88, taxes $2,669. Jackson $142,500 11 Buckingham Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old contempo rary; enclosed yard, wall-to-wall carpeting, family room; taxes $2,000. Short Hills $400,000 111 Parsonage Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $6,198. Springfield $157,000 27 Tulip Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; fenced yard, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,910. Toms River $210,000 1585 Sea Island Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; family room with fireplace, hardwood floors, deck, full basement; taxes $2,650. OTHER AREAS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $360,000 317 Elm Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 62-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun room, deck, porch, walk to village; taxes $6,232. Orange, Conn. $363,000 565 Broadview Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; dead- end road, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Smithtown, L.I. $161,000 23 Briaroot Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old split level; dining room, den, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200.

title: Bruckner's Impact
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY DECIDES ON A KOSHER KITCHEN
description: IT has been a little more than a year since an Oreo cookie has passed through our kitchen door. Or a slice from the local pizza parlor for that matter. You see, we made our home kosher last year.

title: STAGE: 'MAMA DRAMA,' COLLAGE ON MOTHERHOOD
description: The joys, pangs and anxieties of motherhood are treated with sympathetic self-awareness in ''Mama Drama,'' an unassuming little collage of sketches at the Ensemble Studio Theater. The show is the collaborative venture of seven articulate women, five of whom also appear on stage. In spite of the diversity of hands and the brevity of the individual pieces, ''Mama Drama'' has a cohesiveness, which can be attributed to the director, Pamela Berlin, and to the point of view shared by the participants.

title: A TEST FOR WOULD BE TEACHERS
description: The following multiple-choice questions are from the 1983 National Teachers Examination. The sampling is taken from the section dealing with professional knowledge. Answers appear at the bottom. 1. Because of energy conservation measures in the school district, classroom thermostats have been lowered to 68 degrees. Students in a particular class complain about the cold, but the temperature conforms to the school district guidelines. The teacher could most successfully urge the students to accept the situation in a realistic way by saying which of the following? a. ''You're right, it is cooler than we are used to, but the thermostat has been lowered to save energy, so we'd all better keep our coats on for now and come dressed for a cooler room.'' b. ''It doesn't seem so cold to me. I'll bet you won't even notice it after a while.'' c. ''I'm sorry, but it won't do any good to blame me - I don't control the thermostats.'' d. ''I don't agree, but those who feel it is too cold tomorrow should present their complaint to the principal.'' e. ''Yes, I know. But tell me, do you think we would have this problem if our government stood up for our rights against all those countries that are our energy suppliers?'' 2. During oral reading, a pupil reads ''axt'' for ''asked.'' This oral reading behavior must be evaluated in terms of the a. context clues available b. pupil's written work in reading c. pupil's conversational language d. end-of-unit test in the teacher's manual e. oral reading behaviors of others in the class 3. A fourth-grade class is going to visit a museum for the first time. In order to prepare the pupils to learn from the experience, the teacher should do which of the following? = I. Give the pupils a set of questions about the exhibits in an effort to focus their attention during the visit.

title: Alison Robbins Weds Dr. Gould
description: Alison Gwen Robbins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robbins of Manhattan, Bedford, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married last night to Dr. Howard Gould, a son of Susan Gould of Brookline, Mass., and Dr. Lawrence Gould of Boca Raton, Fla., and Casco, Me. Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik performed the ceremony at the Plaza assisted by Cantor Ellen S. Math.

title: Damage Award in Scalding
description: A Federal jury has awarded $2.5 million to Carroll J. Moore Jr., who was severely scalded while showering at the Venice Inn and Motel in Hagerstown in November 1982. Mr. Moore, 40 years old, suffered extensive burns and respiratory injury in the 162-degree shower. The jury found April 2 that the Watts Regulator Company of North Andover, Mass., which makes a valve that the motel had installed to regulate water temperature, was liable for damages. Testimony indicated the valve had corroded. The company plans to appeal.

title: AIDS Virus Carrier Indicted
description: James Vernell Moore, 44 years old, a prison inmate who is a carrier of the AIDS virus, was indicted Thursday by a Federal grand jury for assault with a deadly weapon at a Federal medical center. Mr. Moore, who had been serving a seven-year sentence for credit card fraud in Virginia, is said to have bitten two guards at the medical center at Rochester, Minn., on Jan. 7.

title: ERSATZ TOMBSTONES REPLACE THE HISTORIC
description: IN an increasing number of Connecticut cemeteries, he who steals a historic gravestone steals a fake. Cemetery associations around the state are replacing old gravestones with concrete copies, saving the originals from thieves, vandals and the weather.

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: With all Halston's ''power'' friends, he should be able to do something for the good of our New York City art and design schools. He could give lectures to design students who would pack auditoriums for some free words of advice.

title: Richard Baskin Jr. Is Wed To Elizabeth B. Vrooman
description: Elizabeth B. Vrooman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Vrooman 3d of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard T. Baskin Jr., a son of Alice D. Baskin of Easton, Pa., and Mr. Baskin of Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. W.Bradford Greeley performed the Unitarian ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Separatists Kill 5 in India
description: Sikh separatists in the north Indian state of Punjab have killed five people and burned more liquor, tobacco and barber shops, the police said today. The militants have burned and looted more than 150 shops in the last month. Alcohol, smoking and the cutting of hair are forbidden by the Sikh religion, but the campaign is also seen as an attempt to destabilize the state's Sikh Government.

title: COLLAPSE PLACES NEW EMPHASIS ON BRIDGES
description: WHEN he heard last Sunday that a bridge had collapsed on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in upstate New York, Robert W. Gubala, the chief engineer of the Connecticut Transportation Department, was on the telephone to Albany offering any personnel, equipment or consultations that might be needed.

title: ON THE BRINK OF AN ANTI-BUSINESS ERA
description: BE warned: America is approaching another era of business-bashing. In recent months, high-level officials in the Reagan Administration have attacked bloated, inefficient and irresponsible management. Wall Street has succumbed to scandal. Military contractors have admitted to overcharging the Pentagon. Populist, anti-business rhetoric is finding its way into the early speeches of Presidential aspirants. America is reaching an historic turning point in its cycle of righteous fulmination, and business has none to blame but itself.

title: Understanding Toscanini
description: To the Editor:

title: Understanding Toscanini
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
THE BASICS OF A TREND IN CROP RAISING
description: LEAD: HAD anyone asked me a year or two ago if I considered myself a biodynamic gardener, I might have said ''yes,'' after a pause for a mental joke about being more bio than dynamic. My answer would have been sincere, but incorrect. Biodynamic gardening, for me, used to mean careful composting, crop rotation, companion planting, a reliance on raised beds and cover crops and avoidance of pesticides and synthetic fertilizers.

title: PROPOSED HIGHWAY DEBATED IN MAINE
description: For years, residents of Maine's economically depressed northern communities have watched as southern and coastal Maine cities savored development's boons. Now northern Maine residents say, it's their turn: They want the state to build a highway across Maine that would bring development and perhaps an end to hard times.

title: Amy Rosenfeld, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Rosenfeld of Albany have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Ruth Rosenfeld, to Daniel Alan Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Kaufman of Highland Park, Ill.

title: A TROVE IN A TEAHOUSE SETTING
description: MOST OF THE CATEGO-ries of antiquities and medieval works in ''Japanese Art from the Tajima Collection,'' at Sugimoto Works of Art (through May 23), have not been seen often in New York galleries since before World War II. The occasion for this most unusual low-key exhibition of 35 ancient terra-cotta figures, gilded bronzes, calligraphy, medieval metal mirrors, lacquered boxes, ceramic vessels and paintings is the opening of the new galleries for Japanese art at the Metropolitan Museum on April 25.

title: TWO 'ODD COUPLES' ARE BETTER THAN ONE
description: THEATER THREE in Port Jefferson is alternating productions of the male version of Neil Simon's ''Odd Couple'' with a female version of that play. Both are filled with uproarious laughter, and both are extremely well done. It is your choice which you want to see.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Van Halen: Live Without a Net Warner Reprise Video. 90 minutes. $29.98.

title: Streetscapes: 134 East 60th Street; Holding Out in a Once-Gracious 1865 Brownstone
description: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

title: Sheila S. Berner Is Engaged To Christopher G. Kennedy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Berner Jr. of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sheila Sinclair Berner to Christopher George Kennedy, a son of Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy of McLean, Va., and Hyannis Port, Mass., and the late Senator Kennedy. An August wedding is planned.

title: A NEW PRODUCT FOR CIGARETTE VENDING MACHINES
description: Cigarette vending-machine operators, who have been losing business steadily, may soon be offering the public a new product. Cigarette-sized packages of four condoms and an information booklet on AIDS could start appearing, next-door to packages of cigarettes, in cigarette vending machines in public washrooms nationwide as early as next month.

title: Loan Program for Affluent Students Initiated
description: A group of university officials and bankers have announced that they are initating a new loan program that would lend students up to $15,000 a year at rates currently around 9 1/2 percent.

title: Patrick Fay Wed To Tina Patterson
description: Maria Christina Patterson, a daughter of Edward Patterson of New York, was married yesterday to Patrick Michael Fay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Fay of Joliet, Ill. The Rev. William C. Cunningham performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN THINKING OF TREES, ONES TO AVOID
description: LEAD: WHILE looking through mail-order nursery catalogues, one cannot help noticing the number of shade trees with undesirable characteristics. Some are short-lived, some subject to disease, some are brittle and some so competitive that little else will grow beneath their branches.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE TOUGH COUGHS AS HE PLOUGHS THE DOUGH:

title: Betty Lee and D. A. Ruffle, Computer Designers, Wed
description: Betty Lynn Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Lee of Beaumont, Tex., and Donald Alan Ruffle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Ruffle of Chatham, N.J., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Lewisville, Tex.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in The Times Magazine today - ''Legacy of a Mother's Murder'', by Peter Maas - tells of a lengthy child-custody battle between the child's paternal grandparents in Indiana and his maternal aunt and uncle in New York City.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PUBLISHING PROGRAM
description: LEAD: ''The opportunities in book publishing are vast, but very few high school kids know much about it. We want to tell them about the field and let them know there are jobs available,'' said Al Silverman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Book-of-the-Month Club, which is sponsoring a new publishing program for high school students this spring through the SUNY Purchase Westchester School

title: PRINCE BREWS UP A MORE DANCEABLE ALBUM
description: ONLY PRINCE COULD LAND ''Sign o' the Times,'' a song about AIDS, drugs, sudden death and nuclear war, in the Top 10. And only Prince would conclude, after verses filled with deadpan alarmism, ''Let's fall in love, get married, have a baby.'' On his double album, ''Sign o' the Times'' (Paisley Park/Warner Bros. 25577, LP, cassette and CD), the one-man studio band from Minneapolis dispenses ambitious music, commercial know-how, calculated eccentricities and wacky obsessions, all thoroughly entangled. By now, his audience expects no less. In some ways, Prince has retrenched for ''Sign o' the Times.'' It's harder-edged, less orchestral and more danceable than his last two albums, ''Around the World in a Day'' and ''Parade.'' After his movie-video-record blockbuster, ''Purple Rain,'' whose soundtrack sold more than 10 million copies, those albums (and the film ''Under the Cherry Moon'') did comparatively poorly. But on ''Parade,'' especially, Prince was testing new musical territory - and now, moving like an inchworm, he's letting his tail catch up with his head. Dance grooves and all, ''Sign o' the Times'' reaffirms Prince's ambitions while reasserting his popularity.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ALBERTA HUNTER: A Celebration in Blues. By Frank C. Taylor with Gerald Cook. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Although she won international renown as a blues singer in the 1920's, Alberta Hunter enjoyed her greatest celebrity only after coming out of retirement in 1977, at the age of 82. From then until her death in 1984 she was the toast of Presidents and talk-show hosts, admired as much for her indomitable spirit as for her undiminished talent.

title: CHILDREN'S FESTIVAL OF ARTS IS OUTLINED
description: LEAD: THE president of the Nestle Foods Corporation, C. Alan MacDonald, and the executive director of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, Christopher P. Bruhl, announced earlier this week that Nestle had awarded a $13,250 grant to the council to support the ''Imagination Celebration,'' a festival of 200 events throughout next month that is dedicated to children and the arts.

title: Spring Spending Cools
description: A late Easter is usually good for business: Balmy weather helps retailers sell their spring merchandise. But this year's late Easter won't be enough to get overall consumer spending to bloom.

title: THE SCIENCE OF BEACHGOING
description: LONG ISLAND enjoys the best of two waterfront worlds - its North and South Shores. Yet few of us know how to use the local meteorological advantages for adding at least two months to our nationally famous beach season.

title: LILCO SOUNDS SHARP ALARM ON POWER
description: LEAD: AS much as bird songs and greening lawns, warnings from the Long Island Lighting Company about electrical shortages have become harbingers of warmer weather on Long Island.

title:
TENNIS;
Graf and Maleeva Move Into Final
description: LEAD: Steffi Graf of West Germany and Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria won exhausting semifinal matches at the Family Circle Magazine Cup today.

title: Poll Shows Most in U.S. Back Baby M Ruling
description: The American public overwhelmingly supports the decision in the Baby M case to turn the child of a surrogate mother over to her father, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: License of Bankrupt Jersey Casino Is Renewed
description: The operating license of the Atlantis casino hotel in Atlantic City has been renewed, despite the hotel's bankruptcy, by the Casino Control Commission.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THINGS BRIGHT AND BEAUTIFUL
description: LEAD: Twenty-three years before the American Declaration of Independence, the British Museum embarked on the acquisition of important jewelry collections. Nowhere else has jewelry been collected and studied for so long. In 1976, Hugh Tait, the deputy keeper of the Department of Medieval and Later Antiquities at the British Museum and a world-renowned scholar, mounted an exhibition titled ''Jewelry Through 7,000 Years'' that drew on this wealth.

title: STANDING UNSTEADILY ON WHETHER TO RUN
description: I WOULD LIKE to take this solemn opportunity to declare my noncandidacy for the Presidency of the United States of America. Those of you who are still reeling from Dale Bumpers's decision not to run must be wailing, ''How can we possibly survive two such political earthquakes back to back?''

title: BROWN SKIES STIR HEALTH, JOB FEARS
description: AROUND the turn of the century, people with tuberculosis and other lung problems came here by the thousands, hoping the dry, gin-clear air would ease their illnesses. Today, Denver's air is often so polluted with auto fumes, wood smoke and industrial emissions that doctors warn some patients not to venture outdoors. In winter, when temperature inversions seal in pollutants, downtown is blanketed in a pall of foul-smelling smog that darkens streets and makes even the hardiest westerners wheeze and wipe tears from their eyes.
