title: LEARNING BY ROTE: A NEW APPRAISAL
description: SOLVE the following problems in American education:

title: 2 Attacks Are Reported Near Lebanon's Border
description: Israeli military helicopters rocketed roads near Shiite Moslem villages in southern Lebanon today, killing two people and wounding four others, according to the state-controlled radio.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Secretary Baker's comment was interpreted as a license to sell.'' Richard E. Witten, Goldman, Sachs vice president, after Mr. Baker said the decline of the dollar was ''orderly.''

title: Soviet Astronauts Walk In Space
description: Two Soviet astronauts walked in space today to investigate what went wrong when the new Kvant space research module failed to dock with their orbiting station Mir.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: One Crazy Summer With John Cusack, Demi Moore, Bobcat Goldthwait. Written and directed by Savage Steve Holland. 1986. Warner Home Video 94 minutes, $79.95.

title: DODGERS FINALLY FIND A PLACE IN VICTORY COLUMN
description: Pedro Guerrero and Mike Scioscia hit bases-empty home runs in the second inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers ended a five-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The defeat was the first for the Giants, who had won their first five games for the first time since 1962.

title: EXPERIENCING LIFE IN A CLASSROOM FROM THE OTHER SIDE
description: AS a student of Eastern philosophy and religion, I am familiar with the term karma, which, simply put, means that what we do to others will be done to us. I had always assumed that one had to die and return to life in another incarnation to replay karmic debts, but I've been proved wrong.

title: BREAKING THE CYCLE: SUCCESS STORY IN THE STATES
description: In the last six months, studies cascading out of Government offices and private research centers have produced a new consensus on the need to overhaul the welfare system. This time around, work is perceived as the solution to dependency, and training and job placement as the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle. But as last week's drafting sessions in the House and hearings in the Senate demonstrated, agreement on linking work to welfare is one thing, hammering out the details is another.

title: THE STORK OUGHT TO HAVE ONE OF THESE
description: WHEN Charna Iommetti went into labor, she was alone in her Philadelphia apartment. Her husband, Keith, was driving to New York on a business trip.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: Ride a Wild Pony Starring Michael Craig, John Meillon, Robert Bettles and Eva Griffith. Directed by John Chaffey. 1976. Walt Disney Home Video. 86 minutes. $69.95.

title: Maine's Capital
description: To the Editor:

title: CLAM TRANSPLANTING CRITICIZED
description: LEAD: AN established, state-regulated system for transplanting clams from the polluted waters in western Long Island bays to clean clam beds on the East End is being sharply criticized as unfair by many independent baymen.

title: NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: Following is a roundup of some of the notable recording releases of recent weeks. Schuman: Symphony No.7 Balada: Steel Symphony Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Lorin Maazel. New World Records NW 348-2 (All three configurations).

title: All in Good Fun
description: Palm Sunday Salute April 12 - ''The Spiritual Heritage,'' a symphonic suite for orchestra, choir and soloists by Howard A. Roberts, will be conducted by the composer at Carnegie Hall in a Palm Sunday celebration of the black tradition in music. A 5:45 P.M. Champagne reception at Cafe Carnegie will precede the 8 P.M. concert by musicians from North Carolina Central University. The evening is a benefit for the Afro-American Music Foundation, which was recently established at the university to support research in black music. Tickets, $100, from 212-989-3426 or for the concert alone, $10 to $50 at the door. Party at Lincoln Center April 15 - Created in 1971, the New York Foundation for the Arts is holding its first benefit, a dinner-dance at the Lincoln Center library. The first Champion of the Arts Award will be presented during the evening, which will begin with cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by dinner at 8. Peter Duchin's orchestra and the Billy Taylor Trio will provide the music. Tickets, $275, from 212-233-3900. Night at the Ballet April 20 - The eight-week spring season of the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House will open at 7:30 P.M. with the New York premiere of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's production of ''The Sleeping Beauty.'' The black-tie evening is a benefit for the troupe. Tickets for the performance only are $45, $50 and $75, and those for the performance and a 6 P.M. reception at the Lincoln Center library (Champagne, sandwiches and desserts) are $125 and $250. Tickets for the performance and a Champagne supper afterward are $500 and $1,000. For information: 212-477-3030. Theater Readings April 20 - At the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street, 25 actors will read from their favorite or most recent roles. Teresa Wright and William Roerick's selections will be from ''Ah, Wilderness,'' and Viveca Lindfors, Kate Reid and Alvin Epstein will perform from other works. The 8 P.M. readings will benefit the Source Foundation, a theater group that specializes in readings from Ibsen, Strindberg and Chekhov. Champagne and a light buffet will follow the performances. Tickets, $50, from 212-734-4289. Benefit at Avery Fisher April 21 - After he conducts the New York Philharmonic in Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony at Avery Fisher Hall, Leonard Bernstein will be presented with the 1987 Albert Schweitzer Award. A cocktail party, dinner and dancing will follow on the promenade. The black-tie event will benefit Amnesty International and the Creo Arts Fund, a division of the Creo Society, a nonprofit educational organization that sponsors the Schweitzer award and produces other events to recognize and encourage art, science and philanthropy. Tickets, $100 for the 8 P.M. performance alone or $500 and $1,000 for the performance and party ($250 for those under 35), from 212-581-2571. Paul Taylor Premiere April 21 - The Paul Taylor Dance Company opens its monthlong season at City Center with the 7 P.M. premiere of Mr. Taylor's ''Syzygy,'' after which guests will be served Champagne as they board buses for a ride down to the New York Academy of Art on Lafayette Street, where a dinner and dance will be held. Tickets for the black-tie benefit, $250, from 212-966-6959. For Minority Lawyers April 22 - The Paul Robeson Scholarship in Minority Legal Studies at Columbia University is named for the late athlete, actor, singer and civil rights advocate, who was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Rutgers University and a 1923 graduate of the Columbia Law School. Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta will address a black-tie benefit dinner for the scholarship fund in the rotunda of Low Memorial Library near Broadway and 116th Street on the Columbia campus. The evening will start with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets, $150, from 212-280-2681. Springtime at the Plaza April 22 - The Plaza's Grand Ballroom will be festooned with spring flowers at the annual dinner-dance benefit for the Voice Foundation, which sponsors research and educational programs on the causes, treatment and prevention of voice disorders. Tickets for the black-tie event, which will begin with cocktails at 7 P.M., are $350, from 212-644-0152. Touch of the South April 22 - A bit of Savannah, Ga., one of the architectural showcases of the South, will be transported to Lord & Taylor for a benefit for the Historic Savannah Foundation. Regional foods, period dress and the Savannah Town Crier will be featured at a cocktail buffet at the store from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $50, from 212-391-3632. Artists' Party April 23 - After creativity, perhaps the next major requirement for visual artists is work and exhibit space, neither especially easy to find in New York. Artists Space, a nonprofit group, runs a gallery on West Broadway and offers financial and professional support for emerging artists. A benefit for the organization will be held at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, starting at 7 P.M. Dress will be informal. Tickets, $175 for dinner and a party afterward from 9:30 P.M. to midnight or $50 for the party alone, from 212-226-3970.

title: Miss Keating Wed In Massachusetts
description: The wedding of Alison Anne Keating, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Keating of Wellesley Hills, Mass., to Robert Gustaf Hedlund 3d, a son of Mr. Hedlund Jr. of Chicago and Caroline Lamb of Berkeley, Calif., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. William O'Connor performed the ceremony.

title: Everyday Artifacts
description: One day, we may marvel that it took so long for the artifacts of daily life to be recognized as works of art. For years, we have been celebrating abstraction in modern art, the purity of form in design, the use of unadulterated materials in architecture. But in antiques, only the most sophisticated and ornate would do.

title: IMPROVING PUBLIC'S ACCESS TO JUSTICE
description: LEAD: ON THE third floor of the Burlington County Courthouse here, six people in a simply furnished office run an ambitious experiment to enhance public access to justice and resolve a wide range of disputes without the cost and trauma of litigation.

title: BOATERS TURNING MORE TO DISCOUNTERS
description: CLYDE LOVETT of Boston recently took a day off to buy some things for his home.

title: Mutual Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: Lisa Belkin's article ''The Prisoner of Seventh Avenue'' (March 15) was another reminder that corporate minds and creative minds do not good bedfellows make. Halston himself said it best when he described one such corporation as ''landing on the Halston planet.''

title: Israeli Is Slain on West Bank; Settlers Riot in an Arab Town
description: An Israeli woman was killed by a firebomb thrown into her car in the occupied West Bank Saturday, and in response hundreds of Jewish settlers rampaged in the West Bank town of Kalkilya overnight, breaking windows and setting cars ablaze.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Water-Use Curbs Frustrate Development
description: LEAD: WHEN the state's Department of Environmental Conservation imposed limits last summer on the amount of water that suppliers in Nassau could pump out of the ground each year, the purpose was to force local governments to take conservation measures.

title: Mixed Feelings
description: IT was Tony Pena's first trip back to Pittsburgh since the April 1 trade that sent the popular all-star catcher to the St. Louis Cardinals, and for a while it could hardly have been a happier homecoming. The high-spirited Pena, who played 801 games for the Pirates and cried when he learned of his trade to the Cardinals, pranced round the bases before the game and received two thunderous ovations from the 52,119 fans. Then, while batting for the Cardinals in the ninth inning of the 4-3 Pirate victory, he was struck on the left hand by a Brian Fisher pitch, suffering a broken thumb. Yesterday, he was placed on the disabled list and now he will be out of the lineup at least six weeks. Steve Lake will share catching duties with Tom Pagnozzi until Pena returns.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Okamoto Leads by 3: Ayako Okamoto of Japan, making three straight birdies on the back nine, shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead entering the final round of the $200,000 L.P.G.A. Kyocera Golf Classic in San Diego. Okamoto, holding the lead for the third straight day, had a three-round total of 205, 11 under par on the par-72 course and three strokes ahead of Pat Bradley and Betsy King, who each shot 71. Patty Sheehan, the defending champion and a three-time winner here, was a stroke behind King and Bradley.(AP) LACROSSE Cornell 19, Syracuse 6: The Big Red, ranked second in the nation, routed third-ranked Syracuse, 19-6, yesterday as Steve Meyer, a sophmore attackman, scored seven goals and Jim Goldstein, a junior attackman, had a school record of nine assists. The loss snapped Syracuse's 30-game winning streak at home as it fell to 4-3 for the season. Cornell is unbeaten at 7-0. The Big Red took a 6-0 lead after one period on the strength of two goals by John Wurzburger.(AP) BOWLING Crites Wins Title: Tom Crites of Tampa, Fla., rolled clutch strikes in the ninth and 10th frames to defeat Amleto Monacelli of Venezuela, 232-218, in the $150,000 Showboat Atlantic City Open. The title is Crites's second. Monacelli, who was bowling for his first title, earned his sixth second-place finish. Monacelli earned $14,000, won three matches on the way to the final.(AP) FIELD HOCKEY Americans Win Tournament: In Edinburgh, a second-half penalty corner goal by Megan Donnelly enabled the United States to edge Britain, 1-0, and win a six-nation pre-Olympic women's field hockey tournament. The British team went into its final match against the Americans unbeaten and without having given up a goal. But the Americans staved off pressure throughout the first half, with Patty Shea excelling in goal with a series of brilliant saves. The goal came in the 58th minute. In other matches, Ireland defeated Spain, 4-2, and South Korea edged the Netherlands, 3-2. The Americans finished the round-robin competition with a 4-1 record for 8 points.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Title to Uniondale: The Uniondale High School boys and girls won six track and field events and captured the combined team title at the 20th annual Nanuet Relays. Four victories came in the girls' division as the Long Island school tallied 108 points, 62 scored by the boys, which was enough to win the trophy in that division. Uniondale was led by twin brothers, Kelvin and Kevin McQueen, who won the high jump relay at 12 feet 4 inches. Monique Chin Quee was a member of two winning girls' relays. Two meet records were posted. Suffern, with Bill Brooks, running a 1:53 seconds 800-meter split, was first in the sprint medley in 3 minutes 31.60 seconds. Mount Vernon's 300-meter shuttle hurdles girls threesome was clocked in the winning time of 51.05 seconds.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on March 29 about three pianists misidentified the composer of ''Bagatelles.'' He is Peter Lieberson.

title: 60's CHAPLAINS REFLECT ON STUDENTS TODAY
description: ONE ASPECT of academic life has little to do with finals or grades, professors or administrators. It is the province of campus chaplains and involves, as the Rev. William Sloane Coffin describes it, ''the education of the heart.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on April 5 about the commissioning of orchestral works misidentified a principal patron of the New York Philharmonic and the American Composers Orchestra. He is Francis Goelet.

title: Regine Crespin Feted By Metropolitan Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera's general manager, Bruce Crawford, gave an engraved silver tray to Regine Crespin, the French mezzo-soprano, at a ceremony Wednesday evening celebrating her 25th annniversary with the company and her farewell engagement.

title: No Excuses
description: Taxpayers still puzzling over their 1986 returns might think twice before telephoning the Internal Revenue Service for help. A recent study by the General Accounting Office found that the agency gives wrong or incomplete answers to 37 percent of those calling its toll-free help lines.

title: Iris Schneider to Be Wed To Dr. A. E. Weingarten
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Schneider of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Iris Schneider, to Dr. Alexander Eugene Weingarten, a son of Dr. Ruth Weingarten of Laurelton, Queens, and the late Dr. Morris Weingarten. An October wedding is planned.

title: KOCH INNER CIRCLE IS STILL UNBROKEN
description: UPHEAVAL has been an unrelenting feature of Edward Koch's third term from its first days more than a year ago to as recently as last Thursday, when Bess Myerson became the latest city official to be pressured out of office.

title: PUTTING A STOP TO RAPID CURRENCY SWINGS
description: JUST about everyone is dissatisfied with the wildly fluctuating currency values - euphemistically called ''floating'' or ''flexible'' exchange rates - that characterize today's international monetary system. Without a common monetary standard, under which exchange rates could be stabilized, the remarkable economic integration of Western Europe, North America and East Asia in both commodity trade and financial flows has become less efficient, and is becoming untenable.

title: AIRPORT PLAN DRAWS MIXED APPRAISAL
description: LEAD: A MASTER plan that proposes a new passenger terminal, a new taxiway and other improvements at the Westchester County Airport drew a mixed reaction last week at a public hearing.

title: B.B.B. OFFERS SETTLEMENT SERVICE
description: Although the third of five articles on litigation (March 29) dealt with alternatives to suing, it overlooked the Better Business Bureau's mediation-arbitration program to settle customer-business disputes, which has been offered to New Jersey consumers since 1976.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BARS PROTESTS BACKING DETAINEE FREEDOM
description: South Africa tightened its 10-month-old state of emergency today by putting into effect a law forbidding any protests on behalf of political detainees.

title: CHRISTIANS SHARE JOY OF SEDER T>By CHARLOTTE LIBOV
description: ''BARUCH atah Adonai Eloheinu melech ha-olam borei p'ri hagafen,'' chanted Cantor Deborah Katchko-Zimmerman, beginning a blessing said in Hebrew before the drinking of the four ritual glasses of wine at the Passover seder.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIFE PULSE: Episodes From the Story of the Fossil Record. By Niles Eldredge. (Facts on File, $19.95.) In ''Life Pulse,'' Niles Eldredge, the curator of invertebrates at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, presents the panorama of our planet's history through the lens of paleontology.

title: FASHION VIEW
description: SOME YEARS AGO, THE sight of her first Krizia collection filled one fashion retailer with dismay. ''I cried,'' she remembers.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Delaware On Stage

title: Voices of Spring, Faster and Louder
description: The thawing brooks sounded almost like birdsong, flowing into gray creeks still cuffed with ice which debouched into rivers swelling green with the spring - where phoebes rode down the currents on little ice cakes to grab the first stoneflies. As the snow melted off the fields, skunks and coons snapped up voles and moles whose tunnels had been exposed; and crows did the same, when they weren't pairing off, stalking around chatting shoulder-to-shoulder, while courting killdeer wheeled in the air overhead as agile as terns.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BEEPERS
description: THE scene: a hushed theater, mid-performance. A beeper emits its high-pitched, staccato tones. A plumber gets up and rushes for the phone.

title: MAKING ELECTRICITY, WITH A DOSE OF CONSERVATION
description: When John Warshow and Mathew Rubin met at a demonstration at the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Plant in Vernon nearly 10 years ago, they were bound together by their interest in alternative energy and by a chain locking them in protest to the power plant fence.

title: A GUIDE TO SPRING SALES IN CARIBBEAN
description: Until about the middle of April, the islands of the Caribbean and the Bahamas are in their high, fashionable and more expensive season. Then comes a swift turnaround.

title: Philadelphian Accused of Pocketing Public Funds
description: A community organizer has been arrested and accused of pocketing public housing funds in a case of ''gross governmental mismanagement'' involving the wasting of up to $1 million, District Attorney Ron Castille said.

title: Reuss Released
description: IT was his first major decision since taking over Al Campanis's duties as the Dodgers' vice president for player personnel on Wednesday, and for Fred Claire, the Dodgers' executive vice president, it was a hard one. He cut Jerry Reuss, the pitcher who had played a key role in Dodger championships in 1981, 1983 and 1985. ''He has been an outstanding pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers,'' said Claire, who praised the 37-year-old lefthander as a ''great competitor who has always given his best.'' Reuss, who has compiled a 194-163 record over 16 seasons, played eight years for the Dodgers after being obtained from the Pirates.

title: Contract Dispute Over U.S. Bayonet
description: WHAT it wanted, the Army said, was a bayonet that would do more than simply impale an enemy. Its specifications called for a bayonet that could also snip double-twisted barbed wire and half-inch rope, even saw through an aircraft fuselage.

title: Bardot Ordinaire
description: VOULEZ-VOUS DANSER AVECMOI? LE REPOS DU GUERRIER A COEUR JOIE! All starring Brigitte Bardot. 90 to 100 minutes each. Kartes Video Communications. $19.95 each.

title: Perspectives: South Bronx;  Port Morris Industrial Area Coming Alive
description: TEN years ago, when a company called Borda Products made its appearance in the Port Morris section of the South Bronx, metaphorically minded writers were calling Port Morris the ''soft underbelly of the city.''

title: OFFICIALS CRITICIZE DISCLOSURE PROPOSAL
description: A PROPOSAL to require that Brookhaven officials make public their personal financial data is being assailed by many town officials as a threat to political progress.

title: Golf; CRENSHAW AND MALTBIE SHARE MASTERS LEAD
description: Ben Crenshaw, an admitted sentimentalist seeking his second Masters title in three years, birdied four holes in a row and five of the last seven today to gain a tie for the lead with Roger Maltbie through three rounds of the 51st Masters.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Virginia Beach, Va.;
Schools Give Site an 'F'
description: LEAD: A BATTLE over a school site has focused attention on this growing city's development problems.

title: THE NATION'S WELFARE PROFILE
description: CHARTING THE POPULATION Og the more than 11 million people in Aid to Families with Dependent Children... 50.0%have been there 8 or more years 65.8%are 18 and under 28.1%are under 6 58.7%of parents and guardians are not white 41.9%have had 9 to 11 years of education UNDER THE POVERTY LINE Maximum monthly welfare benefit for a family of four*

title: ONE FAMILY'S TALLY
description: Before Walter Hee, a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science in New York, walked into his first class at Columbia University last fall, his family had already invested more than $2,000 toward helping him make the ''right decision.'' The Hees' costs, shown below, are less than they might have been had the family traveled extensively and incurred hotel expenses. They helped keep costs down by choosing four local colleges, and two that were a little more than 200 miles away. During the Hees' visits to Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., they returned home to Queens the same day, and during their visit to Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., they stayed with relatives. In addition, Walter, unlike many other students, chose not to take cram courses to prepare for admissions and achievement tests, which would have increased costs further. College Admission Tests Scholastic Achievement Test (S.A.T.) $15 Achievement Tests (3), $12 each 36 $51 Application Fees Massachusetts Institute of Technology 40 New York University 35 Cornell University 45 Queens College 25 Columbia University 40 Cooper Union 20 $205 Transportation (3 round trips to Ithaca) 3 travelers, one way plane 630 3 travelers, one way bus 360 (One round trip to Boston) 2 travelers, plane 280 Costs of visits to New York City colleges 15 $1,285 Nonrefundable Enrollment Deposits Columbia University 100 Cornell University 200 $300 Orientation/Columbia University Mother 90 Walter 40 $130 Postage and Telephone Calls One telephone call to Cornell 5 Mailing of college forms 2 7 Grand Total $1,978

title: JUDGE IN MAINE IS SUSPENDED IN SECOND CASE OF MISCONDUCT
description: The Maine Supreme Court has censured District Judge John J. Benoit, one of the state's most popular judges, for improperly commenting on nine drunken driving cases pending in his court.

title: IN NEW MEXICO, THE OTHER LAS VEGAS
description: Las Vegas, N.M. is the original Vegas, not to be confused with the gambling town in Nevada. New Mexico's Las

title: Article 583187 -- No Title
description: The former principal of a private high school, who disappeared after being charged with child molestation, has been arrested and ordered held on $7 million bond.

title: Cecile Burleigh Engaged To Robert Harris Harper
description: Cecile Lee Burleigh, the daughter of Mrs. Philip Hall McCaull of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Cyril Burleigh Jr. of Memphis, is planning to marry Robert Harris Harper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Evans Harper Jr. of Indianola, Miss., on June 13.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Reviving Spacious Victorians in Yonkers
description: ''WHEN I was getting ready to buy the house, I began wondering why nobody else was buying it,'' Richard Kern said recently. ''I was filled with self-doubt.''

title: BESTSELERS: APRIL 12, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 10 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 3 4 5 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an international arms-selling intrigue. 4 5 3 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) The 30-year romance of a couple with diverse backgrounds and ambitions. 5 3 11 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 6 6 37 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the Indiana University basketball team. 2 5 8 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his family's place in upstate New York. 4 8 9 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Changing patterns in love and marriage. 10 10 4 BETTY: A Glad Awakening, by Betty Ford with Chris Chase. (Doubleday, $16.95.) The changing relations between the Society of Jesus and the Roman Catholic Church. 14 13 13 THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the show starring Lily Tomlin. 15 14 27 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the American automobile industry and Japan's role in it. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 27 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 2 2 24 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 3 3 3 HOW TO BE YOUR OWN NUTRITIONIST, by Stuart M. Berger. (Morrow, $16.95.) Ways to create a diet regimen for health and energy. 4 4 43 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 5 5 83 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BERLIN DIARIES, 1940-1945, by Marie Vassiltchikov. (Knopf, $19.95.) High life in the Third Reich, the struggles of ordinary people and stirrings of the plot against Hitler, recorded in detail and often with shrewdness by a clever White Russian princess. PERSIAN NIGHTS, by Diane Johnson. (Knopf, $17.95.) The Shah of Iran is falling in Ms. Johnson's funny, frightening seventh novel; her protagonist, an American wife and mother, learns moral goodness by learning involvement, too late to make a difference. ONCE IN EUROPA, by John Berger. (Pantheon, $14.95.) These stories of contemporary peasant life in a French Alpine village may contain the best writing yet by their protean author, a British art critic, screenwriter, journalist and smart, loving observer. THE OTHER NUREMBERG: The Untold Story of the Tokyo War Crimes Trials, by Arnold C. Brackman. (Morrow, $19.95.) A journalist's augmented eyewitness account of these elaborate, somehow largely forgotten, revelations of revolting villainy. THE CHILDREN AT SANTA CLARA, by Elizabeth Marek. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking, $16.95.) Frustrated as a Harvard student, Ms. Marek joined the staff of a center for disturbed adolescents; her story is a notable addition to the literature of self-healing through generosity and commitment to others. BERNARD BERENSON: The Making of a Legend, by Ernest Samuels. (Belknap/Harvard University, $25.) B.B. failed to write the book of art criticism he owed his generation, but would he have lived this comfortable, elegant life if he had? AN ARROW IN THE WALL: Selected Poetry and Prose, by Andrei Voznesensky. Edited by William Jay Smith and F. D. Reeve. (Holt, $22.95.) This book represents the best attempt so far to bring a contemporary Russian poet into a Western context.

title: Numbers Game
description: I didn't have any trouble solving the March 22 crossword puzzle, ''Numbers Game'' (edited by Eugene T. Maleska). The puzzling thing is that I haven't the slightest idea about the ''interrelationship'' (38 Down) between the words so easily filled in and the theme of ''Numbers Game,'' provided by Ernst Theimer, the author of the puzzle. ELIZABETH M. ROWN Little Falls, N.J. Eugene T. Maleska replies:

title: David Remnick to Wed Esther Fein, a Reporter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hyman William Fein of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Esther Beth Fein to David Jay Remnick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Remnick of Hillsdale, N.J.

title: Cap Baseball Salaries
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: 'HOUSE,' BY TERE O'CONNOR
description: TERE O'CONNOR'S ''In and Around Your House,'' presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, starts out very promisingly. The visual imagery is exquisite as three young women and two young men cross and recross an eloquently lighted stage. The women wear loose white dresses and pale green pinafores, their hair tied back in buns, and the men are dressed in loose white shirts and green breeches. They loop lusciously in little rooted slivers of stylized dance.

title: SITING OF SOIL A TEST FOR STATE
description: LEAD: THE most recent reports on the hazards of radium contamination in Essex County have highlighted once again a question that has plagued the state's Department of Environmental Protection for two years - where to put contaminated soil.

title: Judith Kramer Weds Juerg Stefan Herren
description: Judith Ann Kramer, the daughter of Elaine Kramer of Island Park, L.I., and Robert Kramer of Long Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Juerg Stefan Herren, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Rolf Herren-Berchtold of Biel, Switzerland. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Tower Suite in the Time & Life Building in Manhattan.

title: COLLEGES SPONSOR SUMMER TRAVEL
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER residents who are thinking about summer travel this year might want to explore some of the opportunities offered by area colleges for travel and study. Many of the trips offer college credit. The following selection gives an idea of the variety and focus of trips sponsored by local schools.

title: IT WAS ONLY A TEST
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPE MAY EROSION AID SOUGHT
description: FOR nearly two decades, the Atlantic Ocean has pounded away at the beachfront in Cape May, site of the nation's only Coast Guard training facility.

title: When a Symbol Is Shattered
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz took a swipe at critics of his Moscow trip Saturday as he embarked on a search for progress on arms control and other elements of the Soviet-American relationship.

title: EXPERTS FIND LAG ON TESTING DRUGS IN AIDS PATIENTS
description: Important human trials of drugs potentially useful in treating AIDS have been delayed for months by technical, ethical and financial problems, bureaucratic sluggishness and lack of cooperation from a major manufacturer, according to experts in AIDS research.

title: WHAT CAPITAL INFLOW?
description: IN article after article, economists and journalists lament the United States' growing dependence on foreign capital. They raise the terrifying possibility of disgruntled foreign investors rising up en masse, refusing to underwrite our profligate ways, thus raising interest rates and throwing America and the world into recession. The scenario would be even more terrifying if there were any truth in it. But we are not dependent on foreign capital. In fact, the emperor has no clothes -there is no capital inflow.

title: COMATOSE PATIENT: AN ETHICAL DILEMMA
description: LEAD: IT'S a cheerful room in which Florence LaSala, 82 years old, of Great Neck lies in bed at the South Shore Nursing Home in Freeport. Blue and beige blend in the walls, drapes and bed comforter. Nurses stop by hourly to see if there is anything they can do for her.

title: CD'S CHALLENGE THE ENGINEERS
description: HE WAS THE PRE-EMI-nent conductor on two continents, holding both New York and Vienna in thrall. Even so, Gustav Mahler had a hard time getting his own music performed and consoled himself with prophecy: ''My time will come.''

title: OLD MOSCOW HANDS IRKED ON EMBASSY
description: The accusations of lax security at the United States Embassy in Moscow touched off by the revelations of security breaches by Marine guards have stung former Moscow hands in the State Department, some of whom feel they are being blamed for a flaw no one suspected.

title: Teleport Dishes And Fiber Optics Offer Space Link
description: THE New York metropolitan area is being pushed into the forefront of worldwide telecommunications, with voice, video and data traffic funneling through this area in ever-increasing volume.

title: THE OLD SCHOOL TIE: O! THOSE HALCYON PREPARATORY DAYS
description: MY father is one of the most stoic men I have ever met. He rarely embraces when a hand-shake will do or otherwise lets the world know how he is feeling. I can remember, however, one occasion when tears of emotion streamed down his face. It was not a death, birth or any other momentous occasion; rather it was as he was watching ''Old Yeller.'' Animal films have that effect on him. I am like my father in that public displays of affection and outward emotion also make me uncomfortable and I, too, have films that can make me cry. There are several of them, including ''Good-bye Mr. Chips,'' ''To Serve Them All My Days'' and the biggest waterfall of them all, ''Tom Brown's School Days.''

title: MUSIC: JUILLIARD CONTEMPORARY SERIES
description: AT the final program of the Juilliard School's ''New Music Weekend'' last Sunday evening, it was impossible to evade the sense that a sea-change in contemporary music, long noted and debated, was being acknowledged. On the program were six all-instrumental chamber works composed between 1978 and last year. Every one of them was dominated by musical intervals and relationships traditionally thought of as satisfying, consonant or even pretty. Each deployed the instruments in rhythmic combinations or oppositions that could loosely be described, and could be grasped by the ear, as coordinated - as opposed to rhythms randomly improvised, determined by independent formulas that produce seeming chaos or that are willfully kept out of aural cooperation by elaborate subdivisions and redivisions of the beat.

title: STAYING TUNED TO THE WEATHER
description: NOAA, the short title for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is nearly the perfect acronym. ''This is NOAA Weather radio,'' the voice begins, and the listener envisions Noah himself, dispatching a dove to see if the Flood has abated.

title: Why Do Marines Guard Our Embassies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Alexander And David Slye Marry in South
description: The wedding of Phyllis Alexander, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eben Alexander Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C., and David Morrison Slye, a son of George E. Slye of Tuftonboro, N.H., and Naples, Fla., and Susan Morrison Slye of Newbury, N.H., took place yesterday. The Rev. George Robinson performed the ceremony at the Centenary United Methodist Church in Winston-Salem.

title: INSIDE
description: Jews, Israel and Reagan Jews think recent events involving Israel will fuel anti-Semitism, and they are among President Reagan's biggest critics, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll found. Pages 10 and 35. Primo Levi Is Dead Primo Levi, whose writings drew on his days in Auschwitz and his training as a chemist, died at the age of 67. He apparently killed himself. Page 42. Repairing all the nation's 575,607 highway bridges will cost $50.8 billion, the Federal Highway Administration has told Congress. About 150 bridges collapse each year. Page 24.

title: Topeka Wins Segregation Suit
description: More than three decades ago, Oliver Brown, a black railroad worker, sued the Topeka Board of Education and its ''separate but equal'' system, in which black and white children were required to attend different schools. He won the case in a landmark 1954 U.S. Supreme Court decision, Brown v. Board of Education, which set in motion the desegregation of the nation's public schools.

title:
ARCHITECTURE/DESIGN;
WHEN MUSEUMS OVERPOWER THEIR OWN ART
description: LEAD: DOES THE NOTION OF ''GREAT museum architecture'' involve some contradiction in terms? Is it possible that the greater the architect - the more personal, original and forceful his vision - the more problematic his spaces will be for exhibiting painting and sculpture? Among the many museums built since World War II, some are major architectural achievements.

title: Constance Canning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Canning of Sea Cliff, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance M. Canning, to James E. Branigan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Branigan of Sea Cliff. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Canning, a graduate of the New York Institute of Technology, is assistant to the director of human resources at the Black Clawson Company in New York, a manufacturer of machines for the paper industry. Mr. Branigan, a graduate of the City University of New York, is insurance manager of the MacCrate Insurance Agency in Sea Cliff.

title: U.N.'S WAR CRIME FILES AT ISSUE IN NEW DEBATE
description: THE United Nations War Crimes Commission, which was established during World War II, went out of business in 1948 without establishing clear guidelines for access to the 36,800 files it had compiled on alleged war criminals, suspects and witnesses. The files were shipped to the fledgling United Nations Secretariat, which consulted with former commission officials and ordered them closed, except for ''United Nations purposes.''

title: Mrs. Whitehead Gets Back Her Visitation Rights
description: While she is awaiting the outcome of her appeal, Mary Beth Whitehead will be allowed to visit the child she was hired to bear.

title: Karen Randi Smith to Wed Richard Pavone in October
description: Gladys Randi Smith of Elmhurst, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Karen Randi Smith, to Richard Pavone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Pavone of New Hyde Park, L.I. The couple plan to marry on Oct. 22.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: LEAD: NYDJA WAGES jumps double dutch on Tuesdays. Carrie Carson hauled coal. On Thursdays, which were laundry days, Mrs. Carson ironed blue cotton bloomers. Miss Wages and her friends iron designer jeans.

title: YANKEES REVIVE IN 12-RUN 7TH INNING
description: He has yet to meet the genius requirements of, say, Earl Weaver, his old minor league manager. But the morning after a long and embarrassing night before, Lou Piniella, the manager of the Yankees, who had used the same lineup in the first four games of the season, wrestled with two alternatives.

title: Congress Presses for 2-Year Military Budgets
description: The Congressional committees that oversee the military are struggling to draft legislation that would finance the Pentagon's operations for two years at a time instead of annually.

title: WHILE KEMP COURTS GOP RIGHT...  ...a Liberal and a Southerner Woo Democrats
description: THE Presidential field became still more crowded last week, as Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, moved from the paddock to the starting gate, and two Democratic Senators, Paul A. Simon of Illinois and Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, arrived at the race track. Mr. Kemp's formal declaration had been scheduled for weeks, and Mr. Simon's announcement of a decision to run - he will declare May 18, he said - was expected for days. But Mr. Gore was still undecided, his close advisers said, as late as Friday morning; he announced his mind was made up at 2 P.M.

title: LEGACY OF A MOTHER'S MURDER
description: THE ORDER OF THE New Jersey Superior Court on Sept. 19, 1985, was explicit. Philip Andrew Taylor, 15 months old, would be in the custody of his deceased mother's sister and her husband from ''September 1 each year to June 30 of each following year.''

title: AN ACRE OF L.I., A VISION OF AMERICA
description: I too am in much agreement with Elizabeth Hunter re ''Living on an Acre of L.I.'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 22 ] . I am also in agreement with Gloria Acerra re ''Loving the Acres but Seeing the Flaws'' [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, March 22 ] .

title: Deborah Phillips Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Ann Phillips, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Phillips of Weston, Mass., and Center Harbor, N.H., was married yesterday to John Lee Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pat Robertson of Houston. The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Ewing performed the ceremony at the Trinitarian Congregational Church in Wayland, Mass.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: MY FRIEND PENTAMETER Poets sometimes explain poetry better than critics do because they're not so impressed with it, it's just their everyday suit of clothes. Only a poet - a good one - could be so natural in talking to an interviewer about it as James Merrill is in ''Recitative: Prose by James Merrill'' (North Point), edited by J. D. McClatchy.

title: IMPORTANT POINTS FOR SPRING PLANTERS
description: PLANTING is the first thing to consider now. Soil has dried out from the deluge earlier this week and there will be a rush until the end of May to get things into the ground. First to be set out are container-grown plants, particularly those with woody stems and perennials; these plants will need special attention. Gallon containers hold about three quarts of soil and roots wind around and around this confined area as they grow. Before plants are set in the ground, this root mass must be released - loosened and cut through with a knife. Though this may seem drastic, this deed accomplishes two things: new root growth and better water uptake. The plants initiate new roots as soon as they are set in the ground and these succulent roots are able to absorb water more efficiently. Those who plant container-grown plants must water these new plants often, every three to four days, to be sure the initial start is secure, especially with dry summer months ahead. When woody plants or perennials are shipped, damp sphagnum is used to wrap roots. These plants also need careful planting in a wide deep hole, which has been improved with a good soil mix. Fan the root mass out, firm gently, be sure plants are set at the proper height in the ground and water them in. Seedlings should be kept indoors until the soil is warmer and the weather more settled. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS NEW BASIL

title: NEW DISKS: INSOUCIANT CORNET, NICE FIDDLE
description: Following is a roundup of some of the notable recording releases of recent weeks. Fedora Opera by Umberto Giordano. With Eva Marton and Jose Carreras. Hungarian Radio and Television Symphony Orchestra and Chorus conducted by Giuseppe Patane. CBS Masterworks 42181 (all three configurations).

title: BEYOND THE REACH OF OUR GOOD INTENTIONS
description: WHERE IS NICARAGUA? By Peter Davis. 349 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Nancy Siebert Marries Mark Murphy
description: Nancy Anne Siebert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Siebert of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to Mark John Murphy, a son of Dr. Thomas W. Murphy of Washington and the late Rosemarie Ward Murphy. The Rev. Joseph Michini performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT COMBINES the tactical challenge of the Normandy invasion, the festivity of the Mardi Gras, the endurance of a fraternity all-nighter and the cheerful abandon of the Easter egg hunt on the White House lawn.

title: ANOTHER BLOW FOR HAITI: A SUGAR MILL CLOSES
description: A sugar mill that was Haiti's second largest employer has shut down, saying it was put out of business by sugar smuggled from Miami and the Dominican Republic.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: REFERRING WITH derision to what he called ''so-called notables who were convened as props for Gorbachev's speech,'' Zbigniew Brzezinski used a stinging phrase that has become a term of art among hard-line historians and former national security advisers: useful idiots of the West.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Washington, D.C.: Stunting The Growth
description: LEAD: ALONG the six-lane Wisconsin Avenue in a mostly residential neighborhood here, developers, following zoning codes in existence since 1958, have been gradually constructing more office buildings. But the size of the buildings and the pace of growth is expected to be significantly reduced soon.

title: Getting Honest
description: A heterosexual woman, I was deeply moved by D. Gary Phelps's courageous decision to accept his homosexuality and leave his 13-year marriage - and then write about it.

title: DEBT, THE GRIM REAPER
description: BEYOND OUR MEANS How America's Long Years of Debt, Deficits and Reckless Borrowing Now Threaten to Overwhelm Us. By Alfred L. Malabre Jr. 174 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: RIDE A TIGER. By Harold Livingston. (Morrow, $18.95.) Spanning eight decades, this slick cinematic epic chronicles the life of a Jewish crime boss, Leo Gorodetsky, from his tough, humble beginnings as the guard for a Lower East Side crap game to his tenacious reign as the founding member and C.E.O.

title: JAZZ: PHIL WOOD'S 'LITTLE BIG BAND'
description: THE ''Little Big Band'' that the alto saxophonist Phil Woods introduced on Tuesday evening at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street, is a colorful extension and expansion of the quartet and, of late, the quintet that he has led for more than a decade.

title: Philip Wittenberg, 92, Dies; Copyright Lawyer and Author
description: Philip Wittenberg, a copyright lawyer, author and civil rights leader, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: August Wedding For Ms. McGrath
description: The engagement of Genevieve Marie McGrath to Martin J. McCann, has been announced by her parents, Genevieve D. McGrath of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Southold, L.I., and Kevin B. McGrath of New York. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin McCann Jr. of Lincroft, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Preserving Beauty: Hilltop Offices
description: Residents and officials of Montville, N.J. - a 19-square-mile residential township in Morris County - have a secret. ''People don't realize how beautiful it is here,'' said Harold Marine, the Town Administrator. ''There are rivers and forests and streams and mountains.''

title: A WORKING PAIR WHO CHANGED A WORLD
description: AMONG my reflections on this 40th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's successful integration of organized baseball is a cherished memory of Jack and me as an effective working pair. The working pair is a common and powerful structure for carrying out functional and emotional tasks. Marriages, partnerships, organizational dyads, and friendships all offer an opportunity to achieve the above. Too often they fail to flourish or meet the public and private challenges confronting them. I believe that the bond that Jack and I worked to create and maintain was crucial to the triumphs we experienced, as we lived in both private and public arenas. Later, in fact, it provided the core support when tragedy struck our family.

title: NOT READY FOR PRIME TIME?
description: THE TALL, ATHLETIC-LOOKING executive drops into a wing chair in his elegant, antique-filled office at Capital Cities/ ABC headquarters on East 51st Street in Manhattan. Then, turning to a guest, Thomas S. Murphy, the 61-year-old chairman of the media conglomerate, eagerly begins to recite the previous night's ratings from memory.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 15 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 15 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Hunting Down An Eagle Slayer
description: THE slaying was done with ''a small-caliber projectile'' that tore through the neck and right lung, officials said. The body was found last Dec. 23 in the Heislerville Wildlife Management Area in Maurice River Township, Cumberland County, N.J. The victim: a young bald eagle. Since then pledges of rewards for information leading to conviction of the killer have grown to about $10,000, says Gregory Huljack, deputy chief of the Bureau of Law Enforcement in the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. The bald eagle is protected by state and Federal law.

title: AT N.Y.U PARCTICE MAKES FILM MAKERS
description: IN A CAVERNOUS sound stage just off Washington Square, a handful of students are sliding a camera on a dolly back and forth, zeroing in on a rumpled hospital bed. Complete with bedpan and get-well cards, the set used to be a New York University gymnasium; now it is a state-of-the-art studio complex equipped to produce films and television programs at broadcast standards.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
NEW PLEDGES FAIL TO BRACE THE DOLLAR
description: LEAD: The dollar's nosedive continued, de spite, or perhaps because of, a reaffirmation by the major industrialized countries that currency rates must be stabilized. The Group of Seven renewed the pledge made in February in Paris to support the dollar. But hints, especially the statement of James A. Baker 3d, the Treasury Secretary, that the dollar's decline was ''orderly,'' led traders to believe that the support level was lower than the dollar was trading.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ROPE-DANCER and CONCERTINA. By M. J. Fitzgerald. (Random House, $15.95 each.) The surreal internal monologues in ''Rope-Dancer'' are so calm and detailed that it is easy for the reader to mistake dream for reality. First published in England, these stories by M. J. Fitzgerald contain a perverse sensuality that narrows the gap between literature and pornography.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN THINKING OF TREES, ONES TO AVOID
description: LEAD: WHILE looking through mail-order nursery catalogues, one cannot help noticing the number of shade trees with undesirable characteristics. Some are short-lived, some subject to disease, some are brittle and some so competitive that little else will grow beneath their branches.

title: ALBANY TAKES BIZARRE TWISTS IN PURSUIT OF THE STRAIGHT AND NARROW
description: IF there was a symbol for last week's extraordinary events here it was Joseph A. Califano Jr., who was ousted as head of a commission investigating government ethics not because he was weak or ineffective but because he was perceived as too strong and unrelenting.

title: ROYAL RETREATS OF GREENERY AROUND PARIS
description: The kings and emperors who ruled France knew the phenomenon well. A hot summer's day in Paris laden with the prospect of thunderstorms. The unpleasant smells of the steets and the Seine wafted over the quays and into the windows of their palaces. They dreamed of green grass, trees and the quiet of nature. Even during the winter and fall, the nobility tired of the noise and crowding and sought refuges outside the city. Using their royal perogatives, the rulers built country palaces and carved out vast parcels of woodlands to provide a locale for a hunt or just a day or two away from hectic court schedules.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: KEYES MARTIN, a Springfield-based advertising and public-relations agency, has been split into two independent companies: Keyes Martin Gaby Linett, for advertising, promotion and direct marketing, and Keyes Martin Public Relations.

title: TENSIONS CONTINUE FOR PERU'S LEADER
description: Just hours after President Alan Garcia dismissed Peru's Air Force commander last week, jet fighters flew low over the national palace in an angry gesture of defiance.

title: CONCERT TO BENEFIT HOSPITAL
description: LEAD: The 15th annual Good Friday concert at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church here will offer Beethoven's Mass in C and Mozart's Mass in C minor. In keeping with a tradition begun in 1973, the concert, at 8:15 P.M., will benefit the Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center.

title: IN TODAY'S ISSUE: Home Design
description: Part 2 of The Times Magazine today is Home Design, including these special reports:

title: IN PURSUIT OF STUDENTS: THE OLD COLLEGE TRY
description: LEAD: THE atmosphere in Caroline Donohue's Manhasset home was as crisp as the white embroidered cloth on her dining room table. The 10 Nassau high school seniors gathered recently under a Mount Holyoke banner tentatively sipped punch, furtively eyed one another and listened politely to the alumnae club members extolling the courses, facilities and camaraderie of the women's college.

title: Efficient Space
description: If design were judged by the square inch, some of today's tiny kitchens, bathrooms and closets would be near the top of the list. These rooms, when transformed by architects and designers, become studies in efficiency, and often display a good deal of style as well. Filled with Lilliputian appliances, they can be as functional as their larger counterparts.

title: OUTPOST OF BRITAIN (IN GLASS) IN TENAFLY
description: THE Studio Glass Gallery of Britain at 9 Church Street will celebrate its recent opening here this afternoon. The gallery, the only American establishment to concentrate exclusively on glass by British artists, will welcome the public between 1:30 and 4:30.

title: SPREADING THE WORD AND SOUND OF JAZZ
description: FOR nearly half a century, Marian McPartland has played piano duets with almost any jazz great you can mention and performed solo in her own trio all over the world. This week in Connecticut she will be doing what she revels in - performing for and with young people, and talking to them about jazz.

title: THE ORDEAL OF ITALIAN JEWRY
description: THE ITALIANS AND THE HOLOCAUST Persecution, Rescue, and Survival. By Susan Zuccotti. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: The Prisoner Of Seventh Avenue
description: The photograph of Lauren Bacall is not from ''Applause,'' but ''Woman of the Year.'' The gown she is wearing was designed by Theoni Aldredge, who designed the entire wardrobe for the production. Ms. Bacall did eventually wear a red Halston suit as a replacement for a gray ensemble in ''Woman of the Year.'' I know this as fact; I produced both shows. LAWRENCE KASHA Culver City, Calif.

title: JITTERY TRADERS STILL WARY OF DOLLAR
description: THE contention - immediately disputed - was that the dollar had finally reached a rough equilibrium with other currencies, after falling almost without interruption for two years.

title: Q AND A
description: Rhine Cruising Question:I want to cruise the Rhine River, starting in Amsterdam and possibly ending in Budapest. Can you direct me to sources for schedules, rates and first-class accommodations? - H. K., New York

title: Brothers Aim for Trans-Atlantic Mark
description: Bruno and Loick Peyron, world-class multi-hull sailors from France, know what it is to compete against each other as brothers. But never has the rivalry been so intense as in their current duel. The two ocean racers are attempting to break the trans-Atlantic speed record, each in his own boat.

title: Elizabeth Evans Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Elder Evans, the daugh-ter of Mrs. Errol Kemp Reece of Greensboro, N.C., and the late William James Evans, was married yesterday to Francis Xavier Queally Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Queally of Greenwich, Conn., and Jupiter, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Jack Hunter performed the ceremony at the Front Street United Methodist Church in Burlington, N.C., assisted by the Rev. Robert Weisenbaugh, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CAPITALS' MASON STARS IN PLAYOFF DEBUT
description: He started the season in the minor leagues as the odd man out on a team with three equally strong goaltenders. But Bob Mason emerged tonight as the hero for the Capitals in the third game of their playoff series against the Islanders.

title: SHUNNING THE HITS
description: A PARADOX OF TODAY'S popular music is that those who love it the most, those who play and broadcast and support and contemplate it most intensely, often don't much like popular music at all.

title:
FOCUS: Des Moines;
Skywalk Reviving Downtown
description: LEAD: LAST February, golf enthusiasts in this cold Middle West city teed off in the heart of downtown dressed in summer sports clothes. They were participants in the second annual Skywalk Open golf tournament, an 18-hole adventure through the city's two miles of enclosed walkways.

title: RUTGERS PRESSES CERAMICS STUDIES
description: LEAD: TIMES have changed since Mr. Robinson uttered his famous one-word career advice - ''plastics'' - to Dustin Hoffman in the 1967 film ''The Graduate.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: OUTNUMBERED BY JERKS
description: BEING INVISIBLE By Thomas Berger. 262 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: CASINO TO DON DEBT AS TAKEOVER ARMOR
description: THE state's Casino Control Commission has approved a Holiday Corporation anti-takeover plan while assailing it as not in the best interests of Holiday shareholders.

title: IN THE HALL OF CONGRESS, COLLEGES TRY TO LOBBY
description: WELCH HALL, once a stately stone administration building at the gateway to Eastern Michigan University in Ypsilanti, is now an eyesore. Four years ago, after its heating, ventilating and electrical systems failed, Welch Hall was closed. While trustees of the lesser-known public university wanted money to restore it, they were reluctant to ask the Michigan legislature for $2 million at a time when they were also pressing the state for a new $20 million business school.

title: Gun Rally Draws Only 100
description: A rally today in support of the right to own guns drew only about 100 people to this city that requires its citizens to own a firearm. Organizers of the event, who had expected more than 1,000 people to show up, said it was important to focus attention this year on the constitutional right to bear arms because the nation is celebrating the bicentennial of the Constitution.

title: Maintaining the Whitney
description: To the Editor:

title: Mariann Walraven Is Engaged to James Ramage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adriaan Emile Walraven of Schenectady, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mariann Elizabeth Walraven, to James Howell Ramage, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Ramage of Williamsville, N.Y. The wedding is to be in October.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DESIGNS ARE RELEASED FOR CONSTITUTION COINS
description: LEAD: The United States Treasury has announced the winning entries in its Constitution coin design competition. The designs will appear on two commemorative coins scheduled for issuance later this year to mark the Constitution's bicentennial.

title: After Bankruptcy: The Stocks of the Largest Survivors
description: Here is how the largest public companies (ranked by total assets) that have reorganized in the past three years have fared in the market since they emerged from bankruptcy protection.

title: Peak May Honor Astronauts
description: A 14,081-foot mountain peak in south-central Colorado should be named Challenger Point to honor the seven astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded last year, the United States Board on Geographical Names has ruled. Donald Orth, executive secretary of the panel, said Friday that the panel voted unanimously on the name, but the action must be approved by Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel. The peak is near Kit Carson Peak in the Sangre de Cristo Range.

title: STEPHANIE A. FRIEDMAN PLANS TO MARRY MAY 30
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Milton friedman of Johnstown, Pa., and Washington of the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Ann Friedman, to Mark Allen Offerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Offerman of Wallace, N.C. The wedding is to be May 30.

title: Methanol
description: To the Editor:

title: A BRIDGE FALLS, AND NO ONE KNOWS WHY
description: LATE last week, the swift currents of Schoharie Creek receded enough to let the state police divers work. Under the concrete and twisted steel of the highway bridge that collapsed last Sunday, they found a crushed car; in it they found but could not identify a body, the fourth verified casualty of the disaster on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Downstream, in another car, they found and identified the fifth, one of three utility workers who had been drivng home from a bowling tournament. Teams of divers moved farther downstream yesterday in search of five more who still are missing.

title: Straus Park Plan: Redrawing the Zoning Map
description: When new buildings complement their neighbors, planners praise them for being ''contextual.'' Housing Futures, which owns the site of the Olympia theater at Broadway and West 107th Street, is seeking such praise, and a lot more, in proposing an apartment house there that would be so contextual it would be a virtual twin of the 1928 building next door. It would have a similar facade and would rise without setbacks to same the height. But realizing that design requires changing the zoning map, and that is what the developer is proposing, for its own site and for others around Straus Park, a triangular plot bounded by Broadway, West End Avenue and 106th Street.

title: ISLIP SUPERVISOR CITES HIS RECORD
description: Frank Lynn is off-base and takes a cheap shot in his April 5 ''Politics'' column. In an article seemingly orchestrated by the local Democratic Party, he charges that my appointment as Islip Town Supervisor occurred because I am a ''protege'' of the Islip Republican leader, Anthony Pace.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SUBSEQUENT PERFORMANCES. By Jonathan Miller. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking, $25.) In this valuable contribution to a longstanding debate, Jonathan Miller marshals his two decades of theatrical experience and his considerable knowledge of art and science to make the case for messing around with the classics. As the director who peopled ''Rigoletto'' with New York mobsters and ''The Merchant of Venice'' with 19th-century bankers, Mr. Miller is not a disinterested observer. But his book is far more than an apologia for his own innovative productions. It is also a practical look at the problems of staging the texts of authors who are no longer around to explain what they meant, and a philosophical inquiry into whether art can ever really be ''timeless.'' Mr. Miller's main point is that plays and operas are written for audiences who share the writer's understanding of the world, and that, as time goes by, this shared understanding disappears, never to be regained - even through meticulous historical research. Thus the most traditional, most reverent presentation of a classic play cannot help being, in fact, a revisionist reading. His arguments are buttressed with illustrations ranging from Renaissance paintings to visual paradoxes, all helping to show that what you see isn't necessarily what there is. Mr. Miller's radicalism stops short, however, when it comes to mixing media. He eloquently explains how ''most novels are irreversibly damaged by being dramatized'' and why ''televising Shakespeare or opera is . . . an exercise in media cross-dressing.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE player who led the United States team in scoring when the Americans won the gold medal at the world championships in basketball last year will not try out for the United States Pan American team this summer. Charles Smith, the Pitt center, said he had declined the invitation to attend summer school. . . . Dan Dierdorf, a former all-pro tackle for the St. Louis Cardinals who has been a television football analyst for CBS, was added to the ABC-TV announcing crew as an analyst for its ''Monday Night Football'' series. . . . Nigel Mansell of England won the pole position for today's Brazilian Grand Prix, the first race of the 1987 Formula I season.

title: BORDERLINE COOPERATION
description: POLLUTION is no respecter of national frontiers. Fallout from Chernobyl was blown across a dozen countries. Toxic chemicals flushed down the Rhine in Basel wiped out river life in France, West Germany and Holland. And half the trees in the Black Forest were found damaged by sulfurous fumes, mostly from Eastern Europe. In North America, industrial pollution from the United States causes acid rain in Canada.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Up to 80 Percent Off On Some Footwear The Shoe Loft opened a year ago in January above the Colonial Village Flower Shop in the Colonial Village shopping center, where Scarsdale meets New Rochelle. The store discounts by 20 percent the suggested retail prices on Italian-made and other imported women's dress and casual shoes, sandals and boots from a dozen major designers, plus the American-made Mosaic line.

title: FROM COUNTRY ROOTS TO ENCHANTED EVENINGS
description: NO memories of Mary Martin washing that man ''right outa'' her hair, or of Ezio Pinza singing of finding everlasting love across a crowded room are getting in the way of Marcia Mitzman and Stanley Wexler.

title: Ten Military Rockets Found In Crates Near Supermarket
description: Ten armed, camouflage-painted military rockets were found in two wooden crates that sat unopened behind a supermarket for several weeks, the authorities said today.

title: INCINERATOR DEAL NEAR AT PILGRIM HOSPITAL
description: LEAD: IN a highly unusual combination of efforts, a deal is being negotiated with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, Islip Town and Pilgrim State Hospital involving the construction of a garbage-to-energy incinerator at the hospital.

title: BLACK DEMONSTRATORS MARCH THROUGH HASIDIC AREA
description: With police officers lining the streets, 400 blacks marched through the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday to protest what they say is harassment by the neighborhood's Hasidic community.

title: BY RADIO, A RABBI'S MESSAGE
description: LEAD: THE voice on the radio is deep, comforting, with a bit of country twang. The subject is religion. But this is not an evangelical preacher, regaling his listeners with tales of fire and brimstone. This is Rabbi Amiel Wohl, senior rabbi at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, a Reform synogogue on Pinebrook

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Paterson Banks on a New Highway Link
description: LEAD: TWENTY years ago, when the open land around Paterson was carved into superhighways, city officials hoped that the new road network would one day turn the aging industrial downtown into a bustling commercial hub.

title: UNDER CLOUDS OF DITRUST, SHULTZ HEADS FOR MOSCOW
description: NO eavesdropping equipment is required to detect what Soviet and American participants want from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit here. Both sides want to clear the way for a summit in Washingon, where President Reagan and Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev can sign the arms control agreement that has eluded them so far.

title: JAZZ: DON PULLEN GROUP
description: PLAYING electric organ instead of his usual piano brought out the down-home side of Don Pullen, who led a 10-piece ''Organorchestra'' Monday night at the Public Theater. Saxophones, trumpets and trombone complemented a basic organ combo, with Mr. Pullen pumping out bass lines on the organ pedals and steaming through blues, ballads and rhythm-and-blues tunes like a latter-day Jimmy Smith.

title: PRIMO LEVI, HOLOCAUST WRITER, IS DEAD AT 67
description: Primo Levi, whose autobiographical writings drew on his experiences as an Auschwitz survivor and his training as a chemist, died today in Turin. He was 67 years old.

title: 6,787 MILES OF GAS LINE-AND IT LEAKS
description: FOR two days last week, customers in a South Bronx grocery store smelled gas. On Wednesday, the second day, the distinctive odor was so strong the manager sprayed air freshener around the checkout counter in the afternoon and told a clerk to call Con Edison.

title: Heinz Reaches Accord With Migrant Workers
description: A three-year contract agreement has been reached between Heinz U.S.A. and migrant workers who pick crops for the company in Ohio and Michigan.

title: FRIENDSHIP SPARKS A BUSINESS
description: FINANCIAL necessity and a love of shopping moved Janet Ackerly and Molly Sweeney to open an interior-design firm 10 years ago in Southport.

title: LIVING WITH LUXURY IN A SMALL SPACE
description: A beautifully proportioned room is one of the greatest luxuries today,'' says Tom Scheerer. This belief prompted the Manhattan decorator to renovate his 17-by-18-foot studio apartment rather than move to a larger space with less appealing architecture. Located in a prewar New York City building designed exclusively for studio living, Scheerer's one room already had atmosphere: a small fireplace; old-fashioned architectural details such as cornice moldings, chair rails and baseboards, and a paned window overlooking a sunny garden.

title: U.S. Denies Reported Accord On Nuclear Arms With Japan
description: The State Department has denied reports by Japan's Communist Party that a document the party discovered was proof of a secret American-Japanese nuclear arms agreement.

title: GORBACHEV ALLUDES TO CZECH INVASION
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew home today after alluding to the Soviet decision to end the liberalization movement of 1968.

title: CONGRESS ACTS TO SHIFT COSTS OF PROGRAM TO EMPLOYERS
description: Unwilling to raise taxes for new social programs, Congress is moving to require employers to provide many additional health and welfare benefits to employees and their families.

title: HORACE ADALI SAWYER
description: Horace Adali Sawyer, a former president and chairman of the Lone Star Cement Company, now Lone Star Industries, based in Greenwich, Conn., died last Wednesday in New Orleans, where he had moved after his retirement. Mr. Sawyer was 92 years old and formerly lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: KNICKS COLLAPSE UNDER BIRD'S 47 POINTS
description: The impact of the loss of Bernard King to a serious knee injury two years ago cannot be overstated. An all-pro who was among the league's elite, he owned the kind of skills no single player could replace. But what the Knicks also missed was the respect he commanded, an aura that benefited the entire team.

title: THIS FLIGHT PATTERN TOO LOW AT SHEA
description: So the Mets thought they had a bad day. Consider the misfortune suffered by a bird that met with a tragic end on a routine flight from left field to center in the top of the third inning yesterday. The unsuspecting dove was struck and killed by a fly ball hit by Dion James, leading off the inning for the Braves.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL ELECTION SEEN AS A TEST FOR THE MAYOR
description: Thirteen candidates, including the widow of Medgar Evers, the slain civil rights leader, will compete for a City Council seat Tuesday in an election that some political analysts say may have a bearing on Mayor Tom Bradley's political future.

title: Skitch Henderson Leads New York Pops
description: The New York Pops, under the direction of Skitch Henderson, played a mildly diverting concert at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon - a concert that could, however, been much more satisfactory than it was. Mr. Henderson is a jaunty, energetic maestro who knows his way around an orchestra; moreover, Robert White, the afternoon's guest artist, is a tenor of smallish voice but considerable cultivation.

title: Audit Criticizes City U.'s Methods
description: City auditors accused the City University of New York yesterday of perpetrating ''a farce'' in its method of selecting collection agencies to obtain overdue bills from students, but the university denied the charge.

title: How to Keep Greece and Turkey Apart
description: Not for the first time, Greece and Turkey barely managed to pull back from the brink of violence recently. Under considerable foreign pressure, the Turkish Government halted a research vessel that was exploring for oil in the contested continental shelf around Greek islands. Yet none of the basic causes of the crisis have been removed. On the contrary, the Aegean Sea continues to separate Turkey and Greece politically as much as physically.

title: POPE ENDS HIS ARGENTINE VISIT
description: Pope John Paul II today opened the holiest week on the Roman Catholic calendar with a spectacular outdoor mass set amid the high-rise buildings of the Argentine capital.

title: Linda Eskay Wed To Robert Becker
description: Linda Ellen Eskay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Eskay of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Kenneth Becker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Becker of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Steven Klein and Cantor Deborah Katchko Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: FOR SMOKERS, DOOMSDAY LOOMS ON MAY 7
description: Marty Seiden peered out into the smoke-filled room and spoke about The Day. ''You've heard what's going to happen May 7,'' he said to the 31 Smokenders students seated before him in a Manhattan hotel room. Ashtrays at the ready, they listened to him in silence, save for the occasional cough.

title: China Said to Interrupt Many Projects' Imports
description: In a move that has puzzled and alarmed some foreign companies, China's central Government has virtually halted imports of materials for special projects, according to business executives and diplomats who follow Chinese trade.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOW I GREW. By Mary McCarthy. Illustrated. 278 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: Gorbachev to Visit Rumania
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will visit Rumania next month, Yugoslavia's official Tanyug news agency said in a report from Bucharest today. Tanyug, quoting unnamed diplomatic sources, said the trip had been originally planned for early May but was delayed toward the end of the month because of a planned trip by Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumania leader, to Prague and also because of Mr. Gorbachev's tight schedule at home. Rumania is the only Warsaw Pact country that Mr. Gorbachev has not visited officially since assuming office in Moscow.

title: WROTE STARK NOVELS OF SOUTH
description: Erskine Caldwell, the prolific novelist whose accounts of deprivation and depravity in the Depression-era Deep South brought him instant fame and instant notoriety, died of lung cancer Saturday in Paradise Valley, Ariz. He was 83 years old and lived in Paradise Valley.

title: ROBINSON'S BATTLES WENT FAR BEYOND THE DIAMOND
description: BY the end of his life, after pursuing a number of political, social and economic paths, Jackie Robinson had come to grips with some realities about baseball and America.

title: Foes of U.S. A-Vessels Victors in Fiji Election
description: A left-leaning coalition that has pledged to ban United States nuclear warships from Fiji won an election victory today over the staunchly pro-Western party that had ruled since independence from Britain in 1970.

title: KISSINGER TO WRITE ON DIPLOMACY
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State and the author of two best-selling books about his years in the White House, has signed with Simon & Schuster to write a book about the meaning of diplomacy. ''I will draw on my experiences,'' Mr. Kissinger said, ''but it will not be an account of my conduct of foreign policy.''

title: SOUTH AFRICAN DECREE ON DETAINEES ASSAILED
description: South African church leaders said today that they were prepared to defy an official decree forbidding protests on behalf of political detainees.

title: ON THE OPEN ROAD, SPEED LAW RATIFIES STATUS QUO
description: Among the more notable accomplishments of David E. White is a ''driver of the year'' award he received last year for ''on-time deliveries, safe driving and compliance with Federal rules and regulations.''

title: CHILE AFTER THE POPE: A MOOD OF ACCOMMODATION
description: A mood of accommodation has swept the Chilean political scene in the week since the Pope's visit, with all sides publicly expressing a desire to end the polarization.

title: DDB Needham Gains Schering-Plough Task
description: Schering-Plough in Memphis has decided to give creative responsibility for most of its Mabelline brand to DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago. The assignments are coming out of Ted Bates Advertising/New York and the Bloom Agency, Dallas.

title: A New Ball Game
description: Southern Methodist University's decision the other day to scrap its football team for a second season in 1988 is only the latest piece of continuing fallout from the ignominy that shook the school this winter.

title: THE DOORS WERE OPEN, BUT RECEPTION WAS HOSTILE
description: THE eulogy rang through the great vaulted Riverside Church in Manhattan. ''The phrase for Jackie Robinson went from 'black bastard' to 'black knight,' '' intoned the Rev. Jesse Jackson. ''We are all better because a man with a mission passed our way.''

title: The Yankees, Out of Sight
