description: For most Yankee fans in New York this year, ''take me out to the ballgame'' doesn't celebrate the pleasures of live baseball so much as it laments a sad necessity: Going to the stadium will be the only way to see the team play.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
description: WHAT must a corporation in the midst of secret discussions with other companies about a contemplated merger or acquisition tell the public?

title: How Porky and Bugs Outwitted the Russians
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAID TO WIDEN GOALS FOR BANNING MID-RANGE MISSILES
description: American arms negotiators are planning to press the Soviet Union to agree to a total ban on intermediate-range nuclear missiles, officials traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: MERRILL UNIT TO ACQUIRE BORG
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners has signed an agreement to buy the Borg-Warner Corporation of Chicago for $48.50 a share, or $4.23 billion, and convert the huge industrial organization into a private company, the two said jointly yesterday.

title: Stuffing the Rush
description: The wheels of justice sometimes turn at such a snail's pace that impatient litigants cry out for streamlined court procedures that would produce quicker decisions even at the expense of more thorough airing of the disputed issues. Now, however, no less an authority than the Chief Justice of the United States, William H. Rehnquist, has questioned whether American society would really prefer speed to judicial accuracy, and to bolster his thesis he has cited the highest authority of all: the solons of the National Football League.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 13, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 U.S. arms negotiators will press the Soviet Union to agree to a ban on intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Asia as well as Europe as a way of alleviating the problem of verification, American officials said. A1 Eduard Shevardnadze has sharpened his diplomatic skills since Secretary of State George P. Shultz last visited Moscow, officials said. The Soviet Foreign Minister was then unfamiliar with Soviet-American issues. A8 News analysis: Arms proposals that President Reagan decided to back away from had a mixed reception in Moscow. Reversing position on his own previous offers has minuses and pluses for the Soviet Union. A8 Chad's victory over Libya showed that the weapons and tactics used by industrial nations are not necessarily appropriate for inexperienced and poorly trained troops of less developed countries. A1 South Korean constitutional changes will no longer be debated until after the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, President Chun Doo Hwan ordered. His decision will likely sharpen the country's political tensions. A1 The flight of Salvadorans to the U.S. by the hundreds of thousands each year has made the migration to the north one of theirmost determined of its kind in recent history. A1 The immigrant's world: low pay and overcrowded housing A6 In South Africa, a new protest law forbidding demonstrations on behalf of political detainees may be defied by church leaders. They were proceeding with plans for a prayer service, possibly the decree's first test. A7 India's Defense Minister resigned under pressure from politicians unhappy with his investigation of kickbacks in the awarding of a defense contract. The move was a blow to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. A3 In Cambodia, appeals for the trust of the Khmer people have been made by both sides in the country's unending war. Support may be flagging and desertions rising in both camps, radio broadcasts suggest. A10 Israeli settlers attack Arabs in West Bank A3 Senegal's isle of slaves A4 Chile after the Pope's visit A6 Governor election a setback for Nakasone A9 Campaign seeks genocide trial of Khmer Rouge A11 Soviet astronauts solve a docking problem A13 NATIONAL A14-16, A20, B9 Texaco filed for protection from its creditors in Federal Bankruptcy Court as a result of its bitter legal dispute with the Pennzoil Company. Texaco is the largest company ever to enter bankruptcy proceedings. A1 Requiring employee benefits from employers is becoming an attractive idea to members of Congress who are unwilling to raise taxes for social programs. The idea draws support from liberals and conservatives. A14 The speed limit is routinely violated and seldom enforced along the open roads of the West. In areas where such regulations seem irrelevant, few people expect changes if the speed limit is increased as allowed by the Federal highway law. A14 Some believe the Devil is a force that tempts humans, a New York Times-CBS News Poll found. Some followers of the Rev. Jim Bakker said the Devil is responsible for trouble in the nation's television ministry. B9 A report of drug use by Julian Bond, the former state senator, and a public retraction of the allegation have become the focus of broad controversy. Mr. Bond's former wife had told the police he abused cocaine. A20 Job security for auto workers will be the top goal when the United Automobile Workers open contract negotiations with the nation's two largest au-tomobile companies this summer, the union's president said. A16 Derailment drama ends in Pittsburgh A14 Navy cites a shortage of sailors A14 L.A. council election is seen as a test for mayor A15 Crimes in U.S. decreased slightly in 1986 B9 WASHINGTON TALK B8 White House's new communications chief Enlisting youth in public service REGIONAL B1-5, B7 Arresting small-time drug dealers is the focus of recent police operations that have sparked debate on whether attacking neighborhood drug marketplaces is the best way to fight illegal narcotics. A1 Stop-smoking programs thrive as smokers from across the city flock to them in anticipation of May 7, when smoking will be prohibited in public indoor areas in the state and restricted in many other places. A1 A chemical smell caused a walkout of workers seven weeks ago from Uretek Inc. in New Haven. But company officals say the smell, similar to that of turpentine or cleaning fluid, is harmless. B1 A school principal was censured in Brooklyn for borrowing $6,000 from a teacher and insisting that it be considered a political contribution. A disciplinary panel called the action ''highly inappropriate.'' B4 A bill that tightens ethics rules for state legislators is ''a step backward'' and should be vetoed by Governor Cuomo, leaders of the state's Bar Association said. The Legislature passed the bill last week. B2 A detention center for illegal aliens with criminal backgrounds will be renovated and the system for holding them will be revised. The center in Manhattan has been criticized in Federal studies. B3 A hospital defended its care of Andy Warhol. The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center issued a statement responding to a State Health Department report that criticized Mr. Warhol's treatment. B3 Metro Matters: City as landlord B1 Concrete plant in jeopardy B1 Soviet emigres mark first Passover in America B1 The battle of the Neversink B3 Cancer unit to move from cityB3

title: Almaden Reassigned To McCann-Erickson
description: Almaden Vineyards is being reassigned to McCann-Erickson, according to a person who knows. The ad budget is in the area of $13 million.

title: PRESIDENT OF SOUTH KOREA ORDERS A HALT TO DEBATE ON CONSTITUTION
description: South Korea's prospects for constitutional changes were shattered this morning when President Chun Doo Hwan ordered a halt to all debate on the pivotal issue until after the 1988 Summer Olympics are held in Seoul.

title: A COMPASSIONATE FORCE IN THE AIDS BATTLE
description: She introduces herself to the members of her counseling group as Judy, or occasionally as Judy Peabody. Sometimes she tells the participants that she has been a volunteer at the Gay Men's Health Crisis for a year and a half, and once in a while she tells them she is a care partner, the increasingly common term for people who accept responsibility for helping a person with AIDS.

title: Lezly Garrett, a Designer, Is Married to Joseph Seijas
description: Lezly Braun Garrett, a fashion designer in Manhattan, and Joseph Seijas, a lawyer in the Bronx, were married yesterday at the Georgine Carmella restaurant in Manhattan, of which the bridegroom is a co-owner. Justice John Carro of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Lester A. Braun of Arlington, Tex., and the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Seijas of New York.

title: 3 Hospital Bidders Facing Skepticism
description: The three men who want to buy the Hospital Corporation of America for $3.8 billion are meeting with skepticism over their ability to finance the deal.

title: Not a National Disaster
description: The near hysteria over espionage these days has produced a thriller atmosphere without the sober reasoning of the best spy thrillers. The preposterous Senate vote recommending that Secretary of State George Shultz cancel his trip to Moscow was an impulse of thoughtless indignation without concern for policy.

title: CANCER SOCIETY CITES COSTS IN VOTE TO LEAVE NEW YORK
description: The American Cancer Society, which has had its headquarters in New York City since it was founded in 1913, will relocate its national offices out of the city in an effort to reduce its costs, an official of the agency said last night.

title: LUKAS'S CONFIDENCE OUTRUNS HIS HORSES
description: The Wood Memorial at Aqueduct Saturday is supposed to be a key prep race for the Kentucky Derby May 2, but D. Wayne Lukas says that the Wood could render the Derby almost anticlimactic.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: D. EDWARD RICCHIUTO
description: D. Edward Ricchiuto, vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Hicks & Greist Advertising Agency in Manhattan, died of cancer Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Ridgefield, N.J.

title: Market Place; Buying a Piece Of Wall Street
description: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS seems to have chosen an ideal time for its initial public offering - the largest of stock in a brokerage house. The stock market is booming and bond prices and the dollar have been gyrating, producing the kind of volatility traders thrive on, and corporations are issuing record amounts of securities.

title: Bull Run
description: The entry application resembles a 1040 tax form, the four-kilometer race is officially designated a ''4(01)K'' in a play on the name of the popular tax shelter, and the date, naturally enough, is April 15. At 7 P.M. the day after tomorrow, 1,000 bankers, brokers, arbitragers and other Wall Streeters wearing business suits and swinging briefcases will take off from the South Street Seaport and scurry through the financial district in what is billed as the First Annual Wall Street Rat Race.

title: National Gallery To Show Marin Works
description: The National Gallery of Art has announced that it will mount a show in the summer of 1988 of the watercolors, paintings and etchings of John Marin, an American artist who died in 1953. The gallery has a large collection of Marin works, donated last year by the artist's son, John C. Jr. J. Carter Brown, director of the gallery, said yesterday that Mr. Marin had promised to the gallery two additional works by his father. They are a watercolor called ''Woolworth Building Under Construction'' and an oil, ''Grey Sea.'' Mr. Brown said the Woolworth work was a significant addition to the gallery's collection of New York scenes.

title: House Ethics Panel to Clear St Germain of Abusing Office
description: A draft report by the House ethics committee found no financial impropriety by Representative Fernand J. St Germain, who was investigated for abusing his office for personal gain, according to a report published today.

title: SALVADORANS STREAM INTO U.S., FLEEING POVERTY AND CIVIL WAR
description: Driven by unemployment and war at home, hundreds of thousands of Salvadorans are estimated to have gone to live in the United States in recent years, according to American and Salvadoran officials.

title: Canadian Joblessness
description: Canada's unemployment rate held steady in March at 9.6 percent as modest growth in the number of people employed was offset by expansion of the labor force, Statistics Canada said Friday. The Government agency said the number of employed in March, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose 23,000 from the previous month, to 11.8 million. The number of unemployed rose slightly, to 1,254,000, from 1,252,000 in February.

title: Plans for Two-Year Notes Expected
description: Today's regular auctions of new Treasury bills due in three and six months are the only sales of Government securities scheduled this week. On Wednesday, securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce plans for a two-year note auction on April 22.

title: Nancy Winston Weds Paul Craig Lounsbury
description: The marriage of Nancy S. Winston and Paul Craig Lounsbury, both practicing psychotherapists in New York, took place yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in Manhattan. Rabbi Charles Lippmann and the Rev. David Lounsbury, an Episcopal priest and the bridegroom's brother, officiated.

title: GOVERNOR ELECTION SEEN AS SETBACK FOR NAKASONE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone apparently suffered a political setback Sunday as his party's candidate lost a closely watched gubernatorial election.

title: TRANSCANADA MAKES OFFER FOR DOME
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. today offered what it said was the equivalent of $4.3 billion, about $3.29 million in United States currency, for the assets of Dome Petroleum Ltd. Dome's chief executive immediately rejected the offer, contending that it violated a confidentiality agreement between Dome and potential buyers.

title: A New Navistar Gets A New Chief Executive
description: The Navistar International Corporation, the former International Harvester Company, began this month with a new chairman and chief executive, James C. Cotting, and a new corporate organization as well.

title: Another Bridge Falls Into Schoharie Creek
description: A portion of a two-lane bridge plunged into the Schoharie Creek Saturday night, three miles from where parts of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed April 5, officials said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Pretoria Decree Assailed South African church leaders said they were prepared to defy an official decree forbidding protests on behalf of political detainees. Page A7. Gandhi Aide Resigns In a blow to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the Indian Defense Minister resigned. His inquiry into possible kickbacks was at issue. Page A3.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM'S NEW UKRAINIANS
description: CONTINUUM, a venturesome chamber ensemble under the direction of Joel Sachs and Cheryl Seltzer, presents two kinds of retrospective concerts -those devoted to single composers (everybody from Anton Webern to Percy Grainger) and those devoted to musical movements and trends (including ''America's Percussion Revolution,'' ''New from Israel'' and ''Eastward Ho! - America's Composers Encounter the Orient.'' Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, the troupe presented one of its most unusual programs to date - a concert called ''The New Ukrainians,'' featuring works by Levko Kolodub, Valentin Silvestrov, Leonid Hrabovsky and Valentin Bibik, all composers living and working in the Ukraine, all composers barely known in the United States.

title: Tax Anxiety
description: Of the 105 million taxpayers who will file personal tax returns for 1986, 30 million haven't yet. Millions put it off because they owe the Government and prudently don't pay until the Wednesday midnight deadline. But other millions just don't want to face the music until they have to.

title: PHILS LEAN HEAVILY ON PARRISH
description: FROM the crack of the bat, everyone near the Philadelphia Phillies' batting cage knew that the ball struck by their newly signed catcher, Lance Parrish, would not stay in the park. The only question was how far it would travel in Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.

title: AT FACTORY, CHEMICAL FUMES SET OFF STRIKE
description: A faint chemical odor lingers in the basement of the Uretek Inc. plant here, where workers walked off their jobs seven weeks ago in a dispute over health and safety conditions.

title: Rose Robbins Is Married
description: Rose Robbins, an administrative assistant to the board of trustees and president of Bergen Community College in Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Buxton, who recently retired as the college's dean of faculty. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at the home of the bride in Fort Lee, N.J. The bride, a widow, will keep her name professionally. Mr. Buxton, a widower, is an adjunct professor of marketing at Rutgers University and William Paterson College.

title: BROOKLYN PRINCIPAL IS CENSURED ON $6,000 'LOAN'
description: The principal of a Brooklyn public school engaged in ''highly inappropriate'' behavior when he borrowed $6,000 from a teacher and then refused to repay the loan, a disciplinary panel has found.

title: Mellon's Growing Loan Pains
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation, for years one of America's most revered financial institutions, is rapidly losing some of its luster.

title: Steffi Graf Extends Unbeaten Streak
description: Steffi Graf of West Germany remained unbeaten for 1987, defeating Manuela Maleeva today in the final of the Family Circle Magazine Cup, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3.

title: NIEKRO, ENTOURAGE ROCKED BY ROYALS
description: Hasn't Jerry Reuss stayed near a telephone since the Dodgers decided to send him away? Couldn't Tom Seaver cope with the I-95 construction delays on his way from Greenwich, Conn., to work at Yankee Stadium? Isn't Ed Whitson willing to consider trying again? Won't Dooley Womack return in his next life as a starting pitcher?

title: Visit From Soviet Brass
description: The Russians are coming, this time at the invitation of the Center for Defense Information, a Washington group headed by retired admirals.

title: ISRAELI ARMY QUELLS WEST BANK VIOLENCE
description: The Israeli Army bulldozed several rows of Arab-owned orange trees outside this village today, a day after an Israeli woman was burned to death by a firebomb tossed into her car from the edge of the citrus grove.

title: DERAILMENT DRAMA ENDS IN PITTSBURGH
description: Churches stood empty in the city's East End on Palm Sunday morning and thick stacks of newspapers sat unsold in the rain as 16,000 people evacuated from their homes waited for workers to remove the deadly chemical cargo of a derailed tanker.

title: American Ballet Theater To Open Season April 20
description: American Ballet Theater is to open its eight-week spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 20 with a gala benefit featuring a new production of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' staged for the company by Sir Kenneth MacMillan.

title: SERIES TIED; ISLANDERS FALL TO CAPITALS BY 4-1 AND FACE ELIMINATION
description: The Islanders play better when they are desperate, or so they tell themselves. Evidently, they weren't worried enough after falling behind the Capitals, two games to one, in their playoff series after Saturday night's game. Tonight, they left themselves one game from elimination as they were beaten, 4-1, by a team that performs like a machine.

title: THE WORLD OF THE IMMIGRANT: LOW-PAYING JOBS AND OVERCROWED HOUSING
description: After Joaquin Romero succeeded in getting himself from El Salvador to a Latin American neighborhood of Los Angeles, one of his first acts was to pay a smuggler to bring his wife and two young daughters here.

title: IN THE DESERT, CHAD EXHIBITS SPOILS OF WAR
description: The Libyan bombers appeared as silver flashes in the blue sky. Their falling bombs exploded nearby and sent plumes of sand, smoke and red-hot metal shards into the desert air. Chadian gunners fired hand-held antiaircraft missiles, but the circling planes flew too high to be hit.

title: Woman Might Get Reprieve to Build Ark
description: A woman who has spent five years building an ark in the center of the city might be allowed to continue her work if a judge stops the city from banishing her from the site, her attorney said yesterday.

title: MANY SEEK EXEMPTIONS AT JAPAN TARIFF HEARINGS
description: A police officer from Alaska, a mayor from Indiana and a horde of corporate executives and lobbyists will converge on Washington today to urge the Government to spare certain Japanese products from stiff tariffs scheduled to take effect Friday.

title: BATTLE OF THE NEVERSINK HEADING FOR THE COURTS
description: In the battle over the Neversink Gorge -which New York State has been losing for more than five years now - perhaps the only agreement is that the land is spectacularly scenic, home to deer and black bear and one of the finest trout streams in North America.

title: HOSPITAL ASSERTS IT GAVE WARHOL ADEQUATE CARE
description: In its first response to a state report charging that Andy Warhol received inadequate medical care before his death, the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said yesterday that its staff had provided ''entirely appropriate'' care to the artist.

title: MORE AID TO AFRICA IS URGED
description: Many African countries will need dramatic increases in foreign aid to continue what development experts are calling historic economic reforms, according to State Department, World Bank and United Nations officials.

title: MURPHY BELTS 2 AS BRAVES CLOBBER METS
description: Between innings, the fans are entertained by taped highlights from last season, played to the tune of ''We Are the Champions.'' Bill Buckner still cannot pick up Mookie Wilson's grounder and Jesse Orosco's glove has yet to come down after his celebratory toss following the final out of the World Series.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 13, 1987
description: Texaco's Bankruptcy Filing

title: Bridge: Number of Entries Is Small For Knockout Event on L.I.
description: A big event attracted a small number of entries at the Long Island Regional Championships during the weekend. Only seven teams, about half the usual number, entered the Knockout Team Championship, a surprise.

title: Key Events in the Pennzoil-Texaco Dispute
description: Jan. 3, 1984: Pennzoil board endorses a Memorandum of Agreement to buy 43 percent of Getty Oil, including one billion barrels of crude oil reserves, for $5.3 billion. Jan. 4: News release about merger is issued by Getty and Pennzoil. Texaco's president, Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., asks a Getty investment banker if the formal papers have been signed. He is told they have not been signed but that lawyers are working on them. Jan. 5: Texaco's board plans a $10.1 billion offer for Getty. Jan. 6-9: Getty's board votes to accept the Texaco offer, and Getty issues a news release. Pennzoil learns of Texaco deal and sends telex to Getty demanding it abide by its pact with Pennzoil. Jan. 10: Pennzoil files suit in Delaware to block the merger. Feb. 7: Chancery Judge Grover C. Brown rejects Pennzoil's plea for an injunction, but notes that Pennzoil might be able to establish in a trial that a contract had existed between Pennzoil and Getty. Feb. 8: Pennzoil files a new suit against Texaco in Houston, seeking damages for interfering in its deal. July 9, 1985: Jury trial begins, with New York laws to apply. Nov. 19: Texas jury rules for Pennzoil with the largest damage award in history: $10.53 billion, plus interest. Of that, $7.53 billion represents the amount Pennzoil suffered by not acquiring Getty and $3 billion is awarded as punishment. With interest, the total is about $12 billion. Texaco's net worth is $13.5 billion. Dec. 10: Texas State Judge Solomon Casseb enters judgment, affirming the jury's award. To stay the order while the case is appealed, Texaco, under Texas law, would have to post a bond of more than $12 billion. Texaco says that could force it into bankruptcy. Dec. 17: Texaco seeks an injunction in Federal court in New York to block Pennzoil action. Texaco says the judgment violated Federal law because it prevented Texaco from pursuing appeals. The court issues a temporary restraining order. Jan. 5-6, 1986: Texaco and Pennzoil hold settlement talks. Jan. 10: Federal Judge Charles Brieant in New York rules for Texaco on bond question, says Texaco could post $1 billion bond instead of $12 billion and also raises questions about fairness of the Texas trial. Feb. 20: The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York partly upholds Judge Brieant's ruling. It finds the bond would violate Texaco's right to due process but rebukes Judge Brieant for raising fairness questions. In Houston, Judge Casseb denies Texaco's motion for a new trial in damage award case. March 25: Top officers of Pennzoil and Texaco agree to resume talks. April 24: Texaco appeals the damage award to the Texas Court of Appeals. Pennzoil reacts coolly to Texaco settlement proposal. June 23: United States Supreme Court agrees to hear Pennzoil's appeal of the Federal court's bond decision. July 31: Companies argue before Texas First Court of Appeals. Jan. 12, 1987: U.S. Supreme Court hears bond arguments. Feb. 12: Texas Court of Appeals upholds award for Pennzoil, but trims judgment to $9.1 billion, including interest. March 30: Texaco asks Texas appeals court to reverse decision. April 6: U.S. Supreme Court rules against Texaco in bond case and invalidates New York Federal appeals court decision lowering Texaco bond to $1 billion. April 10: Texaco files legal documents in Texas saying that it could not afford to pay a bond of more than $1 billion. Pennzoil, in a separate filing, says it wants ''full security.'' April 12: Texaco, after failing to reach a settlement with Pennzoil, files for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. Texaco, meanwhile, makes a final settlement offer to Pennzoil's chairman, J. Hugh Kiedke.

title: MONTREAL SWEEPS BRUINS
description: Bobby Smith's goal tied the game for Montreal midway through the second period and Mike McPhee put the team ahead 30 seconds later as the Canadiens beat the Boston Bruins, 4-2, tonight to sweep their Adams Division first-round series.

title: Franklin D. Schurz Sr. Dies; Media Executive in Indiana
description: Franklin D. Schurz Sr., the longtime editor and publisher of The South Bend Tribune and chairman of Schurz Communications Inc., died at his home here today. He was 89 years old.

title: WILLIAM MORTON
description: William Morton, a star quarterback for Dartmouth in the early 1930's and a member of the College Football Hall of Fame, died Saturday. He was 77 years old.

title: BREWERS' STREAK NOW AT 6
description: B. J. Surhoff's two-run single in the 12th inning today gave the unbeaten Milwaukee Brewers their sixth victory of the season, a 7-5 triumph over the Texas Rangers.

title: LEMMON IN O'NEILL DRAMA
description: JONATHAN MILLER'S version of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' starring Jack Lemmon, began on the stage and had an extensive tour that included limited runs on Broadway and in London. Tonight at 8, it comes to pay cable's Showtime service. This television adaptation has also been directed by Mr. Miller. Michael Brandman and Emanuel Azenberg are the executive producers and Iris Merlis the producer of the ''Broadway on Showtime'' presentation.

title: Sosnoff Is Seen Raising His Bid
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor who has offered about $735 million for Caesars World Inc., raised his bid yesterday from $28 a share, to $32 a share, in the hopes of edging out a management counter-offer valued by the market at around $31, according to a source close to Mr. Sosnoff.

title: STAGE: AT BEAUMONT, 'THE REGARD OF FLIGHT'
description: AS Bill Irwin demonstrates in ''The Regard of Flight'' at the Vivian Beaumont, it is not the size of the theater that matters but the size of the talent. Mr. Irwin has performed versions of this signature show in the studio space at the Dance Theater Workshop, on the compact open stage at the American Place Theater (in 1982) and on ''Great Performances'' on public television. ''The Regard of Flight,'' which returned to New York last night, is blissfully at home at the Broadway-size Beaumont, which, for Mr. Irwin's special spring engagement (through April 26), echoes with the sound of bountiful laughter.

title: A Trade War
description: Japanese trade officials are fighting a crucial battle with their United States counterparts under the watchful eye of the military commander who defeated Japan in World War II. The Japanese delegation, led by Makoto Kuroda, vice minister for international affairs at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, is trying to get the United States to block imposition of tariffs on semiconductors.

title: Illuminating Iran Affair
description: With the public Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair scheduled to begin in three weeks, the investigative committees are trying to figure out a way the audience in the hearing room and people watching on television can follow along when documents are entered into evidence. ''The documents tell the real story here,'' said a staff assistant, ''and we've got to present them so that people can understand them.''

title: MECIR DEFEATS McENROE IN FOUR SETS
description: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, who had not won a set from John McEnroe in two previous matches, beat him by 6-0, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2 today in the final match of the World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: BONN, U.S. POLICIES SPUR CLASH
description: West German and American politicians, business executives and economists have clashed sharply here on national policies for checking the fall of the dollar, reducing the American trade deficit and resolving the world debt crisis.

title: THE STAGE: 'BITTERSUITE'
description: ELLIOT WEISS and Michael Champagne, the composer and lyricist who co-wrote the 21 songs in the cabaret musical ''Bittersuite,'' aren't the first contemporary songwriters to treat popular song as an adult short-story form. Charles Aznavour's rueful vignettes about marriage and the late Harry Chapin's psychological portraits of loners and losers were also conceived for theatrical performance outside of a narrative dramatic context.

title: CAMPAIGN SEEKS GENOCIDE TRIAL OF KHMER ROUGE
description: A New York-based human rights organization has started a campaign to have the Khmer Rouge tried for genocide before the International Court of Justice.

title: Galoob Account Shared By Towne, Silverstein
description: Towne, Silverstein, Rotter of New York has been selected by Lewis Galoob Toys of San Francisco to be its second ad agency and expects to be assigned about half of its advertised products and get about half of its $28 million budget.

title: The Garbage Is Burned, but What About the Possibly Toxic Ash?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kim Kashkashian Offers Viola Recital
description: Kim Kashkashian's viola recital Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum was pristine and deeply satisfying. The viola is too often played as if it were a slightly hoarser version of a violin; less often (and usually more grotesquely) it is treated like a surrogate cello. In fact, of course, at the risk of sounding obvious, it is itself - an instrument of patrician expressivity, with a burnished luster to its alto tone, its somewhat closeted sound made up of wonderfully variegated shades of gray.

title: Nor Should Pharmacists Be Physicians
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Maggie Perkins has joined William Esty Company as senior vice president/creative director.

title: NAVY SAYS SHORTAGE OF SAILORS MAY TAKE SHIPS OUT OF FLEET
description: The Navy may be forced to take warships out of the fleet by the end of the decade because of a potential shortage of sailors, senior Navy officers contend.

title: All in the Family
description: Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau's widening probe of hiring abuses by state legislators prompts emulation by prosecutors in the other boroughs. That's all to the good - except in the case of Queens. There, District Attorney John Santucci would pursue a probe that appears to involve his own son.

title: DANCER: WORKS BY 8 CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: AT a time when several dance series are closing because of financing problems, the debut of the ''Choreographers Showcase'' this weekend in a new downtown performing space was more than welcome.

title: Metro Matters; City as Landlord: A Tenant Is Paid To Stay and Play
description: New York City, which owns Yankee Stadium, is in an unusual position for a landlord. For each of the last five seasons, it has paid the Yankees more to maintain the stadium than the team has paid the city in rent.

title: FLY PATTERNS FOR TROUT
description: AN urge to simplify, to choose a few dozen artificial flies that will enable him to catch trout under all conditions, lurks in the heart of many a fly fisherman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Prost Takes Opener: Alain Prost of France, the two-time world champion, drove a McLaren to victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix yesterday, the first race of the 1987 Formula One season. Brazil's Nelson Piquet was second in a Williams, and Prost's teammate, Stefan Johansson of Sweden, was third. The victory was the 26th of Prost's career, leaving him one short of Jackie Stewart's career record. Austria's Gerhard Berger, making his first start in a Ferrari, finished fourth, and Thierry Boutsen of Belgium was fifth in a Benetton followed by Nigel Mansell of England in the other Williams. (AP) Guerrero's First Indy-Car Victory: In Phoenix, Roberto Guerrero started last and overcame a stop-and-go penalty to win the Checker 200 Indy-car race at Phoenix International Raceway. Guerrero beat the defending Indy-car champion, Bobby Rahal, to the finish line by a solid 8.62 seconds for his first Indy-car victory. Guerrero, a 28-year-old Colombian, was black-flagged into the pits just 39 laps from the end of the 200-lap event. Guerrero's Cosworth-powered March ran over a tire exiting the pits, incurring the automatic penalty. Guerrero averaged a track record 138.020 miles per hour, breaking the record of 134.676 m.p.h. set last October by Michael Andretti. Arie Luyendyk of the Netherlands finished third, a lap behind the leaders. Michael Andretti was fourth, followed a lap down by his father, Mario, and two laps back by Josele Garza of Mexico.(AP) Cobb and Weaver Triumph: In Braselton, Ga., Price Cobb passed Al Holbert eight laps from the finish and pulled away to a 12-second victory in the Atlanta Journal-Constitution Grand Prix Camel GT sports car race at Road Atlanta. Cobb teamed with James Weaver of England to win the 500-kilometer race at a record average speed of 112.944 m.p.h. in their Porsche 962. Holbert and his co-driver, Chip Robinson, led 69 laps in their Porsche 962 to just 23 laps for Cobb and Weaver. Holbert led Cobb by more than 17 seconds with 20 laps remaining when problems developed in the engine of Holbert's car.(AP) Tennis Arias Breezes by Svensson: In Houston, Jimmy Arias successfully defended his title, cruising to a 6-2, 6-4 victory over fourth-seeded Jonas Svensson of Sweden in the River Oaks International tournament. It has been 35 years since an American has won consecutive River Oaks championships. Gardnar Mulloy won the tournament in 1952 and 1953. Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia won the tournament in 1982 and 1983. Arias, of Jericho, L.I., took advantage of Svensson's 13 first-set forehand errors. The Swede made 43 unforced errors in the match. N.B.A. Bullets 103, Pistons 98: Moses Malone scored 27 points, including the 20,000th of his 11-year career, as Washington defeated Detroit. The Pistons lost any hope of capturing the Central Division title, which the Hawks clinched yesterday. Jeff Malone scored 28 points for Washington, which improved its record to 40-38 while handing the Pistons their third consecutive defeat. Malone became the 12th player in league history to score 20,000 points. He finished the game with 20,004.(AP) Bulls 116, Pacers 95: In Chicago, the Bulls' Michael Jordan scored 53 pointsy to break the 50-point mark for the sixth time this season. Jordan, who has scored 40 or more points 35 times this year, helped the Bulls move to within a half game of Indiana for the Eastern Conference's seventh playoff position. Jordan's high this season was 61 against Detroit on March 4.(AP) Track and Field Saleh First in Marathon: Ahmed Saleh of Djibouti won the men's World Cup marathon for the second consecutive time, finishing in2 hours 10 minutes 55 seconds in Seoul, South Korea, yesterday. Saleh won the first World Cup marathon, at Hiroshima, Japan, in 1985 in 2:08:09. Japan's Taisuke Kodama, who exchanged the lead with Saleh until the 19 1/2-mile mark of the 26-mile-385-yard race, finished second in 2:11:23. Italy's Salvatore Bettiol was third in 2:11:28. (AP) Petersen Takes Manhattan Event: Pat Petersen of Team adidas won the Penta-Javits Convention Center 5-kilometer race yesterday through the streets of midtown Manhattan in 13 minutes 58 seconds. Ross Donoghue of New York finished second, 75 yards back in the 3.1-mile race, in 14:25. He was followed by Tom Wood of the Gubbins Racing Team in 14:27. Gillian Horovitz of New York tookthe women's division in 16:42. Gillian Beschloss of the Warren Street A.C. was second in 16:57.(AP) High Schools East Wins All-Star Game: Brian Shorter, who will be attending Pitt, scored 24 points, including 10 in the opening four minutes of the second half, to lead the East to a 118-110 victory over the West in the McDonald's All American High School basketball game. Mark Macon, a Temple-bound senior from Saginaw, Mich., scored 14 points for the East and was named the Most Valuable Player. Chicago's Marcus Liberty scored 19 points to lead the West.(AP) Squash Racquets Talbott Gains Final: Top-seeded Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., defeated third-seeded John Nimick of Philadelphia, 15-12, 15-10, 15-9, yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, to reach the final of the North American Open, the most prestigious title in hardball squash racquets. In the other semifinal, second-seeded Ned Edwards of New York City defeated unseated Dave Boyum of Cambridge, Mass., 16-13, 11-15, 15-9, 15-12.

title: HAWKS ROUT NETS, TAKE TITLE
description: Minutes after Atlanta embar-rassed the Nets by 115-88 today at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Hawks learned that in Landover, Md., the Washington Bullets had beaten the Detroit Pistons.

title: EXECUTIVE WOMEN AND ETHICS
description: Soon after her appointment, a senior financial analyst at a top Westchester corporation was told by her boss to change certain figures on a Philippine company's financial statement to make it look good enough to acquire.

title: SECURITY IS TOUGHENED AT ALIEN CUSTODY CENTER
description: Responding to strong criticism, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun a major renovation of its Manhattan detention center and is revising the system it uses to keep aliens with criminal backgrounds from entering New York City.

title: Trials of a Japanese Ruth Amid the Alien Corn; Foreign to East Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: HORSZOWSKI
description: THE pianist Mieczyslaw Horszowski's concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon was one of the great musical events of the season.

title: Inflation Up In Mexico
description: Inflation in Mexico hit 23.6 percent for the first three months of 1987, the central Bank of Mexico announced Friday.

title: Zimbabwe Reported to Buy 12 Advanced Soviet Fighters
description: Zimbabwe, in a challenge to neighboring white-ruled South Africa, has secretly bought 12 MIG-29 interceptor aircraft, the Soviet Union's most advanced warplane, the Sunday Telegraph reported.

title: PUBLIC ACCESS TV: BEHIND THE SCENES
description: Dr. Barry Bloom is a television star. Every week he sits in a straight-backed chair near an arrangement of flowers and looks directly into a single, sometimes shaky, camera. Viewers call with questions about their dental work and Dr. Bloom gives advice, always stressing the importance of a second opinion.

title: NO NIGHT FOR THESPIANS
description: REGARDING the Hagler-Leonard middleweight title fight last Monday night, some who witnessed it and some who didn't still question whether the only thing square was the ring.

title: HANDLING OF BOND INQUIRY TROUBLING ATLANTA
description: Reports that the wife of former State Senator Julian Bond confidentially told the police her estranged husband was a habitual cocaine abuser and then later publicly retracted the allegation have become the focus of broad controversy here.

title: View From the Grandstand
description: ''He has to do this,'' Jackie Robinson said to us that fall of 1960. ''He has to call Martin right now, today. I have the number of the jail.''

title: C. F. Louis DeWild, 86, Dies; Longtime Painting Restorer
description: C. F. Louis DeWild, for many years a leading professional in the field of painting conservation and the restorer of great paintings that are now in the Metropolitan Museum, the National Gallery of Art, the Frick Collection and elsewhere, died at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on April 2. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DANCE: 2 AT THE KITCHEN
description: CYDNEY WILKES, Nelson Zayas and Linda Mancini examined lovers' problems on Saturday night at the Kitchen. ''One Man's Drink. . .,'' directed by Mr. Zayas and choreographed and performed by Ms. Mancini and him, to a sound score by Lisa Love, was a lighthearted courtship that began with the dancers seated side by side like moviegoers. When Ms. Mancini coquettishly wiggled a foot, Mr. Zayas sought to hold it, but was repulsed. And he kept being repulsed whenever he edged closer.

title: TEXACO STOCK PRICE EXPECTED TO SUFFER
description: Texaco's Chapter 11 filing will likely cause its stock value to plummet, oil industry specialists predicted yesterday. They also said that Pennzoil, which has won most of the legal battles in the case, may see its stock badly hurt.

title: TEXACO, FIGHTING PENNZOIL ATTACK, ASKS BANKRUPTCY
description: In a case that started as a contract dispute between two oil companies, Texaco Inc. yesterday filed for bankruptcy in a dramatic attempt to stay alive pending the outcome of its bitter battle with the Pennzoil Company.

title: DIVESTMENT EFFORTS IN MEXICO DEBATED
description: When President Miguel de la Madrid was elected five years ago, the Mexican Government owned 1,155 companies, including a restaurant and nightclub, several chains of movie theaters, a soft-drink manufacturer and a bicycle factory.

title: Now Bloom Comes Up With 'Human Zooms'
description: The Bloom Agency in New York, as a way of promoting the IQZoom camera for its client Pentax, has created ''Human Zooms,'' people who slide forward and backward trying to get pictures in focus.

title: DANCE: MARIA CHENG
description: MARIA CHENG began with some talk on the business and art of dance today, in a program presented by the Maria Cheng Dance Company on Friday evening at the Triplex Theater. That talk, part of a piece called ''Antecedents,'' proved that Ms. Cheng is a smart and funny observer of the world of dance. But the rest of the evening was disappointing, though Ms. Cheng's charming and adept dancers were a pleasure to be with.

title: ON ISLE WHERE MANY WEEP, PLANS TO LIFT SPIRITS
description: Fifteen minutes by ferry from Dakar lies a low, sun-washed island that was the last bit of Africa seen by millions of people before they crossed the ocean to a lifetime of slavery.

title: Bill Lee for President
description: Bill Lee, the zany left-hander who hasn't played in the majors since Montreal dropped him in 1982 for staging a personal walkout to protest the release of Rodney Scott, a teammate, is making a new pitch for a big-time career. He has announced that he's running for President of the United States - on a Canadian ticket.

title: Addendum
description: * Country Home magazine will raise its circulation rate base 10 percent, to 880,000, and advertising rates 10 percent with the August issue.

title: The U.N. Today: April 13, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Natural Resources - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Sudan Cuts Sentence for Aide Who Helped Ethiopian Jews
description: A court has reduced the sentence given to former Vice President Omar el-Tayeb for his role in transporting thousands of Ethiopian Jews through the Sudan to Israel.

title: EX-GUINNESS CHAIRMAN ACCUSED ON DOCUMENTS
description: The long-running Guinness scandal is again a focus of national attention, as new details, charges and countercharges in the case were revealed last week in a London high court.

title: Shultz and Africa Trip
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has dearly wanted to make a trip to southern Africa before leaving office, and State Department officials were hoping to plan one for July. But East-West issues have so dominated the foreign policy agenda that even thinking about such a journey has been put off, at least until well after the Secretary returns from Moscow later this week.

title: More to Learn From the City Volunteers
description: Two years ago, with talk of a need to foster a ''spirit of altruism'' in the young, Mayor Koch boldly launched New York's City Volunteer Corps. It was to be a three-year experiment and a potential model for a system of national youth service. Now, just into the third year, the Mayor seems ready to declare the experiment a failure and cut its funding from $10 million to $6 million. That judgment, and cut, are premature.

title: CUOMO URGED BY BAR PANEL TO VETO ETHICS BILL AS WEAK
description: The executive comittee of the New York State Bar Association recommended this weekend that Governor Cuomo veto a bill that is supposed to tighten ethics rules for state legislators.

title: NASA ASSERTS CONTROL OF STATION
description: The space agency official in charge of plans for a space station being developed with European, Canadian and Japanese help said Saturday that the space agency, rather than the Pentagon, would control the project.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Pennzoil has placed its own greed above any consideration of fundamental fairness or the public welfare.'' - James W. Kinnear, chief executive officer of Texaco. ''It shows in my judgment an arrogance and disregard for the whole judicial process and an attempt to use the bankruptcy laws improperly.'' - Baine P. Kerr, chairman of Pennzoil's executive committee. [ A1:6. ]

title: SERIES TIED; COMBATIVE PLAY CONTINUES; FROESE IS IN THE MAIN EVENT
description: Of all the violent, chaotic sights last night, the most curious and most significant was Bob Froese, the Rangers' goalkeeper, following Lindsay Carson of the Flyers down the ice, yelling at him and goading him.

title: CITY PROJECT ON CONCRETE THREATENED
description: Eight months after contracts were signed, a Koch administration plan to lower concrete prices by subsidizing the construction of a concrete plant in Manhattan is in serious jeopardy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Good Vibes

title: Back to Energy Independence
description: Last month, the Energy Department finally acknowledged that America faces national security problems because of its increasing dependence on imported oil. If Energy Secretary John S. Herrington had magical power, he might have set the price of oil at, say, $30 a barrel, up from the prevailing $18.

title: A PRACTICED HAND TAKES ON THE TASK OF TELLING REAGAN STORY
description: The phone rang on the reporter's desk and the chirpy voice with a slight Southern drawl said: ''Hi, this is Tom Griscom. Are you doing a Sunday piece on the highway bill?''

title: Not So Rosy in Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Nathan Smith, Hospital Administrator in New York
description: Dr. Nathan Smith, a former superintendent of Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx, died Saturday in Miami. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LIGHTNING STRIKES
description: WHEN asked about the chances of repeating his theatrical Masters victory of last year, Jack Nicklaus joked, ''I'm going out to look for some lightning; maybe I can catch it again.'' And the lightning was out there again yesterday in the clear blue sky above the Augusta National pines, as Greg Norman discovered to his dismay.

title: ENLISTING THE YOUNG IN PUBLIC SERVICE
description: The idea has been around a long time.

title: APATHY IS ENEMY TO BOTH SIDES IN CAMBODIA
description: On the eve of the traditional Buddhist New Year in Southeast Asia, both sides in Cambodia's unseen, unending war have been making urgent appeals for the trust and allegiance of the battle-weary Khmer people.

title: FLYERS ANTICIPATING COMFORTS OF HOME
description: From the Flyers' point of view, their mission was accomplished in New York during their series against the Rangers despite last night's loss.

title: BOND MARKET DRIVEN BY DOLLAR
description: At morning strategy sessions all over Wall Street, bond traders are asking, ''How's the dollar?''

title: SURVEY CITES DROP IN CRIME IN '86
description: The number of crimes committed in the nation fell slightly in 1986 from the year before, continuing a five-year decline, the Justice Department said today.

title: Advertising; Agency's Lesson in Survival
description: THE J. G. Durand Compagnie of Arques, France, is making its debut as an advertiser on American television with a line of low-priced crystal and a line of all-purpose cookware. It is an account that the principals of an ad agency on the verge of death almost died for. This is the story: Stephen Penchina and Arthur Selkowitz founded Penchina Selkowitz in 1982, and it really flourished, thanks largely to one account: the Burroughs Corporation. They gave it great advertising.

title: Islands in Alien Seas
description: The American Embassy in Moscow is an island under constant assault. Laser beams probe the windows for echoes of conversations. Tunnels have been bored below, and antennas thrust up its chimneys. Cocktail bars and swimming pools are alive with ''swallows,'' seductive women who lure the susceptible into ''honey traps.'' Rooms, cars, even typewriters are likely to be bugged. Except in special secure chambers, diplomats assume that all conversations are overheard. In this strange world, several Marine guards fell prey to the swallows, apparently giving the Russians the run of the embassy and themselves a new motto - saepe fidelis, often faithful.

title: ZEVULON AVSHALOMOV
description: Zevulon Avshalomov, a composer and performer of traditional Persian and Caucasian music, died on April 4. He was 77 years old and lived in New York City.

title: G.L. ARTAMONOFF, A SEARS LEADER
description: Col. George Leonidovich Artamonoff, 84 years old, the first president of Sears International Inc. and later director of the Tokyo office of the Marshall Plan, died Saturday of pneumonia in the Potomac Valley Nursing Home in Rockville, Md.

title: V.A. Raises Loan Rates
description: The Veterans Administration is raising its maximum interest rate on federally backed V.A. mortgages one percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent, the first increase in two years.

title: Ellen Grossman Weds
description: At the Marlboro (N.J.) Jewish Center, Ellen Donna Grossman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Grossman of East Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony R. Lieber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Lieber of New York. Rabbi George Schlesinger performed the ceremony. Mrs. Lieber, a graduate of Rutgers University, as is her husband, is an agency finance specialist in Newark, and her husband is an estate and financial planner in New York, both for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company.

title: OLIVER STONE EASING OUT OF VIOLENCE
description: ''Hell is the impossibility of reason.'' Oliver Stone in ''Platoon.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A Red Sox left-hander named Billy Rohr just missed a no-hitter against the Yankees on opening day in his major league debut about 20 years ago. Has anyone ever pitched a no-hitter in his first appearance in the majors? What ever became of Rohr?

title: TV FOLLOWERS SEE DEVIL'S HAND IN BAKKER'S FALL
description: The Devil is not only responsible for the fall of the Rev. Jim Bakker and the troubles facing the nation's television ministry; he is an active, negative force at work in the universe who is constantly tempting human beings, many followers of the television evangelists believe.

title: WAR ON DRUGS SHIFTING FOCUS TO STREET DEALS
description: Turning the theory of how to fight the drug trade upside down, police departments around the country are increasingly blanketing drug-plagued neighborhoods with officers and arresting large numbers of small-time dealers and buyers.

title: Let's Stop Calling Teen-Age Suicides Senseless
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH JOY AND PRAYER, AN EMIGRE FAMILY MARKS PASSOVER
description: In Rome last week, on his way from the Soviet Union to the United States, 60-year-old Michael Arbitman worshiped in a synagogue for the first time, gratefully touching the pages of the Torah with his wizened hands.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 13, 1987: Monday Eastern Utilities Assoc Pueblo Intl Inc PS Group Inc Zurn Indus TUESDAY Barry Wright Hillenbrand Indus Crompton & Knowles Procter & Gamble Diversified Energies Teco Energy Inc WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Dun & Bradstreet Bally Mfg Corp GTE Corp Bard Midwest Energy Clorox Co NCR Corp Columbia Gas System Texas Indus Conrac Corp Wisconsin Pwr & Lt Dow Jones & Co THURSDAY Archer-Daniels-Midland Gillette Co Black & Decker Lamaur Inc Bundy Corp PPG Industries Burlington Indus Sundstrand Corp Central & South West Time Inc Cincinnati Gas & Elec Weyerhaeuser Co First Wisconsin Corp FRIDAY Communications Satellite

title: DISRUPTIVE IMPACT ON DEALINGS EXPECTED
description: Although the bankruptcy filing of Texaco Inc. allows the company to continue operating much as it has before, many oil executives say that the action will have a disruptive impact on the business Texaco conducts with others in the industry. The oil giant pays about $3.5 billion yearly to some 23,000 suppliers and contractors in Texas alone.

title: TOP AIDE QUITS GANDHI GOVERNMENT
description: In a blow to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the Indian Defense Minister resigned today under pressure from politicians unhappy with his attempt to investigate possible kickbacks in the awarding of an overseas defense contract.

title: Randi J. Rosenberg Weds M.D. Steele
description: Randi Joy Rosenberg and Matthew David Steele were married yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated, assisted by Cantor Barbara Horowitz. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosenberg of San Jose, Calif., and Dr. and Mrs. Theodore K. Steele of Great Neck.

title: Decision Near on Hunt Plan
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Dallas is expected to rule Tuesday on whether to allow the Placid Oil Company, one of the Hunt brothers' major holdings, to proceed with a major deep-water drilling effort in the Gulf of Mexico that is known as the Green Canyon project.

title: White House Counsel Seeks Iran Documents
description: The White House counsel has asked President Reagan's senior aides to give him all internal documents related to the Iran-contra affair, including any records that might exist from Mr. Reagan's first term, a spokesman said tonight.

title: Malaysian Family Poisoning
description: Nine people died and six were hospitalized after a family reunion at which they reportedly ate poisonous fish, the national news agency Bernama said today.

title: Fallon, McElligott Gets Squirtco as New Client
description: Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis, continuing to roll, has filled the soft drink niche. The client is Squirtco of Holland, Mich. The assignment is for Squirt and Diet Squirt Plus.

title: Music Noted in Brief; David Van Tieghem, A Performance Artist
description: Experimental music and downtown showmanship have rarely been blended more delightfully than in the early solo performances of the debonair young percussionist and composer David Van Tieghem. In ''A Man and His Toys,'' the show Mr. Van Tieghem toured around Europe and the United States, he played a cheerfully eccentric scientist of sound effects, eliciting an extraordinary range of amplified thuds and squeaks from a laboratory of household objects.

title: Reagans Begin Vacation
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, took advantage today of their first vacation in more than four months at their mountaintop retreat, Rancho del Cielo, near here. The White House press office said the Reagans invited the President's son Michael and his wife, Colleen, to the ranch to celebrate the fourth birthday of their son, Ashley. The President is to return to Washington April 20.

title: OKAMOTO WINS BY A STROKE
description: Ayako Okamoto liked the idea that the only player who could beat her today was playing right beside her.

title: AUTO WORKERS TO SEEK JOB SECURITY IN NEGOTIATIONS AT G.M. AND FORD
description: Improved job security will be the top goal when the United Automobile Workers open negotiations this summer for a new contract with the nation's two largest automobile companies, the union's president said today.

title: Twice Bitten
description: Among the multitude of S.M.U. football players headed for new campuses is Tony Brown, who's getting fed up. Brown was a freshman at Texas-Arlington when that school dropped football for financial reasons after the 1985 season. He became a part-time starter at fullback for the Mustangs last fall, but now, after just two seasons of college play, has twice seen his team fold out from under him. Next stop: Arizona State, which gives no weight to the suggestion that its newest transfer might be carrying a hex.

title: SHEVARDNADZE IS SEEN AS GROWING FAST IN HIS JOB
description: The last time Secretary of State George P. Shultz visited Moscow, in October 1985, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was new on the job and showed it, according to American officials.

title: MIZE MASTERS 140-FOOTER TO WIN TITLE IN PLAYOFF
description: Larry Hogan Mize, born and raised within a few miles of the Augusta National Golf Club, fulfilled a boyhood dream today when he won the 51st Masters by beating Greg Norman with a historic shot.

title: CONCERT: LOCKENHAUS FESTIVAL OFFERS A PREMIERE
description: GIDON KREMER'S Lockenhaus Festival concerts at the Metropolitan Museum, which seem to be aspiring to a sort of European version of Music From Marlboro, offered an important American premiere Friday night.

title: At Last, a Book Dealing With Bernbach's Work
description: The things that William Bernbach wrote - or guided the writing of -changed an industry and affected a nation, but he never wrote a book.

title: Trials of a Japanese Ruth Amid the Alien Corn
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET ASTRONAUTS SOLVE A DOCKING PROBLEM
description: Yuri Romanenko and Aleksandr Laveikin went outside their space station to assure that the new research module Kvant was successfully docked with the orbiting station Mir today, Tass reported.

title: REAGAN SHIFT ON THE ABM TREATY PRESENTS BOTH PROBLEMS AND ADVANTAGES FOR SOVIET
description: President Reagan's decision to back away from proposals that he made at the Reykjavik summit has both minuses and pluses for Moscow.

title: ASTROS OFF TO THEIR BEST STARTS
description: Billy Hatcher had two hits and drove in the winning run as the Houston Astros beat the Montreal Expos, 1-0, today for their sixth straight victory, the best start in their 26-year history.

title: Hungary Lifts Price of Meat And Other Consumer Goods
description: The Government announced consumer price increases today that included a rise of up to 22 percent in the cost of meat.

title: Tariffs Seen as Harmful
description: Users of Japanese electronics today warned of financial losses, layoffs and even a negative impact on public safety if certain targeted goods are hit by punitive tariffs that the Reagan Administration is preparing to impose later this week.

title: White House Counsel Seeks Iran Documents
description: The White House counsel has asked President Reagan's senior aides to give him all internal documents related to the Iran-contra affair, including any records that might exist from Mr. Reagan's first term, according to a White House spokesman.

title: AT ACADEMY, POLICE LEARN LIFE ISN'T TV
description: It is not ''Miami Vice,'' the driving instructors at the New York City Police Academy warned the recruits. So forget about wild chases that leave cars split in half, fruit stands toppled and grandmothers barely escaping with their lives.

title: MARINES STUNG WHERE IT HURTS: PRIDE IN CORPS
description: Master Gunnery Sgt. Michael Hakim was succinct about the accusations against Marine Corps guards who served in Moscow: ''It hurts.''

title: REAGAN'S TOP AIDES ARE LOOKING TO NEW MEETING WITH GORBACHEV
description: White House officials said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz was likely to agree in Moscow on another meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Pact for Clemens
description: Roger Clemens, the 1986 American League most valuable player and Cy Young Award winner who boycotted the entire exhibition season in a salary dispute, agreed yesterday to a new two-year contract with the Boston Red Sox. ''I'm very happy this day came,'' Clemens said at a news conference. ''I don't have any hard feelings.'' The Red Sox refused to disclose details, but the pact was reported to be for about $2 million. Lou Gorman, Red Sox general manager, said it included incentive clauses. Clemens, 24 years old, led the major leagues with a 24-4 record in 1986 as the Red Sox won the pennant. In his 1987 debut against Toronto Saturday, he lasted only four innings, giving up four runs. He left the game with Boston trailing, 4-1, and the Blue Jays won, 11-1. Clemens earned $220,000 plus $120,000 in bonus incentive money in his second full season with the Red Sox in 1986. He had asked for $2.4 million for two years. The Red Sox rejected the pitcher's demand and automatically renewed his contract for $400,000 after he walked out.

title: On Mental Health
description: More than two dozen national organizations concerned with mental health have urged the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, to broaden the search for a new director of the National Institute of Mental Health beyond what they say is the current candidate list of 11 white male psychiatrists.

title: Cold Cut
description: Bob Berry, dropped as coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins despite the strides that the team made during his three-year stewardship: ''I feel like someone who has gone and chopped down a tree, cut the logs, built a fire and then been told to wait outside.''

title: Interfirst Posts Loss in Period
description: The Interfirst Corporation, the fourth-largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it had a loss of $18.9 million in the first quarter of 1987, in contrast to earnings of $2.1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. The company said the loss included $20.4 million in gains from securities sales.

title: Chevrolets on the Shelf In P.&G.'s Latest Caper
description: If you are one of those small-town types who think the drawing for a car is a big deal, you'd better hold onto your hat.

title: MOZART'S ORIGINAL SCORES OF 9 SYMPHONIES TO BE SOLD
description: The scores of nine complete Mozart symphonies, handwritten by the composer, will be auctioned at Sotheby's in London on May 22. The manuscripts, which will be sold as one offering, are expected to bring $1.5 million.

title: Franklin Bandy Dies at 72; Writer Won Mystery Award
description: Franklin Bandy, who wrote mystery and suspense novels and was a director and a former executive vice president of the Mystery Writers of America, died Saturday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center in White Plains. He was 72 years old and lived in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: UPDATING 'THE MIKADO' WITH TARGETS OF TODAY
description: When Gilbert and Sullivan wrote ''The Mikado'' more than a century ago, they listed in the Lord High Executioner's song some of the things society could easily do without.

title: 'FRONTLINE' EXAMINES 'SECURITY RISK' OF 1946
description: PENN TOWNSEND KIMBALL, journalist, professor and sometime political aide, was labeled a security risk by the State Department in 1946. The label, based on flimsy evidence, has apparently never been removed. ''The Secret File,'' a ''Frontline'' documentary on Channel 13 at 10 tonight, examines Mr. Kimball's case. Someone, it is clear, owes him an apology.

title: Penguins Dismiss Berry
description: Although the Pittsburgh Penguins doubled their attendance and almost doubled their points in the last three years, they still failed to make the National Hockey League playoffs. Yesterday, Coach Bob Berry and his assistant, Jim Roberts, were dismissed by the team vice president, Paul Martha. Berry's record with the Penguins was 88-127-25 and his N.H.L. career mark, which included stints with Los Angeles and Montreal, is 311-292-100. The Penguins finished 30-38-12 this past season, good for 72 points but 4 points behind the Rangers, the last team in the Patrick Division to make the playoffs. Berry replaced Lou Angotti as coach in 1984 when the Penguins came off a season with 38 points, their worst in 20 years in the N.H.L.

title: PACT IS REACHED ON OWNERSHIP OF A HOSPITAL
description: The operators of North General Hospital, the only minority-run voluntary hospital in New York State, have reached an agreement that would give them complete ownership of the Harlem center and significantly ease the financial problems that have dogged its eight-year existence.

title: NEW HAVEN CONCERN IS FINED $250,000 ON ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: Uretek Inc. embroiled in a bitter strike over health and safety conditions at its New Haven plant, was fined $250,000 today for illegal storage and dumping of hazardous waste, the authorities said.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the earnings decline for the latest period reflected lower net interest income resulting primarily from placing medium- and long-term Brazilian debt on a nonaccrual basis, as well as lower gains from securities trading and higher noninterest expense. The effect of these negative factors was partially offset by a substantial increase in foreign exchange trading profits and higher fees for other banking services. The company also said the first quarter 1987 net interest income was further reduced by the impact of the lower 1987 federal income tax rate on the calculation of the taxable-equivalent adjustment on tax-exempt assets. The after-tax negative impact on first quarter net income from Brazilian loans was about $12 million.

title: Philharmonic to Give 3 Postseason Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic is to perform three special postseason concerts at Avery Fisher Hall on June 4, 5 and 6 at 8 P.M., devoted to the music of George Gershwin and Duke Ellington. Conducted by James DePreist, the concerts are also to enlist the jazz saxophonist Dexter Gordon, who starred in the film '' 'Round Midnight,'' and the pianist Leon Bates.

title: KLLM TRANSPORT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
SOUTH KOREA STEPS UP ITS ATTACKS ON OPPOSITION
description: The Government stepped up its attacks today on South Korea's two leading opposition figures, blaming them for the suspension of constitutional debate ordered earlier in the day by President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: Careers; A Broker's Training at Giant Firm
description: HIGH on a 40-foot pole a blue flag with a bull outlined in white flaps in the breeze. The bull is the familiar symbol of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: Chicago Merc Rebuffs Shift
description: Members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange soundly rejected a petition yesterday to ban dual trading in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts. Dual trading allows traders to trade for their own accounts as well as for clients.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A HISTORY OF THE JEWS. By Paul Johnson. 644 pages. Harper & Row. $25.

title: ABINGTON SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on sales of securities of $615,000 for the latest quarter and $470,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said per share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago quarter are not available because the bank converted to stock form of ownership in June 1986.

title: Regulator Is Cleared
description: Robert Y. Empie, the embattled Oklahoma banking commissioner, was cleared today of wrongdoing but announced that he would resign June 30.

title: MAGADAN'S RETURN TO METS IMMINENT
description: The Mets did not retrieve Dave Magadan from the disabled list yesterday, the first day he was eligible to return to active duty. But they were expected to restore him to the team by the end of the week, and Magadan reported from Florida: ''I consider myself back to normal.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not the madness of just one man; This is the madness of a government which has long ago lost all legitimacy and can only live out its last days compounding the evil it has begun. I want to say to this government: your days are up and you know that.'' - The Rev. Allan Boesak, a leading South African clergyman, on restrictive new laws. [ A13:5. ]

title: F.A.A. Investigating Reports Of 4 Near-Collisions in a Day
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating four incidents over a 10-hour period in which commercial jets came within 500 feet of colliding with smaller planes, officials said today.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said that latest first- quarter net was reduced by $5.7 million because of a special provision against accrued interest receivable on medium- and long-term loans to Brazil. Year-ago first-quarter net includes securities gains of $15.3 million, primarily related to its Encor interstate banking program, plus unusually high government securities trading profits. The company also said that about $348.4 million of its Brazilian loans are medium- and long-term and subject to postponement of dollar interest payments announced by the Brazilian government.

title: Baseball's Racial Hypocrisy
description: For sheer hypocrisy, the baseball hierarchy's reaction to the discrimination-in-management issue is hard to beat. The same goes for those suddenly expressing outrage at a condition they have silently tolerated for nearly 30 years.

title: HUDSON, YANKS' LATE STARTER, BRIGHTENS A DARK DAY
description: The conditions could not have been less desirable for a home opener in the Bronx. There was a deluge in the morning, a sky full of ominous clouds in the afternoon and a minor emergency about a half hour before game time.

title: Consortium Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Is Dismissed For Evading Queries
description: A New York City police officer who has been indicted on charges of stealing nearly $18,000 from his estranged wife's bank account after she disappeared mysteriously last summer was dismissed from the force without a pension yesterday.

title: Texaco to Keep Backing Opera
description: Texaco, which filed on Sunday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, will continue to sponsor the Metropolitan Opera's radio and television broadcasts, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: BOND AND NOTE PRICES TUMBLE
description: Heavy selling of mortgage-backed securities plus fears that the Federal Reserve was tacitly encouraging higher short-term interest rates led to sharply lower prices for notes and bonds yesterday.

title: WEDTECH SUES ITS AUDITORS FOR DAMAGES
description: The Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that is at the center of several investigations into public corruption, sued two accounting concerns yesterday, charging that they had failed in their responsibilities to disclose ''pervasive fraud'' by Wedtech's former management.

title: RIVAL PALESTINIANS MEET IN EFFORT TO END DIVISION
description: Senior leaders of rival factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization gathered today for the first time in four years in an attempt to end their differences.

title: Chess: Finally, Special Prize Is Won By a Tournament Champion
description: It is a good thing to see the special prizes go to the right players - it does not always go that way.

title: FASCINATION OF TITANIC ENDURES AT 75
description: The wind was down and the sea was calm before midnight 75 years ago as the Titanic ran at a good, but not record-breaking, speed through the ice fields. The danger was reported but, following the habit of many shipmasters, was not handled in more than the most routine manner.

title: Like Hart, His Rivals Seek the Unconventional
description: With his announcement today that he will run for President, Gary Hart formally entered a Democratic contest that is becoming less settled as the 1988 election approaches, rather than more so.

title: The Capital Shrugs
description: In a town normally given to hyperbolic response to the smallest, most distant hiccup, the bankruptcy filing on Sunday by the nation's eighth largest industrial company made virtually no impression on official Washington.

title: INTERNATIONAL POWER MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SANDINISTAS TEST AUTONOMY IN EAST PROVINCE
description: Since Britain withdrew from the eastern half of Nicaragua in 1894, the region has been known as Zelaya Province, named after the Nicaraguan president at the time, Jose Santos Zelaya.

title: 9 Trains Set Afire in Soweto; Pretoria Sees Link to Strike
description: Nine trains were set on fire today in Soweto, the country's biggest black township, in incidents that may be linked to a five-week-old strike by transport workers, the Government's Bureau for Information said.

title: DOCTOR, BACKING HINCKLEY, TELLS OF LETTER TO MURDERER
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who attempted to assassinate President Reagan and is now trying to convince a Federal judge his mental illness is in remission, wrote sympathetically to one multiple killer and kept the address of another, Charles Manson, a psychiatrist testified today.

title: BankAmerica Fills Job at Unit
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that Richard M. Rosenberg had been appointed vice chairman and head of its newly designated California Banking Group. Mr. Rosenberg, who has worked in banking for 28 years, has been president and chief operating officer of the Seafirst Corporation, a BankAmerica subsidiary and parent of the largest bank in the state of Washington, since December 1985. With responsibility for Bank=

title: Wayne Chapman Dies at 54; Cravath, Swaine Law Partner
description: Wayne Ellsworth Chapman, a tax lawyer and partner in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, died of cancer Saturday at his home on Manhattan's Upper East Side. He was 54 years old.

title: Mafia Informer Is Put on Probation
description: A Mafia informer who testified against John Gotti, the reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, and helped jail a corrupt Queens justice was put on probation yesterday on a Federal narcotics charge.

title: RANGERS MAY GET EDGE FROM DEPTH
description: If it should happen again that the Rangers eliminate the Flyers it would be called an upset, a fluke. But by now it should be clear that there is at least one tangible factor at work for the Rangers in the playoffs: They have depth; the Flyers do not.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from overfunded pension plans of $4,896,000 and $3,340,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $208,000 and $619,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and tax credits of $695,000 for the quarter and $3,638,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued $614,000 for the quarter and $1,137,000 for the 9 months; and tax credits of $260,000 and $1,426,000 for the quarter and 9 month, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable May 28.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Maps accompanying reports about Chad on Jan. 18, March 26, April 3 and April 5 incorrectly located Wadi Doum, the Libyan airfield that fell to Chadian forces in March. A map showing the correct location appeared yesterday; Wadi Doum is about 85 miles northeast of Faya-Largeau.

title: KING GETS 19 POINTS IN ROLE OF STARTER
description: It took only three games for Bernard King to return to his familiar form. Not physically, at least not yet. But after just four days in uniform, the 30-year-old Knick captain is talking as boldly as he once played.

title: East German Tells West Berlin No
description: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, announced today that he would not attend a celebration in West Berlin marking the 750th anniversary of the foundation of Berlin.

title: Our Towns; On Volunteering: Doctors Balance Rich and Poor
description: A doctor becomes established in the suburbs, builds a lucrative practice, finds he has free time. What to do? One suburban cosmetic surgeon has hired a public relations outfit and made himself available to discuss advances in permanent eyeliner, for ''today's physically active women whose makeup smudges.'' A Long Island surgeon lectures on the ''art of facelift'' at Bloomingdale's.

title: IRVING BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company stated that the decline in first-quarter earnings resulted from the placement of $215 million and $33 million of medium- and long-term loans to borrowers in Brazil and Equador, respectively, on nonaccrual status. The company also said that excluding the impact of placing these loans on non-accrual status, net income would have increased 8.4 percent to $32,996,000 for the quarter, and per share earnings would have been $1.75 in the latest quarter.

title: CHARRED BODY OF FEMALE SOLDIER IS FOUND IN REFUSE BIN AT FORT DIX
description: A 21-year-old soldier at Fort Dix, N.J., has been found slain on the base, her charred body pulled from a burning trash bin, an Army spokesman said yesterday.

title: 2 May Bid For Dome
description: Two European-based oil companies, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the British Petroleum Company, emerged today as possible bidders for the assets of Canada's troubled oil giant, Dome Petroleum Ltd.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months earnings are restated to reflect an accounting change regarding pensions.

title: NEW YORK INMATES WILL GET CONDOMS AS THEY LEAVE JAIL
description: New York City correction officials will begin issuing condoms to every inmate upon release, and will provide condoms to a small group of homosexual inmates upon request, the Koch administration said yesterday.
