title: DOW PLUNGES BY 51.71 ON RATE FEARS
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 51.71 points yesterday as a wave of selling battered a stock market already reeling from a weaker dollar, worry over inflation and a sharp rise in interest rates.

title: INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY OF SPACE STUDY PLANNED
description: Baby Boomers move over: The Space Generation is on the rise. The new International Space University, a project of the Space Generation Foundation, is evidence that people born since 1957, when humans pierced the veil of earth's atmosphere, are coming of age.

title: Taxi Fare Rise Depends On Faulty Industry Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Genetic Test Approved
description: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company based in Oakland, Calif., said today that it has received permission from the California Department of Food and Agriculture to field-test its genetically altered bacteria intended to protect plants from frost damage. The state permit is the final regulatory approval required of Advanced Genetic. A coalition of opposition groups said it will file suit on Wednesday to block the state from issuing the permit. Jeremy Rifkin, a longtime opponent of such testing, has said that the open-air release of genetically altered organisms could have unforeseen environmental effects.

title: Simmons Aide Fills Chief's Post at NL
description: J. Landis Martin, a top legal adviser to Harold C. Simmons, the Texas investor, has been named president and chief executive of NL Industries, which Mr. Simmons controls.

title: Connecticut Sniper Sought
description: The police searched today for a sniper who struck three cars, slightly injuring one man, on Interstate 95 on Saturday. The first shot, which occurred about 5:30 P.M., shattered the windshield of a northbound pickup truck near Exit 18. Its 30-year-old driver, whose name was not available, was treated for minor cuts and released from Norwalk Hospital. A second car, traveling south toward New York City, was struck on its right side, and a third driver notified police that his car was apparently fired upon as he entered I-95. The police are unsure of what type of gun was used.

title: INSIDE
description: Stretching Nature's Laws

title: Rig Count Falls Slightly
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped last week to 749 from 752 the week before, the Hughes Tool Company said today.

title: DELAYS ANGER ATLANTA AIR TRAVELERS
description: Ellen Timmons's plane from Dallas was due into Atlanta's Hartsfield Airport at 9:19 this morning, plenty of time, she thought, to make the 10:09 connecting flight to Louisville.

title: CLAMOR RISES OVER DETENTION OF CUBAN REFUGEES BY U.S.
description: About 6,800 Cuban refugees remain indefinitely imprisoned in the United States, in a situation denounced as a human rights violation by several civil rights groups and religious leaders.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Marco Baldi, the 6-foot-11-inch center for St. John's, is on crutches and wearing a walking cast over his left ankle. Baldi, who played with tendinitis in his left heel last season, has been informed by doctors that he must take weight off of the foot for at least two weeks. . . . The 76th and apparently final entry in the Indianapolis 500 was named yesterday when Rick Miaskewicz, a rookie from Denver, was named to drive a new Cosworth-powered Lola race car. . . . Bob Knight, who coached Indiana to the N.C.A.A. basketball championship and is a part-time physical education professor, has been chosen the most popular professor on campus. . . . James Lofton, a nine-year N.F.L. veteran and former all-pro wide receiver who is facing trial in Green Bay next month on a sexual assault charge, has been traded to the Los Angeles Raiders for the Raiders' third-round draft choice in the upcoming draft and an undisclosed conditional choice in 1988, the Packers announced yesterday. . . . Ron Fraser, the baseball coach at the University of Miami, has been named head of the team that will represent the United States at the Pan American Games in Indianapolis this summer.

title: Israeli Officials Meet on Corruption Charges
description: The following dispatch was altered by Israeli military censorship.

title: Kent Taylor, 80, Dies; TV's 'Boston Blackie'
description: Kent Taylor, who portrayed the dapper, crime-stopping detective in the television series ''Boston Blackie'' in the early 1950's, died Saturday at the Motion Picture and Televison Hospital. He was 80. As ''Boston Blackie'' from 1951 to 1953, Mr. Taylor played a dashing former crook who became a detective. Blackie, his girlfriend, Mary, and dog, Whitie, were renowned for solving crimes steps ahead of the police, with the detective and Mary punctuating the show with wisecracks and light asides.

title: GTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split in January 1987. The company said results for 1986 have been restated to report operations transferred to US Sprint on the equity basis and to present segment information consistent with 1987 classifications. These changes had no effect on net income or share earnings.

title: SINKING LEADS ARMY TO CURB WATER USE OF TROOP VEHICLE
description: Prompted by a sinking a week earlier, the Army suspended amphibious operations with its Bradley Fighting Vehicle today until critical hinges on the front of the tank-like personnel carrier can be modified.

title: GAF Weighs New Bid; More Borg Data Asked
description: The GAF Corporation refused to say yesterday whether it would raise the bidding for the Borg-Warner Corporation, but it asked Borg for the same information that Merrill Lynch Capital Partners received for a bid valued at $48.50 a share.

title: Man, 77, Who Killed Ill Wife Loses One Bid for Freedom
description: A Federal magistrate today recommended denial of a petition seeking freedom for Roswell Gilbert, the 77-year-old man convicted of killing his terminally ill wife.

title: FOR BLACKS, LOCKER ROOM DOESN'T LEAD TO BOARD ROOM
description: It is easy to see, at first glance, just how far blacks have come since Jackie Robinson shattered baseball's color barrier four decades ago. The proof is on the playing fields and in the arenas.

title: AT I.B.M., A LOT HINGES ON OS/2
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation boasts that its new computers, a silicon menagerie called the Personal System/2, represent the ''second generation'' of personal computing.

title: JURISDICTIONAL ISSUE IS RAISED ON A SCHOOL MEDITATION LAW
description: The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that a 1982 New Jersey law requiring one minute of silence daily in public schools was valid, but that for procedural reasons the Court could not rule on it.

title: Mellon's Chairman Resigns
description: The troubled Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that J. David Barnes, its chairman and chief executive, had resigned.

title: NEW PRESIDENT SELECTED AT DARTMOUTH
description: James O. Freedman, a prominent legal scholar who has been president of the University of Iowa for five years, has been selected as president of Dartmouth College, the college's Board of Trustees announced yesterday.

title: BOTH STOCKS IN OIL FEUD ARE DOWN
description: The stock price of Texaco Inc. fell in very heavy trading yesterday as the large oil company tried to soothe the frazzled nerves of investors, lenders, suppliers and business partners in the wake of its bankruptcy filing on Sunday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Black Leaders Issue Call
description: Three black civic leaders have scheduled a news conference at City Hall today to discuss what they describe as an absence of black executives on both the Mets and the Yankees.

title: I.B.M. REVENUE UP 5.5%, BUT PROFIT DECLINES 23%
description: Showing more strength than many on Wall Street had expected, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported a surprising 5.5 percent rise in its first-quarter revenues, though net income dropped 23 percent.

title: Primo Levi Is Buried in Turin In a Simple Jewish Ceremony
description: Primo Levi, the writer who fell down the stairwell of his apartment on Saturday in an apparent suicide, was buried today in a simple ceremony attended by family friends and members of Italy's Jewish community.

title: PROFITS OFF AT GTE, UNITED TELECOM
description: The GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., which are the parent companies of the troubled U S Sprint Communications Company, both reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: DESKTOP PUBLISHING DEBUGGED
description: A FIRST edition still means something positive when one is dealing with books. Not so when it comes to software, particularly that for desktop publishing.

title: FOLLOWING HIS WHIMSY, SHANDLING FINDS SUCCESS
description: AMBLING along on Showtime for the past couple of seasons, ''It's Garry Shandling's Show'' has become the pay cable crowd's ''Late Night With David Letterman.'' Like NBC's Mr. Letterman, Mr. Shandling is low-keyed and kind of goofy, given to noticing the smaller absurdities of life. He is a well-meaning, rational soul buffeted by a world overdosing on silliness. Frustrated in love, stymied by business opportunities and hounded by well-meaning friends, Mr. Shandling muddles through life engagingly, his bite a good deal sharper than his wimpy bark.

title: Jacques Francois, Civilian on Haiti Junta
description: Jacques A. Francois, the civilian member of the three-man National Governing Council, died today. He was 78 years old.

title: COURT RULING MAY RESHAPE L.I. HOUSING
description: New York State's highest court, the Court of Appeals, may be drafting a decision that could bring about extraordinary changes in the way municipalities can use zoning powers, legal and planning experts say.

title: HART, STRESSING IDEALS, FORMALLY ENTERS THE 1988 RACE
description: On a wind-swept rock formation in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, Gary Hart formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, declaring that the country was falling far short of its ideals and urging the revival of a sense of national purpose.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 113, Bullets 105: Cliff Robinson scored 22 points and Maurice Cheeks added 15 points and a season-high 19 assists to help the 76ers gain the victory over the Washington in Philadelphia last night. A basket by Robinson completed an 8-0 run and gave the 76ers a 105-93 lead with 2:16 left in the game. Washington could move no closer than 7 points in the final two minutes. Jeff Malone led all scorers with 24 points.(AP) Bulls 114, Bucks 107: Michael Jordan scored 16 of his 50 points in the fourth quarter, sparking a Chicago rally in Milwaukee. It was the second straight game and seventh time this season Jordan has scored 50 points or more for the Bulls as he pulled within 37 points of the 3,000-point mark for the season. The only player in N.B.A. history to reach the 3,000-point mark in a season was Wilt Chamberlain, who did it three times.(AP) Squash Racquets Edwards Upsets Talbot: Second- seeded Ned Edwards of New York upset top-seeded Mark Talbot of Barrington, R.I., 15-13, 7-15, 15-10, 15-14, yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, to win the $25,000 1987 North American Open, the most prestigious title in hardball squash racquets. In the semifinals, Talbot defeated John Nimick of Philadelphia, 15-12, 15-10, 15-9, and Edwards defeated unseeded David Boyum of Cambridge, Mass., 16-13, 11-15, 15-9, 15-12. The match was a contrast in styles. The 29-year-old Edwards has a powerful, aggressive, offense, and the 26-year-old Talbot, who is superbly conditioned, is a master of patient retrieving and consistency.

title: The Soviet View On an Arms Pact
description: LEAD: The current discussions on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe shows promise as a basis for an accord between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: PEOPLES HERITAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Includes a net securities gain of $663,000 and $1,173,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. The bank converted to stock ownership in December 1986.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $284,000, or 13 cents a share, for the latest year and $310,000, or 15 cents a share, for the year-ago period, from utilization of net operating loss carryovers.

title: Thiokol Asks to See F.B.I. Report
description: Morton Thiokol, Inc., the rocket builder that has been sued by one of its own engineers over the Challenger space shuttle disaster, today asked to be allowed to look at a report about the company compiled in an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: EX-MILER REFLECTS ON 'BAD GUY' ROLE
description: According to Swedish track officials of his day, Gunder Haegg was a bad guy. The world's best miler was getting money under the table in a supposedly pure amateur sport.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE last five weeks of fashion openings were a perfect illustration of the herd instinct. The unanimous message for fall is short.

title: AGENT FOR MANY TOP ACTORS
description: Bruce Savan, a leading New York theatrical agent whose clients included such artists as Sam Waterston, Bernadette Peters, Vanessa Redgrave, Peter Allen and Mary Tyler Moore, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Savan, who was 59 years old, had been suffering for several months from acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: PHYSICIST AIMS TO CREATE A UNIVERSE, LITERALLY
description: PHYSICISTS often probe the workings of nature on a cosmic scale, but Prof. Alan H. Guth and his colleagues at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology may have set themselves the ultimate research goal. They are seeking a mechanism by which humans might create a new universe from scratch.

title: SHULTZ VISITS EMBASSY SEDER FOR NOTED SOVIET DISSIDENTS
description: In even the most tranquil times, the first night of Passover is full of turbulent emotions for the Jews who have been trying to emigrate from the Soviet Union. The words ''next year in Jerusalem,'' pronounced during the traditional seder, have both a hopeful and a hollow sound.

title: Conviction of 2 Supremacists
description: Two former White Patriot Party members were convicted today of conspiring to buy stolen military weapons for a series of robberies and assassinations, while a third was acquitted.

title: THE METHOD, STILL DISPUTED BUT NOW UBIQUITOUS
description: Forty years after the founding of the Actors Studio - and after years of controversy - the Method has become an accepted and, many would argue, a necessary instrument for the actor, whether or not he is appearing in a naturalistic play. In the 1940's and 1950's, the Method was the predominant influence on American acting, and then went through a period of eclipse as other acting techniques flourished. Today, the Method would once again seem to be back in vogue.

title: AT MACY'S, ALL IS ABLOOM
description: The woods have come to Herald Square: to Macy's, to be precise. The store's 13th annual flower show began its weeklong run Sunday, with rustic fences and all manner of greens and blossoms decorating the windows and spilling over showcases throughout the main floor.

title: A SURGE IN U.S. TRAVEL TO EUROPE IS EXPECTED DESPITE DOLLAR'S DROP
description: Fears of terrorism caused John and Mildred McLaughlin of Clark, N.J., to cancel their trip to Italy and France last year.

title: General Dynamics Signs NASA Deal
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has signed an agreement with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for authority to use NASA facilities to launch payloads into space. Two other companies, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation, are negotiating similar deals, and claim a greater need because they have signed contracts to orbit satellites.

title: Raises - for Some - at City Hall
description: A blue-ribbon mayoral commission rightly concludes that most of New York City's elected officials deserve a pay raise. It wrongly puts members of the City Council on the list.

title: LASER LESSENS THE TRAUMA OF SURGERY IN UTERUS
description: LASER surgery, which has revolutionized the treatment of several sight-threatening eye disorders, now promises to do the same for many common gynecological problems, including one - abnormally heavy uterine bleeding -that is usually treated by hysterectomy.

title: ONE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,259,000 and $239,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. The company said that results for both periods include the operations of the Bank of Hartford, acquired Feb. 23.

title: PENNZOIL'S CHANCES UNCLEAR
description: Not many people ever have the chance to accept a peace offering of $2 billion from an embittered, implacable foe - let alone turn such a deal down.

title: AIDE'S RESIGNATION CREATES POLITICAL CRISIS FOR GANDHI
description: The forced resignation of the Indian Defense Minister over the weekend has created a crisis for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and underscored divisions in the governing Congress Party.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Underground Drama

title: MIZE'S CHIP SHOT BRIGHTENS FUTURE
description: When Larry Mize chipped his golf ball into the cup from 140 feet away on the second playoff hole Sunday to beat Greg Norman of Australia and win the Masters, the future suddenly seemed very bright for the 28-year-old, whose past had been clouded with near misses.

title: ADMIRERS TOAST THE ART OF THOMAS HART BENTON
description: If Thomas Hart Benton had been around -and there were those who thought maybe he was - the turnout Sunday night at a celebration of his 98th birthday would have been enough to soothe his wounded and probably volubly angry spirit.

title: TALE OF 2 EMBASSIES: IRONIES ABOUND
description: Shortly after the first American ambassador arrived in Moscow in 1933, Stalin asked him over dinner whether there was anything he could do for him. Yes, the envoy, William C. Bullitt, replied, he would like ''that lovely bluff overlooking the Moscow River'' for an embassy site.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company's gross income is listed as revenue. The company estimated that the lower value of the dollar, compared with 1986 rates, improved first quarter 1987 net earnings by $95 million.

title: QADDAFI IS FACING UNHAPPY COUNTRY
description: A year after the American raid on Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have taken more power into his own hands but faces a nation unhappy with his costly defeat in Chad and economic chaos at home, according to diplomats here.

title: RECITAL: CHRISTA LUDWIG
description: NOTHING quite satisfies in the same way as a program of German song offered by artists of true understanding and skill to a knowledgeable and receptive audience. There was no question about the audience Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall: In ''Lob des hohen Verstandes,'' Christa Ludwig made the gentlest of double-entendres out of the German word for ''wait,'' addressing it both to the contestants in the song and, sort of, to James Levine at the piano. There was no translation - this was an encore - but a ripple of appreciation ran through the hall. Lots of people who knew the repertory were there. And naturally enough, since no one does the repertory more naturally and satisfyingly than Miss Ludwig.

title: Human Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'BLACK MARIA,' A PLAY OF FILM
description: ENTERING La Mama Annex, rearranged to accommodate John Jesurun's ''Black Maria,'' one immediately wonders where the stage is. The seats are facing in all directions and fill the floor space. The fact is there is no stage. With ''Black Maria,'' Mr. Jesurun has moved a step beyond ''Deep Sleep'' and ''White Water,'' the previous plays in his theater-movies-television cycle. This time, the audience is surrounded by movie screens, four of them as walls and one as ceiling. There are no live actors; the ''play'' is entirely on film.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
THREAT TO TENANTS' SUBSIDIES STIRS CONCERN OF U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Officials around the nation are concerned that over the next decade more than half a million low- and moderate-income families may be ousted from federally subsidized apartments built in the 1960's and 1970's. Hundreds of families already have lost their homes and the numbers are likely to increase rapidly.

title: AMY CARTER TELLS COURT SHE SAT IN ROAD TO ALTER C.I.A. POLICY
description: Amy Carter testified today that she climbed up a fire escape and through a window into a college administration building, and later sat down to block a bus carrying arrested protesters, because she thought it would help end illegal activities in Central America by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax losses of $150,000 for the latest 9 months and $2,018,600 for the year-ago period, both on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Woodward & Lothrop Names New President
description: Tom L. Roach, a well-known retail executive, was named yesterday as president of Woodward & Lothrop, which operates two major department store chains - Woodward & Lothrop in Washington and John Wanamaker in Philadelphia.

title: RAILROAD SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Puerto Rico Floods Kill Man
description: Up to six inches of rain fell in eastern and northern Puerto Rico on Sunday, causing flash floods that killed a 45-year-old man, civil defense officials reported. The officials said the man's body was recovered after his car was carried away by floodwaters as he tried to cross a bridge in Guaynabo.

title: Market Place; Canada Stocks Outpace Dow
description: AFTER being dormant throughout 1986, Canada's stock markets not only sprang to life this year but, as measured by the popular averages, have also been outpacing the spectacular gains posted on the American equities exchanges.

title: L.I. SCIENTISTS DISCOVER ORIGINS OF 'BROWN TIDE'
description: As Elizabeth M. Cosper changed lenses on a microscope and focused it, she cautioned a visitor to the Marine Sciences Research Center here not to expect too much.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $6.7 million from a reserve taken to cover the anticipated costs of closing the company's overseas operations and an overseas operating loss of $400,000. c-Net loss

title: U.S. RELIEVES AIDE WHO RAN DRUG TESTS IN AMTRAK CRASH
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, which is investigating reports of irregularities at its drug and alcohol testing unit in Oklahoma City, has relieved the unit supervisor pending the outcome of the investigation, agency employees familiar with the situation said today.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $4,086,000 and $3,293,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (UPPER EAST TENNESSEE)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted to stock from mutual organization in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: DEEP-POCKETED DEAL MAKERS
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation last Friday acted like any other company under siege by an unwanted suitor: It turned to a major investment bank for help, in this case Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $165,000 and interest income of $951,000. c-Net income

title: Boeing-707 Cargo Jet Crashes, Killing Three
description: A Boeing-707 cargo jet crashed in light fog tonight as it was preparing to land at Kansas City International Airport, killing three people aboard the plane, the authorities said.

title: RULING COULD CURTAIL HIRING MORE WOMEN IN FIRE DEPARTMENT
description: A recent Federal appeals court decision has weakened the impact of a landmark 1982 ruling that led to the hiring of the first women in the New York City Fire Department, making it unlikely more women will be hired, according to legal experts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dataproducts Corp., Woodland Hills, Calif., appointed Robert W. Kilcullen as senior vice president of its line printer business.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNION WARREN SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
EVIDENCE OF SEXUAL ABUSE
description: IN young children, genital or rectal infection with the microbes Chlamydia trachomatis provides strong evidence that they have been sexually abused, doctors have concluded after a study.

title: No Action by Bosworth
description: Brian Bosworth, the Oklahoma linebacker, did not make contact with the National Football League by yesterday's deadline and thus is ineligible for the April 28 draft. Joel Bussert, director of player personnel for the N.F.L., said Bosworth had not submitted the required written statement saying he wished to be included in the regular draft. Bosworth may now choose to enter a supplemental draft to be held later this year, or he can return to Oklahoma where he has one year of eligibility remaining. Barry Switzer, the Oklahoma coach, has said Bosworth would not be back, and the linebacker has not taken part in spring drills.

title: TERRORIST GROUP REPORTED IN INDIA
description: Indian and American authorities have tightened security at airports and at the United States Embassy after receiving reports that members of a Middle Eastern terrorist group entered India last month.

title: Allied to Sell Dillard 31 Stores in South
description: Dillard Department Stores Inc. has reached a definitive agreement with the Allied Stores Corporation to buy the 27 Joske's department stores in Texas and Arizona and the four Cain-Sloan stores in Nashville, for $255 million in cash, the companies said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 14, 1987
description: COMPANIES Texaco's stock price fell in very heavy trading as the large oil company moved to reassure the business community in the wake of its bankruptcy filing. Texaco stock was the day's most-active issue, dropping $3.375, to $28.50, on volume of 12.6 million shares, and Texaco bonds fell in lighter trading. Meanwhile, the shares of its rival, Pennzoil, plunged $15.25, to $77, amid uncertainty about how much the company might eventually collect from its high-stakes legal battle with Texaco. [ Page D1. ] Pennzoil's rejection of a $2 billion settlement with Texaco was probably a historic gamble, and many analysts feel it has lost an important bargaining chip. [ D1. ] Pennzoil is unlikely to succeed if it tries to challenge Texaco's bankruptcy filing, lawyers and bankruptcy experts said. [ D5. ] I.B.M. reported a surprising rise in first-quarter revenues, though net income dropped 23 percent, to $785 million. The results were far better than most analysts had predicted, and I.B.M. stock surged $2.625, to $147.625, amid hopes that a flood of new products later this year will pull I.B.M. out of a two-year slump. [ D1. ] The head of the troubled Mellon Bank resigned. There were indications that J. David Barnes, chairman and chief executive, had been forced out, and analysts speculated that the move was largely at the urging of the Mellon family. [ D1. ] Merrill Lynch's earnings increased 25 percent, and revenues grew similarly. Merrill, the first brokerage house to report results of a buoyant first quarter, was hurt by rising costs but helped by the new tax law. [ D23. ] Chemical and Irving Trust reported lower earnings, citing the change in the status of their Brazilian loans. While Wells Fargo also put its Brazilian loans on a cash basis, it reported higher earnings, helped by its Crocker acquisition. [ D22. ] Wedtech sued two big accounting firms, charging that they had failed to disclose ''pervasive fraud'' by Wedtech's former management. The suits seek $70 million in damages from KMG Main Hurdman and $35 million from Touche Ross. [ B1. ] GAF requested additional data from Borg-Warner, whose stock price rose above the offer, totaling $4.23 billion, from Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. [ D8. ] A $242 million loss at U S Sprint hurt earnings at its two parent companies, GTE and United Telecommunications. [ D23. ] Two possible bidders for Dome Petroleum have emerged. Analysts believe Royal Dutch/Shell Group and British Petroleum are interested in the assets of Canada's troubled oil giant. [ D10. ] Dillard agreed to buy 31 stores in Texas, Arizona and Tennessee from Allied Stores for $255 million. [ D5. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 51.71 points as a wave of selling battered a stock market already reeling from a weaker dollar, fears of inflation and a sharp rise in interest rates. Reflecting the market's recent volatility, the Dow lost 2.2 percent of its value, falling to 2,287.07, for its fourth-largest point drop ever and the biggest since it fell 57.39 points on March 30. [ D1. ] Prices of notes and bonds dropped sharply, hurt by heavy selling of mortgage-backed securities and fears that the Fed was tacitly encouraging higher short-term rates by failing to counteract higher overnight rates. [ D23. ] The dollar dropped again against most major currencies as traders awaited a report due today on the U.S. trade deficit. In New York, gold rose $4.25, to $436.75. [ D24. ] Energy futures advanced amid late buying by traders who had sold short. Oil was under pressure because of reports that OPEC members were exceeding their production quotas. [ D24. ] THE ECONOMY Tariffs against some Japan electronic products will almost certainly go into effect on Friday, according to senior White House officials. They predicted that the action would lead to a ''difficult'' trade situation with Japan. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Blue Cross/Blue Shield is feuding with local hospitals in several areas. As both sides expand beyond their historic roles, cooperation is giving way to competition. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Canada's stock market has surged after a dormant 1986, with gains outpacing those on American equities exchanges. Experts attributed the gains to a stronger Canadian dollar and to demand for precious metals and forest products. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: Bankrupt: Texaco, and Texas Justice
description: If it were a movie, only George Lucas would dare direct: Texaco, America's eighth-largest industrial corporation, is threatened with ruin by the largest legal damage judgment ever awarded. Only bankruptcy, the biggest bankruptcy proceeding ever, can save it.

title: ARCHITECTURE: NEW LLOYD'S IN THE CITY OF LONDON
description: The City of London is a dense web of classicism, a tightly knit mass of low, masonry buildings that in its intricacy feels something like Venice with automobiles. Although plenty of new architecture has come to this old part of London in recent years, no building has arrived with the hoopla that has surrounded the new headquarters for Lloyd's of London, the insurance marketplace. The 12-story Lloyd's building on the corner of Leadenhall and Lime Streets designed by Richard Rogers, who with Renzo Piano designed the Beaubourg Center in Paris, would seem at first glance as unsuitable to the City as any work of architecture could be. Where most of the buildings in the City are of masonry, Lloyd's is of glass and metal. Where most of the buildings are lavish in their use of traditional ornament and decoration, Lloyd's is a high-tech extravaganza, a sleek array of pipes and pods and frames and towers and tubes. Since the building began construction in 1981, it has been called everything from an Erector set to an oil rig.

title: RANDOLPH REFLECTS, BASKS IN SPECIAL DAY
description: A cool, damp day in early April could not diminish the warmth Willie Randolph feels on these occasions. After 12 years, he said that the first home game of the season is still preceded by a restless night before, the anticipation building for the annual reunion of a ballplayer and the fans.

title: Workers Start Strike At Queens Cemetery
description: Cemetery workers went on strike yesterday at Flushing Cemetery in Queens, one of nine nonsectarian cemeteries involved in negotiations with the gravediggers' union, the president of the union said.

title: Insider Suit Is Dismissed
description: The FMC Corporation's lawsuit for damages against three Wall Street firms and four figures involved in insider-trading scandals was dismissed in a United States District Court in Chicago yesterday. The Chicago-based company had sought $260 million from Ivan F. Boesky; Goldman, Sachs; Shearson Lehman/American Express; Drexel Burnham Lambert, and three investment bankers employed at those firms in 1985: Ira B. Sokolow, Dennis B. Levine and David S. Brown.

title: RETREAT IS SEEN BY SOUTH AFRICA ON PROTEST BAN
description: The Government appeared to retreat somewhat today from a complete ban on protests against detention without trial, saying that it would not apply to religious services.

title: NEW FOSSIL IS FORCING FAMILY TREE REVISIONS
description: WHEN the discovery of the provocative ''black skull'' was announced last summer, the small, contentious fraternity of paleoanthropology was stunned into a rare state of unanimity. Everyone agreed that the skull was the most significant early humanlike fossil to be found in more than a decade. Everyone agreed it would necessitate a major rethinking of the human family tree.

title: PASSENGER COMPLAINTS ABOUT AIRLINES UP SHARPLY FROM '86
description: Consumer complaints about the nation's airlines nearly doubled in March from the same month a year ago and increased by 52 percent in the first three months of 1987, according to figures made public by the United States Department of Transportation.

title: CITY LANDMARK DESIGNATIONS SLOWED
description: The pace of landmark designation in New York City has slowed considerably since Gene A. Norman assumed chairmanship of the Landmarks Preservation Commission in July 1983, a new study shows.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Does beer have any nutritional value? A.Beer made from barley malts, rice or corn contains small amounts of protein, minerals and vitamins, according to Dr. Joseph Owades, director of the Center for Brewing Studies, a beer research concern in San Francisco. Barley malts provide beer with protein, minerals and vitamins, while corn and rice impart carbohydrates, Dr. Owades said. One 12-ounce bottle of beer contains one gram of protein, or 2 percent of the recommended daily allowance. It also contains between 1 and 2 percent of the recommended daily allowance of B vitamins, the same amount found in a slice of bread. In addition, beer contains trace amounts of calcium, magnesium, phosphate and potassium. Dr. Owades noted, however, that alcoholic beverages should not serve as substitutes for foods in the four basic food groups. Q. How can scientists distinguish between air pollution that is man-made and that which occurs naturally? A.Scientists use radiocarbon dating techniques to determine whether airborne contaminants, which cause such environmental pollution as urban smog, come from naturally occurring sources, such as vegetative emissions, or from fossil fuel emissions that are produced by cars, power plants and factories. The technique is similar to that used by archeologists to determine the age of artifacts. Scientists collect particle samples on glass fiber filters and combust these particles to measure the amount of carbon 14 they contain. They can distinguish between naturally occurring contaminants and those produced by humans because fossil fuels such as coal and petroleum contain no living carbon 14.

title: Foes of Regime Are Reported To Be Detained in Paraguay
description: Police arrested seven opposition politicians for meeting without prior permission less than a week after a 40-year-old state of siege was lifted in the Paraguayan capital, an opposition leader said today.

title: Regents Can Guarantee Scholarship Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA ACTS TO BAR DEDUCTIONS FOR EXPENSES AT EXCLUSIVE CLUBS
description: State officials have acted to end tax deductions for membership costs in private clubs and, in a separate move, have held that the state has legal authority to revoke the liquor licenses of such groups.

title: Business and Health; Blue Cross Vs. Hospitals
description: IN several places in the country, Blue Cross/Blue Shield is bickering with local hospitals. The traditionally friendly relationship between the nation's largest insurer and the hospitals has been breaking down as both sides have expanded beyond their historic roles - and, in some areas, have begun to be competitors.

title: ALLWASTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Marriott Plans to Test Economy-Lodging Idea
description: The Marriott Corporation is going to test the concept of economy lodging with a chain called Fairfield Inns. Eight facilities are now being built in Detroit, Atlanta and Birmingham, Ala.

title: KOCH SAYS CITY IS READY TO RUN CONCRETE PLANT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City was prepared to take over a private concrete plant that it had helped establish in an effort to force down prices charged by other concrete suppliers.

title: SHULTZ, IN SOVIET, PRESSES FOR PACT ON MID-RANGE ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met today with the Soviet Foreign Minister for more than seven hours in an effort to prepare the way for a treaty curbing medium-range missiles.

title: Building of Ark Allowed to Continue
description: A Superior Court judge ruled yesterday that Kea Tawana can keep working on the 125-ton ark she has been building for five years in Newark's Central Ward.

title: PALESTINIAN KILLED BY ISRAELI TROOPS
description: Israeli troops shot dead a Palestinian student and wounded at least three others today when West Bank youths took to the streets to protest the arrest by Israel of nine Palestinians.

title: BANKING CENTER reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company converted to stock form on Aug. 13, 1986.

title: IN RICE FIELDS OF ITALY, THE WATERS ARE TROUBLED
description: In the next few days, when spring sunshine has warmed the brown plowed floodlands in this area 20 miles south of Milan, immense sluices will be opened permitting waters that flow down from northern Italian lakes to inundate thousands of acres of the oldest and richest rice fields outside the Orient.

title: MORE INMATES SEEN UNDER NEW RULES
description: The number of inmates in Federal prisons would rise substantially under a new set of sentencing guidelines issued today by a Congressionally created commission.

title: COOPERATION VS. COMPETITION
description: Scientists often say that as much as they learn from highly technical presentations at meetings, they learn even more about trends in their field from discussions in hallways and over meals and cocktails. A scientific conference here last week was no exception.

title: EUROPES ANTI-TERRORISM TIED TO U.S. LIBYA RAIDS
description: The American raids against Libya that a year ago stirred widespread protests are today widely acknowledged to have galvanized Western European countries to intensify their own anti-terrorist efforts and to coordinate police operations across borders.

title: HIGH HOPES FOR ENDANGERED FERRET
description: AS the annual breeding season nears its end, only one pair of the 18 black-footed ferrets in captivity here has mated and it is too early to tell if the mating was successful. Still, scientists were heartened by it because it indicates that at least one of the males in captivity is active and fertile, according to Tom Thorne, a wildlife research veterinarian here.

title: State Senate Vote Near On Florida Ad Tax Bill
description: Tallahassee, the eyes of advertising are upon you!

title: NET FALLS AT CHEMICAL, IRVING
description: Three large banking companies yesterday reported lower first-quarter earnings that reflected the negative impact of Brazil's suspension of interest payments.

title: Homes, Jobs and Schools Make Cool Summers
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIALS TRY TO PREPARE FOR NEW IMMIGRATION LAW
description: Less than a month before the sweeping new Federal Immigration Law takes effect, officials are scrambling to prepare for the estimated 750,000 illegal aliens in the New York metropolitan region who are expected to seek to legalize their status.

title: CUBS AN INNING SHY OF NO-HIT GAME
description: Jamie Moyer, making only his 18th major league appearance, pitched a no-hitter through eight innings as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-2, tonight.

title: OFTEN AMBIGUOUS ON LATIN TRIP, JOHN PAUL UTTERED TWO WORDS THAT MEANT VOLUMES
description: Pope John Paul II is a professed believer in the power of signs, and that faith was never more apparent than on his two-week visit to South America, which ended today.

title: Kristiansen Plays Beat the Clock
description: In the last 20 years, while the men's world-best time in the marathon has been improved by less than two and a half minutes, the women's has dropped by more than three quarters of an hour. Now a milestone in the women's steady gains may be at hand. Ingrid Kristiansen, preparing for the London Marathon next month, is taking dead aim at what was once considered an unattainable quest: a time under 2 hours 20 minutes.

title: Bridge: An Experienced Team Wins Final Title at L.I. Regionals
description: The Long Island Regional Championships ended at Hofstra University on Sunday, and the most experienced group in a large field collected the final title.

title: PANEL THAT SET SMOKING CURBS IS DENIED FUNDS
description: New York lawmakers have denied the State Health Department $300,000 to enforce strict new smoking regulations because they believe the rules were adopted illegally by the state's Public Health Council, State Senate aides said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about national service by youth misidentified Paul McCloskey of California. He is a former Representative.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS WANT TOP-LEVEL DRUG FIGHTER
description: Senate Democrats are quarreling with the Reagan Administration again over the creating a Cabinet-level post for the direction and coordination of Federal efforts to combat illegal drugs.

title: U.S. ENTERS CASE OF JULIAN BOND
description: Federal agencies are investigating cocaine abuse allegations against former State Senator Julian Bond and other prominent Atlanta residents, a Federal prosecutor said today.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1985 quarter and year are restated as a result of the pooling of interests of Mid-Continent Life Insurance Co. in December 1986.

title: British Television to Get Ads for U.S. Tourism
description: The United States will be promoting tourism on TV in Britain for the first time beginning April 24.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-Includes a charge of $850,000 for re-evaluation of inventories for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and after extraordinary tax credits of $268,000 for the quarter and $690,000 for the 9 months.

title: Evidence of Corrosion
description: Using an extremely sensitive magnetometer, researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have detected the very weak magnetic fields generated by some forms of corrosion.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Abstain Was All He Said
description: To stop the spread of AIDS, President Reagan advises virginity unto the marriage altar and monogamy ever after. That would probably do it, all right, but the President has yet to follow through with advice on how to bring back those two old lifesavers.

title: EX-M.T.A. CHIEF AND OTHERS ACCUSED OF FRAUD IN A SUIT
description: Harold L. Fisher, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who has long been active in city and state Democratic affairs, and 17 other people have been accused in a civil lawsuit of defrauding two defunct Long Island insurance companies of $16.4 million.

title: Partners Reduce Stake in Gencorp
description: General Partners, an investment group consisting of Wagner & Brown and AFG Industries, has sold all but a tiny fraction of its 8.6 percent stake in Gencorp Inc. Last week the investors terminated their $100-a-share, or $2.2 billion, hostile takeover bid after Gencorp announced that it would pay $130 a share for 54 percent of its stock.

title: FROM 3 AMERICANS, CLOTHES TO FIT CONTEMPORARY LIFE
description: What makes clothes modern?

title: TEACHING AS 2D CAREER: TAPPING THE SCIENTISTS
description: RETIRED scientists, engineers and technically trained military personnel could combat the shortage of mathematics and science teachers and many are ready to do so, according to a new study by the National Executive Service Corps.

title: Name-Droppers
description: Whenever they take to the court, the field or the mats against such rivals as the Ludlow Lions and the Westfield Bombers, teams from Agawam (Mass.) High School are at a pronounced disadvantage.

title: William Stoneman, 83; Foreign Correspondent
description: William H. Stoneman, former chief European correspondent for the Chicago Daily News, died Saturday in Paris. He was 83 years old and lived in a suburb of Paris since his retirement in 1969.

title: Officer Gets Award
description: The State Department has presented its 1986 award for Security Engineering Officer of the Year to Frederick K. Crosher, for supervising technical aspects of the $190 million office building intended to serve as the new United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: U.S. TARIFFS AGAINST JAPAN EXPECTED
description: Senior White House officials said today that President Reagan was virtually certain to issue a proclamation Friday that doubles the import prices of some Japanese electronic products and predicted that the action would lead to a ''difficult'' trade situation with Japan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, APRIL 14, 1987
description: International A2-15

title: Ex-Guinness Head's Denial
description: The former head of Guinness P.L.C. today denied allegations that he had ordered files, appointment diaries and correspondence shredded in December after the Department of Trade began investigating the company.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment tax credits of $900,000 for the latest quarter and $3.1 million for the year-earlier period. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FAS 87 on employer's accounting for pension.

title: Data General Executive Joins MIPS Computer
description: When Robert C. Miller joined the Data General Corporation as a high-level executive six years ago, the company retained an image as an industry maverick, producing innovative computers for engineers who were willing to create their own software.

title: Memorials to the Poet Heine Have Been Dogged by Difficulties
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,097,000 for department closing. The company said that due to the acquisition of Brooks Drug last September and the company's change of fiscal year, prior year results are not comparable. The company said for the eight months ended Dec. 31, 1985, it had a loss of $107,000 on revenue of $24,164,000.

title: Promoting Sun-Ray Defense
description: AFTER the kind of beauteous weekend that New Yorkers just reveled in, the time would seem right to discuss one new development in the sun-lotion arena - now that the sun is no longer considered everybody's friend.

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split on May 16, 1986. The company said the substantial increase in its effective tax rate (applicable in 1987 only) to 44.5 percent from 39.5 percent in 1986, reduced after-tax earnings by $7.4 million, equal to an additional 7 cents a share. The company also said other operations, including Financial Services and Insurance, contributed first quarter earnings of $1,625,000, compared with $228,000 in the year-ago first quarter. Amounts for the 1986 period include Life Insurance operations which were sold during the second half of 1986.

title: ADVANCES POSE OBSTACLE TO ATOM SMASHER PLAN
description: AN awkward and unexpected obstacle to the Government's proposed $4 billion supercollider, a giant particle accelerator meant to extend the experimental reach of modern high-energy physics, has emerged from a recent series of scientific breakthroughs.

title: NEWORLD BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company said that income before income taxes increased by 89 percent over the year-ago quarter; however, increase in net was limited to 12 percent due to the absence of tax benefits relating to tax credits. In the first quarter of 1986, these benefits amounted to $842,000, or 19 cents a share.

title: GENETICS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
6 STATES IN NORTHEAST TO SUE U.S. OVER ACID RAIN
description: Six Northeastern states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said today that they would sue the Federal Government to force it to curb the air pollution that causes acid rain.

title: Yanks, Loud and Clear
description: The Yankees were all geared up for their home opener yesterday. The loudspeakers were turned on high. Ba-boom! The organ was filled with high-test. Dum-dum-dum-dum! And the tapes were tastefully selected. Whoop-whoop!

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3,289,000 from Federal Home Loan Bank Board prepayment penalties. The company said the gains on the sale of mortgage-backed securities amounted to 22 cents a share during the latest first quarter, compared with 42 cents a share realized during the year-ago period. The company said because of the differences in the timing of the phase- in of changes to various partss of the federal tax law, its tax rate rose during the first quarter. Although the tax rate is temporary, it effectively lowered first quarter earnings by 8 cents a share.

title: KEY RATES
Mantle Is Hospitalized
description: Mickey Mantle was in fair condition today after being hospitalized for chest pains, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: ISLANDERS RELISH BEING IN A CORNER
description: The night before had verged on being ugly. There was the 4-1 loss to the Capitals in a game full of penalties. And at the end, the ice was littered with crumpled cups hurled by irate fans who didn't like the notion of their team's limping off to Washington to face elimination.

title: Who Do You Think Started This Chip War?
description: To the Editor:

title: AIRLEASE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The limited partnership was organized last June.

title: UAL Said to Study Pilot Buyout Plan
description: Directors of UAL Inc. were reported to have met in Chicago yesterday to consider a $4.5 billion United Airlines buyout proposal offered by its 7,000-member pilot union. The company refused to confirm or deny that meetings were under way. In Cleveland and Denver, meanwhile, union leaders met with employees in the first of several sessions to explain the plan, which the company is believed to oppose. Union officials will be in Chicago and Seattle today; New York, Washington and San Francisco tomorrow, and Los Angeles and Miami on Thursday.

title: COAST R V INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sosnoff Raises Bid For Caesars World
description: The New York investor Martin T. Sosnoff, as expected, sweetened his unsolicited takeover bid for Caesars World Inc., raising his offer by 14 percent, to $32 a share. In a communication to Caesars' chairman, Henry Gluck, Mr. Sosnoff said that shareholders ''will be best served by our entering immediately into good-faith, friendly negotiations.'' Caesars' stock closed up 25 cents today, at $32.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jackson Stirred
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, an undeclared contender for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, has fired off a testy letter to Impac '88, a group of major party fund-raisers.

title: DANCE: DINIZULU TROUPE
description: DINIZULU and His African Dancers, Drummers and Singers have always known how to put on a good show. But a performance by the company on Sunday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church suggested that their dance and music grows even richer and more impressive with passing time. This was theater that gracefully taught one about history and world cultures, with commentary provided throughout the evening by Amadoma Bediako, the program's narrator and a compelling storyteller. Ms. Bediako's comments also stressed the importance of respecting and honoring the inherent dignity and joy of those cultures and recognizing the part they play in our own lives. But this was also fascinating and vibrant dance.

title: ABC MAY TRANSFER SALINGER
description: ABC News, trying to cut costs in its overseas operations, plans to cut its Paris bureau staff of 25 people by more than half and may transfer its chief European correspondent, Pierre Salinger, out of Paris, according to network officials.

title: Bo Jackson's Big Hits
description: Just 17 months after capping a brilliant college football career at Auburn, in which he rushed for more than 4,000 yards and won the Heisman Trophy, Bo Jackson is turning in some outstanding statistics in major league baseball. The Royals started the tailback-turned-outfielder in left field this season. After the first six games, he was hitting .417 with an on- base percentage of .714 going 8 for 12 against the Yankees Saturday with a home run, five runs batted in and that opposite-field double.

title: Hispanic Employees Are Sought by State
description: A drive to recruit Hispanic college students for mid-level Civil Service jobs in New York State government will begin in the late spring, the executive director of Governor Cuomo's Office for Hispanic Affairs said yesterday.

title: CONGRESS ALARMED OVER WEAPONS-TESTING PLAN
description: A Pentagon plan to reorganize the offices that supervise tests of weapons has alarmed members of Congress who fear that the realism of the tests and the independence of the testers might be compromised.

title: SEOUL'S DECISION PUTS U.S. IN QUANDARY
description: The abrupt cancellation by President Chun Doo Hwan of a political discussion with the South Korean opposition has created a quandary for United States policy makers, according to officials.

title: To Destroy a Country
description: For four months now a prominent black South African editor, Zwelakhe Sisulu, has been held alone in a cell in Sandton, near Johannesburg. The state has not charged him with any crime or told him why he is being detained. There is no way of knowing when or whether he may be released.

title: Fossil Shows Anteaters Lived In Mexico
description: A fossil found by amateur rock collectors provides evidence that anteaters moved from South America to Mexico after the isthmus of Panama rose from the sea about 3 million years ago, scientists reported last week.

title: Learn From Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Landmarks and Anti-Landmarks
description: Every heaven may have its unpleasant alternative, every yin its yang - and every landmark its opposite number, more gross than graceful. Consider the Helmsley Building, the former New York Central Building, at 46th Street and Park Avenue.

title: BANKRUPTCY FILING CALLED HARD TO OVERTHROW
description: The Pennzoil Company is unlikely to succeed if it tries to challenge Texaco Inc.'s filing under the Federal Bankruptcy Code, lawyers and bankruptcy experts said yesterday.

title: Spencer-Chase Suit Over Bankruptcy
description: The Spencer Companies, a footwear and apparel company based in Boston, said it had filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Massachusetts against two units of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, seeking damages it estimated at more than $100 million. Spencer said that Chase Manhattan Bank and Chase National Services Inc. had forced the company's Chapter 11 filing last November.

title: NO SIGN OF SLOWING DOWN AS JET ENGINE MARKS 50TH
description: Just 50 years ago, on April 12, 1937, a device so common today that it is taken for granted roared to life for the first time in a laboratory in Rugby, England, and, although it was not known at the time, a new age in aviation had begun. The jet engine had worked.

title: U.N.L.V. Player Killed
description: A Nevada-Las Vegas football player was shot to death during a drug deal in Fresno, Calif., the police said yesterday. Andre Dwayne Horn, 21 years old, was shot during a dispute Sunday night, then staggered two blocks where his assailants caught up with him and shot him again, the police said. No arrests were reported. Horn was a linebacker for U.N.L.V. in 1985. He sat out last season but was expected to play for the Rebels again in 1987.

title: The '88 Non-Campaign in Korea
description: President Chun Doo Hwan has radically simplified South Korea's political choices. For a time, it looked as though the issue was how much democracy he would allow to succeed him. Now the contest seems to be between him and democracy - and he is winning. By suspending national debate over how to choose his successor, he contradicts the spirit, if not the letter, of his own promises.

title: Convergent Loss
description: Convergent Technologies, a computer manufacturer based in San Jose, Calif., said it expected results for the quarter ended March 31 to show a loss of more than twice the $4.8 million reported in the fourth quarter of 1986. The company predicted declines in both operating groups: its traditional business of supplying computers under other company names, and its business systems group of companies, which supply specialized computer systems to business users. Convergent said the anticipated loss reflected lower-than-expected operating margins, new product start-up costs and higher expenses than planned. The business systems unit also reported a loss, because of lower revenues in the quarter.

title: A PERVERSE CREATION OF SCIENCE: ANTI-RUBBER
description: ONE of nature's most familiar laws - when you stretch a substance, it shall get thinner; when you squeeze a substance, it shall bulge - has succumbed to the perverse inventiveness of science.

title: MERRILL LYNCH EXPANDS NET 25% IN BUSY QUARTER
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported a 25 percent increase in its first-quarter net income, helped by the new tax law and higher earnings from interest on margin accounts.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
SANDWICH TREATS
description: LEAD: THERE is heart between the bread, a spirit, a challenge to make something delicious from the yawning void of a sandwich-to-be.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL'S MEMO TO CUOMO ON ETHICS BILL
description: Following is Attorney General Robert Abrams's memorandum to Governor Cuomo outlining objections to the State Legislature's bill to curb ethical abuses in government:

title: BOND DENIES WIFE'S INITIAL STORY AND SAYS HE NEVER USED COCAINE
description: In his first public response to reports that his estranged wife had told the police he was a cocaine abuser, former State Senator Julian Bond categorically denied today that he has ever taken the drug or committed any crime.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 113, Nets 95: Ron Harper scored 21 points, and Cleveland held New Jersey to 4 points in the first 6 minutes 20 seconds of the fourth quarter last night in Richfield, Ohio. The Cavaliers shot 66 percent in the first half as John Williams, who finished with 20 points, scored 15 and Harper 14. Orlando Woolridge and Buck Williams each scored 22 for the Nets.(AP) Nuggets 142, Blazers 114: Alex English scored 30 points and Lafayette Lever added 26 as Denver clinched the final Western Conference playoff berth. English became the 16th-leading career scorer in league history late in the first half. English has scored 19,199 career points to surpass Gail Goodrich. (AP) Tennis Lendl Defeats Matuszewski: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, playing his first tournament in five weeks after surgery on his knee, beat an American, Richard Matuszewski, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the second round of the $605,000 Japan Open tournament in Tokyo. After a first-round bye, Lendl, the world's No. 1 player, broke Matuszewski's serve in the ninth game of the first set on errors by the American, who is ranked 92d. In the second set, a service break in the ninth game proved decisive. Lendl won the sixth, eighth and ninth games without losing a point in the 82-minute match.(AP) Horse Racing Tempt Sec Wins at Aqueduct: Tempt Sec, coupled in the wagering with Sting-Em as the second choice in the field of seven, held strong in the drive yesterday to win the feature race at Aqueduct by a neck. Amour de Fleuve was runner-up, three-quarters of a length ahead of Getreadyfortheshow. Tempt Sec, ridden by Walter Guerra, carried 109 pounds and covered seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:23 1/5. Tempt Sec earned $17,400 for the victory and returned $5.80 to win. (AP)

title: Ambassador Perkins's Prayer
description: It's finally possible - how long has it been? -for Americans to take pride in some Reagan Administration conduct in South Africa. Washington has rightly and promptly condemned the Pretoria Government's sweeping new rules barring protests against mass detentions without trial. Better still, Edward Perkins, America's new Ambassador and a black, made a point of participating in an ecumenical service in Cape Town that offered defiant prayers for the detained.

title: Real Estate; Downtown Revival in Jersey
description: LIKE lots of other older towns, Hackensack, N.J, saw its downtown wither in the 1960's as suburban shopping centers siphoned off many of the Main Street shoppers, diners and moviegoers.

title: Gencorp Settles TV Station Sale
description: Gencorp Inc. said that it had reached an agreement for the previously announced sale of its television station KHJ-TV of Los Angeles to the Walt Disney Company. Gencorp also announced the settlement of a Federal Communications Commission proceeding involving the station. As previously reported, Disney agreed to pay a base price of $320 million to buy the independent television station.

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
A 'So What!' to Better Health
description: Two months ago the New York State Public Health Council, using authority granted by the Legislature in 1913, did what the Legislature has steadfastly refused to do. It issued rules limiting smoking in public. The regulations, which will take effect May 7, aren't intended to turn smokers into pariahs but to spare the 70 percent of New Yorkers who don't smoke from sharing the other 30 percent's habit - and health risk.

title: APRIL 15 TOLLS FOR REAGANS, TOO: THEIR 1986 TAX BILL IS $123,517
description: Last June President Reagan sold a tractor he bought in 1962 and reported the $1,500 sale as a $373 capital gain on his 1986 Federal income tax return.

title: Appeal to Mets, Yanks
description: Two leaders of the black community said yesterday that they had sent telegrams to the owners of the Yankees and the Mets, asking to discuss the hiring of blacks and other minorities for management positions on the teams.

title: SOUTH KOREA CHURCH LEADERS FAULT CHUN
description: South Korean church leaders attacked President Chun Doo Hwan today for his decision to shut off debate on changing the constitutional method of selecting the next national leader.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Easter Confections Easter dessert confections this year are filed under creamy and adorable, like the bunny-trimmed cakes created by Patisserie Lanciani, 275 West Fourth Street and 177 Prince Street (near Sullivan Street). The sponge layers are filled with fresh strawberries and vanilla butter cream.

title: Retiree Returns To Fill In at MCI
description: V. Orville Wright came out of retirement yesterday to become acting chief executive of the MCI Communications Corporation. Mr. Wright will fill in for William G. McGowan, who is recovering from a heart attack. Mr. McGowan, 59 years old, will retain the title of chairman.

title: CUOMO FORMS ACTION COMMITTEE TO PAY FOR HIS NATIONAL AGENDA
description: Governor Cuomo is forming a Federal political action committee to finance his political travels outside New York State, to sponsor local forums for Presidential contenders and to support candidates around the country.

title: New Haven Concern Is Fined on Dumping
description: Uretek Inc., embroiled in a bitter strike over health and safety conditions at its New Haven plant, was fined $250,000 Monday for illegal storage and dumping of hazardous waste, the authorities said.

title: Pleasant Surprise for Flyers
description: Pelle Eklund played a secondary role in the regular season for the Flyers, but he emerged as a protagonist in tonight's fifth game of the playoff series against the Rangers.

title: TAMPA POLICE FORCE IS FOCUS OF SMOLDERING RACIAL TENSION
description: From College Hill on the northwest side of this port city, the bundle of tall mirror-wall bank buildings stacked far away in downtown Tampa seems like a misty mirage in the daytime heat.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MY grandmother was rather vain, and I loved her for it.

title: PROFITS AT TIME INC. FELL BY 8% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that its earnings fell 8 percent in the first quarter. Profits came to $46 million, or 76 cents a share, down from $50 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues rose 7.4 percent to $939 million, from $874 million.

title: Hart Bets on the Cycle
description: Gary Hart of Colorado enters the Presidential election with the assumption that the mood of the American people is changing.

title: OIL STATES DRAWING HOPE FROM BELIEF THAT THE WORST IS OVER
description: Like survivors poking their heads out after a tornado has passed, economists, bankers and business leaders have begun looking for signs of an economic pickup in the oil-producing states, which were battered by last year's collapse of energy prices.

title: CALIFORNIA JOCKEY CLUB & BAY MEADOWS OPERATING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said California Jockey Club's and Bay Meadows' shares are traded as a single unit under a pairing agreement. Share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend on the paired common stock distributed to stockholders of record Nov. 3, 1986. The company said the prior year results includes a .025 capital gain distributed which resulted from a gain on the sale of land.

title: COLLEGE IS SPLIT OVER AWARDING DEGREE TO BISHOP
description: The faculty council of Brooklyn College has put off a decision on whether to award an honorary degree to Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The increase in first quarter net income reflected the absence of expenditures on the F-20 Tigershark program, which was concluded at the end of 1986, and to improved performance on the F/A-18 program. The company had written off $46 million for F-20 expenditures in the first quarter of 1986.

title: MEXICAN PROCEDURE FOR PARKINSON'S WILL BE USED BY SURGEONS HERE
description: ''I think I witnessed history,'' Dr. Abraham N. Lieberman, professor of neurology at New York University Medical Center, said yesterday after his recent return from visiting four Parkinson's disease patients who received tissue implants in brain surgery at a Mexican hospital.

title: Off on the Right Foot
description: With five stolen bases in his first five attempts this season, Eric Davis of Cincinnati became the player with the highest career success ratio among all active major-leaguers. The top 10 (minimum of 100 bases stolen):

title: TIRED RANGERS WATCH FLYERS TAKE BIG ADVANTAGE
description: The most urgent time of their season was upon them, and there were the Rangers, resting on their knees, leaning on their sticks, doing anything to gather their breath.

title: A GOVERNMENT STILL ELUDES ITALY
description: Prime Minister-designate Oscar Luigi Scalfaro gave up a four-day effort to form a new government today, making a June general election virtually certain.

title: 'POISON PILL' CHALLENGE LOSES
description: Shareholders of the International Paper Company yesterday rejected a call to put to a vote the anti-takeover measures adopted by the company's board.

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $48,000 and $295,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Navy Clamps Down
description: Navy Secretary James H. Webb has ruled that young naval officers will not receive any ''special accommodation'' in the future to play professional sports.

title: The Making of a Presidential Announcement
description: Some contenders announce their candidacy for President. Others announce that they will announce their candidacy. Still others announce the formation of ''exploratory committees,'' which is usually a way of announcing an intention to announce, eventually.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Allied said its latest first quarter results include $24.8 million in securities gains.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE CORP OF WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $267,000 for the latest quarter and a tax credit of $86,000 for the year-ago period.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment securities gains of $2,003,000 for the latest first quarter and $169,000 for the year-ago period. Net income for the first quarter was reduced by $1.5 million, a result of $119 million in loans to Brazil placed on non-accrual status.

title: SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
description: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives. Business executives make and unmake deals over food. Statesmen negotiate treaties over food. Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes. Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward. It can be symbol and metaphor, placing it at the center of most religious rituals.

title: FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The prior year per share figure is restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that strong first quarter performance at its core operations were more than offset by normal seasonal losses of Scott, Foresman & Co., acquired by the company at the end of 1986, and by the absence of one-time gains recorded in the first quarter of 1986.

title: Slam, 7 R.B.I.'s for Bo Jackson
description: Bo Jackson drove in seven runs with a grand slam and a three-run homer tonight to power the Kansas City Royals to a 10-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $299,000 and $1,196,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from adoption of FASB 87 relating to pension accounting. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 30. The company said that results for the latest quarter and year include the operations of LFE Corp. and Gulton Industries Inc., acquired by the company on June 1, 1985, and March 1, 1986, respectively.

title: Reduce State Sales Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Tests Find No PCB's In 5 Wells in Jersey
description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency has told the residents here that final tests have found no detectable traces of PCB's in their water, an agency spokesman has said.

title: About New York; A Dating Service That Matches The AIDS-Free
description: ''I'm looking for the same ideal man every other woman in New York is looking for,'' said Lisa Stillwell, a 28-year-old broker. ''A man who is rich, handsome and AIDS-negative.''

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $490,000 and $1,555,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: A Humorous Touch Wins Radio Ad Drive
description: Because it will surely be a great showcase for their talents, the annual radio industry self-promotion ad campaign attracts many creative volunteers.

title: How Do We Make It Fashionable to Save?
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS IS NOW SPREADING TO POPULOUS WEST AFRICA
description: Africa's AIDS epidemic is spreading from its stronghold in central Africa to a previously untouched area - West Africa, home to almost half of sub-Saharan Africa's population, health experts in the region say.

title: MORTGAGE RATES' FAST RUN-UP
description: The cost of borrowing money to buy a home has climbed as much as a percentage point or more in the last two weeks, and the fear of even higher rates has some individuals rushing to apply for mortgages.

title: REPUBLIC BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AN AFRICAN DRAMA: WILL JULIUS NYERERE LET GO?
description: When Julius K. Nyerere retired as President of Tanzania, he told his successor, Ali Hassan Mwinyi, that he would ''whisper in his ear'' advice gained from 24 years as leader of this hard-luck East African nation.

title: AFTER THE KIWI? PASSION FRUIT, OF COURSE
description: PASSION fruit and the intricate flower that blossoms before the fruit develops are as suitable as the lily at Easter. The passion flower was first named by 17th-century Jesuit missionaries who discovered it in the jungles of South America and related parts of the flower to the Passion of Christ.

title: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Where the Flying Fishes Play, So Do Tourists
description: One of Burma's leading painters, the muralist U Ba Kyi, has just completed an unusual assignment.

title: Three Rivals Join In $155 Bid for Taft
description: The three principal shareholders in the Taft Broadcasting Company, formerly viewed as rivals in their efforts to acquire the company, have joined to make a bid of $155 a share, or about $824 million.

title: VWR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a one-time capital gain of $6.9 million.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1986 are restated to reflect the acquisition of Adel Medical Limited on the pooling of interests method.

title: People
description: * Richard Russo has rejoined Della Femina, Travisano & Partners as a senior vice president, associate creative director.

title: U.S. Allows Condom Labels Citing Value in Barring AIDS
description: Manufacturers have been given Government approval to advertise that latex condoms can help prevent the spread of AIDS.

title: DANCE: 2D AVE. TROUPE
description: THE Second Avenue Dance Company, composed of advanced students at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, presented a superb program Monday night with works by its own members and three guest choreographers.

title: April 15 in the Capital? Ho Hum
description: In the nation's capital, where the agenda and frustrations of April 15's are born, bureaucrats will be having a much less harrowing day Wednesday than the millions of taxpayers around the country who are struggling to meet the midnight tax filing deadline.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that first-quarter results do not include the sales of Avia International Group Inc., which was acquired after the end of the first quarter.

title: DRUG DEFENDANT BELIEVED DEAD IN BOMB BLAST IN COURTHOUSE
description: A man on trial for selling drugs was apparently killed today when a briefcase he was carrying exploded in the Howard County courthouse, and at least 15 other people were injured, including the sheriff, the authorities said.

title: Cuomo to Release His Taxes
description: Governor Cuomo, after initially balking, said today that he would follow through on a campaign promise to make public his income tax returns and a list of honorariums. Mr. Cuomo, who made the pledge in his last year against Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican, said at first that he did not want to make the information public now because of his dispute with the Legislature over an ethics bill he has said he will veto. He said legislators might view his actions as an attempt to embarrass them.

title: A BULLDOZER STARTS, BRIEFLY, ON QUEENS TROLLEY STATION
description: Two century-old towers from which a web of Queens trolleys once spun provided the setting yesterday for a dramatic showdown as preservationists waited - moment by moment - for the city to halt demolition of the former New York and Queens County Railway terminal in Woodside.

title: The U.N. Today: April 15, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Natural Resources - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PRIVATE SHELTERS EVICTING DISRUPTIVE HOMELESS PEOPLE
description: Two years ago, responding to a plea for help from Mayor Koch, the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty set up what it believed to be a model program. The council took homeless men and women from city shelters, provided free room and board and social services, and hoped to help the men and women function on their own in four to six weeks.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT took but seconds to get Tokyo on the line from Manhattan. Across the Pacific the telephone was picked up and answered with a lilting voice and a rush of Japanese words. How lovely, how truly exotic the language is, our friend in Manhattan thought.

title: HE WARNS OF VETO
description: Governor Cuomo said today that a bill passed overwhelmingly by state lawmakers last week establishing ethics rules for themselves was unacceptably weak. He threatened to veto it if legislative leaders did not recall it by Wednesday evening.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10,200,000.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
