Canceled: A Vital Child Welfare Data Service
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 15, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 George Shultz rejected a proposal from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to eliminate all short-range nuclear missiles from Europe along with medium-range missiles, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. Page A1 Offer puts U.S. in a quandry A9 Evidence against two Marine guards accused of espionage at the United States embassy in Moscow is difficult to obtain, officials said. The Marine prosecutors may not meet a military justice system deadline. A1 Three accused marines A8 Kuwait will lease Soviet tankers to transport oil through the Persian Gulf and Soviet warships may escort them, Moscow announced. Diplomats said Soviet convoys in the gulf would cause concern in Washington. A1 A statue of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazis, has been quietly put up in Budapest. It is the private gift of a former American ambassador. A5 Two nuclear accidents in France have prompted new concern about the country's ambitious nuclear power program. The French Government does not know the cause of the accidents, which resulted in no casualties. A10 The Netherlands fears AIDS patients from other countries may come to take advantage of legalized mercy killing. A physician said several AIDS sufferers had been put to death at their request. A12 AIDS spreading to West Africa A12 In South Korea, church leaders attacked President Chun Doo Hwan for shutting off debate on changing the constitutional method of selecting the next leader. A new era has been ''totally shattered,'' one said. A3 In South Africa, a civil rights group said that it will challenge in court new curbs on protest against detention without trial. The group joined church leaders and foes of apartheid who vowed to defy the curbs. A3 Will Nyerere let go in Tanzania? A4 Soviet to begin election experiment in June A6 Contra leader quits post A11 Brazil's battle with bureaucracy A13 Judge rules against Duvaliers A13 Cuba refills Nicaragua's shelves A14 Tourists in demand in Burma A15 NATIONAL A16-25 The U.S. trade deficit grew to $15.06 billion in February, the third-biggest monthly imbalance on record, the Government reported. The figures touched off selling of the dollar while stock prices tumbled. A1 A census report showed a decline from the previous year in the average number of people per household to the lowest level ever recorded. The decline reflects the aging of the population, census officials said. A1 Charges of killing a rare panther were filed by the Justice Department against James E. Billie, chairman of the Seminole Indian tribe in Florida. He says a treaty allows him to shoot animals on the reservation. A1 Racial tension in Tampa, Fla. has not been relieved by the city's commercial prosperity. A smoldering conflict has spurred debate on whether the city can correct the social ills of the urban black poor. A16 Julian Bond denied he used cocaine or committed any crime, responding to reports that his estranged wife had told the police he abused the drug. The former Georgia State Senator blamed the controversy on ''gossip mongers.'' A16 Tissue implants in brain surgery will be performed in a month at New York University Medical Center, said Dr. Abraham N. Lieberman, a neurologist. He had just returned from visiting four recipients in Mexico. A21 Economic woes of the oil region are likely to ease, experts said. A year after the oil industry went into a virtual free fall, the foundation for a modest recovery is beginning to take form, they said. A16 The First Family's tax return was released by the White House, providing a glimpse into their life style and financial picture. In one transaction, the President reported the sale of a tractor as a capital gain. A18 A judge ordered John Hinckley to turn over all correspondence after prosecutors disclosed that the presidential assailant had exchanged secret letters with the convicted murderer Theodore Bundy. A19 Food that can be eaten on the run is growing increasingly popular with Americans. In response, food companies are offering more ready-to-eat items in single-portion servings. C1 Judge supports G.M. on brakes A16 Toxic chemical spill in Utah A18 Poor and elderly pay higher health costs A25 WASHINGTON TALK A22 The making of a Presidential announcement Tax day in the capital? Ho hum REGIONAL B1-4 An ethics bill may be vetoed, Governor Cuomo said. The bill, passed overwhelmingly by state lawmakers last week to establish ethics rules for themselves, is unacceptable and should be recalled, he said. A1 Jail life seems to be tougher for prisoners and correction officers as more inmates flood into overcrowded city jails. ''The situation is now one of maximum acceptable risk,'' one Correction Board official said. A1 A stop work order was issued to halt the demolition of the former New York and Queens County Railway, minutes after a bulldozer and a backhoe clawed its clock tower. B3 Highway deaths in New York rose last year from the previous year, the State Department of Motor Vehicles reported. The report partly blamed a decline in compliance with the state's seat belt law. B4 A request to operate its nuclear plant at Shoreham at 25 percent of capacity to generate commercial levels of electricity this summer was submitted by the Long Island Lighting Company to a Federal agency. B1 Renovation of the military academy at West Point has begun to accommodate a new generation of technologically advanced officers. The $48.2 million modernization program should be completed by 1991. B1 Some shelters evict homeless B1 Nassau inmates freed by error B2 College split on a degree B3 No-smoking rules to move ahead B3

title: RULING THREATENS IMPORTS OF RECORDS
description: A recent decision by a Federal court in New Jersey could greatly reduce the number of albums imported into the United States, according to American record company officials.

title: Want to Debate Trade?
description: On Monday, former Senator Gary Hart formally declared his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Yesterday morning the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit climbed in February to $15 billion, the third-highest on record. By yesterday afternoon, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, one of Mr. Hart's rivals for the nomination, was challenging him to a debate on trade policy.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: Share earnings have not been adjusted to reflect a proposed 3-for-1 stock split previously announced, which is subject to shareholder approval.

title: Advertising; Investors Acquire TVSM Inc.
description: TVSM INC., publisher of the Cable Guide, a 5.5 million circulation publication, has been acquired by a group of investors headed by Mark M. Edmiston, former president of Newsweek. The deal was for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
description: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives. Business executives make and unmake deals over food. Statesmen negotiate treaties over food. Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes. Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward. It can be symbol and metaphor, placing it at the center of most religious rituals.

title: SILVERCREST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR CHINA'S CUISINE, A RETURN TO GLORY DAYS
description: ''THE food in China used to be very good, but it was set back by the Cultural Revolution,'' said Zhou Zhi Bin. That observation is particularly noteworthy because the man who made it is one of Shanghai's oldest master chefs. Western visitors to China have been saying the same thing for years.

title: Gain for Amax Forecast
description: Amax Inc., the natural resources conglomerate, should post higher pretax profits from its aluminum and gold operations this year, its president and chief executive, Allen Born, said here today. After losing $1.7 billion over five years, Amax, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., last year reported profits of $14.3 million. Aluminum, which will account for some 60 percent of this year's revenues, and gold were very profitable and had strong growth potential, he told analysts.

FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DOLLAR FALLS IN SPITE OF FED ACTION
description: The dollar tumbled further against the Japanese yen yesterday after the release of disappointing United States trade figures, but recovered slightly in early trading in Japan today.

title: Aluminum Led Loss at Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, based in Oakland, Calif., today reported a net loss of $29.3 million for the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $17.4 million, or 37 cents a share, a year before.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time reduction in deferred taxes of $4.8 million and a net non-operating gain of $507,000, both recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 1987.

title: Ramada Notes To Yield 11.70%
description: Ramada Inc. is offering $100 million of 11 5/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1999 at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 11.70 percent through Salomon Brothers as sole underwriter.

title: OREGON COURT BROADENS FREE SPEECH RIGHTS
description: An Oregon Supreme Court decision that broadens the right of free speech in that state has added new force to a program of the American Civil Liberties Union that uses state constitutions as a means of providing greater protection to individual liberties.

title: DROP IN SEAT-BELT USE CITED AS STATE'S ROAD DEATHS RISE
description: More people died on New York's highways last year than in the previous year, the state reported today, blaming in part a decline in compliance with New York State's seat-belt law.

title: Old Home Weeks
description: After their move to Los Angeles, Shelly Dinhofer, like many another Brooklynite, remained a fan of the Dodgers - the Brooklyn Dodgers. Now some fruits of her devotion to a team that ceased to exist in 1957 are going on display at the Museum of the Borough of Brooklyn. An exhibition entitled ''The Grand Game of Baseball . . . and the Brooklyn Dodgers'' will be open to the public beginning a week from tomorrow and continuing through June 17.

title: PROFITS SCORTBOARD
53 Dance Groups to Get Philip Morris Grants
description: Philip Morris Companies Inc. has announced grants totaling $1 million to 53 dance organizations and performance centers.

title: TWO ACCIDENTS RAISING QUESTIONS ABOUT FRANCE'S NUCLEAR PROGRAM
description: Two accidents within days at French nuclear installations have prompted new concern about this country's ambitious nuclear power program.

title: Library Nominee Is . . .
description: Through a process of elimination, it now seems that James H. Billington, director of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, is likely to be the next Librarian of Congress.

The company said the latest 6-month results include sales of $1.1 million and net income of $560,000 associated with the favorable settlement of litigation regarding the licensing of certain technology by the company's medical and electronic product business.

title: LILCO SEEKS SUMMER USE OF SHOREHAM
description: The Long Island Lighting Company asked the Federal Government today for permission to generate commercial levels of electricity at its Shoreham nuclear power plant for the first time.

title: VOPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from a joint venture in Canada of $183,000.

title: Shipshape
description: Kent Biggerstaff, the Pirate trainer, responding to word that Pittsburgh's portly Rick Reuschel had gained four pounds since last season: ''That's like putting just another suitcase on the Queen Mary.''

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $369,000 from a tax loss carryforward. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $83,000 and a tax credit of $73,000.

title: Horner Chooses Japan
description: Bob Horner, the free agent who was the Atlanta Braves' first baseman last season, yesterday signed with the Yakult Swallows of the Japan Central League. The contract will pay $1.3 million for a year plus all of Horner's travel and living expenses, Horner's agent, Bucky Woy said. Horner rejected offers of $4.5 million for three years and $3.9 million for two years from the Braves. Last year he hit .273 with 27 homers and 87 r.b.i. in 141 games, the most he played in a season.

title: Market Place; Pennzoil Price Defies Analysis
description: ''DETERMINING the worth of Pennzoil's stock is like trying to catch a slippery eel.'' That's how Earl Lester, oil analyst for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, describes the high-stakes battle between the Pennzoil Company and Texaco Inc. Suddenly, a tantalizing game on Wall Street has become the placing of bets on Pennzoil's fast-moving shares.

title: Citicorp Auction Rates Up Sharply
description: Rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.7842 percent, up from 6.2415 percent last week.

title: MOVE TO PAROLE RAPIST FOUGHT
description: The impending parole of a convict who cut the arms off a 15-year-old rape victim has caused so much anger that state prison officials are considering changing the parole location, a State Deputy Attorney General said today.

title: MORTON WILFRED BLOOMFIELD, HARVARD MEDIEVALIST, IS DEAD
description: Morton Wilfred Bloomfield, a professor of medieval literature at Harvard University, died here today after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch on Friday about President Reagan's reaction to a Soviet proposal to limit nuclear testing misstated American policy on negotiations over the issue. The United States says it will not negotiate additional limits on the number or size of tests until the Soviet Union agrees to new monitoring measures for two unratified treaties limiting underground explosions. It has not set that condition for continuing talks on nuclear testing.

title: Don't Raise the Minimum Wage
description: Democratic legislators are right to search for ways to help the working poor, but wrong to think that raising the minimum wage is one of them. To do that would hurt many low-income workers, something legislators need to grasp before ramming a bill through Congress.

title: WALLENBERG: STATUE RISES IN BUDAPEST
description: Without public announcement, Budapest has put up a statue to honor Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazis and then disappeared in Soviet captivity.

title: ATHEY PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN BRAZIL, BATTLE OF THE BLOATED BUREAUCRACY
description: When Wellington Moreira Franco took over as Governor of Rio de Janeiro on March 15, he learned to his surprise that his predecessor had handed out thousands of new permanent jobs in the state government just hours before he stepped down.

title: STAGE: POLITICAL HOPES IN 'AS IT IS IN HEAVEN'
description: IF Obies were given out for timeliness, ''As It Is in Heaven'' would walk away with this year's prize. Joe Sutton's new play, which opened last night at the Perry Street theater, lets us in on a weekend meeting of the staff of an aspiring Republican Presidential candidate while a deal is being worked out with an unctuous television evangelist named Rat Paterson. None of the staffers is crazy about what Rat stands for, and their reactions are scrutinized in this intermittently smart work that doesn't always seem sure what it is getting at.

title: DOW DROPS BY 34.09 ON BIG VOLUME
description: Stock prices plunged in intense trading yesterday, with declining shares overwhelming gainers by 10 to 1. For the first two days of the week, the Dow Jones industrial average has declined 3.7 percent.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results include a pre-tax gain of $14 million, or 16 cents a share, on the sale of Southwest Forest Industries' preferred stock. The latest quarter also includes results of Hammermill Paper Co., which was merged into International Paper in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: Zimbabwean Denies Reports Country Bought 12 MIG-29's
description: A Zimbabwean Government official today denied reports that the country had bought 12 MIG-29 jet fighters from the Soviet Union.

title: KILLING OF A PANTHER: INDIAN TREATY RIGHTS VS. LAW ON WILDLIFE
description: The Justice Department today charged the chief of the Seminole Indian tribe with shooting and killing a Florida panther in violation of the Endangered Species Act. But the chief's lawyer says hunting panthers is part of the Seminoles' religious and cultural tradition and is protected under the Constitution and by treaty.

title: 'MARIAH,' PRISON DRAMA
description: APPARENTLY suspecting that nobody is watching anyway these days, bottom-ranked ABC is developing a curious devil-may-care attitude toward its schedule, even when it comes to highly touted new series.

title: DR. MATTIE COOK, COLLEGE CHIEF
description: Dr. Mattie Cook, president of Malcolm-King: Harlem College Extension in Harlem, died of cancer Monday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: J & B Scotch Focusing On a Younger Market
description: The Paddington Corporation, anxious to associate its J & B Rare Scotch with a younger and more with-it market segment, is sponsoring three special inserts in Spy magazine, which supposedly reaches that kind of New Yorker. It will be spending just shy of $100,000 to do it.

title: When Telephone Solicitation Is the Best Way; And When It Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VIOLENCE GROWS IN CROWDED NEW YORK JAILS
description: Life in New York City's increasingly overcrowded jails is descending deeper and deeper into the circles of toughness, danger and despair, in the view of inmates and those who run the jails.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its latest-quarter net was reduced by about $7 million, or 12 cents a share, because it placed about $423 million in Brazilian loans on non-accrual status. The company, which reported higher first-quarter earnings, said the percentage increase in earnings per share was smaller than that of net income primarily because of the issuance of common stock in connection with its acquisition of Crocker National Corp. on May 30, 1986.

title: Oilers Wrap Up Series With Kings, 4-1
description: Esa Tikkanen and Glenn Anderson each scored his second goal of the game in the third period to lead Edmonton to a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight that advanced the Oilers to the Smythe Division final.

title: HINCKLEY IS TOLD TO SURRENDER ALL CORRESPONDENCE
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. was ordered today to turn over all his correspondence and writings after Government prosecutors disclosed that he had exchanged secret letters with the convicted murderer Theodore Bundy.

title: GOLDMAN, KIDDER CITED IN UNOCAL INSIDER SUIT
description: The Unocal Corporation today filed a lawsuit against Goldman, Sachs & Company; Kidder, Peabody & Company, and four Wall Street executives, charging them with insider trading relating to Unocal's takeover battle with T. Boone Pickens in 1985.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a provision for taxes of $819,000 and $331,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively; the latest year also includes a tax credit of $660,000 due to amended tax returns for prior years, and 1986 includes a credit of $559,000 for anticipated income tax settlement for 1970.

title: SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
description: LEAD: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives. Business executives make and unmake deals over food. Statesmen negotiate treaties over food. Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes. Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * First Boston Corp. said David C. McCutcheon had joined the firm in New York as a managing director and would serve as senior banker covering Canada.

title: President of N.V. Philips Forms a U.S. Strategy
description: Although most investors sent a negative message through the financial markets yesterday, C. J. van der Klugt selected April 14 as the day to show how bullish he and his company are about America.

title: The Economic Tangle
description: The collapse of that Interstate Highway bridge over Schoharie Creek in New York dramatizes what the Federal Highway Administration recently told Congress - that it will cost $50.8 billion, $13 billion of it needed immediately, to make all the nation's bridges safe again.

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $41,505,000 on oil and gas properties. The company said comparable figures are not available because 1986 was its first full year of operations.

title: Team Doctor: Operating in Quandary
description: They are two of New York's more notable invalids, Joe Klecko and Roger McDowell. In other cities, in other sports, in other hospital beds or in trainers' rooms, dozens of other major league athletes face similar problems and decisions.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in November.

title: CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After a loss of $127,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SCHULMAN, A INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split paid on Feb. 17, as a 50 percent stock dividend. The company said that certain prior years' amounts have been reclassified for comparability.

title: Valentine to Stay Put
description: The Texas Rangers' manager, Bobby Valentine, said he was not interested in moving to the Los Angeles Dodgers, squelching a rumor that surfaced when their executive vice president, Al Campanis, was discharged last week. There was also speculation that Manager Tommy Lasorda of the Dodgers would move into the front office, creating an opening for Valentine, a former Dodger.

title: NEW FUND FOR SMOKING BAN IS SOUGHT
description: The new smoking restrictions in New York State can be imposed despite the denial of a $300,000 legislative appropriation, state health officials said yesterday.

title: TESTS URGED FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The director of the space shuttle program has recommended a practice countdown and test-firing of the main engines of the shuttle Discovery before the first shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster, an exercise that could delay the launching by up to two months, the space agency said today.

title: UNIT AT WRITERS GUILD ENDORSES CBS CONTRACT PROPOSAL
description: The negotiating committee of the Writers Guild of America recommended yesterday that its membership accept the contract proposed by CBS to settle the six-week-old strike against that network.

title: SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
description: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives. Business executives make and unmake deals over food. Statesmen negotiate treaties over food. Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes. Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward. It can be symbol and metaphor, placing it at the center of most religious rituals.

title: CURTICE-BURNS FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $25,092,000, or $2.43 a share, from the sale of the company's insurance premium finance division and other bank assets. The per share figures reflect a 5 percenty stock dividend to be paid on May 29.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RENE HARDY, RESISTANCE CHIEF ACCUSED OF GIVING BARBIE AID
description: Rene Hardy, who built an underground group that sabotaged the German occupation forces in World War II, but was shadowed all his life by the accusation that he was a Gestapo informer, died Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: Sales of U.S.-Built Cars Fall 15 Percent in Period
description: Sales of new American-made cars fell 15 percent, to 193,139 units, in the first 10 days of April, the eight manufacturers reported today. Sales of light trucks rose 1.5 percent, to 97,687, partly offsetting the decline for automobiles.

title: AMERICAN TELEVISION & COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1986 results are restated to include Manhattan Cable Television Inc., which was transferred from Time Inc. to ATC on March 18, 1987 in exchange for 9.4 million shares of ATC Class B common stock.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home Loan Banks Set 3 Bond Issues
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks are offering three bond issues totaling $2.14 billion through various securities dealers at a price of par.

title: CORNELL OPPONENTS ARE SEEING RED
description: It has been a decade since Cornell and its longtime coach, Richie Moran, won a national championship in lacrosse and another opportunity may be at hand. The Big Red has an apparent contender this spring and Moran's unbeaten team captured its most important decision of the season with a 19-6 victory over Syracuse in the Carrier Dome last Saturday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Home Sweet Mansion A premier off-the-beaten-track attraction is the house that since 1942 has been home to this city's mayors, Gracie Mansion, on East End Avenue at 89th Street. The mansion, built in 1799 as Archibald Gracie's country home, was subsequently owned by two private families. In 1896 the city acquired it along with its grounds, most of which became Carl Schurz Park.

title: The Pope and the Victims
description: Pope John Paul II showed the power of moral leadership in his recent trip to Chile. He defended the Chilean church in its mission of solidarity with victims of government persecution. He stood up to Chile's dictator. And he gave hope to a martyred people.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes $1,040,000 from plywood antitrust litigation settlement.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include the accounts of Production Graphics Corp. and the Systems Technology and Weapons Systems Test divisions of New Technology Inc., acquired as of Dec. 30, 1986. The company said that at the beginning of 1987 it adopted FASB No. 87 and that the effect of the adoption increased first quarter 1987 income before taxes $400,000.

title: NOW, FOOD FOR THE OTHERWISE ENGAGED
description: KATE HENNEBERRY, a sales representative for a shipping company, is walking on West 34th Street with a pear in one hand and a briefcase in the other. It is just past noon, and this is the second course of her lunch. The first course, a few blocks ago, was an apple.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHROMA. By Frederick Barthelme. 173 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOVIET TO BEGIN MULTI-CANDIDATE ELECTION EXPERIMENT IN JUNE
description: The Soviet Union has announced that voters will be given a choice of candidates on a trial basis in local government elections in June.

title: Borg Gives GAF Confidential Data
description: Lawyers and investment bankers for the GAF Corporation have begun reviewing confidential data provided by the Borg-Warner Corporation to help GAF decide whether to pursue its interest in the industrial company, Wall Street sources said.

title: NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEART FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on the sale of loans and investments of $272,000 for the latest quarter and $182,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: ROOTS OF YOUNG MARINES IN SPY CASE: LITTLE HINT OF THE UNUSUAL
description: There is little in the lives of three marines accused of allowing Soviet agents into the Moscow Embassy while they were on guard duty there to distinguish them from others of their age and background who enlisted in the Marine reserves while still in high school.

title: Wang Profit Of $5.9 Million
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., the pioneering personal computer manufacturer, returned to profitability today after two quarters of losses, reporting a third-quarter net of $5.9 million. Wang also reiterated its goal of being solidly profitable in its fourth quarter ending June 30.

title: WINE TALK
description: AFTER winter's hibernation, spring quickens the wine industry. Vineyards flower.

title: MOSCOW WEIGHING NAVAL ESCORTS
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would rent three tankers to Kuwait to transport oil through the Persian Gulf, and raised the possibility that Soviet warships might escort them.

title: 'THE KWITNY REPORT'
description: JONATHAN KWITNY tells us where he stands; that's good.

title: CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1.6 million charge for uncollectible receivables, lower recoverable value of inventory and writeoffs of capitalized costs on discontinued projects; $1.7 million for the resolution of a shareholder class action suit; and a $1.1 million loss on the company's 49 percent share of Chronar Frances's operating results.

title: PHILLIES STUMBLE, METS LAND ON TOP
description: Maybe it wasn't exactly a grudge match, but it was certainly a return match. The Mets won it tonight when they took advantage of three errors and rallied for two runs in the ninth inning to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-5.

title: COUPLE IN INDIANA TOLD TO GIVE UP GRANDSON
description: A couple was ordered Monday to give up custody of their 2-year-old grandson, whose mother was murdered in New Jersey by their son.

title: NAPA VALLEY WINE LEGENDS WHO TOIL IN THE VINEYARDS
description: THE occasion was a party held last week in San Francisco to honor some of the Napa Valley's most famous wine people. The list of 12 being honored was formidable: Joe Heitz, Maynard Amerine, Andre Tchelistcheff, Brother Timothy, Louis P. Martini, Eleanor McCrea, Robert Mondavi, Peter Mondavi, Hanns Kornell, Legh Knowles, Myron Nightingale and Roy Raymond Sr. The affair was presented to promote Napa wines and to emphasize, gently, that the Napa Valley has been around for a long time. But I have trouble with the word legend, which is what each of these wine makers was being touted as.

title: POOR AND ELDERLY SAID TO PAY HIGHER HEALTH COSTS
description: Cost-cutting steps enacted by Congress in the past six years have substantially increased out-of-pocket medical expenses for the nation's poor and elderly, a new study concludes.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $46,000 for both periods. c-Includes a tax credit of $22,000 for both periods.

title: Economic Scene; Trade Deficit: Strains Grow
description: THE huge United States trade deficit - and the huge surpluses of Japan, West Germany and the newly industrialized countries of Asia -could become the focal point of the 1988 Presidental campaign. The trade imbalance, which widened to $15.06 billion in February despite the falling dollar, is already imposing severe strains on international relations.

title: MUSIC: GOLDEN PALOMINOS
description: THE Golden Palominos are essentially the splendid rock drummer Anton Fier and a shifting cast of supporting players. But lately the shifting has been minimal, and a real band has been emerging. Driven by Mr. Fier's deftly architectural drumming, the Palominos have coalesced around Syd Straw's riveting vocal presence and urbanized-country soul, the luminous clarity of Jody Harris's lead guitar, Robert Kidney's energy and rock-and-roll attitude and Peter Blegvad's incisive songcraft.

title: STAR-DIRECTOR DISPUTES TROUBLE THE MET OPERA
description: Maria Ewing has withdrawn from her future engagements with the Metropolitan Opera and from an appearance elsewhere with the house's artistic director, James Levine. The mezzo-soprano asserted that Mr. Levine had made oral commitments to her, and that he had not honored them. Mr. Levine, in response to news of Miss Ewing's statement, disputed the singer's recollection of their conversations, and said he had not made the promises to which she referred.

title: Debt and Drugs in the Third World
description: Among the issues that most trouble the West and especially the United States are the international traffic in drugs and the third world debt. The linkage between the two is often missed. Both involve corruption, but there is more to the relationship than that.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net includes an after-tax gain of $4.8 million from the sale of a subsidiary bank.

title: Mantle Leaves Hospital
description: Mickey Mantle, the former Yankee star, was released from the hospital in good condition today after tests that showed chest pains he suffered probably stemmed from stress syndrome, a hospital spokesman said.

title: TOM ABBOTT, DANCER KNOWN FOR STAGINGS OF ROBBIN'S WORKS
description: Tom Abbott, a dancer known for his stagings of Jerome Robbins's musicals and ballets, was found dead in his home in Manhattan last Wednesday. He was 53 years old.

title: SUNS' DRUG INQUIRY TO GROW, AGENT SAYS
description: Several additional members of the Phoenix Suns are likely to be called before a Phoenix grand jury investigating drug use, an agent for one of the players said yesterday.

title: The Rarest Kind Of Ball Club
description: When it comes to ''necessities,'' the most fateful word Al Campanis ever spoke, Tracy Lewis would appear to have all she needs. She is the 25-year-old president of the Savannah (Ga.) Cardinals, a Class A St. Louis affiliate that is unique as a black-operated professional baseball team, and she has begun turning around what used to be a dismal franchise.

title: U.S. TRADE GAP WIDENS, ADDING TO DOLLAR STRESS
description: The United States deficit in international trade grew to $15.06 billion in February, the third-biggest monthly imbalance on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Robelo Plans to Quit Contra Umbrella Group
description: Alfonso Robelo, the last of the original three directors of the largest bloc of Nicaraguan rebels, said today that he would soon quit the organization's top leadership and would not be a candidate for one of seven slots of an expanded directorate that will be chosen in the next few weeks.

title: 16 NASSAU PRISONERS WERE FREED BY MISTAKE
description: Sixteen convicted felons were mistakenly freed from the Nassau County Correctional Facility between March 24 and April 5, but 15 of them were recaptured when the error was discovered Monday, officials said today.

title: First Baby M Visit Under New Ruling
description: Mary Beth Whitehead visited her year-old daughter yesterday for the first time since she was stripped of her parental rights.

title: US TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
