description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,435,000. The company said that results for the latest period reflects a reclassification of the operations of Directories America, United Telesentinel and Information Line from United Telephone System to complementary businesses to be consistent with 1987.

title: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a restructuring charge of $37 million. c-Net income

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $911,000 and $91,000 from securities transactions for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: A Construction Worker Dies in Cave-In of Ditch
description: A 37-year-old construction worker died and a 24-year-old colleague was hurt yesterday in a series of cave-ins in a drainage ditch at a construction site in Ronkonkoma, L.I., the Suffolk County police said.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Latest quarter and 6 months are equal to 13 weeks and 26 weeks, respectively. The company said that results include recently acquired Texas Industrial Services for the eight weeks ended Feb. 28, 1987.

title: Smoke Bomb in a Dormitory Leads to Death of a Student
description: A fire in a college dormitory was started early Sunday by a smoke bomb that was apparently set off as a prank, and an 18-year-old student died after being overcome by smoke, the police said.

title: UAL's Adviser To Discuss Bid
description: UAL Inc., apparently bowing to Wall Street pressure, instructed its investment banker today to discuss an unsolicited offer that it had received from its pilots' union.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Provision for loan losses was $56.6 million in the latest first quarter, compared with $52.2 million in the year-ago first quarter. Net loan chargeoffs were $41.9 million in the latest quarter, compared with $42.2 million in the year-ago period.

title: 'Secret of My Success' No. 1 at the Box Office
description: ''The Secret of My Success,'' starring Michael J. Fox, took in $7.8 million at the box office last weekend as it opened around the country, gaining the No. 1 spot for the week.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter results are restated to include New Jersey National Corp., acquired in October 1986 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: ADVANCES IN BRIDGES: NEW WAYS TO MAKE SPANS SOUND AGAIN
description: THE problem was emphasized tragically in New York last week: Almost half of the bridges in the United States are structurally deficient, no longer able to carry the loads for which they were designed.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Insane Risk
description: The world is a pretty crazy place, and most people have little power to do anything about it. Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker is an exception. He is the judge who'll decide whether John Hinckley Jr. should be granted a 12-hour unescorted pass from a Washington D.C. mental hospital to visit his parents on Easter.

title: Hunts' Plan on Placid Cleared
description: The Hunt brothers won a significant legal battle tonight as a Federal bankruptcy judge in Dallas ruled that the Placid Oil Company could proceed with a Gulf of Mexico drilling operation known as the Green Canyon project.

title: SCHOLARS SET HOLIDAY TABLE WITH A FEAST OF REASON
description: BREAKING bread is at the heart of our secular and religious lives. Business executives make and unmake deals over food. Statesmen negotiate treaties over food. Families meet over food, even if the food is only doughnuts and the meeting lasts but minutes. Food has functioned as sacred offering, sacrifice, display of wealth, relief for the poor, penance, punishment and reward. It can be symbol and metaphor, placing it at the center of most religious rituals.

title: A Way to Control Handguns
description: Who would argue against legislation that could keep criminals and crazies from buying a handgun? Who would argue against legislation that could have prevented John W. Hinckley Jr. from buying the Saturday night special that injured President Reagan and gravely wounded James S. Brady, his press secretary? Not surprisingly, the National Rifle Association is preparing to fight such legislation with all the high-powered political ammunition it can muster.

title: Ashton Software
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said that it had introduced a new word processing software product, Multimate Advantage II, designed to provide more power and to be easier to use than its widely sold predecessor. The new software, priced at $565 to $595, includes a 40,000-word thesaurus and a 110,000-word speller dictionary.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FINANCIAL CORP WISC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,272,000 for the latest quarter and $683,000 for the year-ago period.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Backs G.M. on Safety A Federal judge rejected Government charges that General Motors sold 1.1 million 1980 X-cars it knew had unsafe brakes. Page A16. AIDS Reaches West Africa Africa's AIDS epidemic is spreading from its stronghold in central Africa to a previously untouched area: populous West Africa. Page A12.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST & HOTEL INVESTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $55,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a gain $778,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Both the companies shares are paired and traded together. The company said the increases in the revenue and income this year reflect the impact of additional hotel purchases during the first six months of fiscal 1987 and the acquisition of Western Host Inc. in December 1986.

title: P.L.O. Decides to End Jordanian Agreement
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has decided to scrap an agreement with Jordan for a joint approach to a Middle East settlement and will seek a wider accord with Arab governments.

title: SKINNER'S BLAST BEATS INDIANS
description: There was something majestic about the grand slam. It soared into the sky, cleared the wall in left-center field and settled in the distance, 450 feet from where Joel Skinner had first struck the ball that Steve Carlton threw in the fifth inning last night.

title: CALMAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $41,371,000 on the sale of Valley Reclamation Co. stock.

title: Kickoff Classic On a Sunday
description: The first college football game of the season, the Kickoff Classic between Iowa and Tennessee, will be played at 1 P.M. Sunday, Aug. 30, instead of Monday night, Aug. 31, so it can be televised nationally by ABC.

title: Standard Board Defers on B.P. Bid
description: The board of the Standard Oil Company said yesterday that it would follow the recommendation of its special committee and not take a position on a bid by the British Petroleum Company, its major stockholder, to buy the rest of the company. The board, after a daylong meeting at Standard Oil headquarters in Cleveland, said the special committee would make a recommendation on the offer to the board by April 23.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Blackhawks Plan Shifts
description: The Chicago Blackhawks, losers in four consecutive games to the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League playoffs, are in for an overhaul, which will include a new coach. ''I think we will have a major shakedown,'' the team's owner, Bill Wirtz, said yesterday. ''Our fans deserve better than they got at the end of this season.''

title: SOVIET OFFER PUTS U.S. IN A QUANDARY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer to eliminate short-range missiles in Europe seems to put the United States in a quandary.

title: RIDGEWOOD PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FOR 'ASINAMALI!' BACKERS, MORE THAN JUST A PLAY
description: Mbongeni Ngema's ''Asinamali!'' - born of a rent strike in a South African township before traveling to Harlem a year ago and scoring a resounding success as the opening production of the ''Woza Afrika!'' festival last September at Lincoln Center - stakes a timely claim on Broadway tonight.

title: GEORGIA PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $6 million from the redemption of preferred stock and a gain of $8 million from a change in timber capitalization policy.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''IT takes years to get skin cancer. Most of us get an early start.'' This is the message on two potentially life-saving posters being distributed by the Skin Cancer Foundation in an effort to halt a fast-growing health threat. The posters depict children playing on the beach, their tender skin exposed to the searing sun. While most people don't start worrying about skin cancer until midlife, the foundation's experts warn - and the posters suggest - that the disease actually starts in youth.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A.I.D. Post Rejected
description: Speaking of filling Washington jobs, former Gov. Robert D. Ray of Iowa has turned down an offer to become head of the Agency for International Development, the Government office that handles American foreign aid. He was the Reagan Administration's first choice to replace M. Peter McPherson, who is leaving that post to become Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, succeeding Richard G. Darman.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS TO RENDER EUROPE CLEAR OF MISSILES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed ridding Europe of all short-range nuclear missiles along with medium-range missiles, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 15, 1987
description: The Economy

title: RIGHTS GROUP TO FIGHT PRETORIA CURBS
description: Amid growing expressions of defiance, a civil rights group said today that it would go to court to challenge the Government's new curbs on protests against detention without trial.

title: Prices Off a Bit in Wild Day
description: After a day of wild gyrations in the credit markets, prices of Treasury notes and bonds were down modestly while short-term interest rates were mixed.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $5.5 million. c-Net loss and after a gain of $7,596,000 from debt repayment.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CALF'S liver has a distinctive and, I might add, admirable flavor all its own. But I still put it in the category of foods like potatoes, pastas and snails that gain in character if combined with other foods that have more pronounced flavors.

title: COMPANIES CALM ABOUT INTEREST RISE
description: Before interest rates surged in the past 10 days, the Colgate-Palmolive Company had planned a bond issue of $75 million to $100 million, expecting to use the money to retire some of its floating-rate debt.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The figures are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a technical error, an article about the pace of landmarks designation in New York City appeared twice in some copies yesterday and an article about efforts by New York officials to deal with new Federal immigration rules was omitted. Readers wishing copies of the missing article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $47,000 and $100,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: In Remote Nicaragua, Cuban Ships Refill Shelves
description: Normally, residents of this isolated coastal area of northeast Nicaragua are entitled to buy one pound of low-priced beans and a like amount of rice every 15 days. But in the second half of March, supplies ran low and residents were put on half rations.

title: FAN SOCIETIES BUILD POPULARITY OF FOLK AND BLUES
description: Neil Sharrow, a fan of Louisiana folk music, approached the microphone and spoke to the 500 music-loving revelers at the nightclub.

title: JUDGE SUPPORTS G.M. ON BRAKES IN 1980 X-CARS
description: A Federal District Court today dismissed a Government lawsuit aimed at forcing the General Motors Corporation to recall more than a million cars because of what safety officials said were defective brakes.

title: Bridge: Player, Rushed to Hospital, Returns to Help Team Win
description: Many players struck by illness have had to be taken to a hospital in the middle of a tournament. On one memorable occasion a declarer who had suffered a slight heart attack and was lying on the floor while awaiting an ambulance insisted on being handed his cards. He happily completed his three no-trump contract from the floor and made it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was an absolute massacre at one point.'' - Gerald Walsh, a stock analyst, on Wall Street's second-busiest day. [ D1:6. ]

title: DUTCH FEAR: AIDS CASES' LAST STOP
description: Government and medical officials of the Netherlands, where an estimated 5,000 cases of voluntary euthanasia occur each year, are carefully guarding against the nation's becoming the terminal refuge for the sufferers of AIDS.

title: EXPERTS ASSESS IMPACT OF MOZART MANUSCRIPT
description: Scholars and dealers in New York and London excitedly assessed the importance yesterday of a 500-page manuscript of nine of Mozart's early symphonies, a bound work that has not been seen or handled widely in this century by scholars and musicians and that is to be auctioned next month.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary after-tax loss of $6,479,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1986 and 5 percent stock dividend paid in September 1986.

title: ROLLINS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago periods have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September 1986.

title: BankAmerica Adds to Board
description: The BankAmerica Corporation today named two corporate officers and a real estate developer as directors, increasing the number of board members to 17. The new outside director is

title: SUICIDE RATES OF TEEN-AGERS: ARE THEIR LIVES HARDER TO LIVE?
description: EVERY 1.1 seconds a teen-ager tries to commit suicide.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $900,000 from discontinued operations. The year-ago figures have been restated for discontinued real estate operations and the adoption of financial accounting standards relating to employers' accounting for pension plans.

title: STATE JUDGE ORDERS DUVALIER ACCOUNTS IN NEW YORK FROZEN
description: A judge in Manhattan has rejected arguments by Haiti's former President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, and his wife that their personal fortunes should be protected under a theory of international law from seizure by Haiti's new Government.

title: IN GREEN ON RED'S NEW 'KILLER,' A NOD TO FILM NOIR
description: GREEN ON RED, a rock quintet with Arizona roots, a Los Angeles home base and a dedicated European following, doesn't believe in ''the good old days,'' those legendary times when America was standing tall and everything worked the way it was supposed to.

title: U.S.-JAPAN TRADE TENSION MOUNTS
description: Against today's report of a growing trade deficit and new declines in the dollar, the Japanese-American hostility over trade seemed to intensify. Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said the two countries could be hurtling toward an accidental trade war, while a senior Japanese official said the trade deficit was America's problem, not Japan's.

title: Argentine Loan Accord
description: Argentina said today that its creditor banks had agreed to refinance a major portion of its $50 billion foreign debt and to provide about $1.8 billion in fresh funding.

title: ISLANDERS AVOID ELIMINATION
description: It was the narrowest of escapes, but the Islanders, using Capital Centre for their recovery room, survived to play another day.

title: CLUB CHIEF'S MURDER CASE NEAR CALIFORNIA JURY
description: The possibility that a jury could send a man to death only to learn later that his purported victim was alive was raised today in final arguments at the murder trial of Joe Hunt, leader of the Billionaire Boys Club, a group of young men from wealthy families.

title: MGM-UA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $1,185,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The company said the results are not directly comparable and there are no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company was a unit MGM-UA Entertainment Co. until June.

title: KEY RATES
TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suspended Professor Takes Post at Cornell
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran, who was suspended as a professor of theology from Catholic University of America for his dissent on sexual issues, will take a post as a visiting professor at Cornell University, the university said today.

title: AVERAGE SIZE OF HOUSEHOLD IN U.S. DECLINES TO LOWEST EVER RECORDED
description: The average number of people per household in the United States declined last year to 2.67, the least ever recorded, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: FILM: BECKETT AND BLIXEN
description: TO ask that a documentary capture the vision of a great writer is to ask too much.

title: Gypsum Offers 10-Year Notes
description: The National Gypsum Company is offering $300 million of 11 3/8 percent priority senior subordinated notes due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Purolator Nod To Emery Bid
description: The board of the Purolator Courier Corporation today recommended that company shares be tendered to the Emery Air Freight Corporation. Emery, based in Wilton, Conn., has offered to buy 6.3 million Purolator shares, or 83 percent of the company's stock, for $40 each in cash. It would purchase the remaining shares for 13 percent junior subordinated debentures with a face value of $40. The total value of the offer is about $306 million.

title: SILICON GRAPHICS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,262,000, or 9 cents a share, and $3,133,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $202,000, or 2 cents a share, and $304,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: PROSECUTION LAGS IN MARINE SPY CASE
description: The Marine Corps is having trouble gathering sufficient evidence to prosecute the two Marine guards accused of espionage at the United States embassy in Moscow, according to Administration officials.

title: Hart Discusses Rumor Sources
description: One day after opening a Democratic Presidential campaign that he said would highlight ideas and issues, former Senator Gary Hart moved on to more political matters today, saying he had heard that workers in other campaigns were spreading rumors about his personal life.

title: Mumtaz Nassar Dies at 72; Led the Egyptian Opposition
description: Mumtaz Nassar, member of the New Wafd Party and former leader of the opposition bloc in Parliament, died of kidney failure today, his party announced. He was 72 years old.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
THE RICH PROMISE OF RARE EARTHS
description: WHEN 3,000 physicists swarmed into the New York Hilton last month to hear about fast-breaking discoveries in superconductivity, Herman C. Mihalich was there, working the corridors and handing out his business card until the early hours of the next morning. Those physicists were the most tantalizing business opportunity he had seen in a long time.

title: Accounts
description: * Princess Tours, Seattle, to Tracy-Locke, Los Angeles.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THEATER: 'PRIME TIME'
description: ''PRIME TIME,'' the AMAS Repertory Theater's new musical production, is a contemporary parable of cultural assimilation told in the gee-whiz vocabulary of 1940's movie musicals.

title: Prime Computer's Two New Models
description: Prime Computer Inc. said it had introduced a more powerful minicomputer that executes 11.8 million instructions a second and can run applications previously used by mainframes and minicomputer networks. In addition to the new computer -the 6350 system - Prime showed its ''dual processor'' version, the 6550, which combines two processors in one computer. Prime said that both computers were compatible with its 50 Series systems and that users running software on any of these systems could transfer their applications to the new systems without modification.

title: WHEN THE DODGERS IGNORED ROBINSON
description: The reincarnation of Jackie Robinson resumes. Out on Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn at noon today, in front of the Ebbets Field apartments, the Brooklyn Dodgers Hall of Fame will honor baseball's first black major leaguer on the 40th anniversary of his first game. And on Friday a three-month exhibit of Jackie Robinson memorabilila will open at the New-York Historical Society at 170 Central Park West.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable May 4.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SABERS AND LASERS MEETING AT WEST POINT
description: The United States Military Academy, showing its age as the oldest of the service schools, has begun a $48.2 million renovation program to accommodate a new generation of technologically advanced officers.

title: Preserving and Maintaining Wetlands Is Critical for Staten Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Fordham to Pick Coach
description: Nick Macarchuk, a former assistant at Providence and the head basketball coach at Canisius for the last 10 years, is expected to be named head coach of Fordham today at a news conference that the school has scheduled.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When Telephone Solicitation Is the Best Way
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR A FESTIVE EASTER
description: 1.Nesting Eggs From Germany comes this trio of decorative hand-painted Easter eggs. The large egg opens, becoming a nest for the two smaller eggs. For $24 at Matt McGhee, 18 and 22 Christopher Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Waverly Place. 2.A Basketful of Treats What is Easter without a basket? The New-York Historical Society has a large selection, ranging in price from $10 to $150. The basket shown here, which costs $50, includes a stuffed rabbit, papier mache eggs, a glass paperweight in the shape of a rooster, a pewter bunny pin, a Beatrix Potter coloring book and more. In the Museum Store, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street. Telephone orders are accepted at 212-873-3400. 3.Flowery Bonnet A versatile straw bonnet can be worn not only on the holiday but through the spring and into the summer, in either the city or the country. This one, designed by Frank Olive, is decorated with a wide purple bow and a spray of lilacs. The bonnet costs $125 and can be found in accessories on the first floor at Bonwit Teller, 4 East 57th Street at Fifth Avenue. 4.Aerobic Bunny For children, or for parents who are kids at heart, here is the Easter bunny of the 1980's. It is dressed in up-to-the-minute aerobic attire, complete with leg warmers and a headband. The bunny is diminutive, measuring only six inches tall, and can be used as a doll or hung as a wall decoration. A ballerina bunny, complete with tutu, is also available. The price is $15 at Judy Corman, 198 Columbus Avenue, at 69th Street.

title: CONTEL SEEKS TO PULL OUT OF COMSAT MERGER DEAL
description: The Contel Corporation said today that it was seeking to end a proposed $2.4 billion merger with the Communications Satellite Corporation, known as Comsat.

title: U.S. LABOR OFFICIAL
description: Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics for the Department of Labor from 1946 to 1965, died of Alzheimer's disease Sunday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 90 years old and lived in Washington.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes securities gains of $4,175,000 and $15,411,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, and the latest quarter also includes an extraordinary loss of $1,893,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ORDER GIVEN IN CUSTODY CASE
description: The aunt and uncle of a 4-year-old girl whose father has been charged with trying to sell her were ordered today to surrender their passports to prevent them from fleeing the country to avoid a custody fight with the girl's stepmother.

title: TOXIC CHEMICAL SPILL IN UTAH CAUSES A DEATH AND 6 INJURIES
description: About 2,000 gallons of a toxic chemical spilled from a ruptured pipe today, killing one man, injuring six other people and forcing the evacuation of about 1,000 people from an industrial park here, officials said.

title: Northrop Net Climbs 3.3%
description: The Northrop Corporation's first-quarter profit grew 3.3 percent, to $40.6 million, or 87 cents a share, from $39.3 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 9 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.3 billion.

title: COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter figures are restated to reflect results of Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. under the equity method of accounting.

title: Japan to File a Protest to GATT on Tariffs by U.S
description: Japan formally warned the United States today that an imposition of American tariffs, expected to occur on Friday, would result in a Japanese protest to the international body that governs world trade.

title: CITIZENS BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $739,000.

title: HAGLER' STRATEGY NEVER MATERIALIZED
description: What happened to the game plan that Marvelous Marvin Hagler and his brain trust, Pat and Goody Petronelli, discussed through the long weeks of training leading up to the April 6 middleweight title fight against Sugar Ray Leonard?

title: People
description: * Michael D. Donahue, an executive vice president, was named executive management director at DFS Dorland/New York.

title: THE STAGE: 'DRIVING MISS DAISY'
description: IN ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' Alfred Uhry has taken familiar material - the growing friendship between a crotchety, aged Southern lady and her black chauffeur - and treated it with renewed sincerity. The play, which opened last night in the small studio theater at Playwrights Horizons, is enhanced by Dana Ivey and Morgan Freeman, character actors convincingly assuming the mantle of old age and offering twinned, revealing performances.

title: Group Head Retires At Morgan Stanley
description: Richard A. Debs, who initiated Morgan Stanley's international business arm 11 years ago, plans to retire June 30.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $32 million for the latest quarter and $15 million for the year-earlier period. The company said the 1986 share earnings are restated for 135 percent stock dividend in February 1987.

title: Two Get Immunity in Investigation of Iran Affair
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has granted immunity to the security chief and a former accounting officer of a company linked to Gen. Richard V. Secord and others in the case, their lawyer said today.

title: Loss Reported By Caterpillar
description: Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of earth-moving machines, said today that it lost $84 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $111 million, or $1.13 a share, a year ago.

title: THE POLLARD AFFAIR: SPEAKING FRANKLY
description: Mark Saltzman is a 35-year-old New York songwriter who always considered himself Jewish, but needed a trip to Israel to establish that identity ''beyond maztoh ball soup and even beyond religion.'' Philip Heimowitz, a Wall Street lawyer, has been secure in his Orthodox Judaism all his life.

title: NEWMARK & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Howser Is Honored
description: The Florida Legislature voted unanimously yesterday to rename the baseball stadium at Florida State in honor of its most famous baseball alumnus, Dick Howser, former manager of the Kansas City Royals. Gov. Bob Martinez has said he would sign the bill. The 50-year-old Howser, ill with brain cancer, stepped down from his manager's post in February. He was the Seminoles' first all-America baseball player, in 1957.

title: Withdrawal Asked In Bid for Symbion
description: Dr. Robert K. Jarvik, chairman and chief executive of Symbion Inc., said that the takeover bid by E. M. Warburg Pincus & Company, an investment firm, should be withdrawn. Dr. Jarvik, the designer of the Jarvik-7 artificial heart, which was made by Symbion, is at odds with the Symbion board, which said yesterday that it would remain neutral toward the Warburg Pincus offer for $3.50 a share, or $8.75 million.

title: DESPITE ACCORD ON DEBT, MANILA SEEKS RATE CUT
description: In an unexpected setback for the global debt situation, the Philippines said yesterday that it would seek to renegotiate its recently completed debt restructuring accord in an effort to obtain the same favorable interest rate won by Mexico and Argentina.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sales of securities of $2,540,000. c-Includes gains of $612,000.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: In the latest quarter, income before expenses for acquisition of United Bank, Tacoma, was $17,882,000, or 81 cents per share. Results for both periods have been restated to reflect the United Bank acquisition acccounted for on a pooling- of-interests basis.

title: Tornado Kills Florida Woman
description: A tornado ripped a mobile home from its foundation here today, fatally injuring the owner who was tossed 50 yards into a field. Seven other people were injured. The victim, Charlotte Staples, 68 years old, died about three hours after the tornado struck, officials said. Tornadoes hit two other parts of Lake County and the Bevilles Corner area of neighboring Sumter County around 11 A.M. today, but no injuries were reported there.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: I THINK that Henry VIII had at least one happy marriage. It was to Catherine Parr, and it may have been that at the age of 52 he was at last adult enough to marry. He also married a woman who was better educated and more intelligent than his former wives, so that at last he had somebody to talk to who didn't bore him.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A. T. Brod & Co., an investment banking firm, announced the election of Michael L. Brod as president and chief operating officer. He replaces Albert T. Brod, who remains chairman and chief executive. Berkey Inc., White Plains, a photographic chemicals and processing concern, announced that Jonathan Taplin had replaced A. Michael Victory as chairman. Mr. Victory remains a director of the corporation.

title: GENMAR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRSTFED AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted to stock ownership last December.

title: Guilty Plea by Jefferies Seen
description: Boyd L. Jefferies, who earlier settled civil charges that he participated in an illegal stock ''parking'' scheme and manipulated the price of a stock, will plead guilty today to two felony charges, according to court documents and his lawyer.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PARKER HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reduced by 2 cents a share as the net effect of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, and by another 2 cents a share for the cost of implementing early retirement pension benefits. c-Reduced by 3 cents a share by the tax reform act and by another 3 cents a share from premium payments to redeem all outstanding 11.75 percent notes, and also includes gains of 11 cents a share for the sale of the EIS brake parts division, dispositions of real estate and the settlement of a previous interest in a joint venture.

title: The Perfect Candidate
description: You'd think, with a dozen candidates in the Presidential field and a half-dozen more getting the uncontrollable itch to drop their coyness, a voter would have a good shot at finding one that fits.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AFTER HU, CHINA'S RELATIONS WITH JAPAN MAY BE COOLING
description: Relations between China and Japan have cooled in the last few months, partly because of the resignation of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader in January, Japanese and Western diplomats and business executives say.

title: BOOKS THAT CAN INSPIRE AND INSTRUCT
description: GARDENING books are variously constructed. Some are meant to instruct, explain and explore; some philosophize, reflect and theorize, and in some the text is mainly meant to accompany pretty pictures. Whatever their purpose, most books about gardening openly address a captive audience, that indefinite, unspecified ''you'' to whom author and publisher make grandly optimistic promises.

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $443,000.

title: GENERAL CERAMICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL IS INDICTED
description: The former chief of staff at the Department of Health and Human Services was indicted today for mail fraud, lying and engaging in a conflict of interest by using his official position to promote a company in which he was a director.

title: San Miguel To Sell Stake
description: The San Miguel Corporation said today that it had accepted a bid from Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia for 13.9 percent of its shares.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TALK BY SHULTZ
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference today in Moscow, as recorded by Federal News Service: * * *

title: Sharing the Burden Of Latin Debt
description: Puerto Rico is America's vantage point for the Caribbean and Latin America, a bridge between North and South. We would therefore be remiss if we failed to warn Washington that democracy in Latin America could be in grave danger if the debt problem is not brought under control.

title: THIS TREE USED TO GROW IN NEW JERSEY
description: LEAD: CARL TORSILIERI'S specialty is moving big trees.

title: DOME SPURS CANADIAN DEBATE
description: By unleashing a scramble for the assets of financially crippled Dome Petroleum Ltd., TransCanada PipeLines Ltd. appears to have set the stage for a new round in Canada's debate about foreign ownership of its major industries.

title: Nippon, Calgene Plan Vegetable Oil
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation said it had entered a multiyear agreement with Calgene Inc. of Davis, Calif., to jointly develop a vegetable oil with industrial applications, including steelmaking. Calgene specializes in the application of recombinant DNA technology to plants. A Nippon Steel executive said the company would invest more than $1 million and send researchers to California, but did not provide further details.

title: Private Is Charged in Death Of Another Soldier at Ft. Dix
description: A 17-year-old soldier was charged today in the strangulation of a another private whose beaten body was found in a burning trash bin here, Army officials said.

title: Qaddafi A Fizzler By Satellite
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was supposed to appear at a rally here Tuesday night by way of a sort of electronic magic carpet from Libya, and, as one adherent put it, ''look right in the window of the White House,'' with perhaps a few choice words for President Reagan himself.

title: 'MOYERS: IN SEARCH OF CONSTITUTION'
description: PREPARE now for 10 hours of talk, some of it rich, some of it maddening, but very little of it irrelevant. It is ''Moyers: In Search of the Constitution,'' which begins tonight on Channel 31 at 8 and Channel 13 at 9 o'clock. In the opening episode, Bill Moyers talks with three scholars in Independence Hall in Philadelphia, where the Constitution was drafted 200 years ago. Do not be put off by the word ''scholars.'' There is no academic dust.

title: BIDEN REPORTS $1.7 MILLION RAISED IN BID FOR DEMOCRATIC NOMINATION
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware announced today that it had raised $1.7 million in 27 days.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter figures include loan losses charged to income of $5.6 million, an increase of $1.4 million from the year-ago period.

title: Clemens's Figures
description: If Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox repeat their 1986 success, Clemens could be in line for a 1987 income of $1,075,000 and a 1988 salary of $1.4 million. Whatever they do, though, he will receive a guaranteed $1.7 million in salaries for the next two seasons.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $3,300,000, or 13 cents a share, related to hedging losses.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
FOE OF APARTHEID URGING DEFIANCE
description: A leading foe of apartheid, speaking at a rally that the police had sought to ban, called tonight for mass defiance of new Government restrictions on protest.

title: REQUEST FOR HINCKLEY LEAVE WITHDRAWN
description: The Federal mental hospital where John W. Hinckley Jr. is a patient today withdrew its recommendation that he be permitted an unescorted visit to his family for Easter. The hospital said it needed to assess the ''clinical significance'' of Mr. Hinckley's correspondence and other materials that it had not examined before.

title: Bernard Jankelson, 84, Dies; Expert on Jaw Malfunctions
description: Dr. Bernard Jankelson, a dentist and a pioneer researcher in cranio-mandibular orthopedics and the study of head pain traceable to jaw malfunction, died here Monday. He was 84 years old.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN BIONETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MOUNDS OF GARBAGE SIGNAL LANDFILL CRISIS IN JERSEY
description: A tidy pile of garbage bags outside the Hunterdon County offices here serves as an unnecessary reminder to county officials throughout northern New Jersey that they are running out of places to put their trash.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Masterly Writing

title: NEW SEASON FOR CARNEGIE AND NEW SOUND FOR WEILL
description: Carnegie Hall announced yesterday a 1987-88 season that will bring the German baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau to New York for the first time in eight years. Mr. Fischer-Dieskau will give three lieder recitals next March with all-Schubert, all-Brahms and all-Wolf programs.

title: CENTURY COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $150,000. The company said in the year-ago third quarter preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. The company also said the decrease in earnings for the latest quarter is due to an increase in non-cash expenses of depreciation and amortization connected to Cable Television Systems acquisitions in the period.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $440,000 and $627,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FINDING TREASURES IN COMMERCIAL TABLEWARE ON THE BOWERY
description: FOR those who like durable, moderately priced china and glassware, and who also like to entertain, the restaurant equipment shops dotting the Bowery from Canal Street north to Bleecker Street are a resource to be treasured.

title: KEY RATES
OUTDOOR FURNITURE: TO REFINISH OR NOT?
description: LEAD: NO matter what wood is used to make outdoor furniture - and it can be teak, the most desirable, as well as such woods as the ever-popular whitewood coated with a redwood finish - it will probably survive without attention for as many years as you are prepared to put up with it. The durability will depend mostly on the sturdiness of the component parts.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NATIONAL COMMERCE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Their Spies, Our Spies
description: The Russians spy on us and we spy on the Russians. Win some, lose some and why all the fuss when they win one, as in the American Embassy in Moscow? Actually, except for the marines, it is rather funny and just goes to show that the two superpowers are a lot alike when you get down to it.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Placed Don Aase, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list with tendinitis in his right shoulder. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Placed Rich Gossage, relief pitcher, and Stan Jefferson, outfielder, on the disabled list. Jefferson, with a badly swollen left ankle, was put on the 21-day disabled list. He was replaced on the roster by Luis Salazar, who was signed as a free agent April 2 after his release by the White Sox. Gossage was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a pull in his rib cage. ANKEES (AL) - Optioned Bob Tewksbury, pitcher, to Columbus of the International League. Activated Tim Stoddard, pitcher. BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Announced that Kenny Carr, forward, will miss the rest of the season with recurrence of the back pain that had sidelined him for two months this season. FOOTBALL CINCINNATI (AFC) - Waived Bobby Kemp, strong safety. DALLAS (NFC) - Waived Rafael Septien, place-kicker, who admitted to indecency with a child and was placed on probation last week. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Signed Tony Champion, wide receiver, to a three-year contract. COLLEGE FORDHAM - Named Nick Macarchuk head basketball coach. GEORGIA TECH - Announced that Pat Turner, quarterback, has withdrawn from school. MANCHESTER - Named Pat Cunningham head basketball coach.

title: MUSIC: HORST RICKEL PIECES
description: HORST RICKEL'S Sunday-evening program of original compositions at Roulette, entitled ''The Five Winds,'' was alternately frustrating and fascinating. Mostly frustrating as sheer music - an audience listening to Mr. Rickel's determinedly sparse sounds (mostly long drones, rattles, snorts and whistles) at home, on a radio or recording, with no visual counterpart, would have found little to engage the attention.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter results included Technical Publishing, which was sold in October 1986.

title: Dokes Is Jailed
description: Michael Dokes, the former heavyweight champion, remained jailed without bail following his arrest in Las Vegas, Nev., on drug and probation violation charges. Dokes, who was sentenced to five years' probation in February after pleading guilty to possessing cocaine, was arrested Monday after police noticed his car speeding as it swerved down a street. He was booked into the Clark County Detention Center on charges of driving while under the influence of a controlled substance, being under the influence of a controlled substance and probation violation.

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and 9 months results are restated.

title: George W. Kennedy, 96, Dies; Pioneer Maker of Car Parts
description: George W. Kennedy, retired president and chairman of the Kelsey-Hayes Company in Romulus, Mich., an early manufacturer of wheels and brake components for automobiles, died Sunday at his home in Del Ray Beach, Fla. He was 96 years old.

title: Swiss Aid VW In Fraud Case
description: Swiss investigators said today that they had seized documents in connection with a suspected currency fraud that cost Volkswagenwerk A.G., the West German auto maker, as much as $260 million. VW has said computer programs were erased and documents faked.

title: FEW BLACKS REACH LOCAL FRONT OFFICES
description: The furor arising from the remarks made last week by a Los Angeles Dodger executive, Al Campanis, concerning the scarcity of black executives in professional sports has caused the baseball, football and basketball leagues and their franchises to come under close scrutiny for their minority hiring practices.

title: Rams Name Macarchuk
description: Fordham took a step toward rebuilding its basketball program yesterday by signing the former Canisius coach, Nick Macarchuk, to a five-year contract. Sources close to the program said the agreement would make the 45-year-old Connecticut native the highest-paid coach in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

title: Roster Limit Upheld
description: An arbitrator upheld baseball's 24-player roster yesterday, ruling that major league teams were within their rights to cut back their rosters from 25 players.

title: In South Bronx, A Park's Name Splits Community
description: Neither side was willing to budge, and the impassioned debate raging in the South Bronx reflected fundamental divisions and conflicting loyalties that even pitted brother against brother.

title: VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INLAND STEEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: EUROPEANS WORRY THE DOLLAR'S FALL WILL SLOW GROWTH
description: The falling dollar is taking Western Europe's export-driven economies with it.

title: ONE-NIGHT ENCORE FOR 'THIS IS YOUR LIFE'
description: He surprised people on the street, in restaurants and nightclubs, even on other people's television shows. When he had trapped his unsuspecting victim, he pulled out a scrapbook and exclaimed, ''Tonight, this is your life!'' Those words will be uttered again Sunday when Ralph Edwards acts as host to a new installment of ''This Is Your Life,'' at 10 P.M. on NBC.

title: BLINDS: WOOD FOR WARMTH
description: ''WOODEN Venetian blinds are getting more and more popular,'' said Virginia Conn of the Manhattan Shade and Glass Company, a 66-year-old institution that Ms. Conn called ''a neighborhood store on the Upper East Side.'' Why the renewed interest? ''Because they have a finished and sturdy look,'' she said. ''It's a reaction against Eurostyle, that cold plastic and metal look.''

title: U.S. JUDGE OVERTURNS LAW ON FAMILY LIFE PROGRAM
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that key provisions of a 1981 law designed to discourage adolescent sexual activity were unconstitutional because they violated the requirement for separation of church and state.

title: CBS NET NEARLY TRIPLES
description: Buoyed by the strong performance of its record division and reduced interest expenses, CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its net income nearly tripled in the first quarter.

title: Why Fewer Blacks Are Becoming Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bit Too Shady
description: Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears, who already have Jim McMahon, explaining the team's professed lack of interest in Brian Bosworth: ''There wouldn't be enough sunglasses to go around.''

title: Broad Rise For Yields
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money-market accounts and money-market mutual funds all rose for the week ended yesterday.

title: CUOMO SEEKING FORDHAM DEAN FOR ETHICS PANEL
description: Governor Cuomo hopes to name the dean of the Fordham University School of Law to replace Joseph A. Califano Jr. as head of a commission to investigate possible unethical conduct in government, aides to the Governor said tonight.

description: After nine weeks of bitter courtroom drama, a Federal jury found yesterday that The Daily News racially discriminated against four of the newspaper's black editorial employees between 1979 and 1982.

title: SHULTZ CALLS PACT ON MID-RANGE ARMS IN EUROPE POSSIBLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a treaty eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe was within reach, despite continued differences over how to verify an accord and what limits to set on short-range missiles.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN INSTRUMENTAL WORLD, MODERN IS ALSO ANTIQUE
description: THE early-instrument movement proceeds apace, the pace being that of a small hurricane. We are now at the point of having not just original-instrument recordings of Beethoven symphonies, but competing recordings of the whole Beethoven cycles undertaken by the top-dollar record companies. Original-instrument Berlioz is on the way. At this rate, Verdi and Brahms will have been taken in stride by the turn of the millennium.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indiana Utility Rating Raised
description: The rating on $1.1 billion of the Public Service Company of Indiana's outstanding debt has been raised from speculative grade to investment grade, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

description: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $125 million of 9 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2017 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The bonds are nonrefundable for five years and yield about 1.28 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury issue due in 2016. The bonds are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poors Corporation.

description: In a move that could worsen the political crisis faced by the Government of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, Japan's governing party today forced a crucial budget bill through a parliamentary committee. It was a rare show of force in a society that usually seeks rule by consensus.

KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HART VOWS JOBS FOR STEELWORKERS BUT OPPOSES 'PROTECTIONIST WALLS'
description: In the shadow of a mammoth, idled steel mill, Gary Hart evoked some of his party's classic themes today and promised to put the steel mills back to work. But he asserted that ''protectionist walls'' were not the way to do it.

title: AIDS MAY BE ACTIVATED BY INFECTIONS
description: AIDS viruses lying dormant in human cells can probably be activated by any of a wide variety of other infections, some of them minor, scientists reported yesterday.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said an $8 million pre- tax reduction in fee income was recognized in the latest quarter to conform with the terms of the February 1987 memorandum of understanding between the company and NASA relating to the modification of the solid rocket motor contract.

description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $27,622,000 and a tax credit of $8,466,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $9,737,000.

title: BRAZILIANS AND CUBANS: AN UNLIKELY COURTSHIP
description: It has been described here as a mid-life romance in which the interest of the richer and more glamorous partner may well fade, but in recent months Brazil and Cuba appeared to be rapt in an intensive honeymoon.

title: Apple Net Up 6.6%
description: Apple Computer Inc., aided by the strong sales of its new Macintosh SE computer, recorded surprisingly high sales and earnings in its second fiscal quarter ended March 27.

title: THREE (OR MORE) FOR THE MAJORS
description: When Jim Paciorek hooked on with Milwaukee as a utility man this season, his family became the 16th that has sent at least three brothers to baseball's major leagues. The players, listed alphabetically, and the span from the time one brother broke in until the last retired: ALLEN - Dick, Hank, Ron, 1963-77. ALOU - Felipe, Jesus, Matty, 1958-79. BOYER - Clete, Cloyd, Ken, 1949-71. CLARKSON - Dad, John, Walter, 1882-96. CROSS - Amos, Frank, Lave, 1885-1907. CRUZ - Hector, Jose, Tommy, 1970-present. DELAHANTY - Ed, Frank, Jim, Joe, Tom, 1888-1915. DiMAGGIO - Dom, Joe, Vince, 1936-53. HIGH - Andy, Charlie, Hugh, 1913-34. MANSELL - John, Mike, Tom, 1879-84. O'NEILL - Jack, Jim, Mike, Steve, 1901-28. PACIOREK - Jim, John, Tom, 1963-present. SADOWSKI - Bob, Eddie, Ted, 1960-66. SEWELL - Joe, Luke, Tommy, 1920-42. SOWDERS - Bill, John, Len, 1886-90. WRIGHT - George, Harry, Sam, 1876-82.

description: Manager John Felske of the Philadelphia Phillies, who smashed his office furniture Tuesday night, called a clubhouse meeting tonight to find out why the Phillies had lost six of their first seven games. He apparently didn't find out.

description: To the Editor:

title: Barry Goldwater in Hospital
description: Former Senator Barry Goldwater was admitted to a hospital here, but a spokesman said Mr. Goldwater had asked that no information be released. Last week, Mr. Goldwater told a Kingman, Ariz., high school student who had invited him to a May 23 graduation that he would be unable to attend because he was having knee surgery. A former Goldwater aide, Doris Berry, said the surgery was necessary because of a knee injury Mr. Goldwater had suffered as a college football player.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for 13wks to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 6.

title: FOR A NEW LOS ANGELES STYLE, A PLACE IN THE SUN
description: THE guests at the recent opening of a new Los Angeles restaurant called Kate Mantilini thought they had come for the food, but many simply abandoned their chicken potpies and grilled swordfish and strolled around, wine in hand. First they gazed up at a huge metal ''sundial'' apparatus suspended like a centerpiece beneath the skylight, and then they walked over to a long, gently bowed mural of a boxing match. Fragments of the mural were scattered around the room on walls that were themselves broken into intricately layered sections, as though a Cubist painting had been turned into architecture.

title: NAVY SECRETARY REINSTATES OFFICER PROMOTIONS
description: For the second time since taking office on Friday, Navy Secretary James H. Webb Jr. has overturned one of his predecessor's decisions, this time by reinstating a list of officers who were recommended for promotion to the rank of captain, the Navy said today.

title: Trial Testimony Ends In 3 Deaths on Film Set
description: Both sides in the manslaughter trial that stemmed from the deaths of three people on the ''Twilight Zone'' movie set rested their cases today, the 100th day of testimony, and the judge ordered jurors to return Monday to hear final arguments.

title: Coca-Cola Posted Rise In First-Quarter Profits
description: The Coca-Cola Company, whose big worldwide soft-drink operations make it a leading beneficiary of the declining dollar, said today that its first-quarter profits rose 15 percent.

title: Italy Turns to Fanfani To Form Government
description: Italy's President asked former Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani to form a Government today, and the move was expected to lead to early elections in June.

title: BREWERS' NIEVES HURLS NO-HITTER
description: Juan Nieves said he had a ''mediocre fastball and awful slider,'' but his pitching tonight was good enough to record the first no-hitter in Milwaukee Brewers history.

title: Technologies' Net Falls 23%
description: The United Technologies Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit had fallen 23 percent, to $98.2 million, in spite of a 13.9 percent increase in revenue.

USE OF AN AIDS VIRUS DRUG CURBED ON THE BASIS OF DATA
description: The Food and Drug Administration has told a California pharmaceutical company that there is not yet enough evidence to justify more widespread use of its antiviral drug ribavirin to treat patients with early symptoms of infection with the AIDS virus.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Mecir Advances: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, playing his first match 24 hours after his arrival in Tokyo, trounced Tsuyoshi Fukui, Japan's No. 1 player, 7-5, 6-1 yesterday to advance to the third round of the $605,000 Japan Open tournament. In another men's match, Ramesh Krishnan of India, seeded 11th, defeated Ben Testerman, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4. In the women's singles second round, Melissa Gurney, seeded first, beat Lea Antonoplis, 6-1, 6-2. Gourney will meet Etsuko Inoue in the quarterfinals. Inoue beat Akiko Kijimuta by 6-1, 6-2. (AP) Fast Work for Carlsson: After playing for over two hours late the evening before, Kent Carlsson of Sweden, the top-seeded player, needed just 15 minutes to finish his victory over Jim Pugh, 2-6, 6-4, 9-7, completing the first round of the $104,900 Nice Grand Prix tournament in Nice, France. The Carlsson-Pugh match had been suspended because of darkness. Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union upset Tarek Benhabiles of France, the sixth-seeded player, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2 to reach the quarterfinals. Joining Chesnokov is Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia, whose second straight match was cut short when his opponent, Diego Perez of Uruguay strained ligaments in his right ankle after he won the first set, 6-4. Perez must wear a cast for six weeks. (AP) Graf in Quarterfinals: Top-seeded Steffi Graf needed only 41 minutes to defeat Bettina Fulco of Argentina, 6-0, 6-1, last night to earn a quarterfinal berth in the Women's International Tennis Association Championships at Amelia Island, Fla. Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, seeded seventh, defeated Hellas ter Riet of the Netherlands, 1-6, 6-1, 6-1. (AP) BOXING Black Outpoints Reyes: Michael Black of Las Vegas and Sergio Reyes of Fort Worth each scored second-round decisions last night to lead 51 fighters into the quarterfinals of the National Golden Gloves tournament at Knoxville, Tenn. Black, fighting in the 132-pound division, was way ahead when his opponent, Cisharles James of the Des Moines team, twisted his knee and the referee stopped the fight at 1:43 of the second of three scheduled rounds. Reyes stopped Mark Morgan of the Hutchison, Kan., team 58 seconds into the second round with a series of combinations to Morgan's head. (AP) DIVING Louganis Qualifies: Greg Louganis, a two-time Olympic gold medalist who holds 41 world diving titles, qualified first yesterday with 593.37 points in the semifinals of the United States indoor diving championships at Baton Rouge, La. (AP) N.B.A. Bullets 110, Cavaliers 101: Terry Catledge scored 14 of his 22 points in the second half last night at Landover, Md., helping Washington hold off Cleveland and giving the Bullets a one-game lead over Chicago in the battle for sixth place in the Eastern Conference. Moses Malone led Washington with 30 points. (AP)

description: CARRYING an acoustic guitar, wearing a black T-shirt, the singer came on stage Tuesday night at Town Hall to a rapturous ovation; he opened with a song about an ''ordinary man,'' a factory worker facing unemployment. No, it wasn't Bruce Springsteen; it was the Irish singer Christy Moore. But like Mr. Springsteen, and like Mr. Springsteen's idol Woody Guthrie, Mr. Moore sings heartfelt, plain-spoken, politically charged songs that bring audiences to their feet.

Jefferson, who was hitting .286, was placed on the 21-day disabled list with a badly swollen left ankle. He was replaced by Luis Salazar, who was signed as a free agent in April. Gossage, who was placed on the 15-day disabled list, has not pitched this season. He is troubled by a pull in his rib cage. Gossage was replaced by Greg Booker, a relief pitcher, who had been on the 15-day disabled list.

title: YOUTHS' GOAL: CORNER OFFICE
description: A poll of teen-agers indicates that they would rather be presidents of companies than President of the United States. More than half said they would like to become entertainers.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The paint is peeling off two of my bathroom walls down to the original plaster (the walls are solid, not plasterboard). These walls contain no pipes, and have had only four or five coats of paint. The exposed plaster is powdery. What is causing this problem? Can it be stopped ? A.It sounds as if there may be a problem with the plaster. If bare plaster is powdery, something is wrong with it and it won't hold paint for long. You can try taking all the paint off those walls, using a nonflammable semipaste remover; wash with detergent and let dry completely. Apply an alkyd-base primer-sealer and let dry several days. The primer should form a smooth, relatively hard film that won't come off when you rub it hard with a cloth.

title: PANEL SAYS ST GERMAIN DID NOT ABUSE POSITION
description: Citing evidence of only minor infractions, the House ethics committee today unanimously cleared Representative Fernand J. St Germain of charges that he used his influence to amass a personal fortune.

title: Different Rat Race
description: Frank McConville, a 23-year-old securities trader, and Gillian Horovitz, a 31-year-old bookkeeper, won the first Wall Street Rat Race as they and 938 others scampered over a two-and-a-half mile course through the financial district wearing business suits and carrying brief cases. McConville won the men's division in 11 minutes 31 seconds. Horovitz won the women's division, in 13 minutes flat. The race, designed to commemorate the income-tax filing deadline, began and ended at the South Street Seaport.

title: Behind the Smoke, an Arms Deal
description: The vacillation had to perplex expert and casual observers alike. First, the United States childishly bewailed Soviet spying. Moscow followed with silly complaints about American policy toward Afghanistan. On Monday, Tass reported Mikhail Gorbachev's unhappiness about Secretary of State Shultz's reaction to his new proposal on medium-range missiles. On Tuesday, Mr. Shultz proclaimed agreement to be ''close-to-hand.''

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY: TRIBUTE: FORGING OF THE CONSTITUTION
description: There were pounding drums and lilting fifes. There was the raising of a 13-star American flag by a Marine color guard. The scene at the New York Public Library yesterday morning was so patriotic that even the lions wore tricornered hats of the Revolutionary era.

title: STAGE: 'SLEEPLESS CITY' AT LA MAMA
description: IN a city whose dictator (the Organizer) has decreed general insomnia, people live nightmares and hallucinate realities - arresting police officers, men climbing trees among fiery birds, eyes of spies under the floor. Jean Tardieu, a French poet, has created, in ''The Sleepless City,'' a musical, poetic, balletic meditation on illusion which, in the performance under Francoise Kourilsky's direction at La Mama, is a two-hour trance from which we emerge shaken awake, longing to dream again.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NEW wood glues and ''all-purpose adhesives'' have revolutionized bonding and repairing techniques. These glues and adhesives - the words are now used almost interchangeably - are easy to use and make it possible to join materials that once were almost impossible to bond.

title: On Fixing Constitution And Spilling Gravy All Over the Preamble
description: Warren E. Burger retired last year as Chief Justice of the United States to devote full time to his chairmanship of the commission that is leading the celebration of the bicentennial of the Constitution. He still retains chambers at the Supreme Court, and the other day he paused while working there to discuss the accomplishments and frustrations of the bicentennial effort thus far and to look back on some of his years on the Court. Q: Do you miss not being on the Court? A: I don't believe in the carry-off theory, that you stay there until you're carried off. Q:fe,r10: But you were Chief Justice a long time. A: Yes, for 17 1/2 years, which is longer than anybody in the 20th century had served. It might be different if I had simply moved into this grand office here and had nothing to do, but I'm busier than I have ever been in my life. Q: No regrets? A: No regrets whatever. There is a need to fill the gap that's resulted from our - I mean all of us - having taken this Constitution for granted. That includes lawyers as well as nonlawyers. I was in very, very active practice in the private sector for 21 years and I had just one constitutional case in all that time when I represented a young Negro who was head of the Young Communist League and I was volunteer counsel. He was in court because he was arrested and improperly persuaded to enter a guilty plea to a charge of indecent exposure, and he had ineffective assistance of counsel. This was an offense for which normally you would get a slap on the wrist and a $50 fine and a 10-day suspended sentence, and as I recall this, he got 364 days. A group of us from the big law firms formed a little committee and included the legal counsel of the electrical workers union. That was a divided group. And we got it reversed in the Supreme Court. Now the ordinary affairs of life don't bring constitutional questions, so we've all taken it for granted too much. Now we are going to try to break through that. Q: Speaking of a Constitution that is now 200 years old. Some people would like to amend it. But you have said that a new constitutional convention to consider new amendments would not be a very good idea. Why? A: It would be a grand waste of time. If you have a tire go flat on your car, you don't throw the car away. If your carburetor isn't working, if it's too lean, you don't throw the car away. You fix it. Q: And this car is pretty good after 200 years? A: For 200 years this car has not been just pretty good. It is not perfect, as Franklin said, but the best thing of its kind that was ever put together. Here these extraordinary guys took and did the impossible, and it has worked. Q. Getting back to the celebration and the many events planned, what are the plans so far for a session of Congress and a session of the Supreme Court in Philadelphia? There seems to be some confusion about that. A. I don't think there is any session of Congress in Philadelphia. And there has been something amounting almost to misrepresentation about the Court's position.

title: LONDON DISPLAY EVOKES 1800'S ELEGANCE
description: When it was carved in Vienna nearly 140 years ago, the enormous Gothic bookcase was described as ''a cathedral in wood, massive, bold and well adapted to a palace.'' Appropriately enough, it was presented to Queen Victoria by Emperor Franz Josef of Austria. But before that, the bookcase, adorned with spires and figures of angels, was displayed in London at the Great Exhibition of 1851. It is now on view once again, in the Victoria and Albert Museum's new gallery, ''Art and Design in Europe and America, 1800 to 1900.''

title: CONSERVATORS ENDORSE SISTINE RESTORATION

After a visit to Rome at the invitation of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, the group reported yesterday that ''the new freshness of the colors and the clarity of the forms on the Sistine ceiling are totally in keeping with 16th-century Italian painting and affirm the full majesty and splendor of Michelangelo's creation.''

description: THE highlight of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Sunday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was a propulsive, streamlined performance of Arnold Schoenberg's ''Kammersymphonie'' for 15 solo instruments (Op. 9), conducted by Gervase de Peyer. This is music at the threshold of atonality, full of chromatic tension, yet its gestures and rhetoric remain fully grounded in Brahms and the 19th century. One noticed a slight, timid, exodus from the auditorium before the work began, but those who stayed were rewarded by an excellent performance, and the house rang with bravos.

''When I don't pitch as well,'' Tewksbury said as he stood in front of the space in the Yankee clubhouse that belonged to him until late yesterday afternoon, ''I go over a few things, but I try to forget it as fast as I can.''

His stay there, he said, ''showed me a lot of things in my life that went wrong.''

title: DESIGNERS' WARES FOR FLAIR AT THE TABLE
description: THE interior designers Bob Patino, near left, and Vicente Wolf have designed their first collection of china, glass and flatware for Sasaki. ''We often found that clients didn't want traditional floral-patterned bone china,'' Mr. Patino said. The designers like the idea of having mismatched dishes and flatware for an eclectic, rather than a homogeneous, look. For the sandblasted glass Candice candlestick holder, far left, they wanted a hard material to look soft and fluid, so they devised a draped effect. Nine inches high, the piece costs $125. Mr. Patino and Mr. Wolf live in an apartment whose windows are laid out in grids, and that gave them the idea of the Windows flatware, below, with open, not solid, handles. A five-piece place setting is $75 in plain stainless steel, $100 with a matte black finish. Looking at Vincent Palladini's collages of layers of different-sized grids, the designers developed their Gridlock Black dinner plate, the dark one at bottom left. The plate is sold only as part of a 20-piece package containing four five-piece place settings ($150). The Low-Keyed Gold pattern, which seems to be cracked, is a joke. ''We wanted a plate to look broken,'' Mr. Patino said. A 20-piece package is $200. All are at Bloomingdale's and its branches.

title: NEW BRONX CHIEF HOPES TO RESTORE 'FAITH': FERNANDO FERRER
description: In his first minutes on the job as the new Bronx Borough President yesterday, Fernando Ferrer delivered a ringing speech facing up to what everyone knew: the Bronx is in serious trouble.

title: Officer Struck by Object
description: A uniformed police officer on anti-drug patrol in the Bronx was struck in the head by a brick or rock apparently thrown from the roof of a building near her post yesterday, the police said. The officer, Victoria Mills, 23 years old, was conscious and in serious but stable condition at Jacobi Hospital after the incident, which occurred at about 2 P.M. at Prospect Avenue and East 178th Street in the East Tremont sectiom, the police said.

title: Bridge: New Book on Falsecards Gives Unexpected Advice
