title: PFIZER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today: April 16, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 16, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. economy is showing signs of fragility, after performing better than expected in the first few months of 1987. The Goverment reported that industrial output in March fell 0.3 percent, its biggest drop in 10 months, and that retail sales rose a paltry 0.2 percent. Most private analysts are expressing increasing fears about a financial and political climate that they believe could eventually tip the world economy into recession. Their concerns include the dollar's decline, the American trade and budget deficits, trade disputes and inflation. [ Page D1. ] Secretary Baker said Japan had reached a ''watershed'' in its relations with Washington. In a speech to the Japan Society, he criticized Tokyo for maintaining policies that contributed to the dollar's decline. [ D1. ] Japan formally warned the U.S. that an imposition of American tariffs, expected tomorrow, would result in a Japanese protest to GATT. [ D8. ] The dollar rebounded slightly after a six-day drubbing, lifted by the same kind of comments from prominent officials that had contributed to its fall. In New York, gold dropped $8.50, to $442.50. [ D20. ] Western Europe's export-driven economies are being hurt by the dollar's drop. Auto, oil, chemical and machinery companies have been affected, and many top exporters warn that the worst is yet to come. [ A1. ] Some Japanese experts voiced deep concern that a continued decline of the dollar could harm both the Japanese and American economies. [ D14. ] A variety of American companies are finally reporting an upturn in exports, 19 months after the U.S. and several allies acted to lower the dollar's value. [ D14. ] A House panel cleared Representative St Germain of allegations that he used his influence to amass a personal fortune. The House ethics committee's 1,405-page report showed only minor transgressions of House rules by the Rhode Island Democrat. [ D5. ] A New York State law that curbs hostile takeovers initially cost shareholders at least $1.2 billion, a Federal study concludes. [ D15. ] MARKETS Stock prices recovered in brisk trading on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 29.97 points, to 2,282.95, after giving up 86 points in the preceding two sessions. A firmer credit market helped the stock market. [ D1. ] The Treasury bond market began to recover, encouraged by a modest rise in the dollar, weak economic data and the belief that bond prices had declined too far, too fast. [ D18. ] Yields on C.D.'s, bank money-market accounts and money-market mutual funds all rose for the recent week. [ D19. ] Energy futures advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange after an industry report showed lower inventories. [ D20. ] INTERNATIONAL The Philippines dealt a setback to the global debt situation. It is seeking to renegotiate its debt restructuring accord to obtain the same favorable interest rate won by Mexico and Argentina. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Earnings rose 25.7 percent at A.T.& T., thanks in part to cost cutting, but analysts said the company had yet to overcome many of the problems that have caused disappointing results since the 1984 divestiture. Nynex and Ameritech earnings were flat. [ D1. ] Digital Equipment rose 81 percent, while Apple climbed 6 percent. [ D4. ] CBS profits nearly tripled because of a strong performance at the company's record unit and reduced interest expense. But the broadcasting unit's performance remained lackluster. [ D1. ] Earnings rose at two banking companies, Continental Illinois and Security Pacific, while First City Bancorp of Texas posted another loss. [ D4. ] Coca-Cola's earnings rose 15 percent. [ D2. ] A new debate on foreign ownership of Canadian businesses may be a result of TransCanada's bid for Dome Petroleum. [ D15. ] A $8.4 million payment authorized by Guinness' ex-chairman to a company director during a takeover was ruled unlawful. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A Texaco-Pennzoil deal could come at almost any time, many legal experts say. According to lawyers close to the case, a quick settlement would allow Texaco to wrap up its bankruptcy status without much delay. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Utility stocks may deserve new attention as long-term investments, especially higher-quality issues, several analysts contend. The sector has been a weak performer. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Shareholders Back NCR 'Poison Pill'
description: The NCR Corporation's shareholders rejected a challenge to their ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan yesterday at their annual meeting in Dayton, Ohio. About 26 percent of the votes cast favored the proposal by the California Public Employees Retirement system to rescind the poison pill. About 62 percent voted against the proposal. The poison pill plan could drive up the cost of acquiring NCR in the event a takeover bid is opposed by the board. The anti-takeover measure is formally known as a shareholder rights plan.

title: N.A.A.C.P. to Push Baseball on Hirings
description: Dr. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., said yesterday that the civil rights organization had begun a national effort to influence the minority hiring policies in major league baseball.

title: AMR's Profits Increase 44.2%
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 44.2 percent, to $19.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from $13.8 million, or 20 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues increased 3.4 percent, to $1.51 billion, from $1.46 billion.

title: Gorbachev, With Deft Offer to Rid Europe of Missiles, Poses Uncomfortable Choices
description: With several deft moves, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has maneuvered the United States into an awkward political corner by exploiting the West's ambivalence about arms control. By offering to rid Europe not only of Soviet and American medium-range missiles, but of shorter-range missiles as well, the Soviet leader has left the Americans, for now, with three uncomfortable choices.

title: WILLIAM V. SHANNON
description: William V. Shannon, senior vice president of Gannett National Newspaper Sales, died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Hunts' Plan Approved
description: The Hunt brothers won a significant legal battle Tuesday night, when a Federal bankruptcy judge in Dallas ruled that the Placid Oil Company could proceed with a Gulf of Mexico drilling operation known as the Green Canyon project.

title: STAGE: BARBARA COOK IN SONG AND MEMORIES
description: IT'S not just Barbara Cook, now appearing in concert at the Ambassador, who has traveled a long way from the 1950's Broadway of ''Candide'' and ''The Music Man.'' As the passing decades have matured this one-time ingenue, so they've diminished the musical theater in which she made her name. But for everything that has changed, Miss Cook's creamy soprano remains remarkably intact: it's still a lovely instrument whose uncomplicated personality seems as sunny as the happy days that musical comedies used to celebrate. One need only hear Miss Cook's eternally youthful voice connect with the eternal old songs to feel the tingling sensation of years and years - hers, ours, Broadway's - dropping away.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $16.2 million for the latest quarter and $17.6 million for the year-ago period. All per share earnings are fully diluted. The latest first quarter's net was reduced by $10.9 million as a result of placing medium-and long-term loans to Brazil and Ecuador on a cash basis. The company said that its latest quarter earnings included $3.2 million, representing the first full quarter of income from the December 1986 acquisitions of three community banks and of First Options of Chicago Inc.

title: DOW ADDS 29.97 POINTS IN REBOUND
description: Stock prices snapped back yesterday, helped by a moderate decline in interest rates and a stabilized dollar.

title: U.S. Should Be Neutral
description: To the Editor:

title: Markets Shut Tomorrow
description: American stock and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday. Most foreign markets will also be closed. Banks, most businesses and Government offices will be open.

title: PIANIST REGAINED FAME IN 70'S
description: Erwin Nyiregyhazi, a Hungarian-born American pianist who dropped out of sight for decades and then made a remarkable comeback in the 1970's, died of cancer Monday in Los Angeles. He was 84 years old. Mr. Nyiregyhazi enjoyed a considerable career as a child prodigy in Europe, and then as a young virtuoso in Germany and the United States in the 1920's. He mightily impressed the composer Arnold Schoenberg when he heard Mr. Nyiregyhazi play in the 1930's.

title: Placing Blame for the Latest Aegean Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOTT 1-HITTER STOPS DODGERS
description: Mike Scott threw a one-hit shutout, and Billy Hatcher hit a homer, a double and a single to continue his torrid start as the Houston Astros downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0, tonight. Hatcher has hit in all nine games for Houston this season, and is 17 for 36.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS- PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock form on Jan. 20. It said the latest quarter includes results from Jan. 21 to March 31.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELERAPH CO INC (AT&T)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter results were restated from $529 million, or 47 cents a share, because of a previously reported change in accounting for depreciation made in 1986.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coleman Picks Hotelier As Chief and Chairman
description: Alphonse W. Salomone, who has spent 35 years in the hotel industry, is teaming up with John B. Coleman to run the Coleman hotels - the Ritz-Carlton in New York and Washington and the Whitehall and Tremont in Chicago.

title: FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,284,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $808,000 (plus income of $188,000) and a tax credit of $161,000 from spun-off operations. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the spinoff of Nycor Inc.

title: Talking Deals; If Oil Giants Settle Quickly
description: WHEN Texaco Inc. filed for bankruptcy last Sunday it looked as if all hope was lost for a quick settlement of the $10.3 billion judgment the Pennzoil Company had won against Texaco. That is because Pennzoil, in turning down Texaco's previous offers, appeared to prefer to take its chances in court that the ruling would be upheld -a process that, along with resolution of the Chapter 11 reorganization proceedings, could take years.

title: SHULTZ OPEN ON SOVIET TV
description: Soviet television broadcast an interview today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in which he defended American arms positions, complained about Soviet espionage and criticized the Soviet presence in Afghanistan.

title: RANGERS MAY END SEASON OF TURMOIL
description: A sheet of yellow legal paper lay on a chair in a vestibule adjacent to the empty Ranger locker room. On it were three words scribbled in red ink: ''Mental . . . Defense . . . Patience.''

title: Turkey Seeks Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $1,149,000.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5.7 million and a loss of $1.3 million on disposal of discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated for the discontinuance of the company's educational and professional publishing operations.

title: Hong Kong Exports
description: Hong Kong was the world's biggest exporter of clothing, toys and games in 1986, the Government said today.

title: STANFORD UNIVERSITY UNVEILS $115 MILLION ATOM SMASHER
description: Physicists at Stanford University today unveiled a $115 million atom smasher meant to provide new information on the makeup of matter.

title: Shots and Shots
description: There's nothing like downing a few at the bar while watching a basketball game on TV to stir a tippler to dreams of glory. Is it any wonder, then, that the barroom arena of imaginary skyhooks and game-winning midcourt shots at the buzzer has become the setting for an actual athletic competition for elbow benders, or that a distiller is the chief backer?

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split March 5.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a provision for loan losses of $44.2 million. c-After a loan loss provision of $275 million.

title: Bic Lighter Inquiry in House
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee said today that he was beginning an investigation into the safety of disposable lighters made by the Bic Corporation.

title: Format Is Criticized
description: The Masters is too important a tournament to be decided in a sudden-death playoff, Seve Ballesteros said yesterday. He thinks the format should be changed to an 18-hole test if there is a tie after regulation play. ''I said it in 1979, so nobody can accuse me of crying because I lost,'' he said. ''Anybody can win one hole. Over 18 holes the champion will win.''

title: SOME IN JAPAN FEAR NEW FALL IN DOLLAR
description: Some Japanese economists and currency traders voiced deep concern today that a continued fall of the dollar could harm both the Japanese and American economies. They said further decline could discourage Japanese investment in United States Government bonds and help spur inflation in the United States.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: HUBBELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Trade War
description: Specialists from a half-dozen Federal departments and agencies are working overtime this week trying to come up with a list of electronics products that President Reagan is expected to impose sanctions on tomorrow in a dispute with Japan on computer chips.

title: Night Trading Is Approved
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it had received approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to begin night trading.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes equity in losses of a joint venture of $2,231,000 after taxes. The joint venture, with McCaw Communications Inc., involves the cellular telephone and paging systems businesses. c-After a loss from the discontinued operations of the company's radio stations of $138,000 and its share of losses in discontinued cable television operations of an affiliate of $731,000. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January.

title: Addendum
description: * Elle magazine is raising its circulation rate base and its rates 21.7 percent with the September issue. The new base will be 700,000.

title: Hotel Fire Trial Is Delayed
description: A judge has agreed to delay the trial of three men charged with setting the Dupont Plaza Hotel fire that killed 97 people. Superior Court Judge Laura Nieves agreed Tuesday to reschedule the trial from May 19 to Aug. 24 to give the defense more time to examine the evidence. The defendants, Hector Escudero Aponte, 35 years old, Armando Jimenez Rivera, 29, and Jose Francisco Rivera Lopez, 40, all hotel employees, have been charged with 96 counts of murder and one count each of arson and conspiracy. The three also face Federal arson charges.

title: Puff the Tragic Dragon
description: Except for three brief sightings since being stopped by Larry Holmes five years ago, Gerry Cooney seemed to have disappeared in a puff of smoke. And when introduced yesterday in the glitz of the Empire State Ballroom at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, he literally reappeared in a puff of smoke. In his dramatic entrance, the 30-year-old sometimes heavyweight was wearing a shiny gray sharkskin suit, a burgundy-and-gray tie on a white shirt, and black suede loafers that matched his trimmed black beard.

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7 million for the latest quarter and $3.2 million for the year- ago period. The year-ago quarter results have been restated to reflect the spirits and wine segment as a discontinued operation.

title: Article 876487 -- No Title
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation, the nation's 15th-largest oil and gas company, yesterday reported earnings of $181.5 million, or $2.15 a share, for the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $339.3 million a year ago. Revenues fell by 14 percent, to $1.23 billion, from $1.43 billion.

title: Martha Graham Ensemble
description: The Martha Graham Ensemble, a group of professional-level students at the Graham School, will present its first New York season in performances from April 23 to 26 at the Graham Center, 316 East 63d Street. Under the direction of Yuriko, the company has performed in schools and community centers throughout the metropolitan area. The ensemble's program includes ''Diversion of Angels,'' ''El Penitente'' and ''Acts of Light,'' all by Miss Graham. Admission is $7. Reservations: 838-5886.

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STATE'S MERGER LAW SAID TO HURT STOCKS
description: A 1985 New York State law that restricted hostile takeovers of companies based in the state initially cost shareholders at least $1.2 billion in the value of the stock they owned, a study by the Federal Government concludes.

title: RHODEN MAKES USE OF OFFENSE
description: Seven seasons were long enough for Rick Rhoden. He labored through good times and bad for the Pittsburgh Pirates, pitching well but rarely enjoying the support of a productive offense that once thrived under the leadership of Willie Stargell and Dave Parker.

title: CONCERT: WOLFF LEADS NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY
description: IT is rather common for a moderately talented young conductor to make a strong impression when he appears as a guest with one of the world's great orchestras. Except in rare instances when they take a dislike to an uncommonly arrogant or incompetent novice, musicians on that level have a corporate pride that works to the benefit of the leader. Unless hindered intolerably by a novice's ineptness, they will produce at least an acceptable performance and, occasionally, a surprisingly fine one. The young baton waver then escapes with honor, and few listeners can know the difference.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SIGN A PACT OVER EXPLORATION IN SPACE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union signed an accord today on cooperation in space exploration.

title: SIGNS OF ECONOMIC FRAGILITY
description: The economy, after performing better than expected during the first few months of 1987, is showing signs of fragility.

title: ART: NEW SCULPTURES FROM EUROPE AT MODERN
description: IN the year since it was re-established at the Museum of Modern Art, the ''Projects'' series has been one of the few programs in New York City consistently responsive to contemporary sculpture. Three of the five exhibitions, including the one that inaugurated the new series, have been on sculpture, and a fourth, an installation by Justen Ladda, had sculpture in it.

title: Tampering Charge
description: The New England Patriots have accsdeRoR MeMrrththr former coach and now the Indianapolis Colts' coach, of tampering with Irving Fryar, the Patriots' wide receiver.

title: A Minor League for L.I.
description: It won't be the biggest game in town. But this summer, fans in the metropolitan area will be treated to what many smaller communities across the nation have known to be the only game in town. The Empire State Baseball League, an independent minor league for rookies based on Long Island, is scheduled to open in July.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FARM & HOME SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect the change in accounting for loan acquisition costs in accordance with F.A.S.B.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings for year-ago quarter is restated to reflect the 3-for- 2 stock split on Nov. 7, 1986. The latest quarter includes gains of $5.3 million from the sale of other securities, compared with the year-ago period's gain of $8.8 million from the sale of real property.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $3.2 million for both periods; the latest 6 months include an after-tax gain on the sale of a business of $209.3 million; year-ago 6 months include an after-tax unusual charge of $24.5 million relating to the closing of a tuna plant. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $10.3 million. d-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $113,400,000 and an extraordinary charge of $13,500,000.

title: Brigitte Haudebourg
description: Brigitte Haudebourg, a French harpsichordist, will play works by Rameau, J. S. Bach, Martinu, Couperin and Domenico Scarlatti in a recital Sunday at 2 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall. Miss Haudebourg studied piano as a child with Marguerite Long and Jean Doyen, and harpsichord at Paris's National Conservatory with Marcelle Delacour and Robert Veyron-Lacroix. Tickets to the recital are $10; information: 247-7800.

title: SOME OFFBEAT OUTINGS ON A HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: AMID the plentiful ways to celebrate Easter traditionally, here are some weekend possibilities that have nothing to do with eggs or rabbits. They involve, among other things, ghosts, workhorses, Svengali and medieval African music.

title: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DPL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: ANNETTE LEMIEUX IN 2 MIXED-MEDIA SHOWS
description: ANNETTE LEMIEUX'S work is not easy to get into in the visual sense. Both segments of her double exhibition - at Josh Baer Gallery (270 Lafayette Street) and Cash-Newhouse (170 Avenue B, at 11th Street) - have, upon first encounter, the appearance of rather tightly selected group shows. The individual pieces range from strategically altered objects and photographs to paintings that combine abstraction with either appropriated photographic imagery or overly meaningful words (''Godspeed,'' ''Mother''). Also included are two low stacks of old books, collectively called ''Two Short Stories'' and individually subtitled ''Paradise'' and ''Inferno'' - the titles on their spines are cropped so that oddly truncated narratives are spelled out. These works seem to need each other for their full meaning to emerge, and sometimes ideas can ricochet between them like little darts.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains primarily from early bond redemptions of $5.4 million for the latest quarter and $2.2 million for the year-earlier period. Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect a change in pension accounting.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS THE WALKERS GAVE SOVIET MUCH KEY DATA
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the John A. Walker Jr. spy ring had given Soviet officials information on a wide range of highly sensitive subjects, including terrorist threats.

title: MICROSOFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ayer Helps Recruit Priests
description: N.W. Ayer may have lost the Army account, but it hasn't given up recruiting. Its latest client is the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit, which needs priests.

title: INSIDE
description: Rangers Fall in Six Games The Rangers were eliminated from the National Hockey League playoffs by Philadelphia. The Islanders-Capitals series is tied at 3-3. Page B7. Telephone Fee Raised Residences and small businesses will pay $1.50 more a month for service, the F.C.C. decided. But it said long-distance rates would fall. Page D1.

title: FILM: A DOCUMENTARY, DIANE KEATON'S 'HEAVEN'
description: ''HEAVEN,'' a film by Diane Keaton, is the cinema equivalent of a book that's discounted to $19.95 before Christmas with the warning that it will be $50 after. If you respond to that kind of come-on, you may respond to ''Heaven.''

title: CADWELL DAVIS GETS BASF CARPET BUSINESS
description: Cadwell Davis & Partners, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, has been named agency for the residential carpet fiber business of the BASF Corporation's Fibers division, based in Williamsburg, Va.

title: 5 INDICTED IN PLAN TO SELL FAKE INDONESIAN NOTES
description: Investigators in Manhattan said yesterday that they had uncovered a swindle scheme involving fraudulent Indonesian Government promissory notes with a face value of $3.5 billion. They said the scheme was controlled by a Middle Eastern businessman whom law enforcement officials have linked to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS (MONANA) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FILM: 'CAMP NIGHTMARE'
description: THOUGH it sounds like a slasher film, ''Summer Camp Nightmare'' is an earnest little rip-off of ''The Lord of the Flies.'' This version of adolescence-turned-evil relies on the heavy political symbolism a 15-year-old might take to heart - and look back on at 16 with embarrassment.

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gains at Lotus And Microsoft
description: Buoyed by strong sales of core products and gains in overseas sales, the two leading personal computer software companies - Microsoft and Lotus Development - reported record revenues and earnings today.

title: UNIVERSITY FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Net sales exclude sales of Weyerhaeuser Real Estate Co., an unconsolidated subsidiary accounted for under the equity method. Net earnings per common share are computed by dividing net earnings less preferred and preference share dividends in 1987 and 1986, respectively, of $2,241,000 and $9,474,000 by the average number of common and common equivalent shares outstanding during the respective periods; the company's convertible preference share issues are common share equivalents. Latest quarter is comprised of a 13- week period.

title: F.B.I. INQUIRY FOCUSES ON ROCKETS FOR SHUTTLE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating whether Morton Thiokol Inc. committed fraud in supplying the Government with faulty booster rockets that led to the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger, according to court papers made public today.

title: HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $15,000.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dow Profits Surge 40.6%
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its first-quarter profit surged 40.6 percent, to $246 million, or $1.28 a share, from $175 million, or 92 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Kemp Now 'Bona Fide'
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp has become the first Republican Presidential contender to qualify for matching public funds.

title: ADAMS-RUSSELL ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 17, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The President's budget director warned the Fed not to raise interest rates, saying such action could cause a recession. The Reagan aide, James C. Miller 3d, seemed to be positioning the Administration to blame the Fed if a recession occurs in 1988, an election year. Paul A. Volcker has indicated that the Fed might have to consider pushing up rates to combat the dollar's slide. [ Page A1. ] The F.C.C. voted to raise the monthly telephone access fee to $3.50, from $2, for residential and small-business users. The commission said the increase would generally be offset by a further decline of at least 15 percent in rates for long-distance calls. [ D1. ] The F.C.C. adopted tighter curbs on the broadcast of explicit language about sex and body functions. [ A1. ] Housing construction fell 3.2 percent in March, the biggest decline in six months and the first since November. [ D1. ] Factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.2 percent of capacity last month, off 0.5 percent. [ D3. ] Business sales climbed a record 4.4 percent in February, while inventories rose a small 0.2 percent. [ D3. ] The U.S. will allow patents for animals, clearing the way for inventors to patent life forms created through gene splicing. [ A1. ] COMPANIES A. H. Robins filed a plan to satisfy creditor claims by allotting $1.75 billion for women who contend they were injured by using its Dalkon Shield birth control device. Lawyers for a class of the Dalkon Shield claimants said they would fight the plan, which was filed in bankruptcy court. [ D1. ] A swindle scheme involving fraudulent promissory notes for Indonesia with a face value of $3.5 billion was disclosed by investigators. The authorities said the scheme was run by a Middle Eastern businessman who has previously been linked to the P.L.O. [ D1. ] G.M. will scrap its executive bonus system in favor of a stock option plan, The bonus plan, in effect since 1918, has long been criticized by consumer activists and labor leaders. [ D1. ] Bic said it had 42 lawsuits outstanding that were brought on behalf of people burned or killed by fires allegedly caused by malfunctioning disposable butane lighters that it made. [ D3. ] Net income fell 21.4 percent at American Express, but last year's first quarter included a large one-time gain. [ D2. ] Two tobacco conglomerates, Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco, showed strong gains for the quarter. [ D2. ] Texas Instruments posted an $83.8 million profit, compared with a year-earlier loss, helped by the settlement of patent infringement lawsuits. [ D2. ] Pacific Telesis reported a 7.1 percent earnings gain, while Southwestern Bell reported a 3.4 percent decline. [ D2. ] Borg-Warner agreed to provide GAF with confidential data about itself for GAF to consider a new takeover bid. [ D3. ] Time Inc.'s editor in chief, Henry A. Grunwald, will retire in December. Jason McManus was named as his successor. [ B5. ] Agents arrested 16 stockbrokers on charges of selling cocaine and trading it for stocks and information. [ A1. ] MARKETS The jittery stock, bond and currency markets calmed following a comment by Treasury Secretary Baker that ''a further decline of the dollar'' could be ''counterproductive.'' The dollar strengthened against the yen and the West German mark. Gold rose modestly in New York after falling $4 to $6 an ounce in Europe. [ D1. ] Stocks ended mixed in pre-holiday trading. Several positive events including a stronger dollar and lower interest rates, failed to support blue-chip equities. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.96 points, to 2,275.99. [ D4. ] Treasury issues continued to recover, with intermediate maturities showing some of the best gains of the day. [ D10. ] Grain and soybean futures prices rallied, lifted by expectations of wheat sales to the Soviet Union. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The computer chip dispute may be just the start of U.S. action against Japan in the high-technology area. Washington's impending tariffs, expected today, may make the trade question an important one for GATT. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Mutual funds were highly favored for I.R.A. investments because of the market's surge this year. In past years, when interest rates were much higher, fixed-income funds and money market funds were more dominant. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: FIRST MICHIGAN BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RAN NAVY'S LOGISTICS IN KOREA
description: Vice Adm. Francis C. Denebrink, a Navy veteran of both World Wars and of the Korean War, in which he was responsible for the logistic support of all United States naval forces, died April 8 at Letterman Army General Hospital in San Francisco. He was 90 years old.

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COLUMBIA FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 18.

title: BATTALIONS FORM FOR ORMOLU CLOCKS AND CHERUBS
description: The second most powerful man in the French Government sits in a magnificent office in the Louvre Palace these days, warily watching an army of construction workers at the building he occupies.

title: French Offer to Saudis
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said today that France was ready to offer Saudi Arabia the latest industrial and military technology as part of a drive to forge a close economic partnership by the end of the century. Mr. Chirac made the offer at a lunch for King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who was making a 24-hour visit to Paris, his first official trip to France since becoming monarch in 1982.

title: Met Acquires Collection Of Historical Photos
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired a major collection of more than 500 photographs documenting early 20th-century photography and will exhibit 120 of the works in 1989 in celebration of the 150th anniversary of the birth of photography.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 1, 1986.

title: BRONX PAPER'S EDITOR IS CITED
description: Jonathan Freedman of The Tribune in San Diego, who won the Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing, was one of three finalists in the category.

title: Twice, but No Cigar
description: The no-hitter that Milwaukee's Juan Nieves hurled against Baltimore on Wednesday night guaranteed him headlines but no immortality. Here are the pitchers in modern major league history who've thrown two no-hitters and who, having been retired at least five years and thus made eligible for the Hall of Fame, have never been elected. $ Club Vs.
