title: F.C.C. ACTS TO RESTRICT INDECENT PROGRAMMING
description: The Federal Communications Commission, responding to public complaints, unanimously adopted measures today intended to sharply restrict explicit language about sex and bodily functions on radio, television and telephone services.

title: MARKETS CLOSED TODAY
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will by closed today in observance of Good Friday. The credit markets will also be closed, as will most foreign stock markets. Government offices and most business, however, will be open.

title: NOT GUILTY, TRADERS SAY
description: The Government moved a step closer yesterday to its first trial in the Wall Street scandal when three senior securities traders pleaded not guilty to criminal insider-trading charges.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter net has been restated to include the acquisition of IVB Financial Corp., purchased March 31, 1986.

title: New Feathers For the Mustangs
description: Southern Methodist University's football scandal may have made the Mustangs the ugly ducklings of college sports, but the way the head of the school's new executive committee sees it, S.M.U. could emerge from its cloud of disgrace as the eagle of national reform.

title: Helmuth Rilling
description: Helmuth Rilling conducts the National Arts Center Orchestra and the Gachinger Kantorei of Stuttgart, West Germany, in three choral masterpieces this weekend at Carnegie Hall. Tomorrow night at 8, the program will feature Haydn's ''Lord Nelson'' Mass and the Mozart Requiem; Sunday night at 7, Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' will be performed. Soloists in both programs include Edith Wiens, Janice Taylor, David Gordon, William Parker and Andreas Schmidt. Admission is $12.50 to $20. Information: 247-7800.

title: KEY RATES
FIRST FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: THIRTY-TWO years after its publication, ''The Ginger Man,'' J. P. Donleavy's classic, has been optioned for the screen. Having turned down offers over the years by such screen luminaries as Robert Redford, John Huston and Mike Nichols, the New York-born writer who studied and now lives in Ireland has reached an agreement with the newly formed Bluebird Films, an independent company headed by his son, Philip Donleavy, and Robert A. Mitchell, a producer. The partners, who have raised some funds independently, are hunting for a distributor, actors and a director while the author completes the last draft of the screenplay, which will be filmed in Ireland. Mr. Donleavy has also sold Bluebird Films the rights to ''A Singular Man,'' which will be filmed after ''The Ginger Man.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Photographs yesterday depicting stages of restoration of a lunette in Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel were published with attribution inadvertently omitted. They were from the book ''The Sistine Chapel: The Art, the History and the Restoration,'' c 1986 Harmony Books, a division of Crown Publishers, Inc.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 6 months' figures have been restated to reflect an accounting change and a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 2, 1987.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HAYDN EASTER WORK Haydn's ''Seven Last Words of Christ'' is a series of solemn musical meditations that the composer wrote for a Good Friday observance. It was originally scored for instrumental ensemble and later arranged variously for string quartet and piano, string quartet and soloists, and orchestra with chorus and vocal soloists. At Carnegie Hall tonight at 8, the Juilliard Quartet and a vocal ensemble made up of Benita Valente, Jan DeGaetani, Jerry Hadley and Thomas Paul will perform the ''Seven Last Words.'' Tickets are $9 to $15. Information: 247-7800. BRITISH COMEDY ''Milestones,'' a British comedy of manners by Arnold Bennett and Edward Knoblock, was first staged almost 75 years ago in London and arrived on Broadway shortly thereafter. The story of three generations over half a century, it chronicles changing manners and morals, young firebrands growing into old conservatives, the Victorian era gradually giving way to Edwardian sophistication. Now the Meat and Potatoes Company has revived ''Milestones'' at the Alvina Krause Theater, 306 West 38th Street, and will present it tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3 P.M. The production is directed by Neal Weaver. Admission is $10; information: 564-3293. JACKIE ROBINSON Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier 40 years ago when he joined the Brooklyn Dodgers and became the first black to play major-league baseball in America. Today the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West (between 76th and 77th Streets), will unveil an exhibition called ''Jackie Robinson: An American Journey,'' devoted to Mr. Robinson's life and career. The society is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow and from 1 to 5 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $2 for adults; $1.50 for the elderly and $1 for children under 12. ''Jackie Robinson: An American Journey'' will run through July 15. Information: 873-3400. SATURDAY WRITER ON CANVAS Meyer Schapiro has been one of the century's most distinguished art historians, teaching and writing prolifically over the past 60 years. All the while, unbeknownst to most of his students and the public, Mr. Schapiro has been creating artworks of his own. Now Columbia University, where Mr. Schapiro spent his academic career, will present an exhibition of his paintings, drawings, prints and sculpture, beginning Saturday and continuing through May 23, in the Wallach Art Gallery on the eighth floor of Schermerhorn Hall, at 118th Street on the Columbia campus. Hours are Tuesday to Saturday, 1-5 P.M. Admission is free; information: 280-0513 or 280-4505. FELD BALLET ON L.I. The Feld Ballet, which recently presented several programs at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea, will spend Saturday evening on Long Island, presenting several original works by Eliot Feld at the Tilles Center of Long Island University, in Greenvale. The program will include ''Medium: Rare,'' ''Adieu,'' ''The Jig Is Up'' and ''Harbinger,'' the last with music by Prokofiev. The program starts at 8:30 P.M. Admission is $15 and $17.50; for information and directions: (516) 922-0061. SPOLETO IN BROOKLYN The Spoleto Festival, with branches in Italy, South Carolina and Australia, will pay a visit to Brooklyn Saturday night at the Helen Owen Carey Playhouse in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place. The program, entitled ''Spoleto Comes to BAM,'' will feature works by Bach, Handel, Telemann, Vivaldi, Couperin and Stravinsky played by Ani Kavafian, violinist, Paula Robison, flutist, and Kenneth Cooper, keyboardist, among others. The concert starts at 8. Admission is $7.50 and $10; information: (718) 636-4100. SUNDAY BIG APPLE TOUR The Big Apple Circus sets up its tent at Lincoln Center every fall. But the larger Big Apple is more than just Manhattan, and this weekend the circus will begin its annual tour of the other four boroughs. At 12:30 and 4 P.M. Sunday, the Big Apple Circus, under the direction of Paul Binder, will offer its customary blend of thrills and chills at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, right next to Wollman Rink. Come watch the Flying Gaonas, the Woodcock Elephants and Vanessa Prater, billed as the ''Hula-Hoop artiste extraordinaire.'' Admission is $8 to $15. Information: 391-0760.

title: SIGNS OF SOUTH KOREA CRACKDOWN AGAINST THE OPPOSITION MULTIPLY
description: In the last few days, unmistakable signs of a Government crackdown have begun to creep in at the edges of this capital's unsettled political life.

title: Getting to Know You
description: Before the Rangers ever had a chance to get acquainted, their season ended last night with a 5-0 thrashing by the Flyers on their home ice.

title: FIRST U.S. BRAIN GRAFT GIVES NEW HOPE TO PATIENT
description: The first person to undergo brain graft surgery in this country says it has given her hope of overcoming Parkinson's disease, and her doctors called it a breakthrough in treating disorders of the nervous system.

title: Dining Out Guide: Easter Sunday
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Silence By Libel
description: It is an important book. Critics hailed it. It was made into a notable movie. But you cannot buy it anywhere in the United States. The reason is a libel suit: a suit that successive courts have found without merit.

title: Peak Competition
description: The third annual Pillar Mountain Classic is history, but less than a month after an obscure amateur named Rick Lindholm captured the 1987 title, Andy Lundquist, the tournament chairman, is already laying grandiose plans for next year. In an effort to attract a recognizable pro, Lundquist is lining up a free salmon-fishing vacation and other inducements, and he'll need every one of them to tempt a regular away from the sunny climes of the PGA Tour. The Pillar Mountain Classic takes place outside the island community of Kodiak, Alaska, preferably in the kind of weather that attended it three weeks ago: a swirling snowstorm and subfreezing temperatures.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 7
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $2,550,000 for both the quarter and 9 months and extraordinary gains of $120,000 and $790,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in October 1986.

title: CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MAJESTIC WORKS BY A NOBLE FIGURE IN FRENCH PAINTING
description: THE current show of paintings, drawings, watercolors, prints and sculpture by Theodore Gericault at the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries at 22 East 80th Street has to rank as one of the most rewarding that has been set before us this season in a dealer's gallery.

title: Big Jim McNeely
description: The duo of Big Jim McNeely on piano and Rufus Reid on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440), starting at 9:45 P.M. There is no cover charge.

title: If Aquino Is to Avoid Failure
description: The late Benigno S. Aquino Jr. predicted that whoever succeeded Ferdinand E. Marcos as President of the Philippines would be ''doomed to failure'' because of the devastation wrought by 20 years of Mr. Marcos's corrupt dictatorship. Mr. Aquino could hardly have guessed he was forecasting the fate of his own wife.

title: He's Just 'Bo,' as in 'Reggie' and 'Babe'
description: Conversations temporarily cease. Visits to the rest room are delayed. Vendors find it convenient to be situated at the head of an aisle, where they are afforded a closer view of the field. No one looks hungry or thirsty, anyway. All eyes in Royals Stadium are watching Number 16 walking deliberately to home plate, twirling a bat as if it were a drum major's baton.

title: JUDGE UPSETS LAW ON GIVING REALTY DATA
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled invalid a New York City law that forces some property owners to reveal how much money they make from their buildings.

title: FILM: 'PROJECT X,' ABOUT BOY AND SIMIAN SIDEKICK
description: HOW much you enjoy ''Project X'' depends on how much monkeying around you can take. As somebody says, ''There are monkeys all over the place.'' The stars of this show, upstaging Matthew Broderick all the way, are a chatter of chimpanzees, an aptitude of apes. They play experimental animals at an Air Force base in Florida who are taught to fly an airplane (in simulated circumstances) as a prelude to the final, but final, experiment.

title: Player's Lawyer Sees Indictments
description: As many as seven former and current members of the Phoenix Suns basketball team have testified before a grand jury investigating drug use in the Phoenix area, according to a lawyer representing one of the players.

title: INVENTORIES UP SLIGHTY
description: Business sales climbed a record 4.4 percent in February from weak January levels, while inventories rose a small two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: DESPITE THE DECLINE IN 18-YEAR-OLDS, APPLICATIONS RISE AT MANY COLLEGES
description: As high school seniors braced for word from college admissions offices this week, many college officials reported record numbers of applications this year despite a continuing decline in the number of 18-year-olds.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $34,987,000 and $33,330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a gain of $408,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $413,000 for the year.

title: BUNNIES AND BONNETS
description: For those who consider Easter a matter of eggs, bunnies, bonnets and lilies, a bit of all four can be found at events scheduled around the city this weekend.

title: Calling for I.R.S. Aid
description: Further on the matter of taxes, as the midnight Wednesday deadline drew closer, the Internal Revenue Service found the calls to its toll-free assistance program increasingly desperate and disparate. Apparently a lot of people who fear they owe the Government money wait until the last-minute and make heavy use of the assistance service to figure every possible angle and deduction.

title: Machinists' Union Cool to United Bid
description: The machinists' union at United Airlines said that it was ''unlikely'' to join the pilot union's $4.5 billion takeover proposal for the airline. The machinists told the pilots' union that they envisioned problems with employee ownership, particularly in not being able to strike for seven years under the pilots' proposal. Still, they said they were evaluating their own plans, although they gave no details. The airline's parent, UAL Inc., has said it will study the pilots' bid.

title: AVX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-Net loss

title: BIC SAYS THERE ARE 42 SUITS
description: The Bic Corporation said yesterday that it has 42 lawsuits outstanding that were brought on behalf of people burned or killed by fires allegedly caused by malfunctioning disposable butane lighters made by Bic.

title: CONNECTICUT RESIDENTS ARE AT TOP IN INCOME
description: Residents of Connecticut had the highest average income of those in any state in the country in 1986, displacing Alaska residents in the No. 1 spot for the first time in 14 years, the Government reported today.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $301,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: SOVIET COMPLAINS SHULTZ WAS UNABLE TO BARGAIN
description: A Soviet spokesman said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his aides had come to Moscow unprepared to bargain on arms control, and ''left hiding behind the backs of their allies.''

title: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain from cumulative effect of a change in accounting of $58.2 million. The year-ago first quarter results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Consultant to Lead Empire Blue Cross
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the private, not-for-profit health insurance company in New York State, said yesterday that it had named Albert A. Cardone chairman and chief executive.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $139,600,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings and shares outstanding are unadjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split declared March 23, 1987, payable May 8, 1987 to shareholders of record on April 3, 1987. The company said prior year's results included a $139.6 million gain on the sale of the company's interest in Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. (Warner Amex) which is being treated as a discontinued operations.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $427,596 for the quarter and $577,596 for the 9 months.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Includes $1.7 million in charges for depreciation purposes. c-Net income

title: STAGE: JASON ROBARDS IN 'A MONTH OF SUNDAYS'
description: ALTHOUGH David Letterman has long been considered the prime candidate to inherit Johnny Carson's late-night television throne, one must now wonder if Jason Robards, of all people, is throwing his hat into the ring. In ''A Month of Sundays,'' his new vehicle on Broadway, the silver-haired Mr. Robards sports an increasing resemblance to Mr. Carson, brandishes wisecracks with the wry and unerring flair of a vaudevillian and, in general, holds forth from a center-stage armchair as if the Ritz Theater were the ''Tonight'' show's make-believe living room and Ed McMahon were the arbiter of public taste. Why would one of our most brilliant actors turn sit-down clown? Mr. Robards is no fool. Confronted with a nonrole in a nonscript, the star must live by his wits, if only to prevent himself from going batty and the audience from going home.

title: NEW INDEX FINDS SOME CANCER DANGERS ARE OVERRATED AND OTHERS IGNORED
description: A new system of ranking the dangers posed by hundreds of cancer-causing substances suggests that while some banned chemicals are probably of little health consequence, millions of people are exposed to far greater cancer hazards that are all but ignored by regulatory agencies.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said revenue for the latest quarter includes revenue subject to refund of $82,722,000 pursuant to the May 16, 1986 order of the Curcuit Court of Cook County, Ill.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: John Cale, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). The singer-composer and one-time electric violist in the Velvet Underground is leading a band that features Chris Spedding, guitarist. John Cale, who might be called a romantic primal screamer, writes and sings poetically surrealistic rants that evoke extreme emotional and physical states. The songs' dreamlike lyrics often have a historical resonance. Unlike other rockers who deal with deep visceral feelings, Mr. Cale's music is not about physical incitement; it deals with the artful exorcism of pain. Shows are tomorrow at 8:30 and 11 P.M., and tickets are $11.

title: The Critical Mass in City Jails
description: New York City's big jail on Rikers Island appears headed for a perilously hot summer and fall. Severe crowding, unrelieved despite huge investments in jail expansion, are already building pressure dangerously. Worse, the jail population is expected to grow faster than building plans can bring relief. Is there no better response than resignation to riots? Of course. Much can be done to ease the jail burden with more efficient procedures in the courts. The need has never been more urgent. The city suffers chronic jail crowding. In 1983 a Federal judge ordered the release of 611 prisoners. Mayor Koch then embarked on a construction program that has produced an additional 4,200 beds at a cost of $186 million.

title: EXCEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago share net is adjusted for 5-for-4 stock split in January 1987.

title: Tania Leon to Conduct
description: Tania Leon will conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic Chamber and Percussion Ensembles in a program of works by Hispanic-American composers in the Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section, tomorrow afternoon at 2. The performance is the final one in a three-concert series intended to introduce children and their families to a wide range of music in an intimate space, at reasonable cost. Admission is $5 for adults and $3 for children. Information: (718) 636-4120.

title: NORDIQUES ELIMINATE WHALERS
description: Peter Stastny scored his second goal of the game on a breakaway at 6 minutes 5 seconds of overtime to give the Quebec Nordiques a 5-4 victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight that clinched the Adams Division semifinal series.

title: ALBANY LAWMAKERS FUME OVER FIGHT ON ETHICS CODE
description: State legislators today vigorously defended a proposed code of ethics in government that was vetoed Wednesday by Governor Cuomo, saying it had been depicted unfairly by the Governor and by groups unfamiliar with its history.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NAVY HEAD ORDERS A LOOK TO FUTURE
description: The new Secretary of the Navy, James H. Webb Jr., said today that he had ordered senior Navy admirals and Marine Corps generals to assess within 60 days where their services now stand and where they should be in 10 years.

title: BOULEVARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FIDELITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JERSEY AIDE TIES HOSPITAL NEGLECT TO DEATHS OF 3
description: The New Jersey Public Advocate said today that ''extreme negligence'' on the part of physicians and employees at three state psychiatric hospitals led to the deaths of three patients over the last year.

title: SOME NATO ALLIES COOL TO REMOVING SHORT-RANGE ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz briefed the NATO allies here today on his talks in Moscow, and several expressed concern about a Soviet proposal to eliminate both short-range and medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Endangered Habitat, Endangered Species
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BUDGET CHIEF OPPOSES INCREASE IN INTEREST RATES
description: President Reagan's budget director, James C. Miller 3d, warned the Federal Reserve today not to raise interest rates, saying such action could cause a recession next year.

title: Shamrock to Sell Coal Subsidiary
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said that it had once again agreed to sell its coal subsidiary to the Arch Mineral Corporation for $135 million. The two companies had reached a similar agreement last July regarding the Diamond Shamrock Coal Company, but in October Diamond Shamrock said they canceled the deal because they ''were unable to reach mutually acceptable terms.''

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Union Carbide's South Africa Plan
description: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said it would use dividends from South African operations to assist blacks in that country, but anti-apartheid groups criticized the plan as a cosmetic approach to dealing with racial segregation. The chemical giant's plan to use its dividends to finance education, legal aid and social improvements was announced by its chairman, Robert D.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CENTRAL BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Central Bank converted to a stock savings bank in July 1986.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes charges of $1,850,000 and $2,575,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, for the estimated cost of hazardous waste removal.

title: QUAKER STATE OIL REFINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FEDERAL OF THE CAROLINAS FA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS (ALAAMA) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Firs Federal converted to stock form last December.

title: Borg Agrees to Give GAF Information
description: After extensive negotiations, the Borg-Warner Corporation agreed yesterday to turn over confidential information about itself to the GAF Corporation as part of what could be a new takeover bid by GAF for the Chicago-based industrial company.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF your idea of a big night on the town includes donning a billowy Hawaiian shirt sporting palm trees, sipping frothy pastel-colored drinks with names such as Pensacola Passion, Dr. Voodoo and Kissimmee, and munching on pot stickers ($7.95) and Key West satays ($13.25), Panama City awaits. This reggae-pulsed, cartoon-colored bar and restaurant on the Upper East Side is among the hottest new yuppie ports-of-call. And the food, for the price, isn't bad at all, based on a recent rum-soaked visit.

title: 4.2% Canadian Inflation
description: Higher prices in Canada for most consumer goods and services pushed up the annual inflation rate to 4.2 percent in March, from 4 percent in February, Statistics Canada said today. The federal agency said that higher costs for gasoline, cigarettes and housing contributed to the overall increase, the second consecutive monthly rise. The inflation rate stood at 3.9 percent in January.

title: Citing Fiscal Health, Koch Seeks Tax Cuts
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that if the city can afford it, taxes should be reduced in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Editorial Feud at Washington Times
description: Ever since The Washington Times began publication five years ago with financing provided by associates of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the South Korean-based Unification Church, the newspaper has periodically fought against speculation that the church was influencing its editorial policy.

title: AMCORE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROBINS: $1.75 BILLION FOR DALKON USERS
description: The A. H. Robins Company, the pharmaceutical giant that sought Chapter 11 protection in 1985, yesterday filed a plan to satisfy creditor claims by allotting $1.75 billion for women who contend they were injured by using its Dalkon Shield birth control device.

title: REGAN, IN TALK, BACKS REAGAN
description: In his first speech since resigning as White House chief of staff in February, Donald T. Regan said President Reagan knew nothing about the reported diversion to the contras of money from American arms sales to Iran.

title: ISLANDERS STAY ALIVE
description: Kelly Hrudey raised his gloved hands, forgot he was wearing 35 pounds of goalie equipment and leaped into the arms of Ken Morrow. The adrenaline, he said later, finally got to him.

title: Haitian Soldiers Said to Kill A Squatter in Clash in North
description: Soldiers beat and fired on peasants occupying land owned by the Rural Development Center, a Canadian religious mission in northern Haiti, killing one of them and wounding several others, a private radio station said Thursday.

title: IN YONKERS, KAWASAKI OFFERS HOPE
description: If smokestack America has any future left in the New York metropolitan region, it may be here, where Japanese engineers have retooled an abandoned factory to make subway cars for New York and New Jersey.

title: MEDITERRANEAN VILLAGE ON STATEN ISLAND'S SOUTH SHORE
description: Waterfront property suitable for resort-style living is a scarce commodity in New York City. One of the assets of Staten Island is that it has a fair amount of such land on its south shore, where a strip of beaches and boatyards is protected and enhanced by the Gateway National Recreational Area, a giant hook of land encircling Great Kills Harbor.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Part of a chart printed yesterday with an article on the threat to European economies from the falling dollar was mislabeled. The top of the chart showed the economic growth rates of West Germany, Britain, France and Italy, not their export performance. That was shown, and correctly labeled, in the bottom of the chart.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUCTIONS
description: GUERNSEY'S is to auction 2,000 collectibles next weekend in a two-day marathon of gaveling that will present one man's mania for buying Mickey Mouse figures, wind-up toys, traveling salesmen's sample cases, vintage packaging, theatrical memorabilia, Art Deco kitchen appliances, early typewriters and advertising materials.

title: 7 NATIONS AGREE TO LIMIT EXPORT OF BIG ROCKETS
description: The United States, Japan and five major allies have agreed to control exports of large missiles and related technology in an effort to limit the spread of nuclear weapons, their governments disclosed today.

title: ATLANTA TO REVIEW INQUIRY ON COCAINE
description: Mayor Andrew Young said today that he would name a panel to review the way his office handled allegations of cocaine use involving several prominent public figures here, including Mr. Young himself, his brother and some members of his staff.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 common stock split-up distributed on April 10, 1986, to stockholders of record on March 14, 1986.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that latest-quarter results include the operations of American Can Packaging Inc., acquired effective Nov. 1, 1986. Share earnings are after paid or accrued dividends of $426,000 for the latest quarter and $2,159,000 for the year- ago quarter on preferred shares.

title: COLUMBIA PURSUES THE ART OF BASEBALL
description: LEAD: At Columbia University's Andy Coakley Field on the northern tip of Manhattan, it is 360 feet down each foul line and 345 feet to dead center. It is also a foul pop away from the football field where Columbia is enmeshed in a 31-game nonwinning streak.

title: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lockheed Net Dips Slightly
description: The Lockheed Corporation today reported first-quarter earnings of $86 million, or $1.30 a share, a small decline from earnings of $87 million, or $1.32 a share, a year ago.

title: ERA ENDS FOR A CITY BOOK FAIR
description: The grande dame of the small-press world, the New York Book Fair, will bow out with a flourish in its 12th and last year of presenting the works of small presses to the public. Two hundred publishing houses from around the country will exhibit their literary wares from noon to 8 P.M. today and tomorrow, and from noon to 6 P.M. Sunday, in Ferris Booth Hall of Columbia University at Broadway and 116th Street. Admission is free.

title: CONSTITUTION CELEBRATION AT LIBRARY
description: The 200th birthday of the Constitution of the United States is having its biggest New York celebration at the New York Public Library. Starting tomorrow, an exhibition of nearly 200 items, including original documents, portraits and maps, will go on view in the classic interior of Gottesman Hall in the library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue. Other presentations on the same subject are scheduled for the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, the Lincoln Center Library and other places in the library system.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Henry Marshall, a wide receiver for the Kansas City Chiefs, was fined $40,000 in Federal Court in Kansas City yesterday after having pleaded guilty to two counts of failing to file Federal income-tax returns for 1982 and 1983. Marshall, 32 years old, was placed on probation for three years and ordered to perform 320 hours of community service. . . . The Alabama-at-Penn State game has been moved from Oct. 24 to Sept. 12 at 8 P.M. so it can be televised by CBS. ''After considerable internal discussion and conversations with Alabama, we felt the positives of a prime-time national telecast against a quality opponent represented an opportunity we couldn't ignore,'' said Jim Tarman, the Penn State athletic director. . . . Gary Nicklaus, the 18-year-old son of Jack Nicklaus, has decided to follow in his father's footsteps and play golf at Ohio State. . . . The brothers of two National Basketball Association all-stars may be playing for Indiana State next year. The team will have Taju Olajuwon, brother of the Rockets' Akeem Olajuwon, and Eddie Bird, brother of the Celtics' Larry Bird.

title: Banks Await Manila Plea
description: Jaime Ongpin, Finance Minister of the Philippines, will formally ask bankers to reopen talks on their completed debt-restructuring accord with his country, people familiar with his plans said yesterday.

title: WORLD'S MARKETS TURN CALM
description: The jittery stock, bond and currency markets calmed today after a comment by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d that ''a further decline of the dollar'' could be ''counterproductive.''

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 16, 1986.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,314,000 from discontinued operations.

title: RJR Nabisco Rises 6.8%; Philip Morris Up 22.2%
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 6.8 percent, to $220 million, or 84 cents a share, from $206 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 2.6 percent, to $3.49 billion from $3.40 billion.

title: NACCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect the conversion of North American Coal Corp. common stock into two shares of class A common of Nacco on June 6, 1986, and the distribution of a stock dividend of one share of class B common stock of Nacco for every two shares of class A common paid in July 1986.

title: READER'S DIGEST INSERT FEATURES U.S. PARKS
description: The Reader's Digest, which has a fairly long and successful record of running advertiser-sponsored inserts, will present another imaginative entry with its May issue, a 12-page, four-color guide to our national parks called ''America's Parks -Our National Splendor.''

title: FOR EARLY BIRDS, EASTER IS A FLORAL TREAT
description: Manhattan's flower market glowed yesterday morning as wholesalers prepared a bounty of snow-white lilies, hot-pink hyacinths, tulips, orchids and violets for the Easter rush.

title: KEY OUTDUELS CLEMENS
description: Jesse Barfield's run-scoring single snapped a sixth-inning tie and Jimmy Key tossed a two-hitter over six innings tonight to outduel Roger Clemens and give the Toronto Blue Jays a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Market Place; Mutual Funds' I.R.A. Rush
description: MANY investors who placed their money in tax-deductible Individual Retirement Accounts for 1986 favored mutual funds as a reflection of the booming stock market. The nationwide I.R.A. rush built to a crescendo just before Wednesday's qualifying deadline and financial institutions kept their offices open - some until midnight - as they wooed accounts.

title: G.A.O. Backs Chip Duties
description: Japan is continuing to violate a semiconductor agreement with the United States, and the Reagan Administration's planned sanctions to enforce it would ''strengthen the credibility of the U.S.,'' a Congressional watchdog agency said today.

title: CHARTER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
American Express Net Off 21.4% in First Quarter
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its net income fell 21.4 percent in the first quarter.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CULTURAL LITERACY: What Every American Needs to Know. By E. D. Hirsch Jr. With an Appendix, ''What Literate Americans Know,'' by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph Kett and James Trefil. 251 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

title: Don't Be Afraid of 'Da'
description: The 1979 NATO decision to put medium-range American missiles in Europe unless the Russians pulled theirs out is now coming full circle. Mikhail Gorbachev said yes, his would go. The major European allies then said something would have to be done about the huge Soviet advantage (estimated to be 9 to 1) in shorter-range missiles. Mr. Gorbachev said get rid of them all.

title: UNION STILL ON STRIKE AT ABC
description: Members of the Writers Guild of America who work for CBS voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a contract proposed by CBS and end a six-and-a-half-week strike against that network.

title: Neil Effman, Airline Official; Developed Pan Am Shuttle
description: Neil Effman, a former executive with Trans World Airlines for 25 years, died of a heart attack Tuesday while on vacation in Mexico. He was 52 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $297,000. The bank converted to stock form in December.

title: STARTS OF HOUSING FALL 3.2%
description: Housing construction fell 3.2 percent in March, the biggest decline in six months, the Government reported today.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 15 percent stock dividend paid January.

title: WOOD SHAPES UP AS TEST FOR CAPOTE
description: Capote was beaten 9 1/2 lengths while finishing behind Gone West, Shawklit Won and Gulch in the Gotham Stakes 13 days ago. But he has been made the morning-line favorite to beat them, and five others, in the $595,500 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct tomorrow.

title: Irene Reid, Basie Singer
description: Irene Reid, formerly a singer with the Count Basie band, is performing through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: FILM: 'WILD THING'
description: WHO is ''Wild Thing''?

title: KEYSTONE HERITAGE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect 6 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS SECORD ON BANK SECRECY
description: A Federal judge today refused to order Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord to waive the secrecy of foreign bank accounts that are linked to the Iran-contra affair - a decision that could seriously hinder the work of Congressional investigators.

title: 19 Films Chosen to Vie For Top Cannes Award
description: Entries from France, Italy, the United States and Britain dominated the 19 films announced today to compete for the Golden Palm Award for best film at the 40th Cannes Film Festival May 7 to 19.

title: 2 Named by Cuomo To Ethics Commission
description: Governor Cuomo today appointed John D. Feerick, dean of the Fordham University School of Law, as chairman of the commission on government ethics formerly headed by Joseph A. Califano Jr. Mr. Califano, whose leadership of the panel was strongly opposed by many legislators, was removed under an agreement last week between Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders that limited the panel's membership to residents of New York State. Mr. Califano lives in Washington.

title: HOME FEDERAL BANK OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $115,000 and a charge of $202,000 for the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Foes of Chicago Mayor Lose
description: In sharp contrast to the opposition raised on the City Council to Mayor Harold Washigton's proposals in his first term, the Council voted overwhelmingly today to remove two of Mr. Washington's foes from powerful committee posts and replace them with his supporters. By a vote of 40 to 9, Alderman Edward Burke, head of the Finance Committee, was replaced by Alderman Timothy Evans and Alderman Theris Gabinski, head of the Zoning Committee, was replaced by Alderman Danny Davis. The April 7 election gave Mr. Washington a big majority on the 50-member council.

title: EQUITABLE BANCORPORATION (BALTIMORE, MD)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARGONAUT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sales of investments of $7,100,000 for the latest quarter and $1,000,000 for the year-ago period. Year-ago figures are pro forma.

title: PRESS MARAVICH
description: Peter (Press) Maravich, the father and former coach of Pete Maravich, college basketball's leading scorer, died at Highland Park Hospital Wednesday night. He was 71 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boy Caught in Custody Fight Is Brought Back to New York
description: A 2-year-old boy who has been the subject of a custody dispute since his father murdered his mother in 1984, was brought back to New York by his uncle yesterday after being surrendered by his grandparents in Indiana.

title: STRAWBERRY, METS TURN ON THE POWER
description: Power. The Mets have it. The Mets flaunt it. Dave Johnson loves it.

title: MANVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter earnings include a $9 million gain from the sale of the company's interest in two real estate joint ventures in Colorado and New Jersey. The year-ago quarter's net is restated to reflect a pension accounting change.

title: BLOC WAS PREPARED TO CRUSH SOLIDARITY A DEFECTOR SAYS
description: Soviet, Czechoslovak and East German troops were twice poised to invade Poland in the 16 months before the Polish Government crushed the Solidarity movement, according to an account by a defector from the Polish general staff.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: COLLEGES

title: S.A.T.'S ARE BIASED AGAINST GIRLS, REPORT BY ADVOCACY GROUP SAYS
description: High school girls get lower scores than boys on the Scholastic Aptitude Test because the tests are biased against girls, according to a report released yesterday by an advocacy group that monitors standardized testing.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IF this were a baseball column - actually, it is not dissimilar in the way it chronicles the fragile fortunes of highly competitive teams - the following yarn would recount the dramatic story of Le Chantilly, a three-star powerhouse back in 1978 that hit an extended slump three years later. Last season, a despairing front office brought in a new manager in hopes of rekindling the old flame. In fairy-tale fashion, the strategy paid off - the team once again looks like a pennant contender.

title: Tutu and Ministers Tell Botha of Defying Ban
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and 46 Anglican ministers wrote to President P. W. Botha today to endorse civil disobedience against a Government decree outlawing organized protest against detention without trial.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Builder to Examine 2 Queens Towers
description: Saved from demolition on Monday with minutes to spare, the towers and entryway of the 102-year-old trolley station in Woodside, Queens, may become part of a new shopping center at that site, Borough President Claire Shulman has announced.

title: First Interstate Net Rises 5.7%
description: First Interstate Bancorp said today that first-quarter earnings totaled $83.5 million, or $1.76 a share, up 5.7 percent from $79 million, or $1.71 a share, a year ago.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 382 money market mutual funds increased $333.4 million, to $237.16 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds were down $836.1 million, to $64.82 billion. Assets of the 196 general-purpose funds were up $1.78 billion, to $65.60 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds fell $613.4 million, to $106.74 billion.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 30 cents a share for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: FMC to Appeal Dismissal of Suit
description: The FMC Corporation said it would appeal a Federal Court ruling that dismissed its lawsuit against Ivan F. Boesky, Goldman, Sachs & Company and others. The $260 million lawsuit, filed last December, alleged misuse of information and price manipulation relating to FMC's $2 billion recapitalization completed last year, it said. Goldman, Sachs acted as investment adviser to FMC during its restructuring. The suit also alleged that Boesky, the former stock speculator who settled insider trading charges last year, misused confidential information about the recapitalization.

title: CARTERET SAVINGS BANK FA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $5,471,000. c-After a tax credit of $9,502,000 and an extraordinary charge of $407,000 for the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Misjudging the Frankfurter Chats
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTORED APARTMENTS: ELIGIBILITY IS DEBATED
description: In Harlem, the South Bronx, Bedford-Stuyvesant and many other New York City neighborhoods, nearly 5,500 apartment buildings sit stripped and abandoned. For more than a decade, they have symbolized the decline of once-vibrant residential communities.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''WHY don't you do a lot of the material that's unknown in the United States?'' asked Miche Brel, the widow of Jacques Brel. She was talking to Andre Ernotte, who was in Europe at the time, and for a moment, Mr. Ernotte thought she must be kidding. But only for a moment, because there in front of him was a treasure trove of songs. He chose 20 of what he termed the ''most theatrical and dramatic,'' and that's how the planned production of ''Jacques Brel Blues'' came into being.

title: ELECTROMAGNETIC SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A SASSY GUIDE TO THE STATUES HANGING OUT IN CENTRAL PARK
description: THERE is a rumor - neither confirmed nor denied by city officials - that some pigeons from out of town, seeking a spot for their annual convention, have turned down Central Park because they find the statues dull.

title: Treasuries Continue Recovery
description: The rebound in prices of Treasury debt issues continued yesterday, with intermediate maturities closing with some of the best gains of the day. The shortening of maturities by investors increased the demand for Treasury bills as well, causing their rates to decline further.

title: IN MEXICO, THE GRAFT LOOSENS ITS GRIP
description: ''The phenomenon of corruption is like the garbage,'' Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza said. ''It has to be removed daily. We can't make it disappear altogether, but our objective is to lessen its presence within Mexican public administration.''

title: F.C.C. VOTES $3.50 PHONE ACCESS FEE
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to raise to $3.50, from $2, the monthly access fee levied on residential and small-business telephone customers.

title: ART: PEGGY GUGGENHEIM EXHIBITION
description: YOGI BERRA once said, ''It ain't over till it's over,'' and every year, regular as the output of a lithium battery, the World Series proves him right. The corollary to this is that when it's over it's over, and its proof is ''Peggy Guggenheim's Other Legacy.''

title: EASTERN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCERT: MAHLER WORK
description: AS an interpreter, Leonard Bernstein has always been temperamentally inclined to stretch toward the outer limits of credibility. His expansive reading last evening of Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony with the New York Philharmonic was perfectly in character for the orchestra's laureate conductor. If the means could be argued over, there was no question about the result: tremendously exciting and moving Mahler in the most apocalyptic Bernstein mode. If any work justifies such an interpretative conceit, of course, it is the ''Resurrection,'' and that was made clear in this singular but heart-piercing performance by a composer who has long been Mahler's most devoted secular prophet.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $9.1 million. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $10.8 million from redemption of debentures.

title: BARD, C R INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
15 EMPLOYEES OF WALL STREET FIRMS ARE ARRESTED ON COCAINE CHARGES
description: Fifteen employees of Wall Street firms, including brokers and a senior partner, were arrested by Federal agents yesterday and charged with selling cocaine and trading the drug for stocks, information and lists of preferred customers.

title: KRAFT IS TO BUY FLYING FOODS
description: Kraft Inc., the food giant, is negotiating to buy Flying Foods International Inc., a small New York business that supplies exotic fresh foods to restaurants all over the country.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,887,000 from a pension plan termination for both periods and a loss of $1,590,000 and $4,949,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from equity in the extraordinary loss of an affiliate. c-Includes a loss of $268,000 and $1,221,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from equity in an extraordinary loss of an affiliate.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jeffrey Schanzer and Mark Howell, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). Jeffrey Schanzer and Mark Howell are improvising guitarists, exploring the areas opened up for the instrument by rock's Jimi Hendrix and free music's Derek Bailey. Mr. Schanzer's band will include the saxophonist Marty Ehrlich, who has been proving his mettle in a variety of jazz situations. Mr. Howell's group includes the saxophone deconstructionist John Zorn. The performance begins at 9 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Misjudging the Frankfurter Chats; Equal Proselytizing
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's always great when someone sees value in your work. I think they are responding to the humanity of the characters, recognizing themselves on some level. Of course, it is a black family. Maybe, for the first time, a general audience has been touched by blacks.'' - August Wilson, author of ''Fences,'' winner of the Pulitzer Prize for drama. [ B5:3. ]

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RHNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes the cumulative effect of accruing unbilled revenue of $91,323,000. The company said that its earnings were reduced by 31 cents a share due to a change in the method of recording revenue from the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant. In addition, earnings were reduced by 14 cents a share by a one-time charge related to a voluntary retirement program.

title: A Dawning Revolution in Israeli Politics
description: LEAD: There is something new in the air and it is not just spring. For the first time ever, there is talk here of a sweeping change of leadership. Unlike Menachem Begin's victory of 1977, when an angry and disillusioned electorate kicked out one team to put in another, the urge these days seems to be for a deeper change that would cut across party lines.

title: Philips Discusses Medical Venture
description: Philips Gloeilampen Fabrieken N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, said it was talking with the General Electric Company about a cooperative agreement between its medical unit and G.E.C.'s medical subsidiary, Picker International Inc.

title: STAGE: BEIJING ACROBATS
description: THE art of the acrobat is exactly that in the hands of its Chinese practitioners. And the Beijing Acrobats troupe now touring the United States is well within that time-honored tradition.

title: O.K. Armstrong, 93, Journalist and Teacher
description: O. K. Armstrong, a teacher and journalist who served two terms in Congress, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 93 years old.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect 3-for- 2 stock split paid in December 1986.

title: REPAIRS TO F.D.R. DRIVE TO REQUIRE 27 MONTHS OF MIDTOWN DETOURS
description: Reconstruction of the sea wall along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from 42d to 54th Street will force extensive lane closings and detours for 27 months, the City Transportation Comissioner, Ross Sandler, announced yesterday. The work is to begin Monday.

title: CITATION FOR EX-CHAIRMAN
description: The Pulitzer Prize Board awarded Joseph Pulitzer Jr. a special citation ''for extraordinary services to American journalism and letters during his 31 years as chairman of the Pulitzer Prize Board and for his accomplishments as an editor and publisher.''

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in March.

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two-Car Family
description: Romance in the workplace is nothing new, and neither are marriages. But for Wally and Robin Dallenbach, both auto racers, last weekend at Road Atlanta did mark something novel. For the first time, both were racing at the same track, and longtime pit-side observers say they can't recall a previous appearance at a major event of spouses competing on the same card.

title: LURIA, L & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest year net includes the cumulative effect of an accounting change in 1987, which increased net income by $608,000.

title: Jazztet at Sweet Basil
description: Benny Golson on saxophone and Art Farmer on fluegelhorn will lead their six-piece Jazztet tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: 'To Be a Priest,' A Channel 13 Documentary
description: ''To Be a Priest'' is reverential, although in these disputatious times that may be a relief. The Vatican speaks; all over the world, critics grumble. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, has nothing to do with that. It looks at the life of a contemporary parish priest. Sometimes this is slow going, but stay with it because there are rewarding moments. They come when the priest meets people.

title: FILM: JOE ORTON'S LIFE, IN 'PRICK UP YOUR EARS'
description: LIKE John Lahr's 1978 biography of Joe Orton, the English playwright, the screen adaptation of ''Prick Up Your Ears'' comes immediately to the harrowing point: Kenneth Halliwell's hammer-murder of Orton, his lover and friend; his own suicide, and the subsequent discovery of the bodies.

title: MEESE INVESTED OVER $50,000 WITH FIGURE IN WEDTECH CASE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d invested more than $50,000 in 1985 with a financial consultant to the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor at the center of an inquiry into corruption, according to Government filings.

title: A RETURN TO CONDE NAST FOR SPORTS PUBLISHER
description: Sal Schiliro is returning to Conde Nast, where he was once publisher of Gentlemen's Quarterly, to be publisher of its Street & Smith Sports Group.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Navy Returns Fire In Attack on Carriers
description: To the Editor:

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform with the current period presentation.

title: CENTRAL BANKING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dow Off 6.96 in Late-Session Decline
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday as positive events, including a stronger dollar, lower interest rates and several reports of improved earnings, failed to support blue-chip equities.

title: S.I. Man Is Indicted In Woman's Death
description: A Staten Island man was indicted in Brooklyn yesterday in connection with three murders, including the execution-style slaying of a woman who was abducted last year.

title: Pay 'N Pak Stores
description: Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc. said that its board had decided to solicit potential buyers for the company. The company said it would hold discussions with those parties that have already expressed an interest in acquiring it. But Pay 'N Pak said its board had rejected a $19-a-share bid from the investor Paul Bilzerian as inadequate, although it said it was willing to discuss the bid with Mr. Bilzerian.

title: 'THE LAST INNOCENT MAN' ON HBO
description: THE Home Box Office movie ''The Last Innocent Man,'' starring Ed Harris and having its premiere on the pay-cable service Sunday at 8 P.M., proceeds on the premise that, with the possible exception of drug dealers, a certain class of lawyers may be today's true social villains.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on March 29 about Judge Harvey R. Sorkow's conduct of the Baby M trial described the legal history of surrogate motherhood incompletely. A Michigan ruling in March 1986 declared a couple the legal, biological parents of an unborn child being carried for them by a surrogate mother. The embryo had been conceived through fertilization in vitro and carried to term by the surrogate mother.

title: BANCORP HAWAII CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tony Williams Quintet
description: Tony Williams, on drums, is leading a quintet - with Billy Pierce on saxophone, Wallace Roney on trumpet, Mulgrew Miller on piano and Charnett Moffett on bass - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $84,000.

title: LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in February. Certain 1986 costs have been reclassified in the statements of operations to conform with current presentation.

title: 4 Are Named to Win Champion Art Awards
description: A bank, an artists' colony and two individuals are the recipients of the first Champion of the Arts Awards, given by the New York Foundation for the Arts. The recipients are Chemical Bank; the artists' colony Yaddo in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.; Howard Klein, of the Rockefeller Foundation, and Ellen Stewart, founder of La Mama Experimental Theater Club.

title: Fanfani Forms Cabinet In Italy; June Vote Seen
description: Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani today told Italy's President he can form a Government, which political sources said would take Italy to early general elections in June.

title: STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,700,000, or 36 cents a share, from adoption of pension accounting change.

title: RJR NABISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $208,000,000, which was offset by after-tax expense provisions of $209 million for equipment and facilities writedowns, restructuring costs and the costs of early retirement of high-interest debt. c-Includes a gain of $11 million from discontinued operations.

title: Pollard Sentence Is Way Out of Line
description: To the Editor:

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter and year-ago period include foreign currency exchange losses of $14.5 million and $16.1 million, respectively.

title: MUSIC: AFRO-AMERICAN 'SPIRITUAL HERITAGE'
description: THE repertory of Afro-American spirituals, to which tribute was paid Sunday night in Carnegie Hall in a new suite for chorus, orchestra and soloists called ''The Spiritual Heritage,'' has been an ornament to a formal concert life enriched by the participation of black American singers. Spirituals have been to Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price and Kathleen Battle what Neapolitan songs were to Caruso, Gigli and Di Stefano: music in which glorious voices could mingle with a folk idiom of looser disciplines and more spontaneous expressiveness. That and more: They nobly embody a heritage of faith and struggle that cannot fail to move an audience.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: Bill Denehy, the baseball coach at the University of Hartford, was dismissed yesterday over remarks attributed to him following two brawls with Connecticut. The dismissal came after Denehy, a former pitcher with the Mets, the Senators and the Tigers, was quoted in The Norwich Bulletin as saying that ''UConn has no . . . class, none whatsoever.'' In a reference to Mitch Pietras, the Connecticut assistant coach, Denehy was quoted as saying, ''I hope when he comes up to Hartford somebody bombs his car.''

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trio at Cafe Lido
description: The trio of James Williams on piano, Harvie Swartz on bass and Eliot Zigmund on drums will perform tonight and tomorrow at Garvin's Cafe Lido, 15 Waverly Place (533-4151). Music begins at 8:30 P.M.; there is no cover or minimum.

title: LOUISIANA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mr. Reagan Aims, at America's Foot
description: Today could be the day President Reagan goes to war - against the United States. He is scheduled to sign an order doubling the price of an array of electronic imports from Japan. If he goes through with it, the Japanese would surely feel the blow, but so would all America.

title: McNamara's Balk
description: John McNamara, the Red Sox manager, is worried about a potential conflict with his ace right-hander, Roger Clemens, in connection with selecting pitchers for this season's all-star team. So McNamara wants somebody else to pick the pitching staff, and he plans to discuss that idea with the league president, Bobby Brown.

title: LADD FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FILM: WILL VINTON'S 'FESTIVAL OF CLAYMATION'
description: ''CLAYMATION'' is the name imposed by Will Vinton on his technique for making animated movies with clay figures. It's a clunky word, appropriate to what is often a clunky form. A 90-minute sampler of the Vinton group's work over the past several years, ''The Festival of Claymation,'' can be seen starting today at the Bleecker Street and Metro Cinemas.

title: LeRoy's Train
description: When Warner LeRoy built his flashy restaurant, Potomac on the River, in Georgetown, he encircled the dining area with a model train track, complete with locomotive and cars. But the system has given trouble and, at the moment, doesn't run.

title: Clean Needles Program Has to Be Long-Term
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Editorial Notebook; It's Not Tia-Wanna Anymore
description: Peer south from Otay Mesa in this southernmost part of California and you can see the future. Scrub grass and bare canyon stretch to the border. Then, suddenly, on the hilly Mexican side, the vista is transformed into city. Twin 40-story hotel towers rise from an urban center. The receding hillsides bristle with thousands of tents, shacks and concrete block houses. The flats below are packed with hovels, sticks and blue plastic.

title: Plant Use Declined In March
description: American factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.2 percent of capacity in March, down from 79.7 percent in February and the lowest level in four months, the Government reported today.

SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: New York State Also Trains the Poor for Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Moody's Cuts Mellon Rating
description: The debt rating of the Mellon Bank Corporation and its subsidiaries was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service. About $1.5 billion of long-term debt is affected.

title: Looking Toward '88, Some See a Mirror in '60 and '76
description: The campaign of 1988, they are saying around Washington these days, will remind us of those of 1960 and 1976.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 NATO foreign ministers were cool to the idea of eliminating short-range missiles in Europe after Secretary of State George Shultz briefed them on his talks with Moscow about short-and medium-range arms. Page A1 News analysis: Negotiations within NATO and the Reagan Administration over removing nuclear missiles from Europe may be as difficult as the bargaining Goerge Shultz just completed with Moscow. A8 The U.S. was unprepared to bargain with Moscow on arms control, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said. He warned that extensive delays would endanger prospects for an arms agreement. A8 Reagan plans to consult allies A8 Controls on exports of large missiles and related technologies were agreed to by the U.S., Japan and five major allies. The pact was made in an effort to limit the spread of nuclear weapons. A1 Argentine President Raul Alfonsin refused to negotiate with rebellious army officers in the provincial capital. An officer had refused to be questioned about allegations that he took part in human-rights abuses. A1 Warsaw Pact troops were ready twice to invade Poland in the 16 months before the Government crushed the Solidarity movement, a defector from the Polish general staff has written in an emigre journal. A9 A dispute over space in the Louvre has forced French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur to fight to keep his offices in the palace against those who want to expand the museum into that space. A4 U.S. judge backs Secord A2 Regan backs Reagan A3 Mexico battles corruption A6 Anglicans to defy South Africa A7 Weinberger on Walker spies A9 NATIONAL A10-13, A32, D15 Raising interest rates could cause a recession in 1988, the President's budget director warned the Federal Reserve. The Fed had indicated it might have to increase rates to combat the dollar's fall. A1 Patenting new forms of animal life will be allowed under a new policy adopted by the Commerce Department. The policy specifically bars patenting of genetic characteristics in humans. A1 Restrictions on explicit language about sex and bodily functions on radio, telephone and telephone services were adopted by the Federal Communications Commission. The measures stemmed from mounting complaints. A1 Far greater cancer hazards may be caused by substances that are ignored by regulatory agencies than by some chemicals that have been banned, according to a new system of ranking dangers posed by carcinogens. A10 Formaldehyde a cancer hazard A10 The investigation of Morton Thiokol is focusing on whether the company committed fraud by supplying the Government with faulty rocket motors for the space shuttle Challenger. D15 Using motivational gurus to change the way employees think is being resisted by workers who say training programs use ''mind control'' techniques. Employers say they make workers more productive. A10 Senator Dole is confident of victory in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination. He said he had ''a good shot'' at defeating Vice President Bush, the favorite in the opinion polls. A11 The maker of the Dalkon Shield, the A.H. Robins Company, filed a reorganization plan in U.S. Bankruptcy Court. The plan provides for a $1.75 billion trust to administer claims by users of the contraceptive device. D1 An increase in telephone access fees of $1.50 for residential and small-business users was approved by the Federal Communications Commission. The monthly charge will increase to $3.50 over the next 2 years. D1 Henry Anatole Grunwald will retire as the editor-in-chief of Time, Inc., in December. Mr. Grunwald has occupied the post since 1979. Jason McManus, managing editor of Time magazine, will replace him. B5 Panel pursues cocaine allegations A11 Navy Secretary orders a look to future A32 Brain-graft patient sees hope D15 WASHINGTON TALK A12 Politics: For '88, some see a mirror in '60 and '76 Feud at Washington Times REGIONAL B1-5 Agents arrested 15 employees of Wall Street firms and charged them with selling cocaine and trading it for stocks and information. Brokers and a senior partner were among the people charged. A1 Pulitzers in drama and biography went to a play about black American life on the eve of the civil rights movement and a biography of Martin Luther King Jr. In journalism, The New York Times won two prizes. A1 Illegal immigrants from Ireland have made their presence felt in the old Irish neighborhoods of Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx. Many, however, fear the impact of a new immigration law. B1 Plans for filling vacant housing in New York City have caused a debate over whether low- or middle-income residents should be eligible to live in the buildings once they have been restored. B1 Record numbers of college applicants have been reported by admissions officers at many colleges. They say they had to reject students who would easily have been admitted a few years ago. B2 Legislators defended the ethics code for government officials that Governor Cuomo vetoed Wednesday. They complained that they were being treated unfairly in the growing public debate over the proposal. B3 Realty data law ruled invalid B1 Kawasaki plant helps Yonkers B1 S.A.T's called biased B2 3 deaths laid to Jersey hospitals B2 Repairs to alter East Side road B3 Meese's Wedtech ties deepen B3 State to press Koch on cable TV B5

title: Gilbert and Sullivan
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players present a double bill of ''Trial by Jury'' and ''The Sorcerer'' at Symphony Space this weekend, tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 4 P.M. Admission is $15 to $25; $10 to $20 for the elderly. Symphony Space is at 95th Street and Broadway; information: 864-5400.

title: Nancy Wilson to Sing
description: Nancy Wilson will be singing through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Shows begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $20 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $10 music charge at the bar.

title: TIME'S CHIEF EDITOR TO RETIRE AT END OF YEAR
description: Henry Anatole Grunwald, the gravel-voiced Austrian immigrant whose career at Time Inc. spanned more than 40 years, announced yesterday that he would retire in December as editor in chief of the company, a post he has occupied since 1979.

title: NEW ANIMAL FORMS WILL BE PATENTED
description: The Federal Government, in a decision with broad moral and ethical implications, said today that it was clearing the way for inventors to patent new forms of animal life created through gene splicing.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STORY OF BLACK LIFE IN 1950'S CAPTURES PULITZER FOR DRAMA
description: A play about black American life on the eve of the civil-rights movement, August Wilson's ''Fences,'' and a biography of the man who led that movement, ''Bearing the Cross: Martin Luther King Jr. and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference'' by David J. Garrow, won Pulitzer Prizes yesterday. Mr. Wilson is a self-educated ninth grade dropout, Mr. Garrow a professor and scholar.

title: NEW JOBS EASE PAIN AT ALLY
description: LESS than a month after the morale-destroying loss of the $25 million Federal Express account, Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising anounced yesterday that it had picked up three other pieces of business with combined billings in the neighborhood of $20 million.

61 for Jordan, 23 in a Row
description: Michael Jordan scored 61 points tonight to become the second player in National Basketball Association history to score 3,000 points in a season.

title: Relative Value

title: DOLE CONFIDENT HE CAN DEFEAT BUSH IN G.O.P. RACE
description: Nearing the end of a weeklong drive in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, Bob Dole expressed confidence today that he would defeat Vice President Bush, the favorite in the opinion polls.

title: INDEPENDENT BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Bridge: Six From Toronto Will Face U.S. Team in Jamaica Match
description: In odd-numbered years the world team championship is for the Bermuda Bowl, with representation by continental zones. In Jamaica in October North America will have a United States team, to be determined by a four-team playoff in Memphis in May, and a Canadian team.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Slump Worries Mattingly
description: The best hitter in baseball was sitting near his dressing stall the other day when a clubhouse attendant approached cautiously and asked him to autograph a couple of baseballs. Don Mattingly, soaked in perspiration from a session in the batting cage, smiled and obliged.

title: Paroled Ex-Lawmaker Held
description: Former Representative George Hansen of Idaho, the first Congressman to be jailed for violating finacial disclosure laws, was arrested at an airport here Wednesday night on parole violation charges, Tom O'Hara, a United States marshal, said. He said Mr. Hansen left Virginia, the state of his parole, several times, leading to the issuing of an arrest warrant. Mr. Hansen, 56 years old, was released last year from a Federal prison camp in Petersburg, Va., after serving six months of a prison term for violating the Ethics in Government Act. The House voted overwhelmingly to reprimand him in August 1984 and he lost his bid for re-election that year.

title: INVISIBLE ALIENS: IRISH FEAR EFFECT OF NEW IMMIGRATION LAW
description: Patrick, an Irishman who lives in this country illegally, resents being called an undocumented alien.

title: GURUS HIRED TO MOTIVATE WORKERS ARE RAISING FEARS OF 'MIND CONTROL'
description: In their zeal to become more competitive, American employers have turned increasingly to motivational gurus who say they can change how employees think. But now employers are encountering resistance from workers who assert that many of the training programs use ''mind control'' techniques or promote values alien to their religious views.

title: OLDER, WISER, RONNIE LANE FIGHTS BACK
description: THE last time Ronnie Lane performed in New York was in 1983, when he came onstage for the finales of the Action Research for Multiple Sclerosis benefit concerts at Madison Square Garden. The concerts were organized because Mr. Lane, who has multiple sclerosis, believed he could aid fellow victims. Surrounded by the likes of Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck and members of the Rolling Stones, the Who and Led Zeppelin, Mr. Lane, with a game but weakened voice, sang his own ''April Fool'' and Leadbelly's ''Goodnight, Irene.'' Few listeners expected a return appearance.

title: HIS TALKS WITHIN THE ADMINISTRATION AND WITH NATO COULD BE DIFFICULT
description: Now that Secretary of State George P. Shultz has finished three days of bargaining with the Russians on removing nuclear missiles from Europe, the other negotiations are beginning - those within the Reagan Administration and within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. And they may be nearly as difficult.

title: RANGERS' BIG GUNS MISFIRE
description: Lack of production in the playoffs by the leading scorers in the regular season was perhaps the biggest key to the elimination of the Rangers from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Economic Scene; The Strains With Japan
description: THE United States Government appears almost certain today to go through with its plan to impose 100 percent tariffs on up to $300 million in Japanese imports in retaliation for the purported dumping of semiconductors in third markets.

title: Wickes Sees Carpet Liability
description: The Wickes Companies said that, for a decade, its Collins & Aikman subsidiary produced and sold $360 million worth of commercial carpeting that did not meet all flammability tests.

title: TALKS A SECRET FOR FOUR YEARS
description: For more than four years, seven nations worked in secrecy to limit the export of large missiles. Today, as the controls were announced, the negotiators expressed relief and surprise that their work had not been disclosed ahead of time.

title: Pakistan Shoots Down An Afghan Warplane
description: Pakistani fighters shot down an Afghan warplane that crossed into Pakistan today, the Defense Ministry said, and Afghan guerrillas said they had downed a second plane.

title: Our Towns; A Slow Week For a Sky Diver Who Is Blind
description: Last summer, Marcy Catauro was at a nude beach when someone told her about a blind guy who sky-dives and was looking for a roommate to share an apartment. ''A blind guy who sky-dives?'' she said. ''That's funny.''

title: ARGENTINE CHIEF RESISTS DEMANDS OF OFFICERS REBELLIOUS OVER ARREST
description: In the face of an uprising by army officers, President Raul Alfonsin said tonight he would not negotiate, declaring that Argentines ''do not want to return to being the pariahs of the world.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A FEW floors above lived Greta Garbo, who in her day used to sit, swathed in a burnoose, on the sands of the Lido with Gayelord Hauser. Or was it Capri? In any case, Garbo was nowhere to be seen. Nor, despite a fondness for things Venetian, was Susan Gutfreund. ''She called in with a stiff neck,'' said Laurence D. Lovett, president of Save Venice Inc., seated on a sofa at Nin Ryan's apartment on the East River.

title: CHARLOTTE CURTIS, A COLUMNIST FOR THE TIMES, IS DEAD AT 58
description: Charlotte Curtis, a columnist for The New York Times and former editor of the newspaper's family/style news and later of its Op-Ed page, died of cancer yesterday at Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. She was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan and Columbus.

It lost $23.8 million during last year's first quarter.

title: G.M.'S GOODBYE TO THE BONUS
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would scrap its often controversial executive-bonus system in favor of a stock-option plan, but not before paying its chairman, Roger B. Smith, about $1.8 million in salary and bonuses for 1986.

'Sleight' Postponed
description: The opening of the Broadway show ''Sleight of Hand'' has been postponed until May 4, from its original date of April 26. The play will open at the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street. The opening was postponed by the producer, Suzanne J. Schwartz, to ''give the company a few more days to perfect the show,'' said the press spokeswoman for the show, Patt Dale.

title: HERBERT BLUMER
description: Herbert Blumer, an emeritus professor who was a longtime chairman of the Department of Sociology at the University of California at Berkeley, died Monday. He was 87 years old. Professor Blumer was a sociological scholar of the 20th century. Before joining the Berkeley faculty in 1952, he taught for 11 years at the University of Chicago, where he earned his doctorate in sociology.

The district president of the airline's machinists' union, Charles Bryan, denounced the move, saying it was part of a Texas Air plan to dismantle Eastern.
