title: Nukes Are Not Tanks
description: Europe's fear of eliminating short- as well as intermediate-range missiles from the Continent is based on the fallacy that their nuclear warheads are weapons, like battleships or tanks. They aren't, because they can't be used by rational leaders except to deter their use by others.

RICHARD WILBUR IS NAMED NATION'S POET LAUREATE
description: Richard Wilbur, a man of letters who has won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, the applause of theatergoers for his lyrics to the musical ''Candide'' and the praise of scholars for his translations of Moliere, was named today the poet laureate of the United States.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA GRAND JURY IS FOCUSING ON FUND-RAISER
description: The grand jury in the Iran-contra affair has questioned witnesses in recent days about their knowledge of a conservative Washington fund-raiser and his role in providing millions of dollars for Nicaraguan rebel groups, according to lawyers with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $60,000 and $151,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: NICARAGUAN INDIANS ARE BACK HOME
description: Overcoming their fears of war and defying the inhospitable rain forest, more than 10,000 Miskito Indian refugees have returned to their traditional homeland along the broad, free-flowing Coco River.

title: 4 Utilities to Assure The Poor on Service
description: Four utilities have agreed to participate in a program that guarantees yearlong gas and electric service to thousands of poor families. At least 20,000 of the 39,000 families in the state who receive public assistance are expected to be eligible for the program, which begins Monday.

title: Mt. Etna Eruption Kills Two
description: Ashes, gases and tons of rocks showered tourists on Mount Etna today, killing an 8-year-old French boy and his mother and injuring seven people, officials said. The police in this city on Sicily's eastern coast said all nine were among a group of tourists who were caught in a brief eruption while walking near the volcano's summit.

title: I.M.F. Studies Privatization
description: The goal of many governments to put state-owned businesses into private hands is easier to espouse than to carry out, the International Monetary Fund said in a report.

title: PHILIP CROSBY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Weapons and Parts Stocks Put Navy Readiness at Peacetime High
description: To the Editor:

title: CB&T FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HART TO SEEK RULING ON USE OF '88 FUNDS FOR '84 DEBT
description: Gary Hart's campaign manager said today that the campaign organization would ask the Federal Election Commission whether money raised for Mr. Hart's 1988 campaign could be used to help pay off the $1.3 million debt from his Presidential bid in 1984.

title: HAVANA REPORTS 3 CUBANS DEAD OF AIDS AND SETS UP ISOLATION UNIT
description: In its first extensive report on AIDS in Cuba, the Government said today that three Cubans had died from the disease and that it had created a special isolation unit for people discovered to be infected by the AIDS virus.

title: FOR THE HOMELESS: A NEW IDEA
description: An architect has designed his own low-cost solution to the problem of homelessness: a small weatherproof plywood shelter with windows, a mattress and a place to hang a hat.

title: Yankees Rained Out
description: The rain that pelted New York yesterday washed out the Yankees' game with Kansas City last night, but it created the possibility of an infrequent event at Yankee Stadium tomorrow: a doubleheader. The game was rescheduled as part of a 1 P.M. doubleheader, which would be the first at home for the Yankees since Sept. 29, 1985. The teams are also scheduled to play today at 1:30 P.M.

title: Don't Hang Up Modular Housing
description: How can costs of housing construction be brought within the reach of moderate-income New Yorkers? Modular or prefabricated units, turned out en masse by factories in the city, offer one answer. But realizing it requires the cooperation and careful planning of city officials, factory owners and unions - especially unions.

title: Night to Remember
description: The words on a 14-by-18-foot billboard outside the Spectrum in Philadelphia bore last night's theme: ''We'll never fill your shoes. Thanks for everything Doc.'' The words were surrounded by 50,000 signatures of Julius Erving's fans. It was Dr. J's last regular-season home game after 11 years with the 76ers, and a sellout crowd of 17,967 was present.

title: CONGRESS IS EXPECTED TO KEEP PRESSING FOR TRADE LEGISLATION
description: White House sanctions against Japan may shore up the Administration's credibility in Congress to conduct trade policy, but they will not stop moves to enact tougher trade legislation, according to many legislators and trade analysts.

title:
PATENTS;
Launching A Shuttle's Satellites
description: LEAD: METHODS of launching satellites from an orbiting space shuttle and landing them on the shuttle were patented this week for the RCA Corporation. The inventors are staff members at the RCA astrospace division in East Windsor, N.J.

title: Article 424387 -- No Title
description: The Chrysler Corporation paid its chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, $14 million in salary, bonus and stock in 1986, and he exercised stock options netting another $9.6 million, bringing his total compensation for the year to $23.6 million.

PACIFIC FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: 'Pygmalion' Postponed
description: The opening of the Broadway show ''Pygmalion,'' with Peter O'Toole and Amanda Plummer, has been postponed to April 26 from April 21. The revival of the Shaw play, which will be at the Plymouth Theater, 236 West 45th Street, is being produced by the Shubert Organization, Jerome Minskoff and Duncan C. Weldon.

Our Complicity in Trade Problems
description: LEAD: An oft-told anecdote among the British supposedly involved Winston Churchill and Lady Astor, a fellow Member of Parliament. One evening, Lady Astor approached Sir Winston at a party and said, ''You are drunk.'' Sir Winston retorted: ''Madam, you are ugly. But in the morning I will be sober.''

title: Correction
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about the Metropolitan Museum's acquisition of a photograph collection described the transaction incorrectly.

title: Sony Thai Project
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan plans to begin a $15 million project here to produce video and audio tapes, mainly for export, according to Chira Phanupong, head of Thailand's board of investment. Mr. Chira said Sony would probably receive investment tax incentives from his agency, which promotes foreign investment.

title: Correction
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about the rescheduled opening of the Broadway show ''Sleight of Hand'' gave an incorrect date. The play will now open May 3 at the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch from San Francisco yesterday about motivational training programs for workers misidentified a man from Carmel Valley, Calif., whose program is used by Pacific Bell. He is Charles Krone.

title: BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect the acquisition of White Technology Inc.

title: Ron Carter Quintet
description: Ron Carter, a bassist, is leading a quintet, featuring Kenny Barron on piano, through tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight and at 8 and 10 P.M. tomorrow; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title:
PATENTS;
A Dental Rinse For Plaque Removal
description: LEAD: Oral Research Laboratories, in New York, received a patent this week for a pre-brushing dental rinse trademarked Plax and the method of using it. It is said to remove more plaque than brushing alone can do.

title: Co-op Loan Shopping
description: DR. PETER HOFMANN, who lives in a Manhattan apartment building that was converted into a cooperative, was faced with a task recently that thousands of other apartment dwellers are faced with each year - finding a mortgage. Yet even though the sponsor of the conversion had arranged with one bank to supply mortgages in bulk to all of the tenants, Dr. Hofmann chose another. ''The bulk interest rate was 9 3/4 percent, but I'm only paying 9 percent,'' he said. ''The difference was significant.''

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 20
description: b-Includes a U.S. tax credit of $240,000 and a $380,000 gain from the sale of surplus equipment resulting from 1986 restructuring activities. c-Includes a European tax credit of $279,000.

title: Newton's Principia: Heroes, Legends and Myths; Einstein's Inclination
description: To the Editor:

title: CHESS AT NEW YORK OPEN: 'IT'S LIKE A WAR'
description: ''I could've been a contender,'' Asa Hoffmann said. ''I could've been a grandmaster.'' Instead, Mr. Hoffmann is a hustler, the Fast Eddie Felson of the knight and rook set.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $288,000 and $436,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also includes a loss of $2,027,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $167,000 for the quarter and $586,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest 9-month includes a $1.7 million loss on the first quarter sale of the company's dental laboratory business, which has been treated as a discontinued operation. The company also said the year-ago 9-month includes a $2.8 million, or 53 cents a share, gain on the first quarter sale of the company's plasma center and a $900,000 charge related the second quarter shutdown of certain facilities.

title: Citrus Disease in Florida
description: Citrus canker, a disease that ruins fruit and weakens trees but does not harm humans, has been found in Florida for the first time since January. But Kevin Kiefer, a supervisor of the Citrus Canker Project, says the infection of 10 trees in residential areas does not mean the blight is spreading. The new cases were found on Anna Maria Island and in south Bradenton.

description: b-Includes a provision of $2.3 million for the planned sale or liquidation of Control Laser Ltd.

title: Markets Shut Yesterday
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. The credit markets were also closed, as were most foreign markets.

Railroad to Settle Discrimination Suit
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company has agreed to buy about $33 million in goods and services from black and Hispanic companies to settle a discrimination lawsuit, according to court documents. The settlement, in which the railroad does not admit guilt, is the first resulting from a 1979 lawsuit filed against three railroads by the Chicago-based Organization of Minority Vendors Inc.

title: HINCKLEY'S FATHER PAID FOR EXPERT'S TESTIMONY
description: The United States Attorney's office here said today that a psychiatrist who testified last Monday in behalf of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s request to be released temporarily from a Federal mental hospital had not been paid by the hospital but by Mr. Hinckley's father.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $108,000, or 2 cents a share, from final proceeds for its Springfield, Mass., property.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People don't look up to chess players in this country. The public thinks all chess players are short, fat and wear glasses.'' - Asa Hoffmann, chess player for fun and modest profit. [ 24:2. ]

title: Tokyo Sees Violation Of Rules
description: Charging that the American decision to impose tariffs violated international trading rules, Japanese officials today called on the United States to withdraw the measures.

title: Italy Wine Exports Hurt
description: Italy's wine-doctoring scandal produced a sharp fall in exports last year, the Foreign Trade Institute said today. It said total exports of wine and vermouth fell 35.8 percent, to 242 million gallons in 1986, from 396 million gallons in 1985. Several countries imposed curbs on Italian wine imports following the scandal early last year, when 23 people died after drinking the cheap wine, adulterated with wood-based methyl alcohol. Earnings from wine exports fell to 1.26 billion lire ($968 million) last year, from 1,67 billion lire ($1.3 billion) in 1985, the institute added.

title: LOWELL INSTITUTION FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank went public May 1986.

title: MOSINEE PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEOUL ANNOUNCES A PLAN TO FREEZE ITS SURPLUS IN U.S. TRADE
description: In an attempt to forestall the sort of bitter trade dispute that led to United States sanctions against Japan, South Korea today announced a program to freeze its fast-growing trade surplus at current levels.

title: 7 CITIES PICKED IN PLAN TO FOSTER SCHOOL ATTENDANCE
description: A national business organization has named seven cities to participate in a project based on one here to encourage teen-agers to stay in school by offering them jobs after graduation.

description: Officials of the New York Racing Association expressed optimism about reducing the takeout on parimutuel wagers at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga.

GORBACHEV URGES MINORITY STATES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev suggested this week to a group of members of Congress that the United States solve its race problems by setting up separate states for blacks and other minorities, according to several members who were present.

Davis's 'Second Strike'
description: Walter Davis, the Phoenix Suns' all-star guard, has been suspended for cocaine use, General Manager Jerry Colangelo said in Phoenix yesterday. Colangelo said that Davis admitted he had become involved with cocaine again and would re-enter a drug-treatment program.

title: AGENCY STUDIES PLAN TO EVAPORATE 3 MILE ISLAND'S RADIOACTIVE WATER
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has begun considering a plan by the operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant to evaporate 2.1 million gallons of radioactive water into the atmosphere.

title: DISCLAIMER ON MILLER'S REMARKS
description: The White House today attempted to disassociate itself from comments by James C. Miller 3d, the budget director, who warned the Federal Reserve on Thursday that raising interest rates could lead to a recession.

MARINE CORPS CHIEF WARNS OF MANY MORE PROSECUTIONS
description: The investigation of security breaches by Marine guards at American embassies could lead to ''a far greater number'' of prosecutions than have begun so far, including charges against civilian embassy officers and employees, according to a memorandum endorsed last week by the Marine Corps Commandant, Gen. Paul X. Kelley.

title: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $1,574,000. c-After a tax credit of $1,663,000.

title: Argentina's Easter Rebellion
description: Sooner or later, some diehard officer in Argentina was bound to be loopy enough to believe that his country truly needed and wanted a fresh smack of military rule. Coups have long been the tradition, and not since 1930 has a civilian president completed his term. Proof that times are changing resounds in the country's response to an attempted rebellion in provincial Cordoba. It was led by a disgruntled major, who clearly picked the wrong time, opponent and cause.

title: ETHNIC JOKES IN CAMPUS COMPUTER PROMPT DEBATE
description: A collection of ethnic, racial and other jokes offensive to specific groups, all put into a computer by students at the University of Michigan in recent months, has provoked feverish debate over freedom of speech and computer propriety.

title: THE MONITOR SEEKING LISTENERS AS WELL AS READERS
description: The Christian Science Monitor, a 79-year-old newspaper with a distinctly contemplative approach to international affairs and a perennially unfavorable balance sheet, began short-wave radio broadcasts to three continents last month, part of a major shift in strategy by the church.

title: CONGRESS STREET PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $163,000 from the sale of real estate. c-Includes gains of $4,000 and $11,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the sale of real estate.

title: TWO ITALIAN PIES TO BRIGHTEN EASTER SUNDAY FEASTS
description: You have been invited to Easter dinner and asked to bring something to eat. The first thing that comes to mind is probably dessert, undoubtedly egg-shaped and made of chocolate. This indicates a definite lack of imagination, but at this late hour, panic is about to set in.

title: McKesson Unit
description: The McKesson Corporation said it had combined its divisions in health care systems, manufacturing and distribution to form a McKesson Home Health Care division. The three operations currently have annual revenues of more than $60 million.

title: 2 NAMED IN WORLD OF WORDS
description: President Reagan yesterday nominated James H. Billington, an expert on the Soviet Union, to replace Daniel J. Boorstin as Librarian of Congress. And Dr. Boorstin, who is retiring, named Richard Wilbur, a Pulitzer Prize winner, as poet laureate of the United States.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chemlawn Corp., Columbus, Ohio, said that because of an offer by Ecolab Inc. for Chemlawn shares at $36.50 each, it had postponed its annual meeting, which had been scheduled for April 23. No new date was set. The offer is to expire April 20.

title: MOXIE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year net is after a $383,000 reserve for assets of the chocolate beverage business and a $618,000 reserve for long-term notes receivable on a pre-tax basis. The prior year revenue has been restated from $39,172,000 to recognize the impact of selling Dari-Tech on July 14, 1986. The 1986 income is also attributable to the gain recognized on selling Dari-Tech to Bunge Corp.

title: MEN DISCOVER THE JOYS OF SALON PAMPERING
description: ''I'm from Morocco, and this makes me feel like a sultan,'' Leon Amar said as he lay stretched out on a table, his body swathed in a white sheet, his head wrapped in a white towel, his face smeared with cream.

title: Orpheus Replaces I Musici
description: I Musici, the Italian chamber group, will not appear Monday night at 8 at Carnegie Hall because one of the musicians is ill. Appearing instead will be the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which will perform works by Haydn, Mozart and Bartok. The guest soloists are David Jolley, a french horn player, and Charles Neidich, a clarinetist. Tickets for the performance by I Musici will be honored Monday evening.

title: A SCHOLARLY LIBRARIAN: JAMES HADLEY BILLINGTON
description: It was rush hour on the Moscow subway, with thousands of commuters hurrying to and fro. In the middle of the crowd, oblivious to the tumult about him, an American scholar was pointing out mosaics on the walls of the subway station. The scholar, James

description: The Wall Street drug dealer looked like many other successful young female executives. Stylishly dressed and wearing designer sunglasses, she sat in her 1983 Chevrolet Camaro in a no-parking zone across the street from the Marine Midland Bank branch on lower Broadway.

PRESIDENT IMPOSES TARIFF ON IMPORTS AGAINST JAPANESE
description: President Reagan, asserting that he was trying ''to enforce the principles of free and fair trade,'' imposed a 100 percent tariff today on some Japanese-made computers, television sets and power tools.

title: LATIN AMERICAN DEMOCRACIES STILL IN FEAR OF THEIR ARMIES
description: The latest crisis between Argentina's civilian Government and a group of military officers has coincided with growing concern over the vulnerability of new democracies throughout Latin America.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN OF CHATTANOOGA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted to stock form in December.

title: Helicopter Crashes in Idaho
description: A chartered helicopter carrying state Fish and Game officers on a survey of bighorn sheep crashed in a rugged wilderness area, and the pilot is feared dead, the authorities said today. The pilot's identity was not immediately known. Two department officers who were flying as passengers suffered injuries when the helicopter went down in the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness.

title: Taiwan to Buy in U.S.
description: Taiwan said today that it would send a mission to the United States in June to buy $450 million of products, and it reached agreement with the United States on terms that would allow more American insurance companies to operate here.

title: New Drug Problem
description: The San Francisco Giants announced yesterday that Eddie Milner, the 31-year-old outfielder acquired Jan. 8 from the Cincinnati Reds for Frank Williams, a pitcher, had voluntarily entered a medical-counseling program for treatment of a drug problem. Al Rosen, the Giants' general manager, said said the outfielder, who was batting .222 with one run batted in, had been placed on the 21-day disabled list, but was expected to need 28 days for treatment.

title: 9 SENATORS TRY TO BLOCK FUNDS FOR U.N. OFFICE ASKED BY U.S.
description: Nine United States senators have begun an effort to block money for a new United Nations information office sought by the United States Mission. The senators charge that the office will help Soviet spy efforts.

ROBERT H. BETHKE
description: Robert H. Bethke, a former chairman and chief executive officer of the Discount Corporation of New York, died of cancer Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Armonk, N.Y.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,382,000. c-After extraordinary losses of $2,544,000 and $2,470,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: The Crunch in Submarine Warfare
description: The Navy's fleet of attack submarines is caught between the Devil and a deep red ink ocean. Soviet submarines, once far inferior in stealth and technology, are rapidly catching up. And the Navy's attempt to regain its lead with an expensive new design, the SSN21 Seawolf, may help plunge the Navy into a severe budget crunch in the mid-1990's. Neither the Navy nor Congress yet has a grip on the underlying problem: American antisubmarine warfare has rested too long on its well-earned laurels, during a cascade of Soviet innovations.

title: CUOMO'S RISKY STRATEGY
description: Although Governor Cuomo's confrontation with the Legislature stems from a genuine desire to obtain a tougher code of government ethics, it also stems, in the view of both lawmakers and some administration officials, from just plain anger and a calculated strategy that the dispute will strengthen the Governor politically.

title: LA JOLLA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PISA IS HOPIN TO GIVE LEANING TOWER A REST
description: ''The problem is no one really knows why this tower doesn't fall,'' said Giuseppe Toniolo, the tower's white-haired keeper, gazing at it through finely traced Gothic windows. ''From an engineering point of view, it's an enigma.''

title: Newton's Principia: Heroes, Legends and Myths; Halley's Intervention
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Cites Need To Compete Better
description: The General Motors Corporation believes it must become more competitive with other auto makers in the next five years or stop building cars in the United States, a senior G.M. official was quoted as saying. The Detroit Free Press quoted Alfred Warren, G.M.'s industrial relations vice president, as saying, ''We've got about three to five years to either get our act together or get out of the business.''

Though some of the individual projects have merit, the general practice does not - yet the Legislature has continued its extravagance.

Sports of The Times; CORDERO CRUISING IN WAKE OF SUCCESS
description: Angel Cordero Jr. was named to ride four horses at Aqueduct yesterday, but took himself off the first three, telling the track stewards he wanted to observe Good Friday. He was excused from his early mounts in minor races and suited up only to ride King's Swan, the morning-line favorite in the $177,300 Excelsior Handicap.

title: ALLIANCE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bird Outduels Jordan: Larry Bird scored 38 points to lead the Boston Celtics to a 108-105 victory night over the Chicago Bulls last night in Boston. The Bulls' Michael Jordan scored 17 points and missed the last 18 minutes with an apparently minor thigh injury. Jordan, who scored a regular-season career-high 61 points Thursday night, was forced out because of a bruise suffered in the 117-114 loss Thursday night to Atlanta. He had scored at least 50 points in each of his previous three games before last night. Boston improved its record to 58-23, one game ahead of the Hawks. The teams play at Boston Garden in the season finale tomorrow, with the winner getting a homecourt advantage throughout the Eastern Conference playoffs. An Atlanta victory would give the Hawks the same record as Boston, but their 4-2 head-to-head edge would give them the homecourt edge. Chicago finished the regular season at 40-42.(AP) Horse Racing Lac Ouimet Wins: Lac Ouimet scored an easy five-length upset victory on wet footing yesterday in the $177,300 Excelsior Handicap at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old son of Pleasant Colony and Northern Sunset was second to King's Swan for nearly six furlongs, then surged to the lead and drew off at every call. Alioth was a steady second, 3 1/2 lengths in front of Proud Debonair. Lac Ouimet paid $17.60 for $2 to win as the fifth choice in a field of nine and covered the mile and a quarter in 2:02. Ice Hockey World Championships Begin: Canada edged the United States, 3-1, yesterday on the opening day of the 52d world hockey championships in Vienna. In other first-day matches, the defending champion Soviet Union crushed Switzerland, 13-5; Sweden, last year's losing finalist, shut out West Germany, 3-0, and Czechoslovakia beat Finland, 5-2.(AP) Tennis Graf Gains: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany defeated Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-1, 6-0, in the quarterfinals of the Women's International Tennis Association Championships in Amelia Island, Fla. Graf will face fifth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini in today's semifinals. Sabatini downed Helen Kelesi of Canada. Second-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia earned a semifinal berth by defeating Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y. Mandlikova will oppose Zina Garrison, who defeated Kathy Rinaldi.(AP) Golf Hayes Keeps Lead: Mark Hayes, shot a three-under-par 68 and retained a one-stroke lead after the second round of the Heritage Classic at Hilton Head Island, S.C. Larry Mize, the Masters champion failed to make the cut.(AP) Surprise Leader: Missie McGeorge, who ranks 63d on the Ladies Professional Golf Association's money-winning list this year, fired a six-under-par 66 to take a two-stroke lead after the first round of the Santa Barbara Open in Santa Barbara, Calif. She had missed the cut in four of her eight tournaments this year. Dale Eggeling was second with 68.(AP) Diving Louganis Loses Again: At Baton Rouge, La., Kent Ferguson won the 3-meter springboard event last night at the United States Diving indoor championships, taking another title held by Greg Louganis for six of the past seven years. Ferguson scored 660.84 points to 644.31 for Louganis. It was the second night in a row that Louganis - considered American's premier diver - had lost an indoor title to one of his teammates. In Thursday's 1-meter finals, Louganis finished second to Doug Shaffer. In women's action, Megan Neyer won her 13th national title, taking the 3-meter springboard finals. Neyer's triumph over Kelly McCormick came on her last dive. The five-day meet ends today with the men's and women's 10-meter finals.(AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 18, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5,20 President Reagan imposed a tariff of 100 percent on some Japanese-made computers, television sets and power drills. Mr. Reagan said he was trying ''to enforce the principles of free and fair trade.'' Page 1 In Sri Lanka, guerrillas killed 107 civilians on three buses and two trucks. The Tamil guerrillas dragged passengers onto the jungle road and killed them with machine guns and grenades, officials said. 1 Rebel Argentine Army officers opposed to the prosecution of military men on human-rights charges faced action by the military command. Troops took position outside a base where the last of the officers were holding out. 1 The crisis in Argentina coincides with growing concern over the vulnerability of new democracies throughout Latin America. Several countries have recently been shaken by power struggles or rumors of possible takeovers. 5 A Soviet nuclear test proposal that would allow each superpower to conduct a test on the other's territory in order to improve verification techniques was discussed in Moscow, American officials said. 1 Helmut Kohl is in a bind as the major Western European nations shape their response to proposals for the elimination of all Soviet and American ballistic missiles in Europe. 4 U.S.-Soviet human-rights discussions left the American delegation pessimistic about a significant, long-term increase in Jewish emigration, the State Department's senior human-rights official said. 5 Some Miskito Indians returned to their traditional homeland along the Coco River in Nicaragua. ''Let's see if we can make this river bank live again,'' said one of the more than 10,000 Indians reclaiming their villages. 3 Soldiers loyal to Ferdinand Marcos forced their way into a military camp in Manila and occupied the main headquarters of the Phillipine Army. But officers loyal to the government said the situation was under control. 3 A fund-raiser is being investigated by a grand jury in the Iran-contra affair. Witnesses have been questioned about Carl R. Channell and his role in providing money to the contras. 3 3 Cubans reported dead of AIDS 2 Amsterdam acts against drugs 4 Marines foresee more arrests 4 Effort to block U.N. office 4 Gorbachev on races in U.S. 5 Plan for Tower of Pisa 20 NATIONAL 6-7, 13, 26 2,5.4,q>Tests of an advanced bomb detector will be conducted this spring by the Federal Aviation Administration. The system is designed to keep explosive devices from being loaded into cargo holds of airliners. 1 Man in the news: James H. Billington will be the 13th person to head the Library of Congress if his nomination is approved by the Senate. The position is at the pinnacle of American intellectual life. 26 A new poet laureate was named for the United States. Richard Wilbur, a man of letters who has won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, the applause of theatergoers and the praise of scholars, was appointed by the Librarian of Congress. 26 News analysis: Animal life patents, which are now allowed by the United States Patent and Trademark Office, are likely to spark a fierce debate, pitting companies against ethicists and animal rights groups. 6 The Christian Science Monitor seeks a wider audience through broadcasting. , It already produces radio and television reports for American stations and began short-wave broadcasts to 3 continents last month. 7 An election in Corpus Christi, Tex., for mayor gives voters a choice between a Vassar-educated woman from a wealthy New York family and a man who began life as a child of poor Mexican immigrants to South Texas. 6 Offensive jokes held in a computer at the University of Michigan have provoked debate over freedom of speech and computer propriety. The collection includes jokes about homosexuals, Jews and blacks. 6 Gary Hart will seek to use donations to his 1988 Presidential campaign to help pay the debt from his 1984 bid, officials said. ''This debt has to be paid off, and we're trying every legal avenue,'' one official said. 7 A psychiatrist who testified in court in behalf of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s request to be temporarily released from a Federal mental hospital was not paid by the hospital but by Mr. Hinckley's father, officials said. 26 Research on drugs to combat AIDS may be aided by a new development, scientists said. They reported the development of a way to make bacteria produce a key protein from the virus that causes AIDS. 2 Revised minority employment rules adopted by the Federal Communications Commission could result in closer scrutiny of the broadcast industry's efforts to recruit and promote minorities. 42 Shakeup of health officers planned 7 Plan to evaporate radioactive water at 3 Mile Island 7 Lead pollution down in 1985 13 Plan to foster school attendance 26 New idea for the homeless 26 Donator seeks return of $6 million from church 26 REGIONAL 21-24 2,4.3,q>News Analysis: Governor Cuomo's conflict with the Legislature stems from both a desire to obtain a tougher code of government ethics and from a calculated strategy that the dispute will strengthen him politically. 1 Would-be kings and queens of chess have joined 45 grandmasters at the Penta Hotel in midtown Manhattan, where they have gathered for one of the richest and most prestigious tournaments - the New York Chess Open. 1 A convicted airline hijacker escaped from a Federal prison 60 miles northwest of New York City yesterday, setting off a nationwide manhunt. The authorities said the inmate was considered ''extremely dangerous.'' 21 Street repairs are being delayed in Queens and the Bronx by investigations of two asphalt supply companies that were the low bidders for $6 million in New York City contracts, officials said. 21 Wall Street's drug subculture is very discreet, two Federal agents said after the arrest on drug charges of financial district workers. ''It is as if you could run into anyone you knowat any minute,'' one agent said. 21 A church-run shelter closed after serving more than 1,400 people since it opened in 1974. ''We're waiting to see what rises from the ashes,'' said the monsignor of Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. 23 Winning an award can be bittersweet in its dividends. Prize winners tell of a puzzling emptiness and disappointment as well as affirmation and financial reward, anxiety as well as eminence and entree. 21 Slaying stuns Forest Hills 22 6 escape fatal plane crash 22 L.I. trash barge in the Gulf 22 No closing for firm in drug raid 23 77 held in drug raids 23

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Dixons did not say whether the company had been contacted by interested buyers. Dixons had said previously that it was interested in acquiring Cyclops's Silo Inc. unit, which operates a chain of electrical appliance stores.

title: UNIBANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $516,000.

title: BONN AND ARMS PLANS: KOHL IN A BIND
description: As the major Western European nations shape their response to proposals for the elimination of all Soviet and American ballistic missiles in Europe, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany finds himself in an awkward bind.

title: KOOP PLANS A SHAKE-UP OF PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICERS
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop told members of the nation's corps of Federal health officers Thursday that they had grown sluggish and faced a major overhaul to deal more effectively with AIDS, natural disasters and drug abuse.

title: MEESE MAY END LINK TO A FIGURE IN WEDTECH CASE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d may end a $60,000 investment with a former director of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that is at the center of a Federal corruption investigation, his press spokesman said yesterday.

Is the Van Gogh Auction Price an Omen?
description: LEAD: Envision the scene. A room filled with wealthy collectors; dealers primed with bidding instructions from clients around the world; fascinated onlookers eager for excitement. Surrounded by security guards, the highly publicized treasures about to be auctioned are on view. There is a sense of occasion in the air.

title: Malaysia Dooms Traffickers
description: A Malaysian court today convicted two men of drug trafficking and sentenced them to death. The national news agency, Bernama, said Nordin Abu Bakar, 36 years old, a salesman, and Lim Kong Seong, a former technical school student, were charged under a law that carries a mandatory death sentence.

description: The Federal Communications Commission has adopted revised equal employment opportunity rules that could result in closer scrutiny of the broadcast industry's efforts to recruit and promote minorities.

title: H.C.A. Cool To Buyout Bid
description: An investor group's proposal to buy the Hospital Corporation of America for $3.85 billion brought a cool response today from the company's board, which took no action on the bid.

title: Plea by James Brady Rejected In Case Against Gun Maker
description: A Federal appeals court refused today to revive a lawsuit against the maker of the pistol that John W. Hinckley Jr. used to shoot President Reagan and his press secretary, James S. Brady.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 18, 1987
description: The Economy

title: CONSOLIDATED ENERGY PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes $784,000 equity loss from interest in a hotel partnership and a gain of $34,000 from sale of marketable securities. c-Includes $512,000 equity loss and $450,000 provision for loss on marketable securities.

title: Mauritius-Boeing Deal
description: Air Mauritius has leased a second Boeing 747 SP jumbo jet and will take delivery of two Boeing 767-200 long-range airliners in 1988, the airline's general manager said today. The second-hand 747, which was acquired on a renewable one-year lease, made its first scheduled flight, to Munich, West Germany, earlier this month, he said. The twin-engined 767-200's, costing a total of $130 million, are to be delivered early next year.

title: LAYING DOWN THE LAW AT THE 'CANNABIS CAFE'
description: A museum dedicated to the lore and enjoyment of marijuana opened on a busy canal-front street here last month and was immediately raided by the police.

title: CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION FOR SHARON
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation, once a major part of the financial empire of Victor Posner, the Miami financier, asked a Federal bankruptcy court in Erie, Pa., yesterday for protection from creditors.

title: Sri Lanka-I.M.F. Talks
description: Sri Lanka and the International Monetary Fund have broadly agreed on economic reforms, but tough negotiations will be necessary to win approval of loans of $240 million, a Government official said today. A senior official of the Finance and Planning Ministry said an I.M.F.-World Bank team would be in Colombo next month to start talks on details of a three-year reform of the island's economy.

title: Who Cares About the Hudson?
description: LEAD: Even as the fisheries of the major estuaries along the East Coast have been failing for years, the Hudson River continues to maintain abundant populations of its original spawning stocks. Scientists call this the ''enigma'' of the Hudson. But for fishermen, who have litigated and lobbied to protect the river's estuary, the reasons for the Hudson's health are clear.

title: PETROLEUM INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
3 Women Charged With Welfare Fraud
description: Three Union County women have been indicted on charges of cheating the county welfare system out of about $60,000 in separate cases, authorities said.

title: DIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net reflects change in accounting estimate of amortization of deferred acquisition costs. The share earnings, which are adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid as a 25 percent stock dividend on Jan. 8, 1987, are after preferred stock dividend requirements of $4,000 and $19,000 for the latest quarter and year, respectively, compared with $200,000 and $800,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $631,529 for the quarter and $436,270 for the 6 months, and a tax credit of $1,768,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $233,137 for the quarter and $781,194 for the 6 months. The latest quarter net includes a pre-tax gain of $5,526,154 on the sale of Lexicon's special computer terminal operations. The year-ago revenue is restated to reflect the sale of Lexicon's special computer terminal operations Dec. 15, 1986.

title: ALFRED LUCIEN FOULET
description: Alfred Lucien Foulet, professor emeritus of Romance languages and literatures at Princeton University and a faculty member for 40 years, died Wednesday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: MUSIC: BRAHMS BY AN ALL-STAR SEXTET
description: High-powered soloists do not always combine to make great chamber music. Goethe once defined chamber music as a discourse between reasonable individuals, and there are few things in life less reasonable than superstars. The Jascha Heifetz-Gregor Piatigorsky chamber music recordings of the 1960's, for example, all but transformed Mendelssohn's Octet and the Schubert Quintet (Op. 163) into violin concertos - fundamental misreadings, in other words, however brilliant. So one aproached a glittering Thursday evening concert at Carnegie Hall -devoted entirely to the Brahms string sextets played by the violinists Isaac Stern and Cho-Liang Lin, the violists Jaime Laredo and Michael Tree and the cellists Yo-Yo Ma and Matt Haimovitz - with some trepidation.

title: P.A.M. TRANSPORTATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VOTERS IN CORPUS CHRISTI WILL CHOOSE MAYOR TODAY
description: When Corpus Christi voters elect a new Mayor this Saturday, they will choose between a Vassar-educated woman from a wealthy New York family and a man who began life as one of eight children of poor Mexican immigrants to South Texas.

title: BUILDING A MANHATTAN EMPIRE
description: Olympia & York, the giant Toronto-based real estate company, came to New York 10 years ago to see the elephants and ended up buying the circus. Now the quietly effective Canadians, already the largest commercial landlord in New York, are negotiating to capture another mammoth chunk of the Manhattan market as well.

title:
PATENTS;
Herpes Treatments
description: LEAD: Harvey T. Collins, who has done research at the Provident Hospital and Medical Center in Chicago, was awarded two patents this week for methods of treating herpes simplex virus infection. Patent 4,657,933 covers application to the infected skin of a preparation in a coconut oil carrier. Patent 4,657,934 provides for the use of other vegetable oil carriers.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
High School to Close at 106
description: The 106-year-old St. Mary's Seminary, a Roman Catholic high school, will close after graduation on June 13. The Very Rev. Edward Gilbert, provincial of the Baltimore Province of the Redempterist Fathers, which operates the school, said this week that declining enrollment was a major factor.

title: HART JUMPS IN, RIVALS UNDISMAYED
description: PERCHED on a rock in Red Rocks Park, Colo., last Monday, Gary Hart became the third official candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''I make this race because I love my country and I want America to do better and move forward,'' the former Senator from Colorado said. He promised a campaign of ideas.

title: Helene Kurz to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jules I. Kurz of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helene Kurz, to Louis Posmantur, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Posmantur of Lawrence, L.I. Ms. Kurz and her fiance are both employed by the Equitable Financial Companies in New York, she as a marketing consultant and he as a sales representative. They plan to be married in June.

title: ONE OF THOSE DAYS? IT'S BETTER NOT TO PLAY
description: WHAT do you do on a day when you have an awful premonition that things are going to go wrong? Don't play. Yes, that's right - don't play. Because a feeling like that is invariably a valid foreboding, no matter whether it originates in unsynchronized biorhythms or any other way of being out of sorts.

title: 'LOST' ARTIST RECALLS DAYS OF THE W.P.A.
description: LEAD: FOR two months now, Ida Abelman has been in the throes of what she considers ''a happy nightmare.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TIRELESS EFFORT
description: LEAD: A STATE Supreme Court judge has given the operator of an automobile junkyard in Putnam County 60 days to remove several million tires. But town officials and the attorney for the operator say it will be virtually impossible to meet the deadline.

title: Perspectives: Low-Rise Innovation; Staten Island Project Is Back on Track
description: EIGHT years have passed since a developer succeeded in getting a plan for a 210-unit town-house development in the Arlington section of Staten Island through the city's reviewing agencies.

title: A PROPHET HONORED AT LAST IN HIS OWN LAND
description: SURELY NO ARCHITECT IS quite so much a prophet without honor in his own land as James Stirling, an artist of extraordinary inventive power who has had almost nothing to do in his native England for more than a decade. Mr. Stirling, who won the gold medal of the Royal Institute of British Architects in 1980 and the Pritzker Prize, often called architecture's Nobel, in 1981, had sat in London designing museums for Germany, civic buildings for Italy and academic buildings for the United States, and as his reputation had grown greater and greater around the world the absence of a major recent Stirling building in England had become something of a polite embarrassment.

title: Seeking Answers to Queens's Rise in Murders
description: A 54-year-old woman is stabbed to death when she interrupts a burglary in her home in Woodside, Queens.

title: Craftsman Farm
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING OLD WOOD NEW AGAIN WITH CHEMICAL PAINT STRIPPER
description: STRIPPING paint or varnish from a valued piece of wood furniture is a time-consuming, tedious job no matter what method is used. However, in many cases it is the only way to restore the original beauty of the natural wood, and it is an essential preparatory step before you can stain or bleach the wood.

One can have the best seeds or plants, put them in at the best time, keep them free of pests and diseases and still fail if the soil conditions are not right.

title: Doll Sold in Boston Arouses Protest
description: A bag lady doll being sold at an exclusive Boston store has stirred a protest by advocates for the homeless who say the doll is cruelly exploiting the disadvantaged for profits.

title: IS IT TIME TO WORRY ABOUT INFLATION?
description: THE decade was the 1970's and inflation had so warped the economy that some Americans actually hoarded pennies, because soaring copper prices had pushed the value of the copper in each coin above one cent.

description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: NO EX-OFFICIALS AS COUNTY CONSULTANTS
description: I read, with great interest, your article ''Gibbs Sets Out on His Last Career'' (March 29). Like many others who have worked with Mr. [ Edward M. ] Gibbs, I regret that the deputy county executive has decided to retire. Mr. Gibbs was a good deputy and before that he was a dedicated legislator.

title: PAX SYRIANA UNFOLDS UNDER CLOSE SCRUNITY IN LEBANON
description: IT is as if the Syrians had never left. Soldiers dressed in red uniforms and steel helmets man checkpoints built of bricks and sandbags in most streets of mainly Moslem West Beirut. Foot patrols armed with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades provide an imposing presence long lacking in this lawless city.

title: Christopher Stout Plans to Be Wed To Lisa C. Ulrich
description: Lisa Caroline Ulrich, a financial analyst at Paine Webber, and Christopher Kellogg Stout, a banking officer at Chemical Bank, are planning an October wedding. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Ulrich of Chappaqua, N.Y. Mr. Stout's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Prentice K. Stout of Wakefield, R.I., and Cuttingsville, Vt.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: THE Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is taking steps to provide long-term relief from flight delays at Newark International Airport, spending nearly $14 million to improve taxiways.

title: IN AFRICA, FRANCE IS STILL A MILITARY POWER
description: AFTER a highly publicized meeting with Muammar el-Qaddafi in Crete two years ago, President Francois Mitterrand of France received some of the most intense criticism of his long career. Conservative critics said Mr. Mitterrand had been duped by Colonel Qaddafi while the Libyan leader was in the process of reneging on an agreement by both countries to remove their troops from Chad. Critics portrayed Mr. Mitterrand as gullible and accused him of wavering in France's commitment to poverty-striken Chad, a former French possession torn asunder by civil war.

title: THE MARCOSES' MOONLIGHT SONATA
description: IMELDA MARCOS, FORMERLY of Manila, sits in her sunny Makiki Heights living room with a view of Honolulu, sketching vigorously on a yellow legal pad. Her husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, the exiled President of the Philippines, is asleep upstairs, taking the late-afternoon siesta his doctors have ordered.

title: Waiting for Burial In Maine
description: IN a nutshell, the problem in Kennebunkport, Me., was that anyone planning to be buried in the town's last open cemetery had to get in line and wait. Even Vice President Bush.

title: The TV Evangelists Thrive on Skepticism
description: To the Editor:

title: Robinson's Days: Sweet Memories
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DRIVING CURBS IN SEASIDE HEIGHTS
description: The Seaside Heights Borough Council has enacted an ordinance forbidding motorists from driving past certain points three or more times within an hour or six or more times within any three-hour period between 9 P.M. and 4 A.M.

title: JAPANESE TAKING TARIFFS IN STRIDE
description: Despite protests over the United States decision to impose tariffs on some Japanese electronic products, there is little fear here that the tariffs will touch off a trade war or fundamentally harm the close relations between the two nations.

title: KNOWING NO BOUNDARY
description: CAN A FRENCH chef find fulfillment cooking with Asian ingredients in an Italian restaurant? Jacky Robert can. He calls his experiment in culinary cross-pollination the ''cuisine of tomorrow,'' but at San Francisco's venerable Amelio's, Robert's culinary internationalism is very much of the here and now.

title: State to Compare Rents With Incomes
description: ANYONE who has searched for an affordable apartment in New York probably has heard about rich people who live in rent-regulated buildings and pay rents that look like grocery bills.

title: Trucker Trapped After Crash
description: A tractor-trailer overturned after colliding with a car on an eastbound lane of the George Washington Bridge early yesterday, trapping the truck's driver beneath the cab and blocking traffic for more than five hours, the Port Authority said.

title: TEXACO'S CHAPTER 11 THWARTS PENNZOIL
description: Texaco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in a move intended to keep Pennzoil from seizing any assets. Facing a court decision that it must post a $12 billion bond as it appeals a jury award to Pennzoil for interfering with Pennzoil's deal to buy Getty, Texaco said it had no choice after Pennzoil rejected a $2 billion settlement offer. But it placed only its corporate parent and two financial subsidiaries into Chapter 11, hoping to keep its operating units relatively untouched. James W. Kinnear, Texaco's chief executive, said the bankruptcy filing eased fears among its suppliers. Indeed, Texaco's stock suffered less than Pennzoil's.

title: House Speaker, in Soviet, Finds New Freedom There
description: The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Jim Wright of Texas, said on Soviet television today that the United States and the Soviet Union ''have a common purpose, and the common purpose is peace.''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Marine Discounts At Defender Industries Defender Industries has been in the marine-supply business for 48 years and in New Rochelle for 18 years at 255 Main Street, both for mail orders and counter service and with a small outlet for clearance items from the 220-page catalogue.

title: McCauley's Plot Revealed
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE SLEEPING BEAUTY' AWAKENS ANEW
description: EVER SINCE ITS PREMIERE IN St. Petersburg in 1890, ''The Sleeping Beauty'' has been admired for its sumptuous music by Tchaikovsky and dazzling choreography by Marius Petipa. Yet, if Russia is that ballet's birthplace, Great Britain may be its second home; many important productions of the ballet have taken place in Britain, and others have been staged elsewhere by British dancers.

title: BOOK AWARDS
description: Jean S. Harris, who is serving a 15-year sentence at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, has won the nonfiction award of the Westchester Library Association with her book, ''Stranger in Two Worlds.''

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. WILL STEP UP PUSH ON MISSILE ACCORD
description: President Reagan, sounding an optimistic note on the possibility of reducing medium-range nuclear weapons, said today that American negotiators would ''intensify'' efforts to resolve any remaining differences with the Soviet Union on the issue in Geneva later this month.

title: Dorothy Chanock To Marry June 20
description: The engagement of Dorothy Caeser Chanock to Robert Owen McCabe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aloysius B. McCabe of Washington and Wellfleet, Mass., has been announced by Martha Johnson Caeser of New Haven, mother of the bride-to-be. A June 20 wedding is planned.

title: Shultz's Easter Miracle
description: History may, as so many cynics have said, be merely a record of the crimes, follies and misfortunes of mankind, but it also has its miracles.

title: SLOAN FOUNDATION AWARDS 90 GRANTS
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation of New York has awarded $25,000 grants to 90 young scientists in chemistry, mathematics, economics and neuroscience.

title: FORGET FLIPPER - HERE'S THE NEWS
description: CREATIVE programming used to be a foreign concept to Spanish-language television stations. They were the only game in town, so they made do with a few crudely produced variety shows, occasional bullfights or dubbed episodes of Flipper, and anything else that Univision, the main supplier of Spanish programming, brought in from Mexico.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BOLET IN MONTCLAIR The pianist Jorge Bolet, known for his affinity for Liszt (he has recorded many Liszt works for London/ Decca), will be presented by Unity Concerts in Montclair next Sunday.

description: A NEW clause in labor contracts was announced in Worcester, Mass.: the dry workday.

description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: Constance Casari Wed To a Fellow Journalist
description: The marriage of Constance Casari, a copy editor on the cultural news desk of The New York Times, and Steven Reddicliffe, editor of the Part II feature section of New York Newsday, took place yesterday in Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. Dr. Otis Young performed the ceremony at the First Plymouth Congregational Church.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: REASONS OF THE HEART. By Henry Giniger. (Franklin Watts, $16.95.) The story of an unlikely friendship between an old, embittered man and a young troublemaker is not particularly new, but Henry Giniger's first novel intends a fresh retelling. His hero, David Becker, is a cranky Jewish ex-schoolteacher who spends his days planning which upper Broadway bench to occupy - until Carlton White, a k a Sam, tries to sell him a joint.

description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: HAWKS FULFILING TALL ORDER
description: WHEN Mike Fratello - who says he is 5 feet 7 inches (though in a pinch could probably pass for 5-6), and is short enough to have once been turned down for a National Basketball Association head coach's job because of his height - when Mike Fratello, now the coach of the Atlanta Hawks, stands next to Tree Rollins or Kevin Willis, both of whom are 7 feet tall, and gives them instructions, it looks as if he's calling up to the second floor.

description: OLDER people who want to give up a large family home and move into something smaller are often appalled to discover that so much of the profit from the sale of their house will be lost in taxes.

title: PARIS
description: Paris by day and Paris by night are undergoing a subtle metamorphosis.

title: AWAITING MY TURN ON A NIGHT OF STARS
description: I'VE rehearsed my acceptance speech a thousand times. It's a mix of humility, awe and gratitude, laced with professionalism and childish innocence. It's still your basic ''I'd like to thank the members of the Academy who voted for me, my producer, my director, and my mother'' - with a focus on the film I was privileged to star in, the cast, the crew and, of course, the caterer. But I'm getting ahead of myself. That Monday night, my 7-year-old daughter, Maria, and I were dressing for the 59th annual Academy Awards. We hadn't reserved a limousine because the television set is just a stone's throw from the powder room, and we were too busy coordinating our outfits.

description: ''My fear is that if we get into a recession we are in deep soup, and there is no question about it.'' James C. Miller 3d, budget director, cautioning against a rise in interest rates.

title: CURE FOR THE DULLS: SPEED AND A DASH OF POWER
description: ''WHEN you step on it, it screams!'' say advertisements for the Isuzu Turbo Impulse. You don't have to drive it 132 miles per hour, but it is nice to know that you could, Saab says about its new 9000 model. A Chevrolet Beretta lurks like a killer shark under the water in television commercials before exploding to the surface, ready for trouble.

title: SWEDES IN NEW JERSEY
description: ALTHOUGH no one seems to mind that the first Swedish settlers in New Jersey did not arrive 350 years ago, the state will participate in New Sweden 88, a celebration of 350 years of Swedish settlement in Delaware and New Jersey.

description: IF there is one word that sets fire to the soul of a true car buff, it is the word Italian. For more than half a century, Italian design has been synonymous with flair, power and grace.

description: LEAD: EVEN though she lives nearby, Ella Siemerling of Granite Springs no longer visits the old family farmhouse where she was born 72 years ago and where she spent a good part of her life.

description: THEY are an unusual collection of patients, sitting amid the clutter of toys and baby pictures in the small waiting room in the Yonkers pediatrician's office.

description: ''S EEK AND LISTEN,'' said the pianist Hilton Ruiz. ''That's what Rahsaan Roland Kirk would always say to me, seek and listen. And that involved a lot of research.''

title: HEWLETT HOME OPPOSED
description: LEAD: THE South Shore Association for Independent Living (SAIL), made up of parents of the mentally disabled, plans to create its second community residence for the mentally disabled in the Five Towns over the objections of homeowners who say that Hewlett and Woodmere already have more than their share of hostels - even though at least half the residents would be from local communities.

title: Bonnie Smith Engaged To Gordon Gannon 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Robert C. K. Smith of Short Hills, N.J., of the engagement of his daughter Bonnie Diane Smith to Gordon Gannon 3d, a son of Rita Burke Gannon of Lake View, N.Y., and Mr. Gannon Jr. of Buffalo. A June wedding is planned.

title: Prosecutor Cited for Racial Remarks
description: A state appeals court has ordered a new trial for a black man convicted of a weapons charge, finding that a Brooklyn prosecutor's repeated references to race could have prejudiced the jury.

title: Separating Illusion From Reality In War on Cancer
description: On paper, the National Cancer Institute appears to be making progress. The survival rate for bladder cancer was 53 percent in 1950 compared with 77 percent in 1982. Improvements also have been reported for patients with breast cancer, lung cancer, colon and rectal cancer and other malignancies.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: LEAD: Elmer Fudd's Comedy Capers Directed by Friz Freleng, Chuck Jones and Robert McKimson. Warner Home Video. 57 minutes. $14.98.

title: Headliners; Devoted to Battle
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran has taken another job, it was announced last week, but that doesn't mean he has quit fighting for his old one. Father Curran, who was suspended as a professor of theology from the Catholic University of America because of his dissent from Vatican doctrine on sexual issues, will be teaching at Cornell University during the next academic year. Cornell said in a statment that Father Curran would be a visiting professor of Catholic studies and a senior fellow in the university's Society for the Humanities. At the same time, Father Curran is also continuing a court battle against his suspension from the Catholic University. He has said repeatedly that he would not leave the school permanently.

title: It's Better To Build
description: World Airlines has been traversing the globe for 40 years, and should be ''flying over the North Atlantic for a good many more.'' So, given rising rents in Nassau County, L.I., and a 15-year lease that was on the verge of expiring, Mr. Roney, systems and budget manager for Sabena, thought it would make sense for the company to build its North American corporate headquarters. ''We felt that having our own building would be a good investment,'' he said.

title: Army Ratings Aim to Restore Sergeants' Authority
description: The Army is testing a new system for rating the performance of sergeants in an effort to enhance their authority and prestige, according to Army officials.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THEOLOGY AND AMITY The College of New Rochelle has scheduled four weekly discussions beginning at 7 P.M. Wednesday, exploring the ''Theology of the Jewish-Christian Reality.'' Sister Nancy Malone, editor of Religion and Intellectual Life, published at the college, will lead the discussions.

title: 'Poorest of the Poor' Are the Target of Welfare Society Grants
description: New York's oldest family welfare organization, the Community Service Society, is searching for neighborhood groups to help spend $2.7 million for ''the poorest of the poor.''

title: Ms. Oulmann to Wed Joseph Stecher in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rene J. Oulmann of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Lizbeth Alexandra Oulmann to Joseph D. Stecher, a son of Justice Martin B. Stecher and Dr. Judith Stolitzky Stecher of New York. A July 19 wedding is planned.

title: LEARNING NATURE'S HARMONY
description: NATURE is impressive this time of year. Brown patches in the backyard take on a greenish hue, and trees that only months before were barren, angular silhouettes against the gray horizon suddenly explode into patchworks of colors and shapes. Beautiful shapes that emit beautiful sounds.

title: West Germany: Dissonance Over Corporate Sponsors
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: IN STAMFORD, CLUSTERS OF $1 MILLION HOMES
description: Little boxes on the hillside, Little boxes made of ticky tacky, Little boxes on the hillside, Little boxes all the same. c 1962 Shroder Music Company. THOSE lyrics by Malvina

title: LAW OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: Mr. Kristof's piece on criminal justice in foreign lands claims foreign visitors bring with them their ''mental baggage'' of justice standards to be appplied to the host country, to the point where it may justify intervention in the enforcement of a Draconian sanction. He raises a host of issues that all people traveling abroad, especially to countries with considerably different cultural and/or economic circumstances from his own, should contemplate.

title: Tougher Line Is Urged in Sri Lanka After Attack
description: Sinhalese groups called on the Government today to take a tougher line against Tamil terrorism, a day after 126 people were killed in a guerrilla attack.

title: Rebel Troops Give Up in Manila After One Is Killed
description: The Philippine military took a tough new approach today as it quickly put down a small mutiny here led by renegade soldiers apparently loyal to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA'S ARMS BUILDUP: THE RISK OF GUNS WITHOUT BUTTER
description: As Central America undergoes the most rapid military buildup in its history, with forceful American participation, civilian government leaders and diplomats are concerned about prospects for weak governments that must deal with the vastly strengthened armies in their countries.

title: HOSPITAL FEES SOAR UNDER NEW SYSTEM
description: A NEW hospital-payment system intended to contain costs has raised rates an average of 18 percent for inpatient treatment and has sometimes produced charges of more than $9,000 for an overnight stay.

title: GASOLINE TAX RISE: PRESSURE INCREASING
description: PROPONENTS of a 5-cent increase in the state gasoline tax to finance a renewal of the Transportation Trust Fund are stepping up their efforts to get the tax passed before the present trust fund goes dry in July. As could be expected, they are drawing criticism from tax opponents.

title: New York Youth Dies on Trip
description: A New York City teen-ager died this week, apparently of alcohol poisoning, during a school trip to the Soviet Union. The youth, Damon Walsh, 16 years old, was found dead in his Leningrad hotel room Friday by a chaperone, said Jerry Aldredge, dean of resident students at St. Johnsbury Academy here. Mr. Aldredge said that while it appeared that the youth died of alcohol poisoning, he did not know if there was evidence of alcohol in the room. The victim was among 26 students and 4 teachers touring England and the Soviet Union, Mr, Aldredge said.

title: ANOTHER CHARGE SEEN IN SUNS CASE
description: At least one more indictment is expected from a county grand jury investigating cocaine trafficking that involves players with the Phoenix Suns, the authorities said today.

title: GOVERNOR CUOMO VS. THE LEGISLATORS
description: Here is how Governor Cuomo has attacked, and legislators have defended, the ethics bill approved overwhelmingly by both houses but vetoed last week by the Governor. The bill would have restricted the activities of legislators, legislative employees and all state employees in policy-making positions. Financial disclosure:

title: BAN ON A BOAT PAINT GAINS ON EAST END
description: LEAD: THE refusal by some East End boatyard owners to use a paint believed to contain a compound toxic to shellfish has lent momentum to efforts by environmentalists and public officials to ban the paint throughout New York State.

title: Bulls, Bears and M.B.A.'s
description: As graduation season approaches, the roar of the stock market is being heard at the nation's top graduate business schools.

title: HOW BOTH SIDES GAIN FROM MOSCOW TALKS
description: IT would be difficult enough for the Soviet Union and the United States to agree on reducing nuclear arms if their negotiators could simply lock themselves in a windowless room and deal dispassionately in the intricate calculus of complex weaponry. But the outside world intrudes; political emotion, theatrics and imagery also have seats at the bargaining table.

title: TOWNS TO GATHER HOUSEHOLD TOXINS
description: MORE towns than ever are encouraging their residents to dispose of hazardous household waste, such as pesticides, spot removers and disinfectants, through organized collections and supervision by the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Candidates are Striving to Establish THE Image
description: THIS is the period known as ''the invisible primary,'' the stage of the Presidential campaign when candidates run almost no television commercials and receive no votes. It is the time for battling for staff, struggling for campaign money and skirmishing for the hearts and hands of the party activists who do the unheralded work of democracy.

title: WHO IS TO SAY WHAT'S RIGHT INTEACHING ETHICS?
description: It's hard to find anyone these days who opposes the teaching of values in the public schools. Politicians from President Reagan to Governor Cuomo have made an issue of it, while many educators have repudiated ''values clarification,'' a theory fashionable in the 1960's and 70's that held that teachers should not tell children the difference between right and wrong. There also seems to be wide agreement that religion's role in American life has been slighted in school textbooks.

title: EASTER BUNNY LARGESSE: DON'T HOP TO CONCLUSIONS
description: LEAD: IN a disclosure that apparently has failed to shock many county residents, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has admitted receiving unreported gifts from the Easter Bunny, a Westchester resident, he said, who ''has visited me often and has always left me goodies, which I always accept.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, some copies of the Real Estate section today omitted the continuation from the first page of an article about comparing rents with incomes, and carried the Northeast Notebook twice. Readers wishing copies of the continuation of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: LOST SEASON FOR NETS FOLLOWED BIG HOPES
description: It has been this kind of season for the Nets: In the Detroit airport last week, Coach Dave Wohl leaned against a barrier and inadvertently set off the security-alarm system.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: BY NO MEANS WAS IT really teed up for him. . . .'' That phrase, teed up, was used by then-White House chief of staff Donald T. Regan in testimony before the Tower Commission. I defined it here to mean ''spelled out, as if to a child or someone unfamiliar with the language; explained so that understanding is easy.''

title: Castro Says Harmony Is Up to U.S.
description: Shortly after midnight in the starkly modern Palace of the Revolution, Fidel Castro was presenting himself as the good neighbor.

title: TRYING TYO ANSWER TYHE ANCIENT QUESTIONS
description: A HISTORY OF THE JEWS By Paul Johnson. 644 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.

title: WIDER RENT PROGRAM FOR THE AGED URGED
description: TO the city, the program has meant creation of another layer of bureaucracy and the loss of millions of dollars in taxes each year. To landlords, it has meant paperwork and sometimes frustrating waits for reimbursement of forgone rent payments.

title: INSIDE
description: Japanese Calm Over Tariffs Japanese are voicing little fear that the American tariffs will touch off a trade war or fundamentally harm the countries' close relations. Page 11.

title: I AM CINDERELLA'S STEPMOTHER AND I KNOW MY RIGHTS
description: I have been asked to verify for those to whom it is not immediately apparent that since the following is a work of fiction (inspired by the recent suit against the movie based on Sylvia Plath's ''Bell Jar'') ''written by'' a person who never existed, the events referred to in it could not have taken place.

title: LAW OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: In ''Dealing With the Law of the Land'' (Travel, Feb. 15), Nicholas D. Kristof writes, ''Imposing our values on a foreign culture is less of a sin than participating in such excesses as amputation or execution by flogging.'' This kind of arrogance makes the blood of many believing Muslims boil. If Mr. Kristof wishes to discuss ''sin,'' let him and his readers not the following:

title: A TREE FOR WINE
description: IT'S just the sort of thing that might make a serious enophile quake with trepidation: a wall-hung vertical rack from which cantilevered wine bottles protrude. But it only looks precarious.

title: BUILDING HOSTELS FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: In response to the recent letters to the editor regarding residential hostels to be built on Long Island:

title: OVER 2.7 BILLION BARRELS, TEXACO SEEKS PROTECTION
description: WALL Street had mercilessly beaten down the stock prices of companies throughout the oil industry by the end of 1983, a consequence of slipping energy demand and rising production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: CONGRESS GETS SERIOUS ABOUT D.C. STATEHOOD
description: FOR the first time since the idea began being bandied about in the early 1970's, there is a good chance Congress will seriously consider a proposal to make the District of Columbia a state.
