title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THREE DAUGHTERS. By Anna Mitgutsch. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) In this first novel, which has won two prizes in Europe, Anna Mitgutsch, an Austrian writer now living and teaching in Boston, chronicles a heritage of family violence in rural Austria from the period of Hitler's rise to power to its hangover in the postwar reconstruction.

title: THE THIRD DEGREE AT THE BORDER
description: Some people collect restaurant menus on their travels; others keep Kaopectate bottles labeled in French, in German, in Spanish, in Hindi: a record of successive and sudden onslaughts of bodily distress. Still other travelers clutter their living rooms with Indian brasses or Provencal pottery or Fijian tapa cloths. As for me, I collect border incidents. Now I don't know why it is that one fairly ordinary, fairly normal family, consisting of one academic (father), one writer (mother) and two teen-agers, one male and one female, both rather preppy-looking, should have struck so many immigration and customs officials, at so many borders, as worthy of their full attention, their exhaustive third-degree audit, their exclusive Unlimited Length Delay Program, their Special Reserve Grudging Admittance with implied reproach: All right, we'll let you in this time, but we don't trust you. You are riddled with irregularities and we strongly disapprove.

title: PUTTING A PRICE ON ANGER OVER IMPORTS
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN retaliated last week against Japanese trading practices that, the Administration said, violated a 1986 computer chip agreement. He imposed tariffs that may double the price of some color television sets, computers and power tools. Retailers said consumers should feel little effect, except for those who buy laptop computers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: To non-weavers, the term interlacing sounds a bit cryptic. The noted textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen and the writer Betty Freudenheim unravel it in INTERLACING: The Elemental Fabric (Kodansha International, $60), a richly illustrated volume that, in contrast to so many books on design, has a distinctly anthropological bent. Interlacing refers to the kind of fabric construction common to weaving, plaiting and braiding, in which each element passes over and under elements that cross its path. ''Almost as elemental as fire,'' write the authors, it is an extremely ancient technique that has spanned a panoply of objects and cultures. The book, which is an appreciation of interlacing as well as a description of it, covers everything from little girls braiding pigtails as a fledgling act of childhood adornment, to the hundreds of exquisite and practical variations - Czechoslovak bobbin lace, Guatemalan corn dollies, East African beer stirrers, wedding baskets from Burkina Faso and the legendary Panama hat. Though the book is at times a bit technical for a general audience, the photographs, in particular, many in color, are an accessible and enticing introduction to the subject, as is the excellent bibliography. Only Mr. Larsen's voluminous personal experiences, fleetingly alluded to in the text, are missing. What was the dean of New York textile designers doing in Vietnam, for example, designing interlaced sea-grass mats?

title: HOME VIDEO: RELIGION
description: The First Easter The New Media Bible: The Gospel According to Luke Vanguard Video 70 minutes. $49.95.

title: Trash Barge From L.I. To Move After Leaking
description: A barge laden with 3,100 tons of industrial waste from Islip, L.I., will be moved from Louisiana waters because liquid oozing from the bales is seeping into the Gulf of Mexico, a state environmental official said.

title: MUSIC: 'PLANCTUS MARIAE'
description: THE ''Planctus Mariae,'' as offered at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Good Friday afternoon, re-enacts the lamentations of the three Marys at the foot of Jesus's cross. This modern version of a 14th-century church drama has been realized by W. L. Smolden and uses four players - the Virgin, Mary Jacobi, Mary Magdalen and John. In costume, they move and gesture in a sort of slow ritual. They also sing, sometimes in the kind of metrically free, modal plain chants that shape themselves to the texts, elsewhere in uniform, rocking, three-beat melody. Standing to the rear of Friday's worshipers, the small choir directed by Paul Halley commented on these events.

title: Ana Maria Allessi to Wed
description: Ana Maria Allessi and Keith Talbot plan to be married June 21, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Allessi of Cincinnati, have announced. The future bride is an account manager at Marke Communications, a New York retail advertising company. Her fiance, the son of Paul Talbot of New York and Ruth Talbot of Richmond, is producer of ''Kids America'' on WNYC radio.

title: EUROPE, TOO, POSTS 'NO DUMPING' SIGNS FOR JAPANESE FIRMS
description: WESTERN EUROPE, like the United States, is using far more than words in its trade disputes with Japan. Europe, in fact, seized the weapon of duties against Japan well before Washington decided to impose high tariffs, which went into effect Friday, on some Japanese electronic goods in retaliation for the purported ''dumping'' of computer chips at unfairly low prices.

title: Dr. Jane Becker Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Becker of Long Island City, Queens, and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jane Leslie Becker, to Jason Kintzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kintzer of Long Beach, L.I. Dr. Becker is a first-year resident in internal medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center. Her fiance is a senior consultant at Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a New York real-estate consulting and accounting concern. They plan an October wedding.

title: 'FREQUENT FLIERS' CRYING FOUL AS AIRLINES CHANGE THE RULES
description: For the past seven years Raymond W. Zrike went out of his way to fly Trans World Airlines, and last month it was about to pay off: he passed the 90,000-mile mark, enough to get two free first-class round-trip tickets to Europe.

title: Sanibel Island
description: To the Editor: In the article on Sanibel Island (Travel, March 8) the author states that Cross Creek, the settlement Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings made famous in her writings, is ''nearby'' the Everglades. That's roughly equivalent to saying, in terms of mileage, that Washington, D.C., is nearby to New York. The Cross Creek settlement is only a few miles south of Gainesville, Fla.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Hiawassee, Ga.;
Cultivating The Tourists
description: LEAD: IN 1942, the Tennessee Valley Authority flooded 7,050 acres of mountain valleys on the Georgia-North Carolina border to create Lake Chatuge for flood control, navigation and the generation of electricity.

title: WHY IS THAT MAN TIRED?
description: TEXASVILLE By Larry McMurtry. 542 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: British Engineer, Held for 6 Years, Expected to Be Released by Libya
description: A British engineer, imprisoned by the Libyan Government for six years, has been moved from his cell in preparation for ''imminent release,'' the British Consul said here today.

title: FOX'S FARE: MORE OF THE SAME
description: JUST WHEN AMERICAN TELEVISION SEEMS ON the brink of becoming strictly entertaining, 24 hours a day, along comes Fox Broadcasting Company - a satellite-delivered national program supplier for independent stations - promising the mass public nothing less than another ''service that will entertain America.'' Eager to become the nation's fourth commercial network -alongside ABC, CBS and NBC - Fox has already brought the hyperactive vulgarity of Joan Rivers to the late-night schedule and now, over several Sundays, is introducing its first full evening of prime-time programming.

title: Tax-Exempt Group's Payment of $115,000 Is Called Possible Violation of Law
description: Thousands of dollars raised by a tax-exempt organization for the Nicaraguan rebels and for conservative causes was paid to a friend of the organization's president and to a concern headed by a friend of the group's executive director, records show.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: LEWISBURG, PA.;
Protecting a Victorian Past
description: LEAD: WHEN an ordinance went into effect in June 1985 requiring property owners in this college town to get approval for even minor exterior changes, grumbling began that persists even today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in today's New York Times Magazine discusses the political activism of Palestinian students at Bir Zeit University on the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: Israel: Antiquities For Sale: Plunder or Boon?
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: Transforming a Riverfront
description: As manufacturing and refining plants have deserted the Hudson River waterfront in Edgewater, N.J., developers with visions of opulent residences facing a Manhattan skyline have moved in.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE loggerhead shrike would be added to the state's list of endangered species under changes proposed by the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Hartford's Getting a World Trade Center
description: A $100 MILLION World Trade Center to rise in downtown Hartford is expected to promote an increase in Connecticut's foreign trade, and to stand as a symbol of its role in international commerce.

title: SCHOOL NEWSPAPER LIBEL SUIT SETTLED
description: THE student press here was set back earlier this month when an out-of-court settlement ended a libel suit being heard by a jury and Superior Court Judge Marianne Spinosa Murphy in Morristown.

title: India: Folk Art Festival Sparks Furor
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: TRADE COMES AROUND
description: DESPITE the Commerce Department's stunning report that the trade deficit remained above $15 billion in February, there is increasing evidence that the country's underlying trade position has begun to improve.

title: Panama Refuses Accused Nazi
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d tried unsuccessfully last week to help find a home for a 67-year-old Long Island land surveyor accused of Nazi war crimes.

title: LAWYER TO HEAD BAR
description: For the first time in the seven-year history of the organization, a Westchester lawyer has been named head of the Women's Bar Association of the State of New York.

title: MODEL TRAINS: NOT JUST TOYS
description: MORE THAN 250 PEO-ple traveled from throughout Europe and the United States to Lausanne, Switzerland, two years ago to celebrate the 70th birthday of Count Antonio Giansanti Coluzzi - and to play with his model trains.

title: LEFT COLD BY CARS: A WOMAN'S STRUGGLE
description: I have a confession to make, and this seems as fitting a place and as good a time to make it as any. I cannot change a tire. Nor can I differentiate between the carburetor, if cars still have such things, and the radiator, air filter, gear box or condenser. In a crisis, when the hood of the car is sprung open, revealing the grayish-brown tangle of hoses and boxes and releasing the thick, warm odor of melting rubber, I stand there dazed, my face suspended over the engine with feigned concern but my spirit adrift.

title: Sending Up
description: Tama Janowitz managed to do the impossible: have a bad time in Los Angeles and obtain a non-interview from Bette Midler (''Adventures in Tinseltown,'' March 22). Ms. Janowitz then wrote about her non-adventures and -most astonishing of all - The Times Magazine ran it.

title: HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
description: If all baseball and football executives who believe with Al Campanis that blacks don't have the necessities to be executives would follow his example and resign, there would be many vacancies for qualified blacks to fill. LLOYD L. BROWN New York

title: Richard Rosenthal, Arbitrager
description: Richard Gerson Rosenthal, a New York investment banker, was killed in the crash of a small plane in Westchester County Friday at the age of 45. He was a resident of Briarcliff, N.Y.

title: THE POET AS EFFICIENCY EXPERT
description: SHIFTING GEARS Technology, Literature, Culture in Modernist America. By Cecelia Tichi. Illustrated. 310 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $14.95. A SPEAKER at the elaborate ceremonies marking the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge on May 24, 1883, hailed the span as a great victory in the ''never ending struggle . . . to subdue the forces of nature to [ human ] control and use.'' But it was a special victory, a triumph of the machine and engineering technology that gave the United States much of its physical and cultural shape at the turn of the century. And the bridge immediately became the symbol of the era Hugh Kenner, in ''The Mechanic Muse,'' describes as ''the golden age of ironware, when every thinkable human activity save perhaps the reproductive was being mapped onto machinery.''

title: A GUIDE TO WHERE TO STAY AND EAT IN LONDON
description: Following is a selection of hotels, restaurants, pubs and general information. Major credit cards are accepted in hotels and restaurants unless otherwise stated.

title: SETON HALL PLANNING A MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: LEAD: AT THE urging of the state's Catholic hospitals, Seton Hall University in South Orange has established a graduate medical school that will train doctors in nine specialties and offer advanced degrees in molecular biology.

title: A Landmark With an Unwanted Status
description: DEPENDING on your point of view, it is either an architectural mishmash or a masterful example of scientific eclecticism. But the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew on the Upper West Side, everyone agrees, has become one of New York's enduring real-estate controversies. After landmark designation in 1981 stalled a plan to demolish most of the church at West 86th Street and West End Avenue for redevelopment, its trustees began a legal battle to overturn the landmark status.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: LEAD: There are no photographs of freaks in the small show of early works by Diane Arbus at the Robert Miller Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, through Saturday - unless a sideshow contortionist with his head facing in the opposite direction from his feet is a freak. These photographs also lack the familiar square format and confrontational use of flash that gives Arbus's best known works the look of a greatly enlarged identification photograph.

An account of the actor's life written with his cooperation. 45 THE TOWER COMMISSION REPORT. (Times Books/Bantam, $5.50.) The full text of the President's Special Review Board. 524 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's experiences flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. Weeks This On Week List; Nonfiction: Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous146 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 212 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) Lose weight, stay fit. 346 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Advice about a family problem. 41 THE BILL JAMES BASEBALL ABSTRACT 1987, by Bill James. (Ballantine, $8.95.) An analysis of baseball statistics. 523 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1987. 61 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his cat and his parents. 76 GARFIELD: FOOD FOR THOUGHT, by Jim omic strips. 85 WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles. (Ten Speed, $8.95.) Job and career advice; 1987 edition. 928 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) A Scientology handbook. 1011 J. K. LASSER'S YOUR INCOME TAX. (Prentice Hall, $8.95.) The 1987 edition. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title:
TELEVISION;
INNOVATION IS A PRIMARY COLOR ON THE VIDEO ARTIST'S PALETTE
description: LEAD: TELEVISION IS ALWAYS hungry for innovation. What many viewers may not recognize is that much of mainstream television's eye-catching novelties - the stylistic flourishes seen in ''Max Headroom,'' ''Miami Vice'' and MTV, for example - owe more than a tip of the hat to experimentation dating back almost two decades and pioneered by a small but vibrant subspecies within the fine-arts field: the video artist.

title: THE TRUE ADVENTURES OF SHYLOCK'S DAUGHTER
description: SERENISSIMA A Novel of Venice. By Erica Jong. 225 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title:
ART;
'MONUMENTAL TO MINIATURE' AT THE GALLERY IN HASTINGS
description: LEAD: ONE comes away from the current exhibition at The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson with something of an ''Alice in Wonderland'' feeling. While there, one has come to think in terms of small-to-large and back again, although the work of the four artists exhibited isn't pliable in itself. ''From Monumental to

title: EMBASSY SECURITY: STORY OF FAILURE
description: Three years ago, President Reagan and his advisers gathered for a slide show about the vulnerability of the American Embassy in Moscow to Soviet espionage.

title: MUSIC: FAYRUZ SINGS
description: FAYRUZ, a singer whose music has become a symbol of Lebanese unity, performed to an adoring reception Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall. In the Middle East, where she has been performing for three decades, Fayruz is a superstar, appealing to Christian and Moslem audiences alike; she even appeared on a Lebanese postage stamp. She is a youthful-looking woman in her early 50's who sings about loving her village and her country and hoping for peace, in a cosmopolitan blend of Middle Eastern traditions with European and Western pop. Onstage, she is stiff and almost imperious, never speaking, staring unblinkingly at the audience and gesturing only in the final notes of a song.

title: Craigin Howard To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Calhoun L. H. Howard of Oak Bluffs, Mass., on Martha's Vineyard, have announced the engagement of their daughter Craigin Lee Howard to James Glenn Salsgiver Jr., the son of Mrs. Salsgiver of Westport, Conn., and the late Mr. Salsgiver. A July wedding is planned.

title: Food for Thought
description: MY DINNER WITH ANDRE Directed by Louis Malle. Screenplay by Wallace Shawn and Andre Gregory. Produced by George W. George and Beverly Karp. Pacific Arts Video. Color. 1981. 110 minutes. $79.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: RESURRECTIONISTS. By Russell Working. (University of Iowa Press, $14.95.) The Iowa Short Fiction Award is among the most prestigious literary prizes America offers. It has been given every year since 1970 by the University of Iowa - and let there be no snide jokes about ''corn country.'' The judges are always people with distinguished writing careers of their own.

title: SAMURAI SUCCESS: FIND MARKET AND CONQUER
description: LORNA Altemus was shopping for a new Jeep when she came upon a magazine article comparing the Suzuki Samurai with several other four-wheel-drive vehicles.

title: Q & A
description: CONTRACT FOR REPAIRS Question: I recently purchased a studio in a cooperative building. There had been previous water damage to the bathroom ceiling, but the repair job was so poor that the walls are still bumpy and crooked. Before the closing the sponsor's selling agent signed an agreement stating that the sponsor would repair and paint the wall and ceiling by last Jan. 1.

title: AVOIDING THE FOOT-IN-MOUTH SYNDROME
description: STORIES abound about the ways American companies have messed up when they advertised to foreign audiences. ''Finger lickin' good,'' Kentucky Fried Chicken's slogan, once came out as ''eat your fingers off'' in Chinese. And many Asians interpreted Pepsi's ''come alive generation'' as a call to bring back the dead.

title: AT JAVITS CENTER, THE WORLD IS MORE AND BETTER
description: THE 1987 New York International Automobile Show opened yesterday at its new home at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where it is commemorating the 100th anniversary of the first motorcar, patented by Carl Benz in 1886.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: EASTER PARADE Since it's Easter Sunday, today's the day to be in Garden City, because that's where it's happening. What's happening? Why, the 28th annual Easter Antique Car Parade and Exhibit. At 1 P.M., Franklin Avenue dons its holiday finery as the vintage autos make their way toward their destination across from the Village Hall on Stewart Avenue.

title: Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
description: I am writing to protest some of Dave Anderson's remarks in his column on Dwight Gooden (''Now Mets Know About Gooden,'' The New York Times, April 2). Mr. Anderson asks, ''Has cocaine forever changed his body chemistry that created that spectacular 24-4 season?'' and then engages in a good deal of speculation on that question.

title:
GARDENING;
SOIL IS A PREREQUISITE FOR SUCCESS
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH not the most popular gardening subject when it comes to having a successful garden, a good case can be made for soil preparation having top billing. One can have the best seeds or plants, put them in at the best time, keep them free of pests and diseases and still fail if the soil conditions are not right.

title: Tech Transfer
description: To the Editor

title: Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
description: During the last two weeks members of the New York news media have shown me their true colors. While reading the various headlines, I wasn't sure if Gooden was a mass murderer, a key witness in the Iran-Contra affair, or a celebrated AIDS patient. Whatever the case, the Big Apple's journalists have turned their pens on the Doctor: spewing venom rather than ink.

title: IN YOUR FACE: THE SCOWL RETURNS FOR BERNARD KING
description: UP to now, everybody has been making a big fuss over the doctor and the physical therapist who helped Bernard King return from knee surgery. But nobody has praised the drama coach who gave King back his game face.

title: THE FARMER AND HIS WEALTHY UNCLE
description: THE United States has been blessed with a more than adequate food supply, the best and purest food supply in the world. In America, the lowest number of hours in the entire world go into securing food for a family -and therein lies the problem.

title: Cindy Peterson to Wed Seth Jacobs, a Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morton Peterson of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Peterson, to Seth Jacobs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Jacobs of Teaneck, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Carla Pellegrino, Personnel Director, Is Fiancee of Carlton Penavera-Cabot
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Peter Pellegrino of North Andover and Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carla Anne Pellegrino, to Carlton Penavera-Cabot, a son of Mrs. Louis Wellington Cabot of Boston and Osterville and Jaime Penavera of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING Honeyghan Keeps Titles: Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain won a unanimous 12-round decision over Maurice Blocker of the United States in London yesterday to retain his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation welterweight championships. The victory, in his second title defense, lifted Honeyghan's record to 30-0. But the 26-year-old champion had to work hard to hand Blocker his first career loss in 25 fights.(AP) Chavez Retains Title: Julio Cesar Chavez of Mexico stopped Francisco Tomas da Cruz of Brazil at 2:34 of the third round in Nimes, France, to retain his World Boxing Council junior-lightweight title. It was the ninth title defense for Chavez, unbeaten in 53 fights. Da Cruz is 26-2.(AP) ICE HOCKEY 81 Saves but No Victory: In the World Hockey Championships in Vienna, Finland edged Switzerland, 3-2, overcoming a stalwart performance by Oliver Anken, who made an astounding 81 saves. The Finns outshot Switzerland, 84-29, getting off 34 shots in the first period, 33 stopped by Anken. In other games, Sweden beat the United States, 6-2, the Soviet Union defeated West Germany, 7-0, and Czechoslovakia and Canada tied at 1-1.(AP) TENNIS Maleeva Wins: Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria upset Barbara Gerken of the United States, 6-2, 6-3, to win the women's singles title at the Japan Open in Tokyo. Stefan Edberg of Sweden beat Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2, in a men's singles semifinal and will meet David Pate of the United States in today's final. Pate, of Las Vegas, Nev., defeated Scott Davis, of Bardmoor, Fla., 7-5, 6-1.(AP) Graf-Mandlikova Final: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany and second-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia won straight-set semifinal matches at the Women's International Tennis Association Championships at Amelia Island, Fla. Graf beat Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and Mandlikova downed Zina Garrison of the United States.(AP) DIVING Louganis's Plunge Continues: Greg Louganis lost his third national title in three days, coming in second to Matt Scoggin in the 10-meter platform championship at the United States Diving Indoor Championships in Baton Rouge, La. Louganis lost the 1- and 3-meter springboard titles Thursday and Friday to Doug Shaffer and Kent Ferguson, respectively. Michele Mitchell retained her women's national title on the 10-meter platform.(AP) GOLF Sauers and Jones Share Lead: Gene Sauers birdied the final hole to finish with a seven-under-par 64 and gain a share of the lead at 200 with Steve Jones in the third round of the Heritage Classic at Hilton Head Island, S.C.(AP) Okamoto on Top: Ayako Okamoto used three birdies on the final seven holes to score a three-under-par 69 and take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Santa Barbara Open in California. Okamoto was at three-under-par 141 heading into today's final round. Jan Stephenson, Patty Sheehan and Alice Ritzman were tied for second at 142. BOWLING Norman Wins U.S. Open: Carol Norman defeated top-seeded Cindy Coburn, 206-179, to capture the $40,000 first prize in the United States Open at Palisades Mentor Lanes in Mentor, Ohio. Norman, a 25-year-old right-hander from Ardmore, Okla., had never finished higher than 24th place in any previous United States Open. The tournament was the richest in the history of women's bowling.(AP) Handley Takes Hartford: Bob Handley of Pompano Beach, Fla., beat Jimmy Keeth of West Palm Beach, Fla., 247-201, to capture the Greater Hartford Open in Windsor Locks, Conn.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD Big Day for Boys and Girls: Boys and Girls High School won three events at the ninth annual Mobil Big Apple Relays for Public Schools Athletic League teams at Midwood Field in Brooklyn. Two of the victories came in girls' relays. The 3,200-meter quartet of Denise van Nooten, Sandra Burke, Terry Adams and Samon McQuade won in 9 minutes 45.1 seconds. Then Adams teamed with Sharon Moore, Elaine Leshore and Theresa Weeks to take first place in the distance medley in 12:34.8. The Brooklyn school's third triumph was registered in the 400-meter relay for boys. The team of Eric Lipscomb, Andre Peterson, Bryan Dick and Kevin Gordon was a 2-meter winner over DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx in 43.9 seconds. Temple Wins 4 Events: Temple won four events and Manhattan took three as the 20th annual Rutgers Relays ended at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway, N.J. The Lady Owls were first in the 400-meter relay (46.5 seconds), the 800 meters (1 minute 37.6 seconds) and the 1,600 meters (3:46.5). Temple also won the men's 800-meter relay in 1:27.1. Manhattan won gold medals in the distance medley and 6,000-meter relays. Gary Halpin, Manhattan's outstanding hammer thrower from Ireland, was first in his specialty at 212 feet 10 inches. Shot-Put Record: John Brenner of Fullerton, Calif., set an American record in the men's shot-put with a heave of 73 feet 1/2-inch during a track meet between U.C.L.A. and Houston at Drake Stadium on the U.C.L.A. campus. Brenner, a former U.C.L.A. standout who was competing unattached at the meet, set the record on his first throw of the day. He broke the mark of 72-9 3/4 by Brian Oldfield in 1984.(AP)

title: RUTGERS DEFENDS TUITION INCREASES
description: LEAD: RUTGERS, the State University, is increasing its tuition by 22 percent over the next two years. The decision was made by the board of governors despite a State Senate resolution calling for a postponement, a move backed by a student organization and a bargaining unit that represents 3,700 faculty members.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Windsor, Vt.;
Gambling on Appreciation
description: LEAD: PROPERTY values have more than doubled in West Windsor since November 1983 when Summit Ventures bought the bankrupt Mount Ascutney ski resort and began pumping millions of dollars into it.

title: AMERICAN BASKETS DRAW PRAISE ABROAD
description: ON A SMALL scale, but with a success largely unheralded outside of diplomatic circles, American crafts are finding a role as cultural ambassadors to countries with their own craft traditions.

title: SAN DIEGO HAS EDGE FOR NEXT CUP RACE
description: The next venue for the America's Cup could be any of at least 12 cities across the United States. But one place has the edge - San Diego, the California city whose sailing team beat Australia for yachting's best-known trophy.

title: SPECIAL BUS TOLL LANES ON TURNPIKE SUGGESTED
description: The anti-public-transportation bias of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, as described in Gregory Bender's March 29 Opinion article, is accurate.

title: WHT'S NEW IN FOREIGN LANGUAGE TELEVISION
description: ROBERT HITCHENS, until recently a salesman for the Spanish International Network in New York, used to find selling advertising on Spanish-language programs a thankless task. ''We kidded about the orders we got: Get out, stay out, don't come back,'' he recalled.

title: HOW ONE COMMUNITY HANDLES RECYCLING
description: LEAD: HOW MUCH can New Jersey recycle? One answer comes from Woodbury Township, a residential community in Gloucester County with the oldest full-scale mandatory recycling program in the state. It has been collecting cardboard, paper, glass, aluminum, light metal and used oil since 1980.

title: Argentina Thwarts Military Rebellion
description: When an Argentine Army officer refused last week to be questioned in court about allegations of human rights abuses, he precipitated a serious challenge to the three-year-old civilian Government of President Raul Alfonsin.

title: An Older Father
description: When his son is a teen-ager, Richard Taylor will be in his 80's. The chances of his being at his son's graduation from high school, not to mention college, are minimal. No service was done to little Aristotle Eli when he was born to a man close to 70 and a woman in her early 20's. Rather than being a loving, nurturing event, the birth of Aristotle is another example, albeit a subtle one, of the narcissism of our time. Baby M has it better! PETER F. WORMS Associate Professor of Psychology Montclair State College Parsippany, N.J.

title: Escaped Hijacker Surrenders Peacefully
description: A convicted Croatian terrorist who escaped from a Federal prison in Orange County, N.Y., early Friday surrendered meekly yesterday morning to a village police officer who found him resting on the back porch of a store in Milford, Pa., 18 miles southwest of the prison.

title: Bakkers Reportedly Got $4.8 Million Since '84
description: The Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy, received nearly $1.6 million in pay and bonuses from the PTL television ministry last year and $640,000 more the last three months, The Charlotte Observer reported today.

title: Fanfani Is Sworn In as Head of Italy's 46th Postwar Cabinet
description: Amintore Fanfani was sworn in today as Prime Minister of a minority Italian Government that is expected to lose a vote of confidence in Parliament in the coming week, paving the way for elections June 14.

title: A SEARCH FOR SERVICES FOR HANDICAPPED BOY
description: The article in your March 22, 1987, issue, ''Expense Rising for Education of Disabled,'' leaves the reader with the impression that Westchester County provides an abundance of expensive services to the preschool, handicapped population. I am a parent of an 18-month-old boy with Down's Syndrome and was astounded to find that I was unable to secure county-funded services for him until he was 12 months old. At that time, all that was made available to him was a weekly home visit by a special educator that lasted a couple of hours.

title: HARVARD, IN SWEEP, OUTLASTS PRINCETON
description: Fog shrouded the Charles River today, causing difficulties in the opening races of this morning's regatta. But it lifted for the varsity race, allowing spectators to witness Harvard's heavyweight varsity draw away to victory over Princeton and capture the Compton Cup.

title: MAGNIFICENT OBSESSION: A HOUSE IN THE COUNTRY
description: STANLEY GULKIN, A TRIM, FIERCELY energetic man in his late 40's, is a tax and corporate lawyer who has, he says, ''worked very hard and done very well.'' At his office in Livingston, N.J., he gets 50 phone calls a day. ''You get pulled in all directions - this is success! It makes me feel important.'' But a couple of years back, he felt he was ''on a merry-go-round. My daughters were growing up, I started noticing my gray hair, started worrying about mortality. You ask yourself, 'What's it all for?' So instead of having a mid-life crisis, I bought a house in the country.''

title: FRANCE: CRITICS BLAST BALLET ABOUT MALRAUX
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: New Hampshire
description: To the Editor: Your Feb. 22 article on crafts in New Hampshire's Monadnock region named a few lodging and dining places but neglected to describe bed & breakfast guest homes.

title: AGONY AND APOSTASY
description: HIGHROAD TO THE STAKE A Tale of Witchcraft. By Michael Kunze. Translated by William E. Yuill. Illustrated. 424 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: Sarah Showalter and Morgan Murray Are Planning to Be Married in August
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Emmet M. Showalter 3d of Albuquerque, N.M., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Joan Showalter to Morgan J. Murray Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray of Morristown, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: The Leaks In N.B.A. Umbrella
description: Its nickname was derived from the Valley of the Sun, but this pro basketball franchise should be known now as the Phoenix Shadows.

title: Panny Thomas to Become the Bride of Mac King
description: Leeanne M. Thomas, a news assistant in the cultural news department of The New York Times, and Richard M. King, a mechanical engineer with the Permanent Label Corporation in Clifton, N.J., plan to be married later this year.

title: PROFESSOR'S NAME IS IN THE SKY
description: LEAD: A PROFESSOR at Wesleyan University has been notified that two associates had arranged for his name to be placed on several square miles of undeveloped real estate.

title: A DEADLINE PASSES: SUPERFUND CREEPS SLOWLY TOWARD CLEANUP GOALS
description: UNDER the law Congress passed nearly seven years ago to protect the public and the environment from the dangers of abandoned toxic waste dumps, a grand total of 13 sites have been completely cleaned up. Considering that there are tens of thousands of such dumps around the country, perhaps 20,000 of them seriously contaminated, the record can hardly be called impressive.

title: ALLANTE HAS A LOT TO SAY
description: MORNINGS, I am not good. But sometimes you do have to get up to meet a worthy adversary, in this case the dentist. So I growled and grumbled in my empty house, and then I went out to the car, which nearly spoiled the whole day. The car said, ''Good morning.''

title: WHEN ALL IS NOT ENOUGH
description: IN a world where few drivers can remember life before cruise control, automakers are scrambling to develop new amenities to win over well-off buyers who are used to being pampered.

title: Honor for Bowler
description: A Brooklyn-born bowler who has earned $1,207,707 since joining the Professional Bowlers Association tour in 1970, will be inducted tomorrow into the P.B.A. Hall of Fame in Akron, Ohio. Mark Roth, who is second in career earnings by less than $60,000 to Earl Anthony, will be honored for performances that include winning 32 tour events, leading the tour in average score for five years, most recently in 1981, and being selected as P.B.A. player of the year four times, most recently in 1984. Also being inducted are Jim Godman of Lorain, Ohio, and Raymond Firestone, the sponsor of the $250,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions.

title: THE DANCE: CUMMINGS
description: BLONDELL CUMMINGS was charming, witty and poignant last Sunday afternoon when Blondell Cummings and Performers appeared at the Triplex of Manhattan Community College. The troupe was the final attraction in a series of concerts by young choreographers associated with the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival last year.

title: Woman Killed on IRT Tracks
description: A 29-year-old Queens woman died when she lay on the tracks in front of an uptown IRT subway train as it pulled into the Union Square-14th Street Station, the transit police said yesterday. The victim was identified as Pamela Dalton, of 141-36 84th Road inFloral Park. The incident occurred at 8:30 P.M. Friday and interrupted service for 90 minutes, the transit police said.

title: Tracy A. Boehlert To Marry May 23
description: Mrs. Robert Dessoffy of Alexandria, Va., and Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert of New Hartford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tracy A. Boehlert to Palmer G. Suk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Suk of Charlotte, N.C. A May 23 wedding is planned.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 'PAPA' AND THE BABY BOAS HERBERT D. HERMSDORF recently became a father. Well, not technically, the Longwood High School earth science teacher admits. ''But everyone's calling me 'papa,' '' he said.

title: IN STAMFORD, STUDY SPANS GENERATIONS
description: THE Friday morning eighth-grade English class at Stamford's Cloonan Middle School is unusual.

title: Canada: Grants for New Talent or Established Artists?
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: Help From Friends
description: IT'S not easy for a 37-year-old to score 38 points, even in an emotional farewell appearance, but Julius Erving of the 76ers had a lot of help from his teammates Friday night as he became only the third player in National Basketball Association history to reach the 30,000-point mark. Erving, playing his last regular-season home game, got 2 more points than he needed in the game against the Indiana Pacers, bringing his career total to 30,002 and putting him in the company of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has 36,374, and Wilt Chamberlain, who has 31,419.

title: THE MATURING OF NATHANAEL
description: TWO LIVES AND A DREAM By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Walter Kaiser in collaboration with the author. 245 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: PARTISANSHIP'S PART IN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: Upon reading the story on the political impact - or its lack - of Westchester's recent village election [ ''Assessing the Impact of Village Elections,'' March 29 ] , a few questions came to mind.

title: LAW OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: To what purpose did Nicholas D. Kristof write ''Dealing with the Laws of the Land''? I was surprised that someone who lives abroad would come to such an immature view of respect for the law (and therefore culture) of another country while traveling. The gist of the article seemed to be that the victim of a crime should have remorse for having a thief proseuted under the legal system under which he (the thief) lives.

title: LINGUIST PLEADS FOR A GLORY THAT WAS GREEK
description: Within the marble colonnades of the Academy here, girt by worthy tomes, there is a man who has thought much on Greece and its language. And he has decided that here, in the land of the classics, a heritage is being denied.

title: DETENTION OF CHILDREN FUELS NEW DEFIANCE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: THE REV. ALLAN BOESAK, the anti-apartheid leader, spoke out on an issue that is causing increasing concern to South Africans. ''When I think of what this Government is doing to our children,'' he said last week, ''I get so angry that I also feel like saying: I hope there is a God in heaven that can forgive you, for I do not think that I can.''

title: A New Soviet Role in Mideast?
description: The Iranians have taken some wild gambles in their war with Iraq. But even they might think twice before attacking a ship belonging to a superpower. That is the reason why Kuwait, which supports Iraq, might hire three Soviet tankers to transport its oil through the Persian Gulf.

title: Nigeria: Strife Stirred By Best Seller
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MIND TOOLS: The Five Levels of Mathematical Reality. By Rudy Rucker. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) For those who gave up college mathematics for what seemed more liberal arts, Rudy Rucker's new book, ''Mind Tools,'' is a dazzling refresher course. As in past works, like ''The Fourth Dimension,'' he rekindles the wonder that can come from contemplating logarithms, exponential curves and transcendental numbers. Refreshed in the basics, readers get a tour of such fascinating, if faddish, worlds as fractals, Turing machines, cellular automata, Godel's theorem and catastrophe theory. This will be familiar fare to readers of Martin Gardner, Douglas Hofstadter, Morris Kline, Michael Guillen and other artful expositors. But Mr. Rucker, the author of a dozen books of science and science fiction, connects mathematics' five domains - number, space, logic, infinity and information - in unusual ways, and ''Mind Tools'' is an absorbing map of his complex mind. Sometimes he is annoying. When he meditates on mystical, universal meanings of one and zero he seems to be spinning dogma for his own Pythagorean cult. But his very open mind never takes itself too seriously, and in the end Mr. Rucker provides an interesting and rigorous argument for his belief that there will never be an explanation for the universe that is any less complex than the universe itself.

title: Michelle Lichter Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry Lichter of Lido Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Lichter, to Adam Mark Rosmarin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Rosmarin of Briarcliff, N.Y. A September wedding is planned. Miss Lichter, an analyst in the corporate finance department of Shearson Lehman Brothers, graduated cum laude from the State University at Albany. Mr. Rosmarin, a graduate of Boston University, is a real estate broker for Harper Lawrence Inc. in New York.

title: NASSAU SHOULD SET THE RULES
description: NASSAU COUNTY is enjoying one of the strongest economic periods in its history. Jobs are plentiful, salaries are among the highest in the nation and business is booming. But the flourishing growth may dry up for lack of a simple necessity: water.

title: DANCE: DOUGLAS DUNN PRESENTS 'LIGHT, O TEASE'
description: THE setting was familiar, with the usual bare white walls and clear wood floor serving as a theater for Douglas Dunn's ''Light, O Tease,'' performed on Tuesday at Mr. Dunn's SoHo studio. But once the new piece began, the space became a cage full of exotic birds, peculiar yet instantly recognizable as they picked their way along the knotty bypaths of modern-day human mating rituals. The dance's title might have been conceived by one of the metaphysical poets. Certainly the dance had something of the elegance, quirky passion and ironic wit of their poetry.

title: HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
description: The question is really ''How big a problem is racism in the nation?'' Sports mirrors the larger society. The presence of the Abdul-Jabbars, Robinsons and Strawberrys in sports, as well as black superstars in other fields, may give one the impression that racism is a dying monster, but it is not. The monster changes form but does not die. It will not die in sports until it dies in the nation. Sports is but one battle in an endless war. CLYDE J. HART Jr. Washington

title: Patricia M. Mulry Engaged to Douglas D. Morgan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Mulry of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Mary Mulry to Douglas Dane Morgan, a son of Jeanette Philipp Morgan of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Lacy L. Morgan. The wedding is to be in June.

title: ENROLLMENT OF MINORITIES IN COLLEGES STAGNATING
description: Two decades after colleges and universities began opening their doors to substantial numbers of minority students, the effort to diversify American higher education appears to have stagnated.

title: HOW TO TEST-DRIVE A NEW CAR AND DO IT RIGHT
description: IT has been an article of faith among automobile dealers that getting a customer behind the wheel of a new car for a test drive is the first step to closing a deal. Experiencing the feeling, smell and special allure of new cars, dealers hope, will overcome a customer's innate caution.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Costa Rica chose butter over guns a long time ago. In Central America it would be much better to spend money on economic development or education instead of guns. It is so clear, but nobody does it.'' - President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. [ 16:6. ]

title: A New Measure Of Indecency
description: Howard Stern, the radio morning-show host, had agreed not to say any of the seven words banned from the airwaves for the last decade. But still the complaints came, about Mr. Stern and about other sexually explicit programs and telephone services. And so the Federal Communications Commission decided that seven words were not enough.

title: Reviewing Adrienne Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Heath to Wed in September
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Heath of Bannockburn, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Anne Heath to Steven G. Fauntleroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence G. Fauntleroy of New Canaan, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

title: Dream House
description: Millions of Americans grew up in houses that looked like this one, and many of those people are still around to remember what living in them was like.

title: Preserving a Rural Haven
description: The Adirondacks are sometimes called the ''lungs of New York,'' by Manhattanites fleeing city pollution. In a conference next weekend called ''Buildings, Landscapes & Customs: Preserving New York's Rural Resources,'' architects, preservationists, developers and public officials will study the potentials - and obstacles - of preserving the Adirondacks and other rural regions in the state.

title: Richmond Battles to Control Swollen James River
description: National Guardsmen helped patrol the city's streets today and huge pumps that drain the James River were sandbagged to protect them as the swollen river threatened Richmond.

title: BEST SELLERS: APRIL 19, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 11 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 3 3 6 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an international arms-selling intrigue. 4 4 4 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his family's place in upstate New York. 3 4 10 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. 4 2 9 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) From the Boston slums of Irish immigrants to the White House: three generations of a family. 5 6 5 BOONE, by T. Boone Pickens Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 2 3 4 HOW TO BE YOUR OWN NUTRITIONIST, by Stuart M. Berger. (Morrow, $16.95.) Ways to create a diet regimen for health and energy. 3 2 25 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) WHERE IS NICARAGUA? by Peter Davis. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The documentary film maker (''Hearts and Minds'') visits Nicaragua as an intelligent amateur, a curious gringo offering penetrating questions rather than answers about the country as a revolutionary experiment and as an icon in the American mind. STARING AT THE SUN, by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $15.95.) Precision of language, ironic detachment, a talent for incarnating ideas: these are the author's tools in a brilliant novel about a woman living between enchantment and disenchantment, between God and technology in the 21st century. BEYOND OUR MEANS, by Alfred L. Malabre Jr. (Random House, $17.95.) America can't live forever on borrowed money, says the economics editor of The Wall Street Journal, and describes various possible consequences of trying, most of them dreadful. BEING INVISIBLE, by Thomas Berger. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Enraged, cranky and bold as usual, Mr. Berger delivers us a comic hero whose invisibility is a weapon in his war on society. BERLIN DIARIES, 1940-1945, by Marie Vassiltchikov. (Knopf, $19.95.) High life in the Third Reich, the struggles of ordinary people and stirrings of the plot against Hitler, recorded in detail and often with shrewdness by a clever White Russian princess. PERSIAN NIGHTS, by Diane Johnson. (Knopf, $17.95.) The Shah of Iran is falling in Ms. Johnson's funny, frightening seventh novel; her protagonist, an American wife and mother, learns moral goodness by learning involvement, too late to make a difference. ONCE IN EUROPA, by John Berger. (Pantheon, $14.95.) These stories of contemporary peasant life in a French Alpine village may contain the best writing yet by their protean author, a British art critic, screenwriter, journalist and smart, loving observer.

title: Leigh Topping to Wed N. F. Brady Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rankin M. Smith of Atlanta have announced the engagement of Mrs. Smith's daughter, Leigh Topping, to Nicholas Frederick Brady Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brady of Far Hills, N.J. A May 30 wedding is planned.

title: TRIALS OF A TEMPORARY BACHELOR
description: FOR just about the whole first week, everything around here was in apple-pie order. The three of us all get up at different times to go to work and, like Dagwood Bumstead, at top speed, washing-shaving-toothbrushing-dres-sing zap!!, out the door, but nobody was ever late because clean clothes and toiletries were in good supply and easy to find. At dinner time, the larder was full.

title: In the Shadows Of Watergate
description: LEGAL fallout from the Watergate scandal continued to flutter down last month, nearly 15 years after the affair began.

title: Britain: Challenges For the Beeb's New Head
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DEATH WITHOUT DIGNITY: The Story of the First Nursing Home Corporation Indicted for Murder. By Steven Long. (Texas Monthly, $18.95.) Steven Long's first book is powerful drama, containing both the fascinating inside story of an unusual trial in 1985-86 and a glimpse into the painful reality of nursing home care.

title: Teicher On His Role
description: The New York Times Magazine recently published two articles that inaccurately and unfairly report about my role on the staff of the National Security Council.

title: DISPUTE ON TOWN'S CLEANUP
description: LEAD: EMBROILED in a dispute with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, the Brookhaven Highway Department will limit its spring cleanup to the collection of leaves and brush this season, leaving residents with old refrigerators, washing machines or television sets to fend for themselves.

title: Data Update
description: MEDIAN HOUSE PRICES

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: PLAYERS' CHOICE by Eugene V. McCaffrey and Roger A. McCaffrey. Facts on File Publications. 226 pages. $16.95.

title: SCHEDULE PUTS KNICKS OUT OF THEIR MISERY
description: In theory, the Knicks' miserable season ended a while ago - sometime after the inevitable dismissal of Hubie Brown as coach last December and before the incessant string of injuries made each contest an unpredictable adventure. And yet, in truth, the misery didn't end until tonight, when the Knicks lost to the Cleveland Cavaliers, 122-113, in their final game of the season.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE HOUSE ON MAPLE STREET By Bonnie Pryor. Illustrated by Beth Peck. Unpaged. New York: William Morrow & Company. $13. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Correction
description: A chart in Travel Advisory on April 5 misstated room rates for Holiday Inn hotels in London because of incorrect information supplied by the hotel chain. The usual Holiday Inn-Mayfair rates are $:91 to $:110 ($147.60 to $178.40) a night for a room for two; the usual Holiday Inn-Marble Arch rates are $:85 to $:120 ($147.60 to $194.65). The summer sale rate, which has a four-night minimum, is $:90 ($146) a night for a room for two at both hotels.

title: '47 Footnote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STILL AWAITING ITS FATE, STRATFORD STAGES 'THE TEMPEST'
description: WHILE the fate of Stratford's beleaguered American Shakespeare Theater remains a matter of mystery and speculation, a student-audience season - the 28th and the shortest in the theater's 32-year history - is scheduled to run from April 27 through May 16.

title: Golden Gate's 50th Birthday Party Is Rescued
description: It seemed so simple a year ago: a party to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Golden Gate Bridge, the best-known Western gateway to the nation. It would be a $21.9 million civic party, community leaders promised, rivaling the centennial of the Statue of Liberty.

title: COLLECTING WITH A TOUCH OF GLASS
description: IT is fragile, durable, decorative and practical - and part of America's past. It may be found in junk shops, encased in museums or sparkling on living-room shelves. Depending upon one's point of view, glass is something to break and replace or to collect and cherish.

title: COULD VEBLEN EXPLAIN TODAY'S OPERA?
description: CONSPICUOUS CONSUMPTION is nothing new at the Metropolitan Opera, which was founded, after all, as an amusement of New York's leisure class and until well into this century was almost entirely funded by a handful of bankers and other barons of business. In that dim past, the show of wealth was most evident not onstage, but in a select sector of the audience where the instinct to display fine feathers was as strong as any peacock's. The phenomenon took the form in the old Metropolitan Opera House of the famous Diamond Horseshoe, where rich patrons could sport their tiaras and brocade in full view of their social peers and a curious public.

title: The Crash of '87
description: Each week brings fresh evidence for prophets of economic doom: Brazil defaults on its foreign debt . . . The monthly U.S. trade deficit hits $15 billion . . . The dollar falls to new lows against the yen . . . President Reagan succumbs to pressure for retaliation against Japan. And for the first time, responsible officials like Fed chairman Paul Volcker openly speculate about a world financial crisis. Is the crash of '87 in the works?

title:
INVESTING;
PLAYING A SLOW RISE IN RATES
description: LEAD: Is a short-term surge in interest rates good or bad for companies tied to the housing industry? As long as rates do not climb too fast - or too far -some analysts argue that the rise actually can spur business. ''People seeing rates rising will panic and buy a home quickly,'' said Jay Charles Goodgal, a Paterson, N.J., money manager.

title: ISLANERS, CAPITALS IN THIRD OVERTIME
description: It seemed like it would take forever to decide which team would face the Philadelphia Flyers for the division championship, and in what would definitely be the longest game in either team's history, the Islanders and Capitals went into the third overtime tonight tied, 2-2.

title: BELLPORT RESISTS TIDES OF CHANGE
description: LEAD: IN 1820, when a sailing schooner carrying a cargo of millstones went aground in the shallow Fire Island inlet opposite the small village of Bellport, some villagers salvaged a few of the stones to use as doorsteps for their New England-style houses clustered near Great South Bay.

title: Jennifer A. Porter To Marry May 30
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Porter Jr. of Washington of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Alexanderson Porter to Vincent John Dowling Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dowling of West Hartford, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. A May 30 wedding is planned.

title: 'GREAT MOMENTS,' REMEMBERED FONDLY
description: I write to express my full enjoyment of the Long Island Opinion Page Article ''Great Moments (Well, Almost) in L.I. History'' [ March 22 ] . It was a delightful spoof of the Constitution, history and Long Islanders, with special emphasis on their high opinion of themselves - not fully deserved in many cases.

title: Soviet Union: New Ventures Sprout in Cultural Thaw
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: AND VISIONS BEYOND
description: LEAD: VISITORS to the auto show will get a glimpse of 21st-century transportation in such prototype vehicles as the Chevrolet Express and Pontiac Pursuit.

title: Ms. Ackerman Plans To Marry K. I. Siegel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ackerman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joyce Ina Ackerman to Kenneth Ian Siegel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Siegel of Stamford, Conn.

title: THE HOT HISTORY DEPARTMENT
description: A GOOD PORTION OF THE PRINCETON HISTORY department usually turns up on Friday mornings in the seminar room deep in the bowels of the Firestone Library. But one Friday last October, the place was jammed and the air was alive with anticipation. Jean-Christophe Agnew, a Yale professor, had ventured into the weekly Shelby Cullom Davis Seminar, a lion's den in which many a historian has been torn apart, to question the very concept that has made the Princeton department the most interesting, lively and controversial in the country: its use of cultural anthropology to interpret the past.

title: TREBELHORN OF THE BREWERS: A NAME TO NOTE, FOR NOW
description: TOM TREBELHORN never quite made a name for himself during an unspectacular minor league career spent primarily in the Northwest League towns of Bend, Ore.; Walla Walla, Wash., and Lewiston, Idaho. His name wasn't generally known either when he became a major league manager last September. Now, though, his team is making him known.

title: Play IT AGAIN, SAM
description: EVAN EISENBERG'S ''THE Recording Angel: Explorations in Phonography'' (McGraw-Hill) seems to be the first full-length book on the implications and effects of recording on music. It's bursting with ideas, taking up topics from the ties between ritual and music to the compression that 78-rpm records brought to the classic blues. For most of the book, Mr. Eisenberg deliberately limits himself to the listener's perspective - but recording has had just as much impact on musicians at work. It has affected the nuances of instrumental technique and larger questions of form, structure and correct performance. And, as creating music and recording it become more entangled, the lessons of recording feed back into live concerts.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Tides of Change Surge Along the Shore
description: LEAD: THE Jersey coast has long been perceived as a summer resort of beachfront towns where tiny bungalows stand close to the edge of the ocean. But over the last decade its complexion has changed dramatically.

title:
ART;
6 GENERATIONS OF CUBAN ARTISTS AT RUTGERS'S ZIMMERLI MUSEUM
description: LEAD: NOT SINCE 1944 at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City has there been a major survey of art from Cuba.

title:
ART;
WHAT THE JURORS CHOSE FOR ISLIP MUSEUM SHOW
description: LEAD: AS in previous years, the annual juried exhibition at the Islip Art Museum is outstanding in the categories of photography and works on paper and weak in the areas of painting and sculpture.

title: Uncertainties of a Chemical-Filled World Bring Fear to a Suburb of Denver
description: Parents in the suburb of Friendly Hills here believe toxic chemicals from a nearby aerospace complex entered their drinking water, causing sickness and death among their children. But state and Federal Government agencies say they have found no evidence of unusual health problems in the area.

title: COUNTY ITEMS FARE WELL IN STATE BUDGET
description: LEAD: COUNTY officials say they are resting easier now that the State Legislature has passed a $41 million budget containing financing for five key Westchester projects, including a $500,000 allotment for the operation of the Mental Retardation Institute in Valhalla, which provides services for mentally handicapped and developmentally disabled people throughout the lower Hudson

title: FLUID MATH MADE SIMPLE - SORT OF
description: OF all the hard problems occupying the world's supercomputers, one heads the list: calculating the flow of fluids.

title:
SOUND AND RECORDINGS;
COPLAND'S THIRD: LANGUAGE OF HOPE
description: LEAD: EVERY SO OFTEN IN A NA-tion's history, a composition is created that captures the mood of a people, that speaks a shared language of hope, conviction, and affirmation. Such a work is Aaron Copland's Symphony No. 3 (1944-46). On one hand, it sums up Mr. Copland's work of the 1930's and 1940's, the frankly populist Americana now transformed into a subtle but pervasive folk influence.

title: WOMEN AT BAY
description: TEMPORARY SHELTER By Mary Gordon. 213 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: STUDENT PRESS DRAWS PRAISE
description: ''LIKE every high school, we've been affected by such concerns as suicide and divorce, and our student-newspaper reporters have written about them from their viewpoint,'' said Sharon Miken, the journalism teacher at Triton Regional High School here.

title: THE PAST INTRUDES UPON A WEDDING LIST
description: JACKIE, our youngest daughter, will be married this summer. Just as Jackie is the youngest of 5, I was the youngest of 6, and my mother was the youngest of 11. So when I sit down to write the invitations for Jackie's wedding, I remember again what being the youngest daughter of a youngest daughter meant to me. Because I feel the weight of the past so strongly, I procrastinate and am unable to choose the guests for the wedding.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
HOBOKEN
description: LEAD: FROM a grimy industrial port that went into a decline decades ago, Hoboken has sprung back to life as a residential community where development and restoration are commonplace.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: NEW magazines usually emerge hard on the heels of a shift in life styles, despite oft-repeated warnings about the high failure rate of such publications.

title: TRYING TO KEEP THE WATER CLEAN AND PURE
description: WHEN John H. Foster was a boy, growing up in Quincy, Mass., his passion was racing small sailboats in Boston Harbor. ''You always hoped you wouldn't capsize,'' he recalled. ''The water was so full of sewage and when the wind blew from a certain quarter the air was equally foul. What I didn't know then is that the invisible pollutants in the water were even more deadly than the apparent filth.''

title: HER YOUTH OBSERVED
description: HOW I GREW By Mary McCarthy. Illustrated. 278 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: A WAY OF LIFE HANGS IN BALANCE AS ALBANY BATTLES ON ETHICS
description: TIME has little changed the New York State Legislature; its ways are rooted in another era.

title: 12 Die on Jordan School Bus
description: Twelve passengers on a school bus were killed and 22 were injured when the bus overturned during an outing in the Mujib Valley, the official Jordanian press agency said today. The victims of the accident Friday were teachers and students of a boys' secondary school in Dhiban, 30 miles south of Amman.

title: Spending Habits
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DUEL FOR DOMINANCE AT THE TOP OF MONTEDISON
description: IN Italy, Mario Schimberni is something of a management legend.

title: WHAT THE 1990's HAVE IN STORE
description: LEAD: THE futuristic automotive systems and gee-whiz gimmickry that moviegoers have seen in films like ''Blade Runner'' may soon be more reality than fantasy.

title: 4 Die in Plane Crash
description: Investigators are seeking the cause of the crash of a small plane that killed all four people aboard. The plane, a Piper Cherokee from Charleston, W.Va., crashed Friday night just off the York-Thomasville Airport's single paved runway, officials said.

title: Data Bank: April 19, 1987
CRIME
description: LAST JUDGMENT by Richard Hugo (Stein & Day, $16.95) is a very fine book. Its prologue goes back to the German invasion of Poland in 1939 and the theft of an unknown da Vinci painting. Switch to the present, and the apparently unrelated mass murder of a family in London. ''I am the incubus of pure terror,'' says the killer as he pulls the trigger.

title: Golf Round Clock
description: IT'S been almost a year since Mark Matthews played 724 holes of golf in a hectic 24 hours at the Rockwood Golf Course in Fort Worth, Tex., a feat that raised $10,000 for charity last June. Now the 25-year-old Matthews has gotten his reward. He has been notified that his effort has been certified and accepted as a world record by the Guinness Book of World Records.

title: Classical Music
description: It's a good week for new music in New York, with many and variegated events taking place all over town.

title: Vietnamese, in Election Today, Have a Choice for First Time
description: The people of Vietnam will vote Sunday in the first national elections to offer a genuine choice of candidates, according to official newspaper and television reports.

title: Miss Locke Plans To Marry June 20
description: The engagement of Susan Andrea Locke to Nicholas Daland Peirson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Peirson of Corning, N.Y., has been announced by Jean Locke of Gilford, N.H., and Kent Locke of Sanborton, N.H., parents of the bride-to-be. A June 20 wedding is planned.

title: DAI RAKUDA KAN'S THEATER OF RAW IMAGES
description: DAI RAKUDA KAN, FOUNDED and directed by Akaji Maro, was the first company to introduce Japan's Butoh dance-theater on a large scale to the United States. It is true that earlier, Japanese dancers who had been influenced by Butoh had performed as individuals in New York. But significantly, their work was not seen in the context of the still-unfamiliar fusion of German dance expressionism and Japanese experimentation that became Butoh in the 1960's.

title: Dr. Forrest Is to Marry James Litzow, a Student
description: The engagement of Dr. J.Kim Forrest to James Litzow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Litzow of Elmgrove, Wis., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Silvi Forrest of New York and Mel Forrest of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A June 6 wedding is planned.

title: Why We Should Root for Gorbachev
description: LEAD: America seems to be of two minds about Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Some think it fair to give him a chance. Others believe that he is a fraud and is not to be trusted - unless he commits something suicidal like, say, ''discarding the ruling ideology.'' Still others would like to have it both ways: While ascribing to Mr.

title: SWEET MEMORIES OF EASTERS PAST
description: LEAD: EASTERS of long ago, with their customs and rituals, some now lost, can still evoke memories in those who lived them.

title: A SIMPLE EFFORT WILL CONTROL THE WEEDS
description: IF the grass is about three inches tall, start the mowing ritual; be sure cutting blades are sharp and the motor is in good condition. Forsythia in bloom signals application of pre-emergent weed controls to prevent crabgrass and other aggressive lawn weeds from sprouting; also use this form of weed control on service areas and flower borders to prevent nuisance weeds from growing this summer. Check product labels to be sure that all plants growing in the area will not be affected by these pre-emergent weed control products. Since the chemicals must be watered in after application, turn on outdoor water faucets and put the hoses out. Rose pruning and planting of new bushes continues; on established roses, remove leaves from last year as well as winter mulch; apply fertilizer to each rosebush and cultivate it in lightly; start the weekly spray program to prevent diseases, especially black spot. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS EASTER LILY

title: MINING A CD CATALOGUE
description: AS COMPACT DISKS BE-come plentiful enough so that record companies have to compete for buyer attention, an illuminating insight into CD marketing is provided by the first installment of reissues from the Vanguard Recording Society.

title: FOR TAX VOLUNTEERS, IT'S VACATION TIME
description: LEAD: ANOTHER income-tax deadline has come and gone, and 80-year-old Wilhelmine Buckland is finished with her work for at least nine months.

title: PARTICIPATING IN THE WORLD
description: HALF PROMISED LAND By Thomas Lux. 72 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95. THE ENCHANTED ROOM By Maurya Simon. 104 pp. Port Townsend, Wash.: Copper Canyon Press. Paper, $9. THE MARBLE QUEEN By Henri Cole. 64 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $15. Paper, $8.95.

title: IN PURSUIT OF THE ULTIMATE FICTION
description: LEAD: ACENTURY ago the writing of biography, according to Lytton Strachey, was an exercise in piety and discretion. Like family lawyers, journeyman biographers did the work the community expected of them and then drew back into the silence of confidentiality. But nowadays biographers are anything but merely dutiful, modestly self-effacing.

title: Apartheid and the West
description: To the Editor:

title: DECIDING CONSEQUENCES OF INSANITY DEFENSE
description: WHEN John W. Hinckley Jr. was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the shooting of President Reagan, prosecutors and most Americans expected it would be years before he would be allowed even to leave the grounds of St. Elizabeths hospital here.

title: CONCERT: INDIANA GROUP PERFORMS EARLY MUSIC
description: THE performance of early music on period instruments is assuming an ever-larger part of our music conservatories' activities. Indiana University has long been involved in this field, and on Wednesday the large and accomplished Baroque Orchestra of the university's Early Music Institute appeared at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGES CELEBRATING
description: LEAD: WITH the slogan, ''A Great Place to Find Yourself,''

title: THE MALLING OF MAIN STREET
description: NOT too long ago, shopping along Greenwich Avenue in stately old Greenwich, Conn., was a strictly local affair. The merchants were familiar figures in the town of 60,000, and the only businesses owned by outsiders were Woolworth's and the telephone company.

title: The TV Evangelists Thrive on Skepticism; Old-Time Folk Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Pride Schuler Marries Dr. William Winkenwerder
description: Mary Pride Schuler, the daughter of William Moughon Schuler of Birmingham, Ala., and Mary Fountain of Charleston, Ore., was married yesterday to Dr. William Winkenwerder Jr., a son of Mr. Winkenwerder and Martha Loew, both of Asheville, N.C. The Rev. Dr. John D. Hewitt performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church in Asheville.

title: Michael Beatty Is Married To Linda Rudd, a Student
description: Linda Joyce Rudd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Rudd of Wellesley, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Beatty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Beatty of South Yarmouth, Mass. The Rev. Douglas Showalter performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Falmouth, Mass.

title: GOULD AND THE CD: MADE FOR EACH OTHER
description: GLENN GOULD WOULD probably have loved the compact disk. He was nearly as interested in new methods of recording as he was in the piano; for him, recordings were not merely an appendix to concerts, but a satisfactory replacement for them.

title: SUIT ALTERNATIVES: NO PANACEA
description: LEAD: ATHOUGH there is general satisfaction with the way some conflicts are decided outside courtrooms, court officials and legal scholars say the benefits of alternatives to litigation have yet to be demonstrated.

title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: Save the Panda National Geographic. Vestron Video. 1986. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: THE SLEEPY GUM GIANT BEGINS TO WAKE UP
description: LEAD: IT'S hardly a new concept: five sticks of gum for a quarter. What is new is that the William Wrigley Jr. Company will be the first to bring it back.

title: STATE TO BUY HERON SITE ON S.I.
description: New York State will buy a major heron breeding site at the Goethals Bridge Pond area on Staten Island as the first expenditure from the $1.2 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act passed by the voters in 1986.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: Learn 'n' Play: Voyage to Mermaid Island Scholastic Lorimar Reading Vol. 2 30 minutes. $14.95.

title: 2 in Seoul Opposition Sentenced to Jail
description: A South Korean court imposed jail sentences on two opposition legislators today amid published reports that prosecutors planned to step up criminal proceedings against 15 or more anti-Government politicians.

title: ABUNDANT OFFERINGS OF PIANO AND VOICE
description: THERE'S something for everyone on this week's music calendar, but if your tastes run to vocal and piano performances, the choices are especially abundant.

title: THE PALESTINIAN CAMPUS
description: IT WAS THE WEEK BEFORE STUDENT-COUNCIL elections at Bir Zeit University, on the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Rival factions were trying to wrest control of the council from a coalition backing Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The campus was plastered with campaign posters depicting Jerusalem surrounded by barbed wire; fat Jews eating skinny Palestinians with forks and knives; grenades, fists and guns embedded in the map of Israel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, APRIL 19, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17 U.S. negotiators will 'intensify' their efforts in Geneva to resolve remaining differences with the Soviet Union on the possibility of reducing medium-range nuclear missiles, President Reagan said. Page 1 Military buildups in Central America have civilian leaders worried about long-term prospects as weak governments deal with increasingly strong armies in their countries. 1 The President knew of weaknesses in the American Embassy in Moscow that made it vulnerable to Soviet espionage, an official said. Three years ago, Mr. Reagan saw a slide show about the embassy's problems. 1 In Athens, a dispute about Greek and its proper form has been renewed. Some favor ancient Greek and some the 19th-century Greek called Katharevousa. ''The language has become impoverished,'' one professor said of modern Greek. 1 A Catholic abbey in the Netherlands run by the Rev. Arthur Baeten attracts outsiders visiting the ''rebellious'' abbot. He offers sanctuary to dissident Catholic priests and laymen at odds with the Vatican. 1 In Tokyo, few fear a trade war will result from the United States decision to impose tariffs on some Japanese products. Instead, the action has raised questions about whether a hard-line Japanese trade policy could backfire. 11 Argentina's leaders will negotiate with rebellious infantry officers who are demanding an amnesty for security forces accused of past human-rights abuses. The move is intended to end the crisis peacefully. 17 The Philippine Army ended a mutiny led by renegade soldiers apparently loyal to the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos. The mutineers tried to free comrades who were being held after an earlier uprising. 12 Castro says harmony is up to U.S. 3 Vietnamese voting with a choice 4 Tougher line urged in Sri Lanka 6 Book looks at U.S.-Manila policy 12 Fanfani heads 46th Cabinet 14 NATIONAL 20-27, 38-39 Minority enrollment in colleges and universities appears to have stagnated. The latest Federal figures show that blacks have a smaller presence on American campuses than they did six years ago. 1 Frequent fliers on airlines are angry over recent decisions by many carriers to increase mileage levels needed to win free trips or better seats to popular destinations like Hawaii and Western Europe. 1 A tax-exempt group paid friends of two of the organization's leaders thousands of dollars. The friends of Carl R. Channell and Daniel L.
