Conrad, officers of the group, received money raised for conservative causes. 24 George Bush is biding his time while some of his potential rivals have declared their candidacies recently in much publicized events. But the Vice President has been appealing to supporters for funds. 27 Former foes back Chicago's Mayor, Harold Washington, as he consolidates his political power with the City Council. Mr. Washington's re-election is a large factor in attracting old opponents. ''I can count,'' one said. 22 Near Denver, toxic chemical fears unnerve a middle-class community. Parents believe the chemicals have caused sickness and death among their children. But Government officials say there is no evidence. 26 Volunteer firefighters are declining in number at departments across the country. They have become victims of Americans' peripatetic way of life and the social and economic pressures that have changed the fabric of Main Street. 20 Dispute over screening of aliens 20 Report Bakkers got $4.8 million since 1984 20 Silver lining for Golden Gate's 50th 21 Plan to restore authority 23 REGIONAL 28-36, 40-41 An escaped prisoner surrendered to a police officer who found him resting on a porch in Milford, Pa., 18 miles from the prison. The convicted hijacker was exhausted after 30 hours of trekking through a cold drizzle. 28 A court criticized a prosecutor from Brooklyn in a unanimous ruling. The decision found that repeated references to race could have prejudiced a jury against a black defendant and denied him a fair trial. 28 New York State's emission testing for cars remains one of the most ineffective in the nation and in some cases is hampered by fraud, according to Government documents and interviews with Federal and state officials. 30 Tunnel officers exposed to car fumes for 10 years were 88 percent more likely to die from heart disease than men in the general public, apparently due to the carbon monoxide, a Federal report says. 30 Touched by deaths in a tragic fire, young men at a Harlem apartment building repeatedly struck by tragedy in the last year make a special effort to help others, including the young children who live at the plaza. 32 Queens' murders rose 25.1 percent in 1986, the biggest percentage increase of any of New York City's five boroughs. The increase has caused some concern among government officials and community leaders. 32 Trucker trapped after crash 32 Feeding-tube removal asked 35 Helping ''poorest of poor'' 36

title: SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PHILADELPHIA PREMIERE

title: Armchair Shopping For Homes
description: ROY and Cathy Lloyd's three-level town house in Alexandria, Va., was shown on Washington's Channel 7 one chilly Sunday morning in January. That afternoon, 24 people trekked through the Lloyds' two-bedroom home during an open house that had been promoted on the television program that morning. On Monday, more prospective buyers came to look and on Tuesday, a few more trickled in. Thursday brought the Lloyds a substantial offer and by Friday the town house was sold for $99,000.

title: Q/and A
description: Europe by Ship Question:Do you have information on the Polish liner Batory which sails from Montreal to Poland? - J. N., Hudson, Fla. Answer:Passengers who want to cross the Atlantic on the Stefan Batory had better do so this year. A spokesman for Polish Ocean Lines said that it had been decided to discontinue the vessel's trans-Atlantic schedule after its four crossings in 1987. The Batory will then do two cruises of the Norwegian fjords and, next winter, two long cruises to South America, but what its subsequent role will be has yet to be decided, the official said.

title: Cousteau at Scripps
description: To the Editor:

title: AN EASTER PARADE IN THE NEW WORLD
description: WHITE bunnies, real or fluffy velour. Painted hard-boiled eggs, or tiny chocolate ones wrapped in colored foil. They always remind me of this special holiday time.

title: Iran Reports New Raids on Iraq
description: Iran asserted today that its troops and allied Kurdish irregulars had killed 1,500 Iraqis in hit-and-run attacks in the Kurdistan mountains, where a smoldering guerrilla war is heating up.

title: Montie M. Mills To Wed May 30
description: Announcement has been made by Frieda Smith Odom of Myrtle Beach, S.C., of the engagement of her daughter Montie Marion Mills to Mark Sherman Perry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Perry of Avon, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The wedding is to be May 30.

title: ROVER: ROUGH YET SMOOTH
description: LEAD: IT seems that hardly a week goes by without some new car company opening shop in the United States. Most, like the recent crop from Malaysia, Taiwan and Thailand, intend to flood the country with inexpensive little economy cars. But one new entry from Britain, the Range Rover, is aimed at doing just the opposite.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: THE FANCIEST DIVE: What Happened When the Media Empire of Time/Life Leaped Without Looking Into the Age of High-Tech, by Christopher M. Byron. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) In 1982-83, the author was an editor at Time Inc.'s ill-fated TV-Cable Week, one of the most expensive failures in the history of magazine publishing - the direct cash loss was some $47 million.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: A COUPLE of years ago a young man was given what he considers a major gift: a friend introduced him to the Conservatory Garden, a quiet, symmetrical oasis in the upper reaches of Central Park.

title: IN HUNTINGTON, A BOSSA NOVA BEAT
description: FABIO'S features food with a bossa nova beat. This Brazilian restaurant is one of Huntington's newest and most visually arresting eating places. A pink exterior highlighted by an aqua blue awning and painted palm trees previews the interior decor and the Latin American food featured here.

title: DANCE: THE WENDY PERRON TROUPE
description: WENDY PERRON is a quietly arresting performer who moves through a dance with a look of in-turned concentration and great physical delicacy and adroitness. Her dances are like that, too, with a sure, sometimes fierce intelligence driving them along. They curl into space like flowering vines, but a closer look reveals that the vines and tendrils are steely sinew. Buried scenarios informed the dances performed by the Wendy Perron Dance Company on Wednesday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The stories were not all that clear, and one wasn't always sure what Ms. Perron was up to. But these were pieces that convinced the viewer to follow them through their mysterious routes.

title: THE TERRIFYING NORMALACY OF AIDS
description: DISNEY'S EPCOT CENTER in Orlando, Fla., is a technological tour de force and a conceptual desert. In this permanent World's Fair, American industrial giants have built their versions of an unblemished future. These masterful entertainments convey but one message, brilliantly packaged and relentlessly expressed: progress through technology is the solution to all human problems. G.E. proclaims from Horizons: ''If we can dream it, we can do it.'' A.T.& T. speaks from on high within its giant golf ball: We are now ''unbounded by space and time.'' United Technologies bubbles from the depths of Living Seas: ''With the help of modern technology, we feel there's really no limit to what can be accomplished.''

title:
INVESTING;
CHOOSING SECURITIES FOR A RAINY DAY
description: LEAD: In the past two hectic weeks, many nervous investors have bailed out of the bond and stock markets. Individuals who tend to get spooked have had plenty cause for worry: large trade deficits, a sinking dollar, rising interest rates, fear of inflation and a nagging suspicion that the party in the stock market is over.

title: Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
description: Two different statements by two Times reporters on Dwight Gooden's drug problems point up the challenge professional sports face in curbing drug use. Dave Anderson, in writing about drugs in other teams in his column of April 2, ended on the prophetic statement ''it was never just one player.'' That day and next, Joseph Durso quoted a number of Gooden's Mets teammates as being incredulous that the ace pitcher could be on cocaine.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: The Maltese Falcon Colorized version. Starring Humphrey Bogart, Mary Astor; featuring Gladys George, Peter Lorre, Sidney Greenstreet, Lee Patrick, Barton MacLaine, Elisha Cook Jr. Directed and written by John Huston. 1941. CBS/Fox Video. 101 minutes. $59.98. (Available in black and white for $29.98.)

title: Commercial Property: Mixed-Use Buildings; The Rocky Marriages of Offices and Apartments
description: AN unprecedented number of mixed-use buildings are opening in Manhattan, prompting debate over whether apartments on upper floors will cast a discouraging shadow over office space below.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: Puccini With Robert Stephens and Virginia McKenna. Directed and edited by Tony Palmer. Home Vision. 113 minutes. $59.95.

title: Life With Trixie
description: TRIXIE IS NOT THE FIRST dog I had after I became an adult, or even the second. I got the first one almost 15 years ago, and named her Mary. She was a gray-furred, blue-eyed Weimaraner. She fell asleep by sucking my thumb until she nodded off. From the day my girlfriend and I carried her from San Francisco to Santa Cruz in a napkin, Mary lived with me - for 10 years. The girlfriend came and went. Mary stayed. ''A man and his dog'' is more than a phrase.

title: THE LENGTH OF A TERM, THE PAIN OF A SURVIVOR
description: COUNTY officials are calling it a mistake, a consequence of trying to meet the federally mandated jail-population limit. The people directly involved are calling it something more serious.

title: U.S. Rules Out Hatfield Charges
description: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute Senator Mark O. Hatfield in connection with his relationship with a Greek businessman who paid $55,000 in real estate fees to his wife.

title: Brown-Bagging It
description: THE QUEEN OF ENGLAND MAY rely on a retinue to carry her impedimenta, but the rest of the world's women must tote the works themselves. For many women, the tote bag is an office away from the desk, a portable dressing table, a locker room, lunch pail, library, shopping cart, travel bag or an amalgam of all these. Such is life today that women often go about hoisting two at once -one for the personals, the other for work. The truth of the matter is that the tote bag is today's indispensable accessory. And there are ones for every budget. In summer, straw versions traditionally are popular. The Gap stores always stock their roomy canvas tote priced at $19.50. Plastic pressed to look like leather is tough and resilient, as are leathers imprinted to resemble even more luxurious ones. This past year, alligator was the overwhelming favorite fake in either of these materials. The real was also remarkably successful, despite its high price tag. This season, ostrich is the favored leather, real or impersonated. Once again, bags made of the real stuff are prohibitively priced, but as is true of alligator, they can last a lifetime. This season, too, tawny tones are the most fashionable and popular. Brown-bagging it has never been more chic.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: IT'S TIME TO CONSIDER A KEOGH - FOR '87
description: IF you are a self-employed professional, or a homemaker or salaried worker with a sideline business, a Keogh plan is one of the most attractive ways to accumulate money for retirement. Similar in concept to a corporate retirement or profit-sharing plan, a Keogh plan allows you to make tax-deductible annual contributions to it, and the earnings accumulate tax-free until they are withdrawn at retirement.

title: ROONEY IS FUNNY THING AT FORUM
description: MICKEY ROONEY stars in ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' which is making a fast stop at the Westbury Music Fair during its current national tour.

title: Border Officers To Weigh Pleas Of Illegal Aliens
description: The Government has named Border Patrol agents, investigators, deportation officers and other enforcement personnel to review applications from illegal aliens seeking legal status under the new immigration law.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE road back to the major leagues begins in Miami for the former Baltimore Oriole and Montreal Expo pitcher, Dennis Martinez. A free agent who had a 3-6 record and a 4.59 earned-run average with the Expos last year, Martinez has signed a two-week contract with the Class A Miami Marlins in an attempt to get in shape for a possible comeback with the Expos when he becomes eligible to rejoin them May 1. . . . Pitt's 6-10 center, Charles Smith, said he was 80 percent certain he would pass up his senior year and declare himself eligible for the National Basketball Association draft. He must notify the league by May 8. . . . Scott Hartman, the Tennessee freshman hammer thrower struck in the head Friday by a 16-pound hammer at the Kentucky Relays in Lexington, was in critical condition yesterday at a hospital there. . . . Bonnie Gadusek, the 23-year-old, seven-tournament winner during six seasons on the tennis tour, announced her retirement yesterday.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Support Your Local Sheriff With James Garner, Joan Hackett, Walter Brennan, Harry Morgan, Jack Elam, Bruce Dern. Written and produced by William Bowers. Directed by Burt Kennedy. 1969. Playhouse Video. 93 minutes. $19.98.

title: Trinity's Bridge
description: There was a time when Trinity Place in lower Manhattan was so serene and empty on weekends that ''you could bowl down it,'' said Kenneth A. Ellis, a spokesman for Trinity Church, a city landmark on Broadway at the head of Wall Street. But traffic has mounted along this narrow street that separates the rear of the church from its parish office tower. And so, too, has traffic between church and parish hall as parishioners cross back and forth to Trinity's growing Sunday school, daycare center and community programs.

title: A TOUCH OF SOHO IN SONO
description: SONO, as the renovated area of South Norwalk is called, is developing a SoHo look, reminiscent of the rejuvenated art neighborhood south of Houston Street in Manhattan, and so are its new restaurants.

title: TURNING JAPAN INTO AN IMPORTING NATION
description: AS evidenced in plummeting bond prices and soaring interest rates, the microchip war has badly shaken the international financial markets. Unfortunately, the recent United States tariffs on certain Japanese electronics products appear to be only the first in a series of moves to protect American high-tech industries. The battering sustained by Wall Street early last week suggests that investors anticipate further protectionist steps that threaten to undermine the domestic economic and financial system, which now depends heavily on the inflow of Japanese capital.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: MANCHESTER, N.H.;
Auctioning Off A Post Office
description: LEAD: WHEN officials of Devine, Millimet, Stahl & Branch decided it was time to find new office space, they went to the Manchester post office. And they bought it. The law firm - with 40 lawyers, one of the largest in New Hampshire - paid $2.5 million at a December 1985 auction of the 54,000-square-foot building, which had served as post office and a Federal office building since its construction in 1933.

title: EQUALIZERS CHIP IN WITH INTELLIGENCE
description: MORE AND MORE these days, machines are taking over the tasks that some people aren't smart enough to do themselves. If you don't know how to add, all you need is a pocket calculator; and if you don't know how to spell, a modern typewriter can help you out with some computerized orthography. That kind of handy automation has lately come to audio in the form of self-regulating equalizers.

title: Miss Kirksey to Marry Michael Floyd in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wiley F. Kirksey of Eutaw, Ala., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dianne Faye Kirksey, to Michael Floyd, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Floyd of Conway, S.C. The wedding is to be next month.

title: F.D.A. Finds Diluted Caffeine Lessens Danger
description: Some bone defects seen in the fetuses carried by rats that had been given large amounts of caffeine appear to reverse themselves after birth, a finding scientists say may lessen concerns about effects of the stimulant on human fetuses.

title: U.S. AID EXPANDED ON FUSION RESEARCH
description: THE nation's fusion-energy program began in 1951 at Princeton University, but fusion-generated power may not be available commerically until 2051. However, every long journey begins with a first step, and Congress appears ready to take it.

title: PANELS ACT TO SHUT 2 OVERSIGHT OFFICES
description: TWO watchdog agencies created by the Republican- controlled General Assembly in 1985 to monitor the workings of the state government have been targeted for extinction by the Democratic majorities in this year's legislature.

title: Traveling With The Pack
description: IT ISN'T OFTEN THAT THE COSMETICS industry thinks in purely practical terms. But with the proliferation of makeup, hair-care and skin-treatment products that are small, lightweight and ideal for travel, it seems that common sense has at last pervaded the business.

title: New Book on Marcos Says U.S. Knew of His '72 Martial-Law Plans
description: Contrary to official assertions, the United States Embassy in Manila knew that President Ferdinand E. Marcos was about to declare martial law in 1972 and did not act to stop him, according to a new book by Raymond Bonner.

title: SWEDEN SHARES ITS FRENCH RICHES
description: THIS YEAR MARKS THE 10TH AN-niversary of the founding of the Drawing Center, now at 35 Wooster Street in SoHo. Some form of celebration was clearly desirable, and it is our good fortune that the Nationalmuseum in Stockholm agreed to send over an exhibition called ''The Art of Drawing in France 1400-1900.'' Chosen and catalogued by the museum's present director, Per Bjurstrom, the show, comprising 145 works, can be seen at the Drawing Center through July 22.

title: MARYLAND'S REVISIONS IN GAMING
description: Slot machines will soon be permitted on Maryland's Eastern Shore, but legal casino nights that recently inspired gambling fever around Baltimore are out under legislation passed by the State General Assembly.

title:
DINING OUT;
A RETURN TO BUCKS COUNTY
description: LEAD: IT'S INTERESTNG when a restaurant is acquired by new owners. A little more than five years ago, I reviewed an utterly charming one in Erwinna, Pa., the Golden Pheasant Inn. At the time, this Bucks County restaurant was decorated in a style that was slightly larger than life, but it had considerable charm nonetheless.

title: GULCH FIRST IN WOOD
description: Gulch, the best 2-year-old in the country last summer but a disappointment ever since, rallied from far back under Jose Santos to catch Gone West in the final stride and win the $590,500 Wood Memorial by a head yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: YANKS COOL OFF JACKSON AND WIN
description: Bo Jackson, baseball's latest early-season phenom, could not have cooled off any faster if he had locked himself in the freezer of a Lower East Side butcher shop or jumped into the Hudson River in January.

title: House Group in Soviet Hopeful on Arms
description: The Soviet Union, eager for an agreement to eliminate medium-range missiles in Europe, appears willing to compromise further to get one, according to Congressional Democrats who completed meetings with Soviet leaders today.

title: DELAWARE JOINS 3 STATES IN BIG LOTTERY
description: Twice a week, on Wednesday and Friday, Ike Williams leaves his job in Delaware and drives 21 miles to Jayco Liquors in this border town. A teetotaler, he ignores the rows of bottles. Instead, like thousands of other Delaware residents hoping to strike it rich, he comes here to buy Maryland lottery tickets.

title: JAZZ FOR CHURCH SERVICES MAKES MEASURED PROGRESS
description: LEAD: ''E VERY MAN PRAYS IN HIS own language,'' said Duke Ellington, ''and there is no language God does not understand.'' For Ellington, of course, the language was jazz, and he as well as other noted jazz artists have composed works designated as ''sacred'' or written to be included in church services.

title: BUSH QUIETLY SETS STAGE FOR DRIVE
description: While some of his rivals for the Presidency are declaring their candidacies in highly publicized events designed for maximum attention on television, Vice President Bush is waiting.

title: Anne Keesee To Be Wed Next June 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Woodfin Keesee Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Hartford Keesee, to Thomas Michael Niemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Oscar Niemann of St. Louis.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: MAJOR ROAD IN MEXICO BEING WIDENED

title: HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
description: You'll hear plenty about the dearth of black managers and executives, but let's not forget that there is also still bias in fielding teams. If many black athletes are superstars, then many must also be excellent or good journeyman players. But at the journeyman level, blacks are often not well represented, as they should be if skill were all that mattered. ALBERT WEISSMAN Westerly, R.I.

title: TIGHTENING THE REINS IN BALLISTIC MISSLE RACE
description: IN South America, Argentina and Brazil are to be the proud new owners of ballistic missiles. On the subcontinent, India leads Pakistan in the race to obtain powerful missiles. Asian nations that rim the Pacific - the Koreas, Taiwan, Indonesia - are climbing the technical ladder toward mastery of missile technology. In the Middle East, count Israel, Egypt, and Syria among the missile states.

title: ARGENTINA DELAYS ATTACK ON REBELS
description: Argentina's civilian Government today delayed moves to crush a mutiny by infantry officers who are demanding amnesty for members of the security forces accused of human-rights abuses.

title: OLD RAIL ROUTES SOUGHT AS PARK TRAILS
description: THE decline of rail lines in Connecticut could mean miles of new recreation trails for hikers, bikers, horseback riders and others, under a new program of the State Environmental Protection Department.

title: Getting a Patent On Animal Life
description: As scientists become increasingly adept at manipulating the molecules of life, the line between the animate and the inanimate becomes ever more indistinct.

title: South Africa Says Its Forces Killed a Rioter Near Durban
description: South African security forces fired on a group of blacks setting fire to homes in a black township near Durban, killing one man, the Government's Bureau for Information said today.

title: FATHERS, DAUGHTERS AND HOODLUMS
description: THAT NIGHT By Alice McDermott. 184 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: ARBITRARY, UNILATERAL CAPS ON WATER USE WILL HURT
description: WHEN a massive glacier trudged north several million years ago, it left behind an interesting piece of geography to the east of the mainland now known as Long Island.

title: First Lady
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPANSION OF COLLEGE IS OPPOSED
description: A plan by Baruch College to expand its campus near Gramercy Park has generated a bitter neighborhood battle over that most precious and volatile of Manhattan commodities: space.

title: LILCO'S PLEA POINTS UP DUAL EFFORT ON POWER
description: LEAD: HIDDEN agendas seemed to be dictating events surrounding the Shoreham nuclear power plant last week.

title: Recent Sales
description: Coram $136,000 4 Row Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old center- hall colonial; family room, partial basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. East Islip $140,000 281 Wensley Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, den, utility room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Holtsville $150,000 137 Abner Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 23-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, deck; taxes $2,600. Lake Ronkonkoma $117,000 33 Pineland Street 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; patio, 2-bedroom, 1-bath cottage; taxes $1,200. Massapequa $255,000 136 Alhambra Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old waterfront ranch; solarium, den, 2 fireplaces, central air-conditioning; taxes $4,500. Shirley $125,000 391 Puritan Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; fire place, 2 kitchens, basement, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,500. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. $370,000 7 Bolton Gardens 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old stucco town house; modern kitchen, porch, flagstone terrace; taxes $4,202. Livingston, N.J. $196,000 96 Hobart Gap 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old colonial; fire place, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,531. Stamford, Conn. $542,500 25 Knob Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2 bath, 11-year-old colonial; studio with skylights, landscaping, 1 acre; taxes $5,350.

title: RECYCLING: A NEW APPROACH TO GARBAGE
description: LEAD: MANDATORY recycling becomes the law in New Jersey tomorrow, and garbage collection will never be the same. The change will not be as easy or as quick as the stroke of Governor Kean's pen; however, once the measure is implemented, it will affect the daily life of every state resident, a claim that can be made for few pieces of legislation.

title: Anne E. Leonard Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Anne Elizabeth Leonard and James Batchelder Hardy Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardy of Ridgefield, Conn., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Leonard of Westport, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: BATTLE LINE ON GRAFFITI IS SHIFTING
description: New York seems to be winning its war against graffiti in the subways, but many of the graffiti writers are using their spray cans and brushes on alternate targets: bridges, buildings, playgrounds and, particularly, the equipment of the Department of Sanitation.

title: Jury Finds Bias By Daily News
description: Testimony in the trial lasted a rancorous nine weeks, with four black journalists accusing the management of The Daily News of racism and The News accusing them of incompetence. Last week the jury agreed with the journalists.

title: AFFORDABLE HOUSING: THE 'DENSITY' FACTOR
description: The article headed ''Zoning Is Vital to Quality of Life'' [ Opinion Page, March 15 ] , written in answer to Bishop John McGann's fine pastoral letter, is typical of the sophistry commonly offered in opposition to affordable housing. Density is fast becoming a code word for justifying exclusionary zoning practices.

title: NEW HEAD IS NAMED FOR BEIRUT SCHOOL
description: The new president of the American University of Beirut, Dr. Frederic P. Herter, says that despite continued troubles in Lebanon, the independent private university still has ''a major role to play in forming leaders of the Middle East.''

title: Martha Dickenson to Wed Timothy Health in October
description: Mrs. Eustis Walcott of Boston and David S. Dickenson of Cleveland have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Stuart Dickenson to Timothy Edward Heath, a son of Ann O. Heath of Newport, R.I., and Richard O. Heath of New Canaan, Conn. An October wedding is planned. Miss Dickenson, a licensing technician for the New England life insurance company in Boston, attended Boston University, of which her fiance is a graduate. Her father owns Dickenson & Associates, a life insurance brokerage in Cleveland.

title: A Second Vote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Myth Making
description: William Safire incorrectly asserts that the letter sent recently to The Wall Street Journal over my signature was in fact written by former President Nixon. Though much of the factual material was drawn from Mr. Nixon's excellent memoirs, every word of the letter was mine. But, while I don't imagine Mr. Safire intended to pay me a compliment, I take as high praise indeed that I have so thoroughly absorbed the former President's brisk, evocative prose style that a former Nixon speechwriter such as Mr. Safire has mistaken my writing for the boss's. JOHN H. TAYLOR Assistant to President Nixon New York City

title: MAKING 'NEWS ON THE CHEAP' PAY OFF
description: IT is 8 o'clock in the morning, and the assignment editors and the producers of Cable News Network troop into the conference room for their regular morning meeting. There are no pretensions here. The table is too small, so some of the people grab outlying chairs and a few stand. Those who want coffee bring their own - if they can find clean mugs. Heads bent over story summaries, the editors crisply rattle off the pieces they hope will fill up 24 hours without a stop: a State Department briefing, budget testimony before the House Appropriations Committee, hearings on the Amtrak train crash in Baltimore, Virginia officials banning a paint used on boats because it is poisoning fish.

title:
THEATER;
LOOK OO'S PLAYIN' 'ENRY' IGGINS NAOW
description: LEAD: PETER O'TOOLE, AN ACTOR WHO can improvise an entire ballet without moving out of a Louis Seize chair, drives a hand through his hair and crosses his legs. Soon thereafter, he uncrosses them and gently hugs a knee to his chest. Then he discards the knee to reach for a Gauloise. The cigarette is inserted into a holder at a jaunty if precarious 15-degree angle; after it has been smoked, the long, eloquent fingers reach for a pastille - ''My Jujubes,'' he calls them - a French confection that resembles an undersized gumdrop and tastes like medicine.

title: Outdoors; Canada Increases Its Support for Salmon
description: CANADA is giving greater recognition to the economic role played by its Atlantic salmon sport fishery, a development that delights the Atlantic Salmon Federation, a nonprofit conservation organization with branches in that country and the United States.

title: TRUTH, OPIUM AND MUDDY WATERS
description: AN INSULAR POSSESSION By Timothy Mo. 593 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: MUNICIPALLY BASED LAND-USE CONTROL IS CALLED A FAILURE
description: NEW JERSEY'S municipally based system of land-use control has badly failed our people. The sorry evidence of that failure is apparent in the congestion on our roadways, the outrageous cost of decent housing, the disappearance of our farms and natural areas and the blight of our cities.

title: Part and Parcel
description: On the grounds of the rambling suburban estates that burgeoned around the turn-of-the century, the outbuildings were, more often than not, designed in styles similar to the grander main house. As a growing number of these estates are now being subdivided into more managable packages of land, many of the utilitarian structures - like barns, grain houses, stables and chicken coops - have been renovated to become main houses themselves. Shown here, for example, is the former chauffeur's barn for Conyer's Manor, a 1500 acre estate in Greenwich, Connecticut that belonged to Edmund Cogswell Converse, one of the founders of U.S. Steel and Bankers Trust of New York. Renamed Conyer's Farm, the property has recently been subdivided.

title:
GARDENING;
THERE'S MORE THAN ONE LILAC FOR PLANTING
description: LEAD: MENTION lilacs, and most gardeners envision sprays of lavender blossoms, fragrant in the early warmth of May and filled with the murmuring of innumerable bees. They are probably thinking of the all-too-common lilac, Syringa vulgaris, when, in fact, there are many more. At least 25 species of lilacs are known, and 1,400 varieties.

title: LONDON ON A PEDESTAL
description: When I first saw the view from my office in London, I felt as if I had inherited a great painting, and in a sense, I had. For when I look south across a sweeping bend of the Thames, I can see the New Palace of Westminister, home of the Houses of Parliament - a filigreed Gothic ramble marked at one end by soaring Victoria Tower and at the other by the familiar Clock Tower of Big Ben. Off to the right, lower and more massive, are the western towers of Westminster Abbey, each wearing a prickly crown of four spires. When the afternoon sun is just so, the scene is magical. The surface of the river, faceted by wavelets, is luminous with a bitter blue-silver light. The sky is silvery, too, except in its higher reaches. There the mists reflect the tawny coloring of the Westminster limestone, and the air around the palace seems brushed with gold. If you want to know how it looks, I refer you to the painting by Claude Monet, entitled ''The Thames Below London.''

title: Myth Making
description: In his article ''Ten Myths About the Reagan Debacle'' (March 22), I found William Safire's observations to be shrewd and surprisingly objective, as I confess to anticipating an impassioned apologia for the Reagan Administration's indefensible operational blunders.

title: Debate Silenced In South Korea
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea had a simple solution to the conflict over how to select a leader to replace him: He suspended the debate over constitutional changes that would decide the issue. But there were some signs last week that his move might only deepen resistance to his rule.

title: HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
description: Al Campanis only voiced what many others in decision-making positions in sports believe and practice. The ''old boy'' network that can always find another assignment for a white manager with a less-than-outstanding record has historically had nothing but a deaf ear to the entreaties of the aspiring black manager.

title: FOR HEADLIGHTS, LESS IS MORE
description: LEAD: As the automobile industry streamlines cars to improve performance and economy, engineers say headlights will get smaller and smaller until they become mere slits of light.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: REVOLUTION AS ILLICIT LOVE Sometimes a writer exhilarates us with the sheer voluptuousness of his imagination. Ronald Paulson sees the female figure of Liberty in the art of the French Revolution as combining Venus, a virgin state, a charitable woman, a sentimental love object and the mother of the new order. This is from ''Representations of Revolution (1789-1820)'' (Yale University).

title: Spies I Have Known
description: During the last week I was in Poland as a correspondent, three people tried separately to entrap me - a doctor, a writer, an architect.

title: INFINITY IS BIGGER THAN ALL OF US
description: IN ''Past Tense,'' the first volume of his diaries, Jean Cocteau says that ''Gide has never experienced the discomfort of infinity.'' It's a rather catty remark, but it rings true. It reminds me of a photograph I saw of Gide: he was at the opera in Paris, sitting in the orchestra, and over his beautifully domed bald head he had draped a silk scarf. I had supposed the scarf was meant to protect him against the cold in the theater, but now I realize that it was the draft, the discomfort, of infinity he feared.

title: HE FOUND IT AT THE MOVIES
description: ''RONALD REAGAN,'' THE MOVIE And Other Episodes in Political Demonology. By Michael Paul Rogin. Illustrated. 366 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: Edward B. Pinger Plans to Be Wed To Minna Towbin
description: Minna Towbin, research editor of Elle magazine in New York, and Edward B. Pinger, a shipping broker at New England Tanker Chartering in Rowayton, Conn., plan to be married Aug. 1.

title: AT A 'REBELLIOUS' DUTCH ABBEY, EASTER FOR ALL
description: A bright pile of yellow flowers, fresh cut from this nation's spring treasure of blossoming fields, was all that punctuated the Good Friday hush when Jesus was pronounced dead once more in the church of Berne Abbey.

title: Cecil King, 86, Dies in Dublin; A British Newspaper Leader
description: Cecil King, chairman of what was believed to be the biggest publishing empire in the world in the 1960's, died at his Dublin home on Friday. He was 86 years old.

title: THE WHEELCHAIR TRAVELER
description: For the individual confined to a wheelchair who fights a never-ending battle against architectural and other barriers on home turf, the prospect of international travel looms as the impossible dream.

title: Deborah Jensen Planning to Wed Randolph Barker
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Jensen of Weston, Mass., and Moultonboro, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Jensen, to Randolph Harrison Barker, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Randolph Barker of Ithaca, N.Y.

title: AT HOME ANYWHERE, ON VIEW IN NEW YORK
description: Le Mans is an old and honored name for Pontiac cars, and a new model bearing that designation is due for introduction in a few weeks. But the car will be unlike anything Pontiac has ever sold, and its origins illustrate how radically the automobile business has changed in the laste few years.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
A 4.2-MILE-LONG BANANA SPLIT
description: LEAD: Today is Princeton's annual Communiversity Day, a festival celebrating town-gown relations. However, at 10:30 A.M. Saturday, some 8,000 Princeton University students and area residents will go bananas for a good cause. Some may even go nuts.

title: SUBWAY DOOR PROBLEM NO OPEN AND SHUT CASE
description: AT 3:55 P.M. on April 9, a southbound J train left the Chambers Street station in Manhattan with one door open.

title: Headliners; Voted In
description: The Bronx, whose political leadership has lately hinged more on the ballots cast by grand jurors than on those of ordinary voters, got a new Borough President last week. City Council members from the borough chose Fernando Ferrer for the post, which was vacated last month when Stanley Simon resigned from the office as he was about to be indicted various charges. State Assemblyman Jose Serrano, who also sought the Borough Presidency, said the selection of Mr. Ferrer, who has been a supporter of Mr. Simon and of former Bronx Democratic leader Stanley Friedman, who was convicted of racketeering, represented ''politics as usual.'' Mr. Ferrer, who resigned from the City Council to take the new job, promised change. ''In six months, people are going to say they have seen the most dramatic change ever,'' he said.

title: BE NEUTRAL - OR ELSE
description: AMERICAN BROADCASTING AND THE FIRST AMENDMENT By Lucas A. Powe Jr. 295 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: 'BIG SCREEN' TAKES ON NEW MEANING
description: THE MOST VISCERALLY EXCITING, mind-expanding movies being made today - the kind that provide windows on worlds previously undreamed of, or that discover the spectacular mysteries within something as commonplace as bird-flight - aren't to be found in conventional theaters, and aren't likely to turn up in theaters soon. There'll never be a video cassette heaven for these movies. The best of them aren't just big -they are gigantic, and gigantism is their method as well as their style.

title: Jazz
description: Oliver Jones did not undertake a full-time jazz career until 1980, when he was 46 years old. By then he had spent the better part of two decades as accompanist and musical director for a Jamaican singer, Kenny Hamilton. However, he was born and grew up in Montreal, three blocks away from the great jazz pianist Oscar Peterson. He began studying piano with Mr. Peterson's sister Daisy when he was 9, and Chuck Peterson, the famous pianist's brother, was associated with Mr. Jones during the early days of his career.

title: Myth Making
description: If Ronald Reagan is the ''Great Communicator,'' then William Safire is certainly the ''Great Apologist.'' Rather than write what he knows to be true about the President's blundering, Mr. Safire attacks William Casey, Donald Regan, Edwin Meese, even Nancy Reagan - anyone, in fact, but the man who is presumably in command. If ''myths are for the lazy,'' as Mr. Safire proclaims in his article, then apologies must be for the unscrupulous. ROBERT ZUKERMAN New York City

title: TUNING IN TO A 'PERSIAN JOHNNY CARSON'
description: IRANIANS in Southern California rarely stay up to watch Johnny Carson these days. Instead, they get up to catch Parvis Afshar, the Iranian version of America's late-night comedian. Each weekday morning at 7 a.m., KSCI in San Bernadino broadcasts Mr. Afshar's ''Sima-E-Ashena,'' an hour-long Persian-language show of news, commentary and interviews.

title: NEW LIFE FOR EARLY MUSIC
description: MANY RECORDINGS of pre-Classical music used to be sold in what amounted to plain brown wrappers with such plain brown titles as ''Monody, ca. 1600 - Research Period VII'' (and many, though by no means all, of the performances were monochromatic, too). If this left little doubt about the high-mindedness attached to the whole operation, it also probably discouraged casual purchases, limiting the audience to those already in the know.

title: New York Car Exhaust Test Assailed as Ineffective and Hampered by Fraud
description: Despite repeated warnings from Federal environmental officials, New York State's system for testing car emissions remains one of the most ineffective in the nation and in some cases is hampered by fraud, according to Government documents and interviews with Federal and state officials.

title: SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DRIVING PASSION: The Psychology of the Car. By Peter Marsh and Peter Collett. (Faber & Faber, $16.95.) This volume offers a fast, funny and insightful account of the worldwide romance with the automobile. With special emphasis on the United States and Great Britain, Peter Marsh and Peter Collett, respectively a lecturer in psychology at Oxford Polytechnic and a researcher at Oxford University, contend that from its earliest days the car has been more important as a means of self-expression than as a form of transportation.

title: An Older Father
description: In his article ''A Fulfillment'' (About Men, March 29), Richard Taylor states, ''My thoughts are free to focus entirely on my wife and baby,'' now that he is an older father and no longer burdened with career, status, income and the many other necessities that take up our ''normal'' child-rearing years. How lucky he is to have this opportunity. As a working mother, I have often thought how wonderful it would be to focus my energies on my husband and young children. I often see the irony: when we finally do have time to relax and enjoy our families, they no longer need us. BELINDA RUBINO Jackson Heights, Queens

title: Fairy-Tale Ballet
description: NAPOLI Choreographed by August Bournonville; music by Rossini, Helsted, Gade, Paulli and Lumbye; staged by Kirsten Ralov; directed for television by Preben Montell; performed by the Royal Danish Ballet. Home Vision 100 minutes; $39.95.

title: Mexico: A Call for Home-Grown TV
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: PUBLICITY, POWER AND THE POLICE
description: As a representative of an organization called Victims of Police Crime who has long been uneasy with the amount of publicity intentionally generated by police unions, I would like to respond to Arthur Cliff's letter to the editor on March 22 [ ''Police Association's View on State Inquiry'' ] .

title: DANCE: ACANTHUS BALLET
description: THE Acanthus Ballet is a group of likable young dancers who presented a likable program of dance on Friday at the Field, a performance space at the Pineapple Dance Center on Houston Street. Highlights were ''Garnets,'' a new work by Richard Allan Ploch, the director of Acanthus, and ''Ives' Scene America,'' by Robert Yohn.

title: Dial Sets Record
description: IN a performance heightened by controversy, Joe Dial soared 19 feet 4 3/4 inches yesterday at the Kansas Relays in Lawrence, Kan., to break his American pole-vault record.

title: Faith, and Freedom
description: Holy Week: the week of Easter, and also of Passover, a week to think of renewal and freedom, as good a week as there is to believe anew that faith can move mountains. In a cathedral in Cape Town and in a mansion in Moscow, people gathered for religious services seemed to believe it.

title: Toxic Leak Rule in Effect
description: A little-publicized provision of Federal law that took effect today requires states to plan for the evacuation and medical treatment of people at risk from toxic leaks at chemical plants.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: IT WON'T BE BUSINESS AS USUAL;
TEXACO FILES FOR A TRAUMATIC FUTURE
description: LEAD: TEXACO Inc. has temporarily eased the pressure from the Pennzoil Company by seeking refuge in Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. Many analysts have applauded Texaco's action as a legal maneuver that will enable the company to retain its assets and conduct business while seeking to resolve its legal problems with

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BILLYBALL. By Billy Martin with Phil Pepe. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Given the stormy reputation of its author, a former manager of the New York Yankees, this book is surprisingly mild in tone and substance. The stated purpose of the volume is to present Billy Martin's views on managerial strategy and tactics. Some of the chapters do indeed discuss aspects of the craft - when to bunt or hit-and-run, how best to utilize one's personnel, what the strengths and weaknesses of current major league managers are and so on. Unfortunately, such topics pop up more or less randomly, with little rhyme or reason in the sequence of subject matter. If the book has any theme at all, it is not managerial decision-making but a chronological account of Mr. Martin's career, both as player and manager, accompanied by his opinions on such things as the players' current economic power, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's positive influence and drugs in baseball. Fans who crave more of Billy Martin should enjoy ''Billyball''; those who prefer a more structured and systematic presentation of managerial strategy would be better off reading ''Weaver on Strategy,'' co-written by the Baltimore Orioles' former manager, Earl Weaver.

title: STOCK-CAR DRIVERS CHASING EARNHARDT
description: The Winston Cup stock-car racers have this weekend off, giving them time to think about one thing: how to catch Dale Earnhardt.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A LIFE IN MOVIES: An Autobiography. By Michael Powell. (Knopf, $24.95.) The author of this intelligent and superbly written autobiography, the British film director Michael Powell, is known in this country chiefly for the cult ballet movie ''The Red Shoes'' (1948), though some consider the subtly erotic tale of Anglican nuns in the Himalayas, ''Black Narcissus'' (1947), and the benignly decadent, self-reflexive ''Peeping Tom'' (1960) even better. What is perhaps most fascinating about this book is Mr. Powell's obvious intention of chronicling the entire history of British and American cinema through his own career. And he almost succeeds. The first part of the book offers an affectionate paean to silent film making, which he learned at the side of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Rex Ingram in the 1920's. He then moves on to his struggle to establish himself as a director in England in the 30's and to the powerful films he made during World War II with the screenwriter Emeric Pressburger, ending with an insightful portrayal of the rapacious creativity of postwar Hollywood. The co-stars of this autobiography are the legendary British moguls Mr. Powell worked for, such as Alexander Korda and Arthur Rank, but we also get incisive portraits of the likes of Laurence Olivier and Alfred Hitchcock along the way. Though success makes him swagger a bit now and then, Mr. Powell is remarkably egalitarian in an industry that thrives on self-promotion, giving elaborate credit to everyone who has ever worked for him. Alas, this is also the book's chief weakness: this closely-printed, 700-page volume covers only the first half of his life, up to the late 1940's. Now an octogenarian, Mr. Powell seems to want to get everything down all at once, including all the trips he has ever taken and apparently everyone he has ever known. Despite the occasional longueurs caused by the tyranny of his total recall, one looks forward to hearing about the rest of his eventful life.

title: MASSACHUSETTS PLANNING NEW AID FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: Manicured lawns offer a regal entry to the Metropolitan State Hospital for the mentally ill and a stark contrast to conditions inside.

title: The TV Evangelists Thrive on Skepticism; What Calvin Stood For
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ORLEANS, AND ALL THAT JAZZ
description: What Lincoln Steffens wrote of Paris well describes New Orleans, our belle ville at the bottom of America: ''A loose merger of many, very many small provincial communities, each of which is pleasantly or offensively clannish.''

title: No Headline
description: Dick Shawn, the comic actor who played Hitler in the Mel Brooks movie ''The Producers,'' died Friday night after collapsing in front of an audience that at first thought the fall was a joke. He was 63 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: WELCOMING THE SEASON ON 2 AGING WHEELS
description: SPRING has made its annual appearance and it's time to put a little air in the bike tires.

title: PANEL HOPEFUL ON BILL TO RECYCLE TRASH
description: LAST year the state legislature allocated $13 million to help communities start programs to recycle garbage. Last week the Environment Committee of the legislature unanimously recommended a compulsory recycling measure to put the law where the money is.

title: 3 COMPOSERS WHO DEFINED OPERA IN THE 18TH CENTURY
description: LEAD: IN HIS QUITE REMARKABLE LITTLE volume ''The Opera, Past and Present''(1901), the noted Boston scholar W. F. Apthorp respectfully acknowledged Gluck as ''the father of modern opera,'' properly observed that Mozart's exceptional genius created operas ''as if Gluck had never existed,'' and - after expressing his admiration for the beauty of Handel's writing - virtually dismissed his operas for a style that was ''antagonistic to all true scenic conditions.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ON NEW ISSUES AND HELPFUL PUBLICATIONS
description: LEAD: TODAY marks the start of National Coin Week, an annual observance to increase public awareness of coin collecting and attract new recruits to the hobby. All week long coin clubs and individual hobbyists throughout the nation will engage in special activities for numismatics that will include exhibits, lectures and question-and-answer forums in schools and libraries.

title: Recent Sales
description: Dover $142,000 21 East Crystal Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; modern kitchen, patio; taxes $1,721. Livingston $196,000 96 Hobart Gap 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old colonial; fire place, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,531. Mahwah $320,000 30 Indian Field Court 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old town- house condominium; deck, central air- conditioning; maintenance $138, taxes $3,325. Pompton Lakes $145,000 415 Colfax Avenue 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old brick ranch; enclosed porch, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,517. Warren $285,000 9 Sage Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old contem porary; family room, fireplace, hardwood floors; taxes $2,634. West Orange $1.2 million Oak Bend Llewyln Park 12-bedroom, 8 1/2-bath, 43-year-old English manor; 7 fireplaces, formal dining room, den, 3-car garage; taxes $27,000. OTHER AREAS Massapequa, L.I. $255,000 136 Alhambra Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old waterfront ranch; solarium, den, 2 fireplaces, central air-conditioning; taxes $4,500. New Haven, Conn. $106,500 78 Milton Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old Cape Cod; vinyl siding, on land lease; taxes $2,066. Putnam Valley, N.Y. $108,500 Barger Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 56-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, deck, 1-car detached garage, 0.92 acre; taxes $2,450.

title: HERR SLAMS METS IN 10TH
description: On a night that will haunt their memories, the Mets blew a five-run lead in the fourth inning and a pair of one-run leads in the ninth and 10th innings tonight. And then they blew the entire evening when Tommy Herr of the St. Louis Cardinals whaled a grand slam off Jesse Orosco that buried the Mets once and for all, 12-8.

title: A BOOK ON AIDS
description: A major reference work on the subject of AIDS, edited by the chief of infectious diseases at the County Medical Center, Dr. Gary P. Wormser, is about to be published.

title: Headliners; Voted Innocent
description: To hear Amy Carter and her 13 co-defendants tell it, their campus protest trial ended last week with a guilty verdict against the Central Intelligence Agency. Miss Carter, the daughter of former President Jimmy Carter, and the others, including Abbie Hoffman, were acquitted of trespassing and disorderly conduct in connection with a demonstration against C.I.A. recruiters at the University of Massachusetts last fall. Lawyers for the protesters used the ''necessity defense,'' a tenet of Massachusetts law that exonerates people who commit crimes in order to prevent the commission of other, more serious crimes. The prosecutor, W. Michael Ryan Jr., said the jury believed the defense. ''Middle America doesn't want the C.I.A. doing what they are doing,'' he said.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FINE THINGS. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Bernie Fine is a nebbish yuppie with a relentlessly Jewish mother. His life is generally miserable. He is lonely. Beautiful women use him and leave him. He is transferred from his beloved Manhattan to manage the San Francisco branch of a Bendelish department store.

title: DANCE: ENZO COSIMI AND TROUPE FROM ITALY
description: MODERN dance is not a purely American form, having strong roots in Central Europe. Nonetheless, Europe failed to sustain a strong modern-dance tradition after the 1930's, and it is only since the 1970's that dance as a form of individual expression has gained popularity there.

title: SHE SELLS THE CLOSEST CLOTHES
description: ''WHAT'S making it exciting,'' said Carole Hochman of Manhattan and Quogue, ''are the new things we're doing that are sexy.''

title: WRITING THAT ANGRY LETTER
description: There is a glutted file in this department where copies of travelers' letters of complaint accumulate. Some are heartrending, some are amazing; all are angry. The opposite of the little black box that emits applause sounds when the lid is lifted, this file drawer seems to give off steam and sounds of fury when opened.

title: Poetry And Reality
description: As a poet and native North American, I read Francisco Goldman's article ''Poetry and Power in Nicaragua'' (March 29) with a blend of relief and wistfulness: relief that I live where I have little to fear because of what I write, and wistfulness that I do not live where what I write commands political or social impact. Perhaps it is a necessary trade-off. One writes one's poems under either the stringency of a young revolution or the broad twilight of a social order so established and old nobody remembers that here, too, it was a faction that once took power, and still rules. DOUGLAS MOREA Newark, Del.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
OF FAITH, YOUTH, ETHICS AND CHANGE
description: LEAD: ''WHY is this night different from all other nights? On all other nights, we eat bread, croissants, even muffins,'' posits Howard Zaharoff in a Baltimore Jewish Times parody called ''The Yuppie Haggadah.'' ''Why, on this night, only matzoh?''

title: TWO TYPES OF AUTO-FOCUSING
description: EVERYONE'S talking about automatic focusing these days, and quite a few photographers think it is the greatest invention since flexible film. But I suspect that few purchasers of auto-focus cameras know how it works, or recognize that there are several kinds of auto focusing, depending on the type and brand of camera.

title: Fear and the Feerick Commission
description: To win funding for his new Commission on Government Integrity from the New York Legislature, Governor Cuomo went along with the sacrifice of his choice for chairman, Joseph Califano. That was a heavy price; Mr. Cuomo recovers it with interest by naming John Feerick, dean of the Fordham Law School, as chairman and Cyrus Vance, former Secretary of State, to another vacancy.

title: 'LES MISERABLES': THE DISTINCTIVE AND STIRRING VERSION IS STILL VICTOR HUGO'S
description: THERE WERE PEOPLE who told me ''Les Miserables'' was going to be wonderful and people who told me it was going to be terrible. The truth - or my reactions, at least - turned out to lie somewhere in the middle. If the lyrics were often little more than doggerel, and if the score often seemed the musical equivalent of doggerel, there were compensations in Colm Wilkinson's rightly acclaimed Jean Valjean, in a few of the supporting performances, in the scenery and lighting, and, every now and then, in a genuinely striking dramatic effect. But none of it added up to Victor Hugo.

title: Two Russian Guards Killed by Guerrillas Near Afghan Border
description: Afghan guerrillas attacked an outpost of Soviet border guards last week and killed two of them, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: TROUBLE IN RIVER CITY, RIGHT HERE IN BEIJING
description: Dear Director,

title: CORRECTION
description: An art review in the March 29 Westchester Weekly section incorrectly identified Arthur Rothstein, whose works were among those of several members of the Photo League of New York on display at the Hudson River Museum.

title: PIERCING THE EXCUSES IN BASEBALL HIRINGS
description: LEAD: FORTY years ago Jackie Robinson integrated the playing fields of major league baseball. We are still waiting for blacks to integrate the front offices of major league baseball. I have been asked many times why there are no black managers or general managers for the 26 teams. Al Campanis finally answered that question better than I can.

title: SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: Tech Transfer
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Gogh Would Have Been Horrified
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Mayor's Victory Prize: Council Peace
description: Twenty years ago a ward boss on this city's West Side laid down the first rule of Chicago politics. ''Don't make no waves - don't back no losers,'' the ward chief, Bernie Neistein, advised.

title: NEXT YEAR'S MODELS THIS YEAR
description: LEAD: As automakers are displaying their 1987 models at the New York International Auto Show, they are also turning their attention to 1988 and beyond. Here is a glimpse at some models scheduled to make their debut in the next 12 to 18 months.

title: PUPIL HEALTH CENTER FACES BOARD VOTE
description: LEAD: A SHARPLY divided school board in Mount Vernon is expected to decide this week whether to continue support for a student health center that includes referrals for birth-control counseling.

title: Sending Up
description: Tama Janowitz's ''Adventures in Tinseltown'' was most interesting. She has the talent of describing people and situations with clarity in a minimum of words. Bette Midler came alive on the page, with more dimension than on the silver screen.

title: JAZZ: 'DYNAMIC DUOS' PLAY IN N.Y.U. PROGRAM
description: THE ''Dynamic Duos'' that were featured in the ''Highlights in Jazz'' program on Thursday evening at the N.Y.U. Loeb Student Center were, in the words of Jack Kleinsinger, host of the series, ''cooking on a low flame.''

title: Miss Bast to Wed L. B. Welch
description: The engagement of Beatrice Weeks Bast to Leighton B. Welch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Overman Welch Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bast of Ambler, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: Hong Kong: Uproar Over Film Censorship
description: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

title: IS THE LABOR PARTY AN ENDANGERED SPECIES?
description: BY midweek, politicians were streaming out of the capital for Britain's protracted ''Easter hols,'' and that may be the best news the Labor Party and its leader, Neil Kinnock, have received all year. Recent polls showed Labor 10 to 13 points behind the Conservatives, but barely holding onto second place over the Alliance of Liberals and Social Democrats, which hopes to displace Labor as one of the two major parties. On Thursday, a new Gallup survey put the Conservatives at 40.5 percent, the Alliance, 29, and Labor slipping to third at 28.

title: A SETTING FIT FOR A SHOGUN
description: THE FIRST WORD I HAD OF the plan to create a new space for Japanese art at the Metropolitan Museum came three years ago from a Buddhist priest I met at the Miidera (also known as Onjoji), the imposing temple complex that overlooks Lake Biwa, east of Kyoto. I had gone there, as I had long intended, to pay my respects at the grave of Ernest Fenollosa (1853-1908), the American scholar who did so much not only to introduce Japanese art to the West but to persuade the Japanese, then in the throes of modernization, to preserve their traditional arts. After his death in London, his ashes were brought for interment to the Miidera, a temple he had especially admired.

title: Comatose Man's Family Seeks Removal of His Feeding Tube
description: The family of a 34-year-old exercise physiologist, hospitalized at the Westchester County Medical Center in a vegetative state, has asked a state appeals court for permission to remove a feeding tube - an act that his family said he had indicated he would favor.

title: Tech Transfer
description: To the Editor

title: Pamela Ross to Wed Michael J. Ciszewski
description: The engagement of Pamela Anne Ross and Michael John Ciszewski, 1984 graduates of Dartmouth College, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Ross of Tiburon, Calif. An August wedding is planned.

title: FULL COATS GLOW IN APRIL SHOWERS
description: AS usual, April has brought its share of rainy, windy days. But the gloom of the weather has been offset by the fresh array of voluminous, richly colored raincoats that women are wearing, most of them every bit as breezy as the elements.

title: TIME TO HONOR A SYMBOL OF DEMOCRACY
description: IT was as recently as 20 years ago.

title: Mariner Deal Off
description: THERE'S nothing like taking a close look at the books to give some previously eager baseball investors cold feet. That, anyway, is apparently what happened to Don Drysdale and some fellow plungers who announced a week or so ago that they would buy the Seattle Mariners. Now, however, after studying potential purchase, the group has called the whole thing off. There was no immediate comment from Drysdale, the former Dodger pitcher who now works as a broadcaster.

title:
GARDENING;
SOIL IS A PREREQUISITE FOR SUCCESS
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH not the most popular gardening subject when it comes to having a successful garden, a good case can be made for soil preparation having top billing. One can have the best seeds or plants, put them in at the best time, keep them free of pests and diseases and still fail if the soil conditions are not right.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: STARLIGHT. By Scott Ely. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) Andre Gide wrote of the French novelist Celine, ''It's not reality which Celine paints but the hallucination which reality provokes.'' This description applies equally well to ''Starlight,'' Scott Ely's startling first novel about a combat unit in the Vietnam war.

title: Patrick John Barry Plans Wedding to Mary K. Nutt
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Tysen Nutt of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Katharine Nutt to Patrick John Barry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Barry of Lake Forest, Ill. The wedding is planned for July.

title: AGENCY TO ADVISE RESIDENTS ON RADON
description: THE State Department of Health Services is setting up a program to advise residents of how to deal with radon after recent tests showed high levels of the gas in some towns.

title: Next Week; What Do Giants and Jets Need In the Draft?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: WHEN SIMILARITY RESIGNS, STYLE IS SUBSTANCE
description: LEAD: THE success of the Ford Motor Company's Taurus and Sable has been widely attributed to the way they look. Their rounded, aerodynamic shape has proven so popular with buyers that the cars' 1986 sales helped Ford post bigger profits than General Motors for the first time in more than 50 years.

title: QUEST FOR SUCCESS FOR THE ISLAND
description: Perhaps, since so many of Long Island's business leaders are forecasting gloom and doom, the time has come to review the basic equation for success.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: WELL, WE HAD the usual big April to-do this week at our house. The worst moment came when Clemmie, 14 months old, got lost in the file cabinets.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 55 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 55 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Ms. Schulman to Wed David Nachman
description: The engagement of Amy Weinfeld Schulman to David Eli Nachman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey B. Nachman of Santurce, P.R., has been announced by Alvin H. Schulman of Princeton, N.J., and Ann Schulman of New York, parents of the future bride. The wedding is to be Aug. 16.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE VIRTUOUS JOURNALIST. By Stephen Klaidman and Tom L. Beauchamp. (Oxford University, $19.95.) This study of ethics in journalism is best when Stephen Klaidman and Tom L. Beauchamp evaluate the actual performance of the press. In one discussion, the authors level a devastating indictment at the CBS documentary ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietman Deception,'' which purported to show that Gen.

title: IN THE MIDST OF PLENTY, PLENTY IS MISSING
description: SOMETHING CURIOUS and paradoxical has happened in the New York museum scene.

title: HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
description: Forty years ago, Jackie Robinson became the first black man to play major league baseball. However, the struggle for racial equality and equal opportunity in professional sports is obviously far from being complete. The lack of administrative and managerial opportunities for racial minorities is indeed a sad commentary on our nation's commitment to equality and opportunity for all.

title: THE WINNERS WHO CAME FROM BEHIND
description: WHEN world championships are instituted, American selection procedures tend to be haphazard. In 1937 Ely Culbertson selected his own team to play in Budapest, and the United States women's team arrived with just three players. In 1960 the first American women's team in a Team Olympiad included a player who had never before played with any of her teammates.

title: Miss Goldstein to Wed Dr. Robert E. Steckler
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ronald F. Goldstein of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Ann Goldstein, to Dr. Robert Eric Steckler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Steckler of Smithtown, L.I.

title: TAILORING THE DATA BSE TO THE DATA
description: TWO years ago, a data base management program called Reflex was released, and I was rather taken by it. First of all, it was easy to use, and I'm certain that far more software is bought than is ever used, quite simply because learning how to run it is an overwhelming task. But I also liked the program because it surpassed the usual data base manager in its ability to manipulate and analyze the information that it stored.

title: SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: MAKING FRATERNITIES NOT FOR MEN ONLY
description: LEAD: AT Wesleyan University, where there is about an equal number of men and women, fraternities give the biggest parties, have the nicest places to eat, and live in houses in the best locations on campus, members and nonmembers alike agree.

title: MUSIC: JUILLARD QUARTET AND HAYDN
description: ONE of Haydn's most fully characteristic works - therefore unique, original and lacking ostentation - is the series of slow instrumental ''sonatas'' on the seven last words of Christ. The cycle was composed about 1786, and later published in arrangements, including one for string quartet that the Juilliard Quartet has often performed. Still later, Haydn encountered another composer's vocal adaptation of the music, and touched it up with the help of a colleague to make an oratorio for soloists, chorus and full orchestra. Friday night at Carnegie Hall the Juilliard enlisted the aid of four vocal soloists to present a hybrid version.

title: FAMOUS THOUGHTS ON SOME SPECIAL CARS
description: SLEEK and sassy or sturdy and comfortable, slow to start or quick to stop - whatever the style, many people who've gone on to bigger and better things cling to memories of their first cars.

title: RECIPES TO KEEP IN HAND FOR THOSE TASTY ASPARAGUS SPEARS
description: IN April and May asparagus is cheap and plentiful. It comes in many sizes, from thin as a pencil to almost as thick as sugar cane. All sizes are good - whether you like your asparagus served hot with melted butter and lemon juice or cold with a vinaigrette. But after awhile, I like to be more adventurous, and serve asparagus with a puree of red peppers sprinkled with fresh tarragon or, as the Italians do, with Parmesan cheese and baked in a hot oven. I also like to eat it with pasta, in a cream sauce with prosciutto or shrimp.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Gibson Jazz Concert Phil Woods, Urbie Green, Clark Terry, Dave McKenna, Buddy DeFranco, George Duvivier, Shelly Manne, Johnny Smith and Budd Johnson. Sony Video Software. 53 minutes. $29.95.

title: August Wedding For Miss Hulen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Culbertson Hulen of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Natalie Spencer Hulen to James Carmen Diana, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph N. Diana of Syracuse. An August wedding is planned. Miss Hulen, who graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College, expects to receive a J.D. degree from the New York University School of Law on May 29 and to join the Washington law firm McKenna, Conner & Cuneo in September. Her father, a lawyer, retired from the Foreign Service after serving as a political officer in Manila and Islamabad, Pakistan. Her mother, Mary F. Hulen, teaches piano at the Potomac School in McLean, Va., and performs with the Friday Morning Music Club in Washington.

title: Carolyn Frye Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Wesley Frye Jr. of New York and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Ann Frye to Michael John Halloran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Halloran of New Canaan.

title: LINDEN HAS PLANS FOR AIRPORT
description: OFFICIALS of this Union County city, where industrial and commercial properties take up 50 percent of the developed land, would like to see the municipally owned, 188-acre airport put to better use.

title: RARITIES SALE HAS AN APPEALING AGENDA
description: THE Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries will conduct the company's 24th annual ''Rarities of the World'' auction on May 2. The sale will begin at 1 P.M. at the New York Helmsley Hotel, Third Avenue and 42d Street. Copies of the auction catalogue can be obtained for $3 at stamp dealers or by mail from Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries, Inc., 160 East 58th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: Why Not Choose One?
description: To the Editor:

title: SAYING ALOHA TO POLO
description: Polo is seductive: galloping speed and hazard, enthusiasm and thundering horses are alluring everywhere, and on the north coast of Oahu, where shadowy green mountains form a backdrop, the game is wrapped up in sunlight on a field framed by coco and ironwood trees. In Hawaii the sport becomes an island vacation as well, with matches and tournaments to watch every Sunday, and all the requisites of luxury living in the country. If you ride, there are polo clinics and a school, and if you're good at it you can take a team guest spot to play in a match game.

title: MUSIC: SHELLEY HIRSCH
description: ONE of New York's most delightful experimental singers, Shelley Hirsch brings an impressive stylistic versatility to her explorations of the human voice. Ms. Hirsch, who performed three pieces at Roulette on Thursday evening, portrays all vocal styles - from pure operatic warbling to hard, twangy country singing - as related colors on a continuous vocal spectrum. Abstract vocal excursions in an invented language fade in and out of recognizable fragments of popular songs in captivating stream-of-consciousness journeys.

title: THE ESSENCE OF DEVELOPING FRIENDSHIPS
description: ''WE are lonely,'' says Letty Cottin Pogrebin in her new book, ''Among Friends,'' ''but we fear intimacy.''

title: Verbatim; What Good Is Jail?
description: ' After spending my life in the city, including 20 years in police, I say what the hell good is jail? It costs too much and we get almost nothing for it, except they don't do a crime while they're in the box. And that's all we get. ' - Richard J. Koehler, New York City Correction Commissioner, discussing the city's overcrowded prisons.

title: LAW OF THE LAND
description: To the Editor: Reading ''Dealing With the Laws of the Land'' served to remind me why Americans are viewed as they are around the world and particularly in Central and South America and the Middle East. Mr. Kristof's Victim as Apologist must seem hysterical to local authorities, reinforcing the arrogant but essentially spineless stereotype that their governments and media tout.

title: Parties With a Purpose
description: Roman Celebration April 20 - The American Academy in Rome, in a magnificent Italian Renaissance mansion, has fostered some of the most illustrious talents in American arts and letters since its founding in 1894 as a center for advanced studies. Three composers who spent some of their formative years at the academy - Aaron Copland, Elliott Carter and Lukas Foss - will be honored at a black-tie benefit for the institution at the Equitable Center. After cocktails at 7 P.M. the Brooklyn Philharmonic will give a concert of their music in the center's auditorium, with Mr. Foss conducting. Dinner follows. Tickets $250, from 212-580-5511. Bosses' Treat April 23 - An ''All-Star Salute to Secretaries'' consists of lunch and entertainment at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria from 11:30 A.M. to 1:45 P.M., with secretaries and their bosses invited. The event will benefit the Arthritis Foundation. Tickets $50, from 212-477-8316. Shakespeare Uptown April 23 - The Theater Classics Repertory Company is a new group intent on promoting the classics. The company begins its career with a benefit production of Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' at the Riverside Church, 120th Street at Claremont Avenue. Champagne at 6:30 P.M. precedes the 7 P.M. performance and a party afterward with cast members. Tickets $100, from 212-876-2250. Salute to Volunteer April 23 - Volunteer is a national organization founded in 1974 by George W. Romney to promote and support volunteer work in a variety of endeavors. A benefit for the organization as well as an 80th-birthday salute to Mr. Romney will be held at the New York Hilton. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M., followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets $300, from 212-889-2244. Busman's Holiday April 23 - The New York Theater Workshop is a nonprofit Off Broadway company that produces and develops the work of new playwrights and directors. Fledgling artists will meet some masters of the profession at a benefit preview performance of the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''Liaisons Dangereuses'' at the Music Box Theater. Dinner at the Dish of Salt restaurant follows the 8 P.M. performance. Tickets $175, from 212-302-7737. Music for All Tastes April 24 - Avery Fisher Hall will resound with an eclectic selection of music at the annual black-tie benefit of Musica Sacra. The Dave Brubeck Quartet will join the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra at a 7:30 P.M. concert. Then, after dinner on the Grand Promenade, there will be dancing to the music of the Peter Duchin Orchestra. Tickets $175 from 212-874-3104. Brooklyn Extravaganza April 25 - Champagne at 7:30 P.M. will be followed by dinner and dancing until 12:30 P.M. in the Grand Court of the Brooklyn Museum. The black-tie benefit for the museum has been held each year since 1957 to honor art collectors past, present and future. Tickets $125, from 718-789-2493. Noted Briefly: April 25 - Meredith Monk and Nurit Tilles will be performing at an 8 P.M. benefit for the Greenwich House Music School on Barrow Street west of Sheridan Square. A Champagne reception follows. Tickets $60, or $40 for the performance alone, from 212-242-4770. April 26 - The Negro Ensemble Company's first Adolph Caesar Performing Arts Awards benefit will be held at the Shubert Theater. A 5:30 P.M. reception precedes the 8 P.M. awards and variety show, followed by a party until 1 A.M. at the California-New York Club. Tickets $250, or $125 for show and post-performance party, or $35 and $75 for the show alone, from 212-575-5860. April 26 - The Harmonie Ensemble will benefit from a 1 P.M. luncheon and screening of ''never-before-seen historic footage of George and Ira Gershwin'' at the Conservatory, 16 Central Park West. Tickets $30, at the door. Information: 212-874-2745. April 26 - The 33d benefit dinner-dance for the Brooklyn Philharmonic will be held at the Plaza starting at 6 P.M. with cocktails. Tickets for the black-tie evening $150, from 718-636-4120. April 27 - Cocktails at 7 P.M., dinner and a 90-minute variety show at the New York Hilton will mark the spring benefit of the Manhattan Theater Club. Tickets $200, or $50 for the show alone, from 212-645-5590. April 27 - A black-tie tribute to the late Harold Arlen at the Pierre will benefit the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. Cocktails at 6 P.M.; dinner, dancing and an Arlen medley sung by Tony Bennett. Tickets $300, from 212-944-5700. April 27 - The Millay Colony for the Arts, which provides a retreat without cost for writers, composers and visual artists in Austerlitz, N.Y., will hold its 10th black-tie benefit at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof. A feature of the evening, which starts with 6:30 P.M. cocktails followed by dinner, will be the first presentation of songs from next season's musical ''Into the Woods'' by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, a former Millay Colony resident.
