Tickets $150, from 212-799-7654.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: PRIZE STORIES 1987: The O. Henry Awards. Edited, and with an introduction, by William Abrahams. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The 67th annual edition of O. Henry Prize stories is meant to be a sample of the best in recent fiction, though to call it representative is also to admit that the collection is uneven.

title: RECITAL: JOSEPH SMITH
description: IN an art that has come to equate importance with size, Joseph Smith is an attractively reticent pianist. Playing at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, Mr. Smith made Beethoven's early F minor Sonata a model of Classical grammar, managing to be expressive without ever inflating a relatively contained format beyond its natural boundaries. Schumann's ''Kinderscenen'' was also aptly modest, with no attempt to exceed its scale. Here again Mr. Smith had the sense and the sensitivity simply to play the music with caring simplicity rather than clutter it with ''interpretation.''

title: Willi Smith, Clothes Designer; Creator of Vivid Sportswear
description: Willi Smith, one of the fashion industry's most successful young designers, known for spirited and trendy clothes, died of pneumonia Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dr. Cortes Plans To Marry June 20
description: Dr. Martha Cortes, a clinical instructor of dentistry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, plans to be married June 20 to Dr. David Gaudino, a surgical resident at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: GOOD BUYS DOWN UNDER
description: As Australia rises in popularity as a place for Americans to visit, the land Down Under has become -coincidentally - a better and cheaper place for shopping. The attractive prices on Australian-made goods, which until a few years ago were not particulary valued, is a result of the Australian Labor Government's devaluation of the Australian dollar. It was a move designed to make Australian manufactured goods more competitive overseas, and it has had the side effect of making American dollars go much farther for American visitors.

title: SHOULD GRIPES AGAINST BROKERS GO TO ARBITRATION?
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

title: Israelis Said to Kill 18 Pro-Iran Fighters In Lebanon's South
description: Israeli troops and South Lebanon Army soldiers killed 18 guerrillas early today while driving back an attack by the pro-Iranian Party of God on an outpost in southern Lebanon, a military spokesman said.

title: VIEWS OF A KALEIDOSCOPIC CITY
description: Take a bus tour of a foreign city, and you will see its principal attractions in an afternoon. But the visitor who rides on a public bus from one end of its route to the other will learn a lot more about the life of the city and its people.

title: Miss Kemble To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by William Kemble of Bedford Hills, N.Y., of the engagement of his daughter, Susan Bayard Kemble, to George Patterson West of Findlay, Ohio, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Kase West of Danville, Pa. The wedding is to be June 20.

title: PARK SERVICE ENDORCES PLAN TO PROTECT 3 RIVERS
description: IN a reversal of its position last year, the National Park Service has endorsed a plan to federally protect three South Jersey rivers, but an agency official says the state should pay for a study of the pristine environment.

title: MISTAKE ON RELEASE STIRS NEW JAIL DEBATE
description: THE jail-population problem in Nassau County, which has bounced in and out of the Federal courts as well as political arenas since 1981, came to the fore again last week when it was learned that 16 prisoners, convicted of felony charges, were inadvertently freed as part of a Federal court-mandated early release program.

title: DISEASE IS CALLED INCREDIBLE
description: THOSE familiar with compulsive gambling say that the common reference to it as a disease, like alcoholism and other addictions, is not merely metaphoric but technically accurate.

title: Ranks of Volunteer Firefighters Thinned by Changing Society
description: When a 100-year-old farmhouse caught fire recently on a secluded hill over Lake Louise, the siren in this township's fire hall wailed its melancholy summons. But the five men who responded were too little and too late. By the time reinforcements from nearby departments arrived, flames had consumed the house, leaving little more than charred beams and rubble.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MARKING TIME A THE BALLANTINE HOUSE
description: LEAD: ONE OF the Newark Museum's principal assets is Ballantine House, the eclectic Victorian mansion built by John Holme Ballantine, a wealthy brewer, for his family in 1885.

title: DAVIS AND REDS SMASH ASTROS, 8-0
description: Bill Gullickson pitched a four-hitter, and Eric Davis drove in three runs with a home run off Nolan Ryan and a triple as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Houston Astros today, 8-0.

title: Q & A: RISE OF A 'MEGADEALER'
description: NORMAN Braman is an example of a growing phenomenon in the automobile business, a ''mega-dealer'' who owns 19 automobile dealerships that sell cars ranging from Toyota and Honda to Porsche and Rolls-Royce. He is also chairman of Austin Rover Cars of North America, importer of a new British-Japanese luxury car, theSterling, whose introduction in mid-February underlined the increasingly international nature of the car market.

title: Tamils Kill 126 Civilian Bus Riders In Sri Lanka War
description: In the civil war in Sri Lanka, the opponents are the minority Tamils, most of whom are Hindus, and the majority Sinhalese, most of whom are Buddhists. Since 1983, 5,000 people have been killed in the fighting in the country of 16 million. Thousands of Tamils have sought political asylum and public sympathy in the West, maintaining they are victims of persecution by the Government.

title: WHAT DO TIES AND TOOTHPICKS HAVE IN COMMON? TIMBER
description: WHEN Allen Lord ties one on, he creates quite a stir. That is because while he wears ordinary trousers, shirts and jackets, his silky-looking ties are not made of silk, or cotton, rayon or Dacron.

title: THE CHINESE AMBUSH
description: EAST OF CHOSIN Entrapment and Breakout in Korea, 1950. By Roy E. Appleman. Illustrated. 399 pp. College Station: Texas A&M University Press. $22.50.

title: Andrea Atkins, a Reporter, To Marry David Hessekiel
description: Andrea Neale Atkins, a reporter for The New Haven Register, and David Scott Hessekiel, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Stanford University, plan to be married Sept. 13, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Norman Atkins of Emerson, N.J., have announced.

title: A PLACE TO WORK, A PLACE TO REST
description: MY workshop is a special place. It is removed from the rest of the house in a corner of the basement away from casual traffic. It is comfortable and familiar. It is my place. It has all kinds of things that are used in home and car repair - wrenches, screwdrivers, saws, hammers, tape rules, assorted nails, screws, nuts and bolts, pliers and some power tools. It is a small area with little room for loitering; it is a place to work, to make repairs and to extend the longevity of appliances. After long exposure to mean weather or just a mean day, puttering around the shop restores order to body and mind. For a person without a favorite chair, slippers or sweater, it is a safe harbor.

title: BREWERS TIE RECORD WITH 11TH IN A ROW
description: The undefeated Milwaukee Brewers tied an American League record for quick getaways by winning their 11th in a row, 4-3, today over the Texas Rangers.

title: CERTIFICATION OF COMPULSIVE-GAMBLING COUNSELORS PROPOSED
description: RESPONDING to increases in the incidence of compulsive gambling, an ad hoc committee of the New Jersey Council on Compulsive Gambling last week urged state certification of gambling counselors and proposed specific criteria to be used.

title: Revival Efforts Divisive In Texas Ghost Towns
description: It's not easy running a ghost town. Just ask Bill and Rex Ivey, who own this crumbling abandoned mercury-mining town near the Mexican border in the dusty reaches of Texas' biggest and loneliest county.

title: Gooden Case: Sharing Blame
description: A few thoughts concerning Dwight Gooden. 1. The Mets' organization should be rebuked for letting a gem become tarnished. 2. Davey Johnson, the manager, should be dismissed - or at least given a stern reprimand - for being blind to the plight of his star pitcher. It's impossible to believe that he was looking when Gooden was having pitching problems. He and the pitching coach were only concerned with his ''push-off'' off the mound. What nonsense. What blindness. 3. The sportswriters don't come off too well in this either. After the story broke, they all said ''there were rumors.'' What did they do about that? Did they track them down? Did they go to management? What did they do? 4. I hope that Gooden returns and performs as he did in 1985 -for his sake, not the Mets'. Doubleday, Wilpon and Cashen simply don't deserve to benefit at the box office from Gooden's comeback. 5. A personal note. As a fan nearing 60, I hope that Gooden returns in style. I figure he is the last baseball player whose career I will get involved with -rooting for him as if he were family. RICHARD WALDSTEIN Manhattan

title: ON RESIDENTIAL USE OF LARCHMONT BEACH
description: I wish to correct a factual error in remarks attributed to me in the March 29 article titled ''Davids I. Debate Crosses City Borders.''

title: HOPES FOR SATURN RETURN TO EARTH
description: IT is perhaps the most famous car never sold. The first commercial Saturn, General Motors's high-technology gamble designed to compete with Japanese manufacturers, will not roll off an assembly line until the 1990's. Yet, for more than two years, the car has been the subject of more speculation, hype and hope than almost any other product in the American auto industry.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Seattle; Designing By Committee
description: FOR nearly 30 years, Seattle has been trying to build a downtown public square and, later, a shopping mall. Critics say that the effort has become a textbook example of the problems that are inherent in urban planning.

title: WHAT ALL AMERICANS BOUGHT IN 1986
description: The following were the 10 best-selling automobiles in the United States in 1986, along with the number sold of each model, according to the trade journal Automotive News. Chevrolet Celebrity 408,956 Ford Escort 402,181 Chevrolet Cavalier 357,112 Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera 329,930 Honda Accord 325,004 Ford Tempo 265,382 Ford Taurus 263,450 Oldsmobile 88 261,260 Buick Century 240,747 Honda Civic 235,801

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GIVE AND TAKE
description: LEAD: ANDREW D. FREDMAN, 33 years old, is an architect with offices in Manhattan and the kind of busy schedule one expects of that ubiquitous breed, the young urban professional. For the last two years, however, he has been taking a few weeks off each year to return to his junior high school alma mater, the White Plains Middle School.

title: NEW WAYS OF LOSING AROUND THE STATE
description: LEAD: CONNIE MATRONI gained 100 pounds after her son died two years ago. ''I went from a size 7 to a 20,'' said the 53-year-old Brooklyn, N.Y., resident.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $540,000 268 Succabone Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 57-year-old colonial; tennis court, guest cottage, large playroom, 4.1 acres; taxes $5,971. Bronxville, N.Y. $370,000 7 Bolton Gardens 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old stucco town house; modern kitchen, porch, flagstone terrace; taxes $4,202. Putnam Valley, N.Y. $108,500 Barger Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 56-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, deck, 1-car detached garage, 0.92 acre; taxes $2,450. Monroe, Conn. $259,900 25 Bart Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; 2-car garage, in-law apartment, 2.2 acres; taxes not yet available. New Haven, Conn. $106,500 78 Milton Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old Cape Cod; vinyl siding, on land lease; taxes $2,066. Stamford, Conn. $542,500 25 Knob Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2 bath, 11-year-old colonial; studio with skylights, landscaping, 1 acre; taxes $5,350. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. $196,000 96 Hobart Gap 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old colonial; fire place, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,531. Pompton Lakes, N.J. $145,000 415 Colfax Avenue 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old brick ranch; enclosed porch, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,517. Shirley, L.I. $125,000 391 Puritan Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; fire place, 2 kitchens, basement, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,500.

title: CASTRO TELLS OFFICIALS HE IS OPTIMISTIC ON CUBA'S PARTICIPATION
description: Officials of the Indianapolis Pan American Games organizing committee ended three days of discussions with Cuban sports and Government authorities late Friday night with a 75-minute meeting with President Fidel Castro. The Cuban leader told them he was optimistic that any problems involving the Cuban delegation to the games could be worked out.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Demand Grows for Specialty-Shop Strips
description: LEAD: WHEN Neil Feldstein decided to build a new Hyundai dealership on Route 112 in Medford, he asked Mojo-Stumer Architects of Great Neck to design a 30,000-square-foot shopping strip that would attract high-quality tenants to complement his automobile showroom.

title: Hhway Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebecca E. Spiro To Marry June 7
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Spiro of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Elizabeth Spiro, to Robert Jeffrey Shore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Shore of London, Ontario. The wedding is to be June 7.

title: PROUDLY POLISH COLLEGE TO SHUT IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Alliance College is a school so Polish that the evergreens lining the campus were imported from southern Poland.

title: COPING WITH THE DEMANDS OF LISZT
description: LEAD: THE ROMANTIC 19TH CEN-tury was a time in which legions of composer-pianists and pianist-composers flourished mightily; Beethoven and Chopin may be the most familiar of them, but their ranks also include the likes of Anton Rubinstein, Xaver Scharwenka and Ferrucio Busoni. Many were simply creative virtuosi whose music was little more than an extension of their playing.

title: Q. & A.: Stephen G. Breyer; WITH UNIFORM SENTENCING - SAME CRIME, SAME TIME
description: TOWARD the end of 1985, the United States Sentencing Commission took up the task of making punishment for Federal crimes more uniform, effective and fair. Last week it recommended ranges of sentencing for 43 categories of crimes, based on a statistical analysis of present sentences. Convicts would no longer be paroled, more time would be served for drug-related offenses and prison would be prescribed for many white-collar crimes under guidelines that become binding on Federal judges Nov. 1 unless Congress rejects or amends them.

title: Kenneth W. Kaufman To Wed Laura Thrall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver J. Thrall 2d of Windsor, Conn., have annnounced the engagement of their daughter Laura Elizabeth Thrall to Kenneth William Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kaufman of Armonk, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW AMERICAN FARE IN TARRYTOWN
description: LEAD: THE name of this dining spot says it all.

title: THE MOST ITALIAN OF SPIRITS
description: In Italy, mornings are for cappuccino, but in northern Italy, they're also for a tiny cup of syrupy espresso with a shot of fiery grappa, the most Italian of spirits.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: WINDSOR, VT.;
Gambling on Appreciation
description: LEAD: PROPERTY values have more than doubled in West Windsor since November 1983 when Summit Ventures bought the bankrupt Mount Ascutney ski resort and began pumping millions of dollars into it.

title: HOW BIG A PROBLEM IS RACISM IS SPORTS?
description: We need more courageous people like Branch Rickey, people who aren't afraid to take risks. Al Campanis showed that we as a people have much growing up to do. KEVIN C. LEWIS Staten Island

title: A GUITARIST, A FLUTIST, A PIANIST AND A SINGER APPEAR IN NEW YORK RECITALS
description: Baltazar Benitez

title: After Fatal Fire, Youths Rethink Life
description: In the elevators and upper floors of 1295 Fifth Avenue, a smoky smell lingers and the ceilings remain blackened. On the 33d and 34th floors, the doors leading to the apartments of the seven people who died in a fire there last month stand burned beyond use. A bouquet of dried, shriveled flowers is taped beside each door.

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Three by Three,'' which will be shown on Friday night at 9 on Channel 13, is the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at its most eclectic. Mr. Ailey's ''Blues Suite'' and Donald McKayle's ''Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder'' are fine old repertory works - and American modern dance classics - in the company's distinctive dance-theater style. ''Fever Swamp,'' by Bill T. Jones, is a cool sizzler of a new postmodernist dance that promises to become a classic.

title: COMMISSION ON HOMELESS EXPLORES HOUSING OPTIONS
description: WESTCHESTER is in danger of providing nothing but emergency housing for the homeless instead of building permanent, moderate-priced housing for them, the Rev. John P. Duffell, pastor of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Yonkers, has warned the County Commission on the Homeless.

title: BROOKLYN MINISTER IS FOUND SLAIN IN HIS ROOM AT STOREFRONT CHURCH
description: The body of a 36-year-old minister, apparently the victim of a burglary, was found yesterday afternoon in his living quarters behind a storefront church in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: GUSTAV OSWALD LIENHARD, 81
description: Gustav Oswald Lienhard, who guided the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation as it became the country's richest source of grants in the field of health care, died of cancer Friday at his home. He was 81 years old and lived in Edison, N.J.

title: CRITICS SAY THIOKOL WOULD PROFIT FROM NASA PLAN ON SHUTTLE COST
description: A plan by the space agency to greatly increase the amount it pays Morton Thiokol Inc. to build the space shuttle's booster rockets has drawn criticism in Congress and from rival manufacturers.

title: Lucky Stores Chooses Grey
description: Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, which until recently had the $15 million Vons Grocery Company account, has been named agency for both the Northern Food and Southern Food divisions of California's Lucky Stores Inc. The account should bill around $30 million, the agency said.

title: The U.N. Today: April 20, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Girl Bitten by a Shark Off Texas Loses Arm
description: A girl whose arm was bitten off by a shark remained hospitalized in serious condition today, but officials said they would not close beaches to the thousands of Easter weekend visitors.

title: U.S., JAPAN PREPARE FOR TARIFF TALKS
description: High-ranking American and Japanese envoys today prepared for talks on the new United States trade sanctions, while Japan's foreign minister appealed for increased dialogue and understanding.

title: Giant Pandas Arrive For Bronx Zoo Visit
description: Two giant pandas arrived safely in New York City this weekend after a flight of more than 20 hours from China.

title: FASHION, SERMONS AND RALLIES: IT'S EASTER
description: The crowd wore fake grass and bunny ears, purple eggs and lots of lace.

title: U.N. Action in Barring A Woman Is Protested
description: A human-rights group has protested the barring from the United Nations building of a woman who is seeking compensation for families of the victims of a 1972 massacre in Burundi.

title: Market Place; Less Caution On Computers
description: WALL STREET analysts are predicting continued growth for the second quarter and second half of 1987 for the leading computer manufacturers, some of which reported strong results last week. Despite the generally bullish tone, though, many of the stocks closed off a few points Thursday, the last day of trading in a holiday-shortened week, as wary investors sold on the good news.

title: PRICES OF METALS RISE AMID FEARS OF INFLATION
description: These are the times that swell the hearts and fill the pockets of gold bugs, that hardy band of investors in precious metals who thrive on economic misery. While Wall Street may mock gold as a ''sterile investment'' or ''barbaric relic,'' the recent sharp rise in gold and silver prices has given investors in stocks and bonds much to worry about.

title: Egypt Oil Plan Draws Drillers
description: American and West European companies will participate in a new tender by the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation for oil exploration in Egypt's western desert.

title: Long Game Leaves Capitals in a Daze
description: Mike Gartner, like almost all the members of the Capitals, was planning a trip to Philadelphia even before the deciding game of the playoff series against the Islanders.

title: A Ram for Rose Hill
description: It's been a decade since the Fordham Rams had a real live ram to call a mascot of their own. Now Frank McLaughlin, who took over as athletic director a year and a half ago, is determined to revive the tradition, although so far he's been butting his head against the wall.

title: Reversing Field
description: Three years after the Supreme Court struck down the legal underpinnings of gains that female collegians had made under Title IX, women's athletic organizations foresee a brighter day for themselves this summer. That's when Congress seems likely to pass the Civil Rights Restoration Act, which among other things would reverse the Court's Grove City decision.

title: What Will Bonn Do?
description: For some time, a feeling has been growing in the Reagan Administration that West Germany will probably not allow the extradition of a Lebanese, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, to this country to face charges of air piracy and murder in connection with the hijacking of an airliner to Beirut in 1985 and the death of a United States Navy diver who was among the passengers. But officials now discount reports heard with increasing frequency in Europe that Bonn intends to free Mr. Hamadei after a brief trial so as to gain the release of two German hostages in Lebanon.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DALLAS, AMID CHANGES, ELECTS WOMAN MAYOR
description: Annette Strauss, a City Councilwoman, on Saturday became the first woman elected Mayor here, capping a year of extraordinary ferment in Dallas with a decisive runoff election victory over Fred Meyer, a businessman.

title: THE WAYS OF EASTER IN SEVILLE
description: His feet black from the dirt of the cobblestoned streets, his clothing sweaty and his neck bearing a fresh scar, Francisco Deblas ended 14 hours of religious tradition with a glass of beer.

title: JONES DOUBLE BOGEY GIVES LOVE VICTORY
description: Davis Love 3d won the Heritage Classic today when Steve Jones drove out of bounds and scored a double-bogey 6 on the 18thhole.

title: Asian Growth Averages 6%
description: The economies of 17 Asian members of the Asian Development Bank grew an average of 6 percent in 1986, the same as in 1985, the bank's annual report said.

title: 3 in Financing Of Borg Deal
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had received commitments from three major banks for $3.4 billion in financing for its previously announced acquisition of the Borg-Warner Corporation.

title: Apple's Software Chief Shifts to New Program
description: Guy Kawasaki joined Apple Computer Inc. in 1983, when the Macintosh personal computer was still perceived by software developers as innovative, but too slow and lacking in power to appeal to business users. His job as self-described ''software evangelist'' was to ''use fervor and zeal to convince developers'' to write programs for the new machine.

title: TECHNOLOGY FOCUS OF POPE ON EASTER
description: Pope John Paul II, in an Easter message formed as a commentary on the text of a hymn, appealed today to the world not to abuse life through modern technology.

title: COLUMBIA SUES LAWYERS IN EVICTION
description: Columbia University has filed suit against two attorneys, charging that they abused the judicial process in their attempt to overturn the eviction of a woman from a university-owned building.

title: GREENWICH FEARS SITE FOR TRUCKS
description: Fear has gripped this sylvan duck-pond paradise on the New York border. The gentry are troubled that their town of stately mansions and Mercedes-Benzes soon might become home to a truck weigh station.

title: VOTING IN VIETNAM IS REPORTED HEAVY
description: Vietnam reported a heavy turnout today in general elections intended to ease out the Communist Party's old guard and bring in a new and more efficient government.

title: AMOCO BID FOR DOME IS ACCEPTED
description: A political storm developed in Canada today after debt-ridden Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced its acceptance of a takeover bid by the Amoco Corporation of Chicago. The transaction, worth $5.1 billion Canadian ($3.85 billion United States), would increase the already dominant position of American companies in the Canadian oil and gas industry.

title: BankAmerica Stock Plan
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank holding company, has asked stockholders to increase its authorized number of common shares to 300 million, from 200 million.

title: KING'S SEASON ENDS TOO SOON
description: The mood in the locker room reflected a collective relief, the release of an emotion held inside for months. Finally, there were no more games, no more nights for the Knicks to endure defeat.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: MANTLE BACK AT STADIUM
description: Mickey Mantle was at Yankee Stadium yesterday, performing his cable-television broadcasting assignment and looking healthy one week after a heart-attack scare during a flight to Dallas.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: An O'Neill Classic

title: Della Femina Expands Schering-Plough Work
description: Schering-Plough, which already uses the Della Femina, Travisano & Partners ad agency, has given it another assignment: Feen-a-Mint, a product of the Personal Care Group.

title: GORBACHEV REMARKS ARE DENIED
description: United States and Soviet officials denied today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev seriously suggested to visiting American legislators that the United States set up separate areas for blacks and other minorities.

title: NEGOTIATIONS TO START
description: Representatives of National Football League players and owners are scheduled to meet here Monday to begin what could be long and arduous negotiations leading to a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Heaven Can Wait
description: If there's a heaven on earth for football coaches, Roger (Dutch) Ouderkirk may have found it not far from the Arctic Circle. Ouderkirk, a 62-year-old assistant in charge of running backs at St. John's, enjoys relaxed summertime employment, a certain local acclaim and the life of Riley, all in the town of Hyvinkaa, Finland. No wonder he has spent the last two summers there, giving clinics and coaching the Hyvinkaa Falcons, one of about 60 semipro teams playing a May-to-September schedule in a country growing football-crazy less than a decade after taking up the sport in earnest.

title: DEAVER RENEWING FIGHT OVER PROSECUTOR LAW
description: Michael K. Deaver will seek to overturn his perjury indictment Monday by resuming a constitutional challenge to the special-prosecutor law, which has also come under attack in the Iran-contra investigation.

title: Big Acquisition Is Part Of Rorer Leader's Plan
description: Robert E. Cawthorn has been rejuvenating the Rorer Group - and now he is seeking a big acquisition that would make Rorer one of the drug industry's major companies.

title: 2 ISRAELI SOLDIERS AND 3 GUERRILLAS DIE IN A SHOOTOUT
description: Two Israeli soldiers and three Palestinian guerrillas were killed today in a shootout after the Palestinians cut through a Lebanon border fence and crossed into northern Israel, an Israeli Army spokesman said.

title: Seymour Acted Fairly In Deaver Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurting Huron
description: Tom Grundner survived. He pulled a hamstring, he ached all over without respite, and fatigue was a loyal companion, but he got through all four weeks of drills with Eastern Michigan University's football team.

title: A Blackout in Manila Starts Rumor of Coup
description: A power blackout darkened Manila and much of the main island of Luzon tonight, but service was restored about three hours later, officials said.

title: Promoting 7-Eleven's Changes
description: THE growing number of convenience stores has led 7-Eleven, the leader, to lower some of its premium prices and introduce new products and services to keep ahead of the competition. Its ad agency will promote the changes as if the client really wanted to make them.

title: SURVIVORS OF ATTACK IN SRI LANKA TELL OF 'CALM, DISCIPLINED' KILLERS
description: What V. B. Jayasuriya remembers most clearly was the cool, businesslike way the massacre happened.

title: A Frequent Flyer Explains the Thrill
description: The mail has brought the news from XYZ Airlines that my 30,000-odd miles of travel last year qualifies me for ''premier'' status in its Frequent Flyer program (or at least I think it does: my newspaper also brought the news that the airlines have recently upped the ante in mileage requirements). The details, however, are less important than my reaction to the honor: This was one of the most important and positive letters of my week.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Sweeps Mandlikova: Top-seeded Steffi Graf defeated second-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to win the Women's International Tennis Association Championships at Amelia Island Plantation in Florida. Graf, a 17-year-old ranked second in the world, has won 22 consecutive matches. Mandlikova, the Australian Open champion, who is ranked third in the world, had her serve broken five times, and she had seven double faults. (AP) Carlsson Takes Title in Nice: Kent Carlsson of Sweden, playing in only his second tournament in six months, captured the $17,880 first prize by beating Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday in the final of the Nice Grand Prix tournament. (AP) Edberg a Winner: Stefan Edberg of Sweden beat David Pate of the United States, 7-6, 6-4, to win the men's singles title in the Japan Open Tennis Championships in Tokyo. Edberg earned $68,000. The first-set tiebreaker score was 6-3. (AP) GOLF Ballesteros Takes Playoff: Seve Ballesteros came back from losing the Masters playoff to win a playoff with Ian Woosnam of Wales yesterday at the Cannes Open in France. Ballesteros birdied the last hole to send the two-day event into a playoff on the course at nearby Mougins. Both men finished at 13-under-par 275. Ballesteros had a 68 and Woosnam a final-round 70. Ballesteros almost fell out of contention at the par-4 10th with a triple-bogey 7. He drove out of bounds, chipped poorly and two-putted. Three birdies in the last four holes sent him into the playoff. (AP) Littler Triumphs in Japan: Gene Littler shot a three-under-par 69 in Tokyo to win the Seniors Grand Slam Golf Championship by two strokes over Miller Barber. Littler, who started the final round one stroke behind Harold Henning, had six birdies and three bogeys. (AP) Boxing McCallum Keeps Title: In Phoenix, Mike McCallum retained his World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title yesterday when he stopped Milton McCrory at 2:20 of the 10th round. Referee Joe Cortez stopped the scheduled 15-round bout with a bloodied McCrory slumped against the ropes in a neutral corner. McCallum, 30 years old, took control of the close fight in the eighth round when he opened a cut on McCrory's left eyelid. McCallum's record is now 31-0 with 28 knockouts. McCrory, 25, saw his record fall to 31-2-1. On the undercard, Meldrick Taylor, a former Olympic champion, won a unanimous 10-round decision over Primo Ramos of Mexico in a junior-welterweight fight. The 20-year-old Taylor is 15-0-1 as a professional. (AP) BOXING McCallum Keeps Title: In Phoenix, Mike McCallum retained his World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title yesterday when he stopped Milton McCrory at 2:20 of the 10th round. Referee Joe Cortez stopped the scheduled 15-round bout with a bloodied McCrory slumped against the ropes in a neutral corner. McCallum, 30 years old, took control of the close fight in the eighth round when he opened a cut on McCrory's left eyelid. McCallum's record is now 31-0 with 28 knockouts. McCrory, 25, saw his record fall to 31-2-1. On the undercard, Meldrick Taylor, a former United States Olympic champion, pounded out a unanimous 10-round decision over Primo Ramos of Mexico in a junior-welterweight fight. The 20-year-old Taylor, from Philadelphia, is now 15-0-1 as a professional. (AP)

title: Justice Dept. Booklet
description: A new Justice Department booklet, ''Enforcing the Law,'' was written as a benign report to inform members of Congress, journalists and high school and college students about what the department does and how it does it.

title: TOP-OF-THE-LINE CHICKEN SOUP
description: It wasn't as momentous as the splitting of the atom, but the world should note that a contest to acclaim the best chicken soup was held the other day. No lives were lost. No governments fell. The sun also rose the next morning.

title: EXLORERS FIND EXOTIC FAUNA NEAR GEYSERS ON FLOOR OF PACIFIC
description: Diving into a trough west of the Marianas Islands, in the western Pacific, the submersible Alvin has discovered pits resembling ''woks completely full of writhing snails, shrimps and crabs'' according to an account radioed from the mother ship Atlantis II.

title: INDUSTRY RELUCTANT TO SPEND
description: The Exxon Corporation's petrochemicals business is enjoying good times. Profits are rising, demand is brisk and most of its plants are operating nearly flat out.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1987
description: International A3-9

title: HOLLYWOOD AMBIVALENT AS FILM TRIAL NEARS END
description: A few weeks ago, after spending the day at his trial for involuntary manslaughter, John Landis showed up at a party for a new 20th Century-Fox movie, ''Raising Arizona.''

title: BREWERS BELT OUT RECORD
description: Rob Deer hit a three-run home run to tie the score and Dale Sveum won the game with a two-run shot as the Milwaukee Brewers rallied for five runs in the ninth inning today to beat the Texas Rangers, 6-4, and set an American League record with their 12th straight victory to start the season.

title: A Matter of Measurement
description: This will not begin with the phrase ''the long and short of it.'' Nor will there be any references to ''lofty ambitions'' or ''measuring up.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; New York's Old, and Fat, Constitution
description: Instead of celebrating this 200th year of the United States Constitution, scholars and legal experts are ''cerebrating.'' Meanwhile, the New York State Constitution, which is older and longer - at times unfathomably longer - doesn't even warrant a public seminar on its 210th birthday, which happens to be today. Yet it, too, is a document that is worth pondering.

title: U.S. Cautions South Korea
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige warned South Korea today that it must open its markets to prevent a tougher American attitude from developing over a flood of imports.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The chemist mixes it in a pot and cooks it, and what comes out depends on all sorts of things.'' - Robert Cava of Bell Laboratories on superconductivity experiments. [ A17:6. ]

title: ANTONY TUDOR, CHOREOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Antony Tudor, one of the foremost choreographers of the century and widely considered the master of the psychological ballet, died last night of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old. Mr. Tudor, choreographer emeritus of the American Ballet Theater at his death, revolutionized ballet with his introduction of strong psychological motivation in choreography, reflecting the influence of Freudian thought.

title: SMOKING CURBS POSE CHALLENGE FOR BUSINESSES
description: Less than three weeks before strict new antismoking rules are to go into effect, offices, restaurants and other businesses throughout New York State are grappling with a change that could have a profound effect on both those who smoke and those who don't.

title: INSIDE
description: Antony Tudor Is Dead at 78

title: CELTICS GET HOME-COURT EDGE
description: It's not the ordinary home-court advantage. That's why it was so important that Atlanta get it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc., Boulder, Colo., said Kent O. Olin, president and chief operating officer, had been named to the additional post of chief executive officer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TRUST ME. Short Stories. By John Updike. 302 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: How Young & Rubicam Extols Express Mail
description: Cynthia Beck is a recent arrival at Young & Rubicam, where she is a vice president and associate creative director. She is also the writer half of a team whose art direction comes from John Triolo, senior vice president and also an associate creative director.

title: On Dogs and Drugs
description: The trouble, it seems, is that the canine nose just isn't good enough. The United States Customs Service, alarmed at the large amounts of cocaine and heroin that slip into this country undetected, has awarded a preliminary $90,000 contract to a Massachusetts biotechnology company to develop a device that, if it works, would be 1,000 times more sensitive to the presence of drugs than trained dogs are.

title: GIANTS WIN 8TH 1-RUN GAME
description: Glenn Hubbard's fielding error at second base with two out in the ninth inning enabled Chris Brown to score from third and give the San Francisco Giants a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

title: INDIANS END SLIDE
description: Pat Tabler drove in three runs with a pair of singles and a bases-loaded walk to help the Indians to an 8-7 victory over the Orioles and a douleheader sweep today. Cleveland won the first game, 3-0, on Greg Swindell's six-hitter.

title: In Arms Control, a Quiet Success
description: After four years of secret talks, the United States and six allies have put a new obstacle in the path of proliferating nuclear capabilities. They agreed to strong controls on the export of missiles and missile technologies that can be used to deliver nuclear weapons. This is a real arms control achievement at a critical time.

title: METS FALL AGAIN; SHUTOUTS STOP ROYALS
description: Whether shipbuilder or baseball club owner, George Steinbrenner has obviously been involved in the wrong line of work all these years. The efforts of the Yankees' starting pitchers in yesterday's doubleheader attest to the idea that Steinbrenner should be a baseball scout.

title: TRANS-ATLANTIC RECORD
description: A catamaran sailed by Bruno Peyron, the French ocean racer, limped across the finish line on the Southwest coast of England yesterday to set a trans-Atlantic record, despite crashing into rocks three hours earlier.

title: SCHOOL'S PLAN FOR AN ANNEX STIRS A DISPUTE ON EAST SIDE
description: A legal battle is being waged that could have a major impact on how community facilities - schools, churches and doctors' offices - are built in New York City's residential neighborhoods.

title: COVERT OPERATIONS CHANGES URGED
description: President Reagan will be urged to consolidate some of the Administration's covert operations overseas and to end others that are considered outdated, a White House official said today.

title: Reagans Attend Services
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, attended Easter Sunday services at a Presybterian church here, taking hundreds of congregants by surprise. A white cloth with the words ''Christ is Risen'' greeted the Reagans as they shook hands with the Rev. Robert Pryor, the church's pastor. Because of security concerns, little advance notice was given to the First Presbyterian Church, and the Reagans traveled to the church in a car without a police escort.

title: WHY MYSIFY THE BUDGET?
description: What's a cut in a Federal program? What's an increase? If you put these two questions to the average person, they probably would tell you that a cut is when some program is to get less money this year than it got last year. Or, in the case of an increase, more money this year than last year. If you pressed the person, he or she might adjust these numbers for inflation - that is, a cut or an increase in real terms compared to last year.

title: NO REST FOR WEARY ISLANDERS
description: There was barely enough time to repack suitcases and reconvene for yet another in a series of team meetings.

title: Safeway Texas Closings
description: About 8,000 employees of Safeway Stores Inc. in northern Texas will join the ranks of the unemployed on Friday. The chain is selling or closing 131 of its Dallas division stores, along with processing and distribution systems in the Dallas suburb of Garland. Safeway announced the action April 3, saying it was part of the company's restructuring in order to become more competitive.

title: SOBERING CHANGE FOR SOVIET WINERIES
description: Tengiz Nanitashvili smiled gamely as he held aloft the gnarled salami-like object, but it was clear his heart really was not in the latest mass-produced product from the sun-drenched wine country of the Soviet Union.

title: BALLET THEATER OPENING AMID GLAMOUR AND BUSTLE
description: Big season openings have a special magic, and American Ballet Theater's eight-week spring engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House is one of the biggest of the dance year. Glamorous types will mill about the Met lobby tonight for Ballet Theater's opening. Last-minute worries and triumphs will preoccupy those who put the ballet on the stage. The dancers' warmups in the wings will have an edgier, first-night quality to them. New young corps dancers will gravitate toward one another for a moment's unspoken assurance, eyes catching every detail of the bustle about them. The tour is over. The season has begun.

title: A THIRD OF ROBBERY VICTIMS ARE HURT, STUDY FINDS
description: An average of 1.2 million robberies occurred annually in the United States from 1973 to 1984, according to a Justice Department report released today.

title: THE STAGE: 'PLAIN BROWN WRAPPER'
description: KEITH REDDIN, who made a splash a couple of seasons ago with ''Rum and Coke,'' has taken to concocting watered drinks. His ''Plain Brown Wrapper,'' now being served up on the stage of the Nat Horne Theater, consists of five skits that together take about an hour. Their main ingredient is sex of a one-liner sort; they don't deliver much of a kick.

title: Correction
description: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Thursday misstated a bankruptcy judge's ruling on salaries of Texaco Inc.'s officers. Judge Howard Schwartzberg ruled that the salaries of Texaco's top 20 officers were not to exceed $2,000 each for the 11 days before Texaco's bankruptcy filing April 12 but that there would be no restrictions during bankruptcy.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Bo Jackson's sensational start this season revived memories of another running back from a college in the South who had to choose between baseball and football, Charley Trippi. How much success did Trippi have in pro football? Did he ever play in the major leagues in baseball? Trippi never played in the majors after he chose football over baseball and he never regretted it because he made it to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1968, 13 years after he retired. After finishing as runnerup to Glenn Davis of Army for the 1946 Heisman Trophy, Trippi, a running back and outfielder for the University of Georgia, was wooed by both the Boston Braves and Red Sox in baseball and the new Miami pro football franchise in the All-America Conference. He was also the No. 1 draft choice of the Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League. The Yankees, headed by Larry MacPhail and Dan Topping, were even more tempting: They offered Trippi a contract to play both sports for them, at a time when they had a team in the new football league.

title: MARK HOWE IS SKATING A STEADY COURSE
description: FROM where Mark Howe sees it in the deep end of the ice where he smoothly gathers up the puck, bodies are usually flying around in front of him, someone is usually falling over someone else, and maybe, someone is throwing a punch. Then he starts out.

title: ANOREXIA AS FAMILY PROBLEM
description: FAMILY relationships are getting more attention in the treatment of anorexia nervosa, an eating disorder that primarily affects teen-age girls and young women. Mental health experts say that families can help alleviate conditions that contribute to the disease.

title: Nothing Like a Vacation And Some Distance To Lift the Spirits
description: Maybe getting away from Washington had something to do with it. Or maybe it was just the passage of time. Or perhaps it was the new approach to running the White House that began earlier, back in the capital, with a new management team in place.

title: SEOUL POLICE ACT FORCEFULLY TO BLOCK START OF A PROTEST
description: In a shattering display of raw force, South Korean combat policemen broke up a street demonstration today almost before it could begin, rounding up scores of anti-Government students and punching and kicking many of them.

title: SUPERCONDUCTORS: TINY FLAWS MAY BE THE KEY
description: Scientists have succeeded for the first time in photographing the individual atoms in a newly discovered superconducting material, revealing a surprising host of tiny flaws that may be a key to its extraordinary electrical properties.

title: METS FALL AGAIN; CARDINALS IN SWEEP
description: Talk about the unthinkable: The Mets, who arrived here this weekend in first place with a three-game winning streak, left today in second place with a three-game losing streak.

title: FOR STOCKHOLDERS: MORE RESOLUTIONS
description: Proposals for social action and challenges by powerful institutional investors to anti-takeover plans are on a record number of annual meeting agendas this year, according to organizations that monitor shareholder resolutions.

title: AGENT SAYS FOUR RECEIVED IMMUNITY
description: The season ended for the Phoenix Suns Saturday night with a 121-106 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers, but the focus afterward was on the team's off-court problems.

title: FROM BOTH PARTIES, SUPPORT FOR JERSEY'S 'WORKFARE'
description: When Governor Kean proposed last winter that all able-bodied welfare recipients in New Jersey be forced to go to school and seek employment, he expected sharp criticism.

title: E.P.A. Is Backed On Residues
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has justified its permission for residues of ethylene dibromide, a pesticide, to remain on mangoes imported from Caribbean countries, a Federal appeals court ruled Friday.

title: JAZZ: PETE COMPO QUARTET
description: THE closing within the last two years of Jimmy Ryan's, Eddie Condon's, Hanratty's and the Red Blazer Too wiped out almost every venue in town where traditional jazz could be heard regularly. But things are now looking up for jazz traditionalists with the reopening of the Red Blazer Too at 349 West 46th Street, instead of its previous Upper East Side location.

title: THE LATE, LATE SHOW
description: SO there was Harry Lime, clawing his way up the sewer stairs for the millionth time, but it was time to press the remote-control gadget and get back to the real life-and-death struggle, not in war-ravaged Vienna but in hockey-crazed Maryland.

title: PRIVATE AMERICAN-ART MUSEUM TO OPEN IN ILLINOIS
description: For a cultural institution, the Terra Museum of American Art has had a meteoric career. The latest entry in what seems to be an increasing trend toward private museums, it started out seven years ago with a highly personal selection of paintings - dating mainly from 1850 to 1900 - installed in a former florist's shop in nearby Evanston. Tuesday, at four times its original size and with holdings more oriented to the needs of a public institution, it opens in a pair of elegantly refurbished buildings on North Michigan Avenue, part of a $25 million real-estate package in the heart of Chicago's ''Magnificent Mile.''

title: OF ADS AND ELDERS: SELLING TO NIGERIANS
description: A village elder, dignified in his flowing boubasha gown and thick gray mustache, raised a glass of schnapps and poured it with ceremony over the engine of a new car to bring the car good luck.

title: SOME SEE SEEDS OF NEW EXODUS IN CUBANS FLOATING TO FLORIDA
description: The number of refugees fleeing Cuba to Florida by water in makeshift rafts has picked up in recent weeks, leading to speculation that pressure for another major exodus may be building up on the island.

title: A Happier Grimm Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: WHIFFENPOOFS: 'GENTLMEN SONGSTERS' STILL
description: If all goes as planned, at midnight tonight the 14 members of the 1987 Whiffenpoofs will assemble at Harkness Tower for ''Tap Night.'' With crowds of observers in pursuit they will run through the Yale University campus, stopping at the rooms of the students who have been selected to be next year's Whiffenpoofs, the fabled a capella group. To each they will hand the traditional ''tap punch'' in a Mory's cup and sing the Mory's drinking song.

title: Thon to Play In Minor League
description: The Houston Astros have reinstated Dickie Thon and assigned the shortstop to their Class AAA Tucson team in the Pacific Coast League.

title: THE SEVENTH, THE EIGHT AND THE DECIDING GAME
description: IT was hockey, but as the skaters skimmed slowly into quadruple overtime, the scene resembled the gradual disintegration of a marathon dance contest. The pace slowed, and the progression up and down the ice toward goals that suddenly loomed imposing as brick walls looked almost surreal. Even the ice seemed to respire, as if in weariness, and long glaring puddles formed at random on its surface.

title: DERBY PICTURE MUDDIER THAN EVER
description: At offices and taverns around the country during the next two weeks, people who usually pay no attention to horse racing will be asked to cough up a dollar or two and pick from a hat the name of one of this year's Kentucky Derby entrants.

title: DUGOUT MISHAP FELLS TUDOR
description: John Tudor was sitting in the St. Louis Cardinals' dugout, minding his own business today when Barry Lyons, the rookie catcher for the Mets, came running over, chasing a foul pop fly. That led to a bizarre accident that disabled Tudor for three months or more. It was the kind of accident that sometimes alters careers and championships.

title: Baby M Verdict Neglected the Mother's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Submerged Ship on Register
description: The C.S.S. Georgia, a 10-gun ironclad that helped guard Savannah from the Union Navy during the Civil War, has been added to the National Register of Historic Places even though the vessel lies 30 feet underwater. She was scuttled in the Savannah River in 1864 when Gen. William T. Sherman's troops captured Savannah.

title: WHAT PRICE NUCLEAR POWER? IN SIBERIA, IT'S HIGH
description: Before a reactor exploded at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Ukraine a year ago, officials at the Bilibino atomic energy station had not thought of how they might evacuate residents from this industrialized island in the tundra of northeast Siberia.

title: WALL STREET FIGHTS FANNIE MAE PLAN
description: Five of the nation's largest investment banking firms have joined forces in an effort to persuade the Government to bar the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, from the newest and one of the most lucrative mortgage underwriting markets.

title: Hotel Cuts Use of Kitchens In Ohio Poisoning Outbreak
description: The Dayton Marriott Hotel closed most of its kitchens for the weekend to try to stop an outbreak of food poisoning.

title: TROUBLED TIE: NEIGHBORHOOD AND COLUMBIA
description: More than 200 years ago, Columbia College proclaimed its independence from England, putting an end to the problems of crown and gown. This month, as it celebrates the bicentennial of its charter, Columbia finds itself once again in an uneasy relationship - brought about this time by problems of town and gown.

title: Barge Called a Hazard To the Gulf of Mexico
description: Although the owners of a barge loaded with 3,100 tons of industrial waste from Islip, L.I., have agreed to move it from an oil rig where it was moored, the vessel will be a hazard as long as it's in the Gulf of Mexico, the Mayor of a barrier island said yesterday.

title: Metro Matters; Now the Debate Begins to Boil Over City Charter
description: Boss Tweed had an enduring ring to his name, but mention Tammany protege Robert Van Wyck nowadays and what comes to mind is the Queens expressway dedicated to his distant relative, Abraham Van Wyck.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 19, 1987: MONDAY Dana Corp Republic Gypsum Jorgensen (Earle M) Southern Co Lilly (Eli) & Co Twin Disc TUESDAY Amer Cyanamid Security Pacific CSX Corp Smucker (JM) Honeywell Inc Southern Ind G & E Lee Enterprises SunTrust Banks Parker Drilling Tribune Co Philips Industries V F Corp Scott Paper WEDNESDAY Barnett Banks of Fl Pacific Scientific Belding-Heminway Panhandle Eastern Corp Eaton Corp Potomac Elec Pwr Energen Corp Products Research & Chem Ennis Business Forms RJR Nabisco Inc Hexcel Corp Russell Corp Hughes Tool SCANA Corp Jostens Inc Shaw Industries Inc Kollmorgen Corp Sherwin-Williams Mexico Fund SmithKline Beckman Natl Medical Enterprises Union Carbide Outboard Marine Wynn's Intl THURSDAY CBI Industries Mead Corp Dexter Corp Morton-Thiokol Duke Power Natl Distillers & Chem Ethyl Corp Pfizer Inc Empire District Elec Sealed Air Corp General Signal Standard Oil Handy & Harman Thomas Indus Interstate Securities Triangle Indus Iowa-Ill G & E WICOR Inc FRIDAY Brown & Sharpe Mfg Monsanto Co Central Louisiana Elec Nasua Corp Fedders Corp Scotty's Inc Harland (John H) Snap-On Tools Kysor Industrial Sonat Inc Lomas & Nettleton Fin't U S Leasing Intl Mobil Corp Univar Corp SATURDAY Zero Corp

title: NEW PETTY ALBUM SIGNALS RETURN TO BASIC ROCK
description: It's back to basics for Tom Petty, the Florida-born, Los Angeles-based rocker who has been making best-selling albums for a decade. The last album by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, ''Southern Accents,'' took two years to record; ''Let Me Up (I've Had Enough)'' (MCA Records), which will be released today, took a month of basic sessions and another of polishing. The result is Mr. Petty's most casual, rowdy, ornery record so far. It has the professionalism of the Heartbreakers' other albums without the worked-over sound of most Los Angeles studio products. And its straightforward rock - kin to Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen and the Rolling Stones - is the band's closest equivalent yet to the down-home pride in Mr. Petty's lyrics.

title: TIME RUNNING OUT FOR BILL RODGERS
description: IN many ways, he is still the same Bill Rodgers. The face is boyish. The sandy hair is slightly unruly. Two apples make a nice lunch. All is well with the world.

title: People
description: * James A. Voss-Grumish, executive director/broadcast production, elected to senior vice president at Campbell-Mithun, Minneapolis.

title: IN NICARAGUA, THE CYNICISM OF CENSORSHIP
description: The newsstand at the busy Lewites Market in Managua offers a limited selection of periodicals, and even the proprietor, Ramon Ramirez, says he cannot find much that he wants to read.

title: China Securities Firm
description: The first securities firm in China since 1949 opened on Friday in the northeast city of Shenyang, The People's Daily overseas edition said today. It added that the new firm will handle short-term bonds and stocks issued by companies; medium- and short-term bonds issued by banks, and discount bills and the lending and borrowing of bills and funds. The first securities market in China since 1949 opened in Shenyang last August. Four more have opened since then, mostly trading bonds.

title: KRISHNA CONVICT FILES LAWSUIT
description: A Hare Krishna follower who is serving a life prison term for the murder of another member of the sect has sued state prison officials, asserting that they have denied him the right to worship according to his religion.

title: CATCHING SPIES: INTELLIGENCE OFFICIALS SAY U.S. LACKS THE RESOLVE TO IMPROVE
description: As President Reagan awaits new Government recommendations on altering counterespionage policy, present and former intelligence officials said that the problems were already well known but that the Government apparently lacked the resolve to solve them.

title: GREEK EASTER: DIET OF LAMB AND VICE
description: In the harbor, a moored ferry signaled the festival with long blasts of a foghorn that rumpled a still night. On the roadsides people walked home, just after midnight, clutching lighted candles that spread a warming glow, nurturing a flame whose smoke would mark the cross on the lintels of their doors.

title: Bond Recovery May Continue
description: After a harrowing plunge in bond prices early last week, the market in long-term fixed-income securities came roaring back to close essentially unchanged from the previous Friday.

title: Last Wild California Condor Netted in Breeding Program
description: The last California condor known to be in the wild was captured today for a captive-breeding program intended to save the giant birds from extinction, the National Audubon Society said.

title: Port Authority Exists for Public Benefit, Not to Make Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Small-Claims Attitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Easter, With Music, in the Park
description: The woman jogger was humming ''Jesus Christ, Superstar'' as they ran down the West Road in Central Park. ''Why not, it's Easter,'' she said. ''It sure is,'' said the man, gesturing to the haze of new green on the trees. ''Listen,'' she said as they ran past Strawberry Fields, the newly landscaped section given by Yoko Ono, John Lennon's widow. From just ahead, near 72d Street, came the sounds of a synthesizer and a guitar, playing in sweet homage ''Imagine,'' the famous John Lennon song. Like dozens, then hundreds of others, the runners stopped to listen.

title: PESTICIDE STILL CANCER RISK DESPITE CAUTION, U.S. SAYS
description: A new study by the Environmental Protection Agency has found that chlordane, a pesticide used in millions of homes to control termites, can pose a high risk of cancer even when properly used.

title: MOYNIHAN WORKING ON IMAGE
description: After seven days of talking and listening to hundreds of constituents in 15 towns across western New York State, Daniel Patrick Moynihan might have shown a trace of flagging energy or interest.

title: Journalist of 'Killing Fields' Issues Appeal to Cambodia
description: Dith Pran, the Cambodian journalist whose four-year ordeal under the Khmer Rouge and escape in 1979 was portrayed in a film, ''The Killing Fields,'' urged the Cambodian Government yesterday to let his ailing mother come to the United States for medical treatment.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Treasury Statement March Wednesday Durable Goods Orders March Thursday Corporate Profits 4th qtr. Friday Consumer Prices March Personal Income March

title: Business and the Law; Legal Ties With China
description: IN two weeks, Xi-Qing Gao, a 33-year-old associate at a large New York firm, is scheduled to be sworn before a judge to practice law in the United States. Last summer he became the first citizen of China to pass the New York Bar examination.

title: 2 Virginia Teen-Agers Die in Double Suicide
description: Two teen-age boys from Virginia died of carbon monoxide poisoning in a double suicide this weekend in rural south-central Pennsylvania, the authorities said.

title: Old-Line Insurer Invests in Culture
description: Henry E. Kates, the new president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, has added a touch of culture to the business of the old-line Newark-based insurer.

title: The Most Stressful Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus Shifting to New 2-Year Issue
description: Sales of Government securities this week include today's $13.2 billion auction of new Treasury bills equally divided between the three- and six-months maturities. On Wednesday dealer attention will turn to a $10 billion issue of new 2-year bills, which are auctioned by the Treasury on a monthly basis.

title: APPLAUSE, YAWNING OVER CHESS
description: After two weeks of mind-warping triumph and tragedy, with clocks ticking at elbows like timebombs and dozens of world-class egos on the line, one of the nation's richest and most prestigious chess tournaments ended yesterday with fireworks and a fizzle.

title: THE STAGE: 'ALL THE KING'S MEN' IN PROVIDENCE
description: On its most immediate level, Robert Penn Warren's novel ''All the King's Men'' follows the rise and fall of the populist demagogue Willie Stark, the fictional equivalent of Huey Long. At the same time, the book tells the story of Jack Burden, the reporter as historian, a character whom the author has described as ''intelligent enough to understand everything except himself.''

title: Ad Industry Battling Proposed Florida Tax
description: In Florida the State Senate and House of Representatives passed bills last week authorizing a new tax package that would include a 5 percent sales tax on advertising in all media. Today a conference committee will try to iron out differences between the two versions.

title: What the U.S. Gets for Its Contra Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Family Planning Program Advocated
description: A comprehensive global family planning strategy is needed to keep accelerating world population growth from outpacing available resources, according to a report made public today by the Population Institute.

title: Bridge: Scissors Coup Is a Maneuver Culbertson Failed to Name
description: A little over half a century ago, Ely Culbertson's considerable talent for terminology for once failed him. ''The Coup Without a Name'' was the best he could manage for a play by declarer that cuts the defenders' lines of communications. Two decades later it became, more appropriately, the Scissors Coup.

title: IN PORTLAND, ORE., 'POLITICS AS USUAL' USUALLY ISN'T
description: Mayor Bud Clark had just emerged from a controversy that left him typically unfazed when he announced that he planned to run for a second term in 1988.

title: Outdoors: Outfitting Fly Anglers
description: ALTHOUGH fly fishermen represent only a small percentage of the millions of anglers in this country, they do not suffer for lack of attention by the manufacturers of their equipage.

title: U.S. to Add Germanium to Stockpile
description: As part of an effort to update its stockpile of strategic metals, the Government said it planned to buy up to 2,000 kilograms of germanium, a grayish-white metallic element of the carbon family that occurs in trace quantities in the mining of other minerals and in coal.

title: GUNMAN FIRES INTO A CROWD AT JERSEY PARK
description: A gunman opened fire last night in a crowded plaza just inside the main gate of the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson, N.J., wounding a 23-year-old man and sending dozens of other people running for safety, the police and Great Adventure officials said.

title: The Pentagon's Cartoon Offensive
description: Each spring, just as the crocuses wilt, the Pentagon's printing presses churn out a tulip-red broadsheet entitled ''Soviet Military Power.'' This hardy perennial, grown with finest intelligence fertilizer, features Soviet military equipment just the way the Kremlin would like the world to see it - a teeming profusion of menacing missiles, planes, ships and the like, all outnumbering their American counterparts. Thus begins the annual bean-count battle of Soviet versus American weapons.

title: The Sanctity of Greed
description: Elizabeth Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, came to town last week to address a conference celebrating the centennial of the International Herald Tribune. She was vigorous, charming, Reaganesque in her hearty advocacy of taking government out of business, deregulating, letting money talk. She sounded superconfident.

title: 'HARD KNOCKS,' SITCOM
description: SOME ''alternative'' broadcasting entities talk confidently about producing sitcoms that are not likely to be found on the presumably more conservative or timid commercial networks. The results so far have been short of startling. But Showtime does more than talk. The pay-cable service has already delivered innovative series such as ''Brothers'' and ''It's Garry Shandling's Show.'' Now, tonight at 9:30, Showtime is introducing ''Hard Knocks,'' which stays loose enough to let its characters meander easily from comedy-variety to horror-movie spoofs, all the while commenting dizzily on everything from communal bathing to Uncle Charlie in ''My Three Sons.''

title: A GROWING FISCAL BURDEN: DECAY OF BRIDGES AND ROADS
description: Heavy trucks, harsh weather and time are chipping away at bridges, highways and roads in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, turning a transportation network once worthy of envy into a continuing financial burden.

title: CONCERT: 2 MASSES AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: TWO masses at Carnegie Hall Saturday evening commemorated perhaps the darkest moment of the Christian year - the night before Christ's Resurrection. As sung and played by the Gachinger Kantorei of Stuttgart and the National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada, Haydn's ''Lord Nelson'' and the Mozart ''Requiem'' offered - at least superficially - two very similar faces. Both works spring from the last years of the 18th century, indeed, from the same city (Vienna). Both are in D minor, and each represents a partial summation of the Classical era's two great musical careers.

title: Stop the Espionage Race
description: The medium-range missile treaty is all but wrapped up; short-range missile reduction is a sweetener just tossed in the deal; a space exploration treaty awaits signing at a summit; the old ABM treaty will be saved in the next year when a new treaty is agreed on to permit space-shield testing.

title: CONCERT: BERNSTEIN'S 'MASS'
description: IT often happens that musical works requiring unusually large (or simply unusual) performing forces must be scaled down in order to circulate beyond the big institutions and special occasions for which they are made. Wagner's music dramas are given all the time with reduced orchestrations; big Parisian operas were routinely cut to workable lengths for other audiences. It is not surprising that Leonard Bernstein, a year after his ''Mass'' opened the Kennedy Center in Washington, made a chamber orchestra version of the sprawling work. The Columbia University Glee Club gave this its first New York performance Saturday evening in Alice Tully Hall. A listener who knows the original ''Mass'' only through the recording cannot compare the versions in impact, but the character and spirit of the piece certainly seemed to come through. The new version uses 16 instrumental players (only two of them strings), with some use of prerecorded music.

title: Soviet Output Increases 2.5%
description: Soviet industrial output grew by 2.5 percent in the first quarter of the year from the comparable period of 1986, the Politburo has been told.

title: DANCE: 'INCEST' AT EDEN'S EXPRESSWAY
description: THREE years ago, Wendy Yuni Hoffman began to have memories of having been molested as a child by members of her family. Out of those memories came ''Incest,'' a theater-dance piece performed on Saturday at Eden's Expressway in SoHo.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1987
description: COMPANIES Dome Petroleum said it had accepted a bid by Amoco, prompting a political storm in Canada over how such a move would increase the already dominant position of U.S. companies in the Canadian oil and gas industry. [ Page D1. ] NASA's renewal of a Morton Thiokol contract was criticized by Congress and rival rocket manufacturers. The deal would increase payments to Morton Thiokol to $1.8 billion for rockets for the space shuttle. Those who oppose the plan say it means that the company most widely criticized in investigations of the Challenger explosion stands to profit from the disaster. [ A1. ] Shareholder resolutions are on a record number of agendas at annual meetings this year, according to organizations that monitor them. Resolutions seeking social action have more than doubled, while many pension funds have offered resolutions opposing provisions to shield companies from hostile takeovers. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Five Wall Street firms are seeking to have Fannie Mae barred from issuing real estate mortgage investment conduits, or Remics - a new and highly lucrative mortgage underwriting instrument. The Department of Housing and Urban Development plans to rule tomorrow on the petition. [ D1. ] U.S. and Japanese envoys prepared to discuss the new American trade sanctions, while Japan's Foreign Minister appealed for cooperation between the two countries. [ D1. ] Soaring precious metals prices are one indication that investors are worried about inflation. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL Marketers in Nigeria draw on traditional African psychology to promote their products. The country has the largest national market and the largest advertising industry in black Africa. [ D10. ] The Soviet wine industry has been struggling to adapt to the stringent controls imposed on the sale of alcoholic beverages nearly two years ago. Its efforts include an increasing emphasis on quality and a turn toward non-alcoholic spinoff products. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A move to train more people in the laws of China is being applauded by businesses. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Analysts predict continued growth for top computer makers, although many investors sold last week. Market Place. [ D6. ] The credit markets are expected to respond to dollar trading again this week. Credit Markets [ D7. ]

title: Child Services Policy Faulted
description: Abused and other vulnerable children and the chronically ill elderly have been illegally denied services by the Reagan Administration, which has withheld millions of dollars in congressionally approved aid, according to a report made public today by a House panel.

title: VISIT BY ALFONSIN PEACEFULLY ENDS ARGENTINE MUTINY
description: President Raul Alfonsin went to an army base this afternoon and persuaded rebellious officers there to surrender, ending a four-day mutiny.

title: CONCERT: HISPANIC PROGRAM
description: HIGH above the main auditorium of the Brooklyn Academy of Music is a handsome loft called the Lepercq Space. It was here that Tania Leon led members of the Brooklyn Philharmonic in a program of music by Hispanic-American composers Saturday afternoon, as part of the orchestra's series of family and community concerts. Ms. Leon introduced each work cheerfully, occasionally repeating herself in Spanish; several of the composers were also on hand, and Kenneth Adams, a saxophonist and clarinetist, provided brief, slightly bemused introductions to the two instruments.

title: Yeats Wrote of the Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT THE U.S. GETS FOR ITS CONTRA AID
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $19 million for a stock repurchase. c-Includes a charge of $29 million for early retirement program and withdrawal.

title: COMMANDER OF NATO IS OPPOSED TO RIDDING EUROPE OF ALL MISSILES
description: The NATO military commander has recommended that the United States deploy short-range missiles in Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: HUTCHINSON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $240,000, or 6 cents a share, and $370,000, or 10 cents a share, for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, from the sale of certain technology. The company said the year-ago quarter and 6-month results have been restated to reflect the adoption of new interim reporting periods. The company also the first, second and third quarters are changed to 13- week from 12-week period; fourth quarter is changed to a 13- or 14-week period.

title: TEKELEC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Broker Says Fed Official Did Not Leak Rate Data
description: The former president of a now-defunct securities firm, testifying today in his fraud trial, denied receiving confidential interest-rate information from a director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Congress's Trade Mood
description: Unlike other visiting leaders from abroad, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan will apparently not address Congress when he comes to Washington next week.

title: COLORADO DEBATE GROWS ON HOMEOWNER DEFENSE
description: When David Guenther was arrested here and charged with killing his wife on March 1, it caused more commotion than usual for a murder case.

title: THE STAGE: SHAW'S 'MISALLIANCE'
description: IT'S a mighty broad ''Misalliance'' bouncing around the Equity Library Theater.

title: MOTIVE UNCLEAR
description: The Brooklyn man who was shot by a gunman at the Great Adventure amusement park here Sunday has told the police that he did not know his assailant or the reason for the shooting, officials said today.

title: NATIONAL ENTERPRISES BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Hot Starts
description: The record-breaking streak by the Milwaukee Brewers is one of 10 in which teams have won at least nine straight games at the beginning of a season. Five of those teams went on to win division or league titles, four by margins of a game and a half or less. The early-season leads were squandered by four teams, which finished eight or more games behind the eventual winners:

title: KERR'S THREE GOALS FOR FLYERS TOP WEARY ISLANDERS
description: The Flyers were not willing to claim much credit tonight for their victory in this, the inaugural game of the Patrick Division championship, but Philadelphia was agreeable about accepting a 1-0 series edge after defeating the Islanders, 4-2.

title: THEY TRICKLE BACK, THOSE WHO LEFT WITH HOPE
description: For three decades, the men of this town in the arid highlands of central Mexico have gone north to earn their livelihoods in the factories of Chicago, in the restaurants of Dallas and with the construction crews of Los Angeles.

title: SUN STATE SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPOSER, 80, URGES SOVIET TO ALLOW EXIT
description: The last surviving pupil of Alban Berg - and perhaps also the last of Anton von Webern - has long been prevented by the Soviet Union from visiting Vienna to pass on his firsthand knowledge of the two masters of 20th-century music, according to the pupil, who is a composer, and to Austrian diplomats.

title: Amdahl Profits Rise Tenfold
description: The Amdahl Corporation, a mainframe computer maker, reported first-quarter earnings today of $25.2 million, or 51 cents a share, more than 10 times the $2.4 million, or 5 cents a share, reported a year earlier. Sales rose 59 percent, to $318.5 million, from $200.2 million in last year's first quarter. Amdahl, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., attributed the gains to strong shipments of its model 5890 central processors and its new disk storage systems.

title: INSITUFORM GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the U.S. dollars figures are calculated on the basis of $1.48 to one British pound for the latest periods and $1.45 to one British pound for the year-ago periods.

title: GREAT WESTERN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes an extraordinary loss of $704,000 from prepayment of F.H.L.B. advances.

title: SOUTH KOREA CRACKDOWN: COURTING NEW COLLISIONS
description: By abruptly shutting off public discussion on altering South Korea's basic electoral structure, President Chun Doo Hwan has increased the chances that he and the opposition will collide head-on.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ASSEMBLY HEAD FAULTS CUOMO ON ETHICS VETO
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said yesterday Governor Cuomo was wrong to veto the ethics bill that passed the Legislature, but indicated he would be willing to try to negotiate a bill Mr. Cuomo could approve.

title: Alfonsin Triumphs - But Next Time?
description: President Raul Alfonsin's fortitude and his nation's massive show of support for him have overwhelmed Argentina's brief military mutiny. Important causes of the political crisis continue unabated, however. The United States should take the cue provided by the army officers' rebellion to increase its support for Argentine democracy while there is still time.
