title: Our Towns; Need Something In a 66 Waist? No Problem, Sir
description: For a while, pot bellies were on the run. The wise guys at the health spas started passing the word that the last few pot bellies in the suburbs had been sighted and were about to be eradicated. Decent, hard-working men who had moved out here specifically to drink beer by the pitcher and grow a belly suddenly felt ashamed, as their bellies lost prestige.

title: SEKO WINNER IN BOSTON
description: A little more than six miles remained in today's 91st annual Boston Marathon, and Toshihiko Seko was discouraged. The head winds were too strong, he said. Too many good runners remained in the leading pack.

title: KIN CUT OFF FROM THEIR DEAD FIGHT FOR ROADS TO CEMETERIES
description: A showdown may finally be at hand in a 43-year-old dispute over whether to build roads to 29 isolated family cemeteries within the boundaries of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in southwest North Carolina.

title: Andrei B. Severny, 73, Top Soviet Astronomer
description: Andrei B. Severny, a leader in Soviet astronomy and an authority on the physics of the sun and the stars, died April 4, the Soviet press has announced. He was 73 years old. Dr. Severny had been director of the Crimean Astrophysical Observatory since 1952, and was one of the pioneers of setting up astronomical observations on artificial satellites in orbit around the earth.

title: BECOR WESTERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Tandem Discloses New Hardware
description: Tandem Computers Inc., based in Cupertino, Calif., announced two new computer systems and a new desktop laser printer. The 32-bit LXN multi-user system is Tandem's first based on the Unix operating system developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, with prices starting at $18,012 per unit. The Nonstop CLX system uses Tandem's Guardian operating system, with prices beginning at $39,900 per unit in lots of 25-39, or $57,000 for single units.

title: FREEDOM FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $686,000 for the latest quarter and $601,000 for the year-ago period.

Wickes-Dura Deal
description: Wickes Companies Inc., a manufacturing and retailing conglomerate, said it had agreed to buy the Dura Corporation, a closely held automotive equipment maker based in Southfield, Mich., for an undisclosed price. Wickes said Dura would be ''a natural extension'' of its own automotive products segment. Last year, Dura had sales of more than $100 million.

title: MIDLIFE: AGING BRAIN LOSES CELLS FOR ANXIETY
description: Researchers examining new data on the brain believe they have discovered one physiological basis for the diminished anxiety that has often been documented among people in their forties and fifties: the loss of cells in a brain center that modulates anxiety.

title: A COMPUTER COMES IN FROM THE COLD
description: RETURNING 10 pounds heavier and mentally refreshed from a vacation in Hawaii, I was welcomed home by a wigged-out computer.

Bryson Oil Studies Bid For Cenergy
description: Bryson Oil and Gas P.L.C., which is based in Belfast, Northern Ireland, said that it might seek control of the Cenergy Corporation, a Dallas-based oil and gas exploration concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bryson said that it was considering seeking control of Cenergy ''through representation on the board.''

Results include Vega Vending since its acquisition in the latest third quarter.

title: Brett Sidelined
description: The Kansas City Royals placed George Brett, their all-star third baseman, on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with an injury to his right ribcage suffered in his first time at bat at Yankee Stadium Sunday.

title: Three Suns Pass Drug Test
description: Tests showed no traces of illegal drugs in the three Phoenix Suns players indicted on cocaine charges last week, the National Basketball Association said yesterday.

title: Schlumberger Profit Plunges
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the oilfield service and electronics company, said today that its first-quarter earnings plunged 96 percent, reaching $5 million, or 2 cents a share, from $148.2 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 24.8 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $1.46 billion. The company blamed the oil industry's slump.

title: WALKAWAY UNIONISM: LABOR UTILIZES NOVEL TACTIC IN ST. PAUL
description: When a sheet metal workers' union in St. Paul threatened to stop representing the employees of a local construction company, it might have seemed like a dream come true for the company's management.

title: KNICKS, STUCK AT BOTTOM, DISMISS STIRLING AND HILL
description: When the Knicks' season ended three days ago, it was clear that dramatic changes were needed to reverse the team's failing fortunes. Yesterday afternoon, the changes began at the top. In the boldest move of Madison Square Garden's new management regime, Scotty Stirling, the Knicks' general manager, was dismissed, and it was announced that Bob Hill would not return as head coach.

title: TUCKED AWAY ON EAST SIDE, 2 COMMUNITIES RESIST PROJECT
description: When Harvey Hockman moved into the Stuyvesant Town development in 1949, he was the first tenant in a building that soon filled up with other ex-G.I.'s and their wives. Mr. Hockman later got a new apartment in the development, and World War II veterans soon became the minority. But not much else changed in his corner of Manhattan on the East River.

description: A coalition of environmentalists, fishermen and others worried about Louisiana's coastal erosion have announced a plan to save the state's lush wetlands, which scientists say are disintegrating at the rate of 50 or more square miles a year.

title: Iraq Invites U.N. Inspection Of Chemical War Accusations
description: Iraq has agreed for the first time to let a United Nations team visit and investigate its claim that Iran uses chemical weapons, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Louis R. Lowery Dies; Took Iwo Jima Picture
description: Louis R. Lowery, a retired Marine Corps photographer, died last Wednesday after contracting aplastic anemia. He was 70 years old.

title: ERNEST PAGNANO
description: Ernest Pagnano, a popular New York dance teacher and former member of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and Harkness Ballet, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at his family's home in Harwich, Mass. He was 41 years old. Born in Provincetown, Mass., Mr. Pagnano trained with Niles Marsden in Providence, R.I., and at the Boston Conservatory before moving to New York, where he studied at the Joffrey Ballet School. He joined the Ailey company in 1967, and went on to dance with the Harkness Ballet, Berlin Opera Ballet, Netherlands Dance Theater and Cliff Keuter Dance Company. He was a founding member of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company.

title: Court to Weigh Liability Of 'Sellers' of Securities
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a person who buys securities he knows are unregistered and who brings other buyers into the deal may sue the seller for his own losses and avoid liability for the losses of the other buyers.

title: Forked Tongue News
description: During the last football season there was considerable talk about clock-cleaning. Immense linemen declared their intentions to clean the clocks of opposing players, and men describing games sometimes said things like ''He really got his clock cleaned that time.''

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1.6 million and $3.1 million in the latest and year- ago quarters, respectively, and the year-ago period also includes an after- tax gain from pension accounting change of $67.7 million. Results for 1986 have been restated due to the adoption of the new FASB pension accounting principles in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: Jackson Sees Ueberroth
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met with Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday, then called on baseball's owners to do away with hiring policies that they know ''are immoral and unjust.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our nation has proven that we need not choose between exploring for and developing the energy necessary for survival and growth on one hand, and protecting the environment on the other.'' - Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel. [ D31:4. ]

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FED'S ANGELL SAYS VOLCKER IS BACKED
description: A member of the Federal Reserve Board, Wayne D. Angell, said today that the board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, was not at odds with the panel's Reagan-appointed majority about whether interest rates should rise to support the dollar and head off higher inflation.

title: STAGE: 'HEART THAT EATS ITSELF,' ON KAFKA
description: THE most striking image in Theater for the New City's production of Rosalyn Drexler's play, ''The Heart That Eats Itself'' is the ashen face of the veteran actor George Bartenieff. Portraying the tubercular Franz Kafka in his final hours, Mr. Bartenieff gazes stoically from his bed, his gaunt face a mobile, enigmatic mask that clenches in spasms of agony, then eases into feverish reveries.

description: An administrative judge for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has given the Toledo Edison Company approval to bury slightly radioactive sludge at the Davis-Besse nuclear power station, according to a decision made public today.

SUIT ON EVACUATION OF JAPANESE-AMERICANS IS CALLED TOO LATE
description: Forty-four years after it upheld the forced evacuation of Japanese-Americans from the West Coast, the Supreme Court was told today by Solicitor General Charles Fried that the decision was wrong and the detention ''deplorable,'' but that it was too late for the victims to sue the Government for compensation.

title: Hockey Brunch?
description: For hockey fans wondering if there was any time limit on play Saturday night and Sunday morning in the marathon Stanley Cup game between the Islanders and the Washington Capitals, the answer is no. Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League executive vice president, said yesterday, ''The league bylaws call for each Stanley Cup game to be played to completion, with no provision for stopping.''

title: SRI LANKAN GUERRILLAS SAID TO KILL 15
description: At least 15 Sinhalese villagers were killed early today, apparently by Tamil guerrillas, in the same northeastern district where terrorists killed 127 people in an ambush last week, the Government said today.

title: Tax Watch; Hiding Money Is Harder Now
description: TAX evaders, insider traders, drug traffickers and others looking for foreign places to hide ill-gotten money are discovering that even in the clandestine world of tax havens and numbered accounts some bankers can no longer be counted on to keep their mouths shut.

title: She Who Has Seen the Wheel Come Full Circle
description: Power is ephemeral in Washington. One who knows that well is Esther Coopersmith, who, without benefit of an official title, is nevertheless counted a member of the capital's power structure.

title: 14 Are Killed in Raid Against Peru's Army
description: Rebels ambushed a troop truck at a highlands bridge, killing 10 soldiers and 4 civilians, the military said today. It was believed to be the single most deadly attack on troops in the seven-year insurgency of the Shining Path guerrilla organization.

title: CONTRACT FOR BALLET THEATER
description: The management and dancers of American Ballet Theater have reached an agreement on a new three-year contract.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch yesterday from Portland, Ore., about politics and the annual Mayor's Ball there, misidentified the beneficiaries of last year's ball. They were the Interagency Food Bank and Oregon Food Share.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, said it had sold its international medical technology unit to PPG Industries. Terms of the cash deal were not disclosed.

Surgeon Is Killed in Plunge From a 13th-Floor Window
description: A senior surgeon at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center leaped to his death from his 13th-floor apartment yesterday after leaving notes indicating that he was despondent over the breakup of his marriage, the police said.

description: Revenue represents gross income.

Brewers Win Record 13th The Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Chicago White Sox and ran their record to 13-0, equaling the best start in major league history. Page B5.

title: 4 TAYLOR DANCERS CREATE WORKS FOR THE TROUPE
description: It all began when Paul Taylor walked into the rehearsal studio last fall, called out the names of four of his dancers and asked each of them to create a dance. The results will be seen during the Paul Taylor Dance Company's four-week season at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, which opens tonight.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Chase said its latest first quarter provision for possible loan losses was $160 million, compared with $130 million for year-ago period.

title: Yes, Patent Life
description: Can animals be patented? Ridiculous, intuition suggests, but today the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office will rule otherwise. Researchers who add genes to animal embryos by gene splicing may apply for patents, just like any other inventors. Will private greed and scientific hubris now engender a misbegotten Garden of Eden, crawling with mutant beasts and their Frankenstein-like owners? Or is the Patent Office just trying to keep up with the brisk march of biotechnology?

title: N.F.L. TALKS: FIRST AND LONG
description: With months of preparations and posturing behind them, negotiators for the National Football League players and owners met today and exchanged opening proposals for a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: TV NEWS GETS A SUBTLE SALES PITCH AS THE PRESS RELEASE GOES ELECTRONIC
description: ''It's like someone strangling you,'' said Billie Bloom, an 11-year-old asthmatic, grabbing her throat as she re-enacted an asthma attack that occurred after she switched medicines. Her story was part of an evening news report on KGTV in San Diego that conveyed what the Federal Food and Drug Administration considers a false message: Generic drugs can be less safe than brand-name products.

title: Commerce Aide Resigns
description: Contending that the sanctions against some Japanese goods could be dangerous and that the United States is doing a ''half-baked job'' of promoting its exports, the director of the Commerce Department's local office here said today that he had submitted his resignation.

description: The familiar voice of Billy Smith yelling and screaming instructions to his teammates tonight brought memories of his heroics in leading the Islanders to four Stanley Cup triumphs.

LeMond Shot
description: Greg LeMond, the only American to win the Tour de France bicycle race, was reported to be in fair condition at a Sacramento, Calif., hospital yesterday after suffering a shotgun wound in a morning hunting accident. ''He should recover from all injuries and they should not affect his performance as an athlete,'' said Dr. Sandy Beal, one of three surgeons involved in a two-hour operation on the cyclist at the University of California at Davis Medical Center. LeMond, 25 years old, was flown to the hospital from a rural hunting site about 100 miles east of San Francisco after sustaining a wound to his right side and back while hunting with his uncle and brother-in-law, the spokesman said.

description: b-Net loss

title: THOMAS J. PAOLINO
description: Thomas J. Paolino, who for 21 years served on the Rhode Island Supreme Court, died Saturday at his home here. He was 81 years old. Mr. Paolino, who retired as an associate justice of the Supreme Court in 1977, was the leader of the Republican Party in Rhode Island before he was named to the high court in January 1956.

description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1986.

description: Paul H. O'Neill owns 200 shares of the Aluminum Company of America, according to the proxy statement of the nation's leading aluminum producer. But before long, he will probably own considerably more.

title: A Strange Solicitude
description: Justice can never catch up with the crimes of the Nazis. But we must take whatever opportunity arises to hold even a small part of those horrors up to the light of justice. Otherwise we would fail our inescapable obligation to the victims of Nazism: to remember.

title: CHESS: QUEEN SACRIFICE BY SEIRAWAN
description: Yasser Seirawan, the United States champion, led a 204-player field to win the Lugano International Open Tournament in Switzerland. The 27-year-old Seattle grandmaster, who had previously triumphed in Lugano, in 1983, this time posted a winning score of 7 1/2-1 1/2.

title: CONSOLIDATED CAPITAL REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Israeli Embassy Party
description: The Israeli Embassy's reception May 4 in celebration of Israel's independence day will also serve as a farewell gathering for Ambassador Meir Rosenne.

title: Reporting Rape
description: Rape may be ten to fifteen times more common than official Government figures reflect, according to a national study of college-age women. The study found that 38 per thousand of the women had been raped within the previous six months. Comparable figures for women of college age from the National Crime Survey, a Federal project that relies on public surveys, are 2 to 4 per thousand, depending on the exact age of the woman. ''It must be concluded that offical surveys fail to describe the full extent of sexual victimization,'' the new report said.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

CORRECTIONS
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day yesterday misstated the position of Harold A. Poling. He is president and chief operating officer of the Ford Motor Company and is now a director of the NCR Corporation.

title: Benefit for Homeless
description: The rock performers Clarence Clemons, Buster Poindexter, Phoebe Snow, Paul Shaffer and Jimmy Vivino are to appear at a benefit for the homeless on Monday at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street. Proceeds will benefit two New Jersey shelters, the Bishop Mahurter Shelter for the Homeless in Hoboken and the North Hudson Community Action Corporation in Union City. Shows are at 8 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $15. Information: 228-6300.

title: INTERIOR CHIEF URGES U.S. TO OPEN ARCTIC REFUGE TO OIL EXPLORATION
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel today recommended to Congress that the entire 1.5 million-acre coastal plain within the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge be opened to oil development.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
China Assails U.S. on Trade
description: The Chinese Government accused Washington today of delaying approval of the sale of technology products to China and said that, as a result of this policy, the United States was missing out on export opportunities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15 The Argentine Army chief resigned less than 24 hours after a rebellion of infantry officers ended peacefully. The resignation paves the way for a shake-up of the entire army high command. Page A1 By resolving the military mutiny, President Raul Alfonsin achieved a triumph that was a watershed in Argentina's long and often frustrating struggle for democracy, officials said. A14 China's birth rate is rising again as the country's monumental and controversial birth control campaign loses its grip, experts say. Growing rural wealth seems partly responsible. A1 A computer will be shipped to Iran following a decision by the Reagan Administration to permit export of the $900,000 system, officials said. The decision overrode objections by the Defense Secretary. D1 News analysis: South Korea's crisis of confrontation between the Government and opposition leaders has been exacerbated by President Chun Doo Hwan's decision to end debate about altering the electoral structure. A8 West German peace marchers returned for annual Easter demonstrations that have been held since 1959. This year, Ronald Reagan's enthusiasm for abolishing medium-range missiles has made him the demonstrators' ally. A6 Neo-Nazis have increased efforts to prove their contention that the wartime diary of Anne Frank is a hoax. The attempts to discredit the diary follow the publication of its most complete version. A10 Many Mexicans are returning home from the United States, propelled by new immigration legislation. For the Mexican Government, the change in traditional patterns of migration is a social and economic challenge. A4 Army role in contra case studied A2 P.L.O. chiefs are making up A3 In Libya, a wary middle class A3 NATO commander wants missiles A6 Sri Lankan guerrillas kill 15 A8 Composer seeks to leave Soviet A11 Tanzania plants the three R's A12 NATIONAL A18-27 Karl Linnas was deported last night to the Soviet Union, where he faces a death sentence as a Nazi war criminal. His departure came after the Supreme Court refused to block his deportation, ending years of litigation. A1 Oil development in an Arctic refuge for wildlife was recommended by Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel. Mr. Hodel said that the plan offered the best hope for a major onshore oil strike within the United States. A1 Country music is on the rebound after half a decade of slumping sales and stifled creativity. Record sales of country music, which had slumped to $175 million annually, have climbed above the $200 million level. A1 Commercial use of television news is creating rising concern. The use of video news releases, which are produced by public relations firms but look like news reports, cause some to worry about misleading viewers. A18 A Colorado law allowing deadly force to be used by homeowners against intruders is creating controversy. ''The law, in my estimation, is a legal loophole for murder,'' said an assistant district attorney in Denver. A19 Evacuations of Japanese-Americans by the United States government during World War II was wrong and their detention ''deplorable,'' the Solicitor General told the Supreme Court. But he argued that it was too late for the victims to sue. A24 A Federal agency will investigate its own operations following allegations of impropriety. Top officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission may have had improper contacts with electric utility companies. A18 Michael Deaver sought to overturn his perjury indictment. The former White House aide depicted the special prosecutor as a vindictive person who was intentionally distorting truthful testimony. A23 A search for new ''solar systems'' is under way. Discovery of one would buttress theories that life exists elsewhere in the universe. C1 Milwaukee school rights case A20 Labor adopts a novel tactic A21 A fight to visit the dead A22 Plan to save Louisiana wetlands A27 WASHINGTON TALK A26 Profile: Esther Coopersmith REGIONAL B1-4 Simplified telephone rates were proposed by the New York Telephone Company. Under the new system, calls within New York City and within sections of Long Island and Westchester County would be billed at the same rate. A1 Dozens of hospital patients died from missed diagnoses, emergency room errors and medical and nursing mistakes in 18 private and public hospitals in New York City from 1983 through 1985, a report says. B3 Two pandas arrived at the Bronx Zoo recently, and will make their first public appearance to New Yorkers on April 30. Their arrival marks the culmination of seven years of negotiations with the Chinese. B1 Some fear a waterfront development will destroy a slice of New York's past on the East Side. Opponents of a luxury apartment plan say it would put a wall between the river and two older apartment complexes. B1 Mel Miller criticized the Governor for vetoing the ethics bill that passed the Legislature. But Mr. Miller said he would try to negotiate a bill Mr. Cuomo could approve. B4 Seven people were killed by a fire in Camden. Three adults and four children died and another child was critically injured by the blaze that swept through a brick rowhouse. B1 Concerns about trial tactics have been raised by recent actions taken by some defense lawyers, reviving a debate among legal scholars and lawyers about what is permissible in the courtroom. title: YANKEES' PITCHING RIVALS THEIR BATS
description: Who said the Yankees don't have good starting pitching? Many people, actually, and as the season progresses, they may be proved correct. For the past week, though, the starting pitchers have contributed significantly to the team's seven-game winning streak.

title: File Now - or Pay Later
description: Most Americans have now calculated their 1986 taxes, but many have not yet calculated how much 1987 tax should be withheld from their pay. They fail to do so at their peril.

title: SALE OF COMPUTERS TO IRAN IS ALLOWED
description: The Reagan Administration decided late last week to permit the shipment of a $900,000 computer system to Iran, overriding the objections of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, according to Government and industry sources.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Trenton dispatch last Thursday about a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling on AIDS regulations misstated the number of justices who supported it. The ruling, which upheld state regulations that allow children with AIDS to attend public school, was unanimous.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE fall fashion openings are over and buyers are now deciding which styles their stores will carry. Last week the Fashion Group, an organization of designers, buyers and other fashion professionals, held a series of shows at the New York Hilton that summed up fall trends for its members. The luncheon show also attracted many top designers.

title: CARLOS BAKER, 77, A PROFESSOR AND HEMINGWAY BIOGRAPHER
description: Carlos Baker, a Princeton University professor who wrote the authorized 1969 biography ''Ernest Hemingway: A Life Story'' and a 1952 book-length study, ''Hemingway: The Writer as Artist,'' died Saturday at his home in Princeton. He was 77 years old and had retired from teaching in 1977.

title: One-Time Gains Lift MCI Net
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that profits in the first quarter had increased 26.3 percent, to $25 million, from the first quarter of 1986.

title: Profits Up At 5 Drug Companies
description: Five of the nation's leading pharmaceutical companies yesterday reported higher first-quarter earnings.

title: Maldives to Get Storm Aid
description: The United States and Britain have promised aid to the Maldive Islands after a storm caused $12 milion in damage this month. No deaths or injuries were reported. The British High Commission here said Britain had given $400,000, and the United States Embassy said it was donating $25,000 worth of food, materials for shelter and medical supplies.

title: Key to Keystone
description: Terry Bross, the 6-foot-9-inch center for the St. John's basketball team, has moved his power game from the pivot to the mound as a pitcher for the Redmen's baseball team.

title: LILLY, ELI & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: OCEAN SEDIMENTS TELL TALE OF GREEN ANTARCTICA
description: THANKS to a companion ship that lassoed giant icebergs and towed them out of the way, a research vessel has drilled through the sea floor off Antarctica and extracted detailed samples recording the continent's complex, even verdant, past.

title: A.T.&T. Names Head For International Group
description: John A. Hinds, an executive who led the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's negotiations for a business alliance with Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, has been named president of AT&T International Inc.

title: JAZZ: FARMER-GOLSON GROUP
description: THE Art Farmer-Benny Golson Jazztet, featuring Curtis Fuller, has now been together longer, and with more consistent personnel, than the original Jazztet of the late 50's and early 60's. The early versions of the Farmer-Golson band went through a succession of pianists (including a young McCoy Tyner) and trombonists as well as rhythm players. The 80's band has been defined as much by Mickey Tucker's omnivorously bluesy piano and Mr. Fuller's warm-toned trombone as by the solo styles of its co-leaders. The Jazztet is at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, through Sunday.

description: Yasir Arafat's attempt to unite warring factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization met with some success at the formal opening of a conference here.

title: Coke Preserves Office

The office, which contains hundreds of mementos from Woodruff's six decades with the soft drink company, including stints as president, chairman and board member, had been left as it was in March 1985, when he died. ''We wanted to create a permanent memorial to Mr. Woodruff,'' a Coke spokesman said.

description: Executives of TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. said today that they intended to ''pursue every avenue open to us'' to block the takeover of Dome Petroleum Ltd. by the Amoco Corporation of Chicago.

description: The second phase of a Federal race discrimination trial involving The Daily News was scheduled yesterday for May 11, when the jury will determine the financial damages due four of the newspaper's black employees who had sued.

Dunes Sale May Collapse

description: Millions of adult Tanzanians, gathering under shade trees, in private homes and in other makeshift classrooms, have learned to read and write. By doing so, they have helped to weave a success story of sorts in this impoverished country's tapestry of failures.

Revenues rose 24.8 percent, to $1.76 billion, from $1.41 billion.

description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is the clear, tart liquid that sometimes forms on the top of yogurt? A. This liquid is whey, the thin watery part of milk that separates from the curds, the thicker, white portion, when milk is fermented to make yogurt, according to Michel Saintain, a researcher at the Dannon Yogurt Company. The whey consists mainly of water and a small amount of potassium and calcium, while most of the protein and calcium is contained in the curds. The longer fermentation lasts, the more whey migrates to the top of the yogurt container. Mr. Saintain said the whey can also be shaken out of the heavier yogurt protein during shipping, especially when trucks are used, he said. Manufacturers can control fermentation through refrigeration. ''If we didn't stop the fermentation after a short period of time, we would create some type of cheese,'' Mr. Saintain said. Q. What is smoke and what gives it its color? A. Smoke is a suspension of tiny, solid particles in a gas. Smoke contains minute particles of ash, carbon and other products of combustion that are suspended, but not dissolved, in air. These particles are so small that they are not visible to the naked eye but appear as a continuous flowing medium. Such a mixture is known as a colloid, in which one substance is uniformly distributed in a finely divided state through a second substance.

title: Coleco Loss Of $8.9 Million
description: Coleco Industries today reported a first-quarter loss of $8.9 million, in contrast to earnings of $5.7 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago. Interest expense of $12.6 million was $6.7 million higher than for the period a year ago, Coleco said.

title: LATIN LOANS CITED
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday announced a 28 percent drop in its net income for the first quarter, largely because of problem loans to Brazil.

title: U.S.-Kuwaiti Pact Near
description: The United States and Kuwait are working out an agreement under which some Kuwaiti oil tankers would fly United States flags in the troubled Persian Gulf, the State Department said today. The department said the registration switch could pave the way for American warships to protect those Kuwaiti ships in the gulf, where Iran and Iraq have attacked shipping in their six-year-old war. Moscow announced last week that Kuwait had leased three Soviet tankers to carry Kuwaiti oil in the region as a protective measure, but there has been no indication that Kuwaiti ships would fly Soviet flags.

Soviet-China Talks End With 2 Sides at Odds
description: The Soviet Union and China completed weeklong talks today on normalizing relations, but diplomats said they remained at odds over the problems of Afghanistan and Cambodia.

title: ON FASHION'S CREATIVE FRINGE
description: Many New York designers operate on the fringes of fashion. During this month's fall openings, young designers in particular tended to have small shows in out-of-the-way places.

description: Reeves Lewenthal, a leading patron of American art and the founder and chief executive officer of a group of natural gas and oil exploration and development companies, died Sunday in Broward General Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., several days after undergoing cancer surgery. He was 77 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Chinese Rules on Gold
description: China announced restrictions on gold prospectors today in an attempt to halt smuggling, which is estimated to keep $90 million worth of gold out of the national Treasury each year. The China Daily newspaper reported that the Metallurgical Industry Ministry had issued regulations that ban gold processing by individuals and restrict the number of places where prospectors can seek gold after receiving authorization. China is the world's fourth-largest gold producer.

The S.E.C. said Jan E. Brooks, a principal and director of Brooks until October, had agreed in a consent decree to a four-year suspension from trading. William P. Satnick, a broker with Brooks until October, and Marvin Hamburger were barred for five years. The three accepted the suspensions without admitting or denying the charges, the S.E.C. said.

The effect, analysts and competitors said, would be an overall increase of about 10 to 12 percent in the most heavily discounted fares.

title: SABLE, BEAVER AND FOX: LUXURY TOUCHES FOR FALL

Stoles and jackets are bordered in fur, and some of the most sumptuous coats shown in the last few weeks were Carolina Herrera's navy cashmeres lined in sable. Why the fur explosion? ''I really wanted to call attention to the legs,'' said Bill Blass, who almost always has some fur in his fall collections, but this time had more than usual. He used only the most luxurious furs, like fox and two kinds of sable, the golden variety and the rich dark brown skins.

The choir's richness and beauty of tone, and the fervency with which it gave the wide spectrum of dynamics and articulation Mr. Rilling demanded, put to rest all the various questions that swirl around modern Bach style before one could think of asking them.

title: MUSIC: DUPRE'S 'STATIONS'

Nevertheless, devotees of the 20th-century French organ repertory will find much to admire in Dupre's work, which combines chromaticism and polytonality in a manner that seems both antiquated and Modernist at the same time.

description: Antony Tudor, one of the foremost choreographers of the century and widely considered the master of the psychological ballet, died last night of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was variously reported to be 78 or 79 years old.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP (COMSAT) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $500,000 for the latest quarter and $900,000 for the year- earlier period. The company, which said it recorded a $5.5 million after-tax reserve in the 1987 first quarter for a potential refund as a result of the FCC's on- going rate investigation, said that in that investigation, the FCC common carrier bureau directed Comsat to refund about $62 million in revenues related to alleged excess pre-tax earnings for the period from 1983 to mid- 1986 or to show cause within 45 days why the corporation should not make such a refund. The company also said that through March 1987, about $28 million is subject to an accounting order imposed by the FCC in November 1985. The company has provided for an amount totaling about $9.5 million (pre-tax), which represents the amounts of alleged excess earnings relating to services for which there was a rate increase and of disallowed costs for that period.

title: THE N.B.A. HOLDS ITS BREATH
description: Quietly, the National Basketball Association is holding its breath that the Phoenix Suns cocaine scandal doesn't evolve into point-fixing.

title: Making Another Belfast in Sri Lanka
description: Dostoyevsky once remarked that no cause was worth the murder of a single child. That view doubtless would be rejected as sentimentalism by Tamil zealots in Sri Lanka. They are so intoxicated by the purity of their separatist cause that last Friday they systematically massacred 127 civilians, including tiny children. The deed occurred during a week sacred to the island's three major religions - Buddhism, Hinduism and Christianity - and was followed yesterday by the deliberate killing of at least 15 more Sinhalese civilians, 5 of them children.

description: b-Includes a writeoff of $2,622,000 of investment tax credits. c-Net income

title: CHINA'S BIRTH RATE ON RISE AGAIN AS OFFICIAL SANCTIONS ARE IGNORED
description: Birth rates are rising again in the world's most populous nation as China's monumental and controversial birth-control campaign loses its grip, Chinese officials and foreign experts agree.

title: TRADING UP AT I.B.M.
description: THE new I.B.M. personal computers have several new features that, in the short term at least, will complicate life for the upwardly mobile user. Specifically affected are the owners of ''PC classic'' models - the current I.B.M. PC's, XT's, AT's and compatibles -who are thinking of switching to the new Personal System/2 - the Models 30, 50, 60 and 80.

The company said in light of the continuing unavailability of primary levels of errors and omissions insurance coverage, it set up a reserve of about $1,100,000 in the latest first quarter to fund losses within the deductible under its errors and omissions coverage and other litigation expenses.

title: IN LIBYA, WARY MIDDLE CLASS ENDURES
description: For educated, middle-class Libyans, life under Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has become a mental and materialistic endurance test, sustained by the hope that they will outlast him or that he will change.

title: SABERHAGEN AT 3-0 ON COMEBACK TRAIL
description: Bret Saberhagen earned his third victory in three starts as the Kansas City Royals beat the Boston Red Sox by 10-2 today, spoiling the 75th anniversary of the opening of Fenway Park.

title: Texas Air Stake In Maine Carrier
description: The Texas Air Corporation agreed to acquire 50 percent of Bar Harbor Airlines and arrange for the sale of Provincetown-Boston Airline Inc. to Bar Harbor, officials said. Texas Air, the nation's largest airline holding company, would provide additional capital to Bar Harbor, based in Bangor, Me., in the form of convertible debt, the company said.

title: Separate but Equal, Soviet-Style
description: The Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, startled visiting Congressmen recently with a suggestion that the United States solve its racial problems by setting up separate states for blacks and other minorities. Mr. Gorbachev's men hastily played down the remark but the damage was done: he had made plain a surprising ignorance of American society, as well as Moscow's general insensitivity toward minority problems in the Soviet Union.

title: Hijacker Who Fled Prison To Be Returned to New York
description: A convicted hijacker who escaped from a Federal prison in New York State waived objections at a hearing today and will be returned to New York as soon as possible, officials said.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $18,363,000 and a gain of $24,793,000 from the sale of securities. c-Includes a gain of $4,135,000 from the sale of securities.

title: Town's Protest Bars Inmate
description: A state prison inmate who was convicted of raping and mutilating a teen-age hitchhiker will not be paroled to the town of Antioch in northern California as planned, largely because of community opposition, the authorities said today.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods reflect a $25 million addition made at the end of the March quarter to the company's provisions for possible losses.

title: CHAIRMAN RESIGNS AT SANTA FE
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation announced today that John J. Schmidt, its chairman and chief executive since 1983, had resigned. The turmoil in Santa Fe's executive suite comes at a time when the company is considered a possible takeover target.

title: ARMY COMMANDER IN ARGENTINA QUITS IN WAKE OF REVOLT
description: Less than 24 hours after a rebellion of infantry officers ended peacefully, Argentina's army Chief of Staff resigned today in a shake-up of the entire army high command.

title: MILWAUKEE TRIAL UNDER WAY IN SCHOOL DESEGREGATION SUIT
description: Trial began today on a Federal court suit filed by the Milwaukee School Board and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charging that racial segregation exists in the city's schools as a result of action by the state and the city's suburbs.

title: Hart the Elder
description: Gary Hart cut his teeth on generational politics, from his days as the manager of George McGovern's 1972 Presidential campaign to his race for the Senate in 1974 and on to his 1984 Presidential bid, when he contended that it was time for a new generation of Democrats to lead the nation.

title: Anti-Alcholism Spots For Ages 8 to 12
description: It is a dismal sign of our times. The Children's Television Workshop, which has created so many lovely features for the children of America, has now done a public service campaign aimed at keeping the 8-to-12 set from becoming drunkards.

title: Never Mind Central Park's Tennis House; Fix the Court Surfaces
description: To the Editor:

title: INADEQUATE CARE BLAMED FOR 43 HOSPTIAL DEATHS
description: Forty-three patients died from inadequate care at 18 private and public hospitals in New York City from 1983 through 1985, according to a state review of hospital mortality that was made public yesterday.

title: SIMPLER (AND LOWER) PHONE RATES ARE PLANNED FOR NEW YORK REGION
description: The New York Telephone Company proposed a simplified rate system yesterday under which all calls within New York City, as well as within large sections of Long Island and Westchester County, would be billed at the same rate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Party Time

title: FIX THE COURT SURFACES; Gothic? Who Cares?

Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption, in December 1986, of FAS No. 87, Employer's Accounting for Pensions, for International pension plans and to reflect certain reclassifications to conform data to the 1986 annual report presentation.

title: Ogilvy Puts Romance In Concord Watch Ads
description: Readers familiar with the lore of the ad game might have suspected that the Concord watch ad they ran into while leafing through The New York Times Magazine on Sunday was the work of Ogilvy & Mather. What agency other than David Ogilvy's would be likely to come up with a long-copy ad to sell a watch? And it's a romantic sell at that. That ad, like another one completed for the campaign, was done in both single-page and spread versions. While Sunday's had to do with a romantic woman who presents a watch to a practical engineer ''with a soft spot for me,'' the other ad's underplayed headline is: ''She'd told me at the beginning I would know when the time was right to whisk her away for a weekend. All I did was hasten the process.''

title: DEFENSE LAWYERS' TACTICS: UNFAIR OR JUST AGGRESSIVE?
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., the defense lawyer, opened the trial of two men accused in the razor attack on the model Marla Hanson by asserting that she has ''racial hangups'' and then aggressively cross-examined her with questions laden with sexual innuendo.

title: Telescopes To Operate From Trucks
description: A Nobel Prize-winning physicist, using instruments mounted on trucks, has developed an infrared telescope system he said would be able to penetrate the dust and gas shrouding parts of the universe.

title: BELLSOUTH CORPORATION BELLWETHER EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid in February.

title: Moscow Is Gaining An Edge in Space
description: While the United States is busy creating its Strategic Defense Initiative, which will be of absolutely no value unless an enemy chooses to attack in a particular way, the Soviet Union is rapidly outflanking us by extending its reach into space. As we pour human and financial resources into this military initiative, the Russians are making a long-term investment in space exploration that will pay handsome economic, scientific and political benefits.

title: 'CARNEGIE HALL: GRAND OPENING'
description: IF you didn't have a ticket for the occasion last Dec. 15, tonight's ''Carnegie Hall: The Grand Reopening'' on CBS at 9 will serve as a tidy substitute. In fact, you are probably better off. Intended as a television special, the gala ran on for hours as the stage was constantly being rearranged for an assortment of performances. By the end of the evening, even the celebrities began to slip out the side exits, leaving many seats quite visibly vacant. This television recording, the equivalent of a glossy souvenir program, is considerably more efficient than the event itself.

title: Karl Linnas's War Crimes Are Not in Question; U.S. Court Findings
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC NEWS'S 'TRILLION FOR DEFENSE'
description: THE title explains it: ''A Trillion for Defense: What Have We Bought?'' A lot of hardware, ammunition and weapons systems, the NBC News special answers, although not always sensibly or well. Interservice rivalries, improper purchasing procedures and a lack of policy planning hurt the process. The criticisms are not new, but the special, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, presents them in fresh, timely fashion. The program is worth watching.

title: GARBAGE RECYCLING BILL BECOMES LAW IN JERSEY
description: Governor Kean signed a mandatory-recycling law today under which all New Jersey residents will be required to separate materials like glass and newspapers from their household trash.

title: Tudor's Account
description: ''What's done is done,'' said John Tudor, the Cardinals' left-hander who is sidelined with a serious leg injury after Barry Lyons, the Mets' catcher, barreled into him chasing a foul pop on Sunday in St. Louis. Tudor said he tried to catch Lyons. ''He never even broke stride,'' Tudor said. ''If I wasn't there, I don't know what would have happened to him.

title: U.S. DEPORTS MAN CONDEMNED TO DIE BY SOVIET UNION
description: Thirty-six years after arriving in the United States from Germany, a Long Island man was deported last night to the Soviet Union, where he faces a death sentence as a Nazi war criminal who commanded an Estonian concentration camp in World War II and supervised the mass execution of Jews.

title: THE SEARCH FOR PLANET SYSTEMS ACCELERATES AMID NEW CLUES
description: Tantalized by recent clues, astronomers are stepping up their search among nearby stars for the first direct evidence that planetary systems are not unique to the Sun and may even be prevalent in the universe.

MAXWELL D. TAYLOR, SOLDIER AND ENVOY, DIES
description: Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, a daring pioneer commander of airborne troops who became a major force in determining American military and diplomatic strategy from World War II through the Vietnam War and beyond, died Sunday night at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington. He was 85 years old.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS 2 KEY CHARGES IN ZACCARO CASE
description: A Queens judge, rejecting a motion by John A. Zaccaro, ruled yesterday that the real-estate broker had to stand trial on charges of attempted extortion and bribe-seeking stemming from an investigation into the awarding of cable-television franchises in Queens.

title: Bridge: Diluted 1 No-Trump Bidding Has Been Gaining Popularity
description: Three decades ago almost every American expert used the traditional 16-18 point no-trump opening. Nowadays, however, a substantial minority, perhaps a quarter, choose a weak no-trump, and those who stay with the strong variety tend to dilute it to 15-17 or 15-18.

title: Dow Drops by 5.39 on Inflation Fears
description: The stock market opened strongly yesterday - the Dow Jones industrial average was up 16.77 at 9:45 A.M. - but a sharp rise in interest rates, and in gold and silver prices, quickly cut the rally short.

title: A Soldier's Story
description: Archeologists and historians have joined to identify a skeleton found in Philadelphia as that of a British infantryman who apparently died 210 years ago fighting in the American Revolution.

title: AFTER FLYING FIRST-CLASS, PANDAS SETTLE IN BRONX
description: They flew first-class from Beijing. They were whisked from Kennedy International Airport to the Bronx Zoo in the dead of night with the delicacy and secrecy befitting foreign ambassadors. Now they sleep and eat in seclusion, while the zoo hums with the excitement of welcoming such exotic visitors.

title: POSSIBLE CHARTER ISSUE: CAMPAIGN FINANCING
description: Richard Ravitch, chairman of New York City's Charter Revision Commission, said yesterday he wants to determine whether the City Charter can mandate the public financing of campaigns in municipal elections.

title: Farmer Dukakis
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, was not exactly a hit in Iowa earlier this year when he suggested that hard-pressed farmers should consider crop diversification, planting Belgian endive, for example, in place of corn or soybeans.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Government bond prices plunged, in some cases by nearly two points, and interest rates soared yesterday on a report that Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, favored tightening credit.

title: UNION CAMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Another Interest Rate Expert
description: Budget Director James Miller, whose management of the Federal deficit leaves something to be desired, now asserts expertise on managing the nation's money supply. He warned the Federal Reserve not to raise interest rates - an initiative quickly squelched by the White House, which said he was speaking ''personally.'' Personal or official, such free-wheeling comment only sows confusion.

title: Lech Walesa Reports Writing Autobiography
description: Lech Walesa, the shipyard electrician who won the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize for his leadership of the now-outlawed Solidarity labor movement, said today that he had completed an autobiography but did not disclose when or where it would be published.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
FANCIFIED VEGETABLES
description: LEAD: VEGETABLES are the white hats. Correctly prepared and not corrupted with fats, they ought to make up an important part of the diet. It has long been known that vegetables contain substances associated with preventing cancer and lowering the level of cholesterol in the blood.

title: Tokyo Stock Record
description: Encouraged by yesterday's rally on Wall Street and the yen's depreciation against the dollar, stock prices set a record today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The Nikkei Stock Average, comprising 225 issues, rose by 202.75 yen to close the morning trading session at 24,088.85 yen, passing the psychological barrier of 24,000 yen. An estimated 1.3 billion shares were traded. In the currency markets, the United States dollar strengthened against the yen, closing at 142.67 yen in the morning, compared with a close of 142.10 yesterday.

title: NIGHTCLUB WITHOUT SMOKE
description: Chubby Stevens likes his cigar. But these days, when the trio at Jerry Farber's small jazz and comedy club here breaks between sets, Mr. Stevens, a bass player and singer, takes five in the parking lot out front.

title: POLICEMAN SLAIN, 64 WOUNDED IN SOWETO
description: A black police trainee was killed today and 64 of his colleagues were wounded, six of them seriously, by a hand grenade thrown into a crowded police parade ground in Soweto, officials said.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change relating to pensions.

title: 'OUR PLANET' MAKES FUN OF TV NEWS
description: SAY this about the Zucker brothers, Jerry and David: they have a certain healthy perspective about the television business. On the subject of ''Our Planet Tonight,'' a ''docu-comedy'' on NBC at 8 o'clock, the brothers declare, ''We don't know if it will be any good, but we hope to make a lot of money.'' Zucker successes in the movies have included ''Airplane'' and ''Ruthless People.'' After ''Our Planet Tonight,'' Zucker successes on television clearly remain to be seen.

description: The year-earlier periods' per share earnings not available because the bank converted to a public company June 1986.

CITICORP AND HANOVER REPORT LOWER PROFITS
description: Citicorp and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday, citing their placement of billions of dollars in Latin American loans on a cash basis. But the Bankers Trust Company, which also placed some Latin loans on a cash basis, reported record earnings and credited continued strength in its investment-banking division.

title: STRIP-MINE CHANGE WINS VOTE IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives today approved legislation to tighten a provision of a law intended to curb the environmental abuses of strip mining.

title: 'HOUDINI!,' A TRIBUTE TO THE ESCAPE ARTIST
description: ''HOUDINI!'' doesn't explain everything about the great illusionist and escape artist. That's fine; if you like magic, there are some things better left unsaid. The 30-minute documentary, on Channel 13 at 9:30 tonight, memorializes a legendary entertainer. It is a pleasant and imaginative tribute.

description: The Amoco Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits declined 21.5 percent, to $260 million, or $1.02 a share, from $331 million, or $1.28 a share.

description: The price of crude oil surged yesterday, topping $19 a barrel for a near-month futures contract, as crude oil and petroleum products advanced across the board.

title: 15 Poles Vanish in Bavaria
description: Fifteen Poles on an Easter bus tour to West Germany have disappeared, leaving the driver and tour guide for the return journey to Poland, the Bavarian border police said today. A spokesman said the 15 Poles disappeared in Munich during the holiday weekend and it was not yet clear whether they would apply for asylum or spend a few weeks in the West before returning home.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS STATE ON CURBING HOSTILE TAKEOVER
description: In an important victory for companies seeking protection from takeovers, the Supreme Court for the first time today upheld a state law that restricts hostile offers for companies incorporated in that state. M Reversing a Federal appellate decision, the Court ruled that the 1986 Indiana law, which resembles laws in Ohio, Pennsylvania and several other states, violated neither the Federal Williams Act of 1968, which regulates tender offers, nor the Commerce Clause of the Constitution, which bans state obstruction of interstate commerce.

title: SIR PETER HALL RELISHES NEW COMMERCIAL ROLE
description: In 1960 Peter Hall, a hot young director out of Cambridge University, transformed a summer stock theater at Stratford-on-Avon into the Royal Shakespeare Company. Thirteen years later he succeeded Laurence Olivier at the rival National Theater as it struggled to complete a new home that was still $35 million and four years from opening. This year, Sir Peter (he was knighted in 1977) announced the formation of a company that will produce plays for the commercial theater, thus closing one chapter in a tumultuous and always controversial career and beginning, undoubtedly, another.

title: Hagopian Laments Trend to Mega-mergers
description: American business is in trouble, and the agency industry along with it, because of the current obsession for making quick money, Louis T. Hagopian suggested yesterday. He then called on agencies to help restore normalcy by returning to their role as builders of businesses.

title: HOME OWNERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $52.1 million.

title: More Service Workers
description: In advanced countries, 60 percent of the workers are employed in service industries such as transport, while farm and factory employment is shrinking, the International Labor Organization said today.

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DONOVAN DEFENSE CALLS NO WITNESSES
description: After listening to the prosecution's evidence for seven months, former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and seven co-defendants took two minutes yesterday to rest their case in a larceny and fraud trial in the Bronx.

title: A Real Toll Call
description: George Argyros, the Seattle Mariners' owner, who is trying to sell the team and buy the San Diego Padres, has been fined $10,000 for a congratulatory phone call to Larry Bowa, the Padres' manager. The fine, levied by the baseball commissioner, stemmed from a conversation between Argyros and Bowa on Thursday following the Padres' 10-inning, 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. According to a spokesman in the commissioner's office, Argyros ''had been informed that he could not have any contact'' with the Padres to avoid a conflict of interest. Argyros, reached at his home, said: ''If someone misunderstood that, I am sorry. The commissioner is entitled to do whatever he wants to do, and I will certainly live by any decision he makes.'' Shortly after Bowa received the call, the National League president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, walked into his office. Also in Bowa's office was the Padres' general manager, Jack McKeon, who asked who had called when Bowa hung up. Bowa replied: ''George'' Giamatti asked: ''George Argyros?'' Bowa said: ''Yes.'' ''If I would have known it would have gotten him in trouble I wouldn't have said anything,'' Bowa added.

title: Gone West Will Skip Kentucky Derby
description: Gone West, who won the Gotham Stakes April 4 and was beaten just a head despite trouble in the Wood Memorial last Saturday, will not contest the Kentucky Derby May 2, his trainer said today.

title: Which Dirty Words? When?
description: Vagueness is the classic tool of oppressive censorship - a tool now wielded by a surprising censor, the Federal Communications Commission. The F.C.C., in recent years a pioneer of deregulation, now has abruptly warned broadcasters that it will apply new rules to future decisions about ''decency'' on the airwaves.

title: CAPITAL CITIES' OPERATING GAIN
description: Capital Cities/American Broadcasting Companies announced yesterday that its first-quarter operating income climbed 71.6 percent, to $97.3 million, from $56.7 million in the comparable period of 1986.

The company said the latest first quarter includes a gain of $4.5 million from quarterly distributions of Freeport-McMoran Gold Co. common shares, compared with a gain of $7.3 million a year-earlier.

title: WEST AND THE REST
description: Of N.B.A. history's top 10 players in postseason scoring average, half will be in action during the playoffs that start tomorrow night. The leaders (minimum of 25 games): G Pts. Avg. Jerry West 153 4,457 29.13 K. Abdul-Jabbar* 180 4,912 27.29 Elgin Baylor 134 3,623 27.04 George Gervin 59 1,592 26.98 Akeem Olajuwon* 25 643 25.72 Bob Pettit 88 2,240 25.45 Alex English* 48 1,201 25.02 Adrian Dantley* 32 799 24.97 Kiki Vandeweghe* 29 723 24.93 Rick Barry 74 1,833 24.77 *In coming playoffs.

title: ORCHESTRAL EXPRESSIONS IN JOE JACKSON ALBUM
description: LISTENING to Joe Jackson's new, all-instrumental album, ''Will Power'' (A&M) one is reminded of George Gershwin's rapid development from a Tin Pan Alley tunesmith into a composer of serious concert music in the 1920's. The compositions on ''Will Power,'' written and scored by Mr. Jackson for a 40-piece orchestra, include his 16-minute impressionistic ''Symphony in One Movement,'' a Chopinesque ''Nocturne'' for solo piano, the sharply percussive Latin-flavored ''No Pasaran,'' and ''Solitude,'' a piece inspired by the Duke Ellington song of which it incorporates a fragment sung by a boy soprano.

title: PENTAGON LINKING SECRET ARMY UNIT TO CONTRA MONEY
description: The Pentagon said today that it recently discovered that a secret Army unit disbanded in 1983 had set up a Swiss bank account that may later have been used illegally to finance arms for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: DOME REJECTS TALKS WITH TRANSCANADA
description: The controversy surrounding the Amoco Corporation's takeover bid for Dome Petroleum Ltd. heightened today after Dome's executives rebuffed efforts to reopen negotiations with a rival bidder, TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.

title: POINDEXTER IS GIVEN IMMUNITY
description: The Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair voted officially today to compel the sworn testimony of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter by giving him immunity from prosecution based on his Congressional testimony.

title: Peru Suspends Sales of Silver
description: Apparently in an effort to lift silver prices, the Peruvian Government is suspending sales of silver abroad, Wilfredo Huayta, the energy and mines minister, said today.

title: CLEMENS WINS ON 3-HITTER, 8-0
description: Roger Clemens, who lost his first two decisions after missing all of spring training in a contract dispute, pitched a three-hitter tonight for his first victory of the season as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Kansas City Royals, 8-0.

NEGLIGENCE RULING ON U.S. ATOM TESTS OVERTURNED
description: An appeals court has overturned a Federal judge's ruling that Government negligence in above-ground nuclear weapon tests from 1951 to 1962 caused cancer in some residents downwind from the Nevada test sites.

description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: SOME IN ESTONIA GREETED NAZIS IN '41 AS LIBERATORS
description: When Hitler's Army invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941 and, in a matter of weeks, overran the Baltic states, annexed by Moscow only the previous year, the Baltic populations generally greeted the Germans as liberators.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,557,000.

title: Reagan's Chance To Alter History
description: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's breakthrough in Moscow promises an agreement on missiles in Europe and a summit meeting. But that prospect lifts only a small corner of the shroud hiding a remarkable opportunity to turn decisively away from the final superpower confrontation that has long seemed almost inevitable.

title: Judge Delays Cocaine Trial
description: A Federal judge today delayed until Sept. 8 the trial of a reported Colombian cocaine smuggler, Carlos Lehder Rivas, and warned defense attorneys, who had asked for a nine-month continuance, that they were unlikely to get another delay. The trial was to have begun May 18. Mr. Lehder, 37 years old, was arrested after a shootout Feb. 4 with the Colombian police at his jungle hideout and extradited that night to Florida.

title: Reform Thruway Board
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUNDATION AWARDS GO TO 8 NEWSPAPERS AND 5 BROADCASTERS
description: The Scripps-Howard Foundation today honored eight newspapers, three television stations, two radio stations and a cartoonist at its National Journalism Awards banquet here.

title: DEBUNKING MYTHS OF THE MALE SHOPPER
description: FORGET the image of the male grocery shopper of the 1950's: sent to the store for a can of peaches, he came home with a sheepish look and a jar of chocolate-covered ants. Working women and job-sharing at home have changed all that. Men are going to the grocery store in record numbers, and while some still break out in a cold sweat just walking through the automatic door, far more are at ease in the aisles and thoroughly capable of distinguishing between a mango and a papaya.

title: JAMES A. BOYLE, KENNEDY'S JUDGE
description: James A. Boyle, the judge who presided at the inquest into the death of an aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy on Chappaquiddick Island in 1969, died yesterday at his home on Cape Cod after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: OILERS TRIUMPH, 3-2, AT 0:36 OF OVERTIME
description: Glenn Anderson scored on a low wrist shot 36 seconds into overtime to give the Edmonton Oilers a 3-2 victory over the Winnipeg Jets tonight in the first game of the Smythe Division final.

title: ESTONIAN DEPORTED BY U.S. ARRIVES IN SOVIET
description: Karl Linnas, under sentence of death for war crimes in the Soviet Union and deported Monday night from the United States, was returned to his native Estonia tonight.

title: Ethics Law Rerun
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court upheld a state curb on hostile takeovers for companies incorporated in that state. The 6-to-3 ruling, which sustained an Indiana law, was an important victory for companies seeking takeover protection. Under the law, a company could deny voting rights to those making tender offers or to any investors who increase their holdings above a certain level. [ Page A1. ] Fannie Mae will be allowed to underwrite a new type of mortgage-backed security. But the Administration told the agency that it must move swiftly toward complete privatization. In the next 15 months, the agency will be able to issue $15 billion of real estate mortgage-investment conduits, or Remics. Five major Wall Street firms had opposed the Remic plan. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stock prices rallied strongly on Wall Street as concerns on interest rates and inflation eased. The Dow Jones industrial average nearly equaled its best point gain ever, rising 66.47 points, to 2,337.07, a performance that had its roots in a firmer bond market and computerized trading. The Dow had lost 135 points after hitting a record 2,404.54 on April 6. [ D1. ] Treasury bond prices gyrated wildly, falling sharply in early trading but recovering to end with modest gains. Despite new optimism on interest rates, traders remained wary. [ D17. ] Many local government officials are delaying bond sales because of the recent sharp rise in the yields on tax-exempt issues. [ D17. ] The price of gold in U.S. markets was depressed by profit-taking and a soaring stock market. In New York, gold dropped $5.50, to $447. The dollar was little changed. [ D18. ] The price of crude oil surged above $19 a barrel, but analysts said the gain did not foreshadow a long-term trend. [ D18. ] COMPANIES Citicorp and Manufacturers Hanover reported lower earnings for the first quarter, citing the placement of billions of dollars in Latin American loans on a cash basis. But Bankers Trust, which took a similar action, reported record earnings because of continued strength in its investment-banking division. [ D1. ] First Boston and Paine Webber reported gains. [ D8. ] Sears, Roebuck's net income jumped 47.4 percent. Its retailing and insurance units posted strong gains, but the biggest turnaround involved Dean Witter. The financial services unit's income was $6.1 million, a $12 million improvement over a year-earlier loss. [ D1. ] Fears that a shortage of Japanese laptop computers will result from new U.S. tariffs have prompted retailers and some consumers to accelerate their buying, computer industry executives said. [ D1. ] Capital Cities/ABC reported higher operating income for the first quarter, helped by an accounting change, cost-cutting measures and improved results at its TV stations. But it said the outlook for its TV network remained uncertain. [ D4. ] The Tribune Company reported a sharp drop in earnings, while the Washington Post Company reported a gain. [ D4. ] Dome Petroleum executives rebuffed TransCanada's efforts to reopen takeover negotiations. The Canadian Government, meanwhile, faces growing pressure to favor a Canadian buyer. [ D4. ] Bally will sell its Six Flags theme park to Wesray for $350 million in cash and the assumption of $250 million in debt. [ D4. ] A $3.8 billion bid for Hospital Corp. was dropped by an investor group, whose offer had been rejected. [ D12. ] TECHNOLOGY Electronic monitoring devices are being used by understaffed law-enforcement departments to keep track of released criminals on probation. [ D7. ] Colorization has given new life to 63 films, at a cost of up to $350,000 each. Critics profess to be ''sickened'' by the altered black-and-white classics. Advances. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The U.S.-Japan trade waltz shows that both sides fear a trade war. Such mutual deterrence needs to be reinforced, in both the economic and military spheres, by accords to enhance stability. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Some brokerage houses are taking a more cautious stance in their investment advice because of the sharp swings in the currency and securities markets. Market Place. [ D8. ]

description: It took more than a paintbrush to give Santa Claus rosy cheeks in ''Miracle on 34th Street'' or to create a blue suit for Cary Grant in ''Topper.'' It costs as much as $350,000 per film and requires the help of I.B.M.-PC's, Apple Macintoshes and similar computers, as well as patience and artistic license to transform black and white films and television programs into new commercial video releases for broadcast and pay television, for use in VCR's and for airline licensing.

Mr. Sosnoff wants Caesars shareholders to remove the four inside directors from the nine-member board, to repeal certain antitakeover measures and to block any recapitalization that would involve additional debt without prior shareholder approval.

title: Encouraging Meeting
description: After a meeting yesterday with Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said he was encouraged that major league baseball would make a strong effort to hire blacks for key managerial positions. The meeting came one day after Ueberroth discussed minority hiring practices with the Rev. Jesse Jackson. ''The commissioner is sensitive to the situation and committed to change,'' Mr. Lowery said. ''I'm very encouraged. We want to see blacks on the board of directors, managerial positions in the office and on the field. His role is key to setting the tone of the owners.''

title: Playtex Ads Will Show Bras on Live Models
description: Two Playtex Inc. bra commercials, which are expected to be the first to take advantage of relaxed TV network standards and show the goods on live models, should be totally inoffensive to viewers untroubled by the scanty dance costumes and bikinis already prevalent on the tube.

title: Boxing Changes Made
description: Jose Torres, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that, starting in mid-May, a boxing manager and a promoter who are related to one another will no longer be permitted to be associated with a match involving a fighter to whom both have rights. Torres said that a fighter in that instance would then have the option of securing another manager or negotiating on his own with the promoter. Another rule change that Torres said the commission expects to effect by mid-May would forbid a manager who has rights to both fighters in a single bout to negotiate for both men. These changes, Torres said, grew from the investigation by Joseph Spinelli, the state's Inspector General, following the World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight last Dec. 12 between Tim Witherspoon, then the champion, and the challenger, James (Bonecrusher) Smith. Smith, who replaced Tony Tubbs after Tubbs said he had a shoulder injury, knocked out Witherspoon in one round as part of Home Box Office's heavyweight unification series. Tubbs, who was promoted by Don King and managed by King's son, Carl, had asked that the bout be postponed so that he would not lose his chance to fight for the title. He has brought an $11,425,000 suit against both Kings. Witherspoon, who was managed by Carl King and promoted by Don King, has also brought a suit that includes the Kings as defendants.
