RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Soviet Union Beats Czechoslovakia: In Vienna, the Soviet Union scored a major victory in defense of its world championship yesterday by beating Czechoslovakia, 6-1. The Soviet team leads the standing with 8 points on a 4-0 record. Sweden is second at 3-1. Finland defeated the United States, 5-2. The American squad is 0-4. Canada was defeated by West Germany, 5-3. Sweden routed Switzerland, 12-1. (AP) TENNIS Arias Upsets Becker: Jimmy Arias upset top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the $513,000 Monte Carlo Open in Monaco. Thomas Muster of Austria beat the defending champion, Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 0-6, 6-3, 7-6. Mats Wilander of Sweden beat a countryman, Jan Gunnarsson, 6-3, 6-2. Martin Jaite of Argentina defeated Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-2. (AP) Navratilova Beats Benjamin: Martina Navratilova, seeded first, defeated Camille Benjamin, 6-2, 6-1, in first-round action last night at the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tournament. The 23-year-old Benjamin kept pace with Navratilova through the first four games, winnning her first two service games. But when Navratilova, 30, warmed up, she broke Benjamin's serve in the fifth game, and then won 12 consecutive points to win the set, 6-2. Third-seeded Chris Evert glided past Nathalie Herreman of France, 6-1, 6-1. (AP)

title: Quarter Profit For A.M.C.
description: The American Motors Corporation, which the Chrysler Corporation has agreed to buy, posted a first-quarter profit, compared with a loss in the comparable 1986 period, it reported today.

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: WINE TALK
description: THE pitchman on Milton Berle's television show in the 50's, Sid Stone, is remembered for a spiel: ''Ya say you're not satisfied? Ya want more for your money? All right, just a minute. Tell ya what I'm gonna do.'' The ''tell ya'' preceded inside dope about a bargain. So let me ''tell ya'' about Chilean wines.

title: LOTS OF SPOTS AND POLKA DOTS
description: 1. A Different Diameter The man who is tired of striped ties might want to try dots -polka dots as big as pennies. The dots are in shades of red, blue and raisin on a yellow ground. Other color combinations are available, with backgrounds of tan, blue, green, pink, burgundy or navy. The ties cost $27.50 at Paul Stuart, Madison Avenue at 45th Street. 2. Botany Plus Zoology Let your indoor plant go wild in this spotted planter in the shape of a fanged leopard on the prowl. The planter is hand-crafted in Italy and costs $96. It is part of a collection that includes matching lamps, boxes, bowls and figurines. At Villas Boas, 74 Grand Street (Wooster Street). 3. Tropical Inspiration For warm-weather entertaining, favorite recipes can be served on this tropics-inspired buffet plate. Made in Italy, the plate is white, with a border of palm trees. The price is $42. A matching mug, salad plate and regular-size dinner plate are also available. On the seventh floor at Bergdorf Goodman, Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. 4. Plain but Elegant Richard Meier has put his architectural imprint on this silver-plated bowl, designing it with a dramatic combination of elegance and simplicity. The bowl is perfectly plain, except for tiny perforations around the rim. For $250 at Conran's in the Citicorp Center, 160 East 54th Street.

title: CHEMICAL WASTE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A SPORT OF NATURE. By Nadine Gordimer. 341 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: NEW RULES ON PIZZA REJECTED
description: The Agriculture Department has rejected a 1983 proposal to require frozen meat pizzas to have a certain amount of cheese.

title: ARSON DAMAGES DISPUTED FOSTER HOME IN QUEENS
description: A small house in Queens where the Koch administration had planned, in the face of sharp community opposition, to provide care for six foster-care infants was damaged by arson Monday night, the authorities said yesterday.

title: GOVERNOR STUMPS TEXAS IN FUND RIFT
description: Gov. Bill Clements of Texas brought his antitax message here today as part of an unusual 17-city tour that is putting him on a collision course with the State Legislature as Texas tries to deal with one of the most difficult budget sessions in its history.

title: MOSCOW LETS WOULD-BE EMIGRE GIVE RECITAL
description: Vladimir Feltsman today played his first recital here since 1978 to jubilant applause. But the pianist hopes it was his Soviet farewell appearance.

title: First Boston's Net Up 8.5%
description: First Boston Inc., aided by profits from a huge merchant banking transaction, yesterday reported that its first-quarter net income rose 8.5 percent, to $76.2 million, from $70.2 million the year earlier.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $138,318 from the sale of Los Angeles Daily News and a $3,618,000 gain from the sale of other assets.

title: Cost Reductions Lift Unisys
description: The Unisys Corporation reported yesterday that cost savings had resulted in improved earnings in the first quarter.

title: PITINO READY TO LISTEN
description: In the hours before the Knicks dismissed Scotty Stirling and Bob Hill Monday, Rick Pitino said that coaching such a woeful team would not be considered an attractive job by any casual observer. But Pitino, whose surprising success at Providence College has made him the front-runner for a Knick job, said his interest was more than casual.

title: Budget Deficit In U.S. Lower
description: The Government said today that its March budget deficit was $28.01 billion, down from $30.14 billion in March a year ago. The deficit in February this year was $28.37 billion.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time after-tax charge of $20 million from the restructuring of distribution operations by the Sears merchandise group.

title: ARISTECH CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was spun off last year by USX Corp.

title: Problems Foreseen in Talks
description: It is still too early to call it an impasse, but with the National Basketball Association and its players union far apart on the key issues after their first two collective bargaining sessions, there are signs of impending problems.

title: 105 SRI LANKANS DIE AS BOMB RIPS INTO BUS STATION
description: A powerful bomb ripped apart the main bus station at rush hour Tuesday night, scattering shattered bodies and the bloodied fragments of vans and buses across more than a hundred square yards of a busy bazaar.

title: About New York; Punk Poodles And Dog Gossip: Mel's Kingdom
description: ''I'm sorry,'' the receptionist said to the caller, saying what all good receptionists say: ''Mr. Davis is busy at the moment. No, Mr. Davis is not in conference. He's washing a cat.''

title: AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect early adoption of FAS 87 in June 1986.

title: WEAK DOLLAR ADDS TO MILITARY COSTS
description: The swift drop in the value of the dollar has added heavily to the cost of operating United States military forces abroad, senior officials in the Defense Department say.

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hospital Corp. Bid Is Dropped
description: The HCA Acquisition Company, the concern formed to purchase the Hospital Corporation of America, said today that it had dropped its $3.8 billion all-cash offer for the company.

title: U.S. WORKERS STAY IN LIBYA DESPITE BAN
description: An American oil executive, sitting in an office decorated with a portrait of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said he enjoyed doing business here and had no qualms about violating President Reagan's order banning Americans from working in Libya.

title: DART GROUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $1,553,000 for the quarter and $5,258,000 for the year. The company said the increases for the latest periods are primarily due to the consolidation of Crown Books Corp. and Trak Auto West Inc. in the current year; Dart's ownership in Crown Books was increased to 52 percent and ownership in Trak Auto was increased to 100 percent.

title: DANCE: AT THE JOYCE, JENNIFER MULLER TROUPE
description: IT is said that we live in an age of anxiety. That may be unfortunate for ordinary mortals -but not necessarily for choreographers, for depicting anxious people in action allows them to explore many types of grotesque movement. The latest choreographer to make such an exploration is Jennifer Muller, whose ''Interrupted River'' was one of two world premieres offered last night by her company Jennifer Muller/The Works at the Joyce Theater.

title: MANY LAWMAKERS BACK MISSILE PLAN
description: As Congress and the White House returned to work today from Easter vacation, lawmakers from both parties expressed support for a proposal the Soviet Union made during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit last week to eliminate short- and medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: SOME BONN AIDES WANT A TREATY TO RETAIN WIDE ARRAY OF MISSILES
description: Senior figures in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party have started to discuss expanding the kinds of missiles that would be kept in West Germany under any Soviet-American agreements on limiting nuclear arms in Europe.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Great National Pastime

title: FOR THE OWNERS OF CHANTERELLE, SUCCESS WITHOUT CELEBRITY
description: DAVID WALTUCK'S description of his adolescence in the Bronx sounds like a scene from a Woody Allen movie. There he was at the family dinner table, faced with his mother's ''not very inspired'' steaks and potatoes and occasional matzoh balls, and all the while his mind was filled with stories he had been reading about the legendary chefs and great restaurants of France. While his friends were collecting stamps or shooting basketballs, David was in the kitchen whipping up souffles and other classical French dishes.

title: MUSEUM SAYS EX-CHIEF SOLD OFF 30 RARE LETTERS
description: A museum of rare books and manuscripts in Philadelphia has charged in a civil suit that its former director illegally removed up to 30 rare and historically important letters worth about $250,000 from the museum's archives and sold them to a private autograph dealer.

title: FILM: 'PADRE NUESTRO'
description: BENEATH the austere compositions of ''Padre Nuestro'' beats an operatic heart. The eccentric, alluring Spanish movie, which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street, begins in the Vatican with a witty and humane conversation between the down-to-earth Pope, who is rather possessive about his connections to heaven, and an important cardinal who has learned he has less than a year to live. The no-nonsense faith they share runs through all that follows.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results reflect the previously announced $53 million after-tax charge resulting from the placement of $3.8 billion of loans to Brazil on non-accrual status.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Former Official Recovering
description: Arthur F. Burns, the 82-year-old former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and former Ambassador to West Germany, was reported in stable condition at the Johns Hopkins Hospital today after undergoing triple bypass heart surgery. Hospital officials declined to discuss his condition at the request of family members.

title: Fred Silverman, President Of Bronx-Lebanon Hospital
description: Fred Silverman, the president of Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, died of a heart attack Thursday while vacationing in Stratton, Vt. He was 52 years old and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: ARTHUR O. CHOATE Jr.
description: Arthur Osgood Choate Jr., a retired general partner and executive committee chairman of Clark Dodge & Company, investment bankers, died Sunday at Jupiter Hospital in Jupiter, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Hobe Sound, Fla., and Manhattan.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Municipal Authorities Postponing Bond Sales
description: Local government officials around the country are appalled by the recent sharp rise in tax-exempt bond yields, and in many cases they are delaying bond sales until conditions become more favorable.

title: A MAINE MILKMAN WHO'LL FEED THE CAT OR REPLACE A FUSE
description: BOB GARLAND guides a blue pickup with a wooden milk rack along the early-morning streets of this blue-collar town of 2,250 in central Maine. He has taken the route thousands of times for nearly 50 years and is a fixture here, almost as much a part of the landscape as the Kennebec River or the paper mill.

title: KEY RATES
BIOTECH'S GROWTH IN EUROPE
description: THE demand in Europe for research equipment and products in genetic engineering is surging, and many American companies, bolstered by a weak dollar and a technological headstart, are aggressively marketing their wares in Europe.

title: PLAYED MR. GREEN JEANS ON TV
description: Hugh Brannum, who charmed millions of children as Mr. Green Jeans on the ''Captain Kangaroo'' television show, died Sunday at Pocono Hospital in East Stroudsburg, Pa. He was 77 years old and lived in Saylorsburg, Pa.

title: FANNIE MAE TO SELL NEW SECURITIES
description: The Reagan Administration today permitted Fannie Mae to begin underwriting a new kind of mortgage-backed security but put the agency on notice that it must move swiftly toward complete privatization.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter has been restated to reflect the previously reported adoption in 1986 of FAS No. 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions.

title: U.S. BOND PRICES END HIGHER
description: Treasury bond prices gyrated wildly yesterday, falling sharply early in the day but recovering during the afternoon to end the day with modest gains.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SALAD AND SEURAT: SAMPLING THE FARE AT THE MUSEUMS
description: RECALLING his battle ennui during World War II, the journalist A. J. Liebling described his thoughts at the front in The New Yorker:

title: CHARLES BRINCKERHOFF
description: Charles M. Brinckerhoff, a former president, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Anaconda Company, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 200-MILLION AGENT ORANGE AWARD IS UPHELD BY U.S. APPEALS COURT
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed most of a complex plan to distribute more than $200 million among 250,000 Vietnam veterans and their families who filed claims for injuries from the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: U.S. ACTS TO LIMIT USE OF COKE OVENS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed rules requiring iron and steel companies to reduce air pollution from their coke ovens, saying the pollution could cause cancer.

title: 2 SMUGGLERS ARE SAVED BY CROWD IN BAHAMAS
description: A United States-Bahamian drug task force chasing suspected marijuana smugglers was attacked by a crowd of more than 100 on a beach in the Bahamas, a United States Customs official said today.

title: PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brooks Offer Reported
description: The Minnesota North Stars have reportedly offered Herb Brooks the posts of coach and assistant general manager. Brooks, according to a source familiar with the negotiations, met with the Stars' owners, George and Gordon Gund, and General Manager Lou Nanne in New York yesterday. No agreement was reached. Brooks, most recently the coach at St. Cloud State, is said to want a one-year contract that includes a percentage of attendance receipts. The team is said to be offering a two-year pact with a bonus for a division title. Brooks, 48, led the United States team to a gold medal at the 1980 Olympics and later coached the Rangers.

title: AMOCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRESIDENTIAL MEDALS AWARDED
description: President Reagan has chosen the late actor Danny Kaye and the late composer Meredith Willson as recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the White House announced today.

title: RIVER FOREST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEALTH MANAGEMENT ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Meese Weighs Visa Response
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d agreed today to investigate possible antitrust violations by Visa in its response to the American Express Company's plan to introduce a revolving-credit card that would compete with Visa's bank credit cards.

title: Give Smoking Addicts Treatment and Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Lack Trade Bait
description: Because of their huge number of injured players, the Jets do not have enough bait to trade for a higher choice in next week's college draft, the team's player personnel director said yesterday. So the Jets probably will not choose until the 21st pick. Mike Hickey, who runs the team's draft, explained that ''injuries are a factor in trades and we have too many injured players.'' As a result, he expects the Jets to draft from a second rank of about a dozen players.

title: JORGENSEN, EARLE M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.3 million, or 36 cents a share, from the reduction of LIFO inventory quantities carried at lower costs in prevailing prior years.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: War-Crime Suspect Arrives

title: JUSTICES SEEM TO WIDEN DEATH PENALTY
description: In a decision that may lead to much wider use of the death penalty, the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that some accomplices in crimes leading to death may be executed even if they did not personally kill or intend to kill.

title: Take Yes for an Answer on Missiles
description: Not a chance! That's what Western experts said about President Reagan's 1981 proposal to eliminate all medium-range missiles in Europe. Too one-sided, they scoffed; Moscow would never accept it. The Russians would have to destroy 1,300 SS-20 warheads compared with 300 for the United States.

title: Xerox Net Falls As Sales Rise
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter net income slipped 5.6 percent, although sales increased 17.3 percent. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., said that net income in the latest three months slipped to $135 million, or $1.25 a share, from $143 million, or $1.35 a share, a year earlier. Revenue advanced to $3.33 billion, from $2.84 billion.

title: Japan Hunts for 'Science'
description: Japan recently announced the end to five decades of commercial whaling. Yet now it plans to send its whaling fleet to the Antarctic - through a giant loophole in the whaling treaty.

title: Resignation at Wachovia
description: Thomas Williams will leave his post as chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation, one of the South's leading regional banks, on April 30 to form a private investing company. Mr. Williams, who oversaw the merger of First Atlanta and First Wachovia in December 1985 to form a bank with assets of $18.7 billion, said today that he had accomplished his objectives. John Medlin, the current chairman of the Wachovia Corporation and the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company, will become chairman of First Wachovia and the First Atlanta holding company.

title: Japan Trading Inquiry
description: The nation's two largest futures exchanges said they were studying the possibility of improper trading practices by some Japanese brokerage houses. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said it had been aware of questionable practices ''for some time.'' The investigations center on whether Japanese brokers have used private, noncompetitive trading to reduce margins, the amount of money they are required to set aside to cover potential losses from trading.

title: NO 'PROSECUTING' ROLE, ETHICS PANEL CHIEF SAYS
description: The new chairman of Governor Cuomo's ethics commission stressed yesterday that the panel was ''not a prosecuting agency'' and that it had no jurisdiction to investigate the official affairs of the Legislature.

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After equity in earnings of affiliates of $14,372,000 for the latest quarter and $10,455,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In a terrorist war, a few fellows can still do a lot of harm.'' - Lalith Athulathmudali, Sri Lanka's Minister of National Security. [ A6:6. ]

title: A Monthly Magazine Of Finance
description: THE team that brought you Venture, the Magazine for Entrepreneurs, in 1979 is preparing to strike again.

title: Bally to Sell Six Flags Parks
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Six Flags theme park subsidiary to the Wesray Capital Corporation for $350 million in cash and the assumption of $250 million in debt.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter includes a gain of $90,500,000 from the sale of th Himont Inc. affiliate and a one-time charge of $6,100,000 for various unspecified items.

title: PRISONS BEING OPENED FOR DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: Two wood-shingled barracks, used since World War II by National Guard trainees, are being converted into a temporary prison for drunken drivers here as part of Connecticut's battle against prison overcrowding.

title: PROJECT WOULD EXTEND OFFICE TOWERS TO NINTH AVENUE
description: A subsidiary of Lazard Freres & Company is seeking approval from New York City to build a 32-story office tower at Ninth Avenue at 33d Street.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said consolidated operating results for the latest quarter are not comparable to the year-ago first quarter. Net sales and earnings were adversely affected by the Palm and Easter weeks selling periods, which occurred in the second quarter of 1987 versus the first quarter of 1986. In addition, the latest quarter had one less selling day than the year-ago first quarter.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 28 cents a share from a favorable tax court decision and the sale of a biotechnology investment and a gain equal to 4 cents a share related to a change in the method of determining pension expense.

title: IN CLEVELAND, A SAVORY MICROCOSM OF TRUE SLOVENIAN CUISINE
description: In the post-Easter lull, Azman & Sons Market is once again turning out 500 pounds of sausage a week, shipping some of the freshly stuffed garlicky klobase to transplanted Clevelanders with gastronomic yearnings. Around town, youngsters are polishing off what is left of the 240 nut rolls called poticas (and pronounced po-TEE-tsas) prepared by an assembly line of women for the Easter season.

title: MEXICO TO BAN SALE OF BLOOD
description: The Mexican Government announced today that it would prohibit all commercial dealings in blood and blood byproducts, saying the rapid spread of AIDS among the Mexican population made the measure ''urgent and imperative.''

title: One More Time: A Torch Relay
description: The swelling emotions that attended the carrying of the Olympic torch on a 9,000-mile route through 33 states three years ago have since spawned other torch relays and similar symbolic athletic efforts, including last year's First Peace Run to mark the United Nations' International Year of Peace.

title: NASA WILL DELAY '88 SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: The space agency said today that it was delaying for several weeks the first launching of a space shuttle since the Challenger explosion because it was adding two major tests to the schedule.

title: SOME RADIO HOSTS FLOUT F.C.C. OBSCENITY RULING
description: The effect of the Federal Communications Commission's warning last week that it would no longer turn a deaf ear to what it defines as obscenity on the airwaves can be seen in radio- and television-station board rooms, where executives are re-examining obscenity policy, and can be measured at the F.C.C. switchboard, which is receiving scores of calls from stations asking for clarification of the sweeping decision.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter results benefited from income of $9 million from a rights offering by Mim Holdings Ltd. and a $3.6 million recovering of costs from and reduction of Asarco's interest in the Wiluna Gold project in Australia.

title: PANEL TO SEEK FINANCING FOR SCHOOL RENOVATIONS
description: Citing continuing physical deterioration and overcrowding of New York City's public schools, the Board of Education named a task force yesterday to seek ways to help pay for its 10-year, $4.5 billion improvement plan.

title: Like Others in the Past, Deaver Says Fair Trial Isn't Possible in Capital
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide indicted on perjury charges, does not want to go on trial in the city of Washington.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CUTTING A RULE, NOT FROGS
description: Many high school students would like to avoid dissecting frogs in biology class, but not many are prepared to make a Federal case of it.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Restated to reflect a change in pension accounting. The company said the year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect the company's recapitalization.

title: HELPING THE RICH BUY ART
description: Estelle Schwartz is an art adviser, although she prefers to describe her business as ''aggressive, prescient art collecting.'' Which is to say, she buys modestly priced works, mostly by young artists who she believes will one day be famous, making their works more valuable.

title: The Bronx Coo
description: New York City has tunnels, bridges, highways, cars, subways, buses and ferries. Theaters, movies, museums, opera companies, dance companies and clubs ranging from the intime to the ridiculous. Small wildlife: rats, roaches, squirrels and a sky's worth of pigeons. Big wildlife: lions, tigers and elephants. But for the last 36 years it hasn't had a panda.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IT was not until my last year in college that students could live in a coeducational dorm.

title: DOW SOARS 66.47 POINTS, TO 2,337.07
description: Wall Street suddenly shook off a bad case of nerves about interest rates and inflation yesterday, and stock prices rallied so powerfully that the Dow Jones industrial average nearly equaled its best point gain ever.

title: UNISYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was formed in September in the merger of Burroughs and Sperry corporations. In the year- ago quarter, the acquiring company, Burroughs, reported net income of $16 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenue of $1.14 billion. Year-ago first quarter net is after a charge of $2.5 million, or 5 cents a share, from the restructuring of certain operations.

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hart Loses Credit Ace
description: Gary Hart has lost his top fund-raiser, Michael Novelli, with $1.3 million still outstanding from the 1984 Hart Presidential campaign.

title: Listening to Jackson
description: If you think Jesse Jackson is just the ''black candidate'' for President, maybe you'd better think again - and listen.

title: EMBASSY SECRUITY: PROBLEMS EXIST FOR U.S. AROUND THE WORLD
description: Some of the security problems that have arisen at the American Embassy in Moscow are present in a number of other American missions around the world, according to Administration officials, intelligence experts and current and former American ambassadors.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER'S NEW 'BEAUTY'
description: THE death of Antony Tudor, choreographer emeritus of American Ballet Theater and one of its founding members, could not but affect the company's opening Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Nonetheless, the show did go on - in the form of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's lavish, unusually lyrical new production of ''The Sleeping Beauty.''

title: SENATE VOTES FAIRNESS BILL
description: The Senate approved a bill today that would write into law a policy requiring broadcasters to cover controversial issues and present opposing views.

title: FANS PAYING PRICE FOR YANK TELECASTS
description: The word around town, to paraphrase a beer commercial, is SportsChannel. It's a word that's making some people unhappy.

title: Indoor Bounce For Football
description: Pro football of a peculiar sort will be played indoors this summer in the Washington, Denver, Pittsburgh and Chicago areas. The sites to be used are the Horizon in Rosemont, Ill.; McNichols Arena in Denver, Civic Arena in Pittsburgh, and Capital Centre in Landover, Md.

title: Occidental to Sell Pipeline Company
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had agreed to sell its United Gas Pipe Line Company, which has 9,800 miles of pipeline and assets of $1.2 billion, to the LaSalle Energy Corporation. Occidental said the sale would be a stock transaction but did not give any details. Roy H. Bettis, chairman and chief executive of LaSalle, said the Dallas-based company was formed for the purpose of buying United Gas, but he declined to discuss the deal until it closes on June 30.

title: ECOLAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Predictions From Iowa
description: The morning line from Iowa looks grim for Mr. Hart, but that could be misleading. A lot of campaigning is left before the Presidential caucuses there next February. But Bonnie Campbell, chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, who was in town this week, the best-organized candidate in Iowa is Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona. ''Babbitt has been better for longer,'' she said.

title: Economic Scene; On Mutual Deterrence
description: WITH conflicts raging over trade and protectionism, currency instability, third-world debt and the means of checking inflation and recession, international relations have been severely strained and financial markets have turned nervous and apprehensive.

title: EXCHANGE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $73,000.

title: SINGLE ROOMS FROM DIOCESE AID HOUSING
description: After separating from her husband almost two years ago, Lillian Olivencia had no place to call her own. She could not afford an apartment, so she moved into her daughter's apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, sharing three cramped rooms with her daughter and two grandchildren.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday, with an article about weakness in the outlook for capital spending, mislabeled two components. The chart, showing fixed investment in the nation, depicted structures, the smaller part, and producers' durable equipment, the larger part.

title: METS STILL SPUTTERING, BUT END SLIDE, 9-6
description: In their latest adventure, the Mets threw two home-run pitches in the same inning tonight for the third time in two games. They blew most of a five-run lead in the eighth. And they hit into a triple play in the ninth.

title: BAY VIEW FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in May 1986.

title: Regulate the Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PLAYING SCARED INSPIRES HRUDEY
description: On the afternoon that he was to become, for the second time in his four-year career with the Islanders, their starting goalie in a Patrick Division championship series, Kelly Hrudey experienced the same daydream that precedes all his ritual game-day naps.

title: EASYGOING ISLE, AN UNEASY MATCH WITH MAINLAND
description: The people of this tropical island of cloves and intrigue are more than laid-back.

title: 9-YEAR-OLD NIGERIAN IS FOUND AT KENNEDY WITH HEROIN CACHE
description: A 9-year-old boy from Nigeria, arriving alone at Kennedy International Airport, was discovered carrying three pounds of heroin hidden in a small trunk, and Federal authorities expressed concern yesterday that overseas drug rings might now be using young children to smuggle narcotics into this country.

title: ISLAND OF PINK TULIPS TO BLOSSOM ON PARK AVENUE
description: Mary Lasker looked over Park Avenue one day and thought it might be nice if, come springtime, the malls bloomed with pink tulips.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF A VEGETARIAN FAMILY
description: A FEW years ago, my husband became a vegetarian. This confused our son, then a first grader, who burst into the kitchen to tell me the news.

title: NATO Maneuvers in Turkey
description: Troops from seven NATO countries will conduct maneuvers in eastern Turkey during June, NATO's Supreme Allied Headquarters in Europe announced today. The maneuvers, named Aurora Express, will test the ability of NATO's Allied Mobile Force to deploy rapidly.

title: Breakthrough
description: Shelley Verses, a 26-year-old native of Stamford, Conn., has become a soigneur for a French professional bicycling team. And if the job description sounds a bit demeaning -soigneurs must truck baggage for the riders, offer them first aid, prepare and deliver their sandwiches and high-energy food during races, ease their way at hotels and give them massages - Verses has no complaints. When she took up her duties with the 25-rider Toshiba team recently, she became the first full-time female soigneur ever hired by a team of European cyclists.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Strikes in Yugoslavia
description: A new wave of strikes has broken out a month after a partial pay freeze touched off industrial unrest, press reports and factory officials indicated today. The Tanyug press agency reported strikes at two of the nation's largest industrial enterprises - Smederevo, the iron and steel center with a work force of 10,000, and a rolling stock plant in Kraljevo that employs 4,500.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings for the first quarter of 1986 include results of Louisiana Coca-Cola Bottling Co., which was acquired in February 1986 and consolidated as of Jan. 1, 1986. The company also said first quarter 1987 results differ substantially from the actual results for 1986 due primarily to the effect of bottling company acquisitions made in the latter half of 1986. The company said on a pro forma basis, 1986 net income for the first quarter was $15,000, based on revenue of $692,648,000. In the opinion of management, pro forma first quarter 1986 results - which present the operating results of Coca-Cola Enterprises as if the acquisitions made in 1986 had been completed at the beginning of that year - provide a more comparable basis for evaluating 1987 results.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHAT'S up? Breakfast eating, that's what. After a decades-long decline in the proportion of Americans who regularly eat breakfast, newly released data indicate that the trend might have reversed.

title: Savagery on the Subcontinent
description: The killing of Sinhalese men, women and children by militant Tamils in Sri Lanka has virtually coincided with the slaying of Hindus by radical Sikhs in India's troubled Punjab state. These recent incidents, perpetrated by youths with a dark vision of the future, have severely shaken the philosophical self-image of the Subcontinent as a nursery of nonviolence and passive resistance. While today's threat in both nations is to communal harmony, further casualties may well be long-term economic progress, the nurturing of democracy and the ethic of moderation and tolerance.

title: RECITAL: KIRKPATRICK SINGS
description: IN Weill Recital Hall Monday night, Elizabeth Kirkpatrick gave a recital devoted to the conservative American art-song tradition. It is a genre largely underappreciated, partly because some proponents overrate it, but more fundamentally because it is out of tune with the times. Several generations of American composers in this century set out to do what Europeans had already done and (for the most part) quit doing - namely, to supply large amounts of lyric poetry with music for voice and piano, to be sung comprehensively to a comprehending audience.

A Question of Values
description: To The Home Section:

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Afraid of Babies in Queens
description: The suspicious fire at a prospective foster care home in Queens inspires astonishment. People in Fresh Meadows, transcending the usual grumbles of other neighborhoods, oppose providing even the most elemental social services in their community. What is there to fear from a half-dozen infants? New York City urgently needs decent care for increasing numbers of abandoned, abused and neglected children. Some are infants, the boarder babies, who have languished for months in hospital cribs because of an acute shortage of foster homes. The city, criticized for being slow to find suitable homes, recently earned praise for progress. It includes putting some temporarily into group homes. The Human Resources Administration's plan to lease a family-sized house in Fresh Meadows was part of that effort. No more than six babies at a time would be placed in the house, all under age 2; the average stay would be three months. Who could possibly object? Fresh Meadows residents find reasons that make little sense: ''People . . . coming all kinds of hours; the mothers, people who work there changing shifts, people visiting.'' In fact the home would be no more disruptive than a large family or a neighborhood play group. The opposition sounds racist. City officials have tried to address even that mean irrationality. The babies are to be taken to a neutral site for visits - if any - with relatives or prospective foster parents. In any case, the city would open the home on a temporary lease, pending exhaustive review procedures that give community residents ample opportunity to voice their concerns.

The ensemble has undergone several personnel changes in the past few years; it now consists of Donald Weilerstein and Peter Salaff on violin, Atar Arad on viola and Paul Katz on cello. In the past, Cleveland performances have thrived on a certain kinetic friction: this listener cannot recall the group ever sounding so mature and so smoothly unified.

title: LEE BAILEY'S SPARE DESIGN RESURFACES
description: SINCE closing his shop at Henri Bendel, where he had been for 14 years, Lee Bailey has moved to Saks Fifth Avenue. Beginning next Monday he will once again offer a mix of streamlined houseware along with an occasional bottle of white truffle oil, for which he is famous. ''The shop will reflect my point of view, but not a category,'' said Mr. Bailey, left. ''I prefer the simplest, almost skeletal forms. I think china looks better when it is a blank, fresh out of the mold, than when it is decorated.'' In his 350-square-foot shop, cotton napkins of his own design, above, are $8; a stainless-steel wine cooler that holds two ice packs, above right, is $100, and cotton rag rug pillows, right, in white or pale gray, are $48. While most objects are for the home, there are also animal-shaped rubber rafts for children, sunglasses with tiny radios and chocolates that are only 20 calories each. ''If I like something, whether it is a book, toy or food, I try to sell it,'' Mr. Bailey said. ''This is a very personal shop.''

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LAKERS LOOK STRONG, AND CELTICS ARE GETTING THERE
description: With the 16-team National Basketball Association playoffs getting under way tonight, it would be easy to predict another championship matchup between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Boston Celtics. Not only did the Lakers of Magic Johnson, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and James Worthy win their sixth straight Pacific Division title, but their 65-17 record was best in the league. The Celtics, seeking to become the first team since 1969 to repeat as champion, had the best mark in the Eastern Conference and the second best in the league (59-23). So what's the problem? In an informal survey of general managers and coaches, they unanimously picked the Lakers in the West but did not favor the Celtics in the East with the same certainty.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Six black rail workers were killed and four police officers were seriously wounded in two clashes in South Africa, and 16,000 workers were dismissed for ignoring a deadline to end a strike. A4 Zoning plan threatens Savile Row A1 Argentina considers appeasing army A3 Peru's chief under fire as rebels gain A3 Palestinians harden policy A5 Eastern-bloc call for candor A8 Soviet press widens coverage A8 Warsaw accuses U.S. aide of spying A9 NATIONAL A16-24, B10-15 >Death penalties are constitutional even when statistics indicate race is a major factor in the decisions to impose them, the Supreme Court ruled in upholding Georgia's capital punishment law, 5 to 4. A1 Pessimism over Star Wars has reportedly been expressed by key physicists. They said so many breakthroughs are required that it will take a decade or more to determine whether the program can be carried out. A1 The bond market is suffering its worst beating in nearly three years as thousands of investors are selling their holdings out of fear that the plummeting dollar will revive inflation. A1 107,000 schools would be inspected for asbestos, and administrators would be required to remove the carcinogen under new rules proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency. A1 A jury convicted Joe Hunt of murder in the death of Ronald Levin of Beverly Hills, Calif. The panel deliberated only two days in the five-month trial of Mr. Hunt, the leader of a group called the Billionaire Boys Club. A16 The N.B.A. is expanding by four franchises. The owners of the 23 existing teams unexpectedly voted unanimously to award franchises to two Florida cities, Miami and Orlando, as well as to Charlotte, N.C., and Minneapolis. A1 Welfare payments could be halted to a family that received a lump-sum personal injury award, the Supreme Court ruled. The 5-4 decision involves a major Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependant Children. B11 The elderly fared far better than all other American population groups in their income gains in the first half of the 1980's, according to an analysis of Census Bureau statistics. C1 Report station dispute settled A6 Drug use declines in military A16 Families fear nuclear-waste test A16 F.A.A. to study controller errors A18 List of AIDS test-takers is lost A21 Researchers test Herpes vaccine A24 Panel denies waiver on Seabrook reactor A24 WASHINGTON TALK B10 The politics of arms control Police memorial unveiled REGIONAL B1-9 Residents are increasingly opposing New York City's attempts to open any centers residents fear would harm the character of their neighborhoods. Some officials call it a ''not in my backyard'' phenomenon. A1 Racial harassment occurred in a March 21 clash between several black and white students at Columbia College, according to administrators. They said they were disciplining an unnamed white student for verbal abuse. B2 A jail official upheld negotiations over force in defending correction officers' treatment of rebellious Rikers Island inmates last October. The official, Robert Kasanof, challenged a state report. B5 Governor Cuomo is endangering the independence of the New York State Public Service Commission by becoming directly involved in utility rate-making, the outgoing chairman of the panel charged. B1 Despite repeated flooding, residents of the Passaic and Pompton river plains are resisting government buyout offers. In a soaring real-estate market, sellers say they must leave the area for affordable housing. B1 The lynx will be reintroduced to New York by wildlife scientists about a century after it disappeared from the state. The scientists hope to establish a colony of about 70 of the shy, reclusive cats. B2 Inquiry clouding Goldin's future B1 Harlem River Houses still special B1 Special memories of the Dodgers B3 Two may shun ethics inquiry B3

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $605,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $220,000.

title: Chaney Is Dismissed
description: The Los Angeles Clippers dismissed their head coach, Don Chaney, yesterday. The team finished with the league's worst record, winning only 12 of 82 games. No team had done that badly since 1972-73, when the Philadelphia 76ers went 9-73 en route to becoming the worst team in National Basketball Association history. Chaney's record is 53-123 in just over three seasons as a head coach. Among those the Clippers intend to interview as a possible successor are John MacLeod, the former Phoenix coach, Hubie Brown ,former Knick coach, and Gene Shue, former Washington coach.

title: 15 RECEIVE JOURNALISM AWARD
description: The Scripps-Howard Foundation honored eight newspapers, three television stations, two radio stations and a cartoonist Tuesday at its National Journalism Awards banquet here.

title: GEPHARDT SEES TRADE COMPROMISE
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt said today that he is willing to compromise with the Senate on the amendment he will offer to the House trade bill next week. The decision increases the likelihood that some form of the provision would be included in a final bill.

title: Experimental Drug for AIDS Will Be Tested With Patients
description: Stanford University doctors will begin trials of an experimental AIDS drug on patients with the disease.

title: WELLS FARGO SHIFT
description: Shareholders of Wells Fargo & Company have approved the company's reincorporation in Delaware, where the law is more favorable on legal claims against corporate directors.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said Electronic Data Systems earnings are used to calculate the GM Class E common stock share earnings.

title: THREE MEN, THREE STYLES, ONE PARTNERSHIP
description: ''THE dialogue that goes on in our firm is the dialogue that goes on in the field of architecture,'' said Stephen Byrns, 32 years old, of Byrns, Kendall & Schieferdecker. He met his two partners, Harry Kendall, 33, and George Schieferdecker, 34, at the Columbia School of Architecture.

title: EVENTS: COLLECTIBLES AND WALKING TOURS
description: Antiques and Collectibles Show, field house at Rockland Community College, 145 College Road (New York State Thruway, exit 14B), Suffern, N.Y.; 914-356-4650.

title: JAPANESE MOVE INTO FOREIGN FUTURES
description: Japan's Ministry of Finance announced yesterday that for the first time it would permit domestic Japanese financial institutions to use foreign futures and options markets to hedge their investment portfolios, perhaps as early as next month.

title: EXPOS DOWN PHILS WITH 6 RUNS IN 6TH
description: A leadoff home run by Tim Wallach and a bases-loaded triple by Mitch Webster highlighted a six-run sixth inning as the Montreal Expos beat the Philadlephia Phillies, 7-3, today.

title: MILITARY TO HELP CIVILIANS ON AIDS WARNINGS
description: United States military officials have been ordered to help the health authorities around the world identify civilians exposed to AIDS by American military personnel, the Defense Department said today.

title: STAGE: 'THE MEETING'
description: DICK ANTHONY WILLIAMS and Felton Perry bring so much energy and passion to their roles as Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in ''The Meeting'' that they almost make this static play get up and move. And Taurean Blacque as Rashad, Malcolm X's bodyguard, is forceful enough to make one wish Jeff Stetson, the playwright, had not moved him offstage during the long confrontation between the two principals, which is the heart of the play.

title: 'THE BOMB FACTORIES' ON ABC
description: ''THE BOMB FACTORIES'' persuades us that nuclear-weapons plants have safety problems. It leaves us unclear, though, about the size, shape and nature of the risk. Some technical information in the ABC News documentary is difficult to absorb; some of its targets seem too easy. The documentary, on Channel 7 at 10 o'clock tomorrow night, is ambitious and smartly done, but occasionally its reporting grows confusing.

title: VAN DORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
7-to-21-Year Term In Death of Lover
description: A man who said he killed another man after they had sex because the partner told him he had AIDS was sentenced yesterday to seven to 21 years in prison.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Forgotten Prisoners
description: This is addressed to those many Americans who believe strongly that Mikhail Gorbachev is trying to lead his country into a new era of political and personal freedoms and that we should do what we can to support him.

title: Film Maker and Singer Win First Segal Awards
description: The first annual Martin E. Segal Awards - established to honor the chairman emeritus of Lincoln Center - were given yesterday to Anita Thacher, a film maker, and Karen Notare, a soprano.

title: 13 PRIZES AWARDED FOR MAGAZINE EXCELLENCE
description: Money magazine won a National Magazine Award yesterday for a report that investigated the failure of the not-for-profit blood industry to act quickly in testing to avoid collection and distribution of AIDS-contaminated blood.

title: A SECURE EMBASSY IS CALLED POSSIBLE
description: The State Department's top security official said today that the United States was able to ''neutralize'' any electronic listening devices that might have been placed in the new United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: US TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that results for 1986 have been restated for an accounting change, resulting in reduced pension costs of $1.3 million, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter.

title: Bond Traders Alter Tactics
description: CONFRONTED with large potential losses in their bond portfolios, investment professionals are trying to deal with the recent sharp rise in long-term interest rates.

title: COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $2,327,000 for the latest quarter and $1,528,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Nicholas M. Acquavella, 88, An Art Dealer in Manhattan
description: Nicholas M. Acquavella, a leading art dealer in Manhattan for a half-century and the founder of the Acquavella Galleries, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. He was 88 years old.

title: PHONE EXECUTIVE RISES TO CHIEF'S JOB AT ALLTEL
description: Joe T. Ford began his career in the telephone industry by selling ads in the Yellow Pages. Yesterday he was elected chief executive of the Alltel Corporation, a major telephone company.

title: F.A.A. REACTING TO MISTAKES, WILL STUDY CONTROLLER ERRORS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, reacting to a sharp increase in mistakes by air traffic controllers this year, today announced the formation of a group to study the operational errors.

title: Tate Gallery Seeking Funds to Buy Constable
description: The Tate Gallery has said it is making a ''desperate final appeal'' for funds to buy a major painting by John Constable.

title: KEY RATES
Ex-C.I.A. Aide Called a Principal in Iran Affair
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra inquiry said today that Thomas Clines, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, was a ''principal'' in his criminal investigation.

title: Michael and Jessica, You Have Company
description: Jessica, after six years of finishing second, finally made it to the top. Robert disappeared from the top 10 entirely. And Jonathan was third, with a bullet.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $934,000 which represents the company's approximately 11.5 percent equity share in the earnings of Piedmont Aviation Inc., from March 8, 1987, through the end of the month. c-Net loss and results are restated for FASB 87 pension accounting change.

title: Thiokol Denies Charge
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the space shuttle's solid rocket boosters, denied a charge yesterday from one of its former engineers that it had created a ''slush fund'' from Government payments intended to increase quality control in the company's rocket manufacturng plant.

title: Judge Acted Bravely in the Baby M Decision; Findings of Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: HEAD OF U.S. ARMS CONTROL AGENCY CRITICIZES SOVIET PROPOSAL
description: A senior Administration official criticized the latest Soviet position on short-range arms today as American and Russian negotiators prepared to open a new round of arms talks on medium-range missiles in Geneva.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A SHAPER OF MET'S JAPANESE GALLERIES
description: ''You can count the serious collectors of Japanese art in this country on one hand,'' said Barbara B. Ford, associate curator of Asian art at the Metropolitan Museum. ''It's pitiful how little interest in it there still is here. But I hope we're going to redress it.''

title: MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,383,000 for the latest quarter and $1,598,000 for the year-ago period.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MacNamara, Clapp Wins L'Amy Account
description: L'Amy, a French eyeglass-frame manufacturer, has chosen MacNamara, Clapp & Klein to handle its advertising in the United States. Three agencies, including one with a French affiliate, had participated in a two-month competition. The ad budget is $2 million.

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after non-recurring strike-related costs of $7 million.

title: In Alaska: Drill, but With Care
description: Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is an untouched and fragile place that supports rare mammals and myriad species of birds. It is also the most promising untapped source of oil in North America. Should America drill for it?

title: FAMILIES FEAR TEST ON NUCLEAR WASTE
description: When Dave and Annette Glynn moved into their new home in the Denver suburb of Westminster in February, they did not pay much attention to the large Federal facility across the road.

title: UNITED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Concerns on Dome Deal
description: As the Canadian Government reviews the proposed takeover of Dome Petroleum Ltd. by the Amoco Corporation of Chicago, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his Cabinet are said to be giving weight to the effect their decision could have on trade talks with the United States.

title: Giuliani Asks Congress to Define Insider Trading
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, asked Congress today to pass legislation that would define illegal insider trading, saying it would help him in prosecuting criminal cases.

title: Profits Rise at 3 G.M. Subsidiaries
description: Profits of the General Motors Corporation's three main subsidiaries increased in the first quarter, the companies reported today.

title: JEFFERSON BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A map on Tuesday showing Paul Revere's route, with a dispatch about a re-enactment of his ride, carried an incorrect scale. The length shown equaled four miles, not two.

title: Court Rules On Benefits
description: The Supreme Court today struck down a business accounting technique in a ruling that the Reagan Administration said could save the Government many millions of dollars.

title: AS INQUIRY CLOUDS POLITICAL FUTURE, GOLDIN PERSERVERES
description: Harrison Jacob Goldin's political future never looked brighter than it did at the start of 1987. All signs pointed to his finally making a bid for the elusive prize of the mayoralty of New York City.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago results include $27 million of tax credits and other non-operating gains. Results are in U.S. dollars.

description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $200,000 related to a defect in batteries supplied to U.S. Navy.

title: RUSSIANS EXTEND CALL FOR CANDOR TO TIES WITH BLOC
description: The call for candor that has been echoing through the Soviet Union was extended across its borders into a sensitive area this week in a speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: GAINSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $27,044 for the latest quarter and $49,422 for the year-earlier period.

title: THEATER: RICHARD KILEY IN MILLER'S 'ALL MY SONS'
description: IN an America rocked by inside traders on Wall Street, ethically blind managers in the space program and shredded documents in the National Security Council, no one can doubt the continued pertinence of ''All My Sons.'' Though four decades old, Arthur Miller's first Broadway success tells a story that really can be found in today's newspapers: The protagonist, a businessman named Joe Keller, stands accused of having covered up his role in manufacturing defective parts that doomed 21 Air Force planes in World War II. If anything, ''All My Sons'' may be too topical for its own theatrical good. Keller's selfish disregard for his responsibilities to society is a sad commonplace now. Even as a 1987 theatergoer admires Mr. Miller for fastening on an eternal issue, it's hard not to ask the weary, equally eternal, question, ''So what else is new?''

title: New Zealand Paper Sale
description: A publishing group partly owned by Rupert K. Murdoch will buy The Press, a leading New Zealand paper, to become the country's biggest media group. The purchase, announced Tuesday by Independent Newspapers Ltd. of Wellington, which is 40 percent owned by Murdoch's News Ltd., leaves only one independent major daily in New Zealand, The Otago Daily Times.

title: Quebec Defeats Montreal
description: Michel Goulet and Basil McRae scored 17 seconds apart early in the third period to end a scoreless duel, and the Quebec Nordiques held off a Montreal rally to beat the Canadiens, 2-1, tonight for a 2-0 lead in their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Taking Several For the Team
description: An apparent epidemic of wild pitching in collegiate baseball has been traced to an outbreak of wily batting. According to a survey by Collegiate Baseball, the official publication of the American Baseball Coaches Association, batters in unprecedented numbers are being hit by pitched balls this season, especially in California. Imbued with the ethic of ''taking one for the team,'' they've decided to take several instead.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of about $3.3 million from repurchase of debt and a tax credit of about $3 million. c-Includes a tax credit of $3,277,000.

Strauss to Leave HBM/Creamer
description: Hal Strauss, 55, having built up HBM/Creamer enough to make it attractive to a British buyer, has now resigned, intent on finding some partners so that he can build another agency group.

title: METS JUST HANG ON AFTER A 6-RUN LEAD
description: To put it bluntly, the Mets scored 23 runs in three games here, and needed every one because the Pirates were scoring 22. And, by that high-risk difference, the Mets won two of the three games.

title: STARS GET THEIR MAN
description: The former Ranger coach, Herb Brooks, has been offered the North Stars coaching job, according to a Minnesota team source familiar with the negotiations, and Brooks has apparently accepted. The team has scheduled a news conference for this afternoon, and although Joe Janasz of the North Stars' public relations department said he couldn't disclose the nature of the conference, he said: ''Expect something really big.''

Metro Matters; For Homeless, Struggles Include Getting to School
description: Nancy Gonzalez was boasting about her son's chosen profession yesterday as she waited, just after 7 A.M., with her own children and several dozen charges in front of the Prince George Hotel on East 28th Street for the bus to Public School 151 on East 91st.

title: Computer Cost Cut
description: The American Telephone and Tele-graph Company, responding to price cuts in the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer line, said it would reduce the prices of its PC's by up to 38 percent. The cuts affect the A.T.& T. PC 6300, the PC 6310 and the PC 6300 Plus computers. For example, a 6300 with 640,000 bytes of internal memory and two floppy disk drives would cost $1,565, down from $2,020.

title: 2d Rights Trial Opens In 1982 Beating Death
description: The 1982 beating death of a Chinese-American was a result of a confrontation between angry men, not of racial prejudice, a defense lawyer said in his opening argument today for an unemployed automobile worker who faces Federal civil rights charges in the death of Vincent Chin.

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $141,000.

title: 6 BLACK WORKERS REPORTED SLAIN AS PRETORIA MOVES TO CRUSH STRIKE
description: At least six black railway workers were reported shot and killed today in two clashes with the police, and 16,000 of their colleagues were dismissed for ignoring a deadline to end a strike.

description: b-After a tax credit of $526,000. c-Net loss and includes a gain of about $3.9 million from the sale of certain Brink's operations in Quebec. title: 'GUEST RELATIONS' BRINGS A NEW LOOK TO HOSPITALS
description: AS a flight attendant with Trans World Airlines, Janet DiNovis dispensed friendly smiles and conversation, along with instructions, snacks and beverages. Now she uses the same professional cordiality as a guest-relations manager at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

description: The trial of a suspended police officer accused of selling crack and marijuana in his Brooklyn precinct began yesterday with jury selection in State Supreme Court.

title: Sharif, York Will Star In Maidenform Ads
description: At a time when women's undergarment manufacturers are preparing TV advertising with live models for the first time, Maidenform Inc., which has had some of the most visually revealing lingerie advertising, will this summer unveil some of the least.

title: IN VAST WAREHOUSE, FAMILY CARVES OUT AN ELEGANT HOME
description: NOBODY would ever accuse the Toledanos, voracious collectors, of doing things in a small way. Ben C. Toledano, a lawyer with an ample girth and an appetite for modern Southern literature, buys four copies of every book by Walker Percy or Eudora Welty, one for each of the Toledanos' children. His wife, Roulhac - who has renovated homes in New Orleans, written about New Orleans architecture and now runs an antiques shop here - said that they ''just entertain hugely.''

title: OMNICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results include an after-tax charge of $698,000 related to the sale of Inspiron Hospital Products division and after-tax income of $1.2 million from contracts.

description: Dr. Robert J. Schnitzer, a specialist in chemotherapy and one of those who developed a principal drug used against tuberculosis, died yesterday at his home in Nutley, N.J. He was 92 years old.

description: Anna Maximilian Potok, a co-founder of Maximilian Furs, whose luxurious styles won her an international audience, died of heart failure yesterday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 89 years old.

title: Dog Is Rescued From Ledge
description: Park employees bent the rules to rescue a dog who fell 75 feet into a 200-foot gorge and was stranded, unhurt, on a ledge for 27 hours. The dog, named Oreo, was retrieved Tuesday morning from the gorge at Letchworth State Park, where officials do not usually try to rescue animals. Oreo, who belongs to Margaret Rambler of Castile and her 11-year-old son, Jason, was retrieved after a state park police officer and a park employee lowered themselves into the gorge by rope.

title: Federal Judges Are Found Not Gilty
description: In the past six years, more than 20 percent of the appointees to the major Federal courts have been millionaires. Two years earlier, during the Carter Administration, the figure was 5 percent. The dramatic difference between the Carter and Reagan appointees may be partly due to the different constituencies of the Democratic and Republican parties from which judicial candidates typically emerge. But that is not the whole story.

title: NEW FORM FOR NEWS ANALYSTS
description: ''THE JENNINGS/KOPPEL REPORT'' is something new: The anchor for ''World News Tonight'' and the interlocutor for ''Nightline'' sit on a stage and talk about issues. The issue tonight, on ABC at 10 o'clock, is Ronald Reagan. Where has he been, and where is he going? The bigger issue, though, is where is television going? Can two journalists, almost unaided, do an hour of prime time? The program is supposed to be the first of a series.

title: Ex-School Official Sentenced
description: A former deputy superintendent of the city's public school system was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for taking sexual liberties with students on the promise of better grades when he was the principal of their high school. Five students at Kelvyn Park High School said they had engaged in sex with the principal, James Moffat, in his office from 1982 to 1984 because he promised to help them with their grades. Mr. Moffat maintains he was victimized by students opposed to strict disciplinary measures he instituted at the school. His attorneys said they expected to appeal.

title: RJR NABISCO FILLS POST

The company had said in March that Mr. Sticht, who retired as chairman of the former R.J. Reynolds Industries in 1984, would replace J. Tylee Wilson. F. Ross Johnson, president and chief executive, follows Mr. Sticht as chairman of the executive committee of the board.

title: B.P. Stockholders Back Standard Bid

The vote took place at a special shareholders meeting. British Petroleum announced last month that it would offer $70 a share in cash for the 45 percent of Standard Oil that it does not already own. The offer closes April 28, unless extended.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE CANNA, OLD FAVORITE, RISES AGAIN
description: AMERICA'S long, if now somewhat cooled, love affair with cannas seems to have begun in 1777 in southern Louisiana, when William Bartram, the noted botanist and plant explorer from Philadelphia, first spotted the native species he called Canna indica (actually Canna flacida). In his ''Travels,'' published in London in 1792 and reprinted in a handsome facsimile edition in 1980 by the University of Virginia Press, Bartram described his hardships - the clouds of biting mosquitoes, the alligators - but then he writes glowingly about the cannas he found ''in surprising luxuriance, presenting a glorious show; the stem rises six, seven and nine feet tall, terminating upwards with spikes of scarlet flowers.''

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $108,999,000 and $85,522,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, on the sale of loans and mortgage backed securities. c-Includes a tax loss carryforward credit of $17,667,000, or 47 cents a share. The company said the year-earlier first quarter net was comprised of operating income of $31,421,000, or 74 cents a share. The company also said it made an additional provision of $79.8 million to its reserve for loan losses on loans and real estated, thus raising the reserve to a total of $854 million at March 31.

COMMUNITY BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: CATS ARE NOW NO. 1 IN PET POPULARITY
description: LEAD: THERE'S bad news for Bowser: the cat has emerged as our new best friend. For the first time, there are more cats than dogs in homes around the country; 56.2 million of them, surpassing the number of dogs by almost 5 million, according to MRCA Information Services, a market research company in Stamford,

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mattingly's Laboratory
description: Don Mattingly is nearly himself again. With only 1 hit in his first 16 times at bat this season, he had been struggling at .063. Worse, he was lunging at pitches, as off-balance as a tightrope walker about to fall. He even struck out three times in one game; he struck out only 35 times all last season. But when the Yankees open a 12-game road trip in Cleveland tonight, the Yankee first baseman will be batting .242. He has five doubles, a triple and two home runs. He has driven in 15 runs.

Quinlan gave Ruiz a six-month suspended sentence and ordered him to pay $500 to a court operating fund. title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Edberg Upset: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeded second, was upset by a countryman, Ulf Stenlund, yesterday, 2-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the second round of the $513,000 Monte Carlo Open. Edberg followed top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany and the defending champion, Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, to the sidelines. Stenlund, a 20-year-old ranked 32d in the world, is making a name for himself on clay. Last year, in his first French Open, he made the round of 16 before losing. (AP) Navratilova Gains: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova had four first-set aces on the way to a 6-3, 6-4 second-round victory over Laura Gildemeister of Peru in the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston. Navratilova will next face Lori McNeil, who advanced when Andrea Jaeger withdrew because of bursitis in her right shoulder. Third-seeded Chris Evert broke Marianna Perez-Roldan's serve five times in route to a 6-2, 6-1 victory over the 19-year-old Argentine. Second-seeded Hana Mandlikova and fouth-seeded Zina Garrison also advanced. (AP) Polo Mexico Defeats Australia: Mexico beat Australia, 11-5, in Buenos Aires to set up a deciding match Saturday with Argentina for the World Polo Cup title. Argentina leads with 6 points from three games, followed by Mexico with 5 from three games. Brazil has 2 points, Spain 1 and Australia none.(AP) Decathlon Masgay and Mann Win: Dave Masgay, a Penn State senior from Forty Fort, Pa., won the javelin throw and tied for first in the pole vault yesterday in winning the decathlon of the 93d annual Penn Relays at Franklin Field in Philadelphia. Masgay finished at 7,282 points, 139 ahead of Knut Gundersen of Mount St. Mary's College in Maryland. Barry Walsh, a Penn State freshman from Limerick, Ireland, finished third with 7,051. A University of Florida senior, Heidi Mann, set a meet record in winning the heptathlon. Mann, of Glens Falls, N.Y, finished with 5,580 points, surpassing the mark of 5,538 set by Tracy Hanlon of Army in 1984. Mann finished 378 points ahead ofPam Connell of Penn State. (AP)

title: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Q&A
description: Q. Our bathrooom tiles were painted blue by the previous owner. The original tiles were white and, although old, seem in good shape. The blue paint is chipping off where it gets wet, and we want to remove it all. Are we better off using a paste paint remover or a heat gun? A. I favor a semipaste remover that is water washable and nonflammable. A heat gun might cause tiles to crack or harm the grout or the cement that holds the tiles in place. A remover may be more expensive, but it is usually faster. Lay it on in thick layers over a few square feet at a time. Give it time to soften all the old paint, then scrub with a stiff brush and detergent solution. Q. I recently put a layer of unfaced insulation over 25-year-old insulation in my attic. The paper vapor barrier on the old insulation has deteriorated, and now the new insulation shows signs of condensation on its surface. I don't want to put down a new vapor barrier. Is there a paint that I can apply to the ceilings below to keep moisture out of the attic? A. Yes, some paints will act as vapor barriers. One nationally sold latex type is Glidden's Insul-Aid. Other products that will work as vapor barriers are shellac-based sealers like B-I-N and Enamelac (both can be thinned with alcohol). Most high-gloss alkyd enamels (not latex) also act as vapor barriers. Q. Our house is in an area with a high water table. The previous owner installed perforated drainpipes in a ditch around the interior perimeter of the basement and connected these to a sump. However, the water-collecting trench at the base of the walls is always wet, sometimes overflowing and flooding the floor. I have read that it is best to install these drain lines in an excavation around the outside footing. But waterproofing contractors I have called in merely want to replace the existing system. Who is right? A. There is no definite right or wrong. In most cases digging around the outside is best, if the job is done right. However, this is a lot more expensive than interior installation. And in 9 cases out of 10, installing the drains on the inside works almost as well - again, if the job is done right, which it seems yours was not. The drainpipes are not large enough or were not put deep enough, or the angle of slope toward the sump may not be steep enough. If a knowledgeable contractor rebuilds the system properly, I think this should do the trick.
