description: For the previous five innings on a cold and windy night at Comiskey Park, the White Sox fans had been celebrating the anticipated end of the longest winning streak at the start of a season in the history of the American League. The fans had been singing since the third inning as the Milwaukee Brewers, in search of a 14th consecutive victory, fell five runs behind. Now it was the eighth, and the score was 7-1, and Chicago's leadoff batter had tripled, and Milwaukee's Tom Trebelhorn, in his first full season as a major league manager, strolled toward the mound. As the manager motioned toward center field, he was demonstrating that his workday was not yet done.

title: Victories Stripped
description: The executive council of the International Ice Hockey Federation voted, 8-3, in an emergency meeting yesterday to strip West Germany of its two victories, over Canada and Finland, for using an ineligible player in the world hockey championships in Vienna. The player, Miroslav Sikora, 29 years old, has been suspended indefinitely.

title: Iran Gives American 10-Year Sentence for Spying
description: Iran has sentenced an American engineer to 10 years in prison, saying he had spied for the Central Intelligence Agency, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

title: A Good Marriage
description: To The Home Section:

title: 2 EHTICS PANEL OFFICIALS MAY SHUN INQUIRY ROLE
description: The two top officials of the statewide ethics commission established by Governor Cuomo said yesterday that they were unlikely to participate in the panel's investigation because they were troubled by the resignation of the former head of the commission, Joseph A. Califano Jr. Two other leading figures have left the commission staff, leaving it now with two lawyers and three secretaries, according to members of the commission.

title: CITYFED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted. The net income includes a non- recurring item in the form of a $2.5 million after-tax benefit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change relating to the earlier termination of a pension plan. The net also includes a gain of $1.7 million from a previously announced sale of eight savings bank branches in Florida which was consummated in January 1987.

title: HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IFR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BIG FINE IN TEXAS THRIFT CASE
description: The former chief executive of a Texas savings and loan association agreed today to settle charges that he milked the institution into bankruptcy, and the Government claimed that it stood to recover up to $100 million of losses it sustained.

title: Mercedes Prices
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America, a unit of Mercedes Holdings, said it would increase 1987 model vehicle and optional equipment prices by 3.7 percent, effective with cars delivered to dealers June 1. It said cars already in dealer inventory would not be affected by the increase.

title: MUSEUM SALUTING VINTAGE TV
description: What two things do ''I Dream of Jeannie,'' ''Police Story'' and ''QB VII'' have in common?

title: PANEL DENIES A WAIVER ON SEABROOK REACTOR
description: A review board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today rejected a request by the operators of the Seabrook nuclear power reactor to reduce the mandatory 10-mile emergency evacuation zone around the New Hampshire plant to a radius of one mile.

title: BAKER HUGHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes charges of $140 million relating to the combination of Baker International Corp. and Hughes Tool Co. into Baker Hughes Inc. earlier this month for both the quarter and 6 months; and pension reversion gains of $21 million for the quarter and $55.8 million for the 6 months.

title: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $106,000. c-Net loss and after a loss of $461,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the discontinued computer graphics business.

title: SRI LANKA AIR FORCE RAIDS TAMIL GUERRILLA BASES
description: The Sri Lankan Air Force attacked bases of two Tamil guerrilla separatist groups in the north today, killing 80 people, the Government said.

title: ACETO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Whitehead's Parents Appeal Baby M Rule
description: Mary Beth Whitehead's parents appealed yesterday in their fight against a decision that forbids them to visit the child their daughter bore under a $10,000 surrogacy contract.

title: J. C. Plowden-Wardlaw Weds Angela Weldon
description: Angela Hill Weldon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Hill of New York, was married yesterday to James Campbell Plowden-Wardlaw, the son of Eleanor Getman of Lehigh Acres, Fla., and Thomas C. Plowden-Wardlaw of Nonquitt, Mass., Vero Beach, Fla., and Harbour Island, the Bahamas. The Rev. Charles A. Armstein performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the New York home of Frederick D. Hill, the bride's brother.

title: HOME & CITY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $643,000.

title: ROCK: BIG AUDIO DYNAMITE
description: BIG AUDIO DYNAMITE would be a worthy band indeed if only it had a passable singer and all of its good ideas were not second hand. Led by Mick Jones, formerly of the Clash, Big Audio Dynamite opened a sold-out, five-night stand at Irving Plaza on Tuesday. The group intends to make political statements over streetwise dance grooves - a potent combination, but not in Big Audio Dynamite's hands.

title: PEOPLES WESTCHESTER SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $2,570,000 for the latest quarter and $1,583,000 for the year-ago period. The bank went public in June.

title: ALFRED T. GIFFORD
description: Alfred T. Gifford, a founder of Country Miss, a successful producer of women's apparel, died of a respiratory ailment Sunday in the San Pablo Hospital while on vacation in San Juan, P.R. He was 69 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: ADVO-SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $515,000. c-Net loss

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect affiliations of eight banking organizations accounted for as poolings of interest.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $343,775 from the writeoff of the balance of unamortized issuance cost of subordinated debt redeemed Jan. 31.

title: Some U.S. Officials See Slower Growth
description: Because of increases in interest rates, turbulence over the dollar and impasses in making international policy, some Government officials say they expect the American economy to be weaker this year than they were predicting a few months ago.

title: ISLANDERS SCORE WITH :003 TO PLAY AND TIE SERIES, 1-1
description: The game, a close-checking duet that unfolded ever so warily, became the property of the Islanders when they played without making a single mistake and the Flyers, perhaps overanxious about avoiding overtime -an Islander specialty - did not.

title: Van Brunt Woos Back Barbados Tourism Ads
description: With obvious glee, Albert Van Brunt, president of Van Brunt & Company, yesterday announced the return of the Barbados Board of Tourism and its $1.75 million ad budget.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
That Nuclear Bonus
description: Victor Stello Jr., the top staff executive of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, was accused at a Senate committee hearing last month of having ''improper'' personal contacts with executives of electric utilities that were under investigation by the nuclear agency. In a longstanding complaint, some members of Congress and industry officials have accused Mr. Stello of ''coaching'' a nuclear power company with business before the five-man commission. Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, asked yesterday in a formal letter to the commission's chairman that Mr. Stello be removed.

title: Texas Sees Easing Of Creditor Pressures
description: A senior official of Texaco Inc. said yesterday that the pressure on its business operations has eased considerably in the last week but that some of its essential operations were still having trouble with creditors.

title: 'REVERSE LBO'S' BRING RICHES
description: When the Rockefeller family decided it no longer wanted to own Outlet Communications, a broadcast company based in Providence, R.I., some of Outlet's executives took it off the Rockefellers' hands - and put millions into their own pockets.

title: NATIONAL SANITARY SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter earnings include pro forma adjustments that assume that as of Jan. 1, 1986, National Sanitary acquired the business of Paul Ross Supply Co., resolved the contingent payment of $10 million to the former owners and incurred the additional costs of operating as a separate public company. The company went public in June 1986.

title: GENETIC ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a deferred gain of $1,551,595 from the sale of real estate for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: DUQUESNE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in February 1987.

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,086,000.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $14 million. The company said the results for the year-ago first quarter have been restated for the sale of the company's Flint and American Critical Care units which have been accounted for as discontinued operations.

title: Prosecutorial Politics
description: Look: you do something nice for somebody, he does something nice in return.

title: Hinckley Parents Deny Paying for Testimony
description: Spokesmen for the family of John W. Hinckley Jr. and the mental hospital where he is confined today disputed reports that Mr. Hinckley's father paid for a psychiatrist's courtroom testimony.

title: German Shipyard Order
description: The German shipyard Lloyd Werft said today that it had won a $7.5 million order from Klosters Cruisers S.A. to refit the 70,000-metric-ton cruise liner Norway. The announcement came as the Queen Elizabeth 2 ended sea trials after her $155 million refitting at the shipyard, the most costly in commercial shipping history. The work included the installation of new engines, new ballrooms, bars and a squash court. The QE2 will be delivered to its owners, Cunard Lines Ltd., on Saturday and will resume trans-Atlantic passenger voyages on April 29.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reduced by about $2 million due to an accounting change.

title: LONG DELAYS SEEN
description: A panel of the nation's leading physicists will report Thursday that so many breakthroughs are required to develop laser and particle beam weapons for the proposed ''Star Wars'' anti-missile system that it will take a decade or more of intensive research just to determine whether the job can be done.

title: PERVASIVE TESTING CREDITED
description: The use of illicit drugs in the armed forces has been driven to the lowest point in six years, and officers in all four services credit the drop to the deterrent of pervasive testing through urinalysis.

title: MICRO D INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $213,100.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 23, 1987
description: Markets

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
JAZZ: OLIVER JONES, PIANIST
description: TO many listeners, the performances of the Canadian jazz pianist Oliver Jones have evoked comparison with the virtuosity of Art Tatum and Oscar Peterson. At Positano, Park Avenue South at 20th Street, where Mr. Jones is appearing through tomorrow, one hears light-fingered reminders of the facility of Mr. Tatum and Mr. Peterson, but it is done in a context that is reminiscent of the big, buoyant melodic structures that were created by Erroll Garner.

title: Third Hudson Ferry Starts
description: A third Hudson River commuter ferry, between the foot of East Jersey and Front Streets and Pier 11, south of Wall Street, started yesterday, The service, run by Tradebase International Inc., will make the trip six times each way weekdays, the company said. On Saturdays, the ferry will make five trips each way. The cost of a one-way 40-minute trip on the Spirit is $6, including coffee.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article and a headline in some copies yesterday about a New York regulation barring insurance companies from testing for the AIDS virus misstated the policies that would be affected, and quoted Governor Cuomo incorrectly on the subject. It also gave an incorrect address for the Gay Community Services Center, where the Governor spoke. The regulation would apply only to health insurance. Mr. Cuomo said, ''This is the first step in achieving a regulation prohibiting a blood test for the HIV-1 infection as a condition of issuing health insurance.'' The community center is at 208 West 13th Street in Manhattan.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: $ Mobil Corp. 252,000,000 -42.7 Panhandle Eastern Corp. 41,900,000 +6.1 Phelps Dodge Corp. 16,800,000 +10.5 Pitney Bowes Inc. 41,000,000 +10.5 Santa Fe Southern Pacific 45,900,000 +54.5 Union Pacific Corp. 121,900,000 +18.2 USAir Group Inc. 23,500,000 *- USG Corp. 85,000,000 +64.4 U.S. Tobacco Co. 28,500,000 +25.0 See accompanying notes for special items. * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: NEWMONT GOLD CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. COURT ALLOWS USE OF DRUG TESTS
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the United States Customs Service could require applicants for certain jobs to submit to drug tests.

title: Bridge: New York Expert Has Given His Version of Majority Rule
description: Majority rule was an easy concept for the ancient Greeks, a harder one for modern democrats and totally esoteric for bridge players.

title: SPEAR FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item of $419,151 and $170,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, from a reduction of income taxes resulting from utilization of net operating loss carryforward.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $30.9 million for the Sundstrand hydraulic power systems business which was not consolidated in 1987.

FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment losses of $154,000 for the latest quarter and $31,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: The Hall's Big Hit
description: Rick Cerone of the Yankees and Charlie Puleo of Atlanta are the only Seton Hall alumni on current major league rosters, but if they stick around a while longer, they may well be getting company. The school has a right-handed-hitting first baseman who turned heads as the Big East freshman of the year in 1985, missed the end of last season with a broken arm suffered in a basepath collision and has come roaring back with flourishes.

title: D&N SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GALLAGHER, ARTHUR J & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1986 results are restated to reflect three acquisitions accounted for on a pooling-of-interest basis. The company said in light of the continuing unavailability of primary levels of errors and omissions insurance coverage, it set up a reserve of about $1,100,000 in the latest first quarter to fund losses within the deductible under its errors and omissions coverage and other litigation expenses.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PIONEER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New York Borrowing Is Smallest Since 1974
description: New York State is offering $2.6 billion of notes due March 31, 1988, with a yield tentatively set at 4.85 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: BROOKLYN HONORS ITS DODGERS IN MEMORY AND ART
description: The pitcher Carl Erskine was there, big as life and sporting his glittering 1955 World Series ring, which seemed big as a baseball.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Major Acquisition By G.E. Possible
description: The General Electric Company's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., said the giant manufacturing and services concern would make another major acquisition if it found a target as attractive as the RCA Corporation, which was bought last year. ''Acquisition is clearly an acceptable route toward accelerated growth and, should another opportunity of the quality of the RCA merger present itself, we will move decisively,'' Mr. Welch said at the annual meeting.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ECHO BAY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1.1 million on the sale of the Convair aircraft.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: DINERS who have a difficult time digesting $20 bowls of pasta at Upper East Side restaurants should venture downtown some evening to TriBeCa, where several impressive and affordable new Italian establishments have taken root. One of the most original I have found recently is four-month-old Arqua, named after a village in northeastern Italy that was the home of the 14th-century poet and philosopher Petrarch. Leonardo Pulito, the 30-year-old Italian-born chef who runs the restaurant with his wife, Antoinette, has a poetic streak himself, as evidenced by his sensitive and lyrical pasta compositions.

title: Boyd in Pain
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Boston Red Sox had to quit in severe pain after warming up for a test of his ailing right shoulder in a simulated game against teammates at Fenway Park.

title: 'TRICKY' BUILDING METHOD AT SITE OF COLLAPSE
description: The construction technique used for the high-rise apartment building that collapsed yesterday in Bridgeport, Conn., poses special challenges for construction crews, experts said.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Make-a-Wish to Aid Terminally Ill Children
description: The second annual Make-a-Wish street fair, run by students from more than 20 private high schools in New York City, will be held tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on 75th Street between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: SALAZAR BRAVING THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: In 1976, a senior from Wayland, Mass., won the high school two-mile event and was named the outstanding schoolboy runner in the Penn Relays. Meet officials sent him a lovely plaque marking the occasion. In big block letters on the plaque was his name:

title: Casey 'a Very Ill Man'
description: William J. Casey, who resigned as Director of Central Intelligence in January after surgery to remove a cancerous brain tumor, appears too ill to undergo questioning about the Iran-contra affair, a friend reports.

title: MCKESSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4.4 million. c-After net from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for the quarter and $3.8 million for the year. The latest year net includes an after-tax gain of $10.6 million on the sale to the public of about 14 percent of the company's PSC Inc. unit, partially offset by a special contribution to the McKesson foundation. The latest year net also includes a loss of $2.4 million from minority interest and three special fourth quarter items which total about $4.5 million in after-tax charges. The company absorbed in the latest quarter $5 million more in pre-tax LIFO inventory charges than in the year-ago period. In addition the company said it incurred one-time expenses of $3 million in its general merchandise operations and an additional $1 million charge against earnings from stock appreciation rights. The company said the items totaled about $9 million pre-tax, or $4.5 million, or 9 cents a share, after tax.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $800,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $3.1 million.

title: THE DAUNTING GANDHIS AND A DAUNTLESS CHALLENGER
description: With a potential scandal and countless other headaches, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is receiving a constant thrashing from critics in Parliament. His critics have seldom had it so good.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Defend America With Foreign Aid
description: What does Secretary of State George Shultz think is the No. 1 problem facing U.S. diplomacy? Answer: The foreign affairs budget now before Congress. It's a budget full of vexing choices: whether to emphasize military security or economic developmental needs . . . whether to focus foreign aid on Israel and Egypt or spread it around more . . . how much to pay for embassy security.

title: HOUSE TRIMS $2 BILLION FROM '87 SPENDING BILL
description: The House of Representatives this morning voted to cut a supplemental appropriation bill for this year by $2 billion to bring it in line with the ceiling set by Congress for 1987.

title: SRI LANKA BOMBS REBEL BASES A 2D DAY
description: Government planes bombed suspected Tamil guerrilla bases in northern Sri Lanka for the second day today, according to officials and Tamil groups.

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 24, 1987
description: International A2-10 Yasuhiro Nakasone was set back when Japan's opposition forced him to set aside plans for a new sales tax. Mr. Nakasone's defeat increased chances he would be forced out of office before October. Page A1

title: LAMBORGHINI GOES TO CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation added another exotic Italian name to its lineup today when it acquired Nuova Automobili F. Lamborghini, a producer of ultra-fast, ultra-expensive grand touring cars. Chrysler executives are clearly hoping that the glamour of Lamborghini - combined with the luster of Maserati, already a Chrysler affiliate - will go a long way toward helping Chrysler change its image as a blue-collar automobile company.

title: Mathias Polakowitz Is Dead; Pen Name Was Paul Mathias
description: Mathias Polakowitz, who under the name Paul Mathias was a foreign correspondent for Paris-Match magazine and who covered the 1956 revolt in his native country, Hungary, died of cancer on April 9 in Paris. He was 65 years old.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC (TWA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5% Sales Tax Placed On Florida Advertising
description: In Tallahassee, Fla., the Legislature yesterday passed a tax bill that includes a 5 percent sales tax on advertising originating in the state and entering the state. Governor Bob Martinez quickly signed the measure into law.

title: Pitino Warming to the Suns
description: Rick Pitino's heart may be with New York, but he is pricing homes in Arizona.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Restated to reflect new pension accounting standards which increased net income for the quarter by $600,000, or 2 cents a share; and increased net income for the 9 months by $2,100,000, or 6 cents a share. The company said its first and second quarter net for fiscal 1987 was reduced by $551,000 due to the elimination of the investment tax credit.

title: GM HUGHES ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Taxi Fare Rise Won't Lure Many New Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: MARINE CORPS CUTS PERIOD GUARDS STAY AT MANY EMBASSIES
description: The Marine Corps has shortened to one year the tour of duty for embassy guards in countries such as the Soviet Union where they are considered subject to compromise by foreign agents, the Pentagon said today.

title: The Difficulties of Picking a New S.E.C. Chief
description: When the White House announced March 20 that John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had been nominated as Ambassador to the Netherlands, top aides to President Reagan said they would come up with a successor within 10 days.

title: Article 037887 -- No Title
description: The LTV Corporation, in a return to profitability for the first time since the final quarter of 1983, said today that it earned $129.6 million, or $1 a share, during the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $109.1 million a year ago. Revenue for the three months increased 6.1 percent, to $1.91 billion, from $1.8 billion a year ago.

title: STARPOINTE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $525,000. The bank converted to stock form in October 1986.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOCIETY FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $707,000 and an extraordinary charge of $165,000 related to the repurchase of debt. c-After a tax credit of $2,163,000. The per share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1986.

title:
Economic Scene;
A Plan to Ease Global Stresses
description: LEAD: IN the world's financial markets, the tendency toward equilibrium that one reads about in textbooks is a myth. The tendency in the real world is toward excesses that, left unattended, would eventually lead to a breakdown of the international trade and payments system. The system would have broken down in 1982, for instance, if the monetary authorities had not banded together to prevent the wholesale default of over-indebted countries.

title: WITNESS TELLS OF SUDDEN PANIC
description: Ray Mendoza though it was a joke.

title: NAKASONE SUFFERS A SEVERE SETBACK AS JAPAN'S LEADER
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone suffered a severe political defeat tonight when an emboldened opposition forced him to set aside his plans for a new sales tax.

title: Santa Fe Stock Up on Rumor
description: Shares of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation jumped $2.625, to $41.875, in heavy New York Stock Exchange trading today amid reports that Bear, Stearns & Company had put the stock on its restricted list.

title: International Controls Gets Bid
description: The International Controls Corporation, a manufacturer of aerospace and electronic devices, received a $32-a-share buyout offer from its president, Arthur Goldberg, and Bear, Stearns & Company. The company's stock jumped 24 percent, or $6.50, to $33.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: On AIDS and Moral Duty
description: LEAD: Potential AIDS victims who refuse to be tested for the disease and then defend their right to remain ignorant about whether they carry the virus are entitled to that right. But ignorance cannot be used to rationalize irresponsibility. Nowhere in their argument is there concern about how such ignorance might endanger public health by exposing others to the virus.

title: Give Air Passengers More Information
description: To the Editor:

title: GUILTY PLEA ENTERED BY BOESKY
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the speculator at the center of Wall Street's insider-trading scandal, pleaded guilty yesterday to a single criminal charge -conspiracy to ''make false, fictitious and fraudulent statements'' to the Government.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I saw it fall down like a deck of cards. There was no explosion. It just went. I saw people screaming and running off the top of the building. I heard metal bending.'' - Steve Russo, in Bridgeport, Conn. [ B4:1. ]

title: DEBATE ON ENDING MISSILES IN EUROPE DIVIDING EXPERTS
description: Proposals to eliminate medium-range and short-range nuclear missiles from Europe have prompted an unusual debate among arms control experts about how best to deter war and reassure Western European nations of the American commitment to defend them in the event of an attack.

title: AFTER 86 YEARS, ROCKAWAYS PLAYLAND TO BE RAZED FOR 300 CONDOMINIUMS
description: Rockaways Playland in Queens, one of the last large amusement parks in New York City, is heading into memory as it is torn down to make way for a housing development.

title: BALLET: 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: AS American Ballet Theater's new staging of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' acquires new casts, it is natural for expectations to be fulfilled and surprises to occur.

title: ISRAELIS ON P.L.O. TALKS: DREAD, ANGER, SATISFACTION
description: Israeli leaders are watching the group that the Palestine Liberation Organization considers its parliament with an unusual mixture of anger, dread and satisfaction.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson Clicks in New Arena
description: Mike Tyson's first major product endorsement will be for Eastman Kodak.

title: WARREN FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no per share earnings for the year-ago quarter because the bank converted to stock form of ownership in July 1986.

title: GOLDIN CLASHES WITH THE MAYOR ON CITY HOUSING
description: Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin clashed yesterday over New York City's efforts to create permanent housing for the homeless. Mr. Goldin accused the Mayor of failing to renovate available apartments in city-owned buildings, and Mr. Koch dismissed the criticism as uninformed and politically motivated.

title: GROUP EXHIBITIONS SHOW OFF NEW TALENT AND STRIKING STYLES
description: GROUP exhibitions organized by commercial galleries and by this city's various corporate and alternative spaces might be seen as the filler or the white noise of the art world. Only intermittently reviewed, they are ever with us; the more you look for them, the more you find. They are the backdrops against which one-person exhibitions stand out, as well as the crowded stages on which most young artists make their debuts. They provide galleries with a break in the relentless march of solo appearances, giving dealers a chance to flex some curatorial muscle or to try out new artists that they are thinking of taking on. Such exhibitions also allow others - writers and especially the new breed of freelance writer-curators - to get into the curatorial swim.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUSTICE DEPT. INVESTIGATES NUCLEAR AIDE
description: The Justice Department today opened a criminal investigation of Thomas M. Roberts, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, effectively removing the commission from the case.

title: Loss at Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said today that it lost $18.8 million in the first quarter, compared with a $13.4 million loss a year earlier. Revenues fell 23.2 percent, to $204.6 million from $266.4 million. Western Union provides a variety of communications services and has interests in communications satellites. Western Union has suffered losses for the last few years and is attempting a major restructuring.

title: Spring Cleaning in the Bronx
description: In his five years as a Bronx City Councilman, Fernando Ferrer was known for competence as a legislator and loyalty to the borough's powerful Democratic machine. Now, in only a few days as Bronx Borough President, he has shown commendable independence.

title: 2 More Victims Found In Collapse of Bridge
description: The police today identified two more victims of the collapse of a New York Thruway bridge April 5. Their bodies were recovered by divers Wednesday.

title:
SCOUTING;
Philatelically, It's Phelps
description: LEAD: There are things on Digger Phelps's mind that are of national significance, and not just to Notre Dame alumni.

title: Disaster in Phoenix
description: Perhaps the worst thing about the Phoenix Suns' drug scandal, involving at least half a dozen present and former pro basketball players, is that it comes as no surprise. If drug availability is a river in the rest of society, it's an ocean in professional sports. After two members of the Houston Rockets were expelled from the league for cocaine abuse, their teammates described relentless pressure from dealers and the fortitude required to resist.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''I Love a Piano,'' Parsons School of Design auditorium, 66 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (741-8950). Sixteen top-flight jazz pianists are to play a marathon of solos and duets tomorrow and Sunday at the Parsons auditorium to raise money for a piano scholarship in the New School's Jazz Department, which is now completing its first year. The performances each day are to be a continuous series of pianistic musical chairs from 2 to 7 P.M. The first pianist each day will play 20 minutes as a soloist and then will be joined by a second pianist for 10 minutes of duets. The second pianist will then play 20 solo minutes, after which still another pianist will appear for 10 minutes of duets and subsequent soloing - and so forth for five hours. Tomorrow, the pianists will be Sir Roland Hanna, Dick Wellstood, Derek Smith, Hilton Ruiz, Roger Kellaway, Toshiko Akiyoshi, Hal Galper and James Williams. On Sunday, Dick Hyman, Herman Foster, Tommy Flanagan, Jaki Byard, John Hicks, Barry Harris, Joanne Brackeen and Ken Werner will play. Tickets can be bought at the box office, 66 Fifth Avenue. Admission is $20 for each day. Patron's tickets at $100 include admission to both concerts and the opportunity to socialize with the pianists in the musicians' room when they are not playing. 14th Annual Birthday Tribute to Duke Ellington, St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street (935-2200). The first celebration of Duke Ellington's birthday, April 29, at St. Peter's Church was organized by the Rev. John Gensel in 1974, barely a month before the great jazz composer, pianist and bandleader died at the age of 75. Since then, St. Peter's birthday celebration has been an annual event, an occasion for paying tribute to the Duke and hearing his music. This year's celebration, which is to be held on Sunday, has a slight twist - the High Society Quartet, led by the drummer Bill Eldridge, will play a program of compositions by the Duke's alter-ego, Billy Strayhorn. ''In effect,'' as Mr. Gensel points out, ''Billy Strayhorn will be paying tribute to the Duke.'' The celebration will also include some little-known Ellington compositions played by the Ellington scholar and pianist Brooks Kerr and performances by the baritone saxophonist Joe Temperley, who occasionally substituted in the Ellington band for Harry Carney and who now carries on the Carney role in the band led by the Duke's son, Mercer. Musicians in the audience will join in a jam for the Duke at the end of the concert, which is to start at 7 P.M. There will be a free-will offering.

title: Discrimination in Death? Yes, 5-4.
description: How does the Supreme Court respond to evidence that American justice values the life of a white murder victim more highly than a black victim? It doesn't make any difference.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 2 BY MENOTTI Gian Carlo Menotti, who is composer, librettist, director, conductor and arts administrator all rolled into one, has now staged two of his operas - ''Amelia al Ballo'' (1937), written when Mr. Menotti was 23 years old, and ''Tamu-Tamu'' (1973), with a libretto in both English and Indonesian - for performances this weekend at the Juilliard School. Mark Stringer will conduct the Juilliard Symphony. ''Tamu-Tamu,'' a gloomy allegory influenced by the Vietnam War, has never been published, and the Juilliard production will introduce the work to New York. ''Amelia,'' a comic opera in one act, had its world premiere in Philadelphia in 1937 and was staged at the Metropolitan Opera in 1938. Performances will take place tonight at 8, Sunday at 3 P.M., and Tuesday at 8 in the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 66th Street. Admission is $10. Information: 874-7515. EGLEVSKY BALLET The Eglevsky Ballet is to combine familiar works (''Swan Lake, Act II Pas de Deux,'' George Balanchine's ''Allegro Brillante'') with more recent creations (Michael Vernon's ''Twelfth Night'' and a new piece by Saeko Ichinohe) at the Maguire Theater, State University College at Old Westbury, L.I., this weekend. There are to be three performances - tonight at 8, and tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. Admission is $14.50 and $17 for the evening performances, $13 at the matinee. Mr. Vernon is the artistic director of the Eglevsky Ballet; Katherine Healy, a ballerina, will be the guest artist. At the matinee performance, Mr. Vernon will provide narration. Information, reservations and directions: (516) 746-1115. 'WORLD IS MADE OF GLASS' Quite a bit of 20th-century theater has made much of psychology, but Morris L. West's ''World Is Made of Glass'' is actually based on a true case study by Carl Jung. This weekend the American Ensemble Company will present the American premiere of ''The World Is Made of Glass'' at the Church of the Holy Scapular, 339 East 28th Street. Robert Petito will direct; the cast includes Sheila Saunders, Sal Condoluci, Joan Nimmo and Susan Gregory. Performances take place tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3. Admission is $8. Information: 571-7594. SATURDAY MANHATTAN ARCHEOLOGY Saturday afternoon from 1 to 4, the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, will present a symposium entitled ''Archeology Around the Town,'' an afternoon of slides and discussion focusing on recent archeological excavations throughout the city. The presentations will include ''Buried History at the 1661 John Bowne House, Flushing, N.Y.,'' ''Messages From the Dead: Social and Cultural Information from Gravestones, Long Island, N.Y., 1630-1800'' and ''Barges and Piercesheds: The Archeology of New York Harbor.'' The symposium is free and open to the public. Information: 534-1672. DO YOU BELIEVE IN MAGIC? The Society of American Magicians presented its first ''Salute to Magic'' in New York on April 15, 1909. The celebration continues Saturday night at 8, when Mike Caveney, Dale Salwak, Ken Turner, Constantine, Lyn and Ken, and other illusionists, manipulators and comedians converge on the Hunter College Auditorium, Park Avenue and 69th Street. Terry Seabrooke, whom the society recently voted the ''Magician of the Year,'' will be on hand to present his own special brand of magical mayhem. The ''Salute to Magic'' is believed to be the oldest continuing magic show in the United States, and this will mark its 78th anniversary. Admission is $10 and $18. Information: 873-3043. IN TANDEM Saturday morning at 10:30, the ''Trevira Twosome'' couples' race will begin and end at Tavern on the Green in Central Park (near Central Park West and 67th Street). The race, open to couples only, begins with a 10-mile race, and then continues with a two-mile ''mini-fun run'' immediately thereafter. It's too late to enter the ''twosome'' officially this year -some 4,000 runners signed up before the April 15 cutoff date - but you're welcome to watch from just about any place in Central Park. The race is sponsored by Hoechst Fibers Industries and is under the auspices of the New York Road Runners Club, Information: 869-3850. SUNDAY THE BOROUGHS BY BIKE Some 20,000 bicyclists are expected to ride 36 miles Sunday in the 11th Annual Citibank-American Youth Hostel Five Boro Bike Tour. The route goes from Battery Park up the Avenue of the Americas through Central Park to the top of Manhattan and through the Bronx, Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island, winding up (after a restful ride on the Staten Island Ferry) back in Battery Park. All the roads will be cleared of traffic, so bicyclists can proceed at their own pace. Rain or shine, the tour begins at 7:30 Sunday morning. The $5 fee entitles participants to a detailed information kit with a map of the route and a free safety vest. Information: 431-7100. MEADOWFAIR ON S.I. The Staten Island Children's Museum will present Meadowfair, an all-day family arts festival, Sunday afternoon starting at noon at Snug Harbor. The festival will include outdoor games, arts workshops, crafts, food, performances - in short, the proverbial ''fun for the whole family.'' As in previous years, Meadowfair will conclude with a balloon launch. Each balloon will carry a tag that announces its date of launch and offers a cash reward for the person who returns the balloon that has traveled the farthest. The Staten Island Children's Museum is at 1000 Richmond Terrace, Building M, at Snug Harbor, an 80-acre park in Livingston, S.I. Information: (718) 273-2060. In case of rain, the festival will take place on May 3. SUNDAY IN THE PARK Meanwhile, back in Manhattan, the Stuyvesant Park Neighborhood Association presents its annual Stuyvesant Park Festival, with food, drink, antiques, collectibles, entertainment and crafts. The park is at 16th Street and Second Avenue; proceeds will benefit the magnificent old trees that grace the Stuyvesant, the city's oldest fully fenced public park. The fair will take place from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; rain date: May 3. Information: 684-4077.

title: Our Towns; Suburban Blight: $1 Million Homes On a Dead-End
description: North Murray Avenue is a lovely, secluded winding lane where the most well-to-do of this well-to-do suburb live. Two years ago, Frank Joy bought a 16-room mansion on 9.5 acres for $3 million. In January 1986, he announced plans to use eight of those acres to build eight new million-dollar homes.

title: Russians Say Estonian Could Seek a Pardon
description: The Soviet Union said today that Karl Linnas, who was deported here from the United States on Monday, could appeal for pardon from the death sentence for war crimes that was passed by a Soviet court in his absence.

title: War Wins on Disqualification
description: The fans at genteel Keeneland Race Course rarely boo, but they howled today when War was led into the winner's circle after the $227,900 Blue Grass Stakes. They knew that War, who finished second but then was placed first through the disqualification of Alysheba, had been only the third-best colt in the race.

title: Beaten, and Badly
description: The Los Angeles Clippers, playing an 82-game schedule, finished 53 games out of first place in their division this year, a deficit equivalent, for instance, to 104 games over the course of a major league baseball season. Here are the most thoroughly whipped teams in N.B.A. history when games behind are expressed as a percentage of the total number of games played. $ Yr.* Club G GB Pct. 1973 Philadelphia 82 59 .720 1987 L.A. Clippers 82 53 .646 1972 Portland 82 51 .622 1967 Baltimore 81 48 .593 1973 Buffalo 82 47 .573 1986 Knicks 82 44 .537 1953 Philadelphia 69 34 1/2 .500 1968 San Diego 82 41 .500 1982 Cleveland 82 40 .488 1982 San Diego 82 40 .488 1985 Golden State 82 40 .488 *The year is that in which the season ended.

title: A Spring Market
description: More than 150 dealers are expected to take part in an annual spring market on Sunday at Heckscher Park, off Route 25-A, Main Street, Huntington, L.I. Proceeds from the market will benefit its sponsor, the Huntington Historical Society, which operates two museums, a library and a yearly program of exhibitions. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Donation, $2. Information: (516) 427-7045.

title: Editors' Note
description: A Washington dispatch on March 8 described legislation in the 100th Congress focusing on esthetic concerns.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect the adoption in the fourth quarter of new accounting procedures for pension.

title: U.S. TO FOCUS ON MAJOR COMPANIES ON CURB ON ALIENS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would focus on ''Fortune 500-type companies'' in enforcing a new law that prohibits employers from hiring illegal aliens.

title: Libya Releases a Scot Held 5 Years in Spying
description: A Scottish engineer given a 12-year jail sentence in Libya in 1982 for ''economic espionage'' has been released and plans to return home soon, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A HANDSOME and streamlined new seafood restaurant has berthed on the Upper West Side, and based on several recent visits, it shows promise of helping fill the insatiable demand for fresh fish at relatively moderate prices. Called Coastal, on Amsterdam Avenue at 74th Street, it is kin to the restaurants Memphis and 107 West.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from restructuring of employee benefit plans of $30,581,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a net gain of $9,469,000 from restructuring of employee benefit plans and a net loss of $3,515,000 resulting from adjustments required by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, principally the repeal of the investment tax credit. Revenue includes excise taxes.

title: FILM: IN 'LINK,' A CHIMP WITH A ROVING EYE
description: IT'S the season of the chimp. Last week brought us a screenful of the cute critters in ''Project X,'' and starting today the Thalia SoHo is offering Richard Franklin's smart-monkey movie, ''Link.'' Link may not be King Kong, but he's one champ chimp. As played by a primate named Locke (trained by Ray Berwick, who was responsible for the flights of Hitchcock's ''Birds''), Link is an ape-of-all-work in the isolated mansion of an anthropologist (Terence Stamp). Link's response to the appearance of a student assistant (Elisabeth Shue) is as macho as the next fellow's. Not only is Miss Shue more resourceful than Fay Wray in ''King Kong,'' she is a lot more robust; one glimpse of her as she steps into the bath is enough to give Link ideas about a meaningful relationship.

title:
SCOUTING;
Going Long
description: LEAD: All Pat Brennan knows about football in England is that it's said to be played on roughly the Division III level and that he gets expenses paid for three months abroad. Yesterday, equipped with only that information, he left for a city named Blackpool on the Irish Sea. The Fylde Falcons, who play American football there, open their season

title: TWIN DISC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company has elected to apply the provisions of SFAS 87 to account for pension expense of the domestic defined benefit plans effective with fiscal year 1987; pension expense provided in the third quarter computed in accordance with the provision of SFAS 87 was $414,000 which was $193,000 less than the pension expense that would have been provided under the provisions of APB opinion No. 8. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: LeMond Recuperating
description: The father of cycling champion Greg LeMond said yesterday that his son, wounded in a hunting accident this week, will not defend his title in the 24-day Tour de France.

title: A Democrat Whose Forte Is Funds
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the former House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., were discussing their diets. Linda Robb, daughter of President Johnson, was telling former Senator George McGovern a story about ''Daddy'' and his chauffeur. Representative Les Aspin was plunging shrimps into cocktail sauce. Senator Robert C. Byrd seemed engrossed by the harp music.

title: Vintage and Modern Films
description: For fans of the vintage and the most-up-to-date in film and video, two festivals are now under way.

title: DOLLAR DIPS BENEATH 140 YEN
description: The dollar broke below 140 yen this morning, trading at 139.05 yen, despite hectic intervention by the Bank of Japan.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ozone Subversion
description: A few man-made chemicals are gnawing at the ozone layer, the invisible shield in the stratosphere that protects life from ultraviolet rays. The State Department hopes Europe and Japan will phase down production of the ozone-destroying chemicals, starting with a 50 percent cut. But just as negotiations are to resume, the department's position is being undermined by the Office of Management and Budget.

title: ARGENTINE OFFICERS RESISTED GENERALS
description: The command structure of the Argentine Army virtually collapsed in the midst of the rebellions that erupted in the last week, according to reports here.

title: Why No Chilean Opposition Leader Emerges
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CPC's New Chairman
description: James R. Eiszner. president and chief executive of CPC International Inc., was named to the additional post of chairman. Mr. Eiszner, 59 years old, succeeds James W. McKee Jr., 64, who plans to retire Sept. 1. CPC, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., produces Hellman's mayonnaise, Mazola margarine and Skippy peanut butter. Mr. Eiszner is a graduate of the University of Illinois and received a doctorate in chemistry from the University of Chicago. He joined CPC in 1965, and was named president in 1979 and chief executive in 1984.

title: NORTH SIDE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $773,000 for the quarter and $1,814,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $523,000 for the quarter and $1,042,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago periods' per share earnings were not available because the bank was not public before April 15, 1986.

title: DISNEY, WALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CARDINALS' COX 3-0; HERR HURT
description: A freak injury spoiled the 1986 season for Danny Cox, but he is making up for it in a hurry.

title: EQK REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ODYSSEY OF THE UNWANTED TRASH GOES ON
description: The garbage without a country, in a barge floating for the last three days in international waters in the Gulf of Mexico, eluded United States officials today, who said the barge was being towed toward Mexico.

title: PREMARK INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: MET'S NEW JAPANESE GALLERIES
description: FOR the second time this year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has inaugurated galleries, and for the second time, the museum cannot adequately fill them. The Sackler Galleries for Asian Art that open to the public tomorrow are much smaller and more modest than the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for 20th-century art, and the art in them, being from one country, is more of a piece. But, here, too, there is not enough first-rate art. The Met continues to reinforce its reputation as an encyclopedic institution, at the expense of its reputation as a defender of the highest artistic standards.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 24, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The economy expanded at a 4.3 percent rate in the first quarter, the best performance in three years. However, analysts said the economy was still growing very modestly. They noted that the improvement reflected an unexpectedly large rise in inventories, mainly of cars and trucks, and they predicted that the buildup would hurt the economy in the present quarter as manufacturers cut production to reduce their stocks. [ Page A1. ] Senator Baucus plans a trade bill amendment under which the U.S. and other nations might ultimately raise tariffs against Japan using a rarely invoked provision of GATT. [ D1. ] MARKETS Ivan F. Boesky pleaded guilty to a single criminal charge -conspiracy to make false statements to the Government. Lawyers said the felony charge was so finely drawn that his vulnerability to lawsuits from stockholders was considerably lessened. The guilty plea involved only his actions in accumulating shares in the Fischbach Corporation. [ D1. ] A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold for $1 million, the highest price ever paid for what has become one of the hottest properties on Wall Street. On Wall Street, the buyer was identified as Stern Brothers, a small brokerage. [ A1. ] The dollar broke below 140 yen in Tokyo this morning. Yesterday, it fell sharply against the yen in New York, trading around the 140 level. New economic data touched off fears of a weak economy and higher inflation. In New York, gold bullion rose $10.75, to $459.50 an ounce. [ D1. ] Silver led the way as the demand for precious metals futures intensified. [ D13. ] The stock market ended with a modest loss, compared with huge swings earlier in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.97 points, to 2,280.97, after seesawing all day as the market reacted to news on the economy and worries about the dollar. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds weakened slightly, reacting to conflicting signals from the economy and foreign-exchange market. [ D12. ] Small businesses that have financed new facilities with tax-exempt industrial development bonds are facing an imminent rise in interest rates of as much as 3 percentage points. [ D12. ] COMPANIES G.M.'s net income dropped 23.1 percent, reflecting production cuts made in response to slumping sales and the cost of incentive campaigns. Its operating earnings fell by almost half. Analysts said the company might have to cut production later this year because its output is far exceeding sales. [ D1. ] Sales of domestically produced new cars rose 3.8 percent in mid-April. [ D4 ] Chrysler acquired Lamborghini, the Italian producer of ultra-fast, ultra-expensive grand touring cars. Chrysler, which already owns Maserati, is apparently trying to shed the image of a blue-collar auto maker. [ D1. ] ARCO, Standard Oil and Ashland Oil reported lower profits, while Diamond Shamrock reported a loss. [ D13. ] T.W.A. reported a smaller first-quarter loss, while Delta posted a profit, compared with a year-earlier deficit. [ D4. ] Salomon reported a 21.6 percent drop in earnings, better than what analysts had forecast. [ D4. ] Abraham & Strauss will open its first Manhattan store by rebuilding and moving into the former Gimbel's store between 32d and 33d Streets, on the Avenue of the Americas. [ A1. ] Another top executive of J. Walter Thompson has quit, apparently after a disagreement with the head of the JWT Group. [ D15. ] France agreed to sell a telephone concern to a consortium led by Ericsson, touching off protests by the losing bidders, A.T.&T., Philips and Siemens. [ D4. ] The board of Continental Illinois is seeking a chairman and chief executive to replace John E. Swearingen. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan's Prime Minister suffered a severe defeat when the opposition forced him to set aside a plan for a new sales tax. [ A1. ] TODAY'S COLUMN The international trade and payments system is threatened by various stresses, such as the American trade and budget deficits and the Japanese trade and savings surpluses. Solving such complex problems requires a far-reaching plan. Economic Scene. [ D2. ]

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Nana Vasconcelos and Arto Tuncboyaci, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (242-3374). If an instrument can be tapped, scraped, shaken, hit or rung, it's likely that one of the two master percussionists at this concert can make music with it. Nana Vasconcelos, a Brazilian, is well known to fans of jazz and new music around New York; along with his arsenal of percussion instruments, he uses his own body - clapping hands, tapping cheeks, singing in an open-toned tenor and a sweet falsetto - for even more sounds. His album ''Bush Dance'' (Antilles) adds drum machines and rapping, in pieces full of sly humor. Arto Tuncboyaci, who is Armenian, has kept a lower profile, but he has brought an alert ear and quick hands to jazz groups. He uses the Turkish sazabo (lute) and Armenian tumpuc (drum) along with numerous other instruments from all over; his own music covers plenty of territory. The percussionists will play solos and duets. Tonight at 8; tickets are $10.

title: AUTO SALES RISE 3.8%; FORD LEADS
description: Sales of domestically made new cars rose 3.8 percent, to 201,141, in the middle 10 days of April, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Hearing for Spencer
description: Brian Spencer, the former Islander player who has been charged in a slaying in Florida, will have a bail hearing this morning in West Palm Beach. At the hearing, the state attorney will have to divulge some of the prosecution's evidence before Spencer can be denied bail. The 37-year-old Spencer is awaiting trial on charges arising from the kidnapping and fatal shooting of 29-year-old Michael Dalfo. Spencer has been out of hockey since 1980. He was an Islander from 1972 through part of the 1973-74 season.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 15 percent stock dividend paid in May 1986.

title: TAYLOR IS LAID TO REST NEAR SOLDIERS OF 3 WARS HE FOUGHT IN
description: Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, one of the nation's best-known soldiers, was laid to rest today close to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery. That tomb contains the remains of soldiers from the three wars in which he had seen combat.

title: JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR A GENETIC TEST
description: A judge cleared the way today for an historic experiment in which genetically altered bacteria will be released into the environment for the first time.

title: WESTERN UNION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5,657,000 and a loss of $1,940,000 from an extraordinary item which includes $4.1 million of expenses associated with the exchange of certain notes payable, partially offset by a $2.2 million gain recorded in connection with the termination of a subsidiary's pension plan.

title: DELTA AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.17 a share from the sale of aircraft. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of 20 cents from the disposition of aircraft. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month include the operations of Western Air Lines from Dec. 18, 1986.

title: FILM: 'ANNEE DES MEDUSES'
description: AH, civility. Where but on the French Riviera could the concept of mother-daughter toplessness be greeted with such heavenly nonchalance? Christopher Frank's ''Annee des Meduses,'' which opens today at the Paris, is about a beautiful, voluptuous teen-ager (Valerie Kaprisky) and mother (Caroline Cellier) who vacation together in an atmosphere of utterly casual exhibitionism. The beach is glamorous, the clientele well heeled, and no one spends a nickel on swimwear. So the women are forever rolling things down or peeling things off, and the men never bat an eye. The film's cast does include a couple of pre-adolescent boys, but sadly, their reaction to these goings-on is left unrecorded.

title: REPORT QUESTIONS SOME CANCER TESTS
description: Adequate studies have not been carried out to determine whether breast self-examinations prevent early death from cancer, according to a new medical report. But the American Cancer Society warned against abandoning the technique.

title: Seminole Chief Denies Guilt in Panther Case
description: A Seminole chief pleaded not guilty today to two Federal misdemeanor counts in the 1983 killing of a Florida panther on the tribe's reservation.

title: PLAZA COMMERCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes a charge of $18,200,000 from early redemption of debt and a loss of $14,800,000 from writedown of investment in an unconsolidated affiliate for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $3,800,000 from redemption of debentures for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 382 money market mutual funds increased $1.63 billion, to $238.77 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds were up $506 million, to $65.32 billion. Assets of the 200 general purpose funds were up $823.1 million, to $66.43 billion. The 89 broker-dealer funds rose $298.2 million, to $107.02 billion.

title: COUPLE IS HELD ON SMUGGLING OF U.S. MONEY
description: A Colombian couple were arrested yesterday at Kennedy International Airport after Customs inspectors found $226,256 hidden in their belongings, including $41,900 in a teddy bear being clutched by their 4-year-old son, Federal authorities said.

title: CBS AND CNN PROJECT COVERAGE FOR ELECTIONS
description: With 19 months remaining until the 1988 Presidential election, CBS News has announced plans for campaign coverage. The network says it will offer two one-hour forums to all candidates before the first primary or caucus is held and will provide full prime-time coverage of the ''Super Tuesday'' primaries next March.

title: Hammer Has Willed Artworks to National
description: The industrialist Armand Hammer announced today that he had bequeathed his collection of more than 47 drawings by Old Masters and Impressionists to the National Gallery.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: LEAD: IF Orson Welles's first full-length film, ''Citizen Kane'' - thought by many to be one of the greatest movies ever made - is known as his masterpiece, his second, ''The Magnificent Ambersons,'' is known mostly as the film that ruined his career. The film's frustrating, controversial history, which included RKO studio executives' ordering 43 minutes cut and a new ending shot and inserted, was recalled by Welles in a BBC interview near the end of his life.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A television review Wednesday of an NBC show, ''Our Planet Tonight,'' misidentified an actor. He is Mitchell Laurance, not Matthew Laurance.

title: SUBURBAN BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNITED BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $556,717 from sales of securities for the latest quarter and $349,647 for the year-ago period.

title: Rates to Rise on Development Bonds
description: Small businesses that have financed new facilities with tax-exempt industrial development bonds are facing an imminent rise in interest rates that goes far beyond the general increase in rates during the past month.

title: Arms Control Details
description: There's a certain Alice's Tea Party quality to the debate developing on arms control as serious prospects emerge for agreement. Soviet officials accuse the West of having bluffed all along, since it is having such a hard time deciding what it really wants now that it may have to take what it asked for.

title: Rep. Leach Adopts Infant
description: Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, and his wife, Deba, have adopted a baby girl. They took her home Tuesday but still had not selected a name by today, said Mr. Leach's press secretary, Andy McLeod. The Leaches have a son, Gallagher, 5 years old.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A FULL WEEKEND OF EVENTS: WHERE THE MONEY GOES
description: This is the tally for the cultural-marathon weekend, with expenses for an individual. For two people, there could be savings on such items as taxi fares, making the total for the weekend $747.15, somewhat less than twice the total for an individual.

title: INVESTIGATORS GET CONTRA FUND DATA
description: Congressional investigators have obtained additional documentary evidence that proceeds from the American arms sales to Iran were used to assist the rebels in Nicaragua, a Congressional staff assistant said tonight.

title: L.M. Ericsson Gets French Company
description: The French Government said today that it would sell its Compagnie Generale Des Constructions Telephoniques to a Swedish-French consortium led by L.M. Ericsson A.B., the Swedish telecommunications group.

title: JURY ACQUITS JUDGE IN TRIAL FOR BRIBERY
description: A State Supreme Court justice was acquitted yesterday of taking bribes in the form of interest-free loans in return for funneling children's trust funds he controlled to a Brooklyn credit union.

title: RICHMOND HILL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,443,000 for the latest quarter and $1,385,000 for the year-ago period.

title: RAISED MONEY FOR OFFICE SEEKERS
description: Marvin Rosenberg, a textile manufacturer and close friend of the late Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, for whom he served as chief fund-raiser, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FILM: 'EXTREME PREJUDICE'
description: ACTORS get leaner and meaner when they work for Walter Hill. The sun shines down with an angrier glare. The gunfire is sharper, the insults more ambitious, and the only gentle sounds are those of womenfolk, as they (vainly) importune their tough guys to stay. In this hard-boiled universe, nothing is too nasty: not a bomb inside a bunny rabbit, or a point-blank surprise shot to someone's forehead, followed by the off-handed comment ''I liked him, too.'' If Mr. Hill, whose best films have a genuinely hard-boiled glamour, never intends this as parody, neither is he ever more than a hair away.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey First Victory for U.S.: The United States gained its first victory at the world ice hockey championships in Vienna yesterday, winning by 6-4 from a West German team that was stripped of two earlier victories. The International Hockey Federation, the sport's governing body, overturned West Germany's upset victories over Finland and Canada after ruling that a Polish-born defenseman, Miloslav Sikora, was ineligible to play for his adopted country because he had played in a junior tournament for Poland. While the Americans celebrated their first victory after four losses and the first points of the championship, the Soviet Union, the defending champion, maintained its undefeated record in five games with a 4-0 victory over Finland. Czechoslovakia defeated Switzerland, 5-2.(AP) Tennis Wilander and Arias Gain: Mats Wilander of Sweden set up a rematch with the man who beat him at the French Open, and Jimmy Arias also advanced to the quarterfinals of the $513,000 Monte Carlo Open yesterday. Wilander beat Thierry Tulasne of France, 7-5, 6-3, and Arias defeated Aaron Krickstein, 7-5, 6-1, in third-round matches. Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union beat Ricki Osterthun of West Germany, 6-3, 6-4. Chesnokov beat Wilander at the 1986 French Open in straight sets.(AP) Sabatini Advances: Gabriela Sabatini lost only 10 second-set points as she routed Michelle Torres, 6-1, 6-0, in a 62-minute second-round match at the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston women's tournament. Raffaella Reggi defeated Gretchen Magers, 6-3, 2-6, 7-6, in a 2-hour-40-minute match.(AP) Golf Fiori and Barr Share Lead: Ed Fiori and Dave Barr tamed the Woodlands Country Club fairways and greens with six-under par 66's to share the first-round lead in the $600,000 Houston Open yesterday. The co-leaders held a two-shot lead over four other golfers over the par-72, 7,042-yard Tournament Players Course. Barr had a bogey-free round that included long-range birdie putts of 35, 25 and 25 feet and an 18-foot downhill birdie on No. 15. Fiori birdied four of the first six holes, but he had no long putts. Keith Clearwater, Howard Twitty, Ray Stewart and Perry Arthur were tied at 68. (AP) Two-Way Tie for Lead: Miller Barber and Bob Charles finished off a 61 with birdies on the last three holes and gained a tie for the first-round lead in the $500,000 Legends of Golf in Austin, Tex. Charles, a New Zealand left-hander, and Barber played the back nine in 29 and came within a stroke of the tournament record in this best-ball competition for senior players age 50 and older. But it only brought them a tie with Bobby Nichols and Butch Baird.(AP) Boxing Jackson Wins Title: Tyrone Jackson of New York won the World Boxing Council Continental Americas superfeatherweight championship last night when he knocked out Floyd Favors of Washington at 1:46 of the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round bout at Felt Forum. In another bout, Juan LaPorte, the former featherweight champion, won a unanimous decision over Rafael Gandarilla in a lackluster 10-round bout.

title: STANDARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOUSE APPROVES ARMS PLAN BANNING MOST NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The House of Representatives, despite the opposition of the Reagan Administration, approved two arms control provisions today that would ban all but the smallest underground nuclear tests and require adherence to the unratified strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979.

title: MISSILE DEFENSE: NEW TURN IN DEBATE
description: By placing the date for the possible deployment of an advanced anti-missile system well into the next century, a panel of leading physicists has highlighted the stark change that the nation's vision of a futuristic defense has undergone in recent months, scientists and arms control experts say.

title: G.M.'S FIRST-QUARTER NET DOWN 23.1%
description: The General Motors Corporation today reported a 23.1 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, citing production cuts in response to slumping sales and the cost of sales incentive campaigns.

title: Carnegie Hall Solos
description: Bobby McFerrin, a singer, Michel Petrucciani, a pianist, and Stanley Jordan, a guitarist, will each perform solos tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall (247-7800). Tickets are $15 to $20.

title: EASTERN U.S. AGENCIES THAT ARE AIDING ALIENS
description: Following is a list of religious, civic and community groups in the Eastern Region of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service that will help process applications by aliens for legalization under the new immigration laws: NEW YORK METROPOLITAN AREA Manhattan

title: Affirmative Action
description: General Manager Frank Cashen of the Mets met for an hour and a half with black community leaders yesterday and both parties emerged with promises that they would meet again in about three weeks to check on the team's progress in hiring more blacks and women on all levels of the team's operation.

title: Dining Out Guide: Long Island
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: BOSSY, SUTTER NEARING RETURNS
description: The Islanders, who seem to be gaining in composure and momentum and appear to lack only a persistent scoring touch, are now poised for the return of Mike Bossy and Brent Sutter this weekend.

title: EDDIE DAVIS, FORMER NIGHTCLUB OWNER, DIES
description: Eddie Davis, an entertainer and nightclub owner who ran one of New York's leading clubs during the 1930's and 40's, died on Monday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: Dow, After Seesawing, Falls by 4.97
description: The stock market ended the day with a modest loss yesterday compared with its huge swings earlier in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.97 points, to 2,280.97.

title: Isaac Pacht, Prison Reformer And Former California Judge
description: Isaac Pacht, a prison reformer and former judge who helped revise the California Penal Code, died Saturday. He was 96 years old.

title: Morgan Grenfell Names A New Top Executive
description: John Craven, the much-traveled investment banker named yesterday as the new chief executive of the Morgan Grenfell Group, acknowledges that he is facing ''quite an undertaking.''

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1986 first quarter net was restated to reflect the retroactive adoption of new accounting rules for pensions to Jan. 1, 1986. The effect of this change increased the net by about $2.6 million. Sales for 1986 include units now part of the Dresser-Rand partnership. The first quarter 1987 sales reflect the company's 50 percent interest in Dresser-Rand on the equity method of accounting. The company said the comparable quarter of 1986 included about $73 million of sales and $4.1 million of operating losses from units that are now part of Dresser-Rand Co. The first quarter of 1987 includes pre-tax losses of about $10 million attributable to the Dresser-Rand investment.

title: GROWTH IS 4.3% FOR THE QUARTER, BUT DISCOUNTED
description: The nation's economy expanded at a 4.3 percent rate in the first three months of this year, the biggest quarterly figure since the spring of 1984, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 'Barbara Cook' to Close
description: ''Barbara Cook: A Concert for the Theater,'' is scheduled to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Ambassador Theater. The one-woman show under the direction of Wally Harper will have run for 13 previews and 13 regular performances.

title: CRITIC OF SOVIET PSYCHIATRY GIVEN PERMISSION TO LEAVE FOR THE WEST
description: Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist who spent six years in prison camps for reporting on the Soviet use of psychiatric treatment to imprison political dissidents, has been given permission to emigrate to Switzerland, the official press agency Tass announced today.

title: Texaco Allowed To Resume Fight
description: The legal war between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company that drove Texaco to seek bankruptcy protection can resume in the Texas courts, Judge Howard Schwartzberg of Bankruptcy Court ruled.

title: Corrections
description: A Washington dispatch by The Associated Press on April 8 about a meeting between American and Angolan officials misstated the legal standing of Angola's southern neighbor, Namibia. The territory is ruled by South Africa in defiance of the United Nations.

title: PLANS FOR PHILADELPHIA MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: Philadelphia's American Music Theater Festival will expand into international territory next fall, but the company's American works still provide a strong center of interest. Chief among the latter is a production of Harry Partch's ''Revelation in the Courthouse Park,'' a theater piece incorporating 16 instruments homemade by the composer from hubcaps, lightbulbs and bottles. They will be augmented by a marching band, drum majorettes and tumblers.

title: Chairman Replaces Commodore Chief
description: Commodore International Ltd., the home computer maker that has been recovering after several quarters of heavy losses, said yesterday that its chairman, Irving Gould, would replace Thomas A. Rattigan as chief executive.

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $58.2 million. c-After net from discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and $10.2 million for the 9 months.

title: BROADWAY
description: WHEN Will Shakespeare meets New Vaudeville, the zaniness is all.

title: U.S. DROPS SUBVERSION CASE AGAINST FIVE OF SEVEN ARABS
description: The Justice Department today withdrew charges of political subversion here against five of seven Palestinians it had accused of fostering the actions of a terrorist group.

title: OPERATOR OF NEWSSTANDS GUILTY IN SALES TAX CASE
description: The operator of all the newsstands in the New York City subway and Long Island Rail Road stations pleaded guilty yesterday to charges involving the evasion of $325,000 in sales taxes.

title: FIRST UNITED FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Continental Illinois Search
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said today that its board was beginning a search for a chairman and chief executive to replace John E. Swearingen.

title: KEY RATES
ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $10 million after-tax gain on the sale of certain oil and gas properties; a $19 million after-tax gain related to the sale of a corporate asset and a $35 million after-tax charge for early redemption of certain debt issues.

title: Thompson Loses Top Executive
description: ANOTHER high-level executive of J. Walter Thompson has left the company.

title: OUTDOOR
description: Although paddling your own canoe has merit, there is no need to neglect the sport if you don't own one. In most areas, there are those who will rent one to use on the stream of your own choice.

title: Article 037087 -- No Title
description: Guinness P.L.C. reported net income equivalent to $172 million for the 15 months ended Dec. 31 after taking a $206 million charge related partly to the company's involvement with the stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yes, Geography
description: Educators have long been disturbed by the average American student's lack of familiarity with basic geography. But what about Congress's knowledge of the subject?

title: Comings and Goings
description: As expected, Herb Brooks, who coached the United States Olympic team to the gold medal in hockey in 1980, was hired by the Minnesota North Stars yesterday, signing a two-year contract for undisclosed terms. . . . Matt Prescott, the leading rusher on Rutgers' football team last season with 606 yards on 155 carries, will be sidelined next season because of a knee injury suffered in spring practice Wednesday that will need at least a year of rehabilitation, according to Coach Dick Anderson. . . . A disorderly conduct citation against Reggie Jackson of the Oakland Athletics was dismissed by Milwaukee Circuit Court Commissioner Harry Holloway. The incident arose last year when Jackson was with the California Angels.

title: A TOWER PLAN IN CHELSEA IRKS LOW-RENT NEIGHBORS
description: A tattered bed sheet still flutters across the brick tenement on Eighth Avenue at the corner of 17th Street proclaiming, ''Unite for low-rent, low-rise housing in Chelsea.''

title: B.P. Extends Offer For Standard Oil
description: The Standard Oil Company, considering a $7.4 billion tender offer from the British Petroleum Company for the 45 percent stake that B.P. doesn't own, said that discussions were continuing and that it would make no recommendations yet to minority shareholders. Both companies agreed that B.P. would extend its tender offer to May 4, from April 28.

title: SARA LEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net reflects a pre- tax charge of $66 million to cover costs of an early retirement program. The year-ago period's earnings had been adversely affected by a pre-tax writeoff of $47.9 million, or 61 cents a share after taxes, taken in connection with the AH-64 Apache helicopter program.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses of $51,086,000 for the latest quarter and $15,890,000 for the year-earlier period from discontinued operations resulting primarily from the sale of the company's coal unit.

title: U.S. TELLS OF GOAL ON WASTE STORAGE
description: The Energy Department said today that it had tentatively set the year 2007 as the target date for selecting possible sites for a permanent nuclear waste repository in the Eastern United States.

title: 'Music as Satire'
