description: The Downtown Chamber and Opera Players will present a program entitled ''Note From the Underground: Music as Satire'' at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, 344 East 14th Street, tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8. The program will include William Walton's ''Facade,'' to poetry by Edith Sitwell; Paul Bowles's ''Music for a Farce''; the world premieres of ''Self-Reference,'' a parody on modern dance and opera by David Finkelstein, and ''The Tangoed Web,'' by Marshall Coid, with the stilt-dancers Friends in High Places. Both evenings will also include a showing of Rene Clair's ''Entracte,'' with a score by Erik Satie. Mimi Stern-Wolfe will conduct. Admission is $8; $4 for the elderly. Information: 673-2207 or 477-1594.

title: MAPLE LEAFS STOP RED WINGS
description: Toronto got first-period goals from Steve Thomas, Rick Vaive and Dan Daoust tonight as the Maple Leafs beat the Detroit Red Wings, 7-2, to take a two-game lead in their four-of-seven-game Norris Division final series.

title: Bridge: A Champion Reports a Pass That Led to a Great Disaster
description: If your right-hand opponent bids a suit in which you have length and strength, the normal strategy is to pass and await developments.

title: DEATH PENALTY RULINGS: OPENING NEW ERA FOR APPEALS
description: For opponents of the death penalty, who lost two important Supreme Court rulings this week, both by 5 to 4, the best, if somewhat bleak, hope of saving many of the nation's 1,900 death row prisoners is to continue procedural challenges in case-by-case trench warfare. At a news conference here today, black leaders and other opponents of capital punishment strongly denounced the decision Wednesday. It upheld Georgia's death penalty despite strong evidence that the race of the victim and of the defendant influences its use.

title: DONNELLEY, R R & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
12 WITH NAZI TIES FACING DEPORTATION
description: More than a dozen foreign-born residents of the United States who have been accused by the Federal Government of lying about their involvement in Nazi war crimes could face deportation to the Soviet Union, a Justice Department official said today.

title: FIRST OAK BROOK BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
APPLE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,503,000. The year-ago first quarter earnings is adjusted to reflect the results of Eastern Savings Bank, acquired Dec. 31.

title: Yes, College Without Bankruptcy
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Profit Jumps 76%
description: The Walt Disney Company, benefiting from higher attendance at its theme parks and a strong lineup of movie releases, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 76 percent, to $91.2 million, or 66 cents a share, from $51.8 million, or 38 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue increased 29 percent, to $766.3 million, from $592.4 million.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a one-time charge of $335 million after tax relating to problems the company ahd with its tylenol drug and sale of its technicare imaging equipment business.

title: Silver Leads Advance As Demand Intensifies
description: Demand for precious metals intensified in futures trading yesterday, largely because a further weakening of the dollar and rising interest rates are stirring fears of greater inflation.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (SPOKANE, WASH)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,197,000 for the latest quarter and $617,000 for the year-ago period. The year-ago per share earnings have been restated to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend paid in June 1986.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1 million.

title: NATIONAL BANC OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSIDE
description: Subversion Case Dropped

title: GOODEN MAY REJOIN METS NEXT THURSDAY, PITCH 2 WEEKS LATER
description: Dwight Gooden will end one month of treatment for drug use and leave the hospital next Thursday to rejoin the Mets. But he is not expected to pitch for them until he gets back into playing shape and regains his pitching precision, perhaps two or three weeks later.

title: Donald T. Regan Book Is Sold for $1 Million
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff who resigned during the Iran-contra affair, will receive $1 million from Harcourt Brace Jovanovich for a book tentatively titled ''My Six Years With Reagan,'' a spokesman for the publishing company said.

title: JOHN S. GIBSON Jr.
description: John S. Gibson Jr., a former president of the City Council who represented the harbor area of this city for 30 years, died Wednesday. He was 84 years old.

title: PROTEST BY BLACKS IN SOWETO GROWS AFTER POLICE KILLINGS OF 6 WORKERS
description: A protest strike by residents of Soweto, Johannesburg's sprawling black satellite city, appeared to gain momentum today as tensions remained high after six black workers were killed by the police.

title: Airlines Warned of Sanctions
description: A group of senators warned the airline industry today that it faced possible renewal of regulation or heavy Government-imposed penalties for inferior service.

title: STUDY CONTRADICTS STEREOTYPE OF ALCOHOLIC WOMAN
description: New evidence contradicting the stereotype that women with drinking problems are middle-aged homemakers has been offered by a study of women and alcoholism in the New York metropolitan area. The study found that more than half the women being treated for alcoholism are 18 to 34 years old, and that nearly half are employed outside the home.

title: New York Arts Awards
description: More than 50 writers, poets and playwrights will receive fellowships this year from the New York Foundation for the Arts. This is the third year for the awards, which carry a $5,000 stipend for each recipient. The fellowships are among a total of 248 given to New York State artists this year by the foundation. An awards ceremony is planned for May 18 at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan.

title: RULING PARTY WINS INDONESIA VOTE
description: President Suharto's party won a landslide victory in national elections held Thursday, taking more than 70 percent of the vote with about three-quarters of the votes counted as of this morning.

title: MACK TRUCK AND AUTO UNION REACH A SETTLEMENT
description: Mack Trucks Inc. and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative settlement today that could save about 5,600 jobs in New Jersey, Maryland and Pennsylvania.

title: MUSICIANS IMPROVISE TO A GLOBAL BEAT
description: RAVI SHANKAR, the sitarist from India who is performing tonight at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, says Americans who ask him about his music make the same comparison over and over again; they tell him it reminds them of jazz. Mr. Shankar heard Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong first hand in the 1930's, when he visited America as a teen-ager with his older brother Uday Shankar's dance troupe, and he finds the comparison superficial at best. ''The only resemblance between jazz and Indian music,'' he said, ''is improvisation.''

title: STILL ANOTHER WALL STREET RECORD: EXCHANGE SEAT SELLS FOR $1 MILLION
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $1 million, the highest price ever paid for what has become one of the hottest properties on Wall Street.

title: FEAR OF AIDS STIRS NEW ATTACKS ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: In the Bohemian neighborhood of New Town on this city's North Side, several shops and bars that are popular among homosexuals here have recently been scrawled with obscene slurs and the imperative: ''Die!''

title: Bethea Apparent Suicide
description: Larry Bethea, a former defensive lineman for the Dallas Cowboys, died today of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound within hours of being identified as a suspect in two armed robberies, the police said. He was 30 years old.

title: The U.N. Today: April 24, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Correction: Issues By Nassau County
description: A report yesterday about Nassau County bonds misstated the terms and lead underwriter. The Long Island county is offering $87.7 million of unlimited tax bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY DENIES CHARGE
description: A State Senator charged yesterday that 300 new buses for New York City have potentially dangerous front axles, but the Transit Authority denied any serious problem and said it had ordered 300 more buses with the same axles.

title: Thinking About The Chief
description: Every morning when he is home, Al Campanis drives a few miles to the house of his mother, where breakfast is awaiting him.

title: Symbion Bidder Has 55% of Shares
description: The Warburg, Pincus Capital Company L.P. said that about 2.2 million shares had been tendered in its $3.50-a-share offer for up to 2.5 million common shares of Symbion Inc. The tendered shares included 672,500 owned by Dr. Robert K. Jarvik, Symbion's chairman and chief executive, and his family. Warburg, Pincus said that the tendered shares, when added to its previous holdings and a stake owned by a second Warburg, Pincus partnership, give the company control of about 55.3 percent of Symbion's outstanding shares.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MOVING FROM STREETS TO WELFARE ROLLS
description: ''Mr. Wilson has been homeless for the past two years. He has been surviving by collecting cans and bottles and doing odd jobs such as carrying packages in markets. He eats by going to soup kitchens.'' The note was scrawled by a volunteer in the stained-glassed sanctuary of the Church of the Holy Apostles at Ninth Avenue and 28th Street, and, with some luck, it will be Mr. Wilson's key to a $226 welfare payment each month - at least until he misses a letter addressed to him at the post office, or forgets about an appointment.

title: Entombed Beneath City, The Treasure of the IRT
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OVER THE EDGE. By Jonathan Kellerman. 373 pages. Atheneum. $17.95.

title: ART: SHOW OF NEW SCULPTURES BY JUAN HAMILTON
description: THE new sculptures by Juan Hamilton at the Robert Miller Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, have a paradoxical presence. It would be difficult for anyone not previously tipped off to say at first glance either who made them, what they are made of, or in what particular discipline they are rooted. It might even be difficult to say from what culture they come.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ANDOVER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no per share earnings for the year-ago period because the bank converted to stock ownership in May 1986.

title: Let's Try an American Kind of Glasnost and Call It 'Openness'
description: To the Editor:

title: Salomon's Net Declines 21.6%
description: Salomon Inc., Wall Street's second-largest firm, yesterday reported a 21.6 percent drop in first-quarter earnings from the year earlier. Analysts said, nonetheless, that Salomon's earnings were better than expected.

title: New Farm Team For the Rangers
description: The Rangers have signed an agreement to become the National Hockey League parent team for Denver's prospective International Hockey League franchise, to be known as the Colorado Rangers.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $52.4 million. c-Net loss

title: MARGARET ISRAEL, 57, AN ARTIST
description: Margaret Israel, an artist whose mixed-media constructions and collages were highly praised for combining the fancy and innocence of folk art with a modern sophistication, was killed Wednesday in Manhattan in an accident while riding her bicycle. She was 57 years old.

title: SKYDIVER SAVED IN MIDAIR
description: A skydiver went into a 200-mile-an-hour free fall to reach an unconscious colleague Saturday, then managed to open her parachute seconds before she would have struck the ground after a 13,500-foot fall.

title: RUNNING A CULTURAL MARATHON: PACKING PLAYS, MOVIES AND POP INTO ONE ARTS-FILLED WEEKEND
description: MY cultural inferiority complex invariably pops up at this time of year, in part from watching the Academy Awards on television and realizing that I haven't seen most of the nominated movies. Then comes the Pulitzer Prize for drama (haven't seen the play), followed later in the year by the Tony Awards (even more humiliating), all worsened by the salvos of publicity everywhere you look in Manhattan for next season's concerts, dance performances, opera and art extravaganzas.

title: BOND PRICES WEAKEN SLIGHTLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices weakened slightly yesterday in a day of conflicting signals from the domestic economy and foreign-exchange markets.

title: Knee Sidelines Miller
description: Cheryl Miller, who led the United States women's basketball team to a gold medal in the 1984 Olympic Games and dominated the college game in four years at Southern California, will miss this summer's Pan-American Games after having had knee surgery.

title: SCAASI: JUST RIGHT FOR THE 80'S
description: When Arnold Scaasi walks into a charity ball in New York - which he might do several times a week - he greets the chairwoman and tells her how beautiful she looks in her Scaasi dress. Then he circles the room, smiling and saying hello to everyone he knows while mentally counting the Scaasis. The count often goes into double digits.

title: FRIENDS AND SPIES IN 'A PACK OF LIES'
description: THE British play ''Pack of Lies,'' written by Hugh Whitemore (''Stevie''; television's ''Concealed Enemies''), is with us once again. It will be shown on CBS Sunday at 9 P.M. The London stage production starring Judi Dench and Michael Williams was a substantial hit. But a Broadway production in 1985 with Rosemary Harris and Patrick McGoohan withered rather quickly, despite a brilliant performance by Ms. Harris. It seems that the story about spying and personal relationships made a number of Americans uneasy. Some recalled, disapprovingly, E. M. Forster's remark that if he had a choice between betraying his country or his friend, he hoped he would have the courage to betray his country. Certain Americans find it difficult to believe that Forster, always a model of clarity, meant precisely what he said.

title: GRANITE STATE BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago per share earnings not available, the company converted to stock form of ownership in August 1986.

title: A SENATE ALTERNATIVE ON TRADE
description: Senator Max Baucus said today that he would introduce an amendment to the Senate trade bill under which the United States and other countries might ultimately raise tariffs against Japan using a rarely invoked provision of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: PLAN FOR REAGAN LIBRARY AT STANFORD IS DROPPED
description: Bowing to growing pressure from students and the faculty, the trustees of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation said today that they had abandoned plans to build a library honoring President Reagan on the campus of Stanford University.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SCORES of gem collectors and dealers have visited Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, in recent weeks to preview the jewelry to be up for sale on Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. Most of these shoppers have come either to see the necklace, bracelet and brooches that belonged to Ingrid Bergman, or one of the rarest types of stones ever auctioned - a purple-red diamond.

title: DANCE: 3 BY PAUL TAYLOR COMPANY
description: PAUL TAYLOR offered a feast for the eyes on Wednesday night when the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented three works from its repertory at the City Center Theater. The program demonstrated that Mr. Taylor is an unusually versatile choreographer and that his dancers are talented and good-looking.

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUMMER HOME RENTALS ARE UP AND MORE COSTLY
description: With travel agents, airlines and hotels reporting strong advance bookings to Europe for the summer, the summer rental industry on Long Island and the Jersey Shore might be expected to be bracing for a second consecutive disappointing season.

title: STANDARD FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $10,723,000 and a charge of $358,000 from a prepayment penalty. c-After a tax credit of $20,670,000. The bank went public Jan. 28.

title: THE U.S. CASE AGAINST THE ESTONIAN
description: Karl Linnas, who was deported this week to the Soviet Union under death sentence for war crimes, smiled as he handed a Jewish girl and her doll into the red Volvo bus that carried her to a Nazi killing ground, according to a witness who testified in Mr. Linnas's trial.

title: EXPLORING THE LIMITS OF DANCE
description: ''It's a very slippery piece,'' Lisa Kraus said with relish, talking of her new dance. ''We've made a sort of a vehicle for dancing dark and powerful emotions. And it's been a challenge. I spent over a year making and throwing things away.'' Making and throwing things away is an important part of the creative process fostered by Movement Research Inc., as is the understanding of the slipperiest of esthetics. And so, Ms. Kraus said, it seemed appropriate that she present an excerpt from the dance, ''Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Haydn,'' tomorrow in a performance at the Triplex Theater in TriBeCa.

title: ERVING WON'T LOOK BACK
description: It was about this time last year that the telephone rang unexpectedly early at the sprawling home of Julius Erving, stirring the man of the house from a much-needed slumber.

title: ASSET SALES HELP LIFT BANKAMERICA'S PROFIT
description: Buoyed by large asset sales, the BankAmerica Corporation reported first-quarter earnings of $67 million, or 34 cents a share, up slightly from $63 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier. More important, the bank continued to narrow its operating losses in comparison with the two previous quarters, excluding extraordinary gains and charges.

title: Brooklyn Tours
description: A walk tomorrow through Williamsburg is the first in a series of spring tours in Brooklyn that will be sponsored by the Prospect Park Environmental Center. The tour, led by Marvin Gelfand, will last two to three hours and meets at 1 P.M. at the Williamsburg Savings Bank, corner of Driggs Avenue and Broadway. There is a $2 fee ($1 for children). Other tours in the series will focus on the Gowanus Canal area (May 30); the Brooklyn Bridge (June 6) and the Fulton Ferry Landing (June 13). Information: (718) 788-8500.

title: Tom Rush to Sing
description: Tom Rush will sing tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: Union Committee Backs Proposed ABC Pact
description: The negotiating committee for the Writers Guild of America will recommend that its members accept a contract proposed by ABC management to end the eight-week-old strike against the network.

title: Control Data Has Profit
description: The Control Data Corporation today reported its first quarterly profit in more than two years. The computer maker earned $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share, in the first three months of 1987, in contrast to a $21.2 million loss a year earlier. The last time it was in the black was the third quarter of 1984. Revenues in the latest quarter rose 3.2 percent, to $821.7 million, from $796.1 million.

title: A.&S. WILL REPLACE GIMBELS IN HERALD SQUARE
description: Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based retail chain, will open its first Manhattan department store in the fall of 1988 by rebuilding and moving into the former Gimbel Brothers' store on the Avenue of the Americas between 32d and 33d Streets.

title: FILM: 'MY DEMON LOVER,' GOTHIC TALE IN GOTHAM
description: ''MY DEMON LOVER'' is about a young man who turns into a wild animal in the presence of the opposite sex, and it's a movie to bring out the beast in us all. Its hero and heroine, Kaz (Scott Valentine) and Denny (Michelle Little), are as painfully cute as their names, with Denny, when she first appears, wearing a bowler hat and jauntily toting a loaf of French bread. After they meet at a health-food restaurant, Kaz starts using Fruitburger as an affectionate nickname. Charles Loventhal's frenetic direction would barely suit a sitcom, let alone a film that also sets out to scare.

title: Poisoning Ourselves
description: A hallmark of President Reagan's foreign policy has been an increasing reliance on covert operations. A name, the Reagan Doctrine, was coined for the idea that the United States should use any means to overthrow left-wing governments it does not like. The Administration set a massive example by financing and directing a terrorist war on Nicaragua.

title: Cuomo Signs Energy Bill
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation here today intended to keep low-cost hydroelectric power flowing to upstate companies, send relatively inexpensive nuclear power downstate and create jobs statewide.

title: FILM: SCHYGULLA IN 'FOREVER, LULU'
description: THINGS are tough all over. The otherwise great Hanna

title: WIFE OF ANTI-RACIST CLERIC IS ATTACKED
description: The wife of a prominent Dallas minister was in a coma today, one day after her husband found her beaten, choked and unconscious in the garage of their home.

title: 28 FEARED DEAD IN A BRIDGEPORT BUILDING COLLAPSE
description: A $17 million high-rise apartment building under construction in downtown Bridgeport, Conn., collapsed in a thundering roar of concrete slabs and twisted steel beams yesterday afternoon, trapping dozens of construction workers under tons of rubble.

title: Boy Gets 3d Liver Implant; Organ Is Termed Perfect Fit
description: Seven-year-old Ronnie DeSillers, fighting infection, pneumonia and an inflamed pancreas, came through a third liver transplant ''with flying colors'' today after his mother told him ''you can't keep a winner down.''

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $3,224,000 and $4,612,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and restructuring charges of $2.2 million for the quarter and $7 million for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $2,395,000 for the quarter and $3,700,000 for the 6 months; and the 6 months also includes a $1.1 million restructuring charge.

title: NBC Radio Days
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: WITH New York's frenetic party season a month away from the finish line, are the city's social whirlers showing signs of wilting in the home stretch? Is an invitation to yet another lavish late-night dinner the last thing they want to see in the mailbox?

title: Truth and Fairness in Sentencing
description: Two people are convicted of bank robbery. Neither has a prior criminal record. Neither has a high school education, a job or close ties to family and community. One offender is sentenced by a tough ''law and order'' judge to nine years in prison; if he behaves while in jail, he will likely be released on parole after serving just three years of the sentence. The other, luckier, is sentenced to probation by a judge who views the offender as a victim of social forces that are a breeding ground for crime.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $8,900,000. The company said that exchange rate fluctuations had a net favorable pretax impact on 1987 versus 1986 of $10.7 million, resulting from a $1.4 million favorable effect in 1987 versus a $9.3 million unfavorable effect in 1986.

title: New Yorker Leaves Bates
description: The New Yorker, yes, The New Yorker is returning to Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, after a five-and-a-half month absence at Ted Bates Advertising. According to Steven T. Florio, publisher, Bates was unable to come up with a good print campaign over that time so he decided to return to Lord, Geller, after smoothing over the personality conflict with Dick Lord, the chairman, which he acknowledges was the reason for the split in the first place.

title: ROBERT M. DOWLING, CLOTHIER WHO POPULARIZED SANFORIZING
description: Robert M. Dowling, a clothing executive who popularized the Sanforizing process in the 1940's and 1950's, died Tuesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the effect of a change in the method of accounting for pension costs.

title: WINFIELD HITS 2, STREAK HITS 10
description: The game was moving toward its climactic moment tonight when Dave Winfield turned to the Yankee batboy and uttered the words that he would joyfully recall later.

title: CELTICS STAGGER PAST BULLS IN OPENER
description: The Boston Celtics' old legs showed their wear and tear in the fourth quarter tonight, but it was not enough save the Chicago Bulls.

title: DOLE URGES TIGHTER SENATE SECURITY
description: The Senate Republican leader said today that the handling of classified information and security clearances in the Senate was so lax as to be ''a disaster waiting to happen.''

title: FRANCES LINDLEY, 75, AN EDITOR
description: Frances Lindley, a senior editor at the publishing house of Harper & Row, died in her sleep Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75 years old.

title: TAUNTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank went public in June 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues section of Business Day yesterday, about a bond offering by Nassau County, misstated its terms. A corrected report appears today on page D12.

title: FILM: 'DYSLEXIA IN 'THE HOUSEKEEPER'
description: ''THE HOUSEKEEPER,'' based on Ruth Rendell's Edgar-winning suspense novel, is neither good enough to support Rita Tushingham's carefully considered performance as a closet psychotic nor bad enough for one to accept its mindless horrors for their own entertaining sake.

title: AZP GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $16,110,000, or 20 cents a share, from a one-time non- recurring change in the method of accounting for unbilled revenue at AZP's Arizona Public Service Co. subsidiary.

title: ART: SHOW OF WORKS BY TOM WESSELMANN
description: SPRING has sprung and so, at the Queens Museum, has Tom Wesselmann. This is no flight of journalistic fancy: Mr. Wesselmann has been showing signs of self-renewal for some time. Having made his name more than two decades ago with his smart-alecky investigations of what Mario Amayo has called ''the purgatory between reality and illusion,'' he seems now to have settled down with illusion.

title: Good Food Magazine Names New Publisher
description: Robert E. Young, 51 years old, who joined Triangle Publications' Good Food magazine last year as associate publisher, advertising, has now been raised to publisher. He will not replace anyone and will continue to report to Frank G. Wolf, group publisher of Seventeen and Good Food.

title: CUOMO BARS SOVIET TRIP, CITING BATTLES AT HOME
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he was canceling a trip to the Soviet Union next month because his battles with the Legislature made this a bad time to be away from Albany.

title: Texas Court Denies Requests by Texaco
description: A Texas appellate court today turned down a request by Texaco Inc. to reverse its Feb. 12 decision upholding a trial court's verdict that Texaco unlawfully interfered with the Pennzoil Company's plan to merge with the Getty Oil Company in 1984. A ruling in Texaco's favor had been considered highly unlikely by legal experts in Texas.

title: READING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss is due to losses at the El Paso Refining Co., in which Reading holds an equity interest, and a loss at Reading's SWS unit; the company also said that the first quarter historically is among the slowest for El Paso Refining.

title: Ralph Gabriel, 96, Dies; Taught at Yale for 43 Years
description: Dr. Ralph H. Gabriel, the Sterling Professor Emeritus of History at Yale University who developed a pioneering course in American thought and civilization, died Tuesday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 96 years old.

title: Chamber Society to Tour
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will travel to Australia next month for a two-week tour that begins in Sydney on May 13. The group will play music by the Australian composer Malcolm Williamson and by Ned Rorem and Elliott Carter. This is the second Australian tour by the society, which is the ensemble in residence at Alice Tully Hall.

title: MOBIL RELOCATING NEW YORK HEADQUARTERS TO VIRGINIA
description: The Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that it would move its headquarters over the next three years from its office tower on East 42d Street in Manhattan to a suburban office complex in Fairfax, Va.

title: DRIVE TO MODERNIZE LIBYA: A MAGNET FOR FOREIGNERS
description: In the town square in this city 125 miles east of Tripoli, pink and beige slabs of marble were being laid today by Turkish craftsmen hurrying to complete the reflecting pool of an elegant open-air plaza.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: READING WRITERS

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When Blacks and Jews Pull Together
description: In the most dramatic moment of a dramatic evening, Barry Friedman, a Queens College student, stood at the microphone in the aisle of the college's Colden auditorium in the midst of 1,700 blacks and Jews. Mr. Friedman, president of the Jewish Activities Club, said: ''Reverend Jackson, we can't seem to get a dialogue going with the black students on campus. Can you help us?''

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RAGE, ROOTLESSNESS AND GUNS, THE FORMULA FOR A MASSACRE
description: Multiple murders of strangers, like the rampage Thursday in Palm Bay, Fla., are not unique to American society. But the incidents in the United States often involve more victims because guns are readily available to a pathological individual with an urge to express a murderous rage.

title: Florida Power Utility Fined Over Nuclear Plant Security
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has imposed a $50,000 civil penalty against the Florida Power Corporation because of security violations at its nuclear plant here, the agency announced Thursday.

title: New Zealand Orders Soviet Envoy to Leave
description: The New Zealand Government today ordered the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat who it said was a K.G.B. agent.

title: Golson and Farmer
description: Benny Golson on saxophone and Art Farmer on fluegelhorn will lead their six-piece Jazztet through tomorrow night at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum tomorrow.

description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $1,909,000 related to the estimated future costs of the restructuring of Life Technologies and the plastic businesses of Specialty Materials & Engineered Plastics Group. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $3,400,000 from sale of assets and a pre-tax charge of $4,400,000 related to restructuring costs.

LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

PATENTS;
Missile Devices By Boeing
description: LEAD: THE Boeing Company in Seattle received patents this week for a missile power source, a missile control device and a warhead.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,000. c-Includes income from operations of $17,000 and the cumulative effect of a change in accounting method of $1,503,000.

title: 3 ADMIT SETTING HOTEL FIRE THAT KILLED 97 IN SAN JUAN
description: Three hotel workers pleaded guilty today under a plea bargaining agreement to Federal charges of setting a fire on New Year's Eve that killed 97 people and injured 150 more at the Dupont Plaza Hotel.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WATTS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes a net gain of $680,000, or 6 cents a share, on sale of property.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $605,000. c-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $760,000. Westmark was a subsidiary of Squibb Corp. until it was spun off Jan. 2.

title: MEDICINE SHOPPE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1987.

title: COLOMBO RETURNS TO LIFE AS CURFEW IS EASED
description: This capital city surged back to life today with the lifting of a curfew imposed after the bombing of the central bus station three days ago.

title: THE ENIGMA OF V.S. NAIPAUL'S SEARCH FOR HIMSELF IN WRITING
description: Shortly before he turned 18, V. S. Naipaul, a ''boy traveling to be a writer,'' left his native Trinidad for the first time and went to England to continue his education at Oxford University. Since then, his life and his art have been a series of journeys - arrivals and departures - as he has tried to find his way and his place in several worlds. Years later, in his maturity, he discovered that the man and the writer were the same person.

title: NEW HEAD OF U.S. BANK BOARD IS NAMED
description: Dan M. Wall, top aide to Senator Jake Garn and staff director of the Senate Banking Committee from 1981 through 1986, has been chosen as the next chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the White House announced today.

title: WRIGHT ACCEPTS A LOSS TO WIN A SPENDING BILL
description: It was nearly midnight Thursday and Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, was stretched out on a sofa in the House lobby.

title: Second of Five Babies Dies
description: The tiniest of the four surviving quintuplets born March 2 died in her mother's arms today. The infant, Kindrea Leigh Jenkins, died of what a hospital spokesman said was ''multiple major organ failure.'' The five babies were born March 2, about 10 weeks prematurely, to Wayne and Robin Jenkins. One died the next day. The three surviving quintuplets were reported in satisfactory condition.

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Confirmation on Gooden
description: Saying that he did not believe a date had been set, Charles Ehrlich, an attorney for Dwight Gooden, confirmed yesterday that the Met pitcher would be released around next Thursday from a drug-rehabilitation center in Manhattan. ''It could be a day earlier or a day later, but it's in that time frame,'' the attorney said in an interview from St. Petersburg, Fla.

title:
PATENTS;
Magnets Put to Use In Processing of Ores
description: LEAD: The mining industry has traditionally separated minerals from ores and beach sands through concentrating them by weight. Edward Martinez of Chapel Hill, N.C., a consultant in mineral and metallurgical processing, proposes in patent 4,659,457, issued this week, that magnets be added to the separators.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCERT: THE PHILADELPHIA IN CARL NIELSEN'S SIXTH
description: Before intermission, the Philadelphia Orchestra concerts on Tuesday resembled too closely the unimaginative affair that is so often criticized when a visiting orchestra comes to Carnegie Hall. First came the short, token contemporary piece (Piston's ''Toccata,'' a well-made exercise), next the very familiar concerto with the very familiar but not quite special soloist (Dvorak, cello, Lynn Harrell, undisciplined expression).

title: GOETZ LOSES LAST-MINUTE ATTEMPT FOR TRIAL DELAY
description: Defense attorneys for Bernhard H. Goetz lost a last-minute bid yesterday to delay his trial or have the charges dismissed. They also said they were seeking several witnesses who were on the subway train on Dec. 22, 1984 -when Mr. Goetz shot four young men -but who were never called to testify before a grand jury.

title: AUTO SAFETY BILL CLEARS SENATE
description: Lap-and-shoulder seat belts would be required in the rear seats of automobiles under a bill passed today by the Senate, and consumers could be able to compare how well the cars they were shopping for would withstand a crash.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $93 million gain from the sale of assets and a $65 million charge from adjustments and writedowns. The company said it had foreign currency losses as a result of fluctuations in the dollar of $10 million for the latest quarter, compared with a loss of $1 million for the year-ago period.

title: Report on Drug Use
description: Two members of the Philadelphia Eagles said that some of their teammates on the 1981 squad apparently attended a drug party the night before the club lost to the Giants in an opening-round playoff game, according to a published report. The Philadelphia Inquirer yesterday quoted John Spagnola, a tight end, and Ron Baker, a guard, as saying they had heard about the party. Spagnola made the comments Thursday in a talk on drugs and sports at a meeting of the Philadelphia Psychiatric Center, according to The Inquirer. Baker's comments came in an interview with the newspaper later that evening.

title: INTERSTATE SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: ARENA READY FOR ATHLETES ON RANDALLS I.
description: Randalls Island, home of New York City's most extensive recreation complex, will have its centerpiece restored today with the reopening of Downing Stadium.

title: FLORIDA WIDENING SALES TAX'S REACH
description: In the face of legal challenges and threatened boycotts, Florida today began preparing to adminster a sales tax affecting advertisers, law firms and accountants across the nation.

description: According to the ''Dictionary of the American West,'' the term ''rustle'' evolved this way:

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock form July 24, 1986.

title: Devils' Chief Resigns
description: Bob Butera resigned as president of the Devils, but he will remain with the club in a part-time managerial and consultant role. John McMullen, chairman of the Devils, said the team would appoint a new president in the next 10 days.

title: Malaysian Holds Party Leadership by a Narrow Vote
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad turned back an unusual challenge to his party leadership in a narrow vote today that could have ended his six-year tenure as Malaysia's leader.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $4,000 and $37,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: DANCE: KENNETH TOSTI CREATES 'DIARY OF A FLY'
description: Beginner's luck? Kenneth Tosti, a leading dancer in the Paul Taylor Dance Company, had never choreographed anything before ''Diary of a Fly,'' which had hundreds cheering following its premiere Thursday night.

title: Japan's Vehicle Output
description: Japan's vehicle production in March rose 4.1 percent from a year earlier, to 1.14 million, the first year-to-year gain after five successive monthly declines, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said. The March output rose from 1.03 million vehicles in February. Production consisted of 720,040 cars, 419,081 trucks, and 5,057 buses. Cumulative January-to-March production totaled 3.11 million vehicles against 3.10 million in the same months last year.

title: Shakuhachi Concert
description: There will be a concert of traditional shakuhachi (Japanese bamboo flute) music by Kodo Araki and Ralph Samuelson, tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Uris Auditorium, presented by the Society for Asian Music and the World Music Institute (206-1050). Tickets are $8, or a Theater Development Fund voucher and $3.

description: b-After gains of $509,000 for the latest 9 months and $330,000 for the year- ago period from the repurchase of debentures.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOAD
L.I.'S GARBAGE NOW AN ISSUE FOR DIPLOMATS
description: The pariah garbage barge from Long Island became an international issue today as Mexican authorities said they would refuse entry to the barge and the Environmental Protection Agency referred all inquiries about the garbage to the State Department.

title: LORD & TAYLOR CELEBRATES THE CHARM OF SAVANNAH
description: When the banjo player struck up ''Dixie,'' nearly 100 Georgians rose to their feet and joined in song. It was the first hint all evening that, much as they were enjoying their trip to New York, it was, after all, a nice place to visit.

title: Vietnam War Resister Enters 2 Guilty Pleas
description: An opponent of the Vietnam War who spent 17 years underground has agreed to plead guilty to a Federal felony charge and a state assault charge stemming from protests in 1969 and 1970, his attorney said.

description: A close friend and adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said yesterday that Mr. Meese never owned stock in the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor at the center of a Federal corruption investigation.

title: GEORGETOWN TEAM SETS MEDLEY RECORD
description: Of the four favored teams in today's distance medley relay at the Penn Relays, Arkansas had one runner from Texas, one from California, one from Canada and one from England. Villanova had two from Ireland, one from Bophuthatswana and one from Delaware. Mount St. Mary's had three from Kenya and one from Zambia.

title: The Perfect Place
description: In that shabby old shrine known as Boston Garden, built on the second floor of the Boston and Maine Railroad Station, and where the only semblance of a garden is when nosegays are sold at the station entrance, the first game of the 1987 National Basketball Association playoffs commenced Thursday night.

GIRL, 17, SAYS HER FATHER FORCED HER TO HELP IN SUBWAY ROBBERIES
description: A 17-year-old girl from Queens, who the authorities said, was part of a father-daughter robbery team, pleaded guilty yesterday to two subway robberies and tearfully told a judge that her father had beaten and slashed her to force her to join him in the crimes.

title: UAL Rejects Offer by Pilots
description: UAL Inc. said today that its directors had rejected as ''grossly inadequate'' a $4.5 billion offer from its pilots' union to buy its United Airlines subsidiary.

title: Experts on AIDS Will Answer Questions
description: Physicians will answer listeners' questions about AIDS during a live call-in radio program on Sunday from 7 to 10 P.M. over the NBC Radio Network; in New York, it can be heard on WNBC-AM (660) and WYNY-FM (97.1).

PATENTS;

description: LEAD: Treatment of prostate cancer in warm-blooded animals and humans is described in patent 4,659,695, granted this week to Prof. Fernand Labrie of the Central Hospital at Laval University in Quebec. The process has been in clincal use in Canada.

description: A. C. Reed and the Spark Plugs will play the blues tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

ART WORLD STUNNED BY 3 FAKES
description: The discovery that three prized pre-Columbian sculptures at the Dallas Museum of Art are actually cheap copies sent tremors through art circles today as curators combed their collections for similar fakes.

description: LEAD: A consulting engineer in Villanova, Pa., proposes that telephone callers get an immediate signal when there is to be no answer. Constantine R. Kraus believes the signal would save 20 seconds on each of the 90 billion such calls made annually.

description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York and northeastern New Jersey area rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, spurred by higher costs for spring and summer clothes.

ISLANDERS SINK AS FLYERS RISE
description: To date, the style of game that carried the Islanders, at heart an ordinary team, into this playoff round was an ordinary style. It was not a particularly vivid style, nor did it demand or accomodate much flair. When the Islanders dumped the puck toward the opponent's goal and chased in after it, they created their own inelegant sort of forechecking, and they usually managed to rattle the opposing goaltender enough to eke out a victory.

title: RADIO STATION CENSORS ITSELF AFTER F.C.C. ACTION
description: A radio station threatened with criminal prosecution for broadcasting a graphic play about homosexuality says that it has pulled possibly sensitive programs off the air and may sue the Federal Communications Commission.

The proposed purchase hinges on Caterpillar reaching an agreement with its workers to end their occupation of the tractor plant, which is located in the southern suburb of Uddingston.

FIDDLING WITH SOUND OF WEILL
description: Who shall say if the business of acoustics is a science or a crap shoot? Some halls glow with an inexplicable beauty - Boston's Symphony Hall, for example, the Concertgebouw in Amsterdam, Vienna's Musikvereinsaal. Others - despite careful planning and exhaustive expertise - have emerged stillborn.

title: Dismiss McCarran-Walter, Not Principle
description: Just a few days before a scheduled hearing, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has withdrawn charges of political subversion against six aliens it seeks to deport. It still wants to oust them but now solely for visa violations. Are these aliens dangerous troublemakers or aren't they? If the I.N.S. had a good deportation case, why did it clutter things up with bad reasons? The original action arose from misguided principle. The new retreat seems unprincipled altogether.

title: KEY RATES
Making Inequity Acceptable
description: Is it really a ''potentially irrelevant factor'' - whatever that may mean - that in the state of Georgia from 1973 to 1978 those who murdered white people were 11 times more likely to receive the death penalty than those who killed blacks?

Tampa Bay received two draft picks and cash. The move came three weeks after the Buccaneers signed Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback who won the Heisman Trophy, to a six-year, $8.2 million contract.

title: Lesson in Legal Spelling

McIntosh and Edward Heller, of Kansas City, Mo., filed a request for a subpoena in connection with their representation of two people involved in an accident. But Federal District Judge Sherman G. Finesilver denied their request, largely because they had written ''subpeona'' in their motion and in a supporting memorandum.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Arias to Play Skoff: Jimmy Arias and Horst Skoff of Austria will meet today after scoring quarterfinal victories yesterday in the Monte Carlo 0pen. Arias advanced when Kent Carlsson of Sweden, seeded seventh, felt dizzy in the second set and had to retire from the match. Arias had taken the first set, 6-0, and the score was 2-2 in the second when Carlsson withdrew. Skoff, an 18-year-old Austrian, beat Andres Gomez of Ecuador, seeded fifth, by 7-5, 2-6, 6-4. Two Swedes will meet in the other semifinal. Mats Wilander beat Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 6-3, and Ulf Stenlund beat Martin Jaite of Argentina, 2-6, 6-0, 7-6. (AP) Mandlikova Advances: Second-seeded Hana Mandlikova edged fifth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini, 7-5, 6-4, last night to advance to the semifinals in the Virginia Slims of Houston. Mandlikova will play third-seeded Chris Evert, who defeated eighth-seeded Kate Gompert, 6-3, 6-3. Earlier in the day, Zina Garrison, seeded fourth, took less than an hour to beat Rafaella Reggi, 6-1, 6-0. She will play top-seeded Martina Navratilova, who eliminated Lori McNeil, 6-1, 6-2, in a quarterfinal match. (AP) Bowling Murtishaw Leads Heading into Final: Jim Murtishaw of Vista, Calif., never bowled less than 201 during the match-play finals and took the lead after the sixth round of the Firestone Tournament of Champions last night. Murtishaw's match-play record was 15-9 with a pinfall of 11,344. After leading the first five rounds, Art Trask of Fresno, Calif., slipped to second. Mark Roth will be seeded third in today's final. Competing in the first match of today's championship will be fourth-seeded Mike Aulby and Pete Weber. (AP) Hockey Russians Edge Canadians: Vladimir Krutov tipped in a shot with 4 minutes 30 seconds to play yesterday, lifting the unbeaten Soviet Union to a 3-2 victory over Canada at the world hockey championships in Vienna. In the day's only other game, Finland upset Sweden, 4-1. The Finns will play Canada Sunday in a game likely to eliminate the loser from the medal round. With the score 2-2, Krutov deflected a long shot past Bob Froese of the Rangers to give the Soviet Union its sixth victory in as many games. Dino Ciccarelli of the North Stars and Kirk Muller of the Devils scored Canada's goals. (AP) Golf Levi Ahead After Two Rounds: Wayne Levi birdied three of his first four holes, then broke away from six challengers on the final three holes yesterday to take a one-shot lead after 36 holes of the Houston Open at The Woodlands. Levi got his sixth birdie with a 20-foot putt on the par-4, 413-yard No. 7 hole and finished with a five-under-par 67 for a 137 total, 7 under for the par-72 Tournament Players Course. (AP)

Down at the other end, his wife, Millie, saw to drawing the final pint of stout for the one regular customer in the place, a quiet man named T. P. Fughnan.

title: CONTRA SUPPLIERS REPORTEDLY GOT U.S. MILITARY HELP
description: The Congressional committees looking into the Iran-contra affair have found evidence that American military personnel in Central America actively helped in the privately led effort to resupply the contras despite a Congressional ban on such help, an official familiar with the investigation said today.

title: 'Moulin Rouge'

The program includes Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' Offenbach's ''Orpheus in the Underworld'' overture (with can-can dancers) and other works by French and American composers. Tickets are $12 and $18 at the door.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, APRIL 25, 1987
description: The Economy

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A CUT-RATE AIR FARE IS CHALLENGED
description: ONE of the most successful new tickets offered by airlines is the ''maxsaver,'' an extremely low fare with an unusual catch: it is nonrefundable. Since airlines started selling the ticket in January, travel associations have credited it with increasing the number of air passengers by 15 percent. Travel agents say the biggest problem is that there are not enough of the tickets to go around.

title: LICENSE REVOKED, A PRIEST FIGHTS ON
description: In the eyes of the Roman Catholic Church and in his own heart, the Rev. Vaclav Maly is no less a priest than he was when he was ordained 15 years ago. But to the Czechoslovak authorities, he is not a priest, having lost his state license eight years ago after he signed petitions for human rights.

title: INDIAN HEAD BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On Rikers Island: Crushing Azaleas To Erect Jails
description: ''Something has got to be done about the crime problem,'' said Pablo Jimenez, 20 years old, doing 8 months on Rikers Island for possession of a gun and selling drugs. ''They're building new prisons and wiping out our nursery.''

FOES IN SUBVERSION CASE CLASH OVER WHETHER U.S. HAS PROOF
description: A Government lawyer asserted today that the Justice Department had the evidence necessary to prove that eight immigrants here engaged in subversive activities to support Palestinian terrorism but was willing to disclose it only in a judicial proceeding barred to the public and the press because of national security considerations.

title: CURBS ON SMOKING ARE STRUCK DOWN IN NEW YORK COURT
description: Just two weeks before broad restrictions on smoking were to go into effect in New York State, a State Supreme Court justice struck them down yesterday because they had been issued without the approval of the Legislature.

title: ISSUE ON THE SHUTTLES: WHO NOSHES BEST?
description: It was the 9 A.M. Eastern Air Lines shuttle from New York to Washington. A New Yorker accepted her little bag of food, a version of what Continental calls the Flying Nosh but comes without a name on Eastern and Pan Am.

title: Reagan to Answer Questions
description: President Reagan, who does not plan to hold a formal news conference in April, will be questioned briefly by six reporters Tuesday, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today. He said a transcript of the 15-minute session with the jouranlists would be made available immediately to the rest of the White House press corps.

title: 18 HURT IN BUS BOMBING NEA U.S. BASE IN ATHENS
description: At least 16 Americans and 2 Greeks were wounded today in a bomb attack on a bus taking them to the United States air base in Athens.

description: Interest rates resumed their rise yesterday as dealers marked down prices of all Treasury maturities in what proved to a largely futile effort to attract investors.

title: Texas Commerce Merger Is Backed
description: Stockholders of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. approved a merger with the Chemical New York Corporation. The merger proposal was approved by 98.7 percent of the 76.2 percent of the stockholders voting. Chemical stockholders are expected to vote on the merger at their annual meeting on Tuesday.

title: INCOME, SPENDING POST WEAK GAINS
description: Personal incomes edged up a tiny two-tenths of 1 percent in March, the poorest showing in four months, while consumer spending was weak after a strong February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CYPRUS MINERALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed most of its earnings drop to the loss of income from two metallurgical coal contracts, which were cancelled by LTV Steel Co., when LTV Corp. filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy code last July.

PRICES INCREASED 0.4% IN MARCH FOR CONSUMERS
description: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed indicator of inflation, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department reported today. On an annual basis, the increases so far this year translate into an inflation rate of 6.2 percent.

title: Seating of 2d Archbishop For Seattle Is Discussed
description: Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle has been asked by a Vatican commission to accept the appointment of an archbishop with whom he would have to consult on important church matters and who would eventually succeed him as head of the troubled archdiocese, several Roman Catholic church officials said yesterday.

title: American Held in Italy In Antiterrorism Effort
description: The Italian police have detained an American woman and five other people in a nationwide dragnet aimed at resurgent left-wing terrorist groups, senior law enforcement officials said today.

title: Lilliputian Politics in Huge Indonesia
description: President Suharto called it a ''festival of democracy,'' but his landslide victory in Indonesia this week was about as spontaneous as a regimental parade. All competing parties favor his re-election to a fifth term, all are financed by his regime, all endorse his nebulous ''Pancasila democracy'' meant to bind together a huge, sprawling nation of over 175 million people.

title: SCHOOLGIRL FINDS VICTORY ALONE IS NOT ENOUGH
description: They exit late each April through the opening in the chain-link fence at the western end of Franklin Field, away from the Versaturf track that is surrounded by walls of brick and streets filled with T-shirt stands, music boxes and exotic pushcart food. The sights and sounds and smells of the Penn Relays provide its soul, but emotions are its heart.

STAGE: 'THE STICK WIFE,' KLAN MEMBERS IN 1963
description: In ''The Stick Wife,'' Darrah Cloud looks through a distorting lens at the Birmingham, Ala., church bombing of 1963. Little is said about the victims or the larger issue of racial injustice and violence in America. ''The Stick Wife,'' at Hartford Stage, is not an overtly political play.

Eccentric Folk-Pop
description: The disk jockey Vin Scelsa will be the host for a triple bill of eccentric folk-pop, called ''For People Who Have to Get Up Early in the Morning,'' tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Featured will be They Might Be Giants, Uncle Bonsai and A Rage to Live. They Might Be Giants cram puns and paradoxes into manic songs; Uncle Bonsai, two women and a male countertenor with a guitar, itemizes the vagaries of romance and junk culture. A Rage to Live is led by Glenn Morrow, formerly of the Individuals. Shows at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $11.

title: Brazil's Trade Surplus
description: Brazil's trade surplus in March totaled $136 million, down from $1.14 billion in the comparable period last year, the official Banco de Brasil said today. In a news conference, the director of the bank's foreign trade department, Roberto Fendt, attributed March's weak performance to strikes by workers. March exports totaled $1.43 billion, against $1.53 billion in February and $2.16 billion in March 1986. Imports in the month totaled $1.29 billion, compared with $1.27 billion in February and $1.02 billion in March 1986.

title: No Way for Women to Treat Women
description: LEAD: It's discouraging to watch the importance and dignity of women put down by the attack on the rights of men to maintain their single-sex clubs.

title: Why Japan's Students Outdo Ours
description: LEAD: The latest reports on the superiority of Japanese students over our students is likely to prompt further debate over why Johnny can't keep up with Hiroshi on standardized achievement tests.

description: A 17-year-old youth was sentenced today to a minimum of 30 years in prison for killing a passer-by who tried to stop another teen-ager from being robbed of a leather bomber jacket. The youth, Damon Venable, was convicted on March 11 in Superior Court of shooting Ronald Griffin, 23, in the stomach when Mr. Griffin tried to recover the jacket.

description: The nation's largest textile producer, Burlington Industries, became a takeover target yesterday.

title: Angola Says It Downed Plane With U.S. Pilot
description: The Angolan press agency said today that Angolan fighters had shot down a small aircraft over southern Angola piloted by an American citizen possibly on a spying mission for South Africa. [ In Washington, State Department officials said they had no information about the report. They said they were urgently trying to get in touch with Angolan officials about it. ] The Angolan press agency, monitored in Lisbon, said the plane, which it did not identify by type, was downed Tuesday over Otchinjau, in Cunene Province, which borders South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. South-West Africa is ruled by South Africa in defiance of the United Nations.

The company also said the second quarter and first half results include about $6.2 million and $10.9 million, respectively, of non-cash acquisition accounting charges related to the acquisition of Uniroyal Chemical Co. description: The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday that it had failed to receive a sufficient number of shares to proceed with a $500 million leveraged buyout of Allegheny International Inc. But it said it still intended to pursue the deal.
