title: TRACING THE NORMAN RULERS OF SICILY
description: Standing in the back of a three-wheel pickup in Piazza Garraffello, a young curly-haired vendor adds his shrill cries to the din that has given Palermo's bustling outdoor market its nickname, 'A Vucciria (The Voices). The young man is knee-deep in gray-green bundles of fresh artichokes, which he tosses about freely and, in the process, reveals a strange series of brightly colored decorations hand-painted along the inside of the back of his pickup.

title: IMAGE SHIFT AT CHARITY FOR ACTRESS
description: When Dina Merrill, the actress, was a newlywed in her 20's, her mother-in-law introduced her to the New York City Mission Society, saying, ''Every bride should have a charity.''

title: A C.E.O. Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: President Warns About a 'Fierce Trade War'
description: President Reagan, seeking to blunt Congressional enactment of tough protectionist legislation, warned today that such laws could set off a ''fierce trade war'' costing millions of American jobs.

title: IT'S A BUSY TIME FOR TROWEL AND SPADE
description: THE native dogwoods need attention since blooms are expanding and leaves will soon follow; use one of the mancozeb-based fungicides applied according to the label rate; make a second and third application at 10-day intervals. On dwarf conifers, use a pruning shears or sharp lawn clipper to cut in half the new growth to keep these needled evergreens in their compact shapes. When tulip and daffodil flowers fade, snap them off promptly to prevent wasteful seed pods from forming; allow foliage of earlier flowering chionodoxa and scillas to ripen naturally. New perennials and shrubs should be planted so they are well established by summer; it is still too early to set out tender annuals and vegetables, either the plants or seed. The Classics

title: Categorizing 'Real Rape'
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Hits Philippines
description: An earthquake shook the capital and other areas of the island of Luzon on Saturday night, sending thousands of people into the streets in panic, the authorities said. No injuries or damage were immediately reported. The Government said the quake struck registered 5.5 on the Richter scale.

title: The Curse of Memory
description: One of the bad things about getting old is that you start living in the past. You keep remembering homey little luncheonettes where gross corporate towers now loom. You remember buying the morning papers in midtown on the way home from a show. You wonder why they don't play more James Taylor and Judy Collins on the radio.

title: R. L. Hornsby Weds Lisa Pines, a Painter
description: Lisa Pines, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan A. Pines of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Leslie Hornsby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bobby Hornsby of Fort Worth. Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin of the Appellate Division, First Department, of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Windows on the World in New York.

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENT TAKES ON NEW ROLE
description: LEAD: IN her 20 years as a top administrator at the College of New Rochelle, Sister Dorothy Ann Kelly has weathered crises ranging from student antiwar protests to alumnae complaints about the expansion of the college.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ELDERFAIR

title: India Studies Payoffs in Arms Deals Abroad
description: Faced with charges of corruption in overseas weapons contracts, the Indian authorities say they have begun investigating the role of local agents hired by foreign suppliers on deals with India.

title: SHAKING UP SLOAN-KETTERING FOR A NEW ASSAULT ON CANCER
description: DR. PAUL A. MARKS IS confident the time is at hand. ''We're ready for the next quantum jump in terms of being effective against cancer,'' he says, his piercing blue eyes staring out through aviator glasses, their very intensity seeming to will the quantum jump to proceed. Marks is president and chief executive officer of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the nation's oldest and largest research and hospital complex devoted exclusively to cancer. It is also the wealthiest, with an annual operating budget of more than $335 million.

title: OPINIONS DIVIDED ON SCIENCE SCHOOL
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR CUOMO'S proposal to create a public school on Long Island for the state's top math and science students has divided legislators and educators.

title: REVISIONS IN ENDING PARENTAL RIGHTS SOUGHT
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to make it easier to strip negligent or incapable parents of their rights and free their children for adoption has been drafted in preparation for introduction in the Legislature.

title: 'Trust Me'
description: I ONCE read that if the universe, having come to the end of its explosion, collapses on itself, time will run backward. On no good grounds I imagine this as meaning that suburbs will grow new, then raw, and will then recede; that surgeons and scientists will daily master the use of cruder instruments; that every life will be shadowed by the inevitable onset of callowness, childhood and dreaded infancy. In such a world retrospection would be visionary, and events would be rescued from seeming entropy, from mere accident and mere loss. So it is in these 22 stories by John Updike, which assume for their characters a past of such density that it stands on the temporal landscape as stolidly as an empty house - promising comfort, needing care, full of habit and purpose somehow interrupted and abandoned.

title: ITALIAN FOOD WITH A PARTY MOOD
description: LA TAVERNETTA in Woodmere bubbles with crowds and excitement. There's a party mood, and the diners all seem to be regulars. There are extravagant greetings and bear hugs. Later in the evening, waiters are slapped on the back by doggie-bag-carting customers as they depart.

title: 'OPEN MIND' SPEAKS OF IDEAS
description: TALK IS ABUNDANT ON TELEVISION, BUT usually in short bursts. Television talk is concise.

title: MOYNIHAN CRITICIZES EDUCATION SECRETARY ON LIMITS ON BONDS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, criticizing Education Secretary William J. Bennett, said yesterday that Federal limits on the authority of such private institutions as universities and hospitals to issue tax-exempt bonds were threatening their abilities to conduct research important to the country.

title: PUTTING ONE'S HOUSE AND LIFE IN ORDER
description: I AM beginning to think that selling a home is an unsettling experience in every sense. About two years ago I mentioned to my children that when I reached 55, I would sell our house and make a few changes in my life. I had been a widow for a number of years; they had established themselves out-of-town, and it seemed wasteful to be taking up so much space by myself.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This year, people want competence and they want passion. All the candidates have pretty good head credentials.

title: Good News for Boyd
description: PLAGUED by a shoulder ailment since early in spring training, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the Boston Red Sox right-hander, has received an encouraging report after an examination Friday at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) The television star's humorous reflections on parenting include thoughts on the care and feeding - as well as the naming, the dressing, the educating and the letting go -of children. Last year our reviewer, Karen Ray, said the book's message is ''that children are often exasperating and that fatherhood is both rewarding and difficult -with emphasis on the difficult.'' THE HOUSE IN PARIS, by Elizabeth Bowen. (Penguin, $6.95.) An illicit love affair blossoming in a French boarding house has tragic and long-lasting consequences for several sets of characters in this novel by the Irish-born author Elizabeth Bowen (1899-1973). In 1936 our reviewer, Edith H. Walton, said the work is ''so perfect of its kind, so witty and so subtly exciting, that even those with robuster tastes can hardly deny its excellence.'' Scenes involving children, she added, ''are almost miraculously good; they are sheer delight. . . . Actual pain and ecstasy break through the fragile, elaborate structure of Miss Bowen's craftsmanship.'' KEEPING HOPE ALIVE: On Becoming a Psychotherapist, by F. Robert Rodman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) While this memoir was intended as a guide for prospective psychotherapists, F. Robert Rodman ''writes so well of his experiences . . . that the book should have wide appeal,'' Dava Sobel said in The Book Review last year. ''Accounts of his patients sparkle with his candid reactions. . . . He has the ability to define monumental concepts in psychiatry - schizophrenia, transference neurosis - in a sentence or two without trivializing them.'' A FALL FROM ALOFT, by Brian Burland. (Norton, $6.95.) Bound for public school in England, 13-year-old James Berkeley leaves his home in Bermuda in 1942, serving on a freighter that must cross submarine-infested waters. In 1970 one reviewer found the novel ''tightly and superbly crafted'' and praised its ''unsentimental, unlovely, and altogether harrowing exposure of adolescence.'' Norton has also reissued the second novel in Brian Burland's Bermudian trilogy, A FEW FLOWERS FOR ST. GEORGE ($6.95). SATURDAY NIGHT: A Backstage History of ''Saturday Night Live,'' by Doug Hill and Jeff Weingrad. (Vintage, $8.95.) The authors trace the evolution of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' program, which achieved cult status in the mid-1970's, and show how the pressure of trying to maintain that popularity affected its creators and stars. ''The book is packed with the kind of behind-the-scenes information that reveals the world behind the hoopla,'' Ellin Stein said here last year, ''besides having a special interest for those fascinated with the mechanics of production.'' NO MARBLE ANGELS, by Joanne Leedom-Ackerman. (Saybrook/Norton, $7.95.) These nine stories are variations on the theme of separation - barriers created by age, race, sex and class. The author writes with honesty and compassion, Jill McCorkle said in these pages in 1985, and ''her dialogue is sharp and accurate, drawing the reader close to the conflicts that produce full-bodied characters deserving of the emotional impact they evoke.'' ALL THE OLYMPIANS: A Biographical Portrait of the Irish Literary Renaissance, by Ulick O'Connor. (Owl/ Holt, $10.95.) The turn-of-the-century Irish literary renaissance was a remarkable phenomenon and produced a galaxy of greats, including the likes of Wilde, Shaw, Yeats, Joyce, O'Casey and Synge. Ulick O'Connor's ''biographical portrait'' of the literary revival ''captures the excitement and the spicy flavor quite splendidly,'' Desmond Rushe said in The Book Review in 1985, ''and a delightfully vivid portrait it is.'' GODBODY, by Theodore Sturgeon. (Signet/New American Library, $3.50.) God reveals Himself to the residents of a small American town in this novel by Theodore Sturgeon (1918-1985). Told in a series of first-person testimonies, the ''modern-dress version of the Gospels, or, to be more accurate, of the Second Coming, is a fitting coda to Mr. Sturgeon's career,'' Gerald Jonas said here in 1986. ''It takes risks that only a mature writer would take, and it is more successful than it has any right to be.'' REDISCOVERING AMERICA: John Muir in His Time and Ours, by Frederick Turner. (Sierra Club, $10.95.) John Muir (1838-1914), the Scottish-born naturalist and conservationist who dedicated his life to preserving America's wilderness areas, is the subject of Frederick Turner's biography. In 1985 our reviewer, John Tallmadge, called it ''imaginative, beautifully written,'' and its style ''masterly and loving.'' Another publisher, Penguin, has reissued MY FIRST SUMMER IN THE SIERRA ($6.95), a diary-memoir written by Muir in the summer of 1869, which he spent in the Sierra Nevada. In 1911 our reviewer found in the record ''some of that quietly joyful stuff of which pastoral poetry is made,'' and said the book is ''charged with the awe that dwells in mountain silences.'' AMMIE, COME HOME, by Barbara Michaels. (Berkley, $3.50.) Ruth Bennett's college-age niece brings a visitor home to their 150-year-old house in Washington's Georgetown section - an archeology professor who's an authority on black magic. ''When the seances get going and the ghosts walk (and talk), the ectoplasm grows thick enough for even nonbelievers to take notice,'' Martin Levin said here in 1968. THREE FARMERS ON THEIR WAY TO A DANCE, by Richard Powers. (McGraw-Hill, $4.95.) This first novel by Richard Powers consists mainly of the unnamed narrator's extended meditation on a 1914 photograph by August Sander of three young German men going to a dance. In 1985 our reviewer, Marco Portales, said the author's ''writing engages, and his re-creation of the characters' thoughts captures postmodern, fragmented 1980's consciousness well.''

title: SOME HIGH PRAISE FOR NEW ISSUES
description: THE glamour of ancient whaling ships and the excitement of manned spacecraft are featured on recant sets from the Marshall Islands. The tiny nation in the western Pacific Ocean is administered by the United States as part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific. Although the United States Postal Service carries mail to and from its shores, the Marshall Islands have been issuing stamps since 1984.

title: FADED GLORY, VANISHED HOPES By John Logue. 230 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.    DREAMS of bygone glory dominate the lives of a diverse group of Alabamians in John Logue's intriguing novel, set in the capital city of Montgomery in 1967. The populist Governor, Jesse Stuart, recalls his youthful hopes that his gifts as a baseball hero would lift his family from rural poverty. A cynical newsman, Jack Harris, yearns for the passion and commitment that had distinguished his coverage of the famous bus boycott. A black clergyman, James Boone Jr., guiltily regrets his loss of faith; his parishioner, Arabella Jackson, whose son has died in Vietnam, wants to bury him on a beloved hillside, now annexed to the city's whites-only cemetery. In covering this dramatic story, Jack Harris runs into an even more explosive one: the Governor is secretly selling criminal pardons to secure his family's fortune before news of his mortal illness becomes public.   There is material here for several novels. Mr. Logue, who is the creative director of Southern Living magazine, nicely catches the inky ambiance of the newsroom before the computer terminal took over, and he has created a persuasive narrative voice for Jack Harris, the editor-narrator. Yet the author allows Harris to tell only portions of the story, disconcertingly shifting in and out of third-person narration in ways that sever the dramatic links his complicated tale requires. Moreover, perhaps his experience as the author of three mystery novels has led Mr. Logue to take technical shortcuts in which violent action substitutes for acuity in characterization.   The story is set precisely in January 1967, yet the mood of the novel seems distinctly late 1970's. Harris walks in front of Martin Luther King Jr.'s church on Dexter Avenue, musing about ''a movement now as forgotten as the river,'' without mentioning the great Selma march past that very spot not two years before. Boone complains that the burial of a black soldier shouldn't cause an uproar because ''nobody here wants to think about this war anymore,'' a sentiment that seems totally wrong for Alabama in 1967. Similarly, the police are stern with the surprisingly small number of redneck opponents of the soldier's burial and astonishingly courteous to the black mourners.   As the soldier's family watches his internment, an angry white family scrambles in the clay to remove a coffin from the adjacent plot. Having failed to rouse a violent protest, they have obtained a court order allowing them to open the grave rather than allow their mother to be buried near a Negro. Despite the historical discontinuities of the mood, Mr. Logue has written a powerful epitaph for the social conflict that still gripped Alabama in 1967.
description: BOATS AGAINST THE CURRENT

title: SUGAR AND SPICE AND EVERYTHING LACY
description: AMONG life's most endearing cliches is the sight of a little girl in lace. Can even the most barnacle-encrusted soul resist the munchkins pictured here? Not likely.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SILVER DREAMS
description: LEAD: WHOEVER said making movies was glamorous?

title: Meatpacker Fined $690,000 By a Federal Safety Agency
description: The Labor Department has fined John Morrell & Company $690,000 for alleged coverups of job-related amputations and other disabling injuries at its meatpacking plant in Sioux Falls, S.D.

title: INTERNATIONAL CASH FLOW FOLLIES
description: HOT MONEY AND THE POLITICS OF DEBT By R. T. Naylor. 463 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: MAY DAY SURPRISES FOR FREE AGENTS
description: THE first day of May means different celebrations to different people. In some places, they have a parade of dancers around the Maypole. In the Soviet Union, they stage a parade of military might. On the first day of May this year, major league baseball will add a new celebration to the world's calendar of May 1 events: the return of chastened free agents to their former teams.

title: Michele Fortune to Marry
description: The engagement of Michele Fortune, senior vice president of merchandising for Lord & Taylor in New York, to Edward G. David has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Fortune of Auburn, Calif. Mr. David, a management consultant in New York, is a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Walter David of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. A June wedding is planned.

title: 53 Veterans Win Long Battle
description: Fifty-three Filipino war veterans have won a 41-year battle for United States citizenship. The men, guerrillas in World War II who fought the Japanese in the Philippines, had sued the Immigration and Naturalization Service, saying the Government had reneged on a promise of citizenship.

title: Spagnola Backs Off
description: JOHN SPAGNOLA said statements he made about drug use by members of the Philadelphia Eagles the night before a 1981 playoff game were based on rumor and innuendo, not specific knowledge.

title: JUSTICE POWELL SHAPING LAW AS SWING MAN ON HIGH COURT
description: He is slender, almost frail at 79 years of age, a soft-spoken Virgina gentleman whose friends worry about his health. His is not a household name.

title: SCIENCE CLASS GOES BEYOND THEORIES
description: LEAD: EACH Monday afternoon throughout this semester, 12 Westchester and Rockland high school students are learning how to use sophisticated chemical instruments in a class at Westchester Community College.

title: 'I HAD TO WIN'
description: NIXON The Education of a Politician 1913-1962. By Stephen E. Ambrose. Illustrated. 752 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: The Son-in-Law Watcher
description: Mell Lazarus can relax about his sons-in-law. He fails to take notice of how easily his daughters controlled him. They evidently learned something from their mother. NANCY GLASSMAN North Woodmere, L.I.

title: DEMON LOVER NO. 2
description: NOTHING NATURAL By Jenny Diski. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Q and A
description: Security Deposit Question: We recently bought a building in Brooklyn with a commercial space on the ground floor that we are using and two rental apartments above. One apartment is rent-controlled and does not have a lease or security deposit; the other, which is not rent controlled, also has no lease. When we bought the building the owner turned over a security deposit for that unit to us. Are we required to put this deposit in an interest-bearing account?

title: ..AND 'UNBANKABLE' HOMEOWNERS GET HELP
description: LEAD: LAST Thanksgiving, Emma Swift was almost at her breaking point. For the second winter in a row, she had no money to fix her furnace, and the prospect of another season of bundling her children in front of the kitchen stove was more than she could face.

title: Arab Motorists Are Targets Of Firebombs in Gaza Strip
description: Gasoline bombs were thrown at two Israeli cars in the occupied Gaza Strip today, an Israeli Army spokesman said. An Arab and his 3-year-old son in one car were slightly wounded, the spokesman said.

title: Amy Klingenstein Engaged to Marry Kenneth Pollinger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Klingenstein of Rye, N.Y., and Abaco, the Bahamas, have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Jo Klingenstein to Kenneth David Pollinger, the son of Merrill R. Pollinger of Bricktown, N.J., and Barbara Kleinrock Pollinger of Trenton.

title: KEY ISSUES FOR L.I. TAKE SHAPE IN ALBANY
description: LEAD: WHEN the State Legislature reconvenes tomorrow, it is expected to start discussion on a wide slate of environmental issues of concern to Long Island.

title: Miss Hambrick Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Patricia Lynne Hambrick to Scott Alden Rossborough took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco. The Rev. Maurice Turner performed the ceremony.

title: HERZOG CELEBRATES AS METS FIZZLE OUT
description: The St. Louis Cardinals' 3-2 victory over the Mets yesterday was the 1,000th victory of Whitey Herzog's 14-year managerial career. Some of his Cardinal colleagues gave him a bottle of 1980 Dom Perignon champagne to celebrate.

title: Medicare Bill Is an Inequitable Old-Age Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: A FRENZY TO MARKET MUTUAL FUNDS
description: HARD hat in hand, a motorcycle messenger strode into the beehive-like Park Avenue office of Fidelity Investments earlier this month. He went directly to a multi-colored video display terminal, punched a few numbers into a keyboard, looked up at the screen and walked away smiling.

title: ANYTHING CAN HAPPEN
description: LEAD: I'VE LIVED IN NEW YORK FOR about 12 years now. I had to build up to it. To someone who grew up in a small suburban town, New York was the city, the center of the creative world. I started with short visits, then increased the dose till I was hooked.

title: WANDERING IN COLETTE'S WORLD
description: Although the writer Colette changed houses at least 14 times in her long life, the house she always returned to in her memories was her first, the house where she was born. Today it remains unchanged, a solid burgher homestead in the little village of St.-Sauveur-en-Puisaye in northwest Burgundy.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Traverse City, Mich.;
Boyne Country Sets the Pace
description: LEAD: THE northeast coast of Lake Michigan from the Grand Traverse Bay area to Little Traverse Bay - one of the Midwest's fastest-growing year-round resort regions - has been given a lift by the decision of the National Governors Association to hold its annual conference here July 26-28. The Governors will meet at the Grand Traverse Resort in Acme, northeast of Traverse City.

title:
FOCUS: OMAHA;
Creating Flexibility In Zoning
description: LEAD: THIS city has adopted its first zoning ordinance overhaul since 1945, and planners say they have borrowed ideas from around the country to shape a code suited for the diverse Midwest community of 350,000 residents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, APRIL 26, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20 A request for refuge for Salvadorans has been made by El Salvador's President to President Reagan. He said that the new United States immigration law could have a disastrous effect on his country's economy. Page 1 The Chernobyl accident did not cause major technical changes in the nuclear power industry in the West, experts say. But they agree that the accident forced new attention to the human factor in nuclear safety. 1 The nuclear disaster's anniversary was noted in Moscow with press reports and news conferences designed to make the day a celebration of Soviet heroism, candor and resourcefulness. 1 In Belfast, a car bomb killed a judge and his wife, the police said. Lord Justice Maurice Gibson was Northern Ireland's second most senior judge. The bomb was set off by the Irish Republican Army, officials said. 1 A Central American peace plan may be in trouble, Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez said. He said he worried that no agreement on the plan will emerge from the upcoming summit of Central American presidents. 15 In Sri Lanka, the navy destroyed a vessel apparently carrying munitions for Tamil guerrillas on Friday night in the strait separating Sri Lanka from southern India. 18 South Africans strike into Zambia 3 Communist paper goes lively 6 Kenya detains U.S. woman 10 U.S. to run Liberia's finances 11 Tamil leaders go to India for talks 18 India studies arms dealings 19 NATIONAL 24-33, 46-49 Justice Powell has cast decisive votes in most major 5-to-4 rulings by the Supreme Court over the past decade. He has had a powerful influence in setting the law of the land on an array of social issues. 1 Image problems for the candidates in the 1988 Presidential race are creating a new campaign style. The contenders are showing their emotions and discussing intimate details about their pasts. 1 A fund-raiser is at the center of the unfolding Iran-contra affair. Carl R. (Spitz) Channell had been a relatively unknown conservative fund-raiser, but he is now a target of several investigations by the Government. 32 A new panel to study AIDS has been recommended to the President, who is expected to approve its creation, White House officials said. The panel would study the crisis and suggest Administration responses. 24 A civil rights group is under fire from critics because of a suit that it filed over legal fees. Critics say the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People cannot afford to waste money on the suit. 33 At some parole hearings, the victims of crime or their next of kin are per-mitted to appear and give testimony. Last year, Oregon joined 32 other states that had already adopted laws to allow such testimony. 29 Thousands marched in Washington to protest American policy in Central America. The marchers, heavily represented by church groups and organized labor, demonstrated in the streets of the Capitol. 32 New Zealanders join in U.S. sheep shearing 24 Development boom in Maryland 24 Cost of parental leave called exaggerated 25 Alcohol affects 24% of families 26 U.S. and Mexico differ on milk and beef imports 28 Deaver's mental state may be issue in trial 30 REGIONAL 34-43, 50-56 An immigrant community is shaken by the deaths caused by the collapse of an apartment building in Bridgeport. The accident killed friends and family members of residents of Waterbury, many of whom came from the same small town in Italy. 1 The search for workers continued at the apartment building, but no signs of life were detected in the rubble of twisted steel and concrete and officials said hopes for survivors had all but vanished. 38 Smokers reacted with ambivalence to a court ruling that smoking in New York State might not be restricted on May 7. ''I realized I was going to go through this no matter what,'' one smoker said of his efforts to quit. 35 Witnesses to a subway shooting will be the focus of the Bernhard H. Goetz trial, lawyers said. Arguments are to begin tomorrow in the trial of Mr. Goetz, who is charged with attempted murder and assault. 38 A Wall Street executive was arrested for purportedly stealing $19 million from a brokerage firm over the past year, officials announced. The accused man is Mark L. Stahl, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers. 43 Bilingual teachers will be recruited by the city from Puerto Rico and, for the first time, from the Dominican Republic, a city official said. Teachers will no longer be recruited from Spain, he said. 42 Boys Clubs debate name change 37 Lines for Putnam condominiums 38 Armenians recall genocide 40 Regents back plan to cut dropout rate 41 Detectives find drug cache 42

title: Casa De Campo
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from an extremely hassled week at Casa de Campo. Hassled is probably the best word to describe the resort, although I never saw the word used in your article (Travel, Dec. 28).

title: RECORDS FROM THE ROADHOUSE
description: ROCK-AND-ROLL IS MORE than 30 years old as a popular phenomenon, and it's astonishing how little we really know about where it came from and how it grew. Book-length histories continue to proliferate, but most are content to restate the same tales and myths. Meanwhile, in England and Europe, the recent flood of reissued recordings from rock's early years shows no signs of abating. These reissues are going to provide future rock historians with a storehouse of primary data beyond their predecessors' wildest dreams.

title: LINGERIE CATALOGUES: CHANGING IMAGES
description: IT'S not Playboy or Penthouse, and its photos of scantily clad models in provocative poses are aimed primarily at women, not men.

title: Boys Clubs Debate Putting Girls in Their Title
description: ''Welcome to the Constitutional Shootout,'' the chairman said to more than 100 people in a conference room yesterday in Manhattan. Laughter rose from the group of conventioneers, primarily men in suits and ties, as some of them waited to fire the first shot.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: White Castle, La.;
Preservation Plus Profits
description: LEAD: THE Old South's way of life may be a thing of the past, but tax credits for rehabilitating historic property have helped restore many Louisiana plantations and create new enterprises in recent years. They have led to the conversion of most of the state's plantations into commercial ventures, offering tours and bed-and-breakfast accommodations.

title: Some Action, More Talk on Japan Trade
description: Japan's reported plan to put up $30 billion for new loans to Latin America is a welcome sign of global responsibility, albeit late. But generous gestures by a nation grown rich on export surpluses mustn't distract from fundamental responsibility -to cut those chronic and disruptive surpluses.

title: THERE IS A PLACE, A SECRET PLACE, OF PRIVATE VISTAS
description: LINDA said she had a surprise. I had to drive but she wouldn't tell me where we were going.

title:
DINING OUT;
A WIDE CHOICE OF JAPANESE FARE
description: LEAD: AFTER some confusion regarding its name, Shinjuku, Central Avenue's newest dining spot, has finally emerged. Named after a section of Tokyo, this unusual Japanese restaurant offers a variety of cooking and dining styles under one roof.

title: THOUSANDS PROTEST U.S. POLICY IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Tens of thousands of demonstrators, many representing churches and organized labor, marched through the streets of Washington today to protest American policy in Central America.

title: HEARST'S EIGHT-YEAR BUYING SPREE
description: THE headlines have been steady and frequent: Hearst buys Esquire and Redbook. Hearst buys William A. Morrow & Company, the book publisher. Hearst buys television stations and cable TV systems.

title: Representative Ford Indicted
description: The Butcher brothers, the financiers whose now collapsed empire once included 27 financial institutions in Tennessee and Kentucky, never hesitated to think big. Neither, according to Federal prosecutors, did Representative Harold E. Ford, a Memphis Democrat.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Winifred Svikhart Wed At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday Winifred Tooley Svikhart, an early-childhood special educator at Family Resource Associates in Shrewsbury, N.J., was married to Michael David Supple, a technician for A.T.&T. Information Systems in Middletown, N.J. The Rev. William Kokoszka performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Miles Svikhart of Rumson and Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Daniel Supple of New Smyrna Beach, Fla.

title: Miss Lamberton Weds Robert H. Morrow 3d
description: Maria Lewis Lamberton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ian Ker Lamberton of Wilmington, N.C., was married there yesterday to Robert Hemphill Morrow 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrow of Philadelphia. The Rev. Robert D. Cook and Bishop Thomas H. Wright, who is retired from the Diocese of Eastern Carolina, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: SIR ALEC: AMID THE LAURELS, VERY HARDY
Deaver's Mental State May Be Issue at Trial
description: The psychological state of Michael K. Deaver, a former Presidential aide, when he gave grand jury and Congressional testimony could become an issue in his perjury trial, legal sources say.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: STATE SCARLET. By David Aaron. (Putnam, $18.95.) David Aaron worked on the National Security Council during the Nixon and Carter Administrations, and his experience serves him well in his first novel, ''State Scarlet.'' It is set in the not-too-distant future. A newly elected President finds his honeymoon is over when terrorists steal a nuclear warhead and threaten this country's annihilation unless the United States removes its military presence from Europe.

title: CABARET: CHRIS BARRETT SINGS SHOW TUNES
description: CHRIS BARRETT attempts to build his sets of songs in the Ambassador Room of the U.N. Plaza Hotel, 44th Street at First Avenue, around the musicals of the spring season on Broadway and London's West End. But the pickings are pretty slim, especially on Broadway, and he is glad to grasp at revivals of shows by Rodgers and Hart or Jerome Kern presently in or planned for London.

title: PORT UNIT TO SPEND $5.8 BILLION
description: LEAD: WITH the recent increases in bridge and tunnel tolls, years of strategic planning by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for a multibillion-dollar capital program are expected to begin to bear fruit.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN COMMANDOS RAID ZAMBIA
description: The South African army struck into Zambia early today by helicopter, killing four Zambians and destroying two buildings in the southwestern town of Livingstone, the Zambian Government said.

title: Colleen Sullivan Weds Wilkie Bushby
description: Colleen Patricia Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Michael Sullivan Jr. of Bethesda, Md., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Little Flower to Wilkie Flint Bushby, the son of James Cheney Bushby of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Diane Brayton Bushby. The Rev. John Hogan performed the ceremony.

title: 'What Makes A Landmark?'
description: Since enactment of New York City's landmark legislation in 1965, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has brought 51 historic districts, with 15,000 buildings, and 700 individual structures under the protection of the law. Considered by some owners the ultimate architectural distinction and by others a nuisance, designation has expanded to include street clocks and even magnolia trees.

title: YOU CAN EXPLAIN ANYTHING IN MEXICO
description: MUMMY By Daniel Curley. 241 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: BICYCLISTS HEADING FOR THE OPEN ROAD
description: SINCE 1965, says Freddie Hoffman of River Edge, he has bicycled more than 600,000 miles, or ''more than enough to go to the moon, orbit twice and come back.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: EMINENT DOMAIN. By Dan O'Brien. (University of Iowa, $13.95.) Just when a reader is ready to draw a depressing conclusion about the new short story in America, along comes Dan O'Brien (co-winner with Russell Working of the 1986 Iowa Short Fiction Award) with a strong and tantalizing collection of 10 short stories, ''Eminent Domain,'' to make such conclusions questionable.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SLAVE CULTURE: Nationalist Theory and the Foundations of Black America. By Sterling Stuckey. (Oxford University, $27.50.) Sterling Stuckey, a professor of history at Northwestern University, accepts anthropological findings that Africa survived in New World slave culture and here posits the theory that these survivals formed the basis for ethnic interaction among slaves who represented a great variety of African tribes, each with its own language and customs.

title: Proof of Guilt?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IS NATURE JUST A FORM OF PRIVATE PROPERTY
description: UNDER A radical new policy that it adopted last week, the Patent and Trademark Office now will consider patenting all forms of animals on earth, with the exception of homo sapiens. Any animal engineered with characteristics not attainable through classical breeding techniques is now considered a ''human invention,'' qualifying as ''patentable subject matter.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an April 12 article about Dr. Mitchell L. Marks and his wife, Dr. Carolyn A. Houss, who received National Health Service Corps scholarships for their medical education and who face financial penalties if they do not accept Government assignments to medically needy areas, the doctors' reason for declining some assignments was incorrectly reported.

title: 3 Killed as Crane Collapses
description: Three workers were killed today and another was injured when a 12-story crane collapsed,, the police said. The four ''apparently rode the crane down as it fell and jumped off when it got close to the ground,'' said Sgt. G. S. Beck of the Dallas police. He said one of the workers was crushed by the crane, which was being dismantled when it fell. The injured worker was taken to the Parkland Memorial Hospital.

title: Military Reports Drug Use Down
description: The armed services say that drug use among military personnel has declined dramatically, presumably because of widespread, random and frequent urine testing.

title: Jennifer Gregory Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday, Jennifer Lovering Gregory and John Stephen Wehrle were married by the Rev. C.Hugh Hildesley. The couple's parents are William Hamilton Gregory 3d of Glen Cove, L.I., and Mrs. Eugene Morris Cheston Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Mr. and Mrs. John Lackey Wehrle of Ladue, Mo.

title: FEELING POOR ON $600,000 A YEAR
description: EVERYONE earning more knows it, but it comes as a shock to those earning less: The New York investment bankers under 30 with staggering $600,000-a-year incomes are not rich and may never be.

title: HOW THE FIRST ROUND MIGHT GO
description: The projected No. 1 picks as selected by Michael Janofsky of The Times. Washington and Los Angeles Rams do not chose until the second round No. of Projected Teams Picks 1st Pick Comment Tampa Bay 16 Vinny Testaverde The Bucs will spend other picks Buccaneers Miami QB trying to improve a poor defense. Los Angeles 9 Ron Morris With Jim Everett developing at Rams S.M.U. WR quarterback, the Rams need a 47th pick speedy receiver to match Ron Brown on the other side.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHENDOOM CAME TO THE DOGWOODS
description: LEAD: DOGWOODS once bloomed on my hillside, in wondrous profusion. Not a few, not a dozen, but scores. Looking out my living room window, the hill falling off precipitously below, my dogwoods filled the air with their white blossoms, like a spring snowstorm. My dogwoods were not transplanted from some nursery row, straight and properly trimmed and set in place by the orderly hand of man.

title: Kenya Detains American Wife of Jailed Historian
description: A university lecturer from New York City who is married to a Kenyan historian jailed since 1982 on sedition charges was picked up by four plainclothes policemen nine days ago and held for about 32 hours before being released.

title: DANGERS OF OUTLAWING OUR DIFFERENCES
description: THE ''English as the official language bill,'' rejected earlier this month by the legislature's Committee on Government Administration and Elections, still keeps me awake nights because proponents are trying to revive it. It is just as upsetting to consider the results of a recent local news poll that showed over 90 percent of the callers favored English as the state's official language.

title: TAMIL LEADERS GO TO INDIA FOR TALKS
description: India summoned Tamil extremist leaders here for secret talks this week and urged them to negotiate a settlement with the Sri Lankan Government, officials and other sources said today The guerrillas reportedly answered that they would not talk with the Colombo Government until it stopped attacks on Tamil strongholds in the northern Jaffna Peninsula.

title: ORIGINAL PRINTS AT THE NEUBERGER BY 16 ARTISTS IN ATELIER PROJECT
description: THE premiere exhibition of original prints by 16 of the nation's leading artists and sculptors opened last week at the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: ADAMS CUP TO NAVY
description: Navy's heavyweight varsity crew won the Adams Cup today, beating Pennsylvania by the minuscule margin of four-tenths of a second. Harvard finished third.

title: BELTER FURNISHES A MARRIAGE
description: GLORIA AND RICHARD Manney began collecting American antique furniture 23 years ago, when Mrs. Manney made their first purchase - a vehemently Victorian chair she saw in the window of an upholstery store. That acquisition started the couple on a 15-year pursuit of 19th-century rococo revival furniture by John Henry Belter and his contemporaries.

title: HAVE YOU HEARD THE ONE ABOUT 'PUNCHLINE'?
description: EVER SINCE THE FIRST COURT jester stood before the throne and delivered a one-liner for the king, the stand-up comic has been making his uphill way in the world. It is a calling whose heroes are mostly unsung, whose practitioners are always endangered by the threat of laughless listeners. Comedians rank with actors and other cultural heroes, such as Sergeant York, Emile Zola and Bernadette, when it comes to being immortalized in movies, but the stand-up has been left standing, off-screen. And now, in a stroke of revisionism, Columbia Pictures is doing a feature film about stand-up comics, starring Sally Field and Tom Hanks.

title: California Chief Told to Expand List of Chemicals
description: A judge has ordered Gov. George Deukmejian to add 201 chemicals to a list of toxic substances he was required to issue under a voter-initiated referendum approved last November.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Judge Harvey R. Sorkow's decision should be reversed on the simple ground that a contract for the sale of a child is illegal and unenforceable as a matter of public policy in the state of New Jersey, as it should be in every other state.

title: Paying The Devil
description: With push-button phones, I no longer ''dial a number,'' I ''mash'' it. I learned this term in Washington, when, on an elevator, I was asked to ''mash'' the button for the fourth floor.

title: Kresge Chain Founder Came From Tradition of Frontier Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: GLASNOST: BETWEEN HOPE AND HISTORY
description: THE news flowing from the Soviet Union these days under the banner of ''glasnost'' often provokes ambivalent reactions and lively debate. Some hail the new openness as a long-awaited thaw, harbinger of a cultural renaissance. From other quarters, skeptical voices urge caution.

title: VIOLENT DEATH MAKES VIOLENTLY UNHAPPY PEOPLE
description: I COULD not imagine what was about to transpire shortly after a second rejection notice from Harper & Row left me feeling once again the anguish about which I wrote. Only a few days later, I read the shocking news about the four teen-agers who took their lives not far from where I live.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
JACK-IN-THE-PULPIT
description: LEAD: Arisaema triphyllum

title: OFFICIALS CITE 22 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Classical Music
description: Sunday's schedule is rich in concerts that will recommend themselves to admirers of the artists involved, but my pick of the bunch is the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra under Nicholas McGegan at Tully Hall at 8 P.M. This group, associated with the leading festival of its kind in the Western Hemisphere, is what you've been waiting for if you assume that ''early instrument'' orchestras are either sterile or inexpert or both. If the playing matches the standard set at the last festival, then the Handel and Geminiani on the program should be rendered with grace, imaginative energy and effortless command. And the orchestral textures are bound to be a revelation for anyone who is not already accustomed to the sound of the old instruments.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LIBRARY AGREEMENT
description: LEAD: The White Plains Public Library and the Westchester Library System have settled a dispute that might otherwise have led to the withdrawal by the White Plains Library from the central library system.

title: IN SEARCH OF A DRUG-FREE WORKPLACE
description: WHEN prospective employees are interviewed at Simmonds Precision in Tarrytown, they are asked to take a drug test. Simmonds, a manufacturer of highly sophisticated electronic instruments for the aircraft industry, has made it a condition of employment that potential Simmonds employees be tested, by urinalysis, for drug abuse.

title: Smoking Rules Are Overturned
description: Just as nonsmokers in New York State were starting to take deep breaths and smokers were planning strategies, a nonsmoking State Supreme Court justice last week threw everyone's plans up in the air.

title: WATER IN EAVES, MILDEW IN CLOSETS AND OTHER PROBLEMS
description: TO catch up on the mail, Home Clinic is devoted this week to answering questions about commonly encountered repair and maintenance problems.

title: WHAT WILL IT TAKE TO UNSETTLE A CARIBOU?
description: INTERIOR SECRETARY DONALD P. HODEL last week set the stage for a classic legislative battle, by recommending that the entire 1.5 million-acre coastal plain within the 19.5 million-acre Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska be opened to oil development.

title: VINTAGE CLOTHES ARE AUCTION OFFSHOOT
description: SOON, Linda Stamm will begin dressing the mannequins, adorning one in billowing piles of Victorian lace, and another, perhaps, in a balloon-skirted, Balenciaga evening gown, the type worn by fashionable Hollywood stars in glamorous 1930's movies.

title:
ART;
UNUSUAL ENERGY MARKS JURIED SHOW
description: LEAD: THE annual Long Island Artists Exhibition, sponsored by the Huntington Township Art League and now on view at the Heckscher Museum, has become one of the region's most popular juried shows. Now in its 32d year, it attracted more than 700 entries, from which a selection was made by Irving Sandler, the art historian and critic, and Gerard McCarthy, an assistant curator at the Brooklyn

title: REVENGER DELAYED
description: A WEEK IN SOUTH DAKOTA By Gary Gildner. 180 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $14.95. THE SECOND BRIDGE By Gary Gildner. 188 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $15.95.

title: CAMPERS WAIT DAYS ON A CONDO TRAIL
description: They began arriving 10 days ago, dozens of people on the condominium trail. In warm sun and then cold rain, they lived in a community of cars, campers and trucks, assuring themselves a chance to pay $175,000 and up for one of the 100 town houses that will become Society Hill.

title: The Japanese Nuremberg
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomb Alert in the Punjab
description: The Punjab police issued an alert and stepped up patrols today against possible bomb attacks by Sikhs. The police said extremists arrested last week told them of plans to bomb social and religious gatherings of Hindus in Amritsar.

title: Money and Freedom
description: MAKING MONEY has always been a passion of mine.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Anne Taylor Fleming's sensitive article is, at the same time, remarkable and disturbing for its casual portrayal of women's sexist attitudes.

title: LOUIS SULLIVAN'S CHICAGO
description: LEAD: Possibly more misfortune through demolition, neglect and remodeling has befallen the buildings of Louis Sullivan than those of any major architect in the 19th and 20th centuries. In his adopted Chicago, Sullivan designed and co-designed over 200 structures, of which about a couple of dozen remain, many of these of modest pretensions, and only two built at the full urban scale of Chicago's Loop.

title: SALVADOR RIGHTS ABUSES STILL OCCUR, G.A.O. SAYS
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, says that some of the Salvadorans sent home from the United States have experienced ''personal security problems'' because of the strife in that country.

title: Dr. Seuss and Butter Orientation
description: To the Editor:

title: INJURED ATHLETE, 17, RETURNS TO COMPETITION
description: AN injury from a bad spill during a training session last year almost ended the promising freestyle skiing career of Stacy Blumer, but there were few signs of the injury as the 17-year-old Southington resident recently capped her comeback by winning the Junior National Freestyle Championships.

title: One Knick Woe For Another
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CELEBRATING TIMEKEEPERS OF TIMES PAST
description: LEAD: CAR clocks and mantle clocks, electro-mechanical clocks and paperweight clocks, cranks for grandfather clocks, pendulums for cuckoo clocks, plus a vast assortment of pocket watches and wristwatches were among the items on display at a meeting of the Westchester chapter of the National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors one recent Sunday morning at the Hommocks School in

title:
ART;
PORTER EXHIBITION YIELDS UNEXPECTED COMPARISONS
description: LEAD: MAJOR bequests of art to eastern Long Island institutions have been surprisingly few, considering the number of artists and patrons in the region. The Parrish Art Museum has two important legacies, however, concentrating on works by William Merritt Chase (1849-1916) and Fairfield Porter (1907-1975), and it takes a serious approach toward its responsibility to the public and to the art.

title:
GARDENING;
KNOW YOUR NEEDS BEFORE BUYING PLANTS
description: LEAD: DEDICATED and casual gardeners alike will descend upon the neighborhood garden center over the next several weekends to create elbow-to-elbow crowds at displays and cash registers. Under such circumstances, it will be next to impossible to get one's question answered or even to read the labels on the products.

title: STAGE: 'EXTENDED WINGS' USES FLIGHT AS A METAPHOR
description: ''THERE are things about the world I can learn only from 5,000 feet above it,'' writes Diane Ackerman in ''On Extended Wings,'' her poetic memoir about learning to fly an airplane. The author's intense philosophical wonderment permeates Sara Brooks's stage adaptation of the work at the No Smoking Playhouse.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRIVATE PRISONS;
CARPETS AND COURSES FOR $100 A DAY
description: LEAD: UNTIL recently, companies that wanted to make money on prisons had to be content with running juvenile-detention facilities, half-way houses and centers for illegal aliens. But now, with state prisons bursting at the seams, the private firms are finding profit opportunities throughout the prison system.

title: 'WATERFORNT' - 'MORE THAN A 90-MINUTE MOVIE'
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the film ''On the Waterfront'' is now part of motion picture lore, the background of my novel ''Waterfront'' is less familiar. This was no ''novelization,'' that bastard word for a bastard byproduct of Hollywood success. Reviewers, actually invoking Zola and Dreiser in their praise of the work, were surprised that after all the kudos the film had received, there was still so much more to say than a 90-minute movie - even one of the best of them - could possibly suggest.

title: POSTINGS: Regulation Fee;
description: New York City is telling landlords to pay up.

title: COMPOSERS FIND SUPPORT IN GROUP
description: ''LET'S face it, new music has a pretty bad reputation,'' said Ken Steen, a 28-year-old composer who lives in Hartford. ''It's a constant frustration for all of us.''

title: Cost of Parental Leave Is Called Exaggerated
description: A proposed law guaranteeing leaves of absence for new parents is likely to cost business substantially less than the multibillion-dollar figure cited by the bill's principal opponents, Government researchers told a Senate panel this week.

title: Terrific Bonus for Smokers
description: So there I was, 13 years old, the smallest boy in my freshman class at DeWitt Clinton High School, smoking a White Owl cigar.

title: AFTER YEARS OF WARNING, JERSEY HAS SUDDEN TRASH CRISIS
description: A BARGE with 3,100 tons of Long Island garbage has been haunting ocean waters from Islip as far south as the Gulf of Mexico in search of a place to dump. Long-distance truckers are hauling waste from the metropolitan region to dumps as far away as West Virginia, Michigan and Ohio.

title: LEFTISTS CLAIM ATHENS ATTACK
description: A left-wing Greek terrorist group said today that it was responsible for a bomb attack on a bus here Friday that wounded 16 American military personnel and dependents and two Greeks.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Sprucing Up Those Weary Downtowns
description: LEAD: DOWNTOWNS developed as the commercial and social centers of their communities, lively places where residents shopped, banked, dined, greeted neighbors and celebrated civic events.

title: TIME TO BET AGAINST THE CLONES?
description: When the International Business Machines Corporation unveiled its new generation of PC's on April 2, the new machines were pronounced impressive, but scarcely the clone killers that had been anticipated. That day, I.B.M.'s stock fell $3.125 to $148, while the stocks of most other personal computer makers rose.

title: NEW ZEALANDERS THRIVE ON U.S. SHEEP SHEARING
description: With a heave, John Burt pulled the sheep on its back and pinned it between his legs. Then, reaching for his clippers, he went to work.

title: THE PITFALLS OF WORKING PAST RETIREMENT
description: AFTER 47 years of work, Mary C. Kelly of West Hartford, Conn., retired from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to a comfortable life of gardening and travel. But a few months later, she was back at work: ''I was bored, and the money comes in handy,'' she said. Today, Mrs. Kelly, 69, and another returned worker share a job at the Travelers Companies as co-directors of the Retiree Job Bank - finding jobs for fellow retirees.

title: DON'T STOP FIGHTING AGAINST WAR CRIMINALS
description: The Ukrainian and Baltic organizations that are attempting to bar the extradition of Karl Linnas, accused as a Nazi war criminal [ ''A Nazi Past and the Present,'' March 29 ] , are also battling to dismantle the Office of Special Investigations, the Nazi-hunting section in the Justice Department. In pursuing their aims, they are employing methods all too reminiscent of McCarthyism by applying such labels as ''the O.S.I./KGB position'' or ''the O.S.I.-KGB conspiracy'' to those favoring extradition to stand trial; and by darkly hinting at ''a special-interest group'' that opposes their efforts.

title: DANCE: ARLET BON GROUP
description: THE Fools Company has presented some fairly awful dance in its International OFFestival each year. The Danse Ensemble Arlet Bon, which performed under festival auspices Wednesday in a bleak basement rehearsal studio at the John Houseman Theater, did not sink to those previous levels. But it was a tedious and disappointing event.

title: O'ROURKE RELEASES LIST OF COUNTY LAND
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH presented as a straightforward inventory of county-owned property, part of which might be suitable for affordable housing, the list circulated last week by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke is being interpreted by some officials as an attempt to ease tensions between his administration and local governments.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: SPACES AND PLACES
description: New York City long offered real estate developers the opportunity to circumvent certain zoning restrictions if, in exchange, they would provide public amenities on the sites of major developments. Now, after some experience, architects have a much better sense of what attracts people than they did in the 1950's, when Lever House and the Seagram Building were among the only skyscrapers in town with outdoor space dedicated to public use. The most successful and active areas, open-air or enclosed, have proved to be those that offer a mixture of attractions - food, seating, architecture, sunlight, air-conditioning, shops, cafes, fountains, art or gardens. Here, three Times writers sample these public spaces around town. RESTAURANTS From the marmoreal opulence of the hall in Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue to the leafy expanse of the Park Avenue Atrium (between 45th and 46th Streets) opportunities for dining, or simply noshing, have blossomed in Manhattan in recent years. The resounding commercial success of the Citicorp Center in midtown, completed 10 years ago, with its buoyant food bazaar on the ground level, underscored the demand in this frenetically paced town for informal drop-in restaurants that satisfy time-pressed office workers and at the same time humanize potentially sterile public spaces.

title: Kenner Incredulous
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OTHER SIDE OF PUERTO RICO
description: Puerto Rico is really two islands in one. Visitors who come for the beach find enough in and around the capital, San Juan, to fill their days. Another Puerto Rico is nestled in the high mountains, shrouded in tropical wilderness. It is an old Puerto Rico, with a history and culture going back to Christopher Columbus and earlier. The adventuresome visitor can get to know something of this other Puerto Rico by taking a two-day drive to the west coast.

title: TWO HADYNS AND 2 EXPERTS IN CAMDEN
description: LEAD: A HAYDN festival that will present music not only by Joseph Haydn, but also by his younger brother, Michael - and will include the first documented performance of a Michael Haydn work - will be offered this week by the music department at Rutgers University's Camden College of Arts and Sciences.

title: ARGENTINA SEEKS JUSTICE FOR PAST WITHOUT LOSING IT'S FUTURE
description: IN the renewed debate over human-rights violations that has come with the Army rebellions of recent days, some Argentines are talking about the excesses that the military committed during the mid-1970s, recalling court testimony of the bestial molestation of women and the torture of men.

title: DEFING A GOOD FIGHT
description: PACIFISM AND THE JUST WAR A Study in Applied Philosophy. By Jenny Teichman. 138 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $19.95. TRANQUILLITAS ORDINIS The Present Failure and Future Promise of American Catholic Thought on War and Peace. By George Weigel. 489 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50.

title: ACROSS THE GENERATIONS, 1915 HAUNTS ARMENIANS
description: Generations have passed, but the terror remains an agonizing rend in the consciousness of the Armenian people.

title: Hovnanian Branches Out
description: Kevork Hovnanian, whose company had $300 million in sales last year, is the fourth-largest home builder in the nation and No. 1 in New Jersey. Now this residential developer is poised to make a big splash in the world of commercial real estate.

title: The Son-in-Law Watcher
description: In his article ''The Son-in-Law Watcher'' (About Men, April 5), Mell Lazarus asks: ''Does she know the first rule of marriage, the one that says it doesn't necessarily have to last forever?'' Is Mr. Lazarus aware of all the consequences of such an attitude? There is a casual outlook on life - if it doesn't work, we'll simply throw it out. But I think that marriage, as an institution, deserves a better fate. FRANK CAROLLO Dongan Hills, S.I.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: LEAD: The Adventures of Mark Twain Produced and directed by Will Vinton; with James Whitmore. Paramount Home Video. 86 minutes. $59.95.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Koyaanisqatsi Presented by Francis Ford Coppola. Produced and directed by Godfrey Reggio. Photography by Ron Fricke. Music by Philip Glass. 1983. Stereo. Pacific Arts Video. 87 minutes. $59.95.

title: 'EXODUS' IN SAMIZDAT: STILL POPULAR AND STILL SUBVERSIVE
description: WHEN Leonid Volvovsky was convicted of slander in 1985 and sentenced to three years in Soviet prison, one of the charges against the Jewish computer expert was that he distributed ''anti-Soviet propaganda'' - namely, Leon Uris's novel ''Exodus.'' Several months earlier, Yakov Levin, a Hebrew teacher in Odessa, had been similarly sentenced to three years for alleged anti-Soviet activities, which also included circulating ''Exodus.'' Both men were released several weeks ago.

title: Hearings Set to Administer Agent Orange Settlement
description: A Federal judge has scheduled two hearings on plans to carry out the $200 million settlement of the Agent Orange suit.

title: ON THE RATING OF COMPOSERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: EASTON, PA.;
A Hometown Investment
description: LEAD: FORMER heavyweight boxing champion Larry Holmes has invested more than $5 million in an office project here that he hopes will draw New York and New Jersey businesses and bolster the image of his hometown.

title: DETECTIVES ON HOMICIDE INQUIRY FIND $18 MILLION DRUG CACHE
description: Two New York City police detectives who went to an Elmhurst, Queens, apartment Friday wanted only to ask some questions about a recent homicide. Instead, they discovered a drug cache with a street value of $18 million and arrested three men described by the authorities as high-level cocaine dealers.

title: TOO-GOOD-TO-BE-TRUE VACATION BARGAINS ON THE RISE
description: Travel swindles are a growth industry.

title: A REMNANT OF A RUSSIAN COMMUNITY
description: LEAD: IN the 1940's and 50's, people used to flock to this Ocean County village to swim, dance, sing, eat and drink.

title: TRIANGLE PARK: NORTH CAROLINA'S HIGH-TECH PAYOFF
description: AZT was all but forgotten, an ineffective cancer drug, when the Burroughs Wellcome Company moved its North American headquarters and research laboratories in 1970 from New York's Westchester County to the Research Triangle Park near here.

title: WITH TEARS AND REVELATION, '88 CONTENDERS SOFTEN IMAGES
description: The Presidential contenders all have image problems.

title: THE BROTHERHOOD OF THE SHROUD
description: THE FIERY CROSS The Ku Klux Klan in America. By Wyn Craig Wade. Illustrated. 526 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ELMER AND HIS FRIENDS Christine Moravick loves Elmer. It appears that Elmer loves Christine. But Elmer and Christine have to part. ''He's just gotten too big for the house,'' Ms. Moravick said. At 1,000 pounds, Elmer is almost too big for the yard.

title: ON THE RATING OF COMPOSERS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATES PURSUE SUNKEN LOOT, REAL AND ARCHEOLOGICAL
description: TO the treasure hunters who scour the seas for gold bullion and pieces of eight, sunken ships mean adventure and dreams of sudden wealth. But to scientists and historians, the wrecks are ''underwater archeological resources,'' as worthy of preservation as Plymouth Rock.

title: QUEEN'S GAMBIT TAKES ON NEW LIFE
description: NOWADAYS, the Queen's Gambit Accepted is truly living up to its name as a real gambit and producing wild games.

title: 38 DOWN: OOPS!
description: FOR SHAME!'' THE letter in my lap exclaims. ''Mr. Hirsch's first name is Elroy -not Leroy! Why don't you get your act together?'' I stare at the accusation in stunned silence. Another ''Gotcha!'' How did I let that mistake go through? And to think that Crazy Legs was one of my football heroes.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
EXPECTANT PARENT FAIR
description: LEAD: Several years ago Toni Calabrese Boelsen, director of marketing and public relations at the White Plains Hospital, noticed a ''mini baby boom'' at the hospital. ''We knew that parents-to-be are very inquisitive, and we wanted to provide education for them,'' Ms. Boelsen recalled. Thus was the Annual Expectant Parent Fair born.

title: FOR SUNS, 'A BLANKET FELL OVER US ALL'
description: ON Tuesday, April 7, we won our fifth straight game, which, for the Phoenix Suns of the last two seasons, was cause for celebration. Wednesday morning we flew home from Seattle, and as we started to land I was kidding some of the younger players that there would probably be a crowd of well-wishers and television crews to greet us. They doubted me, asking, ''Why?'' And I told them that's usually what happens during a late-season surge and especially because the last three games had been won in overtime.

title: About Cars; BRITISH ADD FLAIR TO HONDA MODEL
description: I HAVE to say that I am puzzled.

title: Deaver Charges 'Vindictiveness'
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former top White House aide who last month was indicted on perjury charges a last week renewed his challenge to the constitutionality of the special prosecutor law under which he was charged. Mr. Deaver, a longtime friend of President and Mrs. Reagan, also accused Whitney North Seymour Jr., the prosecutor, or independent counsel in his case, of ''prosecutorial vindictiveness.''

title: FRESH SHAD MIGRATES INTO THE MARKET FROM COASTAL RIVERS
description: FRESH shad, which began to appear in local markets about four weeks ago, is a sure sign of spring. As the weather warms, this fairly large member of the herring family migrates north into coastal rivers to spawn. The shad, a traditional springtime delicacy, makes itself available for harvest.

title: CRIME
description: About four years ago this department encountered S. T. Haymon's ''Ritual Murder,'' and the name of Dorothy Sayers was immediately evoked. Ms. Haymon's settings, delicate probings into human behavior and detailed backgrounds were reminiscent of those of her great predecessor, even if there was no equivalent to Sayers' Lord Peter Wimsey. With Ms. Haymon's new DEATH OF A GOD (St. Martin's, $14.95), there seems no reason to change that estimate.

title: Another Mistake
description: THE wrong woman was named a divisional winner in last Monday's Boston Marathon, according to the Boston Athletic Association, which organizes the event and used a new computer to keep track of the finishers. It was the second such error reported by the association, which declared Carolyn Cappetta of Concord, Mass., as the correct winner of the women's 50-59 age division. Because of a computer mistake, Shirley Foley of Boston's Charlestown's section had been declared winner. The disclosure came a day after it was learned that Sean Sweeney of Annapolis, Md., was erroneously listed as the winner of the men's 50-59 age division. Sweeney did not run in the race.

title: Senate Hearing Due On Collapse of Bridge
description: A subcommittee of the United States Senate is to hold a hearing next month to determine why the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway bridge collapsed into the Schoharie Creek on April 5.

title: M.D.'S TRY WRITING AS OFF-DUTY SPECIALTY
description: LEAD: PARDON the expression, said Dr. Richard Selzer, but a rash of medical doctors in Connecticut, primarily New Haven, have become authors of books for lay audiences.

title: Leanne Bucher Is Married
description: Leanne Beth Bucher, a daughter of Carol and Kenneth Bucher of La Crosse, Ind., was married yesterday to George McPherson Jr., a son of Catherine McPherson of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McPherson. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Leslie Bucher, performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Chapel of the Resurrection at Valparaiso (Ind.) University. Mrs. McPherson is an accounting analyst for the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains. Her husband is an electrical engineer for the United Technologies Corporation in Norwalk, Conn.

title: A CASE SEDUCTION BY THE BROOK
description: IN 1959 CHRISTOPHER HAMPTON, 13 years old, shammed his way into an adult movie theater in which the adult movie was Roger Vadim's adaptation of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' a bomb forgotten by nearly everyone who saw it except, of course, Christopher Hampton, for whom it became a sort of obsession.

title: COME AUTUMN, SERIES SPINOFFS WILL SPROUT IN ABUNDANCE
description: IT'S APRIL. DO YOU KNOW where your favorite TV characters are?

title: THE RECORDINGS, FROM HAYDN TO BRAHMS
description: HAYDN

title: WATCHING THE WATCHERS
description: BEHIND THE FRONT PAGE A Candid Look at How the News Is Made. By David S. Broder. 393 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Anita Storch Is Wed
description: Anita Storch, the daughter of Irma Storch of Clifton, N.J., and the late Dr. Murray Storch, was married yesterday to Jack J. Kassel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E.Joseph Kassel of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J. The bride, a graduate of the University of Maryland, is a stylist for CGI Textiles Ltd. in New York. Mr. Kassel, a graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, is a vice president of the Kassel Corporation in Ramsey, N.J., a wall coverings manufacturer headed by his father.

title: Marion Irwin Is Bride of Paul Turgeon
description: Marion Reynolds Irwin, a daughter of Donald J. Irwin of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Irwin, was married yesterday to Paul Boyd Turgeon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Boyd Turgeon of Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. John Baran performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church in South Norwalk, Conn.

title: White Supremacist At Large
description: One of 15 white supremacists indicted by Federal grand juries on charges of sedition and other crimes remained at large today, the authorities said.

title: TO SAVE WATER BIRDS, THEY'LL COUNT THEM
description: LEAD: ''A WHEEL doesn't run as well if you pull out some of the spokes,'' Paul Stoutenburgh said. ''It's the same thing with birds. They're part of a system, made up of many parts, that creates a complete cycle of life.''

title: NEW ROCHELLE RESISTS AMTRAK'S PLAN FOR STATION
description: AMTRAK is planning to build a new station in New Rochelle to replace its current stop at the Metro-North station in Rye, but what is planned by the railroad as an improvement is looming in New Rochelle as a threat.

title: Dr. Helen Shields Wed to R. A. Aparo
description: Dr. Helen Marie Shields, an assistant professor of medicine at the Harvard Medical School and an internist specializing in gastroenterology at the Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday to Richard Anthony Aparo, a project engineer for research and development in the medical division of the Hewlett-Packard Company in Waltham, Mass. The Rev. Arthur M. Calter performed the ceremony at Our Lady's Roman Catholic Church in Newton, Mass.

title: AFTER FEASTING IN '86, GIANTS GET LEFTOVERS
description: THE REWARDS for the Super Bowl champions were great: parades, celebrations, parties, appearances, endorsements, commercials, autograph parties, dinners, autobiographies and more.

title: A FRENCH PARISH TAKES TO BARRICADES
description: A battered 18th-century church, festooned with daisies and daffodils and strangely littered with the remnants of cinder-block barricades, stands in this residential community in the far western suburbs of Paris as a kind of emblem of a new stage in the long history of religious conflict in France.

title: Chasing a Fortune In Texas Oil
description: THOUSANDS of claimants of an oil fortune believed to be worth billions gathered in Johnson City, Tenn., after decades of frustration to try to establish conclusively that they were heirs.

title: DRIVE-INS WANING
description: THE year was 1946. The place was the Milford Drive-In, Connecticut's first drive-in picture show. Hundreds of Buicks, Studebakers and Packards filled the lot every night, paying 75 cents a carload, to watch the likes of Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and Bette Davis on the 80-foot screen as people listened through speakers attached to their cars.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Vistas Are Opened On Antique Country

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: Bill Cosby's Picture Pages Vol. 3. Math Walt Disney Home Video. 55 minutes. $49.95.

title: Recent Sales
description: Chatham $163,500 8 East Centennial Court 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1-year-old town-house condo; screened porch, wall-to-wall carpeting, 1-car garage; maintenance $138, taxes $2,220. Livingston $167,000 16 Winchester Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,093. South Orange $145,000 657 Hamilton Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 43-year-old colonial; living-room fireplace, den, enclosed patio; taxes $3,494. Springfield $350,000 68 Greenhill Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,853. Succasunna $292,000 107 South Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 85-year-old colonial; family room, 2 fireplaces, in-ground pool; taxes $2,785. Woodbridge $135,000 50 High View Drive 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old town-house condo; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, patio, maintenance $78; taxes $1,977. OTHER AREAS Lincolndale, N.Y. $229,000 Orange Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old frame raised ranch; deck, beach rights; taxes $2,595. Stratford, Conn. $173,500 399 Windsor Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; screened porch, deck; taxes $1,230. Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. $145,000 15 Arlington Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, central A/C, porch; taxes $2,000.

title: COURT STANDS BEHIND THE DEATH PENALTY
description: OPPONENTS of the death penalty had viewed McCleskey v. Kemp as their best hope since the Supreme Court allowed states to resume executions a decade ago. For Warren McCleskey of Georgia's death row, and in effect for hundreds of others, the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund argued that the sentencing process was infected with racism and therefore unconstitutional. Last week the Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, disagreed.

title: TEX-MEX MENU AT MODERTE PRICES
description: LURED by an advertisement, we entered a new restaurant, Chavoya's, in the small revived shopping complex along Whalley Avenue in New Haven. Inside, the configuration of the room revives memories of Bourbon Street, a former inhabitant of the space. The juxtaposition of the long bar area, separate from but open to the large two-tiered dining room, stirs echoes of the past. Pink is the dominant color again, in tablecloths and as part of the pastel flower paintings on the walls, whose floral motif is picked up in the fabric seat coverings of the bentwood chairs.

title: Anger and Arson In Queens
description: When the Jewish Child Care Association of New York announced last year that it planned to establish a foster home for adolescent girls in the predominantly white community of Fresh Meadows, Queens, it immediately encountered angry opposition. Residents said that such use of the property would cause real estate values to drop and could endanger their children.

title: ORCHESTRAS SET TO CALL IT A SEASON
description: A VARIETY of operatic and musical-theater productions are being scheduled as orchestras conclude season concert series.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about a Beijing production of ''The Music Man'' gave an incorrect location for the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center. It is in Waterford, Conn.

title: HOMELESS HELPED BY YALE STUDENTS
description: LEAD: VERA WHITE expected trouble last November when she was told the state was cutting off her emergency housing benefits. She expected that she and her three children would have to pack their belongings and leave the Branford Motel, with no forwarding address. It was the second motel they had lived in since their September eviction from an apartment in New

title: GAS-PIPELINE PLAN STIRS DEBATE
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to transport 200 million cubic feet of natural gas a day via a pipeline from Canada has aroused anger among some Long Island residents.

title: CONGRESS DRAWS A BEAD ON THE IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
description: A LULL set in several weeks ago in the news about the Reagan Administration's dealings with Iran and the rebel forces in Nicaragua. But the White House and the Capitol are gripped by the sense that this period of calm is an illusion. On May 5, a week from Tuesday, the special Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair will begin public, televised hearings. No one doubts that thunderbolts will once more begin to fall.

title: LAKERS COAST TO VICTORY
description: The Denver Nuggets got physical with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and the rest of the Los Angeles Lakers this afternoon, but it didn't do any good.

title: New Look at 'Star Wars': Back In the Future?
description: Even the supporters of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative concede that an antimissile weapons system of lasers and particle beams sounds futuristic. But they insist that the technology can be developed to deploy ''Star Wars'' in this century. Last week, a panel of leading American physicists disputed that forecast, saying it will take at least a decade of testing just to determine whether the weapons will work.

title: Gary Davis Burnett Wed To Nicole Anne Sandifer
description: Nicole Anne Sandifer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Sandifer Jr. of New York and Juillac, France, was married yesterday to Gary Davis Burnett, a son of Lieut. Col. Donald H. Burnett, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Burnett of Durham, N.H. The Rev. Dr. Walter Wagoner performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS:APRIL 26, 1987
