title: QUIET ELEGANCE SETS OFF SHOW AT ARMORY
description: WITH three New Jersey artists honored for their contributions to the craft field, a first-time event designed to establish a new level of ''peak experience'' in craft shows will open in New York City Thursday night with a benefit preview and continue through next Sunday.

title: Building Collapses In Bridgeport, 28 Feared Dead
description: A 13-story apartment building under construction in Bridgeport, Conn., collapsed with a roar last week, crushing at least 13 construction workers to death. Fifteen others were missing in the rubble and a dozen more were injured.

title: Cable TV
description: Glenda Jackson fans - and who isn't? -have a double treat from England this week with the home-screen premiere of ''Turtle Diary'' (1986) and a repeat of the memorable ''Stevie'' (1978), both on Bravo.

title: Makers of the Bomb
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT DO GIANTS AND JETS NEED IN DRAFT?
description: The Giants' and Jets' needs in the draft offer an ironic twist: To round out their championship squad, the Giants could use a top-flight wide receiver, which the Jets have.

title: A PILGRIMAGE OF TASTES AND SIGHTS
description: Siculus coquus et Sicula mensa - a Sicilian cook and a Sicilian table -was a proverbial aspiration of the gourmet in classical Rome, and throughout subsequent centuries travelers to Sicily have lavished praise on the island's food, but it is not always easy for the contemporary tourist to understand why.

title: A COALITION GETS $43,800
description: An ecumenical, multiracial coalition formed after the Howard Beach racial attack has received $43,800 to train high-school students and adults in resolving racial and ethnic disputes.

title: Kathleen Clancy To Wed This Fall
description: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Clancy to Hallett R. Gates 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gates Jr. of New York and Lyme, Conn., has been announced by Dorothy Clancy of Morristown, N.J., and Richard J. Clancy of Boston, parents of the bride-to-be. An October wedding is planned. Miss Clancy is an associate in the retail division in New York of Allied Irish Banks. She attended Mount Vernon College and graduated from Xavier University. She is a member of the Junior League of New York. Her father is president of the Clancy Management Corporation and a vice president of Moors & Cabot Investor Services, both in Boston.

title: DURATE APPEALS TO REAGAN TO LET SALVADORANS STAY
description: The President of El Salvador, alarmed about the new United States immigration law, has appealed to President Reagan to give temporary refuge to Salvadorans living illegally in this country.

title: Launching The Basilica
description: AT the heart of Boston's plan to transform the Charlestown Navy Yard into a mixed-use waterfront neighborhood is Building 106, a cavernous turn-of-the-century warehouse the Navy built to house a metal-working shop.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GETTING BLUE. By Peter Gethers. (Delacorte, $16.95.) Alex Justin is an ordinary New York teen-ager who lives with his family in Stuyvesant Town in the 1950's when we first meet him in these pages. Ordinary - but for one thing: he is an extraordinary baseball player who makes it onto the farm teams, into the majors and, 30 years later, to the perfect play that he dreamed about all his life. As we follow Alex through four decades, it soon becomes clear that although Peter Gethers has framed his story knowledgeably and colorfully around the national pastime, he is more interested in the dreams of men and women, those who seek perfection and recognition - as he calls it, ''getting blue'' -and those who shy away from it. Mr. Gethers, who has written a previous novel, ''The Dandy,'' and is a co-author of ''Rotisserie League Baseball,'' writes excellent descriptions of farm-team life in a Southern town where Alex meets the young players he will grow old with. The range of characters is, like that of war stories, wide: the Deep South fundamentalist who has a hopeless predilection for getting hit by pitched balls, the superb young black outfielder, the Midwestern pitcher who is too cynical to be carried away by the spirit of the game. In effect, the women serve as mere accessories, except perhaps Alex's wife, who learns that she too is a person unto herself. The story is lined with violence and inordinate clinical accounts of sexual encounters, to the point where thighs and sighs, thrashing and bashing, obscure what begins as an intelligent and sensitive treatment of a man who discovers for himself that nothing fails like success. For all its wool-gathering and bed-rumpling, ''Getting Blue'' is a good, fast read. Mr. Gethers may not have homered, but he has hit a very nice double.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS A SPECIAL PANEL ON AIDS CRISIS
description: President Reagan is expected to approve creation of a special commission to study the AIDS crisis and suggest ways for the Administration to respond to what he has called ''Public Health Enemy No. 1,'' according to senior White House officials.

title: A DAUGHTER ALL HER LIFE
description: FIERCE ATTACHMENTS A Memoir. By Vivian Gornick. 204 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: Casa De Campo
description: Touran I. Rateb, managing director of Casa de Campo, replies: Casa de Campo was completely booked during the days of both visits, which were in February. Problems of this nature occur at times during peak periods, as extended stay-overs create a sold-out situation. The hotel tried to provide the best alternative accommodation in order to alleviate the inconvenience. At Casa de Campo we are continually looking for ways to increase guest satisfaction. Because of this we are starting construction of an additional 100 casita rooms. We have also just received an additional 200 guest power carts as well as the long-awaited imported parts to repair the existing carts. Construction is well under way on a third Pete Dye golf course, and additional buses have been ordered to keep the transportation system on schedule.

title: U.S. and Jacksonville, N.C. Reach Accord in Bias Lawsuit
description: The Justice Department announced Friday that it had approved a consent decree with the City of Jacksonville, N.C., and its Fire Department in a discrimination suit.

title: BEST SELLERS: APRIL 26, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 6 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 12 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 3 5 13 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 4 3 7 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an international arms-selling intrigue. 5 4 5 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) The 30-year romance of a couple with diverse backgrounds and ambitions. 6 7 3 TEXASVILLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) From the 50's to the 80's in Thalia, Tex. - a sequel to ''The Last Picture Show.'' 7 8 3 THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 9 9 3 THE THANATOS SYNDROME, by Walker Percy. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) The continuing battle between good and evil seen through a psychiatrist's adventures in 1996. 10 12 26 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy aviators at war over Vietnam. 11 1 NO DEALS, MR. BOND, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $13.95.) James Bond returns to solve a case of ritual killings of amazing similarity. 12 * 10 30 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 13 15 33 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 14 2 SANTORINI, by Alistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Espionage, treachery and retrieval of a sunken atom bomb in the Aegean. 15 1 THE ENIGMA OF ARRIVAL, by V. S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $17.95.) Australia from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. 5 8 2 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Putnam, $17.95.) The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable fro those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THAT NIGHT, by Alice McDermott. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) A brief, elegiac, lyrical, morally complex novel centered on a teen-age love affair sometime ago on Long Island. AN INSULAR POSSESSION, by Timothy Mo. (Random House, $19.95.) Why the good do evil, and vice versa, is the conundrum at the heart of Mr. Mo's grand-scale historical novel of 19th-century China and its colonial exploiters, all richly drawn and lively. HOW I GREW, by Mary McCarthy. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) ''There is no dampness in my emotions,'' Miss McCarthy writes in this account of her early life, and there isn't; facts are extracted from memory by a strict, piercing inward stare. TEMPORARY SHELTER, by Mary Gordon. (Random House, $16.95.) Frightened and suffering women inhabit these 20 short stories, women scared for their children, their lovers, themselves; gloom penetrates the author's personal, diarylike manner. A HISTORY OF THE JEWS, by Paul Johnson. (Harper & Row, $25.) An estimable one-volume account covering the last 4,000 years, by the distinguished and omnivorous British journalist and film writer whose earlier productions include ''A History of Christianity'' and ''A History of the English People.'' WHERE IS NICARAGUA? by Peter Davis. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The documentary film maker (''Hearts and Minds'') visits Nicaragua as an intelligent amateur, a curious gringo offering penetrating questions rather than answers about the country as a revolutionary experiment and as an icon in the American mind. STARING AT THE SUN, by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $15.95.) Precision of language, ironic detachment, a talent for incarnating ideas: these are the author's tools in a brilliant novel about a woman living between God and technology in the 21st century.

title: The Lions in Spring
description: COACH Larry McElreavy of Columbia, which has no victories in its last 34 football games and has suffered 31 straight losses, surveyed 92 candidates yesterday during the one day of spring practice allowed Ivy League teams. ''In some ways I'm glad we didn't win a game last year because we didn't work hard enough to deserve it,'' said McElreavy, whose Lions were 0-10 last season. ''It would have been positive reinforcement for the wrong reasons.

title: VOLUNTEERS SOUGHT FOR DEPRESSION RESEARCH
description: LEAD: TO discover how biological rhythms affect individuals who have been described as clinically depressed, the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center - Westchester Division has begun a study using paid volunteers.

title: A DIFFERENT KIND OF DOCTOR
description: CHEU TE?'' ASKS DR. JOSEPH Lurio, and the broad-faced Cambodian woman in the chair facing him nods: yes, it does hurt. He turns to Somontha Lam, a Cambodian translator employed by this family clinic, and asks, ''Did she ever go to her orthopedics appointment?''

title: DEBORAH B. RICHARDSON WEDS RICHARD BEINECKE
description: Deborah Brewster Richardson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas deQuartel Richardson of Norwak, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Hinrichs Beinecke, the son of Herbert H. Hinrichs of Tenafly, NJ., and Mary Ann Beinecke of Port Clyde, Mr. The Rev. Donald W. Emig, pastor emeritus of the United Congregational Church of Rowayton, Conn., and the Rev. John Eusden, former chaplain of tilliams College, officiated at the Drumlin Farms Sanctuary of the Massachusetts Audubon Socity inLincoln, Mass.

title: THE LINNAS CASE: 'THE U.S. WAS A HAVEN FOR NAZI WAR CRIMINALS'
description: WHEN Karl Linnas stepped onto the airport runway in Tallinn in his native Estonia Tuesday, he completed his passage from the hands of the American judicial system to the Soviet Union. Mr. Linnas, a 67-year-old Long Island resident, was sentenced in absentia to death by the Russians 25 years ago for war crimes, although Soviet officials said his case would be reviewed.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Crime Peril? Or Paranoia?
description: After Bernhard Goetz pulled a gun and shot down four young men he believed were about to mug him on a subway train on Dec. 22, 1984, his case quickly evolved into a Rorschach test. Crime victims, civil libertarians, gun owners - each could find satisfaction, outrage or vindication in the case. The various reactions attest to the ambiguity of what actually happened. The Goetz trial, which starts tomorrow after years of preliminary skirmishes, can finally resolve some nagging questions:

title: BEHIND SRI LANKAN COMMUNIQUES, A FRUSTRATION OVER INDIA'S ROLE
description: The Sri Lankan Government said today that its navy destroyed a vessel apparently carrying munitions for Tamil guerrillas on Friday night in the strait separating Sri Lanka from southern India.

title: Knicks' Priority: The G.M.
description: JUDGING by the headlines, the Knicks' search for a new coach appears confined to Rick Pitino, the former Knick assistant coach who guided Providence to the Final Four last month. But according to Richard H. Evans, the new corporate commander at Madison Square Garden, the search has just begun both for a coach and, even more important, for the successor to Scotty Stirling as general manager.

title: Kevin Miller Wed To Nancy Morris
description: Nancy Ford Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Adams Morris Jr. of Plandome Manor, L.I., and Kevin deWolfe Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hodges Miller Jr. of Munsey Park, L.I., were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Jeffery Johnston performed the ceremony.

title: Christina A. Nichols and Brian Carter Are Married
description: Christina A. Nichols and Brian Carter were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. T.Guthrie Speers. Elinor Ritt was maid of honor and the bridgroom's brother, Bruce A. Carter, was best man.

title: CELLO: ANDRE EMELIANOFF AND GUESTS
description: ONE comes across few recitals with such concern for substance and adventure as Andre Emelianoff's ''Cello Plus One'' at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. The ''One'' in Mr. Emelianoff's program ranged from piano to soprano to timpani to prerecorded tape. There was also music of considerable quality -some of it new, all of it from the 20th century.

title: NAVY FAMILIES FIND HOUSING IN NEWPORT STRAINING PAYCHECKS
description: Newport, with its millionaires' mansions, is a hard place to live on a Navy sailor's salary, sailors and their families say.

title: Paying The Devil
description: In answer to the question ''What are things called when they are cooked in a microwave?'' - they are ''nuked.'' Someone should spend a week with high-school students. We come up with all the new words. HEATHER WOODING Blairstown, N.J.

title: The Son-in-Law Watcher
description: Mell Lazarus apparently has never noticed the way men routinely treat women and the way husbands routinely treat their wives in this culture. No news here.

title: SCENT'S THE THING
description: LIKE A REGENCY HIGHBOY OR A PORTRAIT by Sargent, some scents claim a pedigree. Caswell-Massey, an American purveyor of fragrances and grooming aids, likes to boast that George Washington wore its No. 6 cologne, a blend of natural essences aged, to this day, in sturdy oaken casks.

title: CLARA SCHUMANN AND HER PUPILS
description: CLARA SCHUMANN - THE widow of Robert, friend and spiritual mentor to Johannes Brahms, expert and often eloquent minor composer and, by all accounts, a great pianist and teacher - was one of the most remarkable women of the 19th century. Now Pearl, a record company based in England, has issued a nine-disk set titled ''Pupils of Clara Schumann'' (Pearl CLA 1000, LP only, available from Qualiton Imports, 3928 Crescent Street, Long Island City, Queens, 11101.) It is of considerable interest, although it does not tell the whole story.

title: Debora L. Spar, a Student, Is Married to an Architect
description: Debora Lynn Spar, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin H. Spar of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Miltos Catomeris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Spiros Catomeris of Toronto and Corfu, Greece, were married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Mikelson, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Memorial Church in Harvard University.

title: Jocelyn Javits Has Wedding
description: Jocelyn I. Javits, the daughter of Stephanie L. Javits of Key Biscayne, Fla., and Eric M. Javits of New York, Southampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Timothy D. Williamson, a son of Rhea Williamson of Murphysboro, Ill., and the late Russell M. Williamson. The Rev. Elwood Graves, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Javits home in Palm Beach.

title: Headliners; Off the Street
description: The spectacular stock market career of Ivan F. Boesky came to a formal end last week in perhaps the most significant trade of Mr. Boesky's life. Appearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Boesky, who made hundreds of millions of dollars on Wall Street, pleaded guilty to one count of violating securities laws, presumably in return for a lenient sentence. As part of the deal, he has also helped implicate others in Wall Street's insider trading scandal and agreed to pay a $100 million civil penalty and to get out of the securities business.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: INTO LOVE AND OUT AGAIN. By Elinor Lipman. (Viking, $15.95.) Reading this collection of stories is very much like meeting half the residents of a small New England town. Or perhaps meeting most of the women. Elinor Lipman, who has published her stories in a variety of magazines, comically presents the frustrations of women whose lives aren't going the way they planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE LIBERATION OF BEING A GRANDPARENT
description: LEAD: LAST summer I achieved, through no personal effort, a milestone: I became a grandfather for the first time.

title: The Star Wars Chip: Use It or Lose It
description: President Reagan is fond of saying that the Russians are tough bargainers. They are, and thus they must see what's happening to Star Wars, his key bargaining chip in the strategic arms talks. He's on the verge of losing it. Mr. Reagan's vision of a Strategic Defense Initiative may never be achievable in space but it has packed a powerful diplomatic punch. Moscow has shown itself willing to pay a high price in reducing offensive arms to slow the program down. But now the dream and the punch are fading, fast. Congress expects to cut the Star Wars funding request in half. Equally devastating, a group of leading American physicists now concludes that it would take 10 years even to assess whether critical Star Wars components would work.

title: MISSLE ISSUE TANGLES PARTY LINES
description: THROUGHOUT the capital last week, experts in and out of Government were debating a momentous question: Would the United States and the Western alliance be better off reaching an agreement with the Soviet Union to limit nuclear arms in Europe? Or would the West be more secure if it retained and augmented its arsenals?

title: Casa De Campo
description: To the Editor: After reading about Casa de Campo one cold Sunday, I couldn't resist this vacation paradise. I wish to inform you about the real Casa de Campo.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: In her article ''Our Fascination With Baby M'' (March 29), Anne Taylor Fleming expresses with great lucidity that the central issue in the Baby M case is motherhood. Indeed, the right of a mother to her child has been one of very few ''absolutes'' in our society - so basic that the framers of the Constitution never thought that it needed to be guaranteed. The emotional impact of the case, and the danger that it presents, stem from the fact that this right is being challenged on grounds of economic status and contract law. GAIL RAIMI DREYFUSS Madison, Wis.

title: PARENTS COUNSELED ON SPINA BIFIDA
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of heightened sensitivity to anesthesia, Linda Caruso of Thornwood slept for almost two days following the birth of her son, Michael, who was born by Caesarian section five years ago. When she awoke, it took only one look at her husband's face to know that something tragic had occurred.

title: EXTRAS ADORN LOW-PRICE AUDIO
description: ON HAPPY THOUGH IN-frequent occasions, one encounters audio equipment that might be described as congenial and considerate. What makes it so -aside from good performance - are thoughtful engineering touches that contribute to the listener's convenience and pleasure.

title: FLORIDA MARKET: BALLYHOO AND BARGAINS
description: COMMERCIALS for ''Mediterranean villas'' fill Florida's airwaves and the state's roadways are littered with billboards announcing such events as the grand opening of the 19th phase of the 34th suburban-style project on the left.

title: WRITERS EXCHANGE WORDS WITH PUBLIC
description: ON a recent evening Margaret Gibson, a poet, brought ''Photographs, Footnotes, and the Foul Rag and Bone Shop of the Heart'' - a talk on the sources she used for her latest book - to an audience at Otis Library in Norwich. Earlier that day, she discussed poetry with students in a writing class at Mohegan Community College, also in Norwich.

title: ON THE RATING OF COMPOSERS
description: To the Editor:

title: The PAWs That Refresh
description: THOMAS B. MORGAN is a classy writer. His new novel, ''Snyder's Walk,'' is about a crusty magazine writer's confrontation with the peace movement in the mid-1960's, and critics will hail it for all the right reasons, but I know he is a classy writer because he makes a poetic allusion the way it ought to be done -cold turkey, no hints, and if the reader gets it, fine; if not, not.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: HEADLIGHTS AT HIGH NOON;
A SILENT SPRING IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: LEAD: ACCORDING to Marxist theory, environmental problems cannot occur in Socialist countries because man and nature are inherently in harmony. Unfortunately, the trees, rivers and air of Eastern Europe do not understand Marx.

title: George H. Gillies Dies at 95; An Authority on Horticulture
description: George H. Gillies, a noted horticulturist, died Thursday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 95 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FROM THE CAMERAS OF LIFE

title: A Lively Format for Italy's Communist Paper
description: Posters put up in Italy's major cities in the last few days announced that the Italian Communist Party's newspaper, L'Unita, now offered its readers ''the new battles, the new ideas, the new desires.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: The G.N.P. Gallop?

title: 4.3% G.N.P. GROWTH DRAWS FEW CHEERS
description: The economy grew at a 4.3 percent rate in the first quarter, the best performance since 1984. Still, the news had economists scowling rather than cheering. They say the increase came mainly from a buildup in inventories that could cause manufacturing to slow, dragging down future growth. Most of the sectors that make up the G.N.P. actually showed declines. Growth in the fourth quarter of 1986 was at just a 1.1 percent rate, and some analysts suggested that a more accurate reading of the economy would be obtained by averaging the two quarters, to a 2.7 percent rate.

title: The 'Hybrid Pseudo-Modern' on Columbus Circle
description: THE 50's may be back in style, but not soon enough to save the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. The exposition hall has been sold to Coliseum Associates for demolition to make way for a mixed-use project with two towers rising 68 and 58 stories. Construction is scheduled to begin late in the spring and by summer's end the blank, boxy Coliseum will be but a memory.

title: Unconscious Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY NEWARK'S ARK SHOULD BE SAVED
description: For five years, Kea Tawana has been building an ark with material from abandoned buildings in Newark's Central Ward. She sees the vessel - 86 feet long, 20 feet wide and 28 feet high - as a symbol of new life for a neighborhood racked by riots 20 years ago.

title: PANDA PAS DE DEUX IN BRONX
description: A couple of giant pandas, which have not been known to live voluntarily in New York, flew in from China for a visit last week. At the same time, state officials disclosed plans to reintroduce the lynx to the wilds of New York, from which the small wildcats departed when loggers moved in a century ago.

title: A DISCOGRAPHY OF THE CLASSICAL SYMPHONY
description: IN THE 1950'S AND EVEN 60'S, IT was possible to compile lists of recommended recordings from a fairly narrow field, and to know that, in terms of recorded sound, all the competing versions were in the same rough competitive league.

title: Next Week; Are Viewers Entitled to Games on Free TV?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: HOSPITALITY JOBS GO BEGGING AMID BOOM
description: LEAD: THE rapid growth of the hotel and restaurant industry in the state has created a greater demand for an already short supply of managers and executives in those field, a situation that colleges, with the help of a tuition program, are seeking to remedy.

title: By QUEEN OF PARNASSUS
description: JUDITH GAUTIER A Biography. By Joanna Richardson. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $22.95.

title: JETS NEED HELP EVERYWHERE
description: THEY were the team that had everything only a draft ago. Now, the Jets seem to need everything, at least defensively.

title: Headliners; Out of the Club
description: Joe Hunt, leader of a California group called the Billionaire Boys Club, is no longer a boy and, as of last week, unlikely to become a billionaire. After a five-month-long trial, Mr. Hunt was convicted murdering Ronald Levin, a Beverly Hills man who duped him in a business deal. Mr. Levin's body has not been found. Fellow club members testified that the 27-year-old Mr. Hunt boasted of killing Mr. Levin after forcing him to sign a $1.5 million check. The jury, which disregarded testimony that Mr. Levin had been seen alive since his supposed death, is to decide in May whether Mr. Hunt should get life in prison or death.

title: Data Update: April 26, 1987
description: NATIONAL HOUSING TRENDS (In thousands of units, seasonally adjusted annual rates)

title: Data Bank: April 26, 1987
VERMONT TOWN UNITES TO AID REFUGEE FAMILY
description: The plastic pages of the brown photograph album are smudged with fingerprints. Sarin Rom turns those pages over again and again, studying the pictures of his family. They are all he has seen of them for seven years.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRIVATE PRISONS;
WEEKEND WORK WITHOUT TRIPLE PAY
description: LEAD: RUNNING prisons is not the only way to make money from the prison system. Nowadays, hotels, computer companies and manufacturers are also profiting from incarceration. They are hiring inmates, usually below minimum wage and with no extra pay for weekends or holidays, to provide goods and services at a fraction of normal costs.

title: Headliners; Cutting Class
description: Lawyers for 15-year-old Jenifer Graham maintain that it is a small but logical leap from First Amendment safeguards of religious beliefs to similar constitutional protection against having to dissect frogs. Miss Graham, a vegetarian who attends the Victor Valley High School in Victorville, Calif., says she has been told either to cut up frogs or to get out of her biology class.

title: PRESIDENT OF TAX COMMISSION
description: Mary Elizabeth Mann, a property-tax lawyer and president of the Tax Commission of New York City since March 1978, died of cancer Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63 years old and also had a home on Shelter Island, L.I.

title: GOIING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FESTIVAL IN DELAWARE

title: HIS HOME WAS HIS MUSEUM
description: ''T HE SOANE MUSEUM IS AS deep as St. Paul's dome is wide,'' Ian Nairn, the British architecture critic, wrote in 1966, and that is as good a beginning as any to the story of why this is among the most remarkable buildings in England. The Soane Museum - Sir John Soane's Museum, in proper parlance - at No. 13 Lincoln's Inn Fields, is but a trio of adjoining town houses but it is as intriguing an exploration into the depths of architectural space as exists in London. The museum was built in the early 1800's as the city residence of Sir John Soane, a neoclassical architect who evolved a highly personal, even idiosyncratic, style; it was very much Soane's design laboratory, the place where many of his ideas were most completely expressed.

title: Nancy C. Pattillo Weds Ens. Christopher Soltis
description: At Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Suffield, Conn., yesterday Nancy Craig Pattillo, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Gilchrist Pattillo 3d of West Suffield, Conn., was married to Ens. Christopher B. Soltis, U.S.N., a son of Judith Krawski of East Windsor, Conn., and the late Col. Ronald B. Soltis, U.S.A.F. The Rev. Kevin P. Cavanaugh performed the ceremony.

title: A DECADE OF CHANGE FOR MEDICAL CENTER
description: LEAD: IT was 10 years ago this week that the Westchester County Medical Center was dedicated, amid controversy about whether it was an unnecessary luxury that would forever drain county tax dollars.

title: REINVENTING THE CITY
description: Alexander Cooper's office does not have a drafting board. What it does have is a square black table, a large leather swivel chair, picture books of the architecture of Sir Edwin Lutyens and McKim, Mead & White and a bulletin board displaying photographs of the old Pennsylvania Station, plans of the cities of Detroit and Washington and announcements about current sculpture shows. Wide windows look out to the old McGraw-Hill Building, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and the Hudson River waterfront.

title: Inside
description: South Africa raids Zambia Soldiers from South Africa killed five people Pretoria said were terrorists in Zambia. The Zambian Government said four civilians were killed. Page 3.

title: RAGS OR RICHES?
description: THEY say charity begins at home, and I believe it because of the clothing drive.

title: Paying The Devil
description: The Macquarie Dictionary (of the Australian language) defines de facto: '' [ 3 ] a woman who lives with a man as his wife, but is not married to him; [ 4 ] a man who lives with a woman as her husband, but is not married to her.''

title: 2000 STUDY RECEDES INTO NEAR FUTURE
description: CAN Long Island politicians, businessmen, civic leaders, academia and the public reach a consensus on Long Island's major problems and their solutions for the turn of the century? That's what Long Island Project 2000 hopes to accomplish. But Long Islanders will have to wait a while longer for the results of this 250-member, nine-panel, $100,000 study.

title: FOR BELAGA, POITICS IS ACADEMIC
description: THE topic was campaign strategies. In a second-floor dining room at Harvard University's Institute of Politics, Julie D. Belaga was entertaining four political scholars with tales of Connecticut's gubernatorial races.

title: NO SIGNS OF LIFE DETECTED IN WRECKAGE OF BUILDING
description: The grim search for construction workers buried in the collapse of an apartment building in Bridgeport, Conn., continued yesterday, but no signs of life were detected in the rubble of twisted steel and concrete and officials said hopes for survivors had all but vanished.

title: Bird's-Eye Solutions for Low-Level Ills
description: DEVELOPERS in Westchester are taking to the skies to solve some of the problems that are hard to solve on the ground - and within a few months, they may even get help from satellites.

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Shoah'' (in Hebrew, ''Annihilation''), Claude Lanzmann's huge oral history of the Holocaust is unlike any other Holocaust film ever made. This isn't a conventional documentary composed of newsreel footage from the archives. Everything is of the present - the faces of the ''witnesses'' as well as the tranquil, neatly tended landscapes that once were the death camps. Where there'd once been railroad tracks leading to Treblinka, there's now only a path through a forest. In ''Shoah,'' which will be shown on Channel 13 in four parts this week, Monday through Thursday, at 8:30 P.M., that path suggests the roadbed of the River Styx.

title:
GARDENING;
A PRACTICAL APPROACH YIELDS EARLY TOMATOES
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to tomatoes, gardeners will try anything to push the season. Fortunately, for the vast majority of us who don't have greenhouses, seed companies are now offering extra-early cultivars for cool temperatures that produce fruit well ahead of other tomatoes.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Jane Austen in Manhattan Starring Anne Baxter and Robert Powell. Directed by James Ivory. Produced by Ismail Merchant. Screenplay by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. 1981. Charter Entertainment. 108 minutes. $59.95.

title: ENIGMATIC FUND-RAISER IS FOCUS OF 3 INQUIRIES
description: Less than a year ago, Carl R. (Spitz) Channell was a relatively obscure fund-raiser who had built a network of conservative enterprises by boasting to wealthy Republican donors about his White House connections.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Balance of Flavor and Lady Bernard Berenson described Gertrude Stein as a ''primeval female straight from the desert.'' Ernest Samuels also tells us how she described him in ''Bernard Berenson: The Making of a Legend'' (Belknap/Harvard University).

title: Made Elsewhere
description: THIS IS BEING WRITTEN on a computer made in the U.S.A. at a desk made in Denmark. When completed it will be reproduced on paper made in the U.S.A. by a printing device made in Japan.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
INVESTMENT GOALS ENCOURAGE NEW BUYERS
description: LEAD: SIX months after its introduction, the American Eagle rules the roost in the bullion gold coin market. However, foreign competitors have not been swept aside. Some seem to be stronger than ever.

title: MUDEROUS FEUDS THREATEN UNITY OF SOUTH ASIAN STATES
description: ACCORDING to an old colonial axiom, the British maintained their power in the Asian subcontinent by a clever policy of ''divide and rule,'' playing religious and ethnic groups off against one another. But after 40 years of independence, the region still is riven by ethnic and religious conflict.

title: MARYLAND TOWN MADE FOR QUIET LIVING IS HUB OF DEVELOPMENT
description: Paul Staples's telephone sometimes rang a hundred times a day. One after another, the callers asked the same question: Would he sell Staples Corner?

title: PANORAMIC VIEWS OF THE WHOLE COSMOS
description: LEAD: ON GLORY ROADS A Pilgrim's Book About Pilgrimage. By Eleanor Munro. 297 pp. New York: Thames & Hudson. $17.95.

title: GREENWICH MAN'S ANTI-DRUG CRUSADE
description: GROWING up in Greenwich in the 30's and 40's, Lawrence J. Pugliese knew little about drugs. ''To me, they were something your parents got at the drugstore when you were sick,'' he said.

title: Mary A. Walsh Wed To Thomas P. Loftus
description: Mary Anne Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T.Craig Walsh of Port Washington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Thomas P. Loftus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Loftus of San Jose, Calif. The Rev. William I. Delaney performed the ceremony at the St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church.

title: HOMELESS: STATE PLAN ON HOLD
description: LEAD: ABOUT 900 New Jersey children were in foster care in 1986 because of homelessness.

title: HARD ROAD FOR NATIVE CONDUCTORS
description: ALTHOUGH THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY OR-chestra as an institution is nearly 150 years old, it has produced remarkably few conductors of the first rank. A reminder of that deficiency came recently when two of those few, Leonard Bernstein and James Levine, happened to appear on successive evenings at the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera. The oddity is that the symphony orchestra, the strongest, most solidly financed and most widely dispersed phenomenon in this nation's musical culture, should have proved to be so infertile a ground for native talent. For a long time, of course, boards of trustees and audiences snobbishly demanded foreign conductors, which shut out Americans from the major orchestras. A few smaller cities did install Americans, generally not top-rankers, as music directors: the names of Thor Johnson, Walter Hendl, Milton Katims, Thomas Schippers, Howard Mitchell and Robert Whitney may be remembered as pioneers, at least.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: ON THE TRAIL

title: N.A.A.C.P. ASSAILED OVER SUIT ON FEES
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is under increasing fire from within and outside the organization because of a suit over legal fees it has filed against some of its former lawyers.

title: IN JERSEY CITY, MEDICAL CENTER'S FUTURE IS PLANNED...
description: LEAD: WHEN the Jersey City Medical Center moves out of its complex of skyscrapers here in about four years, it will leave behind one of the few examples of Art Deco architecture in the state and one of the city's foremost landmarks.

title: BOARD WON'T HIRE TEACHERS IN SPAIN
description: After two years of recruiting bilingual teachers from Spain, the New York City Board of Education has decided not to hire from Spain this year but to recruit more teachers from Puerto Rico and, for the first time, from the Dominican Republic.

title: A Gloomy Report About Robberies
description: At first the news sounds hopeful: From 1973 through 1984, the national robbery rate declined by 15 percent. This, however, was because of a decline in unsuccessful attempts, in which a robber accosted a victim but failed to get any loot. The rate of successful robberies remained unchanged. Altogether, there were on average 1.2 million incidents a year.

title: Miss Harbison Weds Roderick P. Hoover Jr.
description: The marriage of Cornelia A. Harbison, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Richard T. Harbison of Pensacola, Fla., to Roderick P. Hoover Jr., the son of Barbara S. Hoover of Charlotte, N.C., and the late Mr. Hoover, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Pensacola. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, senior minister of the church. He was assisted by the Rev. Robert E. Roach, the bridegroom's brother-in-law.

title: ON THE RATING OF COMPOSERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: PATENTING FORMS OF ANIMAL LIFE;
PLAYING GOD? WE'VE DONE IT FOR CENTURIES
description: LEAD: EARLIER this month, the Patent and Trademark Office adopted a sensible policy that sets the stage for patents on new forms of animal life developed by man. The decision will help preserve the domestic biotechnology industry and will not, despite the near hysterical cries from some quarters, launch us on some perilous voyage into a commercial Brave New World.

title: Pauli Murray's Life
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
KNOW YOUR NEEDS BEFORE BUYING PLANTS
description: LEAD: DEDICATED and casual gardeners alike will descend upon the neighborhood garden center over the next several weekends to create elbow-to-elbow crowds at displays and cash registers. Under such circumstances, it will be next to impossible to get one's question answered or even to read the labels on the products.

title: IRAN ALLOWS PRAGMATISM TO DICTATE ITS SHOPPING LIST
description: IN an interview with a Teheran reporter a few months ago, Hassan Abedi-Jafari, Iran's Commerce Minister, boasted that Iran's Islamic Republic had successfully shifted its trade relations away from the West in favor of the developing Islamic world.

title: Lisa Fielder Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Walter Gustafson of Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gustafson's daughter Lisa Ann Fielder to Virgil Thomas Fryman Jr., the son of Mr. Fryman of Washington, Ky., and the late Elizabeth Louis Marshall Fryman. A June 20 wedding is planned.

title: Erin Danielson-Haskell Becomes Bride
description: Erin Danielson-Haskell, a daughter of Cynthia Burnside Haskell of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Maj. Raymond Warren Danielson Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, of Merced, Calif., was married yesterday to Andrew Martin Ross, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Conrad Ross of Greenwich, Conn., and Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Gethin B. Hughes, assisted by the Rev. Dr. J.George Hall, performed the ceremony at All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara.

title: Injured Driver Survives For 16 Days on Water
description: A teen-ager who suffered a leg fracture and was trapped in her car after it ran off a road and into a ditch was not found for 16 days, but she survived because she had access to water.

title: A CORRECTION
description: A picture caption April 19 with an article on proposals to increase housing aid to the elderly in New York City misidentified Barrington Wright, the chief administrator of the city's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption program.

title: Concern About Inflation Rises
description: Two important measures of the economic condition reported hefty increases last week. One, a 4.3 percent expansion in the nation's output of goods in services for the first three months of the year, was quickly discounted by most analysts. The other, a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in consumer prices in March, was more heavily weighed. ''I'm getting a little uncomfortable,'' said Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official who is now executive vice president for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, of the latest inflation report.

title: DANCE: MULLER'S 'DARKNESS AND LIGHT'
description: JENNIFER MULLER tackles conscious and unconscious life in ''Darkness and Light (Polarities),'' performed by Ms. Muller and the Works on Thursday at the Joyce Theater. A stew of six loosely joined episodes, the evening-long dance has some charming moments. Ms. Muller's dancers are good-looking and ingratiating. But ''Darkness and Light (Polarities)'' is a surprisingly naive piece given the sleekness - and slickness - of Ms. Muller's work in general.

title: Once Again, the Search for a Developer
description: WITHIN the city's Public Development Corporation, a new request for proposals is in preparation for a developer to produce and rent out the first private building in the downtown office district in Jamaica, Queens, a central element in 15 years of revitalization effort.

title: Must Miskito Indians Be Pawns in Our Game?
description: To the Editor:

title: VACANT LIVES IN GREAT BIG AUSTRALIA
description: THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI By Colleen McCullough. Illustrated by Peter Chapman. 189 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Paying Public
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SAN FRANSICO'S VIBRANT CHINATOWN
description: The entrance to San Francisco's Chinatown, where Grant Avenue meets Bush Street, is marked by an elaborate gate topped with green tiles and carved red curlicues and encrusted with golden dragons. Grant Avenue itself is lined with buildings with pagoda roofs and lacquered and gilded facades, and even the light fixtures are designed to look like Chinese lanterns.

title: STUDY CHARTS MOTIVES FOR CHARITABLE GIVING
description: Historically, many American foundations began small and were nurtured by their benefactors until they grew into sturdy institutions. But that ''acorn theory of philanthropy'' may no longer hold, according to a new study that sees worrisome implications for the future.

title: A NEW CHANCE FOR 'TENDER LAND'
description: THE NEW PRODUCTION OF Aaron Copland's opera ''The Tender Land,'' opening Friday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is more than a revival. There have been only a few scattered productions of a revised version made by Mr. Copland and his librettist, Erik Johns, since the premiere of the original version in 1954, so the reputation of ''The Tender Land'' rests wholly on critical reviews of the first performances, which were mixed.

title: Inquiry Begun on Heart Error
description: A hospital has begun a review of procedures after a patient was given a heart of the wrong blood type and surgeons had to implant an artificial heart when his body rejected the donor organ, a spokeswoman says.

title: MOBILE HOMES GAINING ADVOCATES
description: MOBILE HOMES could be the answer to Connecticut's growing housing problem, a special state advisory panel says, but the group has found resistance in many towns.

title: VERMONT GOAT FARMERS ASSAIL RAW MILK CURB
description: Catherine Mabie's goats are self-supporting. The income from the sale of their raw, unpasteurized milk pays for their grain and the bills from the veterinarian. It buys the gas and oil that run the equipment that cuts the hay they eat.

title: Massachusets College Editor Ousted Over a Parody Paper
description: The Student Government Association at North Adams State College has voted to oust the editor of the campus newspaper because of an April Fool's Day issue that depicted the school president as running a telephone-sex service.

title:
ART;
'CONTEMPORARY DIPTYCHS' AT THE WHITNEY MUSEUM
description: LEAD: TWO heads may be better than one, and a painting or sculpture with two distinct parts can hold more interest at times than the usual single component work. This is one of the premises of ''Contemporary Diptychs,'' which is at the Whitney Museum's branch in Stamford through May 27.

title: IDEAS PEOPLE THINK WITH
description: CULTURAL LITERACY What Every American Needs to Know. By E. D. Hirsch Jr. Appendix: What Literate Americans Know. By E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph Kett and James Trefil. 251 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: POLAND'S PLUCKY ACTIVIST
description: WHEN ADAM MICHNIK, THE OFTEN-IMPRISONED Polish human-rights activist, political theoretician and writer, was on trial two years ago for inciting civil unrest, the Polish court, as is its custom, received a character analysis of the defendant from a policeman, a certain Sgt. Andrzei Solecki of the Warsaw midtown precinct in which Michnik lives when he is not in detention.

title: THE LATEST ECOLOGICAL WONDER - MUD STOVES
description: WHILE the rest of the world agonizes over the possibility of eventually exhausting the global oil supply, Africa is beset with another kind of energy crisis: a growing scarcity of wood.

title: Amy Philips Marries Joseph V. Sullivan Jr.
description: The marriage of Amy Sarah Philips and Joseph Vincent Sullivan Jr., who both received Master of Architecture degrees from Princeton University, took place last evening at Federal Hall in Manhattan. Rabbi Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: ON THE RATING OF COMPOSERS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dream Come True
description: WHEN BUSINESSMAN Eugene M. Lang delivered the commencement address nearly six years ago to the sixth graders at his former grammar school, and spontaneously promised to pay their college tuitions, he didn't know what he was getting into. Lang has so far spent $125,000 on the students of P.S. 121 in East Harlem - arranging writing workshops and cultural trips, hiring tutors and mentors. ''We're trying,'' says Lang, ''to give these ghetto kids the kind of support they would get if they had been born into a relatively affluent family.'' About two-thirds of the 52 students in Lang's ''I Have a Dream'' program have been accepted at colleges or have applications pending. One graduated from high school while in jail. Most of the remaining students are expected to graduate next year. LARRY DOUGLAS

title: ISLANDERS EAGERLY AWAIT BOSSY'S RETURN
description: First, Mike Bossy unwound the yard of tape that was plastered along his left leg from knee to ankle. Then he shivered out of the black brace, so form-fitting that it's almost painful. He was wearing the brace in order to skate, and he will wear it again Sunday night at Nassau Coliseum when he returns to the Islanders' lineup and perhaps provide a scoring touch.

title: ROLE CALL: WAIF, WIFE, DRUMMER GIRL
description: IN BETH HENLEY'S NEW PLAY, ''THE Lucky Spot,'' Mary Stuart Masterson is a waif, a smudged-face, dirty-nailed, pregnant 15-year-old who was won in a poker game. Dressed in a tan apron and pants, heavy workboots and a battered hat, she is Little Orphan Annie from the school of hard luck.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RUNAWAY. By Lucy Irvine. (Random House, $18.95.) Very early in Lucy Irvine's account of how she dropped out of schools and into communes, hitched rides through Britain, Western Europe and the Middle East, scrounged meals and relied on the kindness of strangers, this reader got the uncomfortable feeling that hers was less the tale of an adventuresome young woman than that of a disturbed adolescent. Although many teen-agers feel ready to tackle the world on their own, what kind of parents let them do it? In the author's case, being allowed to leave school at age 13 sets the pattern for a series of increasingly dangerous journeys, interrupted periodically by stays at her father's hotel in the Scottish Highlands. These pastoral interludes hardly restore her equilibrium, since her chief task seems to be to serve pastries to male guests. The ultimate, predictable brutality befalls her at a deserted lakeside in Greece where, naively, she has assumed she was being taken to swim. Unable to repress this trauma, she makes her way back to England and a psychiatric hospital. There, a partially drawn curtain discloses characters in a familiar setting: seductive father, rejected mother, a marriage that failed long before it ended. To the narrator, all this seems forbidden territory, best avoided by another escape, this time into the classroom and her teacher's bed. Ms. Irvine writes a frank and lively, if overwrought prose (tension bursts off the tongue in ''snappy bubbles,'' ''chunks . . . crack off'' the parents' marriage, and so on). By the end of the book, she has joined forces with a man who wants a ''wife'' to share a yearlong exile on a tropical island. That adventure furnished material for the author's previously published ''Castaway,'' a more disciplined, focused work than this one.

title: THE RETURNS ARE IN
description: SOMEONE MENTIONS sending back wine at a restaurant, and I think of a fearsome editor to whom I once was indentured. One day, a young reporter returned to the office without the interview he'd been sent to get.

title: ALCOHOL FOUND A PROBLEM IN 24% OF FAMILIES
description: The number of American families affected by alcohol-related problems has doubled since 1974, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: HARD JOB HUNT FOR GIMBEL'S WORKERS
description: When Gimbels went out of business last November, Lena DiPasquale was earning $8 an hour as a sales clerk in the Herald Square store.

title: ASCETICISM AND ANIMAL FAITH
description: GEORGE SANTAYANA A Biography. By John McCormick. Illustrated. 612 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30. PERSONS AND PLACES Fragments of Autobiography. By George Santayana. Edited by William G. Holzberger and Herman J. Saatkamp Jr. With an introduction by Richard C. Lyon. Illustrated. 761 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $35.

title: WADDLING WELLES
description: TOUCH OF EVIL With Orson Welles, Charlton Heston, Janet Leigh, Joseph Callelia. Directed and adapted by Welles, from a novel by Whit Masterson. 1958. MCA Home Video. 108 minutes. $29.95.

title: BUILDERS THREATEN SUIT OVER NORTH SALEM ZONING
description: NORTH SALEM'S month-old zoning code, which reduces the number of potential multifamily units by half and raises thousands of acres to four-acre residential zoning from two acre, is the most restrictive code in the state, a coalition of builders charged recently, as they announced they would sue to have the code overturned.

title: PALERMO'S GREAT STREET FOOD
description: My husband and I were in Sicily searching out authentic Sicilian dishes. A Sicilian friend who lives in New York had spoken quite rapturously of a street food called guasteddi - fresh buns filled with ribbons of calf's spleen, ricotta cheese, strands of caciocavallo cheese and a drizzle of hot lard. ''I practically lived on those spleen-filled buns when I was a student,'' he said, sighing with nostalgia. ''They're the best street food of the city.'' But warning us that guasteddi might be a little harsh for our unschooled palates, he told us we could eat a highly refined version in a restaurant called Harry's Bar. When we got to Palermo we phoned up Harry's but were told they didn't serve the dish. I think we would have let the matter rest there, if, during our wanderings in The Vucciria, a maze of alleyways lined with food stands that is one of the great markets of the Mediterranean, we hadn't seen men hungrily lining up to buy guasteddi and then devouring them with gusto on the spot.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
HOW DOES A MAN CHANGE CHANNELS IN THE MIDDLE OF LIFE?
description: LEAD: Once upon a time, life was simple: at 40, men had coronaries and women had hot flashes. Today, the women's movement, and midlife careers, have made the female menopause obsolete (at least it seems that way - nobody I know has time to go through it).

title: CABARET: DORY PREVIN SINGS A POP BILL
description: WHEN Dory Previn emerged onto the pop scene in the early 1970's at the height of the singer-songwriter movement, she stood out as an intriguing oddball. Evoking in song the same Hollywood-as-Babylon vision that Joan Didion portrayed in ''Play It As It Lays,'' Ms. Previn added her personal twists of occultism and feminism, as well as a very dry, quirky sense of humor. Musically, her songs didn't conform to the folk-rock mode of younger confessional writers like Joni Mitchell and Jackson Browne. Lightly flavored with ragtime and swing, they inflected the pop-folk genre with a Kurt Weill-like jazziness.

title: PIANO: GARY GOODMAN
description: GARY GOODMAN has two attractive talents as a pianist - one visceral, the other more reflective. The first, as demonstrated in his evening at Weill Recital Hall on Friday, was a joy in how music moves. One felt it in the quicker movements of Bach's A-minor English Suite, also in the last movement of ''Les Adieux'' by Beethoven, which, in Mr. Goodman's hands, defined exactly its tempo marking of ''Vivacissimamente.'' This young American pianist possesses as well the gift of tempo - an ability to find the speed slow enough to explain, outline and clarify and yet fast enough to preserve the music's energy.

title: Custom-Designed Bacteria Released In Outdoor Test
description: In a California strawberry patch, scientists from a company with the futuristic name Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc. were finally allowed last week to release into the world the tiny creatures they had invented.

title: POLES ACT TO CURB OPPONENTS
description: The Polish security police gave more than 500 political opponents ''warning talks'' and seized illegal materials in a two-day operation, the Government press agency reported today.

title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: Touch the Sky Starring Christopher Reeve and the Navy's Blue Angels flight team. CCR Video Corporation/Twin Tower Enterprises. (800) 553-4321. 60 minutes. $39.95.

title: DARCI KISTLER: THE ODYSSEY BACK
description: LEAD: FROM THE OUTSET, THE career of Darci Kistler, the last teen-age prodigy annointed by George Balanchine, seemed singularly blessed. Plucked by the master choreographer from the School of American Ballet at age 15, Ms. Kistler joined his New York City Ballet in May of 1980, immediately following her valedictory graduation performance as Odette in ''Swan Lake.

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN DRAWS NEW DOUBT
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez, author of a much-praised initiative intended to bring peace to Central America, said this week that his plan might be in trouble. Foreign diplomats agreed with his assessment.

title: Tina Frangos Is Married
description: Tina Frangos, an associate in the New York law firm Spitzer & Feldman, was married yesterday to Robert DiMino, a vice president of Wilson Pleus & Company, an investment banking firm in Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. Nicholas Magoulias performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I. The parents of the couple are Capt. and Mrs. John Frangos of Garden City, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. John DiMino of Norristown, Pa.

title: Office Tenants Invading an Enclave of Eclecticism
description: WITH its Italian marble and opulent hues, the new lobby of 584 Broadway in SoHo looks like an interloper from Madison Avenue. Next door, the new lobby of 588 Broadway, offbeat and brash, fits right into the neighborhood.

title: WHO'S A PRINCESS? HERE'S THE TEST
description: AMERICAN princesses come in all colors and religions and may be found anywhere in America (even in K-Mart country, but not, of course, in an actual K-Mart). This is according to the latest sociological studies.

title: DAZZLING IN SPITE OF HIMSELF
description: LEAD: FRYDERYK CHOPIN Pianist From Warsaw. By William G. Atwood. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $30.

title: Amy Goldsmith Wed to Leslie Charmatz in Jersey
description: The marriage of Amy Morrison Goldsmith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Goldsmith of South Orange, N.J., to Leslie Howard Charmatz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Charmatz, also of South Orange, took place last night at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club in South Orange. Rabbi Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony.

title: STARGAZERS
description: The edge of change is the natural habitat for the leaders in any field. They mnake it their business to know, before the rest of us, who is likely to touch our lives. So we sought out leading figures in some of New York's most notable disciplines, from law enforcement to dance, and asked them to do some stargazing -- to predict who, in their respective fields, will make a difference in the future of New York. Here are their forecasts. LAW ENFORCEMENT Rudolph W. Giuliani spotlights Barbara S. Jones

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of a brief Washington dispatch on April 9 about Kurt Waldheim and an article in The Week in Review on April 12 about Nazi crime files both misstated the position of two United States Senators on Mr. Waldheim. The Senators, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island and Bob Dole of Kansas, have asked Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for information or a decision on proposals to bar Mr. Waldheim from the United States.

title: Kathie Horton Weds John Sarrett in Jersey
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday Kathie Mead Horton, a daughter of Mrs. William Leonard Horton of Summit, N.J., and Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Mr. Horton, was married to John Garrison Sarrett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Lee Sarrett of Virginia Beach, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David B. Earnest, assisted by the bride's aunt, Nancy Horton McCarthy, an Episcopal deacon.

title: THE COSTS AND THE CARE OF A DISABLED CHILD
description: I am deeply disturbed by the article I read in the Westchester section on March 22 [ ''Expense Rising for Education of Disabled'' ] .

title: MAGAZINES TAKE SELECTIVE AIM
description: Free copies of Goodliving and Boulevard, the latest magazines published for and by Long Islanders, have been turning up in select mailboxes across the North Shore.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MOVES AGAINST RESISTANCE
description: THE South African Government deployed thousands of police officers and troops in Johannesburg and the black township of Soweto last week to crush a strike by black railway workers.

title: Cornell Orders Closing Of Fraternity Until '91
description: A Cornell University fraternity has been ordered closed for four years by administrators, who have accused the group of sexual abuse, house mismanagement and illegal use of alcohol, the university said today.

title: Elizabeth Brown Married in South
description: Elizabeth Thayer Brown and John Berwick Warters were married yesterday at the Hilton Presbyterian Church in Newport News, Va., by the Rev. Gary Charles. The bride is the daughter of the late Moreau D. Brown Jr. and the late Mary Elizabeth Gaylord Brown, both of Rye, N.Y., and is the stepdaughter of Mrs. Brown of Darien, Conn. Mr. Warters is a son of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Warters of Lincroft, N.J.

title: BEATING IN ARREST IS DEFENDED
description: A New York City police officer has told authorities that he struck a man three times with his night stick during an arrest that was filmed by an onlooker last month because the man was resisting arrest and he believed the man had a knife, the officer's lawyer said yesterday.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Robert Reed's first novel, THE LEESHORE (Donald I. Fine, $16.95), has a lot going for it. The setting is well-conceived - a watery planet called Leeshore whose sky is home to lighter-than-air life forms so numerous that sunlight is prevented from reaching its surface, where bioluminescent flora and fauna live off the droppings from above. The premise of the story is intriguing - on distant Earth a terrible war has been fought between the Alteretics, who have built a supercomputer they hail as a god, and those humans who resist such idolatry. The Alteretics, bested in battle, have fled with their god and come to the watery planet. Their enemies are in close pursuit; the final battle, evidently, will be fought on Leeshore.

title: FINE PERFORMANCES LIFT 'REARDON'
description: IN Paul Zindel's ''And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little,'' currently at the Arena Repertory Players Theater, three sisters outdo one another in various forms of unpleasant behavior. What saves the play from becoming two long, unremitting acts about the facets of vicious, sexually repressed women is that each sister gets as much as she gives.

title: Pierre S. du Pont 5th, a Consultant, To Wed Jenny Young, a Law Student
description: Mrs. Llewellyn P. Young of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Jean Averill Young to Pierre Samuel du Pont 5th, a son of Mr. du Pont 4th, former Governor of Delaware, and Mrs. du Pont of Rockland, Del. An August wedding is planned.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Perhaps the saddest point of the whole Baby M case is that, in wanting to keep Baby M, Mrs. Whitehead is responding most normally. The surrogates who can part with their children are probably not as emotionally healthy as Mrs. Whitehead. So it is this very natural phenomenon of wanting to mother the child she carried for nine months that has brought Mrs. Whitehead to court. Actually, the Sterns chose well. They sensed, and so selected, a woman who was instinctively maternal. PAT GALLANT WEICH New York City

title: OPERA: MENOTTI STAGES A DOUBLE BILL AT JUILLIARD
description: IN Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Tamu-Tamu'' - revived Friday by the Juilliard American Opera Center as part of a double bill directed by the composer-librettist - Mr. and Mrs. Hudson, an urban couple, see a picture of a family fleeing bullets in a war-torn Indonesia and give expressions of concern and detachment. Mr. Hudson leaves for work; the bell rings - and suddenly the Indonesian family bursts in. Tamu-tamu is Indonesian for ''the guests.''

title: FLORIDA'S SEAFARING BIG-GAME HUNTERS
description: Capt. Ken Moore, who earns his living taking strangers out on the Atlantic to catch fish, was at the dock and working by sunrise, two hours before the day's clients were due. Almost a million dollars worth of deep-sea charter boats and fishing gear, all of it the captain's responsibility, floated in four slips at the Harbor House marina.

title: CABARET: RUSSELL AND MARTI
description: ''MUSIC . . . IT'S THE OCEAN,'' the title given the latest series of concerts at the Kitchen by its music curator, Arto Lindsay, seemed particularly appropriate on Thursday night. The two performances, by Arthur Russell with his cello and Virgilio Marti with his Guaguanco ensemble, called up mental images that were insistently aquatic - Mr. Russell alone on a sailboat, singing into the wind; Mr. Marti and his Afro-Cuban percussionists overlaying waves of rhythm.

title: PRESCHOOL: LET'S PRESERVE THE CHOICES
description: THE new Federal legislation affecting the education of handicapped preschoolers may on the surface seem like an advancement in special-education financing, but may actually serve to undermine an extremely effective system already in place in New York State.

title: Scapegoat Now
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Saving a Foot By Rare Surgery
description: VLADIMIR RAMOS, 13 months old, was in his mother's arms when she leaped in front of an oncoming subway train in Manhattan.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NO REASON TO TALK ABOUT IT: Families Confront the Nuclear Taboo. By David S. Greenwald and Steven J. Zeitlin. (Norton, $22.95.) The authors - family therapists in Philadelphia and Boston - have interviewed 25 families to explore why they fail to talk about nuclear war and what the consequences of this failure are.

title: Bakker's TV Ministry Sued for $601 Million
description: Three members of a family have filed a $601 lawsuit in Federal District Court here against a television ministry formerly led by Jim Bakker, charging that their contributions to the group were used for illegal, illicit and immoral purposes.

title: MANHATTAN POOL HALLS FADE IN BLOOM
description: Manhattan's pool halls, smoky dens that were the stuff of neighborhood legend, have nearly disappeared, even as the game is in the midst of a resurgence in much of the country.

title: SCOTTISH CASTLES, MEDIEVAL AIR
description: High on a promontory, overlooking the Firth of Forth as it runs into the North Sea, sits the ruin of Tantallon Castle, the 14th-century home of the Earl of Douglas. Below the castle, the currents swirl among rocky islets where puffins, gannets and guillemots build their nests, and the wind pounds stiffly against the cliffs.

title: OILERS WIN FOR 3-0 SERIES LEAD
description: Jari Kurri scored twice, including the go-ahead goal 17 minutes 18 seconds into the second period, as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Winnipeg Jets by 5-2 tonight and took a 3-0 lead in the Symthe Division finals.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Bowling Younger Weber Winner: Pete Weber, age 24, became the youngest player to win 10 Professional Bowlers Association titles when he captured the Firestone Tournament of Champions by beating Jim Murtishaw, 222-190, yesterday in Akron, Ohio. The $50,000 winner's share put Weber at the top of the P.B.A. earnings list with $149,825 this season and enabled him to pass his father, Dick, in career earnings, $733,331 to $731,003. (AP) Hockey Americans Edge Switzerland: The United States team posted its second consecutive victory of the world championships by beating Switzerland, 6-3, yesterday in Vienna. The Americans, boosting their record to 2-4, built a 2-0 lead in the first period and then staved off the Swiss, who have not won a game. Eddie Olczyk of the Chicago Blackhawks and Clark Donatelli of Boston University put the American squad ahead with goals at 6 minutes 37 seconds and 8:06 of the first. (AP) Golf Gardner, Forsman Share Lead: Buddy Gardner shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday and earned a tie with Dan Forsman, who finished with a 68, to share the third-round lead at 206 in the Houston Open at The Woodlands, Tex. Gardner and Forsman will enter the final round at 10 under par, two shots ahead of the second-round leader, Wayne Levi, who shot a 71, and Nick Price, who shot a 68. (AP) Tennis Arias Reaches Final: Jimmy Arias of the United States advanced to the final of the Monte Carlo Open by defeating Horst Skoff of Austria, 7-5, 6-1, yesterday. Arias will meet Mats Wilander of Sweden in today's final, worth $74,700 to the winner. The fourth-seeded Wilander defeated a fellow Swede, Ulf Stenlund, 6-2, 6-2, in a earlier match. Stenlund lost all eight of his service games.(AP) Navratilova vs. Evert: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova beat fourth-seeded Zina Garrison, 6-1, 7-6, in the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament. Combined with the 6-3, 7-5 upset by third-seeded Chris Evert of second-seeded Hana Mandlikova, Navratilova's victory set up the 72d career meeting between Evert and Navratilova in today's championship match.(AP) Swimming Biondi Sets Freestyle Mark: Matt Biondi of the University of California set a world record yesterday with a time of 21.84 seconds in the 50-meter freestyle at the inaugural Avis Swimming Championships in Los Angeles. Biondi broke the 50-meter freestyle mark of 21.89 set by Dano Halsall of Switzerland last year. (AP) Horse Racing Filly First in Upset: Peggy's Dream, the only filly in the field of eight, beat Omar Khayyam, the odds-on favorite, by a neck in the $71,500 OTB Big Apple Handicap for New York-bred 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. Omar Khayyam was two lengths ahead of Lone Quadrant. The victory was the fourth in nine starts this year for the daughter of Sir Wimborne-Cousins Three. She carried 113 pounds a mile in 1:36 2/5 to earn $42,900 for Margaret Smyth and returned $17 for $2 to win. Gymnastics U.C.L.A. Takes Team Title: Tony Pineda, who finished seventh in the individual all-round competition Friday, led U.C.L.A. to the team title in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's gymanstics championships in Los Angeles yesterday. U.C.L.A. finished with 285.30 points to Nebraska's 284.75.(AP)

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Perth Amboy Board of Adjustment is expected to end its hearings next month on plans for a $400 million residential development on 116 waterfront acres and about 15 acres inland.

title: TRIBAL ICONS CONJURE VISIONS OF AFRICA'S PAST
description: EVER SINCE IT WAS OPENED IN September 1984, the Center for African Art, at 54 East 68th Street, has had a character all its own. It has a clearly defined function. It is exactly the right size. It is run with an eye for true quality. And it deals with subject matter that is compellingly and controversially alive.

title: Shelley Rodes Slade Is Wed
description: Shelley Rodes Slade, an associate in the Washington law firm Arnold & Porter, and Mark Dobson Betts, an associate in the Washington office of the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, were married yesterday. The Rev. David Randolf performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in Manhattan.

title: Innovations Prompt a New Look
description: SEVERAL changes in the time-shares industry are providing fresh opportunities for anyone tempted by this type of ownership.

title: OPERETTA, SINGSPIEL AND 'L'HISTOIRE' SET
description: THE Monmouth Civic Chorus will perform Franz Lehar's popular operetta ''The Merry Widow'' four times over the next two weekends at the Count Basie Theatre in Red Bank.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The collapse of the dollar has somehow become synonymous with an imminent resurgence in inflation.'' Stephen S. Roach, Morgan Stanley chief economist.

title: Pan Am Plans German Shuttle Starting June 1
description: Pan American World Airways plans to begin a shuttle service June 1 between West Berlin and three other West German cities.

title: Pleasant Puccini
description: MANON LESCAUT By Puccini; starring Renata Scotto, Placido Domingo, Renato Capecchi, Pablo Elvira. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus conducted by James Levine. Directed by Kirk Browning. Bel Canto: Paramount Home Video. 135 minutes. $59.95

title: Books From The Times
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES YEAR IN REVIEW 1986. Edited by Adam Clymer. (Times Books, Paper, $14.95.) This documentary history of last year's events, people and trends combines at-a-glance facts and figures with analyses and summaries prepared by Times staff members. Organized chronologically within categories (International, National, Business and Industry, Living, Public Opinion, Finance and Markets, Sports and Culture), the collection ranges from capsule histories of the space shuttle explosion and the Chernobyl disaster to a chart of the 10 biggest raises in baseball players' salaries, the results of the New York Times/CBS News Polls, and sketches of the 22 leading tall ships in the July 4 Parade of Sail.

title: Lyssa Raichelson To Wed This Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Raichelson of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lyssa Ann Raichelson, to Steven Scott Girden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Girden of Stamford, Conn. A November wedding is planned. Miss Raichelson, a magna cum laude graduate of Northwestern University, is a broadcast production assistant at the Louden, Kaplan & Elegant advertising firm in New York. Her father is an internist in Montclair, N.J. The future bride is a granddaughter of Leon Leonard of Atlantic City, a retired judge of the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court.

title: VICTIM'S RELATIVES OPPOSING PAROLE
description: Exercising a new right given to crime victims, Stan Turel appeared before the Oregon Parole Board today to warn, ''Rod Addicks is better at crime now than he was when he went into prison.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN PRIVATE PRISONS
description: LEAD: CRIME may not pay - but by the same token, rehabilitation is not cheap.

title:
FOOD;
AN EXOTIC PILGRIMAGE
description: LEAD: WHEN I FIRST DISCOVERED that there was a large Moslem population in China, I couldn't wait to explore its cuisine. After all, I had always been fascinated with Chinese food. Furthermore, I had spent most of my childhood in Egypt and had quite an interest in Moslem dishes. The possibility of a dual cuisine whetted both my appetite and my culinary soul.

title: 'PAINTING CHURCHES' STAGED AT LONG WHARF
description: ALMOST a year ago, ''Painting Churches'' was rushed, or so it seemed, into Stamford's Hartman Theater in place of another play. And so it is now in New Haven with what looks like a hasty staging of Tina Howe's increasingly handy work, which replaces the originally scheduled ''Bailegangaire'' by Thomas Murphy at Long Wharf Theater's Stage II.

title: IN SOVIET, HEROISM AND CANDOR ARE HAILED, BUT QUESTIONS LINGER
description: The Soviet Union this week remembered the world's worst civil nuclear disaster with press reports and news conferences designed to make the anniversary a celebration of heroism, candor and resourcefulness.

title:
GARDENING;
KNOW YOUR NEEDS BEFORE BUYING PLANTS
description: LEAD: DEDICATED and casual gardeners alike will descend upon the neighborhood garden center over the next several weekends to create elbow-to-elbow crowds at displays and cash registers. Under such circumstances, it will be next to impossible to get one's question answered or even to read the labels on the products.

title: 2 SCHOOLS WIN RELAY AMID CONTROVESY
description: An unusual controversy with an unusual solution marked today's closing program of the 93d annual Penn Relays.

title: Dr. Joan Mannick Becomes a Bride
description: At the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Dr. Joan B. Mannick, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Mannick of Weston, Mass., was married to Dr. James Austin Talcott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Talcott of Great Falls, Mont. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Preston Hannibal, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Thomas Powers, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: COUNTY VOLUNTEERS HONORED TOMORROW
description: LEAD: ACCORDING to the winners of the annual awards given by the county's Volunteer Service Bureau of United Way and the Westchester Corporate Volunteer Council, the volunteers get as much enjoyment and satisfaction from their commitments to others as they give. Nevertheless, tomorrow they will be on the receiving end as they are honored at a luncheon scheduled to coincide with National Volunteer

title: DETAILS VIEWED AS KEY IN GOETZ TRIAL
description: After more than two years of legal maneuvering and public anticipation, arguments are to begin tomorrow in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz in the shooting of four youths on a subway train.

title: Garvey's Back-to-Africa Dream Lives On
description: To the Editor:

title: MALAYSIAN LEADER TIGHTENS HIS HOLD
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad consolidated his hold over his divided party today, and Malaysians were waiting to see whether he would dismiss his opponents or seek to heal the rifts.

title: MORTGAGE LENDERS FACING NEW CURBS
description: REGULATIONS to be proposed soon by the state's Department of Banking would require lending institutions to state in writing how long it will take to process a mortgage loan application.

title: Saying No To Subdividing
description: LONGTIME residents here are feeling the pressure of development as their central Maine town of 900 people gains in popularity as both a bedroom community and as a summer residence for out-of-staters.

title: Elizabeth J. Ashcroft Wed to A. D. Guthrie
description: Elizabeth Jennifer Ashcroft, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Derrick Ashcroft of Princeton, N.J., and Truth or Consequences, N.M., was married in Princeton yesterday to Alexander Davis Guthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Davis Yokana of Princeton and Biddeford Pool, Me. The Rev. Bruce Webber performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: CD VIDEO IS ON THE WAY
description: WHEN LAYMEN walk in to a store to buy video equipment, they are confronted, befuddled and flummoxed by VHS, VHS-C, HQ-VHS, Hi-Fi VHS, Beta, Super-Beta, 8-millimeter and LaserVision. On the premise that too much is not enough, a few more formats are about to be added.

title: Man Shot Dead by 2 Others In Brooklyn Ice-Cream Parlor
description: Two men followed a ''nervous'' man into a combination ice-cream parlor and social club in Brooklyn yesterday morning and shot him once in the head, killing him, according to the police.

title: Verbatim: Acid Rain Reaction
description: ' There is a widespread perception that Americans really don't give a damn if we have any forests, any fish or any lakes. The sense of an incredible selfishness on the part of the U.S.

title: California Handyman Charged in 6 Murders
description: The police have charged an itinerant handyman with six murders, and detectives are digging at the man's previous residences and work sites for more possible victims.

title: MAVERICK ENDING A CAREER
