description: LOUIS T. HOWARD, an unusual legislator in an often unusual Suffolk County Legislature, is winding up a 24-year-long political career that has spanned the most turbulent years in Suffolk County history.

title: Plagiarism Charge Against Professor
description: AN Ohio University electrical engineering professor who said he could not read Russian stood accused of the ''shameless'' plagiarizing of the works of a Soviet physicist.

title: Lawyer Married To Ms. Mathews
description: Elizabeth Holladay Mathews, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hayden Mathews of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Episcopal Church there yesterday to Giovanni Pasquale Prezioso, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fausto Maria Prezioso of Towson, Md. The Rev. John W. Bishop, rector of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Joseph Barr, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ARBOR DAY AWARD
description: What was once used as a dumping ground for old tires, blocks of concrete, toilet basins and pieces of tile has become an award-winning nature preserve. The four-and-a-half-acre preserve, which includes woodlands and a bird sanctuary, is on the grounds of the William B. Ward Elementary School in New Rochelle.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES COMING UP
description: LEAD: WITHOUT the high profile of other attractions - or figures to support a data base - antiques-related activities in the metropolitan area may be outnumbered in popularity and profitability only by the entertainment industry, sports and the Atlantic City gambling casinos.

title: UPDATING THE BARD WITH FALSTAFF IN PIN STRIPES AT THE OLD VIC
description: FOR MANY OF THOSE SIT-ting happily through 12 hours of Shakespeare during a merciless gray April Saturday, the rudeness seemed quite welcome: Spear carriers done up as the modern soccer hoodlums who jingoistically give Britain a bad name, transposed five centuries back in time as they head to France as part of Henry V's invasion force, waving a vulgar, threatening banner about ''the Frogs'' and singing the intimidating anthem of the modern punk-style tourists and boozy soccer hooligans who take the ferry to the European mainland: ''Here we go, here we go!''

title: MUSIC: THE GEWANDHAUS ORCHESTRA
description: A NATIONAL style, curiously enough, often reveals itself through the work of outsiders. Thus anyone wanting to encapsulate the spirit of Leipzig's Gewandhaus Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Thursday night had only to hear them play American music.

title: IN WEST, AFTER ANXIETY, NO MAJOR TECHNICAL CHANGES IN INDUSTRY
description: In the year since the Chernobyl disaster, nuclear power has undergone its most critical appraisal since the invention of the reactor in 1942. But despite the global anxiety created by the Soviet accident, experts say that it has not caused major technical changes in the nuclear power industry of the West.

title: BANKER RUNS AHEAD OF PACK
description: WHILE running backward, Stanley Wunderlich is headed unswervingly into the high-tech future.

title: HOW AUTO-FOCUSING WORKS
description: CANON EOS, Minolta Maxxum, Nikon N2020, Olympus OM77-AF, Pentax SF1 and Yashica 230-AF; these are the SLR cameras that represent the vanguard of auto-focusing technology. Based without exception on passive, phase-detection sensors, which distinguish between sharp and fuzzy edges of objects seen through the lens, they evidence a remarkable consensus among camera designers.

title: HAVING IT ALL IN BOCA RATON
description: Immediately east of the Boca Raton exit off the Florida Turnpike, just 30 minutes from either Palm Beach or Fort Lauderdale airports and minutes away from the Intracoastal Waterway, lies Boca West.

title: 'ON YOUR TOES,' IN ELMSFORD, HAS IT ALL
description: WHAT musical begins with a vaudeville routine, has a mock Russian ballet as a first-act finale, ends with an American jazz ballet and, all along, offers one dandy musical comedy song-and-dance number after another in a tradition that bespeaks the best of Broadway?

title: EXPERIMENTAL WELFARE PLAN IS THREATENED IN ROCHESTER
description: An experimental program to provide health care to welfare recipients through a health-maintenance organization is in danger of failing because the medical providers are threatening to withdraw.

title: RULING ON COTTAGES
description: FIFTY cottages in Cortlandt have been ruled seasonal, for summer use only - but because summer is almost here and 30 homeless families are already living in the cottages, the families may be allowed to stay until the end of summer.

title: SPACES AND PLACES
description: New York City long offered real estate developers the opportunity to circumvent certain zoning restrictions if, in exchange, they would provide public amenities on the sites of major developments. Now, after some experience, architects have a much better sense of what attracts people than they did in the 1950's, when Lever House and the Seagram Building were among the only skyscrapers in town with outdoor space dedicated to public use. The most successful and active areas, open-air or enclosed, have proved to be those that offer a mixture of attractions - food, seating, architecture, sunlight, air-conditioning, shops, cafes, fountains, art or gardens. Here, three Times writers sample these public spaces around town. GALLERIES Any well-planned tour of skyscraper lobbies in Manhattan these days can offer a museum-going experience that rivals going to museums. The reason is that an increasing number of developers are installing permanent art exhibits, and even entire galleries, in their ground-floor lobbies and public spaces.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A transmission error in an article last week on the new School of Graduate Medical Education at Seton Hall University reversed the meaning of a statement by Dr. Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Dr. Bergen's statement about family planning, contraception and abortion services should have read:

title: Limits to Lawsuits In War and Peace
description: Whatever misjudgments it commits and injuries it causes, the Government cannot be sued without its consent. And while Congress has provided limited consent, two Federal courts last week confirmed that especially where the military and its contractors are concerned, the limits are broad and the consent narrow.

title: N.R.C. Accused Of Favoritism
description: During the Reagan Administration, the relationship between the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the utilities it oversees has met with disapproval from many Capitol Hill Democrats. Last week, grumbling turned into challenge when two legislators accused the N.R.C.'s top management of showing favoritism toward the industry and asked the commission to act to curb it.

title: SMITHSONIAN HEAD LOOKS INWARD IN AUSTERE ERA
description: When Robert McCormack Adams assumed the secretaryship of the Smithsonian Institution, a number of people took it upon themselves to give him a bit of guidance.

title: 10-MILE RACE PROVES A SNAP
description: A few days ago, when Lesley Welch realized she had no plans for the weekend, she decided to run a road race to keep in shape.

title: TAKING TO THE HIGHWAY IN ITALY
description: Visiting motorists who travel from northern Italy to Rome or from Venice to Tuscany will, after studying the road maps, in all likelihood head for the Bologna-Florence autostrada. They ought to be warned to drive defensively on that 60-mile highway across the sullen ranges of the Apennines; during peak periods an alternative route may be preferable.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended April 11 MANHATTAN Chelsea $144,000 365 West 20th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; dining area, eat-in kitchen, original moldings; maintenance $630, 52% tax-deductible (Broker:

title: Jean Lewis Wed To a Biochemist
description: Jean McArthur Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hiram Lewis 3d of West Hartford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. Hans-Rudolf Boehringer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugen Boehringer of Zurich. The Rev. Ross McNeil Ludeman performed the ceremony at the Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: COXING HER WAY TO VICTORY
description: I LAY THERE, THINKING ABOUT HOW MY boat was going to lose. For two weeks, as May turned to June, the Harvard crews trained on the Thames River in Connecticut for the annual races against Yale. This was the 14th morning I had woken up with a pain in my stomach, knowing my junior-varsity boat would practice with the varsity, that no matter how well we raced we would trail behind a superior crew. Two months ago, I'd been the coxswain on the varsity boat.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Red Auerbach Trophy as coach of the year in the National Basketball Association has been voted to Mike Schuler, who in his first year as coach of the Portland Trail Blazers led the team to the third-best record in the Western Conference. . . . Micheal Ray Richardson, the former Net, pleaded not guilty Friday in Hackensack, N.J., to charges of illegally cashing a check for more than $9,700. He was ordered to attend a pretrial conference on June 17. Richardson was indicted on March 30 on one count each of theft by deception and forgery and could face six and a half years in prison and a $15,000 fine if convicted.

title: BUGGY WHIPS OF THE INFORMATION AGE
description: THE skunk cabbage was peeking through last year's matted brown leaves and coltsfoot bloomed in the meadow. In the space of 24 hours, nature had shrugged off winter and announced that, yes, finally spring had arrived. This was no day to hang around computers. Better to go riding. I popped off to the tack shop to replace a broken set of reins neglected over the dreary winter months.

title: CASTING A WARY EYE ON WASHINGTON
description: WALL STREET may not think much of the way business is done in Washington, but their comments - at least in public - tend to be diplomatic. If tact befits players in a politically regulated industry, nobody seems to have sold the idea to Mark L. Melcher. The 47-year-old native Iowan, first vice president and director of Washington research for Prudential-Bache Securities, writes an acerbic Potomac Perspective column advising clients of what's afoot in the political realm that could affect their investments.

title: Daniel Becker to Wed Martha A. Toll in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour I. Toll of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Anne Toll, to Daniel F. Becker, a son of Dr. David V. Becker and the late Naomi I. Becker of New York. A June 7 wedding is planned.

title: FOR SMOKERS, RULING BRINGS AMBIVALENCE
description: For a moment, Haris Makkis was delighted by the news that a judge had struck down broad restrictions on smoking in New York State.

title: RUTGERS: 'OUTSIDERS' AND ONE 'INSIDER'
description: TWO exhibitions are on view through May 8 at the Robeson Center Gallery on the Newark-Rutgers campus. One is of paintings and sculpture by 14 artists, most of them ''outsiders''; the other is a selection of nudes and landscapes by Nancy Depew, an ''insider'' by virtue of her academically realist technique.

title: Karen Friede to Marry Martin Holden in June
description: Karen Michele Friede, who expects to graduate in June from the University of California at Santa Cruz, and Martin John Holden, a member of the class of '88 at Santa Cruz, plan to be married June 27. Mr. and Mrs. John A. Friede of Rye, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Warren Holden Jr. of El Cajon, Calif., and Annette Lough Jones of La Jolla, Calif.

title: FUNDS ARE SOUGHT BY WHITMAN GROUP
description: LEAD: THE Walt Whitman Association, whose president calls it ''a volunteer group of teachers, librarians and poetry readers never in a position to raise a lot of money,'' is reorganizing and looking for ''resource people'' to save the home of George Whitman, the poet's brother, from the wrecking ball.

title: STUDY HOPES TO IDENTIFY TOXINS IN THE AIR
description: LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Protection and the Yale Comprehensive Cancer Center have begun a collaborative program to identify and control airborne toxins in Connecticut that may contribute to cancer and birth defects.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF CONCERTS
description: THE spring rush is on, musically speaking, with more than a dozen events jostling for attention today and at least that many waiting to usher in May.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Mary Beth Whitehead made a deal. She made a terrible, terrible mistake, but she made it and should accept the consequences. Perhaps others will learn from her experience that children are not so easily relinquished.

title: FALLING AWAY, HERE AT HOME
description: ''WHAT'S next?'' my daughter asks. Her soft, expressive face has that wooden look I have seen once, or twice, in the last few months when she has spoken of her own death, so I know that she is asking me: Is this the place we have come to, now? It is. She is 23. She has adrenal cancer. Adrenocortical carcinoma is rare, with only about 150 cases a year. It is, as yet, incurable.

title:
DANCE VIEW;
THE WELLSPRINGS OF ANTONY TUDOR'S GREATNESS
description: LEAD: WITH ANTONY TUDOR'S death in New York City on April 19 in his 79th year, the world has lost one of the few genuine innovators who took dance into the 20th century. Tudor crossed esthetic borders into a realm of universal appeal, one that went beyond the ready labels often affixed to his career.

title: MORE IN THE MIDDLE CLASS SEEK 'HELP IN A HURRY'
description: LEAD: Tragedy recently engulfed a Long Island family. The father of two children, both under age 2, who was under extreme stress - husband, wife and children all lived in one room - shook one infant violently, rupturing the aorta. The baby died on the way to the hospital.

title: AT PLAY IN THE BACKYARD OF THE PSYCHE
description: TRUST ME By John Updike. 302 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. I ONCE read that if the universe, having come to the end of its explosion, collapses on itself, time will run backward. On no good grounds I imagine this as meaning that suburbs will grow new, then raw, and will then recede; that surgeons and scientists will daily master the use of cruder instruments; that every life will be shadowed by the inevitable onset of callowness, childhood and dreaded infancy. In such a world retrospection would be visionary, and events would be rescued from seeming entropy, from mere accident and mere loss. So it is in these 22 stories by John Updike, which assume for their characters a past of such density that it stands on the temporal landscape as stolidly as an empty house - promising comfort, needing care, full of habit and purpose somehow interrupted and abandoned.

title: HOME VIDEO: SPORTS
description: The Insiders' Guide to Salmon Fishing With Marlin Gibbs. Kartes Video Communications. 40 minutes. $19.95.

title: Alison Paul Weds Douglas G. Miller
description: Alison Elise Paul, the daughter of Mrs. Victor Alphonse Sachse 3d of Baton Rouge, La., and William George Paul of Bartlesville, Okla., was married yesterday to Douglas Gilmore Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Baldwin Miller Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. James M. Coleman performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Baton Rouge.

title: No Move on Nelson
description: THE owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, Herbert Kohl, said the Knicks had not sought permission to interview Coach Don Nelson in their search for a replacment for Bob Hill. ''I have not had any communication with Richard Evans,'' Kohl said of the Knicks' president.

title: WHAT TO STOCKPILE - AND HOW MUCH?
description: Every time a heat-seeking missile's infrared sensors lock onto target, a little bit of a mineral called germanium is at the heart of the guidance package.

title: SOMETIMES, BAD GRAMMAR GOES TOO FAR
description: NOW just a minute here.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Having brought men into Lamaze classes and delivery rooms, having rightly demanded that men take up their equal share of nurturing and parenting, now some feminists would condemn a man who is fighting for his right to be exactly that: a loving, responsible father. It was William Stern who yearned for a child, not Mary Beth Whitehead. DORIS GAHLER New York City

title: SRI LANKA ACTING TO CONTAIN REPRISALS
description: WITH images of horror still fresh, the Government of President J.R.

title: THE FRAGMENTED FACTIONS THAT MAKE POLICY IN JAPAN
description: PRIME Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone visits Washington this week to try to defuse the latest trade crisis. But the importance of the visit is more symbolic than real. Most changes in Japan's economic policies are not the result of bold initiatives from the Prime Minister, but of painstaking bargaining among a group of powerful constituencies, including bureaucrats, politicians and businessmen. That process has become even more fragmented in recent years as Japan's economy has grown stronger, making the process of negotiating trade concessions far more complicated.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY -- PERFECT TOGETHER
description: LEAD: TWO chief executives whose organizations are often thought of as economic competitors recently signed a multibillion-dollar joint capital-investment plan for upgrading facilities used to meet intensifying competition from others.

title: YANKS BEATEN AGAIN AS BATS TURN COLD
description: Lou Piniella struck down the notion quickly, even before the question had been fully formed. It came in the aftermath of a difficult 2-1 defeat on national television today, the Yankees' second loss in a row, both to Cleveland, after they had soared to 10 consecutive victories.

title: BRINGING NEW LIFE TO THE PARKS
description: LEAD: Decades ago, when I was a little girl in the Bronx saddled with a baby sister whose pram had to be dragged to Crotona Park for fresh air and a quiet nap, the first welcoming gesture was a wave of the hand from Guido, the gardener, whose spiky red flowers in stiff rows I didn't like. But I liked Guido, my host and, in an important sense, my guardian.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: Der Rosenkavalier Opera by Richard Strauss and Hugo von Hofmannsthal. Sung in German with English subtitles. Royal Opera production by John Schlesinger, with Kiri Te Kanawa, Anne Howells, Aage Haugland and Barbara Bonney, Georg Solti conducting. Stereo hi-fi. Home Vision. 3 hours, 24 minutes (two cassettes).

title: WORRIES FOR DEMOCRACY ON THE RISE IN HONG KONG
description: Apprehensions are growing among some residents of this capitalist enclave that China and Britain together are choking off the prospects for a democratic future for Hong Kong.

title: Where the Elite Meet to Eat on the Job
description: SOME of New York City's finest restaurants are not in the Guide Michelin or the Mobil Touring Guide, but they are becoming the in places to eat - if you are invited.

title: A BOOK BY WALESA IS PRINTED IN PARIS
description: Lech Walesa, founder of the now-banned Solidarity labor union, says he likes to compare his country to a poor man who ''occupied a corner in a beautiful house that he did not own.''

title: A TRE'S BLOSSOMS, A FAMILY'S ROOTS
description: THE white dogwood in my backyard is not a prize-winning specimen, pruned and shapely. Its April petals bloom on branches that stretch every which way, just as they did in the unspoiled wilds of Gramp's woods.

title: In Today's Issue: World of New York
description: Part 2 of The Times Magazine today is The World of New Emerging City: On the Edge of Change,'' including these special reports: * How the planner Alex Cooper and planner, is redesigning the * A renaissance is bringing new city. life to the parks - with a user's guide to the five boroughs. * Young literary circles. * Paul Simon and LL Cool J compare notes on pop music.

title: DAVID BOWIE MINGLES GLAMOUR AND GLOOM
description: EVERY FEW YEARS, DAVID Bowie turns up in a new guise -Ziggy Stardust the glitter-rocker, the jaded Thin White Duke, the stateless recluse of '' 'Heroes.' '' He writes songs that fans and waves of imitators take to heart; at the same time, he's openly theatrical, self-consciously conjuring with appearances and artifice, a series of shifty ''I's.'' Who is he now? On ''Never Let Me Down'' (EMI album, cassette and CD 17267), he's a split persona. As he was on 1980's ''Scary Monsters,'' he's a media-barraged observer with an oblique but unflinching point of view. But since the release of the multimillion-selling ''Let's Dance'' in 1983, Mr. Bowie has also been an arena-filling pop star, no longer an outsider. His plan, now, is to make a mainstream audience think twice.

title: Two Women Win Big in Texas
description: In elections that reflected the changing politics of urban Texas, the voters of Dallas and Corpus Christi last weekend elected women as mayors for the first time.

title: MANSIONS FILLED WITH DESIGNERS' IDEAS
description: LEAD: THIS spring, adding fuel to the desires of homeowners to beautify their houses, in an area of high disposable income and a booming housing market, two interior design shows are going on at the same time.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MATTERS GRAY AND WHITE: A Neurologist, His Patients, and the Mysteries of the Brain. By Russell Martin. (Holt, $18.95.) The hero of this excellent book is the pseudonymous John Ferrier, a young neurologist who, after residencies in Denver and Vancouver, British Columbia, and research fellowships and studies at Oxford, Cornell and Columbia, elected to set up private practice in a Rocky Mountain city.

title: ON CAMPUS, A BOON IN GIVING
description: COLLEGES are asking alumni, the public and corporate supporters to dig deeper into their pockets than ever before, and their enthusiastic response is resulting in an academic fund-raising boom in Connecticut.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ROCKET MAN: The Roger Clemens Story. By Roger Clemens with Peter Gammons. (Stephen Greene, $15.95.) Last year, at the age of 24, the astounding Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox won most, if not all the marbles - the Cy Young and Most Valuable Player awards in the American League, as well as the Most Valuable Player for his starting and winning pitching performance in the All-Star Game.

title: IN THE WINGS, 'NOH, NOH, NANETTE'?
description: THE FABULOUS EAST HAS CAP-tivated American audiences for more than a hundred years - often through the most blithely fanciful presentations. This season, several revivals recall milestones in this long affair with Orientalia. ''The Mikado,'' the English import that triggered the craze in 1885, is currently on Broadway (this time imported from Stratford, Ontario); it features such merry anomalies as a British patter song sung by kimono-clad officials and a Japanese tea ceremony using Victorian tea service. ''South Pacific,'' the City Opera's season opener, creates its fictive Polynesia with a little pidgin English and a staccato melody in one ''native'' song, ''Happy Talk.'' Come summer, the same company will present Sigmund Romberg's 1926 ''Desert Song,'' which makes a Valentino-style romance out of the Riff uprisings in Morocco.

title: Secession Plan Returns in Boston
description: IN November, voters in Boston defeated by more than 2 to 1 a plan to carve a new town, Mandela, out of the primarily black districts of the city. But leaders of the secession movement say they are undaunted by the defeat, and they vowed this week to try to get the issue on the ballot again this fall.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Death Watch With Romy Schneider and Harvey Keitel. Directed by Bertrand Tavernier. Embassy Home Entertainment. 117 minutes. $29.95.

title: The Lessons of Chernobyl, One Year Later
description: LEAD: Today is is the first anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident in the Soviet Union. Chernobyl was a major tragedy for the Soviet Union - a tragedy from which it has not yet fully recovered, physically and emotionally. But Chernobyl has also influenced the Soviet Union and the rest of the world positively.

title: COVERED BRIDGE RESTORER IS LAST GUARDIAN OF AN AGE
description: Stoop-shouldered, shuffling along, Milton Graton is the last of a kind, a legacy of a fading Americana he is dedicated to preserving. At 78 years of age, he is still building and restoring covered bridges.

title:
DINING OUT;
BELGIUM OUTPOST ON STATEN ISLAND
description: LEAD: LA FOSSE AUX LOUPS is unique in that (a) it specializes in Belgian cuisine, (b) is said to be the best restaurant on Staten Island and (c) the name on the awning out front is Montezuma.

title: DHOW, QE2 AND CONCORDE
description: It's years since I heard anyone suggest, except with a cynical smile, that travel broadens the mind. Travel has been transformed - by technology, popular taste and marketing pressures. Time and distance contract: We travel in a time warp - is today yesterday, today or tomorrow?

title: WOMEN RE-CREATE CAVALRY TRADITION
description: LEAD: MEMBERS of Gold's Dragoons, a cavalry unit that was founded in Fairfield in the mid-1600's, are once again mounted and ready to serve, after a brief reactivation in the 1930's. But the recently reactivated unit, composed of 11 women, has a different agenda these days.

title: FROM ROCK TO RAP
description: IN THE FACE OF IT, THE two musicians sitting on the foot of the bed in the equipment-filled basement studio of the modest house in Queens would seem to have almost nothing in common.

title: Jennifer Lambert Engaged<u4 to Wed Daniel Churchill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Lambert of New York and Locust, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lambert to Daniel C. Churchill, the son of Mrs. James Farley of Cornish, N.H., and the late Creighton Churchill. The couple will be married June 27.

title: The 'Cost' of 421a
description: LEAD: To the Editor:

title: On Language
description: To the Editor: The article ''So You Don't Speak Japanese'' (Travel, March 15) brings back a memory of my travels in the Tokyo area many years ago, courtesy of the United States Army. While standing on a bus that had one inch less head room than my 6-foot 1-inch frame, a Japanese man standing next to me seemed sympathetic to my discomfort. So I tried out my few words of Nihongo and said, ''Chisai'' (CHEE-sigh), meaning small, referring to the size of the bus. He smiled and gently corrected me by saying, ''Takai'' (TAH-kigh), the Japanese word for large. I learned about being a guest in another land. EUGENE BIANCHERI Wayne, N.J.

title: STOCKPILING LAND FOR WASTE DISPOSAL
description: The March 29 letter to the editor in response to my Long Island Opinion article, ''We'll Drown in Garbage, Unless...,'' on March 1 is a melange of facts and fantasy. It is easily demonstrable that the facts in that letter support my proposal that we stockpile land for solid waste facilities.

title: Pop Music
description: During Wayne Shorter's 15 years with Weather Report, his fans grew frustrated, hearing only a few bars of his saxophone here and there. But with his own group, appearing Saturday at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, he is at center stage, spinning out solos that are fierce and tender and articulate.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Unable to Buy, Many Now Rent Houses
description: LEAD: FOR the last eight years, Barbara and Daniel Sexton, and their two children, ages 11 and 12, have lived in a rented ranch house in Selden. But now the owner is selling the property and, lacking enough of a down payment to buy a house, the family is in the market for another rental.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE RAIN began shortly after midnight, a hard spring rain. ''Good,'' I mused vaguely. ''A rainy Sunday morning for writing.'' Writing always goes better with rainy mornings.

title: 4 Injured Crewmen Rescued From Tug in Middle of Pacific
description: In a dramatic international rescue effort, four American crewmen who were injured in a tugboat fire in the middle of the Pacific were transferred Friday to a Japanese freighter by paramedics who had parachuted to their aid.

title: Justices Uphold Takeover Limits
description: For the first time, the Supreme Court last week approved state restrictions on hostile takeovers, upholding an Indiana law that limits the voting rights of those seeking to gain control of companies incorporated in the state.

title: BENEFITS AROUND THE CITY
description: Open House on 77th St. April 28 - The home at 53 East 77th Street has been called ''one of the most unusual houses on the East Side,'' with its Georgian paneling, extraordinary skylight, staircase decorations and garden now in bloom. From 6 to 8 P.M. guests will be permitted to wander through the house, which has been specially decorated for the event by 17 designers. Refreshments will also be served at the Georgian Suite at 1A East 77th Street. The preview open house and reception will benefit the 3,400 chilfren who attend programs run by the Kips Bay Boys' Club at their clubhouse in the Bronx. The house will be open to the public April 29 through May 17. Tickets for the preview, $100, from 212-893-8600. A Tribute for Women April 28 - Donna E. Shalala, the president of Hunter College, will suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous kidding at the hands of Bella Abzug, Carol Bellamy, Judy Collins, Arthur Levitt Jr., Gloria Steinem and others. The event will benefit the Women's Action Alliance, a national nonprofit organization seeking full equality for women. Dinner at 8 P.M. at Windows on the World. Tickets, $125; $250 includes a 7 P.M. cocktail party, from 212-532-8330. Francophile Gathering April 28 - The Foundation Lafayette Memorial, an American charity, is seeking to restore the French ancestral home of France's most notable contribution to the American Revolution, the Marquis de Lafayette. His descendant Gilbert de Lafayette 6th and Robert Coles Jefferson, a descendant of Thomas Jefferson, will contribute to the historical atmosphere at a black-tie cocktail and dance starting at 9 P.M. at Maxim's. The event will be hosted by the French Ambassador, Emmanuel de Margerie, and Pierre Cardin. Tickets, $100, or $50 for those 35 and under, from 212-751-5111. Worldwide Help April 28 - For 35 years Human Assistance Programs has provided emergency and long-term assistance to improve food production, health care and job training in poor countries. Last year, about 720,000 people were aided in Asia, Africa and the South Pacific. The organization's annual ball, this year honoring Helen Hayes, starts with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. at the St. Regis-Sheraton, followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $175, from 212-684-6804. Briefly Noted: April 28 - The Creative Arts Rehabilitation Center will offer cocktails at 6 P.M. followed by dinner and a concert by the pianist Richard Goode to benefit its psychiatric rehabilitation programs. Tickets for black-tie event at the Union Club, 101 East 69th Street, are $200, from 212-246-3115. April 28 - At the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street, the United States Committee for United World Colleges, of which there are now six around the world, will hold a black-tie dinner-dance starting with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $250, from 212-734-4990. April 30 - The Governor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement, founded in 1955 to help send young New Yorkers to college, is holding its 32d annual black-tie dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Tickets, $350, from 212-687-2922. April 30 - Sports figures will be out in force at the 15th annual Dinner of Champions to benefit the New York Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Tickets for the black-tie dinner-dance, which starts at the Marriott Marquis with cocktails at 6:30 P.M., are $400, from 212-921-9199. April 30 - The skirl of bagpipes will resound through the St. Regis-Sheraton ballroom at the Wallace Award Dinner. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. James D. Watson, a Nobel Prize winner, and Hedrick Smith, a Pulitzer Prize winner, are among those to be honored at the benefit to establish a Scotland House in New York. Black or white tie or Highlands evening dress. Tickets, $95, from 212-988-4468. May 2 - The Kalichstein/Laredo/ Robinson Trio with the St. Lukes Chamber Orchestra will perform at 7:30 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall to benefit Selfhelp Community Services, which serves over 25,000 elderly New Yorkers. Reception at 6:30 P.M. Tickets, $25, $50 and $100, from 212-533-7100. May 3 - Mookie Wilson of the New York Mets will be on hand for a cocktail party from 5:30 to 8 P.M. at the USA Border Cafe on Broadway at 100th Street to benefit Veritas, an drug rehabilitation project on the Upper West Side. Tickets, $75, from 212-666-1411. An Artful Afternoon May 3 - For 18 years Hospital Audiences has brought cultural activities to more than 4.4 million people in 1,000 hospitals, nursing homes and mental health centers. A benefit for the organization will be held from 1 to 6 P.M. in Long Island City, Queens, at the Oil and Steel Gallery, 30-30 Vernon Boulevard. There will be a fashion show, food, wine and a silent auction of works by artists including Lichtenstein, Christo, Longo, Rauschenberg, Rothenberg and Segal. Round-trip bus service, at $5, will be provided from midtown to the gallery. Tickets, $75, from 212-575-7676 Ball on Staten Island May 3 - Snug Harbor on Staten Island, a delightful oasis of 80 acres with 28 buildings primarily in the Greek Revival style, is holding its annual Neptune Ball to benefit the organization's many activities. Seventy-five homes and restaurants on Staten Island and in Manhattan will offer dinner, followed by a cocktail party from 5 to 7 P.M. with entertainment in the Harbor's recently renovated great hall. Tickets for the black-tie event, $110, from Lillian Schwartz at 718-448-2500.

title: THE FUTURE LOOKS FAMILIAR
description: A speculative foreigner in the city, in the second half of the 1980's, I stand on the deck of the ferry, at the top of the skyscraper, in the green of the park, in the melee of the midtown street, and looking around at the tumultuous presence of New York, I think it can never have been New Yorkier than it is today.

title: DAVIS: 9 STRIKEOUTS IN ROW
description: Eric Davis, the Cincinnati outfielder, set a major-league record tonight when he struck out for the ninth straight time, but the Reds overcame his misfortune to earn a 3-0 victory over Houston in 10 innings.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with the About Westchester column last week incorrectly identified the woman helping students make a mural at the George Washington School. She is Penelope Ventura, an art teacher.

title: A HARPSICHORDIST, A SOPRANO, AN ORGANIST AND A PIANIST PLAY LOCAL RECITALS
description: Brigitte Haudebourg Brigitte Haudebourg plays the harpsichord with flair, expertise and the grand manner of a virtuoso. Not for her the tinkling, timid interpretations of too many early-music specialists with their desiccated, self-conscious and excruciatingly correct trills. She is a musician first, a scholar second; her performances are extroverted and often very exciting.

title: LIVING BECAUSE SOMEONE ELSE HAS DIED
description: I SHOULDN'T have been, but I was dumbstruck when a woman, who, like me, was in the doctor's office for a postkidney transplant checkup, talked about the day she would need a pancreas transplant. She had diabetes, a burdensome enough disease in itself and one that may lead to kidney failure.

title: MUSIC: LAOS'S TRADITION
description: POETRY, song and dance are delightfully intertwined in the traditional music of Laos. New Yorkers had a rare chance to hear Laotian music when the singers Khamvong Insixiengmai and Thong Kio Manixone, with Bounxeung Sinanone on kaen (mouth organ) and pin (a fretted lute) gave a marvelous concert Friday at Greenwich Music House, presented by the World Music Institute. There were instrumentals, solo songs for Mr. Insixiengmai and Ms. Manixone, and - best of all - songs in which the two singers re-created traditional courtship rituals, trading semi-improvised poetic lines and dancing in tandem, with graceful, elaborate hand gestures and a few knee-bends and hip-swivels.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE SLOW but steady cleaning up of hazardous-waste sites in New Jersey will get slower, despite a new infusion of money from Washington, state and Federal officials testified at a recent hearing of a United States Senate subcommittee.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Anne Taylor Fleming's description of the agency for surrogate motherhood sounded more like a brothel than an adoption agency. Surrogacy may have started as ''the ultimate act of sisterhood,'' but the introduction of money has quickly turned it into a new form of prostitution. The man now buys the woman's biologic services. LOUISE B. LYNCH Lyme, Conn.

title: A Worried City Is Looking for Alternatives to Jail - Fast
description: THE 296-page report issued by the State Commission of Correction last week did more than blame New York City's Correction Department for failing to control the violence that exploded on Rikers Island last October. It also raised fears that next October could see an even more explosive outbreak.

title: MASSACHUSETTS DEBATES HEALTH CARE PLAN FOR ALL
description: Despite dozens of medical insurance programs that have been legislated in Massachusetts over the last decade, about 10 percent of the state's residents, many of whom are regularly employed, still have no health insurance.

title: David Heffernan Is Wed to Karen M.
description: At the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington yesterday Karen Michele Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Schneider of Summit, N.J., was married to David Vincent Heffernan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Heffernan of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Denis P. Moran performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: HONG KONG
description: May and June are bad months for sea monsters in Hong Kong, but not so bad for humans. The dragon boat races are a lavish spectacle designed to scare away local sea monsters and fish, but they lure tourists and Hong Kong residents to the harbor. The boat races are among Hong Kong's endearing anomalies, a reminder that the territory has not lost its soul in the process of building a financial district and a subway that works.

title: AIR CANADA TESTS A BAN ON SMOKING
description: Passengers waiting for the ''No Smoking'' light to go out on the Air Canada flight from La Guardia Airport to Toronto this morning will be disappointed. It won't.

title: TEMPERATE SIL, TALINUM ARE OUT OF THE DERBY
description: Temperate Sil and Talinum, two of the early favorites for the Kentucky Derby next Saturday, will miss the race because of physical problems, their trainers said today.

title: Unemployment
description: To the Editor:

title: Cynthia Cutting, an Artist, Marries Kendall Robinson
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday Cynthia Cutting and Kendall W. Robinson were married by the Rev. T.Carleton Lee. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cutting Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., is a graduate of Skidmore College. She is an artist and a substitute teacher at the East Woods School in Oyster Bay.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bohemia $131,000 22 West Wind Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; family room with fireplace, basement, pool; taxes $2,300. Lake Ronkonkoma $145,000 15 Arlington Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, central A/C, porch; taxes $2,000. Sayville $152,000 323 Lowell Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Shirley $118,000 344 Auborn Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new high ranch; eat-in kitchen, dining area; estimated taxes $2,400. Tanglewood Hills $135,000 4 Whitney Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; center hall, den, family room, in-ground pool, 2-car garage; taxes $2,500. Williston Park $158,000 216 Cornwell Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. OTHER AREAS Lincolndale, N.Y. $229,000 Orange Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old frame raised ranch; deck, beach rights, 2-car garage; taxes $2,595. Stratford, Conn. $173,500 399 Windsor Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; screened porch, deck; taxes $1,230. Livingston, N.J. $167,000 16 Winchester Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,093.

title: U.S. AND MEXICO DIFFER ON MILK AND BEEF IMPORTS
description: Mexico and the United States are at odds over Mexico's ban on importing milk from the United States and a sudden increase of Mexican cattle imports into this country.

title: COSAT TO COAST WITH A GOOD HORSE
description: TARNISHED CROWN The Quest for a Racetrack Champion. By Carol Flake. 375 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: TRENTON COMPANY: FORMULA PROVES HIT
description: THE Passage Theater Company here has come upon what Veronica Brady, one of its three producers-directors, calls ''the best marketing program you can design'' for an up-and-coming resident theater: free tickets.

title: COURSES OFFERED TO EASE FARM LABOR SHORTAGE
description: A BOOMING economy in Connecticut has not been good news for farmers, who are so short of farmhands that they have been unable to find the help they need to harvest crops.

title: A WOMEN'S COLLEGE LOOKS TO MEN, SKEPTICALLY, FOR SURVIVAL
description: THROUGHOUT its 152-year history, Wheaton College has proudly asserted itself as a school dedicated to the education of women. But in an abrupt reversal, Wheaton's trustees are expected to vote next month to begin admitting men in the fall of 1988. They have already approved a resolution favoring the proposal, which has raised protests from some alumnae who cannot imagine a Wheaton with men.

title: Noel Brown, a Writer, Is Wed to Stephen Lieb
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York yesterday, Noel Brown, a daughter of Patricia Mulhern Brown of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Sheldon Herbert Brown Jr., was married to Stephen Joseph Lieb, the son of Joseph P. Lieb of New York and Marianne Evans of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Joseph P. Mulhern, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: The Quiet Survivors
description: There is going to be some kind of agreement with the Russians on the control of nuclear weapons - on that most observers agree -but many of the most experienced minds here are still divided on what that agreement should be.

title: GOLD MEDALIST VIES FOR OLYMPIC SPOT
description: ALTHOUGH she is a most unlikely looking champion, most observers agree that when it comes to kicking and punching, Anne M. Ryerson has few equals.

title: DINNER AT 8. WHEN'S THE REVOLUTION?
description: THE SHRAPNEL ACADEMY By Fay Weldon. 186 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Paying The Devil
description: Douglas Starr is all at sea when it comes to cats in bags (''Paying the Devil,'' On Language, March 22). In days gone by, country yokels would buy ''a pig in a poke'' and would find to their dismay that instead of a piglet in the bag, there was a cat. Sometimes this scam would come unstuck because someone ''let the cat out of the bag.'' JAMES W. HARKNESS Louisville, Ky.

title: Dr. Carolyn D. Runowicz Is Married
description: Dr. Carolyn D. Runowicz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S.Robert Dilworth of Miami, and Dr. Sheldon H. Cherry, the son of Fannie Cherry of New York and Miami and the late Nathan Cherry, were married yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Charles G. Agin of the Free Synagogue of Flushing, Queens.

title: Greening a Development
description: The clean-shaven look typical of new suburban developments, with barely a bush or bough to offset the structural monotony, can be unkind to esthetically minded neighbors - and it doesn't offer much in the way of privacy for the residents, either.

title:
GARDENING;
KNOW YOUR NEEDS BEFORE BUYING PLANTS
description: LEAD: DEDICATED and casual gardeners alike will descend upon the neighborhood garden center over the next several weekends to create elbow-to-elbow crowds at displays and cash registers. Under such circumstances, it will be next to impossible to get one's question answered or even to read the labels on the products.

title: THE VOYAGER NOW
description: THIS 'N THAT By Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. Illustrated. 207 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. NARROW IS THE WAY By B. D. and Jeremy Hyman. 285 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Men-Only Clubs Curtail the Unconscionable Id
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ALVIN AILEY TOUR

title: Ellen G. Stolzman To Marry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Beverly Stolzman of Roslyn, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter Ellen Gray Stolzman to Kenneth Ian Moch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Moch of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The couple will marry on June 27.

title: Victories Restored
description: WEST GERMANY'S hockey team, which had two victories taken away in the world championships in Vienna last week, had the victories temporarily restored yesterday. The International Ice Hockey Federation took the victories away because West Germany, in its first four games, used Miloslav Sikora, a Polish-born defenseman who competed for Poland in a junior hockey tournament. International rules prohibit competing for more than one country.

title: A UTOPIAN SCULPTOR STEEPED IN TRADITION
description: IN HIS QUIET WAY, JOEL FISHER HAS been trying to reinvent sculpture. His two current shows include standing, seated and walking figures. There are still lifes, reliefs and objects that seem to have been cast from everyday life. His sculptures suggest numbers, letters and signs. The works glide effortlessly between ancient and modern, figurative and abstract, art and nature. They listen and look, as well as perform. They share a particular silence, a particular simplicity, a particular quality of resolution.

title: PLENTY OF RUMORS, BUT TALENT IS THIN
description: IT's not a great National Football League draft this year - strong in linebackers, running backs and players from the University of Miami, but short on offensive linemen, tight ends and defensive backs. Many personnel experts say 10, maybe 12 instant-impact players are available, then there's a round and a half of second-rounders. A real falloff hits by the fourth round, two rounds sooner than last year, and from there, as one general manager said last week, ''it's a dart throw.''

title: STRIPED BASS THRIVE INLAND
description: IN the open bass boat, we were taking a beating in the wind.

title: Q And A
description: Leningrad Visit Question:I have heard that quick visits by sea to Leningrad are possible, and without a visa, from Helsinki. Whom do I contact? - J. D., New York Answer:The North American agent for a Finnish shipping company, the Sally Line, can book short, weekly trips from Helsinki to Leningrad from May 18. Soviet visas are not required. However, the agent, Cosmos International Tours (12 South Dixie Highway, Lake Worth, Fla. 33460; 305-585-6870 or 800-556-5305), says that the shipping line's agreement with Soviet authorities requires that reservations must be made at least 45 days ahead of departure. And although a Russian visa is unnecessary, each passenger has to fill in a questionnaire ahead of time for the Soviet authorities. A spokesman for Cosmos said it was a short, simple form. Cosmos is a tour operator that specializes in the Soviet Union.

title: JILTED KIDNAPPER
description: THE TRUE DETECTIVE By Theodore Weesner. 383 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE GIRLS: A Story of Village Life. By John Bowen. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) If it were not for its humor, ironic tone and eccentric characters, this well-crafted novel of murder and mystery could be mistaken for an example of feminist-separatist literature. Set in an English village where the main event is the annual flower show, ''The Girls,'' by the English novelist and playwright John Bowen, opens with a resonant description of a septic tank whose stench is that of a body decomposing.

title: PIANISTS AT THE PODIUM- OLD TRADITION, NEW INTEREST
description: ADD MURRAY PERAHIA TO the formidable list of pianists have turned to the podium. On Wednesday at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Perahia will conduct Mozart concertos from the keyboard. It will be his first New York appearance as a conductor, and the event is a gala benefit for the Metropolitan Museum concerts.

title: REGENTS BACK A PLAN TO CUT THE DROPOUT RATE
description: After two years of study and discussion, the State Board of Regents has given preliminary approval to a plan for reducing the high school dropout rate.

title: DEMOCRATS CONCENTRATE ON 3 ISSUES
description: ENTERING the final six weeks of their legislative session, the Democratic majorities of the General Assembly focused last week on issues involving the family, finances and Fairfield County.

title: Esposito Moves
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Valerie Boulou Marries
description: At St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Valerie Genevieve Yvonne Boulou, the daughter of Mrs. Michel Rietsch of Tours, France, and the late Jacques Boulou, was married to John Francis Creamer 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Creamer of Darien and Quogue, L.I. The Rev. Pierre Botton performed the ceremony. Mrs. Creamer is a junior at Hunter College. Her husband, an alumnus of the University of Maryland, is director of international trade for the Motor and Equipment Manufacturers Association in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston; Launching The Basilica
description: AT the heart of Boston's plan to transform the Charlestown Navy Yard into a mixed-use waterfront neighborhood is Building 106, a cavernous turn-of-the-century warehouse the Navy built to house a metal-working shop.

title: Pickens vs. Sigler
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Garrett Horan, an Executive, Is Married to GrayReisfield in Jersey
description: Lian Gray Reisfield, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald R. Reisfield of East Brunswick, N.J., and Palm Desert, Calif., was married in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School yesterday to Richard Garrett Horan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Horan of Rehoboth, Mass. The Rev. Robert Farrell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Virgil M. Rogers of the Reformed Church in America.

title: Dominican Capital
description: To the Editor: On April 12 the Travel section, under the heading Dominican Republic, listed Ciudad Trujillo. For a new generation of Dominicans, such a mistake may be offensive. I am certain you know that after the assassination of the despot the name of the capital was returned to the historical and certainly better sounding Santo Domingo. FELIX E. F. LAROCCA, M.D. St. Louis

title: PLAYING THE RIGHT HAND IN THE WRONG SEAT
description: THE simplest form of duplicate play, and the most skillful, is the head-to-head match between two teams of four. The degree of difficulty involved in putting one team North-South at one table and East-West at the other might seem trivial, but failures have been surprisingly frequent in tournament play.

title: U.S. WILL OVERSEE LIBERIAN FINANCES
description: In this land on the west coast of Africa where ''eating money'' - stealing public funds - is a time-honored tradition, the United States has accepted a rare invitation to play financial diet doctor.

title: 'IS MOMMY GOING TO DIE?'
description: THIS FAR AND NO MORE A True Story. By Andrew H. Malcolm. 247 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: NEW YORK'S SPINNING LITERARY CIRCLES
description: A writer's life may be one of dreary solitude, but the Literary Life - ah, the Literary Life promises glamour, fame, a seat next to Hemingway as he scribbles immortal prose in a Paris cafe. The myth is so alluring it can survive even the most scaled-down atmosphere. On a typical New York night, for instance, David Leavitt, Meg Wolitzer and Gary Glickman - all novelists in their 20's and the best of friends - are likely to be having dinner at their favorite restaurant, a dingy, hole in the wall in the West Village. ''Even as we sit there,'' Glickman says, ''I sometimes wonder, 'Is this it? Is it the Cafe de Flore?' '' As Hemingway might have said, isn't it pretty to think so?

title: SPACES AND PLACES
description: New York City long offered real estate developers the opportunity to circumvent certain zoning restrictions if, in exchange, they would provide public amenities on the sites of major developments. Now, after some experience, architects have a much better sense of what attracts people than they did in the 1950's, when Lever House and the Seagram Building were among the only skyscrapers in town with outdoor space dedicated to public use. The most successful and active areas, open-air or enclosed, have proved to be those that offer a mixture of attractions - food, seating, architecture, sunlight, air-conditioning, shops, cafes, fountains, art or gardens. Here, three Times writers sample these public spaces around town. PLAZAS AND ATRIUMS Direct sunlight is perhaps the most obvious attraction of the International Paper Plaza (behind the office tower at 1166 Sixth Avenue, between 45th and 46th Streets). On the right spring day, many New Yorkers simply bask here, often in the company of fusilli al pesto from Plums, the carry-out charcuterie at the back of the plaza.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: In this brief but copiously illustrated biography, Judy Taylor adds much fresh information to what was previously known about her sanguine-spirited and intensely private subject's life. BEATRIX POTTER:

title: Paraguay Lets an Exile Return
description: Domingo Laino, an opposition leader exiled four years ago by the Government of President Alfredo Stroessner, returned home today without incident.

title: A COMMUNITY SHARES GRIEF IN BUILDING'S FALL
description: In this blue-collar New England city, the American dream has always seemed particularly vivid, embodied in the saga of the proud Pontes, as they are known. By the hundreds, they came here from the small Italian town of Pontelandolfo, where they struggled to grow grapes and olive trees out of rocky soil.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MARY AND THE GIANT. By Philip K. Dick. (Arbor House, $16.95.) Philip K. Dick, the redoubtable science fiction writer who died in 1982, left a body of unpublished work outside the genre, of which ''Mary and the Giant'' is a fine example. Set in the early 1950's in a small northern California town, the story travels between the sensibilities of Joseph Schilling, an aging, world-weary music publisher, and Mary Anne Reynolds, a 20-year-old woman-child whose dark intensity keeps everyone around her guessing.

title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS
description: IN 1823, Hezekiah Pierpont, the first developer of Brooklyn Heights, attracted buyers to the bluffs overlooking the East River by advertising ''a home in the country with all the convenience of the city.''

title: BOND RULES TAKE TOLL IN STATE
description: LEAD: NEW restrictions on tax-exempt bonds are beginning to affect housing and development projects in New Jersey.

title: JAZZ: LESTER BOWIE
description: A LIME green bow tie and cummerbund! A white satin laboratory jacket! Orchestral fanfares worthy of the Tonight Show Band! Could this be Lester Bowie, trumpeter with the Art Ensemble of Chicago, erstwhile standardbearer of the avant-garde?

title: Recent Sales
description: Bridgeport, Conn. $152,000 586 Woodside Avenue 6-bedroom, 3 bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, patio, 75- by 100-foot lot; taxes $1,783. Guilford, Conn. $290,000 271 Durham Road 3-bedrooms, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; alarm system, screened porch, 1.1 acres; taxes $2,599. Stratford, Conn. $173,500 399 Windsor Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; screened porch, deck; taxes $1,230. Bronxville, N.Y. $337,000 6 Pasadena Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, deck, library, alarm system, walk to station and shopping; taxes $6,011. Lincolndale, N.Y. $229,000 Orange Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old frame raised ranch; deck, beach rights, 2-car garage; taxes $2,595. Peekskill, N.Y. $230,000 31 William Pucky Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old frame contemporary; deck, vaulted ceiling, pine grove; taxes $3,481. OTHER AREAS Springfield, N.J. $350,000 68 Greenhill Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,853. Williston Park, L.I. $158,000 216 Cornwell Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. Tanglewood Hills, L.I. $135,000 4 Whitney Lane, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; center hall, den, family room, in-ground pool, 2-car garage; taxes $2,500.

title: P.L.O. Session Ends After Concessions by Arafat
description: A meeting of reconciliation for rival factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization nearly collapsed here Saturday night after Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, balked at giving his opponents a more visible role in the guerrilla organization's leadership.

title: RAILROAD STRIKES: MAKE THEM ILLEGAL
description: With memories of the January strike and its hardships still in our minds, the unions threatened to strike the Long Island Rail Road again. This threat created anxiety among all railroad users, who desperately searched for alternative transportation. Fortunately, the strike did not materialize; it was settled by negotiations before the deadline. This is the way all labor disputes should be settled.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA OFFERS MODERN PROGRAM
description: FEW organizations with the reputation of Musica Sacra would dream of devoting an evening entirely to works composed within the past 25 years. This chorus could easily have sold out Avery Fisher Hall Friday night with music by Bach or Handel - maybe even Carl Orff or Charles Ives - but opted instead for the more difficult task of fighting for the music of our own time, with a correlative drop in attendance. Such courage must be acknowledged, and the words that follow should be read in the spirit of critical admiration.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PRIVATE PRISONS;
DO PROFITABLE JAILS SERVE A SOCIAL GOOD?
description: LEAD: BY NOW, few prison experts, either in the public or private sectors, deny that private prisons in some form or another are a permanent fixture on the corrections landscape. But the debate continues over whether that is good or bad.

title: Miss Rutledge Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Louise Heyward Rutledge, a daughter of the Rev. Fleming Rutledge and Reginald E. Rutledge Jr. of Port Chester, N.Y., to William L. Donigan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donigan of Gainesville, Fla., took place yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: Our Fascination With Baby M
description: Until recently, I understood the bottom line of feminism to be a rejection of the assumption that biology is destiny. Who are these so-called feminists protesting outside the court on Mrs. Whitehead's behalf?

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: The MTV Video Music Awards Collection Warner Reprise Video. 41 minutes. $19.98.

title: HOME VIDEO: DANCE
description: LEAD: American Ballet Theater in San Francisco With Natalia Makarova, Cynthia Gregory, Fernando Bujones. Home Vision. 105 minutes. $39.95.

title: Protest Staged by Serbs In an Albanian Region
description: Thousands of Serbs demanding better treatment in Yugoslavia's Albanian minority region of Kosovo staged an all-night vigil after the ethnic clashes.

title: ARTS SCHOOL HEARS OWN DRUMMER
description: LEAD: THERE is little sign of desks or blackboards. The classrooms are dance studios and art labs, and the library has a piano. Instead of lockers, paintings and drawings line the halls. Students dress in leotards and spattered smocks, and there is a kinetic energy among them.

title: A Broker Is Charged in Check-Kiting Scheme
description: A senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers has been charged in a yearlong, $19 million check-kiting scheme that involved the brokerage firm's money, the Federal prosecutor in Manhattan announced yesterday.

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: In the article ''Stepping Up to 11,300 Feet'' (Travel, Feb. 15), the author identifies the ''stellar jay'' and the ''Ingleman spruce.'' The bird, which is named for Georg Wilhelm Steller, is correctly called a Steller's jay. And the evergreen is named for a man called Engelmann, not Ingleman.

title: DETECTOR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: RESEARCH FRONTIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: 76ERS EVEN SERIES AS BARKLEY EXCELS
description: Nothing this season has been easy for the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: END BELIEVED NEAR FOR U.S. SANCTIONS IMPOSED ON JAPAN
description: President Reagan is expected to tell Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone this week that the United States may be able to end trade sanctions against Japan by the end of June, according to Administration officials.

title: Surplus Cheese Plan Is Being Investigated
description: State and Federal investigators suspect that surplus cheese destined for soup kitchens and school lunch programs in New York City is being diverted from one or more warehouses in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Nassau County and sold to restaurants in upstate New York, according to an official who monitors the Federal food program.

title: AMOCO BID FOR DOME ADVANCES
description: By outbidding a Canadian rival at a time when Government attitudes toward foreign investment are relatively benign, the Amoco Corporation appears likely to succeed in its offer to buy Dome Petroleum Ltd.

title: Saatchi Loses BVD Account
description: The Union Underwear Company, a subsidiary of Farley/ Northwest Industries, is taking all of its business out of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton. It should be about $5 million in billings.

title: Jean Zimmerman Is Bride Of Gilbert Reavill, a Writer
description: The marriage of Jean Zimmerman to Gilbert Reavill took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Zimmerman, in Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Raymond G. Manker, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
13 Inmates in Jersey File Suit Over AIDS
description: Thirteen inmates have filed a lawsuit in Federal court here contending that they risk contracting AIDS because of inadequate and poorly enforced policies by the New Jersey Department of Corrections.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,232,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The company said the year-ago 6-months net reflect a one-time gain of 6 cents a share related to the sale of a hospital in St. Louis. The company also said the latest 6-month results reflect the reversal in the first quarter of $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, of investments tax credit in connection with tax reform legislation.

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes for the first quarter a $7.5 million ''fresh start'' income tax benefit resulting from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, and also includes for the first quarter gains on sales of investments of $11.3 million compared to $26.3 million in the year-ago first quarter. c-Includes an after-tax gain on the sale of the company's Canadian property and casualty insurance subsidiary of $47 million, or 78 cents a share; on Jan. 8, the company sold the capital stock of Pilot Insurance Co., a wholly-owned foreign property and casualty insurance subsidiary, for $143.6 million in cash. The company said the increase in revenue reflects the price increases obtained by its property and casualty insurance operations and the continuing growth of its life and title and mortgage insurance operations.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK POWER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DREXEL OFFICIAL IS SAID TO AID INQUIRY
description: The Government has advanced its investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. by gaining the cooperation of an important official at the Wall Street firm in return for immunity from prosecution, according to lawyers and Wall Street executives with knowledge of the Government's investigation.

title: European Happy Talk
description: There is a new buzz of talk about European consolidation of all kinds - economic, monetary, social, military. It sounds as if a vital new momentum were building up, the kind of determined surge that led to the Common Market 30 years ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Learning the Score

title: ADVANCED MAGNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in June.

title: ADT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net of $400,000 from discontinued operations.

title: COMPUFLIGHT OPERATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WEYENBERG SHOE MANUFACURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Those Blue Grass Blues
description: The Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland, once considered the major prep for the Kentucky Derby but declining badly in recent years, reached what is probably the lowest point in its history when it was run for the 63d time last Thursday. Only five 3-year-olds were entered, none of them a prominent Derby prospect. Indeed, just one of the five had ever won even a minor stakes race.

title: THEATER: O'TOOLE AND PLUMMER IN 'PYGMALION'
description: THE erratic amusements offered by Broadway's new revival of ''Pygmalion'' may have only a glancing connection to Shaw's wonderful play, but it would be folly to pretend that they don't exist. Not every day do New Yorkers get to see a precise replica of a London ''all star'' mounting of a classic - the sort of package that draws busloads of international tourists and British provincials to the Haymarket.

title: HOLOCAUST VICTIMS ARE MEMORIALIZED
description: The deportation of Karl Linnas, who faces a death sentence in the Soviet Union as a Nazi war criminal, was hailed yesterday at a Holocaust memorial service as an act of justice and as a warning to those who collaborated with the Nazis that they will be doggedly pursued for their crimes.

title: ALABAMA FEDERAL S&L ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VELOBIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
CONCERT: SIMON'S 'GRACELAND'
description: FOR a project that's earnest, meticulous and politically sensitive, Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' show is also a lot of fun. It arrived Saturday at Radio City Music Hall for the first of five sold-out concerts, interspersing South African-derived songs from Mr. Simon's ''Graceland'' with the music of South Africans themselves.

title: Critically Ill 7-Year-Old Boy May Receive a Fourth Liver
description: Ronnie DeSillers, weakened by three liver transplants and a host of complications, remained in critical condition today as doctors searched for another liver for him.

title: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CASEY, IN HOSPITAL, CRITICALLY ILL
description: William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, was in critical condition with pneumonia today at a hospital here.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A DEBATE IN CHINA OVER STOCK TRADING
description: Before the Communist victory in 1949 exorcised almost all traces of capitalism from China, this city boasted of having the biggest stock market in Asia. Now, as the nation tentatively rediscovers the need for capital markets, Shanghai has a new stock exchange - one that lists four stocks and two bonds.

title: FROM AN EDUCATION CHIEF, TOUGH TALK AND POLITICS

title: Switch-Pitcher
description: Coasting on a 10-run lead the other day, Greg Fine of Delaware Valley High School in Everittstown, N.J., caused some double-takes when he began warming up for the fifth inning against rival Dunellen. If memory served, Fine had just pitched four shutout innings as a lefty. Now he was throwing right-handed, and the Dunellen bench didn't quite know what to make of it. ''We checked his number, and it was the same kid,'' said Coach Pio Pennisi. ''I'd never seen or heard of anyone pitching left- and right-handed.''

description: PART of the current generation of screaming performers, Sam Kinison does his act in white sneakers, a tweedy beret and a dumpy overcoat, looking for all the world like the neighborhood flasher. That's his more likable side. Claiming to have once been an evangelist preacher, Mr. Kinison is still another comedian determined to shock paying customers. He has been shouting his way threateningly through such television formats as ''Saturday Night Live'' for the last year or so. Now he has his own pay-cable special on Home Box Office. Taped at the Roxy Theater in Los Angeles, ''Sam Kinison: Breaking the Rules'' had its original debut date postponed so as not to offend viewers during Easter week. description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9, B12 The U.S. may end trade sanctions against Japan by the end of June, officials said. President Reagan is expected to tell Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone this week that the restrictions might be lifted. Page A1 In a Japanese gesture to Washington, Mr. Nakasone instructed Japan's Fisheries Agency to re-examine plans to conduct whaling in the Antarctic for research purposes. ''Let us not fool ourselves that what is happening in Ireland today is any less than disaster,'' one Irish emigrant said. Dilson Funaro, who was largely responsible for Brazil's decision in February to suspend interest payments on its $68 billion foreign-bank debt, said his decision was irrevocable. Radiation exposure could cause mental retardation and genetic defects, but some problems may not become evident for 50 years, experts said. A8 Changing attitudes in Europe A9 Environmental and economic crises are interlocking problems that threaten humanity, a United Nations commission warns. The commission concluded that environmental protection and economic growth are inseparable. The special prosecutor is considering criminal conspiracy charges against Albert Hakim, an Iranian-born arms dealer. The legalization process for some aliens is to begin next week. But in the 1988 campaign, the task presents unusual problems. A1 George Bush's image problems hamper his campaign for the 1988 Republican presidential nomination. ''Mr. Bush brought this on himself by displaying an excess of caution,'' one former aide to the Vice President said. B8 W. Wilson Goode is favored to win renomination for Mayor of Philadelphia less than a month from now and go on to reelection in the fall despite accusations of incompetance. The Cowboy Church in Fort Worth is a blend of rodeo ambiance and evangelical Christianity that has gained a loyal following. A12 The Rev. Jerry Falwell may resign Tuesday as head of the PTL Club, the troubled television ministry, he said. Mr. Falwell said he was under pressure from ministers around the country to withdraw. ''Everybody knows the Midwest is out there, but there's very little scholarly work on precisely where,'' one professor said. Almost half of the top managers of New York City's welfare system may not qualify for their jobs under the Civil Service rules. title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Easy Victory for Crampton and Moody: Bruce Crampton and Orville Moody pulled away with birdies on the first five holes and cruised to a four-stroke victory and a record score yesterday in the Legends of Golf in Austin, Tex. The Crampton-Moody pair combined for a best-ball 64 and completed 72 holes at 251, a tournament-record 29 under par on the Onion Creek Club course. Their total broke by four shots the 72-hole record of 255 set last year by Don January and Gene Littler. It was the eighth victory for Crampton, 51 years old, in his brief Seniors tour career, and the third for Moody, 53. Each collected $60,000. Bobby Nichols and Butch Baird came on with a last-round 62, 8 under par, and finished second at 255. In the Legendary Champions competition for players 60 and older, Jerry Barber, 71, and Doug Ford, 64, scored an easy seven-shot victory.(AP) Haas Rallies, Takes Playoff: Jay Haas ran in a 60-foot birdie putt to force a playoff, then sank a 2-foot par putt on the first playoff hole of the Houston Open to deny Buddy Gardner his first PGA Tour victory. Gardner, who got his fourth runner-up finish, chipped out of a bunker to within 3 feet of the cup on the par-3, 177-yard first playoff hole at No. 16. Haas, in winning his sixth tour event and earning $103,000, chipped off the fringe on his second shot, then sank a 2-footer after Gardner missed his short par putt.(AP) Hockey Canada in Playoffs: Canada gained the playoff round of the world championships by beating Finland, 7-2, yesterday. But Sweden, which needed a point from its game against the Soviet Union to guarantee a place in the last four, lost by 4-2. The two results forced the International Ice Hockey Federation to decide whether to obey a court order restoring West German victories over Finland and Canada that the federation had taken away because the Germans had used an ineligible player. Canada's victory over Finland guaranteed that it qualified, along with the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia. If the Finns were allowed to keep the points awarded them after throwing out the West German victory, they would be tied with the Swedes and advance on the strength of beating them, 4-1. Otherwise, Sweden would advance. (AP) Auto Racing Four Straight for Earnhardt: Dale Earnhardt charged past a spinning Geoff Bodine with only 17 laps left and raced off to his fourth straight victory, taking the Sovran Bank 500 at the Martinsville (Va.) Speedway. Bodine appeared to have the race well in hand, leading Earnhardt by about 5 seconds as he tried to end a 26-race victory drought. But on lap 484 of 500 on the half-mile oval, Bodine got tangled up with Kyle Petty in the second turn.(AP) Horse Racing Ms. Eloise Wins on Late Charge: Ms. Eloise made her patented late run work to perfection for the third straight time when she came from last in the field of eight to register a three-quarter-length victory in the $230,800 Top Flight Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. Carrying 116 pounds under Robbie Davis, Ms. Eloise went a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:50 1/5. Beth's Song, the second longest price in the field, was runner-up a length ahead of Clemanna's Rose. Ms. Eloise earned $138,480 for Margaret E. Grimm with her fourth victoryin seven starts this year. She paid $6.60 for $2 to win.

title: People

title: RECITAL: LANDES, PIANIST
description: GARAH LANDES, a Manhattan School of Music graduate who studies with Earl Wild, has a more interesting sense of the piano's coloristic possibilities than some of his contemporaries, and his recital of Bach, Prokofiev and Liszt at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon disclosed a strong musical grasp as well. The overall level of accomplishment did not immediately insist that Mr. Landes has realized his full potential, but he is a young artist worth keeping an eye on.

title: N.A.A.C.P., IN REPORT ON HIRING BIAS, CRITICIZES THE RECORDING INDUSTRY
description: Widespread discrimination and a lack of support from major black artists have prevented blacks from making significant inroads in the recording industry, according to a recent report by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and interviews with industry executives and music historians.

title: Pilots Criticize UAL Decision
description: The United Airlines pilots union today lashed out at UAL Inc.'s board for rejecting its $4.5 billion offer to buy the airline subsidiary and threatened to take ''alternative action'' to acquire United.

title: Foster Grant Is Putting Its Focus on Fashion
description: Foster Grant, the leading force in the country's $1 billion sunglasses market, is changing its advertising tack under its new management.

title: JOHN BASKS AS YANKS GET HOT
description: In one glorious afternoon of hitting, the Yankees erased the possibility of a disastrous weekend on the shores of Lake Erie. And yet even as they reveled in a 14-2 dismantling of the Indians today, it was Tommy John, their wondrous 43-year-old pitcher, who enjoyed the finest moments at Cleveland Stadium.

description: Sixty people have been arrested in connection with a spate of bombings in February, the police said today.

And that is what Bendel's specialized in.

description: THE music of 20th-century Britain has hugely profited from the fervent ministrations of British musicians and the British musical press. What we may be seeing is an intensely patriotic attempt to transfer pre-eminence in diplomacy and economics -now lost - to affairs of the soul. If the empire no longer rules the corporeal world, they seem to be saying, let us lead it in sensibility.

title: Daughter's Suicide Results In Father's Accidental Death
description: A 34-year-old woman committed suicide by letting a car engine run inside a garage, and the carbon monoxide fumes accidentally killed her father in an upstairs bedroom, the authorities said.
