Catching Up
description: * If this is springtime, then you'd think that the San Jose Bees and the Miami Marlins would be providing showcases for former major-leaguers who want another shot at the big time, and you'd be right. Last year the unaffiliated, Class A Bees gave Derrel Thomas, Mike Norris, Daryl Sconiers, Steve Howe, Fernando Arroyo, Darryl Cias and Ken Reitz a chance to attract the scouts, but none got a return call to the majors. Reitz and Sconiers are now back in San Jose, where they've been joined by Charlie Moore, Steve McCatty and Roger Erickson. Warren Brusstar quit the team last week, and he had his reasons: a 20.77 earned run average, 14 hits, 3 walks, a hit batter and 2 wild pitches - all in four and one-third innings. Meanwhile, the Marlins, like the Bees a Class A haven in recent years for last-gasp big-leaguers, have become a way station for Dennis Martinez, one of those man-without-a-team free agents. Martinez, who could be headed back to Montreal after May 1, joined Miami a week ago and got some quick work -eight innings in two games, with no earned runs yielded.

title: STOCKER & YALE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
16 Who Can Do the Job
description: THREE weeks ago, Al Campanis mentioned that blacks in baseball ''may not have some of the necessities'' to be managers or front-office executives. In the uproar that followed, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and leaders of black organizations met with baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and some major-league clubs to spur the hiring of blacks in those roles. But no names surfaced from those meetings. So the question remains: Of the older players, ex-players, and current major-league coaches, who possess the credentials, the personality and the inclination for those jobs?

title: BLAS ROCA, CUBAN COMMUNIST AND PARTY THEORETICIAN, DIES
description: Blas Roca, a leading theoretician of the Cuban Revolution who led Cuba's prerevolutionary Communist Party, died Saturday in Havana. He was 78 years old. [ The Cuban Government declared three days of official mourning, Reuters reported from Havana. More than 100,000 mourners stood waiting overnight to view the body of Mr. Roca, which lay in state under a huge statue of the Cuban nationalist hero, Jose Marti, in Revolution Square, Reuters said. The Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, was among those who came to pay his respects. ] Mr. Roca, who was born Francisco Calderio in the eastern Cuban city of Manzanillo, left school at the age of 11 and began shining shoes to help support his poor family, the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said in a dispatch monitored in Mexico City. He changed his name to Roca, meaning rock, after he joined the Communist Party in 1929.

description: Chris Evert upset Martina Navratilova, 3-6, 6-1, 7-6, today to take the championship in the Virginia Slims of Houston women's tennis tournament at Lakeside Racquet and Athletic Club.

description: The minister for Northern Ireland said today that he would investigate how Irish guerrillas knew enough about the travel plans of the province's second most senior judge to kill him in a car bomb attack.

description: Lisbet Palme, widow of the assassinated Swedish Prime Minister, Olof Palme, looked down at the silver Algerian brooch gleaming on her lapel.

title: DANCE: THE PAUL TAYLOR TROUPE
description: THE Paul Taylor Dance Company's current season has all the earmarks of being a historic one. It has a company dancing at peak strength, a repertory that for the first time reveals Mr. Taylor's unusually wide range as a choreographer and another first -the inclusion of works by four men in the company.

description: Leslie Harwood was married yesterday to Stephen A. Ehrlich at Temple Beth-El in Jersey City. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Bruce Block, assisted by Rabbi Samuel Berman.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Once Is Enough
description: Irena Kirszenstein Szewinska of Poland is one of history's great track and field athletes. Over her long career as a sprinter, hurdler and long jumper, she won seven gold medals in five events at four Olympics. She broke 10 world and 12 European records, and she won 10 European and 21 Polish titles.

title: KNUTSON MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in October 1986.

title: SENATOR GORE? IS HE THE ONE MARRIED TO TIPPER?
description: In the capital, Albert Gore Jr., the handsome young Senator from Tennessee who is the latest entry in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination has been written about so much that Newsweek labeled the phenomenon 'Gore chic.'

title: PENNZOIL AND 25 OTHERS WILL MONITOR TEXACO
description: The United States trustee in the Texaco Inc. bankruptcy case today appointed 26 Texaco creditors, including the Pennzoil Company, to monitor the activities of Texaco. These creditors, along with Texaco, will help decide on a plan of reorganization for it.

title: OPERA: WAGNER'S 'RING DES NIBELUNGEN' IN NIGERIA
description: At the end of this season, Michael Gielen will retire after 10 years as director of the Frankfurt Opera. For his final production, the company has assembled a new staging of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' The individual operas of the cycle have been appearing since 1985, and the complete tetralogy was presented for the first time starting April 17 and ending with ''Gotterdammerung'' Sunday night, with two more cycles scheduled for this season between May 17 and 25 and between June 14 and 24.

title: GOODYEAR POSTS PROFIT AFTER LOSS IN '86 QUARTER
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which sold most of its non-tire businesses last year to thwart a takeover attempt, yesterday reported a first-quarter profit of $284.2 million, compared with a loss of $212.7 million in the period a year ago.

title: Grenades Thrown in Manila At U.S. Advisers' Compound
description: Grenades thrown from a passing vehicle exploded inside the compound of American military advisers in suburban Manila today, a Philippine officer said. No casualties were reported. Several hours before the attack, the military said that dissident troops had abandoned plans to seize two garrisons in suburban Manila, and that troops remained on alert in case of another coup attempt before the May 11 elections.

title: Fed Official Prods Banks
description: The Federal Reserve's vice chairman, Manuel H. Johnson, suggested today that major commercial banks be penalized if they remain unwilling to make new loans to heavily indebted countries of Latin America.

title: Growing Nuclear Arsenal
description: A new study says the United States has produced more than 60,000 nuclear weapons since 1945, a number that, on average, works out to four warheads a day, seven days a week. And during the Reagan Administration, the historical average has been topped.

description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $10.1 million.

Creative Head Resigns At Ogilvy & Mather
description: Pleading that he has reached a point in life when he'd like to build something for himself, Jay Schulberg, 47 years old, an executive vice president and for the last two years the creative head of Ogilvy & Mather New York, has resigned from the company.

title: MAKEUP VIDEOS TO TAKE OUT
description: ''When you have your makeup done, your eyes are closed half the time,'' said Katie Ford, ''so you don't know what's happening. You have to go back and find out what they did. With this video, you can just play it and see everything.'' ''It's like a refresher course,'' said Cynthia Gibbons. The two women were at the Estee Lauder counter in Bloomingdale's on Friday, waiting for experts to make them up and record the process on video cassettes they could buy and take home. While this is not the first use of video for demonstrating makeup, officials of Lauder say they believe that the company's three cameras in Bloomingdale's New York store form the first permanent installation. Lauder and other cosmetic companies send cameras on periodic trips to stores in other cities.

description: On May 15, if Hollywood rumor is to be trusted, Pamela Ewing of CBS's ''Dallas'' will be a victim in a fiery car crash, ending the season near death and wrapped in bandages. An hour later, most of the cast of the same network's ''Falcon Crest'' will sink from sight into San Francisco Bay, not to be heard from until the new fall season.

description: The chairman of a House subcommittee has asked the Justice Department to investigate 10 regional civil rights offices of the Department of Education where employees admitted last July that they backdated discrimination complaints and pressed witnesses to withdraw charges of discrimination.

title: Ex-Governor Gubbrud Of South Dakota Dies
description: Archie M. Gubbrud, who doubled state aid to education in his tenure as Governor of South Dakota from 1961 to 1965, died of lung cancer Sunday at McKennan Hospital here. He was 76 years old.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will decide Wednesday whether to ask Congress to give it the authority to regulate commercial banks engaged in the securities business.

title: 'FAST COPY,' MAGAZINE-STYLE PROGRAM
description: ''FAST COPY'' is an entertainment program that looks like a news program, or maybe it's the other way around. In other words, it's ''infotainment,'' or popcorn news, and as such, it's not bad at all. Meanwhile, even if it's not trying to, ''Fast Copy'' is slyly raising a question: Does television need reporters? The NBC program, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, relies on video.

title: PRESIDENT CRITICIZES TRADE PLAN
description: President Reagan warned today that a restrictive amendment to trade legislation being debated on Capitol Hill this week was a dangerous proposal. He said it could disrupt the world trading system and jeopardize relations with some of America's major trading partners.

title: Correction
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign misstated four items of polling data. A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last month interviewed 394 likely Republican primary voters (not registered Republicans), with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points, not three. Another poll by the same two organizations was conducted April 5 through 8 and interviewed 1,045 people.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: BROADWAY openings once epitomized cosmopolitan glamour. But the audience for the premiere of ''Pygmalion'' at the Plymouth Sunday could have used some sartorial help from Henry Higgins.

description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres are locked in a tug-of-war over whether Israel should attend a Middle East peace conference, and it is becoming increasingly evident that the rope is Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Oilers Top Jets, 4-2, To Sweep Series
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen scored a goal and assisted on two others in a three-goal first period as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Winnipeg Jets, 4-2, tonight to wrap up the National Hockey League's Smythe Division championship.

description: It may be a while before you can take a flier on the Yankees or sell the Mets short on the New York Stock Exchange. But five months after the Boston Celtics made financial history by selling their shares to the public, other clubs have disclosed plans to make similar offerings, and still more are waiting in the wings.

description: Richard J. Ferris, chairman of UAL Inc., scheduled a news conference in Manhattan Thursday after the company's annual meeting of stockholders. It would be Mr. Ferris's first such meeting since United Airlines' pilots offered three weeks ago to buy the huge carrier for $4.5 billion. UAL said the carrier was not for sale.

description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the industrialist who sometimes knows a good deal about what's going on between the United States and the Soviet Union, has some interesting predictions about relations between the two nations in the months ahead. At a dinner last week at the National Gallery, he said he believed Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, would attend a summit meeting in the United States this year and would be invited to address a joint session of Congress.

Compaq Profits Soar
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its earnings for the first quarter more than doubled to a record $20.2 million, or 56 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or 27 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. For the three months ended March 31, the company, which is based in Houston, said that revenues rose 47 percent, to $211 million, from $144 million in the period a year ago. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Compaq rose $1.875, to $34.875 a share.

title: GIANTS ARE AT FOES MERCY, FOR A CHANGE
description: If you think you know who the Giants will choose on the first round of today's National Football League draft, please let the Giants know. Their front office is resigned to the fact that because the Super Bowl champions get the 28th and last pick, they are at the mercy of the teams that pick ahead of them.

title: Student Slaying Stirs Grief Across Detroit
description: High school students and parents gathered in assemblies across the city today to discuss guns in the schools, a problem pushed to the forefront by the recent killing of a 17-year-old boy.

title: Delivering the Vans
description: The men and women who deliver the mail are trading up from their familiar red, white and blue Jeep to a newly designed and more rugged delivery van. The first of 99,000 of the new models to be manufactured by the Grumman Corporation, better known for aircraft, will be delivered to Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch outside the Washington headquarters of the United States Postal quarters tomorrow morning.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Sirk at the Thalia

title: Wild Metal Shifts Led By Silver
description: The precious metals markets went through their most volatile day in years yesterday in a session driven by the changes in the dollar's value. Silver prices were especially wild, swinging by an astonishing $4 an ounce.

title: Sanction Off In Tyson Bout
description: Jimmy Binns, legal counsel to the World Boxing Association, said yesterday that his organization was withdrawing its sanction of the Mike Tyson-Pinklon Thomas heavyweight title bout if it is held, as planned, in Nevada.

SETTLEMENT REACHED IN INDECENCY CHARGE INVOLVING EDUCATOR
description: Charges of indecent assault and battery against the former president of Westfield State College, Francis J. Pilecki, were dropped today in Superior Court after a judge heard that a civil settlement had been reached between the official and the student he was accused of abusing.

title: Burlington Accused Of Stock Violations
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, and Dominion Textile Inc., Canada's biggest textile manufacturer, accused Burlington Industries yesterday of taking unlawful steps to manipulate the price at which the two could buy Burlington shares, preventing them from trying to take over the company.

title: Market Place; Ad Tax's Effect On Papers
description: ONE week ago, Salomon Brothers lowered its investment rating on newspaper stocks in the expectation that Florida would enact a 5 percent sales tax on a wide range of services, including media advertising.

title: JOIN FORCES, KOCH URGES 150 MAYORS
description: Mayor Koch today asked 150 mayors of large cities and towns to withhold endorsing Presidential candidates for the 1988 election until next fall, in the hope of developing a bipartisan urban agenda to be presented to Republican and Democratic candidates.

description: The Lotus Development Corporation and I.B.M. have always fed on each other's success but deliberately remained at arm's length.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: WHEN the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center combines triviality and substance the way it did at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, then there is genuine entertainment for its listeners. This particular program placed a wan and forgettable trio movement by the teen-age Beethoven next to one of his later, but still youthful, triumphs, and also a Martinu flute sonata filled with character against a new piece by Carla Bley distinguished mostly for its neutrality.

description: b-Includes after-tax charges of $10 million for amortization of intangible assets related to the Bayliner and Sea Ray acquisitions.

title: Bonn Divided on Missiles
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl failed to reconcile differences within his coalition today over its approach to a Soviet proposal to abolish short-range missiles in Europe.

title: L.I. Skateboard Bill Passed
description: The Islip Town Council today outlawed skateboarding on sidewalks in business districts. Edward Wankel, a deputy town supervisor, said skateboarders posed a danger to pedestrians and motorists in the downtown areas, where most skateboard accidents occur. The new ordinance also requires skateboard users to wear reflective clothing at night. Those who violate the rule face a $25 fine.

description: b-Net income The company said interest income previously included in revenue is now being reported as an offset to net financing costs and has been reclassified for prior years for comparative reporting purposes.

Swearingen as chairman, is expected to result in the departure of several executives in the Ogden camp, according to bank officials who requested anonymity.

title: OLD SOLDIERS OF 2 CAMPS TALK OF PEACE
description: Seven Soviet generals and admirals, men who have spent their lives planning and fighting wars, are at the end of a highly unusual visit to Washington, where they spent a week talking peace with Americans who once wore stars on their shoulders.

title: Bonds Plunge, but End Higher
description: The bond market staged a dramatic comeback yesterday after another plunge in prices earlier in the session.

title: Cosby and the Muppets Win Peabody Awards
description: ''The Cosby Show'' and Kermit the Frog and his Muppet pals were among the winners today of George Foster Peabody Awards for distinguished broadcasting in 1986.

title: Super Hasty on the Supercollider
description: A sudden interest in high energy physics is sweeping state capitals from coast to coast. The reason is the superconducting supercollider, the new atom smasher endorsed by the Reagan Administration. Though only one state can win, at least 26 are lobbying to be its site. New York, Illinois and Texas are spending millions on surveys and formal proposals.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART BLOOMS AS BRIDGE TO TRANSPLANT
description: WHILE the use of permanent artificial hearts has stalled, the temporary implanting of the devices to sustain patients waiting for human heart transplants has emerged as a frequent and less controversial procedure.

title: DANCE: 'FAUN VARIATIONS'
description: THE third in the series of four solos choreographed by dancers in the Paul Taylor Dance Company this season turned out to be an imaginative gloss upon Vaslav Nijinsky's ''Afternoon of a Faun.''

title: First-Rate
description: Rickey Henderson's nine home runs as a first-inning leadoff batter set an American League record last season and fell just two short of Bobby Bonds's major league mark. Henderson has already hit three more such homers in 1987 and may catch Bonds, the major leagues' career leader in the category, before the year is out. Baseball history's top 10: Bobby Bonds (332 total homers) 35 Rickey Henderson (109) 31 Eddie Yost (139) 28 Jimmy Ryan* (118) 22 Lou Brock (149) 21 Felipe Alou (206) 20 Dick McAuliffe (197) 19 Eddie Joost (134) 19 Hank Bauer (164) 18 Tommy Harper (146) 16 * Never heard of him? Ryan was an outfielder and part-time pitcher who played 18 seasons for the Cubs and the Senators before retiring in 1903.

title: Bridge: Unusual Play by Declarer May Trip Up the Defenders
description: Defenders are always guided by a simple assumption, that the opposing declarer is playing normally.

description: b-Includes special charges of $9,400,000 for the quarter and $12,450,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes special charges of $3,300,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said results for the latest quarter were affected by a 13 percent decline in unit volume shipments for the quarter chiefly a result of the Bridgeport plant strike plus the closing of the tube division. The company also said it incurred strike-related costs of about $2.5 million in the quarter. Results were helped by reduced raw material and energy costs; lower salaried staffing levels and by a change, in the method of accounting for pension costs, effectively July 1, 1986. Adoption of FASB 87 improved latest third quarter earnings by $1.4 million after taxes.

title: PITINO PREFERS FRIARS TO KNICKS

description: PEER pressure, group support, external rewards and a nagging spouse may prompt people to change their bad health habits, but these popular incentives often backfire in the long run, according to a leading specialist in health promotion.

YANKEE PITCHING STAFF SOLID
description: Except for the workers who had begun to push brooms through the cluttered aisles, the only visible signs of activity this morning were players standing casually on the field at Arlington Stadium. The Yankees had the day off, but they worked anyway under a bright and warm sun, preparing for a two-game series against the Texas Rangers and still basking in a lopsided victory Sunday in Cleveland.

title: JAMES R. WITHROW Jr.
description: James R. Withrow Jr., a senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, died of a heart attack Thursday at a friend's home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SILHOUETTES, AN OLD ART REVIVED
description: A portraitist in the tradition of the silhouette artists of the 18th and 19th centuries will be at the Museum of American Folk Art Shop Friday and Saturday to cut visitors' profiles from black paper and mount them on white card stock.

title: BREAKUP OF HOUSING FOR POOR IS BACKED IN INTEGRATION MOVE
description: A group of poor blacks, the City of Dallas and the Reagan Administration have agreed, with the approval of a Federal district judge, that 2,600 public housing units in the city's most infamous slum should be destroyed and that many of the tenants should be dispersed throughout the Dallas metropolitan area.

title: WALSH'S LAW FIRM WAS RETAINED BY SOUTHERN AIR
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, Lawrence E. Walsh, acknowledged today that his Oklahoma City law firm had done work for Southern Air Transport, a Miami-based cargo carrier that has been linked to the case.

title: PITCHER'S HIT LIFTS GIANTS
description: Kelly Downs, the pitcher, drove in the tie-breaking run with a single in the seventh inning and Chili Davis hit a two-run single and a homer as the San Francisco Giants downed the Atlanta Braves, 7-3, tonight.

title: Casey Still Hospitalized
description: William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, remained in a hospital where he was being treated for pneumonia, but a spokeswoman declined to release any further information today. ''The family has requested no statements be given,'' said Renee Paley, director of communications at Glen Cove Community Hospital.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said all share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split of the company's common stock that was distributed April 24, 1987, to stockholders of record on March 31, 1987.

title: COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing >Desirous Wins at Aqueduct: Desirous, with Angel Cordero Jr. riding, beat the favored Self Image and Eddie Maple to post a half-length victory yesterday in the $31,000 Fides Purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and upward at Aqueduct. It was six more lengths back to the third-place Stated. The victory was the second in six starts this year for Desirous, who went a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:52 1/5. Desirous, carrying a low weight of 107 pounds, paid $7.40, $2.80 and $2.80 for $2 across the board. Self Image returned $2.60 and $2.20 and Stated paid $3. (AP) SQUASH Talbott Defeats Boyum: Top-seeded Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., defeated unseeded David Boyum of Cambridge, Mass., 15-5, 15-10, 15-6, Sunday to advance to the final of the $20,000 Newport Open Squash Racquets Championships in Newport, R.I. In the other semifinal match, second-seeded Ned Edwards of New York beat eighth-seeded Juan Mendez of Mexico City, 15-11, 15-6, 15-2.

title: KERR GLASS MFG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $185,000 from the sale of land. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago period.

title: Why the Dollar Ought to Drop
description: Some say the dollar is too weak. Others say it is too strong. In either case, the dollar's steady march downward that began two years ago has now brought it back to 1980 levels. Paul R. Krugman, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology international economist and former staff member of the Council of Economic Advisers, argues that the dollar will - and should - continue to sink. Q. How much more will the dollar fall? A. It will fall perhaps as much as another 20 percent. And it will take something like that for the U.S. to be able to balance the trade deficit. Since the last time we had balanced trade, which was in 1981, a number of the aspects of the world economy have become more adverse: lagging growth in Europe, the third-world debt crisis, increased competition from new sources and the loss of the superior technology the U.S. once had. All this means the dollar has to fall even further to offset some special advantages we no longer have. Q. What happens if the dollar doesn't fall by that much? A. The big danger is the trade balance fails to show improvement and, in the short run, protectionist pressures get out of hand. But, we have no options. Sooner or later the dollar will fall. The world will not allow the U.S. to borrow infinite sums of money. And the longer we wait, the more debt that will be built up, the further our competitive decline will have come and the harder the fall when it comes. Q. What are the inflationary risks of a falling dollar? A. There is no avoiding inflation. We are beginning to see some of that, and it's been pretty mild so far. If we don't pay the inflationary costs, we will pay them later - with interest. It's hard to think of a better time to accept it than now when the underlying inflation is low. And if inflation goes back up, the Federal Reserve may feel it has to tighten monetary policy. I hope they won't do that, but I can understand their nervousness. Q. And recession? A. The risks of recession come if the dollar doesn't come down. If we go staggering along with only modest improvements in our trade balance and if the rapid growth we've seen in domestic demand does not continue forever, which it will not, we do run the risk of recession. Q. Do you think that the world's central banks will act jointly to support the dollar?

title: BIRMINGHAM RACE TRACK OFF TO SLOW START
description: When it opened March 3, the Birmingham Turf Club became not only the Deep South's first thoroughbred horse racing track, but also an important symbol to leaders craving a more magnetic image for Alabama's biggest city.

title: F.S.L.I.C. Sues Vernon Officials
description: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation today filed its largest lawsuit ever, against former officers and directors of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, which was closed last month, The insurance fund said it was seeking to recover several hundred million dollars in damages from the principal owner and six former officers of Vernon for their ''systematic looting and wasting'' of the thrift association's assets. According to court documents, Don R. Dixon, who owned more than 90 percent of Vernon's stock, and the officers specifically misappropriated ''at least $40 million'' through unwarranted bonuses, illegal dividends and other unlawful payments. A lawyer representing Mr. Dixon, Marshall Simmons, did not return phone calls to his office.

title: Court Ends Zenith's TV Suit
description: The Supreme Court today ended a 17-year-old, billion-dollar suit by the Zenith Electronics Corporation and another company against Japanese television producers for allegedly using unfair pricing to destroy United States competitors.

title: OFFICE PLAN FOUGHT IN PRINCETON AREA
description: A plan by the Educational Testing Service to double the office space on its 370-acre campus here has drawn strong opposition from neighbors, who say it is a case of a nonprofit corporation trying to become just another office-park developer.

title: Lewis in Comeback
description: ''I'm not dead and I'm not old,'' said Carl Lewis after turning in a remarkable series of long jumps in his first outdoor meet this season. The 25-year-old Lewis, competing in the Mount San Antonio College Relays in Walnut, Calif., Sunday, following arthroscopic surgery on his left knee last September, soared beyond the 28-foot mark six times.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago Cubs' Andre Dawson, who had nine hits, including three doubles and three home runs, along with 11 runs batted in, was named the National League Player of the Week. . . . Wally Joyner of the California Angels, who batted .480 with five home runs and 13 r.b.i., was cited as American League Player of the Week.

title: Air Traffic Restrictions Urged
description: James A. Burnett, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said today that airline traffic should be restricted during the peak summer travel period in order to insure the safety of airline passengers.

title: EVE OF U.S. TRIP: NAKASONE PACKS GIFTS AND WOES
description: Politically battered at home at a time when his country faces rough challenges abroad, Yasuhiro Nakasone is scheduled to leave Wednesday on his sixth trip to the United States as Prime Minister. He said today that it was his ''most important visit of all.''

title: SINGLE WOMEN: COPING WITH A VOID
description: There is a single woman in New York, bright and accomplished, who dreads nightfall, when darkness hugs the city and lights go on in warm kitchens.

title: Group Seeks Mariners
description: The same group that Steve Garvey, the San Diego first baseman, put together in an unsuccessful attempt to buy the Padres has now made ''elementary inquiries'' about buying the Seattle Mariners from George Argyros, according to The Los Angeles Times. Argyros is seeking to buy the Padres but he can't assume control of the team until he sells the Mariners. Garvey was quoted as saying he would not be one of the investors at the present time because he is still playing, but could get involved after he retires. Garvey's $1.4 million-per-year pact with the Padres expires after this season.

title: GAF WITHDRAWS BID FOR BORG
description: The GAF Corporation yesterday withdrew a hostile takeover bid to buy the Borg-Warner Corporation, the big Chicago-based industrial company.

title: HIGH-FASHION LEATHER ACQUIRES GENTEEL IMAGE
description: The upward mobility of leather as an ingredient of fashion has been underscored repeatedly in new fashion collections all over the world. Once the symbol of rebellion, the black leather jacket was identified with James Dean in ''Rebel Without a Cause'' and Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One,'' as well as their host of imitators. Now it is identified with Yves Saint Laurent, Emanuel Ungaro and other establishment designers in Europe and the United States.

title: HERBERT ROSENGARTEN
description: Herbert Rosengarten, the founder and former president of the Herbert Manufacturing Company, a Manhattan textile concern, died of complications from Parkinson's disease yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $9.2 million from the sale of the company's medium-duty truck transmission business and Clark Equipment Credit Corp.

title: KINGS HIRE RUSSELL AS COACH
description: Bill Russell returned to coaching yesterday after an absence of 10 years. The 53-year-old Russell, who played for 11 National Basketball Association championship teams in his 13 seasons with the Boston Celtics, and coached two of them, was named yesterday as coach of the Sacramento Kings. He is to become president of the team eventually.

description: b-Includes a gain of $15.1 million from the sale of Helme Tobacco Company. The company said year-ago revenue included $50,500,000 from Metropolitan Distribution which was sold in September 1986.

title: Daiwa Names Economist
description: Michael J. Moran, a staff economist with the Federal Reserve Board, has been named to the new position of chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc., a unit of the leading Japanese securities firm.

title: MANAGUA SPRUCES UP FOR CONFERENCE
description: For the first time in eight years of Sandinista rule, the streets of Managua have been repaved.

title: Boeing Income Slides 20.3%
description: The Boeing Company today reported lower first-quarter earnings compared with a year ago and predicted a decline for the entire year. Boeing attributed the decrease to increased research and development costs and to lower profit margins in government and commercial business.

title: HOUSTON IS BUYING HOMES FOR LOW-INCOME TENANTS
description: The economic troubles in Houston that have cost many people their homes have made Annie Robertson a pioneer in an ambitious public housing experiment.

description: Egypt closed offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Cairo and Alexandria today in an angry reaction to harsh criticism from the P.L.O.'s legislative body, which concluded its session here Sunday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There'll be a lot of screams, I'm certain.'' - Governor Cuomo on his plan to raise $1 billion for roads. [ A1:1. ]

title: JETS MOVING INTO A NEW ERA
description: The heart of the Jets' defense is not only older, but is also hurt, badly hurt. So, when the team starts to pluck healthy young players from the college draft today, it is likely to be the beginning of a new defensive era.

title: Policy on Horses Weighed
description: The Bureau of Land Management is considering a policy change that would allow the killing of surplus wild horses and burros 90 days after they are put up for adoption. Five years ago, the bureau Director, Robert Burford, placed a moratorium on destruction of surplus, healthy wild horses.

title: Oil Rig Count Up by 15
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States this week totaled 765, up 15 from the previous week, the Hughes Tool Company reported today. The nationwide count totaled 750 last week, the Houston-based maker of oil tools said. The rig count, considered to be the baromoter of drilling activity, totaled 855 at this time last year.

title: VAST CLUSTERS OF GALAXIES SEEN AS 'GREAT ATTRACTOR'
description: ASTRONOMERS believe they have located an extraordinary concentration of galaxies, far more massive than any other known, whose gravity is pulling the Milky Way and thousands upon thousands more galaxies in its direction.

title: U.S. OFFERING PLAN ON DRILLING FOR OIL IN OFFSHORE AREAS

title: U.N. Panel Urges Steps For Preserving Ozone
description: Faced with growing pressure for action to preserve the earth's ozone shield, the United Nations Environment Program urged a 30-nation conference here today to adopt measures swiftly for eliminating production and use of chlorofluorocarbons by the year 2000.

title: CAPE TOWN POLICE, USING BIRDSHOT, ARE SAID TO WOUND 8 ON CAMPUS

title: Barges Won't Solve the Waste Problem
description: Since March, a barge carrying 3,100 tons of garbage from Islip, L.I., has journeyed down the East Coast and into the Gulf of Mexico in search of a dump site. Although the barge has been turned away at each stop, private waste contractors are now negotiating with a Caribbean country in hopes that it will agree to take the waste.

description: Fire struck part of the 19th-century legislative office building today, causing extensive damage and forcing legislators and others to evacuate.

title: J & J SNACK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Forest Food
description: Walking in the woods recently, a friend found a patch of brownish trout lilies, some yellow violets and blooming squirrel corn, bloodroot with big white flowers and white and purple trillium. Also, white toothwort, lavender hepatica, dwarf ginseng and wild ginger, walking fern on mossy limestone boulders and flat-leaved sedges pollinating. He nibbled a wild leek bulb and the marble-sized, sweet, chestnut-flavored tuber of a purple spring beauty. Most forest flowers hurry toward maturity before the canopy of trees shuts out sunlight, but not so fast that the bumblebees that pollinate them have not emerged from hibernating in old rodent burrows.

description: Mayor Thomas W. Bucci said today that the prospects of finding survivors in the wreckage of a collapsed apartment complex here were ''bleak'' and that officials would probably decide next Saturday whether to continue the rescue efforts.

title: Meeting the Backers
description: At least five Republican Presidential candidates will make separate private appearances in Washington this week before a group of 150 Jewish fund-raisers and contributors. The sessions, at an unannounced location and closed to the press, are being held by the National Jewish Coalition, a group dedicated to increasing Jewish participation in the Republican Party. It identifies participants in the candidate interviews as ''philanthropists, industrialists and financiers.''

title: Pilot in Angola Identified
description: The State Department said today that the American whose private plane was shot down recently by Angolan Government forces had been identified as Joseph F. Longo of Greensburg, Pa. He was apparently flying from the Ivory Coast to Johannesburg to deliver the plane, a Beechcraft F-33 Bonanza. When Angola announced last week that it had shot down the plane over Cunene Province, it said the pilot might have been on a spying mission for South Africa.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What does a sievert measure? A.The sievert is an international measurement of tissue damage caused by the absorption of radiation. It accounts not only for the amount of radiation absorbed at a point in the body but also for the damaging ability of that radiation based on its distribution, according to Dr. Roland A. Finston, director of health physics at Stanford University. In the United States, the standard unit of absorbed radiation dosage is the rad, or radiation absorbed dose, which is equal to energy absorption of 100 ergs per gram. The typical chest X-ray supplies one-tenth of a millisievert. A millisievert is one-thousandth of a sievert. The sievert unit is equal to 100 rads of X-radiation or gamma-radiation absorbed into soft tissue. For other types of radiation, one sievert may be produced by less than 100 rads. The distinction is necessary because the damage caused by radiation in living tissue is proportional not only to the amount of energy absorbed but also to the type of radiation exposure. Some kinds of radiation are more damaging than others. Q.Why do beavers build their dams? A.Beavers build dams in order to maintain a supply of water that will hide the entrance of their burrow and allow for food storage. They place long sticks, beginning in the middle of the channel, parallel to the current and hold them in place with rocks and mud. Extensions are built to each shore. The dam holds the water level constant so that the submerged entrance to the beaver lodge will keep terrestrial predators out. The resulting pond also makes it easier for the beaver to pull limbs and twigs for food and constructing the dam.

title: WRIGLEY, WM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 28, 1987
description: MARKETS The dollar rebounded in hectic North American trading, after being pummeled in Asian and European dealings. The currency was lifted by supportive comments from President Reagan and a collapse in precious metals that eased fears of inflation. Some analysts predicted near-term stability for the dollar, although many remain bearish for the longer haul. In New York, gold fell $17.50, to $445 an ounce. [ Page D1. ] The precious metals markets had their wildest day in years. Silver was especially volatile, swinging from a high of $11.25 to a low of $7.20, before ending at $7.80. [ D1. ] The stock market ended lower despite a valiant effort to rebound. After being down 42 points in early trading, the Dow Jones industrial average wound up losing 4.83 points, at 2,230.54. Trading was enlivened by mining issues, which swung wildly and ended sharply lower. [ D14. ] ''Short interest'' on Nasdaq stocks rose 6.1 percent, to 197.9 million shares, for the month ended April 15. [ D30. ] Bond prices staged a dramatic comeback after plunging in earlier trading. The Fed had been expected to inject reserves into the banking system to drive down the Federal funds rate. But rates rose after the Fed did not act, which traders took as a positive sign because it would help the dollar and make Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors. [ D25. ] THE ECONOMY A study finds that the world economy would be helped little by the policies of Treasury Secretary Baker and those of Japan and West Germany, according to officials familiar with the research. In effect, the work concludes that the international coordination that Secretary Baker has sponsored - as a means to resolving currency turbulence, trade imbalances, uneven growth and third world debt - will not produce the 3 percent growth with low inflation that the major nations say is needed for global prosperity. [ D1. ] President Reagan assailed a trade bill amendment offered by Representative Gephardt as a ''dangerous'' proposal. He said the provision, which would require retaliation against nations with large surpluses, could disrupt the world trading system and jeopardize relations with some major trading partners. [ D8. ] An auction of mortgages on low-cost housing was called off by the Administration. An official warned that the sale could lead to displacing low-income families from their homes. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Lotus signed a 10-year agreement with I.B.M. to design software for the computer company's largest models, starting with a version of Lotus 1-2-3 for the System/370 mainframes. The move is critical to Lotus in its battle with Microsoft, the maker of the operating system for I.B.M. PC's. The new alliance might have a devastating effect on Ashton-Tate, the No. 3 software maker. [ D1. ] Texaco's activities will be monitored by 26 of its creditors, including Pennzoil. The creditors, which were appointed to two committees by a Federal trustee, will also work on a plan of reorganization for the oil company. [ D1. ] GAF withdrew its hostile offer for Borg-Warner, deciding not to top the $4.23 billion bid by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. GAF expects a pretax profit of more than $190 million on its Borg stock. It also plans to buy back up to three million of its own shares. [ D1. ] Chrysler expects a final accord to acquire American Motors in the next 10 days. The auto maker, which also reported a 24.4 percent drop in first-quarter income because of marketing and retooling costs, disclosed several cost-cutting moves. It also said that it would expand production at the recently acquired Lamborghini. [ D2. ] Goodyear Tire and Rubber posted a first-quarter profit of $284.2 million, compared with a loss of $212.7 million a year earlier. The nation's largest tire company attributed the improvement mainly to the sale of several non-tire businesses. [ D2. ] Burlington Industries was accused of taking illegal steps to manipulate its stock price in order to thwart a takeover bid from Dominion Textile and Asher B. Edelman. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The dollar's downward march will - and should - continue, argues Paul R. Krugman, an economist at M.I.T. He predicts that the currency will fall another 20 percent. Talking Business. [ D2. ] The recent buffeting of newspaper stocks has divided analysts. Some cite Florida's 5 percent sales tax on media, while others point to the market's overall drop and other factors. Market Place. [ D14. ]

title: LeMond Released
description: Greg LeMond, the star cyclist, was released Sunday from a hospital in Sacramento, Calif., six days after he was wounded in a hunting accident. LeMond, 25 years old, was wounded by a shotgun blast last Monday as he hunted with his brother-in-law, Patrick Blades, about 20 miles northeast of Sacramento. He was hit by 20 to 25 shotgun pellets when Blades fired at a turkey in heavy brush. LeMond was on the other side of the brush. LeMond's father, Bob LeMond, said the accident would prevent his son from defending his title in the 24-day Tour de France this summer. LeMond is the only American to have won the most prestigious race in cycling.

It cited evidence that Mr. Waldheim had ''participated in activities amounting to persecution'' of Jews and others in Greece and Yugoslavia during World War II.

title: How About an Informal U.S.-Japan Inc.?
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is arriving here at a time of unprecedented American-Japanese tensions. On both sides, the irritation is real. The Japanese feel victimized, the Americans feel exploited and resentment is reciprocal. Americans should not underestimate the continuing Japanese sense of national vulnerability. Economic success, based on trade, has become to the Japanese the key to their social survival, but it also remains a fragile blossom. At the same time, Americans are naturally worried that our industrial and even high-tech economic sectors are being literally ruined by unfair Japanese competition.

title: STAGE: 'THE ART OF WAR'
description: THE old Saturday movie serials were seldom more fun than ''The Art of War'' by George F. Walker, a Candian playwright, playing at the New Theater of Brooklyn. Every quick episode closes with someone in peril and the comedy ends with a breakaway by the bad guys that suggests there might be a sequel. After all, this is the third Walker comedy about the alcoholic investigative reporter Tyrone M. Power and, although Power is shot in the final scene, he is not dead.

title: MUSIC: ORPHEUS GROUP AND ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: ALICIA DE LARROCHA is a living paradox - a strongly individual musician who somehow contrives to make one listen to what the composer is saying rather than to her own virtuosity. Although by no means self-effacing as an interpreter, the Spanish pianist can immerse herself so deeply in the music that her artistic personality seems to exist only to highlight and focus the score's excellences. That, at least, was the impression one received last evening at Carnegie Hall, where Miss de Larrocha played keyboard concertos by Mozart and Haydn in partnership with the conductorless chamber orchestra known as Orpheus.

title: Webster Leaves Ranger Job
description: The troubled and confusing coaching regime of Tom Webster ended yesterday. The inner-ear disorder that Webster first suffered 18 days after his appointment as head coach of the Rangers last November limited his National Hockey League coaching record to five victories and four ties in 16 games, the shortest tenure in the history of the organization.

Purcell, former chairman of the SFN Companies Inc., and Jim Hilliard, former head of Blair Radio.

title: THE MAKING OF A BALLET ON THE RUN
description: Choreography is a divine art inspired by the touch of the muse Terpsichore in George Balanchine's ''Apollo.'' Peter Martins danced Apollo, with the same cool elegance he brings to everything. But today Mr. Martins and Jerome Robbins, who as Balanchine's successors direct the New York City Ballet, have a company to be kept dancing. There is a public to be lured by the promise of City Ballet's traditional season premieres, called ''New Ballet 1'' and ''New Ballet 2'' until the last possible moment. This season, which opens tonight at the New York State Theater, both ballets are by Mr. Martins.

title: The Dollar's Down. Why Not the Deficit?
description: The villain, almost everyone agreed back in 1985, was the overvalued dollar. It had priced American goods out of world markets and it had burdened the economy with an elephantine trade deficit. The dollar has since fallen by about 40 percent. It now buys less abroad than it did in 1980, a year in which the foreign accounts were virtually in balance. Yet the U.S. trade deficit has remained stuck near the record $170 billion figure of last year. Why?
