title: CENVILLE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NANOMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $850,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,211,000.

title: GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
J. RUSSELL McSHANE
description: J. Russell McShane, a former president of the New York University Alumni Association, died April 19 at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: Passage to Lanai
description: Deer hunters were ranging the craggy slopes of this pineapple island over the past weekend, which suggests that even in the middle of the Pacific Ocean it's hard to get away from mankind's peculiar touch.

title: RELIANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge from minority interests of $1,292,000 and net realized gain on investments of $6,155,000; also includes $9 million ''fresh start'' income tax benefit resulting from the tax reform act of 1986. c-Includes a charge from minority interests of $1,292,000 and net realized gain on investments of $10,369,000; also includes an after-tax gain of $52.4 million on the sale of the company's Canadian property and casualty subsidiary. The company is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: JETS TAKE FULLBACK
description: For a team that picked 28th and last in today's National Football League draft, the Giants did better than they might have hoped for. For one thing, they found plenty of wide receivers - three on the first four rounds.

title: ARX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been restated to give retroactive effect to the 5-for-4 stock split declared Feb. 3, 1987, and the 5-percent stock dividend declared April 29, 1986.

title: Unisys Contract
description: The Unisys Corporation said it had received a computer contract, which could be valued at more than $50 million, from the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. The 10-year agreement provides for a new banking terminal system for the worldwide branches of the Hongkong bank.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge related to costs associated with early retirement of long-term notes of $8,585,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: SOME LAWMAKERS WANT TO END U.S.-SOVIET EMBASSY ACCORD
description: Several members of Congress moved today to force the Administration to scrap the agreement allowing the Soviet Union to build a new embassy on one of the highest hills in Washington, according to officials in the State Department and on Capitol Hill.

title: GUITAR: TOM VERLAINE
description: ONE icy, quivering tone from Tom Verlaine's guitar is enough to announce his presence unmistakably, but that sound hasn't been heard much recently. Mr. Verlaine, the New York rocker, poet, founder of Television and an imposing influence on post-1977 guitarists, has been living and recording in Britain. His latest album, ''Flash Light,'' a superb piece of work, hasn't been issued by an American label. But Mr. Verlaine was at the Ritz on Sunday, passing through, taking a quartet of longtime New York compatriots on a world tour.

title: CHEVRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $48 million in net gains from asset dispositions, including the company's share of Amax's asset sale. The company said the year-ago results include net gain of $36 million related to asset dispositions and writeoffs.

title: CONCERT: JAPANESE FLUTE MASTER
description: KOMUSO (priests of nothingness) was a Japanese name for the wandering Zen monks who refined the playing of the shakuhachi, or bamboo flute, during the 17th and 18th centuries. One of the first albums of traditional shakuhachi music released in America was called ''A Bell Ringing in an Empty Sky.'' And the gliding, quivering phrases of the shakuhachi can give the impression of hanging suspended in a void.

title: The Better Way to Tax Oil
description: Virtually all fiscal analysts agree that more revenue is needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Now Richard Gephardt joins Gary Hart in proposing to raise the money with a tariff on imported oil. Could this be the beginning of a trend among Democratic Presidential candidates, and others?

title: KEEPING FIT WASN'T EAXY IN 1837, EITHER
description: HO-HUM, let's rehearse once more the predictable answers to the 1987 Health and Fitness Quiz. What are they saying about coffee and tea? ''Potentially harmful stimulants.'' Salt and sugar? ''Detrimental if overused.'' Fried and fatty foods? ''Unhealthy in the extreme.'' Dietary fiber and bran flour? ''Greatly advocated.'' What should we be doing? ''Taking a preventive approach to health.'' Which includes? ''Exercise, which is essential for men and women, and convenient if performed on home-exercise machines. To music, naturally.''

title: Rochester Gas Sets 8.89% Yield
description: In the corporate bond market, where a sense of wariness still prevails, many investors for the moment are reluctant to commit themsevles to long-term issues, especially after the volatility of recent days. Instead they are favoring maturities of up to 10 years.

title: YOUTH RECEIVES PRISON SENTENCE FOR L.I. KILLING
description: Despite a dramatic plea for leniency by his lawyer, a popular high school student who admitted killing a classmate's father for $1,000 was sentenced today to 24 years in prison with no eligibility for parole before eight years.

title: B.P. IN $7.82 BILLION DEAL FOR STANDARD
description: The British Petroleum Company and the Standard Oil Company agreed yesterday on a $7.82 billion price for B.P.'s purchase of the 45 percent of Standard Oil that it does not yet own.

title: Shamrock Units Split Tomorrow
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said its exploration and production unit would be renamed the Maxus Energy Corporation on Thursday when it becomes independent from Shamrock's refining and marketing unit. The split-up of the two units was announced in February. Maxus Energy, with $2.6 billion in assets, will be the nation's largest oil and gas company and its shares will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol MXS, the company said. The refining and marketing unit will be known as Diamond Shamrock R & M Inc. and trade under the symbol DRM.

title: CANADIENS LEAD, 3-2
description: Ryan Walter scored on a 15-foot wrist shot with 2 minutes 39 seconds remaining to give the Montreal Canadiens a 3-2 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight and a 3-2 lead over in the four-of-seven-game Adams Division final.

title: PREVIEW OF THE SOON-TO-BE-FAMOUS LAWYERS FOR CONGRESS
description: When the special Congressional committees begin their televised hearings on the Iran-contra affair next week, 11 senators and 15 representatives, many of them familiar political figures, will be seated on two tiers across the front of the Senate Caucus Room.

title: Corporations Threaten TV, Witnesses Say
description: The battles for corporate control of the television networks threaten the integrity and independence of their news divisions, with grave consequences for a public dependent on television for information, witnesses told a House subcommittee today.

title: Emery Waives Tender Condition
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation said it had waived a condition of its $40-a-share tender offer for the Purolator Courier Corporation. Emery said that it would no longer require that the sale of Purolator's Canadian operation be completed before shares were tendered.

title: TRANSIT POLICE DRAGNET CATCHES 385 IN THE BRONX
description: Two hundred Transit Authority police officers conducted a boroughwide dragnet yesterday at 37 subway stations in the Bronx, arresting scores of fare beaters and other violators.

title: WRIGHT IN F.S.L.I.C. REVERSAL
description: House Speaker Jim Wright, suffering an embarrassing reversal, announced today that he now favors a much larger bailout of the nearly depleted Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation than he had previously sought.

title: THE STAGE: 'STARMITES,' A MUSICAL
description: WHEN ''Starmites'' had its premiere in 1980 at the Ark Theater Company, it was clearly the tiniest -and the most intentionally amusing -of intergalactic epics, a musical spoof that could bring smiles to the faces of the most ardent star warrior or trekkie. While its big screen cousins have gone on to a cycle of sequels, the small-stage ''Starmites'' remains singular. Call it ''Starmites, Part I, the Story Begins.'' Happily, in its newly revised version, the show is still tongue-in-cheek and mirthful.

title: Bridge: A Mystery Double Was Sign Of an Expert Player at Work
description: Suppose that a player passes originally, keeps passing and finally doubles a three no-trump contract reached without interference. What do you conclude? Presumably you are trying to point your partner in the direction of a specific lead.

title: Hemmed In
description: A woman buying clothes these days is justified in feeling disoriented. Designers show raised hemlines for fall, harking back to miniskirts of the 1960's. The new short skirts are said to be a sign of prosperity. A woman in a classically tailored suit, with yards of leg showing, is all set, noted one commentator, for a visit to her broker.

title: MAI BASIC FOUR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CENTERIOR ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the 1986 results are based on a consolidated restatement of the 1986 figures of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co. and Toledo Edison Co., which affiliated a year-ago as subsidiaries of Centerior.

title: UTILICORP UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LOWER PRICES HURT PROFITS OF 3 BIG OIL CONCERNS
description: Three large oil companies yesterday reported first-quarter earnings that were hurt by lower oil prices.

title: Pressure Too Great
description: The pressure of breaking a United States college baseball winning streak might finally have been too much for the Point Park Pioneers, Coach Mark Jackson said. ''With all the publicity, it makes it harder,'' he said. ''Every team is out there gunning for you. Every game is the World Series for them.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LAMBERTS. George, Constant and Kit. By Andrew Motion. Illustrated. 388 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: Journalist Gets to Go
description: Wolf Blitzer, Washington bureau chief for The Jerusalem Post, has just returned from a six-day trip to Jordan, touring the country and meeting with Jordanian officials. He was, he said, ''made to feel entirely welcome.''

title: Dining for Dollars
description: It seems that T. Boone Pickens, the famed corporate raider, has suddenly put on another Texas-size hat, that of chairman of the President's Dinner, the year's largest and most lavish Republican fund raiser.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Ellington Observance One of America's greatest composers, Duke Ellington, was born 88 years ago today. He died May 24, 1974. His first composition was ''Soda Fountain Rag,'' inspired by his after-school job as, to use an old phrase, a soda jerk. His last was the musical ''Queenie Pie,'' which he did not complete. In all, he composed more than 900 pieces. These included the popular classic songs such as ''Satin Doll,'' ''Sophisticated Lady,'' ''In My Solitude,'' ''Don't Get Around Much Any More,'' ''Mood Indigo'' and ''I Let a Song Go Out of My Heart.'' But he also wrote such long works as ''Sacred Concert,'' ''Black, Brown and Beige Suite'' and ''Far East Suite.''

title: CELTICS RALLY TO SWEEP BULLS BY 105-94
description: Larry Bird scored 15 of his 32 points in the fourth quarter tonight as the Boston Celtics rallied to defeat the Chicago Bulls, 105-94, and complete a three-game sweep of the first-round series.

title: FILM: 'BROTHERS QUAY,' ANIMATION
description: ''THE BROTHERS QUAY'' is the umbrella title for the four animated Surrealist films (in which miniature objects are photographed in stop-motion) that make up the program opening today at the Film Forum 1. The Brothers Quay are, in fact, the American-born, London-based film makers, Timothy and Stephen (identical twins). The Quays, who started out as graphics designers, are now specialists in clever cinematic nightmares inspired by the fears, frights and longings of others.

title: DEMOCRAT WINS QUEENS RACE FOR A VACANT ASSEMBLY SEAT
description: Audrey Pheffer, an organization Democrat, defeated two opponents yesterday in a special election for the vacant Queens Assembly seat of Gerdi E. Lipschutz, who resigned last month because of her role in a no-show job scheme.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CUOMO IS SAID TO BACK TAXES TO PAY HIGHWAY UPGRADE
description: Governor Cuomo will support a new six-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline and a new property tax on automobiles to raise $975 million for improving New York's roads and bridges, officials familiar with his position said today.

title: TV MINISTRY CUTS OFF BAKKER SALARY
description: The leadership of the troubled PTL television ministry said today that it had cut off the salary of the Rev. Jim Bakker, who resigned last month in a scandal over a sexual encounter. The leadership declared that he would not be allowed to return to the ministry he founded here.

title: Skepticism Rises on Treasury Chief's Ideas As World's Economic Growth Slows Down
description: The once-celebrated policies of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d are eliciting growing skepticism as world economic growth persistently slows down.

title: 2 Testify in Inquiry
description: At least two men who are said to have connections with illegal gambling operations have testified before a Maricopa County grand jury investigating drug use by current and former members of the National Basketball Association's Phoenix Suns, according to a report in The Phoenix Gazette yesterday.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CONVERGENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Knuckleball Goes to School
description: Research by a mechanical engineering professor at Cooper Union could make the notoriously erratic knuckleball more baffling than ever to hitters, while, for the first time, giving pitchers precise control over its disconcerting movements.

title: Portuguese Plan Vote; Parliament Is Dissolved
description: President Mario Soares dissolved Parliament tonight and set elections for July 19, two years early, to resolve a political crisis.

title: Nixon and Kissinger
description: A letter to Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger:

title: STATE DEPT. FAULTS SOVIET DEMAND ON BONN MISSILES
description: The State Department today criticized a Soviet demand that American warheads for West German missiles be destroyed as part of missile accord in Europe.

title: Pace University Shift
description: The scholars at AC&R/DHB & Bess, the Ted Bates subsidiary, are going to handle the promotion needs for Pace University and that means advertising, direct marketing and sales promotion. The budget is $1 million. The former agency was McCann-Erickson.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Yesterday with scarcity of new tax-exempt issues on the calendar and rates in the municipal market holding at about the same as levels the previous day, New Jersey brought to market a $299 million issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank. Last week some major sales were postponed because of extremely volatile market conditions.

title: The Ultimate Insider Party
description: The band played ''Jailhouse Rock,'' but the inmates wore pin stripes, not prison stripes. About 600 executives and investors dined amid the cell blocks as the San Francisco investment banking firm Hambrecht & Quist Inc. began its annual technology conference Monday night with a $70,000 party on the island of Alcatraz, the former maximum security Federal penitentiary. The party featured a staged prison break, $7,000 in flowers and an abundance of Ivan F. Boesky jokes.

title: Nelson May Quit
description: A feud has developed between Herb Kohl, owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, and Don Nelson, the coach, and it will probably result in Nelson's leaving the team after this season, The Milwaukee Journal reported yesterday.

title: BALLET THEATER'S NEW RISING STAR
description: Julio Bocca rode into the Metropolitan Opera House for American Ballet Theater's summer season on a wave of excited speculation and glowing reviews of recent touring performances as Ballet Theater's newest principal dancer.

title: NUCLEAR METALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STANFORD TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOETZ JUDGE BLOCKS ATTEMPT TO USE A VICTIM'S STATEMENT
description: The defense lawyer for Bernhard H. Goetz lost what he called an important legal argument yesterday when the judge in the case refused to allow the jury to hear a statement from one of the men Mr. Goetz shot.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 29, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 High officials are the focus of the inquiry into the Iran-contra affair, Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor, said. Mr. Walsh gave his strongest indication that he would seek indictments. Page A1 A senior arms adviser was rebuked by the Reagan Administration for criticizing its arms control strategy. Edward L. Rowny's comments could complicate talks with the Soviet Union, Administration officials said. A1 Kurt Waldheim assailed a U.S. move to bar him from entering the country, calling the decision ''incomprehensible.'' The Austrian President said he had a ''clear conscience'' about his wartime activities. A1 U.S. studied Waldheim data A6 News analysis: James Baker's ideas for addressing pressing economic problems were praised when first announced. But signs of economic deterioration have caused the Treasury Secretary to be seen as a man with nothing new to offer. A1 Italy's Parliament was dissolved by President Francesco Cossiga, who said he saw no chance of putting to-gether a majority to govern the nation. The Government then ordered elections for June 14. A3 The contras killed a U.S. citizen in an attack, the Nicaraguan Government said. Benjamin Ernest Linder of Portland, Ore., is the first American civilian reported to be killed by the Nicaraguan rebels. A3 In Zimbabwe, abolishing white seats in Parliament is being approached cautiously by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe in his drive to turn the multiparty democracy into a one-party state. A4 Sri Lanka's Moslem's uneasy A9 Suspect asks release of Germans A7 Russian hopeful on arms A10 Conservative rattles Australia A13 Lawmakers want end to accord D30 NATIONAL A21-33, D30 A teen-ager's murder in Detroit has infuriated residents who had become anesthetized to such violence. The shooting of the high-school football player has led to assemblies on youth violence and calls for hard-line strategies against crime. A1 A political scientist was rejected as a nominee for the National Academy of Sciences. Samuel P. Huntington was turned down after an internal struggle over whether his work amounted to equations used to dress up political opinions. A1 Paul Laxalt will run for President. The former Nevada Senator, who was President Reagan's closest friend in Congress, announced that he was a candidate for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination. A22 Kemp has campaign shakeup A23 Congress may call films propaganda under a 45-year-old law, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-3 decision. The Court rejected the claim that classifying some foreign films as ''political propaganda'' violated the First Amendment. A28 New rules to protect farm workers were issued by the Labor Department. The rules require that clean drinking water and sanitation facilities be provided on large farms to nearly 500,000 fieldworkers. A22 Jim Bakker's salary was cut off by the leadership of the PTL television ministry and he will not be allowed to return to the group, officials said. The Rev. Jerry Falwell agreed to stay on as the ministry's chairman. A22 Jim Wright favors a larger bailout for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation than he had originally sought. The Speaker of the House said the thrift industry's problems were greater than he had realized. D1 ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' will be re-released by Disney, accompanied by a large promotional effort. The film has won a place in movie executives' hearts. '' 'Snow White' saved the studio,'' one said. C19 Financing issue may stall reform A21 Air Force Two grounded A23 Proposal assailed on atomic permit A26 Judge questions deportation of 2 A28 Inquiry on Meese tie to Wedtech sought A29 U.S. mayors draft urban platform A30 Restrictions to E.P.A. sought A33 WASHINGTON TALK A32 Lawyers on the case for Congress The politics of picking houses REGIONAL B1-8 J. C. Penney plans to relocate its corporate headquarters to Dallas, people helping to plan the move said. About 4,000 people working at Penney's 45-story tower in Manhattan would be affected. A1 Columbia will receive $25 million from the chairman of the Metromedia Company, officials from the university said. The gift from John W. Kluge, a Columbia graduate, will be the largest in the school's history. B1 The Mafia has infiltrated industries and unions, Federal prosecutors said at a racketeering trial of 12 men. ''It is fundamentally a case about the Mafia of the 1980's - the mob gone corporate,'' one prosecutor said. A33 A program to train minority youths should be undertaken by business leaders, Governor Cuomo said. He said that he hoped the leaders would comply out of ''love,'' but that the program would also be in their self-interest. B1 Man in the news: Harold T. Shapiro was high on the list of candidates to be the new Princeton University president, although few thought he would take the job. But Dr. Shapiro will become the university's 18th president. B2 A legislator's use of public funds is being questioned in New York. Allegations against State Senator Leonard P. Stavisky have come to light at a time such practices are being investigated by the Manhattan District Attorney. B2 Bernhard Goetz lost a legal ruling in what his lawyer called an important argument when the judge in the case refused to allow the jury to hear a statement alledged to have been made by one of the men Mr. Goetz shot. B3 Man slain by motorist in midtown B1 More bodies removed from rubble B2 Hired teen-age killer sentenced B2 Church continues fight for tower B3 Cuomo is said to back new taxes B4 Judge acts in foster-care dispute B5 Transit police arrest scores B6

title: Judge Voids More of Pretoria's Emergency Rules
description: A provincial court justice today overturned emergency regulations that prohibited protests and appeals on behalf of people detained without charge.

title: New Majority Leader For Assembly Named
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller today appointed James R. Tallon Jr., a Binghamton Democrat, to the position of majority leader.

title: WEATHER AND SCOTT GIVE METS SHIVERS
description: The Mets, playing dreadfully and having plunged into third place Monday night for the first time in 53 weeks, wasted no time yesterday in calling off last night's game with the Houston Astros. It was rescheduled as part of a twilight-night doubleheader July 24.

title: PROSECUTORS SAY MAFIA INFILTRATED 3 INDUSTRIES AND TEAMSTERS' UNION
description: Federal prosecutors told a jury in Manhattan yesterday that the Mafia had infiltrated the construction, trucking and food industries and ''the highest levels of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.''

title: PRIMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $29.1 million, or 54 cents a share. This non-recurring gain includes the following items: an after-tax gain of $37 million, or 69 cents a share, from the sale of certain timberlands; an after- tax gain of $15.2 million, or 38 cents a share, from the public offering of common stock by the company's subsidiary, Musicland Group Inc.; and, a partially offsetting after-tax charge of $23.1 million, or 43 cents a share, related to the participation of a unit in a real estate join venture, which has been adversely impacted by conditions in certain real estate markets and the tax reform act of 1986 on real estate investments. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $29.3 million, or 55 cents a share. This non-recurring gain includes the following items: an after-tax gain of $800,000, or 2 cents a share, from the sale of Timberlands; an after-tax gain of $42.1 million, or 78 cents a share, from the public offering of 17 percent of the common stock of American Capital Management & Research Inc.; and, a partially offsetting after- tax loss of $13.6 million, or 25 cents a share, resulting from a labor strike in the discontinued packaging business. American Can Co. shareholders voted today to change the company's name to Primerica Corp.

title: MONCRIEF FIGHTS PAIN AND WINS
description: The length of a professional basketball player's career is most often determined by the speed at which his skills diminish. But sometimes the years are measured much differently - by the amount of pain his body can endure.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company said the latest quarter includes sales of $9 million from Williams Gold, acquired at the end of 1986.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let me say in all simplicity, but with unequivocal clarity: I have a clear conscience.'' - President Kurt Waldheim of Austria. [ A1:4. ]

title: Tim M. Pollak to Direct Y.& R.-Dentsu Venture
description: Tim M. Pollak, 41, an executive vice president at Young & Rubicam, has been named president of DYR, the joint venture agency of Young & Rubicam and Japan's Dentsu. He replaces Alex Brody, 54, who is retiring.

title: '21' AND EL MOROCCO: 2 LEGENDS REOPEN
description: For a minute, it seemed like a sure thing. A nod from Walter Weiss at the door, a wave to Hubie Boscowitz at his regular table, an iron-grip handshake from Pete Kriendler and there in a Bernard Weatherill suit, Turnbull & Asser shirt and Lobb shoes would be John O'Hara, lounging against the bar and talking about Yale.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of 5 cents a share from reversal of 1986 investment tax credits. c-Includes a gain of 10 cents a share from issuance of Alco Health Services stock. The company said as a result of the reduction of its's investment in Alco Health Services to below 50-percent in August 1986, Alco Health Services is now being accounted for on the equity method rather than on a fully consolidated basis.

title: Dollar Mostly Higher; Dealers Unimpressed
description: The dollar ended mostly higher in comparatively light volume in world currency markets yesterday.

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a realized gain on investments of $6,155,000 and $10,369,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, and for the latest quarter also includes $9 million of ''fresh start'' income tax benefit resulting from the tax reform act of 1986. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. The company is a subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: SUZANNE VEGA TALKS ABOUT 'SOLITUDE'
description: THE mood of ''Solitude Standing'' (A&M), the quietly powerful second album by Suzanne Vega, a New York singer and composer, might be described as translucently grim. One of the most talented songwriters to emerge from the Greenwich Village folk-music world in recent years, Ms. Vega observes the world with a clinically poetic eye. And her beautiful vibratoless voice conveys neither the bleeding-heart compassion nor the self-absorbed erotic angst of an older generation of women who are folk-oriented singers.

title: SOME SHADES OF MEANING
description: The Supreme Court, in upholding a ''propaganda'' label for films produced by foreign governments, acknowledged that the term is widely perceived as carrying a negative connotation.

title: BUSINESS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 29, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Yeutter Sees Gain on Chips
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that Japan appeared to have ended its dumping of computer chips on overseas markets. The comment was the strongest suggestion yet from a high Reagan Administration official that retaliatory tariffs against Japan might soon be lifted.

title: HARRY SELETSKY
description: Harry Seletsky, president of the Election Commissioners' Association of the State of New York and a Sullivan County Election Commissioner, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Pembroke Pines, Fla. He was 72 years old and also lived in South Fallsburg, N.Y.

title: INQUIRY STUDIED DATA WALDHEIM GAVE IN REBUTTAL
description: The Justice Department's yearlong deliberations over whether to approve a recommendation that President Kurt Waldheim of Austria be barred from the United States was largely spent investigating information that he submitted to rebut charges against him, department officials said today.

title: UNUSUAL LOAN FROM A BANK: A JET FOR BUSH
description: Vice President Bush lost one of the comforts of his office today, turning to a small corporate jet to fly him here after Air Force Two developed hydraulic problems on takeoff.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net income from discontinued operations of $4,900,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $29,436,000 and a tax credit of $5,530,000. Year-ago results were reclassified for discontinued operations.

title: Texas Wins an Order Lifting Fines in Prison Reform Suit
description: Officials announced Monday that the state had been granted an order calling off fines that could have totaled $800,500 a day in a long-running case over prison reform.

title: 3 FILMS CITED BY JUSTICES
description: The three films cited in the Supreme Court's decision yesterday on the Reagan Administration's right to label works as ''political propaganda'' were ''If You Love This Planet,'' ''Acid From Heaven'' and ''Acid Rain: Requiem or Recovery?'' All were produced by the National Film Board of Canada, and all deal with nuclear or environmental issues.

title: Article 402787 -- No Title
description: Local officials say that 15 million to 20 million people play the games at Las Vegas casinos each year dreaming of a mighty hit, even though the odds of winning a quarter of a million dollars or more are a million to one or higher.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $76,000 $501,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $839,000 for both periods.

title: PLANNING FORESTS FROM LAB CULTURES
description: IN a laboratory here, tall redwoods from little test tubes grow.

title: CATALYST ENERGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increase in the latest quarter net and revenue was due to the interest in Alamito Co., an electric generating company acquired in the second quarter of 1986, and to the district steam heating and cooling systems in Philadelphia and Boston, which were acquired in the first quarter of 1987.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * McDonald's Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., appointed James R. Cantalupo president of McDonald's International.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kirk McCaskill, a 17-game winner for California last year, underwent surgery Monday for the removal of bone chips in his right elbow and will miss about three months, according to the Angels. He was 2-0 this season. . . . Saying he didn't know where he would fit him into the outfield, General Manager John Schuerholz of Kansas City said the Royals would not re-sign Lonnie Smith, the free-agent outfielder who is eligible to rejoin the team Friday.

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $13.4 million for the latest quarter and $14.3 million for the year-earlier period.

title: Dean Witter's Merchant Bank
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., the financial services arm of Sears, Roebuck & Company, said that it was creating a merchant banking unit.

title: Citicorp Rates Up at Auction
description: Interest rates were up at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper with maturities of 91 and 182 days. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper yesterday at an average rate of 6.827 percent, up from 6.605 percent last week.

title: PANNILL KNITTING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: PEOPLE KNOW POLITICS BY HOUSES AND AREAS IN NATION'S CAPITAL
description: In this city of transients, where politicians come and go, and with them their appointees and staffs, real estate agents have come to discern two distinct types of house styles: Republican and Democrat.

title: TISCH DEFENDS COST CUTS TO JOURNALISTS
description: In what was interpreted as an attempt to improve his public image, Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS, addressed a group consisting mostly of journalists in a speech delivered yesterday at the Gannett Center for Media Studies.

title: NEW HEAD OF PRINCETON: DR. HAROLD TAFLER SHAPIRO
description: When James A. Henderson, chairman of the committee charged with finding a new president for Princeton University, began calling around, one name repeatedly headed the lists: Dr. Harold Tafler Shapiro, president of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.

title: Leads Are Lacking In Waite Kidnapping
description: Unofficial, unconfirmed messages from Lebanon continue to report that Terry Waite, the kidnapped envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, is alive and well, the Archbishop's office said today.

title: USX Loss; Bethlehem Has Profit
description: The USX Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $97 million, while the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the third largest, posted a $25.6 million profit.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $103 million from the sale of certain chemicals operations; latest quarter also includes a gain of $20 million recognized as an extraordinary item, reflecting the federal income tax benefit realized from the application of a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains. c-Includes $24 million from the sale of certain oil and gas interests.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS CONTRAS KILLED AMERICAN CIVILIAN
description: The Nicaraguan Government announced tonight that an American civilian had been killed in a rebel attack.

title: Conservative Shakes Up Politics in Australia
description: A campaign for the Prime Minister's job by a 76-year-old right-wing politician has shaken up Australian politics and inspired both jeers and alarm among his rivals.

title: 2 MORE BODIES PULLED FROM BUILDING'S RUBBLE
description: Rescue workers removed two more bodies today from the rubble of a collapsed apartment complex and found a device - a central hydraulic-lift control unit - considered critical to the investigation of the disaster, Mayor Thomas W. Bucci said.

title: KINDER-CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it changed its year-end to Dec. 31 from Aug. 31; the comparability of the current year's quarters to year-earlier periods has been significantly affected by the change of fiscal year, the restatement of the prior year's quarters because of the change in fiscal years and acquisitions completed in the prior year. The company also said share earnings restated to a calendar year basis for 1986 are 15 cents for the first quarter; 30 cents for the second quarter and 17 cents for the third quarter. The company had a loss for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, 1986.

title: When Central America Responds to Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: J.C. PENNEY PLANS MOVE TO DALLAS FROM NEW YORK, CONSULTANTS SAY
description: The J. C. Penney Company will announce today that it will relocate its corporate headquarters to Dallas, according to consultants helping to plan the move from Manhattan. About 4,000 people working at Penney's 45-story tower on the Avenue of the Americas at 52d Street are affected.

title: PANEL SEEK INQUIRY ON MEESE TIE TO WEDTECH
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is seeking to expand the scope of the investigations into the Wedtech Corporation to include the relationship of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d with the company.

title: Citicorp Recruits At Goldman, Sachs
description: Citicorp Investment Bank, which in recent years has seen a number of its top traders desert for higher pay and greater freedom at Wall Street firms, scored a victory yesterday. It hired David A. Jones, the manager of fixed-income trading operations for Goldman, Sachs & Company in London, to head a new trading division in New York.

title: People
description: * John Bell, chief executive of DMB&B/New Zealand, has been appointed a senior vice president of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO RESTRICT E.P.A.
description: A House subcommittee was told today that the Reagan Administration was trying to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its power to order Federal departments to clean up their hazardous wastes.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK U.S. INQUIRY INTO FUND-RAISING ACTIVITIES
description: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee filed a complaint today with the Federal Election Commission against conservative fund-raising groups controlled by Carl R. (Spitz) Channell.

title: About New York; Softball Is Back And Central Park Is Vibrant Again
description: The baseball season has begun, and the men on the benches in Central Park are at it again, holding lively discussions - peppered with hot arguments - about the legendary players of old and the promising players of today.

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes losses from equity in loss in unconsolidated subsidiaries and affiliate of $294,000 and $127,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Incudes gains of $144,000 for the quarter and $1,658,000 for the year from equity in net income in unconsolidated subsidiaries. Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1987.

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes the impact relating to amortization of discount on preferred stock. c-Net loss

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a writedown of oil and gas properties of $11.1 million.

title: STAGE: 'LUCKY SPOT' BY BETH HENLEY
description: THE poor Depression-era hicks who inhabit Beth Henley's new play, ''The Lucky Spot,'' may be losers, but they wax more poetic than anyone who ever trod Tobacco Road. ''The people are so lonely you can smell it rotting on them,'' says Hooker (Ray Baker), the most notorious gambler and rake of Pigeon, La. ''My heart is spinning inside of me like a runaway top,'' says Hooker's estranged wife, Sue Jack (Amy Madigan), just released from the state pen after a three-year term for jealousy-provoked assault. ''Sometimes life makes me want to puke,'' says Turnip (Alan Ruck), the young yet metaphysically inclined handyman who may have heard tell of too much metaphorical rotting and spinning for his own darn good.

title: How City Aide Got Car Is Under Investigation
description: The city Department of Investigation is looking into allegations that Morris Tarshis, Director of the Bureau of Franchises, acquired a car from a bus company that the bureau regulates, an official of the department said last night.

title: JOINT STAND ELUDES ALLIES ON ELIMINATING MISSILES
description: Western European foreign and defense ministers today expressed ''serious concern'' at the Soviet superiority in short-range missiles, but failed to adopt a common position on a Soviet proposal that they be eliminated.

title: U.S. JEWS FOUND MORE WILLING TO CRITICIZE LEADERS OF ISRAEL
description: American Jews are more willing than ever before to criticize the Israeli Government, a survey by the American Jewish Committee has found.

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said there were no share earnings in the year-ago period after giving effect to preferred dividend requirements.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
TALKING BACK TO RECIPES
description: LEAD: IF you spend many waking hours in search of ''healthy'' recipes, you might be devoting too much time to the maintenance of your fettle. Don't wait for an imprimatur on a cookbook or recipe, or for a fitness guru's approval. Do a little critical thinking of your own, and analyze and modify recipes to suit your needs.

title: BATTLE MOUNTAIN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
H.R.A. TOLD TO AID 10 FAMILIES
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that New York City had failed to provide social services that would have kept the children of 10 poor families out of foster care.

title: The Reigns of April
description: The Milwaukee Brewers were 17-1 and had three games remaining in April as they headed into play at California last night. Here are the best April records since 1961, when the American League, preceding the National by a year, lengthened its schedule and brought about earlier starting dates. W-L Pct. Finish 1966 Orioles 11-1 .917 1st 1966 Indians 10-1 .909 5th 1984 Tigers 18-2 .900 1st 1981 A's 18-3 .857 1st* 1977 Dodgers 17-3 .850 1st 1964 Phillies 9-2 .818 2dd 1986 Mets 13-3 .813 1st 1971 Giants 18-5 .783 1st 1976 Yankees 10-3 .769 1st 1978 A's 16-5 .762 1st * Strike season. A's had best cumulative record in division. d Tied for second place with Cincinnati.

title: DEALER IN CONTEMPORARY ART
description: Xavier Fourcade, internationally known as a dealer in contemporary art and the founder and owner of the Xavier Fourcade Gallery in New York, died of pneumonia yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 60 years old.

title: YUGOSLAVS PUT EXECUTION OFF
description: The execution of Andrija Artukovic, a convicted Croatian war criminal who was extradited by the United States, has been postponed indefinitely because of poor health, legal sources said today.

title: A CHEF-S-EYE VIEW OF TOASTER OVENS
description: TOASTER ovens, like microwave ovens, are handy supplementary appliances that have become increasingly popular. They might have been made just for single people, who put a premium on simplicity in their cooking and cleanup; with a toaster oven, you don't have to work with a full-size oven to prepare a small dish.

title: AN AGENT'S BIG DAY AT DRAFR
description: Norby Walters, the agent at the center of an F.B.I. investigation into reported threats against athletes, says that at one time he had representation agreements with 7 of the 28 first-round picks in yesterday's National Football League draft.

title: ITLAY'S GOVERNMENT FALLS AND A JUNE ELECTION IS CALLED
description: President Francesco Cossiga dissolved the Italian Parliament tonight, ending a bitter eight-week political crisis. The Government then ordered general elections for June 14.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHAT is your excuse for not exercising regularly, not eating more healthfully or not changing some other unhealthy habit? Is it one of these?

title: The U.N. Today: April 29, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY International Convention on Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TRAINER IS HOPEFUL WITH NEW CHANCE
description: Asked to compare Masterful Advocate with Roving Boy, Joe Manzi bit his lower lip, replacing one painful twinge with another.

title: Apple to Spin Off Software Business
description: Apple Computer Inc. plans to spin off a company that will develop, publish and sell software for Apple personal computers, the company said today.

title: PRIME MOTORS INNS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising A Gumlike Tobacco Product
description: QUITE by coincidence, the Pinkerton Tobacco Company has developed a product that could well find a market among smokers facing government-mandated curbs on that activity.

title: Extradition to Canada Is Ordered for L.I. Man
description: A Long Island man was ordered extradited to Canada today after a Federal magistrate ruled there was substantial evidence linking him to the fatal shooting of a Canadian highway patrolman.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch April 16 from Santiago, Chile, on human-rights lawyers misattributed remarks that the ''best reply'' to Government accusations of aid to Communists was ''our history and the international respect that we have won.'' The speaker was Enrique Palet, the executive secretary of the Vicariate of Solidarity, and not Luis Toro, a lawyer on the Vicariate staff.

title: POGO PRODUCING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pretax writedown of $9l.3 million of its oil and gas properties.

title: KEY RATES
Illness Delays Donovan Trial
description: Final arguments in the larceny and fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan were delayed indefinitely yesterday by the illness of the chief prosecutor, Stephen R. Bookin. Lawyers for Mr. Donovan and seven co-defendants had been scheduled to begin their summations yesterday in the seven-month trial in State Supreme Court in the Bronx. Today's proceedings also were canceled after Mr. Bookin, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, notified court authorities of his illness.

title: MUSIC: ALL-FINNISH CONCERT
description: TIME has generally been a good editor. In this age of historical re-examination, the process of unearthing lost works by long-gone composers has become a flourishing business. Private archives, neglected library shelves and an attic or two have yielded to inquiring musicologists a good number of finds that have then found their way to the concert stage, and, in many cases, onto recordings.

title: The Price of Notoriety
description: To the Editor:

title: Addendum
description: * The Martin Agency, Richmond, will acquire 30 percent of Husk Jennings Overman of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Market Place; Behind Silver's Wild Gyrations
description: IT was a day that Robert E. Fink and other precious metals floor traders on the Commodity Exchange said they would never forget.

title: COURT BACKS ST. BART'S IN TOWER LEGAL BATTLE
description: St. Bartholomew's Church can continue its long and costly battle to build a skyscraper on its Park Avenue property, under a ruling yesterday by the State Court of Appeals.

title: LAXALT JOINS G.O.P. RACE FOR PRESIDENT
description: Former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, who built a reputation as President Reagan's closest friend in Congress, announced today that he was a candidate for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Adoption Makes One Family at Another's Expense; >Why Not a Black Baby?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Meese vs. the Nazis
description: Nazism embodied one of history's great evils; to resist it now, 42 years after World War II, sounds like routine virtue. But it can require strength, even courage. Twice now in a week, Attorney General Edwin Meese has shown it.

title: MEDCO CONTAINMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PROMINENT HARVARD SCHOLAR BARRED BY SCIENCE ACADEMY
description: The National Academy of Sciences, the nation's leading honor society for scientists, rejected a prominent Harvard political scientist today after a bruising internal struggle over whether his work amounted to ''pseudoscience'' in which equations were used to dress up mere political opinion.

title: Accused Spy Leaves Libya
description: Robert Maxwell, a Scottish engineer freed by Libya last week from a 12-year jail sentence for ''economic espionage,'' flew out of Tripoli today, the Libyan news agency said. Mr. Maxwell, 38 years old, left the Libyan capital with his wife and son on a Maltese airliner, according to the report monitored here by the British Broadcasting Corporation. The plane was believed headed for Malta. Mr. Maxwell, jailed in 1982, was freed after appeals by his wife and British politicians.

title: SHORTER SKIRTS SET OFF A CLOSET IDENTITY CRISIS
description: I SEE short skirts are coming back. This should make my husband happy. The first time he met me, I was wearing a skirt so short that if I had reached for something on a closet shelf it would have constituted a crime in some states. My hair was almost as long as my dress. In the years since, the trend toward shorter hair and longer skirts has often filled him with a deep sadness. He believes that women should show lots of leg and no ear.

title: Soil on Troubled Waters
description: There has always been value in trash for those who know where to find it. Nowadays there is also value in disposing of trash, if one can find a place to put it. The National Waste Corporation finds itself with an embarrassment of trash, floating about the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico on a barge. Its fate remains unclear, but it serves as a warning that more such embarrassments are likely in the absence of sound planning.

title: Japanese Recovery Sign
description: Japan's leading economic indicator continues pointing to a possible recovery in the near future, but Government economists caution that the yen's renewed upswing may do more economic damage. The Economic Planning Agency said today that the leading indicator for February, the latest reporting month, stood at 66.7, falling from 75 the previous month. Economists consider any reading above 50 as an indication that the Japanese economy will expand in the near future. Any level below 50 heralds a contraction.

title: TIGHTENING OF CREDIT BY FED SEEN
description: The Federal Reserve, after weeks of ambiguity and at some risk to the economy, has clearly moved to tighten monetary policy to defend the dollar, most economists and market analysts now maintain.

title: WELL-BRED SAUSAGES SPORT A LOWER-FAT PROFILE
description: SOME foods enter the mainstream of what might be called ''new'' American cooking with such subtlety as to go almost unnoticed by the casual restaurant-goer. More and more, for example, you find variations on ravioli served with fillings that bear no resemblance to the standard meat or cheese; fine platters of polenta, a kind of Italian cornmeal gruel, are making repeated menu appearances served with things like game sauce or quail, and crunchy french-fried potato nests are being topped with quail eggs or perhaps a spoonful of caviar.

title: DANCE: MOLISSA FENLEY
description: MOLISSA FENLEY certainly knows how to make choreography look energetic. Yet though energy is important in dance, energy isn't everything, and over the years Ms. Fenley has struggled to find ways to channel her energy that are artistically satisfying. Some of her successes and failures were on view last night when Molissa Fenley and Dancers opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss for debt prepayment of $604,000 after taxes.

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes exchange gains of $73,000 for the latest quarter and exchange losses of $105,000 for the year- earlier period; and the latest quarter also includes a gain from minority interest of $524,000.

title: Flyers Bracing For Final Surge
description: The answer everyone wanted to know from the Flyers after the loss to the Islanders tonight was whether they feared a repeat of the Islanders' triumph in their series against Washington.

title: INSIDE
description: N.F.L. Fancies the Passers Vinny Testaverde, the No. 1 choice out of Miami, was one of four quarterbacks chosen in the first round of the draft of college players. Page D31.

title: ACTION IS URGED IN 3 JET FAILURES
description: Reacting to three failures of a late-model Pratt & Whitney engine in flight and to damage in other engines of the same type, the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday urged prompt action to require inspection and replacement of the troublesome parts.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: WALDHEIM SAYS DECISION BY U.S. TO BAN HIM IS 'INCOMPREHENSIBLE'
description: President Kurt Waldheim tonight described as ''dismaying and incomprehensible'' a Justice Department decision to put him on a list of people barred from entering the United States. He said he had a ''clear conscience'' about his wartime activities.

title: Uneasy Sri Lanka Moslems Ask to Join Talks
description: While Sri Lanka's Sinhalese-dominated Government has been looking for a way to create an autonomous but not independent region for the country's ethnic Tamil minority, a third group of Sri Lankans, the Moslems, have become uneasy about their future.

title: Court Backs Rail Unions
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that courts may not bar railroad workers from extending labor disputes nationwide to increase leverage against their own railroad by engaging in secondary picketing of any or all other railroads.

title: CLIFF ROBERTSON PORTRAYS HENRY FORD
description: CLIFF ROBERTSON, longtime star of A.T. & T. commercials, is venturing into another part of corporate America. He plays the lead in ''Ford: The Man and the Machine,'' a four-hour movie being marketed as an Operation Prime Time presentation. The first half had its premiere on WPIX, Channel 11, on Monday. It will be repeated tonight at 8 o'clock. The rest can be seen next Monday and Wednesday, also at 8 P.M.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Purple-Red Diamond Is Sold for $880,000
description: A purple-red diamond weighing less than one carat was sold yesterday for $880,000 at Christie's in Manhattan to Theodore Horovitz, a Geneva merchant in precious stones. The sale set a record at auction per carat for any gem.

title: New Mexico Issue
description: New Mexico yesterday priced a $35 million issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation. Yields range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6 percent in 1992 and 6.75 percent in 1996. Backed by the full faith and credit of the state, the issue is rated Aa by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: JAPAN WINNING RACE IN CHINA
description: By outworking and often outsmarting their American and European rivals, Japanese companies have taken such a lead in doing business with China that other countries have only a meager chance of catching up.

title: CENTER FOR ELDERLY PROVIDES JOBS FOR STAVISKY ALLIES
description: A Queens center for the elderly that is financed by a $125,000 annual state grant obtained by State Senator Leonard P. Stavisky provides jobs for Stavisky political allies and put out a newsletter that was sent to prime Democratic voters just before the primary last September.

title: India's Boom Leaves One State in Dark Ages
description: About 300 million Indians are said to be living below the poverty line, but Government statistics still portray a trend in which poverty is gradually being reduced. Such hopeful projections run up against a harsh reality for millions of people here.

title: Administration Split on Dollar
description: AS Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone arrives in Washington for his crucial talks with President Reagan, there are uncertainties and divisions within the American camp on the matter of greatest immediate concern to the Japanese: the yen-dollar exchange rate.

title: LAGGING CAMPAIGN IN IOWA LEADS KEMP TO A BIG SHAKE-UP
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, lagging in this crucial state in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, has shaken up his Iowa campaign and made major changes in the structure of his national organization, his aides said today.

title: Softness Group Buys Siesel for $2 Million
description: The Softness Group, a 27-year-old public relations firm, has acquired the Siesel Company, which does both advertising and public relations, for $2 million to be paid over five years.

title: CORREA LOSES BID FOR NO-HITTER IN 8TH
description: Not long after the Yankees had escaped becoming the victims of a no-hitter, Rickey Henderson stood in the relative quiet of his team's clubhouse and insisted the Yankees had beaten themselves. He was not impressed by Edwin Correa, the Texas Rangers pitcher and youngest player in the major leagues, who had gone into the eighth inning without permitting a hit.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CONVERSATION overheard (and scrawled on a slightly soggy cocktail napkin) by Joe Brescia, a late-night reveler about town. The place is Tunnel, an in-vogue club in Manhattan. There, in the wee hours of a recent morning, a young man in up-to-date attire bumps into a leather-jacketed, long-haired man. The snazzy dresser does a double take. ''Ah, Rick,'' he stammers. ''Um, Rick . . . ah . . . ''

title: Dollar Helps Bonds
description: Bond prices ended sharply higher yesterday, helped by the strengthening of the dollar in the world currency markets, especially against the Japanese yen.

title: Loss Reported By Convergent
description: Convergent Technologies Inc., the troubled computer manufacturer that is based in San Jose, Calif., today reported a first-quarter loss of $11 million in contrast to a profit of $2.1 million, or 5 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: COURT BACKS 'PROPAGANDA' LABEL FOR 3 CANADIAN FILMS
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a law classifying as ''political propaganda'' all foreign government films that might influence public opinion on United States foreign policies.

title: Suspension Ordered For Bronx Surrogate
description: The state's highest court has suspended Bronx Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand while it decides whether to remove him from office on charges of abusing his judicial authority during an affair with a female law assistant.

title: Guilty in 3 California Deaths
description: A man arrested after a bungled jewel robbery led to a siege at a jewelry store on Rodeo Drive in Beverely Hills last June entered surprise guilty pleas today to 12 charges. The defendant, Steven Livaditis, 23 years old, pleaded guilty to three counts of murder, five of robbery, one count of burglary and three counts of kidnapping. He entered the pleas as attorneys were selecting a jury for his trial in Santa Monica Superior Court. Jury selection is expected to continue so that the jury could recommend a penalty. Mr. Livaditis could be sentenced to death.

title: Blazing Speed in a Supercold Steel Tank
description: A NEW generation of supercomputer, so blazingly fast that it has to be dunked in liquid nitrogen to keep it from melting, was installed at Florida State University this week.

title: Terror Suspects Urge Release of Germans in Beirut
description: A Lebanese terrorist suspect and his brother, both in jail here, have written to relatives in Beirut urging them to free two West Germans who have been held hostage there for three months, according to a senior West German official.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $619,000 related to the refinancing of about $22 million of long-term debt. The company said the refinancing of its long-term debt in the fourth quarter will result in annual interest savings of $600,000.

title: U.S. MAYORS DRAFT URBAN PLATFORM
description: Hoping to make the health of cities a major issue in the Presidential primaries, the United States Conference of Mayors today began drafting an urban policy platform here to serve as a ''message'' to candidates of both parties.

title: CANFOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $1.4 million tax credit. The company attributed the improved earnings to reduced operating and financial costs and to better markets for its products.

title: Reagans to Be at AIDS Event
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will join the actress Elizabeth Taylor at a fund-raising dinner for AIDS research on May 31, officials said Monday. The dinner, to be held in Washington, is expected to attract an audience of politicians and Hollywood celebrities. It is being given by the American Foundation for AIDS Research, a nonprofit organization.

title: Tonka Names Overseas Chief
description: The Tonka Corporation announced yesterday that it had named James D. Miller president of its new unit, Tonka Toys International.

title: When Central America Responds to Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: MASCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Impaced by reduced interest costs resulting from the retirement of the company's $320 million of 16 percent subordinated debentures with the proceeds of a recent financing and by about $6.6 million, or 13 cents a share, from a net gain relating principally in the increase of the carrying value of marketable securities, which had previously been reduced in 1986 to reflect a decline in valuation.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss was caused largely by costs associated with recent acquisitions.

title: Lord & Taylor President Comes From Within
description: Frank C. Watson has been named president of Lord & Taylor, the retail fashion chain, its parent, the May Department Stores Company, announced yesterday.

title: BELIZE REJECTS L.I. TRASH BARGE
description: The Government of Belize said today that it would not allow a barge filled with 3,100 tons of garbage from Islip, L.I., to enter its territorial waters. The decision prolongs the vessel's monthlong search for a dumping ground.

title: PERES IS SAID TO MEET HUSSEIN
description: Two Israeli newspapers said today that Foreign Minister Shimon Peres met with King Hussein of Jordan in recent weeks, and won his agreement to an international peace conference that would lead to direct negotiations.

title: MAN SLAIN BY MOTORIST IN MIDTOWN
description: A pedestrian was stabbed to death on 42d Street in Manhattan yesterday morning after he accosted and scuffled with a motorist whose van may have grazed him as he tried to cross the intersection at Eighth Avenue, the police said.

title: Coming Despite Debate
description: At almost the exact time that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's plane touches down here today, the House will be taking up legislation aimed at Japan and other countries that enjoy large trade surpluses with the United States.

title: What Libel Suit Over 'Missing' Is About
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUGRAPHIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUDGE APPROVES REPAIRING HOUSE IN QUEENS SOUGHT FOR FOSTER CARE
description: A judge held yesterday that New York City could repair arson damage to an unoccupied Queens house it planned to use to shelter six foster-care infants, but that it could not convert the house to such use until she ruled on a challenge by neighborhood residents.

title: TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
1971 RADICAL PLEADS GUILTY TO PLANTING BOMBS IN BANKS
description: A former student radical who was arrested here last July after 14 years as a fugitive pleaded guilty on Monday to charges of planting explosive devices in 1971.

title: CUOMO URGES BUSINESS LEADERS TO AID MINORITY YOUTH TRAINING
description: Saying that racial tensions in New York had worsened and hinting at possible violence this summer, Governor Cuomo called on business leaders yesterday to undertake a campaign of training and guiding minority-group youths.

title: Amoco May Sell Some Dome Assets
description: The Amoco Corporation, which has agreed to buy Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada for $3.8 billion (United States), said it might sell some of Dome's assets. ''Selloffs are a possibility,'' Amoco's chairman, Richard Morrow, said after the company's annual meeting. ''They have to be considered, but financing the deal does not hinge on this possibility.''

title: ANY 'UNDERWEAR PLAYERS?'
description: One by one, as the names were announced in the Broadway Ballroom of the Marriott Marquis yesterday, each of the National Football League's 28 teams had what their coaches and personnel people will surely describe as a ''good draft.'' On draft day, there is no such thing as a bad draft. For every N.F.L. team, hope springs eternal with every choice. But beginning in July at training camp, each team will start wondering about some of its rookies. In a few weeks many of those rookies will have departed. Especially the ''underwear players,'' those who turn out to be more impressive in shorts than in pads.

title: NEW BRAZIL FINANCE MINISTER
description: After four days of political consultations, President Jose Sarney tonight named Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, an economist with vast business experience, to succeed Dilson Funaro as Brazil's Finance Minister.

title: EMPIRE OF AMERICA FEDERAL SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,750,000 and $3,564,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively; and gains on sale of loans and investments of $9,511,000 for the latest quarter and $37,600,000 for the year-ealier period.

title: Pinch Reassigned
description: Schenley Industries' Renfield division has assigned Pinch 12 Year Old Scotch from the Haig & Haig distillery to the Chester Gore Company. The billings, about $3 million, previously went through Grey Advertising.

title: RUSSIAN, IN GENEVA, HOPEFUL ON ARMS
description: A senior Soviet arms control negotiator said today that the Reagan Administration was taking an ''unconstructive'' attitude toward Soviet proposals for the elimination of medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles in Europe. But he said an agreement remained possible this year.

title: No to a Fast-Food, Fast-Sex, High-Crime 42d St. Historic District
description: To the Editor:

title: 61 NEW ACADEMY MEMBERS AND 15 FOREIGN ASSOCIATES
description: Following are 61 newly elected members of the National Academy of Sciences, whose total membership is now 1,523. In addition, 15 citizens of other countries were chosen as foreign associates, bringing that group's membership to 249. NEW MEMBERS ABRAHAMS, Elihu, Serin Professor of Physics, Rutgers University. BRINSTER, Ralph L., Richard King Mellon Professor of Reproductive Biology, University of Pennsylvania. BRYANT, Marvin P., professor of microbiology, University of Illinois, Urbana. JULESZ, Bela, research head, visual perception research department, A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. KAISER, Emil T., Haggerty Professor, The Rockefeller University. KABACK, H. Ronald, head, department of biochemistry, Roche Institute of Molecular Biology. KAULA, William M., professor of geophysics, University of California, Los Angeles. Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. PANISH, Morton B., member, technical staff, A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. PATTERSON, C. C., senior research associate, California Institute of Technology. PRESTON, Samuel H. professor of sociology, and director, Population Studies Center, University of Pennsylvania. RODBELL, Martin, scientific director, National Institute for Environmental Health Sciences, National Institutes of Health, Research Triangle Park, N.C. RUBIN, Gerald M., John D. SCHIFFER, John P., senior physicist, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Ill. SHU, Frank, professor of astronomy, University of California, Berkeley. SOKAL, Robert S., Leading Professor of Ecology and Evolution, State University of New York, Stony Brook. STARK, George R., senior scientist, Imperial Cancer Research Fund, London, England. Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. THADDEUS, Patrick, Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, and professor of astronomy and applied physics, Center for Astrophysics and Division of Applied Sciences, Harvard University. TSUI, Daniel, professor of electrical engineering and computer science, Princeton University. UNANUE, Emil R., Mallinckrodt Professor of Pathology, Washington University School of Medicine. WASSERMAN, Harry, Eugene Higgins Professor of Chemistry, Yale University. Lawrence, professor of psychology, Oxford University, London, England. WENDORF, D. Fred, Henderson-Morrison Professor of Anthropology, Southern Methodist University. WHITING, John W. M., professor emeritus of anthropology, Harvard University. FOREIGN ASSOCIATES BINNIG, Gerd K., member, research staff, I.B.M. Zurich Research Laboratory, Switzerland. BURGEN, Arnold S. V., Master of Darwin College, Cambridge, England.
