title: INQUIRY BY WALSH SAID TO SCRUTINIZE HIGH U.S. OFFICIALS
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that his investigation covered ''high Government officials'' as well as others and gave his strongest indication to date that he would seek indictments.

title: IN CHINA, BEAUTY IS A BIG WESTERN NOSE
description: WU FEN is a vivacious 21-year-old law student with sparkling black eyes. She wishes, however, that her eyelids folded like those of Westerners. So Miss Wu is going to have an operation to add a fold in each eyelid and make her eyes look rounder.

title: Adoption Makes One Family at Another's Expense; Network of Siblings
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH CUISINE SETS TO SEA IN POUCHES
description: LEAD: THERE will be freshly squeezed orange juice and omelets with fines herbes for breakfast, saucisson with Brie and French bread for lunch, tournedos and Bordeaux for dinner, and for dessert almond cake and coffee - and perhaps a Cognac.

title: Big in the Bushes
description: John Metzger and Jeff Rogovin are baseball fans who ran a quiet little commercial printing shop in Collegeville, Pa. That's not far from Reading, home of the Phillies' Eastern League affiliate, and one day two years ago Metzger and Rogovin decided to print up a set of baseball cards for the Reading team. That done, they named their fledgling business ProCards and set out that December for San Diego, where the baseball winter meetings were convening. ''We were hoping to sign up about 35 or 40 minor league teams,'' recalled Metzger. ''We came back with 68.''

title: Theater Group Leader From Ethiopia Defects
description: The theater manager for an Ethiopian folkloric group said today that he had defected to the United States because he could no longer function in a country where all artistic endeavors are controlled by the state.

title: FHP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company had its initial public offering last July. The company said the year-ago 9-month are presented as if the conversion to for-profit status, which actually took place Nov. 26, 1985, had occured July 1, 1985.

title: Group Raises Burlington Stake
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc., which have joined in a bid for Burlington Industries, said they had raised their stake in the company to 8.7 percent of its stock, from 7.6 percent. Mr. Edelman and Dominion, a Canadian company, are bidding $1.5 billion, or $60 a share, for the largest United States textile concern.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
College Sports Notebook; CORNELL KEEPS LACROSSE RECORD PERFECT
description: Victories over Hobart and Princeton last week continued Cornell's unbeaten streak, and the Big Red's lacrosse record is 10-0 with one regular-season game left, against Brown on Saturday.

title: WINE TALK
description: John S. Dyson - an industrialist, a candidate for the 1986 Democratic senatorial nomination in New York, ex-chairman of the State Power Authority and a former state commissioner of commerce and of agriculture - is a man for all seasons. So he spends a good part of those seasons on hillsides tending his vines here in Dutchess County.

title: MCDONALD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
Apparent Drug Relapse
description: Tony Collins, a running back for the New England Patriots, has apparently suffered a drug relapse and has been checked into a rehabilitation center by the team, according to a report in The Boston Globe yesterday.

title: The Meaning of Meow
description: Americans keep 56 million cats as pets and spend an estimated hour a day ''interacting'' with them. Many do so for a powerful reason: Cats appear to supply the affectionate companionship that may be lacking from other humans. But whatever goes on in people's heads when they cuddle and coo with their pets, the interaction means something different to the cat.

title: TEXACO PANELS PICK CHAIRMAN
description: Members of the two committees that will monitor Texaco Inc. during its bankruptcy proceedings yesterday chose a representative of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to head one panel and one each from the Pennzoil Company and Tenneco Inc. to head the other.

title: PUBLIC FINANCING ISSUE MAY STALL BILL TO LIMIT CAMPAIGN SPENDING
description: Senate Democrats are trying to complete a bill to restrict spending on political campaigns, but the issue of public financing of campaigns could become an obstacle to passage next month.

title: Trade-Aid Bill Backed
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved an expanded trade adjustment assistance program that will extend cash benefits and retraining to workers whose jobs are indirectly affected by import competition, including previously ineligible workers in the oil and gas industry.

title: Adoption Makes One Family at Another's Expense
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Gracious Southern Fare Savannah, Ga., is known for its hospitality, and Northern hosts might consider having some of its specialty foods on hand for entertaining. Set out a dish of spiced or caramelized pecans, for example, and cocktail nibbles are taken care of; butter thins are all you need with ice cream or fruit for dessert.

title: If the Missiles Go, Peace May Stay
description: The rapid movement toward an arrangement that would remove both Soviet and Western intermediate-range missiles from the European theater has caused great concern - even among longtime advocates of arms control. As one who originally encouraged the ''zero-zero option,'' and was forced from office partly for advocating the idea, I urge my nervous friends in Europe and America to embrace it. Their fears that the removal of these weapons will leave Europe vulnerable to Soviet attack are misplaced.

title: Adoption Makes One Family at Another's Expense fe,r10:Children Are Available
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVISER REBUKED BY WHITE HOUSE FOR ARMS REMARK
description: The Reagan Administration today rebuked Edward L. Rowny, one of its senior arms advisers, for criticizing its arms control strategy, and said his comments could complicate talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Rents Soar For Needle Trades
description: IN the face of escalating rents, the Manhattan needle trades are struggling to maintain the traditional clustering that has helped them prosper.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
description: b-Includes a gain of $3.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from the disposition of the company's investment in a Swedish firm.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Tampa Officers Are Cleared
description: Two police officers were cleared Monday of wrongdoing in the death of Otis Bernard Miller, a 35-year-old transient who was the fourth black man in five months to die in confrontations with white police officers here. Mr. Miller, who had a chronic heart valve disorder, died a few hours after scuffling with the two officers, Roxana Wollam, 25, and Michael Noyes, 33, on April 5. The assistant Prosecutor, Charles A. Caruso, attributed the death to a cardiac rhythm disturbance.

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge from minority interests of $1,306,000, $9 million ''fresh start'' income tax benefit resulting from the tax reform act of 1986 and includes gains of $10.2 million on the sale of investments. c-Includes a charge from minority interests of $1,309,000, an after-tax gain of $52.4 million from the sale of the company's Canadian property and casualty subsidiary and includes gains of $16.5 million on the sale of investments. The company is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $760,000.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER IN ANTONY TUDOR'S 'LEAVES'
description: PETIPA, Balanchine and Tudor - not a bad trio of choreographers to represent a company, as the first mixed bill of the American Ballet Theater season proved Monday night.

title: CILCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $7.5 million resulting from an accounting change.

title: MOTO PHOTO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed its higher revenue in the latest first quarter to the addition of 27 company-owned stores.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INCOME SECURIIES reports earnings for Assets at March 31
description: Assets represents net asset.

title: Cenergy Stake
description: Snyder Oil Partners said it had agreed to purchase an additional 439,418 shares of the Cenergy Corporation's common stock, raising its stake to more than 16 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Snyder said it might seek to acquire all of Cenergy. Snyder said the shares had been bought at an average price of $8.89 a share and that the sellers included members of the Murchison family of Dallas.

title: 'WE LOVE LUCY,' PASTICHE FROM 50'S
description: OBVIOUSLY, Lucille Ball will be on television forever. It is a cultural fact of life. ''I Love Lucy'' began in 1951, ran six years and never ranked less than third among all programs. Then Miss Ball and her husband, Desi Arnaz, did a series of specials; some of those will be around forever, too. Witness ''We Love Lucy'' on Channel 5 at 8 o'clock tonight. It's not just that the old programs stand up; it's that they stand up so well.

title: CHRISTIAN CHURCHES STILL PLAY A ROLE IN EDUCATION IN CHINA
description: On the wooded Dragon Hills of Hangzhou, the Chinese lakeside city, about 400 college faculty members, alumni and local journalists gathered recently to celebrate the 140th anniversary of one of the oldest Christian mission colleges in China.

title: Profits Scoreboard
ORNAMENTS WITH A PAST
description: 1.A Useful Decoration This metal chocolate mold, made in Dresden, Germany, before World War II, makes an unusual kitchen wall decoration. If you are more ambitious, it can also be used for making pretty chocolates. Patterned with fish and manufactured by the Anton Reiche Company, the mold is 9 by 4 inches and costs $85. It is from a collection of molds made for European chocolate factories and candy shops. At Laura Fisher, Gallery 57, 1050 Second Avenue, at 55th Street. 2.Waist Enhancements The name of Sheila Toma's studio says it all: the Waists of Time. She designs leather and suede belts finished with antique buckles. The belt shown, which can be worn for daytime or evening, is black suede, with an Art Deco buckle made from cut steel. It is $155 at the Waists of Time, 120 East 34th Street. 3.Socks to Prance In A man can literally step into spring with a pair of these Mondrian-inspired socks. A blend of cotton and acrylic, the socks are patterned with panels of pink, yellow and gray against a slate background. They cost $14 at Avalanche, 152 Eighth Avenue, between 17th and 18th Streets. 4.A Handful of Art Art lovers will have fun with a new card game called ''Quartet: The Art Collector Card Game.'' The deck of 52 cards has reproductions of paintings by 13 artists in the collection of the Tate Gallery in London, including Cezanne, Dali, Constable, Gainsborough, Hockney, Matisse, Picasso, Sargent and Turner. Each artist is represented by four works. The goal is to accumulate entire collections. The cards, made in Great Britain for the Tate Gallery, are $18 at Sointu, 20 East 69th Street.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE dish that I recall most fondly from my childhood is the pot-au-feu made by my mother. It was generally a special treat served on Saturday nights. Yet as often as pot-au-feu was served, its preparation seemed to vary from week to week.

title: MERRILL SAYS IT FACES SUIT BY HAFTS ON BUYOUT
description: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners disclosed today that the Haft family of Washington planned to sue the investment firm for unspecified damages stemming from the takeover battle for the Supermarkets General Corporation.

title: Ketchum May Close Deal for Hicks & Greist
description: Ketchum Communications of Pittsburgh, which has long been trying to build a strong New York office, could sign the papers tomorrow to acquire Hicks & Greist, a New York packaged-goods agency billing about $100 million.

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS DEPORTATION OF 2
description: A Federal district judge has questioned the Government's attempt to deport two Palestinians because they were reported to belong to a Marxist faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Dow Rise of 1.42 Ends 4-Day Slide
description: Stocks edged slightly higher yesterday, ending Wall Street's four-day slide.

title: A LAND OF SERBS AND ALBANIANS AND TROUBLE
description: The church bells tolled at 5 A.M. to signal the protest, and the people lighted candles by the graves of their dead to bid their ancestors a sort of farewell.

title: LARGEST GIFT TO COLUMBIA TO AID MINORITY STUDENTS
description: Columbia University will receive a gift of $25 million, the largest donation in its history, from the chairman of the Metromedia Company, Columbia officials said yesterday.

title: BODDICKER'S 1-HITTER DOWNS ROYALS, 3-0
description: Mike Boddicker pitched a one-hitter tonight, yielding only a sixth-inning single to Willie Wilson, and Nelson Simmons had three hits as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-0.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES ON SANITATION FOR FARM WORKERS
description: The Labor Department today issued long-deferred rules requiring that clean drinking water and sanitation facilities be provided on large farms to nearly 500,000 fieldworkers.

title: ISLANDERS, FACED BY ELIMINATION, ARE AT IT AGAIN
description: For a change, Ron Hextall, the Flyers' goaltender, had a night worth forgetting, but he will have bruises to remember it by. The Islanders, the magicians of playoff comebacks, upended Hextall and the Flyers, 2-1, forcing a sixth game in their Patrick Division final.

title: Professor Is Said to Weigh Journalism Post at Columbia
description: A journalism professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is considering an offer to become dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, according to officials at both institutions.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Seville, Spain, on April 20 about Holy Week celebrations misidentified a church there. It is the Macarena Church.

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special gain of $10.8 million, or 27 cents a share, from the previously announced sale of a 4-percent interest in a Japanese subsidiary in which Engelhard retains a 46-percent interest. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 31. The company said net earnings in the latest quarter excluding the special gain increased 18-percent over last year's first quarter despite a significantly higher tax rate in 1987 due to the new tax law. Earnings before taxes and the special gain were up 31- percent from a year-earlier.

title: A PROMOTIONAL BLITZ FOR SNOW WHITE
description: The Snow White Task Force met in the briefing room at Walt Disney Studios a couple of months ago. In a movie equivalent of an election-year campaign, the 16 Disney executives were planning the proclamations, parades, public appearances, television specials, toy dwarfs and soft-drink tie-ins that will culminate on July 17 with the re-release of ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' in nearly 4,000 theaters around the world.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net income

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FOUR PASSERS TAKEN AS NO. 1
description: In a year quarterbacks were not expected to arouse much interest - outside of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' taking Vinny Testaverde of Miami with the first pick - the National Football League's college draft shoved them into the forefront yesterday, when four were taken on the first round, leaving several veteran quarterbacks to wonder about their futures.

title: PROPOSAL ASSAILED ON ATOMIC PERMIT
description: A proposal by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to ease Federal emergency evacuation requirements for the Shoreham and Seabrook reactors came under wide criticism today at a day-long hearing of the House Interior Committee.

title: MAXTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,524,000, or 8 cents a share, and $3,962,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: A GUARANTEE, AND AN ERA, FADE AWAY IN ZIMBABWE
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe is moving cautiously to abolish guaranteed white seats in Parliament in his drive to turn this multiparty democracy into a one-party state.

title: Becker Illness Baffling
description: Several medical examinations have reportedly failed to determine the cause of the illness that has kept the two-time Wimbledon champion, Boris Becker, out of action in recent weeks. But the speculation goes on.

title: ALLEN GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a provision for credit losses totaling $1,800,000 with respect to certain loans and leases of the company's West German leasing subsidiary.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $58 million, or $1.42 a share, for the write-down of the oil and gas properties of its 48.7- percent-owned affiliate, Proven Properties Inc. c-Net loss The company said that certain prior period items have been reclassified to conform to current year presentation.

title: DETROIT CRIME FEEDS ON ITSELF AND YOUTH
description: In a city where officials say there are more guns than people, crime influences almost every decision. It determines when people leave home, what routes they drive, where they walk. Crime is a conversational ice-breaker, like the weather or the Detroit Tigers.

title: 'Tourism Leader' Award
description: Martin B. Segal, the chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts, has received the ''Tourism Leader of the Year'' award given by the Tourism Industry of New York. The award, given during a luncheon yesterday at the New York Hilton Hotel, cited Mr. Segal's ''impressive contributions to the vitality of New York's cultural community.'' A scholarship in Mr. Segal's honor is to be created at the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center. The Tourism Industry of New York is a statewide business group.

title: NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 2, 1987.

title: WRESTLING WITH AND IN A CLASSIC MENU
description: AFTER months of expectation, the magic moment arrived.

title: Prime Introduces Computer System
description: Prime Computer Inc. said it had introduced a supermicrocomputer to run programs for Unix-based systems and International Business Machines personal computers simultaneously. The new multi-user system is called Prime EXL 316.

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOME '84 BORDEAUX DEFY THE FORECAST
description: BORDEAUX'S 1984 vintage, preceded by a spotty reputation, arrived at the Four Seasons Sunday and, before 185 dinner guests, behaved itself admirably. The 10 reds, 6 of them patricians, displayed grace under nature's pressure.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1987
description: International A3-17

title: JURY HEARS TAPE TELLING OF THEFT BY CITY OFFICERS
description: A New York City police officer being tried on corruption charges was heard yesterday on a tape recording describing how he and two other officers stole 67 pounds of marijuana from a Brooklyn drug dealer while on duty, then sold it to another dealer for $4,500.

title: FEDERAL BOARD TO URGE CURBS ON AIR TRAFFIC
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is urgently working on formal recommendations to ease air traffic congestion in summer and help reduce the danger of collisions, an agency official said yesterday.

title: EX-AIDE SAYS REAGAN GOT FLAWED ADVISE ON ABM'S
description: A former State Department aide told Congress today that Administration officials ignored dissenting legal views and provided flawed advice to President Reagan in recommending the adoption of a broad interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title:
ADVERTISING;
A Loss Is Posted By JWT
description: LEAD: THE JWT Group, parent of the J. Walter Thompson Company, had a $1.4 million loss in the first quarter, it announced yesterday.

title: A VIOLIN TEACHER'S LIFE
description: HOW do you get to Carnegie Hall? ''Practice, practice, practice,'' the old saw goes, although it may help to study with Josef Gingold. ''Josef Gingold: A Musical Life,'' on Channel 13 at 11:30 tonight, explains why. As Isaac Stern says in an interview on the film, Mr. Gingold is a ''role model for the younger musicians.''

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $25,542,000 for the latest quarter and $9,362,000 for the year-ago period.

title: THE BEASTS OF THE FIELD COME INTO THE HOUSE
description: FIFTEEN years ago, when the painter Gerard Rigot bought a farmhouse in Toulouse, France, he began to make furniture. Inspired by his cat and using native oak and pine, he carved and painted naive animal furniture: cat chairs and toucan benches. In Mr. Rigot's small atelier an assistant cuts the wood into rough shapes. Mr. Rigot, top right, uses hand tools to refine the shapes, and he joins them with dowels. When he paints the pieces he takes liberties with the animals' colors - a camel might be yellow - but he captures the particular charm and posture of each animal.

title: S.E.C. to Ask Congress For Authority on Banks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to ask Congress for the authority to regulate, for the first time, the securities operations of commercial banks.

title: TV EVANGELIST DENIES A HOAX
description: Robert Schuller, the television evangelist, says his organization had no intention of deceiving donors when it mailed a fund-raising letter and faked photograph showing him on the Great Wall of China before he made the trip.

title: PERU (POP. 20 MILLION) IS STARTING TO CRY 'ENOUGH!'
description: A small white van carrying a doctor, an obstetrician and a psychologist turned off a busy highway on the outskirts of Lima and bounced its way up a dirt track to a slum perched high on a barren hillside overlooking this city.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains of $267,000 for the latest quarter and $155,000 for the year- ago period from sale of property and investments. Revenue figures exclude revenue from sales of properties and investments.

title: ROCK: BRITAIN'S MEKONS
description: ROWDY, drunken desperation - not the quiet kind -drives the music of the Mekons, who played the Cat Club Monday night. The Mekons have been a virtual institution of independent British rock since 1977; as some 75 musicians have passed through the group, its singer-guitarist, Jon Langford, has led the Mekons from punk-rock toward a British version of country music that waltzes and twangs and kicks. The current band has six members, including a fiddler.

title: ZYCAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $255,000. c-Net loss and results are restated to reflect the pooling of interests with Silicon Solutions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The House approved a restrictive trade bill amendment, reflecting disarray over the direction of a new trade policy. The measure, proposed by Representative Gephardt, requires retaliation according to a rigid formula against countries such as Japan, whose large trade surpluses with the United States have grown, in part by shutting out American products. The measure was passed by a close 218-to-214 vote, suggesting that it may be abandoned in a final House-Senate compromise. But supporters said its approval meant that the final bill would be tougher, in any case. [ Page A1. ] Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan arrived in Washington for talks to defuse the trade dispute with Washington. [ D4. ] The volatile index of leading indicators rose 0.4 percent in March, the fifth increase in six months. At the same time, the February increase was revised downward by nearly one-half. The latest figures seemed to suggest that the economy will accelerate only slightly in coming months. [ D1. ] Sales of new homes slumped 3.6 percent in March, while the nationwide median sales price climbed to a record $101,500. [ D8. ] MARKETS Merrill Lynch said it had lost $250 million on bonds that plummeted in value when interest rates surged. Wall Street executives could not recall an occasion when a securities firm lost so much in so short a time - apparently in little over a week. Merrill attributed the loss largely to unauthorized trading by a senior official, who was dismissed. But executives at the firm said that supervisory lapses and errors in judgment had contributed. [ A1. ] Bond prices plunged in tandem with the dollar when the House passed the Gephardt amendment. The bellwether long bond lost more than 2 points. Market experts said the vote raised fears that Japanese investors may reduce their participation in next week's $29 billion quarterly Treasury refunding. [ D1. ] The dollar fell sharply against the yen in U.S. trading, and dealers said that traders feared Japanese retaliation on trade. In New York, gold dropped $1.25, to $450.50. [ D22. ] Silver futures advanced, while gold contracts closed lower. [ D22. ] The stock market scored a strong gain despite an upward swing in interest rates and an undercurrent of nervousness. A surging technology sector and solid earnings reports pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up by 22.30 points, to 2,254.26. [ D12. ] Yields were mixed for consumer money products. Rates rose on certificates of deposit, but were unchanged for bank money market accounts. For money-market mutual funds, the seven-day yield fell and the 30-day yield rose. [ D19. ] The S.E.C. will ask Congress for the authority to regulate, for the first time, the securities operations of commercial banks. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Ford's quarterly earnings more than doubled, exceeding the combined first-quarter profits of its domestic competitors. The performance exceeded analysts' estimates, and Ford's stock surged by $6 in heavy trading, to $87.75. Analysts said the results reflected Ford's model mix, effective cost-cutting measures and the weaker dollar. Meanwhile, union leaders said they expected Ford to share its good fortune with workers in coming contract talks. [ D1. ] Texaco reported a 64 percent drop in earnings, citing depressed oil prices and the ''direct and indirect costs'' of its legal fight with Pennzoil. But Texaco's stock rose as the earnings report was overshadowed by speculation about the activities of the two committees of creditors that will monitor Texaco during its bankruptcy proceedings and by rumors of a Texaco-Pennzoil settlement. [ D1. ] Burlington accused Paine Webber of leaking inside information to several parties, including Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile, to induce them to take over the textile producer. [ D4. ] Donald J. Trump has sold his stake in UAL for a profit of about $80 million, a source close to the New York developer said. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A.T.&T. learned that deal making can be unpredictable in Europe, in part because of the importance of politics there, when it lost out to Ericsson in a three-way competition to acquire France's second-largest telephone switching company. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The daily ritual is changing at the Chicago Board of Trade. At 6 P.M. today, night trading begins with a three-hour session that is part of the vaunted move toward a world where deals are made 24 hours a day. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: Q&A
description: Q.The ceilings in my house are covered with old, yellowing 12-inch-square tiles. I do not want to paint them, but would like to cover them to give the appearance of a smooth plastered ceiling. Can I plaster over them or cover them with wallpaper that will conceal the seams, or do you have other suggestions? A.Ceiling tiles are quite porous and have a fuzzy, textured surface, so plastering is impossible. A wall covering would be equally impractical. Your best bet is to put up a ceiling of gypsum board (dry wall). You may be able to nail these up over the tiles, but you would get better results by taking the tiles off and then putting up the dry wall. Cover the joints with joint cement and the perforated tape sold for this purpose. Q.The cedar shakes on our house get blacker with mildew every year. We have been told of companies that wash this off with a powerful spray, but this might ruin some brittle shakes. Besides, we feel that after the washing we would have to stain or treat the shingles again. Aside from its ugliness, is this mildew causing any harm, such as rotting the wood? A.Mildew can harm wood shingles and structural members inside the wall. It should be cleaned and the fungus killed with a mildewcide. Mix about one part fresh liquid laundry bleach to four parts water. Throw in a handful or two of trisodium phosphate (TSP) or a similar cleaner. Scrub this on, let dry and rinse with lots of water. Repeat if necessary. As for treating the shingles with stain or a clear preservative, this should be done periodically anyway. It helps protect the wood from checking and discoloration, and a water-repellent stain or preservative helps keep moisture away so there is less chance of the mildew's returning. Q.The front wall of our brick fireplace stretches to the ceiling and in several places we have noticed a powder that looks like salt coming out of the brick. It is unsightly, and I am afraid to hang anything on the wall or to put a clock on the mantel because it might be damaged by the white powder. Can you tell us what might cause this problem, and what can be done? A.The white powder is efflorescence, caused by moisture that leaches out alkaline salts in the masonry. You can remove it by washing the brick with a mild acid solution, such as one part muriatic acid (sold in paint stores) and five parts water. However, it may come back. A permanent cure requires solving the moisture problem outside. A missing or cracked cap at the top of the chimney, defective flashing or caulking where the chimney meets the house wall, or mortar joints that need tuck pointing in the outside brickwork are common reasons for your moisture problem. Q.An old brass chandelier turned black, so I cleaned and polished it with brass polish and soap-impregnated steel wool. The metal had a nice shine, so I sprayed it with a clear lacquer to keep it from tarnishing. However, the lacquer dried with a dull finish, rather than a high gloss. What went wrong? A.There are two possibilities. The spray lacquer might have been semigloss, rather than high-gloss. Or when spraying, you might not have held the spray can at the right distance. Directions usually say 8 to 10 inches, but this can vary among brands. If you hold the spray too far away, the fast-drying lacquer begins to set up while still in the air, creating a slightly fuzzy, dull finish. Holding the spray can too close can do the same, because you might overspray work that is still wet. Spray on lacquer in several thin coats, not one heavy coat, and keep the spray can moving all the time.

description: A conference on black playwrights in the American theater is to be held tomorrow at the University of Massachusetts, in Amherst, in honor of the retirement of Doris Abramson. An expert in black theater and a member of the faculty for 34 years, Ms. Abramson wrote ''Negro Playwrights in the American Theater, 1925-1959.'' Among the people expected at the daylong conference are such black playwrights as James Baldwin, Alice Childress, William Branch, Loften Mitchell and Louis Peterson.

title: GUS JOHNSON, EX-N.B.A. STAR WITH BALTIMORE, IS DEAD AT 48
description: Gus Johnson, who brought National Basketball Association fans to their feet with his backboard-shattering dunk shots, died of brain cancer Tuesday night at Akron City Hospital in Ohio. He was 48 years old.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $1,125,000 gain from litigation settlements.

title: Toxic Emission Linked To a Plutonium Plant
description: A plutonium plant at the Hanford nuclear reservation in south-central Washington has spewed tons of a suspected carcinogen into the air, a Government report says, adding that there has been no attempt to control the emissions.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LOBBY. Jewish Political Power and American Foreign Policy. By Edward Tivnan. 304 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: DR. GEORGE KHOURY
description: Dr. George Khoury, who had been chief of the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of the National Cancer Institute since 1980, died of complications related to lymphoma Saturday in Bethesda, Md., where he lived. He was 43 years old.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Interpublic Net Rises 27.9%
description: LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies has started the year out on the right foot, with a first-quarter earnings report that shows net income up 27.9 percent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp, Bethlehem, Pa., said its directors had voted to omit second-quarter dividends on its common stock and two classes of preferred stock.

title: Europe Jobless Dip
description: Unemployment in the 12-member European Community fell in March to 16.8 million from 17 million in February because of an improvement in the weather, the group's statistics agency, Eurostat, said today.

title: TEXAS PLAN FOR SCHOOL FINANCING IS FOUND DISCRIMINATORY BY JUDGE
description: The Texas system of financing public schools discriminates against students in poorer districts and is unconstitutional, a state judge ruled today.

title: NASA and Chile Carve Up Easter Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallowing in Food
description: To people who spent their childhoods trying to slip the liver to the cat or wondering if the world's starving people would really give anything to get their lima beans, Bruce Rosenbaum of Numidia, Pa., must be a kind of hero. He is, after all, the man who showed America what to do with creamed spinach. Wrestle in it.

title: FLORIDA EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $449,000.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Brown Is Early Leader: Ken Brown, a 30-year-old Englishman, shot an 8-under-par 64 on the Las Vegas Country Club course yesterday to take a one-stroke lead in the $1.25 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational. But only half the field was able to finish the first round after a severe thunderstorm forced a three-hour delay. Seventy-eight in the field of 156 pros, including the defending champion, Greg Norman, could not finish before darkness and were to complete their rounds today. (AP) HOCKEY Canada Ties Soviet Union: Canada held the Soviet Union to a scoreless tie yesterday in the opening medal-round game at the world hockey championship in Vienna. Bob Froese of the Rangers, the Canadian goaltender, made 22 saves and was selected as his team's outstanding player. In the second game, Hakan Loob of the Calgary Flames scored his third goal of the game with 39 seconds remaining to give Sweden a 3-3 tie with Czechoslovakia. (AP) ROWING Successful Regatta: The Princeton heavyweight crews had the most successful regatta of their season, winning four of their five races yesterday against Yale, including the varsity contest. The Yale junior varsity prevented a Tiger sweep, coming across the finish line 5.2 seconds ahead of Princeton, the widest margin of victory in any of the races on a calm Housatonic River in Connecticut. TENNIS Lendl and Mecir Advance: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, seeded first, and his countryman, Miloslav Mecir, seeded second, advanced to the third round of the $375,000 German Open tennis tournament yesteray with straight-set victories in Hamburg. Lendl beat Darren Cahill of Australia, 6-2, 6-1, while Mecir defeated Cassio Motta of Brazil, 6-3, 6-3. Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, seeded fourth, Emilio Sanchez of Spain, seeded fifth, and Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, seeded sixth, were among the other second-round winners, while Kent Carlsson of Sweden, seeded third, and Thierry Tulasne of France, seeded ninth, were the first to advance to the quarterfinals. (AP)

title: 7 Years After Deaths, Boat Hits New Bridge
description: A shrimp boat slammed into a concrete bumper protecting the new $240 million Sunshine Skyway Bridge today on the eve of its reopening. It was seven years ago that another vessel struck the old bridge, sending 35 people to their death.

title: Fireworks Bring Queries
description: A fireworks display last night over the Hudson River in celebration of the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution prompted numerous telephone calls to the police in New Jersey and New York, the authorities said. The display, sponsored by Maxwell House and launched from its coffee-factory property in Hoboken, N.J., produced numerous calls to the police in both Hoboken and Manhattan from people who were uncertain of the cause of the noise, the police said.

title: USX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company had an operating loss of $27 million for the first quarter of 1987, compared with an operating loss of $42 million in the first quarter of 1986. The latest quarter operating results reflect both the effects of the steel strike and costs associated with starting up our steel facilities after the labor agreement had been reached. Latest quarter results include $57 million of benefits from LIFO inventory liquidations, compared with $20 million a year ago.

title: SENATORS BACK DEMOCRATS' BUDGET, 50 TO 49
description: The Senate, by a one-vote margin, gave preliminary approval today to a 1988 budget that would raise taxes, cut President Reagan's military spending request and allow selected increases in domestic programs.

title: A FAIR WHERE CRAFT MERGES INTO ART
description: A FAIR that explores the region where craft merges into art, and that therefore looks unlike most craft fairs, opens tonight at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue. It has been carefully designed to be a hybrid of craft fair, art exposition and gallery exhibition.

title: Nuclear Test Set for Today
description: The sixth announced nuclear weapon test of the year, a major blast up to 10 times the force of the Hiroshima atomic bomb, is scheduled to occur Thursday in the desert.

title: DEMOCRATIC GROUP MAPS VOTER DRIVE FOR DAY OF 14 PRIMARIES
description: The Democratic Leadership Council, a group of centrist and conservative Democrats, today outlined plans to increase voter participation in the primaries scheduled in 14 Southern and Border states on March 8 next year, hoping to produce a Presidential nominee ''with broad-based support.''

title: Texas Air in Talks With Air Atlanta
description: The Texas Air Corporation has begun negotiations with officials of Air Atlanta, which could lead to a purchase of the troubled Atlanta airline's remaining assets. Michael Hollis, chairman of Air Atlanta, has been been meeting with Texas Air officials in Houston this week, and two airline executives confirmed that those negotiations concern a possible purchase.

title: A NEW PRESIDENT IN A WEEK OF RALLIES AND PARTIES
description: Harold T. Shapiro is well known to educators as one of the country's most distinguished college presidents, but initial on-campus reaction to the announcement Tuesday that he will become the 18th president of Princeton University tended to run along the lines of ''Harold Who?''

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chips Are Up At Georgia
description: It's a familiar sight and, depending on where your rooting interests lie, a sometimes exasperating one. After a runner bulls his way through the line and is tackled by a swarm of defenders, an official steps forward to peel back the tangle of bodies and retrieve the football, which he then carefully positions on the field at the precise spot that - in his best guess - marks the extent of its forward motion. Or, on a punt that angles out of bounds, it is again eyesight and judgment that determine just where the ball has crossed the sideline.

HONORING DESIGNS IN CLASSICAL TRADITION
description: An awards ceremony Monday night at the National Academy of Design in Manhattan honored a spectrum of design achievements that covered museums, beds and even a presidential seal. Though disparate, the works share a common theme: all were created in the classical tradition. The Arthur Ross awards, honoring classical design in painting, sculpture, architecture and landscaping, were given by the New York-based organization, Classical America, and presented by Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island.

description: A second test of bacteria genetically altered to inhibit frost began today as scientists prepared to plant potato seeds treated with the strain.

description: HOMEOWNERS tend to ignore the outside of the house in winter. But with warm weather they suddenly become aware that exterior paint might need redoing or that winter storms damaged the siding, shingles or gutters.

title: U.S. Player Suspended
description: Scott Young, a right wing on the United States team playing in the World Hockey Championships in Vienna, has been suspended from international play for 18 months after failing a postgame drug test. The International Ice Hockey Federation said that Ephedrine, contained in nasal decongestants and on its list of prohibited substances, was found in two tests after the United States team's 4-2 defeat Monday by Czechoslovakia.

title: MET SAYS ITS POPULAR CAT IS PROBABLY FAKE
description: One of the most popular sculptures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a 15-inch-high Egyptian bronze cat that was believed to have been a coffin for a mummified cat, was declared yesterday by museum officials to be ''in all probability a modern forgery.''

title: ART OF THE MIND'S EYE IS THE OBJECT OF UNUSUAL AUCTION OF CONCEPTUAL WORKS
description: Last Monday at 10 A.M., David Higginbotham slapped his ruler firmly against a white wall at Christie's and began redrawing Sol LeWitt's 1971 work ''Ten Thousand Lines About 10 Inches (25 cm.) Long, Covering a Wall Evenly.'' The 8-foot-square re-creation of Mr. LeWitt's drawing was being made for the edification of potential bidders prior to its offering at Christie's next Tuesday night.

title: Steel Production Down

For the first quarter as a whole, production fell 6.5 percent, to 101.80 million tons, the institute said. The 30 nations reporting to the institute account for 97 percent of world production, excluding that of China, North Korea and most members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.

title: CONCERT: EARLY MUSIC ORCHESTRA
description: THE more one hears Handel on period instruments, the more one realizes how individual and particular are the orchestral pieces that have sometimes seemed cut in a generic pattern. The familiar Concerto Grosso in A (Op. 6, No. 11) begins with one of those dotted-rhythm movements that one thinks of as severe and majestic; grins of delight must have spread around Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening when the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra gave forth instead a gentle jogging or rocking sound, nimble on its feet, moving by whole measures rather than single beats. Then one began to attend anew to the marvelous instrumental invention -for instance, to how many different ways Handel could arrange the elements of a striking repeated crescendo gesture: from minor to major, low to high, slower notes to faster ones, repetitions to alternations.

title: ON THE JOB: APPRAISING THE CONTENTS OF A HOME
description: THIS is what Eleanore Sue McMillan takes with her when she goes to work: several tape measures of assorted lengths, scales operated by pulleys for weighing silver, magnifying glasses in various sizes, a flashlight, an ultraviolet black light, a camera, a pen and note pads.

title: ROCK: ERIC CLAPTON
description: ERIC CLAPTON played a flashy, crowd-pleasing concert Monday at Madison Square Garden. He belted out his best-known songs and fired off speedy guitar solos. But even with the spark of a guest drummer, Phil Collins, the music was hollow arena-rock; the blues feeling that permeates Mr. Clapton's best efforts was at a minimum.

title: Trade Surplus For Germany
description: West Germany today reported another strong monthly trade surplus. Economists were surprised at how well exports fared despite the appreciation of the mark against the weakened dollar.

description: The Federal Reserve Board approved an application by the Republicbank Corporation to acquire the Interfirst Corporation, creating a $28 billion banking concern that would be the largest in Texas. Republic and Interfirst, which are both based in Dallas, are currently the second- and third-largest banking organizations in Texas, with $14.4 billion and $13.6 billion in domestic deposits, respectively.

description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had lost $250 million this month because bonds that it owned plummeted in value when interest rates surged.

title: No Decision on Nelson
description: Herbert Kohl, owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, said he has not decided whether he would grant permission to any team, including the Knicks, wanting to interview his coach, Don Nelson. But, Kohl added, if Nelson were eager to leave, he would not stand in his way.

title: The F.C.C. Keeps It Clean
description: In a controversial decision, the Federal Communications Commission seems to have taken all the fun out of radio with an order that chillingly warned broadcasters to avoid ''indecent'' programming. Among the objections that have been quick and exceedingly strong, the First Amendment is serving as the central cry. But an examination of the history of radio suggests that the ruling not only is solidly rooted but also represents a rediscovery of the Federal Government's important role in superintending the public airwaves.

title: STOCK UP

title: FANTASY AS A WAY OF LIFE
description: IN past years, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House was the bellwether of decorating trends, innovative solutions and practical tips. And no matter how fanciful, many of the rooms had some relationship to the world in which most of us live. Elaborate exercise spaces pinpointed concerns about fitness and health, complex electronic installations mirrored our passion for new technology and magically outfitted small rooms reflected real-life concerns about organizing tiny spaces.

Donald Joyce played it Tuesday evening in a program ranging from the 16th century to Keith Jarrett, and though the instrument is not capable of great tonal variety, it served Mr. Joyce's sure fingers and firm, flowing sense of rhythm most enjoyably in a great variety of music.

title: THE ROAD TO A VIOLENT DEATH: VICTIM SOUGHT 'SOCIAL IMPACT'
description: The American volunteer who was reported killed by Nicaraguan rebels was described by friends as a political activist interested in Central American causes.

title: TRAINERS FIGHTING A NEW WAR OF ROSES
description: The mood surrounding the principals in the 113th Kentucky Derby is turning catty.

title: Thomson, STET In Chip Venture
description: The Thomson group of France and STET, the Italian state telecommunications enterprise, said they would join forces to create Western Europe's second-largest manufacturer of semiconductors.

title: LANDMARK SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,562,000 from a tax credit. c-After a loss of $94,000 from early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $712,000 from a tax credit.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect issuance of 1,200,000 shares in December 1986.

title: QUESTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes writedowns of oil and gas properties of $9 million for the latest quarter and $9.8 million for the year-ago period.

title: COMMERCE BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of Commerce Bank-Pennsylvania in January.

title: FAMILY MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to a stock form from mutual in November 1986.

title: America's Debt, Japan's Leverage
description: LEAD: The Administration is congratulating itself on having designed its 100 percent tariffs on selected Japanese imports in such a way as to make a strong symbolic statement to Japan without incurring the risk of retaliation. No retaliation? Just wait.

title: Bach Piano Works
description: Edward Aldwell, an American pianist, music theoretician and author, is to play two long works by J. S. Bach in a recital at Merkin Concert Hall tonight at 8. The two works, from the composer's ''Clavierubung,'' are ''Overture in the French Manner'' (BWV 831) and the ''Goldberg Variations'' (BWV 988). Tickets, at $9, are available at the box office, 129 West 67th Street, or may be charged by calling 362-8719. Tickets at $5 for students and the elderly will be available at the box office before the recital this evening.

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WINGS BEAT LEAFS
description: Glen Hanlon notched Detroit's first playoff shutout in 21 years as the Red Wings beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-0, tonight to stave off elimination in the National Hockey League's Norris Division finals.

title: ACQUITTALS OF 5 INDIANS BASED ON ANCIENT RELIGIOUS RIGHTS
description: A jury of the Yakima Indian Nation here has acquitted five of its members charged with violating the tribe's salmon fishing regulations.

title: Earnings Flat At Pepsico
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that its first-quarter earnings were virtually unchanged from a year ago because of a loss related to the sale of its retail bakery division.

title: C.H. Butcher Pleads Guilty
description: Eight months after C. H. Butcher Jr. was found not guilty of Federal bankruptcy fraud in connection with the failure of the Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, Mr. Butcher has entered guilty pleas to 13 counts of a 16-count state indictment.

title: LEADING-INDICATOR INDEX ROSE BY 0.4% IN MARCH
description: The Government's economic-forecasting index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the fifth increase in six months, the Commerce Department reported today. At the same time, the February increase was revised downward by nearly one-half.

title: CMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $163,000.

title: RECITAL: DAVID JOLLEY, HORN PLAYER
description: WHAT makes David Jolley one of the better French horn players around today is the graceful sensibility of his work. Mr. Jolley, who offered a recital Tuesday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall, has an impressive technique but eschews flashy gestures for more subtle and satisfying forms of musical persuasion.

title: Now, What About Babies N, O and P?
description: Appellate courts willing, Baby M has finally found a permanent home. But if the future of Baby M - now Melissa Stern - is assured, that of Babies N, O, P and others born out of surrogate arrangements is not. That's why the states need legislation to establish public policy on firmer footing than that provided by individual emotion-laden cases.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 30, 1986.

title: BROADWAY TICKET PRICES SLOWLY RISE
description: The cost of a ticket to a Broadway show, which has remained virtually stable for the past two years, is slowly rising as producers and theater owners respond to expenses that continue to go up and to wage increases scheduled for the fall.

title: GOETZ ACCOUNT OF SHOOTING 4 GIVEN ON TAPE
description: For more than two hours yesterday, the voice of Bernhard H. Goetz - high pitched and nervous, sometimes choked with emotion - filled a courtroom, as prosecutors played a 28-month-old tape on which Mr. Goetz described how, and why, he shot four young men on a Manhattan subway train.

title: ESSELTE BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $205,000 for the latest quarter and $139,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Iran Threatens to Close Gulf
description: Iran's Navy commander, Mohammed Hoseyn Malekzadegan, said today that Iran would close the entrance to the Persian Gulf if its shipping were disrupted, the Teheran radio said.

title: NUMERICA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of the American Express Co., appointed David B. Kalis senior vice president, worldwide communications.

title:
GARDENING;
PERENNIAL ARRAY FOR BOUQUETS
description: LEAD: ONE problem in a backyard or weekend flower garden is having enough flowers to provide continuous display in beds and borders and yet have lots of extras for indoor bouquets. Old-fashioned cutting gardens - a phrase dear to the hearts of estate gardeners - usually were placed in an out-of-the-way spot and never intended for garden display.

title: 'Bridge of Trinquetaille' By van Gogh to Be Sold
description: Van Gogh's ''Bridge of Trinquetaille,'' from 1888, will be auctioned by Christie's in London on June 29.

title: KEY FIGURE ADMITS FRAUD CONSPIRACY ON CONTRA FUNDS
description: Carl R. Channell, a professional fund-raiser, pleaded guilty in Federal court today to charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by raising tax-exempt funds to arm Nicaraguan rebels. He named Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North as a co-conspirator.

title: DATA BACK ESTROGEN THERAPY
description: Women who undergo hysterectomy with the removal of both ovaries face double the usual risk of heart disease if they do not receive estrogen supplements, a study has concluded.

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 21
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1.3 million and a net loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $11.5 million. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1 million.

title: BRAINTREE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEAGULL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a pretax charge of $26.6 million relating to the valuation allowance to reflect a accounting adjustments on its oil and gas reserve.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 16wks to April 18
ANATOMY OF A PERFECT ROOM
description: ''CONGRATULATIONS,'' chirped the voice. ''You have been chosen to participate in the Kips Bay Show House.'' It was a wintry afternoon last February. For 30-year-old Jeff Bilhuber and 31-year-old Tom Scheerer, this was no ordinary phone call. This was the call that hundreds of young decorators in New York pine for: Harvard Medical School, the Pulitzer Prize, the Baseball Hall of Fame and the New York State Lottery rolled into one.

title: KEAN VOWS TO SIGN A BILL CUTTING AUTO LIABILITY INSURANCE BY 50%
description: Governor Kean said today he would sign legislation mandating a 50 percent cut in the liability section of automobile insurance premiums in return for limits on the rights of accident victims to sue.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,007,000.

title: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,800,000 from a tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: SAVERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Secord to Be First Witness in Iran-Contra Hearings
description: Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a central figure in the Iran-contra affair who has never told his story in public, will be the opening witness when Congressional hearings begin next week, legislators announced today.

title: WESTPORT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Daiwa Buys Seat in Toronto
description: The Daiwa Securities Company of Tokyo has bought a seat on the Toronto Stock Exchange for $361,000 Canadian (about $270,000 United States), becoming the first Japanese securities firm to do so. It also said today that it planned to open a new Canadian brokerage house later this year.

title: Maryland National Note Offering
description: The Maryland National Corporation is offering $75 million of 9 3/8 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.50, to yield 9.45 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: COUPLE DIE IN MURDER-SUICIDE
description: An elderly couple were found shot to death in their apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, last night, apparently the result of a murder-suicide pact they entered into because they were ill and unable to care for themselves, the police said.

title: ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock form of ownership in May 1986.

title: William H. Kearns Dies at 78; Retired Advertising Executive
description: William H. Kearns, a former top official of the Ted Bates advertising agency, died of cancer Tuesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: METS SOLVE SCOTT FOR FERNANDEZ
description: More than six months after the seventh game that never was, the Mets found a strategy to handle Mike Scott and that crazy pitch of his. It included lining baseballs off his leg, his hand, and generally pestering him and roughing him up.

title: CUOMO REJECTS GAS-TAX RISE FOR ROADS
description: Governor Cuomo today ruled out an increase in the state gasoline tax, although he said again that some taxes or fees would have to be raised to pay for $1 billion a year in road and bridge projects.

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,198,000 for the quarter and $5,300,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $961,000 and $2,158,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WILLIAM COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $29.7 million. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6.5 million. Year-ago results were restated to reflect as discontinued operations thr results of Agrico Chemical Co., Williams Realty Corp. and Peabordy Holding Co. and to include operations of an additional subsidiary as part of the operations of Williams gas marketing.

title: Sound Credit
description: As any theatergoer knows, wristwatches have been beeping for several years now. Doctors, business executives and messengers also beep without warning. Now a California company has introduced a wallet that beeps when credit cards aren't returned to their proper place in it.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,213,000. c-Includes a gain of $990,000.

title: US SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PANEL DECLARES LANDMARK SITE AT TOWN HOUSE
description: Landmark status has been unanimously granted to an eclectic and eccentric 19th century town house at 520 West End Avenue that is known locally as the ''Castle'' and known citywide as the site of a most unusual development plan.

title: CROSS, A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-Lehigh Student Sentenced To Electric Chair for Murder
description: A jury on Tuesday night sentenced a former Lehigh University student to death in the electric chair for raping and strangling a freshman a year ago.

The measure calls for retaliation against countries that maintain large trade surpluses with the United States. Casting a ''yes'' vote for the amendment were 201 Democrats and 17 Republicans. title: Fiji's Leaders Weigh Curbs on Nuclear Ships
description: The new Government of this South Pacific island group is studying various options to cut off port access to nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships, the Foreign Minister said today.

title: Kodak Says Profit Tripled
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that its first-quarter earnings more than tripled, to $178 million, or 79 cents a share, from $48.6 million, or 22 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 13 percent, to $2.66 billion, from $2.35 billion last year.

title: VMX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CONCERT: THE ATLANTA SYMPHONY
description: NO two pieces could be more different in tone or style than the ones that began the Atlanta Symphony's concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night. John Harbison's ''Remembering Gatsby'' was the picture of nonchalance, and the Concerto for Orchestra by Witold Lutoslawski, the Polish composer, was a painfully serious exercise - one that tries very hard to crack a smile in its second movement but never quite succeeds.

title: Contract for McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation was awarded a $774.7 million Government contract today to set up production and begin ordering parts for its F-15E jets.

title: New-Home Sales Fall; Median Price a Record
description: Sales of new homes slumped 3.6 percent in March, led by a big drop in activity in the Middle West, while the nationwide median sales price climbed to a record $101,500, the Commerce Department said today.

title: PIERRE BOURDAIN
description: Pierre Bourdain, an executive in the classical-music recording industry, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: CHERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: DOW UP BY 22.30 IN NERVOUS MARKET
description: A surging technology sector and solid earnings reports pushed the stock market to a strong gain yesterday, despite an upward swing in interest rates and an undercurrent of nervousness.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Leading, With Compassion
description: Appearing recently at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in Greenwich Village, Governor Cuomo announced a proposed ban on AIDS testing for health insurance. He also spoke of Peter Vogel, former vice chairman of the state's Advisory Council on AIDS and chairman of the Governor's Task Force on Gay Concerns. Last year, Mr. Vogel died of AIDS.

title: WHAT TO TALK ABOUT WHEN THERE'S COMPANY
description: When a foreign leader comes to the United States, Congress usually goes out of its way to play the gracious host.

title: NEW SOVIET AID TO SYRIA REPORTED
description: Western diplomats believe that the Soviet Union will provide Syria with more advanced weapons and reschedule the Syrian debt under an agreement last week between President Hafez al-Assad and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Extra Points
description: What they were saying in the wake of the N.F.L. draft:

title: Expulsion for Weapons Set
description: After two days of assemblies that drew more than 40,000 students and parents, the Detroit Board of Education has voted to expel students who carry weapons into high school. The board voted Tuesday to approve a policy that students in the 7th through 12th grades who were found guilty of carrying guns or other lethal weapons would be expelled from regular schools.

title: KEY RATES
